https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/06/world.print_headline: Israeli Leaders Delay Debate on Peace Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/06/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and Foreign Minister Shimon Peres today postponed a debate on proposals for a Middle East peace conference. **********The two leaders of the coalition Government are deeply divided about whether to seek such a conference. They agreed in a 50-minute meeting to put off a discussion by the 10-member inner Cabinet until Monday. It had been scheduled for Wednesday. **********Mr. Peres, who heads the Labor Party, has sought to arrange a broad conference that would lead to direct negotiations with Jordan, and he has said that Jordan is close to agreeing to negotiate on terms acceptable to Israel. Mr. Peres has threatened to pull out of the national unity Government if Mr. Shamir, leader of the Likud bloc, continues to oppose international sponsorship of such a meeting. **********Mr. Shamir, on the other hand, opposes an international conference, contending that it would put pressure on Israel to give up territory captured in 1967. In addition, Likud leaders dispute Mr. Peres's assessment of how much Jordan's position has changed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/17/world.main_headline: Turkish Parliament Is Summoned To Resolve a Crisis Over Election
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/17/world.print_headline: Turkish Parliament Is Summoned To Resolve a Crisis Over Election
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/17/world.body_text: **********Turkey's Parliament was called into emergency session tonight in an effort to resolve a crisis over procedures for a national election. **********The crisis is seen by Western diplomats as a test of Turkey's return to democracy after a referendum Sept. 6 restored the political rights of leading figures whom the military had banned from seeking office. **********Members of Parliament were summoned from a pre-election recess after the country's highest court last week rejected new electoral procedures put through by Prime Minister Turgut Ozal to enable him to call an early general election on Nov. 1. **********The court's decision blocked the electoral plan, forcing Mr. Ozal to seek a compromise with political rivals to reschedule the vote for Nov. 29. Some opposition parties, however, are seeking a later election. Unwelcome Memories of 1970's **********The prospect of protracted haggling in Parliament unsettled some Turks, analysts said, since it revived unwelcome memories of the late 1970's, when frequent legislative stalemates fostered political violence that claimed 5,000 lives. **********In 1980 the violence led the military to stage a bloodless coup. The generals held power for three years before returning the country to civilian rule under Mr. Ozal, who has a 250-member majority in the 400-seat Parliament. **********On Sept. 6, in what Western diplomats now call a miscalculation, Mr. Ozal announced the Nov. 1 election and pushed legislation through Parliament outlawing candidate selection procedures comparable to American primaries. They were replaced by rules requiring party leaderships to nominate candidates without seeking approval in their constituencies. **********As a result, several parties alienated followers by drawing up slates excluding members of Parliament who had held their seats for the last four years. Mr. Ozal alone dropped 61 names from his slate, meaning that the extent of his support in Parliament was uncertain as it prepared to reconvene. **********Mr. Ozal announced the election on the same day as the referendum narrowly restored the political rights of former politicians, including former Prime Ministers Suleyman Demirel and Bulent Ecevit. Mr. Ozal's supporters blame the two politicians for the political paralysis of the 1970's.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/13/world.body_text: **********The Soviet Union said today that it had serious reservations about an American draft treaty to reduce long-range nuclear weapons. **********The Foreign Ministry spokesman, Gennadi I. Gerasimov, cited five Soviet concerns, including the absence in the proposal of any measures to address the development of space weapons. **********He repeated Moscow's longstanding position that it would not accept reductions in long-range missiles unless they were part of a broader package that also limited the development of space weapons. **********The American draft was presented in Geneva last week. The Soviet response today, which Mr. Gerasimov called a preliminary reaction, underscored the wide differences that remain over reductions in long-range weapons and the development of space-based offensive and defensive systems. Outlook on Medium-Range Arms **********The Geneva negotiations on long-range missiles and bombers are separate from the more promising talks on reducing medium-range missiles in Europe that both sides have said could produce a treaty by year's end. **********American officials said last week that the draft treaty on long-range missiles was unlikely to win Soviet acceptance, but that it was being presented to show Washington's willingness to press ahead with negotiations on strategic weapons despite the obstacles. **********Mr. Gerasimov said a Soviet draft document on reductions in strategic weapons more closely reflected understandings reached by President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, during their meeting in Iceland last October. **********He said the proposed American treaty departed from several points of agreement in Iceland, including the understanding that an initial 50 percent cut in strategic weapons would be made in five years. Seven-Year Period Cited **********Mr. Gerasimov said the latest American proposal called for reducing strategic offensive arms by half over seven years. **********In addition, Mr. Gerasimov said the American document, by setting subsidiary limits on specific classes of weapons, would force the Soviet Union to restructure its nuclear forces, a step that he said would be detrimental to Soviet security. **********The third objection raised by Moscow was Washington's failure to include a cut in long-range sea-launched cruise missiles in the draft treaty. **********Mr. Gerasimov said the fourth objection was to the absence in the document of provisions for further talks about the eventual elimination of all strategic offensive weapons. **********The fifth Soviet objection was the lack of any link between cuts in strategic weapons and curbs on the development of space weapons.  ---- NATO BACKING SOUGHT **********OSLO, Norway, May 12 (Special to The New York Times) - Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger plans to use a meeting of NATO defense ministers to seek Western support for proposal to eliminate all medium-range missiles, senior Defense Department officials said today. **********The United States and the Soviet Union agreed in Iceland on a formula that would eliminate medium-range missiles from Europe, while allowing each side to keep 100 warheads outside Europe. The Soviet Union would keep its weapons in its Asian territory, while the American warheads would be kept in the United States. **********Mr. Weinberger said today that this approach was inadequate. Although the Reagan Administration has said that it would prefer the elimination of all medium-range missiles, it has also stated it would settle for what was agreed on in Iceland. **********But Mr. Weinberger pressed his point with special vigor. ''We want global zero,'' he told reporters today en route to Norway. ''Nobody gains anything from 100 in Asia. There is no logical basis for supporting it.'' **********An aide to Mr. Weinberger said the Defense Secretary would stress this point at a two-day meeting of NATO's nuclear planning group, which begins Thursday in Stavanger, Norway.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/30/world.main_headline: EXCERPTS FROM SPEECH BY SEOUL PARTY CHIEF
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/30/world.print_headline: EXCERPTS FROM SPEECH BY SEOUL PARTY CHIEF
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/30/world.body_text: **********Following, in official translation, are excerpts from a nationally broadcast address today by Roh Tae Woo, chairman of the governing Democratic Justice Party, proposing sweeping constitutional changes: **********I have now come to a firm conviction about the future of our nation. I have anguished long and hard over the genuine mission of politicians at this historic time when deep-seated conflicts and antagonisms so accumulated among our citizens that they have erupted into a national crisis. **********Today, I stand before history and the nation with an extraordinary determination to help build a great homeland in which there is love and harmony among all segments and strata of the population, in which all are proud of being citizens and in which the Government can acquire wisdom, courage and genuine strength from the people. **********I will hereby forthrightly present my ideas. I intend to recommend them to President Chun Doo Hwan and am resolved to translate them into concrete action with the enthusiastic support of my party colleagues and the general public. **********First, the Constitution should be expeditiously amended, through agreement between the Government party and the opposition, to adopt a direct presidential election system, and presidential elections should be held under a new constitution to realize a peaceful change of government in February 1988. **********This does not mean a change in my belief that a parliamentary cabinet system . . . is the form of government best suited to enabling democracy to take hold in our country. However, if the majority of the people do not want it, even the best-conceived system will alienate the public, and the government that is born under it will not be able to dream and suffer together with the people. **********Accordingly, I have come to the conclusion that a presidential election system must be adopted at this juncture in order to overcome social confusion and achieve national reconciliation. People are the masters of the country, and the people's will must come before everything else. Revising Election Law **********Second, in addition to switching to a direct presidential election system through constitutional revision, I think that to carry out elections democratically, it is necessary to also revise the Presidential Election Law so that freedom of candidacy and fair competition are guaranteed and so that the genuine verdict of the people can be given. **********Even under a direct election system, there should not be groundless character smearing and demagoguery to incite hostility, confusion, disorder and regional antagonisms, thereby undermining national stability and impeding genuine democratic development. There must be a solid framework to insure that elections are bona fide competitions in policies and ideas. **********Third, antagonisms and confrontations must be resolutely eradicated not only from our political community but also from all other sectors to achieve grand national reconciliation and unity. In this connection, I believe that Mr. Kim Dae Jung also should be amnestied and his civil rights restored, no matter what he has done in the past. **********At the same time, all those who are being detained in connection with the political situation should also be set free, except for those who have committed treason by repudiating the basic free and democratic order on which our survival and posterity hinges, and a small number of people who have shaken the national foundation by committing homicide, bodily injury, arson and vandalism. **********Fourth, human dignity must be respected even more greatly, and the basic rights of citizens should be promoted and protected to the maximum. I hope that the forthcoming constitutional amendments will include all the strengthened basic rights clauses being proposed by the Democratic Justice Party, including a drastic extension of habeas corpus. **********Fifth, to promote the freedom of the press, the relevant systems and practices must be drastically improved. . . . Newspapers should again be permitted to station their correspondents in provinces, the press card system should be abolished and newspapers should be allowed to increase the number of their pages as they see fit. **********Sixth, freedom and self-regulation must be guaranteed to the maximum in all other sectors also. . . . Local councils should be elected and organized without any hitch. . . . **********Colleges and universities - the institutions of higher learning - must be made self-governing, and educational autonomy in general must be expeditiously put into practice.  The Political Climate **********Seventh, a political climate conducive to dialogue and compromise must be created expeditiously, with healthy activities of political parties guaranteed. A political party should be a democratic organization that presents responsible demands and policies to mold and crystalize the political opinion of the people. The state should exert utmost efforts to protect and nurture political parties, so long as they engage in sound activities and do not contravene such objectives. **********Eighth, bold social reforms must be carried out to build a clean and honest society. In order that all citizens can lead a secure and happy life, crime against life and property, such as hooliganism, robbery and theft, must be stamped out, and deep-seated corruption and improprieties that still linger in our society must be eradicated. **********My fellow countrymen, on the strength of your expectations that there will be continued development rather than disruptions, I dare to make this proposal today in humble veneration of history and the people. These ideas stem from my genuine patriotism, and I am confident that they will blossom with support from all the people, and not only President Chun and members of the Democratic Justice Party. **********When these basic ideas have been accepted, additional details can be worked out. If they fail to be accepted, however, I want to make it very clear that I will resign from all public duties, including the presidential candidacy and the chairmanship of the Democratic Justice Party. **********Under no circumstances must we neglect to safeguard and promote the liberal democratic system. The task of peacefully changing administrations is the immediate task at hand. **********Furthermore, now that the Olympics are approaching, all of us are responsible for avoiding the national disgrace of dividing ourselves and thus causing the world to ridicule us. **********With the sacred right to vote at hand, let us all work together to create a society where young people develop their capabilities to realize their ideas, where workers and farmers can work free of anxiety, where businessmen exert even greater creative efforts and where politicians exercise the art of debate and compromise to work out the nation's future. I pledge my utmost efforts to create a dynamic, developing and genuinely democratic society where law and order prevail.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/25/busin.main_headline: Court Is Picked For LTV Case
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/25/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Court Is Picked For LTV Case
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/25/busin.body_text: **********Federal District Judge Robert Sweet has ruled that a dispute over who has financial responsibility for the LTV Corporation's pensions would be litigated in Federal district court rather than bankruptcy court. **********The Dallas-based LTV filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 bankruptcy in July 1986. Last January, the Federal Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, which insures pension plans, took control of the three LTV Steel Company pension plans, assuming financial responsibility for $2.3 billion in unfunded liabilities. However, in September the agency returned trusteeship of the plans to LTV. The company contends the agency's move is illegal.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/06/busin.main_headline: 'Why Dad Was in Such a Bad Mood'
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/06/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS FORUM: AT THE HELM ON 'BLACK MONDAY'; 'Why Dad Was in Such a Bad Mood'
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/06/busin.body_text: **********THE other night, I was at dinner in Washington with five senators, three members of Congress and some Wall Street leaders. There was much talk about the causes and effects of the October crash. One senator said, ''Look, if I asked you to tell me what to do if you were in my shoes, what three steps would you take to solve the problem?'' Other than reiterating impatience with the budget deficit, all the Wall Street leaders were silent. **********Everyone is pointing a finger at everyone else. Wall Street tells the Government that it alone can solve the problem by closing the deficit. The Government tells Wall Street, ''We can try to do that, but you also have to try to get your act together; you've got to be more prudent on new products and regulate your own affairs.'' Each thinks it knows what the other should do. The truth is no one knows how to prevent another crash. **********We know that the net wealth of the nation cannot be reduced by something like half a trillion dollars without having some impact on the economy. The financial community was probably due for a cyclical downturn in any case, given the excesses of the past few years. But now everyone is watching to see what the impact will be on consumers. This could be critical; it is consumer spending rather than capital spending or profits that has kept the economy going over the past few years As I look back at those critical two weeks just after the crash, certain things stand out in my mind. I knew I was in uncharted waters, and much of what I had learned in previous crises was no longer relevant. We were dealing with something no one had seen before, except for those who lived through the 1929 crash. We became painfully aware that there was no coordinated mechanism in place for the markets to deal with each other. We all talked to one another about what was going on and we tried to coordinate activities, but there were no formal means by which the major decision-makers could work together. Nobody had ever imagined that something like this could happen and there was no emergency plan to handle it. **********I spent a good deal of my time on the trading floor, because I knew that the fate of the institution would depend on how our specialists and traders performed. I also knew that there were decisions I could make on the spot to help the specialists - a change in the system, a mid-stream adjustment, an emergency exemption from a rule. I wanted them to know, without a doubt, that the full power and influence of the institution was behind them. **********There was no sense of despair as apparently was the case during the 1929 crash. Nobody was threatening to jump out of windows. I was worried about one specialist who I know had suffered two heart attacks, but he seemed well and in control of himself. There was a very strong sense of camaraderie, a sort of battle mentality. We felt that we had a mission to carry out, to let the world know that we would be able to maintain liquidity in the marketplace. People knew they were going to lose money, but what was important was to maintain confidence in the system. The overriding objective was to keep the market open, because if that failed, panic could well set in, and the entire institution as well as individual businesses could be undone. **********We have always taken our mission to provide public access to the securities markets very seriously. We don't close during snowstorms, blackouts, power failures. We have back-up computers and take all sorts of steps to provide the kind of redundancy that assures continuity. We didn't want to fail now in the face of our greatest challenge. **********There are more war stories going around today about Terrible Tuesday - the day after the crash - than about Black Monday. People are wondering how close we came to international financial catastrophe. They want to know who talked to whom on the phone, what was said and what was done. But there is also talk about the system, whether it performed well and what corrections and adjustments need to be made. **********At the American Stock Exchange we were particularly fortunate that an enhancement to our new stock display system went into operation on Oct. 19. It was pure coincidence, but we had installed it on the previous Friday, tested it over the weekend, and turned it on Monday morning. Our previous system did not have the capacity to provide all the necessary financial information to our floor professionals, and they were always facing the possibility of losing out to traders upstairs or around the world who had more timely information. Our new system prevented that, and if we had not had it ready on that Monday, or if it had developed glitches the first day it was on, we would have been in deeper trouble than we were. With this new enhancement, the trading floor system actually worked better on Oct. 19, when there was four or five times the normal volume, than it had ever done before. **********It was a strange feeling to know that the maelstrom you were living through was the leading news story of the day. Although I felt it was important to maintain our tradition of being accessible to the press, there was the danger of being too visible at a time when difficult decisions were being considered. If news leaked out that we were contemplating closing the markets, which we were, it could have been catastrophic. Also, I could not reassure the public that things were going to be all right and that the market had bottomed out. **********I had expected to be badgered by friends and family for advice on what to do with their investments, but there was practically none of that. Instead they were worried about me, how I was holding up under the pressure. I stayed in Manhattan almost every evening, and I had acquiesced to carrying a beeper with an 80-mile radius to keep me in touch continuously with what was happening. **********IT was the worst period of tension I can remember, and I guess this was apparent to everyone I knew, including my 8-year-old daughter. One of her regular third-grade assignments is to write a news story every week about something going on in the world. Knowing that her father was at the center of the story of the week, she had asked me what the ''crash'' was all about. I explained that something which sold for $9 yesterday was now selling for $6. She wanted to know why that was bad. I pointed out that if she had bought it for $9 with the idea of selling it for $12 or $13 she would be upset if all she could get was $6. I wasn't sure she understood until I saw her news story at the end of the week, with the headline ''The Market Goes Crash'' and her explanation of why that was bad. I was amused to see that she ended her story with the sentence, ''So that's why dad was in such a bad mood.'' She included a drawing of me baring my teeth and saying, ''I'm mad. Grrr.'' **********That was the only news story that week that gave me a lift.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/14/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Woodward & Lothrop Names New President
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/14/busin.body_text: **********Tom L. Roach, a well-known retail executive, was named yesterday as president of Woodward & Lothrop, which operates two major department store chains - Woodward & Lothrop in Washington and John Wanamaker in Philadelphia. **********The company is owned by Alfred A. Taubman, an investor and developer of shopping centers. Mr. Taubman acquired Woodward & Lothrop in 1984 and recently completed the purchase of Wanamaker's. **********Mr. Roach, 43, succeeds David P. Mullen, 52, who has resigned to pursue other interests. He has been with the company since 1972. **********Mr. Roach most recently was chairman and chief executive of the J. W. Robinson Company department stores of Los Angeles, resigning in February after a restructuring by its new owner, May Department Stores of St. Louis. **********In the often volatile world of retail executives, Mr. Roach had spent just 10 months at the 23-store Robinson chain, a division of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation. He had been assigned there to help improve performance, but his tenure ended when May bought Associated Dry Goods. **********At Woodward & Lothrop Mr. Roach will be working with Edwin K. Hoffman, chairman and chief executive. Woodward & Lothrop and Wanamaker's together have about 32 stores and more than $1 billion in sales annually. **********Mr. Roach has been in the department store business since 1966, when he joined Burdine's in Miami. For a big-city retail executive, he hails from an unlikely place - Cody, Wyo., near the Yellowstone National Park. **********Mr. Roach graduated from the University of Wyoming, where he also received his master's degree in business. **********''I had lived in a cold climate all my life,'' he said yesterday, ''and migrated to Miami.'' There he met Joseph E. Brooks, who was an executive at Burdine's, a unit of Federated Department Stores. Mr. Brooks gave him a job there and became Mr. Roach's mentor. ''As Joe moved, I moved with him,'' Mr. Roach said. **********After various jobs, they both left Federated for Associated, and their paths diverged within that company. Mr. Roach became chief executive of Robinson's of Florida and then chief executive of Associated's Denver Dry Goods unit, which he turned around and brought to record profitability. Mr. Brooks retired last fall as chief executive of Associated's Lord & Taylor, after May took over.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/12/busin.print_headline: MARKET PLACE; Implications Of a Stock Split
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/12/busin.body_text: **********AS stock prices have surged to record levels with virtually each passing day, stock splits have proliferated, especially in the shares of many blue-chip issues. **********Although stock splits are generally regarded positively and seem to flourish in such a heady environment, analysts generally minimize the significance of a split for the average investor. Some say it is a case of marketing rather than finance. **********''Companies split their stock to broaden its distribution and make it more appealing to retail investors,'' said Richard Schmidt, director of research at Advest Inc. in Hartford. ''I would not, however, advise a strategy of merely buying stocks that have split or where a split appears imminent. It's a great flag, or starting point, but it should be only one of several criteria to be considered.'' The investor's temperament and financial objectives, Mr. Schmidt added, should also be taken into account. **********In the last few weeks the likes of General Electric, 3M, Great Northern Nekoosa, Chrysler and, more recently, International Paper have decided to split their shares. **********Analysts note that several of these stocks are components of the Dow Jones industrial average, the measurement of market movement based on 30 issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange. After a split the new, lower-priced stock continues to be divided by the same denominator to arrive at the index number, resulting in a more volatile Dow. **********According to Standard & Poor's, a record number of Big Board companies could declare stock splits this year. The record is 225, set in 1983, S.&.P. said. Last year 209 companies declared splits of 3 for 2 or more. **********''When management splits its stock, it signals confidence in the company,'' said Phil Goldsmith of Goldsmith & Harris, an investment research and advisory firm. ''This usually follows several quarters of good earnings growth with the prospects of a couple more good years ahead. We continue to like Borden, which split 2 for 1 in 1985 and 3 for 2 in 1986.'' **********Other stocks he favors include Ethyl Corporation, which split 2 for 1 in 1983, 2 for 1 in 1985 and 2 for 1 in 1986; American Cyanamid, which just announced a split, and Loctite, which he believes might consider a split in the foreseeable future. **********Mr. Goldsmith said Green Tree Acceptance, the nation's largest originator and servicer of manufactured-housing mortgages, is another of his favorites. ''The stock has done exceptionally well since it split 2 for 1 in June of 1986, rising from a post-split price in the mid-teens to its closing yesterday on the Big Board of $34.375,'' he said. **********The concept of the stock split is simple, but its implications and advantages for the investor are more subtle. **********In a 2-for-1 split, the holder of one share of stock is like the owner of one pint of ice cream who suddenly finds he has two half-pints instead. At first the two new units have the same total value as one of the older units. **********Market history proves, however, that several positives usually go hand-in-hand with a split, including enhanced investor confidence, an increase in the cash dividend and possibly improved profits. **********The split also makes shares more manageable and attractive to small investors if they like to buy in round lots of 100 shares. Also, if the market turns down, individual shares do not show as much of a dollar loss, often a psychological advantage. **********By attracting small investors with a lower-priced stock and thus getting more of the shares into the hands of individuals, a company provides itself with greater insurance against the possibility of unwanted takeover attempts. **********Mr. Goldsmith said the lure of lower-priced equities for investors was borne out by New York Stock Exchange statistics showing that over the last 10 years 91.6 percent of all stocks on the Big Board traded below $60 a share, 85 percent below $50, 74.4 percent below $40 and 56.3 percent below $30. Last year 84 percent traded below $60 a share. **********''Investors should keep in mind, however, that a lot of smaller institutions are not immune to the attraction of a lower-priced stock,'' said Mr. Schmidt of Advest. **********According to Mark Grinblatt, assistant professor of finance at the University of California at Los Angeles Graduate School of Management, stock splits are indeed good news for investors. **********A study he helped write, published in the Journal of Financial Economics in December 1984, said a typical stock split on the New York Stock Exchange was associated with a 2.6 percent increase in the stock's price on the day of the announcement and the day after. **********''The number of firms that had positive stock increases was 73.5 percent,'' he said. ''One of the reasons was that a large number of stocks in our sample - 850 stock splits over a period of 10 years -also reported positive earnings and cash dividends on the day of the stock split announcement. **********''Other than superior price performance around the ex date of the split, there is no evidence that stocks experience long-run abnormal performance subsequent to the announcement.'' **********What does a split mean mean for the stock itself? The 3-for-2 split announced by Chrysler last Thursday illustrates the fact that instant, though sometimes not substantial, rewards can occur. After the announcement, Chrysler's stock jumped $2, to $52.875, and it closed yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange at $54.50. **********The General Electric Company, another household-name glamour issue, surged $5.375, to $103.50, in volume of more than 1.7 million shares when its stock split was announced on Feb. 13. G.E. closed yesterday at $107, up about 9 percent since then. **********And International Paper, which decided Tuesday to split its stock 2 for 1, saw its stock leap $2, to $99.75, in heavy trading. Yesterday, however, it closed at $98.50, down $1.25 for the day.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/08/busin.body_text: **********Just three days before two important OPEC committees meet to discuss overproduction, the International Energy Agency said today that Saudi Arabia had joined other OPEC members in exceeding production quotas. **********In its end-of-August report, the International Energy Agency, a Paris-based organization of 21 Western oil-consuming nations, estimated that the output of Saudi Arabia, the group's largest producer, reached 4.5 million barrels of crude oil a day in July, compared with a quota of 4.3 million. **********Over all, the agency said, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries produced a total of 19.7 million barrels of crude oil a day in August, compared with 18.2 million in July and the official daily quota of 16.6 million set by OPEC in June. The agency's figures for total OPEC output were comparable with those reported recently by the Middle East Economic Survey, a Cyprus-based journal. **********In response to the I.E.A. report, several industry analysts predicted that OPEC production would decline over the next few months. But they were divided on whether a drop in production would result in a firming of prices, since many believe there will be a concurrent drop in purchases due to a reduction in stockpiling. **********''Right now OPEC is overproducing, but it's not so bad because there is stock-building due to the tensions in the Middle East, but the stockpiling cannot go on forever,'' said John Calverly, a senior economist with the American Express Bank in London. Prices Are Vulnerable **********Many oil analysts say the crisis in the Gulf has placed some upward pressure on oil prices, but Mr. Calverly contends that prices are vulnerable because of the combination of oversupply and a probable slowdown in stockpiling. **********On Thursday, two important OPEC committees, on price stability and on quota adherence, will meet in Vienna. They are expected to urge members to reduce production to help strengthen prices, which have dropped since early last month. But because of tensions among Gulf states, the committees are expected to have a hard time convincing members to band together to restrain output. **********''We don't expect much from the meetings,'' said one European-based oil analyst. ''The worst overproducers, Iran and Iraq, won't be there and the committees will have a hard time getting them to cut production because of the war.'' **********According to the I.E.A., Iraq, which has been at war with Iran for more than six years, produced 2.2 million barrels a day in July, compared with the quota of 1.5 million barrels, while Iran, produced 2.8 million barrels compared with its quota of 2.4 million. **********In the past the Saudis have reduced output to help stabilize prices. However, some analysts said the Saudis' recent overproduction indicated that they were not so eager to strengthen prices because that would help Iran, a leading OPEC price hawk. Spot Prices Decline **********A major reason for the jump in production from July to August, industry analysts said, was that oil companies were eager to buy from OPEC nations because their official $18-a-barrel price was lower than the spot price, which had been driven above $21 a barrel as a result of tensions in the Persian Gulf. **********But the overproduction got so out of hand that spot prices, according to the International Energy Agency, have fallen about $2 a barrel since late July. **********''As the spot market for Mideast oil stays below official OPEC prices and assuming that OPEC producers hang tough on their official price, the oil companies will cut back on their purchases from OPEC and will buy on the spot market to meet demand,'' said William L. Randol, an analyst with the First Boston Corporation. He said this would encourage OPEC to rein in production and put some stability into oil prices. **********Mr. Randol predicted that OPEC output would decline by as much as 1.5 million barrels a day over the next few months, helping to stabilize spot prices in the $18- to $20-a-barrel range. He also anticipates that OPEC would seek to push up its official price by $1 or $2 a barrel at the December meeting of the 13 member nations. **********One of the biggest questions in OPEC is how the cooperation between Saudi Arabia and Iran that has helped lead OPEC in recent months will be affected by the recent rift between the two nations resulting from the deaths of Iranian pilgrims in Mecca.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/05/world.main_headline: IRAN 'MONEY TRAIL' IS FOCUS OF HOUSE INQUIRY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/05/world.print_headline: THE REAGAN WHITE HOUSE; IRAN 'MONEY TRAIL' IS FOCUS OF HOUSE INQUIRY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/05/world.body_text: **********The chairman of the special House committee investigating the Iran-contra affair said today that his panel's inquiry would focus on what happened to the proceeds from the sale of arms to Iran. **********''We still have a very incomplete understanding of the money trail at this point,'' the chairman, Representative Lee H. Hamilton, said. **********Mr. Hamilton said public hearings on that aspect of the case would be held jointly with the Senate investigative committee and would start in late April. He spoke today at a news conference after a brief, closed meeting of his committee. **********The chairman, an Indiana Democrat, noted that the Tower Commission, which issued its report last week, had thoroughly explored the issue of the arms sales themselves. He suggested that the Congressional committees would not duplicate that work. Bank Records Withheld **********On the other hand, the Tower board, which did not have the authority to issue subpoenas, take sworn testimony or grant immunity from prosecution to compel testimony, was unable to determine whether the proceeds from the arms sales had been used to help the Nicaraguan rebels or for other purposes. **********Evidence bearing on that point is contained in secret bank records in Switzerland, according to the Tower Commission. Thus far, the Swiss Government has refused to allow the records to be released, and the Congressional committees have had no success obtaining them elsewhere. **********The Swiss bank accounts were apparently controlled by Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, the former White House assistant at the center of the controversy, and Richard V. Secord, a retired Air Force major general who worked with Colonel North. Both have asserted their Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination and have refused to testify or produce records in the case. **********Mr. Hamilton said his investigators were taking other steps to obtain the records, but he would not say what they were. **********Last week, the special Senate committee voted to begin unusual legal proceedings against General Secord that, if successful, would compel him to authorize release of bank records in his control or face imprisonment for contempt of Congress. Mr. Hamilton said the House committee supported this maneuver but was not directly involved in it. #100 Subpoenas Issued Mr. Hamilton said his committee had issued about 100 subpoenas so far. The senior Republican representative on the committee, Dick Cheney of Wyoming, said the panel had compiled ''thousands of pages of documents and thousands of pages of testimony in depositions.'' **********But Mr. Hamilton and Mr. Cheney said the special prosecutor, Lawrence E. Walsh, continued to refuse to turn over material to the Congressional committees. **********Mr. Hamilton said he continued to negotiate with Mr. Walsh almost daily. ''I do not consider us to be at an impasse,'' he said, ''but neither can I tell you we expect to get the material any time soon.'' **********Mr. Walsh has repeatedly refused to comment on the issue. **********Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d met with Mr. Walsh today and agreed to join him in his effort to overturn the lawsuit filed by Colonel North that questions the constitutionality of the special prosecutor law. But Justice Department officials said Mr. Meese's objection to the suit will be based on narrow procedural grounds and will leave aside the constitutional questions. **********Reagan Administration officials said Mr. Walsh had also indicated to Mr. Meese that he would be willing to accept appointment as an independent prosecutor within the Justice Department. Officials said that might undercut the argument in Colonel North's lawsuit that prosecutors must operate under the authority of the President or the Attorney General. **********In an appearance before the Senate Judiciary Committee today, Mr. Meese said he wanted to insure that Mr. Walsh and other special prosecutors now at work are permitted to continue their investigations. **********''You can be sure that we will be looking for a way not only to enable the independent counsels to go forward, but to preserve the fruits of their labor,'' Mr. Meese said. **********Mr. Meese faces a paradox because of lawsuits filed by Colonel North and Michael K. Deaver, another former Administration official under investigation by a special prosecutor. Justice Department officials have repeatedly questioned the constitutionality of the 1978 special prosecutor law, but any effort now to overturn the law could be seen as an attempt to hinder Mr. Walsh's investigation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/26/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Triangle Stake Being Sold
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/26/busin.body_text: **********The Primerica Corporation announced today that it had agreed to sell its entire common stock investment of nearly five million shares of Triangle Industries to CJI Industries. **********The sale price is $124 million in cash plus an additional amount comparable to that received by other minority shareholders of Triangle in excess of $25 a share if Triangle is acquired by CJI or one of its affiliates within a year. Triangle's stock jumped $2 a share, to $26, on the New York Stock Exchange. **********Primerica also announced that its board had authorized the repurchase of up to five million shares of its own common stock, subject to market conditions. Primerica's shares rose 87.5 cents today, to $27.875, on the Big Board. **********Primerica, which has about 52 million shares of common stock outstanding, said its previously announced repurchase program of 6 million shares was 500,000 shares short of completion. **********Greenwich-based Primerica, formerly the American Can Company, sold its packaging operations to Triangle Industries, based in New Brunswick, N.J., last year for $570 million. **********Primerica did not expect any material gain or loss as a result of the stock sale to CJI.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/13/world.main_headline: Canada Examines 174 Said to Be Refugees
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/13/world.print_headline: Canada Examines 174 Said to Be Refugees
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/13/world.body_text: **********A group of 174 people who claim to be refugees from India arrived at a tiny fishing village in Nova Scotia off Canada's east coast today, Federal Immigration Minister Benoit Bouchard said. **********''They claim to have left India on the 20th of May and to have been brought ashore in Nova Scotia from an unknown ship,'' Mr. Bouchard told a news conference. **********Mr. Bouchard added that the authorities had begun searching for a vessel. **********Immigration officials also said they are investigating reports that a second boatload of refugees, possibly of women and children, is on its way. No other information about the reports was available. **********The Canadian Press news agency earlier had reported that 157 Tamils from Sri Lanka had landed at the village of Charlesville, near Yarmouth. But the nationalities of the people in the group, which the authorities now say consists of 173 men and one woman, were not officially verified. **********Mr. Bouchard said they were being bused to a military base in Halifax, where they were to be questioned to verify identity and to investigate claims for refugee status. **********In Ottawa, an Immigration Department spokesman said the Royal Canadian Mounted Police had arrested two people in connection with the group's arrival. **********According to the spokesman, one of those arrested was said to be the ship's captain. No other details on the arrests were given.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/17/busin.body_text: **********Five Japanese television manufacturers denied today that they were exporting color picture tubes to the United States at unfairly low prices. **********Some said they could be adversely affected if punitive customs duties were imposed. **********Sony, Toshiba, Sanyo, Hitachi and Matsushita all said they either did not ship tubes to the United States or did so only for use in their assembly operations there, not for resale. **********In Washington the Commerce Department said Friday that color picture tubes from Japan, South Korea, Singapore and Canada were being dumped in the United States at less than the cost of production.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/20/world.main_headline: Sikh Radicals Blamed For 6 Deaths in Punjab
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/20/world.print_headline: Sikh Radicals Blamed For 6 Deaths in Punjab
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/20/world.body_text: **********Sikh extremists killed six people today, including a leader of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's Congress Party, according to the police. **********The police said four gunmen shot to death Joginder Pal Pandey, a former Punjab minister, and his bodyguard, Sohan Lal, in Ludhiana, an industrial center about 190 miles from New Delhi. Both victims were Hindus. The police also said two teachers, a Government doctor and a goldsmith were shot to death in separate attacks in the Punjab, where militants are fighting to establish an independent Sikh homeland. **********The police shot to death one extremist who was trying to rob a bank in the Ferozepore district near the Pakistani border, the Press Trust of India, a news agency, reported. **********The deaths brought to 42 the toll in extremist-related violence this year in the Punjab. More than 600 people were killed there last year. **********The police said they had placed Ludhiana, which has a mixed population of Hindus and Sikhs, under a curfew in an effort to prevent violence after the klling of Mr. Pandey, who had served as general secretary of the Congress Party in the state of Punjab and had been a minister for a total of eight years in previous state governments.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/24/busin.main_headline: Equitable to Sell Part of Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/24/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Equitable to Sell Part of Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/24/busin.body_text: **********The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States plans to sell almost one-quarter of its money management affiliate, the Alliance Capital Management Company, in a public offering next year. It will also sell an 18 percent stake to 70 Alliance employees by year-end. **********Alliance, with $30 billion under management, is one of the largest investment management firms. It has more than 300 institutional accounts, including pension and endowment funds, and it is an adviser to 27 mutual funds. **********Although the timing of the offering may not seem ideal with the stock market in the doldrums, Equitable feels it needs to take steps to provide its senior portfolio managers a compensation package that will keep them from walking away - and taking their clients with them - when their contracts expire at year-end. **********Many senior managers at the firm signed three-year contracts with Equitable when it acquired Alliance's parent, the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation, in 1984. Planned Before Market Fell **********The offering was planned before last month's stock market collapse, according to Dave H. Williams, chairman of the firm. **********Equitable, in the offering filed Thursday, said its Equitable Investment Corporation subsidiary would sell the stake in Alliance next year. **********''Equitable's motivation is to give the right incentive to retain professionals,'' Mr. Williams said. **********In addition to the public offering of 6.6 million units, the 70 employees will be offered a combined stake of 18 percent in Alliance. The firm said it had not yet set a price for that sale but, in documents filed with the S.E.C., estimated it at $9 to $11 a unit. **********The offering, in the form of a master limited partnership, will provide these investment professionals with a ''valid public market for our securities,'' Mr. Williams said. Units in the partnership will be traded on the New York Stock Exchange, so employees will be able to cash in their holdings. **********In an industry where professionals' compensation has been compared with that of rock stars, Alliance is known as one of the nation's highest-paying money management firms. Lucrative Compensation **********Its S.E.C. filing discloses extremely lucrative compensation packages. **********In 1986 the total employee compensation as a percentage of revenues was 47.1 percent. The cash compensation for the nine highest-paid executives totaled $8.4 million. Mr. Williams received $1.5 million; Alfred Harrison, executive vice president, $1.4 million; Philip VonBlon, vice chairman, $1.1 million; Frank W. Burr, executive vice president, $1 million, and Clinton J. Kendrick, president, $942,923. **********Alliance joins other investment management firms that have offered the public part of their firms in the form of a master limited partnership. **********Last week Thomson McKinnon Inc. sold 33 percent of its asset management business for $9.25 a unit, raising $28 million. Other firms that have sold limited partnership units to the public are Oppenheimer Capital Management and Reich & Tang. **********Investment management firms use the master limited partnership structure because it lets them pass on their enormous cash flow without paying a corporate income tax. Individual Tax Rates Paid **********Instead, unit holders pay individual tax rates on their share of the profits. Investment management firms need very little capital and do not need to retain earnings. In a partnership they can pass their earnings through to the unit holders and create high-yielding investments for individuals. **********But Congress is trying to change the tax structure, which might make these less attractive investments. In October the House voted to change the tax treatment for such partnerships. The Senate has not yet acted on the bill, and its fate is uncertain. But some money managers believe that new master limited partnerships may no longer enjoy the favorable tax structure. **********In the first nine months of this year Alliance's net income was $6.5 million on revenues of $96.2 million. Last year revenues were $103.4 million, up from $77.2 million in 1985 and $62.6 million in 1984. Money management firms are typically valued at four to five times revenues. **********The revenues of Alliance and other investment management firms are closely tied to the ups and downs of the stock market. Institutional clients pay the firm a percentage, perhaps one-half of 1 percent, of the assets in their account.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/14/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Kaisertech Leader Sets Loan Accord
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/14/busin.body_text: **********Allan E. Clore, the financially troubled chairman of Kaisertech Ltd., disclosed today that a group of his creditors had agreed to forbear his $99 million defaulted loan. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Clore said that the forbearance period expires on Dec. 31, unless Mr. Clore has entered into an agreement to sell his Kaisertech shares. **********In return for the extension Mr. Clore has agreed to pay the creditors 20 percent of the proceeds from any sale of his Kaisertech shares in excess of $12 a share. The group of creditors, under the name BAII Banking Corporation, consists of a syndicate of foreign banks including Lloyds Bank P.L.C., Credit des Bergues, and Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/30/busin.body_text: **********After three years of staggering losses, executives in the oilfield service industry thought that the worst was finally over last summer. Oil prices went as high as $22 a barrel and exploration for new oil in the United States began to accelerate, increasing the demand for the drilling rigs, casing, pipe and other equipment and services needed to find and produce new reserves. **********Further helped by a surge in foreign orders, many members of the industry - including Schlumberger Ltd., the Halliburton Company and Dresser Industries - returned to the black. And many executives were confidently predicting that a $10 billion reduction in operating costs since 1985 would enable the industry as a whole to turn a profit in 1988. A Sudden Reversal **********Now these executives are not so certain. The hopes that better days were at hand dwindled a couple of weeks ago, when oil prices suddenly slumped after OPEC could not persuade all its members to go along with a plan to limit their production. **********For instance, the price of the American benchmark crude oil, West Texas Intermediate, dropped by more than $4, to below $15 a barrel. And although it now sells for just under $17, that is still below the $19 of four weeks ago. **********Even if oil prices average only $15 a barrel next year, the oilfield service industry stands to break even, many in the industry say. That is partly because of belt tightening, bankruptcies of some competitors and consolidations among others over the past two years. For example, Baker Hughes Inc., a company formed by the merger last April of Baker International Inc. and the Hughes Tool Company, says it has reduced its annual operating costs by $85 million by cutting its staff and achieving other economies of scale. **********With oil at $15 a barrel, the number of rigs used to drill for new oil in the United States - a key barometer of the industry's health - would average about 950 in 1988, according to the American Petroleum Institute, a trade group. **********A comparison with 1987 figures reflects the industry's progress in lowering costs and narrowing losses. This year, when the drilling-rig average was 936, or only 14 below the projected break-even average for next year, the 95 public companies in the industry lost 4 cents on every dollar of sales, according to estimates by Simmons & Company International, a Houston investment bank. (Collectively, these companies have lost $11.4 billion in the past three years, Simmons said.) Should oil prices rebound to $18 a barrel next year, the number of rigs would probably average 1,100 to 1,200. The total in operation last Monday was 1,145, still close to the year's peak of 1,181 two weeks ago and far above the low of 744 on May 10. While the $18-a-barrel figure would still be way below the peak of 4,500 in 1981, it would be high enough for most companies in the industry to make money. Lower Prices Seen **********But rather than expecting prices to return to $18 a barrel, some energy analysts and officials of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries say overproduction by the cartel's members makes it more likely that prices will sink to as low as $12 within a few months. ''We expect prices to soften in late January and February, to around $12 or $13, and stay there for some period,'' said Dennis Eklof, a director of Cambridge Energy Research Associates, a consulting concern in Cambridge, Mass. **********If prices average $15 a barrel or less into the summer, another wave of consolidation, through mergers and joint ventures, will probably sweep the industry, analysts and executives predict. Many energy experts fear that the damage from such a contraction would outweigh the gains. **********Indeed, the industry already could not supply the exploration equipment and services that would be required to find enough new oil to keep the nation's dependence on oil imports from rising. Imports now supply about 40 percent of the oil consumed in the United States, and about 2,500 rigs, or more than twice the number in operation, would have to be drilling for new oil just to maintain the status quo, most experts agree. **********At the moment, however, the question of whether the industry could support such an exploration level is academic. Most experts agree that exploration will not increase significantly until oil sells for $25 a barrel for a sustained period. Signs of a Weaker Industry **********Still, the signs of the industry's weakened state are already evident. Richard L. Kinchelow, a senior vice president at Enserch Exploration Inc., a Dallas-based exploration and production company, said the performance of the oilfield service companies he hires ''is acceptable, but down.'' Many have not kept their equipment in good shape, he said. **********Moreover, many analysts and some executives fear that the quality of equipment and service will deteriorate further because the industry cannot attract the capital it needs to maintain existing equipment and to develop new products. **********The oilfield service industry will have to become solidly profitable before the situation is reversed, and that prospect ''looks like a fairy-tale land right now,'' said Matthew Simmons, president of the investment bank that bears his name. ''The industry can't sustain itself as it is.'' Supplies Could Tighten **********Analysts and executives say it would take the industry a minimum of six months and possibly more than a year to gear up to support a healthy rate of drilling - at least 2,000 rigs in operation. **********Many manufacturers of the heavy steel pipe used to drill wells mothballed their operations after 1982, and only three domestic steelmakers have maintained working plants: the USX Corporation; National Oilwell, a joint venture formed in April, and the CF& I Steel Corporation. Meanwhile, supplies of the pipe have sharply tightened in the past year - because of both rising demand and purchases by speculators - and prices of some widely used types of pipe have more than doubled. **********''If you saw a 25 percent increase in active rigs, drill pipe would become a weak link,'' said L.C. Martin, chairman and chief executive of the Aztec Manufacturing Company, a specialized producer of casings, tool joints and other products used by rig operators. **********Mr. Eklof of Cambridge Energy Research predicted that steelmakers that dropped out of the business would quickly reactivate their plants if prices continued to rise. Shortage of Workers Looms **********A looming shortage of skilled workers, especially machine-tool operators, may be harder to cure. ''We're working an awful lot of overtime because of this,'' Mr. Martin said. ''To a certain extent, it's limiting what we can produce.'' **********Many skilled machinists lost their jobs in oil equipment factories after the oil boom ended in the early 1980's. Thousands abandoned the Southwest and found new jobs in other regions. Executives said these workers would be hard to lure back because of worries about being laid off again. **********''Companies are having to talk to 12 or 15 former employees to get one to come back,'' Mr. Simmons said. **********Robert G. Fowler, president of Enserch Exploration, added: ''We would have a serious personnel problem if there was a sharp increase in the rig count, say to 2,000. Probably the bulk of the added people would be inexperienced, and that would put them so far back on the training curve it would cost us.'' **********Marvin Gearhart, chairman and chief executive of Gearhart Industries, thinks the manpower shortage would take more than a year to correct, especially in the production of highly technical equipment used by exploration companies. Gearhart a Case Study **********The transformation of Gearhart, a maker of technology used in wells to improve the analysis of geological formations, illustrates the woes of hundreds of oilfield service companies. Gearhart lost $567 million in 1985 and 1986, and slashed its work force to 500, from 2,000 in 1981. **********This year Gearhart missed deadlines on several debt payments, but fought off bankruptcy by selling assets and by sustaining sales in foreign markets, which accounted for $80 million of an estimated $150 million in revenues this year. Its biggest year was 1985, when revenues topped $640 million. **********Now, even if oil prices suddenly rise, ''we're going to be reluctant to jump back in and hire people,'' Mr. Gearhart said, adding: ''We've lost so much money. We've been burned so bad.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/23/world.main_headline: North Korea Reported To Watch Carefully
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/23/world.print_headline: North Korea Reported To Watch Carefully
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/23/world.body_text: **********The civil unrest here has not significantly affected North Korean military movements, Gen. William J. Livsey, the senior American military commander in South Korea, said today. **********Asked if the South Korean crisis had produced a change on the other side of the demilitarized zone that divides the Korean Peninsula, General Livsey replied: ''Not much. But there has been a perking up of ears, a heightened awareness of what is going on here.'' **********North Korea, he said, is ''watching very, very carefully,'' but he added that the overall pattern remained ''about the same.'' **********General Livsey, who spoke with foreign reporters, is scheduled to retire Thursday after 35 years in the Army. He is to be succeeded by Gen. Louis C. Menetrey, who had been commander of the Fifth Army at Fort Sam Houston, Tex.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/27/busin.snippet: LEAD: SOME of today's most successful purveyors of parent information include a Minneapolis mother, a child psychologist and a TV producer whose star is his wife.
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/27/busin.main_headline:
WHAT'S NEW IN THE PARENT BUSINESS;
SHARING INSIGHTS, MOM-TO-MOM
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/27/busin.print_headline:
WHAT'S NEW IN THE PARENT BUSINESS;
SHARING INSIGHTS, MOM-TO-MOM
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/27/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: SOME of today's most successful purveyors of parent information include a Minneapolis mother, a child psychologist and a TV producer whose star is his wife. **********SOME of today's most successful purveyors of parent information include a Minneapolis mother, a child psychologist and a TV producer whose star is his wife. **********Vicki Lansky stumbled into the business a dozen years ago when, as a young Minneapolis mother with no publishing experience, she put together a cookbook of baby-food recipes to raise funds for her local childbirth education group. Ms. Lansky published the book, ''Feed Me, I'm Yours,'' which sold 100,000 copies before Bantam Books bought the rights. Her second book, ''The Taming of the C.A.N.D.Y. Monster,'' made the best-seller lists. **********By sticking with the formula of sharing practical information, Ms. Lansky has sold three million books at an average price of $5 each. ''My books work for the same reasons that support groups do,'' said Ms. Lansky, whose current projects include packaging book and audio tape combinations and writing a series of read-aloud books for Bantam. **********Michael Krauss's entry into the business, about eight years ago, was more deliberate. The former producer of ''Today'' and ''Good Morning, America'' television shows, Mr. Krauss was looking for program ideas for his production company when his wife Joan Lunden, co-host of ''Good Morning, America,'' was pregnant with the first of their three daughters. **********With Mr. Krauss behind the camera and Ms. Lunden in front, the couple began producing programs that combine Ms. Lunden's mom-to-mom anecdotes with advice approved by the American Academy of Pediatrics. Famous guests add a show-business sheen - Pia Zadora singing a lullabye, Henry Kissinger suggesting ways to mediate family fights. **********The programs include a half-hour program on the Lifetime Cable Network, one-minute spots on regular network channels and, next fall, a talk and variety program. ''It's a multimillion dollar business, but that's not the reason we're doing it,'' Mr. Krauss said, referring to their panoply of ventures, which include books, tapes and a syndicated column that began last month. ''We want to help people relax and enjoy their children more.'' **********Lee Salk, clinical professor of psychology at Cornell University Medical College, has been informing parents for nearly two decades, covering issues from surrogate motherhood to teen-age suicide. In January, Mr. Salk plans to introduce a monthly information service that will include monthly mailings of a newsletter, brochures, charts and checklists, as well as bulletins on health and family topics in the news. The subscription price will be ''substantially under $100,'' Mr. Salk said. **********How big a market does he hope to reach? ''Every parent in America,'' Mr. Salk said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/13/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Philips, Sony Set Audio-Video Plan
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/13/busin.body_text: **********Philips N.V. of the Netherlands and the Sony Corporation of Japan, two of the world's largest electronics concerns, have agreed on specifications for the marketing of a combined audio-video compact disk player, Philips said. Philips said the two companies had set a world standard specification for the new combination player, just as they did two years ago for compact disks and players. A spokesman, Jan Geel, said the new player would enter the market in the Netherlands this summer, priced from $735 to $980. **********A version suited to the American market will be on display at the Chicago Consumer Electronics Show in June, Mr. Geel said, followed by the European model at the Berlin Audio-Video Show in August. The companies will also jointly develop a mini three-inch compact disk for the pop singles market, Philips said. It will play up to 20 minutes of music, against up to 75 minutes on existing compact disks, and be compatible with existing compact disk players.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/14/busin.body_text: **********The American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday provided the first details of an expected reduction in long-distance rates, saying that it would lower basic domestic rates by an average of 4.8 percent on July 1. **********The reduction would save consumers more than $590 million a year, or about 72 cents on a typical $15 monthly bill, A.T.&T. said. It would apply to residential and business long-distance service, but not to A.T.&T.'s 800-number toll-free service or to its WATS service. **********The new reduction would mean that A.T.&T.'s rates have fallen nearly 16 percent so far this year and roughly 34 percent since the breakup of the Bell System in 1984. MCI, U S Sprint to Respond **********A.T.&.T.'s principal competitors, the MCI Communications Corporation and the U S Sprint Communications Company, said they would soon announce their own rate cuts. But they said they wanted to study A.T.&.T.'s reductions before giving details. In the past, the rivals have cut rates to maintain a price advantage of 10 to 20 percent below A.T.&T. **********''We will continue to be priced lower than A.T.&T.,'' said Gary Tobin, an MCI spokesman. **********At U S Sprint, ''We will maintain price leadership,'' said Sid Crossen, a spokesman. **********A.T.&.T.'s action is a direct result of the Federal Communications Commission's decision earlier this year to increase the monthly charge that individuals and small businesses pay for access to the local telephone network, to $3.50, from $2. This access charge helps local telephone companies recover the fixed costs of their facilities and equipment. **********The higher access charge for customers means that the long-distance companies would have to pay less in fees to subsidize these fixed costs. The F.C.C. limits A.T.&T.'s rate of return on long-distance service, and the company is required to pass on these savings to customers. Since A.T.&T. has about 80 percent of the long-distance business, its rivals are under pressure to match any reduction. Only 60 Cents on July 1 **********The A.T.&T. rate reduction, which must still be approved by the F.C.C., actually reflects only a 60-cent increase in customer access charges on July 1. The remainder of the $1.50 increase would be put into effect later this year and next. Whether A.T.&T. customers actually end up with net savings from the rate cut depends on how many long-distance calls they make. **********Just how the price cuts would affect the long-distance companies' financial results remains to be seen. ''In theory it should be a wash,'' an A.T.&T. spokesman said, because the rate cuts are being matched by reductions in the fees A.T.&T. pays to the local telephone companies. Indeed, A.T.&T. could benefit if the lower rates encourage more long-distance calls. The same should hold true for MCI and U S Sprint. **********Still, these lower prices have resulted in reduced profits for MCI and U S Sprint. MCI has already said that while it expects to be profitable in 1987, it foresees disappointing second and third quarters. And U S Sprint, which has been losing money for more than two years, could see those losses widen as a result of the lower rates. **********Wall Street analysts said they had been expecting a cut of the size announced. ''It's about right,'' said Audrey Stevoff, a telephone analyst at Duff & Phelps. She predicted that MCI ''pretty much will follow.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/27/world.main_headline: U.S. CAN RETALIATE FOR MINING IN GULF, WEINBERGER WARNS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/27/world.print_headline: U.S. CAN RETALIATE FOR MINING IN GULF, WEINBERGER WARNS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/27/world.body_text: **********Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said today that the United States would increase its ability to detect and destroy mines in the Persian Gulf, and was ''perfectly capable'' of retaliating against whatever force put mines in the way of merchant ships bound for Kuwait. **********Mr. Weinberger gave no indication that he knew who laid the mine that damaged the Kuwaiti tanker Bridgeton Friday. But he said the United States Navy would search more diligently for mines in the gulf. **********Salvage specialists said today that the Bridgeton was damaged more seriously than originally estimated, according to The Associated Press. Divers who inspected the listing tanker near Sea Island, Kuwait, reported that 4 of her 32 compartments were flooded, according to maritime salvage specialists in Dubai quoted by the A.P. Initial reports had said only one compartment was flooded. A Difficult Task **********The Pentagon has been told to give a higher priority to protecting convoys against mines than to retaliating for the Bridgeton episode. But since neither the Navy nor gulf countries friendly to the United States have many minesweeping craft, naval experts said it would be difficult to prevent a recurrence. **********''If we find the party that laid the mines, we are perfectly capable of taking retaliatory steps, certainly,'' Mr. Weinberger said on the ABC News program ''This Week.'' **********Appearing before Mr. Weinberger on the same program, the Iranian Ambassador to the United Nations, Said Rajaie Khorassani, said that the mine blamed for damaging the Bridgeton ''might be ours, it might be somebody else's.'' 'We Are Pleased' **********But he added, ''We are pleased to see that the tanker was hit.'' **********Asked about the possibility of American retaliation, he said: ''I think if the United States wants to be further involved in the war, it can proceed. We have no objection to that. We have to prepare for the worst, of course.'' **********On Friday, the White House said that retaliation was not being considered, and that there was no evidence of who had placed the mine. But military officials said, even before the escort operation began, that they are prepared if necessary to retaliate if Iran acted against American installations or personnel. French Alert Warships **********In Paris today, a French Defense Ministry spokesman said the aircraft carrier Clemenceau and three support vessels had been put on alert and told they might have to sail for the Middle East within 24 hours. The spokesman said the alert should not imply future action but was ''justified by the international situation in the Middle East, particularly in Lebanon and in the gulf.'' **********In his remarks, Mr. Weinberger said the Navy would not necessarily need to send minesweeping ships to the gulf. The Navy has only a few active-duty minesweepers. **********More likely, officials said, helicopters would be used to search for mines. ''We have a minesweeping capability in the Persian Gulf, and it can be increased and will be increased,'' Mr. Weinberger said. ''What we don't do is talk about it, talk about where it's based and all the rest.'' **********However, naval experts said clearing mines with helicopters alone would be extremely difficult. It would require long hours of flying, in air that is hot, dense and often full of sand. Red Sea Minesweeping Recalled **********Since May 17, five ships have struck mines in the northern half of the gulf. In his efforts to describe the American ability to counter this relatively new threat in the Persian Gulf, Mr. Weinberger mentioned the finding and destruction of several mines in Kuwaiti territorial waters in recent weeks, and a long search for mines in the Red Sea in 1984, when several ships hit mines thought to have been placed by Libya. **********In 1984, mine searching teams from the Netherlands, Italy, France, Britain, the Soviet Union, the United States, Egypt and Saudi Arabia looked for mines in the Red Sea. Few of the devices were found before merchant ships hit them. **********Mr. Weinberger's remarks seemed to suggest that the Navy would use similar tactics. This would mean using RH-53D Sea Stallion helicopters based either on land or on ships. **********One ship used as a helicopter base in the Red Sea, the La Salle, is the command ship for the group of frigates, destroyers and cruisers that is protecting merchantmen flying the American flag in the gulf. The extended escort is taking the warships farther north in the gulf than they used to go. **********In the Red Sea operation, helicopters also worked from a Marine amphibious transport ship, the Shreveport, and an oceanographic research ship also took part in the search. Four Marine amphibious ships, including the dock landing ship Spiegel Grove, the amphibious assault ship Guadalcanal, and two tank landing ships, the Saginaw and the La Moure County, recently moved from the Mediterranean Sea to the Indian Ocean, not far from the Gulf. Saudis Helped Clear Mines **********The Pentagon has been reluctant to say exactly how it assisted Kuwait in clearing mines from waters near its main harbor. It is believed that United States Navy specialists brought special sonar equipment to Kuwait and found the mines, using small boats or aircraft. Kuwaiti frogmen, carrying handheld sonars that can detect basketball-sized objects from 100 yards away, then pinpointed the mines and destroyed them with explosives. **********Saudi Arabia sent two of its four minesweepers to Kuwait to find a clear channel for ships to use. It is not known whether Saudi Arabia has been asked, or would agree, to operate its minesweepers farther at sea, in dangerous waters near the Iranian island base of Farsi, in the area where the Bridgeton sustained damage. **********In his remarks, Mr. Weinberger cautioned that a full investigation is needed to prove that the Bridgeton explosion was caused by a mine. **********''It has not been firmly established that this was a mine,'' he said. ''It could have been an internal explosion. I don't think it was. I think it was a mine. But it hasn't been firmly established.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/08/world.main_headline: Voice of Gorbachev: An Old Summit Hand
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/08/world.print_headline: Voice of Gorbachev: An Old Summit Hand
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/08/world.body_text: **********When Mikhail S. Gorbachev arrived at Andrews Air Force Base today, two translators followed him down the steps from his jet. One of them was a familiar face with a familiar voice, Viktor M. Sukhodrev, who was a rising star among official translators when he came to the United States in 1959 as a backup man for the Eisenhower-Khrushchev summit talks. **********Nearly 30 years later Mr. Sukhodrev has become the translator Mr. Gorbachev likes to use for television appearances in the West. Mr. Gorbachev's other translator looked slightly unhappy when he turned the airport arrival ceremonies over to Mr. Sukhodrev as Mr. Gorbachev stepped up to the microphone. **********Mr. Sukhodrev's career took off in 1959 when the leading translator, Oleg Troyanovsky, got sick, and Mr. Sukhodrev, then 27 years old, stepped into the breach. **********A generation and four Soviet leaders have come and gone, and Mr. Sukhodrev has translated for at least four more summit meetings. While his once-youthful looks have matured, his popularity in the diplomatic ranks in Moscow has not shrunk. **********''He is a fantastic mimic,'' one Western diplomat said recently in Moscow. ''He can do a Yorkshire businessman one minute, and a Houston oil tycoon the next.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/23/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Branko Mikulic, facing widespread strikes and rising political dissent, was quoted today as saying the army would be used if necessary to defend the country's Communist political system. **********He warned that the authorities would use ''all means'' available against those who would try to overthrow Yugoslavia's constitutional system, adding: ''And that includes the army.'' **********It was the first direct public comment by Mr. Mikulic on the wave of industrial unrest. He had been out of the public eye for a week. **********More than 10,000 workers are officially reported to be taking part in 70 strikes, which began early this month and appear to be spontaneous and uncoordinated. Unofficial reports put the number much higher. **********About half the walkouts have taken place in Croatia, one of Yugoslavia's most industrialized republics. The strikes came in response to a wage freeze and other steps taken to fight inflation and deal with the foreign debt. **********Mr. Mikulic, who rarely talks to the foreign press, spoke in an interview with West German reporters. He is scheduled to visit Bonn on Thursday. The interview was published today by the official Yugoslav press agency Tanyug. **********''If these people would organize to overthrow the constitutional system in our country, then we would do the same thing you would do if the constitutional system in your country was threatened,'' he was quoted as saying. **********''There should be no doubt in the country or abroad that we shall defend our system with all means. It is written in our constitution. We cannot accept any dialogue on whether Yugoslavia will remain a federative country or not.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/03/world.main_headline: MILITARY LEADERS IN HAITI YIELD ON PLANS FOR CONTROL OF ELECTIONS
