https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/03/world.print_headline: MILITARY LEADERS IN HAITI YIELD ON PLANS FOR CONTROL OF ELECTIONS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/03/world.body_text: **********In a dramatic effort to end the political crisis that has engulfed Haiti for the last 10 days, the military Government announced tonight that it was restoring control of the country's electoral process to an independent civilian council. **********The nine-member electoral council established in Haiti's recently adopted Constitution immediately announced that it would begin drafting a new plan for conducting elections. **********The Government indicated that a new date would have to be set for local elections, which it had scheduled for Aug. 23. But it made no mention of the presidential elections planned for late November and there was no indication tonight that they might not be held as scheduled. Third Day of Unrest **********The announcements on national television came at the end of a third day of nationwide strikes with scattered eruptions of violence in the capital in which 4 people were killed and at least 13 others were wounded by gunfire from soldiers. Medical authorities said at least 11 people were killed in clashes with troops earlier in the week and that about 70 were wounded. **********It has been one of the bloodiest periods in Haiti since the chaotic weeks that preceded and followed the collapse of the dictatorship of Jean Claude Duvalier 17 months ago. Tomorrow has been declared a day of national mourning by some of the leaders of the latest protests. **********The Government also announced on television tonight the resignation of the Minister of Information, Jacques Lorthe, who had said at a news conference last week that the Government did not care whether its decision to take control of the electoral process was constitutional or not. In a letter of resignation, Mr. Lorthe said he was stepping down to facilitate ''a solution to this national crisis.'' **********When the Government declared 11 days ago that it was taking control of elections from the electoral council, it touched off an uproar that brought virtually every political organization in the country together in opposition. **********The action was almost universally seen as a violation of the new Constitution that was overwhelming endorsed in late March and as an attempt by the military leaders to transform their provisional Government into a dictatorship. **********The great popularity of the Constitution, copies of which some voters had carried with them to the polls, stemmed from its array of carefully worded protections against the kinds of despotism that has dominated Haiti's history. **********Individuals of all social strata condemned the Government's apparent reversion to rule by force that was reminiscent of the nearly 30-year period in which Mr. Duvalier and his father, Francois, ruled and plundered Haiti. **********At barricades in the capital today, two civil servants displayed the depth of feeling the crisis has evoked, speaking bitterly of the Government's seizure of the electoral process and insisting that while they received Government paychecks, their first loyalty was ''to the people.'' Threat of U.S. Aid Cutoff **********In an interview tonight, Pierre Robert Auguste, Haiti's deputy Minister of Information, said the Government hoped the measures it took tonight, under threats from the United States that more than $100 million in foreign aid was in danger of being cut off, would return calm to Haiti. **********The Government's decision, Mr. Auguste said ''guarantees the viability of Haitian democracy, despite its frailty.'' **********But some of the political leaders who have been prominent in the anti-Government campaign on the election issue said they were disappointed that the Government had failed to reinstate a labor federation that it dissolved last week in another apparent contravention of the Haitian Constitution. Late in the night, the sounds of gunshots periodically broke the quiet of the capital's darkened streets. **********Mr. Auguste said that while there had been no specific reference to the banned union tonight, he said he believed the actions on the electoral issue ''opened the way'' to lifting the sanctions. 'Trade Union Freedoms' **********''Trade union freedoms remain guaranteed in the Constitution,'' he said. **********The anti-Government protests began initially with demands for the restoration of authority to the electoral council, but broadened into calls for the resignation of the military Government headed by Lieut. Gen. Henri Namphy. The calls appeared to be gaining increasing public support. **********In demonstrations in half a dozen provincial towns today many protesters chanted slogans insisting that the Government step down and in the dilapidated coastal town of Jacmel, south of Port-au-Prince, marchers carried a coffin that they said symbolized the death of the military Government. **********In the capital, protesters set fire to two buses and two cars and blocked the main road to the south with the charred wrecks. They broke the windows of some other cars, including one carrying a correspondent for United Press International, and looted a hardware store. **********All the commercial airlines serving Haiti, including Eastern Airlines, American Airlines and Pan American Airways, canceled their flights to and from Haiti as protesters barricaded the main roads and taxis and buses stayed in their garages. **********In a speech to the nation late Tuesday night, after two violent days of protest, General Namphy indicated that he was willing to begin discussion on the elections issue. **********The first sessions were held Wednesday. There were conflicting reports on how they were progressing. But their resumption this morning was taken as a hopeful sign. **********The electoral council said in a statement that the first six hours of talks centered on the powers originally granted by the Government to the council in mid-May. **********The electoral council had rejected the Government's delineation of its functions, especially a provision that all of its decisions were subject to review by the Supreme Court. It responded by presenting its own plan of operation which was superseded without comment by a government decree that emasculated the council and provoked the crisis when it became public on June 22.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/21/busin.print_headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES; Browning-Ferris Offers Convertible Debentures
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/21/busin.body_text: **********Browning-Ferris Industries, a Houston-based waste-management company, yesterday began offering $300 million of 6 1/4 percent convertible subordinated debentures due 2012 through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. **********Convertible issues are often described as a hybrid between stocks and bonds, paying interest but giving buyers the option of converting their holding into shares of company stock at a prestated price above the stock's current market value. **********Convertibles are favored by issuers of debt because the conversion feature is an enhancement that allows the security to carry an interest rate that is lower than that of a comparable regular debt offering. **********The Browning-Ferris issue is noncallable for three years. The debentures can be converted at any time into the company's common stock at $41 a share. Shares in Browning-Ferris closed yesterday at $33.25, up $1.125, on the New York Stock Exchange. **********The debentures are rated A-3 by Moody's Investors Service and A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation. **********Proceeds from the sale, the company said, would be used for general corporate purposes including the reduction of variable-rate bank debt and future acquisitions.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/18/busin.main_headline: Guinness Agrees to Buy Schenley From Riklis
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/18/busin.print_headline: Guinness Agrees to Buy Schenley From Riklis
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/18/busin.body_text: **********Guinness P.L.C. announced today that it would buy Schenley Industries, a New York-based spirits distributor, for $480 million to strengthen the British company's control over its brands in the United States. **********The purchase agreement, which had been expected, also ends a legal dispute between Guinness and Schenley's owner, Meshulam Riklis, the New York financier. **********The dispute began last year after Guinness's $4.1 billion takeover of the Distillers Company. That acquisition led to a British Government investigation and the dismissal of a handful of Guinness top executives, including the chairman, Ernest Saunders. The Government is investigating suspicious stock dealings during the takeover bid, and Mr. Saunders has been indicted on three criminal charges. **********For years Schenley distributed Distillers' strongest brands in the United States, led by Dewar's White Label, the top-selling Scotch whiskey in that market, and Gordon's gin and vodka. **********In the run-up to the Distillers acquisition, Mr. Riklis was a heavy buyer of Guinness shares, which helped the Guinness bid prevail over a competing offer. Afterward the legal title to the Dewar's White Label brand and distribution rights were transferred to Mr. Riklis for a nominal sum, raising concerns among British investigators that this was in return for his support of the Guinness stock price. Incentive to Sell Is Noted **********In a statement today, Guinness said that last November's agreement for the assignment of the Dewar trademarks and distribution arrangements had been declared ''null and void.'' **********The Schenley acquisition, according to bankers and analysts, gives Mr. Riklis a fair price to get out of the business. Moreover, they add, Mr. Riklis has considerable incentive to sell because Schenley's $500 million-a-year sales depend largely on distributing brands controlled by Guinness, whose new management views Mr. Riklis as linked to the discredited Mr. Saunders. **********A few months ago Anthony Tennant, the new Guinness chief executive, served notice that Guinness wanted to buy Schenley. ''And since Guinness supplies the brands Schenley sells, Riklis really didn't have much choice,'' said a banker familiar with the deal. **********According to a Guinness spokesman, Mr. Riklis is still believed to hold about 30 million Guinness shares, roughly 3.5 percent of the company. Mr. Riklis could not be reached for comment. **********For Guinness, the Schenley acquisition is a big step in its strategy to control its key brands at every stage of the business, from production and promotion to marketing and sales. Control of Brands in U.S.  ''Guinness will capture the profit of the importer and regain control over the destiny of its brands in the United States,'' observed Marvin R. Shanken, editor of Impact International, a trade journal. **********Mr. Tennant, the 56-year-old chief executive, employed the same strategy when he was in charge of Grand Metropolitan's International Distillers and Vintners subsidiary. For example, analysts note, Grand Metropolitan acquired Liggett in 1980 because it distributed the British company's J & B Scotch whiskey. **********''Tennant is using the same formula at Guinness that he did at Grand Metropolitan and for the same reasons,'' said Daniel Leaf, an analyst for Wood Mackenzie & Company, a brokerage house. **********For his part, Mr. Tennant noted the necessity of managing the marketing of the company's brands. ''This major move will prove to be of considerable benefit to Guinness from the outset,'' he said. **********In the fiscal year ending next Jan. 31, Schenley is expected to have pretax earnings of roughly $65 million on sales of $500 million. **********Besides distributing Guinness products, Schenley markets other brands, including I. W. Harper bourbon, Somona wines of California and Coronet brandy.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/17/busin.body_text: **********The United States textile industry, a leading supporter of tough trade legislation, said today that 1987 would mark the seventh consecutive year of record textile and apparel imports. The American Textile Manufacturers Institute, a trade organization, said in its year-end report that foreign shipments would raise the textile and apparel trade deficit by 20 percent, to $25.4 billion, by the end of December.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/18/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Wheeling Names A New Chairman
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/18/busin.body_text: **********Lloyd C. Lubensky was named chairman of the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation late yesterday, succeeding George A. Ferris. Mr. Ferris, who was named chairman only two months ago, resigned not only that post but his positions as director, vice-chairman, and chief executive. The steel company is in bankruptcy preceedings. **********Mr. Lubensky, 64 years old, is president of the American Jet Industries based in Van Nuys, Calif. The company, a distributor of aircraft parts, was founded by Allen E. Paulson, who had been chairman of the company until early January. **********In January Mr. Lubensky bought a 34.2 percent stake in the company for a mere $100,000 from Mr. Paulson. The market price of the Paulson stake was valued by analysts at $13.5 million. It was thought at the time that Mr. Paulson had sold his stake for such a low sum as part of a plan to install Mr. Lubensky as chairman of the company. **********Apparently developments did not go according to plan and George A. Ferris, who had been vice chairman and chief executive was installed as chairman instead. Then yesterday Mr. Ferris stepped down. **********When the Paulson stake changed hands, Mr. Paulson, who had paid $50 million for the 1.7 million shares that he bought in 1983 and 1984, said that he had sold them at such a dramatic discount to public market prices to offset gains from other investments. **********Mr. Paulson is chairman of the Gulfstream Aerospace Corporation. Mr. Lubensky bought American Jet from Mr. Paulson in 1982. It has since been sold to Ryder Systems, but Mr. Lubensky remains president. Neither Mr. Ferris, Mr. Lubensky nor Mr Paulson could be reached for comment last night.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/10/busin.print_headline: SENATE PLANT RULE KEPT; IMPORT DISCRETION
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/10/busin.body_text: **********Despite the threat of a veto and the loss of business backing, the Senate today approved an amendment to the trade bill that would require 60 days' advance notice to employees and local communities of plant closings and mass layoffs. **********But hours later the Senate, in two voice votes, approved amendments that would restore much of the Presidential discretion in import relief decisions it had taken away Tuesday. **********The acceptance of the plant-closing provison, which is backed by organized labor but opposed by business, could seriously jeopardize the chances for passage of a trade bill this year unless it is dropped in conference with the House. **********The reversal on import relief, however, could negate another serious veto threat from the White House if it survives in the conference with the House. **********Approval of the plant-closing provision came on a 60-to-40 vote that defeated an amendment to strike the provision from the bill. The Senate had approved the provision tentatively Wednesday after its Democratic sponsors significantly eased it to attract support. **********With the vote, six leading business organizations said they would withdraw their support for the entire thousand-page bill. These organizations - including the United States Chamber of Commerce, the Business Roundtable and the National Association of Manufacturers - have been part of the crucial core support for trade legislation and were willing to back Congress on other provisions the Administration opposes. **********The President's trade representative, Clayton K. Yeutter, said, ''There's no chance whatsoever of the President signing a bill that includes the language of the Senate bill as it now exists.'' **********It is not clear whether the House will accept the plant-closing provision. A sponsor of the proposal, Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, Democrat of Ohio, said, ''I don't have much doubt the House will accept this provision.'' But aides to the House Ways and Means Committee chairman, Dan Rostenkowski, Democrat of Illinois, said the conferees from the House were expected to resist the plant-closing amendment. **********Democratic leaders in the Senate hope to have a final vote on the trade bill by the end of the week. But they got bogged down this afternoon on an unrelated amendment aimed at blocking the Administration's plan to provide protection for Kuwaiti tankers in the Persian Gulf. **********But this evening the Senate got back to trade, and that is when it made the surprise turnaround on import relief. **********On Tuesday the Senate accepted, 55 to 41, a proposal that would limit the President's discretion in refusing to grant relief to domestic industries hurt by imports. The relief, in the form of quotas or tariffs, would protect struggling industry from import competition. The vote took away the President's right to consider the national economic interest when deciding whether to carry out a recommendation from the International Trade Commission for relief. **********But this evening the Senate accepted an amendment offered by Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, that would allow the President to consider the impact of any import relief on the poor. For example, he could deny it if it would raise the prices of goods such as shoes, sugar or automobiles. **********Mr. Bradley said the amendment ''rolled back a lot of the action the Senate took on Tuesday.'' In explaining the change, he said senators found it difficult to oppose an amendment helping the poor. **********After this vote, on which there was no opposition, the Senate adopted an amendment of Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, which allows the President also to consider the impact on agriculture of granting import relief. **********Mr. Yeutter, in a statement, said he ''welcomed'' the change. **********The House, in passing its version of trade legislation in April, approved an amendment that requires trading partners, such as Japan, to reduce their trade surpluses with the United States by a fixed formula if they persist in unfair trade practices. It was proposed by Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, a Democratic Presidential candidate. **********This provision, if included in the final legislation, also seems sure to invite a Presidential veto. **********The plant-closing provision requires that companies with 100 or more employees give six months' notice before a plant closing or a mass layoff. The employee figure, according to sponsors, exempts about 85 percent of the businesses in the United States. **********A plant closing is defined as a layoff of 50 or more workers for 30 days or more. A mass layoff would idle one-third of a company's workers for 30 days or more. The notice requirement is waived if the company is seeking capital or business that would prevent the shutdown or layoff. And if it is caused by ''business circumstance,'' the company is exempt. **********Supporters of the amendment argued that it was necessary to give employees time to get the training necessary for new jobs. **********''If you think employees are just chattel,'' Senator Metzenbaum told his colleagues, and ''if you think you can fire people at will,'' then vote against the amendment. **********Mr. Metzenbaum also swept aside the threats of a veto. ''I don't think we should quiver and quake as to whether the President will veto the bill,'' he said. **********Senator Dan Quayle, the Indiana Republican who led the opposition, said the proposal was intended not to facilitate worker adjustment but to just keep the old plants open. Approval of the amendment, he said, would mean ''I say bye-bye to the trade bill.'' **********''We view this as an anti-competitive measure, imposing European-style government intervention in the marketplace when such policies have so clearly failed and led to economic stagnation,'' said Jeffrey H. Joseph, vice president of the United States Chamber of Commerce.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/23/busin.main_headline: ABC-TV Print Account Assigned to B.J.K.&E.
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/23/busin.print_headline: ADVERTISING; ABC-TV Print Account Assigned to B.J.K.&E.
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/23/busin.body_text: **********The ABC-TV Network news division has assigned its print advertising account to Bozell Jacobs Kenyon & Eckhardt. It had been at N. W. Ayer since 1982 and back then it was called a $2.5 million account. **********The assignment is for print only, because the network handles the on-air promotion itself. So B.J.K.&E. will be responsible for print promotion of such programming as ''World News Tonight,'' ''Nightline,'' ''20/20,'' ''Barbara Walters Specials'' and ''This Week With David Brinkley.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/12/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Troubled Times for Big Banks
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/12/busin.body_text: **********In the fourth quarter, the nation's biggest commercial banking companies were plagued by continued weakness in lending, a decline in investment-banking income and a disturbingly high level of special items. As a result, the year turned out to be one of the harshest for the banks since deregulation began in the late 1970's. **********''The industry is just not earning well,'' said Stephen Berman, banking analyst at Nomura Securities Inc. **********Most analysts are only marginally optimistic about the outlook for 1987. **********Even though the large banking concerns are expected to push harder to expand overseas and to win the right to underwrite securities, analysts see no slowdown in the exodus of large corporate borrowers from the banking system. They see no end to the debt problems of developing nations. They think that commercial real estate rents, which banks depend upon for repayment of development loans, will fall further. And they question whether fee-based businesses - an increasingly important source of bank revenue - will lift earnings. Flat Earnings Predicted **********Thus, the consensus is that the banks' financial condition will improve marginally, at best, or remain unchanged, at worst. **********''I'm looking for the banks' bottom-line earnings to be up only slightly this year, in the mid-single digits,'' said George M. Salem, banking analyst at the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation. **********''What you are seeing is stagnancy,'' said Donald C. Waite, one of the senior banking partners at McKinsey & Company, the management consultants. ''Bank earnings are stagnant, and as a result, returns are falling.'' **********To be sure, a few industry experts argue that the banks are performing well. They note that the banks' interest spreads - the difference between what they are earning on loans and paying on deposits - are holding up nicely. They also note that the banks have managed to maintain their absolute level of profits, if not increase them slightly, at a time when the lending world is still troubled by depressed commodity prices and overcapacity. **********''I would contend that a stable profit level is not the worst thing in the world,'' said Richard Stillinger, a vice president at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods Inc., a Wall Street firm that specializes in bank stocks. Key Indicators Are Down **********But such bank boosters are in the minority these days. The more common view is that the big banks are slipping, and the data certainly suggest that. **********At the 24 big banking companies followed by Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, for example, return on equity fell last year to the lowest level of this decade - to 12.5 percent, from a peak of 15.3 percent in 1980. Loans written off as a fraction of average loans reached a record 0.80 percent, up from 0.36 percent in 1980. Return on assets of 0.73 percent, although up slightly from the level of 1985, was still well below its peak in this decade of 0.91 percent. **********Early last fall, the picture did not seem that grim. By chalking up huge gains from their bond portfolios in the first nine months of the year, while interest rates were falling, the banks appeared to be on the verge of matching the previous year's results. **********In the fourth quarter, however, the banks seemed to fall apart. Loan-loss provisions increased markedly, even as investment-banking income declined. Although many banks dug deeply into their pockets and found special items that helped to lift profits, over all earnings were still disappointing, analysts said. In fact, as the most exacting analysts tell it, even the banks now considered the most prosperous reported lower earnings on an operating basis. Special Gains Pad Income **********Consider, for instance, the Bankers Trust New York Corporation. The parent of the Bankers Trust Company reported net income of $1.39 a share in the fourth quarter. Those results, however, included a gain on the sale of a building, a gain from settlement of pension obligations, a benefit from the change in the tax law, and an above-normal increase in loan-loss reserves. As Mr. Berman of Nomura Securities sees it, Bankers Trust's true earnings were $1.03 a share, compared with $1.17 a year earlier. **********Even J.P. Morgan & Company, widely considered to be the nation's most successful big banking concern, had a tough quarter. Although Morgan reported earnings of $1.02 a share, Mr. Berman calculates that Morgan actually earned 87 cents in the year - compared with 93 cents in 1985 - after special items, including an accounting switch, are excluded. **********This type of analysis does not make bankers happy; indeed, many find it irritating. Yet, according to a number of banking experts, the results show that the nation's largest financial institutions are not doing as well as they were just a few years ago. Some Problems Are Clear **********Although the solutions will be difficult, the problems are well defined: While banks continue to lose business to alternative sources of funding, their remaining loans are going sour at an increasing rate. To offset these problems, the banks have succeeded in dominating certain areas of investment banking, such as interest-rate swaps, which generate big fees. But in addition to being keenly competitive, such fee businesses produce far more volatile results than traditional lending. **********As 1987 unfolds, many analysts expect little improvement in the banks' loan woes, so fee businesses will become even more important. A crucial issue will be whether the fee businesses will restore earnings momentum at the banks, whose stock prices and employee compensation are tied to profits. **********''Fees are becoming a more permanent part of banks' earnings,'' said Mr. Waite of McKinsey. But he added, ''What the banks won't be able to do is sustain the growth rate of fees.'' https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/05/world.main_headline: SERENADING THE LOST LAMBS OF THE COUNTERCULTURE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/05/world.print_headline: WARSAW JOURNAL; SERENADING THE LOST LAMBS OF THE COUNTERCULTURE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/05/world.body_text: **********Adam Hanuszkiewicz, who was dismissed five years ago as director of Poland's national theater because of his activities in the Solidarity period, has just been invited to the Ministry of Culture for talks about a new job. Films blocked by censors since 1981 are being released, and some artists and writers who shunned Government contact after martial law was declared are being asked to take tea with Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski. **********The growing courtship of artists and writers is one of several Government initiatives that at the very least are intended to give the appearance of national reconciliation to foreign and domestic critics. **********The more cynical Poles, and those most committed to the opposition, are advising skepticism. They describe the new approach as a tactic. They say the Communists will never willingly relinquish their control over who can say what to whom. **********But there are many ordinary Poles who, however hesitatingly, are taking delight in the pronouncements of Aleksander Krawczuk, a classics professor from Jagellonian University, who as Minister of Culture for the last four months has been drawing much more from John Stuart Mill than from Marx or Lenin. Minister Not in the Party **********Mr. Krawczuk, who is not a member of the Communist Party, has, for example, declared that culture can only develop spontaneously and that its progress will not adhere to plan. This week, at a news conference, he went so far as to declare that this country's prolific underground and illegal press was ''a good thing.'' **********These remarks, made before 50 foreign and Polish journalists, harmonized to some extent with Soviet initiatives for openness, but they went far beyond anything heard in Moscow. They verged on an endorsement of Poland's bootleg cultural industry, which produces hundreds of publications, books and tapes in clandestine workshops. **********''I think it is good to have this second cultural realm,'' said Mr. Krawczuk, who is well known in the country as the host of television programs about life in ancient Greece and Rome. ''I think people should publish in the second sphere and people should read these things.'' **********His major complaint was that the underground press had not produced any masterpieces. ''Most things published in the underground are light, even superficial,'' he said. **********Asked whether, in light of his views of the clandestine press, there remained any justification for censorship, Mr. Krawczuk backtracked a bit. **********''Perhaps I exaggerated what I said about the usefulness of the parallel culture,'' he said. ''I am used to saying what I think. I have been a professor for 26 years and a minister for only four months. You may accuse me of naivete.'' Censorship 'Dying Out' **********As for censorship, Mr. Krawczuk declared: ''It is not only modest, it is dying out. Many critical articles are published. What is censored are insults against our allies and the authorities.'' The last two terms are widely understood to mean the Soviet Union and Poland's Communist leaders. **********''We are not happy about political censorship in this country, but in times of political conflict it is necessary,'' he said. ''It is now receding.'' **********When a Western reporter asked whether the minister's remarks at the news conference would themselves escape censorship in the official press, the question was answered by Jerzy Urban, the Government spokesman. **********''No one can guarantee the publication of this discussion, because it is up to the editors of each paper to decide,'' said Mr. Urban, who is also not a Communist Party member. Still Subject to Heavy Fines **********Mr. Krawczuk said the authorities had been very lenient with the underground press, leaving its writers or readers unpunished. He was then asked why the printers, and those who distributed the materials, were subject to heavy fines and the confiscation of cars. **********Since last September's amnesty of political prisoners, the size of fines for such offenses has grown. The seven largest underground publishers have responded by forming an underground insurance company to protect against such losses, which they jokingly refer to as Lloyds of Warsaw. **********Mr. Krawczuk said such fines and confiscations were not a form of censorship but rather penalties assessed for tax evasion on the part of the clandestine presses, some of which are large enterprises employing as many as 200 people full time. He was then asked whether these enterprises would be permitted to operate unhindered if they paid taxes. **********Mr. Urban again interceded to say there were questions of commercial law covering the registration of enterprises. On the issue of censorship, he said it was a question on the border line of law and politics. In constitutional terms, he said, everything that is not expressly prohibited is permitted, but he added that in practical terms the policy is evolving as the political situation eases. **********The Government has already increased allocations for culture by a third, released all but one of the films that were being kept from circulation because of their political content, and offered employment to theater directors who have not been allowed to run their own theaters since martial law was declared at the end of 1981. In addition, Mr. Krawczuk said he had taken the first steps to permit the re-establishment of the Polish chapter of the national PEN club, which was disbanded in 1981. Hard Line on Key Issue **********But if the general tone set by Mr. Krawczuk has been conciliatory, he came down on the side of the hard-liners on an issue that, more than any other, defines the limits of cultural reconciliation. It concerns an appeal by 62 literary figures for permission to form their own literary union. **********These people, including some of the best known writers in Poland, believe that they cannot in good conscience join in the official writers' union, whose members they largely regard as puppets of the Government, opportunists or collaborators. **********As is often the case, the controversy touched off by the letter does not deal with the essential argument. Instead, it was stirred by the contention made by Mr. Urban last week that the cause of these independent writers was harmed by the inclusion among the signers of Adam Michnik, the Solidarity figure whose political essays and literary criticism are being translated in many countries. Mr. Urban, himself a journalist, said last week that Mr. Michnik was not mainly a writer but rather a political figure. **********Mr. Krawczuk backed up Mr. Urban by saying, ''Strictly speaking, Mr. Michnik has published only political essays, not belles lettres.'' **********Mr. Michnik, who has written extensively on literary matters, said by phone from Gdansk that he wondered if Mr. Urban ''was truly qualified to pass on who was and was not a writer.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/04/busin.body_text: **********Martin T. Sosnoff, the investor who put Caesars World Inc. into play earlier this year, said yesterday that he was still interested in acquiring the casino operator and had made another bid for the company the day after New Jersey's Casino Control Commission rejected Caesar's proposed recapitalization plan. **********''I'd still like to do a friendly deal with Caesars,'' he said. ''I called them the day after the deal was turned down by the commission, and I haven't heard from Drexel, to whom it was proposed.'' Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. is advising Caesars. **********Caesars' stock has been depressed since the commission's ruling on Aug. 12, although some arbitragers have held out the hope that Mr. Sosnoff might revive his takeover attempt. The stock closed yesterday at $28.75, down 25 cents a share, and still far from the $35.75 where it had traded at the height of the takeover skirmish. **********Mr. Sosnoff, who withdrew his bid in June, had offered $35 a share. **********The New York investor said he was ''a little surprised, but not shocked'' by the commission's decision. He said the commission was apparently concerned that other casino operators might try to recapitalize. **********''I don't think they would have approved my deal either,'' Mr. Sosnoff admitted, noting that it would have left Caesars heavily in debt. **********Mr. Sosnoff said he would not take further action until he learned the results of Caesars' petition for a rehearing after Labor Day. **********Neither Drexel nor Caesars World had any comment yesterday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/29/busin.main_headline: Smith Barney Losses Seen Cutting Primerica Net
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/29/busin.print_headline: Smith Barney Losses Seen Cutting Primerica Net
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/29/busin.body_text: **********The Primerica Corporation said yesterday that its fourth-quarter results would be hurt by trading losses suffered in the market plunge by its Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company brokerage subsidiary. **********Primerica also said that Smith Barney's capital position remained strong and that other Smith Barney operations had performed well despite the difficult market. **********Analysts have indicated that other major brokerage firms' results could be hurt by the Wall Street turmoil. On Monday, the brokerage L. F. Rothschild & Company said it had suffered a $44-million loss so far this month. Wall Street sources said yesterday that the firm was seeking a buyer or a major infusion of capital. **********Although it forecast lower earnings in the next three months, Primerica reported a 16.4 percent rise in third-quarter earnings, on a 53.5 percent increase in revenue. **********Primerica said net income in the quarter had advanced to $53.8 million, or 91 cents a share, from $46.2 million, or 75 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. The 1986 quarter included income from discontinued packaging operations of $18.9 million and a gain of $1.3 million from the sale of certain timberlands. **********Revenue climbed to $1.05 billion, including operations of Smith Barney, which was acquired in the second quarter of this year. In the third quarter of 1986, revenue amounted to $684.2 million. **********Formerly the American Can Company, Primerica changed its name in late 1986 as part of a plan to dispose of its packaging, paper and forest products operations. Continuing operations consist of financial services and specialty retailing and financial services including life, accident and health insurance, mutual fund sales and management and mortgage banking. **********Primerica said financial services operating income for the third quarter was up 30 percent from the corresponding quarter a year earlier. **********''This growth reflects the full-quarter contribution of Smith Barney, higher realized gains and increased earnings from RCM Capital Management, the Penncorp Financial group, Transport Life and Voyager Group,'' said Gerald Tsai Jr., chairman and chief executive. ''However, higher interest rates continued to adversely impact the company's mortgage banking and mutual fund operations during the third quarter.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/03/world.body_text: **********The Palestine Liberation Organization has accepted a plan for ending the violence around refugee districts in Lebanon. **********The plan, if it is carried out, offers the first hope for thousands of inhabitants to resume a normal and peaceful life after three years of fighting. **********A spokesman at P.L.O. headquarters in Tunis said Tuesday night that proposals put forward by Nabih Berri, Lebanon's Minister of Justice, who heads Amal, the mainline Moslem Shiite movement, provided a positive solution. The spokesman was quoted by the P.L.O.'s news agency, WAFA, as saying the Palestinians were ready to enter into immediate negotiations to discuss implementation of the proposals. **********More than 3,000 Palestinians and Lebanese were killed and twice that many wounded since Amal militiamen and P.L.O. guerrillas engaged each other in fierce gun battles in and around Palestinian refugee areas in Beirut and southern Lebanon in the summer of 1985. Clashes with artillery and rockets have recurred as Shiite fighters laid siege to the Palestinian shantytowns. #10,000 Members Under Arms Amal, with 10,000 members under arms, said it was determined to stop the P.L.O. from re-establishing a foothold in Beirut and South Lebanon after the guerrilla stronghold had been shattered by the Israelis when they invaded the country five years ago. **********Most of the 13 Palestinian districts, with a total population of about 200,000, are in predominantly Shiite locations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/10/busin.body_text: **********A Federal grand jury yesterday indicted three senior Wall Street traders who had been arrested in February on charges of insider trading. **********The three, Robert M. Freeman, 44 years old, director of arbitrage at Goldman, Sachs & Company; Richard B. Wigton, 52, head of arbitrage at Kidder, Peabody & Company, and Timothy L. Tabor, 33, a former arbitrage trader at Kidder, Peabody, were each charged with four felony counts. The long-awaited charges included conspiracy to commit securities, mail and wire fraud and three counts of having committed securities fraud. **********Through their lawyers, each denied the charges in the indictment, obtained by the United States Attorney in Manhattan. **********A number of lawyers involved in the case, criminal law experts and Wall Street executives said they were struck more by what was not in yesterday's indictment than by what was included. The nine-page document repeats much of the information in the original complaint filed at the time of the traders' arrests, but it contains less information, in several respects, than that complaint. No Other Stocks Mentioned **********No new stocks were identified as the subject of the insider trading. As in the complaints, the only stocks mentioned were of the Unocal Corporation and Storer Communications Inc., and there was no reference to the Continental Group Inc. **********Martin A. Siegel, a former Kidder, Peabody investment banker, previously pleaded guilty to a charge that he had received an inside tip about Continental from Mr. Freeman, and then had Kidder, Peabody profit from trading in its stock. **********In subpoenas issued to the firms after the arrests, the Government sought information about more than 40 companies that had been involved in takeovers or were clients of the firms, sources with knowledge of the investigation have said. The sources said that subpoenas were also issued to individuals at each of the firms. **********In a search warrant obtained to collect records from Mr. Freeman's office in February, the Government also alleged that Mr. Freeman told Mr. Siegel he had created ''padded'' research files on stocks in which he traded illegally, so it would appear that the trades were based on legal information. **********Neither Kidder, Peabody nor Goldman, Sachs was charged in yesterday's indictment, despite the Government's allegation that they had profited from the trading. **********An arraignment of the three traders was set for next Thursday in Federal District Court in Manhattan. Would Be First Insider Trials **********The lawyers for the indicted traders said that they planned to fight the charges in court and insisted that their clients would be vindicated. Their responses indicated that the Government might face its first trials since the scandal blew up last May with the arrest of Dennis B. Levine, a former investment banker at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. Up to now, 10 investment bankers or lawyers have pleaded guilty to felony charges or agreed to do so, without one case having gone to court. **********The indictment had been expected since the three were dramatically arrested, shocking Wall Street and heightening the nervousness created by the spreading scandal. **********Mr. Tabor was arrested at his Manhattan home late on Feb. 11 and Mr. Freeman and Mr. Wigton were taken from their offices on Feb. 12. **********All had been implicated by Mr. Siegel, a former senior investment banker and takeover specialist at Kidder, Peabody. He pleaded guilty on Feb. 13, the day after Mr. Freeman and Mr. Wigton were arrested. He also settled Securities and Exchange Commission charges that he had sold inside tips for $700,000 to the arbitrager Ivan F. Boesky. Siegel Only Known Source **********In its original complaint, the Government hinted that its charges had resulted from information provided by sources in addition to Mr. Siegel, although it did not identify the sources. Nor did the indictment issued yesterday refer to any other potential witnesses. The defense lawyers involved indicated that they looked forward to cross-examining Mr. Siegel, should he be a key Government witness. **********''From what I know there is substantial material that could be used to impeach Mr. Siegel's testimony,'' said Andrew Lawler, Mr. Tabor's attorney. ''We intend to enter a plea of not guilty and to aggressively litigate.'' **********According to the indictment, from June 1984 to January 1986 Mr. Siegel swapped tips with Mr. Freeman about pending takeover transactions on which their firms were working. Secret Details on Storer **********Mr. Siegel reportedly leaked secret details of a takeover involving Storer Communications to Mr. Freeman. Mr. Freeman is said to have then traded with that information, earning unspecified profits for himself, his family and Goldman, Sachs. **********In turn, Mr. Freeman is said to have tipped off Mr. Siegel about a takeover bid involving Unocal, a Goldman, Sachs client. Mr. Siegel is said to have passed this information to Mr. Wigton and Mr. Tabor, who used it to earn unspecified profits for Kidder, Peabody. **********''Mr. Freeman will plead not guilty, and we look forward to going to trial,'' said Paul J. Curran, Mr. Freeman's attorney. **********''Mr. Wigton will be found innocent,'' said Stanley Arkin, his attorney. Kidder, Peabody suspended Mr. Wigton without pay yesterday, pending a trial, the company said. **********Mr. Freeman remains a partner at Goldman, Sachs. Sources close to the firm said that since his arrest he had been spending most of his time helping to prepare his defense. **********Mr. Tabor is currently unemployed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/28/busin.body_text: **********The National Association of Securities Dealers reported yesterday that the number of shares sold short and not yet covered in the month ended May 15 rose 42.3 million shares, or 21.5 percent, to 238.7 million shares. **********In a short sale, an investor, betting that a stock price will decline, sells borrowed stock back later at a lower price. The number of shares in which a short position is still held by investors is totaled by each exchange at the end of a reporting period and represents the ''short interest'' for that period. **********On the surface, a short sale is bearish, representing an investor's belief that the market will turn down. But many investors consider a rise in short interest a bullish sign of potential future buying power in the market. That is because short sellers must eventually buy the stocks that have been borrowed - and those purchases exert an upward pressure on share prices. **********The following N.A.S.D. companies show changes in open short positions of 10,000 shares or more for the month ended May 15: * Could be involved in arbitrage  S Stock split or dividen  N New  R Revise  T Nasdaq Natl Market System

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/20/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Retailer Nips Takeover Bud
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/20/busin.body_text: **********The Dayton Hudson Corporation, the Minneapolis-based retailer, which had declined comment for more than a week as takeover reports fueled a sharp rise in its stock, yesterday said that it has told an ''aggressive buyer'' of its shares that it does not want to be acquired. **********Dayton Hudson, one of the nation's largest retailers, released a letter to its shareholders in which it reported its reaction to the unidentified buyer. While Ann Barkalew, a company spokeswoman, declined to name the purchaser of its stock, financial sources speculated that it was the Dart Group, which has been linked with various retailing takeover moves in recent months. **********In New York, Stanley Rubenstein, a spokesman for Dart, said that the company had no comment on its reported buying of Dayton Hudson stock. **********Yesterday, Dayton Hudson stock rose 25 cents a share, to $56.50, in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange. **********Last week, Dayton Hudson's stock jumped $5 a share on the takeover reports. **********The Dart Group is expected soon to file a statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission on its holdings in Dayton Hudson, financial sources said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/23/busin.main_headline: Perpetual-Note Holders Offered Swap in London
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/23/busin.print_headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES; Perpetual-Note Holders Offered Swap in London
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/23/busin.body_text: **********Investors in the beleaguered market for perpetual floating-rate notes in London may exchange their holdings for new securities, according to a proposal announced yesterday by a group of securities dealers and an insurance concern. **********The exchange offer, which was devised primarily by J. Henry Schroder Wagg & Company, a British merchant bank, calls for holders of perpetual notes to accept new 28-year floating-rate notes insured by Financial Security Assurance, an American company specializing in insurance of corporate debt securities. **********About $14 billion of the $18 billion of outstanding perpetual notes is eligible for the exchange, which is limited initially to $1 billion. Salomon Brothers International and Nomura International are helping handle the exchange offer. **********Perpetual floating-rate notes, which have no stated maturity, were widely issued by commercial banks until last December, when their prices dropped sharply. One catalyst for the steep drop in prices, which ranged from about 10 percent to more than 20 percent of the notes' face value, was the imposition by banking regulators of a 100 percent reserve on banks' investments in capital securities (such as perpetual notes) issued by another bank. As note prices fell and investor demand dried up, many securities dealers stopped trading the notes, which further depressed their price. **********In the exchange offer, each $1 million face amount of perpetual notes, along with a cash payment of $130,000 to $190,000, is to be exchanged for $930,000 of new 28-year floating-rate notes guaranteed by Financial Security, plus stock in a special-purpose corporation called Security Investment Holdings. The new notes are expected to be rated triple A, like other securities backed by Financial Security. **********The cash payment, which will vary from day to day, depending on which perpetual issue is exchanged, will be used to pay Financial Security's insurance premium and to buy zero coupon Treasury or World Bank bonds that would retire the new 28-year floating-rate notes at maturity. The new floating-rate notes will pay interest at three-tenths of 1 percent above the offered rate for three-month bank deposits in London. **********After payment of interest on the new notes and operating expenses, the stock in the special-purpose company will pay a dividend. After 28 years, holders of stock in Security Investment are entitled to 90 percent of its net assets, which will consist primarily of perpetual floating-rate notes. **********The Bank of England said bank investors in the new 28-year notes would be subject to a reserve requirement of only 2 percent to 10 percent, rather than 100 percent on the perpetual notes. Participants in the financing expect similar treatment by banking regulators in Japan and other countries.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/18/busin.main_headline: STOCK RECORDS SET IN FACE OF SCANDAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/18/busin.print_headline: STOCK RECORDS SET IN FACE OF SCANDAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/18/busin.body_text: **********Stock prices soared to another record yesterday as Wall Street shrugged off the anxiety generated by its latest insider-trading scandal. **********The Dow Jones industrial average, the most closely watched measure of the stock market's movement, climbed 54.14 points, to 2,237.49, smashing the previous record of 2,201.49 set on Feb. 5. The point gain of 54.14, representing a 2.48 percent rise in the blue-chip average, was also a record, topping the 51.60-point rise on Jan. 22 and the 44.01-point gain on Jan. 5. **********''The widespread expectation of a market decline due to worries over the widening insider scandals is proving to be an also-ran,'' said Gene Seagle, director of technical research at Gruntal & Company. ''The market just won't buy it.'' **********Mr. Seagle said the market preferred, instead, to take its cue from the favorable outlook for some industries provided by the weaker dollar and the expectation of a further economic upturn this year. Buying by investors with excess cash and by foreigners who consider the market undervalued continued to drive the market, as has happened throughout the 1987 rally. On Friday, the Dow had ended 17.57 points higher after heavy selling pared its gain from more than 27 points in the last hour. After hovering between 20 and 30 points higher throughout most of yesterday morning, the bellwether index had climbed more than 36 points by 3 P.M. and surged further in the closing hour. **********Thus, with traders back from a day off from the Presidents' Day holiday, the market continued a rally in which it has advanced 17 percent since Jan. 2. The market was apparently undaunted by the arrests of three Wall Street professionals last week and the guilty plea of another on insider-trading charges. **********Yesterday, trading volume got an added push when word spread throughout Wall Street that Robert Prechter, editor of The Elliott Wave Theorist, a market newsletter, was predicting that the Dow would advance to the 2,300 level before any correction. **********Volume on the Big Board was brisk, with 187.8 million shares changing hands, up from 184.4 million on Friday. In the busy session, 1,141 issues advanced on the New York Stock Exchange, easily outnumbering the 514 issues that declined. **********''The market's momentum hesitated for only a few days, but today's breadth was too powerful for sellers,'' Mr. Seagle said. ''The market is feeding on itself as historically large cash reserves flow back into blue chips as well as secondaries.'' **********Market measures other than the Dow average also moved smartly ahead. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index advanced 5.79 points, to a record 285.49, while the New York Stock Exchange composite index jumped 2.92 points, to a record 162.48. **********Among blue-chip stocks, International Business Machines rose 3 7/8, to 138 3/8, in active trading and RJR Nabisco surged 3 1/4, to 63, after saying it was weighing plans to spin off its tobacco group. Polaroid, which posted higher earnings, climbed 2 1/2, to 81 1/2. Ford, with higher earnings than General Motors for the first time since 1924, gained 2 3/4, to 78 7/8. **********The Dow transportation average, climbed 26.04, to 948.40, buoyed by strong gains of several airlines.
