https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/10/world.main_headline: U.S. Expected To Initiate Plea For Contra Aid
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/10/world.print_headline: U.S. Expected To Initiate Plea For Contra Aid
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/10/world.body_text: **********The Administration is planning to open its campaign for renewed aid to the Nicaraguan rebels on Thursday with a request for $270 million for both military and nonmilitary purposes over the next 18 months, according to Government officials. **********Secretary of State George P. Shultz is expected to outline the proposal in testimony before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. Mr. Shultz, according to the officials, is to ask Congress to approve the aid immediately after Sept. 30, when the current annual authorization of $100 million expires. **********Such a request is certain to trigger a fierce battle in Congress over continued support for the rebels, known as contras, who are seeking to topple the Soviet-backed Nicaraguan Government. Administration's View of Plan **********Nicaragua and four other Central American countries - Costa Rica, El Salvador, Honduras and Guatemala -last month agreed on a peace plan that would require an end to hostilities throughout the region and an end to all outside military aid to insurgents. **********The plan, modeled after a proposal by President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica, also requires that commissions be established in each of the countries to reconcile political differences. The Costa Rican foreign minister, Rodrigo Madrigal Nieto, who is visiting Washington, asked Congress today not to vote on further aid until after Nov. 7. **********The Reagan Administration, which was taken by surprise when the five governments signed the agreement in Guatemala, has been wary of the proposal, contending that the Sandinista Government of Nicaragua could not be trusted to abide by such an agreement. **********Administration officials have said that in order for any peace accord to work, the contras would have to continue to receive financing in order to maintain pressure on the Sandinistas. **********Representative Jim Wright, the Speaker of the House, who is likely to take the lead in opposing any request for renewed aid, has urged the President to refrain from seeking new aid while the ''peace process is ongoing.'' There was no immediate reaction from Congress to the report of Mr. Shultz's proposal. **********Mr. Wright has invited the Costa Rican President to address a joint meeting of Congress later this month to press that point. Concern Over Funding Gap **********Under the Shultz proposal, new funds would be appropriated at the beginning of October so as to leave no gap in aid for the contras. According to officials, if the peace plan adopted last month appears to be succeeding, the money for the contras could be suspended on Nov. 7 or any time thereafter. **********The money could be used by the rebels for military purposes under the proposal. If at some time there was a cease-fire, officials said, the funds could be restricted to non-lethal uses. **********In that way, the officials said, the contras could be maintained as a political entity until they are integrated into Nicaragua's political system. Strategy Fails **********Underlying much of the maneuvering over the Central American peace plan has been the Administration's interest in renewing financial aid for the Nicaraguan rebels. **********Initially, the Administration had considered asking Congress for about $140 million for the next 18 months. As part of the Administration's strategy, President Reagan, along with Mr. Wright, offered a bipartisan peace plan, which was quickly overtaken when the regional leaders approved their own proposal. **********The Administration had expected Nicaragua to reject the Reagan-Wright proposal, thereby bolstering its case for additional aid. But the strategy went awry when the Central American leaders adopted their own plan. **********Immediately following their agreement, the Administration was uncertain whether it would request renewed contra aid. But after negotiations with Mr. Wright, President Reagan said he would not formally request aid until after Sept. 30. **********Several critics of the Administration, both in Congress and elsewhere, remain deeply skeptical whether the Administration is interested in a negotiated settlement or remains committed to a military solution in Nicaragua. Comparison of Plans **********The Central American leaders' plan affects disputes and issues in all the countries, but for the Administration and its opponents, the principal focus has been Nicaragua. **********In addition to the call for an end to outside aid for rebel groups, cease-fires and the establishment of national commissions to reconcile political differences, the peace plan requires amnesties and movement toward full democratic rights. **********It is generally seen as more favorable to the Sandinistas than the Reagan-Wright plan, which calls for an end to military aid to Nicaragua as well as an end to such aid to the rebels, and would seek an immediate suspension of emergency law in Nicaragua. The Reagan-Wright plan also envisions negotiations to restore full civil rights and elections in Nicaragua. Congress would be asked to resume aid to the rebels if there was no agreement on negotiations by Sept. 30. 'Political Space' **********Earlier today, Mr. Madrigal, the Costa Rican foreign minister, said that he hoped Congress would delay voting on renewed aid to the contras until after Nov. 7. . Mr. Madrigal said Central American leaders needed ''political space'' to implement their peace plan. **********He asserted that a Congressional vote on the issue of aid to the rebels before Nov. 7 would seriously hurt prospects for the Arias plan. **********Mr. Madrigal came to Washington at the suggestion of the State Department to meet with Secretary of State Shultz. In a 30-minute meeting today, the two officials discussed prospects for the Central American peace plan and Administration plans for renewed aid to the anti-Sandinista rebels.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/04/busin.body_text: **********ARE closed-end investment companies the newest takeover prey? That's what some experts are asking in the wake of an unsolicited acquisition offer for the Japan Fund, a closed-end fund that seeks capital gains by investing in Japanese securities. **********It is the unusual nature of closed-end funds -their shares typically sell at a discount to net asset value - that apparently prompted the offer from a group including Thomas B. Pickens 3d, the son of T. Boone Pickens, the Texas entrepreneur. **********The group said on Monday that it owned 1.4 million of the fund's 28 million common shares, and it proposes to pay 95 percent of net asset value, or a 5 percent discount, subject to obtaining satisfactory financing. Prospective buyers also include John S. Grace, president of Sterling Grace Capital Management Limited Partnership, and Oliver R. Grace Jr., general partner of the Anglo American Security Fund Limited Partnership.  * * * Closed-end funds have been reorganized or liquidated in the past, and the goal of outsiders essentially is to close the gap between net asset value -or the dollar value of a portfolio divided by the number of fund shares - and the actual market price. If a group is successful, it can reap a profit on its original investment bought in the open market at a discount. **********The Japan Fund ended last week at a 19.7 percent discount. But the gap narrowed Monday as the stock rose $1.625, closing at a 52-week high of $17.375. Yesterday, the price was unchanged and, based on the net asset value of $19.83, the discount was 12.4 percent. **********In Wall Street, the thinking is that the Grace-Pickens group, rather than a takeover, really wants to force the Japan Fund into becoming an open-end investment company, or mutual fund. And the betting, in the words of one professional investor in closed-end funds, is that in this particular case the outsiders ''have less than a 50-50 chance of success.'' **********Yesterday, the Japan Fund said that its directors would meet Friday and that the proposal would be an item on the agenda. The fund's investment adviser is the Asia Management Corporation, an affiliate of Scudder, Stevens & Clark, the investment counseling firm. **********Thomas J. Herzfeld of South Miami, Fla., who manages nearly $100 million for clients in assets of closed-end funds, believes that activity in closed-ends may be heating up on another front - the single-country funds that went public in 1986 to invest in securities of specific nations. **********''Outside investors have acquired stakes of more than 5 percent each in the Italy Fund, the France Fund and the Scandinavia Fund,'' Mr. Herzfeld said. ''Each of these funds is selling at a discount and reorganization has to be regarded as a serious possibility. There's a chance, too, that some raider might come along and pay minority holders a premium for their shares.'' **********But the giants of the closed-end industry, such as the Tri-Continental Corporation, generally are considered immune from any forced reorganization. Effective control for some funds may reside in the hands of insiders. **********There are critical differences between a closed-end investment company and a mutual fund. A closed-end company has a set number of shares that were issued in an initial offering, and its price - like that of any stock - is determined by supply and demand in the open market. Doubling in size over the last 10 years, the closed-end industry in the United States has grown to include more than 100 funds with assets worth over $16 billion. **********But this sum is dwarfed by the mutual fund industry. According to the Investment Company Institute, mutual funds saw total assets, including those of money market funds, swell to a record $766 billion last year. **********Mutual funds are known as open-end investment companies because they stand ready to sell new shares to people who pay the net asset value - plus any sales charge in the case of ''load'' funds. When investors sell their shares, the mutual fund redeems these at net asset value. In some cases, an ''exit'' fee may be tacked on. **********Closed-end funds sell at a discount for various reasons. ''Stockbrokers would rather peddle mutual funds and rake in a fat commission, than do a one-time, long-term trade in a closed-end,'' said a market professional. ''In addition, closed-ends lack true sponsorship in Wall Street and specialized funds, such as single-country funds or bank-stock funds, may wane in popularity because of an overabundance of their type of products or for other reasons.'' **********Some closed-end funds, including the National Aviation and Technology Corporation in 1979, have been converted, thanks to shareholder pressure, into mutual funds. And, just recently, shareholders of Baldwin Securities, which had traded at a substantial discount, approved a change-over to an operating company. But last month an investor group that had sought control of Bancroft Convertible Fund ended its tender offer after a rejection vote by shareowners.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/09/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Goodyear Begins Management Shifts
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/09/busin.body_text: **********The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company yesterday announced moves to consolidate its management, including the appointment of a corporate vice president for worldwide tire manufacturing. **********William J. Sharp, 45 years old, was named to the new post. He has been production director for Goodyear's European operations based in Brussels. **********The company, which recently fought off a takeover attempt by Sir James Goldsmith, has embarked on a restructuring program prompted by the takeover attempt. For example, Goodyear said yesterday that 644 salaried employees had accepted an early retirement option. **********Mr. Sharp, who was traveling and not available for comment, will be based in Akron, Ohio, Goodyear's headquarters. He will report to Stanley J. Mihelick, executive vice president for corporate manufacturing, who remains responsible for Goodyear's tire and other product output worldwide. **********Goodyear said Joseph C. Graden, 58, was retiring as corporate vice president and vice president of tire production for the Goodyear international subsidiary. Richard A. Davies, 50, who had been corporate vice president responsible for North American tire manufacturing, has been named vice president of manufacturing for a Goodyear subsidiary, Kelly-Springfield. He replaces John B. Row, 63, who is retiring. **********In addition, Goodyear said it had named James K. DeVoe, 49, as corporate vice president responsible for advertising worldwide. Mr. DeVoe succeeds George S. Lenox, 64, who is retiring, and Mr. DeVoe's former position as director of advertising will not be filled. **********The company said five other corporate management positions were being eliminated through early retirement and consolidation of functions. ''We expect to make more such consolidations in the months ahead,'' Tom H. Barrett, president and chief operating officer, said. **********Mr. Sharp joined Goodyear in 1964 and has had several global manufacturing assignements. Mr. DeVoe joined the company in 1983. He had been vice president of advertising and merchandising for RCA Consumer Electronics and earlier worked with various ad agencies in New York and Richmond.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/13/busin.print_headline: ADVERTISING; Advertising Comes To Prescription Books
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/13/busin.body_text: **********Five years ago, Robert L. Curry and William F. Martin started Medical Publishing Enterprises in Fort Lee, N.J., with a single magazine. Now there are 19 titles and the twosome are diversifying, but always within the health-care field and always related to advertising. **********They are, for example, creating television commercials. **********Then there is the joint venture called Scriptech Professional Prescribing Systems, which, according to Mr. Curry, the consummate salesman, benefits everyone in the health-care chain. And it takes ads. **********It looks like a checkbook folder, but the checks are really specially designed prescription blanks intended to cut down on forgery by drug abusers, improve physicians' hand writing by the simple expedient of putting lines on the paper, make a copy available for the physicians' files, and have the word ''VOID'' appear on copies made with copiers. **********Those are some of the benefits to the profession and to the public. The benefit to the operators of the joint venture is that the prescription book can accommodate seven ads from the sponsors, who deliver the book free to medical specialists. The cost to the advertiser goes from $30 to $130 per thousand prescription forms. **********Pfizer Inc. is a sponsor and so too is the Procter & Gamble Company's Norwich-Eaton division.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/21/busin.body_text: **********Merrill Lynch & Company yesterday reported the full extent of the mammoth bond trading losses it suffered last April, saying the gross loss totaled $377 million, $102 million more than previously disclosed. The brokerage firm announced, though, that, as a result of several large, one-time gains, it produced an overall profit in the second quarter. **********In addition, William A. Schreyer, Merrill's chairman and chief executive, said in an interview that the firm would consider the sale of part of its asset management business, in which Merrill manages, for a fee, stock and bond mutual funds and money market accounts for its customers. **********Several Wall Street firms are considering selling a partial interest in their asset management operations, one of the steadiest sources of earnings in the brokerage business. Recently, Oppenheimer & Company sold part of its asset management business. Paine Webber Takes Steps **********And the Paine Webber Group Inc., which reported a very profitable second quarter yesterday, has recently taken steps to establish its asset management business as a free-standing entity, which would make it easier to sell part of the business. **********At the end of the June quarter, Merrill Lynch had $85.6 billion under management, $46 billion of which was in money market accounts. Lawrence Eckenfelder, an analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities, said that Merrill's asset management business would be worth about $3 billion. **********Mr. Schreyer said there were no talks under way for such a sale. But he indicated that Merrill's executives were continuing to analyze the profitability of the firm's separate businesses and that they would be open to the spinning off of all or part of the profitable money management business if it benefited that operation and the firm's shareholders. Share Buyback Expected **********Mr. Eckenfelder argued that it would, and he speculated that the firm might use the proceeds of such a sale to buy back some of its shares. **********''Over all, a sale of that business would benefit shareholders because you'd realize the value there,'' said Perrin Long, an analyst with Lipper Analytical Services. Merrill Lynch's stock rose 62.5 cents yesterday, to $35.75, in active trading on the New York Stock Exchange. **********For the second quarter, Merrill said that its earnings fell 8.6 percent, to $83.3 million, from $91.1 million in the comparable 1986 quarter. Earnings per share slipped to 76 cents, from 86 cents, a better performance than most analysts had expected. **********Over all, Merrill would have had a loss of $41.2 million for the quarter if not for profits from the sale of a large interest in its real estate business and part of its leasing business. **********Merrill reported a $76.2 million profit after taxes from the sale of part of its leasing portfolio, and a profit of $48.3 million from the sale of part of its real estate brokerage business. About $63 million of the reported gain from the leasing business sale came from tax credits. **********Merrill said its revenues rose 4.7 percent, to $2.44 billion, from $2.33 billion. Before taxes, Merrill earned $18.9 million, down sharply from $159.6 million the year before. **********Merrill reported previously that the loss before taxes from mortgage-backed securities trading, the largest in Wall Street history, came to $275 million. Merrill executives said said the $102 million difference reflected $76 million taken from a reserve fund and $26 million taken from a fund used to pay bonuses to its brokers and investment bankers. Move Raises Questions **********Questions were raised, though, about Merrill's use of the reserve fund, which a number of accounting experts and senior executives of other brokerage firms described as highly unusual. Since brokerage firms revalue their securities trading portfolios every day, these experts said, they are generally not permitted by their accountants to hold reserves against unspecified losses they might suffer. But Merrill's executives said they considered the reserve justifiable and prudent. **********Merrill had a strong quarter in some regards. Its investment banking revenues jumped to $292.9 million, from $231 million. Much of the gain came from the huge fees Merrill charged in several major merchant banking transactions during the quarter, involving the buyouts of Borg-Warner, Supermarkets General and Viacom. **********Merrill's insurance revenues soared to $217.9 million, from $83 million, largely because of increased income from the sale of single-premium deferred annuities. Paine Webber **********Paine Webber yesterday reported second-quarter net income of $17.6 million, or 53 cents a share, up sharply from $7.1 million, or 20 cents a share, in the 1986 period. **********Revenues rose 5 percent, to $637.6 million, from $607.5 million. **********Despite the bond market turbulence last April, Paine Webber reported higher revenues from principal transactions of $102 million, up from $97 million a year earlier.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/31/busin.print_headline: A LONG AND WINDING ROAD; Band's Quest For Stardom
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/31/busin.body_text: **********By 7:45 P.M. Madison Square Garden was filling with young, excited rock-and-rollers. A good omen, thought Steve Mountain, manager of the opening act, the Hooters, as he looked at the 18,500 seats. **********The Hooters, a rock band that had already had one million-selling album, was trying to make even more of a name for itself as it stepped on stage at 8 P.M. While its ''Nervous Night'' album had been successful, a rousing welcome at the Garden this hot summer evening, where the singer-guitarist Bryan Adams was the headline act, would bode well for the second album just reaching the stores. **********It was not just Mr. Mountain and the five members of the Hooters who were delighted that the audience was arriving in time to see the opening act. Rock-and-roll is a big business and CBS Records, the Hooters' label, stands to make a good deal of money from the band's success. Recordings a Linchpin **********Indeed, the overall profitability of CBS Inc. is heavily dependent on its records group, the largest American record company. As with the marketing of any new product, the key to this risky business is the selection and promotion of promising performers. **********Every year CBS releases perhaps 150 albums created by its roster of 200 artists. Some are already superstars - Bruce Springsteen, Cyndi Lauper, Michael Jackson, Billy Joel - and sales of their records are a certainty. **********''The superstar is the giant bonanza,'' said Al Teller, the president of CBS Records. ''The big hit is to develop superstar careers. That is the biggest win you can have.'' **********Superstars generate enormous profits for their record companies because revenue climbs dramatically as more albums sell, while production and marketing costs remain relatively fixed. Fueled by its superstars the records group earned $192.1 million in 1986 on sales of $1.49 billion. That accounted for 45 percent of CBS Inc.'s operating profits. Enjoying a Turnaround **********After several years in the doldrums, the recording industry is doing very well. Profits at CBS and Warner Communications, the No. 2 American record company, are at an all-time high, benefiting from both the success of new groups and the sales of compact disks. Sales of disks are up as customers replace their record libraries, and the profit margins on disks are higher than on either records or tapes. **********Nevertheless, Mr. Teller believes this is a particularly difficult time for promoting a new group. ''Once you break a group, you have to sustain it,'' he said. ''But public loyalty is more fickle than it used to be. It is tough to achieve longevity today.'' **********A major problem is overexposure. ''In the 1970's, groups were leery of going on television because it might overexpose them,'' he said. ''Today, it is difficult to estimate the long-term effects of videos. With MTV, the public can get oversaturated with a group sooner.'' **********Finding and nurturing hit groups is a harrowing business, and the casualty rate is high. Although CBS does not release figures, industry analysts estimate that it releases as many as 40 albums a year by newcomers, a third of whom are never heard from again. The benchmark indicator of a group's potential is whether it can sell 100,000 copies of an album. Advertising No Guarantee **********And while record companies are sophisticated in promotion and advertising, public taste is unpredictable. ''You can't advertise your way to success,'' Mr. Teller said. **********The jury is still out on the Hooters, which, despite its platinum album -the recognition accorded for selling one million copies - has not reached superstar status. ''You cannot be considered a superstar,'' Mr. Teller said, until you consistently sell out a 20,000-seat arena. The Hooters is not yet in that category. **********The band's second album, ''One Way Home,'' has been out for a few weeks, and early sales are encouraging but not exhilirating, with a total of 450,000 albums shipped to stores. The first single from the album, ''Johnny B,'' is getting a modest reception from radio stations. At those stations using the contemporary-hits format - the stations with the target audience of a group such as the Hooters - Mr. Teller said the airplay was good but ''not great.'' **********Irving Azoff, the chairman of MCA Records, noted that an act's second album was often not as successful as the first. ''A group can spend years writing and producing its first album, and six months on the second, because they are rushed to get it out,'' he said. ''That can hurt.'' Setting a Goal **********For the Hooters to succeed in its drive for superstardom, the new album must sell at least one and a half million copies. **********Concert tours can be a critical factor in producing such sales. Across the popular-music industry, the biggest stars on tour this summer are doing well. But the second-tier acts have been suffering. **********When CBS signed the Hooters, it put up a ''recording fund'' of about $200,000 for the first album. The group spent slightly more and paid the difference. **********According to Mr. Teller, deals are structured in that fashion to encourage groups to control production costs. Mr. Mountain, the Hooters' manager, said he thought CBS had also spent about $300,000 promoting and advertising the album. Video Costs Shared **********Record promotion these days also includes the cost of music videos, which run from $75,000 to more than $100,000. The record company and the performers generally share that expense. **********When a new group goes on tour, even as an opening act, CBS sometimes underwrites the costs - in order to promote record sales - if the group's expenses are not covered by their appearance fees. Mr. Mountain said the Hooters had not accepted CBS support for the tour because he thought he would have more leverage in future negotiations if it did not. **********The finances of a rock band can be complex. Although the Hooters' first album for CBS contained four songs that became hit singles, the Hooters' members did not become overnight millionaires. Indeed, given the four hit singles, Mr. Mountain said the one million copies sold was a bit disappointing. **********From that album, concert performances and royalties, the members of the group will take in more than $1 million. 'We Came Out Clean' **********Terms of the agreements between performers and companies vary widely. Mr. Mountain said CBS paid the Hooters a royalty fee based on 85 percent of the wholesale price, which is generally about $5. ''You don't get rich selling a million albums,'' he said. ''We recouped enough to pay off the recording fund and our share of the music videos and to make a profit. We came out clean. There are bands out there with very heavy debt.'' **********After recouping costs, CBS Records made $2 million to $3 million on the album, an executive at another record company estimated. **********For the Hooters, the path to success has been tortuous. Its five members are in their 30's. Only two, the keyboard player Rob Hyman and the lead guitarist Eric Bazilian - who write the songs - have been with the group since it was formed nearly a decade ago as Baby Grand. **********Arista Records, a unit of CBS, signed the group in 1978. Two albums were released. Both flopped, and the band was discouraged. ''By 1980, we had done two unsuccessful albums,'' Mr. Hyman said. ''We racked up a hell of a debt. We played lots of little clubs.'' Four years later, Arista canceled the contract. Sounds of Jamaica **********By 1982, the group had reorganized, still a five-piece band but with three new members. It emphasized reggae, Jamaica's popular music, and ska, an up-tempo Engish derivative of reggae. The band built a loyal following in Philadelphia, the home of several members, but still attracted no interest from record companies. **********A year later, friction broke up the band again and two replacements came aboard. At that point the group took the name the Hooters; the musicians say it is a reference to the melodia, one of the instruments they use. **********The band then hired Mr. Mountain. Managers generally get 20 percent of a group's revenues, for which they negotiate contracts with the record companies and booking agencies. They also handle personnel matters such as hiring and firing road crews for tours. **********The Hooters' visibility within the industry increased when Mr. Bazilian and Mr. Hyman were co-authors with Cyndi Lauper of her enormous hit recording, ''Time After Time.'' The collaboration came about because Mr. Bazilian and Mr. Hyman had attended college with Rick Chartoff, a CBS producer working with Ms. Lauper. **********The Hooters then took the somewhat unusual step of recording an album on its own. **********''We knew we needed a Hooters record,'' Mr. Mountain recalled. ''It cost us about $25,000 to make. The group did it in two weeks.'' The album sold more than 100,000 copies, primarily in the Philadelphia area. 'We Had Enough Buzz' **********Those sales were a clear indication that the group had appeal, according to both Mr. Teller and Mr. Mountain. **********''We made about $150,000 from the record,'' Mr. Mountain said. More important, he said, ''by then'' - it was September 1984 - ''we had enough buzz that record companies were finally interested.'' **********At CBS Mr. Chartoff was paying attention. Signing groups is a highly competitive business. Often, newcomers attract their first notice in small clubs. Once in a while, a group actually comes off the street. Spookie, one of the most recent acts to sign with CBS, used to perform on the sidewalk at Century Park West in Los Angeles in order to attract attention. **********A deal was negotiated with CBS, the first album was recorded, and discussions began on what song to release as the first single. ''We wanted people to sit up and take notice,'' Mr. Teller said. ''We knew it would not be a super hit, but we thought it would legitimize Hooters.'' **********Mr. Teller said radio programmers were quickly enthusiastic. Their response is the first hurdle for any new record. ''Generally once the programmers like it, they play it,'' Mr. Teller said. ''Then it is up to the audience.'' **********At that recent concert at Madison Square Garden, the audience liked what it heard, if the cheering and singing along were any indication. The Hooters ''will be a big group,'' said one fan, Anna Maria Santullo, after the performance. ''They're not flashy. But sooner or later, they will get there. They got what it takes.'' **********By another measure, the band still has a long way to go: Not until Bryan Adams strutted into the spotlight did female fans in the front rows start flinging their bras onto the stage.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/08/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Imperial Oil in Deal
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/08/busin.body_text: **********Imperial Oil Ltd., the Canadian oil company that is 70 percent owned by the Exxon Corporation, agreed to pay $680 million (Canadian), or $523 million (United States), for the assets of Sulpetro Ltd., a natural gas company in receivership since June. The Calgary, Alberta-based natural gas concern was hard hit by the slump in oil prices that followed its 1981 purchase of the Candel Oil and Gas Company.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/11/busin.main_headline: UNITED AIRLINES ATTACKS PILOT UNION LEADERSHIP
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/11/busin.print_headline: UNITED AIRLINES ATTACKS PILOT UNION LEADERSHIP
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/11/busin.body_text: **********United Airlines yesterday attacked the leadership of the 7,000-member pilots union for what it called a ''hate management campaign'' and called on pilots to ''set emotion aside and think about your career.'' **********It assailed the ''sincerity'' of the head of the union, F. C. Dubinsky, for his part in directing an acrimonious strike in 1985 and referred to a $4.5 billion takeover bid for the airline last week as ''the Dubinsky plan.'' **********In a telegram to all pilots, Lloyd W. Barry, senior vice president for flight operations, said he wondered whether the ''hate campaign'' since the strike ''wasn't just a smokescreen to cover up a much bigger scheme.'' He said he wondered how ''Dubinsky's $4.5 billion idea would have been received if there had been harmony the last two years.'' **********Since the union's takeover bid, at least three major Wall Street investors are believed to have bought significant interests in the airline's owner, UAL Inc. **********Donald J. Trump, the Manhattan developer, is understood to have almost 5 percent. The Pritzker family of Chicago, which controls Braniff airlines and a hotel chain, have a small amount. And Coniston Partners, a group known for its aggressive investment strategies, is believed to be building a big UAL position. Coniston has a reputation for forcing some kind of change that would enhance stock values. Mr. Trump is understood to want UAL's hotel chain, including the Plaza in Manhattan. The Pritzkers' interest is also thought to be the hotels. **********Jamie Lindsay, vice chairman of the union, said the company was ''attacking Captain Dubinsky's motivation and personality and trying to pit employee against employee.'' **********Asking not to be identified, a business executive familiar with the union remarked, ''Attacking Dubinsky for the '85 strike is like attacking Churchill for World War II.'' He said he thought union members would ''rally 'round the leadership.'' **********The takeover plan is understood to have originated with F. Lee Bailey, the lawyer, who has since advanced the pilots $1.5 million to finance the project. Mr. Bailey has been retained as special adviser to the union. **********The union leadership has asked the members to contribute 5 percent of their salary, or about $5,000 each, to cover initial expenses. **********''I wonder how much the Dubinsky plan will really cost,'' the telegram asked. ''Is the 5 percent the only installment or just the first? These deals are really expensive.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/14/world.main_headline: KEY CONTRA DEMANDS REDUCTION OF RIGHTIST'S ROLE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/14/world.print_headline: KEY CONTRA DEMANDS REDUCTION OF RIGHTIST'S ROLE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/14/world.body_text: **********Alfonso Robelo, a key moderate leader of the Nicaraguan rebel coalition, said today that he could no longer share power with Adolfo Calero, the leader of the rebel coalition's largest group. **********''I don't think I can work with Adolfo Calero anymore, because we have tried this several times,'' Mr. Robelo said in a telephone interview from Costa Rica. **********He said he expressed this position to President Reagan's national security adviser, Frank C. Carlucci, in a recent meeting in Washington. **********Mr. Robelo said he had told Mr. Carlucci that the contra movement must be restructured under a command clearly under moderate leaders. But he denied reports that he had demanded the outright resignation of Mr. Calero from the movement. 'This Is Not Bitter Infighting' **********''I do recognize the right of the conservatives to be there, but it has to be with a clear command by the moderates,'' he said. ''With Mr. Calero, I think it is clearly proven that we don't get the cohesiveness to conduct this struggle. This is not bitter infighting. This is a pragmatic attitude.'' Mr. Calero, whose Nicaraguan Democratic Force has links to the security forces of the regime of the late Anastasio Somoza Debayle, has been reluctant to implement the reforms sought by the other leaders of the United Nicaraguan Opposition, the umbrella group supported by the United States. **********But sources close to Mr. Robelo said today that he had demanded the resignation of Mr. Calero and several members of his entourage. **********Efforts to contact Mr. Calero by telephone today were unsuccessful. A spokesman for UNO in Miami said today that Mr. Calero will hold a news conference in Miami on Monday to address Mr. Robelo's charges. Larger Political Crisis **********Mr. Robelo's remarks reflect a larger political crisis among the contras that threatens their American-sponsored alliance, the United Nicaraguan Opposition. **********Arturo Jose Cruz, also a civilian and the third member of the UNO triumvirate, has announced his intention to resign, citing ''hegemonic tendencies'' and a lack of reform within the movement. Several important contra field commanders have also complained bitterly to Mr. Cruz about Mr. Calero's leadership, according to sources close to Mr. Cruz. **********Contra leaders have been holding a flurry of meetings in Washington and Miami over the last few weeks in an effort to keep their movement together. **********''There's almost a revolution inside the counterrevolution,'' said Robert Leiken, a senior associate with the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace who closely monitors the contras. ''It's the climax of a struggle that has gone on for some time.'' **********Mr. Leiken added that an internal campaign intended to broaden the base of the contras had ended. ''Nicaraguans tell me that because their reform movement was blocked, there must be a radical restructuring,'' he said. Undercutting the Coalition **********Mr. Robelo accused Mr. Calero of violating a May 1986 agreement with other rebel leaders to give UNO control over the diffuse contra movement. **********UNO was created in June 1985 at the urging of the United States as an umbrella organization of opposition groups in order to make the contra movement more broad-based and democratic. **********Instead, Mr. Robelo asserted, Mr. Calero strengthened his own wing, the Nicaraguan Democratic Force, known as F.D.N. **********In the Nicaraguan Democratic Force, ''the control has been in the hands of conservatives that did not identify with the Nicaraguan revolution,'' Mr. Robelo said. ''Mr. Calero has never understood the need to make UNO the vehicle, but has always had a different project, the F.D.N. project.'' **********He denied press reports that he had also demanded the resignation of Nicaraguan Democratic Force's military commander, Enrique Bermudez, stressing that he was not criticizing the military leadership of the Calero group. Congressional Support at Stake **********Mr. Robelo charged that if Mr. Calero and his group were to become pre-eminent in the contra movement, ''I don't think they could ever get the support of Congress or the acceptance that would give us the needed legitimacy from the Western democracies.'' **********The participation of Mr. Cruz and Mr. Robelo in the contra movement is regarded as a crucial element for Congressional approval of $105 million that the Reagan Administration hopes to send to the contras next fall. **********Mr. Robelo said that when he made his views known to Mr. Carlucci and Elliott Abrams, the Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, during a meeting on Jan. 30, he said they remained noncommittal about Mr. Calero's position. ''They have been very respectful,'' he said. ''They have been listening and analyzing the situation, but they have taken no position one way or the other,'' he said. **********He refused to predict what action he might take if Mr. Calero does not leave his leadership post. **********State Department officials declined to comment on Mr. Robelo's characterization of the Jan. 30 meeting. But Administration officials have acknowledged that the contra movement needs serious reform, including minimizing the influence of the Calero group.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/24/busin.main_headline: Your Money; Self-Employed And Tax Law
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/24/busin.print_headline: Your Money; Self-Employed And Tax Law
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/24/busin.body_text: **********THOUSANDS of self-employed engineers, computer programmers and other technical service personnel breathed a sigh of relief this week, following the release of Internal Revenue Service guidelines clarifying their tax and employment status. **********The Government announcement was made because a paragraph in the Tax Reform Act of 1986 led many of these people to believe that they automatically would lose their right to be independent contractors on Jan. 1, 1987. If that were to happen, such technical workers would also lose a number of valuable tax benefits. **********But the I.R.S. says the decisions about whether the individuals are self-employed or employees will be based in each case on ''generally applicable common law standards.'' In addition, the agency says, provisions in the tax law dealing with this matter relate only to ''three-party situations'' involving an individual, a broker-type firm and a client company. **********''People were confused because the law and the conference committee report did not make the impact clear,'' said Joel S. Isaacson, manager of personal financial planning at Weber Lipshie & Company, a certified public accounting firm. ''The I.R.S. notice makes it clear that you are either an independent contractor or an employee, depending on your relationship with the company.'' **********The self-employed have long enjoyed certain tax advantages not available to payroll workers. Among them: Federal income and Social Security taxes are not withheld each pay period, special retirement programs such as Keogh plans can be established and deductions for travel, entertainment and other business expenses are easier to get. **********Of course, there are also some disadvantages, including the absence of health and pension benefits paid by or obtained through an employer benefit plan. But many, if not most, of those who have an opportunity to be taxed as independent contractors choose that route. **********Under the 1978 tax act, the prerogative of being taxed according to the self-employed provisions of the Tax Code was granted to many more men and women. So-called safe-harbor provisions in that law let them claim to be independent contractors for tax purposes if the kind of services they performed had been performed by independent contractors in the past. **********But last year's tax package was largely perceived as tightening the rules governing independent contractors, especially the technical service workers mentioned by category in Section 1706. Those specifically cited are engineers, designers, drafters, computer programmers, systems analysts and other such skilled workers engaged in a similar line of work. **********''The I.R.S. is now saying that things are not going to be mechanical,'' said David S. Rhine, partner of the certified public accounting firm of Seidman & Seidman/BDO, in discussing the revenue service's Notice 87-19 of Jan. 21. ''They will still look to the facts and circumstances of the individual case.'' **********Accountants indicate that a major factor will be the common-law standards relating to who is to be considered an employee. If the company obtaining the services substantially controls the work performed, if the individual runs no risk of losing money on a project or if the person performing the services works on the premises of the company, it may be unlikely that this person can recieve the tax benefits of an independent contractor. **********Also explained in the new I.R.S. notice is its interpretation of the Tax Reform Act that the paragraph covering technical service personnel deals only with three-party relationships. Such relationships involve a broker who provides assignments to individuals from clients, as opposed to a two-party relationship between an independent contractor who works directly with a corporation. **********''A person in this kind of a three-party relationship might want to use this opportunity to clarify his status,'' Mr. Rhine added. ''By fitting into this job category, it doesn't mean that you're necessarily safe as an independent contractor.'' **********Mr. Isaacson gave an example of a three-party situation in which a computer consultant works for a computer consultant broker, which then sells the consultant's services to a bank. The determination as to how the consultant will be treated for tax purposes - an independent contractor whose compensation is recorded on Form 1099 or an employee whose wages are listed on Form W-2 - will be based on considerations such as the percentage of the consultant's overall work that is done for the broker, he said. And when a person is deemed to be an employee, he cannot avoid that status by calling himself a sole proprietor, partner or other other such title. **********Experts advise individuals who fall into the I.R.S.'s classification of technical service personnel to be particularly careful in declaring their tax status as the new law takes effect this year. Questions should be discussed with the appropriate companies or brokers - or with the I.R.S. - in order to avoid potential problems later.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/22/busin.main_headline: Bethlehem Says Chapter 11 Is Possible in Future
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/22/busin.print_headline: Bethlehem Says Chapter 11 Is Possible in Future
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/22/busin.body_text: **********The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, in an unusually pessimistic public assessment, said yesterday that external conditions could compel it to file for bankruptcy in the future. However, the nation's third-largest steelmaker asserted later that it had no imminent plans to seek protection under the bankruptcy laws. **********Bethlehem's statement came in a preliminary prospectus for an offering of 12 million new common shares, which would increase the total outstanding to 64 million. The company said it expected the Securities and Exchange Commission to approve the offering in four to six weeks, with the proceeds to be used for retiring long-term debt. **********Whenever a company makes such a filing, Federal rules require it to discuss its financial outlook. **********Without detailing its concerns, Bethlehem said: ''Future events may result in such adverse changes in Bethlehem's business circumstances or such a decrease in Bethlehem's liquidity as to make it prudent for Bethlehem to file a petition for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code.'' **********Bethlehem has incurred losses totaling more than $2 billion in the last five years. The company has attributed the losses to a combination of rising steel imports, worldwide steelmaking overcapacity, high labor costs and inefficient operations. **********Its recent results have been better. In July the company reported second-quarter earnings of $46.8 million, its highest quarterly profit in six years, on revenues of $1.12 billion. **********Nevertheless, Bethlehem has been a subject of frequent bankruptcy rumors. Those rumors were fueled by last year's Chapter 11 filing of the LTV Corporation, which operates the nation's No. 2 steel producer. **********Bethlehem's chairman, Walter F. Williams, has consistently denied that his company ever seriously considered such a step. He has previously acknowledged, however, that Bethlehem looked into the possibility of a bankruptcy filing earlier this year. **********Mr. Williams could not be reached for comment yesterday. A company spokesman, Henry H. Von Spreckelsen, said, ''We have never ruled out a bankruptcy filing, but we have no intention to file for Chapter 11 at this time.'' **********Bethlehem's latest assessment did not appear to alarm investors. The company's shares slipped 50 cents, to $16.625, on a day when the stock market as a whole was sharply lower. **********Officials of the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, the Federal pension insurance agency, said Bethlehem had made its pension payments last week. Some people in the steel industry had expected the company to file for an extension as a move to delay its pension payments. **********Bethlehem, like other major steelmakers, has benefited from increased demand and higher steel prices in the last few months. And steel producers have reduced their production capacity, tightening the availability of certain products. **********Nonetheless, Bethlehem said it had had trouble raising cash through debt offerings. The company said it would negotiate new bank agreements to replace two current revolving credit pacts, under which borrowings totaled the $300 million maximum. **********Low bond ratings have impaired Bethlehem's ability to issue bonds.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/19/busin.main_headline: U.S. Crude Oil Up a Bit, Nearing $20 a Barrel
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/19/busin.print_headline: FUTURES/OPTIONS; U.S. Crude Oil Up a Bit, Nearing $20 a Barrel
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/19/busin.body_text: **********The price of the most important American crude oil posted a slight gain in thin and hesitant trading yesterday to inch closer to the $20-a-barrel level. It last passed that mark a year ago, when prices were crashing. **********The near-month futures contract for West Texas Intermediate closed at $19.89 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange, a gain of 9 cents. The American blend gained 5 cents on the London-based spot market, to $19.85 a barrel. **********Although crude oil prices have been on a surprisingly long upswing, commodities analysts said they expected the prices to meet considerable resistance at this level. OPEC Causes Uncertainty **********James R. Steel, a commodities analyst at Refco Inc., said that one reason for that belief was that traders were uncertain about the actions of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries when it meets in general session on June 25. Some believe the group will decide to raise the official price for its oil; others believe it will raise production quotas. **********Mr. Steel said that the $20-a-barrel level was also likely to be a strong resistance point because ''we'd be breaking out of the teens for the first time in a long time.'' He added, ''The market may press above $20, but it may only be momentary.'' **********The Iraqi missile attack on the United States frigate Stark in the Persian Gulf on Sunday pushed the market higher at the opening yesterday. But that momentum evaporated when the incident, said to be a mistake, did not lead to a rise in tensions in the area. **********Although the market closed higher on the day, it fell back slightly from levels reached in early afternoon trading. **********The near-month futures contracts for heating oil and unleaded gasoline posted a mixed performance on the futures exchange, although both essentially were flat. Heating oil shifted slightly upward to close at 52 cents a gallon, while unleaded gasoline fell a fraction, to 55 cents a gallon. **********Madison Galbraith, a commodities analyst with Merrill Lynch Futures Inc., pointed out that the strength of crude oil prices in the last two months has been greater than justified by market fundamentals. **********''It indicates that somebody really wants the crude oil,'' Mr. Galbraith said, ''or that the owners of the crude oil are resisting selling at lower prices because they feel the overall price will be as good, if not better, later.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/13/world.main_headline: Gunmen Kill Peter Tosh, Reggae Star, in Jamaica
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/13/world.print_headline: Gunmen Kill Peter Tosh, Reggae Star, in Jamaica
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/13/world.body_text: **********Peter Tosh, a founding member of the Wailers, a reggae group that helped to popularize the vibrant Jamaican music style internationally, was killed at his home Friday night by gunmen, the police said. Mr. Tosh was 42 years old. **********The police said Mr. Tosh and Wilton (Doc) Brown, a maker of health food, died from their wounds en route to a hospital. Five others, including Mr. Tosh's companion, Andrea Marlene Brown, were wounded. **********Radio Jamaica said the attack appeared to have been a robbery attempt. **********Three armed men arrived on motorcycles at Mr. Tosh's home in St. Andrew, a suburb of Kingston, entered the house at about 8:30 P.M. Friday, and shot the seven people present after they refused to give up their money, the radio station said. **********A police detective said that Mr. Tosh had just returned from the United States and that the robbers apparently thought he had a large amount of cash with him. The detective added that the assailants had been tentatively identified, but that no arrests had been made. **********Prime Minister Edward P. G. Seaga extended his condolences to Mr. Tosh's family and friends, and former Prime Minister Michael N. Manley extolled the singer as a man who ''gave to Jamaica and the world an unforgettable library of musical works which will be played and sung by many generations of people.'' **********Mr. Tosh founded the Wailers in 1963 with Bob Marley, who died of a brain tumor in 1981. The Wailers' third star was Neville (Bunny) Livingstone. He left the group with Mr. Tosh in 1973 after Mr. Marley increasingly took over the starring role. **********More than 100 people gathered today at University Hospital, where the wounded were taken. **********The four others who were wounded were identified as Carlton (Santa) Davis, a drummer in Mr. Tosh's band; Jeff Dixon, a disk jockey for the state-run Jamaica Broadcasting Corp.; Mr. Dixon's wife, Yvonne, and Michael Robinson, another musician. **********Mr. Dixon, who had been shot in the head, was in critical condition, Radio Jamaica said, adding that the others were believed to be in stable condition. **********Mr. Tosh was born Winston Hubert McIntosh on Oct. 9, 1944, in Westmoreland, Jamaica. **********A baritone, he was perhaps best known internationally for collaborating with Mick Jagger of the Rolling Stones in the Smokey Robinson song ''(You Got to Walk and) Don't Look Back.'' **********In the lyrics of his songs, he often condemned injustice and poverty and praised the Rastafarians, a Jamaica-based religious sect. **********Like other Rastafarians, Mr. Tosh advocated smoking marijuana. He recorded the album and single ''Legalize It'' in 1976 and often smoked huge marijuana cigarettes, called spliffs, on stage. **********In 1978, before a crowd of 30,000 in Kingston, which included Prime Minister Manley, Mr. Tosh smoked a spliff and berated Mr. Manley for 30 minutes for refusing to legalize ganja, as marijuana is known here. Ban on Anti-Police Song **********Mr. Tosh had several run-ins with the police and was jailed for possessing marijuana in the mid-1960's. In early 1975, he wrote the anti-police song ''Mark of the Beast,'' which was banned from Jamaican radio. **********In the time Mr. Tosh was with the Wailers, the group had a string of hits including ''Stir It Up,'' ''I Shot the Sheriff'' and ''Get Up, Stand Up.'' **********Many of the Wailers' songs were highly political, and the group was extremely popular in Jamaica. The Wailers' 1973 album ''Catch a Fire,'' won reggae, with its characteristic loping beat, an international audience. **********Mr. Tosh's first album in four years, ''No Nuclear War,'' was issued recently. His other albums included ''Equal Rights,'' 1977; ''Bush Doctor,'' 1978; ''Mystic Man,'' 1979; ''Wanted Dread and Alive,'' 1981, and ''Mama Africa,'' 1983. **********He was nominated for a Grammy award in 1985 for best reggae recording for ''Captured Live.'' **********The New Rolling Stone Record Guide described Mr. Tosh's solo albums as ''excellent, pure reggae, truer to the spirit and form of the music than Marley's more celebrated work.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/20/busin.body_text: **********Two more executives have left Merrill Lynch & Company in the wake of the staggering trading losses announced last month. The executives supervised Howard A. Rubin, who was recently ousted after his unauthorized trading contributed to a $275 million loss. **********Both Robert P. Andres, president of Merrill Lynch Mortgage Capital Inc., and D. Gregory Herschell, manager of mortgage-backed securities trading, resigned yesterday under pressure. A third man who had been relieved of his trading duties, Bowers Espy, executive vice president of the mortgage-security unit, did not resign, and company officials said they did not expect more resignations. **********Separately, Merrill confirmed reports that Eugene H. Rotberg, vice president and treasurer of the World Bank for the last 19 years, would be joining the firm. Mr. Rotberg, 57 years old, will become one of six executive vice presidents in mid-June, and will supervise worldwide sales and trading operations. Specifically, he said, he will work on improving the firm's ability to monitor, manage and control its risk-taking positions. **********Although Mr. Rotberg's responsibilities will encompass trading, he and a Merrill spokesman both said their initial talks took place before the firm became aware of the losses.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/01/world.main_headline: WITH GORBACHEV, A COMIC NEEDS NEW JOKES
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/01/world.print_headline: WITH GORBACHEV, A COMIC NEEDS NEW JOKES
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/01/world.body_text: **********To tell the truth, which is what Arkady Raikin has done for a living these last 48 years or so, social satire under Mikhail S. Gorbachev is not so easy as it used to be. **********''We can say anything we want,'' said Mr. Raikin, whose understated ridicule of Soviet idiosyncracies has made him perhaps the country's most beloved comic. ''But nobody is very interested. The newspapers are already saying it.'' **********Take the famous opening monologue of Mr. Raikin's comic review, always a winner with a pre-Gorbachev audience. The comedian, alone in a spotlight, wonders aloud if it would not be better to keep silent. **********''I could just keep my mouth shut for three hours, including the intermission,'' he suggests, in a wistful deadpan. ''We're all so good at keeping silent. Just the other day I met a friend - the things he was keeping silent about, well, I just can't tell you.'' **********These days, when a substantial portion of the Soviet population would probably welcome a bit of silence about domestic problems, the routine draws only a polite ripple of laughter. **********''Before, it was enough to just mention a problem,'' said Mr. Raikin's son and collaborator, Konstantin. ''Just to name a problem was an act of civic courage.'' **********So, at 75 years old, Mr. Raikin is after something new. A team of writers is working up fresh material for the audiences who invariably buy up every ticket in the 1,000-seat Moscow theater the state has given over exclusively to Arkady Raikin and his troupe. **********And if the doctors can be persuaded about the state of his heart, in September Mr. Raikin will make his first tour of the United States, doing 10 shows in seven cities, including New York, where he will be at Town Hall. 'Do You Know the One?' **********The doctors recently told Mr. Raikin, who is frail and trembles slightly from Parkinson's syndrome, that they did not recommend the trip, but he departed for a holiday in a sanitorium outside Moscow and hopes to be in shape by early September to fulfill his American contract. **********''You know the one about the two doctors?'' Mr. Raikin asks, by way of commentary on the medical bureaucrats who will decide if he goes abroad. Perched on a couch amid the books, art works and theatrical memorabilia that fill his eclectic apartment in central Moscow, he mimes the specialist hovering over the patient: ''Well, doctor, shall we treat him, or let him live?'' **********Mr. Raikin is generally regarded as a national treasure. His thick white pompadour is instantly recognized on the street by generations of fans. War veterans buttonhole him to recall that he entertained them at the front in 1943. Children's faces light up. Soviet television recently compiled a two-hour retrospective on him. **********Soviet leaders not otherwise known for thick skins have embraced Mr. Raikin, who has the wise fool's gift for jesting to the point of provocation, but not beyond. He knew Khrushchev well, and was a close friend of Brezhnev, under whose rule Mr. Raikin was made a Hero of Socialist Labor, the highest civilian honor. 'Stalin Liked Papa' **********''Stalin liked papa very much as an artist, even invited him to his birthday party,'' said Mr. Raikin's daughter, Ekatarina Raikin, an actress. She added, to her father's discomfort, ''Maybe that's why papa survived.'' Mr. Raikin was doubly unprotected: a Jew in a perilous profession. **********When he was younger, his routines featured Chaplinesque physical humor. His current show of skits and monologues, which has run for several years, features a satire of indirection and cocked eyebrow, more in the style of Jack Benny, with sentimental homilies and moral uplift. **********He twits the thoughtless overfulfilling of state economic plans in a skit about a Stradivarius factory that churns out dozens of bows a year -and two violins. **********In another routine, a psychologist shows up at the comedian's door to conduct a survey, and the interviewee is paralyzed by the fear that he might be found to have had an unconventional thought. To every question, from his political outlook to the number of sugar lumps in his tea to his relations with his wife, he warily replies, ''Just like all my friends.'' Now Daily Fare **********Another skit suggests that Soviet factories are run so incompetently the managers must be in the employ of foreign saboteurs. **********Mr. Raikin is well aware that his skewering of the mismanagement, alcoholism, conformity and general rudeness of Soviet society, humor that once upset the censors, is now daily fare in the official press. **********''Now you open Pravda and find a satirical article in every issue,'' he said. ''But when I did it in my time, they would say, 'Let's delete this phrase.' '' **********To keep up with the changes, he has ordered new material aimed at getting ''to the source'' of social dysfunction. He will not divulge details of the new material being composed by three leading comic authors, except to say, ''We want to continue being trailblazers, to be the vanguard.'' Hopes for Success **********This is unlikely to mean humor at Mr. Gorbachev's expense, however. Not because Mr. Raikin is leery of offending his leader but because, like many, he holds fervent hope that Mr. Gorbachev will succeed. **********For the American tour, on which his daughter and son will accompany him, Mr. Raikin expects the audiences to be primarily emigres. The shows will be mainly in Russian, although he can be expected to include several routines in English. **********A talented mimic, he has delivered entire shows in German, Bulgarian, Polish, Hungarian and - for BBC in the 1950's - in English, although he speaks none of those languages. **********His cousin, Steven Raikin, an American lawyer visiting Moscow this month, said he had dropped into the BBC archives to view tapes of Mr. Raikin's work in English. A Gentle Caricature **********''It's amazing,'' he said. ''You can tell that English is not his native language, but you would never guess he doesn't speak it at all.'' **********The senior Raikin obliged an interviewer by reciting one of his BBC bits, a gentle caricature of an emigre parent telling a child what it was like in the old country: ''Seasons? You call these seasons? There, we had seasons!'' **********Mr. Raikin said he had been approached many times about an American tour, but had never been granted official approval. He said the American impresario Sol Hurok visited him backstage in Leningrad, where the Raikin theater was based for 45 years before moving to Moscow, but when Mr. Hurok issued an invitation, the authorities told the impresario that Mr. Raikin's health was bad. **********''But at the time you knew nothing about it,'' prompted the comedian's grandson Aleksandr. ''You did not know they told him that.'' **********''No, then my bad health was an official secret, even from me,'' Mr. Raikin agreed with a wry smile. ''At least now I've been let in on it.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/08/busin.main_headline: M.A. Hanna Plans Charge in Quarter
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/08/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; M.A. Hanna Plans Charge in Quarter
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/08/busin.body_text: **********The M. A. Hanna Company, a leading producer of iron ore, based in Cleveland, said it would take a charge of more than $100 million against fourth-quarter earnings, causing a loss for the period. **********Hanna gave these details of the charges: $59.2 million for closing its ferronickel operation near Riddle, Ore., and writing off other nickel investments; $29.7 million for writing down Eastern coal investments because of depressed market conditions; $8.4 million for idled oil and gas well drilling equipment, and $10.7 million for writing down its Western Minerals Properties and a mining equipment subsidiary. Hanna has interests in iron ore, oil and gas, nickel, silicon, coal and management services.

ISRAEL LICHTMAN   Somers, N.Y., Jan. 20
