https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/23/world.main_headline: FILE ON SEIZED NAZI RECOUNTS HORRORS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/23/world.print_headline: FILE ON SEIZED NAZI RECOUNTS HORRORS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/23/world.body_text: **********An elderly Austrian arrested this month on a remote ranch in Argentina has emerged as one of the most brutal commandants of the Nazi labor camps, according to Austrian police files now made public. **********The suspect, Josef Schwammberger, 75 years old, faces extradition to West Germany. He is accused of shooting and torturing hundreds of Jews and of stealing their valuables. **********In questioning in 1945 before he escaped detention, Mr. Schwammberger admitted that he had shot about 35 Jews, according to the Austrian police files. The files were obtained by the Anti-Defamation League and made available to The New York Times. Jewels and Gold From Inmates **********The files show he also admitted that sacks of gold and diamond jewelry found in his possession had come from Jewish slave laborers. **********Mr. Schwammberger maintained at the time that he had been ordered to shoot the Jews for trying to flee his camp, that he had been given the valuables voluntarily and that he had found other riches buried under a cellar. In some cases, he maintained, people had given him gold watches for repair. **********But statements made by camp survivors in 1946 painted a bestial picture of Mr. Schwammberger as commandant of two forced labor camps in Nazi-occupied eastern Poland in 1943 and 1944. Some of the statements have been sent to Argentina for the extradition proceedings under a 1973 West German arrest warrant. **********Witnesses said they saw Mr. Schwammberger execute and torture hundreds of Jews, set his dog on prisoners, and use a pliers to tear gold teeth out of prisoners as he accumulated a fortune in stolen valuables. **********Mr. Schwammberger, short, baldish and heavyset, but seemingly robust, was moved from a cell to a prison infirmary in La Plata last week because of what officials said was a heart condition. In a court hearing last Monday, Mr. Schwammberger showed identification papers in his own name and said that he had never hidden his identity. He said he had worked under his own name for a petrochemical company in the town of Lisandro Olmos, near La Plata. **********He lived in a modest house in the nearby community of Los Hornos before reportedly moving in with a son nearer to Buenos Aires and then moving into the interior. He was captured on Nov. 13 on a ranch near Cordoba, in the interior, by the police and a federal judge, possibly as the result of a tip. The West German Government, which prosecutes war crimes committed under the Nazis, recently doubled its reward for information leading to his capture, to more than $300,000. Dossier Is Given to Argentina **********At a news conference last month in Israel, the Simon Wiesenthal Center named Mr. Schwammberger as one of its most wanted Nazi fugitives and said he was believed to be in Argentina. Rabbi Marvin Hier of the Los Angeles-based center met with the Argentine ambassador in Washington on Friday and turned over a dossier on the case, including witnesses' accounts. **********The postwar documents from Austrian police files and Mr. Schwammberger's SS file in West German archives were collected over the years by the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith. Interest in them grew after Mr. Schwammberger's capture, and copies were made available last week by Elliot Welles, director of the League's Nazi war criminals task force. Escaped Detention After War **********The police records show that Mr. Schwammberger, carrying false papers in the name of an army sergeant, was initially arrested on a tip in Innsbruck, Austria, in the French occupation zone on July 19, 1945. He escaped with two other suspected war criminals from the Oradour detention camp, near Schwaz, during the night of Jan. 2-3, 1948. It is not clear how he made his way to Argentina. **********An Austrian, he joined the Nazi party in 1933 and became a member of the SS elite guard four years later. In 1943 and 1944, he admitted, he operated SS labor camps at Przemysl in Poland, near the Soviet Union, where Jews were forced to clean and repair German Army uniforms; and at Mielec, nearer to Cracow, where the Germans operated an aircraft factory with forced Jewish labor. Jews Had to Be 'Shot by Me' **********Jews sometimes fled Przemysl but most were quickly recaptured and ordered shot, Mr. Schwammberger said in a statement that appeared to bear his signature. ''There were differences of opinion regarding the shootings,'' the statement continued, ''for which reason my command issued the order that all Jews who fled from my camp had to be personally shot by me.'' **********''During my duty as camp commander, it was a question of approximately 35 Jews, who, according to the order, had to be shot by me.'' **********The statements quote Mr. Schwammberger as saying that the killings took place in a field. The prisoners stood facing a wall and were shot in the back of the neck, usually from less than 10 centimeters away, about four inches. The bodies were buried in mass graves. Police Seized Valuables **********When he was arrested in 1945, the police seized eight sacks that contained pearl, gold, silver and diamond jewelry, including watches and wedding rings, and gold coins, plates of tooth gold and other items. **********An appraisal obtained by the police valued the cache at about 50,000 marks in 1945. Mr. Welles of the Anti-Defamation League estimated that the jewelry would be worth more than $150,000 today. He said the Austrian Government auctioned off the jewelry for a pittance as unclaimed property, even though many of the pieces bore initials and other identifying marks. **********Asked to explain the valuables found in his home, Mr. Schwammberger told the Austrian police in 1945 that he had uncovered some buried in a cellar and received others for taking ''some Jews out of the ghetto and putting them with me in the work camp,'' according to the signed statement. He said they were given to him by ''the Jew Goldmann,'' ''the Jew Teich,'' ''the Jew Jonas,'' and ''the Jew Reinharz,'' among others. Roundups for Execution **********But camp survivors offered sharply different accounts, statements taken by the police in 1946 showed. Siegfried Kellermann, a 27-year-old cook from Przemysl, said that in September 1943 he watched from hiding as Mr. Schwammberger lured starving Jews out of the ghetto with promises of resettlement and then rounded them up for execution. **********The SS built a bonfire and made the Jews undress and surrender their jewelry, Mr. Kellermann said. Then, he said, Mr. Schwammberger and other officers shot the men and women, often not fatally, and threw them alive into the fire. Children, he said, were grabbed by an arm or a leg, their heads were smashed against a wall and they were thrown into the flames. **********''In this method and manner 900 people were murdered,'' he said. Ashes Sifted for Gold **********Afterwards, he said, the victims' ashes were sifted for any remaining gold. He said he later came out of hiding, was arrested and sent to Przemysl, where he became a driver for Mr. Schwammberger, often delivering packages of gold and jewels to Mr. Schwammberger's relatives. **********The commandant, Mr. Kellermann said, tried to get his 8-year-old son to help him with the killings but the boy refused, saying he did not like to shoot other children. **********Another survivor, Heinrich Kirschenbaum, a 24-year-old truck driver who was freed from Mielec, told the authorities the camp had food shortages because Mr. Schwammberger took the camp provisions and sold them in Mielec. He said received 100 lashes for being caught with a packet of coffee. **********Mr. Kirschenbaum said the commandant ordered his dog to ''roll him over'' for the whipping. ''He always set the dog, Prince, on the inmates. It leaped on people and tore out entire pieces of their body parts.'' **********Once, he said, his uncle, also a prisoner, had a napkin tied around his jaw because of a toothache. ''Schwammberger took a look and thereby established that my uncle still had four gold teeth in his mouth, which he then simply tore out that same day with a pliers.'' **********The uncle, Salamon Balsam, then 43, corroborated the incident in his own account. He also recounted an incident in which Mr. Schwammberger's horse ran against the camp's electrified fence and was electrocuted. Mr. Schwammberger, Mr. Balsam said, demanded that the oldest Jewish prisoner immediately find him another or he would be shot. **********Another Mielec inmate, Low Chiel, a 21-year-old apprentice locksmith, said 50 Jews at the camp who had been caught hiding valuables were shot. **********''We were further oppressed with a tax of 50,000 zlotys,'' Mr. Chiel said. ''If we didn't come up with it, he would shoot 20 or 30. We didn't bring the demanded sum and he shot 15 Jews.'' Sick Inmates Were Shot **********Unlike at other Nazi concentration and work camps, Mr. Chiel said, there was no sick call at Mielec. Sick inmates were shot. **********He said he was put on a burial detail for one of Mr. Schwammberger's mass shootings. ''Therefore I saw how naked people were driven in the open one kilometer from the airplane factory,'' he said. ''The shooting was by shots in the head. We were ordered to shovel out the graves in five minutes or we would also be threatened with shooting.'' **********''I was interned in various camps during the Nazi time,'' he said, ''but I have never experienced such bestial treatment as by Schwammberger.'' **********It was not clear how many of these witnesses are still alive or could be found 41 years later. But others, hearing of Mr. Schwammberger's arrest, have recently come forward.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/18/busin.body_text: **********Salomon Brothers, Wall Street's largest securities firm, lost about $100 million during the violent plunge in bond prices in April, according to analysts and Wall Street officials with knowledge of the firm's activities. **********Salomon Brothers thus became the third major securities firm known to have suffered major losses during the tempestuous two weeks in April when a becalmed bond market suddenly tumbled. **********The swiftness of the plunge clearly caught even some of Wall Street's shrewdest players off guard; the president of one major securities firm estimated that Wall Street's losses for the month may have approached $1 billion. **********Merrill Lynch & Company said in late April that it had been hit with an unprecedented $275 million loss. And on Tuesday the First Boston Corporation acknowledged that it had also taken a beating, which sources close to the firm put at $100 million. Profit for Quarter Seen **********John H. Gutfreund, Salomon Brothers' chairman, had conceded in late April that the month had been extremely tough, but he had not acknowledged any losses. Yesterday Robert S. Salomon Jr., the firm's chief spokesman, would say only that the firm's profits for the second quarter would be down from the period a year earlier. **********He added that because of First Boston's announcement, Salomon had decided to confirm that its profits would decline. First Boston had said it would show an overall loss for the second quarter because of losses from trading in Treasury bond options. Mr. Salomon said, however, that Salomon Brothers would still show a profit over all for the three-month period. **********Analysts immediately cut in half their profit estimates for Salomon Inc., Salomon Brothers' parent. **********Lawrence Eckenfelder, an analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities, said he had lowered his estimate for Salomon's second-quarter earnings to about 40 cents a share, or $60 million, from 75 cents. In the second quarter of last year, Salomon Brothers earned 78 cents a share, or $117 million. Stocks Decline **********Mr. Eckenfelder said he had calculated that Salomon Brothers probably lost $75 million to $100 million in April from bond trading losses and reductions in revenue because of low trading volume in April and May. Sources close to the firm said yesterday that the figure was more than $100 million in trading and revenue losses and that, over all, Salomon Brothers had lost more than $40 million during April before taxes. **********Salomon's stock price fell to $34.25 yesterday, down $1, as word of the reduction in earnings spread. The stock price of First Boston, which made its announcement after the market had closed on Tuesday, fell to $44.75, down $1. **********Merrill Lynch had suffered its losses from trading in a new kind of mortgage-backed bond, and First Boston mainly from complex Treasury bond options. Neither of the innovative instruments has been well tested in a down market. Behind the Losses **********The Wall Street sources said that Salomon Brothers' losses had come from a variety of areas, but particularly from municipal bond trading. **********The municipal bond market suffered particularly acute problems in April for two reasons: first, because it had less trading volume and thus less liquidity than some other bond markets, and second, because of the growing role of municipal bond mutual funds. **********The lack of liquidity led to a situation where, as the selling gained momentum last April, prices were cut faster in the municipal, or tax-exempt, bond market than in other areas, such as Treasury bonds. **********This trend received further impetus when thousands of individual investors redeemed their holdings in the municipal bond mutual funds. The wave of redemptions forced the funds to sell hundreds of millions of dollars of their bonds, adding significantly to the downward pressure. **********Some hint of the industry's difficulties came in early May, when Edward Ozog, an assistant vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, addressed a gathering of the Public Securities Association. Mr. Ozog, who reviews the records of the primary Treasury security dealers, said the major firms had not reported much profit in the first months of the year because of the lack of trading volume.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/15/busin.main_headline: Business and Health; Rise of Preferred Provider Groups
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/15/busin.print_headline: Business and Health; Rise of Preferred Provider Groups
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/15/busin.body_text: **********IF there is a booming frontier in the health-care industry, it is the preferred provider business. **********But some of the companies that have moved millions of employees to preferred provider organizations are finding a rough-and-tumble environment. Many of the networks have not yet gained solid control over costs, quality and accountability, industry spokesmen and consultants agree. And there are still few role models and little governmental enforcement to guide them. **********Preferred provider organizations, most of which are less than five years old, are a blend of health maintenance organizations and traditional fee-for-service insurance plans. An employee is offered a limited, or ''preferred,'' group of physicians and hospitals in return for improved benefits, such as lower deductibles and lower fees. The employee has a wider choice of medical providers than under traditional H.M.O. plans. And the cost can be far lower than that of traditional fee-for-service plans, whose premiums have begun to soar anew. The employer's incentive is a discount from the doctors and hospitals. In theory, even the medical provider wins because of a higher number of patients. **********Though preferred provider groups have received far less attention than H.M.O.'s, they are now available to more than 30 million people, according to the American Association of Preferred Provider Organizations. H.M.O.'s serve more than 25 million. In the last year the number of preferred provider groups has doubled, to 700. The field, once dominated by small networks of physicians and hospitals, is now being overrun by commercial insurance companies, which often team up with medical providers, and by Blue Cross-Blue Shield. **********Indeed, the preferred provider organization is quickly swapping roles with the open-ended fee-for-service plan that had long been the mainstay of American health care. By 1990, 40 to 45 percent of Americans who have health insurance through their employer will be covered by preferred provider organizations, up from 4 percent in 1985, while the share for traditional plans will fall to 5 percent, from 72 percent, Peter Boland, a health-care consultant in Berkeley, Calif., predicts. **********Many companies offer employees the option of a preferred provider organization, traditional plan or an H.M.O. Others, including Honeywell Inc., have kept only preferred provider groups for some employees. **********But although many employers have bought the preferred provider concept, some are not yet satisfied. ''Our experience is that the P.P.O.'s can be managed much more efficiently than they are,'' said Walter B. Maher, director of employee benefits at the Chrysler Corporation. **********The problem, Mr. Boland said, is that most of these networks have relied too heavily on discounting and not enough on reviewing the performance of the participating doctors and hospitals. ''The insurer and the employer have a difficult time getting meaningful operational and cost data,'' he added. Moreover, he said, there has not been enough effort to weed out doctors who have tried to make up for the lower fees by, say, arranging two appointments for a patient when only one was necessary, or whose treatment did not keep a patient from getting sicker and running up further bills. Indeed, it is in ambulatory care - care outside the hospitals - where cost and quality controls are weakest, industry experts agree. As a result, preferred provider organizations have often fallen short of the 15 to 40 percent savings expected over traditional plans. **********But experts are optimistic. Many preferred provider groups are learning to track more closely the performance of participating doctors and hospitals and keep them in line. Some networks are now moving toward an incentive system for doctors similar to that of H.M.O.'s that emphasizes efficiency by withholding a certain percentage of fees and giving the money to doctors only if they meet certain cost and quality goals, said James A. Hester of Pilgrim Health Care, an H.M.O. in Norwell, Mass. Indeed, some experts say systems combining the fixed-price, prepaid aspects of H.M.O.'s and the discounted fee-for-service features of a preferred provider organization will become more common. **********As the preferred provider industry matures, exemplary models are emerging. Mr. Boland mentions CAPP Care, based in Fountain Valley, Calif., and Benefit Panel Services in Los Angeles. At the same time, studies like one being conducted by the Rand Corporation will further identify what works. And Mr. Boland is leading a panel developing accreditation standards for the industry. **********But some say that self-monitoring is not enough. ''As far as regulation goes, P.P.O.'s have in a sense fallen through the cracks,'' said Nancy C. Turnbull, a Massachusetts deputy commissioner of insurance. She added that virtually no state monitored preferred provider groups for features such as financial disclosure, access to emergency medical care within a network and grievance mechanisms. She is backing a bill to give the state authority to license preferred provider organizations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/09/busin.main_headline: Japan's Raises Seen at a Low
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/09/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL REPORT; Japan's Raises Seen at a Low
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/09/busin.body_text: **********Japanese workers, the world's highest paid, will probably receive their smallest wage increase ever this year, economists say. **********Faced with a growing threat of unemployment, they are likely to settle for an increase of around 3 to 4 percent for the year starting in April, well below last year's 4.5 percent and the previous low of 4.4 percent in 1983. The Government expects consumer prices to rise 1.6 percent in 1987-88. **********Japan's annual wage negotiations have just begun, with unions setting their pay demands for next year. Economists said workers in big industries would be protected from outright pay cuts by Japan's seniority system, which virtually guarantees increases as employees get older. **********Chikara Ohkubo, manager of the research division at the Japan Federation of Employers' Associations, estimates the seniority payments would translate into an average wage rise of 2.1 percent in 1987-88.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/26/world.main_headline: 45 Are Found Dead in Burma In an Airliner That Vanished
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/26/world.print_headline: 45 Are Found Dead in Burma In an Airliner That Vanished
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/26/world.body_text: **********All 45 people aboard a Burma Airways plane missing since Sunday died when the aircraft crashed into an 8,200-foot mountain in eastern Burma, the Government reported Wednesday. **********The wreckage of the Fokker Friendship 27 was sighted on the ridges of Menei Mountain about 40 miles from Heho in the state of Shan, the Government news agency said. **********''It has been learned that all 45 on board - 4 crew members, 36 passengers and 5 children - are dead,'' a brief report from the agency said. It did not say what caused the crash. **********The control tower at the Heho airport lost contact with the plane about 10 minutes after it took off Sunday on an hourlong flight to Mong Hsat, also in Shan state, officials said. Heho is 280 miles northeast of Rangoon. **********The dead were believed to be all Burmese because foreigners are not allowed to travel on the route leading to the Golden Triangle, a major opium-producing area, where the Burmese, Thai and Laotian borders converge.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/12/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********Carole Gould's description of John Markese's formulas for equating 12b-1 costs with both front-end and back-end loads fails to cover his conclusion - namely, that investors should consider total expenses as the most important product of this exercise (''Those Tricky Mutual Fund Costs,'' Personal Finance, March 8). Total expenses include the annual operating expenses of the mutual fund as well as distribution expenses. **********Front-end loads, even the so-called low-loads, penalize the investor far more than a modest 12b-1 plan does. For instance, a mutual fund with a 3 percent front-end load must be held for 12 years before catching up with the asset value growth of a no-load fund which deducts 0.25 percent annually for 12b-1 charges. Many investors refuse to sign up for an investment for 12 years before breaking even on front-end loading expenses. **********The bottom line is that true no-load funds, including no front-end costs and no deferred contingent sales charges, do still exist. There are even true no-load funds with no 12b-1 expense plans; e.g., Scudder and Vanguard families of funds, Loomis Sayles and Northeast Investors funds.  SYLVIA E. GREEN   Boston, March 12

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/20/busin.main_headline: Nekoosa Chief Busy With New Strategy
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/20/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Nekoosa Chief Busy With New Strategy
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/20/busin.body_text: **********William R. Laidig, chairman and chief executive of the Great Northern Nekoosa Paper Company, says he has a lot of woodworking machinery in his basement that he doesn't get much of a chance to use. **********Mr. Laidig is especially busy these days dealing with a major change in strategy for the forest products company. Great Northern Nekoosa has just agreed to pay $1.15 billion for the forest product group of Owens-Illinois Inc. **********''It transforms us from $2 billion to $3 billion in sales,'' Mr. Laidig said, ''but more important it puts us into the corrugated box and containerboard segment of the paper business in a major way.'' The purchase will make the company one of the top five makers of corrugated boxes. **********Currently, Great Northern Nekoosa is more of a raw material supplier of the containerboard used to make the boxes. But providing the raw materials, Mr. Laidig said, is a highly cyclical business. The company wants to get in the box business to level the cycles, thereby smoothing its cash flow and making business planning easier, he said. **********Mr. Laidig began the strategic change last fall with the purchase of J&J Corrugated Box, which had been a major independent. The proposed acquisition of the Owens-Illinois unit will add substantial debt to the company, Mr. Laidig acknowledged, raising debt to almost 60 percent of capital from 26 percent, according to credit-rating agencies. But Mr. Laidig said the company could ''return to more normal ratios'' with the use of cash flow and with possible later restructuring of the debt. **********Great Northern Nekoosa has five main operating divisions, ranging from newsprint to copying paper and it owns 2.9 million acres of timberland, 2.1 million of them in Maine. **********Mr. Laidig was reached in Toledo, Ohio, on Friday, where he was familiarizing himself with the Owens-Ilinois unit. Great Northern Nekoosa is based in Stamford, Conn. **********Mr. Laidig, who is 60 years old, joined the company 37 years ago after graduating from Marquette as a mechanical engineer and working briefly for Inland Steel. He was named Great Northern Nekoosa's chairman and chief executive in 1984 and plans to stay on until he is 65. After that, he may get a chance to do some woodworking in the basement.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/17/busin.main_headline: JWT BOARD WAS GIVEN A TROUBLING REPORT
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/17/busin.print_headline: ADVERTISING; JWT BOARD WAS GIVEN A TROUBLING REPORT
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/17/busin.body_text: **********In an appearance before JWT Group Inc.'s board in January, Joseph W. O'Donnell, then the recently appointed chairman of JWT's J. Walter Thompson Company, presented a letter with a list of 10 suspected financial irregularities he had found in the operation. **********The list included cases of apparent violations of the tax laws of Belgium and Turkey, according to an article in yesterday's European edition of The Wall Street Journal. The presentation came just before Mr. O'Donnell, now chief executive of the William Esty Company, was dismissed by Don Johnston, chairman and chief executive of JWT. **********It had been speculated that Mr. O'Donnell was dismissed for having discussions with an investment banker about taking JWT private. Hostile Bid Under Way **********The existence of the list was verified yesterday by a source close to the company. The disclosure comes as JWT faces a hostile tender offer of $45 a share, or about $438 million, from Britain's WPP Group P.L.C., headed by Martin S. Sorrell, a former Saatchi & Saatchi financial executive. Mr. Sorrell has offered to increase his bid to $50.50 a share, or $491 million, if JWT agrees to a friendly deal. Yesterday JWT stock closed at $52.50, up 50 cents, in active trading. **********The JWT board convened yesterday at 2 P.M., and at 8:15 a JWT spokesman said that the board, with all 11 members attending, had decided not to make an announcement last night. The meeting continued well into the evening. **********According to The Journal's European edition, employees of the Brussels office were receiving part of their pay in expense vouchers as a way of evading local taxes. The paper reported that the Belgian Government was asking for additional tax payments from JWT offices. **********The Turkish matter involved the purchase of an agency in Turkey. Some of the purchase price was purportedly deposited in a Swiss bank to help the owners evade taxes. **********Asked to comment, Donald C. Deaton, a JWT spokesman, said, ''Joe's letter was thoroughly examined by the audit committee of the board and by outside auditors, and they found no cause for action in the letter.'' **********The matters had been ''known and dealt with,'' he said, adding, ''It was a tempest in a teapot.'' **********Such practices are not a normal way of doing business abroad, according to one longtime international agency executive. He said American executives know that if they are caught, their agencies will be prevented from doing business in that country. **********Meanwhile, The Sunday Times in London had reported that Mr. Sorrell had been studying JWT for nine months. He showed he had studied well when he incorporated the Owl Group in Delaware as a WPP subsidiary to purchase JWT stock. The Owl and the Lamp was an early symbol of the 123-year-old J. Walter Thompson agency. Norman Strouse, chief executive in the 1960's, collected owl statuettes, and Mr. Johnston has them on his interoffice memo paper. **********The Ford Motor Company, Thompson's top client, has shown some support for the current JWT management, but this is not the case with the Ford Dealers Advertising Association of Philadelphia, which has a budget of about $7 million. It split with Thompson about two weeks ago and is now talking to other shops. Thompson still handles 40 of the country's 69 Ford dealer advertising associations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/17/busin.main_headline: PUTTING A KIWI IN EVERY LUNCH BOX
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/17/busin.print_headline: WHAT'S NEW IN EXOTIC FRUIT; PUTTING A KIWI IN EVERY LUNCH BOX
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/17/busin.body_text: **********WHAT drives the marketers is the dream of finding the next kiwi, the Horatio Alger of exotic fruit. **********Frieda Caplan began marketing the New Zealand kiwi in the United States in 1962, selling just 2,400 pounds of the fuzzy, brown-skinned fruit to an indifferent public. By last year, though, many Americans had been won over, delighting in the kiwi's cool green flesh and tiny edible black seeds. Indeed, by then, Mrs. Caplan's sales alone had passed 1 million pounds, the kiwi had become a major crop in California and the fruit could be found in 84 percent of the nation's supermarkets. **********Now the California Kiwifruit Commission, a state agency, has even bigger plans. **********''We've already converted the people who are easy to convert,'' said Dennis Palmer, the account executive handling the commission's campaign at Evans/Kraft Inc., an advertising agency in Seattle. ''Our job now is to get the people who aren't experimental in what they eat.'' **********Apparently, there are still plenty of those people around, even for the kiwi. According to Mark Houston, president of the kiwi commission, Americans consumed less than one kiwi each in all of 1986. **********Mr. Palmer's strategy is to cast kiwis as normal, everyday fruit, easily comparable to apples and oranges. Print advertising in the campaign began to appear last year in Sunset, a magazine popular in many Western states, as well as in People. **********The ads pictured kiwis in lively conversations with other fruits. In one, a banana boasts about its high potassium content. The kiwi tartly responds, ''I'm loaded with potassium and a taste that beats you, monkey fruit.'' **********''We want to develop an image, a personality for the kiwifruit,'' said Mr. Houston, whose group spent $1.2 million on the print campaign and other advertising in 1986. **********Earlier print campaigns were limited to women's magazines and pictured kiwis in salads or as garnishes, always as a supplement to other foods. Now, Mr. Palmer said, kiwis are being touted as snacks that can be picked up on the run and eaten on their own. **********''People need to start thinking of it as an everyday product if we're going to sell all that fruit,'' said Mr. Palmer, referring to the huge rise in kiwi production in the past several years. In 1980-81, about 8 million pounds of California kiwis were sold; in 1985-86, the figure was 34 million. The state is now the world's biggest producer after New Zealand. **********Mr. Houston is betting that the kiwi, which he called a ''feisty little character,'' will easily make the switch from exotic to mainstream, and that he will achieve his goal of putting a kiwi on every plate. **********''Look at the banana,'' he said. ''There was a time in the 1950's when people thought that the banana was an exotic specialty.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/15/busin.main_headline: Retiree Returns To Fill In at MCI
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/15/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Retiree Returns To Fill In at MCI
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/15/busin.body_text: **********V. Orville Wright came out of retirement yesterday to become acting chief executive of the MCI Communications Corporation. Mr. Wright will fill in for William G. McGowan, who is recovering from a heart attack. Mr. McGowan, 59 years old, will retain the title of chairman. **********Mr. Wright, 66, retired from MCI in October 1985 but remained on the board as vice chairman. **********Mr. McGowan suffered the heart attack Dec. 22. Mr. Wright said he could not estimate when Mr. McGowan would be back. ''We're playing it by ear,'' he said. **********The company said the board's action had been taken at the suggestion of Mr. McGowan, ''so that he can devote his full attention to his recuperation.'' A spokesman said that Mr. McGowan was now at home and that his condition had been listed as good. **********An analyst, Charles W. Schelke of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, said it appeared that Mr. McGowan probably would not return to his post for some time and that MCI wanted an experienced member of senior management at the helm until Mr. McGowan does come back. **********Mr. Wright joined the company in 1975 as president and chief operating officer, a title he held until he retired. He has been credited with helping Mr. McGowan to build MCI into a leader in communications and long-distance services. **********Burt C. Roberts Jr., 43, took Mr. Wright's place as president and chief operating officer and will continue in that role. **********Mr. Wright was at Hilton Head Island, S.C., yesterday for a golf tournament sponsored by MCI. He said his retirement had been busy, since he had continued as MCI vice chairman and had other duties. ''I didn't just stop,'' he said, ''and I have no problems with coming back full time.'' **********Mr. Wright, a graduate of the University of Kansas, came to MCI after serving as president of the computer systems development division of the RCA Corporation. He also spent 20 years with the International Business Machines Corporation as marketing director and director of systems and technology. **********Mr. McGowan, a Harvard Business School graduate, joined MCI in 1968. **********MCI's stock was bid at $6.375 yesterday, down 50 cents, in over-the-counter trading.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/26/busin.main_headline: SOFTWARE COPYRIGHT BILL MOVES AHEAD IN BRAZIL
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/26/busin.print_headline: SOFTWARE COPYRIGHT BILL MOVES AHEAD IN BRAZIL
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/26/busin.body_text: **********In a move aimed at settling a prolonged trade dispute with the United States, Brazil's Chamber of Deputies has approved a law accepting international copyright rules for computer software programs. **********The law, passed Wednesday night, must still be endorsed by the Senate and signed by President Jose Sarney. It had been demanded by the United States as a condition for lifting its threat to retaliate against the protectionism of Brazil's computer and data-processing industry. Deadline Remains **********The United States recently imposed a deadline of July 1 for Brazil to make changes in its legislation and regulations. In Washington, the software legislation was praised by the United States trade representative, Clayton K. Yeutter. Other officials said that Brazil needs to take more action. **********The conflict began in September 1985, when President Reagan ordered an investigation into whether Brazil's 1984 Informatics Law constituted an ''unfair trade practice'' under the United States Trade Act and was therefore subject to trade reprisals. **********That law, which was acclaimed at the time as an important nationalist victory, created a ''market reserve'' that excluded foreign companies from much of the data-processing industry for at least eight years. Focus on Software Piracy **********But in subsequent talks between United States and Brazilian officials, the focus turned toward American demands that this country adopt legislation to control piracy of software programs. **********One American official said the law adopted Wednesday night was the result of these negotiations, but he added that it allowed the Special Informatics Secretariat to regulate the entry of software into this country. ''It provides copyright protection but controls commercialization,'' he said. **********A foreign computer company executive, who asked not to be identified, said the new legislation was ''better than nothing.'' But he noted that some Brazilian critics of the Informatics Law still felt that the new software law gave the Special Informatics Secretariat excessive powers. **********He added that while protection was granted for 25 years to software programs registered with the Secretariat, there remained questions about how locally made programs identical or similar to foreign programs would be handled. **********One further obstacle to settling the trade dispute is that the Senate must approve the software law before its current session ends on June 30.  ----  PRAISE IN WASHINGTON **********WASHINGTON, June 25 (Reuters) - Clayton K. Yeutter today praised Brazil for its moves to provide copyright protection for computer software. **********But other trade officials said the July 1 deadline remained for Brazil to end all of its unfair trade practices on computers. **********Mr. Yeutter said the move by Brazil's Chamber of Deputies was ''an important step forward in the protection of intellectual property in Brazil.'' He did not say what retaliatory actions the United States might take if Brazil did not end its computer curbs. **********The Commerce Department has estimated that American computer companies are losing $335 million to $450 million a year because of the policies Brazil has erected to shield its infant computer industry from foreign competition.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/11/busin.body_text: **********Few shares of stock were sold on Oct. 19 by firms using computers to shift investments between stocks and stock index futures, a regulatory agency said today. **********In a preliminary report, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission said that only about 9 percent of the stock sold on the New York Stock Exchange that day was associated with index arbitrage, a form of program trading. The report indicates that the technique played a smaller market role than its normal 20 percent. **********Some critics say program trading exaggerated the stock plunge. Index arbitragers using computers try to take advantage of unusually wide differences between stock and stock index futures prices by selling one and simultaneously buying the other for risk-free gains. In a falling stock market, arbitragers would sell stocks while buying futures, in theory narrowing the price gap between them.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/03/busin.main_headline: Talking Business; Today's World Of Commerce: with Pehr Gyllenhammar of Volvo
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/03/busin.print_headline: Talking Business; Today's World Of Commerce: with Pehr Gyllenhammar of Volvo
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/03/busin.body_text: **********Pehr Gyllenhammar is chairman of Volvo A.B., Scandinavia's largest industrial company. Known in the United States for automobiles, Volvo also makes industrial, marine and aerospace products and is active in energy, food and banking. Last year Volvo earned $237.9 million before taxes on sales of $12.71 billion. **********Mr. Gyllenhammar has also used Volvo as a platform to promote European business in general. He is founder and chairman of the European Roundtable, 27 executives who lobby European governments in favor of railway, bridge and tunnel investments, freer trade and harmonization of standards and taxes. During a trip to New York, he talked about the international business scene. **********Q. Do laws limiting the use of Swedish profits overseas inhibit Volvo? **********A. They are being relaxed rather quickly. A lot of people have said we are locked in with Swedish cash we can't move. It's not true. There has never been an investment we wanted to do outside Sweden that has been blocked by the Bank of Sweden. The burden has been that we sometimes had to borrow because we couldn't use the Swedish crowns, which has made some investments more expensive. But the other side of the coin is that Scandinavian assets have been rated at a lower price. We have been able to buy good-quality food companies at 6 to 10 times earnings when internationally they go at double that cost. So it has made sense to expand at home. **********Q. The European Roundtable has a specific agenda, including a bridge-tunnel connection joining Scandinavia to Germany. How are your proposals going? **********A. Our infrastructure program has been discussed within the European Commission as a blueprint for their program. We did a joint study with them on financing that may be important in the long run. We have also supported group research projects and raised venture capital. We can't be corporate marriage brokers, but we can work to make it easier to do business in Europe. Q. In doing business today, how helpful are European governments? **********A. Government attitudes are much more positive than even five years ago, and there's no comparison with the 1970's, when they could think only in terms of subsidies. It's still very slow in tax harmonization and standardization. **********Environmental affairs are another area. We cannot live with a Western Europe where standards differ widely. The Roundtable has to go into this area because industry is seen as a polluter. Q. What about labor?  A. Problems come up when people are threatened. Sweden has next to full employment. We don't know how people would protect their jobs if unemployment would increase. **********There is another problem: organizing modern manufacturing. It's hard to state ahead of time who should be a metalworker and who white-collar. The responsibilities merge if you are a programmer and foreman in charge of a $10 million piece of equipment. We may need to encourage unions to merge as the workplace merges jobs. Q. Will that be tougher in Europe than the United States? **********I don't know. In the U.S. you can still fire people if you don't need them. In Europe you can't reduce your work force through dismissals unless a business is hopeless, so the dialogue will be more complicated. However, well-managed European firms have learned more about working with their employees because you can't dispose of them. Understanding employees is one of the keys to organizing work differently. **********Q. What is your view of the international financial scene? **********Over the last 24 months we have had to live with currency fluctuations that are unheard of in modern history. It's very dangerous for industrial growth. Business today is already encouraged to look too much to the short term. What's happening in the foreign-exchange markets doesn't help. It distorts perspective, creates an added interest in short-term dealings in financial markets and distracts industry.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/07/world.main_headline: Bonn Expectations Revive for a Visit by Honecker
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/07/world.print_headline: Bonn Expectations Revive for a Visit by Honecker
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/07/world.body_text: **********Some recent comments by the East German leader, Erich Honecker, have again raised politically charged expectations that he will finally make his often-postponed visit to West Germany. **********In an interview with a Dutch newspaper last week on the eve of a state visit to the Netherlands, Mr. Honecker said he was in ''close contact'' on the question of a visit with Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany ''and I expect that we will find a time, probably within this year.'' **********Mr. Honecker later eluded questions. On Friday, he told a West German reporter with a smile that the timing of a visit ''is my best-kept secret.'' **********Thin though his comments were, Mr. Honecker's suggestion that a visit was once again in the offing was immediately seized upon in West Germany, and most speculation focused on early fall as the time a visit might possibly occur. Symbolic and Emotional **********No East German party chief has ever visited West Germany, and the prospect has gathered considerable symbolic and emotional significance in West Germany, only increased by the fact that the Soviet Union has blocked Mr. Honecker in the past. **********West German Government officials were quick to stress that although the invitation to Mr. Honecker was always open, no concrete plans had been made. But they said Mr. Honecker would not have casually raised the question. **********''Mr. Honecker put the question on the agenda, and I assume he is earnestly interested in making this visit,'' said Eduard Lintner, chairman of the ruling Christian Democratic party's committee on inter-German relations. **********What gave Mr. Honecker's comments added weight was that he made them directly after a meeting in East Berlin of leaders of the Warsaw Pact, which was attended by Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union. Having been barred from visiting Bonn by the Kremlin in the past, West German officials said, Mr. Honecker must have received some sort of green light from the Soviet leader before speaking out. Nuclear Deal Is Cited **********Other conditions that appeared to make a visit feasible included the recent decision by the West German Government to support American-Soviet moves toward a deal on ridding Europe of medium-range missiles, and the prospect of a Soviet-American agreement. A state visit to Bonn last week by the Bulgarian leader, Todor Zhivkov, was viewed by West German officials as a good omen, since last time Mr. Honecker canceled a planned visit to West Germany, in September 1984, Mr. Zhivkov also canceled his visit. **********During the Parliament debate on medium-range missiles last Thursday, the head of the opposition Social Democratic party, former Chancellor Willy Brandt, spoke of a Honecker visit next fall as a fact. It was not clear whether Mr. Brandt was acting on concrete knowledge or on supposition. **********In 1983 and again in 1984, Mr. Honecker postponed visits to West Germany. Though the stated reason was some unfriendly comment or gesture by West Germans, it was generally accepted that Mr. Honecker had been denied permission by the Kremlin. **********Though he was the East German official responsible for throwing up the Berlin wall in 1961, in recent years Mr. Honecker has sought to improve inter-German relations. A state visit to Bonn would cap his career. **********But Mr. Honecker is generally considered to have less independence in foreign policy than other East European counterparts, in part because of Soviet suspiciousness of the Germans and in part because of 400,000 Soviet troops in East Germany. **********In April 1983 and again in September 1984, his plans to visit West Germany ran into conflict with with Moscow's vitriolic propaganda campaign against the emplacement of American medium-range missiles in Europe, which included charges that West Germany was succumbing to ''revanchism,'' the Soviet propaganda term for seeking a return to the past. **********More recently, Mr. Honecker declined an invitation in April to attend celebrations in West Berlin marking the city's 750th anniversary.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/14/busin.body_text: **********The economy's long-ailing industrial sector is rebounding smartly, but there is still no evidence of significant inflationary pressure, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Alan Greenspan, said today. **********''We are not yet approaching anything close'' to the economy's productive capacity, Mr. Greenspan told a meeting of the Northeast-Midwest Congressional leadership council. One result, he suggested, is that inflation is likely to be lower than expected by investors in the bond market, where long-term interest rates have been soaring. **********Mr. Greenspan was also optimistic about American competitiveness, which he said had improved substantially as a result of the dollar's fall and a ''silent revolution'' of corporate productivity gains that he said had not yet been fully recognized. **********A Fed spokesman said that when Mr. Greenspan spoke, he had not seen the Government's international trade figures for August, which are to be published by the Commerce Department on Wednesday. **********Mr. Greenspan said in his comments on Capitol Hill that the economy, which has enjoyed five years of unbroken expansion, should not be expected to reflect and transmit inflation pressures in the same way that it did in previous decades. Thus, the recent rise in the price of steel scrap and lesser increases for such items as aluminum and lead were not necessarily worrisome. **********Rather, he said, any dangerous inflationary tendencies would probably show up first in slower deliveries of materials. In fact, just the opposite occurred in August, the latest month for which data are available, when the percentage of companies reporting slower deliveries actually fell.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/17/busin.main_headline: Business And The Law; Sale of Robins Poses Problems
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/17/busin.print_headline: Business And The Law; Sale of Robins Poses Problems
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/17/busin.body_text: **********WHEN the American Home Products Corporation withdrew its bid for the A. H. Robins Company last week, most people speculated that the deal collapsed because of concern about potential liability to thousands of women with claims related to Robins' Dalkon Shield contraceptive device. **********But while neither Robins nor American Home Products will say what led to the withdrawal of the bid, others close to the deal say that it collapsed not because of the Dalkon Shield liability, but because of the extensive demands made by Robins. **********''Robins's attitude to the bid was that the family farm is not for sale at any price, and that is a breach of the company's fiduciary duties,'' said one lawyer involved in the bankruptcy whose sentiments were shared by several others close to the deal. ''The withdrawal of the bid was really the loss of a golden opportunity to resolve all the claims in a reasonable way.'' **********Indeed, the most startling aspect of the proposed acquisition was the speed with which American Home Products reached an agreement with representatives of the Dalkon Shield claimants - an agreement that has eluded Robins since those claims, now numbering more than 327,000, pushed the company into bankruptcy court in August 1985. **********Under the proposed bid, American Home Products was to put more than $1 billion into a trust to pay the Dalkon Shield claims and, in return, was to be insulated from all future liability to women who used the intrauterine device. Without such a trust, most legal experts say, any successor to Robins would be engulfed in years and years of litigation over the personal-injury claims. **********Even with the trust, American Home Products might not have had ironclad protection against claims. For there has been immense controversy within the legal profession over whether a company in bankruptcy can use such a trust to resolve all claims - including possible future claims. **********Still, according to Murray Drabkin, who represents the Dalkon Shield claimants in the bankruptcy, it took less than 24 hours to reach agreement with American Home Products on a trust arrangement, indemnification provisions and injunctions against future lawsuits that both assured claimants that they would be compensated for their injuries and made the bidding company comfortable. **********''The possibility of future claims was still there, in metaphysical terms, but as a practical matter, the risk level was so low it was not a major factor in the deal,'' said Mr. Drabkin. **********Generally, under the the doctrine of successor liability, a company that takes over and continues the business of another company becomes responsible for the liabilities that arose out of the normal course of that business. But Robins pulled the Dalkon Shield off the market in 1974, and lawyers differ on whether claims related to the contraceptive device would be considered to arise out of the business the buyer continued. To further complicate matters, different states have different laws on the subject. **********''It just ain't clear,'' said Elihu Inselbuch, who represented the personal-injury claimants in the Manville Corporation's reorganization, another bankruptcy stemming from product-liability claims. ''In Manville, the investment bankers asked, 'What's the deal on successor liability?' and we told them what the law was, but that didn't really answer the question, so they decided to discount the stock by 25 percent.'' **********Manville also faced the problem of future claims. Courts generally have jurisdiction only over the actual claims that are before them, and many legal theorists believe that since a court cannot decide a case that does not yet exist, no bankruptcy court can rule that a future claimant would not have the right to sue the buyer, but would, instead, have to seek compensation from a special trust. **********Indeed, the legality of that arrangement is now on appeal in the Manville case, where hundreds of thousands of future claims are expected from those who have been exposed to asbestos but do not yet know of any injury. Since it can be 30 years after exposure before asbestos-related injuries develop, it is impossible to know exactly how many claims there will be. **********The Dalkon Shield situation is simpler. A few future claims are likely, however, from those who used the contraceptive device as teen-agers, or in their early 20's, and only now, in their 30's or 40's, are trying to have children and finding out that they are infertile. Most injuries related to the contraceptive device, such as pelvic inflammatory disease, became apparent while the device was in use. **********But since the device has been off the market so long, and most women who used it are now past childbearing age, the number of future claims is likely to be small. ''You're dealing with something on which the biological clock is eliminating potential plaintiffs every day,'' said one lawyer involved in the Robins bankruptcy, ''so the problem of latent injuries just isn't that big,'' **********Despite all the legal problems, Victor Schwartz, a Washington product-liability lawyer, believes the courts will uphold the use of trust funds to compensate victims of mass product-liability problems, since most of the parties involved - including the judges who would otherwise have to hear thousands of individual lawsuits - seem to believe that such a resolution is in everyone's best interests. **********''The law goes where the law wants to go, and the law wants to be able to put a line around these things,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/31/world.body_text: **********Asian diplomats here say talks have been under way in West Germany to determine the whereabouts of four Iranian diplomats who have been missing in Lebanon since 1982 and whose fate has been linked to that of the Anglican envoy Terry Waite. **********Mr. Waite, a envoy of Robert Runcie, the Archbishop of Canterbury, disappeared in January while trying to negotiate for the release of hostages. **********In an exchange this month with Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani, the Speaker of the Iranian Parliament, Archbishop Runcie promised to use his contacts to find the missing Iranians. In return, Hojatolislam Rafsanjani said he would use his influence to obtain the release of Mr. Waite. **********Now, according to the diplomats here, a leader of the Lebanese Christian militia, is in West Germany meeting with Iranian officials.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/31/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Rent-A-Center's Chief Happy With Takeover
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/31/busin.body_text: **********Although many chief executives dread the notion of their companies being taken over, the acquisition this week of Rent-A-Center Inc. by Thorn EMI, a British consumer products company, seems to have delighted Thomas R. Devlin. **********Mr. Devlin, who is chairman and chief executive of the chain of outlets that rents televisions, appliances and furniture, said the $594 million purchase of the company he founded 14 years ago amounted to ''a tremendous marriage.'' **********He said the British company ''has tremendous resources and they have been looking for a way to move into the consumer products market in the United States.'' He added that Rent-A-Center had been looking for a way to achieve higher growth. ''This is an opportunity for both parties to achieve their dreams,'' Mr. Devlin said. ''The company will be able to grow much faster. I feel very, very good about this.'' **********Rent-A-Center, which is based in Wichita, Kan., owns 270 stores and 168 franchises in 38 states. **********Mr. Devlin, 40, said he had been asked by Thorn officials to remain as chief executive. But he said he preferred to become a consultant and advise the new owners on acquisitions. ''I know everyone in the business,'' he said. ''I've made good acquisitions since I got into the business, and I know who out there is worth acquiring.'' **********Mr. Devlin, a native of Wichita, attended Wichita State University while working for a consumer product rental company. After being promoted to assistant manager, he dropped out of school in 1970 when he realized that the job he took to pay for his education ''paid more than the salaries of the professors who were teaching me.'' **********After the rental company faltered, he moved to Kansas City, Mo., where he borrowed $15,000 and opened his first Rent-A-Center store. For the fiscal year that ended July 31, 1986, the company reported net income of $9.9 million, or 59 cents a share, on revenue of $138.5 million. Mr. Devlin said that this year's earnings should reach nearly $200 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/10/busin.print_headline: ADVERTISING; Della Femina Adds To Its Sheraton Billings
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/10/busin.body_text: **********Della Femina, Travisano & Partners, which became the corporate agency for the North American operation of the Sheraton Corporation when the HBM/Creamer, New York, agency was merged into it, has been awarded its first regional product advertising assignment, for the Western region as well as for the Hawaii-Japan division. **********The new billings should come to $10 million, according to Jerry Della Femina, chairman of the agency. **********The previous agencies were N. W. Ayer for the West and Fawcett, McDermott Cavanagh of Honolulu for the more exotic locales. **********The Della Femina agency is a subsidiary of Britain's WCRS Group, which has announced that the New York office of the group has established a network group to buy TV time for certain clients of Della Femina and HBM/Creamer. Jennifer Young, formerly of HBM/Creamer, has been promoted to senior vice president and put in charge.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/27/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********Barnaby J. Feder's review of what the dollar's drop may or may not do for American experts (Dec. 6) correctly emphsizes that the competitive advantage we have derived temporarily from currency conversion will not by itself make the United States an exporting nation. **********What would it take to become an expot-oriented nation? Primarily, a fundamental change in our thinking. We must accept that we are only a part of this world and not the center of the universe. The global market, which is huge, may be served either through local production in foreign countries or through exporting from American-based factories, or from any combination of these. **********The prime importance, however, must be to develop all new products, whenever possible, with the global market in mind. If this means dimensions will be metric and certain internationally accepted features confuse the American consumer at first, then so be it. **********This country has tremendous opportunities today, which must be exploited. We have a temporary advantage on currency conversion rates. We are going through a reindustrialization process that will improve manufacturing efficiencies. What we still need is the export mentality. We must put marketing muscle and resources behind American products nd design them for export.  TIBOR DARANY   Greenwich, Conn., Dec. 11

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/03/world.main_headline: HOW TO FIND A COUNTRY WITH CASH
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/03/world.print_headline: HOW TO FIND A COUNTRY WITH CASH
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/03/world.body_text: **********At one point in his testimony, Elliott Abrams explained how he decided to solicit a $10 million contribution for the contras from Brunei. **********MARK BELNICK. You did, after these discussions or in the course of other discussions at the department, select a country, which we're now able to use the name of. Correct? ABRAMS. Correct.  Q. And that country was - A. Brunei. Q. There you go. Who selected Brunei? A. I did. Q. All right. How?  A. Take the list of countries in the world and exclude those who have insufficient resources to make a humanitarian contribution. Exclude further those which are right-wing dictatorships or which are, if you will, on the other side, allied with the Soviet Union. Then exclude those which, over which, we can be said to have some leverage. You are left essentially with oil producers. Then look for non-Arab - since I had been to Ambassador Murphy already - for non-Middle East, non-Arab oil producers. Venezuela, I thought, would not do this. You're down to Brunei. **********Q. I don't know if I would have been down to Brunei, but all right. In any event, you selected - A. I was down to Brunei. **********Q. You were down to Brunei. You discussed it with Dr. Sigur, this selection? A. Yes.  Q. All right. And you discussed it with the Secretary of State. **********A. I think I went back to the Secretary and said, I have a suggestion. **********Q. Did you have an amount in mind of how much to ask Brunei to contribute? A. I did . . . $10 million.  Q. And how did you formulate $10 million as the amount? **********A. We were spending, in the humanitarian aid program, at the rate of $3 million a month, $27 million for what was supposed to be about nine months, initially. In the end it was less than nine months, and we thought we want this to get us to the end of the summer. It's about three months, so, $10 million, $3 million a month. That was the ball park.
