https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/12/busin.main_headline: Electronic Data Official A Key to Navy Contract
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/12/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Electronic Data Official A Key to Navy Contract
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/12/busin.body_text: **********Paul J. Chiapparone, senior vice president of the Electronic Data Systems Corporation, is accustomed to overcoming difficult conditions. **********When he was general manager of E.D.S.'s business in Iran in 1979, Mr. Chiapparone was held hostage for 46 days before escaping. **********Last week, the 48-year-old native of Merrick, L.I., led the company's government systems group to a $544 million Navy contract. **********The 12-year project, which calls for the company to supply an automated inventory-control system to 58 cities worldwide, could be worth as much as $1 billion, analysts projected. **********''This is an incredible victory,'' said H. Ross Perot, the founder of E.D.S. ''But of course, Paul Chiapparone can't win these by himself. He had a very capable team around him, but Paul motivated the team. I consider Paul to be one of the finest men in the computer business.'' **********The E.D.S. unit was formed in 1978 to seek projects with the Federal Government. Mr. Chiapparone assumed control in 1982. **********After the General Motors Corporation acquired E.D.S. in 1984, the division was given the added responsibility of overseeing contracts with state and local governments. With annual revenue of $600 million and about 6,000 employees, the government systems group is considered one of the top suppliers of computer systems to all levels of government, analysts said. **********Mr. Chiapparone said the company was bidding on 10 to 15 other large projects, including a computerized personnel system for the Army and an advanced weather information processing system for the Commerce Department. **********''These mega-contracts take enormous energy to pursue,'' Mr. Chiapparone said. Just the bidding for the Navy project, he said, ''was a very large effort over three years and cost in the millions.'' **********After graduating from Adelphi University, where he studied accounting, Mr. Chiapparone joined the Data Computing Corporation as a market research analyst. He served in the Army from 1962 to 1964, then helped install a computerized typesetting system at Time magazine before joining E.D.S. in 1966 as a systems engineer. He now resides in Vienna, Va.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/27/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Texaco Loses A Legal Move
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/27/busin.body_text: **********The United States trustee in the Texaco Inc. bankruptcy proceedings yesterday rejected a request by the oil company to merge the two creditor committees. **********Harry Jones, the Federal trustee, said that he had decided to retain two separate committees because ''the original reasons for appointing two committees are still valid.'' **********Last April, after Texaco had filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws, Mr. Jones named two creditor committees: one for general creditors, and a second for oil companies, including the Pennzoil Company. Texaco had sought Chapter 11 protection after Pennzoil won a $10.53 billion judgment against it. **********Mr. Jones said then that he favored two committees ''in the hope of having this case proceed in as smooth a fashion as possible.'' **********Early this month, Texaco asked Mr. Jones to merge the second committee into the first, asserting that the White Plains company was being unduly burdened by the cost of having to provide the same information to two groups. **********However, Pennzoil said Texaco was trying to isolate it from the bankruptcy process and obstruct its ability to secure its rights as a creditor.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/11/world.main_headline: TURNING MIGHTY ARMS INTO MUSTY ARTIFACTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/11/world.print_headline: THE SUMMIT; TURNING MIGHTY ARMS INTO MUSTY ARTIFACTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/11/world.body_text: **********The Soviet-American treaty on intermediate-range nuclear forces provides for eliminating missiles by smashing, exploding, crushing, burning, launching and static display. **********Static display? Translation: museums. **********Under the treaty each side may put 15 missiles, 15 containers and 15 launchers on public display -after the propellant is removed and the erector-launcher mechanisms are rendered inoperative. **********Each side must provide the other with the names and sites of the intended displays. **********In the United States, likely sites could be the National Air and Space Museum in Washington, where an air-launched cruise missile is on display. **********Pershing missiles might find a home at the Army Artillery Center and School in Fort Sill, Okla., or the Army Redstone Arsenal in Huntsville, Ala. Ground-launched cruise missiles might be put on display at a museum at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base in Dayton, Ohio, or Davis-Monthan Air Force Base in Tucson, Ariz. **********The Soviet Union has an Army Museum. There is also an Air Force Museum, at a base outside Moscow.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/22/busin.print_headline: OCMPANY NEWS; 5 New PC's From Hewlett
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/22/busin.body_text: **********The Hewlett-Packard Company announced five new computers today in its HP Vectra line of personal computers, which are compatible with the International Business Machines Corporation's PC. The new machines expand Hewlett-Packard's offerings at both the low and the high end of the market, and include a new entry-level computer, two enhanced versions of its current PC's and two floor-standing units. **********Priced from $6,495 to $11,995, the HP Vectra RS PC floor-standing systems are Hewlett-Packard's first to be based on the Intel 80386 microprocessor, considered the standard for the next generation of personal computers. They are designed for use as computer-aided-design work stations, local-area network servers or other demanding applications. At $1,195, the HP Vectra CS **********PC is an entry-level system for use in word processing, spreadsheets and other common business applications. It can also emulate a terminal to gain access to Hewlett-Packard's larger computer systems. Two HP Vectra ES systems, priced from $2,595 to $4,195 depending on configuration, are enhanced versions of the company's existing Vectra systems.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/01/world.main_headline: Tear Gas, and Plenty of It
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/01/world.print_headline: Tear Gas, and Plenty of It
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/01/world.body_text: **********The national police confirmed with statistics today what every resident of Seoul and other big cities had already sensed: a tremendous amount of potent tear gas was fired at anti-Government protesters who took to the streets in the last few weeks. **********According to the National Police Headquarters, officers fired 351,200 tear-gas canisters from June 10 to June 26, the peak period of civil unrest. **********To give an idea of how much gas that is, the total contrasts with the 313,000 canisters that Government records show had been fired at demonstrators over a nine-month period in 1986. **********On average, 20,660 canisters a day were fired in the 17-day period. Looked at another way, that amounted to 164 canisters for each of the 2,145 demonstrations officially recorded across the country. **********The police said they had their share of troubles, too. Altogether, 164 police vehicles were damaged or burned, and 262 police stations or substations were attacked, they said. **********Figures on injuries seemed lopsided, however, given the freewheeling kicking and punching engaged in by some officers. According to police headquarters, 6,305 riot policemen were hurt, compared with only 146 civilians, including students.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/21/busin.body_text: **********The Microsoft Corporation said that several thousand counterfeit copies of the Redmond, Wash., company's operating software had been seized from two Northern California businesses. The seizure netted about 30,000 copies of I.B.M. PC DOS, the International Business Machines Corporation's version of the MS-DOS operating system for personal computers. **********Microsoft said the search, ordered by a Federal district court, also turned up evidence of a counterfeiting network that sold large quantities of software to distributors in Southern California.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/03/busin.main_headline: No Progress Seen In Airbus Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/03/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; No Progress Seen In Airbus Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/03/busin.body_text: **********Talks between American and European officials over subsidies for Airbus Industrie, the European airliner manufacturing consortium, made no progress today in what threatens to become a major trade dispute, the officials said. At the same time, Airbus announced in Paris that it had its best January ever, receiving orders worth $5 billion. **********The dispute centers on the proposed Airbus A340 wide-body jet that would compete with the recently launched MD-11 aircraft of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation of St. Louis. Airline analysts say there are probably only enough orders for one of the two planes to show a profit. The Reagan Administration has threatened to file unfair trading charges against the British, French and West German Governments if the A340 goes ahead, accusing them of providing subsidies that allow Airbus to sell plans at below cost in violation of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/29/world.main_headline: Village Where Peace Fears to Tread
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/29/world.print_headline: TENANCINGO JOURNAL; Village Where Peace Fears to Tread
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/29/world.body_text: **********Abandoned by its people after the air force bombed them in 1983 and after fighting between leftist guerrillas and army troops devastated shops and homes, Tenancingo is a village that has not easily found peace. But it has tried. **********Last year, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of San Salvador won the agreement of the army and leftist guerrillas to permit Tenancingo, then a bombed-out ruin left to weeds and to the sun, to be repopulated as a neutral town - a place in a divided country where both sides would agree not to wage their aging war. **********The healing effort, in one of the dozens of villages in the countryside broken and emptied by the fighting, was heralded as a faint, much-needed sign that a small gesture toward peace was still possible after seven years of civil conflict. But now Tenancingo appears in danger of falling back between the warring sides. **********The army and guerrillas have both violated their pledges of neutrality. First the guerrillas came to hold political meetings and military formations. The army quickly replied by sending troops to guard and occupy the town for the last seven months. Villagers say both sides have informers in the town, and a few peasants in nearby areas have been killed by the rebels and the army, on suspicion of aiding the other side. Politics of War Condemned **********Now, the people of Tenancingo seem sick of taking sides. They condemn both the rebels and the soldiers for bringing the politics of the war back to them. ''When the army comes, the soldiers say they are here to protect us from the guerrillas,'' said Andeas Rauda, an aging woman who is rebuilding her former home. ''When the guerrillas come, they say they are protecting us from the army. What we wish is that all who carry weapons would stay away.'' **********But it looks as if the army intends to stay, spurring fears among villagers that the guerrillas may decide to attack at any time, as they did in the past, to maintain control of the area 25 miles northeast of the capital. Controlling this area gives them influence in the center of the country. **********Army-reinforced firing positions now dot the edge of town and it seems only a matter of time before someone will get hurt. A burst of bullets fired by a nervous soldier last week almost hit a sleeping boy and a few days later an Army land mine killed a cow near the town center. Other mines killed and wounded three soldiers who lost their way earlier this year. An Independent Agency **********The organization overseeing the repopulation of the town and the community's effort to rebuild itself is the Salvadoran Foundation for Development and Low-Cost Housing, known as Fundasal, one of the few effective independent agencies in the country. Its director, Manuel Sevilla, is so concerned about the army's violation of the neutrality accord that he has sent several letters to the high command and says he is considering pulling out of Tenancingo if troops remain. He made the same protests to the guerrillas last year. **********''Tenancingo was a symbol of peace,'' Mr. Sevilla said in an interview. ''Now it is becoming a symbol of loss of hope.'' **********''The fact is that neither the Government nor the guerrillas want Tenancingo to be a success,'' he added. ''They don't want to see it repeated elsewhere in the country. The guerrillas do not see the success of a neutral town as positive and the Government does not want a solution it does not control.'' **********Earlier this year the local army commander tried to establish a permanent, formal garrison in the village. Instead, the army opted for constant patrols that offer de facto control of the town without the political controversy of a permanent base would bring. Army Asserts a Right to Stay **********Mr. Sevilla said his organization would leave immediately if the army were to build a base and may leave anyway to protest the continuing army presence. **********An army spokesman denied in an interview that the army had ever agreed to respect Tenancingo as a neutral town. The spokesman said the army had the right to remain in Tenancingo as long as it pleased, since ''there is no agreement that says we can't.'' **********Mr. Sevilla and several townspeople say, however, that the original pledge to the archbishop by the army and the guerrillas that the town's neutrality would be observed was the main reason almost 600 of the town's original estimated 3,000 inhabitants returned from the refugee camps and urban slums. They had fled following past guerrilla attacks and the unrestrained air force bombing four years ago that killed more than 40 villagers. Repaired the Church **********With international assistance directed by Fundasal, returning villagers have repaired the rocket-shattered church, planted surrounding fields, started cooperatives for weaving and rebuilt the school and several bombed-out houses. **********There is no other example in the country of a village that has so quickly and successfully worked to regenerate itself. But the rubble of broken adobe homes, bomb craters and the gashes left by hundreds of bullets remain to remind townspeople of the war. And the sound of distant firing, the harsh chop of passing army helicopters, as well as thudding bombs and mortars, warn that the war is not ending. **********At the same time, signs of the current uneasy peace can also be seen in Tenancingo. Villagers sit and chat under the large trees in the town square, now covered with rows of blooming orchids. Children step over empty army food ration cans to play soccer in the school yard, and peasants try to ignore the fighting in order to tend their fields. **********''It is our home,'' said a town councilman who asked that his name not be used. ''But really, we all know that we are risking our lives in remaining here. We have suffered before, and we know we may sufer again.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/26/busin.main_headline: S.&P. Reduces Ratings Of 6 Banking Concerns
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/26/busin.print_headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES; S.&P. Reduces Ratings Of 6 Banking Concerns
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/26/busin.body_text: **********The Standard & Poor's Corporation said yesterday that primarily because of the continuing debt crisis in developing nations, it had lowered its debt ratings of several major bank holding companies - the Chase Manhattan Corporation, the Chemical New York Corporation, the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation and the Irving Bank Corporation. **********It also lowered its ratings of the Mellon Financial Corporation and the Security Pacific Corporation, but for different reasons. **********S.& P. said the lower debt rating would affect, in total, about $13.3 billion of securities. **********The downgradings at Chase, Chemical, Irving and Manufacturers primarily reflect those institutions' continued vulnerability through their exposure in underdeveloped countries, S.& P. said. Chemical's downgrading also took into consideration its pending acquisition of Texas Commerce Bancshares. **********The lower ratings on Mellon, based in Pittsburgh, and Security Pacific, of Los Angeles, reflect higher non-performing assets and weaker operating earnings, S.& P. said. **********Chase's senior debt was reduced to AA-, from AA, as was Chemical's; Irving's was cut to A+, from AA-, and Manufacturers' was lowered to A, from A+.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/04/busin.body_text: **********Jay Kriegel, a longtime associate of CBS Inc.'s chief executive, Laurence A. Tisch, has been named senior vice president in charge of external relations and governmental affairs. He will report directly to Mr. Tisch. Mr. Kriegel had been acting as a consultant to CBS. From 1966 to 1973, Mr. Kriegel served as chief of staff and special counsel to John V. Lindsay, who was then Mayor of New York City. Mr. Kriegel built his relationship with Mr. Tisch when he served as director of special projects at the Loews Corporation from 1975 to 1978. Mr. Kriegel also served as publisher of The American Lawyer from 1978 to 1982. Since 1983, he has run Kriegel Communications, a consulting firm in in government relations, corporate communiations and marketing. CBS has been among his his clients.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/31/world.main_headline: Manila Orders Four Officers Arrested For Part in Attacks
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/31/world.print_headline: Manila Orders Four Officers Arrested For Part in Attacks
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/31/world.body_text: **********The Chief of Staff, Gen. Fidel V. Ramos, ordered the arrest today of a general and three officers said to have been involved in armed attacks this week. **********The order came as the armed forces were put on alert against further disturbances after a two-day episode in which dissident soldiers took over a broadcast station. **********General Ramos said 13 officers, 359 enlisted men and 137 civilians were being held after attempts to seize nine broadcast and military installations. **********General Ramos said an order had been issued to arest Brig. Gen. Jose Maria Zumel, Col. Rolando Abadilla and other officers. The two men were also involved also in the two-day takeover of the Manila Hotel in July. **********Also today, Communist rebels issued a statement saying they would ''formally withdraw'' from peace talks with the Government. **********The peace talks, which are the substantive element in a 60-day cease-fire that ends Feb. 8, had been suspended for a week after negotiators for both sides reported receiving death threats.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/18/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; ASEA to Purchase Norway's Elektrisk
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/18/busin.body_text: **********ASEA A.B. of Sweden has agreed to buy control of Norway's largest maker of electronic components, Elektrisk Bureau A.S., for the equivalent of $214 million. Securities analysts said ASEA's 63 percent stake in the Norwegian company was a logical step in the Swedish group's strategy to expand in Europe. **********The deal should also open vital markets to the new group being formed by ASEA's merger with the Swiss concern BBC Brown Boveri. That merger will create one of the world's largest electrical engineering groups, with sales of $15.2 billion a year and a work force of 160,000. Analysts said the Elektrisk purchase would effectively remove competition in Norway for the new group.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/10/busin.main_headline: Large Offering Is Set by B.P
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/10/busin.print_headline: Large Offering Is Set by B.P
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/10/busin.body_text: **********The British Petroleum Company said that it would issue 458.6 million new shares to be sold later this month along with the British Government's 31.5 percent stake in the company. **********British Petroleum has said it wants to raise about $:1.5 billion, or $2.46 billion, through the rights issue. It wants to reduce the debt incurred in May when it acquired the 45 percent of the Standard Oil Company it did not already own. **********That purchase cost about $:4.7 billion - at the time, $7.9 billion - making it the third-largest corporate merger in history, after the $13.4 billion takeover of the Gulf Oil Corporation by the Chevron Corporation and the $10.1 billion takeover of the Getty Oil Company by Texaco Inc., both in 1984. **********British Petroleum said that shareholders as of next Thursday will be entitled to buy one new ordinary share for every 12 ordinary shares held. **********The British Government will buy the new shares from British Petroleum and resell them along with its existing stake of 1.74 billion shares. All of the shares will be sold through a two-part offer. The combined sale is expected to raise more than $:7.5 billion, or $12.3 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/23/busin.print_headline: SOVIET CUTS OIL EXPORTS, SAYING IT BACKS OPEC; FLOOR PRICE PROPOSED
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/23/busin.body_text: **********A plan to provide greater energy security -first proposed by the Ford Administration in the mid-1970's - was revived before a Congressional committee today by James R. Schlesinger, who served as Energy Secretary in the Carter Administration. **********Noting that the United States was again building up a dangerous dependency on foreign oil, Mr. Schlesinger, a Democrat, recommended what was originally a Republican idea - the establishment of a floor price by the principal consumer countries to safeguard future exploration and production by their domestic energy industries. Mr. Schlesinger said dependence on foreign oil was approaching 40 percent of consumption and would top 50 percent in the 1990's. A Reagan Administration official said it was not clear whether Mr. Schlesinger's proposal would be endorsed by the White House.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/15/world.main_headline: STARK VILLAGE JUSTICE: MUST THE LOVERS BE FLOGGED?
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/15/world.print_headline: DHAKA JOURNAL; STARK VILLAGE JUSTICE: MUST THE LOVERS BE FLOGGED?
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/15/world.body_text: **********Disgraced and threatened with public whipping, the lovers have turned against each other, and their stories, told in sullen monotones, are now at odds. **********But one thing is certain. Late one recent night, Abdul Jalil and his neighbor's young wife, Khurshida Ali, were caught as they tried to elope, shaming their families and their village of Bholail, which is about 10 miles south of Dhaka. **********Now they faced the judgment of an ancient trial system known as salish, where village elders, mostly tradesmen and small landowners, would exact justice that could include a public whipping or slapping and a forced realignment of the marriages involved. **********As the salish began, Mr. Jalil, a helper on a minibus who thinks his age is about 25, squatted at dusk in a small courtyard, surrounded by the men and boys of the village as the elders, smoking expensive imported cigarettes, discussed his crime. 'She Tempted Me' **********''I hardly even know her,'' he said of Mrs. Ali. ''She tempted me into it. She made advances.'' The women, who play a secondary role in this Moslem society, were hidden in an adjacent building. Mrs. Ali, if her testimony was needed, was to speak into the courtyard through a darkened window. **********The salish, increasingly rare in Bangladesh, represents an attempt by village leaders to maintain their traditional feudal control and to cling to age-old customs - such as the subordination of women - in a slowly modernizing nation. **********It is an illustration of the distance that remains between thousands of isolated villages and the structures of government, which have yet to reach much of the country with paved roads, electricity, water and administrative control. Police Are Not Trusted **********Recourse to the salish also demonstrates a local mistrust of the police, who are described as corrupt and abusive, and of the government court system, which villagers said is slow, complicated and alien to their customs. **********''I am a poor man and I cannot afford to go to the police,'' said Tamizuddin, the father of Mr. Jalil's wife, Hamida. **********''If we go to court we will be trapped in the system,'' said Mr. Tamizuddin, who is a farm laborer. ''The most powerful forces will win and there will be no justice.'' The Antagonists Balk **********But like the courts of the distant cities, the salish snagged this night on a technicality when the aggrieved husband, a bicycle-rickshaw driver named Mohammad Suruj Ali, failed to appear. **********Two nights later, the salish was again delayed when the accused himself refused to take part. **********As a monsoon downpour brought a luminous early dusk to the village and green rice fields, the other principals gathered at the house of a village elder, a cosmetics salesman named Guyashuddin Ahmed, to discuss the case. **********Standing almost unnoticed among them, in the shadows by a postered bed, was Mrs. Ali, a slight woman of 18 with delicate features, wearing a faded red-print sari. The Young Woman's Tale **********A visitor asked for her side of the story. **********''I ran away because my husband couldn't provide for me,'' said Mrs. Ali, the daughter of a subsistence farm laborer. ''I hardly even know the man.'' **********''My godmother persuaded me to do it,'' she said without expression. ''I didn't want to go. The boy talked me into it. He said he would take the responsibility. He took me by force. He beat his wife and blood was coming from her mouth and nose.'' **********Indeed, Mr. Jalil had recently received a warning from a session of the salish for having beaten his wife, and Mr. Tamizuddin had taken her away from him. **********From behind a curtained doorway across the room came a woman's low voice: ''Don't believe her. She's a loose woman. She is lying.'' 'She Played Around' **********''I am not,'' said Mrs. Ali just as quietly. ''I had work in a garment factory.'' **********''She didn't work,'' said the voice from behind the curtain. ''She played around. She's a slut. Someone said, 'Come with me,' and she went.'' **********''It's not true,'' the young woman said, cracking her knuckles as she spoke. ''He forced me to go with him.'' **********''Don't believe her,'' said the voice. ''These are the stories she prepared for the salish.'' **********Subhan Sardir, a member of the salish, removed his glasses in a gesture that brought silence to the room. **********''We may or we may not whip them,'' he said of the offending couple. ''But we will probably force them to marry.'' 'Who Will Feed You?' **********''Will you marry him?'' he said, turning on Mrs. Ali. ''You won't? You won't go?'' ''I won't,'' she said. ''How will you eat, all alone in the world?'' he asked. ''Who will feed you?'' ''I'll find some way,'' she said. ''You ran away with that boy and now you refuse to marry him,'' said Mr. Sardir, brandishing a large flashlight and raising his voice. ''You know me. I'll bet you never got a real whipping from your father. I'll show you what a real whipping is.'' He turned to the visitor. ''She'll accept,'' he said. ''She must accept. She has put the whole village to shame and it is our obligation under Islamic law to rectify that shame. We will force her to marry him, and force him to marry her.'' **********At that point Mrs. Ali's husband, the rickshaw driver, entered the room. A soft-spoken man of 25, he looked everywhere but at his wife. 'A Very Simple Girl' **********''Will you take her back?'' Mr. Sardir asked him. ''No,'' said Mr. Ali quietly. ''I feel sorry for her,'' Mr. Sardir said. ''She's a very simple girl and she was deceived by fancy words. But we are doing what we must do.'' **********''She is a fallen woman now and nobody else will marry her,'' he said. ''It's the boy's responsibility now to take her as his wife and support her. Otherwise she will starve.'' Mrs. Ali remained standing in the shadow by the bedpost, one bare foot crossed slightly over the other. Both Are Flogged **********When the salish convened again, the village elders tried to persuade the accused man and woman to get married but they declined. **********Mr. Jalil and Mrs. Ali were flogged in public, he 30 times and she 20 times. Mr. Jalil was fined as well. **********''I want my wife back,'' he told the salish. But his father-in law, Mr. Tamizuddin, said his daughter would never go back to such a man. **********Mrs. Ali said, ''I'll work as a maid servant to fend for myself and will never marry again.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/05/busin.body_text: **********ESOP's Edge Up **********More employees than ever are joining ESOP's, or employee stock ownership plans. This year, about 8.6 million workers will participate in ESOP's, says Corey Rosen, executive director of the National Cener for Employee Ownership in Oakland, Calif. **********One reason for the rise, Mr. Rosen says, is better ESOP financing. **********A provision in the new tax code makes it easier for bankers to bundle and market the loans sometimes made to ESOP's for stock purchases: Investors in these debt instruments may now deduct 50 percent of the interest income they collect. **********With more investors interested, the loans -and ESOP's - will get larger, Mr. Rosen says. Recently, the management of the Hospital Corporation of America proposed the largest ESOP yet, a $1.8 billion transaction involving 20,000 employees. **********Such big ESOP's could flex considerable muscle. Mr. Rosen pointed to the proposed buyout by the pilots' union of United Airlines as an example. That proposal set off a chain of events that forced Allegis, United's parent, to announce it would sell its hotels and rental car businesses. In the words of Mr. Rosen, soon other employees in ESOP's may be saying, ''If you don't do what we want, we'll buy you.' ''  Swaps at Thrift Units? **********Property foreclosures are still rising. In the first quarter, the Federal National Mortgage Association reported 8,315 residential and commercial foreclosures, 1,000 more than a year ago. So savings and loan associations, which grant many real-estate loans, may be ready for a version of the debt-for-equity swaps sometimes used by large banks to settle foreign debts, says William A. Kilpatrick, president of Green Mountain United Financial Operations, a real estate investment firm in Littleton, Colo. **********In a typical swap, a thrift unit would trade a foreclosed commercial building or apartment house for shares of a company looking to buy income-producing property at a discount. This way, liabilities are turned into assets on a thrift unit's balance sheets, said Mr. Kilpatrick, adding that ''at least 20,000 to 25,000 properties are available for this kind of swap.'' **********But not every thrift unit will use swaps. ''There are regulatory restraints,'' said Brian Smith of the United States League of Savings Institutions in Washington. Though swaps could work under certain circumstances, he says, Federally insured thrift units, for example, cannot own stock directly.  The Ultimate Export **********Because 20 percent of Japan's population will be over age 65 by the year 2000, Japan, the world's largest exporter, is considering a new export: retirees. **********The ''Silver Colonies'' under consideration at the Ministry of International Trade and Industry would help retirees achieve a ''comfortable, soul-enriching'' life in countries like Australia, Spain or possibly the United States - places where property is less expensive and the cost of living is lower than in Japan. **********But there may be problems, says Ruri Kawashima at the Asia Society in New York. Even though 16 percent of 50-year-olds who responded to a M.I.T.I. survey in Japan said they would consider living in a Silver Colony, the details of medical care and housing have yet to be worked out. And ''it would require a government-to-government agreement'' to overcome such obstacles as immigration laws, she said. **********At any rate, construction for the colonies is not scheduled to begin until 1990, said Ms. Kawashima, and by then, as the obstacles become clearer, ''enthusiasm may cool.''  One 'Olympic' Only **********With the Olympic Games approaching, the U.S. Olympic Committee will be more aggressive about protecting its exclusive right to the word ''Olympic.'' **********''Any use of the name is illegal,'' said George Miller, executive director of the U.S.O.C. in Denver. Indeed, the Supreme Court backed up this view a week ago with a ruling against the five-year-old San Francisco-based ''Gay Olympics.'' **********Disputes are likely. Thousands of American businesses have ''Olympic'' in their names - including more than 60 in New York City alone. **********''We can't go after them all,'' acknowledged Mr. Miller. The main targets, he says, will be athletic contests and businesses that link themselves to the games and thus affect the U.S.O.C.'s ability to merchandise goods, sell sponsorships and raise money. Mr. Miller points out that the Greek airline, Olympic Airways, is outside the committee's jurisdiction.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/18/busin.body_text: **********Home Shopping Network Inc. said today that it planned a major reorganization that would make it a diversified holding company. Home Shopping's chairman, Roy M. Speer, said the company's main business would be the retailing of consumer products and services, ''as well as many other diversified products and services through television, direct mail and telemarketing media.'' **********Home Shopping's stock, which has been riding a Wall Street roller coaster, was down 87.5 cents today, to $14.125, on the American Stock Exchange. **********The company, founded in 1985, enjoyed phenomenal early growth, but its stock has plunged from a high of $47 this year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/01/busin.body_text: **********ROGERS & COWAN, a major American public relations firm that specializes in show business promotions, has been acquired by Shandwick P.L.C., Britain's largest public relations operation, which bought two other American companies in December. **********Now, Shandwick is the world's largest independent public relations firm and third largest among all such companies, after Burson Marsteller, a subsidiary of Young & Rubicam, and Hill & Knowlton, a subsidiary of the JWT Group, according to Rogers & Cowan. **********The first payment to Rogers & Cowan will be $3.5 million, some of which will go to the five shareholders as the first payment for the agency and the rest to be used as working capital. The total payment, based on company performance, could come to as much as $15 million over the next four years. **********Rogers & Cowan will continue to operate under that name, and its founders Henry J. Rogers, 72 years old, and Warren J. Cowan, 65, have both signed long-term contracts, the company said. **********The company, which they founded in 1950, has offices in Los Angeles and the nearby Burbank Studios, New York, London and Washington. Mr. Rogers and Mr. Cowan are the major stockholders. The other three are Richard W. Taylor, president, corporate division; Paul Bloch, president, music division, and Margaret Gardner, president, international division. **********Their organization ended 1986 with $10.6 million in fee income and 164 employees. Adding its assets to Shandwick's will result in a total of $34 million in fee income and a work force of 550. **********Rogers & Cowan's activities are about half for the entertainment world and half general public relations, including corporate work and product publicity. **********The entertainment half includes the traditional publicity work for celebrities and their creative output. And the Burbank Studio office, which is closer to the actual scene of movie production than the Los Angeles headquarters, concentrates on product placement, which means arranging to get clients' brand-name products visibly into movies. **********On the corporate side Rogers & Cowan serves such giants as Ford, A.T.& T., Polaroid and Ralston Purina. And its talent pool includes Paul Newman, Sylvester Stallone, Ann-Margret, Elton John, Bruce Willis, Cybill Shepherd and a cast of thousands. **********In December, Shandwick, a publicly held company, in its first North American incursion, acquired Henry J. Kaufman & Associates in Washington and Rand Public Relations in New York.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/27/busin.body_text: **********The European Community presented a plan today to help its depressed agricultural markets, but several of the member countries complained that it preserved the community's farm subsidies, delegates said. **********The proposal called for large farm producers to agree on fixed export prices for sugar, cereal and dairy products as a first step toward global reform in farm trade. However, the 12-nation group firmly rejected an American campaign to eliminate agricultural subsidies within 10 years. **********Delegates said that only the Nordic countries had strongly endorsed the community's plan. Many nations said it lacked clarity and did not spell out the degree of free competition envisioned or a time frame for reform. **********Michael Samuels, the United States trade ambassador, said his delegation was disappointed in the proposal, which seemed to extend the community's ''highly managed'' agricultural system, delegates said. **********In a statement issued in Washington, Richard E. Lyng, the American Agriculture Secretary, and Clayton K. Yeutter, the trade representative, also expressed disappointment. **********The American statement said the community's plan proposes to increase farm protectionism by raising new barriers to American exports of soybeans and corn gluten feed, a byproduct of corn milling, to Europe.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/09/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Cannon Merger With Melia Set
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/09/busin.body_text: **********The Cannon Group Inc. said today that it would merge with Melia International N.V., a hotel and tourist company in Amsterdam that is partly owned by the film maker's European investor. **********The debt-laden company disclosed no financial details of the proposal, made in London by executives of the company. A company spokesman in New **********York, Bernard J. Kilkelly, said the executives were unavailable. **********''None of the details have been worked out,'' Mr. Kilkelly said. But the deal was disclosed, he said, because ''the company felt a need to show that the company is moving forward.'' **********Cannon, based in Los Angeles, also elected to its board four new European directors, including Bob Hankes-Drielsma, a Melia director. The others are directors of Interpart S.A. of Luxembourg, Cannon's European investor. Since June, Interpart has advanced Cannon money for operating needs and to meet interest payments on its debt. In November, Cannon owed $300 million to banks and $280 million to note holders. **********Under the proposal, Cannon and Melia would each contribute all of their operations to new company called the Cannon-Melia Group. Melia's assets could not be determined. **********Cannon said it would become the senior company in the new operation but provided no further details.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/15/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Gates-Learjet Owners Set Key Appointments
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/15/busin.body_text: **********The new owners of the Gates-Learjet Corporation have moved swiftly to quell uncertainty at the financially troubled company, which has been battered since 1984 by losses, a management shake-up and three previous buyout attempts. **********The first moves by Integrated Acquisition Inc. of New York, which bought a 64.8 percent interest in Learjet for $56.8 million from the Gates Corporation last week, were to name executives to fill three critical jobs at the company and begin nurturing ''participatory management.'' One of the managers' first jobs is to staff a strategy committee to plot the company's future course. **********James B. Taylor, who was recruited as president and chief executive in 1985 to pull Learjet out of its nose dive, was named chairman and chief executive. As chairman he succeeds Charles C. Gates, who is yielding his post at Learjet now that Gates has sold its stake in the company. A successor as president is expected to be named later. **********After the three buyout attempts that eventually fell apart, ''the company had been drifting,'' said Robert J. Edgreen, Integrated's president. Integrated has acquired eight other companies since 1981, and its practice has been to keep management intact, he said. **********Mr. Taylor, a former Navy fighter pilot, has already waged a painful two-year effort to revive Learjet, hurt by a six-year slump in business-jet sales. A partial victory came in the June 30 quarter, when Learjet earned its first operating profit since 1984 on $63.8 million in revenues. The results follow Mr. Taylor's cost-cutting program that pared the company's work force to 2,300 from 3,300, slashed inventory and renegotiated contracts with suppliers and customers. He also began an aerospace division, which already had $30 million in backlogged orders last year in its role as a subcontractor to prime military contractors. **********Whether Mr. Taylor, who is 65 years old, plans to stay for the longer skirmish to return Learjet to industry prominence is not clear. On Monday, he declined to comment on his plans for the company. **********Integrated, however, has pledged that Learjet will remain in the aircraft business and has approved production of a new business jet, the first for the company since 1982. **********Despite Mr. Taylor's staying on, there is turbulence at the company. Three other Learjet executives resigned last Thursday in a clash over the company's post-merger direction. The resignations were by mutual agreement, Mr. Edgreen said. **********For Mr. Taylor, the changes at Learjet come after 40 years in aviation that began on Grumman Aircraft's production line. Along the way, Mr. Taylor has worked as a Pan Am executive, helped pioneer the introduction of Cessna's Citation business jet and served as chairman of Canadair Inc., the marketing aim for the Challenger business jet.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/08/world.main_headline: Japanese Leader Urges U.S. to Reduce Deficit
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/08/world.print_headline: Japanese Leader Urges U.S. to Reduce Deficit
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/08/world.body_text: **********Noboru Takeshita, Japan's new Prime Minister, urged the Reagan Administration and Congress today to move quickly to reduce the United States budget deficit. **********Speaking at his first news conference as the Japanese leader, Mr. Takeshita linked the American deficit with the recent turbulence in the currency exchange and stock markets. **********He also said that Japan would continue to intervene in the currency market, together with other countries, to prevent the yen from rapidly gaining strength against the dollar. Mr. Takeshita's comments meant that the new Government would be no different from the previous one in worrying about the effects of the strengthening yen on Japan's exports. Again and again, Japanese leaders in recent days have put primary blame for the recent world economic turmoil on the United States for failing to deal with its twin deficits - budget and trade. Projecting a Different Style **********Much of the attention here has been focused on the thus-far unsuccessful negotiations between the Administration and Congress to find specific measures to cut the budget deficit. At his news conference, Mr. Takeshita left little doubt that, as suspected, he would be quite different in style from his predecessor, Yasuhiro Nakasone. His substantive comments today were guarded and often laced with homilies. His language was characteristically neutral, making even critical remarks seem bland. **********For example, many Japanese leaders, including Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa, have been fairly blunt in attacking the United States for not coming to grips with its economic problems. Mr. Takeshita, who was elected by Parliament on Friday, suggested today that he felt the same way, but he never said so explicitly. **********The closest he came was an observation that he was ''looking forward to seeing that an agreement between the United States Government and the Congress is reached soon on reducing the budget deficit.'' **********In the last week, the dollar has set new record lows against the yen almost every day despite the Bank of Japan's massive purchases of dollars in a vain attempt to stop the slide. **********At the close of trading here on Friday, the dollar stood at 135.50 yen, a slight improvement from an all-time low of 134.40 reached earlier in the day. It means that the dollar is worth little more than half what it was two and a half years ago. **********For Japanese, their soaring currency has been unremitting bad news, for it makes their products significantly more expensive abroad. **********Earlier this year, corporate profits tumbled as Japanese businesses deferred price increases to keep their exports competitive against overseas competitors. At the same time, unemployment rose, especially in manufacturing industries, where the strong yen took its most severe toll. Bad Times May Return **********After the yen stabilized over the last few months, there were signs of economic recovery. But with some currency dealers and economists predicting that the dollar will soon drop to 130 yen, Japanese worry that bad times will return. **********Ironically, it was Mr. Takeshita who presided over the most precipitous slides in the dollar's value last year and the year before. He was the Finance Minister at the so-called Plaza accord of September 1985, when the major industrialized countries agreed to let the dollar find a significantly lower level. **********Another agreement reached last February, known as the Louvre accord, set ranges for the dollar against other currencies, which to the Japanese implied somewhere around 140 yen. Mr. Takeshita said today that Japan would continue to abide by that agreement, and would intervene in the exchange markets to bolster the dollar. **********''How much and when is a matter that I will decline to tell you,'' he said. ''The influence of intervention into the market is great only when we keep these things secret.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/03/busin.body_text: **********A House of Representatives committee has recommended sweeping changes in the nation's banking laws, criticizing present laws that bar banks from the securities business and other industries as anti-competitive and potentially dangerous to their financial soundness. **********The House Government Operations Committee, in a report adopted Tuesday and released today, recommended changes that would allow federally insured banks and thrift institutions to operate as part of corporations that also owned securities or non-bank financial firms. **********The report, which did not propose specific legislation, comes as Congress prepares to debate bills revising Federal banking laws. **********The report is based on a study by the panel's Subcommittee on Commerce, Consumer and Monetary Affairs, whose chairman, Representative Doug Barnard, Democrat of Georgia, is a member of the House Banking Committee. **********Federal laws prohibit banks from owning or being owned by a company that is not related to banking and ban most banks from being affiliated with securities firms. Major banks have argued for years that the Government should ease the restrictions because of the increasing competition from giant securities houses and other non-bank corporations for the banks' traditional customers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/05/world.main_headline: U.S. Regrets Death of Fisherman in Gulf
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/05/world.print_headline: U.S. Regrets Death of Fisherman in Gulf
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/05/world.body_text: **********The State Department expressed regret today that an Indian fisherman was killed when a United States Navy frigate opened fire on three Arab fishing boats in the Persian Gulf. **********The statement, read by Charles E. Redman, the department spokesman, did not say whether the United States was at fault or made a mistake in the incident, which occurred Sunday evening. **********''The United States regrets any loss of life, regardless of the circumstances,'' the statement said. ''We extend our regrets to the Indian Government and our condolences to the family of the Indian casualty.'' **********The United States also expressed its regret to the United Arab Emirates, the statement added. The fisherman had been aboard an Emirates boat. Warning Shots Reported **********The fisherman, Bekwan Kangee, of Gujarat, India, died after a machine gun bullet hit him in the head as the three boats were returning to the Emirates from a day of fishing. **********The Pentagon said in a statement on Monday that the guided-missile frigate Carr had fired warning shots at one of three suspected Iranian speedboats that appeared to make a high-speed ''hostile run'' at the American tanker Patriot, which the Carr was escorting. **********Asked if the Navy frigate had opened fire believing the fishing boats were Iranian speedboats, Mr. Redman said: ''I just don't have the details. You'll have to talk to the Pentagon.'' **********The Defense Department, in a statement issued later, said the incident was still under investigation. ''The details of the shooting incident are still ambiguous,'' it said.  Iraq Attacks Iran Sites **********MANAMA, Bahrain, Nov. 4 (AP) -Iraq said its warplanes bombed Iran's main oil export terminal today, raided oil sites on the mainland and attacked four tankers in its enemy's coastal waters. Iraq admitted losing one plane. **********The attacks came as Iran marked the eighth anniversary of the seizure of the United States Embassy in Teheran, with huge street demonstrations and renewed demands for a withdrawal of American warships from the region. **********Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani, the Speaker of the Iranian Parliament, called for a weeklong mobilization to ''confront American aggression.'' Iran said millions of people had marched and chanted, ''Death to America!'' **********Iraq said its planes made ''destructive hits'' in bombing the western jetty of the Kharg Island oil terminal.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/05/world.body_text: **********When President Reagan arrives here Sunday for a two-day visit he will find his host, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, more careworn than the last time Mr. Reagan was in Canada. **********That was two years ago, when the two men held hands and sang ''When Irish Eyes Are Smiling'' from a stage in Quebec City. Mr. Mulroney, then six months into his first term as Prime Minister, was riding the wave of the biggest election victory in Canada's history, a landslide in which his Conservatives had swamped the Liberals, winning 211 parliamentary seats to 40. **********Although lacking the cosmopolitan wit of the former Prime Minister, Pierre Elliott Trudeau, a Liberal, Mr. Mulroney, a former corporate executive who speaks French as well as English, had presented himself as well equipped to manage Canada's complex problems of language, regional economic disparities and a sense of nationhood fraught by proximity to the United States. **********But now, the Prime Minister, his Cabinet shaken by political scandals and by popular doubts about his policies, including a bid to negotiate a free-trade agreement with the United States that will be at the center of the talks with Mr. Reagan, finds himself hitting depths in the public-opinion polls that Mr. Trudeau never reached. 'This Is a Bruising Business' **********A poll this week by The Globe and Mail, Toronto, gave Mr. Mulroney a 23 percent approval rating, down from 70 percent in November 1984, and insiders in the Conservative Party have begun to worry privately that he cannot win another election. **********If he fails, it will be the third successive time in 50 years that the Conservatives have been ousted from office, each time by the Liberals, after a single parliamentary term. **********''This is a serious, bruising business,'' the Prime Minister, 47 years old, said this week in a two-hour interview with a group of American reporters. He added, ''We've been to the mountaintop, and now we're coming through a valley, and obviously there are moments that test your resolve, your character and your confidence.'' **********Whether Mr. Mulroney can recover before the next election, probably in 1989, is likely to depend in large measure on his success in negotiating a trade agreement with the United States. He said in the interview that an agreement lifting all tariff and nontariff barriers on the $129 billion in annual trade was ''a win-win situation'' for both nations. Fear for Canadian Institutions **********But many Canadians fear that tens of thousands of jobs here could be lost as cheaper American products compete equally with Canadian goods. **********Recent statements by United States trade officials have stirred concern that the United States could use a free-trade pact to mount a broad attack on the subsidies and other forms of Government aid that have kept many Canadian industries going. **********More than that, some Canadians believe many of the country's distinctive institutions are at stake, like its broadcasting networks, its ''cultural'' industries and its national medical care and welfare systems. **********Mr. Mulroney has said that Canada is ''not a shrinking violet of a country'' that could lose its independence because of a trade pact. But even some of his advisers feel that he has pledged too much on his relationship with the United States and that a more wary approach to Washington, of the kind often adopted by Mr. Trudeau, might be politically advantageous. 'I Like Ronald Reagan' **********In his personal relationship with Mr. Reagan, Mr. Mulroney has held to attitudes that many Canadians consider unbecoming. **********''My position is well known and hasn't changed,'' the Prime Minister said in the interview. ''I like Ronald Reagan, I admire many of the things that he's set out to do and accomplish. He's a straightforward, honest, honorable man who has done a great deal for the United States and the Western alliance and a great deal for Canada.'' **********Mr. Mulroney's sharp decline in popularity perplexes some political analysts here. He has had a series of Cabinet embarrassments, most recently involving a junior minister from Quebec who was dismissed in January amid a multimillion-dollar land scandal. No Worse Than Trudeau **********But the seven ministers who have been forced out or resigned because of conflicts of interest, allegations of incompetence or poor judgement is no worse than Mr. Trudeau experienced at a time when he was still relatively popular, Mr. Mulroney points out. **********Mr. Mulroney's defenders say that under his leadership Canada has progressed on key fronts. Unemployment is down two percentage points, to 9.5 percent. And Canada has one of the West's highest rates of economic growth, more than 3 percent last year, a positive trade balance and a decline in the large Trudeau budget deficits. **********The Prime Minister has produced Government studies suggesting that a trade agreement with Washington could create 500,000 new jobs and ease unemployment rates of close to 20 percent in areas of the Maritime provinces, Quebec and British Columbia. **********In the interview, Mr. Mulroney said he was confident that Canadians would eventually ''start adding all this up,'' with a resulting climb in his standing and that of his party. **********Referring to the next election, he said, ''If you're looking for the Prime Minister of Canada in a couple of years, you're going to be looking for me.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/19/world.main_headline: India Widow's Death at Pyre Creates a Shrine
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/19/world.print_headline: India Widow's Death at Pyre Creates a Shrine
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/19/world.body_text: **********Early this month, grief-stricken villagers gathered here for the funeral of a young man from a prominent local family who had died suddenly, apparently of a ruptured appendix. The cremation ceremony was planned according to Hindu traditions. **********But soon another ancient tradition came to be invoked when the 24-year-old man's distraught widow placed herself - or was placed - on the funeral pyre. Villagers say she died in the flames, chanting a mantra pledging loyalty to her husband of eight months. **********It was a sati, or immolation by a widow, the first in many years. The act was denounced by the authorities, newspapers and women's groups, reviving a debate on why superstitions survive even among the educated and well-off. **********But here in the plains of Rajasthan, home of India's old princely states and the relatively prosperous and well-educated Rajput warrior caste, the 20-year-old widow, Roop Kunwar, has became a saint and her cremation site a shrine. **********''The loss has made me sad,'' said her father, Bal Singh Rathore. ''But there is grandeur associated with sati and my family's name will be famous all over. Just as we bathe in water, she bathed in fire. She has taken her husband with her. They both live.'' **********By truck, bus and camel cart, at least 10,000 villagers each day have descended on Deorala to pay their respects and make offerings. Today, more than 100,000 jammed the area for the traditional final ceremony for a sati, at which the flames, kept alive since Sept. 4, were doused with milk. One of Roop Kunwar's silver and scarlet shawls was draped over the ashes. **********''Sati is not possible for all women, only those who are very blessed,'' said Ratan Kunwar, a 58-year-old mother of two from a nearby village, in a typical comment. ''I have come here for the blessings of this holy place.'' Police Arrive Too Late **********Outlawed since 1829, sati occurs now in India only once or twice in a decade, almost always in the Rajput community. Usually, word gets out in advance, and the police arrive to prevent it. In Deorala, the police arrived late, prompting women's groups to question their willingness to trample on local sensitivities. **********''The status of women has been set back by this event,'' said Suman Krishan Kant, secretary of the Women's Grievances Council in New Delhi. ''Given the attitudes of men and other social factors, the condition of women in India is poor as it is. The families and officials who didn't stop this should be punished.'' **********In fact, under pressure from women's groups, state authorities did act belatedly Tuesday to outlaw any attempt to ''glorify'' the immolation. The police have also arrested the dead man's 16-year-old brother for abetting a suicide, and officials say they will soon arrest his father as well. **********But no one tried to prevent the closing ceremony this morning or stop anyone from attending. Hours afterward, women and their daughters continued to throng the area as young men in brightly colored turbans, holding their swords aloft, circled the cremation site and shouted, ''Victory to the sati.'' Makeshift Shops Spring Up **********Nearby, in a carnival atmosphere, dozens of makeshift shops had sprung up, and hawkers were selling ice cream, trinkets and the most popular souvenir of the day: a montage photograph of Roop Kunwar smiling sweetly over the body of her husband. **********By local standards, the Rajput family thrust into prominence by the events of Deorala is hardly poor or illiterate. Roop Kunwar had passed her examinations after 10 years of school, and her husband, Maal Singh, a high school graduate, was looking for a clerical job. **********Like most Indians, they had a marriage arranged by the family. At the ceremony last January, he wore a gray suit and tie and her face was draped with gold jewelry. The room in their village house here was viewed all week as a shrine by visiting pilgrims. In the corner was a color television set. **********Each day, the couple's relatives have held prayers near the cremation site and have shared with villagers their view that their children have escaped the Hindu cycle of birth and rebirth and gone to heaven. Legends Start to Grow **********Details about how the sati occurred have become a matter of uncertainty and contradiction, with the story changing as the police press their inquiry. Inevitably, myths and legends have also grown up, to the effect that Roop Kunwar has sent messages from heaven and helped to cure pilgrims of diseases or mental disorders. **********Initial accounts were that Maal Singh's father and brother helped Roop Kunwar. Now the father denies he was even present at the ceremony. There have been rumors in Jaipur, the nearby capital of Rajasthan, that she might have been drugged or pressed into it. **********Others note that the cremation occurred only hours after her husband's sudden death, which followed assurances by doctors that he would recover. In this view, the stunned young bride, a devout woman who read from Hindu scriptures every day, may have been susceptible to emotional pressure. **********Among the villagers here, the word was that the family tried to dissuade her, but that she seemed determined and possessed with the spirit of God. Many said that trying to stop her would have invited an evil curse. **********''No doubt this is a bad thing in this modern age,'' said Madan Lal Gupta, a village schoolteacher. ''But she herself was willing to do this act. Nobody forced her. Now there may be some miracles, and many big good things may come to us.'' **********Still others note that the life of a widow in the Rajput community is a bleak one. By custom, widows may not remarry and must often live in seclusion, unable to eat meat or any sweets or enter into family festivities. In some cases, they have to sleep on the floor in the home of their in-laws. The Stuff of Legends **********The concept of sati is said to have arisen in prehistoric times. According to legend, Sati was a wife of the Hindu god Shiva who killed herself because her father had insulted her husband. The act of immolation was first mentioned in the ancient Hindu epics, and the earliest historic case was recorded 2,300 years ago by invading Greeks. **********Among the ancient beliefs that sati may have reflected were the idea of a wife as a husband's possession, and the notion that a man could take his possessions to the next world if they were burned along with him. The idea of a family resenting the widow of a lost loved one is also very old. **********Historians agree that the practice became widespread in the last 800 years after the beginning of brutal invasions by Moslem warriors. In this period, Rajasthan was a place of feudal warlords whose castles and forts still dot the rocky landscape. **********It was not uncommon then for entire families of menfolk to be wiped out in battle. Rather than submit or be swept off by conquerors, women killed themselves. Sati thus became associated with the upper feudal classes. **********Scholars say there are many recorded instances of women being drugged, tied to the burning pyre, held down by long poles or otherwise forced to commit sati - instances somewhat at variance with the romantic legend of self-sacrifice. Still, in Rajasthan the stories of mass suicides and immolations of thousands of women following great battles remain the stuff of legend and poetry. 'Drilled From Childhood' **********''In every Rajput family, it is something drilled into you from earliest childhood,'' said Sushil Kumari, a feminist who is a relative of the royal family of Jodhpur. ''Your husband is supposed to be a sort of godlike figure, and sati is the ultimate achievement for a girl. You're almost hypnotized into thinking this thing.'' **********Across Rajasthan are hundreds of shrines to satis, and festivals at these sites are common. Here in Deorala three such shrines commemorate immolations of 70 and 150 years ago. Villagers proudly said that a new shrine would be built soon. **********''You cannot say when a woman will feel this way,'' said Bhavar Singh Shekhawat, a 30-year-old Rajput landowner. ''People tried to prevent her, but she was very strong. She had faith. The people have come here to honor that faith.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/10/busin.body_text: **********The semiconductor industry's leading indicator fell for the fourth consecutive month, but shipments reached their highest point in three years for manufacturers based in the United States, Europe and Japan, a trade group reported today. The Semiconductor Industry **********Association, based in Cupertino, Calif., reported a book-to-bill ratio of 1.04 for the three-month period ended in September, down from revised figures of 1.06 for August and 1.13 for July. The book-to-bill compares orders to shipments. A ratio of 1.04 indicates that for every $100 worth of product shipped, $104 was ordered. **********At $965.7 million, three-month orders for September were up 2.3 percent from August's $943.7 million. Three-month average shipments for September totaled $930.2 million. Shipments for the month of September came to $1.05 billion, up 19 percent from $885.2 million in August and the highest since September 1983. Total chip shipments to the **********United States market during the third quarter of 1987 are estimated to be $2.79 billion, 10 percent higher than in the second quarter of 1987 and 26.4 percent above those of the comparable quarter last year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/24/world.print_headline: IRAN-CONTRA HEARINGS; Contra Message Confirmations Go Awry
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/24/world.body_text: **********Camille Roman, a social worker from Queens, did not believe Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North when he testified before the Iran-contra panel last week. So she sent a telegram of support to Senator Daniel K. Inouye. **********She was more than a little annoyed when Western Union informed her in a confirmation message that her wire had been delivered not to the senator, but to Colonel North. **********An embarrassed Western Union acknowledged today that it had made several such mistakes July 14. Donn Dutcher, a spokesman for Western Union, insisted, however, that the mistakes affected only the confirmation messages. Although confirmations informed senders that the telegrams had been sent to the wrong recipients, the telegrams themselves actually went to the addressees. **********Mr. Dutcher said the mistaken confirmations were caused by faulty computer programming. **********The hearings have been a boon to Western Union, which has been receiving thousands of telegrams through its office on Capitol Hill, a huge number of them addressed to Colonel North. **********Mrs. Roman said that her telegram was sent July 15 and that the confirmation came July 19.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/10/busin.print_headline: CHRYSLER IS BUYING AMERICAN MOTORS; COST IS $1.5 BILLION
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/10/busin.body_text: **********The Chrysler Corporation said today that it had agreed to acquire the American Motors Corporation for about $1.5 billion. **********American Motors is a tiny company by auto industry standards, and it has been struggling to survive. But its outlook is improving and it could increase Chrysler's share of the market by a few important percentage points. **********Lee A. Iacocca, Chrysler's chairman, said in a statement, ''It'll strengthen both of us in what's already become a tough market.'' Modern Plant Involved **********The transaction would give Chrysler the highly profitable Jeep vehicles to broaden its model lineup, as well as A.M.C's modern assembly plant in Bramalea, Ontario, and 1,400 additional dealers. **********Chrysler announced that it had agreed to buy the 46 percent of American Motors held by Renault, the French Government-owned car company that bought into American Motors eight years ago. With that, automotive analysts said, the takeover is assured. Chrysler will also offer to buy up the remaining shares from the public. Little of the payment may be in cash. **********''It's a great deal for all three companies involved,'' said Jack V. Kirnan, an analyst with the Wall Street firm of Kidder, Peabody & Company. ''Jeep is a major prize.'' Remarkable Comeback **********The merger represents a milestone in the remarkable comeback by Chrysler, which was saved from bankruptcy with the assistance of Government-backed loans in the late 1970's. **********Since then, improved sales of a succession of new car models, including the popular mini-van, returned the company to prosperity and allowed it to repay the last of the Government-backed loans in 1983. Last year Chrysler earned $1.4 billion, while American Motors lost $91.3 million. **********With the merger of the two smallest of the four American-based auto manufacturers, Chrysler demonstrates a new confidence in reaching for a bigger presence in the car market. It also gets a continuing relationship with Renault, one of Europe's largest auto companies. **********Based on last year's results, the acquisition would raise Chrysler's share of the combined car and light-truck market in this country to 13.4 percent from 11.7 percent, although leaving it well behind the Ford Motor Company, which had 21.2 percent, and the General Motors Corporation at 38.5 percent. But Chrysler's share could be somewhat bigger than 13.4 percent if the expected improvement at American Motors is realized. **********In the financial community, analysts said that Chrysler would be gaining important assets, such as Jeep and the dealer network, at a modest price. **********Jeeps fetch as much at $20,000 for the top models, providing high profit margins. **********Jeep alone is worth more than $850 million, according to Ann C. Knight, an analyst with Paine Webber, the brokerage house. American Motors' new Ontario plant, which incorporates modern technology, is worth $650 million, she said. **********Other analysts have estimated that it would cost Chrysler about $1.2 billion to design competitors for Jeep and prepare a plant to produce the vehicles, which would still lack the well-known Jeep brand name. **********The announcement comes after months of conjecture that Chrysler, which is assembling one of its car lines at A.M.C.'s Kenosha, Wis., plant, would make an offer for the company, which endured heavy losses for years, causing a drain on Renault. **********Chrysler and American Motors have a long history of cooperation, and the ties between the two have grown closer in recent years. All Jeeps and other A.M.C. four-wheel-drive vehicles use gearboxes made by a Chrysler division, and last year the two companies agreed to assemble some of Chrysler's older rear-wheel-drive cars in the Kenosha plant. **********Renault, with financial problems of its own, had indicated a willingness in recent months to discuss a sale of A.M.C., but such talks were apparently disrupted by the assassination of Georges Besse, the head of Renault, in Paris last November. **********Bennett E. Bidwell, vice chairman of Chrysler, said today that ''any opportunity we had to do anything came to a grinding halt when Georges Besse was murdered.'' Mr. Besse's replacement, Raymond Levy, only recently resumed the discussions, Mr. Bidwell said. ''The deal came together this weekend, and we signed it this morning,'' he added. **********The United Automobile Workers called the merger ''a good match that potentially points the way to a more secure future for workers at both companies.'' The union, which had been in negotiations over work rule concessions at the Kenosha plant, said it would break off the talks for 30 days to allow the situation to clarify. **********Chrysler will give Renault $200 million in 10-year notes bearing 8 percent interest and other payments ranging from zero to $350 million based on A.M.C.'s future performance. In addition, Chrysler will assume $767 million of A.M.C.'s debt and will pay $35 million for a half interest in the American Motors Financial Corporation. **********Chrysler will also offer Chrysler stock valued at $4 for each American Motors share in public hands. Chrysler officials estimated that would be worth $522 million. **********American Motors stock closed at $4.25 a share, up 75 cents, in today's trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The premium above the $4 offering price suggested to some analysts that Chrysler was in the market aggressively buying up stock, perhaps to give it a clear-cut majority when combined with the 46 percent Renault stake. **********Chrysler officials said they plan to complete the takeover in June. **********Analysts said Chrysler does not need all the plants A.M.C. operates, and they suggested that at least one of its four assembly plants would be sold or closed. **********Chrysler and American Motors have been discussing producing Chrysler's subcompact Omni and Horizon models at Kenosha, which has been underutilized because of the collapse in demand for A.M.C's own subcompact car, the Alliance. However, those talks have been held up by Chrysler's insistence that it has to cut labor costs if it is to make such low-priced models profitably. **********Mr. Bidwell said today that the company would probably have to decide whether to make the cars at Kenosha before taking over American Motors. The Belvidere, Ill., plant was shut recently for conversion to production of a higher-profit car. **********Chrysler has tried to keep its costs under control since escaping from the specter of bankruptcy. But two of A.M.C.'s assembly plants - the Kenosha facility and the Jeep plant in Toledo - date from the turn of the century and have a history of high costs and poor labor relations. **********The Standard & Poor's Corporation said that it was studying Chrysler's credit standing and that a downgrade in ratings was likely as a result of the implications of the A.M.C. acquisition. Including unfunded pension obligations and legal contingencies, largely as a result of rollover accidents in Jeeps, Chrysler is paying a total of $2 billion for American Motors, the rating company said. **********Mr. Iacocca said Chrysler would continue to distribute Renault cars in North America through the A.M.C. dealer network and would work with the French company to develop new products. **********American Motors recently introduced a compact sedan from Renault, the Medallion. It has also planned to introduce a mid-size car, the Premier. Company officials had said this broader product line would give it better prospects for profitability.  OTHER MERGER PLANS SWEEP ECONOMY **********USAir and Piedmont airlines  agreed to merge. **********Resorts International ac cepted an offer from Donald  Trump, and Caesers World re- ceived a takeover bid. **********Harper & Row received a  takeover bid out of the blue. **********Supermarkets General,  owner of Pathmark, also re ceived an unsolicited offer. **********First Boston plans to buy  Allegheny International, which  makes Sunbeam appliances. **********Details in Business Day,  page D1.
