https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/02/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Reichhold Rejects Offer by Dainippon
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/02/busin.body_text: **********Reichhold Chemicals Inc. yesterday rejected a $473 million hostile takeover bid from Dainippon Ink and Chemicals Inc. and said that it would explore other possible offers for the company. **********Dainippon abruptly broke off merger talks with Reichhold last month and told shareholders a week ago that it would pay $52.50 a share for the specialty-chemicals producer. **********It was the second time in less than a year that Dainippon had made a hostile move. Last November, the company shook Wall Street by abandoning friendly talks to buy a Sun Chemical division and making a bid for all of Sun Chemical. It eventually dropped its bid for Sun when the company agreed to sell Dainippon the division. Dainippon then surprised chemical executives by paying $550 million for the division, far more than others might have paid. **********With professionals speculating that something similar might happen to Reichhold, its stock jumped $18.25, to $60.50, on June 25, when the offer was made. Yesterday, the shares closed at $63.125, ahead $2.375 - nearly $11 higher than Dainippon's initial offer. **********Reichhold said its board had rejected the offer as inadequate. It said it had instructed its adviser, the First Boston Corporation, to explore inquiries and develop ''all superior alternatives.'' **********In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Reichhold said it was considering the sale of all or part of the company, a management buyout or other steps, including litigation. It said it had been approached by several American and foreign companies, which it declined to name. **********C. Robert Powell, chairman, said the directors were ''profoundly disappointed'' with what he assailed as ''the manner in which Dainippon approached their discussions with us and their launching of a surprise offer at a ludicrous price in the midst of our talks.'' Insiders said that Mr. Powell had been trying to get Dainippon to pay at least $70 a share. **********Mr. Powell said Reichhold's directors had also decided not to change the anti-takeover defenses that make it expensive to acquire the company. **********The hostile bid was disclosed in a Japanese newspaper, angering Reichhold. The company said that Mr. Powell had called Shigekuni Kawamura, president of Dainippon, to say he was ''upset'' by the report, and that Mr. Kawamura replied that he was also upset and that the account was inaccurate. **********Reichhold then asked the Japanese executive to issue a denial before the stock market opened. Reichhold said Mr. Kawamura had responded that, while he was surprised by the article, he could not say that all of it was false.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/01/world.main_headline: Comrades in Terror; Soldiers and Thugs Are Reportedly Allied In the Campaign in Haiti to Cancel Election
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/01/world.print_headline: Comrades in Terror; Soldiers and Thugs Are Reportedly Allied In the Campaign in Haiti to Cancel Election
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/01/world.body_text: **********The violent disruption of Haiti's elections Sunday seemed to destroy a notion that some mysterious, uncontrollable force had been wreaking violence on the land. **********In several attacks on polling places Sunday, the shooting was done not only by the usual thugs in civilian clothing but also reportedly by uniformed soldiers of the provisional Government. **********Finally, after months of killing and terror attacks by unidentified gunmen, there was evidence that these people were working in concert with the armed forces, the institution that the United States had counted on to bring Haiti to democracy. **********Today, as residents of the capital began a timid return to a normal life, stunned survivors and curious onlookers caused a small traffic jam at a school that was the scene of the worst atrocity.  [ Page A15. ]  Their timidity was understandable. Robert E. White, the former United States Ambassador in El Salvador, said that as an observer of the disrupted elections, he witnessed soldiers cooperating with civilian thugs and was told by a clergyman about an attack carried out by soldiers. There were many similar reports. **********''It seems clear to me,'' Mr. White said, ''that there is a reciprocal relationship between the military and the Macoutes.'' **********Macoutes is short for the Tontons Macoute, a collection of killers, torturers and extortionists that Francois Duvalier, the founder of the family dictatorship, created shortly after his fraudulent election to the presidency in 1957. In the early days, they affected a sinister look with dark sunglasses and fedoras. Officers Reported Angered **********Francois Duvalier and his son Jean-Claude used the Tontons Macoute as enforcers and as a counterweight to the army, which had brought the elder Mr. Duvalier to power. But the Tontons Macoute were also used to carry out onerous, extralegal tasks that even in bloodstained Haiti were considered potentially damaging to the reputation of the armed forces. **********Some Haitians say that many of these former Tontons Macoute have become members of a paramilitary force, available for hire when needed. Some Haitians say some army officers were angered when soldiers and Ma-coutes were seen working together on Election Day. They blame Lieut. Gen. Henri Namphy, the head of the provisional Government, for having damaged the army's reputation and have reportedly been discussing trying to push him aside. Though these officers appear opposed to General Namphy, Haitians say they are by no means in favor of entirely democratic elections. **********From the time of the collapse of Jean-Claude Duvalier's dictatorship 22 months ago and General Namphy's emergence as the provisional Government's head, the general had been saying that his main goal is to turn over power to an elected civilian government. The United States and other major donors of aid to Haiti believed the general. As violence grew before the elections, some diplomats said it appeared that it was being carried out by people beyond his control. Army Is Accused **********But after watching the attacks Sunday, a diplomat said that the election violence was ''obviously aided and abetted by the Haitian Army.'' **********In an early public act as head of government, General Namphy, who is 53 years old and who rose to Chief of Staff under Jean-Claude Duvalier, disbanded the Tontons Macoute. But he did not disarm most of them. **********Not surprisingly, no one has publicly admitted being a member of a paramilitary force, and the structure and control of the force as well as who pays its members remains unclear. But it is these people who are generally referred to as Macoute who are believed to be responsible for the continuing terror. **********Even though the opponents of elections accomplished their objective, they are continuing their intimidation, presumably in hopes of suppressing a reaction from the millions of Haitians who were hoping for a chance to fairly choose their next leader. There were few people in the streets in the heart of the capital today, and as night fell scattered shooting was heard. There was a report that a man had been shot to death on a main avenue a few blocks from the presidential palace. **********The final drive to disrupt what was to have been Haiti's first presidential election in 30 years started in early-morning darkness Sunday with arson fires and attacks with hand grenades and gunfire. Soldiers Are Seen Firing **********In the capital, most of the shooting appeared to have been done by men in civilian clothes. But soldiers were seen firing into a few voting places and before the polls opened, 16 of them destroyed the transmitter for the widely heard Roman Catholic radio station in Haiti, according to a priest. **********In the town of Gonaives, to the north of Port-au-Prince, soldiers stole ballots and ballot boxes and fired into the air to scare away voters, witnesses said. Voters also ran out of voting places in the town of Les Cayes, to the south, as soldiers fired in the air. **********The term Macoute has taken on a broader meaning these days and is being applied to all of those in the minority who have been trying to block democracy with the hope of preserving as much as possible of the social structure created by Francois Duvalier. Duvalier Loyalists **********These people are also often referred to as Duvalier loyalists. They benefited from a system of privileges, but many of them despised the younger Duvalier do not want to see him make a comeback. **********Although General Namphy rose to high office under the Duvaliers, he is remembered as having somehow remained independent and uncorrupted. But ''he was obviously a Duvalierist,'' said a foreigner who has known him for years. **********General Namphy has been the most visible member of the provisional Government, but the other soldier in government, Maj. Gen. Williams Regala, 49 years old, has been more often in touch with United States officials and has made several trips to Washington. **********In the early days of the provisional Government, some Haitians accused General Regala of having been present at a massacre of civilians in the southern town of Jeremie, and there were repeated calls for him to step down. He surprised Haitians by responding to the charges in interviews with newspapers and radio stations, and though he spoke in generalities the calls for his resignation faded. **********General Namphy said Sunday that he remained committed to holding elections in time to have a civilian inaugurated as President next February. He disbanded the civilian council that organized the elections, and some Government officials say they think it is unlikely that civic and political groups will be willing to nominate replacements for the original members. **********''General Namphy wants to have elections,'' a businessman said. ''But he wants to control them so he can make sure that the next President does not cause problems for the army.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/08/busin.main_headline: For Small Planes, More Buyers Think Brazil
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/08/busin.print_headline: For Small Planes, More Buyers Think Brazil
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/08/busin.body_text: **********IN a cavernous hangar at the headquarters of Embraer, as the Brazilian Aerospace Corporation is known, work has begun on the first of 20 twin-prop Brasilia aircraft on order from Texas Air. Near the plant's runway, technicians are testing five single-engine Tucano trainer planes, with the colors of the Peruvian Air Force. In another building, preparations are going ahead for construction of the external flaps for McDonnell Douglas's new MD-11 tri-jet. **********Founded here 18 years ago, Embraer has grown into the largest aircraft manufacturer in the third world. It routinely finds buyers for its small-sized military and civilian planes in the competitive markets of the United States, Britain, France and West Germany. And soon its first jet fighter, the subsonic AMX, which it is building in partnership with Italy's Aermacchi and Aeritalia companies, will be ready for marketing. **********It was not easy for Embraer to nudge its way into the highly competitive market of civil aviation. Who, after all, would want to fly in Brazilian planes when similar aircraft from, say, the United States, Canada or the Netherlands were available? **********''That used to worry us too,'' said Ozilio Carlos da Silva, Embraer's managing director. ''But it's a process. You sell first in your own market, then you become known in air industry literature, then you start going to air shows. I remember the first time Lord Waterpark saw a Bandeirante at the Farnborough Air Show in 1977. He liked it, flew in it and then wanted to sell it.'' Lord Waterpark became Embraer's agent in Britain and has sold 30 Bandeirantes there. **********The twin-engine, 19-seat Bandeirante, popular with commuter airlines, was Embraer's first major success abroad. But it was the Tucano that first won it prestige, beating out the much-vaunted Swiss-made Pilatus PC-9 trainer for a major contract with the Royal Air Force two years ago. Short Brothers of Belfast is building 131 of the Tucanos under contract, while another 120 are being assembled from kits at a plant near Cairo for the Egyptian and Iraqi air forces. Production here is also going full blast, with a total of 592 orders or options for the $1.4 million Tucano. **********None of this would seem unusual, however, were Embraer not in a country caught in its worst economic crisis in decades, one that has a suffocatingly large bureaucracy that loves to meddle. Brazil also has a huge foreign debt, social problems that defy solution and a government that many analysts say is without direction. In this context, Embraer's feat can only be explained as yet another of the contradictions that have long defined this vast nation. **********EMBRAER is not in fact the only state company in Brazil that is well run: the mining giant, Companhia Vale do Rio Doce, and the oil corporation, Petrobras, are also efficient. Nor is Embraer the only Brazilian company to outsell established multinationals in some developing countries: The military hardware manufacturers, Engesa and Avibras, which also have their headquarters in this city 60 miles north of Sao Paulo, do pretty well too. **********Yet Embraer stands out because it neither deals in raw materials nor targets its goods for the third world. Rather, with a self-confidence verging on arrogance, it tried from the beginning to sell high-technology products to industrialized nations. It learned to identify a need, develop a product and market it successfully. In the process, it even became modestly profitable. **********So far, it has made more than 3,500 aircraft of 15 different models. Some, such as the Xavante jet fighter and several Piper models, were simply assembled here. But three planes have marked Embraer's technological advance: the Bandeirante, some 465 of which have been sold in 35 countries, with 147 still being flown in the United States alone; the two-seater Tucano pilot trainer, which is being flown by eight air forces, and the new 30-seat Brasilia, which several United States commuter airlines are already using. This year, Embraer's revenue should exceed $600 million, two-thirds of it from exports. **********That Brazil should build its own aircraft industry is in itself not surprising. The country is so large and many of its regions so inaccessible that efficient air transport is a necessity. The military regime that ruled Brazil between 1964 and 1985 also felt that an independent aircraft industry was essential to security. When businessmen were skeptical about the project's viability, the Air Force used its own money to found Embraer. **********Its good fortune was that a team of engineers and technicians had been working at the Air Force's prestigious Aerospace Technical Center here and had already developed the prototype for the Bandeirante. This team took over Embraer under the leadership of Col. Ozires Silva, 56 years old, a charismatic engineer who came to personify the company's pioneering spirit. Last year, he was named to run Petrobras, no small recognition of his talents, but he remained chairman of Embraer while Mr. da Silva, his assistant, who is 50, took over as managing director. **********''The original team still runs the company,'' Mr. da Silva said in a recent interview. ''There were 150 of us at the beginning, all with the same background and the same objectives.'' The team proved to be both technically competent and creative, which meant that Embraer conceived products that were not only efficient but also competitive. ''Now we have 11,000 employees,'' Mr. da Silva continued, ''but the same esprit de corps infects them.'' **********One rule established early was that Embraer should be run with the discipline of a private company, even though it depended on the Government to replenish its capital. Thus, while many other state-run companies routinely provided sinecures for retired military officers and friendly politicians, the Air Force insured that jobs in Embraer were not traded for favors. ''I think the complexity of our operation moderated the appetite for meddling,'' Mr. da Silva said. **********AS a relatively small company, Embraer still lacks the capacity to develop more than one major product at the same time. Once the Tucano was on the assembly line, though, the company began concentrating on the Brasilia, which now stands at the center of its marketing effort. Its sales team, working out of its subsidiary company in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., has already taken orders and options for 179 Brasilias in the United States, 33 of which are already flying for five small airlines. One sign that Embraer is now fully focused abroad is that only 15 orders and options for the Brasilia are from Brazilian airlines, out of a total of 257. **********The company's next two projects are joint ventures. The AMX jet fighter has given Embraer access to advanced technology obtained from Italy and the company will benefit particularly from Aermacchi's participation in the construction of the European Tornado fighter. But Embraer has no plans to graduate on its own to supersonic fighters. ''We simply don't have the financial resources,'' Mr. da Silva said. ''The Brazilian Air Force could not come up with the development costs.'' **********Cost is also the reason that Embraer has brought in the Argentine Factory for Aerospace Material, called FAMA, as a one-third partner in its next civil aviation project. The 19-seat CBA-123, which will cost $300 million to develop, will use the cockpit and fuselage of the Brasilia and have twin-prop ''pusher'' engines mounted in the rear. Plans to elongate either the CBA-123 or the Brasilia to carry 40 passengers are being discussed, Mr. da Silva said, ''to keep us in the market until 2010.'' But he added: ''We can't go into big passenger planes. It's too expensive and the market is too small. We have to look for other areas of the market.'' **********Embraer may have found one of those areas with its successful bid for the $120 million contract to build composite material flaps for the MD-11. In partnership with Engesa, a manufacturer of tanks and other armored vehicles, Embraer also recently formed a new company, Orbita S.A., to build military missiles and space rockets. The new unit will draw upon technology developed by the Aerospace Technical Center, which acts as the main research body for much of the industry. **********EXPANSION is forcing Embraer to look for new sources of capital. In the past, the company financed operations through sporadic capital infusions by the Government, by reinvesting profits and by benefiting from a plan by which private companies could spend 1 percent of their corporate tax on non-voting shares in Embraer. ''In the 1970's, this was sufficient, but it is not in the 1980's,'' Mr. da Silva said. **********With a third of current income assigned to servicing the company's $95 million foreign debt and accompanying domestic debts, Embraer is negotiating a payment rescheduling with the Government's National Bank for Economic and Social Development. ''Since the debt crisis, we can't borrow abroad for longer than 360 days,'' the official went on. ''If we can switch from short-term to long-term debt, our profitability will improve.'' **********In reality, while the company has had only one unprofitable year (in 1985, when it lost $4.8 million), reinvestment has always taken precedence over profits, which reached a modest $10 million last year on sales of $378 million. This emphasis must change since Embraer hopes to finance development of the CBA-123 on the stock market. ''No one will buy our shares unless we're efficient and profitable,'' Mr. da Silva said. ''You can't be efficient in your technology and marketing and inefficient in your financing and still hope to survive.'' One fashionable solution that is apparently not being debated here, however, is that Embraer should be privatized. Brazilian businessmen, who in 1969 refused to invest in the company, would now be attracted by the idea, but the Government is not selling. The Air Force still sees Embraer as a strategic asset that, in an emergency, can produce the military hardware it needs. But there is also a touch of pride in its jealous hold on the company. ''After all,'' Mr. da Silva said, ''we did it alone.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/29/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Lord & Taylor President Comes From Within
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/29/busin.body_text: **********Frank C. Watson has been named president of Lord & Taylor, the retail fashion chain, its parent, the May Department Stores Company, announced yesterday. **********Mr. Watson, 47, has been vice chairman of Lord & Taylor since 1978. He replaces Harold Leppo, who resigned earlier this month after 10 years with the company. **********Mr. Watson reports to Marshall Hilsberg, 42, Lord & Taylor's chairman and chief executive. **********Lord & Taylor has been going through a period of transition since May acquired it last year through the purchase of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation. In October, Mr. Hilsberg succeeded Joseph E. Brooks, who resigned. Mr. Leppo, a longtime Brooks associate, followed this month. **********Changes in top management at other former Associated Dry Goods chains have also taken place, and Mr. Watson will be among only a relative few of the former Associated Dry Goods executives to make the transition to May. **********''We are very pleased about Frank Watson's appointment as president,'' said David C. Farrell, chairman and chief executive of May, which operates 2,789 stores. ''He is an experienced executive and has played an important role in the growth and expansion of Lord & Taylor.'' **********Mr. Hilsberg said Mr. Watson's responsibilities would not change at Lord & Taylor. He will continue to be responsible for sales support areas, such as operations, finance, human resources, shortage control and design and construction of stores. **********Mr. Hilsberg said he would retain the responsibilities that Mr. Leppo had - merchandising and sales promotions. **********The change basically aligns Lord & Taylor to the traditional structure used at May. James Abrams, May's vice president for communications, said May's units always have a president and a chairman. Mr. Watson's old post of vice chairman will not be filled, he added. **********Mr. Watson joined Lord & Taylor in 1976 as general merchandise manager and senior vice president, two years before he was named vice chairman. He began his retail career at Burdine's in Miami after graduating from Auburn University.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/01/busin.body_text: **********The new year is bringing a 1.3 percent benefit increase to the nation's 37 million Social Security beneficiaries and an end to the temporary respite from the payroll tax for 8.5 million Americans who paid the maximum levy in 1986. **********It took earnings of $42,000 or more in 1986 to earn a break from the Social Security tax. **********But in 1987, taxpayers will have to earn $43,800 before the payroll tax ends for the year. **********Although the tax rate remains unchanged at 7.15 percent, the increase in the wage ceiling to $43,800 means the maximum tax on employees will rise to $3,131.70. That is $128.70, or 4.3 percent, more than 1986's top tax. Employers pay the same amount. **********The average monthly benefit for retired workers will rise by $6, to $488. For an elderly couple, the average payment will go up by $11, to $833. **********But most of the elderly will find their ''take home'' pay from Social Security going up less than $6 because they will be charged $2.40 more each month for Medicare coverage. **********The benefit increase matches the change in the Consumer Price Index from the third quarter of 1985 through the third quarter of 1986. It is the smallest rise since Social Security was linked to the price index in 1975.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/10/busin.body_text: **********Pratt & Whitney has announced that nearly 2,000 salaried workers in four states have agreed to early retirement or voluntary terminations under a program to cut payroll costs. The voluntary response means the East Hartford-based jet engine builder does not expect to lay off any workers to reach its goals, a spokesman, David Long, said. Mr. Long said precise figures on the cutback program were not yet available from Pratt & Whitney's seven plants in Connecticut, Florida, Georgia and Maine. **********The company announced on Nov. 12 that it wanted to cut its 19,700-member salaried work force by 1,500 to 2,000 jobs during 1987. It offered early retirement benefits to employees age 50 to 55 whose age plus years of service totaled at least 65. The reduction program is part of a plan to reduce the 188,000-member work force of Pratt & Whitney's parent company, the United Technologies Corporation, by 11,000 jobs during 1987.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/07/busin.body_text: **********Like the city itself, which went from the precipice of bankruptcy in the 1970's to prosperity, New York's savings banks are back. **********When interest rates passed 20 percent in the early 1980's, savings banks suffered so badly that regulators thought the entire industry might crumble. The banks' capital was virtually wiped out by gaping losses as they were caught between having made long-term, fixed-rate loans at low rates and having to pay higher rates for deposits. The institutions could not even be sold, so serious was their plight. Now, thanks to lower interest rates, balance-sheet restructuring, diversification and a removal of usury ceilings, the savings banks are again prospering. **********''We're not only seeing the light at the end of the tunnel; we're out of the tunnel,'' said John T. Morgan, chief executive of the American Savings Bank. ''It's whoopy time.'' Return to Profitability **********Profits have clearly recovered. After losing hundreds of millions of dollars in each of the preceding five years, the New York savings banks returned to profitability in 1985, earning $573.8 million, for a return on assets of 0.81 percent. In the first six months of 1986 alone, the savings banks exceeded this profit level, earning $800.7 million, for a healthy 1.09 percent return on assets. **********As a result, savings banks have become some of the hottest properties around. In the last six weeks, two of New York's oldest savings banks -the Emigrant and the Williamsburgh - have been sold. In the last 15 months, ownership has changed at five other big New York State savings bank: the Bowery, Dollar Dry Dock, East River, Seamen's and the Savings Bank of Rockland County. The sale of the seven institutions has led to a change in control of $20 billion out of the $120 billion of New York savings-bank deposits. **********Besides demonstrating how much savings banks' prospects have brightened, the quicker pace of sales has tantalized other prospective buyers. Indeed, industry experts say that it is only a matter of time before another big local savings bank goes on the block. **********''Ever since the Emigrant deal was announced, the phones have been ringing a lot,'' said Edward T. Lutz, regional director of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which receives bids on savings banks and manages their sale. ''Other similar deals are being worked on.'' Some Criticism of Sales **********While the selling over all is being viewed positively by regulators - to the extent that buyers inject capital, they help insure the banks' survival and thereby improve competition -the trend has not been without critics. **********Some people fear, for example, that the new owners will not run the savings banks according to their historical mandate: to provide banking services to the working class. They worry that the savings banks will either be broken up or that they will pursue other ventures to the neglect of their lending for home mortgages. **********''To have some developers - a couple of local painters and plumbers -buy up a thrift? That's crazy!'' said Isidore J. Lasurdo, chairman and chief executive of the Green Point Savings Bank of Brooklyn, alluding to local real estate developers who have led the buying spree. **********Others complain that the savings banks are being sold too cheaply. They charge that the F.D.I.C., worried about its own liability if a bank fails, is taking any bid that appears for the institutions. Mr. Lutz of the F.D.I.C. rejects these charges as baseless, but even those who support the F.D.I.C.'s efforts believe that the agency may suffer from a conflict. **********''Obviously, the F.D.I.C. has a self-interest in seeing these deals go through,'' said Howard C. St. John, chairman and president of the Ulster Savings Bank of Kingston, N.Y. Savings Banks' Traditonal Roles **********A bigger fear, of course, is that the savings banks will abandon their traditional roles as neighborhood-oriented housing lenders. While that has not happened, changes have been made. For example, the president of the Seamen's Bank for Savings, Steven H. Rice, quit after executives from the Lomas & Nettleton Company acquired Seamen's in December 1985. **********Richard Ravitch, former chief of the Metropolitan Transit Authority who with other individuals acquired the Bowery Savings Bank in October 1985, brought in an entirely new management team and has since steered the savings bank into the mortgage servicing business, consumer banking and commercial lending, although it continues to make a large number of home loans. **********The sales of the seven New York savings banks are fundamentally different from the so-called thrift conversions that have become all the rage in the savings industry. **********In a thrift conversion, such as the huge conversion recently by the Dime Savings Bank of New York, a savings bank goes public by converting from mutual ownership, in which a bank is owned jointly by depositors, to stock ownership. In cases like the Dime, the shares have been sold to thousands of individual investors, none having a sufficient number to control. 'Change-of-Control Conversions' **********In sales that have been approved by the F.D.I.C. in the last 15 months, by contrast, the institutions have been converted to stock form and the new owner has been either a single individual, one corporation or a small group of well-heeled investors. The Williamsburgh, for example, was sold to a corporation, the Republic National Bank of New York. The other six significant sales in New York have been to small groups of individuals. Such transactions are being called ''change-of-control conversions.'' **********And while each sale has its own twist in terms of financial structure, they all reflect essentially the same economic forces, industry experts say. For the savings banks, the motivation to sell has been a desire to rebuild capital. The savings banks' new owners came to the negotiating table with fat bankbooks and have subsequently injected their institutions with needed cash. **********''Even though we had turned the corner and were profitable, it would have taken us a lot longer to reach our regulatory required capital through earnings,'' said Raymond V. O'Brien Jr., chairman and chief executive of the Emigrant Savings Bank. ''Second, there was the question of whether interest rates might go up again in the future.'' **********For the buyers of the savings banks, the advantage in making substantial equity investments - hundreds of millions of dollars, in some cases - is that they gain control over billions of dollars in loans and other assets, as well as a loyal deposit base. **********''We believed back then - and we believe now - that you can earn a decent return on investment in retail banking in New York City,'' said Mr. Ravitch of the Bowery. Low-Interest-Rate Environment **********In the current environment of low interest rates, savings banks' assets can be far more profitable than in the past, the new owners believe. **********''We view the savings bank as a better investment opportunity than the other things we're looking at,'' said Seymour Milstein, the New York real estate developer who acquired the Emigrant. **********Buyers often intend either to sell the savings bank later to another individual at a higher price or to take the institution public. Other buyers may choose to hold onto their new properties, using their substantial cash flows to bankroll other ventures. **********''It's no different from investing in G.M.,'' said Michael M. Horn, a senior vice president at the Wall Street firm Ryan, Beck & Company. ''These guys feel that if they put X million in, over time the business will grow and their investment will increase in value.'' Savings Banks' Earlier Woes **********Savings banks got in trouble when interest rates rose. Many of their home mortgage assets had maturities of 30 years, but their deposits were short-term. Banks soon found themselves paying steadily increasing interest on deposits while the income from loans remained relatively steady. **********For now, at least, the trends affecting the savings industry are positive. In California, big thrift institutions such as Home Savings and Golden West Financial are shaming big banks, producing double-digit increases in earnings and returns on equity of 25 percent or greater. **********It turns out, moreover, that the same economic forces that have made California thrift units so successful have been increasing returns at New York savings banks - and go far toward explaining the local banks' new allure. Thrift units on both coasts have led the way in issuing variable-rate mortgages, instruments that help shield home lenders from interest-rate risk. And, unlike savings institutions in the heart of the country, the thrift units in New York and California have not been adversely affected by a portfolio of bad mortgages. **********On the contrary, the default rate in New York is among the lowest anywhere. Now that rates have fallen, the banks have sold off their old, low-paying home mortgages with little or no loss. The lower rates have also reduced the interest paid on deposits. With usury ceilings gone, the banks are free to charge what they wish on loans. And diversification efforts should help to stabilize earnings. **********Industry data bear this out. According to the Savings Bank Association of New York State, the industry's ratio of net worth to assets peaked at 6.8 percent in 1979. By 1981, with interest rates rising rapidly, the ratio had fallen to 4.9 percent. It bottomed out at 3.6 percent in 1984 and has since recovered to 5.7 percent. **********Not everyone, however, sees a happy ending. ''All interest rates have to do is rise a percentage point or two, and these savings banks will be back in the proverbial tank,'' said Mr. Lasurdo of Greenpoint Savings. https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/17/busin.main_headline: Economic Scene; UNCERTAINTIES OF TRADE GAP
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/17/busin.print_headline: Economic Scene; UNCERTAINTIES OF TRADE GAP
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/17/busin.body_text: **********PROPHECIES are based on ''imperfect knowledge,'' Oliver Wendell Holmes, the jurist, once observed. Yet ''every year, if not every day, we have to wager our salvation upon some prophecy,'' he said. And prophecies don't always come true. **********Currently the great American economic prophecy is that the huge trade deficit, which began to shrink last fall, will continue a slow decline and someday, in the 1990's, will disappear. **********The only thing the nation has to do, according to this prophecy, is to stick to its present economic course. The dollar must stay down, manufacturing productivity has to go on growing at nearly 4 percent annually and the lid has to remain on wages -to dampen the demand for imports. The Europeans and Japanese also have to do their part, of course, becoming the front-line consumers of America's growing industrial output. **********Viewed from this perspective, there was a lot of shoulder-shrugging among economists Wednesday when the Commerce Department announced that the trade deficit had widened in May. The increase was interpreted as an aberration. ''I think we will continue to get a significant and substantial improvement in the deficit,'' said Robert Z. Lawrence, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution. But he had an important caveat. ''There is a distinction,'' Mr. Lawrence said, ''between getting the trade deficit down and eliminating it.'' **********That is the great concern - the unknown in the prophecy. Many economists agree that $60 billion or $70 billion can be skimmed off last year's trade deficit of $144.3 billion, largely because of the 50 percent decline in the value of the dollar since 1985. The fear is that the remaining $70 billion to $80 billion will turn out to be rooted in the economy and will be an endless drain on the American standard of living. That is because the trade deficit is, in effect, a foreign debt that already costs the nation billions of dollars a year in interest payments. **********The process of shrinking the trade gap began in last year's fourth quarter. Since then, the deficit has shrunk from $47.9 billion, to $40.9 billion in this year's first quarter, as measured in constant 1982 dollars. That fixed yardstick discloses true trade volume by eliminating from the Commerce Department's monthly figures the impact of inflation and the distortions that have resulted from the dollar's devaluation. **********The decline, if it continued into the second quarter - and it very probably did - means the 1987 trade deficit could come in at $163.6 billion, or well below last year's $175.9 billion. In nominal dollars, the shrinkage would be to $127 billion from $144.3 billion. The improvement is cited by the Reagan Administration as evidence that the dollar is already low enough to eventually close the trade gap. **********But more than half the improvement has come from importing less oil, and now oil imports have begun to rise. Over the long term, the key to closing the trade gap lies not in oil and other commodities but in regaining the American advantage in manufacturing, particularly in selling more capital goods, autos, industrial supplies and consumer products abroad, and importing less of each category. Over the last nine months, only industrial supplies - such as textiles, paper and chemicals -have shown much improvement. **********Why is manufacturing so intractable? One view is that other nations have been too successful in overcoming the technology gap and much more must be spent on research to regain lost ground. ''People expect a trade improvement because the dollar has depreciated, but that is not going to be enough with so much high-tech slippage,'' said Kenneth Flamm of the Brookings Institution. **********Without a technology edge, an alternative is to increase manufacturing productivity at perhaps twice the current clip, says Charles H. Ferguson, a research associate for the Center for Technology, Policy and Industrial Development at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. **********Another approach is more devaluation. In the 1970's the United States made up for the rising proficiency in technology abroad by allowing the dollar to erode at an average annual rate of 2 percent to 3 percent a year, according to Paul R. Krugman, an M.I.T. economics professor who recently published a study on the subject. The sharp rise in the dollar in the early 1980's interrupted this process, and the devaluation since 1985 has only now brought the dollar back to the 1980 level. **********The dollar will probably have to fall to between 110 and 120 yen to offset foreign gains in productivity and technology since 1980, Mr. Krugman said. He is not alone in advocating another round of devaluation - one that would bring the dollar below 120 yen and below 1.50 marks - if the trade deficit is to eventually move toward zero. The current levels are above 148 yen and 1.82 marks. **********''I have talked to a lot of corporations in the past week, and no one disagrees that we need considerably more on the dollar,'' said Rimmer de Vries, senior vice president at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company. **********Given the mild economic growth in Europe and Japan, which are counted on to purchase American exports, ''you really need a dollar at 120 yen, minimum, by the end of next year,'' he said, adding that maybe the devaluation should come quickly for maximum effect. **********Devaluation, of course, is a fallback solution. Cut the dollar by enough, say by half, and even the last $60 billion of the trade deficit will disappear quickly as everyone rushes to buy American goods at very low prices in foreign currencies. **********But such a devaluation would drastically reduce American purchasing power and living standards. The trick to eliminating the trade deficit painlessly appears to be some higher level of productivity and some lower level for the dollar.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/25/busin.main_headline: Detectors That Talk to the Front Desk
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/25/busin.print_headline: WHAT'S NEW IN HOTEL SAFETY; Detectors That Talk to the Front Desk
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/25/busin.body_text: **********RESEARCH on smoke detectors, as with most fire safety research, has focused on the issue of speeding up the warning time, giving guests a chance to get out and firefighters a chance to get in before dense smoke and toxic gases make approaching the fire hazardous or even impossible. **********''The biggest weakness in smoke detection is that nobody is in the hotel room when the fire starts,'' said Larry Chervenak, president of the consulting firm, Chervenak, Keane & Company. ''The cleaning staff may be down the hall and a fire can cause a whole lot of havoc before anyone knows about it.'' **********But last week, the National Fire Protection Association, which sets standards that are adopted by many states and by organizations that test safety equipment, issued a temporary standard for wireless smoke detectors, clearing the way for the commercial adoption of the new technology. The wireless smoke detector - now used in only five hotels and manufactured by World Electronics, of Coral Springs, Fla. - is capable of sending a signal to the hotel's front desk the second the detector alarm is triggered. **********Even in a high-rise building, employees manning the front desk could pinpoint the floor and room in which a fire started. They could then sound a general alarm, alert the local fire department and begin an evacuation of the hotel's guests, if that seems necessary. Firefighters could monitor the spread of the fire as signals continued to be sent to the front desk. **********''I know of a lot of hotel organizations that were looking at it and were waiting for the N.F.P.A. ruling,'' said Mr. Chervenak. ''It's on the leading edge of technology.'' **********Mr. Barrett said that the wireless smoke detectors work like cellular telephones. The signals are transmitted on a frequency that is regulated by the Federal Communications Commission. It is less costly, by up to 75 percent, according to the company's estimate, than the smoke-detector systems that require hard wiring. And it promises to be less disruptive during installment in existing buildings, he added. **********The system is also potentially more flexible than existing smoke detectors, once a fire is discovered. Fire department officials can direct firefighting operations from the front desk, alerting the firefighters about smoke-filled stairwells or rapidly spreading fires. **********Despite their manifest advantages, wireless smoke detectors do suffer one drawback. With an installation cost of about $250 a room, they are considerably more expensive than the typical, battery-powered smoke detectors, which might run as much as $25 each. **********World Technologies is a private company with 11 employees and sales last year of about $2.5 million, 70 percent of which came from the sale of its fire safety systems, Mr. Barrett said. With the N.F.P.A. standards rating, Mr. Barrett said he expected sales to nearly double in the next year. ''So many buildings were built before the new fire codes that there is now a drastic need to go back and equip these buildings with smoke detectors,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/07/busin.body_text: **********The Contel Corporation and Comsat yesterday broke off their proposed $2.4 billion merger. **********Instead, Contel will acquire two of the faltering businesses of Comsat -its international private line operations and its VSAT technology, which involves small earth stations that are efficient in transmitting data. The price totals about $38 million. **********Contel, based in Atlanta, had wanted to cancel the merger since April when it learned of several actions by the Federal Communications Commission that would make the Communications Satellite Corporation's business less attractive. $62 Million Refund Ordered The F.C.C. had ordered Comsat to refund $62 million in profits that the agency said Comsat had earned by exceeding its authorized profit margin. Other F.C.C. proposals would decrease the amount of overseas traffic transmitted on Comsat's international networks and increase the use of fiber optics over satellites in trans-Atlantic communications. **********Contel said the actions would hurt Comsat financially and would not have been resolved by the time the merger would have been completed. **********Analysts said that ending the merger was good for both companies. Comsat would shed two of its money-losing operations and probably improve performance, while Contel would gain the international and technological capacity it sought through the merger but at a lower price. Stocks Close Higher **********Comsat stock closed yesterday at $29, up 12.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange. Contel shares closed at $34.125, up 75 cents. **********''We are eliminating businesses that have cost us a lot money and caused a good deal of concern among regulators,'' said Richard L. McGraw, a Comsat spokesman. Mr. McGraw said that during the first six months of the year, Comsat International Communications Inc., which operates the international private line service, had a loss of $3.2 million on revenues of $6.8 million. The VSAT operations of Comsat had a loss of $7.1 million on revenues of $3.3 million. Estimated Book Value **********Analysts estimated the book value of Comsat business to be $19 million for the VSAT technology and $21.5 million for international private line service, giving Contel a discount of $3.2 million. **********''We got the best of the deal,'' said Norman Brust, Contel's vice president of communications. ''These are the businesses that attracted us to Comsat from the start and we are looking forward to integrating them into our network.'' **********International private line networks are designed specifically to meet the needs of investment banks, government agencies and multinational companies that transmit large volumes of voice and data overseas. **********Comsat's VSAT operation makes small earth station antennas, two to six feet in diameter, that can transmit data more efficiently than current transmitters. VSAT stands for very small aperture terminal. **********''On the surface it might seem that Contel bought into a losing proposition, but if you take a closer look it makes a lot of sense,'' said Joel Gross, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. **********''Contel is assembling at low costs all the pieces of the satellite business no one has before - domestic and international satellite capacity. They will be able to build, service and maintain a complete network of satellite operations around the globe at a time when a lot of big players are bailing out.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/31/world.main_headline: SHAMIR, SHARON AND ARENS GAIN SOLID CONTROL OF THE HERUT PARTY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/31/world.print_headline: SHAMIR, SHARON AND ARENS GAIN SOLID CONTROL OF THE HERUT PARTY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/31/world.body_text: **********The Herut Party convention ended relatively peacefully early today, with Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, Ariel Sharon and Moshe Arens having won solid control of the party leadership from David Levy and his allies. **********The voting results formally anointed Mr. Shamir as the party chairman and left Mr. Levy, who was born in Morocco and who believes he is the clear and natural heir apparent to Mr. Shamir, in a weakened position. Mr. Levy wound up with the ceremonial title of deputy chairman but with no formal control over key party machinery. **********At the same time, the voting lifted Mr. Sharon and Mr. Arens into influential jobs controlling the day-to-day party apparatus that will make them even more serious contenders with Mr. Levy for the future leadership of the party whenever Mr. Shamir, 73 years old, retires. From Fists to Fraternity **********The relatively calm and unified manner in which Herut concluded its party convention, after the gathering last year broke up in a welter of flying chairs and fists, will also be a lift for the party as a whole in its national competition with the Labor Party, led by Foreign Minister Shimon Peres. **********Labor officials had been hoping possibly to exploit a divided Herut convention in order to break up the national unity Government. Labor had been prepared to argue to the electorate that a party that could not properly conduct its own affairs should not be allowed to conduct the nation's business. Shamir Not Challenged **********Mr. Shamir's election as party chairman was uncontested. The real excitement came from the runoffs between Mr. Levy, Mr. Sharon, Mr. Arens and their proxies, in tests of strength meant to show the real power each man has in the party and his chances for succeeding Mr. Shamir. **********The most surprising result was that in the secret balloting for deputy party chairman, between Mr. Levy and a pro-Sharon Member of Parliament, Meir Cohen-Avidov, Mr. Levy won by a comparatively small margin of 55 percent to 45 percent. The margin was particularly small considering that Mr. Cohen-Avidov is virtually unknown in the party and was never before considered leadership material. **********Mr. Levy said after the vote was announced that his election to deputy chariman was ''a victory'' that had determined the ''hierarchy of the Herut Party.'' **********Mr. Sharon, however, said the results showed the ''true strength'' of the Levy camp. **********Mr. Sharon, by a margin of 64 percent to 36 percent, trounced a pro-Levy Member of Parliament, Ovadia Ali, for the post of chairman of the party central committee, which chooses all the candidates for Parliament. Enthusiasm for Sharon **********For the first time, Mr. Sharon is now in charge of a key post in the party apparatus. Of all the Herut officials at the convention, it was Mr. Sharon who, as he walked around the hall, generated the most excitement among the delegates. **********Mr. Arens, who was running against a pro-Levy party official, Yoram Aridor, for chief of the Herut Party secretariat, also won a 64-percent-to-36-percent victory. The party secretariat is the bureaucracy that oversees the day-to-day affairs of Herut and should provide Mr. Arens with a base to strengthen his standing.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/07/busin.main_headline: TEXACO SET BACK BY SUPREME COURT IN PENNZOIL CASE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/07/busin.print_headline: TEXACO SET BACK BY SUPREME COURT IN PENNZOIL CASE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/07/busin.body_text: **********In a major setback to Texaco Inc.'s battle for survival, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that a Federal District Court should not have excused the company from posting a bond of more than $10 billion while it appealed a damage award that the Pennzoil Company won against Texaco in 1985. **********The judgment, which now amounts to $10.33 billion including interest, was awarded in a Texas state court. **********Today's decision overturned a Federal court order that barred Pennzoil from seeking to collect the amount from Texaco's assets while the appeal is pending. That appeal is now headed for the Texas Supreme Court. Appeal Not Affected **********Today's decision does not directly affect the appeal but will greatly increase pressure on Texaco to settle the complex suit, and could push Texaco toward bankruptcy proceedings. **********A Texas jury awarded Pennzoil $10.53 billion in November 1985, finding that Texaco illegally interfered with a merger contract between Pennzoil and the Getty Oil Company in early 1984, when Texaco bought Getty for $10.1 billion. A Texas appellate court upheld all but $2 billion of the award on Feb. 12 of this year. Last week Texaco asked the appellate court to rehear the case. **********Texaco's stock fell on the news of the Supreme Court's ruling, dropping $4 a share, to $33.625, on the New York Stock Exchange. Pennzoil soared $6.875, to $88.50. High Stakes Involved **********Texaco said today that it would ''immediately'' urge the Texas courts to suspend enforcement of the award, history's largest, while it proceeded with its appeal in the Texas Supreme Court ''and, if necessary, in the United States Supreme Court.''  [ Page D21. ]  The case has involved the highest stakes, some of the highest-priced legal talent and one of the more unusual procedural maneuvers in American legal history. **********Today's decision grew out of a sepa-rate suit filed by Texaco in the Federal District Court in White Plains, near its headquarters, to block enforcement of the appeal bond requirement and to prevent Pennzoil from placing liens on its assets, so that Texaco could remain intact while its appeal was pending in the Texas courts. **********Although the Supreme Court ruled by 9 to 0 to dismiss Texaco's Federal suit, different Justices gave conflicting reasons. Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. held for himself and four others that the lower Federal courts should have ''abstained'' rather than making what he called ''their unprecedented intrusion into the Texas judicial system.'' **********The decision means that Texas courts will now decide whether Texaco should be relieved from the state appeal bond law, which would ordinarily allow Pennzoil immediately to place liens on and execute its judgment against Texaco assets in the state unless Texaco can post an appeal bond of more than $10 billion. Texaco has said that it could not obtain such a large bond. Bankruptcy Filing Possible **********As a practical matter, if Texaco cannot win relief from the appeal bond requirement in the Texas courts, or in a possible future appeal to the Supreme Court on that issue, it could be forced into bankruptcy proceedings while its appeal of the $10 billion damage award is pending. **********James W. Kinnear, Texaco's chief executive officer, said today, ''If these efforts in the courts and in discussions with Pennzoil fail to provide Texaco with the reasonable relief it requires to continue its appeal on the merits of the case, Texaco would have no alternative but to seek protection of its stockholders under Chapter 11'' of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. **********But he said Texaco still hoped ''to rectify the gross miscarriage of justice that has occurred to this point.'' **********Joseph D. Jamail, Pennzoil's chief attorney in Texas, said in an interview today that, if Texaco would make a ''fair'' proposal for encumbering enough assets in one way or another to secure the total amount of Pennzoil's judgment, he would not insist on a $10 billion appeal bond or seek to execute the judgment or place liens against Texaco while the direct appeal is pending. In a statement issued tonight, Pennzoil said it was amenable to alternative security arrangements. **********Mr. Jamail added that ''for the management of Texaco to even attempt to declare bankruptcy is a totally irresponsible act to cover themselves from the stockholder suits that have been filed against them.'' **********Justice Powell stressed that the majority ruling did not involve the legality of the state court's award of damages against Texaco or the constitutionality of the state's appeal bond law. Rather, he said, the Court ruled only that the lower Federal courts should not have intervened in the case out of respect for the Texas judiciary, which he said was capable of hearing Texaco's challenge to the constitutionality of the state appeal bond requirement. Federalism Principles Cited **********He said Texaco should have sought relief from the appeal bond requirement from the Texas courts, not from Federal courts, which he said ''should have abstained under the principles of Federalism enunciated in Younger v. Harris,'' a 1971 decision barring lower Federal courts from interfering in continuing state criminal prosecutions. **********Justice Powell rejected Texaco's argument that it would have been futile to seek relief from the appeal bond requirement in the Texas courts. While noting the possibility that Texaco may no longer have a right under Texas procedural law to seek relief from the appeal bond requirements in Texas courts, Justice Powell said that was for the Texas courts to resolve. **********''If, and when, the Texas courts render a final decision on any Federal issue presented by this litigation, review may be sought in this Court in the customary manner,'' he added. **********Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Byron R. White, Sandra Day O'Connor and Antonin Scalia joined Justice Powell's opinion. Three Separate Opinions **********Justices William J. Brennan Jr., Thurgood Marshall and John Paul Stevens disagreed strongly with Justice Powell's holding that the lower Federal courts should have abstained from hearing the case but concurred on other grounds, in three separate opinions. **********They agreed that ''Texaco's claim that the Texas bond and lien provisions violate the 14th Amendment is without merit,'' and that Texaco's right to a meaningful appeal ''can be adequately vindicated even if Texaco were forced to file for bankruptcy,'' as Justice Brennan put it. **********Justice Marshall noted in a separate opinion that ''the sole proprietor of a small Texas grocery'' would have gotten nowhere asking a Federal court in New York to intervene in a hypothetical $10,000 lawsuit in Texas. ''The principles which would have governed with $10,000 at stake should also govern when thousands have become billions,'' he said. ''That is the essence of equal justice under law.'' **********Justice Harry A. Blackmun rejected the reasoning of Justice Powell and Justice Brennan alike while concurring on other grounds in the decision, Pennzoil v. Texaco, No. 85-1798. **********Texaco has suggested in the past that it cannot get a fair hearing against Houston-based Pennzoil in state courts in Texas. **********The Texas jury's $10.53 billion award against Texaco on Nov. 19, 1985, by far the largest award of damages in history, was for what the jury found to be Texaco's illegal interference with Pennzoil's plans to acquire three-sevenths of Getty in early 1984. **********It included $7.53 billion in compensatory damages, based on Pennzoil's estimate of what it would cost to drill as much oil as it would have obtained in the deal with Getty, and $3 million in punitive damages. **********Facing what it called imminent bankruptcy because of the Texas law's apparent requirement that it post an appeal bond in the entire amount of the judgment, Texaco filed its highly unusual suit in the Federal District Court in White Plains on Dec. 10, 1985, seeking relief from the appeal bond requirement while it pursued its appeal of the damage award in the Texas courts. **********On Jan. 10, 1986, Federal District Judge Charles L. Brieant held it would violate due process of law to enforce the Texas bond requirement against Texaco, barred Pennzoil from attaching liens to Texaco property while the Texas appeal was pending and attacked the fairness of the entire Texas proceeding. **********On Feb. 20, 1986, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, in Manhattan, upheld the essence of Judge Brieant's ruling while disavowing his criticism of the Texas proceeding. It ruled that Texaco could appeal in the Texas courts by posting only $1 billion in security for its liability to Pennzoil, which was then about $12 billion, including interest. It was this decision that the Supreme Court agreed last June to review, and overturned today. **********While the Supreme Court appeal was pending, the Texas appeals court upheld, on Feb. 12, all of the jury's $7.53 billion compensatory damages award, while reducing to $1 billion the jury's additional award of $3 billion in punitive damages.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/21/busin.main_headline: Market Place; Behind the Fall At Magellan
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/21/busin.print_headline: Market Place; Behind the Fall At Magellan
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/21/busin.body_text: **********WHEN the net asset value per share of the Fidelity Magellan Fund, the nation's largest stock mutual fund, suddenly plunges 11.41 percent - as it did on Monday - a small army of shareowners wonders in alarm: What on earth is happening? **********Admittedly, the stock market was rather weak that day. But the decline of 13.86 points, to 2,258.66, in the Dow Jones industrial average was merely six-tenths of 1 percent. **********That was nothing compared with the drop in net asset value of $6.71, to $52.09, for each Magellan share. Some shareowners asked: Had Peter Lynch, the portfolio manager with the hottest hand in the mutual fund business over the last 10 years, taken a huge wrong turn in the market? Had the $8.8 billion fund been forced to dump stocks at a loss to meet a tidal wave of redemptions?  * * * **********Nothing of the sort, came the comforting response from Fidelity Investments, the giant Boston-based financial complex that counts Magellan as its flagship fund. **********By far the greatest part of the price decline, a Fidelity spokesman explained, represented a cash distribution of $6.21 a share to some one million shareowner accounts of Magellan, which was effective on Monday. This consisted of $5.84 in capital gains and 37 cents in dividends. As a continuing practice, many shareowners prefer to reinvest such distributions in their mutual funds. In any event, a cash distribution automatically lowers the net asset value, on a per-share basis, of any fund. **********The flurry over the big drop in Magellan's net asset value points up the fact that, in the mutual fund tables carried by newspapers, there is nothing to differentiate a cash distribution from a decline that might result from the dynamics of the stock market. Some mutual fund followers have suggested that distributions be designated by an explanatory symbol in the tables. **********Then, too, many funds do not pinpoint the precise date of when distributions are to be made. The prospectus of the Magellan Fund, for example, simply states that distributions are paid annually in May. **********Last year was an exception in this respect. In May, the fund paid $3.99 a share in capital gains and 46 cents in dividends. Then, in December, Magellan made an additional distribution of $2.85 a share in capital gains, in order for shareowners to receive more favorable tax treatment before the new Federal income tax law took effect in 1987. **********''As an actual practice, many people prefer not to buy shares in a mutual fund shortly before the effective date of any distribution, because these payments are a taxable event for the shareowner,'' said Eric M. Kobren, who heads the Mutual Fund Investors Association in Needham, Mass., an independent organization of shareholders in the 100-plus funds offered by Fidelity Investments. **********The 43-year-old Mr. Lynch took the helm of Magellan 10 years ago and charted the fund on a spectacular winning course. Between March 31, 1977, and March 31, 1987, his fund showed a total return - market gains plus reinvested dividends -of 1,962.33 percent, according to Lipper Analytical Services. Over that period, Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was ahead 380.35 percent. **********In an interview, Mr. Lynch said it was unreasonable for investors to assume that Magellan could continue to grow at such a phenomenal rate in the future. ''It is partly a function of the present size of the fund,'' he said. ''But an important consideration, too, is that the stock market now is more fairly priced that it was in the past. In the late 1970's, there were a lot of small growth companies that were overlooked and undervalued.'' **********For a fund with assets of more than $1 billion, he said that ''a reasonable growth target might be to beat the general market by 5 or 6 percent a year.''  * * * **********The Ford Motor Company is Magellan's largest holding, accounting for 4 percent of the fund. Other large positions include the Federal National Mortgage Association, Chrysler, International Business Machines, Ryder System and the Kemper Corporation. The fund owns about 1,800 stocks. **********''Since early this year, we have added to retail stocks, along with automobiles, energy, electronics and railroads,'' Mr. Lynch said. ''We cut back on insurance and utilities and money-center banks. Foreign holdings are now 9 percent of the portfolio, down from 20 percent a year ago.'' **********In the past, Mr. Lynch has turned handsome profits in Chrysler, Volvo and Honda Motor, along with Ford. But for his personal use, the money manager admits that he owns a 10-year-old Concord made by American Motors. And where did he place his Individual Retirement Account contribution? ''This year it was the Magellan Fund,'' he said. ''But sometimes I've used bond funds.'' **********For this year, through May 14, Magellan has a total return of 22.94 percent, slightly ahead of the S.&P. 500's gain of 22.66 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/30/world.main_headline: 100 Haitians, Trying To Vote, Encounter 'Utter Blood Bath'
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/30/world.print_headline: 100 Haitians, Trying To Vote, Encounter 'Utter Blood Bath'
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/30/world.body_text: **********About 100 Haitians lined up to vote at a small school near the downtown area of the capital this morning, and, according to witnesses, were set upon by a mob of 50 to 100 men believed to be remnants of the Tontons Macoute, the old bodyguard of the deposed dictator, Jean-Claude Duvalier. **********The attackers rushed the panicked voters at the Ecole Argentine de Bellegarde, hacking with machetes and firing guns indiscriminately into the frenzied crowd, according to the witnesses, who described the ensuing violence. **********The voters fled into the school. Several caught in the school's central courtyard were dismembered with machetes or shot to death, despite their pleas to be spared. **********The carnage appeared no less horrifying for those trapped inside the classrooms, who tried to hide in corners, behind partitions and under piles of overturned school supplies. **********The killers moved from classroom to classroom killing their victims. Those who were shot died huddled together, to be found and photographed by journalists who arrived soon afterward. Others lay sprawled in pools of blood. **********Haitian radio reports, supported by the accounts of numerous witnesses, said ''at least 15 people'' were killed in the incident at the Ecole Argentine de Bellegarde. Some journalists who visited the school after the massacre thought the death toll was much higher. **********The early-morning blood bath followed a night of sustained automatic gunfire and occasional explosions in the capital. In bright daylight, the courage of the voters who dared line up at polling stations was met with brazen attacks by armed marauders, while soldiers and policemen looked on and, according to some witnesses, took part. **********''There was a lot of blood all over the place,'' said Les Stone, an American photographer. ''The place was all smashed to pieces. I couldn't count all the bodies. We were shot at and just got out as best we could.'' **********Another journalist, David Gollob, a reporter for the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, followed a fire truck commandeered by heavily armed soldiers along a stretch of several blocks from the capital's major international hotel to the school. 'An Utter Blood Bath' **********''It was an utter blood bath,'' Mr. Gollob said. ''Some of the dead were children. ''There were about 20 journalists there, with some screaming at others to help remove the injured.'' **********''The first thing we saw as we approached the school was a group of smashed-up cars, some bullet-riddled, some apparently forced off the road,'' abandoned just outside of the school's courtyard, Mr. Gollob said. ''There were dead bodies in the courtyard, and in classrooms everything was turned upside down, books, sewing machines, clothing.'' **********''Dead bodies were crouched together'' in classrooms, he said. ''Others were piled on the ground behind a wall. The police carried away a girl whose leg had been ripped apart. When another woman who had been shot saw them, she began screaming wildly.'' **********Another group of reporters who arrived at the school soon afterward were fired upon by soldiers, leaving one television cameraman from the Dominican Republic, Carlos Grullon, dead, and at least four others wounded, some seriously. Journalists 'Cornered' **********Peter T. Bentley, a contract photographer for Time magazine, said, ''They had us cornered in the school.'' **********''We heard the guns start popping,'' Mr. Bentley said, still visibly shaken. ''We just hopped over walls I couldn't believe I could scale.'' At about the same time, a camera crew for ABC News was attacked at the school. The crew's Haitian driver was shot in the back. Two American crew members were also wounded, one shot in the arm and another in the thigh. **********The ABC News crew managed to return to a downtown hotel that has served as the center for the international press corps, and were treated by doctors summoned by the United States Embassy. **********Joyce Kravitz, a spokeswoman for ABC News in New York, identified the wounded crew members as Javier Carillo, 33 years old, a Mexican camerman who was shot in the thigh, and Alfredo (Chino) Mejia, 29, a Salvadoran soundman who was shot in the elbow. New Outbreak of Firing **********As an ambulance screeched to a stop in front of the hotel to take the Haitian driver - the most seriously wounded member of the ABC News crew - to a local hospital, bursts of automatic gunfire sounded several hundred yards away, on the other side of the downtown area's public park and amphitheater. Hundreds of reporters and international observers scrambled for cover. **********A handful of French and American reporters who were at the school when the soldiers began their attack on journalists fled over schoolyard walls and took refuge in neighboring homes. **********A group of French reporters, alerted that their colleagues were stranded in the neighborhood, mounted a convoy to attempt their rescue, but were turned back by gunfire only two blocks from the hotel. Soldier's Help Is Asked **********A van driven by a Haitian officer accompanied by a soldier armed with an automatic rifle approached the hotel and the French reporters implored them to help extricate their friends. **********The officer replied, ''I am a member of the medical corps, go call the police,'' and drove away. **********An American photographer, J. B. Diederich, who was trapped with another reporter inside a house near the school, managed to telephone the hotel. Reporters then called the American embassy, which dispatched an armored car to rescue him. It was followed by a crew of French reporters, and when it approached the house where Mr. Diederich was hiding, honked four times. The stranded reporters ran out and were whisked away. **********Riding back to the safety of the hotel, Mr. Diederich said: ''The army did the shooting. They shot at me. They just massacred everybody.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/24/busin.main_headline: Careers; Job Plight Of Middle Managers
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/24/busin.print_headline: Careers; Job Plight Of Middle Managers
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/24/busin.body_text: **********THE plight of middle managers who are at least 50 years old and face dismissal because companies are reducing staffs continues to be sad. **********This group has markedly different needs from younger people who lose their jobs, and those needs often go unrecognized, according to William Brittain, a New York psychologist. **********At a breakfast meeting last week for corporate personnel managers that was held under the auspices of Swain & Swain, which specializes in placing laid-off managers, Dr. Brittain stressed that older employees had certain areas in which they take special pride. These include mastery of one thing well done, recognition and approval needs, success and achievement, security and avoidance of failure. **********''Most of these needs are filled exclusively by the job, which makes termination tough,'' he said. ''We misapprehend the needs of this older group and the psychological trauma involved in job loss, which is even worse if it comes without provocation or warning.'' **********When older middle managers learn of their impending dismissal, their reactions are usually fear first, followed by disbelief that they are about to lose their jobs, anger at the company and, finally, rueful acceptance, Dr. Brittain said. **********Make the break clean and sure, he advised the personnel experts. Often the dismissal is carried out not by an impersonal employment manager but by the employee's own superior. **********He recalled the case of a top executive, charged with dismissing a marketing manager, who said to the manager, ''I think you should give some consideration to whether you should be in this job.'' Rather than this, Dr. Brittain said, there should have been forthrightness. **********According to James E. Challenger, president of Challenger, Gray & Christmas, a Chicago placement company, the older, experienced managers being dismissed in droves these days do find jobs eventually, but usually with much smaller companies. ''They go to smaller companies that need their particular experience,'' he said, often at higher salaries. **********Mr. Challenger said last week that, based on a survey of his clients, half the 50-to-60-year-old employees required a median of more than three and a half months to find a job during the third quarter of 1987, not much longer than job seekers of all ages. A median is a midpoint, meaning that half the older job seekers found employment in three and a half months or less, while the other half took longer. **********Mr. Challenger also noted an increase in age discrimination lawsuits brought by middle-aged losers of jobs, with 54 percent filed by those aged 50 to 59. **********Almost always paid by the companies doing the dismissing, outplacement concerns try to soothe the bitterness and rampant anger of dismissed managers, arguing that they stand much less chance of finding a good job if they sue their former employer. **********However, if severance payments are not generous, many who have lost jobs consider that a lawsuit handled by an able lawyer gives them better odds of receiving what they consider adequate compensation. **********Meanwhile, more and more dismissed older managers, especially those with master of business administration degrees, have been contacting the universities from which they graduated. Many graduate schools of business, such as Columbia and New York University, regularly circulate lists of job openings gleaned from alumni and company personnel managers. **********Although a college contact is always worth a try, few dismissed managers can expect much help from their undergraduate institutions beyond advice on interviewing and resumes. **********Waldo I. Scott. assistant director of career planning for alumni affairs at Colgate University, in Hamilton, N.Y., said last week that ''what I have done is refer a couple of older managers to alumni.'' **********They were former Exxon Corporation managers with six-figure salaries and 16 to 18 years of experience with the company and they did find jobs, he said. Last year he heard from a dozen or more older alumni looking for jobs, but now such requests have pretty much ''dried up,'' he added. **********His alumni board told him that ''your main concern ought to be graduates out three and five years because the older ones should have their own networks,'' he said. **********At Lawrence University, in Appleton, Wis., Gayle Hardt, director of career planning, pointed out a difficulty faced by colleges small and large -finding enough time to help. Lawrence has 1,150 undergraduates who need her advice about summer jobs, internships, careers and jobs after graduation. She runs a one-person office, with the help of a secretary and a part-time assistant. In past years she has received few calls from older alumni who have lost jobs. ''It has been nothing overwhelming,'' she said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/01/world.body_text: **********A missing South Korean passenger plane was reported today to have crashed in the jungle along the Thai-Burmese border, and the airline president said a terrorist's bomb was the most likely cause. **********The plane, a Boeing 707 carrying 115 people, had been missing for nearly a full day after disappearing over Burma and western Thailand on its way to Seoul from the Middle East. **********The disappearance fed intense, and varied, speculation that the jetliner, Korean Air Flight 858, had fallen victim to a hijacking, or a midair explosion, or perhaps simple mechanical failure. The plane, bought from the Boeing Company in 1971, had a history of trouble, and was reportedly to have been taken out of service on Jan. 1. **********As recently as Sept. 2, its landing gear could not be lowered, and it was forced to make a belly-landing at Kimpo International Airport in Seoul. **********But the president of Korean Air, Cho Choong Kun, said this evening, ''It's difficult to think of any other speculation except that it was a bombing.'' **********Most of the passengers were South Korean construction workers returning home from assignments in the Middle East. Also on the passenger list was Seoul's consul-general in Baghdad, Kang Suk Jae. The only non-Koreans on board were an Indian and a Lebanese national living in the United Arab Emirates. **********Flight 858 had begun in Baghdad, stopped in Abu Dhabi in the United Arab Emirates, and was on its way toward a scheduled refueling stop in Bangkok when its signal disappeared from radar screens.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/11/busin.body_text: **********Despite the turmoil in its stock and currency markets, Japan's economy is continuing to rebound from nearly two years of sluggish growth caused by the soaring yen.
