But economists have begun to worry that the dollar's rapid fall against the yen in recent days could slow the robust recovery. **********What is most remarkable about this recovery - and most important for the future of Japan's economy -is that it is taking place entirely in the domestic sector, rather than in the export industries that have historically driven Japanese growth. **********Japan's trading partners have long urged the nation to reduce its reliance on exports so that it can cut its huge trade surpluses. While this recovery shows that domestic demand can indeed spur the economy, it is by no means clear that domestic growth is reducing Japanese manufacturers' commitment to export or Japan's trade surplus with the United States. Japan's Idea of a Recession **********Dissatisfaction over Japan's trade surplus prompted the major industrial democracies to drive down the value of the dollar in September 1985. That move led to what the Japanese consider a recession - unemployment rose and corporate profits fell - although there were never two consecutive quarters of economic decline, the standard measure of a recession in the United States. **********Japan's economy began to bounce back in the summer, and its recent domestic growth continue to be strong, with increases in housing starts, industrial production, equipment investment and consumer spending. Despite the dollar's renewed fall, economists say they are not yet lowering their predictions that Japan's economy will grow by more than 3 percent in this fiscal year, which ends in March 1988. **********''The domestic economy is firing on all cylinders right now,'' said Ron Napier, an economist for Salomon Brothers here. **********But economists fear that improvements in the export sector of the economy may be imperiled if the yen continues to rise against the dollar. The dollar closed today in Tokyo at 133.65 yen, a new low. **********As a rule of thumb, said Hidehiro Iwaki, an economist with the Nomura Research Institute, if the yen appreciates against the dollar by 10 yen, the gross national product should drop by 1 percent because Japan's exports will either increase in price or corporate profit margins will fall. The institute is not revising its estimate of 3.2 percent growth for this fiscal year, he said. But if the yen continues to rise, the effects could be felt in the next fiscal year, which begins in April 1988. The institute had predicted 3 percent growth for that year, but is now reducing that estimate, he said. Effect of the Market Plunge **********Other economists are more optimistic. Mr. Napier said that the previous appreciation of the yen against the dollar had been far more severe. ''In 1986, you had months when the yen was up 30 percent from the previous year,'' he said. ''Now we're only talking about 15 to 20 percent if you assume a 125 yen rate. That's brutal, but only about half as brutal as 1986.'' **********Many analysts are worried about the effect of the stock market collapse on the United States economy. If American economic growth slows, Japan's economy will also be hurt because Americans will be less likely to buy Japanese exports. But there have been few signs of an American slowdown since the market's plunge. **********''We were looking for good recovery of corporate profits on the manufacturing side for next year, but not now,'' said Peter J. Morgan, the chief economist for the British investment firm of Barclays de Zoete Wedd. ''Slower United States growth means slower exports, slower investment, slower income growth and slower spending.'' **********Of far less concern to economists is the effect of falling stock prices in Japan. The Nikkei average of 225 stocks dropped 731.91 points today, to 21,686.46 yen, lower than its closing on Oct. 20, when the Tokyo market plummeted after Wall Street's huge selloff. Economists predict, however, that the declines to date will not slow economic growth appreciably. Fewer Japanese Shareholders **********For one thing, Mr. Napier said, relatively few Japanese individuals have extensive stockholdings. Thus, the Japanese have less of their personal wealth tied up in stocks, which means that a severe market decline would not necessarily lead to cutbacks in consumer spending. That possibility has been raised in the United States. Households own about 30 percent of all Japanese equities, compared with household ownership of more than 60 percent in the United States, according to the Federal Reserve Board. **********In addition, Mr. Iwaki said, stock prices in Japan have not fallen nearly as much in percentage terms as they have on stock exchanges in other parts of the world. **********Despite some warning signs, most economists think that economic growth will continue to be brisk. The recovery is being buoyed by strong consumer spending, an infusion of Government public works spending and a boom in housing construction. **********Few statistics are available yet to measure economic growth since mid-October, when stock prices began to dive and the dollar began to fall further. But Mr. Napier said that two reliable indicators of economic growth - tax collections and electricity generation - increased in October from levels of a year earlier. These growth rates were also higher than those recorded in September. Bonuses Are Expected to Rise **********Moreover, consumer spending, already strong, should get an extra lift from the prospect of high winter bonuses this year. Traditionally, employees receive several months' pay as bonuses twice a year. For the past two seasons, bonuses have fallen, but they are expected to increase between 4 and 5 percent, Mr. Napier said, because of the upturn in the Japanese economy. **********Other indexes of domestic demand continued strong in September. Industrial production was up 4.7 percent from the previous year. Growth was particularly strong in manufacturing industries that concentrate on the domestic market, such as chemicals and steel. Retail sales increased 6.9 percent in September. Machinery orders, an indication of companies' capital spending plans, increased 16.9 percent in August. **********Housing starts also rose 26.8 percent in September from the previous year. While the housing boom may slow slightly, Mr. Napier said the Government's decision to ease monetary policy might push mortgage rates lower and therefore spur spending on housing. **********Corporate profits, particularly those in the domestic sector of the economy, are also recovering. Mr. Napier said that preliminary reports of profits in the period from April through September show average increases of 39.2 percent. Lagging Exports **********In contrast to this domestic growth, exports continue to declne, while manufacturing industries primarily dependent on exports are also lagging. Economists predict that the falling dollar and the prospects of slower growth in the United States will further depress exports. **********''Manufacturers are turning to the domestic market,'' said Nobumitsu Kagami, chief economist of the Nomura Investment Management Company. ''With the yen where it is, they feel that exports are no longer as profitable as before, and they are finding more profit opportunities at home.'' **********One example is consumer electronics companies like the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, which sells its products under such brand names as National and Panasonic. Matsushita has reduced its reliance on exports and developed new products like the ''home bakery,'' an automatic bread-baking machine that is a phenomenal success in Japan. **********Automobile companies, which have historically made most of their money from export sales, have also been devoting more attention to the domestic market. Benjamin Moyer, an analyst with Merrill Lynch & Company in Japan, said that several companies have rushed out new models and have seen a resulting pickup in domestic sales. They have also acted to make the domestic market profitable, switching to less-expensive imported components that reduced manufacturing costs while keeping vehicle prices the same. **********Economists caution, however, that most manufacturers do not consider domestic sales a replacement for exports, and predict that companies will not slacken their export drives. Japan's overall trade surplus has fallen steadily and imports are up sharply, Mr. Napier said. But the improvements do not extend to the United States, whose trade deficit with Japan has dropped only slightly. **********''Too many export industries have such a large unused capacity that they can meet domestic demand and still hunger for more export volume,'' Mr. Napier said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/07/world.main_headline: SRI LANKA'S TIES WITH INDIA WORSEN
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/07/world.print_headline: SRI LANKA'S TIES WITH INDIA WORSEN
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/07/world.body_text: **********The ethnic problems that have burst into violence here in recent weeks have strained relations between Sri Lanka and its powerful northern neighbor, India. **********The two nations, faced with both internal and external problems related to the conflict, have accused each other of encouraging violence. **********Sri Lanka's President, J. R. Jayewardene, said this week that India was taking a ''Hitlerian, not Gandhian,'' approach to the conflict. Military Measures Criticized **********India's External Affairs Minister, Narayan Dutt Tiwari, chided Sri Lanka, which has started a military offensive against Tamil rebels. ''You cannot achieve a political settlement by bombing your own people,'' he said. **********Local and foreign analysts in Colombo say that as the ethnic tensions have grown more intractable, the divisions between the two nations have also become more difficult to resolve. **********The Tamil minority that is agitating for a separate state in the northern and eastern portions of Sri Lanka also forms a powerful ethnic group in the south of India that poses an internal problem for the central Government. **********Political analysts agree that no lasting solution to the problem can be reached without Indian participation. India Called Part of the Problem **********But in recent days, officials in Colombo, including Mr. Jayewardene, have said India itself is part of the problem. **********The ethnic conflict involves Tamil separatists in the northern peninsula of Jaffna, some of whom have taken refuge in the southern Indian state of Tamil Nadu. **********The Tamils make up only 18 percent of Sri Lanka's population - and these are divided between Tamils of the north, the center of militant separatism, and Tamils of the south-central hill country, who are not separatists -but 50 million Tamils live in Tamil Nadu, more than Sri Lanka's total population of 16 million. **********Sri Lanka has complained that guerrillas are being given refuge in Tamil Nadu. If the Indian Government were to join in halting supplies to the rebels, Mr. Jayewardene said last week, ''this war would be over in days.'' **********But political analysts in Colombo said the Government in New Delhi had little political leverage in Tamil Nadu, which is controlled by opposition politicians and where the Tamil issue is a highly emotional one. **********They also said New Delhi might have lost any influence over the Sri Lankan separatist groups who must be brought to the negotiating table. India's Stake in Unrest Cited **********Both Sri Lankan and Western analysts also suggested that India may have a stake in continuing unrest in Sri Lanka, whose independent foreign policy is seen as a threat. **********India is seen as suspicious of Sri Lanka's free-market economic policies and of the possibility that it could be used by the United States for a military role in the Indian Ocean. **********The Indian ambassador, Jyotindra Nath Dixit, in an interview this week, compared his country's relations with Sri Lanka to those of other big nations with small, troublesome southern neighbors. **********Choosing his words carefully, he suggested parallels with the United States and Nicaragua, China and Vietnam, and the Soviet Union and Afghanistan. Plan to Use Force Denied **********Mr. Dixit quickly denied any implication that India contemplated using armed force in Sri Lanka. But a highly placed Sri Lankan official said the Ambassador's remarks were not to be taken lightly. ''Mr. Dixit always says exactly what he means,'' the official said. **********He dismissed the idea that India might use armed force against Sri Lanka, but he said his country was feeling strong and unwelcome pressure from India in resolving its problems. **********He accused the Indians of having aided Tamil guerrillas in an effort to destabilize Sri Lanka but, he said, ''the monster has grown to the point where Indian authorities no longer control it.'' **********India does not want the separatists to succeed in Sri Lanka and set a precedent for its own Tamils or other minorities, he said. But it also hopes to use the continuing unrest as leverage over Sri lanka.''Therefore, it does not want either side to win,'' he said. Indian Backing Seen as Necessary **********A Western diplomat said Sri Lanka, which has stated a hard-line position toward the Tamil guerrillas, was dependent on India for help in reaching a compromise. **********But the diplomat said the fear in Colombo was that ''once the Indians come in, they're not going to go away.'' **********When Sri Lanka called on India for military aid in controlling a Marxist group in 1971, he said, ''they were shocked to see how fast the help came.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/22/jobs/.main_headline: Development and Jobs Speed Along Route 1
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/22/jobs/.print_headline: Development and Jobs Speed Along Route 1
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/22/jobs/.body_text: **********NEW JERSEY'S Route 1 corridor, a rapidly developing nine-mile stretch of highway between New Brunswick and the Princeton-Trenton region, has become a magnet for corporate and technological concerns - and for jobs to make them run - as the state's economy continues its boom. **********''New companies are coming in every day on Route 1, and the outlook is phenomenal,'' said Joseph E. Stoye, president of an executive- recruitment firm in Princeton. ''Buildings are going up continuously.'' **********According to Borden R. Putnam, the New Jersey Commissioner of Commerce and Development, Route 1 ''is a tremendously promising area for jobs and careers,'' though he cautioned that ''right at the moment it is a little overbuilt, with a 25 to 30 percent vacancy factor'' that he predicted would be temporary. **********The approximately 75 corporate buildings flanking the corridor, on U.S. Route 1 in Middlesex and Mercer counties, currently house some 750 companies employing 77,000 people. About 160,000 more jobs are expected to be filled on the corridor by the year 2000. **********John P. Keith, president of the Regional Plan Association, a New York-based research organization concerned with the coordinated development of the Jersey, New York and Connecticut area, voiced concern over the broad planning picture in the corridor. ''Although individual Route 1 buildings are well planned,'' he said, ''there has been no overall planning for the corridor, especially as related to transportation and traffic.'' Asked if inadequate transportation and traffic problems might tend to deter people outside the corridor from wanting to work there, Mr. Keith noted that many people struggle to get to work in Manhattan and added: ''If it isn't easy to get to Route 1, people will, nevertheless, accept employment there if the jobs are worth getting to.'' **********One major need in the corridor area is for engineers, especially for the increasing number of electronic and telecommunications companies along the corridor. Another is for bank employees. ''There are a lot of banking jobs -so many that we can't fill them fast enough,'' a result of business expansion and heavy financial activity in the corridor, Mr. Stoye said. Other positions available are for financial analysts, counselors and planners. Consultants should also be in demand; four consulting firms on international business opened in one building in the last year. **********One indication of corporate growth on the highway is membership in the Princeton Chamber of Commerce. Last year, it had 1,100 members, representing hundreds of companies; the figure is now above 2,000. **********At a conference last month in Cherry Hill, N.J., sponsored by the Mid-Atlantic Association of Personnel Consultants, half the participants were executive recruiters seeking to fill openings in banks on Route 1. These include positions as commercial loan officers and other top bank management and staff slots, for the fast-moving financial needs and changes on the strip. United Jersey Banks, the state's largest financial institution, has opened its headquarters here, and more banks are on the way. **********The largest personnel needs of companies on the Route 1 corridor, however, are for back-office employees, business services, sales and marketing personnel at all levels. ''Meat and potatoes people, but paying good salaries, in many cases,'' according to the manager of a personnel agency who did not want to be identified. **********Mr. Stoye, a longtime resident of the area who has observed Route 1 growth from its beginnings about 10 years ago, does not believe that calling the corridor New Jersey's ''Silicon Valley'' is quite justified yet. ''At this time, it is more of a telecommunications type of tech, not the advanced computer-dominated technology that blankets California's Silicon Valley,'' he said. **********Nevertheless, he ticked off the names of many companies that need engineers. They include the RCA Corporation and three of its divisions: American Communications, Astro Electronics and the Sarnoff Research Center; Mobil Research and Development Corporation; E.R. Squibb & Sons, with headquarters at Lawrenceville and laboratories in Franklin Township, and Johnson & Johnson, the medical-supplies company. M.B.A.'s are also needed, ''especially if they are technically oriented,'' Mr. Stoye said. The largest potential employers are the university- and business-related high-technology centers being established by the permanent New Jersey Commission on Science and Technology, which will require staff members for new businesses and joint ventures. The four centers to be built on Route 1 will do research and development in biotechnology and medicine, computer aid to industrial production, food technology and scientific computing. **********Bordering the corridor are acres of former farmland on which houses are going up by the hundreds, convenient for those who work nearby. But the pastoral quality remains, in large part because many of the modern-design buildings are not visible from the highway. One vast complex, for example, is more than a mile off the road. **********Most jobs at companies along the Route 1 corridor pay well, according to Mr. Stoye, including support personnel - secretaries, receptionists, clerical workers and word-processing staff. Secretaries getting $28,000 are not uncommon, he said. **********Though salaries are not as high as in New York, according to William Hogan, president of Management Recruiters in Princeton, they are offset by New Jersey's lower state income tax and by the absence of city taxes. In addition, commuting for most people in the state is much cheaper. **********Houses in the Princeton area along the corridor are more expensive than in Bergen County, near New York City, according to real estate estimates. The average cost of a house in the Princeton area is $250,000, compared with $150,000 in Bergen County. Renting in the corridor, however, is still reasonable. **********Although Route 1 does not yet pose a threat to Silicon Valley, more high-technology companies are settling in. The centerpiece of these new firms will be the supercomputer research center at Princeton University, which will operate one of the world's fastest computers. The center is one project of the state Science and Technology Commission, whose goal is to convert the state from its faded ''smokestack-industry'' image to a high-technology economy. **********Mr. Putnam, the New Jersey Commerce Commissioner, said that the job range on the corridor reflected the state's wide economic diversity. He pointed out that a downturn in one industry - insurance, for example -might be offset by an upturn in banking, with commensurate job opportunities. He said Route 1 was a prime example of such diversity, and added, ''The corridor is the hottest area in the state and will continue to be.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/25/busin.main_headline: TAKEOVER CLOUDS FUTURE FOR CARLING CHAIRMAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/25/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; TAKEOVER CLOUDS FUTURE FOR CARLING CHAIRMAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/25/busin.body_text: **********Pierre Des Marais 2d has been a mayor, president of an aircraft company and, since last October, chairman of Carling O'Keefe Ltd. But his position at Canada's third-largest brewery has now become uncertain. **********Carling O'Keefe is the object of a $294.3 million takeover offer by one of Australia's biggest companies, Elders IXL Ltd. The brewer's controlling shareholder, Rothmans Inc., the Canadian unit of Rothmans International P.L.C., has said it will tender its 50.1 percent stake to Elders. **********Elders said it planned to maintain current management if its bid was successful, but it could not be determined whether Mr. Des Marais wants to stay on under a new ownership. He was not available for an interview, a spokesman said. **********Mr. Des Marais, who has been on the board of the Toronto-based brewer since 1983, was named chairman in October when S. Roderick McInnes resigned abruptly as chairman, president and chief executive. **********Mr. McInnes left Carling after the brewer experienced more than two years of lagging performance, analysts said. The mission of Mr. Des Marais, who subsequently became president and chief executive as well as chairman, was to revive Carling's fortunes. **********Carling O'Keefe, the No. 3 brewer in Canada, behind John Labatt Ltd. and Molson Companies Ltd., has a market share of about 25 percent. It is licensed to sell Miller beer in Canada, and since last year has also sold the popular Elders beer, Fosters Lager. Carling owns the Quebec Nordiques hockey team, while Molson owns the rival Montreal Canadiens. **********Mr. Des Marais, 52 years old, was president of Canadair, a maker of executive jets, until the Government sold the company to Bombardier Inc. last year. His family owns one of Canada's largest printing companies, Pierre Des Marais Inc., based in Montreal and founded by Mr. Des Marais's father. **********The younger Mr. Des Marais was managing director and later president of the family company. He was also active in Montreal public life, serving as Mayor of Outremont, a Montreal suburb, for 13 years, and was a leader in the fight to keep businesses from leaving Montreal in the late 1970's at the height of the Quebec separatist sentiment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/03/busin.main_headline: London Seeks Part Of A.D.R. Market
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/03/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL REPORT; London Seeks Part Of A.D.R. Market
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/03/busin.body_text: **********In recent years, London has watched with alarm as much of the equity trading in Britain's flagship companies has crossed the Atlantic to Wall Street, where non-American shares are bought and sold in the convenient, dollar-denominated form of American depositary receipts. **********In the United States, where once-parochial investors are increasingly buying foreign shares, A.D.R.'s represent one of the fastest-growing segments of the equity market. The National Association of Securities Dealers' over-the-counter market, which handles most A.D.R. issues, saw turnover jump more than 70 percent last year, after a gain of 53 percent in 1985. **********But London is now striking back, trying to bring this lucrative market back home. Starting Monday, A.D.R.'s will be officially traded on London's stock exchange. The receipts represent the stock in non-American companies whose shares remain physically outside the United States. A.D.R.'s can be bought and sold just like the underlying securities. **********''Some of the trading of A.D.R.'s will be brought back to London,'' said Richard Seaward, a trader at County NatWest Ltd., the securities arm of the National Westminster Bank, Britain's largest commercial bank. ''In a few years, we should be taking business away from New York.'' Another Sign of Globalization **********The advent of A.D.R. trading in London is another sign of the growing globalization of the major stock markets. The shares of multinational companies are becoming worldwide commodities that investors can trade almost round the clock. For example, key customers for A.D.R. market makers in London are expected to be American institutional investors eager to take advantage of the five-hour time difference between London and New York to trade in London before Wall Street opens. **********''A lot of Americans will get up very early in the morning, particularly if they've got a big position in an active stock,'' said Vincent Mackney, a director of Warburg Securities Ltd. **********London's A.D.R. bid is also part of a fight for market share in world equity trading, with London and New York the leading rivals. With many countries easing rules on cross-border investment, share trading tends to migrate to the most efficient and liquid markets. Already, for instance, London has strengthened its claim as Europe's major stock market by taking trading away from such Continental bourses as those in Amsterdam, Frankfurt and Paris. Now, it is going after the A.D.R. business. **********''There's a bit of a war for turf going on around the world,'' said James M. Davin, chairman of the National Association of Securities Dealers. ''And this A.D.R. move in London is part of that.'' London's Success Uncertain **********Just how successful the London assault on the A.D.R. market will be is uncertain. Some British market experts predict London could grab as much as 20 percent of the A.D.R. market within a year, and more later. London, they say, is the natural market for trading the A.D.R.'s of European companies on the presumption that it is closer to the companies and London stock analysts follow the companies more closely. **********Still, even those most enthusiastic about the move do not foresee a British takeover of A.D.R.'s. ''This will allow London to get a slice of the action,'' said Paul Manson, an analyst for Kleinwort Grieveson, a London brokerage. ''But the main market will remain in the U.S.'' **********For their part, the major American securities houses remain skeptical. Major A.D.R. traders such as Merrill Lynch, Shearson Lehman, Morgan Stanley, First Boston and Goldman, Sachs have all decided against becoming market makers in London for the moment, even though they all have huge London offices. ''We're going to monitor it closely,'' said Mr. Davin, who is also a managing director of the First Boston Corporation. ''And we will make markets in A.D.R.'s in London if our customers want it.'' **********In London, the market makers will display A.D.R. prices and trades on the exchange's automated quotation system. The information will be available simultaneously in the United States to firms linked to London's computerized quote network. Seven Firms Involved **********At the outset, seven firms will be A.D.R. market makers in London, including four British houses: Warburg, Kleinwort Grieveson, County NatWest and Smith New Court. Two American-owned London brokers will also participate, Citicorp's Scrimgeour Vickers and Security Pacific's Hoare Govett. In addition, a New York-based market making specialist, Bernard L. Madoff Investment Securities, will be involved. **********Though more A.D.R.'s are expected to be traded as more market makers join, the start-up list contains just 11 issues, led by such well-known British names as British Petroleum, Shell, Glaxo, Jaguar and Imperial Chemical Industries. At least three firms must make a market in the issue if it is to be traded in London. **********American dealers doubt whether the rather thin market in London can compete with that of the United States, where more than 120 issues are traded and liquidity is far greater. For a popular A.D.R. like Jaguar, for example, there are more than 40 market makers trading its stock on the Nasdaq market in the United States.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/06/busin.body_text: **********MOST analysts continue to give high marks to the temporary-help business - a niche industry that sprang into the Wall Street spotlight this week on the strength of a surprise takeover bid from abroad. **********On Tuesday, Blue Arrow P.L.C., the leading employment agency in Britain, offered $75 a share for Manpower Inc., the largest worldwide provider of temporary-help services. The market's immediate response was to send Manpower's stock shooting ahead $15.625, to $78. In Big Board trading yesterday, the shares gained 50 cents, to $78.50. **********While the outcome of the bid for Manpower remains uncertain, shares of other leading temporary-help companies in the United States - Kelly Services, the Olsten Corporation and Adia Services - also reached new highs. However, Jerry Levine of Merrill Lynch said these companies are not regarded as acquisition targets because their control rests securely in the hands of founding families or, in the case of Adia, of a Switzerland-based personnel services company. **********Instead, industry analysts said that what has made these stocks attractive is their record of steady profit growth even in the face of a ho-hum domestic economy. For example, earnings of Kelly Services, the nation's largest supplier of temporary personnel, rose from 73 cents a share in 1982 to $2.27 a share in 1986. **********In one sense, temporary-help companies are a beneficiary of the vast restructuring that has occurred in American industry since the early 1980's, said Judith Scott of Robert W. Baird & Company in Milwaukee. ''As companies concentrated on reducing fixed costs, they realized the advantages and flexibility of using temporary workers in clerical, marketing, industrial and other capacities,'' she said. ''And as demand for new skills increased in such areas as computer programming and data processing, the service companies moved quickly to fill the need at the same time their own training procedures grew more sophisticated.'' **********One advantage, too, of hiring temporary help is that companies avoid paying for fringe benefits. These benefits are shouldered instead by the service companies. **********Mr. Levine of Merrill Lynch carries a ''buy'' investment rating for both Kelly Services and Olsten. ''I estimate earnings of Kelly Services at $2.85 a share this year and, for 1988, profits could show a further gain of 22 to 25 percent,'' he said. **********Olsten earned 75 cents a share in 1986, after adjustment for a recent 3-for-2 stock split. Mr. Levine projects profits of between 97 cents and $1 a share for this year. His estimate for 1988 is for earnings to increase by 25 percent to 30 percent. **********Mrs. Scott of Robert W. Baird & Company also continues to regard Kelly Services and Olsten as ''buys.'' Her estimates call for Kelly to earn $2.85 a share this year and $3.35 in 1988. As for Olsten, she envisions profits of $1 a share in 1987 and $1.20 next year. **********Both analysts said that profits for Kelly and Olsten will be enhanced in 1988 by the effect of lower corporate tax rates. **********Fran Blechman Bernstein, the Merrill Lynch analyst who follows buy-rated Adia Services, estimates net income at between $1.05 and $1.15 a share this year and at between $1.30 and $1.40 in 1988. Last year, the company earned 76 cents a share. **********D. Christine King of Kidder, Peabody & Company accords shares of Kelly Services a top rating for price performance over 9 to 12 months. Both Olsten and Adia Services are rated a notch lower and expected to outperform the general market moderately. **********The Value Line Investment Survey, which sees increased competition looming for Kelly Services, rates the stock as an average market performer in the next 6 to 12 months, despite its forecast of a 20 percent gain in earnings for 1987. It expects Olsten to outperform the market in the coming year. **********On the American Stock Exchange yesterday, Olsten rose 50 cents, to $27.25. The shares have doubled within the last 52 weeks. In over-the-counter trading, Kelly Services gained 75 cents, to $64.25. Its shares have quadrupled in price since mid-1984. Adia Services rose 12.5 cents, to $28.625. Another small but fast-growing company in the field is Uniforce Temporary Personnel. Its shares fell 50 cents, to $12.75, yesterday, after selling as low as $4 within the past year. **********Despite the bright future most analysts envision for the temporary-help companies, their growth could slow abruptly in the event of a severe economic recession. The last recession, for example, pared the profits of Kelly Services from $1.10 a share in 1981 to 73 cents the following year. In the similar period, Olsten's earnings dropped from 43 cents a share to 31 cents. **********''One advantage of this industry is that it is neither capital intensive nor burdened with debt,'' noted Mrs. Scott. ''Thus, the hope is that temporary-help companies could pull in their horns and weather a recession fairly well.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/18/busin.body_text: **********The Chrysler Corporation said today that in some cases it would keep prices steady on its 1988 model domestic cars and in other cases raise them by as much as 5 percent. The decision is tentative, it said, while it completes its pricing strategy. The company said it would not be able to provide an average price increase until all models were introduced in September.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/26/world.main_headline: RUSSIANS HOLD KEY TO POWER, BUT NOT TO AFGHANISTAN'S SOUL
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/26/world.print_headline: RUSSIANS HOLD KEY TO POWER, BUT NOT TO AFGHANISTAN'S SOUL
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/26/world.body_text: **********The rug merchants speak Russian, but gladly accept personal checks for dollars that they deposit in New York bank accounts. **********The stores stock Russian jams, cookies and vodka, but also sell Colgate toothpaste and Heineken beer. **********The Russians, following their custom, installed elevated traffic booths at major intersections here to help maintain order, but the Afghan police rarely use them and the streets are never orderly. A Country Between Cultures **********After seven years of the Soviet military presence, Afghanistan seems to be a country caught between cultures and political allegiances. To a visitor familiar with the Soviet Union, it seemed a country with a Soviet system but not a Soviet soul. **********The topography alone - towering mountain ranges and isolated valleys, huge areas of uninhabited desert -seems to form a natural barrier to the centralized ethos of Marxism-Leninism. **********During a carefully controlled five-day visit by foreign reporters the authorities portrayed Afghanistan differently. They described it as a country living harmoniously under Communism with a party, Government and people dedicated to building a new Socialist order. 'Our Great Northern Neighbor' **********The Soviet Union, described by the Afghan leader, Najib, as ''our great northern neighbor,'' was depicted as a generous guarantor of security against foreign aggression and a source of political inspiration. **********Travel and meetings were arranged by the authorities to support these images, and independent reporting was discouraged. Apart from a brief trip to the provincial city of Jalalabad and the surrounding countryside near the Pakistan border, the reporters were confined to Kabul, the capital. **********But even with the constraints, it was apparent that the reality of Afghanistan was a good deal more intricate, involving a volatile political and social chemistry in which Soviet influence is strong but not completely dominant. **********Under the ostensibly cohesive Socialist surface, there were clearly powerful opposing forces. These included longstanding tribal tensions and distrust of central authority, the growing appeal of Islamic fundamentalism and bitter divisions within the Afghan Communist movement itself. No Quick End in Sight **********Combined with a long history of opposition to foreign intervention, these forces seem likely to impede a political settlement of the seven-year war, the formation of a credible coalition government and the withdrawal of the estimated 120,000 Soviet troops here. **********''Afghanistan has never been one nation, and it is not under Communism,'' one Western diplomat said. ''Historically, it is a land of many peoples and cultures that resisted central authority. Afghanistan in its natural state is an unruly patchwork of autonomous valleys and villages. **********''Moscow cannot Sovietize Afghanistan unless it colonizes it, and that would require an act of conquest, which is not in the cards,'' the diplomat added. ''Afghanistan is a Soviet satellite but not the 16th Soviet republic.'' An Afghan Politburo **********Some in the West have compared Afghanistan, which before the beginning of the war had a population of 15.4 million, to Soviet Central Asia, contending that it was rapidly becoming indistinguishable from the Uzbek and Tadzhik republics just across the Soviet border. **********The Afghan political system is unmistakably patterned on the Soviet Union's, with power held by the Communist Party, known officially as the People's Democratic Party of Afghanistan. The party apparatus includes a Central Committee, Politburo and Secretariat, with Mr. Najib serving as General Secretary of the Central Committee. **********As in Moscow, there is a nominal parliament, the Revolutionary Council, and the president of the council fills the largely ceremonial role of head of state. #9,000 Soviet Civilian Advisers The Government bureacracy is filled with Soviet advisers who, one diplomat said, ''sit at the elbow of every important Afghan official.'' Diplomats said there were about 9,000 Soviet civilian advisers in Kabul. **********The powerful and repressive secret police, the Khad, which Mr. Najib headed until he became a party secretary in December 1985, has close ties to the K.G.B., the Soviet state security agency, Western diplomats said. **********With the grafting of the Soviet political system have come Communist rituals and slogans, some with an Afghan accent, that were familiar to a visitor from Moscow. Officials greeted each other as ''comrade'' and lavished praise on the party and the Afghan revolution. **********In a speech to the National Fatherland Front, a coalition of pro-Government groups, Mr. Najib, echoing words spoken by dozens of officials at the Soviet party congress last February, declared, ''In the current stage of the revolution our main duty is to restructure all spheres of life in Afghan society.'' Less Equality in Kabul **********The director of a state farm near the Pakistan border proudly told visiting reporters that 500 farm workers were loyal party members, some serving on local party committees. ''Everyone from the director to field workers lives in the same kind of housing,'' he said. **********Such equality appeared not to be the rule in Kabul, where residents and Western diplomats said senior party activists and leaders enjoy special privileges, including spacious new apartments and special clinics - privileges common for party members in the Soviet Union. **********Afghan television mirrored Soviet programming, with an emphasis on ideologically safe themes. The evening news program offered a mix of pro-Government and anti-American reports. **********The Government-controlled information outlets, mimicking Pravda and Izvestia, published texts of party declarations and speeches by Mr. Najib, who only uses one name, on the front page under flattering headlines. Education System Reorganized **********The main article in the Jan. 13 edition of The Kabul New Times, an English-language paper, began, ''Comrade Najib, General Secretary of the People's Democratic Party of Afghanistan Central Committee, took part in a grand function devoted to the seventh anniversary of the State Security Ministry.'' **********The education system, according to Western diplomats, has been reorganized along Soviet lines, with intense indoctrination woven into the curriculum beginning in kindergarten. Western diplomats said 40,000 Afghan students were enrolled in Soviet universities. **********Black Volgas, tan Zhigulis and other Soviet-made cars cruised the streets of Kabul. As in Moscow, access to official cars seemed to carry a license to drive three times the speed limit and to ignore traffic lights. **********Russian rivals English, and may have surpassed it, as the preferred foreign language. Nearly all Afghan civilian and military officials speak Russian and use it to converse with representatives from Moscow, according to Afghan aides who accompanied the reporters almost everywhere they went. Mailbox Labeled in Russian **********Most shopkeepers in Kabul and Jalalabad started conversations with foreigners in Russian, and were surprised to find some visitors were Americans. **********Afghan children roaming the bazaar in Jalalabad, apparently thinking they were approaching a group of Russians, told Western reporters in Russian that they could arrange female companionship for the right price. One Afghan urchin reeled off a series of Russian expletives that would have made an adult Muscovite blush. **********At the Spinghar Hotel in Jalalabad the mailbox nailed to the wall was labeled with the Russian word for ''post.'' **********Western diplomats said that Afghan cultural traditions had survived the Soviet military intervention, but that nonconformist writing and art had been discouraged and the intellectual life of Kabul had moved underground. 'Serious Scholars Have Fled' **********''The university, built with American and British aid, is a shell filled with Communist cant,'' one Western diplomat said. ''Serious Afghan scholars have fled abroad.'' **********Despite the Soviet influence, Afghanistan seemed to have retained a diversity and spontaneity rarely found in the Soviet Union. Afghans and Western diplomats said that efforts to impose central management on the economy were defeated by a feisty free-market spirit rooted in Afghanistan's historic role as a trade crossroads between Europe and Asia. **********The variety of goods available in shops in Kabul and Jalalabad were remarkable by Soviet standards. Electronics stores were crammed with Japanese tape decks and stereos. Grocery stores carried a dizzying variety of Soviet, American, British, French, Italian and Chinese goods. **********Money changers in the Kabul bazaar handed foreigners bags full of Afghan money at triple the Government exchange rate. American dollars were welcomed like gold, rubles dismissed with a flick of the hand as almost worthless. Anti-Government Demonstrations **********Almost anything that could be sold was, including gallon cans of vegetable oil sent to many countries by Washington as part of American foreign assistance. The cans were marked: ''Furnished by the people of the United States of America. Not to be sold.'' **********One Kabul shopkeeper, glancing up from another transaction, said the cans were priced at $10 apiece. **********Political diversity, while limited by Western standards, appeared to exceed the Soviet norm. Western diplomats reported that the removal last May of Babrak Karmal as party chief ignited several anti-Government demonstrations. The diplomats speculated that he was removed because he had been identified with the Soviet intervention since 1979, and the Russians wanted a fresh face to lead a peace offensive. **********They said that Soviet troops and armor were called into Kabul to guard Government and party installations during the Central Committee meeting during which Mr. Karmal was ousted. **********As late as October, Karmal supporters openly showed their enthusiasm for the ousted leader, showering him with flowers and applause when he appeared at ceremonies marking the withdrawal of six Soviet regiments. Infighting Threatens Stability **********Mr. Karmal has not been seen in public for several months. Mr. Najib told the visiting reporters that the former leader was living quietly in retirement in Kabul, tending to personal affairs. **********Afghans and foreign diplomats said infighting between the two main groups in the Communist Party, the Parcham and Khalq factions, posed a serious threat to stability, including the possibility of a coup attempt some day. **********The Parchamites, Persian-speaking Communists allied with Moscow, have held sway within the party since the Soviet intervention in 1979. The Khalqs, who generally speak Pushtoon, are considered less elitist and not enthusiastic about the Soviet presence. **********Tribal antagonisms remain strong, not only between those allied with the Government and those who constitute the bulk of the guerrilla fighters, called mujahedeen, but within the opposing camps, diplomats said. Bad Blood Between Tribes **********The Western-supported insurgents have struggled to maintain a common front at the insistence of Washington, but bad blood among Afghan tribes goes back centuries. In addition, Islamic fundamentalism has become a growing factor in domestic affairs, diplomats said. **********Efforts by Mr. Najib to expand the role of women have offended many religious Afghans, and Moslem leaders have made clear they oppose the establishment of a Communist regime supported by Soviet troops. **********Mr. Najib, apparently sensitive to the Islamic threat, has called for religious tolerance. As part of his plan for national reconciliation, he has encouraged party and Government groups to establish links with Islamic organizations. Many Islamic leaders have links to the fundamentalist movement in Iran, which shares a long border with Afghanistan. **********The visiting reporters were taken to a Kabul mosque where they were told that the Government supported unobstructed worship. Unified Nation Called Unlikely **********Several Afghans said Mr. Najib's efforts to court the Moslem community were undermined recently when he was shown praying at a mosque with his shoes on, a serious breach of religious practice. **********Western diplomats said these divisive factors would make it extremely difficult to bring about the kind of national reconciliation outlined by Mr. Najib. **********''Even if the rebels lay down their arms, the millions of refugees return home and the Soviets leave, there can't be a unified Afghanistan,'' one diplomat said. ''Central authority just goes against the grain of these people.'' **********Recently, as Afghan tribal leaders assembled here for a meeting, a nearby bookseller was hawking Russian periodicals. **********The Afghan patriarchs approached the merchant's table one after another, stared momentarily at a handwritten sign advertising ''Books and magazines from the U.S.S.R.,'' then handed the man a coin and picked up a copy of the local Persian-language newspaper. **********Over the next four hours, as the tribesmen were harangued by a parade of foreign and Afghan speakers, including Mr. Najib, some of them surreptitiously read Islamic texts hidden in the folds of their robes.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/21/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; One-Time Gains Lift MCI Net
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/21/busin.body_text: **********The MCI Communications Corporation, the nation's second-largest long-distance carrier after the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, said yesterday that profits in the first quarter had increased 26.3 percent, to $25 million, from the first quarter of 1986. **********However, MCI's results included a $5 million tax credit and a $12 million pretax gain resulting from an antitrust settlement with the Bell System. Without these one-time gains, MCI's earnings would have been about $11 million, a decline of about 44 percent, the Washington-based company said. **********Three of the regional telephone companies formed in the 1984 breakup of A.T.& T. - the Bell Atlantic Corporation, U S West Inc. and the BellSouth Corporation - reported substantial increases in net income. **********Bell Atlantic, based in Philadelphia, said its profits rose 6.1 percent; U S West, based in Denver, posted a 13.5 percent increase; and BellSouth, based in Atlanta, had a 7.7 percent gain. **********Analysts said the results at the three regional telephone companies were generally in line with their projections. They predicted that earnings at the regional telephone companies would decrease as the Baby Bells reach the ceilings on their rates of return. **********MCI said net income in the first quarter was $25 million, or 9 cents a share, compared with $19.8 million, or 8 cents a share, for the comparable quarter a year earlier. Revenues rose 16.5 percent, to $995 million, from $819.4 million. **********Notwithstanding one-time benefits, MCI's profits in the first quarter contrasted sharply with its results in the 1986 fourth quarter, when the company posted a $502.5 million loss because of charges resulting from inventory write-downs and a restructuring of operations. Analysts said the company's earnings had benefited somewhat from a cost-cutting program. **********Although revenue grew during the quarter, MCI said operating income remained flat at about $52 million because of higher local connection fees. These access charges increased by $130 million, to $477 million, practically matching the company's revenue growth, which was $135 million, according to William E. Conway, MCI's chief financial officer. **********MCI said that despite a March 1 rate reduction of about 9 percent its revenue had increased 4 percent since December. The price cut was in response to similar reductions by A.T.& T. that resulted from lower local access charges paid by long-distance companies. **********Analysts said the MCI results met their expectations, but they forecast a rough year with another rate cut ahead.  U S West **********U S West said its profits were $204.2 million, or $1.08 a share, for the first three months of the year, compared with $179.9 million, or 94 cents a share, in the 1986 period. Revenues were essentially flat, at $2.04 billion, compared with $2.03 billion a year ago. **********Jack MacAllister, U S West's chairman and chief executive, said the company's profits were reduced $23.6 million, or 12 cents a share, by a one-time expense related to an incentive plan to reduce the number of employees. U S West also took a $6.6 million charge related to a refund order in Oregon.  Bell Atlantic **********Bell Atlantic reported first-quarter net income of $307.5 million, or $1.54 a share, compared with $289.9 million, or $1.45 a share, in the 1986 quarter. Revenues rose 4.2 percent, to $2.46 billion, from $2.36 billion. **********Thomas E. Bolger, chairman and chief executive, said the results reflected the impact of growth in regional business on Bell Atlantic's network services companies and improved earnings in its non-telephone operations.  BellSouth **********BellSouth posted a profit of $452.4 million, or 94 cents a share, up from $420 million, or 91 cents a share, in the 1986 quarter. Revenues increased 5 percent, to $2.95 billion, from $2.81 billion. **********Earnings tables, page D6.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/12/world.main_headline: JORDANIAN PLEDGE TO LIMIT RUSSIANS IN TALKS REPORTED
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/12/world.print_headline: JORDANIAN PLEDGE TO LIMIT RUSSIANS IN TALKS REPORTED
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/12/world.body_text: **********Jordan has made a commitment to the United States and Israel that would minimize the Soviet role in shaping a Middle East peace agreement, according to diplomatic sources familiar with a three-part memorandum of understanding between Jordan and Israel. **********The document includes a Jordanian agreement to limit the powers of an international conference, which would be convened as a stepping stone to direct negotiations between Jordan and Israel. This would apparently reduce the Soviet Union to a bystander in the process, an arrangement that pleases Washington but does not seem likely to be accepted by Moscow. Reported Meeting in London **********The memorandum's main provisions were reportedly negotiated at a meeting last month in London between King Hussein of Jordan and Foreign Minister Shimon Peres and Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel, and its final language is said to have been polished with the help of the United States's special Middle East envoy, Wat T. Cluverius 4th, who has been shuttling between Jerusalem and Amman. **********According to information from the diplomatic sources, the document contains two sections that are to be made public if the Israeli Cabinet agrees. Under the first provision, the Secretary General of the United Nations would invite the five permanent members of the Security Council - the United States, the Soviet Union, China, Britain and France - to convene a conference based on Security Council resolutions 242 and 338, which envision an Israeli withdrawal from occupied territories and imply the recognition of Israel's right to exist. Committees for Discussions **********The second part provides for the conference to invite ''geographical bilateral committees'' to conduct negotiations, according to the sources. **********The third part, which was to have been kept secret, reportedly says the conference would not impose any solution or veto any accord reached by the bilateral committees. This is described as a commitment that Jordan has made to the United States, and that the United States would convey to Israel. **********In that way, Jordan provides for the first time a clear definition of the severely curtailed powers it envisions for the international conference. **********King Hussein has called for a conference to provide an umbrella of legitimacy for direct talks between a Jordanian-Palestinian delegation and Israel. The Reagan Administration has endorsed the idea on the condition that the Russians not be invited into a prominent diplomatic role. **********Meanwhile, although Mr. Peres has accepted King Hussein's idea of making a conference a prerequisite for direct talks, his coalition partner, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, has not. Mr. Shamir has argued that it is dangerous to allow the Soviet Union to gain a foothold in a conference, and that the language in the agreement dealing with the Palestinians is too favorable to the Palestine Liberation Organization. A Basic Difference **********The political infighting in Israel turns on an essential difference between Mr. Peres's Labor Party, which is willing to consider relinquishing some control over the occupied West Bank, and Mr. Shamir's Likud bloc, which wants to hold the territory indefinitely. In both factions' efforts to sway the Reagan Administration, they have been leaking details of the Jordanian-Israeli understanding. **********The director general of Prime Minister Shamir's office, Yosef Ben-Aharon, is scheduled to arrive in Washington this week to try to persuade the Administration that inviting Moscow would be dangerous. Mr. Peres arrives next week. **********The entire issue may be moot, however, unless the Soviet Union agrees to the restrictions on an international conference. Soviet officials who have spoken with Westerners recently have endorsed the idea that a conference would break up into two-party negotiating committees but have expressed their opposition to any ''separate deal'' that would not have the blessing of the full conference. Israelis Have Leaked Details **********Most details about the agreement have been divulged in Israel. Initially supporters of Mr. Peres made some details known to advance the idea that the accord opens a chance for peace in the region. Later Mr. Shamir's backers provided additional details to show their concern about the language of the accord. The Jordanian Government has said little about the terms of the reported agreement. **********It is not clear how much official discussion there has been with Russians on these matters. State Department officials were asked about this, but the question went unanswered today. **********The secret section of the Jordanian-Israeli memorandum reportedly repeats an earlier Jordanian agreement to arrange for Palestinian representation in a Jordanian-Palestinian delegation and says explicitly that the Palestinian issue will be negotiated in the two-party committee, with the Israelis on one side and the Jordanian-Palestinian delegation on the other. **********This appears to minimize the influence of the Palestine Liberation Organization, which would presumably be invited to attend the main conference, provided it accepted the Security Council resolutions and renounced violence and terrorism. **********But unless the P.L.O. had a role in selecting and giving guidance to the Palestinians on the Jordanian delegation, it would apparently be pushed to the sidelines of the negotiations. **********Again, this may not be acceptable to the Soviet Union, which is expected to coordinate its position with the P.L.O., Syria and other Arabs.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/23/world.main_headline: EHTHIOPIANS OFFICIALLY JOINING RANKS OF COMMUNIST NATIONS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/23/world.print_headline: EHTHIOPIANS OFFICIALLY JOINING RANKS OF COMMUNIST NATIONS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/23/world.body_text: **********Thirteen years after military officers overthrew Emperor Haile Selassie, this country today became the People's Democratic Republic of Ethiopia, with a Marxist party as the ''guiding force of the state.'' **********The changes went into effect as Ethiopia's leader, Lieut. Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam, announced that 81 percent of voters who took part in a national referendum on Feb. 1 had approved a Constitution providing for civilian rule. **********Colonel Mengistu said that 18 percent of the voters voted against the Constitution and that 1 percent of the ballots were spoiled. **********He said 96 percent of Ethiopia's electorate of 14 million took part in the referendum, the first of its kind in Ethiopia's 2,500-year history. In Conformity With Moscow **********The Constitution enshrines the Marxist ideals of Ethiopia's military revolutionaries and puts this East African nation of 44 million people in ideological conformity with the Soviet Union, Eastern Europe, Cuba and Vietnam, Marxist theoreticians here have said. **********''This Constitution only takes them further down the Marxist road to a people's republic,'' a prominent Western aid official said today. **********A series of upheavals in Ethiopia delayed conversion of the provisional military Government into an orthodox Communist civilian government. **********Shortly after the violent overthrow of Ethiopia's monarchy in 1974, this capital was convulsed by two years of factional fighting. **********In 1977 and 1978, Ethiopia fought back an attempt by neighboring Somalia to seize control of the Ogaden region. In 1984 and 1985, much of Ethiopia's interior was racked by drought and famine, and it is estimated that one million people died. **********Throughout this period, the central Government fought secessionist movements in Eritrea and Tigre Provinces. **********After the famine eased last year, Ethiopia's ruling Provisional Military Administrative Council printed a million copies of the new Constitution and sent them to 25,000 locations for debate. A Change on Polygamy **********The only major change that came from the nationwide debate was a decision to drop a clause outlawing polygamy. About 40 percent of Ethiopia's population is Moslem, and the remainder is largely orthodox Christian. **********The new Constitution states that religious freedom ''may not be exercised in a manner contrary to the interest of the state and the revolution.'' **********The new Constitution is unlikely to appease Ethiopia's rebellious minorities. The document makes vague promises of self-rule within the confines of a ''unitary state.'' **********In this one-party state, the Workers Party of Ethiopia, which has 50,000 members, is to serve as a ''vanguard party.'' Later this year, candidates approved by the party are to run for office in the Shengo, which will be the first elected national assembly since the 1974 revolution dissolved the Imperial Parliament. **********The Shengo will elect a president of the republic for a five-year term. Colonel Mengistu, who is general secretary of the party's central committee, is expected to be elected.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/19/busin.main_headline: A SEABROOK OWNER SETS BOND SWAP
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/19/busin.print_headline: A SEABROOK OWNER SETS BOND SWAP
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/19/busin.body_text: **********Financially drained by a $2 billion investment in the dormant Seabrook nuclear power plant, the Public Service Company of New Hampshire gave details today of a capital restructuring plan aimed at reducing the company's cash interest payments by $143 million a year. **********The company, which owes $1.37 billion in long-term debt and loses $1,100 a minute on Seabrook, plans to ask holders of some of its bonds and unsecured debt to exchange them for new, longer-term bonds and warrants that pay interest in common stock rather than in cash. Company officials today called the restructuring proposal ''the largest ever in the electrical utility industry.'' **********The proposal, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission, requires approval by Public Service's stockholders and the New Hampshire Public Utilities Commission, as well as S.E.C. clearance. State's Biggest Utility **********Public Service, the state's largest utility, owns one-third of the Seabrook plant, which has been denied an operating license because it lacks complete emergency evacuation plans. In August, Robert J. Harrison, president of the company, said that the utility would run out of money by the end of the year unless it charged customers an emergency rate increase of 15 percent. **********To get permission to impose the rate increase, the New Hampshire Supreme Court would have to declare unconstitutional a state law passed in 1979 that prohibits utilities from passing on to customers costs incurred through construction projects that are not in commercial operation. The court has set hearings on the emergency rate request starting Oct. 5. **********Company officials said today that, without capital restructuring, it would need to charge customers a rate increase of 75 percent. **********In August, Public Service announced that, starting Sept. 1, it could not guarantee to honor new customer service requests. At the time, the company also put into effect a stringent cost-reduction program, and officials said today that it had reduced internal costs $30 million this year and pared its staff by 150. **********If securities holders agree to the proposal outlined today, company officials say that Public Service will be able to stave off bankruptcy until 1990 without the Seabrook plant's becoming operational. Charles E. Bayless, financial vice president of Public Service, said the plan depended on 85 percent of investors voluntarily exchanging their securities. **********Industry analysts doubted that a high percentage of investors would would be willing to exchange securities that pay interest in cash for ones that pay interest in stock. **********In the proposal filed with the S.E.C. today, the company termed it ''highly unlikely'' that it would be able to make a $40 million debt payment due Oct. 14. The restructuring plan, company officials said, would give Public Service additional time to raise money to pay off debts. **********Paul C. Parshley, a vice president and utility analyst at the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation, said that the restructuring plan would make sense only if Seabrook came on line, which, he said, was unlikely. ''If Seabrook does not become commercial,'' he added, ''this exchange may only forestall the inevitable failure of the company.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/21/world.main_headline: Nicaragua Arrests Three in Draft Protest
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/21/world.print_headline: Nicaragua Arrests Three in Draft Protest
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/21/world.body_text: **********Three members of the opposition were arrested before dawn today after a march by hundreds of women whose husbands and sons have been taken away for military training. **********Residents said the protest was the largest in recent years in Boaco, a provincial capital 50 miles east of Managua. **********Mass demonstrations against Government policies are unusual in this country. **********United States-backed rebels, known as contras, are active in this part of the country. In the past, the authorities have cracked down on protesters, charging that they were trying to organize an ''internal front'' supporting the contras. **********Last week, according to residents and local officials, several hundred men from Boaco and nearby villages were ordered to report for army physical examinations. The men are between the ages of 26 and 40 and as such are required to submit to a month-long military training course and then to serve in the reserves. **********On Friday, two days after the contingent from Boaco departed, word was received that one of its members, Salvador Fernandez, 26 years old, had been killed by gunfire. Although the circumstances of his death were unclear, the news upset many relatives, who had appealed to military authorities to conduct the military training at a base near Boaco rather than in combat zones. March to Red Cross Office **********A crowd, mostly of women, marched through the streets of Boaco on Friday and entered the local Red Cross compound. The protesters, said by Red Cross officials to total about 1,000, asked that representatives of the Red cross from Managua be called to Boaco to serve as mediators. Two representatives arrived at mid-afternoon. **********''They were demanding that their relatives be moved out of the war zone, but we told them this was a military question and that it was impossible for us to help,'' said Adolfo Beteta, one of the Red Cross representatives. ''The Government is not going to give us explanations about something like this, and we are not in a position to demand them.'' **********As the occupation of the Red Cross headquarters was under way, four of the protesters drove to the village of Comoapa, 20 miles away, where scores of men had been mobilized for reserve training last week. After hearing of death of Mr. Fernandez and the protest in Boaco, sympathetic residents of Comoapa occupied their local Red Cross office. Only Neutral Place in Town- **********''The Red Cross is the only neutral place in these towns,'' said a woman in Boaco. ''Going there was the only thing we could think of.'' **********Red Cross mediators arranged for three Sandinista officials to meet with protesters in Boaco, and the officials repeated that it was impossible for them to recall men undergoing military training. After midnight, the crowd at the Red Cross compound began to disperse, according to participants. **********Three local officials of the opposition Independent Liberal Party were arrested by security police after the protest. They included the provincial chief of the party, Francisco Gomez, and two other party members, Horacio Rojas and Francisco Almanza Cuadra. **********The Independent Liberal Party is thought to be the best organized opposition party in this part of Nicaragua. Several of its local leaders were part of the Friday protest. **********The security chief in Boaco, Lieut. Manuel Gomez, no relation to the Francisco Gomez who was arrested, refused to comment on the arrests. But on Saturday, he met briefly with Salvador Gaitan, secretary general of the Independent Liberal Party, who came from Managua to investigate. - Mr. Fernandez, the part-time truck driver whose death sparked the protest, was buried here this morning. Relatives said they had been told by witnesses that he was shot after an argument with his drill instructor.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/24/world.main_headline: POLICE AND PROTESTERS CLASH IN 2-DAY BANGLADESH STRIKE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/24/world.print_headline: POLICE AND PROTESTERS CLASH IN 2-DAY BANGLADESH STRIKE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/24/world.body_text: **********A 54-hour general strike called to force the resignation of President H. M. Ershad provoked violent clashes today between the President's supporters and mobs fielded by opposition parties. **********At least five people died, including two in the capital, and hundreds of demonstrators were injured in the clashes and in firebomb attacks as the strike went into its second day, according to the police. The unofficial death toll is thought to be at least eight. **********Fifty-one police officers were injured and one was taken hostage by a crowd, the Government-run news broadcast said tonight. **********Most casualties occurred when the police fired on stone-throwing mobs that were attacking the headquarters of the President's political party, Jatiya, in the central business district. Police officers shot at demonstrators after failing to disperse them with tear gas. Photographers Are Beaten **********Four newspaper photographers were beaten by police officers during the attacks; press organizations are protesting the police charge. **********The head office of the national airline, Bangladesh-Biman, was also stormed by a crowd of several thousand people. Three vehicles were burned. **********Since the strike began, 31 public buses have been damaged or destroyed by supporters of the action, and 15 drivers or conductors have been injured, five of them critically, the Bangladesh Road Transport Corporation said. **********The strike was called by the opposition after President Ershad refused to step down or withdraw a bill enacted by the legislature on July 12 that allows military officers to serve on district development councils. Charge of Militarization **********The restructuring of local councils to give the army a grass-roots role is ''the first step to militarizing the entire civil administration,'' the President's opponents said in statements. **********The shutdown or disruption of commerce, education and most public transportation here and in towns around the country has raised political tension to its highest level since the lifting of martial law last Nov. 10, according to residents of Dhaka. **********Most people stayed at home today, despite Government pleas that life go on as usual. Only Government workers were reported to have gone to their jobs in significant numbers. Opposition crowds have been stoning people and vehicles that defy an unofficial curfew. **********The strike began Wednesday at 6 A.M. local time and is due to continue until noon on Friday, the beginning of the Moslem Sabbath. Issue Unified Opposition **********The issue of the district council has unified and injected new life into an opposition that was badly splintered in the spring of 1986 over whether to take part in national parliamentary elections called by Mr. Ershad when he was martial-law administrator. In October, he was elected President. **********The alliance of six political parties formed around the Awami League of Sheikh Hasina Wajed - the daughter of President Sheik Mujibur Rahman, who was killed in an army coup in 1975 - decided at the last minute to take part in the May 7, 1986, parliamentary elections. **********Another opposition alliance, led by Khaleda Zia - the chairman of the Bangladesh National Party and the widow of President Ziaur Rahman, who was also assassinated - boycotted the voting. **********The decision of the two factions to join in calling for a national strike on the issue of the District Councils Bill is viewed here as an interesting experiment in testing the joint political strength of the opposition. President Ershad's term has another five years to run.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/13/world.main_headline: Chad Charges Truce Violation by Libyan Jets
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/13/world.print_headline: Chad Charges Truce Violation by Libyan Jets
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/13/world.body_text: **********In the war of words that has followed the Chad-Libya cease-fire, Chad said today that Libyan planes had flown illegally over Chadian territory. **********Chad officials say the planes flew over Zouar and Bardai in northern Chad early today and also over Amzouer near the Sudanese border. **********''They obviously did this to threaten us,'' said Issa Boukar, the spokesman for Chad's Embassy to France. But Mr. Boukar said the Libyan planes had dropped no bombs. **********These charges follow Chad's assertions on Friday that Libyan warplanes bombed two towns - Ounianga Kebir and Wour - 72 minutes after the truce was scheduled to take effect. And on Friday night, Chad officials say, Libyan planes bombed Bardai hours after the cease-fire deadline. Chad May Change its Mind **********This morning, the official Libyan press agency, Jana, denied Chad's charges that it had bombed the towns after the truce deadline. Jana said the last Libyan raid was 15 minutes before the deadline of 10 A.M. Greenwich mean time. **********Mr. Boukar said, ''We will continue to adhere to the cease-fire.'' He added that his country might change its mind if Libya were to continue its truce violations. **********The truce suspends a 14-year desert war that in recent weeks has focused on the Aozou Strip, 43,000 square miles of border land claimed by both countries. Foreign affairs analysts said Hissen Habre, Chad's President, made a sacrifice by accepting the truce while the town of Aozou, the strip's administrative center, was in Libyan hands. **********In return, Libya's leader, Muammar el-Qaddafi, agreed to stop his monthlong series of daily air strikes on Chad. The Chadians have no air force.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/04/busin.body_text: **********Manufacturers of small computers, still uncertain about how to react to I.B.M.'s announcement of a new line of personal computers, had more to say than to show at a major desktop computer trade show here. **********Two months after I.B.M. announced its Personal System 2 line of desktop computers, a few smaller computer companies have moved to capitalize on the new system. But, as expected, the majority of hardware, software and add-on manufacturers continued to show products that are compatible with the International Business Machines Corporation's older PC line of products. **********''With eight million of the old PC's out there it is going to take three or four years for the new line to catch up - if it does,'' said Michael Dell, chairman and chief executive of PC's Limited, an Austin, Tex., company that makes I.B.M.-compatible computers. His company is displaying only a line of computers similar to the old I.B.M. line. **********''That standard has not stopped or lost momentum just because I.B.M. made an announcement,'' he said. Some Showing Both Lines **********On the other hand, several makers of add-on products were showing lines for both the old and new I.B.M. computers. ''We don't make a decision to support a particular standard or not to support it; we move with the market,'' said J. Leland Strange, chairman and chief executive of Intelligent Systems, a Norcross, Ga., company that makes add-on boards for both old and new systems. **********The new I.B.M. line ''is another product that people are certainly going to want to buy,'' Mr. Strange said. His company's Quadram division introduced several products for the new I.B.M. line, including add-on memory boards and color monitors compatible with the new I.B.M. graphics standard. **********But even companies such as Quadram that wish to support the new I.B.M. line are finding difficulties. ''I.B.M. has already locked in a lot of the parts capacity we need,'' said Jim Lindenmayer, Quadram systems manager, referring to orders that I.B.M. has placed with manufacturers of some components of the new system. **********Although Quadram was demonstrating a new communications device for the Personal System/2 line, Mr. Lendenmayer acknowledged that his company would have to stand in line behind I.B.M. until the fall to get enough volume of a critical part to begin full production of the new device. **********For software manufacturers, the problems are slightly different. Michael Burdick, marketing manager of Paperback Software, which is based in Berkeley, Calif., noted that his company had just introduced a new graphics program designed to run on the I.B.M. PC. But because the new models have a different graphics standard, his company's product will have to be modified. **********Interest in the new I.B.M. line, as well as a modest upswing in the small-computer market generally, helped increase attendance at Comdex, one of two small-computer trade shows held annually in the United States. Sheldon G. Adelson, chairman of the Interface Group, which sponsors the show, said 45,000 manufacturers, dealers and members of the press are expected to attend the show, which lasts through Thursday. 'Renewed Excitement' **********''Our pre-registration is up 35 percent, and that is just a result of renewed excitement in the industry,'' Mr. Adelson said. ''Two years ago, the companies in the personal computer business were talking about growth rates of 5 to 10 percent a year. This year, most of the people I talk to are expecting 25 or 30 percent growth.'' **********Part of the renewed interest has been spurred, he said, by the new I.B.M. products. **********''You now have three standards -the Apple standard, the old I.B.M. PC standard and the new I.B.M. PS/2 standard,'' said Frank Girard, vice president of sales and marketing for NEC Information Systems Inc. ''I don't think there is anyone who can tell you how fast the PS/2 standard is going to catch on.'' **********Mr. Girard said that some of NEC's largest personal computer customers had stopped ordering computers shortly before I.B.M.'s April 2 announcement of the PS/2. But after the announcement, he said, users concluded that ''they would not have to throw out what they had.'' The result was a surge of orders for NEC's old-style PC compatibles that still has the Boxborough, Mass., company blacklogged, he said.
