Packaging 'Breakthrough' **********The new I.B.M. computers ''are not a breakthrough in technology but they are a breakthrough in packaging,'' said Jerry Bower, product manager for AST Research Inc., an Irvine, Calif., maker of add-on products for I.B.M. computers. **********His company, which competes directly with Quadram in the add-on computer market, has a series of similar products for the new line of computers. **********''It is too early to tell what corporate America will make of these machines,'' Mr. Bower said. ''About 30 percent will probably buy anything I.B.M. makes. Another 30 percent probably won't change from what they have no matter what I.B.M. does, and 40 percent are somewhere in the middle.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/07/busin.main_headline: ...AND IT MIGHT COST MORE TO DRINK, SMOKE AND DRIVE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/07/busin.print_headline: SENATE APPROVES A BUDGET FOR '88 WITH $18 BILLION TAX INCREASE...; ...AND IT MIGHT COST MORE TO DRINK, SMOKE AND DRIVE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/07/busin.body_text: **********Excise taxes have emerged as the only palatable option that Congressional tax writers see to raise $18 billion in new revenue to meet the 1988 budget target. Such a move would confront motorists, smokers, drinkers and telephone users with the steepest rise in Federal excise taxes ever. **********Legislators have dismissed the idea of raising income taxes so soon after last year's overhaul. And in the face of specific threats by President Reagan to veto any increase in income tax rates, lawmakers believe that excise taxes are the only kind that the White House might ultimately accept. **********Congress has frequently turned to excise taxes to fill small budget gaps, adding pennies to the cost of a pack of cigarettes or a bottle of bourbon to raise a few billion dollars. This year, they are being counted on to raise far more money than that. 'Will Be Exceedingly Difficult' **********Tax writers say they must choose several targets and squeeze them much tighter than political considerations would ordinarily permit if they are to raise the $18 billion. That is the amount called for by the Senate budget plan and a previously passed House package. **********''I spent the weekend going over the list,'' Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat and chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, said of the options, adding that it would ''be exceedingly difficult'' to find the $18 billion. **********Among the proposals being discussed are a doubling of the cigarette excise tax; an increase in the gasoline tax of 10 cents a gallon or the introduction of a $5-a-barrel oil import fee; as much as a 49-cent increase in the tax on a six-pack of beer, and as much as a 52-cent rise in the tax on a bottle of wine. **********With such proposals expected to draw heavy fire from affected consumers and industry groups, tax writers see a difficult challenge in trying to meet the House and Senate targets with excise taxes - if the President agrees to $18 billion in new taxes. **********''You can hit excise taxes very hard and still not get to $18 billion,'' said Representative Byron L. Dorgan, a North Dakota Democrat on the Ways and Means Committee. **********The proposed gasoline tax rise or the oil import fee, for example, would meet only about half the revenue gap, according to the Congressional Budget Office's estimates. Doubling the cigarette tax would raise an additional $3 billion. Raising taxes on beer and wine to the alcohol-equivalent rate on distilled spirits would raise $4 billion. Extending the expiring 3 percent tax on telephone service would raise just over $1 billion. **********Over all, excise taxes, which are placed on designated commodities, would have to be raised by 55 percent to meet the House and Senate budget targets. These taxes now bring in about $33 billion a year. **********Even if the tax target turns out to be less than $18 billion, the outcome of the excise tax debate holds important implications for pocketbooks and also for industries, regions of the country and the overall health of the economy. A Political Issue **********The debate may also influence next year's elections. Democrats are reluctant to impose a sharp tax increase on beer because the beverage is seen as a symbol of blue-collar America, a traditional constituency they do not want to upset. An oil-import fee is embraced by oil-producing states, but fiercely opposed by Northeastern representatives because of its impact on heating oil prices. **********Meanwhile, higher gasoline taxes will be fought by members of Congress from Western and Southern states, where constituents tend to drive long distances. Tobacco states will fight higher cigarette taxes and California representatives will be working to ward off higher taxes on wine. **********Industry lobbyists are already mobilizing. An ad-hoc coalition of industry groups, including the American Automobile Association, the American Truckers Association and two dozen other trade assocations met recently to map strategy to fight fuel tax increases. **********The truckers' group is also leading another coalition, which includes wine, beer and tobacco industry groups, to campaign against all kinds of excise tax increases. These organizations have fresh battle experience. Last year, they were successful in helping to quash a proposal in the Senate Finance Committee to include a excise tax increase as part of its income tax overhaul plan. Prices Distorted **********Excise taxes are not a favorite of economists, either. ''If you gave me carte blanche and asked how you would raise revenue, I think excise taxes would rank fairly low on everybody's list,'' said Emil Sunley, national director of tax analysis at the accounting firm of Deloitte Haskins & Sells and a former Treasury official. **********One failing is that excise taxes distort the prices of goods and are inflationary. Another problem is that most excise taxes are regressive, meaning they hit the poor harder than the rich. The reason is that poor people spend a larger proportion of their income on commodities that are subject to excise taxes. Income taxes, by contrast, impose a progressively larger burden as one moves up the income scale. **********According to a recent study by the Congressional Budget Office, the average increase in excise taxes as a percentage of total income would be about twice as large for families with incomes of $10,000 to $20,000 as it would be for families with incomes of $50,000 or more. It would be about three times as large in the case of beer or tobacco taxes. Only airline excise taxes, now earmarked solely for airport maintenance and improvements and part of the operating costs of the Federal Aviation Administration, are slightly progressive across income lines. **********State governments also do not like the Federal Government to increase excise taxes because they encroach on a tax base that states rely on. Rise Called Overdue **********But some tax economists think a big increase in Federal excise taxes is long overdue and can serve to promote important social and national policy objectives. **********For example, beer and wine taxes have not been raised since 1951. Distilled spirits taxes were raised in 1985, making many in Congress reluctant to hit this category so soon. But the tax now represents only 27 percent of the average price of liquor, compared with 43 percent in 1951. Although the cigarette tax was doubled, to 16 cents a pack, in 1983, the tax now represents only about 15 percent of the price of a pack of cigarettes, compared with 42 percent in 1951. **********Over all, excise taxes account for 4 percent of total Federal revenue, compared with 18 percent in 1951. **********''I think the excise tax structure is extremely low by any standard,'' said Joseph A. Pechman, a tax expert and senior fellow at the Brookings Institution. ''It's true that these taxes are somewhat regressive, but I think poor people should be discouraged from smoking and drinking as well. And there is an overriding national interest in encouraging oil conservation.'' **********Increases in alcohol and tobacco taxes are also viewed as compensation for the health and safety costs that smokers and drinkers impose on society. **********George Thompson, an analyst at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., said he believed that any excise tax increase would have only a modest impact on alcohol and cigarette consumption. But there could be some visible shifts within these industries. **********A big excise tax increase on cigarettes, he said, would probably encourage more smokers to switch to discount brands, now the fastest-growing segment of the market. In addition, purchases from vending machines, normally the most expensive outlet, might decline. The Effect on Brewers **********Beer is a different story, though. Mr. Thompson said the major brewers, whose brands are widely advertised and have a loyal following, were unlikely to be affected much by a tax increase. But smaller brewers could be hurt. ''The ones that will get impacted most significantly are the weaker links,'' he said. ''If you put it on those brands that sell purely on price, the tax is a big negative.'' **********Studies indicate that a big tax increase would discourage smoking and drinking among youngsters, although consumption may not decline much among adults. Teen-agers, with limited spending money, tend to be sensitive to price increases, according to Michael Grossman, a research associate at the National Bureau of Economic Research and a professor at the City University of New York Graduate School According to a recent study that Professor Grossman co-wrote, an increase in beer taxes to the alcohol-equivalent rate of distilled spirits would save 1,000 people a year among those aged 18 to 20 from alcohol-related automobile deaths. The tax increase would also reduce by 11 percent the number of youths between the ages of 16 and 21 who drink beer at least every other day, the study added. **********To equal the tax on distilled spirits, the tax on a six-pack of beer would have to be raised to 65 cents, from 16 cents, and the tax on a bottle of wine to 55 cents, from 3 cents. **********According to a study of cigarette taxes that Professor Grossman helped to develop, the number of smokers between the ages of 12 and 17 would decline by 1.2 percent for each 1 percent increase in the price of cigarettes. Oil Tax Proposals **********The most vigorous debate is likely to be over oil taxes. The main proposals are for an oil import fee and higher gasoline taxes. Their effects are very different. **********An oil import fee is favored by Senator Bentsen and other oil-state lawmakers since it would drive up domestic oil prices and provide relief to American producers hurt by the plunge in world oil prices. **********The import fee would also promote energy conservation and reduce this country's dependence on foreign oil. A $5-a-barrel import fee would reduce imports by 1.2 million barrels a day and cut domestic consumption by the same amount, according to an analysis by Data Resources Inc., an economic forecasting concern. **********But critics contend that an import fee is a threat to long-term national security. It is a ''drain America first'' policy, they argue, using up scarce domestic reserves instead of lower-cost foreign supplies. Economic Impact a Concern **********The higher oil prices that would result from an import fee would also lead to slower economic growth and higher inflation, according to Data Resources, because all sectors of the economy would be affected. Data Resources concluded that an import fee might exacerbate, rather than ease, the Federal deficit problem. **********By contrast, gasoline taxes would have a much smaller impact on consumer energy bills in particular and on the economy in general because gasoline does not have as much bearing on the manufacturing process. Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who is chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, favors a rise in gasoline taxes, as do many in the House from the Middle West and Northeastern states. **********But gasoline taxes would not be as effective in reducing energy dependence. Data Resources estimates that the oil import fee would be six times more effective in reducing imports than an increase in gasoline taxes, and four times more effective in reducing domestic energy consumption. **********The tax-writing committees, which have been busy drafting trade legislation, have yet to focus on the full range of excise tax options, from airline tickets to truck tires, and perhaps even alternatives outside the excise-tax sphere should the debate bog down.  EXCISE TAXES: POSSIBLE OPTIONS  The proposals below are being discussed informally among tax writers. Other ideas include higher excise taxes on airline tickets and truck tires.           Current   Tax Rate   1988        Tax   under   Revenue           Option   Rise              (Billion)        GASOLINE        9 cents a gallon    19 cents a gallon    $9.0        OIL IMPORT FEE        None    $5 a barrel    8.1        CIGARETTES        6 cents a pack    32 cents a pack    2.9        BEER AND WINE        (Linked to rate on        distilled spirits)        16 cents on six-   65 cents on six-   4.2        pack of beer; 3 cents   pack of beer; 55 cents        on fifth of wine   on fifth of wine DISTILLED SPIRITS        $12.50 a proof gallon    $15 a proof gallon    0.4        EXTENDED TELEPHONE TAX        3%    3%    1.3       Source: Congressional Budget Office estimates

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/03/world.main_headline: 3,100 MINERS ON STRIKE ARE DISMISSED IN NAMBIA
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/03/world.print_headline: 3,100 MINERS ON STRIKE ARE DISMISSED IN NAMBIA
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/03/world.body_text: **********A copper-mining company in South-West Africa partly owned by a United States corporation has dismissed 3,100 black workers who were on strike for better pay and working conditions. **********The three mines affected by the strike are owned by the Tsumeb Corporation, of which the United States-based Newmont Mining Corporation owns one-third. **********A South African corporation, Goldfields, is the majority shareholder, and British Petroleum Minerals has a minority stake. **********The miners, all members of the Mineworkers Union of Namibia, as the disputed territory is widely known, were dismissed Friday after they failed to meet a management deadline to return to work. **********The union is supported by the South-West Africa Peoples Organization, the guerrilla group fighting South African-led forces. The union has challenged the company's management to make an ''unequivocal statement'' on the 21-year-old bush war against Pretoria's rule of the mineral-rich territory. **********It is believed to be the first time workers in the territory have demanded that their employers make a public statement on where they stand on the war. **********In a statement last Wednesday outlining the demands of the miners, the union's general secretary, Benjamin C. Uulenga, said that 99 percent of workers at the mines and their families had lost relatives in the bush war and were directly affected by it. Money and Improvements Sought **********The miners are also seeking a 105 percent increase in their $100-a-month pay, improved safety regulations and an end to discriminatory practices in the mines. **********The general manager of Tsumeb, Robert A. Meiring, said in an interview tonight that the management had spoken to the union as part of what he called an open-door policy. **********But he said the company had not negotiated with the union because ''we do not recognize the union as it has not yet proven its membership.'' **********He said the company had not yet decided whether to evict the dismissed workers from company housing. Some of the miners live in single-sex hostels, he said, and others in family housing. **********He denied that the system of contract labor, under which married men are contracted to work and leave their families for a year at a time, was still in use. **********Mr. Meiring dismissed the union claim that 4,600 miners were on strike, and said the remaining 1,900 miners were still working. **********The three mines are in Tsumeb, Otjihase and Kombat, all in the northern part of Namibia near the 150-mile wide strip of territory along the border of Angola that has been declared a war zone by the South African-led security forces. **********Despite attempts to lead the territory to Pretoria-style self-rule, South Africa continues to control the territory in defiance of a United Nations resolution declaring the occupation illegal.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/02/busin.body_text: **********Shearson Lehman Brothers is seeking to make a significant investment in an oil company or other energy concern as a hedge against an expected rise in energy prices and inflation, the brokerage firm's chairman, Peter A. https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/07/busin.main_headline: Dow Drops a Record 91.55 Points On Interest-Rate and Dollar Fears
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/07/busin.print_headline: Dow Drops a Record 91.55 Points On Interest-Rate and Dollar Fears
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/07/busin.body_text: **********Stock prices plunged yesterday amid continued anxiety over rising interest rates and the dollar. **********In its largest point decline ever, the Dow Jones industrial average tumbled 91.55 points, or 3.47 percent, to 2,548.63. The Dow's drop eclipsed the 86.61-point drop of Sept. 11, 1986. **********Waves of computerized selling contributed to the Dow's huge drop, which came less than two weeks after the blue-chip index posted its biggest rise ever, 75.23 points, on Sept. 23. 1,332 Declining Issues By the market's close, declines on the New York Stock Exchange exceeded advances by almost a 4-to-1 ratio as 1,332 issues fell in price and only 338 rose. **********While the Dow's decline was a record in points, the percentage drop was minor compared with the 12.9 percent decline of Oct. 28, 1929 - the day of the stock market crash - when the average dropped 38.33 points, to close at 260.64. **********Despite yesterday's retrenchment, many experts remained optimistic on equities. Several said that above-average third-quarter earnings reports could dictate the market's course in the next few weeks, overcoming concern on interest rates, inflation and the dollar. Adjustment Process Seen **********''There was panic, but there wasn't chaos,'' said Eugene E. Peroni Jr., a technical analyst at Janney Montgomery Scott Inc. in Philadelphia. ''With the stock market as earnings leveraged as it has been lately, you have to expect a much more speculative and volatile environment, especially since interest rates are no longer a supportive factor.'' **********''I think the market is going through an adjustment process where stocks will sink or swim based on the merits of their earnings results,'' he added. **********The stock market's tone had its roots in the bond market, where prices of Treasury issues declined because of worries over higher interest rates. **********The chief concern of bond traders was that higher rates in West Germany would prompt the Federal Reserve Board to tighten credit to maintain the attractiveness of the dollar, which dropped on foreign exchange markets yesterday. Stock investors, in turn, feared resulting interest rate increases would cut into corporate profits. There were also concerns that higher yields would make some bonds a more attractive investment than stocks. **********As the session progressed, bond prices improved, particularly in the final hour of trading, but the stock market's decline accelerated. **********Mr. Peroni, who noted that turnover on the Big Board was mild by recent standards, said yesterday's activity also reflected the market's sensitivity to external impulses, such as comments made by Robert Prechter, the influential technical analyst. **********Early in the day, brokers noted, Mr. Prechter had made bearish comments about the stock market, suggesting a steep decline was possible. Mr. Prechter said that the failure of the Dow to pierce 2,640 would lead to a move to the 2,300 area in the next few weeks. **********Yesterday's trading, however, did not indicate a flood of portfolio adjustments. Just 175.6 million shares changed hands on the Big Board, up modestly from 159.7 million shares traded on Monday. **********Robert E. Walsh, a money manager at Jenswold, King & Associates in Houston, pointed out that the bulk of the decline in the 30-stock Dow was caused by six issues in the average that consititute 41 percent of its value. **********Yesterday, I.B.M. lost 5 1/2 points, to 151; Merck 7, to 201; Philip Morris 4, to 113 1/2; Kodak 2 3/4, to 101 3/8; Procter & Gamble 4, to 99 1/2, and Du Pont 4 1/2, to 118 1/2. **********''We don't view this as the end of the bull market and we're cautioning investors to keep today's decline in persective,'' Mr. Walsh said. ''Market breadth, while decidely weak, was not at record proportions either, as the net difference of advancing to declining isssues was less than 1,000, which is well below 1,200 to 1,300 figures of recent times.'' Effect of Interest Rates **********Richard Schmidt, director of research at the Advest Group in Hartford, said interest rates would be a contributing factor for the stocks of companies whose earnings are weaker. ''Those companies with the potential to show earnings well above the average will make it,'' he said. ''The average stock, on the other hand, will face some downside risk.'' **********And J. Warren Hall, senior vice president of funds management at the National City Corporation in Cleveland, said: ''We think the stock market is sounding a false alarm. The trade balance is improving and inflation is under satisfactory control. At 10 percent, the long bond is now attractive and stocks should do well in a bond market rally.'' **********Yesterday, broader-based averages than the Dow also were hit hard. The New York Stock Exchange composite index dropped 4.46 points, to 178.98, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 8.86, to 319.22. Chemical Stocks Down **********Recently strong groups were among the hardest-hit industrial sectors. Among the chemical stocks, Dow Chemical was down 1 3/8, to 107 7/8; Union Cabide 1 5/8, to 30 1/2, and National Distillers 1 5/8, to 85 7/8. **********In the high-technology area, Digital Equipment dropped 3 3/4, to 194; National Semiconductor 1 3/8, to 20 5/8; Cray Research 2 3/4, to 95; Motorola 2 1/8, to 70 5/8, and Compaq dropped 2 7/8, to 75 3/8. **********Several takeover-related stocks bucked yesterday's trend. **********Tenneco led the Big Board's most-active list rising 1 3/8, to 61 1/4. A Wall Street Journal column stirred speculation that Tenneco might be a takeover target. Gillette rose 1 3/8, to 43 5/8, on rumors that someone other than Revlon might be accumulating stock in the company. **********USG, formerly United States Gypsum, rose 3 1/4, to 54 7/8. On Monday, two Texas investors disclosed they might seek control of USG. **********On the American Stock Exchange, the Amex-market value index fell 3.89 points, to 355.44, while in over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index declined 6.12 points, to 447.51.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/20/world.main_headline: Palestinian Riots Hit Jerusalem; Banks Attacked and Roads Seized
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/20/world.print_headline: Palestinian Riots Hit Jerusalem; Banks Attacked and Roads Seized
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/20/world.body_text: **********Palestinian rioting spread to Jerusalem today, with crowds of rock-throwing youths attacking Israeli-owned banks and taking over the streets of the Arab district for hours. **********Police officials said it was the worst violence here in more than a decade. **********In the extraordinary 11th straight day of violent protests in the Israeli-occupied territories, the focus shifted from the Gaza Strip, which appeared mostly quiet but tense under tight army control, to areas of the Israeli capital captured in the 1967 war. Burning Tires and Barricades **********Crowds of teen-agers poured out of their schools shortly after eight o'clock this morning, heading for Salah e-Din Street, the main commercial artery in Arab East Jerusalem, where they set tires afire and threw up barricades of old furniture, garbage bins, bus stop signs ripped out of the ground and, in one case, a car pushed into the street. **********As police officers firing tear gas chased them, the groups ran and reformed, with the skirmishes continuing until mid-afternoon. **********''This is serious,'' said Police Inspector Gen. David Kraus. ''It seems this was organized through the schools. **********''We used all means at our disposal - tear gas, water cannons, batons - to break up the riots, but no live ammunition,'' he said. Eighteen Palestinians have been killed in the riots, most shot by Israeli security forces. Concern to Tourism Officials **********With Christmas approaching, the possibility that the unrest could continue and spread was causing concern to security and tourism officials. Bethlehem, revered by Christians as the birthplace of Christ, is in the occupied West Bank; other Christian holy sites are in Arab districts. **********There were anti-Israeli demonstrations in Bethlehem, near the Church of the Nativity, and in Hebron, Nablus and Ramallah, other West Bank towns. In some places, stones were thrown at Israeli troops. Several thousand Israeli Arabs also demonstrated in Nazareth, and in Mishkenot Haroim, one of the new Jewish settlements south of Jerusalem that have been built near Arab villages, a restaurant owned by Jews was set afire. Curfews for Refugees **********The Army reinstated around-the-clock curfews today in the West Bank refugee districts of Balata and Askar, after having lifted them briefly. **********Arabs living inside Israel's pre-1967 borders have called for a general strike Monday in support of the Arabs in the occupied territories. The 800,000 Arabs in Israel hold Israeli citizenship and may vote but, with a few exceptions, cannot serve in the Israeli armed forces. **********Israeli-owned banks in the Arab sector appeared to be particular targets in today's rioting. Windows were smashed at four of the five branch offices of Israeli-operated banks in East Jerusalem, and records were destroyed in at least one. Bank Office Wrecked **********At the Bank Leumi branch on Salah e-Din Street, the two big plate glass windows, cobwebbed with the impact of rocks, were pushed in from their frames and the office, guarded at nightfall by two Israelis with automatic rifles, appeared wrecked. **********In Barclay's Discount Bank the computers were smashed, records destroyed and checks and other papers ripped and scattered about. **********The Jerusalem city authorities also appeared to be a target; bright yellow municipal vans were stoned and city cars set afire and destroyed. Police and army cars were also stoned. **********The rock-throwing demonstrators included teen-age girls in their school uniforms. Some youths wore gloves to pick up the tear gas canisters and hurl them back at the police. Called 'Very Serious' **********Palestinians in Jerusalem have been particularly angered because Trade Minister Ariel Sharon, the architect of the 1982 Israeli invasion of Lebanon, has just taken an apartment near the Damascus Gate in the traditionally Arab Moslem quarter of the old city. **********''This is very serious and more than I expected,'' said Mayor Teddy Kollek of Jerusalem. ''It's hard to measure the extent to which Sharon moving into the Moslem quarter is responsible. **********''Mostly it's what's happening in the territories, but in a situation like this, any match can light a fire and Sharon's entrance into the Moslem quarter was more than a match,'' the Mayor added. **********Police officials said it was the most serious unrest in the city since Palestinian protests in 1976, in which four people were killed. #33 Arrested During Day The police said 19 minors and 14 adults were arrested during the day. Four policemen were wounded by rocks and two others were wounded when their car struck a tree as it was being stoned. **********By late afternoon, the smell of burning rubber and tear gas hung in the air as soldiers and the border police patrolled the streets of East Jerusalem. **********Merchants on Salah e-Din Street -named for the Arab hero, Saladin, who took Jerusalem from the Crusaders 800 years ago - had just opened their shops for the first time after a general strike called on Tuesday. They hastily pulled their steel shutters down again. **********Only a few blocks away, in Jewish areas of West Jerusalem, it was a normal Sabbath. Protests by Orthodox **********Indeed, it was so normal that rigorously Orthodox Jews continued their weekly protests against the showing of movies on the Sabbath. The police said an army officer was injured when orthodox militants stoned his car. **********The state radio reported that the Israeli Supreme Court had ordered an inquiry into the death of a Palestinian youth who was said to have stabbed a soldier. **********The radio quoted witnesses as saying the youth, Atweh Abu Samahadna, was shot in the leg after slightly wounding the soldier and taken to an Israeli hospital. He died in the hospital the next morning, but the cause of death was not stated on his death certificate, the radio said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/02/busin.body_text: **********The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board today supported the creation of an umbrella agency to more closely coordinate policy among the major Government bodies that regulate financial institutions. **********Alan Greenspan said the Fed welcomed the proposal for a Financial Services Oversight Commission, which is contained in legislation sponsored by two Senate Democrats, Timothy E. Wirth of Colorado and Bob Graham of Florida. The commission would be made up of representatives from the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, the Government's banking agencies and state insurance commissioners. **********''The need for greater regulatory coordination could not have been brought out more clearly than in the recent stock market developments, where we saw the complex interactions of securities, commodities and banking markets,'' Mr. Greenspan told the Senate Banking Committee. An Example of Agency Role **********The Fed chairman said that such an agency could act as a major clearinghouse for coordinated regulation as the various components of the financial system become more similar in the services and products they offer. For example, he said, one task could be setting capital standards for banks and brokerage firms that are engaged in similar businesses, so that one industry is not given a competitive advantage. **********Mr. Greenspan stopped short of recommending that the Financial Services Oversight Commission be given the broad powers envisioned by Mr. Wirth and Mr. Graham, such as the authority to permit or prohibit certain activities by financial concerns. Rather, he appeared to recommend a more limited role, so the agency would function primarily as a forum for regulators to coordinate equitable existing regulations. **********His endorsement, expressed for the first time today, gives impetus to the concept, but final approval is still in doubt. For one thing, the concept would effectively take away authority from existing Federal agencies, which might object. Support for Proxmire-Garn **********Mr. Greenspan also reiterated his support today for a bill that would repeal major portions of the Glass-Steagall Act of 1933, which separates commercial and investment banking. He urged the Senate Banking Committee to approve legislation sponsored by Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, and Senator Jake Garn, Republican of Utah, that would permit banks to underwrite corporate securities and permit securities firms not associated with insurance or real estate businesses to own and operate a commercial bank. **********In addition today, Senators Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, and Alan Cranston, Democrat of California, introduced a bill that would let any commercial company own and operate a bank. **********In a related matter, Senator Proxmire disclosed that David S. Ruder, chairman of the S.E.C., would support the Proxmire-Garn bill only if the S.E.C. regulated all securities activities of banks, including brokerage services currently permissible. Mr. Ruder is to testify before the Senate Banking Committee on Thursday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/07/world.main_headline: POLISH CHURCH AWAITS POPE, BEWILDERED BY ITS NEW VIGOR
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/07/world.print_headline: POLISH CHURCH AWAITS POPE, BEWILDERED BY ITS NEW VIGOR
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/07/world.body_text: **********The Roman Catholic Church of Poland, which was beleaguered and defensive when Karol Wojtyla was rising through its ranks, has grown remarkably strong in his nine years as Pope. **********Now, as John Paul II is about to begin his third papal visit to his native land, starting Monday, the church from which he came faces serious, paradoxical problems arising from its very success. New, Harder Questions **********When the church was weaker and its priests were being persecuted, it did not have to deal with questions like these: *********** Should the church retreat further from the social activism of the Solidarity period, when it shielded believers and nonbelievers challenging the Communist state? *********** Should it bestow even limited blessing on the policies of Poland's leaders and risk being accused of collaboration? *********** Should it urge Polish workers to work harder for less money? *********** Should it curb its most aggressively anti-Communist priests in the hope of expanding Vatican influence beyond Polish borders to the Soviet Union and Soviet bloc countries? **********For decades, perhaps even centuries, the Polish church saw itself as the good son, who, in the parable cited in Luke, was less warmly appreciated by his father than his prodigal brother. **********Like the good son, the Polish church was loyal, constant, pious and dutiful. Yet it felt itself to be less cherished in Rome than the Italian, French, Irish or American churches. It had a tendency to parochial isolation and its martyrs were more contemporary than those of other churches. **********With the ascension of the then Archbishop of Cracow to the throne of St. Peter, that self-image changed, and the Polish church grew more assertive at home and in the world. A Growing Clergy **********The clergy is growing here. There are now more Roman Catholic seminarians in Poland than in any country in the world. A third of all newly ordained European priests are Poles. More churches are being built in Poland than in the rest of Europe. Mass is broadcast weekly on the state radio. Catholic-sponsored newspapers reach two million families. Most children attend catechism classes. **********''We have virtually attained full freedom of worship,'' said Bishop Jerzy Dabrowski of Warsaw. **********The Rev. Antoni Pominski, editor of a church newspaper in Woclawek, said, ''If someone predicted 10 years ago that the church would have gained so much so soon, I would have thought him mad.'' **********Krzysztof Sliwinski, a writer for liberal Catholic journals who was associated with the now outlawed Solidarity labor union, said, ''Sometimes, I think there are elements in our church that are now almost indecently triumphant.'' **********Just as the elevation of Karol Wojtyla to the papacy inspired the Polish nation, so the rise of Solidarity and its protection by at least part of the clergy further enhanced the church's influence. For centuries, the church defended national interests against real and would-be occupiers and their local cat's-paws. **********The church also prospered after the suppression of Solidarity, when it remained the last refuge and resort of opposition. **********''The church was strong before Solidarity,'' Jozef Cardinal Glemp, the Polish Primate, said in an interview shortly after thousands of Solidarity activists were interned in 1981. ''It got stronger during Solidarity, and it gained again in strength under martial law. It seems that whatever happens in Poland - whatever else it does -strengthens the church.'' From Strength Come Problems **********But with the strength come problems. ''Society has projected its hopes and aspirations on the church and now society expects too much from us,'' Bishop Dabrowski said.  As Solidarity declined, he said, some of its supporters have looked increasingly to the church to take up the struggle for social justice, human rights and broader liberties. At the same time, the Government has sought to cajole the church into giving its blessing to Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski's professed policies of normalization and economic change. **********Many inside and outside the church say they believe that the Pope's visit and planned meeting with Lech Walesa, the founder of Solidarity, and scheduled discussions with women workers in Lodz will communicate his respect for the ideals of Solidarity. **********But there is a general expectation that the visit will mark a transition from a time when many priests could openly identify with the labor unions as a vehicle for national revival and independence. A Nonpolitical Emphasis **********The Pope is to pray at the grave of the Rev. Jerzy Popieluszko, the pro-Solidarity priest murdered by the secret police. But the event is listed as private. Similarly, parish priests are asking people not to bring political placards to observances or to make the ''V'' hand signs for Solidarity. **********Some Poles are asking how much autonomy the church needs before it is prepared to undertake programs of social action. As one liberal Catholic asked over dinner recently, ''How many state authorizations to build churches have to be given before the church authorities can feel bold enough to start demanding the right to organize hospitals, nursing schools, their own high schools or independent associations of Catholic workers?'' **********Though there is a marked hesitancy on the part of some in the hierarchy for institutional broadening of church involvement in social services, the episcopate has in general terms endorsed a course of social activism. A Variety of Strategies **********As explained by several church leaders, the Polish church, chafing under the restraints of once aggressively atheistic Communism, had these possible strategies: *********** It could, as Poland's leaders once hoped, confine itself to purely religious life, officiating at ceremonies and maintaining church buildings and cemeteries. *********** Or it could, in theory, seek to support or initiate small political groupings as embryonic Christian democratic parties that would take part in the limited parliamentary politics tolerated in a country where the Communist Party, by definition, has the deciding role. **********Though both these concepts have their proponents in the church, they have been rejected by the Polish bishops, who instead have claimed the right of the church to involve itself fully in the social and moral life of the nation. **********In the aftermath of Solidarity's rise, some priests saw the nonviolent movement as a re-enactment of 19th century Polish uprisings against occupation forces, which priests joined and blessed. First Visit Inspired Nation **********There are historians and political observers who believe that it was the patriotic aspects of the Pope's first visit in 1979 that generated the jubilation and euphoria that led to the rise of Solidarity. **********When he returned for his second visit, the Pope was clearly sorrowed by martial law and he pressed for release of political prisoners and a national reconciliation. **********Now, on the eve of his third visit, there are no political prisoners, and large parts of Polish society are worn down by the raising and dashing of hope. **********In this atmosphere, church leaders are expecting that the Pope will be stressing personal sacrifice and individual religious and moral transformation rather than a prospect of miraculous or eruptive national redemption. **********''I have a feeling that all of us Poles have failed his hopes and wishes for us,'' said Father Pominski, the editor in Woclawek. ''He came and too many of us thought that things would change by miracle. In the first two visits, we all saw him as ours, a Polish pope, but now I think he is coming as the the world's pope, and I have a feeling he will try to reach each of us deeply in a spiritual way.'' **********Some priests have predicted that the Pope will focus on alcoholism, divorce and abortion. Both in the church and in Polish society there is a significantly widespread view of ''the good Pope'' and ''the bad Primate.'' **********Asked about this, Bishop Dabrowski the Primate's counselor, smiled and said, ''The Pope, speaking with universal authority, inspires with his vision, while the Primate has to pull us back and restrain us from unrealistic aspirations.'' **********Others said Cardinal Glemp was also concerned with strengthening church institutions in preparation for the day when a Pole would no longer be Pope.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/17/busin.body_text: **********Markets **********Stock prices collapsed in a broad selloff, with the Dow Jones industrial average suffering its first daily loss of more than 100 points. Waves of selling produced record volume of 343.2 million shares. The Dow's loss of 108.36 points left it at 2,246.73, which was 235.48 points, or 9.49 percent, below where it began the week. The daily loss, amounting to 4.6 percent, is the sixth largest in postwar records. The breadth of the decline was stunning - only 111 Big Board issues managed to rise, while 1,749 declined. Weakness in the dollar and a related rise in interest rates are being given the blame for a correction that has now seen the Dow back off 17.5 percent, or 475.69 points, from the peak of 2,722.42 set on Aug. 25.  [ Page 1. ] **********Market professionals see no signs of calamity in the decline. Many of them like to remind nervous small investors that the market still has a sizable gain for this year.  [ 1. ]  Computerized trading by big institutions played a key role in the slide.  [ 38. ]  Washington officially maintained its stand of indifference to market developments.  [ 39. ]  The exchanges and trading houses had few problems handling the record volume, thanks to electronics.  [ 38. ] **********Treasury bill rates plunged in the credit markets as money leaving the stock market poured in. The rates on three-month bills fell 43-hundredths of a percentage point, to 6.64.  [ 40. ]  The dollar fell, and traders said the selloff in stocks was largely responsible. Gold gained $7.50 in New York, to $471 an ounce.  [ 46. ] **********Oil futures prices surged as the military tensions in the Persian Gulf increased. West Texas Intermediate went above $20 a barrel, gaining 47 cents, to $20.22.  [ 46. ] The Economy **********Producer prices rose 0.3 percent in September as higher prices for food and automobiles more than offset a sizable decline in energy costs. The figure was about as expected, and economists generally seemed to think it gave no reason for concern about inflation. The energy sector showed a 3.7 percent drop but car prices were up 3.6 percent and food prices climbed 1.1 percent.  [ 37. ] **********The Senate Finance Committee approved, 13 to 7, a tax package that would raise $11.6 billion. The measure, which won the votes of two of the panel's nine Republicans, is expected to face a veto by President Reagan.  [ 37. ] **********Output was up 0.2 percent in September at the nation's factories, mines and utilities. Auto production was down, but the steel and energy industries posted gains.  [ 37. ]  Business sales rose 1.3 percent in August, the biggest gain in seven months, while inventories grew at just half the rate of July.  [ 40. ]  International **********Equipment sent by a French company to the Soviet Union will enhance Soviet military technology, American officials said. The transfer was done by the export arm of a large French bank and involved American technology to make high-speed integrated circuits often used in military applications.  [ 37. ]  A team of U.S. officials will tour Europe to urge better compliance with curbs on exporting sensitive technology to the Soviet bloc.  [ 49. ] **********West German bankers expressed irritation at U.S. threats to push the dollar lower in response to increases in German interest rates. The Bonn Government and the central bank declined to comment on the remarks by Treasury Secretary Baker.  [ 41. ] Companies **********Two big cable TV companies agreed to merge in a stock swap valued at about $2 billion. The company formed by United Artists Communications and United Cable Television, both based in Denver, would be the nation's fourth-largest cable concern and have 1.85 million subscribers. [ 37. ] **********A sweetened offer to take TWA private was accepted by the board. The offer came from Carl C. Icahn, who already holds 73 percent of TWA stock.  [ 49. ] Today's Columns **********Real estate is attracting increasing numbers of investors after five years in which stocks and bonds seemed to offer better opportuniies. Your Money.  [ 38. ] **********An anti-cancer preparation that works with antibodies has been developed. Patents.  [ 38. ]

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/02/busin.main_headline: A REBOUNDING PAN AM SEES BREAK-EVEN YEAR
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/02/busin.print_headline: A REBOUNDING PAN AM SEES BREAK-EVEN YEAR
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/02/busin.body_text: **********Executives at Pan American World Airways expect the airline to break even this year and the overall holding company to make a small profit. **********The carrier, they said, is being helped by heavier travel to Europe and Latin America and even by the deep-discount fares that are filling planes on its domestic division. **********The outlook has brightened in a short time. Only four months ago, Pan Am was holding talks with American Airlines on being taken over and was seeking to sell its shuttle that links Boston, New York and Washington. Now it is seeking to hold onto its assets and even expand them to take advantage of the travel upturn. **********It is in the midst of negotiations with Citicorp, for example, to renew the leases on three Boeing 747's so it can add capacity to handle the heavier demand from customers. **********The carrier, however, could become vulnerable again if terrorist attacks send traffic plunging as happened last year. And its cash reserves are smaller than last year, when it had close to $1 billion, mostly from the sale of its Pacific routes to United Airlines. The current cash reserve is only $150 million. **********Several positive trends have emerged to bolster the carrier's prospects. Pan Am was able to negotiate a lower pay scale for new pilots with the pilots' union last month and has hired about 50 out of a projected 150 pilots to enable it operate its shuttle and its expanded international summer flights. This is the first hiring of pilots by the company in 19 years. **********The lower scale, combined with the delivery of six of the two-engine, fuel-efficient Airbus A310-300 airplanes in June, will enable Pan Am to cut the operating costs of its aged fleet. The Airbus planes can operate with a crew of two, instead of the three on Pan Am's present planes. **********The new capacity is expected to come when Pan Am will be eager for planes to carry the heavy traffic that has been building since March. **********C. Edward Acker, chairman and chief executive of the Pan American Corporation, the holding company, said in an interview yesterday that, while the carrier had expected a recovery in traffic from last year, when terrorist attacks sent traffic plunging by more than 30 percent, the demand this year had been better than expected. ''There is a surge that hit about the middle of March,'' Mr. Acker said. ''Things have really remained strong.'' **********He said that the load factor, which measures how full planes are, was about 63 percent for the airline in April, up from 60 percent in a normal year. **********''It's strong all over,'' he added, ''not only in the North Atlantic but in Latin America as well.'' Pan Am said its travel to Europe in April rose 40 percent from April 1986, with Latin American volume gaining 23 percent. **********Helane Becker, an airline analyst for Drexel Burnham Lambert, said that, if traffic continued strong during the summer, Mr. Acker's projections that the airline would break even were realistic. **********She noted that travelers to Europe had tended to book their trips later and to stay for shorter periods to compensate for the weaker dollar. The shorter durations are a boon to the large international carriers, she said, since, with fewer deep-discount fares available, more people travel at higher fares. **********Revenues were up an estimated 13 percent in the first quarter, according to Mr. Acker. Pan Am expects to release its first-quarter results this week, and Mr. Acker said that the loss would be smaller than the $118 million reported in last year's first quarter. **********Pan Am suffered last year when terrorist attacks in Europe kept American tourists at home. The company's losses totaled $462.8 million last year. **********Pan Am is seeking to build up its reserves further against an unexpected jolt. Citicorp has provided the carrier with a line of credit for $75 million and is seeking to line up $75 million more with other banks that would get backing for the loans in the form of Pan Am engines and spare parts. **********Mr. Acker also said that, to make the carrier viable for the long term, it needs $180 million in concessions from its three unions.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/14/world.main_headline: KOHL ASSURES PUBLIC OF NO SHIFT TO RIGHT IF HE WINS ELECTION
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/14/world.print_headline: KOHL ASSURES PUBLIC OF NO SHIFT TO RIGHT IF HE WINS ELECTION
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/14/world.body_text: **********Chancellor Helmut Kohl sought today to reassure the West German electorate that a victory for his center-right coalition in parliamentary elections this month would not mean a rightward shift in foreign policy. **********At a news conference here, Mr. Kohl said that despite partisan disputes, his Government ''owes our friends, allies and all our neighbors a clear, constant and calculable policy.'' **********The Chancellor said that, anchored in the Atlantic alliance, Bonn sought ''dialogue and cooperation'' with Communist Europe. **********Mr. Kohl's suddenly scheduled news conference was motivated, according to senior Government sources, by nervousness that a series of hard-line statements by members of his Christian Democratic Party had unsettled a number of voters. **********''We were concerned,'' a top adviser to the Chancellor said, ''that certain things said in the heat of the campaign might have clouded our policies. We didn't want there to be any doubt about this outside the country either.'' **********The toughest language has come from the Christian Democrats' highly conservative Bavarian sister party, which is headed by Franz Josef Strauss. Theo Waigel, the Bavarians' parliamentary floor leader in Bonn, recently demanded that a victory for the coalition on Jan. 25 should signal ''a retreat from the detente policies of the 1970's.'' **********Much of the Bavarians' oratory has been aimed at Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher, the leading figure in the small Free Democratic Party. Mr. Strauss's partisans have hinted strongly that they would like to see him succeed Mr. Genscher as Foreign Minister.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/18/busin.main_headline: Market Place; New Optimism On Fast Food
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/18/busin.print_headline: Market Place; New Optimism On Fast Food
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/18/busin.body_text: **********SOME of the smaller fast-food companies are beginning to attract the attention of analysts, who are predicting higher earnings. That is a signal that the entire group - after languishing in the doldrums for more than two years - might be on the brink of a turnaround. **********''The famine in fast-food stocks may be over,'' said Glenn Johnson, restaurant analyst for Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood in Minneapolis. ''There's a trend in Wall Street toward raising earnings estimates on certain restaurant stocks - the first time that's happened in a long while.'' Like other analysts, he noted that stock prices have not yet reflected this new optimism. **********Berton Seltzberg, an analyst at the Advest Group in Hartford, cautioned, however, that the fast-food industry ''continues to be beset by over-saturation of certain food segments, such as chicken or hamburgers, a downturn in same-store customer counts, a saturation in certain geographical areas such as the Northeast and Midwest, and - among the higher-end restaurants - the poor economies of 'oil patch U.S.A.' '' **********He said he was not looking for a recovery of the entire group until the beginning of next year, but he does have his favorites now. He sees Piccadilly Cafeterias Inc. as a good turnaround situation. Piccadilly, one of the largest publicly traded cafeteria chains, carries a lower multiple than many of its competitors, about 10.3 times projected 1988 earnings, according to its close yesterday of $16.50 a share in over-the-counter trading. **********The Baton Rouge, La., company earned 97 cents a share in the fiscal year ended June 30, down from $1.30 in the 1986 fiscal year. However, Mr. Seltzberg is projecting earnings per share of $1.55 to $1.60 in 1988, rising to $1.85 to $1.90 in fiscal 1989. **********''Piccadilly should build better profit margins as it expands the number of its units by 8 to 10 percent annually,'' he said. **********Mr. Johnson's current favorite is Buffets Inc., a small, fast-growing chain based in Wayzata, Minn., that specializes in buffet-style dining. He thinks the company will double its earnings this year while most of the rest of the fast-food industry continues to consolidate. He is looking for earnings of 50 cents a share at Buffets in 1987, up from 24 cents in 1986, and he has raised his 1988 per-share estimate to 75 cents. ''The company offers quality, nutritious food at low prices, which is what the public is turned on to these days,'' he said. Buffets, which trades over-the-counter, closed yesterday at $21 a share, at a rather high multiple, 28 times estimated 1988 earnings. **********Mr. Johnson also is recommending International Dairy Queen of Minneapolis, which has maintained a steady 15 percent annual earnings growth rate. ''The company earned $1.25 a share in fiscal 1986, will do $1.50 a share this year and should make $1.90 a share in fiscal 1988,'' he said. The stock closed yesterday at $32 a share. **********Roger Lipton, managing director of Lipton Research, the restaurant research arm of Ladenburg, Thalmann & Company, said that, while the industry environment was not one of ebullience, the rampant building by start-up companies had abated and the shake-out in the group was largely completed. **********''I favor small companies such as Bombay Palace Restaurants and USACafes,'' he added. ''Although these companies are not generally in favor, I have a strong conviction that inefficiencies in the market allow for some unusual opportunities.'' **********Bombay Palace is a chain of urban ethnic dinner houses, including Indian, Mexican and Caribbean cuisines. Mr. Lipton said Bombay Palace, excluding the pending acquisition of Lifestyle Restaurants, should earn more than 50 cents a share in 1987 and 70 cents a share in 1988. ''The combined company should earn more than $1 a share in 1988 and as much as $1.50 a share in 1989,'' he added. ''At $7 a share, Bombay Palace stock is cheap, whatever the general market environment for small stocks.'' The stock closed at $6.75 yesterday in Nasdaq trading. **********John Hunt, an analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, is particularly bullish on Shoney's Inc., a Nashville-based operator and franchiser of restaurants, primarily in the Eastern United States. ''On a relative basis, the company's shares are selling near their lowest point since 1980,'' Mr. Hunt said. He added that, despite soft store sales primarily related to sluggish industry conditions, the management of Shoney's would be able to maintain earnings momentum. **********''We expect earnings per share to increase 17 percent, to $1.35, in fiscal 1987 and 26 percent, to $1.70, in fiscal 1988,'' he said, noting that earnings growth over the next five years could rise at about 15 percent a year, based primarily on a 10 percent growth in new units of Shoney's and its Captain D's ''fast'' seafood chain, as well as a 4 to 5 percent growth in sales per unit. **********Although most of these experts currently are focusing on smaller-capitalized restaurant issues, the perennial giants of the industry, McDonald's, Burger King, Wendy's, and the like, cannot be ignored. The Pershing division of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette notes in a recent report that these issues continue to dominate the fast-food scene. ''The stronger chains have benefited by acquiring failed units of the weaker operators - often at bargain prices,'' it said. **********''Wendy's is the only one of the three big chains that I would currently recommend because I think they will aggressively roll out their new expanded salad bar, including Mexican and pasta items,'' said Mr. Lipton of Lipton Research. ''By spring of 1988, the expanded salad bar will be system-wide in their 900 company-operated stores.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/13/busin.body_text: **********THE shoplifter is hardly an endangered species these days. But American retailers say they have been making progess in keeping theft down. Innovative electronic tools and sophisticated employee awareness programs have begun to chip away at the billions lost to shoplifters every year. **********''The retailers in our survey now rank shoplifting as the second most significant factor in inventory loss, behind employee theft; 10 years ago, shoplifting was clearly the most significant factor,'' said Stephanie Shern of the national retail group at Arthur Young & Company, who coordinates an annual survey of more than 130 large retailers on the issue of shrinkage - inventory loss due to shoplifting, employee or vendor theft and poor record-keeping. **********Ms. Shern said retailers in her study blamed shoplifting for 32 percent of their losses in recent years, down from 50 percent or more 10 years ago. And another study, by Peter D. Berlin, a consultant specializing in shoplifting and employee theft, found that shrinkage cost department stores about $2.05 for every $100 in sales last year, down from $2.23 in 1985. **********Although precise shoplifting figures are almost impossible to come by, retailers agree that the numbers seem to be down. **********''Most retailers are showing improvement in 1987,'' said Lewis Shealy, vice president of loss prevention for Chicago-based Marshall Field stores, citing a confidential exchange of figures among several store chains. ''There's no question that inventory shrinkage is going down.'' **********''Retailers are getting a better grip on shortages,'' added Mr. Berlin in a recent issue of his Shrinkage Control newsletter. They are certainly working on it. More and more, stores are using cameras, high-tech alarm systems - even old-fashioned courtesy - to cut into shoplifting.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/03/busin.main_headline: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY: Advances in Chips; A Thin Film To Add Speed To Computers
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/03/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY: Advances in Chips; A Thin Film To Add Speed To Computers
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/03/busin.body_text: **********WORKING in a dust-free clean room at Case Western Reserve University in Cleveland, Dr. Scott E. Rickert dips a sterile glass plate into a tub of water. Across the surface of the water, like soap spread across a pool, is a thin membrane one molecule in thickness that adheres to the plate's surface. **********Although the ultra-thin films are being created by a decades-old technology, they are being viewed by Dr. Rickert and other chemical engineers in very new ways that promise important breakthroughs in computer and other technologies. **********Above all, the thin film allows scientists to cram many more transistors, diodes and capacitors onto silicon wafers, a development that could make computers far more powerful and faster. **********The films being created by Dr. Rickert and his team are made from organic, carbon-based molecules that contain metallic atoms. When the film dries and the molecules crystallize, the metallic atoms line up in a precise geometric pattern that conducts electricity. The carbon acts as an insulator. **********The one-molecule-thick films can process information thousands of times faster than conventional silicon chips because they create less resistance to the flow of electricity and because the circuits can be packed more closely together. **********In all, the process is similar to the flow of electrical impulses in nerve tissue or the transport of electrons in photosynthesis, the basic life process in which carbon dioxide is converted into organic material. As a result, some scientists predict that chips made from thin film will hasten the day when computer operations will more closely mimic the biochemical processes of the brain. **********''With this technology microelectronics is merging with organic chemistry and biology,'' said Dr. Rickert, a chemical engineer and one of the country's top thin-film researchers. He predicted that the first experimental computers made solely from thin-film chips would be available in five to ten years. **********Until recently America's only serious competitor in the field was Japan, but because of the huge commercial potential of thin film, other countries, including Britain, France and West Germany, have entered the fray. **********The race is heating up because the potential benefits of thin films are not limited to computer-related technology. Dr. Rickert, for example, is using thin films as sensors. The special electrical behavior, he said, makes various thin films extremely sensitive to changes in humidity, temperature, pressure, the presence of chemicals or other environmental factors. **********Dr. Rickert quantifies the changes by measuring the time it takes electricity to pass through films under different environmental conditions. By attaching the films to integrated circuits, he has developed sensors that can instantaneously measure the presence of ammonia, oxygen, carbon dioxide and other gases at concentrations as low as 5 parts per billion. A conventional meter would take 20 minutes or more to do it. **********The Defense Department, which is financing most of Dr. Rickert's work, is interested in developing sensor devices that soldiers could wear on their wrists to detect poison gases. **********In another application of thin films, Dr. Rickert helped to develop a process for making more complex and faster conventional silicon chips.  * * * **********The dipping technique used to produce thin film was discovered more than 65 years ago by Irving Langmuir and Katherine Blodgett, chemists at the General Electric Company in Schenectady, N.Y. Even though it helped Dr. Langmuir win a Nobel Prize in 1931, the development gained little attention over the next five decades as plastics and composites dominated the field of chemical engineering. In the early 1980's, though, as the space squeeze on silicon chips became more severe, chemical engineers like Dr. Rickert rediscovered Langmuir-Blodgett films. **********Conventional computer chips process information by alternately allowing, then blocking, the flow of electronic impulses carried on wires and switches imbedded in the silicon. The faster the electronic stream is switched off and on, the more information that can be processed and the more powerful the silicon chip. **********A principal rule in making chips is that elements on the chips, such as wires or transistors, can be no closer than the thickness of the surface of the chip, otherwise it will short-circuit. Conventional chips are made using films that are usually one micron thick, or about 100 times the thickness of the thin-film chips. **********Using the Langmuir-Blodgett technique, a special polymer that is light-sensitive is placed across a chromium surface. The polymer - a substance composed of giant molecules formed from smaller ones - is then exposed to microscopic beams of light that trace the grid design of the chip and cause chemical changes within the polymer that turn the microscopic lines red. **********The chip is then dipped into a series of solvents. The first dissolves the polymer that was not exposed to light, and leaves the chromium base and the red lines intact. The second dissolves all the chromium except for what lies beneath the red lines. The third dissolves the red lines, leaving chromium lines. **********Engineers call the final product a ''mask.'' By projecting light through it and onto silicon wafers, masks serve as templates for manufacturing computer chips.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/06/busin.body_text: **********The stock market advanced further into uncharted territory yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average scoring another big gain that moved it closer to the 2,300 level. **********With yesterday's increase of 18.98 points, to a high of 2,276.43, the 30-stock Dow average has now closed at record levels in 23 of the first 43 trading sessions this year. Since Jan. 1, the Dow has risen a spectacular 20.1 percent and is beginning to generate some concern about what lies ahead. 'It's Going to Go Down' **********''It's going to go down,'' said Charles Jensen of MKI Securities Inc. ''But who's to guess when?'' The stocks of paper companies took their turn in leading the market higher yesterday, with an assist from the ever-strong drug group and the newly revived technology sector. **********Of the Dow stocks, International Paper rose 4 3/4, to 98 1/4; while Merck gained 2 1/8, to 160 5/8; General Electric, 2 3/8, to 108 1/8, and Allied Signal, 1 5/8, to 48. Procter & Gamble, a consumer products company, got a 4-point lift, to 91, from an analyst's favorable report, and Du Pont rose 1 7/8, to 102 3/4. **********With the gains in those half-dozen stocks and others, the Dow has begun its assault on the 2,300 barrier. But the spectator sport of watching the blue-chip index break through a ''century mark'' is waning now that the Dow, since the start of the year, has surged past 2,000, 2,100 and 2,200. **********The key question, traders say, is how high stock prices will rise before they head in reverse. 'Internals Are Very Good' **********Michael Sherman, head of the investment policy committee at Shearson Lehman Brothers, thinks there is no immediate reason to worry. ''The internals are very good,'' he said, adding that the economy was growing at a comfortably slow pace while the interest rate picture looked ''benign.'' **********There was one indirect sign yesterday of a pickup in business activity. International Paper disclosed that it had informed customers it was raising the price significantly for linerboard because of strong demand. A pickup in linerboard, which is used to make cardboard boxes, could indicate that more products are being shipped by manufacturers. **********The price rise could also mean better-than-expected earnings for other paper manufacturers. For this reason, Temple-Inland rose 5 3/4, to 78 1/2; Stone Container gained 5 1/4, to 91 5/8; Mead 4 1/8, to 71, and Union Camp 3 7/8, to 68 1/4. **********Such strength, however, was not visible in the market as a whole. On the New York Stock Exchange, only 898 stocks rose in price, while 716 fell. Volume Increases **********The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 1.00, to 165.41, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index jumped 1.90, to 290.52. The American Stock Exchange index rose 3.17, to 329.47, and in over-the-counter trading the Nasdaq index advanced by 2.26, to 429.00. All those indexes were at record closing levels. **********The average share on the Big Board rose 26 cents. Big Board volume picked up, with 205.4 million shares changing hands compared with 198.4 million on Wednesday. **********MFS Multimarket Income Trust, a new issue, led the active list yesterday, trading 4.5 million shares. It closed at 10 1/8, up 1/8 for the day. **********Pepsico, another active issue, rose 1, to 34 7/8, after a Kidder, Peabody analyst issued a favorable report. Chrysler, after splitting its stock 3 for 2 and raising its dividend, rose 2 points, to 52 3/8. But General Motors fell back 1 3/8, to 78 1/8. It had been strong after announcing a huge stock repurchase program. **********USAir Group fell 5/8, to 48 1/2, in active trading. On Wednesday T.W.A. offered to buy USAir for $52 a share, but the bid met with skepticism on Wall Street. T.W.A. fell 7/8, to 31.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/29/busin.main_headline: DEAL MADE ON MAJOR BANK BILL
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/29/busin.print_headline: DEAL MADE ON MAJOR BANK BILL
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/29/busin.body_text: **********Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d struck a compromise with the chairmen of the Senate and House Banking Committees this afternoon that should avoid a threatened Presidential veto of important banking legislation, Congressional sources said. **********The compromise greatly increases the chances that the most far-reaching banking legislation in seven years will be signed into law by early next month. **********After two meetings on Capitol Hill today with the Treasury Secretary, Representative Fernand J. St Germain, Democrat from Rhode Island, and Senator William Proxmire, Democrat from Wisconsin, agreed to three modifications to the banking bill that was passed by House and Senate conferees earlier this month. In exchange, the Treasury Secretary said he would urge President Reagan to sign the legislation. **********''It's as close to a done deal as you can get,'' one lobbyist said. ''But this kind of situation is still very fluid.'' No Veto Expected **********Though President Reagan could still decide to veto the legislation, members of Congress, their aides and lobbyists predicted that he would not. **********And though House and Senate conferees who approved the bill earlier this month would also have to agree to the changes, no one predicted that there would be enough objections to jeopardize the agreement reached today. **********The three provisions will essentially raise the rescue package for the depleted Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation to $10.8 billion, from $8.5 billion; phase out regulatory leniency provisions for thrift institutions after three years, and permit any financial or commercial concern to acquire an insolvent savings and loan association with assets of $500 million or more. **********After the White House had issued repeated threats of a veto, Mr. Baker of the Treasury began quietly last week to try to work out a compromise with members of Congress. White House Position **********Not only did the White House and Treasury contend that the $8.5 billion rescue package of the F.S.L.I.C. was far too small, but other provisions of the bill that place a moratorium on giving commercial banks new underwriting powers and a ban on the further creation of limited-service banks represented a significant setback to the Reagan policy of deregulation. **********Yet, a combination of concern about possible runs by depositors at weak thrift institutions in Texas and the strong likelihood that any Reagan veto would be overridden in the Senate apparentaly led the Treasury to compromise. **********''I think they finally realized that the President's veto simply could not have been sustained, and that brought the Treasury to the bargaining table,'' one lobbyist said. **********Mr. Baker met in the morning with Senator Proxmire and again in the afternoon with Mr. Proxmire, Mr. St Germain and their top aides. Treasury Under Secretary George D. Gould, the key architect of the Treasury banking effort, was also at the afternoon meeting. $15 Billion First Sought The Treasury had at first asked for a $15 billion rescue package of the insurance agency, then began trying to get $12 billion in new funds. Mr. Baker and Mr. Gould finally settled for $10 billion, plus an additional $825 million that represents exhausted assets that thrift institutions had on deposit at the insurance agency. **********The rescue plan is essentially a program that will permit the insurance agency to borrow the $10.8 billion from the public, in the form of goverment-backed bonds, and use the money to shut down hundreds of sick thrift units. The fund is now more than $6 billion in the red, according to some estimates. **********The Administration also strongly objected to the so-called forbearance provisions for troubled thrift institutions, mandated in the conferee-passed bill. Those measures created a lenient regulatory atmosphere and permitted a thrift institution in an economically depressed region, such as Texas, to continue to operate for a period of years even if its net worth fell dangerously close to zero. Regulators complained that such provisions would have made it nearly impossible to supervise and impose discipline properly on such institutions. **********In the compromise worked out today, the regulatory leniency would end after about three years. **********The Administration also had problems with the ban in the bill on new limited-service banks, which it sees as healthy competitors to commercial banks. The bill also severely restricted the activities and growth of the 168 existing limited-service banks. **********Though Senator Proxmire and Mr. St Germain did not compromise on the issue of creating any more limited-service banks, they did permit the existing concerns somewhat more operating abilities, provided they acquire a failed savings and loan association of $500 million or more. The compromise also permits any other financial or commercial enterprise, such as an insurance company or brokerage firm, to buy one or more of these sick institutions. **********Dozens of insolvent thrift institutions exist, and not enough healthy thrift units have come forward to buy them. The compromise is aimed at finding new buyers outside the thrift industry. **********Congressional sources said that the 32 conferees would be solicited this evening and tomorrow morning for their support for the compromise.
