https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/19/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; ALLEGIS? THAT'S THE OLD UAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/19/busin.body_text: **********Unisys and Navistar, meet Allegis, the newest addition to corporate lexicon. **********UAL Inc., the holding company for United Airlines, Hertz and Westin Hotels, picked this bit of corporatese (pronounced uh-LEE-jis ) as its new name today, hoping to show that it is not just an airline company. **********Richard J. Ferris, UAL's chairman, said the company chose to call itself the Allegis Corporation after a yearlong search because it liked the sound and the root words: allegiance and aegis, which means protection. Mr. Ferris spoke of getting the allegiance of travelers and providing protection for them. **********''UAL was thought by many to simply mean United Airlines,'' he said. ''We are a travel company, not just a transportation company.'' **********UAL used an ''identity management consultant,'' Lippincott & Marguelies, and ultimately narrowed its choices to four words. Mr. Ferris said that one of the finalists was ''Covia,'' a name the company decided to adopt for its Apollo Travel Services subsidiary. $7.3 Million for Advertising UAL is starting a $7.3 million advertising campaign to spread the word about its new name - one of many new names that American corporations have chosen in recent years with the aid of name-finding companies and computers that throw out mellifluous sounding words not found in the Oxford English Dictionary. Indeed, the Armstrong Rubber Company announced today that it was dubbing itself Armtek. **********According to Anspach, Grossman, Portugal, one of the consulting firms that mints new names, 1,382 companies changed their names last year, up from 871 two years earlier. Many of the names combine parts of two words, the way International Harvester borrowed from the words navigate and star when it became Navistar. Also in recent months, Sperry and Burroughs have renamed themselves Unisys, Houston Natural Gas adopted Enron and Libbey Owens Ford became Trinova. **********''There are always trends in language and this is just one of them,'' said Victoria Neufeldt, editor in chief of Webster's New World Dictionary. As for UAL's new name, she said, ''Navistar would probably have been more appropriate for them than Allegis.'' Some Have Objections **********Wall Street analysts did not take warmly to the latest move in the renaming of Corporate America. ''It's a confusing name,'' said Helane Becker, an airline analyst with Drexel Burnham Lambert. ''I noticed on the press release they left a note on how to pronounce it. If you have to tell people how to pronounce it, do you really want to call yourself that?'' **********Analysts questioned whether the expensive name-launching campaign would benefit United Airlines, the Hertz and Westin subsidiaries and the Hilton International Hotels, which UAL is scheduled to acquire. The subsidiaries will keep their old names. **********''I can understand their need for a new identity because they haven't done well in the stock market.'' Ms. Becker said. ''Maybe they think this can help their stock.'' **********Aside from the new name, which shareholders will be asked to approve at the annual meeting on April 30, analysts kidded about the company's new stock symbol: ALE.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/20/busin.body_text: **********IN the old days, people flocked to the card shop for birthdays, anniversaries, Christmas and Mother's Day, and a few big companies produced all the good cheer. Today more than 800 publishers vie for business in a $3.6 billion-a-year industry - and the noteworthy event might be a divorce or a promotion, the death of a dog or an unhappy 40th birthday. **********But while the diversity means more choice for consumers, manufacturers are finding the industry tougher and more competitive than ever before. Americans bought more than 7 billion cards last year, but growth in the last two years has been minimal. Unit volume has increased less than 5 percent in each of those years, and analysts do not expect much improvement in the next few years. Baby boomers, who fueled industry surges in the late 1970's and early 1980's, are continuing to buy cards - but no more than they did last year or the year before. **********''Demographics are working against card makers right now,'' said E. Gray Glass, a vice president at Prudential-Bache Securities. **********What spurred the growth during the 1970's and 1980's was a phenomenon that the industry called alternative greeting cards. They featured contemporary graphics, biting sarcasm and a tendency toward the risque - and baby boomers loved them. And, indeed, the alternative card market is still growing by 15 to 20 percent a year, and now accounts for nearly half of the overall card business, according to the Washington-based Greeting Card Association. **********The alternative card market has become so attractive, in fact, that the industry's Big Three - Hallmark, American Greetings and Gibson Greetings - have, in the last two years, started to move onto the turf once dominated by small companies. Fighting back, many small companies are trying to gain a foothold in the retail outlets that have for years been dominated by the giants. **********''What's happening is a crossover in turfs of large and small companies,'' said Hy Mariampolsky of Qualidata, a New York research firm that follows the industry. ''The larger companies have gone after the customers previously served by small alternative companies. The small companies, meanwhile, are trying to get on the shelves of supermarkets and drugstore chains.'' **********Supermarkets and drugstore chains are, indeed, the fiercest battlegrounds in the greeting card skirmish. ''Distribution has shifted in the last few years to the mass merchants,'' said Ed Fruchtenbaum, vice president of marketing at American Greetings. ''People have less time to shop so they're buying everything, including greeting cards, in the same stores.'' **********The battle for shelf space has been costly for all manufacturers. American Greetings, which controls 35 percent of the American greeting card market, and Gibson Greetings, which has just under a 10 percent share, both saw their earnings decline last year. (Privately held Hallmark, which controls an estimated 40 percent of the market, does not disclose financial information.) The strain on earnings is due largely to the stiff competition, which is prompting manufacturers to offer retailers greater discounts -60 percent and up, compared with the traditional 50 percent - and more services, particularly return privileges on cards that do not sell. Competition has also held average card prices steady at the $1 mark during the last two years.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/24/world.body_text: **********After Maj. Pierre Buyoya seized power two weeks ago in this central African land, he moved to ease Government repression against the Roman Catholic Church, announced the release of at least 200 political prisoners and promised more democracy. **********The moves came as a balm to many Burundians, who had seen the tiny landlocked country evolve into what some described as a virtual dictatorship under the leadership of the former ruler, Jean-Baptiste Bagaza. People in Bujumbura, the drowsy capital, where there is scant military presence, speak of a sense of relief. **********''We will now be allowed to go to the President and discuss problems,'' said Marius Rurahenye, general secretary of the Burundi Workers' Union and a former member of the country's Central Committee. ''Bagaza often went and talked to groups, but what he said was very different from what he did. That was not genuine dialogue.'' But while there appears to be widespread acceptance of the new military regime, some Burundians and Western diplomats say it is too early to assess whether a change in leadership will soon translate into dramatic changes in Government policy. Tutsi and Hutu Tensions **********A true test, they say, will be whether Mr. Buyoya moves to modify the balance of power between Burundi's dominant ethnic minority, the Tutsi, and the ethnic Hutu majority, which has long been politically and economically subservient. **********Mr. Buyoya, 38 years old, is ruling the country as head of a so-called Military Committee of National Redemption. He has charged that his predecessor put too much power into his own hands, violated the Constitution and fostered an incoherent economic policy. **********Western diplomats and Burundians say Mr. Buyoya often disagreed with Mr. Bagaza, who was toppled while he was attending a conference in Canada. He is now in Uganda.  The new leader, a Belgian-educated soldier who also took courses in France and West Germany, is said to be highly popular among younger army officers and to have a reserved demeanor. More Balance in Outside Ties **********Mr. Buyoya is expected to maintain the country's official policy of nonalignment, while more evenly balancing links with the West and Burundi's close ties to Libya and the Eastern bloc. **********Although Mr. Buyoya denounced the former Government's economic policy, diplomats here said they expected him to continue a program of economic liberalization in what is one of the world's poorest countries. **********In a radio address to the nation soon after seizing power, Mr. Buyoya, a Roman Catholic, pledged to respect freedom of worship. The statement suggested a more conciliatory approach to the Roman Catholic Church in Burundi, the population of which is 65 percent Catholic. **********His predecessor expelled most Catholic missionaries from the country, banned church lay organizations and permitted priests to offer mass only on weekends. **********Some people suggest that the takeover Sept. 3 was little more than a palace uprising by the same group of military officers who helped put Mr. Bagaza in power in a bloodless army coup in 1976. 'It Is the Same Group' **********Like his predecessor, Mr. Buyoya is a Tutsi, a group that makes up 15 percent of the country's five million people but which has long dominated the Hutus, who make up most of the rest of the population. **********''It is the same group, the same army, the same Tutsi minority,'' a Western diplomat said, although he added that Mr. Buyoya's initial political moves had been ''very positive.'' **********''We had to take a wait-and-see attitude,'' the diplomat said, ''but if the new Government had not intended to modify the positions of the past, I don't think we would have seen these initial steps.'' **********Mr. Bagaza, 41 years old, had been regarded as a peacemaker in one of Africa's most bitter tribal conflicts. That conflict had erupted in 1972, when Tutsi policemen and members of the party's youth group killed about 150,000 Hutus after Hutus killed several thousand Tutsis in an unsuccessful bid for majority rule. **********Despite his attempts at reconciliation, when Mr. Bagaza was deposed three-quarters of his Cabinet, three-quarters of the National Assembly, about two-thirds of the university students, 13 of 15 provincial governors, all the army officers and 96 percent of the enlisted soldiers were Tutsi. Dispute on Identifying Students **********And despite the Bagaza Government's denials of ethnic discrimination, human-rights groups earlier this year accused the former rulers of imprisoning a group of Hutu intellectuals after the leak of an official Government letter that was sent to some primary-school principals. **********In the letter, the principals were said to have been asked to provide lists of students that indicated Tutsis with an ''I'' and Hutus with a ''U.'' **********President Buyoya, who has dismissed all members of the former Government, the ruling party and the country's Judicial Council, has insisted that ''all sections of the public'' will be included in making decisions. **********But some diplomats and others say it will not be easy to improve the complex ethnic situation. The Tutsis, descendants of herdsmen from northern Africa, have for centuries held sway over the Hutus, who are generally peasant farmers of southern African Bantu stock. 'Profound Changes' Coming **********More than 70 years of German and Belgian colonial rule did little to change the situation. Since independence in 1962, every Government has been dominated by Tutsis. **********In a recent interview with Agence France-Presse, Mr. Buyoya challenged assertions that ethnic divisions existed. But he said there would be ''very positive and very profound changes in the direction of more social justice and genuine democracy.'' **********''In one way or the other,'' he said, ''all sections of the public will be called upon to take part in the decision-making process. There are not and will not be any criteria based on ethnic or regional origins under the new regime.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/04/world.body_text: **********A censure vote on the economy today brought down Portugal's 16th Government since a military coup ended half a century of right-wing dictatorship in 1974. **********The vote came after a motion to censure Prime Minister Anibal Cavaco Silva's 18-month-old minority Government, which was accused of not modernizing the nation's economy. Under Portuguese law, a government must resign after a censure motion is passed. **********The motion was made by the opposition Democratic Renewal Party of former President Antonio Ramalho Eanes. It was joined by the Socialists and the Communists in mustering 134 votes, 8 more than is needed in the 250-member Parliament. **********Mr. Cavaco's Social Democrats and the allied Christian Democrats managed only 108 votes, and the single Monarchist Party member abstained. **********Since 1974, no single party has gained a parliamentary majority in Portugal, which has meant a string of minority governments and coalitions with little strength. Not one of the governments has finished a four-year term. **********Portugal's Constitution gives President Mario Soares the power to seek formation of a new government from Parliament or to dissolve the body and call for elections. If the President chooses to dissolve Parliament, elections must follow within 90 days. **********On Friday, Mr. Cavaco made clear that the Social Democrats want early elections. The Social Democrats got 30 percent of the vote and 88 seats in the last elections, in October 1985. **********Mr. Eanes's party has expressed interest in forming a coalition with the Socialists, but the Socialist leader, Vitor Constancio, has hinted at a preference for early elections.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/29/busin.print_headline: MARKET TURMOIL; Across U.S., Anxiety Without Panic
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/29/busin.body_text: **********It was the talk of grocery shoppers like Maria Lacombe at the Lucky Store in Madera, Calif., and of customers like Carl Schobinger, in for a haircut at Hanna's Barbershop in Watford City, N.D. **********But, across the country, the stock market's tumultuous 10 days has provoked mostly talk and little action, many Americans say. Miles away from the turmoil of Wall Street, in industrial Toledo, Ohio, or rural Cascadia, Ore., there may be cause for anxiety, they say, but no reason to run for cover. While some expect no economic downturn, others in already depressed communities do not see how things could get much worse. **********''Just because the market falls on its face doesn't mean that thousands of people will go hungry or lose their homes, their cars, their jobs,'' said Robert Bullard of Bisbee, Ariz. **********Echoing this sentiment, the results of a survey released yesterday indicate that Americans feel their economy remains strong. Consumer confidence dropped only 5 percent after last week's stock market plunge, according to the survey, taken by the Conference Board, a nonprofit business research group. By comparison, consumer confidence dropped 33 percent after the 1973 surge in oil prices, the survey noted. 'Not Very Important at All' **********In fact, many Americans interviewed by The New York Times by telephone said the market gyrations had little impact on their day-to-day life. Rather than monitoring the ups and downs of the Dow Jones industrial average, they were charting the batting averages of the Minnesota Twins. **********''I'm not really up on what's going on with the stock market,'' said John Huth, 26 years old, who operates a machine shop in Toledo, Ohio. ''To me, the stuff that's happened in the stock market is not very important at all.'' **********Linda Workin, of Fargo, N.D., agreed. ''I would say, on a whole it hasn't affected many people up here,'' the 25-year-old legal clerk for a newspaper company said, ''Up here, farming is real big.'' **********Many of those interviewed said that most of the people they know simply are not wealthy enough to have invested in the stock market. **********''Most of the people who work here couldn't care less about the market,'' said Sandra Saghy, a receptionist for a Pittsburgh heating and cooling company. ''They look at what's happened in the stock market crash as rich people's problems.'' 'More Important Things' **********Other world events - from the specter of war in the Persian Gulf to the outcome of the World Series -seem more important than the stock market's frenzy, they said. **********''I don't think anyone really knows how it will affect them or if it will affect them,'' said Shelly Ward, a 28-year-old photographer, in Memphis. ''Frankly, I think there are a lot more important things to worry about like the number of people who are starving in the world and the fact that another major war in the world is a strong possibility.'' **********Even people who own stock said the market's wild activity would not affect them a great deal. Describing themselves as small investors, they said their losses were only on paper because they had chosen not to sell. Now they are ready to wait until the market goes back up. **********''My feeling about it is we should ride it out, and we should probably buy some more,'' said Margaret Hardisty, a publisher of children's books in Lafayette, Calif., a city of 22,500 about 20 miles east of San Francisco. 'Time of Serious Questions' **********''I'm not an economist,'' she said, ''but my feeling as I watch this is, because the present Administration has put our economic house in order as much as they have, we won't feel the effect of the slide as we did in 1929.'' Mrs. Hardisty and her husband had $50,000 invested in several mutual funds. **********A few Americans view the stock market slide as a harbinger of recession or worse. **********''To me this is a time of serious questions,'' said Mark A. Jackson, a 29-year-old sales representative with a chemical company in Indianapolis. ''I have to wonder what effect this will have on business. Are we in store for another time of recession? Are we headed for a depression? I believe a lot of companies will respond to falling stock prices by cutting back on their capital expenditures.'' **********Whether Mr. Jackson's own spending will be altered is unclear. He said he had considered buying stocks and mutual fund shares but was less certain now how to invest his money. **********''I wonder if I should save every penny I can,'' he said. ''And, if so, where do I put it? Where do you invest right now?'' 'Time for Another Depression' **********''I think it's time for another depression,'' said Paul Dees, 20 years old, of Kosciusko, Miss. ''I look at it like this: There hasn't been one since 1929. Things that happened before are going to happen again.'' **********Mr. Dees, a transportation specialist with the National Guard, said many of his friends at work had lost money in the market. But a more worrisome question in his central Mississippi community of 6,922 -where many jobs were lost when a manufacturer of school buses left town five or six years ago - is whether the stock market's trauma will affect employment. **********''Down here in Mississippi, there are not many jobs here as it is,'' said Mr. Dees. **********People who live in regions where jobs are scarce said they were already used to hard times. 'Under the Gun for Many Years' **********''We've lived under the gun for many years in the copper and mining industries,'' said Mr. Bullard of Bisbee, an Arizona town battered by the decline of the copper industry in the last decade. By 1980, about 2,000 of the town's 8,000 citizens had been laid off because the Phelps Dodge Corporation closed an open-pit mine. **********''Bad times are not alien to us,'' said Mr. Bullard, a 45-year-old mechanical electrical company foreman. **********Most of those interviewed, however, do not expect a recession. **********''I don't have too much of a doomsday attitude about it,'' said Mike Horner, the manager of the Triple T Studs Saw Mill in Cascadia, Ore. **********Some said they might tighten their belts - such as buying fewer Christmas presents - if a recession occurs. But most expect life and the economy to go on as usual. **********''Your common folk round here -nobody's really concerned about it, and nobody's really worried about it,'' said Richard Cain, 36, a steelworker and part-time farmer at Paducah, Ky. ''Things are going to keep on going as they have been.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/24/world.main_headline: SURVIVOR OF DEATH CAMP INDENTIFIES ACCUSED GUARD AT TRIAL IN ISRAEL
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/24/world.print_headline: SURVIVOR OF DEATH CAMP INDENTIFIES ACCUSED GUARD AT TRIAL IN ISRAEL
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/24/world.body_text: **********Forty-four years after escaping from the Treblinka death camp, Pinhas Epstein stood in court today to accuse the man he said was the executioner of countless Jews. **********''There is Ivan the Terrible,'' Mr. Epstein testified, pointing at John Demjanjuk, the 67-year-old retired auto worker from Cleveland who is on trial for his life. ''I dream about him every night.'' **********In seven hours of testimony, Mr. Epstein contradicted Mr. Demjanjuk's pleadings of innocence and identified him as the gas chamber operator called Ivan the Terrible. **********The witness provided detailed recollections of Treblinka, where an estimated 870,000 Polish Jews were gassed and cremated during World War II. **********The 67-year-old defendant, born in the Ukraine as Ivan Demjanjuk, denies the charges against him and insists he is the victim of mistaken identity. 'A Predatory Animal' **********But Mr. Epstein, wiping tears away, depicted the accused as ''a predatory animal'' who heightened the terror of the Treblinka gas chambers by gouging victims' eyes and stabbing pregnant women in the abdomen before he turned on the gas engines. **********''When we were told to remove the corpses, this Ivan came out of the engine room and would beat us mercilessly with a pipe or a sword or a bayonet,'' Mr. Epstein testified. ''He would crack skulls and cut off ears and commit the most indescribable atrocities on the corpses.'' **********The defense contends that Mr. Demjanjuk was an anti-Nazi prisoner of war in another camp during the massacre of up to 20,000 Jews a day at Treblinka. He lost his American citizenship in 1985 after a United States court rejected his alibi and concluded he had been at Treblinka. **********Mr. Epstein, the first of half a dozen Treblinka survivors who are to testify, apologized to the court for not being able to fully describe the reality of his 11 months there. Watching His Brother Die **********''I think the human brain cannot grasp it when it's retold,'' the 62-year-old witness said. **********Mr. Epstein said he arrived at the camp in 1942 as a 17-year-old who had never seen a corpse, and within minutes saw his younger brother, David, die on the train platform as a guard cracked his head with a rifle butt. **********His parents and two other siblings were sent with the crowds to their deaths in the gas chambers, he testified, while he was designated for the work gangs. He encountered ''mounds of corpses,'' he testified, and such atrocities as the live placement of an old woman and two newborn infants atop a grill in a fiery cremation pit. **********''The cry of these babies rings in my ears unto this day,'' he declared. **********Mark O'Connor, the chief defense attorney, sought to show that Mr. Epstein's memory was faulty by pointing to several discrepancies in his testimony at other war crimes proceedings in the last 30 years. But the questions did not touch directly on his recollections of Mr. Demjanjuk, and the witness insisted his memory was firm. **********''I dream of Ivan every night, I envision him,'' he said, staring at the accused. ''I see him, I see him, I see him.'' **********Mr. Demjanjuk paid close, silent attention to the testimony.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/07/world.main_headline: Japan's New Cabinet Gets Old Face
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/07/world.print_headline: Japan's New Cabinet Gets Old Face
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/07/world.body_text: **********Noboru Takeshita was elected Japan's 17th postwar Prime Minister today, and he immediately formed a Government bearing the stamp of his predecessor in top positions. **********The transfer of political authority was one of the smoothest in many years. It had none of the rancor that has often accompanied the selection of a Japanese leader even though all prime ministers over the last 32 years have come from the same party. **********A 63-year-old veteran of backroom political maneuvering, the new leader takes over from Yasuhiro Nakasone, who made today's election inevitable two weeks ago when he named Mr. Takeshita president of the long-ruling Liberal Democratic Party. **********Mr. Nakasone had lasted in office for five years, the third longest term for a Prime Minister since the end of World War II. But while he himself may be gone, his influence is not. #2 Cabinet Holdovers His successor picked two holdovers from the Nakasone Cabinet to fill critical economic positions. **********Kiichi Miyawaza, who had hoped to become Prime Minister himself, was reappointed Finance Minister, a position he will hold along with the politically sensitive post of Deputy Prime Minister. Hajime Tamura was retained as head of the powerful Ministry of International Trade and Industry. **********As Foreign Minister, Mr. Takeshita selected an ardent Nakasone loyalist, Sosuke Uno, who in the past has held several important Government and party positions. **********Talking with Japanese reporters this evening, Mr. Uno wasted no time to make clear that he intended to continue basic Nakasone policies, which emphasized close ties with the United States, steady military growth and a reordering of economic priorities to accommodate overseas protests about Japan's huge trade surpluses. Defense Director General **********''I think I need to value the Nakasone heritage, and my role is to develop it further,'' said Mr. Uno, who was a prisoner of war in a Siberian camp for two years after the war. **********In another important Cabinet assignment, Mr. Takeshita appointed Tsutomu Kawara, 50, to be Director General of the Defense Agency. Eiichi Nakao, a Nakasone loyalist, was named head of the Economic Planning Agency. **********In all, Mr. Takeshita filled 20 Cabinet-level posts, and he preserved tradition by making sure that he parceled out ministries carefully to all major ruling-party factions. The largest number of positions, five, went to his own followers. But he also accommodated political demands of the other groups, headed by Shintaro Abe, Toshio Komoto, Mr. Miyazawa and Mr. Nakasone, who retains his seat in Parliament. **********Mr. Abe, who had also sought the party presidency, was personally taken care of last weekend when Mr. Takeshita gave him the politically significant post of party secretary general. Prime Minister Bows Twice **********There was no sense of drama as Mr. Takeshita won an easy and predictable election in Parliament's decision-making chamber, the House of Representatives. When the result was announced, lawmakers burst into applause, and the new Prime Minister acknowledged the ovation by bowing twice. **********He beat three candidates from opposition parties, who had no illusions about their chances of taking power. But one of them, Takako Doi, head of the Socialist Party, became a footnote in Japanese political history as the first woman to be a candidate for Prime Minister.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/26/world.main_headline: Malolos Journal; Fighting the Good Fight (Human and Otherwise)
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/26/world.print_headline: Malolos Journal; Fighting the Good Fight (Human and Otherwise)
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/26/world.body_text: **********It was an embarrassing moment for Serafin Santos. His rooster, tawny feathers spread in anger, waited in the cockpit for the fight to begin, but the bettors favored its opponent, a fierce-looking red. **********''Councilor Santos, if you want the fight to proceed you will have to put down another 500 pesos,'' the referee announced. **********Mr. Santos complied, and within less than a minute tasted vindication. In a flurry of feathers, its sharpened metal spur flashing, his entry was victorious and the red lay dying beside it in the sand. **********''It's thrilling! It's thrilling!'' Mr. Santos said. ''It's violent, like Philippine politics.'' Nation's Two Great Sports **********Cockfighting and politics are the two great sports of the Philippines, and in the cockpit Mr. Santos was indulging in both of them. **********A candidate for councilor in this town 20 miles northwest of Manila -one of 32 men competing for eight seats - Mr. Santos had agreed with the referee that if his name was announced he would help finance any underdogs. He did not suspect that his own bird would be one of these. **********''Everyone hears, 'Councilor Santos, Councilor Santos,' '' he said. ''What more campaigning do you want?'' **********And then, he said, he would turn to the ''Cristo,'' the middleman, and say, ''Brother, bet me 500 pesos on the favorite.'' However the fight goes, Mr. Santos said, he breaks even. **********In the Philippines, people often play politics the same way. **********Mr. Santos, for example, is running on the Liberal Party slate, which opposes the slate endorsed by President Corazon C. Aquino. But he calls himself an Aquino man just the same. **********''We are now the opposition, but actually we are not,'' Mr. Santos said. ''We still belong to the coalition.'' The Traits They Share The two quintessentially Filipino pastimes have a good deal in common. **********As in the cockpit, Philippine politics - from coups to constitutions - begins with a frenzy of bet-placing. **********In the cockpit, as in the political coffee shop, the bettors wave their hands and hiss their odds in time-honored signals that continue noisily even after the fight has begun. **********The betting, like politics, is multilateral, with alliances crisscrossing and interweaving through the shouting crowd, and it sometimes becomes hard to tell where the real stakes lie. **********The bettors must be as fast-moving as the action itself, and in both arenas the decisive question is sometimes not who wins but how agile a man has been in placing his bets. **********In a nation where politics is based on personalities rather than ideologies, it matters less whether the winner is a red or a gray than whether the bettor wins along with him. **********The cocks themselves, like Filipino politicians, posture and raise their feathers in Elizabethan ruffs as the fight begins, leaping suddenly into the air in vivid displays of aggression. How Marcos Lost Respect **********Sometimes, the posturing itself is enough, and one of the cocks turns and runs, pecking at the gate of the arena to escape combat. **********President Ferdinand E. Marcos fled his palace in February 1986 after three days of intense posturing, with hardly a shot fired, and never regained the respect of Filipinos. **********A cock like this is known as a runner, and is cooked and eaten. **********''Nobody will bet money on a runner,'' Mr. Santos said. **********Similarly, if both cocks are too wounded and exhausted to make a kill, the referee lifts them both to see which maintains a posture of aggression, pecking feebly at its opponent. **********And as in Philippine politics -where the current local election campaign has begun before the last contested ballots of May's legislative poll have finally been tallied - the combat never really ends. **********Even as the man with the whisk broom enters the pit to sweep up the feathers, and the losing cock is carried out by its feet, the shouting of the bettors again fills the arena, along with the crowing of other roosters ready for a fight. But Cockfights Aren't Fixed **********At home over bottles of San Miguel beer, as a fluorescent light buzzed overhead, the talk among Mr. Santos and his friends was of politics and cockfighting. **********There are differences, the men agreed. **********Unlike such other betting sports as boxing, horse racing and politics, Mr. Santos asserted, cockfights are rarely fixed. **********And unlike politics - or coups -where threats and warnings are often an end in themselves, a cockfight is always a fight to the finish. **********''The cock that you have will die for your money,'' Mr. Santos said. **********In this way, cockfighting may offer a catharsis for a hesitant and self-doubting people, a country in which foreigners sometimes comment that ''everything starts but nothing is finished.'' **********It also reflects, as Mr. Santos noted, an undercurrent of violence throughout the nation that surfaces when men compete for elective office. **********Political killings, some in towns only a few minutes' drive from from Malolos, have become an almost daily occurrence in the present campaign, which ends in mid-January. Hedging His Bets **********Filipinos seem to be taking the political violence in stride. ''There are too many candidates anyway,'' remarked a young woman in Manila, a journalist. **********The betting in Malolos, in a hot tin-roofed cockpit similar to arenas in most Philippine towns, involved about 10,000 pesos, or $2,000, on each fight. **********The amounts were small in comparison with the major contests in big cities, where millions of pesos are sometimes staked on one encounter. **********But it was big money in a town like Malolos where Mr. Santos, a former clerk of courts, planned to spend about 20,000 pesos on his election campaign. **********Though he will continue to visit the cockpit during the campaign, he said, he will also continue to hedge his bets. **********''I cannot afford to lose money on a fight now,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/18/world.main_headline: Address by Gorbachev To Congress Is Weighed
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/18/world.print_headline: Address by Gorbachev To Congress Is Weighed
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/18/world.body_text: **********The Reagan Administration wants Mikhail S. Gorbachev to be allowed to speak to a joint meeting of Congress during the summit meeting next month only if Moscow permits President Reagan to address the Soviet people, a senior Administration official said today. **********The Administration official, who asked not to be identified, said Moscow had expressed a strong interest in an address by Mr. Gorbachev. Moscow has not said if it would reciprocate, he said. **********A spokesman for Jim Wright, Democrat of Texas and Speaker of the House, said earlier that the Administration had requested a joint meeting for Mr. Gorbachev to address Congress on Dec. 9. Mr. Wright said ''fine,'' according to the spokesman. **********It was unclear whether the invitation was conditional on a reciprocal offer from the Russians.  [ The Associated Press reported that some conservative members of Congress objected to the invitation to Mr. Gorbachev. Representative Dick Cheney of Wyoming, chairman of the House Republican conference, said: **********''It would be appropriate for members of Congress to visit with General Secretary Gorbachev, but appearance before a joint session of Congress is a mark of respect for a foreign leader.''  [ Representative Dan Burton of Indiana and other Republicans said they would try to block the address. Mr. Burton told the A.P. that inviting Mr. Gorbachev was ''analogous to having Adolf Hitler come before the British Parliament.'' ]  Robert C. Byrd, the Senate majority leader, had already invited Mr. Gorbachev to address Congress. But one House official said Mr. Wright had to make the invitation because joint meetings of Congress are held in the House chamber.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/18/busin.print_headline: WHAT'S NEW IN COLLEGE RECRUITING; Prospecting for Smart 18-Year-Olds
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/18/busin.body_text: **********''THE experts tell us there's a lot of attrition at some schools because the whole process of being a freshman is so overwhelming and dehumanizing,'' said Mr. Collier of the SUNY branch at Albany. In response, colleges are increasingly providing friendly advisors, livelier teachers and better living conditions to increase retention of first-year students - which means the school needs to attract fewer of them the next time around. **********At the University of Wisconsin at Oshkosh, for example, retention of students has increased 11 percent in the last decade, and the college has used some of the money it saved on recruiting to completely remodel its dormitories. **********''They look like Holiday Inns,'' says R. Thomas Snider, assistant to the vice chancellor. ''We've set a goal of reducing the university by 200 students each year for four years. We started last year with the idea that about a third would come from the freshman class. The revenue is being displaced by the increased revenue from improved retention.'' **********Oshkosh recruiters are more selective now, aiming at ''appropriate'' students - meaning a good fit between an applicant's career goals and the majors the college offers - and making ''full disclosure'' about the nature of the campus. ''In the past colleges just let the applications flow and rested on their images,'' Mr. Snider said. ''But institutional match is the key to long-term success.'' **********Ethnic match appears to be a key to recruiting minorities. Don T. Nakanishi, assistant professor at the University of the City of Los Angeles, is a member of a committee of 70 minority alumi from Yale University that recruits in 90 high schools. Professor Nakanishi said: ''We share experiences. They always ask, 'How was it?' 'Did you face any racism?' We can provide a more balanced report.'' **********To fish the smaller 18-year-old pool, Carleton College in Minnesota used survey data and conducted group interviews with its own freshmen and former prospects who ultimately chose other schools. Its first surprise was that to woo students in Minnesota, the college needed a different message than to woo students in New England. Minnesota students need to be convinced the $13,640-a-year liberal arts college is a bargain. But to eastern students a ''bargain'' means ''it must not be that good.'' Messages headed east today explain why the lower cost of a professor's groceries and less expensive real estate can help lower tuition in Northfield, Minn. **********The message must be working. In 1974, Carleton fielded 1,400 applications. This year it had 2,900 - for a class of 495.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/06/busin.print_headline: ADVERTISING; THE WAR ON DRUGS BEGINS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/06/busin.body_text: **********THE nation's advertising and media communities and many of their suppliers have been working for months on a gigantic, unprecedented advertising campaign to unsell illegal drugs. Yesterday, they disclosed their plans as the campaign was about to break in donated time and space on TV, radio, billboards, newspapers and magazines. **********Working on the belief that it would be impossible to stop the supply of drugs, the Media-Advertising Partnership for a Drug-Free America is out to dry up the demand. Its effort involves work by almost 200 advertising agencies and donated media time and space expected to total $1.5 billion over the next three years. **********At a news conference yesterday, Allen Rosenshine, president of the Omnicom Group, and chairman of the partnership's creative review board, said: **********''De-normalization cannot be accomplished by a single surgical strike of a single great commercial or even a campaign in the classic sense. De-normalization of attitude and behavior in actual or potential drug usage demands an incessant bombardment from every direction against every strata of society, every month, every week, every day. **********''In a sense,'' he continued, ''the more we can say that drug usage is not O.K., drug usage is not acceptable at any level of consumption, drug usage is not a rational choice, drug usage is not controllable, in short, drug usage is not the normal state of human condition, the more effective I believe we will ultimately be.''  * * * **********A bit later he added: ''At the end of the day, historically great advertising has generated positive reaction to a particular brand of product or service. At the end of our day, the advertising we produce must generate a negative attitude - a social revulsion - to what is now a smile and a wink at the higher end of the socioeconomic spectrum and a fatalistic shrug at the lower levels of social and/or economic deprivation.'' **********Richard T. O'Reilly, longtime agency executive who is national director of the partnership, said that what was being sought from TV, radio and cable networks was the equivalent of two spots a night during prime time; from newspapers, a full page a week; from weekly magazines, one page every other week, and from monthly magazines, one page a month. **********The news conference was broadcast by closed circuit from the J. C. Penney Building in Manhattan to 70 cities around the nation. Those on the dais included Charlotte Beers, chairman of Tatham-Laird & Kudner, Chicago, and chairman of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, the driving force behind the effort; Herbert Baum, president of Campbell Soup U.S.A., and chairman of the management board of the partnership; Daniel B. Burke, president of Capital Cities/ABC, representing the media, and William A. Schreyer, chairman of Merrill Lynch, who is in charge of raising some $3 million for the partnership's expenses.  * * * **********According to Mr. O'Reilly, the news conference had a nationwide audience of about 5,000, which included members of the agency association's regional councils who will be seeking free space and time from local media. **********Judging by the advertising shown yesterday the contributions are of high quality. They are aimed at drug users, potential users and ''influencers,'' the people who can affect the behavior of the other two groups. **********The drugs under attack are marijuana and cocaine, including its derivative crack. Mr. O'Reilly said the partnership's extensive research had shown that among youngsters age 9 to 12, about 37 percent thought that drug users were popular. And among teen-agers, 15 percent saw drugs in a positive light, one out of four had little or no fear of marijuana, and one in six had little or no fear of cocaine. **********There will also be special advertising campaigns directed at physicians and dentists; black and Hispanic Americans, and schoolteachers. **********What is being called the nation's largest communication project in peacetime resulted from nagging by one very dedicated and presistent advertising man who believes in the power of advertising. He is Phillip Joanou, chairman of Dailey & Associates, Los Angeles, and he was at the conference yesterday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/02/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; CPC, Ajinomoto In Asian Venture
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/02/busin.body_text: **********CPC International Inc., the large food concern that has been restructuring since it became a takeover target, said it had agreed to sell interests in several Asian grocery businesses. The interests - in Hong Kong, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, Taiwan and Thailand - will be sold for $340 million to the Ajinomoto Company, a large Japanese food enterprise. The businesses will be operated as a joint venture of CPC and Ajinomoto. **********CPC said the move was aimed at fueling aggressive growth in Asia. A substantial part of the proceeds would be used to reduce debt, which has accumulated from CPC's costly restructuring program, adopted last November after Ronald O. Perelman made an abortive effort to take over the company. CPC sold its European wet-milling corn business to Italy's Ferruzzi Group last week for more than $600 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/11/world.main_headline: MAJOR DEALS CITED IN CHINA-IRAN ARMS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/11/world.print_headline: MAJOR DEALS CITED IN CHINA-IRAN ARMS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/11/world.body_text: **********European and Asian diplomats here have provided new evidence that China, despite its denials, has sold substantial numbers of weapons to Iran, including missiles, jet fighters and field artillery. **********Chinese officials, who consistently assert that Beijing is neutral in the Iran-Iraq war and that it does not sell weapons to either side, repeated the denials again today. **********''Those reports are sheer fabrication,'' said Li Jinhua, a spokeswoman for the Foreign Ministry. ''The Chinese Government maintains strict neutrality in the Iran-Iraq war and is making efforts to urge Iran and Iraq to put an end to the war.'' **********United States officials have said China has provided Iran with the Silkworm missile, a surface-to-surface weapon that can strike oil tankers and warships in the Persian Gulf. Frank C. Carlucci, President Reagan's national security adviser, said on Saturday that the United States did not believe China's statements denying it had sold missiles to Iran.  [ But Howard H. Baker Jr., the White House chief of staff, said in Venice on Wednesday that he accepted Beijing's denials. Later, a White House official said Mr. Baker had been mistaken in his comments. ]  Kuwaiti Request Being Studied At the same time, the Chinese Foreign Ministry acknowledged that Kuwait had asked China to consider allowing Kuwaiti tankers to be registered under the Chinese flag. The ministry said the request was being studied. **********The United States plans to place half of Kuwait's 22-tanker oil fleet under protection of the American flag. **********Many diplomats here say China has sold up to $2 billion in arms to Iran over the last two years. A Kuwaiti newspaper report quoted in a Hong Kong newspaper, as well as two diplomats here, said China had received oil in exchange for the arms. **********Among the arms China is thought to have sold Iran are Chinese-made field guns, Chinese versions of the Soviet MIG-19 and MIG-21 fighters and Chinese-manufactured T-59 tanks, also a copy of a Soviet design. Information on those arms was provided by one diplomat but could not be confirmed by others. **********Much of the evidence cited by diplomats here is fragmentary, but the diplomats say there is no longer any doubt that large quantities of Chinese arms have been shipped to Iran, with much going through third countries. **********Last year, an Asian diplomat said, a shipment of Chinese weapons was sent to Iran through North Korea. A second shipment, the diplomat said, was moved through Hong Kong. Another Asian diplomat, who often travels to Pyongyang, said today that North Korea was a common conduit for arms shipments to Iran. **********Chinese officials, according to American diplomats, have maintained that they had nothing to do with selling arms to Iran, but that North Korea had done so on its own. This assertion, however, has been rejected by Washington. Issued Raised by Arab League **********Last month, a seven-member delegation of foreign ministers from Arab League nations visited Beijing and raised the issue of Chinese arms sales to Iran with Chinese officials at every level, according to an Asian diplomat. **********Several Western European businessmen in Beijing said China had offered to trade oil in exchange for their products rather than make a straightforward cash purchase. An American oil executive here said today: ''It's Iranian oil. That's what they're using.'' **********Asian and European diplomats said China could use Iranian oil in trade arrangements only if it had more oil from its arms sales than it needed. **********According to an Asian diplomat, China's interest in selling arms to Iran has far less to do with financial gain than with strategic interests. China, the diplomat said, wants to use Iran as a counterweight to the Soviet Union and to Soviet influence in Afghanistan. **********Iran's Foreign Minister, Ali Akbar Velayati, is to visit Beijing on Friday after a visit to North Korea.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/09/busin.print_headline: ADVERTISING; Acme Supermarket Goes to Thompson
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/09/busin.body_text: **********J. Walter Thompson, New York, has won the Philadelphia-based Acme Supermarket account, estimated to be in the range of $8 million to $10 million. **********Acme's parent company is the American Stores Company, Salt Lake City, which operates food and drugstore chains. It has more than 350 stores in Pennsylvania, New Jersey, West Virginia, Delaware and Maryland as well as in upstate New York. **********The former agency - Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt - lost other American Stores accounts last year after the company decentralized marketing operations, allowing its various units to review their advertising agencies.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/04/world.main_headline: CHINA HELPING U.S. ON SOVIET A-TESTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/04/world.print_headline: CHINA HELPING U.S. ON SOVIET A-TESTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/04/world.body_text: **********The United States is using monitoring devices in China to improve estimates of the size of Soviet nuclear tests, according to Defense Department documents and interviews with Administration officials. **********The seismic devices, manned by Chinese workers, have been installed under an American-Chinese program to study earthquakes. One device is in the Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region, near the Soviet nuclear test site, and the Defense Department will use data from this and other instruments to improve United States monitoring. **********The data will ''improve our yield estimation'' of Soviet nuclear blasts, according to a budget document prepared last year by the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, part of the Pentagon. Better Distinguishes Tests **********The document also said the data would be useful in improving American ''discrimination capability'' to distinguish Soviet nuclear tests from earthquakes. Such an ability would be necessary to monitor a low limit on the size of underground tests or a total ban on testing. **********The document was obtained through the Freedom of Information Act by William M. Arkin of the Institute for Policy Studies, a nongovernmental research center, and was later made available to The New York Times. **********Some American Government experts have long been interested in establishing a way to monitor Soviet nuclear tests from China. But China has resisted overt efforts at gathering intelligence about Soviet blasts. Initial Suggestion Last Year **********Last year, specialists at the Energy Department, which manages the nuclear testing program, expressed interest in negotiations with the Chinese to set up an advanced array of sensitive seismic devices in China to monitor Soviet tests, particularly blasts of very low yield. The State Department advised against such a move, arguing that the proposal was politically sensitive for the Chinese and that Washington should adopt a go-slow approach. **********The Energy Department's plans were disclosed in budget documents last year before the United States and China decided whether to conduct such talks. The disclosure distressed the Chinese, and the Energy Department effort was dropped. **********Despite this controversy, China and the United States proceeded with a separate project to set up nine monitoring stations in China, primarily for studying and predicting earthquakes. The network was completed last year - using equipment made by China, the United States and other Western nations - under an agreement between Chinese Government seismologists and the United States Geological Survey. **********China and the United States share the cost of the network, and the Defense Research Agency pays most of the American costs. **********''We look on it as a scientific reserach project for the study of earthquakes,'' said David P. Russ of the Geological Survey. ''If a contributor has some other purposes, that is his business. It is not the primary purpose.'' **********Mr. Russ added all of the data would be made public. Another Device in Manchuria **********One device is in Urumqi in Xinjiang, in the northwestern part of China. The device is about 600 miles from the Soviet test site at Semipalatinsk in Central Asia. Another device, in Manchuria, will allow the United States to learn more about the geology of the Soviet Union. **********American officials said that although the network was completed last fall, minor technical problems were still being worked out. The officials said there was a delay of several months in receiving and analyzing the data from China. As a result, the United States has not had a chance to evaluate data on recent Soviet tests, which began in February, when the Russians ended their 18-month moratorium. **********Today, the Soviet Union conducted its third nuclear test since the end of its moratorium. **********In 1981, it was reported that the United States and China were secretly operating an electronic intelligence-gathering station in China to monitor signals from Soviet missile tests. That secret project is different from the installation of the seismic devices, which is being done openly and primarily for scientific research. **********The data from China will supplement information gathered from seismic research installations in Norway, Pakistan, Turkey, South Korea, India and Japan, among other countries. In addition, the Air Force operates secret installations around the world to monitor Soviet tests. Issue of Treaty Compliance **********Data on the size of Soviet tests are important because of the need to determine whether the Soviet Union is complying with two treaties from the 1970's that set a limit of 150 kilotons for underground nuclear explosions. A kiloton represents the explosive force of 1,000 tons of TNT. **********Many experts inside and outside the Government say the Russians are complying with the treaties, which the United States has not ratified. The Reagan Administration has charged that it is ''likely'' that Moscow has violated the treaties, but it is re-examining the issue. **********The data are also important because such information may enable the United States to make more precise estimates of Soviet tests using devices outside the Soviet Union. The Administration has said the monitoring of the treaties should be improved by on-site monitoring at the Soviet test site using a cable inserted in the ground. But some experts say that such intrusive monitoring techniques are not necessary and that improvements in seismic monitoring outside the Soviet Union and possible installation of seismic devices inside the Soviet Union would suffice. Seismometer in Ocean Floor **********In other efforts to improve seismic monitoring abilities, the Defense Research Agency has supervised an experiment about 600 miles off the Kamchatka Peninsula on the Pacific coast of the Soviet Union. **********In that experiment, the Glomar Challenger ship was used to drill a hole in the ocean floor and install a seismometer, according to the budget document from the agency. The purpose of the experiment was to determine if devices in the ocean floor could monitor a test ban or a low limit on the force of nuclear tests. **********Government officials said the experiment established that the ocean floor sites were ''quiet'' enough - that is, free of seismic background noise -that this could be done. **********The Defense Research Agency is also considering an experiment in which the United States could conduct an underground test in Nevada ''in rock believed to be very similar to that at the Soviet test site,'' the budget document says. Measurements would be used to adjust estimates of the size of Soviet tests. The experiment has been deferred in the past for lack of money.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/09/world.main_headline: BIG LIBYAN LOSSES CLAIMED BY CHAD
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/09/world.print_headline: BIG LIBYAN LOSSES CLAIMED BY CHAD
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/09/world.body_text: **********Chad offered a fuller account today of its weekend raid on an air base in Libya, saying it had killed 1,713 Libyan soldiers. **********In a communique read on Chad radio, Chad said its troops had destroyed 26 Libyan planes, including 3 Soviet-made MIG-23 jets, a MIG 24-combat helicopter and four French-made Mirage fighters, in demolishing the Matan as Sarra air base 60 miles from Chad's border. The base had often been used by Libyan planes that bombed Chad. **********Chad added that its forces took 312 prisoners, including two Yugoslavs who it described as mercenaries and one East German. **********The Chadian raid on Saturday followed a Libyan siege of the northern Chad town of Ounianga Kebir. Libya has intervened in Chad repeatedly during the civil war that has gone on almost continuously since Chad's independence in 1960, but the raid on Matan as Sarra was the first foray into Libya by Chadian Government forces. Air Strike on Chad **********Libya responded Monday by sending warplanes over Ndjamena, the Chadian capital, one of which was shot down by French forces. Today Chad's Ambassador to France said that Libyan planes bombed three towns in northern Chad earlier in the day. **********Ahmad Allam-Mi, the ambassador, said the three towns - Wour, Yebbi Bou and Fada - suffered some destruction, but he said that he did not know the number of casualties. **********In describing the attack on Matan as Sarra, the Chadians said they also demolished 70 Soviet-made tanks, eight radar stations and a radio-scrambling device at the airbase. Chad also said its forces destroyed two runways, and that the base ''no longer exists.'' **********The number Chad reported would be the largest toll of casualties Libya has suffered in its 14-year war with Chad. Chad said 65 of its soldiers were killed and 112 wounded in the attack. Libyan Account of Battle **********Today Libya said it had repulsed a second attack by the Chadians on the base and chased them back into Chad. **********Neither the Chadian accounts nor the Libyan report could be independently confirmed. **********Again today, French officials tried to play down their role in Chad, maintaining that the downing of the Libyan bomber Monday did not represent a more aggressive attitude toward Libya. They said that in downing the Soviet-made long-range TU-22 bomber, France's force of 1,200 men in Chad was merely carrying out its role of protecting southern Chad. **********''If France shot down a Libyan plane Monday, it is because it was seeking to bomb Ndjamena,'' Jean-Bernard Raimond, the Foreign Minister, said today. Plea for Peace by Chirac **********In a television interview tonight, Prime Minister Jacques Chriac called on the two nations to stop fighting. **********Mr. Chirac added, however, that ''Chadian authorities are entitled to take control of their territory.'' **********Libya has said that France's action put it in ''direct confrontation'' with Libya. The Libyan news agency, Jana, has accused Chad of being a tool for the ''imperialist'' French and Americans. Both nations have supplied arms to Chad's forces, which have pushed the Libyans out of much of Chad over the last eight months. Greater Consultation Sought **********Francois Fillon, chairman of the defense committee of France's National Assembly, said today that France should reinforce logistical support for Chad, but only on condition that President Hissen Habre consult more with France before taking military action. **********Last weekend, French officials voiced dismay at Chad's attack into Libya. And in early August, French officials criticized President Habre's forces for attacking and capturing Aozou, the main town in the 43,000 square mile border strip that is claimed by Libya and Chad. **********France has urged Chad to agree to settle the dispute over the Aozou strip by arbitration. On Aug. 28, Libyan forces recaptured Aozou. **********Late Monday, Togo called for a cease-fire between Chad and Libya, saying the fighting was taking on ''increasingly worrisome proportions.''  U.S. Backs Chadian Move **********WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (Special to The New York Times) - In its first public comments on Chad's attack on the Libyan base, the State Department today offered criticism of Libya and understanding of Chad's motives. **********''Chad has conducted a limited operation against a base from which it was suffering aggressive Libyan attacks,'' said Charles E. Redman, the department spokesman. **********Mr. Redman's remarks pointedly excluded any criticism of Chad's action.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/02/world.main_headline: TOP SANDINISTA: ORTEGA'S GRASP BECOMES FIRMER
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/02/world.print_headline: TOP SANDINISTA: ORTEGA'S GRASP BECOMES FIRMER
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/02/world.body_text: **********When President Daniel Ortega Saavedra opened the 1987 legislative session recently with a long address in the town of Niquinohomo, he spoke with the authority of a strong national leader secure in his political power. **********In the last year, Mr. Ortega's Government has continued to build its military might and fortify its military against United States-backed rebels. **********But equally important, according to diplomats and Nicaraguan political workers, Mr. Ortega has managed to consolidate his personal base to the point where he is now the unchallenged leader of the Sandinista movement. Directorate Defers **********The nine-member Sandinista National Directorate, which has been all-powerful in Nicaragua since the 1979 revolution, still meets regularly and still has the last word on policy matters. But there are indications that Mr. Ortega, 41 years old, has become the principal figure on the directorate and that it now normally accepts his recommendations. **********Mr. Ortega has maintained a high public profile while isolating potential rivals and placing allies in key Government posts. **********''It isn't something that happened overnight, but the trend is very much in Ortega's direction,'' said an ambassador who maintains personal ties with Sandinista leaders. ''In Latin America, the presidency carries with it a significant enhancement in political power, and that is what has happened here.'' **********Although all Sandinista leaders share a common nationalist and Marxist ideology, Mr. Ortega has been identified by political scientists and others who study modern Nicaragua as among the least dogmatic members of the National Directorate. **********Mr. Ortega's rise within the Sandinista front has been steady. He was a guerrilla leader, became a member of the first revolutionary junta in 1979 and later became ''junta coordinator.'' In 1984, he was the Sandinista candidate for president and won a large victory in an election boycotted by part of the opposition. His term runs until 1991. **********''In today's Nicaragua, there is no longer any doubt that Ortega is at the center of power,'' said Luis Humberto Guzman, a member of the National Assembly who was in Niquinohomo to hear the President's speech on Feb. 21. Borge Faction in Decline **********In December, Mr. Ortega won an important political victory when the assembly, which the Sandinistas control, rejected proposals to limit presidential terms. Before the vote, there had been speculation that supporters of Interior Minister Tomas Borge, another member of the National Directorate, would seek to limit Mr. Ortega's presidency to a single term. **********''The implication of the vote is that Ortega plans to stay in office,'' said a diplomat who follows deliberations in the assembly. ''Borge's future, and by extension his political power base, was put in severe doubt.'' **********Mr. Borge, who helped found the Sandinista front 25 years ago and is the sole survivor of its earliest battles, was once considered a factional rival of Mr. Ortega. Under his guidance, the Interior Ministry has built a large police and security apparatus that includes thousands of combat troops. **********''It got to the point where if Interior Ministry people in the field spotted the enemy, they wouldn't call in the army but would try go get Interior Ministry troops there instead,'' a Sandinista official said. **********Mr. Ortega's military connections, however, are firm - he has the backing of his brother Humberto, the Defense Minister. Humberto Ortega is considered to be his brother's strongest ally on the National Directorate, and analysts now often refer to ''the Ortega faction'' as the dominant force in Nicaraguan politics. **********In August, President Ortega elevated his brother to a new rank, general of the army, formalizing his position as the top Sandinista military man. Mr. Borge was to have been given the rank of general at a subsequent ceremony, but Mr. Borge canceled it at the last minute. Associates said he feared the new ranking system would be interpreted as a loss of authority or prestige for the Interior Ministry. **********''Borge has lost the game, and the power of the Ortegas on the national directorate is greater every day,'' said Virgilio Godoy Reyes, a former Labor Minister now in opposition. ''But I don't see a lot of bitterness on Borge's part. I think he has been persuaded to accept his role.'' **********Mr. Godoy said Mr. Ortega's emergence was a positive development. ''It means there is someone you can talk to who has the authority to make a decision,'' he said. Borge Allies Lose Posts **********The two National Directorate members considered closest to Mr. Borge, Henry Ruiz Hernandez and Bayardo Arce Castano, have both lost important posts since Mr. Ortega assumed the presidency. Mr. Arce once headed the directorate's political commission, but that commission was abolished in 1985 and replaced with an executive committee that Mr. Ortega heads. And in a Cabinet shakeup, Mr. Ruiz was named Minister of Foreign Cooperation, losing his job as Planning Minister to a civilian with graduate training in management, Dionisio Marenco. **********As Mr. Marenco has gained authority, appearing frequently with Mr. Ortega at public meetings where economic problems are discussed, Agriculture Minister Jaime Wheelock Roman is no longer viewed as the country's top economic planner. Mr. Ortega has taken to apologizing for aspects of Sandinista agricultural policy, though he has never publicly criticized Mr. Wheelock, who is a member of the National Directorate, or any other Sandinista colleague. **********In his speech Feb. 21, Mr. Ortega acknowledged widespread discontent over shortages of beef and dairy products, and said his Government ''still has not drawn up an integral plan for the production of meat and milk.'' **********Despite such statements, however, it is not known whether there has been discord or disagreement on important matters within the Sandinista leadership. The National Directorate meets in secret and does not announce decisions or give any account of its deliberations or votes, and Sandinista officials say Mr. Ortega has asked other members of the directorate to refrain from all public discussion of certain topics, like foreign policy. **********Another key to Sandinista rule is the nationwide network of Sandinista defense committees, which serve as the eyes and ears of the revolution in every village and neighborhood. The defense committees are run by Leticia Herrera, a veteran Sandinista who was formerly a close personal companion of Mr. Ortega. She is also a vice president of the National Assembly. **********According to Sandinistas familiar with party politics, Mr. Ortega is now supervising a review of the several hundred party leaders who hold key posts in Managua and in the provinces. **********''The idea is to see who we have and where they can best be used,'' said one Sandinista. ''Daniel is the main part of the decision-making process.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/02/world.main_headline: U.S. BERATES PANAMANIAN REGIME IN PRESSING FOR DEMOCRATIC RULE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/02/world.print_headline: U.S. BERATES PANAMANIAN REGIME IN PRESSING FOR DEMOCRATIC RULE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/02/world.body_text: **********In an effort to bring pressure on Panama's military to allow democratic rule, the Reagan Administration has lashed out in the past 24 hours against the leadership of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. **********Today the State Department charged that the Panamanian Government had helped organize demonstrations on Tuesday against the United States Embassy. **********The statement, protesting the incident ''in the strongest possible terms,'' followed sharp criticism of General Noriega by Administration officials and the United States Congress. A Rebuke by Abrams **********Against a background of street demonstrations against the Noriega leadership that occurred again today in Panama, Elliott Abrams, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, delivered a sharp speech Tuesday to the Washington World Affairs Council. **********Officials called the speech the Administration's harshest official rebuke of General Noriega, Panama's de facto leader and the head of Panama's Defense Forces, and one that reflects growing impatience with his leadership. **********An aide to Mr. Abrams suggested that the speech was intended to send a message to General Noriega that the moment for democracy in Panama had come and that the general was clearly ''an obstacle'' to that process. 'Unmistakable Involvement' **********That speech was followed by a State Department statement this noon accusing Panama of ''unmistakable involvement'' in demonstrations Tuesday that caused substantial damage to American Embassy property in Panama. **********Charles A. Redman, the State Department spokesman, said today that the United States would close the United States consular section and the United States Information Service library in Panama. They will be reopened only when Panama ''offers guarantees of appropriate protection.'' **********Another official said the United States is also contemplating a cutoff of economic aid to Panama until there is ''some recompense'' for damage to American property. **********Tension between the two countries has steadily grown since the Panamanian Government declared a state of emergency last month after two days of anti-Government demonstrations. Embassy Building Stoned **********According to reports from Panama, thousands of Panamanians took to the streets to demonstrate against the United States on Tuesday soon after the Government lifted the 19-day state of emergency, which had suspended key constitutional guarantees. **********Romulo Betancur, chairman of the Democratic Revolutionary Party, the leading party in the Government coalition, and several Cabinet ministers led the protest against what they called American meddling in Panamanian affairs because of opposition in the Administration and Congress to restrictions on civil liberties. **********At the American Embassy, demonstrators painted slogans on the walls and stoned the main building and cars in the parking lot. No injuries were reported. **********Some demonstrators chanted, ''Davis, get out of here!'' referring to the United States Ambassador, Arthur Davis. Panama's National Assembly approved a non-binding resolution early Tuesday calling for Mr. Davis's expulsion. Charge on Embassy Attack **********In his statement today, Mr. Redman said Panama had apparently lifted the state of emergency not for the purpose of restoring civil liberties, but ''primarily to orchestrate a demonstration against the U.S. Embassy.'' **********Police protection was withdrawn from the embassy shortly before the crowds reached it, according to Mr. Redman. ''It is clear that a decision was made at the highest levels of the security forces not to protect the embassy,'' he said. **********The demonstrations were prompted in part by a United States Senate resolution approved last week urging a return to democratic rule in Panama. The resolution also called for the ouster of General Noriega pending an investigation into charges of corruption, election-rigging and political assassination. **********In his speech to the Washington World Affairs Council, Mr. Abrams called on Panama's military leaders to ''remove their institution from politics, end any appearance of corruption and modernize their forces to carry out their large and important military tasks'' in defending the Panama Canal. **********The call on Panama's military to stop corruption was interpreted as an indirect reference to drug smuggling. Although Administration officials have privately expressed concern about suspected drug trafficking by the military, Mr. Abrams's remarks are believed to be the first time an American official has publicly referred to such corruption, albeit obliquely.  ----  NORIEGA FOES DEMONSTRATE AGAIN **********PANAMA, July 1 (Reuters) - Anti-Government protesters returned to the streets today to call for the ouster of General Noriega. **********About 3,000 university and high school students, chanting slogans, tried to march peacefully this morning on the presidential palace. The demonstrators fled about seven blocks from the palace when a small group of men in civilian clothes fired at them with handguns and tear gas grenades, witnesses said. **********About an hour later some 500 rock-throwing students attacked the headquarters of Democratic Revolutionary Party, which is a leading member of Panama's military-backed coalition Government.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/17/busin.body_text: **********THE Center for Molecular Medicine and Immunology of Newark received a patent this week for a preparation regarded as important in the treatment of cancer. **********Patent No. 4,699,784 was granted to Dr. David M. Goldenberg, president of the center, and two staff members, Dr. Lisa B. Shih and Dr. F. James Primus. The invention is an antibody conjugate containing methotrexate, an anti-cancer drug that is released when the cancer cells are reached. **********Preliminary animal tests are encouraging, and the center plans clinical testing.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/13/busin.body_text: **********The Toshiba Corporation and Motorola Inc. said their previously announced joint venture, the Tohuku Semiconductor Corporation, would invest 35 billion yen, or about $250 million, in a plant in northern Japan to make one megabit dynamic random access memory chips and eight- and 16-bit microprocessors. It will later expand to make four-megabit D-RAM's and 32-bit microprocessors. **********The factory is expected to begin operating next spring with an initial output of 3 million chips a month.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/15/busin.body_text: **********Grey Advertising is selling its Chicago office to GGK, the Swiss-based agency that already owns Lois, Pitts, Gershon, Ponn/GGK in New York. **********The top of the office's management will stay in place: Edward H. Holzer as chairman and chief executive and Robert R. Cappelli as executive vice president and general manager. **********Apparently the reason why Grey, a publicly held company, is willing to sell off an office in Chicago, which many other agencies yearn for, is that it is leading to conflict problems. It has had an office there for 15 years, having acquired the Chicago office of Gumbinner-North. **********GGK has 13 offices in Europe and one in Brazil.
