https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/25/busin.body_text: **********The CBS Broadcast Group has named Backer Spielvogel Bates as its first agency of record for the entertainment, news, sports and international divisions. The account, estimated at $50 million, encompasses the extensive daily program advertising nationwide. Ogilvy & Mather, SSC&B and **********D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles were among the other contenders in the competition. **********The new agency will focus on print campaigns, which are scheduled to start this fall and which were previously assigned to outside agencies. **********CBS, however, will continue to work on its own on-air station and program promotions.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/13/world.body_text: **********Defense Minister Humberto Ortega Saavedra said today that Nicaragua plans to more than double its military forces over the next seven years and increase the number of warplanes and other weapons over fear of a United States invasion. **********As part of the Central American peace accord signed in August, Nicaragua pledged to negotiate limits on military forces in the region. **********In a speech to Sandinista labor leaders, Mr. Ortega said the military will increase from 250,000 troops now to 300,000 in the next few months and, conditions permitting, to 600,000 by 1995. **********''This is not Grenada - here it will not be the same,'' Mr. Ortega said, referring to the October 1983 United States invasion of the Caribbean island, which overthrew a leftist regime. **********The Sandinista Government has repeatedly said that the United States is planning military action against it. The United States has denied it, although Washington supports the contra rebels seeking to overthrow the Sandinistas. 'Permanent Headache' for U.S.  ''For the Yankees, it is a permanent headache to have lost Nicaragua,'' Mr. Ortega said, ''and the most reactionary sector of the United States will not rest in their efforts to overthrow the Sandinista popular revolution.'' **********Mr. Ortega said defense personnel figures include regular military troops, reserve forces, militias and security units. He said conditions for an increase to 600,000 include the nation's economic capacity and population growth. The current population is estimated at 2.5 million. **********He also said Nicaragua plans to upgrade its military equipment with new interceptor warplanes and other arms, but did not elaborate. ''We will not renounce having even more modern armaments, adequate for our defense system,'' said Mr. Ortega, the brother of President Daniel Ortega Saavedra. **********United States officials have accused the Sandinistas of building their military establishment, with Soviet and Cuban help, into the biggest force in Central America and far beyond Nicaragua's defense needs. The United States has called the buildup a threat to security in Central America.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/15/world.body_text: **********For the last five weeks, Kim Dae Jung, South Korea's most prominent anti-Government figure, has been held prisoner inside his house in a quiet Seoul neighborhood. **********Dozens of policemen carrying riot sticks and shields block the narrow lanes leading to his home. Stone-faced, they turn away all prospective visitors except a few of Mr. Kim's personal aides. **********Over the last two decades, successive regimes have imprisoned Mr. Kim, sentenced him to death, marked him for kidnapping and assassination, and banned him from political activity. Since he came home in February 1985 after a two-year exile in the United States, he has been put under house arrest more than 50 times. **********But no other confinement since his return has lasted this long, and the 63-year-old Mr. Kim says he has no idea when it will end. ''I'm O.K.,'' he said in a telephone interview. ''But, you know, my neighbors are suffering from this tight surveillance.'' **********The Government's tactics have grown progressively tougher since President Chun Doo Hwan suddenly altered South Korean politics on April 13 by cutting off a yearlong debate on how to change the constitutional process of selecting a national leader to succeed him when he steps down in February. **********Mr. Kim's house arrest is one of the more vivid symbols of a vigorous Government attempt in recent weeks to isolate and intimidate a political opposition that was always fragmented and lacked clear direction. The target is a new hard-line group, the Reunification Democratic Party, formally organized May 1 by Mr. Kim and another anti-Government leader, Kim Young Sam. Intimidating the Opposition **********At least a dozen of the party's 67 National Assemblymen are under indictment or investigation on charges, ranging from parking offenses to forgery, that appear to be politically motivated. **********In late April, thugs broke up regional party meetings, and Reunification Democrats charge that the attackers were hired by the Government. Party leaders also have been unable to find a building in Seoul for their headquarters. They presume that the authorities have warned landlords not to rent space to them, a tactic that has been used in the past. **********More worrisome, they say, are persistent warnings by the Government that it might force the Reunification Democrats to dissolve, and that it might press charges against Kim Young Sam, the party president. **********Officials have accused Mr. Kim of ''defamation of the state'' for two recent remarks. One likened the country's electoral system to that of North Korea; the other warned that the 1988 Seoul Olympics could become ''no more than a re-enactment of the Berlin Olympics under the Nazis.'' The Government and ruling Democratic Justice Party have also singled out for attack a section of the opposition's platform that says ''national reunification is the primary goal of the party, transcending ideology and system.'' 'Threat to the Nation' **********This, the authorities contend, presents ''a threat to the nation.'' They say it implies a willingness to soften South Korea's uncompromising anti-Communist stand. **********In fact, the opposition's policy is close in its language to statements issued by the Government in the past. Mr. Kim insists that he has no intention of yielding to demands that he change the wording or risk legal action. **********Until President Chun cut off debate on the constitution last month, it had been the country's core political issue, raising widespread hopes that an authoritarian system might be pushed toward democratic reforms. But as a result of Mr. Chun's action, the next president will be chosen late this year in the same manner in which Mr. Chun was selected in 1980, by a large electoral college weighted heavily in his party's favor. **********His action has polarized South Korean politics more than ever by eliminating the slender middle ground that had existed for possible compromise. Predictably, anti-Government denunciations have come from certain quarters, such as university students, who have clashed with combat policemen almost daily at campus gates. But other protesters, notably Christian leaders and college instructors, have shown new boldness as well. Religious Among Protesters **********In the last two weeks, Roman Catholic priests and Protestant ministers have staged hunger strikes and sit-in demonstrations. Petitions demanding that Mr. Chun rescind his April 13 decision have been signed by at least 2,000 university professors, writers, artists and film producers. **********But Government officials are gambling that the protests will not turn into a broad uprising. They believe that most South Koreans, especially the growing numbers identifying themselves as middle class, value stability and that they are prepared to wait for democratic change as long as rapid economic growth continues. **********They also believe that Mr. Chun has recovered the political edge he lost in January with disclosures that a student had been tortured to death while in police custody. Underlining its confidence, the Government quietly reinstated three police officials who had been suspended in the case; they were the supervisors of two investigators charged with murdering the youth. **********Asked by a National Assemblyman last week to explain the unannounced reinstatements, Prime Minister Lho Shin Yong replied that the policemen had been given ''the opportunity of again serving the nation and the people by using their knowledge and expertise.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/15/world.main_headline: Nicaraguans and the Winds of Peace
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/15/world.print_headline: Nicaraguans and the Winds of Peace
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/15/world.body_text: **********A month after the signing of a Central American peace accord, Nicaragua is gripped by a mood of expectation unseen since the Sandinistas swept into power eight years ago. **********Politicians of varying beliefs, Sandinista and opposition, say a real possibility of peace exists. **********''Without a doubt, this is the most interesting moment in the entire eight years,'' said Carlos Huembes, who heads the Democratic Coordinator, a strongly anti-Sandinista coalition of political parties, business groups and trade unions. **********Jaime Wheelock Roman, a Sandinista leader who has been addressing party faithful across the country, told one audience that Nicaragua was passing through ''extremely important moments.'' New Posibilities Opened **********''A few months ago, the future of the country was more aggression,'' Mr. Wheelock said. ''Today a new possibility is being opened.'' **********The peace accord applies to all five of the countries whose presidents signed it in Guatemala on Aug. 7. They were Guatemala, Honduras, El Salvador, Nicaragua and Costa Rica. But the accord was tailored to deal with the Nicaraguan situation, and it is in Nicaragua that it is expected to have the greatest effect. **********Under the accord, Central American countries must stop aiding the United States-backed guerrillas, called the contras, whose military campaign has kept Nicaragua in turmoil for five years. The Sandinista Government must, in exchange, negotiate a cease-fire, issue an amnesty, end press censorship and guarantee full political freedom. **********The treaty is to take effect Nov. 7, although the Sandinistas have said they will take some steps before that date. Exiled Priest Returns **********The Rev. Bismarck Carballo, director of the Roman Catholic radio station, and who was expelled from Nicaragua after the station was closed in January 1986, returned on Saturday. His station is expected to be back on the air in a few weeks. Editors of the opposition newspaper La Prensa, which was shut in June 1986, are impatiently awaiting permission to resume publication. **********''For the first time, the Sandinistas have agreed to take a step back, to loosen their rule,'' a South American ambassador said. ''There has never been a possibility like this before.'' **********The peace accord has eclipsed all other topics of discussion in Managua. Senior diplomats posted here are being pressed by their governments for detailed information about the accord's prospects. **********Nearly all the senior Sandinista leaders have made absolute public promises that Nicaragua will comply with every detail of the accord. They have indicated that they are preparing to free thousands of prisoners and find a fomurla to negotiate a cease-fire with the contras. One Official Holds Back **********Only Interior Minister Tomas Borge, who is responsible for internal security and press censorship, has refrained from detailed comment. Mr. Borge's office has said he is not giving interviews for the time being. **********He left Nicaragua on Saturday to visit Cuba. **********After the peace accord was signed, opposition leaders quickly expressed doubt that the Sandinista Government would take it seriously. There is still considerable skepticism, but many opposition politicians have come to embrace the accord as an unexpected but welcome breakthrough in what had seemed a tragically intractable confrontation. **********The opposition placed its seal of approval on the accord last week in a speech by Enrique Bolanos Geyer. Mr. Bolanos heads the country's principal business federation and is among the most articulate and uncompromising Sandinista opponents in Nicaragua. 'Culmination of Our Struggle' **********In a speech to more than 1,000 business people at a convention here, Mr. Bolanos hailed the accord as ''the successful culmination of our struggle.'' **********''There is a commitment signed by President Daniel Ortega which obliges him, among many other things, to give Nicaraguans back our rights to a free press and to complete freedom of spoken, written and televised expression, along with our unrestricted right to meet and demonstrate in public,'' he said. **********''And as if that were not enough,'' Mr. Balanos continued, the accord will be monitored by a National Reconciliation Commission ''providentially, for us, headed by his eminence Miguel Cardinal Obando y Bravo.'' **********The presence of the intensely anti-Sandinista Cardinal on the commission is among the factors that seem to give the peace initiative a better chance than past efforts. 'Now Is the Time' **********The rebels view Cardinal Obando with a reverence that borders on veneration. If he were ever to determine that the Sandinistas had lived up to all their commitments under the peace accord, and if he were then to appeal to the contras to stop fighting, they would be almost forced to obey. **********''I think the Cardinal sees himself as the one who is finally going to fix this mess,'' said an opposition member of the Legislative Assembly. ''He thinks that now is the time and he is the man.'' **********Many obstacles remain, not all of them within Nicaragua. One possible threat, some Central American officials say, is the Reagan Administration's announcement last week that it will seek renewed funding for the contras. **********Despite these uncertainties, opposition leaders have begun preparing for what they hope will be a dramatically different political climate after the peace accord takes force. **********''Nov. 7 is the day the lid comes off,'' said Mauricio Diaz Davila, who represents opposition political parties on the Reconciliation Commission. ''On Nov. 8, we take to the streets.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/27/busin.main_headline: Final Battles Shape Up On Major Banking Bill
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/27/busin.print_headline: Final Battles Shape Up On Major Banking Bill
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/27/busin.body_text: **********It is reckoning time in both the Congress and the Reagan Administration for the most far-reaching banking legislation in more than seven years. **********The bill, approved by conferees on July 1, would rescue the depleted insurance fund for savings and loan associations and set back the deregulation of the financial system. **********After almost four weeks of work on the bill's final language, the House and Senate have just a few days remaining to approve it before they begin their August recess. 'The Decisions Are All Political' **********The White House has both threatened to veto the bill and sent conciliatory signals to Congress about a possible compromise. Certain members of the Reagan camp are concerned about possible runs by depositors at some of the weakest thrift institutions if aid is not forthcoming. Others say that tension continues to exist in the Administration between the pragmatists and the more committed believers in deregulation. **********Moreover, they describe the threatened veto as a major test of President Reagan's support in Congress. **********''I think we are now at a point where the decisions are all political, and not based on what is necessarily good economic policy,'' said one lobbyist in the Reagan camp. **********There are three main parts to the bill. One would allow the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, which insures depositors' accounts for up to $100,000, to borrow as much as $8.5 billion. Another would prohibit the creation of new limited-service banks - financial institutions that either take deposits or make loans, but not both. A third would stop banks from underwriting new types of securities until March 1988. A Stern Warning **********On Tuesday, President Reagan met with the Republican leadership in Congress and tried to whip up support for a veto. That afternoon, Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, sternly warned that a veto was all but assured, calling the legislation ''a very bad bill, unacceptable in every respect.'' **********On that same day, the Federal Reserve Board's departing chairman, Paul A. Volcker, urged the Congress to override any veto, while the budget director, James C. Miller 3d, wrote to Senator Jake Garn, Republican of Utah, that the President had not wavered in his commitment to veto the bill, unless Congress did a major overhaul on its provisions. **********Mr. Garn, as the former chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, is the President's point man in the Congress, trying to drum up support from at least 33 colleagues to produce the minimum of 34 votes needed to sustain a veto. So far, according to partisans on both sides,Mr. Garn has between 18 and 28 votes. A Bid for a Compromise **********But by midweek, Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d began to give out signals that the White House might want to avoid an all-out veto fight. He called Fernand J. St Germain, the Rhode Island Democrat who is chairman of the House Banking Committee, and William Proxmire, the Wisconsin Democrat who heads the Senate Banking Committee, seeking a compromise. **********According to Congressional aides, the Treasury Secretary asked for three changes: *********** The bailout money for the F.S.L.I.C. would be increased to $12 billion, from $8.5 billion. *********** The ban on creating limited-service banks would end after two years. *********** A program to grant regulatory leniency to troubled thrift institutions would be made stricter. 'Too Little, Too Late' **********The Reagan Administration contends that the troubles of the thrift industry go far beyond the $8.5 billion in borrowing authority for the F.S.L.I.C. that the bill would set. The Administration also argues that banning new limited-service banks would be a major setback to its policy of deregulating the banking system. **********In response, the two banking chairmen indicated in a letter that the ban on limited-service banks, also known as non-bank banks, was not negotiable. They added, ''We believe it would be fruitful to attempt to consider some modifications.'' **********Mr. Baker wrote back: ''I am pleased that you are willing to work with the Administration. It would certainly be unfortunate if the F.S.L.I.C. recapitalization were too little, too late and again bogged down because of contentious extraneous issues,'' referring to the fate of limited-service banks. **********House and Senate aides predict that the two chairmen may be willing to raise the F.S.L.I.C. rescue to $10 billion and ''clean up'' some of the provisions, but they wonder whether that would satisfy the President and the Treasury, both strong advocates of limited-service banking. Broader Political Implications **********''I think their bottom line is to get rid of Title 1,'' said a prominent lobbyist, referring to the bill's provision to ban the creation of limited-service banks. ''If they don't get rid of that in some way, I think there is little doubt there will be a veto.'' **********Finally on Friday, the open channels between Congress and the Treasury appeared to break down. ''Proxmire simply told them that he has the votes to override any veto, so why compromise that much,'' one banking lobbyist said. **********But for the White House, a veto of the banking bill has political implications far beyond the difficulties for the F.S.L.I.C. and limited-service banks. With the President beleaguered by the Iran-Contra affair, entering his last 18 months in office, some of his advisers are recommending that he display his strength by vetoing a series of measures. **********If that becomes the White House strategy, some lobbyists feel Mr. Reagan has a good chance of picking up the 34 votes in the Senate to sustain a veto. **********''Under those conditions, you would see a full-court press, and if all the Republicans realized it was an effort to re-establish that Ronald Reagan was in charge, I think they could win that by a hair,'' one prominent lobbyist said. ''Short of that kind of an effort, they're going to lose.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/13/world.main_headline: PRESIDENT OF SOUTH KOREA ORDERS A HALT TO DEBATE ON CONSTITUTION
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/13/world.print_headline: PRESIDENT OF SOUTH KOREA ORDERS A HALT TO DEBATE ON CONSTITUTION
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/13/world.body_text: **********South Korea's prospects for constitutional changes were shattered this morning when President Chun Doo Hwan ordered a halt to all debate on the pivotal issue until after the 1988 Summer Olympics are held in Seoul. **********His decision was likely to sharpen political tensions in South Korea, where the ruling party and the opposition have reinforced hard-line stands in the last few days. **********In a nationally broadcast address, Mr. Chun told Koreans that he would keep the present system of selecting a president by a large electoral college. That process has been denounced by the opposition as one that can be rigged to the Government's advantage. It has even been rejected as undesirable by many politicians in the ruling camp. Vows to Step Down **********Mr. Chun said a new leader would be chosen later this year using the existing rules, and he repeated his often-stated pledge to step down next Feb. 24, at the end of his single seven-year term. **********He blamed opposition ''chaos and infighting'' for his decision, and warned his opponents that he would ''resolutely deal with them'' if they ''continue to be engrossed in futile factional strife over the constitutional issue.'' **********The South Korean leader said he had acted now because time was running short for constitutional change and because the likelihood of compromise seemed remote. Dissident Assails Speech **********His speech was immediately attacked by Kim Dae Jung, the country's most prominent dissident, who has been under house arrest since Wednesday. In a telephone interview from Seoul, Mr. Kim charged that President Chun all along had no intention of changing the political system and wanted to continue his hold on power. **********''From the beginning that was his plan,'' Mr. Kim said, and he predicted ''a harsh crackdown'' against political dissidents. **********President Chun, in his 35-minute speech, said: ''We must not waste this important period when we must decide the destiny of the nation by continuing to be absorbed in counterproductive conflict, confrontation and antagonism. To do so would deepen our internal schisms and dissipate national resources, thereby endangering the very existence and survival of the nation.'' **********Mr. Kim, the opposition leader, also accused the Government of having fomented internal divisions that led last week to a breakup of the main opposition group, the New Korea Democratic Party. **********In that split, Mr. Kim and another leading opposition figure, Kim Young Sam, created a new party committed to a no-compromise position in its demand for direct presidential elections to choose the next national leader. The Kims also took most of the old party's National Assembly members with them, leaving behind an ineffectual shell. Gulf Is Widened **********Their move widened the gulf between the opposition and the ruling Democratic Justice Party, triggering a series of events that culminated in President Chun's announcement today. **********In his speech, the Korean leader said he would move ''progressively'' to increase local autonomy in a country where mayors and other local officials are designated by the national Government. He also pledged ''to broaden the basis for democratic progress,'' a phrase that implied a possible loosening of some political restraints. He offered no specifics, however. **********Mr. Chun, a former general who siezed power in late 1979 after the assassination of President Park Chung Hee, has been cool from the start to the idea of constitutional change. **********Early last year he sought to postpone any political reforms until after the 1988 Olympics, but public pressure, including a surge in campus demonstrations, forced him last spring to agree to negotiations on the issue. **********Since then, however, the rival parties have been hopelessly deadlocked. While the opposition insists on direct presidential elections, the ruling camp calls for an elected Parliament that would then pick a prime minister. Two Different Proposals **********Each side has defended its proposal as more democratic in a country that has never had a peaceful transfer of power since it was formed in 1948. **********It appeared from this morning's announcement that Mr. Chun and his aides have no intention of dealing with the Kims directly on the constitutional issue, and might not even recognize the legitimacy of the new party. **********The action also increases the probability that Mr. Chun will try to designate his party's next presidential candidate and, by extension, his successor. The frontrunner is Roh Tae Woo, chairman of the ruling party, another former general who rode to power with Mr. Chun.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/13/busin.body_text: **********Gary D. Eder, a former vice president and a top stockbroker at the Paine Webber Group Inc., was indicted by a Federal grand jury yesterday on charges that he helped clients move more than $700,000 in cash into their accounts in a way that avoided reporting the transactions to the Internal Revenue Service. **********Although completely unrelated to the recent wave of insider trading indictments, yesterday's charges were another instance of legal troubles for a highly successful Wall Street executive. One colleague said yesterday of Mr. Eder that he ''could not have spent all the money he made even if he quit tommorrow.'' **********In its indictment, the grand jury said that Mr. Eder, 41 years old, and other Paine Webber employees were engaged in a scheme to help clients filter money into their accounts without filing required I.R.S. documents. The papers, called Currency Transaction Reports, or C.T.R.'s, must be filed by brokerage houses with the I.R.S. for all single cash deposits that exceed $10,000. **********David Speers, Assistant United States Attorney in charge of the case, said that Mr. Eder's clients were not trying to launder funds that had been obtained illegally. They merely wished to avoid reporting the deposits to the I.R.S. ''There is no connection to organized crime or narcotics in this case,'' he said. ''A C.T.R. is an I.R.S.-type statute designed to facilitate the collecton of taxes. This was a tax-oriented scheme.'' Separate Charges **********Mr. Eder was also charged with separate crimes of creating false records to disguise the receipt of cash by Paine Webber from customers, and of destroying those records after he learned his activities were the subject of a Federal investigation. **********In order to avoid filing the I.R.S. documents, the indictment charges that Mr. Eder received cash in excess of $10,000 on several occasions, but deposited the money into his clients' accounts in amounts of just under $10,000 on several different days. The indictment cites eight such deposits between August 1981 and July 1983. **********Funneling such money into client accounts would give a stockbroker more money to manage, and the opportunity to earn more commissions. **********Other Paine Webber employees that the Government contends were involved were not named in the indictment. The indictment also did not name Mr. Eders' clients who were purportedly involved. 'Investigation Is Ongoing' **********Mr. Speers said that ''the investigation is ongoing,'' but declined to say if additional indictments would be forthcoming. **********Mr. Eder joined Paine Webber in 1980, when his previous employer, Blythe Eastman Dillon, was acquired by Paine Webber. Over the next six years he built up a large stable of retail clients, garnering millions in commissions and a six-figure salary. **********In a news release accompanying the indictment, the Government said that from 1982 through 1986 Mr. Eder produced more brokerage commissions than any other broker at Paine Webber and was also the firm's most highly compensated broker. **********Those contentions were contested by sources close to Paine Webber, who nevertheless acknowledged that Mr. Eder had been a prolific producer. 'One of the Top Guys' **********''I know for a fact that he wasn't the No. 1 broker last year,'' the source said, ''but he was clearly one of the top guys at the firm.'' **********Mr. Eder was indefinitely suspended from Paine Webber on Jan. 22, 1987, when the firm learned that the Government was preparing a case against him. Mr. Eder resigned on Feb. 17. **********However, sources with knowledge of the case said yesterday that Paine Webber was aware that Mr. Eder was under investigation as long as a year ago, and conducted its own internal investigation to determine if he had committed any illegal acts. That search did not turn up anything, the sources said, and the firm, which heard nothing more from the Government about the case, assumed the investigation had been dropped. **********In a statement yesterday, Paine Webber said: ''There is no room in our organization for people who either violate the law or jeopardize the trust our clients and fellow employees place in them.'' **********Mr. Eder, who lives in Woodmere, L.I., could not be reached for comment. His attorney, Milton S. Gould, declined to comment until Mr. Eder is arraigned next Thursday. **********If convicted, Mr. Eder could receive a maximum sentence of 10 years in jail and a $260,000 fine.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/14/busin.body_text: **********Coleco Industries gave layoff notice to 25 workers at its headquarters Friday and the company said there could be further staff cuts throughout the corporation by the end of the month. **********Coleco laid off about 60 headquarters workers on Nov. 24, according to Barbara Wruck, vice president of corporate communications. **********Before the November layoffs, Coleco had laid off about 560 workers since 1985. The company said the cost-cutting moves were necessary because of slow sales in the toy industry and an expected drop in consumer spending during the first half of 1988. **********More cutbacks are likely before the end of the month at Coleco operations in California and upstate New York, Ms. Wruck said, but she could not estimate the number of workers affected.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/10/busin.main_headline: CENTRAL BANKERS CALL FOR REDUCING TRADE IMBALANCES
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/10/busin.print_headline: CENTRAL BANKERS CALL FOR REDUCING TRADE IMBALANCES
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/10/busin.body_text: **********The central bankers of the major industrial nations today called on their governments to adopt budgetary policies aimed at reducing trade imbalances and stabilizing exchange rates. **********In their first meeting since last month's stock market plunge, the central bank presidents from 11 nations added in a statement that ''they were ready to support these objectives with appropriate monetary policies.'' This could include adjusting interest rates or their nations' money supplies. **********The cautiously worded statement, one of the few ever issued by a meeting of central bankers, was widely viewed as seeking to reassure the financial markets. Stock Market Falls Again **********Stock market investors took little comfort from the meeting. The Dow Jones industrial average finished at 1,900.20, off 58.85 points, or 3 percent. It was the average's ninth-worst point decline ever.  [ Page D1. ] [ In Tuesday trading in Tokyo, the New York decline was echoed, as the Nikkei average of 225 stocks fell 731.91 points, or 3.3 percent. And the dollar fell to a postwar low of 133.30 yen. Page D1. ]  The bankers' statement emphasized the bankers' willingness to take coordinated action with their governments to reduce the huge trade imbalances that have destabilized financial markets. **********Economists interpreted the statement as aimed at the United States, urging it to do more to reduce its budget and trade deficits. ''The central bankers are clearly trying to put some quiet pressure on the United States to cut its deficit,'' said Geoffrey Dennis, an economist with James Capel & Company in London. **********The dollar also continued to slide, as traders saw no signs that the central bankers intended to support the American currency. There were also renewed indications that foreign governments were unwilling to defend the dollar if the Reagan Administration would not.  [ Page D8. ]  Expectations had been larger than usual for the central bankers' regular monthly meeting. Not only was it the first such gathering since the stock market and dollar started plunging, but it also was attended by Alan Greenspan, the new chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. It attracted more than 50 reporters. Normally only half a dozen attend. **********The meeting was held in Basel, a thriving medieval city astride the Rhine that serves as the headquarters for the Bank for International Settlements. This institution is the central bank for the world's central banks and coordinates many of their activities. **********Although the falling dollar was a main subject during the two days of meetings, the central bankers announced no specific measures that would deal with interest rates or the supply of money to help stabilize the dollar. Several currency analysts said the fact that the central bankers disclosed no specific actions or policies helped push the dollar lower in today's trading. **********Other analysts asserted, however, that the markets were not expecting - and should not have expected -much from this regular monthly central bankers' meeting. **********''These are central bankers, and the action is in the hands of finance ministers and politicians,'' said Christopher Johns, senior currency economist with Phillips & Drew in London. **********In the statement issued after their meeting ended late today, the bankers ''expressed their satisfaction'' at the measures taken ''to maintain the smooth functioning of the financial system'' during the recent market turmoil. Analysts viewed these words as the central banks congratulating themselves for intervening to help keep the dollar's trading orderly and injecting liquidity to help prevent financial institutions from going under during the crisis. **********In addition, the bankers welcomed the ''cooperation'' shown by ''recent measures taken by European central banks'' to help stabilize their exchange rates and the dollar. Last week, the central banks of West Germany, Britain, the Netherlands and Switzerland all lowered their interest rates. **********The statement was issued by Karl Otto Pohl, president of West Germany's central bank and also the chairman of the group of bankers who met here. The bankers from the Group of 10 industrial nations represented the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain, Canada, France, Italy, Belgium, the Netherlands and Sweden. The president of Switzerland's central bank also was present. **********As Mr. Pohl left today's meeting, he said: ''I have got nothing more to add. The communique speaks for itself.'' **********Several analysts said they had expected at most a vague statement from the bankers because of differences among their nations. European nations and Japan have criticized Washington for its budget deficit and its decision not to oppose the dollar's recent slide in order to help prevent a recession. They worry that the dollar's recent plunge of 7 percent against the German mark and 6 percent against the yen will hurt their exports and economic growth. **********Meanwhile, the United States and other nations have urged Bonn and Tokyo to do more to lower their interest rates and promote domestic consumption, measures that the other countries say would help stabilize the dollar, reduce the American trade deficit and stimulate world economic growth. **********Several analysts said that, although the bankers' statement showed a continuing belief that international cooperation could bolster the markets and reduce trade imbalances, any major coordinated policy actions would have to await a Group of Seven meeting of the major industrial nations. This group is made up of the United States, Japan, West Germany, France, Britain, Italy and Canada. **********Partly because they feared that the markets would react negatively if the meeting produced little, the central bankers sought to play down its importance. ''It's not the sort of meeting where you're going to get any major decisions,'' said one European central bank president during a break. Desire for Stabilization **********The central bankers were generally secretive during the meetings. Making a rare appearance, Satoshi Sumita, of the Bank of Japan did say, as he left for lunch, that Mr. Greenspan and he both ''wish the stabilization of exchange rates,'' although he failed to say whether they agreed on stability at current levels or lower ones. **********The central bankers would not state publicly how low they thought the dollar might fall. Mr. Johns, the Phillips & Drew economist, said he thought the dollar might fall to 155 German marks and 124 yen early next year. However, Mr. Dennis of James Capel was less pessimistic for the dollar, saying it might rebound soon if President Reagan announced major budget deficit reductions, if American trade deficit figures being announced this week showed improvement and if there was a Group of Seven meeting. **********''Everyone in Basel was concerned about the volatility of the dollar's fall, but they have different long-term goals for the dollar,'' he added.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/07/busin.body_text: **********Last week's increases in the prime and discount rates dashed any remaining hopes that consumers will soon get a second chance to borrow at rates as low as those that prevailed early this year. **********Friday's increase in the discount rate, which is what the Federal Reserve charges on its loans to banks, was quickly followed by a rise in the prime rate, which is what commercial banks use in setting their interest charges. **********For consumers, the biggest impact will be in mortgages. Since home loans involve tens of thousands of dollars, even a small rise in the interest charge can take a large bite out of disposable income. Move on Loans to Veterans **********Only hours after Friday's announcements by the Federal Reserve and the commercial banks, the Veterans Administration said it would raise its mortgage rate to 10.5 percent, from 10 percent. That would mean increased interest costs to home buyers of $400 a year for an $80,000 mortgage. **********Other mortgage lenders are expected to follow suit. ''We're not going to see single-digit mortgage rates in the foreseeable future,'' predicted Warren Lasko, executive vice president of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America. **********The average effective mortgage interest rate on existing homes dipped to 9.97 percent last October, the first time in this decade that the rate has fallen below 10 percent. But it turned back upward in March when rates rose in the credit markets. Welcome to Savers **********The effects of the higher general level of interest rates will be felt by other borrowers as well and by investors. For people with high levels of liquid savings, the increases will be welcome because their money will earn more interest. **********''Money market account rates should rise 15 to 20 basis points'' (hundredths of a percentage point) over ''the next month or so,'' said Robert Heady, publisher of Bank Rate Monitor, a publication that tracks interest rates paid by financial institutions across the country. He predicted that rates on certificates of deposit would rise 25 to 35 basis points. **********But consumers and many investors will be hurt by the rising rates. People who invested in long-term bond funds, for example, already have begun to see the value of their investments decline as a result of the rise in interest rates. **********''The yuppies may be hurt and the elderly who depend heavily on interest income will be helped,'' said Robert A. Schwartz, senior financial economist at Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. **********In the last week alone, the asset values of mutual funds that invest primarily in long-term bonds dropped an average of 95-hundredths of 1 percent, according to A. Michael Lipper of Lipper Analytical Services. That means that a person whose mutual fund holdings were worth $1,000 at the beginning of the week ended the week with a value of only $990.50. Some funds performed even more poorly. The Franklin United States Government Fund dropped 1.31 percent and the Benham Target 2010 fund, which invests in zero-coupon bonds, plunged 8.95 percent, Mr. Lipper said. Rate Often Tied to Prime **********Among borrowers, those who will be hardest hit are people who have taken floating-rate loans, such as home-equity loans or second mortgages. Because of this year's change in the tax law, which still allows individuals to deduct most interest paid on home-equity loans from their taxable income, such borrowing has become increasingly popular. **********But much of it is done on a floating-rate basis, with the interest rate often directly tied to the prime. **********The Chemical Bank charges the prime rate for the first year on its home-equity loans, and then the rate rises to the prime plus 1.75 percentage points. Citibank charges either 1.25 percent or 1.75 percent over prime, depending on how many points the borrower pays when the loan is taken out. At Chemical and Citibank, the increase in the prime rate means a rise in second-mortgage borrowing costs of half a percentage point. On a $50,000 loan that would amount to $250 a year. **********Some issuers of credit cards also have given their customers the option of floating interest rates. The American Express Company's new Optima credit card, for example, will calculate the interest charged by multiplying the prime rate by 1.8. With the prime now at 8.75 percent, that would mean a rate on the Optima card of 15.75 percent. The current rate, which American Express said would continue until the end of the year, is 13.5 percent. Most issuers of floating-rate credit cards have set minimum rates so high that that even before the latest increase, the rates were above what the formula would call for. Dampening of Hopes Seen **********''It will dampen the hopes of people who thought credit-card rates were heading down,'' said Spencer Nilson, who publishes a credit-card newsletter, The Nilson Report. **********Others offering floating rates include the Bank of New York, the First National Bank of Chicago, the Manufacturers and Traders Bank in Buffalo and the Wells Fargo Bank in California. **********The rise in interest rates was much faster than many experts had expected. Mr. Lasko of the Mortgage Bankers Association said he had not expected mortgage rates to rise to the present level for another 18 months and thought they would dip slightly from the present level. **********Robert Van Order, chief economist for the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, said that mortgage rates had edged up 30 basis points already and predicted that, despite Friday's events, they would rise only another 20 basis points or so over the next week.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/22/world.main_headline: A SOVIET SCHOLAR IS MISSING IN INDIA
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/22/world.print_headline: A SOVIET SCHOLAR IS MISSING IN INDIA
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/22/world.body_text: **********A young Soviet research scholar disappeared last week during a shopping trip in New Delhi, and police officials said today that they suspected he had defected to a Western country or had been kidnapped by Afghan exiles. **********''There is a strong possibility that he has defected,'' a police official said of the Russian, identified as Aleksandr Babi. The official added that law enforcement officers were also conducting searches of the homes of Afghan exiles here because they thought he might also have been captured. But the police said they had not turned up any evidence that could explain the incident. **********This is the second time in two years that a Soviet national has disappeared here. In 1985, Igor Gezha, a diplomat at the Soviet Embassy, went for a walk in a local park and did not return. He later surfaced in the United States where he received asylum. American diplomats here were said to helped him escape. **********The most spectacular defection of a Soviet national in India occurred in 1967 when Svetlana Alliluyeva, Stalin's daughter, walked into the American Embassy and asked for asylum. **********Today, an American Embassy official said he had no information about Mr. Babi but said he had noted the speculation in the local newspapers about the possible defection. Soviet Mission Raises Issue **********A Soviet Embassy spokesman said the mission here had raised the issue with the Indian Government. However, he said he did not have any details about Mr. Babi, who was identified as a 25-year-old scholar. He could not say where Mr. Babi had come from or where he worked but pointed out that more than 16,000 tourists from the Soviet Union visited India every year. **********The incident has occurred during the visit of an important Soviet military delegation to India, led by Marshal Sergei F. Akhromeyev, chief of staff of the Soviet armed forces. Mr. Akhromeyev held talks today with Indian officials on ways to increase military cooperation. **********Moscow is India's biggest supplier of modern weapons and local news reports over the weekend quoted Indian military experts as saying that New Delhi is considering buying Russian airborne warning systems for its air force.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/04/busin.body_text: **********Home Shopping Network Inc. said its board had approved plans to offer a stock option plan for its cable television operators. Home Shopping, the leader in the video shopping industry, will offer the options in exchange for a commitment to deliver its programs to a fixed number of subscribers for five years, with a five-year extension option. **********Operators agreeing to the plan would receive options to buy $10 worth of common stock for each cable subscriber committed. The company, which offered a similar program last year, said the current one is directed at those who did not sign up last year and at new carriers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/18/world.main_headline: For One Day, Cyclists Put French Village on Map
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/18/world.print_headline: For One Day, Cyclists Put French Village on Map
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/18/world.body_text: **********The chances are that for the nearly 200 silent, sweating competitors who passed through this little mountain hamlet on today's leg of the men's Tour de France, Valleraugue was just another village, barely glimpsed as a strip of asphalt between two rows of narrow old stone houses on the long and arduous route of the world's most famous bicycle race. **********But for the inhabitants of Valleraugue, one of the dozens of such villages on the route, the fleeting, furious passage of the Tour de France -the first to pass through here since just after World War II - was a great moment, carrying with it the hope that the village, which not only suffers from obscurity but is economically depressed as well, might benefit from a small amount of attention. **********''Of course it's an event for us,'' Christiane Recolen, a villager who works in the mayor's office, said after the racers had passed through. ''We've been sort of ignored for 40 years.'' **********''You can really say that for most people, Valleraugue is almost at the end of the earth,'' she said. ''Even in Nimes, which is the closest city, we're thought to be very remote. People might come during the season to gather mushrooms here, since we have lots of mushrooms in our hills, but then they forget about us.'' **********''Now, maybe we'll be talked about, at least a little,'' Mrs. Recolen said. Threading Villages Together **********The Tour de France, which began in 1903, has often been cited in this country as part of the national patrimony, an event that, in its annual 2,500-mile circuit, is supposed to thread together all of the hundreds of villages passed through by the racers in their fury to win. **********To be sure, the tour is followed with intense excitement throughout the country, and Valleraugue is no exception - even if not everybody here found the race a positive development. **********A few days ago, a woman was observed at the Town Hall asking exactly what time traffic on the road would be blocked for the race, since she wanted to visit relatives in Montpellier, a bit more than an hour's drive away, and did not want to find herself sealed inside the village. **********''I'm not passionate about the Tour de France,'' she said, by way of explanation. 'It's Very Exciting' **********''But you should be,'' Louis Mazel, who has managed the Town Hall since 1962, said, not really seriously. ''It's very exciting.'' ''I'm a free person,'' the woman replied, ''and I'm free not to be excited by a bicycle race.'' **********Still, most of the 1,200 or so people who live in the village and the rugged surrounding countryside seemed excited enough to drop whatever they were doing this morning and watch the event. Many of them came to town hours in advance, lining both sides of the road that leads through the town, past the lone grocery, the bakery and the butcher shop, and the place where newspapers are sold, sometimes a day late. **********Those who could not be in Valleraugue came down from various hilltop hamlets and parcels of farmland to take up positions wherever they could along the route of the race. Valleraugue is trying to encourage its rather small tourist industry by setting up campsites on the land of local farms. And so, the town is a meeting ground of city folks, here for the fresh air and the mountain scenery, and the local people who call themselves peasants and have scratched a living out of the rocky hills raising apples, onions and goats. A Commercial Prelude **********What they all saw was a long prelude and then the passage of the racers, so swift and sudden that it seemed to be over before it began. **********The race, which has become a highly commercial affair in recent years, is preceded by a two-hour caravan of hundreds of trucks, cars and motorcycles, emblazoned with the names of the companies that sponsor competing teams of racers. The caravan passed through, its engines growling, its loudspeakers blaring for the benefit of the scattered groups of customers lining a pristine rural road that has barely seen an advertising billboard in half a century. Among the noisily and cheerfully advertised products were computers, tires, comic books, women's clothing, supermarket chains, watches, copying machines, newspapers, automobiles. Then, a few squadrons of motorcycle police, who descended on Valleraugue like a mechanized infantry division, appeared on the road. They were followed by the racers, pedaling hard, certainly not stopping to look around at the scenery. They were followed in turn by another caravan, this one of cars and trucks carrying spare bicycles for the teams of racers. **********The general feeling in town was that the race would give what a saleswoman at the newsstand called ''a little window of publicity''; the press would mention Valleraugue, at least in its reports on the race today, and maybe that would lead to more tourism, the activity seen here as a possible cure to long-term economic problems. **********It happens that Valleraugue and its region, a place of picturesque, crumbling stone villages perched alongside laboriously constructed, narrow stone terraces, is one of those regions in France - often called deep France by the Parisians - where an old way of life seems on the verge of extinction. A 40-Year Interval **********The last time the Tour de France passed through here, about 40 years ago, this was a prosperous region producing raw silk thread for the weavers of Lyons, about 200 miles away. Mulberry trees, whose leaves are needed to feed the silk worms, grow bountifully in the region and were the basis for the rural prosperity. The evidence of this can be seen in imposing square stone houses nestling in the corners of terraced fields. **********The industry died away after the war, apparently because of Japanese competition, and many of the former farming families went elsewhere, leaving those who stayed behind to cultivate fruit orchards or to raise goats for cheese. According to local officials, however, these activities are fast disappearing, with the risk that the area will be deserted by everybody except those who maintain some of the stone houses as vacation homes. **********''The problem is that even tourism cannot survive if the agriculture disappears,'' Mr. Mazel at the Town Hall said. ''Underbrush grows on untended land and is very prone to fires, which could really destroy the whole region.'' **********Obviously, one passage of the Tour de France hardly marks the village renaissance, and it was not being seen that way here. Nonetheless, at the Town Hall and elsewhere in the village the hope was being expressed that the race might blow away some of dust of obscurity and remind others in France that Valleraugue is beautiful and unspoiled and not all that remote after all.
