https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/08/busin.body_text: **********THE Campbell Soup Company, like most consumer products companies, has always asked its customers lots of questions. Last year alone, its field researchers contacted close to 110,000 people to talk about food - taste, preparation, nutritional value, the works. On the basis of what they said, Campbell changed the seasonings in five Le Menu dinners and introduced a line of low-salt soups called, appropriately enough, Special Request. **********Both the new and the reformulated products are selling well, so the survey techniques clearly gave Campbell's a good reading of consumer preferences. But could Campbell's have gotten the same information more easily - say, from finding out how similar products were selling? Put another way, could knowing what consumers buy today give Campbell's, or any consumer products company, a good idea of what they will buy tomorrow? **********These are by no means simple questions. At least since the days of Sigmund Freud, psychologists have been debating the best ways to predict human behavior. But now that debate has spilled onto Madison Avenue and into board rooms. It lies at the heart of a controversy that is pitting computer specialists against pollsters, market researchers against marketing executives, and psychologists against each other. The outcome could affect not only how companies make marketing decisions but what products people will get to buy. **********In one camp sit the behaviorists, who believe that the best indicator of how people will act in the future is how they act now. Opposite them is the cognitive camp, which says people operate from an endless array of motivations and that the only way to predict what someone will do is to figure out what is going on inside his or her mind. **********In practical terms, the two sides are debating whether computers can replace people as the linchpins of consumer research. And the behaviorists are winning converts. **********''The role of the consumer as the party giving answers and opinions will be significantly less,'' said Jagdish Sheth, a consumer psychologist at the University of Southern California. ''It will be replaced by measuring his behavior, not his opinions.'' **********''We are heading to an age where most information can be captured electronically,'' said George S. Fabian, an executive vice president at Backer, Spielvogel & Bates, a New York advertising agency. ''It is unavoidable. And it is welcome.'' **********Is it? **********Until recently, that would have been a moot question. There were few electronic data sources, so companies had little choice but to plumb the collective consumer mentality through surveys. Ask enough people enough questions, the theory went, and some semblance of truth will emerge. According to Diane Bowers, executive director of the Council of American Survey Research Organizations, companies spend nearly $1 billion each year to ask more than 50 million consumers their opinions on products and services. **********Even proponents of surveys concede that the companies are not buying absolute truth for their money. ''Consumers say they are eating fewer snacks, yet the snack food industry has record sales; they say they are on a diet, yet everyone seems to be more overweight,'' said Anthony J. Adams, director of marketing research and planning for Campbell's. **********Similarly, Lynn R. Kahle, associate professor of consumer psychology at the University of Oregon, cites a recent survey in Detroit in which people were asked what they thought of the Metallic Metals Act. The legislation was purely fictitious; about a quarter of the respondents had an opinion on it anyway. ''People hate to look foolish or uneducated, even to strangers,'' he said. ''They lie all the time to make themselves look good.'' **********STILL, until recently, consumer surveys were the only research game in town, and companies designed countless products, packages and services around them. ''Almost every one of our major product innovations was inspired by something consumers told us,'' said Jonathan B. Sims, manager of media planning and research at the General Foods Corporation. **********But in the last few years, technological and demographic trends have converged to make the validity of surveys suspect. At the same time, alternative ways of gauging consumer preferences have emerged. Scanners in supermarkets and people meters in homes can now electronically record consumer buying and television viewing patterns. That makes it possible for a company to learn overnight how well its product is selling, how competitors are doing and how commercials affect sales. **********Moreover, consumers have systematically been weaning themselves from surveys. In the 1960's, the halcyon days of consumer research, people cheerfully participated in most any question-and-answer exercise that came their way. But that was before many women pursued careers outside the home, before computer-generated phone calls and salesmen masquerading as researchers made many people hostile to surveys, and before banks, insurance companies and other service organizations adopted survey techniques that simply led to survey overload. **********There are even surveys about how people feel about surveys, and they are turning up some discouraging results. ''People are getting burned out on surveys,'' Professor Kahle said. Indeed, studies show that over the last few years, the amount of time it takes an interviewer to get an hour's worth of usable survey data has increased to eight hours, from five. **********And that hour's data are not likely to represent a random sample of the public. Interviewers report little trouble reaching retired people and full-time homemakers. But they have a hard time pinning down working women, city dwellers, young people, families without children and high-income people - often, the very groups that marketers want to reach. **********''No matter how good your sampling method is, as soon as people start refusing in large numbers to participate, your random sample has become a convenience sample,'' said Mr. Sims of General Foods. **********Not surprisingly, companies that sell electronically generated information say computers provide an adequate amount of data on consumer behavior. The small companies and solo practitioners who make a living from field surveys contend that computers simply disgorge information on what is happening without showing why it happens. Such data, they say, cannot provide the basis for a rational marketing decision. **********Neither side is painting the picture all black and white. But each is quite adamant about where the preponderance of evidence falls. **********''Of course we must avoid the arrogance of saying, 'I know you well enough to know how you'll react without asking you questions','' said Lorraine C. Scarpa, vice president of customer information marketing at the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation, whose A.C. Nielsen unit is a leader in electronically provided data. ''Still, the real energy in the business is going to the quantitative side.'' **********''Those who still rely on talk rather than scanners for descriptive information are anthropological artifacts,'' said Joseph G. Smith, a consumer psychologist who is president of Oxtoby-Smith Inc., which does field research. ''But what people do does not say anything about why they do it. There is no surrogate available for talking to the consumer.'' **********Corporate annals are rife with stories that support Mr. Smith's contention. Perhaps the most famous is that of the Pillsbury Company's cake-mix fiasco of 30 years ago. Pillsbury came up with a mix that required cooks to do no more than add milk. It yielded a great-tasting cake, yet it bombed in the marketplace. **********Pillsbury failed to ask a key question: How do cooks feel about the time they spend in the kitchen? The company found in a later study that cooks wanted to feel they were ''adding value'' to a packaged product. It reformulated its mix so the cook had to add an egg. Sales took off. **********ATTITUDINAL research helped Mr. Fabian of Spielvogel avoid a similar failure when he designed an ad campaign for an automotive client. He already knew that price was a major factor when people bought cars. But later research ''showed that people will only buy a low-priced car if they feel smart about the purchase,'' he said. Thus, Mr. Fabian designed his campaign around the idea that the best and the brightest were gravitating to his client's low-priced car. **********General Mills has used a similar combination of descriptive and attitudinal data to design a restaurant chain. A few years ago, responding to figures showing that Italian food is the most frequent choice of those who eat out, the company opened its Olive Garden Italian restaurants. But, because attitude data showed that many people felt that Italian food had too much garlic and basil, the company reformulated Olive Garden recipes to make them less authentically Italian but more palatable to diners. As Lawrence D. Gibson, the recently retired director of market research at General Mills, put it: ''Simply tracking what's going on in the world is never going to tell me how much spice to put in my product.'' **********Still, only the biggest - and richest - companies are willing to spend the hundreds of thousands of dollars that it takes to do both descriptive and attitudinal surveys. And many chief executives are more comfortable with hard data generated by computers and are skewing research budgets toward computerized methods. **********''I'd hate to see us become slaves to computer printouts, but managements want to hear what's happening, not what consumers say is happening,'' said Mr. Adams of Campbell's. ''So the data on actual behavior are beginning to push out a lot of the survey data on attitudes.'' **********PARTICULARLY troublesome to many researchers is that their companies maintain the illusion of continuing direct consumer research by using more focus groups. These are groups of 10 or 12 people who are paid an average of about $50 each to sit for a few hours with a mediator and discuss a product, commercial or concept. The sponsor generally sits apart, often behind a one-way mirror, taking notes. **********Focus groups are easy to fit into squeezed marketing budgets. But they use so small a sample that they are not representative of much of anything. ''Sure, you can get a few perceptions from a focus group, but nothing I would want to build a $10 million factory around,'' said Mr. Adams. Nor should companies build a multimillion-dollar ad campaign around them, said Mr. Fabian of Backer Spielvogel. ''Focus groups can only be an add-on to solid qualitative research,'' he said. **********Researchers have a bit more faith in mail surveys. In fact, marketers are making far more use of direct mail than they have in the recent past, betting that hard-to-reach people will respond when they can do so at their own convenience, and that they are less likely to try to impress a sheet of paper than an interviewer. **********Companies are offering incentives in mailed questionnaires. Although some offer contests with expensive prizes, most just offer token payments. ''It's amazing what a nice crisp dollar bill in an envelope will do,'' said Mr. Gibson, the former General Mills executive. ''People feel guilty if they take the dollar and don't fill out their questionnaires.'' **********Market research companies have mounted an ad campaign, using the slogan ''Your Opinion Counts,'' to woo consumers back to surveys. ''People used to feel that surveys were a way to tell manufacturers how to serve them better,'' said Frank Walker, chairman of Walker Research and the man who spearheaded the campaign. ''We're trying to get them to again believe that their participation will come back in better products and services.'' **********Mr. Adams of Campbell Soup is thinking along a similar vein. He wants to advertise the reasons behind the changes in Le Menu and the introduction of Special Request. ''We're considering a campaign saying that last year, we talked to 110,000 of you and here's what we've done,'' he said. ''To keep consumers interested, we have to communicate some of the action that's been taken on research.'' **********General Foods has already started doing that. ''You talked - Post listened,'' the company says on cereal boxes, referring to the new Zip-Pak resealable packaging that it recently started using. **********Computers, meanwhile, are taking some of the drudgery out of the interview process - automatically calling up Question No. 7 for a telephone interviewer, for example, if the survey requires her to skip questions 4 through 6 for any respondent who said ''no'' to question 3. **********Several researchers are trying Conjoint Analysis, a program developed by Sawtooth Software Inc. that helps figure out how important different product attributes are to different people. A participant in a survey on cars, say, might be asked: Would you rather have a two-door blue car or a four-door red car? The next question would be based on the answer to the first. **********''You wind up with a tradeoff analysis,'' said Richard M. Johnson, Sawtooth's president. ''You find out not only someone's favorite color or favorite number of doors, but whether he would sooner give up his favorite color or his door count.'' **********Normally, researchers who use such computerized surveys ask participants to do their own keypunching. ''There's a whole body of research that says that people will answer emotional questions more honestly if they do not have to verbalize their response, but just have to punch in an answer,'' said Diane Schmalensee, vice president of research operations for the Marketing Science Institute. **********Still, computerized interviews are no panacea. They are impractical for national surveys, they are expensive, and they may turn out to be a fad. ''Computer questioning has a lot of novelty,'' said Professor Kahle. ''But by the 24th time they are asked, people will not find it all that attractive.'' **********The whole business of market research seems in for a bumpy few years. When the dust settles, many companies will no longer be around. Others will have found special niches - for example, working with manufacturers whose products are not sold in supermarkets, or with small manufacturers who cannot afford to subscribe to electronic data services that can cost upwards of $500,000 a year. Still others will have been gobbled up by the giants in the research field. **********The consolidation has already started. In August, Dun & Bradstreet bought Information Resources Inc., one of the fastest-growing firms in market research. SAMI, Time Inc.'s market research arm, bought Burke Marketing a few years ago. And last month, the Control Data Corporation, whose Arbitron Ratings Company is a major purveyor of local television and radio ratings, announced that it will buy SAMI/Burke. **********No one is predicting that old-style consumer surveys will ever be easy or inexpensive again. But no one predicts their demise, either. ''High tech will never replace high touch,'' said Dun & Bradstreet's Ms. Scarpa. **********Indeed, although getting a representative sample of people to sit still for an interview will keep getting harder and more expensive, most experts say there will always be enough companies willing to foot the bill. Backer Spielvogel certainly is one. ''People today are marketing me-too products,'' said Mr. Fabian. And that, he says, makes it doubly important to insure that advertising takes into consideration what motivates consumers. ''We will find the money, our clients will find the money,'' he said. ''We can't afford not to.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/21/world.main_headline: EGYPT-U.S. PLAN TO RAID LIBYA REPORTED
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/21/world.print_headline: EGYPT-U.S. PLAN TO RAID LIBYA REPORTED
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/21/world.body_text: **********Early last year, President Reagan approved a secret directive under which United States military forces would support Egypt in the event of a ''pre-emptive'' attack on Libya, and the two countries continued to prepare for this contingency throughout 1986, Adminstration officials said today. **********The officials said President Reagan agreed to the proposal in early 1986, shortly after the terrorist attacks in the Rome and Vienna airports on Dec. 27, 1985. **********Under the plan, which was supported by some members of Mr. Reagan's National Security Council staff, the United States would support an Egyptian attack on Libya if it were intended as a response to a Libyan military threat. **********The policy allowed for American military strikes against targets inside Libya, officials said. **********The Presidential directive replaced one that had called for logistical support for Egypt only if Libya attacked the Egyptians first, the officials said. **********The Washington Post reported today that the State Department made great efforts in 1985 to block what The Post called a White House plan for a joint American-Egyptian attack on Libya. These included bringing Nicholas A. Veliotes, the Ambassador to Egypt, back to Washington to argue against a proposed mission to Cairo by Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter, then the deputy national security adviser. 'No Policy or Plan' **********Asked about a possible joint invasion of Libya, Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said, ''There was no policy or plan to do that that was put in motion.'' **********It has been previously reported that Admiral Poindexter met with Hosni Mubarak, the Egyptian President, in August 1985 to discuss possible military steps against Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, long a target of the Reagan Administration's polemics and covert activities. **********There have been repeated suggestions that the mission was part of an attempt to prod an unwilling Egypt into providing a military answer to a problem that had defied solution by other means. **********In March 1986, the semiofficial Egyptian newspaper Al Ahram said Cairo had rejected three requests from American delegations for joint military action against Libya. **********But several Administration officials who support President Reagan's policy on Libya insisted today that the meeting with President Mubarak and the subsequent planning were not an attempt to press Cairo to invade. One official said the United States had offered its support only if Egypt were facing a direct threat. **********''It was a very sophisticated approach,'' this official said. ''We wanted the Egyptians to know we were prepared to work with them. We were not trying to start a war.'' **********Another official scoffed at reports that Mr. Mubarak was unwilling to proceed with the military planning. ''They didn't have to be goaded into anything,'' this official said. **********Planning for how to deal with Libya has been a major policy issue for the National Security Council staff for the last several years. In addition to covert operations by the C.I.A. to encourage opponents of Colonel Qaddafi to displace him, the United States conducted bombing raids on Libya last year after what it said was a Libyan-directed attack on a Berlin discotheque frequented by American soldiers. **********Intensified Administration planning on how to deal with terrorism, one official said, was touched off in mid-1985 when Shiite Moslem radicals hijacked a Trans World Airlines flight and held Americans who were aboard hostage in Beirut. **********In one such effort, National Security Council officials began preparing the way for covert arms sales to Iran, in what the Administration has said was an effort to build support for what were believed to be less radical elements in that country. **********Then, in December 1985, terrorists conducted simultaneous attacks at the Rome and Vienna airports in which 20 people were killed and more than 110 wounded. These attacks were subsequently tied to Sabry al-Banna, the terrorist known as Abu Nidal, whose activities over the years are said to have received support from Libya and other Arab countries. **********Officials said it was after these attacks that President Reagan became prepared to authorize extensive American involvement to back Egypt in an attack on Libya even if the attack was in response only to a threat. **********While Abu Nidal is said to receive support from several countries, among them Libya, he also is said to carry out operations without specific sponsorship, and no direct evidence of involvement by Colonel Qaddafi in the airport attacks has been produced. **********In late 1985 the Reagan Administration also began discussing the kidnapping of suspected terrorists for trial in the United States, a proposed program on which The New York Times reported in January 1986. **********Today, officials confirmed a report in The Wall Street Journal that the planning went forward under a Presidential intelligence order, or finding, that authorized the C.I.A. to kidnap terrorists. The officials said, however, that none of the plans had been put into effect. Officials said Lieut. Colonel Oliver L. North, the dismissed National Security Council aide, was directly involved in this effort. **********During this period, according to a military source, the Joint Chiefs of Staff were asked to draw up various contingency plans. One was for an Egyptian invasion of Libya backed by United States air support and logistical assistance, including the use of helicopters to transport Egyptian soldiers. Such an invasion would take place along the Egyptian-Libyan border 600 miles from Tripoli, the Libyan capital. **********The Joint Chiefs were also asked to draw up contingency plans for an American invasion of Libya, but reportedly sought to discourage the idea by arguing that the operation would require six divisions and up to 90,000 men. Administration officials who supported the plans believe the military deliberately overstated its requirements.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/10/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Treasury Bond Prices Climb
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/10/busin.body_text: **********Treasury bond prices closed sharply higher yesterday after laboring under the pressure earlier in the day of economic statistics that were bearish for the credit markets. **********Dealers said the turnabout came in midsession, when short sellers began covering their earlier sales with purchases. The resultant rise in prices brought in fresh buying throughout the rest of the day. **********In late trading and after a bit of profit taking, the bellwether long bonds, the 7.5's of 2016, were offered at 102 20/32, up 19/32 on the day, and now yield 7.28 percent, compared with 7.33 percent the day before and 7.40 percent a week ago. Flood of Surplus Cash **********The discount rate on the 90-day bills fell eight basis points, to 5.39 percent, as a rising flood of surplus cash sought employment. The Treasury 180-day and one-year bills lost three and four basis points, respectively. The basic Federal funds rate eased a touch, to 5 15/16, late in the day, only slighly affected by the Federal Reserve's $2.5 billion repo operation on behalf of a customer. **********''What we saw today was an awful lot of money chasing a relatively small supply of Treasury paper,'' said Norman E. Mains, first vice president at Drexel Burnham Lambert's Chicago office. ''As this became apparent, the sellers began holding back and those who had sold short earlier this week began to buy out of their positions.'' **********The relative dearth of Treasury debt in the market and eager sellers always creates an extremely risky situation for those wanting to sell short. ''But as everyone seemed to ignore the day's economic statistics, there were very few sellers of any kind after lunch,'' Mr. Mains said. Moments afterward, the spot March Treasury bond futures, which had been down 11/32, began to climb and closed up 15/32, at 101.19. Lack of Conviction Seen **********Robert H. Chandross, chief economist at Lloyds Bank's North American headquarters in New York, said that, even when the bond market seemed to be under pressure after a decline in the unemployment rate in December was announced early in the day, the selling lacked conviction. The Government reported that the number of jobless fell two-tenths of 1 percent, to a revised figure of 6.6 percent in December. **********''While employment in the manufacturing sector accounted for only 31,000 of the total gain of 269,000 jobs last month, it does indicate that industrial production rose eight-tenths or nine-tenths of 1 percent in December and that the economy ended 1986 on a rather strong note,'' Mr. Chandross said. **********As a result, he doubted the Federal Reserve would have any reason to lower interest rates in the near future. ''Given this situation, one can say the bond market behaved rather well even before the rally began,'' Mr. Chandross added. **********Although the bellwether long bond showed the best gain, as usual, prices of intermediate Treasury maturities were also strong in the secondary market. In late trading, for example, the 7 1/4 percent notes of 1996 were offered at 101 26/32, up 15/32 and now yielding 6.99 percent; the 7's of January 1994 rose 11/32, to 100 28/32, for a yield of 6.84 percent; the 6 5/8's of 1990 rose 6/32, at 100 12/32, to yield 6.48 percent, and the 6 1/4's of 1988 rose by 3/32, to 100 7/32, to yield 6.13 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/27/world.main_headline: SEOUL PROTESTERS AGAIN FACE POLICE IN FIERCE CLASHES
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/27/world.print_headline: SEOUL PROTESTERS AGAIN FACE POLICE IN FIERCE CLASHES
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/27/world.body_text: **********With tear gas and raw force, riot police struggled but ultimately managed to retain control of Seoul's streets tonight against tens of thousands of anti-Government protesters. **********The clashes in Seoul and 30 other cities were the most ferocious in a week, and they demonstrated graphically that South Korea's political crisis was not near an end. **********But they also wound up as something of a standoff between dissidents and the police, making it difficult to judge whether they will lead to further unrest, as some fear, or will be the last outburst before a lull, as many hope. A Litmus Test **********Foreign diplomats and other observers had portrayed tonight's events as a litmus test of sorts, and beforehand some spoke with dread about the possibility that serious skirmishes could provoke military intervention. **********Although the numbers in the streets were large and were spread across much of the central city, they lacked the crackling tension evident on other recent nights. Moreover, the police were in charge all night, making the imminent use of troops seem unlikely. Both sides could claim victory. A coalition of opposition groups, which had organized the protests as a ''grand peace march for democracy,'' could point to the large outpouring as evidence of popular reaction against maneuvering this week by President Chun Doo Hwan to defuse the crisis.  [ In Washington, a State Department official who met with President Chun this week expressed optimism about the situation and said Mr. Chun was amenable to changes in the electoral system. Page 3. ]  Reports of Reconciliation The ruling party was reported in the South Korean press tonight as considering new conciliatory moves, including the possibility of an interim government to be replaced through direct presidential elections after the 1988 Summer Olympics in Seoul. **********As usual, the crowds today were dominated by college students. But there were many older Koreans as well, middle-class people and laborers, who actively joined in the protests or stood on the sidelines cheering. Across the city, motorists honked horns to show support, creating an enormous din that lasted for more than an hour in some places. **********Large protests, involving tens of thousands altogether, were also reported in about 30 cities, with the numbers said to be greatest in Kwangju and Pusan. Disturbances were described as particularly strong in Kwangju, a symbolically important city because 200 people were killed by soldiers there in 1980. **********But nationwide, there were nowhere near the million people that Kim Young Sam, the opposition leader, had predicted. **********Mr. Kim was one of scores of people taken into brief custody by the police, who showed little patience, liberally using tear gas and fists to break up small groups of people whenever they gathered. **********Mr. Kim was seized as he tried to leave his party's offices to address a scheduled rally that never occurred in nearby City Hall Plaza. He was put into a police van and driven for more than an hour to the Seoul airport and back before being dropped off at his house. Hundreds Confined to Homes **********Earlier in the day, hundreds of dissident leaders had been arrested or confined to their homes to prevent them from reaching designated rallying points for the march. Among them was Kim Dae Jung, another key opposition figure, who had been released only the day before from a house arrest that lasted 78 days. Mr. Kim said he had been told the new restriction would last only a day, and later he said it had in fact been lifted. **********The police could claim victory for maintaining order. There seemed to be many more policemen on the streets than at previous demonstrations, and so they were not overpowered as they had been on several recent days. But that may have been partly because dissidents had shifted tactics to appear more restrained so as not to drive away middle-class supporters. **********For example, thousands of protesters gathered by the East Gate Market, most of them laborers and students. Some picked up stones to hurl at riot policemen, only to have them knocked out of their hands by group leaders. **********Similarly, along Chongno Street, leading to East Gate, thousands of people lined the sidewalks. As some sought to move into the streets, they were pushed backed by leaders who urged against disrupting traffic. Protesters Well Organized **********That demonstrated the organizational skills of the demonstrators, especially the students. So did the conspicuous presence of medical students in white laboratory coats, who patrolled the streets treating the injured and handing out strips of cellophane to protect eyes against the tear gas. **********But generalizations were difficult, and perhaps misleading. **********If East Gate showed a measure of order, South Gate and the Seoul Station, several miles away, were scenes of pitched battles between stone-throwing youths and police officers, who brought in an armored car with a launcher on top. It fired tear-gas canisters into the crowds in deafening automatic bursts. **********Scores of students near South Gate spilled into a nearby street that led to the Seoul Hilton Hotel. When the police routed them from there, they ran into the hotel and refused for a while to leave. **********It was the first major demonstration since President Chun and Kim Young Sam met on Wednesday in what proved to be a vain attempt to end the crisis quickly. Mr. Chun made offers to Mr. Kim that the ruling camp has called significant concessions but that the opposition dismisses as inadequate.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/20/world.body_text: **********The West German police have arrested a young man and woman on suspicion of membership in the Red Army Faction, a leftist guerrilla group, the federal prosecutor's office said today.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/16/busin.body_text: **********Ripe for Restructuring **********America's big corporations will continue their restructuring - divesting themselves of operations that are inefficient or that do not mesh well with their basic businesses. That's the consensus among the 250 chief executives and other senior managers at large industrial companies polled by research firm Penn & Shoen Associates. **********About 23 percent of the executives said that future restructuring of their corporations - selling units to other companies or to a division's management under a leveraged buyout - was ''very likely.'' Some 27 percent said it was ''possible.'' ''Most of the conglomerates of the 1960's are still ripe for restructuring,'' especially those that have to focus better on their core businesses, said Martin H. Dubilier, chairman of Clayton & Dubilier, a New York leveraged-buyout firm that commissioned the study. The executives agree: Some 77 percent said that units of large corporations could function more effectively if they were free-standing units - even with the same management in place.  Moo and Brew **********As big corporations get back to core businesses, companies in the beverage business are branching out: Bottled water is now part of Anheuser-Busch's business, iced tea is one of Pepsi's offerings - and now milk is getting into the mix. **********Canadian beer brewer John Labatt has been buying up dairies on the East Coast. Its recent acquisition of Queens Farms Dairy brought the brewer's share of the New York City area's dairy market to more than 20 percent. In New Jersey, the company claims about 50 percent of the dairy business; in Philadelphia, roughly 85 percent. **********Beer and milk might seem an unlikely combination, said Paul Gillette, publisher of Beverage Hotline, an industry newsletter, but these days ''beverage marketing companies are looking across the entire range of potables.'' With beer sales flattening, brewers and others in the mature beverage industry, he says, are looking to acquisitions for growth. Years ago, diversification was always within a given category - liquor companies acquiring wineries, for example. ''Now,'' he said, ''everything is fair game.''  Cooking the Books **********Fraudulent reporting among public companies is more prevalent than commonly thought, according to a preliminary report by the National Commission on Fraudulent Financial Reporting. **********Hard numbers are hard to come by, said James Treadway, the commission's chairman and an executive vice president of Paine Webber. But ''it is clear that some cases are not discovered'' and that some investigations are stopped for technical reasons. Besides, he added, even one case of fraudulent reporting involves ''hundreds of millions of dollars.'' **********A bill introduced by Representative Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon calls for improved financial disclosure. ''Again and again, on the heels of a clean audit, a company goes belly up,'' Mr. Wyden said, adding that right now ''the process of informing the public and investors is so woefully inadequate that a company has to be virtually a corpse before its condition is made known.'' **********Under Mr. Wyden's bill, an independent auditor who suspects fraud must report it to the company's senior management. If no action is taken, the auditor would tell the Securities and Exchange Commission. **********The National Association of Accountants sees no need for such a bill, saying that the private sector can oversee its own reporting methods and that such fraud is not prevalent. But Mr. Wyden plans to push for the bill in the next Congressional session. ''The majority of business people are honest,'' he said. ''But that minority that is not seems to be getting more unscrupulous and ingenious all the time.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/13/busin.body_text: **********Shares in JWT Group Inc. climbed $1.625 in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, to $50.625, amid widespread rumors that MCA Inc. might rescue the big advertising and public relations organization from an unwanted $45-a-share British takeover bid. **********MCA, a producer of television programming and theatrical films, did not return phone calls seeking comment. Wall Street traders said they had heard rumors that MCA was accumulating stock in the big agency. The Wall Street Journal said yesterday that MCA had met with JWT on Wednesday to discuss a friendly deal. **********The WPP Group P.L.C. of London, headed by Martin S. Sorrell, told JWT on Wednesday that it owned nearly 5 percent of the company and was prepared to buy the rest for $45 a share. WPP, a marketing services agency, brought its offer directly to shareholders yesterday with a tender offer. **********In a letter Wednesday to Don Johnston, JWT's chairman, Mr. Sorrell said he had made arrangements to borrow up to $530 million for the deal. Based on JWT's 9.66 million shares, this would be enough to pay $55 a share. Traders said their calculations showed that the stock might eventually bring $53. **********According to its filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, WPP acquired 448,100 JWT shares in open market transactions from April 29 to May 27 for an average price per share of $30.70.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/27/world.main_headline: Seven Former Defense Chiefs See Peril and Promise for U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/27/world.print_headline: Seven Former Defense Chiefs See Peril and Promise for U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/27/world.body_text: **********Seven former Defense Secretaries who gathered here to compare notes on the nation's defense have concurred that the United States should conclude a prospective agreement with the Soviet Union to eliminate medium- and shorter-range nuclear arms. **********But they disagreed over the Reagan Administration's policy in the Persian Gulf. **********In a panel discussion here Friday, Donald H. Rumsfeld, Secretary of Defense under President Ford, said the Reagan Administration's gulf policy had been successful so far. **********But Clark M. Clifford, who served in the Johnson Administration, said, ''I consider that we are in an exceedingly dangerous position, and I regret that we are in that position.'' **********Elliot L. Richardson, Defense Secretary in the Nixon Administration, said the Reagan Administration was giving serious consideration to a gulf plan he proposed under which Kuwaiti oil tankers and the American naval vessels escorting them would fly the United Nations flag. Support for Space Defenses **********But others said that proposal could create serious problems, particularly if a United Nations force were to include vessels of both the United States and the Soviet Union. **********The former secretaries said research should continue on the Strategic Defense Initiative, the space-based missile-defense system sought by President Reagan. **********But several said the President had raised unrealistic hopes among the American people for what James R. Schlesinger, Secretary of Defense under Richard M. Nixon and Gerald R. Ford, called ''an Astrodome over the United States.'' **********Three of the former Defense Secretaries - Harold Brown, who served in the Carter Administration; Melvin R. Laird, who served in the Nixon Administration, and Robert S. McNamara, who served Presidents Kennedy and Johnson - said plans to build three aircraft-carrier groups at a cost of $55 billion represent a dangerously unbalanced naval policy. **********The Defense Secretaries were in Atlanta at the invitation of the Southern Center for International Studies. They also taped the discussion, which is scheduled to be broadcast Oct. 23 on the Public Broadcasting System.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/28/busin.main_headline: Creative Head Resigns At Ogilvy & Mather
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/28/busin.print_headline: ADVERTISING; Creative Head Resigns At Ogilvy & Mather
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/28/busin.body_text: **********Pleading that he has reached a point in life when he'd like to build something for himself, Jay Schulberg, 47 years old, an executive vice president and for the last two years the creative head of Ogilvy & Mather New York, has resigned from the company. **********He is being replaced by Norman Berry, 55, the agency's creative head worldwide, who will be returning to a job he has already had. Mr. Berry, who had been president of the New York office, was promoted to chairman and given the title of chief executive, new to the office. **********And there are more changes. Brendan Ryan, 41, an executive vice president, has been promoted to general manager of O.& M. New York; Kenneth Caffrey, 48, also an executive vice president, has been named executive director of agency operations, New York, and Jack Reed, 43, a senior vice president, will be director of account-management resources. **********Mr. Schulberg, whose first agency was Foote, Cone & Belding, has been at Ogilvy & Mather for 20 years. He said yesterday that he hadn't quite decided what he would be doing, but that he knew he would stay in the business. He said he was departing with the knowledge that under him the creative department had been responsible for what he called some ''terrific'' advertising campaigns. **********''It was done,'' he wrote in a note after the agency announcement, ''by treating people fairly and decently. One doesn't have to be brutal to bring out the best in people. 'What Makes Sammy Run?' doesn't have to be in the advertising business.'' **********That book, by the way, was by his brother Budd.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/08/busin.main_headline: Manville Fails in Suit of U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/08/busin.print_headline: Manville Fails in Suit of U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/08/busin.body_text: **********The Manville Corporation, now in bankruptcy proceedings, has lost its bid to get the Government to reimburse it for damages the company paid to individuals exposed to asbestos in Government shipyards during World War II. **********Manville, the Denver-based forest and building products company, said Thursday that Federal Claims Court Judge Christine Cook Nettesheim ruled in Washington that the company would not be reimbursed because it failed to prove the Government had breached wartime contracts with it. Manville contended the Government breached supply contracts in its use of insulation and fireproofing materials. **********The Justice Department hailed the ruling, saying it reaffirmed the Government's position that the claims of the asbestos manufacturers were without merit. **********Asked whether Manville would appeal the decision, its senior litigation counsel, Robert Batson, said, ''Certainly the company will consider all of its options.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/17/busin.main_headline: VOLUME IS RECORD; A Crossroad For Wall St.: The Era of Euphoria May Not Be Over Yet
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/17/busin.print_headline: STOCK PRICES FALL ON A BROAD FRONT; VOLUME IS RECORD; A Crossroad For Wall St.: The Era of Euphoria May Not Be Over Yet
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/17/busin.body_text: **********For more than five years, millions of individual investors have enjoyed one of the most prolonged bull markets in history. Even if they did not cash in their chips, they spent more freely and helped lift the economy, thanks to their new-found sense of wealth. **********Now, however, the market is at a crossroads. After the sharp selloff of recent days, these retail investors and mutual fund owners are wondering if the long, euphoric period is finally over. **********The nervousness of so many little investors, however, is not shared by market professionals. Investment analysts and portfolio managers point out that while they have no way of foretelling what lies ahead, there are few signs to suggest that the stock market's recent decline is the start of something calamitous. The economy remains healthy; corporate profits are strong; inflation, though rising somewhat, remains relatively modest. Correction Needed Before a Surge **********Many say the stock market needs to let off steam after a heady run-up. And indeed, if history is a guide, a downward correction is a must before the market takes off on its next binge, as a large, still optimistic group of market professionals think it will. **********To be sure, the recent selloff is based on more than just the jitters. A big rise in interest rates in the last two months has suddenly made investments in money market accounts or such fixed-income securities as Treasury bills, notes and bonds look very attractive. The higher rates are caused in large part by the need to attract foreign investors to buy the Treasury securities that are sold to pay for the country's budget deficit. **********A continued rise in rates, of course, would take its toll on the economy as businesses and consumers slowed their spending. And there is the chance that this could occur if foreign investors demand higher rates to offset a further decline in the value of the dollar, which has already dropped more than 30 percent in the last two years. **********But one driving force that is often behind rising rates is not present nowadays: In the early 1980's, the country was thrown into an economic recession because high interest rates stifled business and consumer spending. Those high rates were necessary, the Federal Reserve Board believed, to curb double-digit inflation, but inflation now appears to be in check. **********To a certain extent, the selloff of late has been a case of easy come, easy go. Analysts point out that for the most part investors who have bought and held stocks since the start of the year are still impressively ahead. **********Hard as it may be to remember, at the start of the year the Dow Jones industrial average was around 1,900, which means that yesterday's close of 2,246.73 still represents a gain of more than 18 percent for the year. And in the last five years, the Dow has risen more than 250 percent. Yesterday's decline of 4.6 percent brought the total drop to 17.5 percent since the Dow hit its high of 2,722.42 on Aug. 25. **********Although there was little evidence that individuals were unloading shares by the bushel at any point this week, analysts said there could well be some increase in retail selling early next week. But at the same time, they pointed out that the big drop in stock prices and positive economic fundamentals make stocks look attractive. **********''If fundamentals count any more, there is still a lot of value out there,'' said Greg A. Smith, chief investment strategist at Prudential-Bache Securities. ''This is the kind of thing everybody wanted to see: a sharp correction to a classic bull market. Now we have it.'' A Closer Look at Bonds Burton Malkiel, whose book ''A Random Walk Down Wall Street'' argues that the stock market is unpredictable in the short run, and a professor of management at Yale University's School of Organization and Management, agreed with other analysts. He said he saw little or no evidence that inflation is about to surge or that the economy is about to go into a recession, a development that is often preceded by sagging stock prices. Still, he said the recent run-up in interest rates makes bonds an attractive alternative to stocks. **********''Rational portfolio allocation would suggest at this stage of the game to take a very close look at the bond market,'' he said. **********Reflecting that view, Merrill Lynch, the nation's biggest brokerage, said late yesterday that its strategists had made a modest change in their asset allocation recommendation to all clients. Stocks and Bonds Evenly Split **********Because of the rise in interest rates, the firm said it was now advocating an increase in the bond portion of its model portfolio to 40 percent, from 35 percent, and a reduction in the stock portion to 40 percent, from 45 percent. The firm's recommendation that 20 percent should stay in cash and securities, such as short-term Treasury bills, was unchanged from its earlier recommendations. **********''With long-term bond yields in the 10 percent range, bonds are likely to do equally well as stocks on a total return basis,'' said Charles I. Clough, Merrill's chief investment strategist. **********A spot check of stockbrokers around the nation yesterday disclosed that while clients were testy, few had chosen to get out of the stock market. Indeed, a number said that some investors were selectively buying stocks they now saw as bargains. Investing Is a Cold Exercise **********One partial reason for individuals' tranquillity in face of the market's nose dive could be the technical, institutional exercise that investing in the market has become. **********''I don't feel that the public ever really got into this market,'' said Bob Berry, the assistant branch manager of Paine Webber's downtown Dallas office. ''There hasn't been any panic, and we haven't seen a tremendous amount of shifting into fixed-income assets like money market accounts.'' **********William Cook, a vice president and retail broker with Merrill Lynch in Washington, said that computer-driven program selling of the type that has dominated the last two days ''is unemotional, but it breeds a lot of emotion.'' **********''My clients are testy, but they are not selling out,'' Mr. Cook added. ''If I had bought bonds for them two months ago to get safe, I would be worse off.'' **********James B. Cloonan, chairman of the American Association of Individual Investors, noted that short-term jitters, however understandable, are counterproductive to the strategy of most individual investors, who generally hold stocks and bonds for the long term. **********''I don't know what the individual investor can do except plan for the long term and keep a balanced investment strategy in place,'' Mr. Cloonan said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/11/world.main_headline: 3 Die as Police Clash With Protesters in Bangladesh
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/11/world.print_headline: 3 Die as Police Clash With Protesters in Bangladesh
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/11/world.body_text: **********At least three people were shot and killed by the police here today as thousands of rioters set fire to cars and buildings, and threw bricks and homemade bombs in an attempt to force President H. M. Ershad from office. **********At the end of the day of running battles between protesters and the police, the streets of the capital's commercial center were strewn with rubble, and the air was tinged with tear gas and smoke. But the likely effect of the unrest was unclear. **********Both sides in the disorders proclaimed victory - the opposition parties because they had carried out a protest ''siege'' of the capital in defiance of a ban on demonstrations, and the Government because President Ershad's position appeared unthreatened, at least for now. **********Opposition leaders acknowledged tonight that they had been hampered in their ability to mount the protest, originally conceived as drawing two million participants. The actual number of protesters was in the tens of thousands at most. **********In addition to outlawing demonstrations, the Government had closed Dhaka University and shut down incoming bus, rail and ferry transportation. Opposition Vows to Fight On **********The opposition parties vowed to continue their drive until President Ershad was forced from office, but Government officials predicted that it would abate as many protests had in the past. **********''The myth has been exploded,'' asserted M. A. Matin, the Home Minister and a close aide to the President. ''They were supposed to force the Government to resign. They couldn't. The so-called siege degenerated into an act of anarchy, vandalism, arson and an attempt to create civil disorder.'' **********Leaders of the main opposition parties said the attacks on their members were unprovoked. They called for a nationwide protest strike Wednesday and Thursday. **********''He will have to resign,'' Khaleda Zia Rahman, the leader of a coalition of seven opposition parties, said of the President. ''It is a matter of time. We will be out in the streets tomorrow and the day after until he goes.'' **********The opposition said a total of six people, not three as the Government said, had died from police gunfire. But the report was impossible to verify because the police had taken possession of the bodies. Nearby hospitals reported two people with gunshot wounds and dozens of others with injuries from the rioting. **********The opposition said dozens were wounded by gunfire. A Turbulent History **********Bangladesh, one of the world's poorest and most densely populated countries, has had a history of natural disasters, riots, assassinations, coups and coup attempts since it broke from Pakistan to become an independent nation in 1971. **********President Ershad was the army's Chief of Staff when he seized power in 1982; he was elected President last October in a day of voting marked by charges of fraud. **********Anti-Government parties renewed agitation against President Ershad last summer, culminating in 3 days of strikes in which 10 people were killed. But protests subsided when Bangladesh was hit by the worst floods in 40 years. **********This fall, the opposition tried to revive the protest drive with what it termed a siege of the capital. The authorities reported arresting more than 1,100 people for political activities in the last few days; the opposition said the number was more than 5,000. **********An unusual aspect of these protests was the unity among political parties of all ideologies, except for the ruling National Party of President Ershad. Anatomy of a Protest **********The day began peacefully, with small groups marching noisily through the downtown area, occasionally broken up by riot police officers wielding clubs and shields or firing tear gas. By mid-morning, demonstrators were throwing bricks and homemade bombs, and the police were firing back with blanks. **********The police later resorted to bullets in ''self-defense,'' Government officials said; opposition spokesmen said the firing was unprovoked.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/22/busin.main_headline: Advertising; A Mobile Pizza Hut Campaign
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/22/busin.print_headline: Advertising; A Mobile Pizza Hut Campaign
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/22/busin.body_text: **********AS a method of communicating what it considers its myriad strongpoints synergistically and within a single advertising campaign, Pizza Hut, the largest chain in the fastest-growing facet of the restaurant business, has borrowed a concept from Charles Kuralt of CBS-TV and has taken to the road. **********The Los Angeles office of Chiat/ Day, Pizza Hut's agency for the last couple of years, has prepared a comparatively huge pool of 30 spots for the first four months of the campaign, which will start running on network and spot TV tonight. **********They star Rich Hall, a young comedian who, aboard his mobile home labeled ''Pizza Hut Mobile Institute For Pizza Studies,'' is traveling the roads of middle America seeking answers to such compelling questions as ''Which is your favorite Pizza Hut delight, and why ?'' **********Favorite products include such trademarked items as the Priazzo, a double-crusted pizza pie, and the Calizza, which was inspired by the calzone. Since the strength of the Pepsico subsidiary is away from the Italian-American population centers, it is quite free to make things up as it goes along without fear of any outrage from the purists. **********Other favorites that the man in the street will be voting for are the traditional pizza, which is called thin and crispy; the deep-dish pan pizza, and the personal pan pizza, intended for the lunchtime crowd and guaranteed to be served within five minutes or you get another pie free. **********Although all the commercials supply some image-like promotion, most also stress a particular product so that local advertising associations can promote individual dishes. The local groups will place the ads though their own agencies while Chiat/Day arranges the national support. **********This first phase of the campaign will be backed by $50 million in national and local ad dollars. **********The interviews that make up the commercials use local residents who have been screened by Chiat/Day casting people. The spots were shot in Chicago; Normal, Ill.; Benton Harbor, Mich.; Chattanooga, Tenn., and Rome, Ga. (as close to anything Italian as they get), as well as on the road in Floyd County, Ga., and in Pell City, Ala. **********But before the campaign settles into its voice-of-the-people phase, it will have four days of nothing but introductory spots in which Mr. Hall will explain his mission. **********Then there will be four weeks of a special traffic-building promotion during which customers will be asked to vote (using specially printed place mats) for their favorite Pizza Hut food. Their ballot form also makes them eligible for a sweepstakes that offers winners a free pizza a week for a year. **********Also in Mr. Hall's pool of spots are two that promote home-delivered pizza, a concept Pizza Hut is testing in 300 non-restaurant locations in order to stay competitive with the fast-growing Domino's Pizza, which is a delivery-only operation. **********According to David G. Ropes, vice president advertising-media of Pizza Hut, who was in from his Wichita, Kan., headquarters visiting with Jay Chiat yesterday, home delivery and frozen pizza are the fastest-growing part of the $12 billion pizza market. **********As far as fast food, generally, he said that traffic - and therefore sales - was either flat or down over all. That means that in each category - pizza, hamburgers or chicken -battles for customers have been raging for the last year and a half. **********''Too many seats, not enough people,'' said Robert Wolf, executive vice president and general manager of Chiat/Day, New York. **********Pizza Hut, Mr. Ropes said, has more than 5,000 outlets in the United States and half of them are company owned. It is the country's third-largest restaurant chain, he said, born in America's heartland, where it has flourished. **********Up to now, the chain has made a poor showing on the two coasts, particularly in the East, where mom-and-pop pizza places dominate. In Boston and on Long Island a number of stores were opened, and then closed. But Pizza Hut, Mr. Ropes said, has now selected those areas for re-entry.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/07/world.body_text: **********The executive of the World Jewish Congress opened a meeting here today, the first gathering of an international Jewish organization in a Communist country since 1967. **********In that year, the Soviet Union and its European allies except Rumania broke diplomatic relations with Israel. **********Organization officials said Hungary had accepted two major conditions for the holding of the two-day meeting. They were that there were to be no obstacles to the attendance of Israeli delegates or any restrictions on subjects of discussion. **********At a luncheon, Ambassador Mark Palmer of the United States, urged that constant pressure be exerted on the Soviet Union on behalf of Jewish emigration. He also described the human-rights situation in neighboring Rumania as ''deplorable.'' He cited the plight of the Hungarian minority, of several Christian denominations and of economic problems in general. **********Edgar M. Bronfman, president of the congress, opened the talks by asking for unanimous adoption of a motion of congratulations to Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d for the action of the Justice Department in barring President Kurt Waldheim of Austria from entering the United States.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/09/busin.body_text: **********The Treasury Department said today that technical problems would force a delay of up to two years in issuing the first redesigned American currency in a half-century. **********The Government had planned to start issuing the new bills this fall, but Treasury officials said problems have been encountered in producing adequate supplies of the new paper. **********The changes being made in the money include adding a tiny plastic thread and microscopic printing around the portraits. Both changes are intended to thwart a new generation of color copying machines. The Secret Service has been afraid that the advent of the new machines would spawn a new class of ''casual'' counterfeiters who would run off money on the spur of the moment. **********The Government, which spent six years and $7.5 million studying the problem, announced in March 1986 that it had settled on changes intended to make it impossible to reproduce currency even with the most sophisticated office copying machines. **********The Bureau of Engraving and Printing had been scheduled to begin full-scale production of the new $1, $5, $10, $20, $50 and $100 notes this spring with the new money scheduled to start appearing in circulation in the fall. But the problems mean the new currency may not start circulating until the fall of 1989. Even after the new money appears, the old currency will still be valid, officials said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/09/busin.body_text: **********Ivan F. Boesky has responded to a lawsuit by former investors in his securities firm by suggesting that some of them were aware of his illegal trading activities. **********The former limited partners in Ivan F. Boesky & Company L.P. lost millions of dollars when the firm was closed after Mr. Boesky settled insider trading charges last year. The investors sued Mr. Boesky, contending they were defrauded by his illegal activities. **********Mr. Boesky first contended that he could not testify in the case because the Government's investigation was continuing, but the judge rejected that argument. **********Mr. Boesky's lawyers responded on Friday by saying they might argue that some of the limited partners were involved in some illegal activities, and thus have no right to contend they were defrauded. **********Legal sources close to the case said that the contention was aimed particularly at Guinness P.L.C., the British brewer being investigated in London for purported illegal stock purchases during a takeover battle last year. **********Mr. Boesky was reportedly part of that scheme. After Guinness won its takeover battle, with the apparent aid of Mr. Boesky and others, it made a $100 million investment in the Boesky firm, becoming its largest investor. **********If the Guinness claim were eliminated by this argument, it could make available millions of dollars to the other limited patners.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/22/busin.body_text: **********In an unusually harsh ruling, the United States International Trade Commission said today that the Samsung Group of South Korea unlawfully sold computer chips in the United States without licenses from the chip inventor, Texas Instruments Inc. **********The order requires Samsung to pay a penalty to Texas Instruments within the coming weeks. Otherwise, sales of all dynamic random access memory chips made by Samsung and all products using the chips would be banned in the United States. **********A high-ranking Samsung official in the United States, who asked not to be named, said he was certain that Samsung was close to settling the case with Texas Instruments and that Samsung would pay ''a considerable amount'' to avoid the product ban. He estimated Samsung's sales of dynamic random access memory chips in the United States at $70 million this year. Settlement Talks Confirmed **********In a statement, Texas Instruments confirmed that settlement talks with Samsung were in progress. Texas Instruments, the nation's largest semiconductor manufacturer, also said it would grant temporary licenses to the dozens of companies in the United States using Samsung chips. **********The ban includes circuit boards and equipment called single-in-line packages made by other companies that use D-RAM's made by Samsung with 64,000 or 256,000 characters of memory. It also covers computers, facsimile machines and certain telecommunications equipment and printers bearing either of the Samsung chips. **********Tim Yaworski, an assistant general counsel for the trade commission, in Washington, said the order was one of the strongest ever issued by the commission in a case involving patent infringement. He added that the investigation on charges brought by Texas Instruments, which also included complaints against eight Japanese chip manufactures, lasted 18 months and was the largest ever conducted by the commission. $138 Million in Payments Earlier this year, Texas Instruments announced that it had reached settlements with seven of the eight Japanese companies on complaints it first brought with the commission in January 1986. The agreements resulted in $138 million in royalty payments in the first half of 1987, the company said. **********Richard J. Agnich, vice president and general counsel for Texas Instruments, said the order today by the commission ''confirms the value of T.I.'s semiconductor technology.'' He added, ''It underscores the role intellectual property can play in providing an adequate return on research and development investment to technology innovators.'' **********Separately, Texas Instruments announced today that it had reached a pact with Japan's NEC Corporation for the two companies to license several of each other's chip patents. The pact called for Texas Instruments to drop charges against NEC that were filed with the commission. The company said the agreement was not expected to have a significant financial impact on Texas Instruments soon but that, in general, it represented ''a plus.'' **********Mr. Yaworski said the commission would deliver both its order and opinion on the Samsung ruling to President Reagan next week. Mr. Reagan then will have 60 days to decide whether to overrule the commission, allow the order to stand with no comment or endorse it. **********The Samsung executive said his company was not surprised by the commission's order because a commission administrative judge said in a preliminary finding last May that Samsung appeared to have violated Texas Instruments' patents in the two D-RAM chips. **********''If we could not reach any agreement with T.I., it would be severely damaging'' for Samsung, he said. **********Nevertheless, the officer expressed dismay at the order and asserted that it was the result of increasing sentiment within Congress to halt the stubborn trend of rising trade deficits in the United States. $7.6 Billion Surplus in 1986 Another company official said South Korea's trade surplus with the United States, at $7.6 billion last year, was modest compared with Japan's $34 billion surplus with the United States. He said Samsung and other major manufacturers in South Korea were acting to increase imports from the United States to reduce reliance on Japanese products and raw materials. **********''This exclusion will be a shock to Korean industry,'' the Samsung executive said. He added it would likely foment anti-American hostility among South Korean college students. ''The United States is demanding many things of Korea,'' he added. **********He said most American companies buying Samsung chips were too small to get much attention from Japanese suppliers. ''They also prefer the Samsung product because it is cheaper than the Japanese product,'' he said. About 80 percent of all D-RAM's sold in the United States are produced by Japanese and Korean manufacturers. **********Samsung's principal operations in the United States are sales offices in Fort Lee, N.J., and Los Angeles, as well as a chip manufacturing plant in San Jose, Calif., opened in 1983. **********Samsung is one of South Korea's three major multinational corporations, along with Daewoo and Hyundai.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/16/world.main_headline: Italy Opens Trial in Airport Raid
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/16/world.print_headline: Italy Opens Trial in Airport Raid
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/16/world.body_text: **********The only gunman who survived the attack on the Rome airport two years ago in which 16 people were killed went on trial today at the Rebibbia maximum-security prison. **********The survivor, Ibrahim Mohammed Khaled, is the only one of the three defendants in the trial who is in custody. The other two - including the guerrilla group's leader, Sabry al-Banna, better known as Abu Nidal - are fugitives. **********The trial is expected to produce testimony on the workings of the Abu Nidal terrorist group, including its operations in Syria, Lebanon and across Europe, judicial officials said. **********Mr. Khaled, the lone survivor of the four Palestinians who carried out the attack Dec. 27, 1985, has already confessed his guilt and given investigators a full account of the operation, according to the 101-page indictment in the case which became public today. **********All three defendants are accused of conducting a massacre and could be given life sentences. Mr. Khaled's court appointed lawyer, Epifanio Ales, said he would plead extenuating circumstances because the defendant was involved in a liberation struggle. **********In a television interview last March, Mr. Khaled, who turned 20 years old today, denied having any links with Abu Nidal. **********Italian police have little hope of aprehending the two other defendants, Rashid al Hameida, who Mr. Khaled identified as the chief organizer of the Rome attack, and Abu Nidal, leader of a shadowy faction that has been held responsible for dozens of assassinations and terrorist attacks since 1974. **********The gunmen hurled hand grenades and fired assault rifles at travelers waiting to check in for El Al and Trans World Airlines flights. In addition to the 16 killed in Rome, about 80 people were wounded. The Vienna attack left 4 people dead and 47 wounded.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/09/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; G.E. EARNINGS ROSE 15.9% IN 2D QUARTER
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/09/busin.body_text: **********The General Electric Company announced yesterday that earnings in the second quarter rose 15.9 percent on a 22.7 percent rise in revenues. **********G.E., a manufacturer of diversified high-technology, electrical and related products based in Fairfield Conn., said that net income in the latest three months rose to $720 million, or 79 cents a share, from $621 million, or 68 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. **********Per-share earnings were adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split earlier this year. Revenues rose to $9.56 billion from $7.79 billion. Strong Revenue Growth Cited **********John F. Welch Jr., chairman of G.E., said that the company benefited from strong revenue growth, particularly in its financial services, aircraft engine, plastics and medical services operations. **********''Throughout the company, we are realizing the positive effects of streamlining, reducing cost structure, and emphasizing product and service quality,'' Mr. Welch said. **********G.E.'s 1986 second quarter included the results of the RCA Corporation for June only. RCA was acquired June 9, 1986. **********In breaking down the results for the latest period, G.E. said that financial services earnings were substantially ahead of the second quarter of 1986, with much higher earnings from the G.E. Credit Corporation and the Employers Reinsurance Corporation; materials businesses had substantially higher operating profit on good revenue increases led by plastics, and major appliances had a much higher operating profit on very strong revenue increases in all product lines. Medical Systems Strong **********In other areas, G.E. said the technical products operating profit and revenues were buoyed by a strong medical systems performance; aerospace profits were well ahead of a year ago on much higher revenues, with the 1987 results reflecting the impact of a full quarter of RCA's aerospace and defense businesses, and consumer products had good revenue and operating profit increases, principally from the inclusion of RCA's consumer electronics business. **********Aircraft engine revenues and operating profit were strong; power systems revenues and operating profit were about even with a year ago; industrial revenues were down slightly, and overall profitability of the industrial sector was down considerably.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/08/world.main_headline: AT ENGLAND'S 'GLORIOUS INDULGENCE,' IT'S ONLY SHEEP WHO ARE INDIFFERENT
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/08/world.print_headline: AT ENGLAND'S 'GLORIOUS INDULGENCE,' IT'S ONLY SHEEP WHO ARE INDIFFERENT
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/08/world.body_text: **********''Picnics is all right for the small town suckers, but we're used to the high life, you know,'' Sportin' Life sang this evening, prophesying the sunset tableaux that followed a short while later out on the pastoral grounds of the Glyndebourne opera estate as the privileged bearers of the single most coveted ticket of the English summer gathered for halftime picnics. **********Never mind a seat at Wimbledon tennis, an invitation to a Buckingham Palace garden party, a ticket to ''Phantom of the Opera'' or a front-row loll at the international test match at Lord's Cricket Ground. **********The scarcest single ticket in England is a seat within the converted Glyndebourne estate house and, more particularly, at the acclaimed production of ''Porgy and Bess'' that reopened tonight for only eight summer performances, all long since sold out, in what has been well-termed Glyndebourne's ''glorious indulgence.'' Dash Through Victoria Station **********Some of the Glyndebourne audience could be seen making a daylight dash in evening clothes through Victoria Station in London for the 2:50 P.M. train here, 50 miles south in the Sussex countryside. They lugged hampers of delicate nibbles and repasts, disembarking in tuxedos and fur capes past indifferent white sheep, placing their intermission Champagne to cool in the estate ponds and generally congratulating themselves for having the rare presence to wander the gardens and witness the opera blossoming on the 700-year-old estate. **********Other opera buffs of humbler means, tuxedoed and gowned nevertheless, came by family cars, arriving by dint of thrift - tickets cost up to $80 each - and persistence. The waiting list is unspecified years long for membership, which then allows a lottery-governed chance for the limited tickets to the 73 evenings of six different productions this summer. **********''We applied for membership in 1959 when we were engaged, and finally were accepted in 1966,'' said Priscilla Pode, a gentle, democratically toned opera lover who still had to wait a year to get tickets for this second and final cycle of ''Porgy.'' ''But the box office people are always wonderful,'' she added, careful not to offend. **********Derided when it was conceived 53 years ago, the Gyndebourne summer opera has come to prevail as perhaps the most exotic hybrid of England's social-show biz cynosures, one that can resist even black-market prices. 'Too Many Parties Now' **********It combines the ticket cachet of the New York Giants' waiting list, the esthetic frenzy of the Metropolitan Opera buff, some of the verve of a Turner landscape and a decided touch of the class struggle that Marx had in mind when he first puzzled out his dogma in English exile. **********''Too many corporation guests and parties now,'' said one longtime Glyndebourne lover who recalled three decades back when the membership waiting list was only seven years long. ''Sometimes they get tipsy at their picnics and tend to giggle in the second half.'' **********This was hardly the case tonight as the audience was riveted, then on its feet for a standing ovation for ''Porgy,'' the performance bolstering the festival's reputation as a place of the highest standards where artists can invest weeks in rehearsals with some of the best directors and musicians of international opera. **********But for George Christie, the Glyndebourne chairman whose parents ingeniously converted the estate house into what is now a charitable trust, this is another summer of agonizing over the ''voracious and relentlesss quest'' for tickets. #250 More Seats Considered And so he is considering providing another dipperful of room for the ocean of demands by adding 250 seats to the splendid 830-seat theater. ''There is a point,'' he said, ''when, if you can't respond to demand, you are at the risk of creating needless chagrin and disenchantment.'' **********Perish that thought tonight as Glyndebourne's happy few fairly danced out onto the lawns for the 75-minute dinner break, humming Gershwin, popping Dom Perignon. **********In the cool English evening after the final curtain, chauffeurs stowed the portable tables and silver candle sticks and gowned guests disturbed the nearby sheep one more time with their limousine departures. Then it was that Damon Evans, the gifted, kinetic Juilliard alumnus who plays Sportin' Life, emerged from Catfish Row to the Glyndebourne gardens for his reverential post-show stroll. **********''It's my moment for expressing my own gratitude that I did one more performance here,'' said Mr. Evans, who has the problem all Americans have in trying to explain to people back home the special concatenation of the artistic, the pastoral and the indulgent that make Glyndebourne so unusual and so English. **********''My only regret is I wish this could be seen in the States,'' he said of the production that some critics have hailed as the finest Porgy ever. **********Naturally, he has had trouble getting enough tickets for kin, but he got one for his 80-year-old grandmother from Baltimore, who was talked into bringing an evening gown over, with her expecting to change at Glyndebourne. ''I told her no, that's not the way it's done,'' Mr. Evans said. ''You have to experience Glyndebourne in order to understand it.''
