https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/21/world.main_headline: Poindexter Questioned on Conflicts With North's Testimony
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/21/world.print_headline: Poindexter Questioned on Conflicts With North's Testimony
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/21/world.body_text: **********Senator George J. Mitchell, a Maine Democrat, questioned Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter yesterday over the admiral's testimony and that of Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North. Following are excerpts of that exchange: **********Q. Perhaps inevitably, the record is filled with conflicts in your testimony with that of Colonel North. I'd like to mention just a few of those that I deem important, and then I want to ask you first whether or not I have accurately summarized your aspect of the testimony, and then I want to ask you about the resolution of those. **********Most significant in my view is that Colonel North testified that he prepared and sent to you five memos which included references to the diversion of funds to the contras from the Iran arms sale, each of which specifically asked you to brief the President and obtain his approval. You have said that you cannot recall seeing those memos except possibly the one that survived. Indeed, just a short while ago, in response to a question by Mr. Rodino, you said you didn't think the other four memos ever existed. **********A. Senator, I listened to Colonel North's testimony quite carefully, because for one thing I knew that he would be aware of details that I was not and so to help fill in the full picture I thought that was important. I don't recall him testifying that positively that there were indeed five. That conclusion was jumped at by several members of the committee, but I don't think you will find in there any very positive statement. **********Q. Now Colonel North testified that on Nov. 21 he assured you that he had gotten rid of all of the memos referring to the diversion, whatever their number, and you say that you cannot recall any such conversation. **********You testified at your deposition that you instructed Colonel North not to put anything in writing concerning the diversion. Colonel North denied that you gave him any such instruction, and he further testified that had he received such an instruction from you, he would not have prepared and sent several separate memos - I have five in mind, but whatever number - for briefing the President and obtaining his approval. **********Colonel North testified that you were aware that the chronologies prepared in November 1986 were false. You have said that you were unaware of any deliberate falsification. **********Colonel North testified that at the meeting on Nov. 20 to prepare testimony for Mr. Casey to give to Congress that you know as well as he did that the testimony was wrong. **********Colonel North testified that his PROF note to McFarlane in which he spoke of your request to him to prepare a memo for the President referred to the one surviving memo which mentions the diversion. You've said that it didn't. **********Colonel North testified that he told you no later than Nov. 21 that he had destroyed documents. You've said that he didn't. **********Colonel North testified that he discussed with Mr. Casey, Mr. McFarlane and with you what Mr. Casey originally called and what Colonel North testified as the fall-guy plan. You've denied any such discussion.  Colonel North testified that on Nov. 21 he asked you whether you had told the President of the diversion and you said you had not. You cannot recall any such conversation. **********Now obviously human memory is such that different people can and frequently do recall the same events differently, particularly with respect to minor details. But as the number and importance of conflict in testimony increase, so also does the likelihood that someone is not telling the truth. Now before I ask a question about these conflicts, if I have misstated your testimony in any way in this summary it was inadvertent, and I want to give you the opportunity to correct it before I ask a question about it. **********A. I think you have misstated my position in several aspects. **********Q. In which respect? Why don't you state what would be the correct reference? I've got the transcript references here. Why don't you go ahead and state in what respects you feel that I have? **********A. Well, Senator, I think this tactic of quoting what Colonel North said and quoting what I've said without -they're not direct quotes, they're your interpretations of what I said - is a highly unfair way to do it. As you pointed out, people have different recollections. I've told you things that I can't recall. I'm not saying that Colonel North didn't tell me those things on the 21st. I simply don't recall it. Q. Well, that's what I said.  A. And I don't think that necessarily is a conflict just because I can't remember it. I don't think I said that the April memo wasn't prepared as a result - or it wasn't the memo that Colonel North referred to in the one PROF note. It may very well have been. I just simply don't recall seeing it then, and it isn't fair even to describe that memo as requesting the President to approve the transfer of funds. That's in a different section of the memo. The memo was asking for me to get the President's approval on the first part of the memo. That part about the transfer of funds is in a background section. It's pretty clear to me that when Colonel North wrote that, he understood that was approved, and it was a reminder to me that that amount of money in his view would be available to be transferred to fullfill the objective that I had approved back in February of 1986. **********Q. It is difficult - at least for me, and I speak for no one else - to reconcile that Colonel North's testimony that he prepared five of these, one for each transaction. He was quite certain in that there were five proposed transactions, some of which did not go through, and he sent them forward for approval. And that you can't recall even seeing them. Is there any way that we can reconcile that in your mind? **********A. Senator, I think you have in exhibits memoranda that Colonel North prepared for various phases of the operation. Those exist. They don't say anything about diversion. I have told you that I don't recall seeing any of the memos until the 25th. I did see the one that survived. I very likely could have seen that in April. I simply don't recall seeing it. **********And the one thing I'm positive about and the thing that's important to you is that I made a decision in February of 1986 not to ask the President or tell him about this proposal. I decided to approve that on my own. **********I made a very deliberate decision not to tell him and frankly whether the memos existed or didn't exist, I frankly don't think they did, I think that Colonel North may be mistaken on that point. He prepared, as you know, an awful lot of papers, probably more than any other staff officer on the N.S.C. staff, and out of all those papers I think he simply has forgotten.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/10/world.main_headline: Nobel Laureate Urges U.S. to End Contra Aid
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/10/world.print_headline: Nobel Laureate Urges U.S. to End Contra Aid
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/10/world.body_text: **********On the eve of accepting the Nobel Peace Prize, President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica today urged the American Congress to resist President Reagan and deny all further funds, even non-military aid, to the contra rebels of Nicaragua. **********''If we really want to reach peace in the region, we should give no more excuses to anyone,'' he declared. **********He contended that continued American intervention would make it easier for the Sandinista Government not to institute democratic measures in compliance with the regional peace proposal for which President Arias was awarded the Nobel Prize. **********In a news conference after his arrival here, the laureate said that the contra insurgency supported and financed by the Reagan Administration in an attempt to bring down the Marxist Sandinista Government was ''the main problem and not the solution'' to realizing the goals of the Guatemalan accord, which was signed Aug. 7. **********''I've been asking Mr. Reagan in Washington that he should stop all economic support to the contras,'' Mr. Arias said. ''As long as there is that aggression, you cannot ask Nicaragua to democratize.'' After first opposing the accord, President Reagan has supported it with open skepticism and the proviso that more contra aid will be sought to maintain pressure on the Sandinista Government. Demands Called Unrealistic **********The question of whether the accord will actually produce an end to the decades of Central American violence and discord, Mr. Arias said, depends less on the five signatory nations and more on whether there will be cooperation from the United States, the Soviet Union and Cuba. Analyzing the current problems of the accord, President Arias said the rebels in both Nicaragua and El Salvador had made unrealistic demands in the early peace negotiating process. ''They ask for too much in order to give concessions later on,'' he said, adding as his advice: ''Ask for less. Be more realistic so that agreement would be much easier to reach.'' **********''The first priority should be a truce until the 16th of January, after the end of the meeting of the five Presidents in Costa Rica,'' he said. He referred to a progress report on the accord to be heard in San Jose by himself and the leaders of the other accord nations, Nicaragua, Guatemala, El Savador and Honduras. **********''I haven't been able to succeed with my recommendation of a truce,'' the President conceded. ''Perhaps the main obstacle is a little bit of intransigence, a little bit of inflexibility, of intolerance'' by the contending forces, he said. 'Ball Is Still Rolling' **********Mr. Arias said he did not feel that the accord process lost its initial momentum once the attempts at negotiation failed to make early progress. ''The ball is still rolling,'' he said. ''I am only complaining perhaps it is not rolling fast enough.'' **********''We all know if we fail now, war will continue,'' he declared. **********The 46-year-old President confirmed that he intended to use the Nobel award of $340,000 to form a foundation to aid the neediest people in his nation, which, he noted, has been exceptional in Central America in not maintaining an army and in pursuing democratic government and such social advancements as free compulsory education and universal medical care. **********Mr. Arias praised President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbechev, the Soviet leader, for the latest nuclear disarmament agreement. ''This is an unforgettable event in recent history,'' he said, while declining to immediately nominate them for the next Nobel Peace Prize. ''Let's see what happens in the months ahead,'' he declared. **********Asked about Nicaraguan charges that a recently captured American was a contra mercenary using Costa Rica as a haven, Mr. Arias said ''it's very difficult to believe'' because his Government had a policy of deporting such people. If necessary, he said, he would ''very strongly protest'' to any outside country trying to use Costa Rica in the regional conflicts.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/25/world.main_headline: CHILD SEX SCANDAL ROILS UNICEF UNIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/25/world.print_headline: CHILD SEX SCANDAL ROILS UNICEF UNIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/25/world.body_text: **********The head of the United Nations Children's Fund in Belgium resigned today after the disclosure of a child pornography case linked to the Belgian branch of the organization. **********A spokesman at Unicef headquarters in Geneva said the head of the organization's Belgian committee, Gilbert Jaeger, had resigned ''to show how angry he is about what has happened in his organization.'' **********In a statement issued in Geneva, Unicef said it is ''deeply shocked'' by the scandal, which has led to 14 arrests in Belgium and others in Switzerland, France and Britain. **********Unicef said it was investigating charges that the Belgian committee was linked to an organization producing pornographic photographs of children and distributing them throughout Europe. **********Unicef's mission is to help and protect the world's children. Like many other United Nations bodies, it has independent volunteer committees in all Western industrial countries to raise money for its activities - in Unicef's case, largely through the sale of holiday greeting cards. 'The First to Suffer' **********The Unicef statement noted that the organization spent $400 million last year on projects promoting the health, nutrition and education of children in developing countries. It is currently drafting an international convention for the protection of children's rights, to be submitted later this year to the General Assembly in New York. **********''The first to suffer from the discredit which would unjustly fall on this organization as a result of this affair would evidently be the children of the third world,'' Unicef warned in the statement. **********The scandal erupted last week, when the Belgian police arrested Jos Verbeek, 63 years old, the director of Unicef's Belgian committee, and charged him with inciting minors to debauchery. **********The arrest followed the discovery of a secret photographic studio in the basement of the Brussels building where the committee's offices are housed. The studio was used to take pornographic photographs of children, many of whom were of North African origin, the police said. #1,000 Photos Seized The police said more than 1,000 such photographs were seized, along with a mailing list of some 400 names in 15 European countries that had been prepared on the Unicef office computer. **********Similar photographs found in several other European countries appear to have been taken in the Unicef office in Brussels, according to investigators. **********Among those arrested was another Unicef employee, Michel Felu, 45, who the police say organized evening computer classes for children in the organization's offices. These children were then sometimes made to pose for pornographic photographs, the police said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/26/world.body_text: **********Paramilitary troops and policemen raided the main Sikh temple complex in the Punjab early today and detained more than 250 people suspected of terrorist activities, the police said. **********No clashes were reported during the searches of several pilgrim's hostels and the office of a radical student organization at the Golden Temple in Amritsar, but the two-hour operation turned up weapons and ammunition. **********As in previous raids, the entry was confined to the periphery of the shrine, where the rest houses are situated. **********The district authorities ordered a curfew in the neighborhoods around the temple, which Sikhs consider their holiest shrine, before the police entered the complex but lifted it afterward. Second Raid This Year **********The police raid was the second on the sprawling complex this year. The latest action is part of a Government crackdown on the radicals that began last month after Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi dismissed a moderate Sikh government in Punjab State. The state is now controlled directly by New Delhi. **********Mr. Gandhi said the moderates had been unable to combat terrorism, and he accused several of their leaders of having connections with extremists, who demand a separate Sikh state. **********In recent months there have been several reports that Sikh extremists were again based in the Golden Temple and were carrying out killings from the sanctuary. More than 400 people have been killed this year in separatist-related violence in Punjab State. **********There have been three earlier raids on the temple. The first and bloodiest came in June 1984, when about 1,000 people died in an army attack on Sikh terrorists. The action led to deep resentment among the Sikhs and apparently to the assassination later that year of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi by two Sikh security guards. **********Last year, the police entered the temple again to rout 200 militants, and in January they arrested six terrorist suspects there. Talks Opened With Gurkhas **********Moving to deal with a separatist threat in another region, Indian officials have opened talks with Subash Ghising, the leader of a Gurkha movement in eastern India, and demanded an end to his violent activities there. **********The Gurkhas, descendants of Nepali settlers, are demanding a separate state in the Himalayan foothills around Darjeeling, an area that is part of the state of West Bengal.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/19/world.body_text: **********Despite protests over the United States decision to impose tariffs on some Japanese electronic products, there is little fear here that the tariffs will touch off a trade war or fundamentally harm the close relations between the two nations. **********Instead, the American action has raised questions about Japanese trading practices and whether a hard-line trade policy works or could backfire. **********In the wake of President Reagan's imposition of a 100 percent tariff on some Japanese-made computers, television sets and power tools on Friday, newspapers editorials and trade experts have called on Japanese companies to re-examine policies that anger their trading partners. And Government officials, although repeating their belief that the tariffs were unjustified and a violation of trade rules, stressed the importance of the overall United States-Japan relationship. **********''I do not think this is a trade war,'' said Japan's Minister of International Trade and Industry, Hajime Tamura. **********''Basically,'' he said, ''America and Japan are the most friendly nations'' in the world. He and other top officials, including Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone, pledged to work for swift repeal of the tariffs. Repeal of Tariffs Expected **********Indeed, one reason for the lack of polemics appears to be Japanese confidence that the tariffs will not remain in effect long. Officials say they will soon have statistical proof that they are complying with the semiconductor agreement at the heart of the trade dispute. The United States has charged that Japan has failed to stop selling semiconductors at low prices in overseas markets and has failed to open its markets to American-made chips. **********Mr. Tamura told reporters today that Japan had decided against retaliating immediately because he hopes that his meetings next week with the United States Trade Representative, Clayton K. Yeutter, can lead to an early settlement of the dispute. Japanese officials are also working on a separate package of trade measures that Mr. Nakasone will bring with him when he visits Washington on April 29. **********To many Japanese, indeed, the tariffs are symbolic. Although Japanese manufacturers registered strong protests today, and although it is clear that the tariffs will hurt exports of specific products, it is unlikely that $300 million worth of tariffs will deal much of a blow to an industry that exported, by Japanese statistics, $21 billion of products to the United States last year. **********Moreover, despite rumblings from Congress about further trade legislation, it appears that many Japanese do not think the United States would be able to shut Japan completely out of the American market. U.S. Said to Need the Trade **********''I think there is some feeling on the part of Japanese that the Americans will no longer be able to do without money or products from Japan,'' said Masahiko Ishizuka, editor of the English-language edition of The Japan Economic Journal. ''This feeling might prove wrong, but it leads to an expectation that the United States will stop somewhere in avoiding a total trade war.'' **********In some quarters, however, the American action has prompted calls for a re-examination of Japanese corporate behavior and trade practices. Yomiuri Shimbun, a leading daily newspaper that often reflects the thinking of the Nakasone administration, said in an editorial this morning: ''The root of the problem is within Japanese corporations, which drive themselves into excessive competition and into obtaining market shares even at the expense of profits. If this situation goes unchanged, Japan is bound to encounter one trade dispute after another with the U.S. and other countries.'' **********A managing director of McKinsey & Company who often writes on trade issues, Kenichi Ohmae, said that although American companies needed to try harder in the Japanese market, Japanese corporate practices were also at fault. In particular, he pointed to the fierce competition between Japanese companies that causes each company to rush to match investments made by its competitors. The result, in cars, shipbuilding and now semiconductors, has been overcapacity, falling prices and trade tensions. 'We Can Be a Menace' **********''It's a kamikaze mentality - if you fail when others fail, it is not considered a shame,'' he said. ''We have to come to grips with this, otherwise we will continue to produce tragedies. We have to realize that we can be a menace to the rest of the world, without any intention on Japan's part to do so.'' **********Government officials often say that American pressure can help to persuade vested interests in Japan to give in. And, with reservations, some Japanese said a tough American policy might prove effective. **********''To some extent this tactic works,'' Mr. Ishizuka said, adding, ''What's lacking in Japanese policy is to take action before being forced to do so.'' **********An endless round of trade sanctions or particularly vituperative criticism from Congress could hurt Japanese pride, Government officials said. **********''If you're slapped on your face,'' a senior Government official said, ''would you be willing to offer your other cheek to be slapped?'' **********Yet Mr. Ishizuka said he thought pragmatism would prevail. ''In the back of their minds, anti-American feeling might be brewing,'' he said. ''But Japanese are very well aware that without the American market, Japan's economy will be in serious trouble.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/16/world.main_headline: VISITORS FIND A RESTRAINT IN IRAN DESPITE MECCA RIOT AND GULF WAR
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/16/world.print_headline: VISITORS FIND A RESTRAINT IN IRAN DESPITE MECCA RIOT AND GULF WAR
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/16/world.body_text: **********After several days of mourning and protest earlier this month over Iranian-Saudi violence in Mecca, this city has returned to relative calm - a possible indication that Iran's leaders have decided to let the issue cool. **********Teheran residents seem oblivious to the Islamic Republic of Iran's diplomatic conflicts with its Arab neighbors and Western powers. **********Cars sped by the occupied Saudi Embassy today, but passengers did not glance at slogans festooned on bent-iron barricades. Elsewhere in the city, the Kuwaiti Embassy stood sacked, the British Embassy was all but vacant and French Embassy staff members were confined to their compound. **********There was no sign of protest at any of the sites. But a Western diplomat said recent actions against the four compounds were evidence that militants were dominant in the Government, even if militancy is largely absent from the streets. **********A Western diplomat said the embassy situations were ''stabilizing -not stable, but stabilizing.'' **********The most vivid demonstration of the militancy came in the protest in Mecca by Iranian pilgrims, whose march provoked a melee and led to the death of hundreds of pilgrims, mostly Iranians, in clashes with Saudi security forces. Cause of Riot Disputed **********Iran and Saudi Arabia are disputing who started the trouble. To present its version of events, Iran this week allowed a handful of foreign journalists to visit Teheran for five days. **********The journalists were promised interviews with returning pilgrims, some of them wounded, and with medical personnel and Government officials. **********Arab support for Saudi Arabia in the crisis may have persuaded Teheran to publicize its version of events, both diplomatically and by inviting Western journalists to Teheran. **********The relentless theme of the Iranian Government remains that the Saudi Government is linked directly to the United States and that the two acted jointly in Mecca. **********So slogans at the Saudi Embassy, under police guard, declare: ''Down with the U.S.A. Down with King Fahd. The Government is American,'' according to an English-speaking Iranian who provided a translation. **********At Friday prayer service, Iran's President, Hojatolislam Ali Khamenei, urged the nation not to seek revenge by attacking embassies. **********''The Government is trying to keep this issue warm but not hot, to play it to some advantage,'' said an Iranian journalist, sipping tea in the lobby of the Laleh International Hotel, formerly the Inter-Continental. The new name means Tulip, a symbol of martyrdom. Iranian Consults in Oman **********On the diplomatic front, Iran dispatched Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati to Oman for talks on the situation in the Persian Gulf and on the Mecca violence. In Iranian eyes the two are closely linked. **********At the Kuwaiti Embassy, every window is broken, furniture is overturned and 14 liquor bottles are prominently displayed on a lower balcony, silently rebuking the Kuwaitis for violation of Islam's ban on alcohol. **********A banner proclaims the position that Kuwait invited the superpowers into the Persian Gulf and hence Iran has taken the embassy. **********A witness told of observing from a distance as a crowd of civilians mixed with Revolutionary Guards stormed the embassy the morning after the Mecca violence. **********''They threw safes out the window, where there was by accident a truck waiting,'' said the witness. **********At the Saudi Embassy, there was ''very tough fighting'' by guards but they were overwhelmed, he said. The Arab diplomats were at first detained but then were put under house arrest, where they remain. Release of Diplomats Sought **********Saudi Arabia and Iran are reportedly negotiating the release of the diplomats, but both sides have refused to give them free movement. **********According to the Western diplomat, four Saudi diplomats and four Kuwaitis are being detained. He said he knew nothing of reports that a Saudi diplomat was missing or hospitalized. **********At the French Embassy, where 11 people, including five diplomats and dependents, are trapped in a diplomatic dispute, there were two banners in French. **********''France will soon taste the bitter taste of its meanness,'' said one. The other read: ''The origin of the moral war in the Persian Gulf is based in the United States. And France and England are standing beside them.'' **********The British Embassy has been deserted because of the break in relations between the two nations. A Swedish diplomat is there as caretaker. Italy has raised its flag over the French Embassy and opened an interest section there. U.S. Embassy Now a School **********Elsewhere in Teheran, at the United States Embassy, now a religious school where militants are said to study, one slogan in English reads: ''The superpowers' law of veto is worse than the law of the jungle.'' **********This seems to be a reference to American and Soviet veto power in the United Nations Security Council. **********Knocking at a side door and presenting press passes issued by the Ministry of Islamic Guidance, three American reporters were let inside the embassy walls briefly. **********Armed and uniformed young men smiled and let them sit in a cool guard house. ''Did you come here by mistake?'' one asked. They spoke little English. **********Later the guards allowed the reporters to walk just inside the front gate but no further. School was out, one said, suggesting another visit the next day.  U.S. WARNS EMBASSIES **********WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (Special to The New York Times) - The State Department has issued a warning to United States embassies throughout the world urging American officials to be on alert for Iranian terrorist activity, a department spokesman said today. **********In a statement, the State Department said, ''Iran has been stepping up its extremist rhetoric against the United States and has shown a past willingness to engage in terrorist attacks. We are taking precautions.'' **********The warning was issued during the last week, a department spokesman said, amid heightened tensions in the Persian Gulf. **********Today's statement was issued after The Los Angeles Times reported in its Saturday editions that Charles E. Lamb, the State Department's chief of diplomatic security, said that Iranians have been ''casing'' American embassies to determine which are vulnerable to attack.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/09/world.main_headline: EX-CHINESE LEADER IS SAID TO BE AILING
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/09/world.print_headline: EX-CHINESE LEADER IS SAID TO BE AILING
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/09/world.body_text: **********Hu Yaobang, who resigned in disgrace as the chief of China's Communist Party three weeks ago, is hospitalized here, according to a Chinese source. **********Mr. Hu, 71 years old, was reported to have entered the 301st Army Hospital for an undisclosed illness shortly after his resignation was announced. The hospital is equivalent to Walter Reed Army Hospital in the United States. **********The source said Mr. Hu was ''distraught'' by the decision to remove him from the party leadership on Jan. 16 after a monthlong wave of pro-democracy demonstrations by students. **********Mr. Hu, who was allowed to retain his seat on the standing committee of the Politburo, the ruling council of the party, has not appeared in public since late December and has not been mentioned in the Chinese press since his resignation. **********There has still been no public explanation for Mr. Hu's political demise, and the turmoil surrounding it has yet to subside. **********Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang was named acting general secretary of the party to replace Mr. Hu, but many basic policies set forth since 1979 by China's senior leader, Deng Xiaoping, for implementation by Mr. Hu and Mr. Zhao appear to be in doubt. Hints of Challenge to Deng **********That doubt arises, some Western diplomats say, because it is unclear who is now exerting power within the party. It has been assumed that Mr. Deng was unscathed by the political upheaval, but the increasing prominence of hard-line party members suggests at least some challenge to his leadership, according to the diplomats. **********There have been recurring articles in national newspapers questioning some basic features of the economic measures designed to stimulate the economy with market mechanisms and private initiative rather than relying on rigid state planning and control. **********Mr. Zhao has insisted that these policies, as well as China's opening to the West, will continue, but the widely trumpeted campaign last summer to extricate the party from daily government, which Mr. Hu pushed aggressively, now appears to be dead. **********One of the targets of the party hard-liners has been four coastal ''special economic zones,'' where many restrictions on imports, exports, and access to foreign currency have been eased. Conservatives viewed these zones, which Mr. Deng created to attract foreign investment and technology, as centers for the infiltration of Western values. Campaign Against Journalist **********Meanwhile, China's Government-controlled press has systematically begun to discredit the investigative reporting of Liu Binyan, a popular journalist who was expelled from the Communist Party two weeks ago. **********The attacks on the articles by Mr. Liu, who became best known for exposing corruption inside the Communist Party, appear designed to subdue independent enterprise by Chinese journalists and to shield the party from public investigations into illegal activity by its local officials. **********Mr. Liu's reports uncovered abuses of power by local party secretaries, extortion, bribery, intimidation of intellectuals and persecution of ordinary people. **********The daily newspaper in Heilongjiang Province, where Mr. Liu did his most celebrated investigative reporting, charged that the journalist wanted his profession to ''become the third force next only to Government and Parliament, just as in Western countries.'' **********The January issue of The Literary Review went on sale with an article by Mr. Liu torn out of each issue and his name blacked out on the magazine's title page. **********After he was expelled from the party two weeks ago, The Shaanxi Daily denounced Mr. Liu on its front page for attacking the party. The provincial paper in northern China charged that his reporting ''meddled in the work of grass-roots party organizations and disrupted the public. By wagging his tongue too freely, he often blackened the situation.'' **********The ferocity of the attacks on Mr. Liu appear aimed at undermining his popularity. Chinese and Westerners who know him say it was common for him to receive hundreds of letters a week at The People's Daily asking him to investigate their personal grievances.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/25/busin.body_text: **********In its latest effort to fend off a hostile $1.2 billion takeover attempt by the Bank of New York, the Irving Bank Corporation has adopted a policy assuring all its employees substantial benefits in case they are laid off after an unfriendly takeover. **********The ploy being used by Irving, which was disclosed in its quarterly filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, is designed to discourage hostile takeovers by making it more expensive for the potential acquirer. **********Known as a ''tin parachute,'' the severance benefits would cover all employees. In that respect they differ from ''golden parachutes,'' which assure only that a company's top executives would receive benefits should they lose their jobs as the result of an unfriendly acquisition. Golden Parachutes in Place **********Even before it adopted the tin parachute last month, Irving already had in place golden parachutes for 13 of its top executives. According to its filing with the S.E.C., the number of employees covered by golden parachutes was increased to 49 earlier this month. **********Although the use of golden parachutes has become widespread, tin parachutes are still rare. Other companies using the device include Mobil, Accuray, America West Airlines and Herman Miller Inc. of Zeeland, Mich. **********In the Bank of New York's attempt to take over Irving with its 10,200 employees, the costs could be substantial because most analysts believe that the acquisition might make sense only if the Bank of New York were to dismiss many employees after a merger. And the Bank of New York has done that in the past. **********When it took over the Long Island Trust Company earlier this year, for example, the Bank of New York laid off about 400 people, or about a third of the Long Island bank's staff. In addition, the Bank of New York gave the dismissed employees so little compensation that Long Island Trust's former owner, a large Italian bank, voluntarily increased the payments out of its own resources. Terms of Program **********Under Irving's program, dismissed employees would receive, in a lump sum, a minimum of one month's base salary for each year of service. But no employee would receive more than two years' base salary. Employees with a base salary of at least $40,000, however, would receive at least six months' base salary, and those earning at least $60,000 would receive at least a full year's base salary. **********The payments would be due whether the employee is dimissed or if he decides to quit after suffering a pay cut or a substantial reduction in duties. It would not apply if an employee were dismssed with cause. **********It remains unclear whether tin parachute plans such as Irving's would be upheld in court. But if nothing else, they threaten potential hostile acquirers with costly and time-consuming legal action. **********Asked to comment on Irving's move, Pierre Brull, vice president in charge of investor relations for the Bank of New York, replied, ''We have taken note that they have done it.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/11/world.print_headline: IRAN-CONTRA HEARINGS; Casey Planned to Write Memoirs
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/11/world.body_text: **********Shortly before William J. Casey was hospitalized last December, his literary agent circulated a proposal for a book of memoirs. **********''We read a short, cryptic synopsis but before we could respond, Mr. Casey had a seizure and never came out of the hospital,'' said Peter Osnos, associate publisher of Random House. **********Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North made a reference to the book yesterday at the Iran-contra hearings, saying, ''I watched him write part of that book and I'm looking forward to it.'' **********Mr. Casey, who was Director of Central Intelligence, died May 6. He suffered two seizures and was hospitalized Dec. 15. Three days later, he underwent surgery for removal of a malignant brain tumor. **********The memoirs might have covered his tenure as head of the Central Intelligence Agency, Mr. Osnos said. He resigned in February. **********But the proposal did not spell out the extent to which the agency would be discussed in the book. The book apparently would have focused at some length on the years from 1941 to 1946, when Mr. Casey served with United States Army Intelligence and the O.S.S., the Office of Strategic Services. Book a Surprise to Friends **********The existence of the book proposal came as a surprise to several of Mr. Casey's friends, including Leo Cherne, executive director of the Research Institute of America. **********Edward Chase, an editor at Macmillan, visited Mr. Casey shortly before his death and read his completed manuscript. ''It was an interesting account of his work in the O.S.S.,'' Mr. Chase said. ''It was definitely a memoir, but only of Casey's experiences down to the end of World War II.'' **********Mr. Casey wrote a number of books on law, taxes and estate planning, as well as a book on the American Revolution. His proposal, circulated to publishers by the Helen Rees Literary Agency, called for a collaborator. **********In calls to her Boston office yesterday, Ms. Rees was said to be unavailable. No one answered in New York.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/08/busin.print_headline: A NEW ERA IN AMERICAN TAX POLICY; Congress To Tackle Taxes, Again
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/08/busin.body_text: **********WHEN President Reagan, in an elaborate ceremony last October on the south lawn of the White House, finished signing the most sweeping tax legislation in a generation, he stood up and, with a flourish, held the book to his chest and slammed it shut. **********Finally, he seemed to be suggesting, the long uphill battle over taxes had been won, and the new law was ready to be engraved in stone. **********The Tax Reform Act of 1986, which slashed individual and corporate rates and broadened the tax base by abolishing many deductions, did indeed bring fundamental change. Yet those familiar with the workings of Washington know that no issue is ever permanently resolved. There will, in fact, almost certainly be fresh tax legislation this year. **********''I have yet to see a Congress that was unwilling to tinker,'' said Gerald W. Padwe, national director of tax policy for Touche Ross & Company. ''They're always looking at something to fix.'' **********The new Speaker of the House, Jim Wright of Texas, did not even wait for the new law to take effect to suggest that tax cuts for the wealthiest individuals should be deferred. This prompted a counter effort by Republicans, which proved unsuccessful, to amend the House rules to bar any increase in tax rates - or a delay in cuts - for two years. **********But just what Congress will do on taxes this year is, as usual, highly uncertain. While big changes seem unlikely, Congressional aides, accountants and lobbyists are warning taxpayers that they must continue to pay close attention if they are to avoid potentially costly errors. **********Frank O'Connell, who follows legislation for Laventhol & Horwath, a large accounting firm, says that while he and his colleagues continue to recommend deferring as much income as possible until 1988, when rates are to be still lower, ''We are certainly cautioning our clients'' of the possibility that Mr. Wright's proposal will be adopted. **********''That 28 percent rate might not be there,'' said Mr. O'Connell, referring to that part of the law that chops the highest bracket to 38.5 percent this year (from 50 percent in 1986) and to 28 percent next January. **********The fact that many politically powerful sectors of the economy - including the real estate and insurance industries and the small-business community - lost important ground in the 1986 legislation means that even the most innocuous bill this year could be transformed into a vehicle loaded with contentious, special-interest amendments. **********Once the legislative process has begun, said Mark A. Bloomfield of the American Council for Capital Formation, ''the whole thing can explode.'' **********This is one reason that there is little urgency about getting started on the routine business of passing a so-called technical corrections bill to rectify the hundreds of mostly minor drafting errors in the 1986 act - with more being found each week. **********Although Congress tried to get this job done last fall - and committee negotiators from each chamber came close to agreement four days before the President signed the tax overhaul legislation itself - the fear of bogging down in debate over substantive issues has put technical corrections well down on the list of priorities. **********Such ''substance'' could be such obviously important ''added starter'' amendments as a measure to restore preferential treatment for capital gains. Or it could be a lower-order but probably controversial item, such as grandfathering the investment tax credit for purchasers of small airplanes built in Kansas, Florida, Georgia and Texas. **********What is to be considered ''technical,'' in other words, is what a majority of Congress says is technical. **********In any event, passing even a corrections bill ''won't happen until the middle of the year at the earliest,'' predicts a Senate aide. Adds Mr. Bloomfield, ''No one I know of is rushing.'' Another uncertainty is just what approach will be taken by Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who has replaced Bob Packwood, the Oregon Republican, as head of the Senate Finance Committee. **********Although Senator Bentsen has said he expects only technical corrections legislation this year, there are signs that he may be receptive to ''doing something'' for the real estate industry, perhaps the biggest loser under the new law. **********Some of the problems in the 1986 act will be worked out by the staff of the Joint Tax Committee, which is producing its formal explanation of the law that will be published, probably in April, in what is called its Blue Book. The principal standard for inclusion in this document is that there must be general agreement among all Congressional parties about the intent of a particular provision. **********Another reason for going slow on tax legislation this year is simply that Congress will in all likelihood be preoccupied with other things, particularly trade legislation and the related, suddenly hot issue of the nation's international competitiveness. **********It will also be spending long hours on the budget, and it is this issue, many believe, that will provide the impetus for any serious revisions of last year's Tax Reform Act. **********Deficit-reduction targets will be hard to achieve in the most optimistic of circumstances, these specialists maintain, and should the economy falter, this would both cut the Treasury's tax take and raise outlays for unemployment and other programs. **********In this situation, a need for revenues could unleash efforts to do something ambitious: perhaps cigarette or other excise taxes, an oil import fee, a broad-based consumption tax or even adjustments to the Social Security system. **********All these things, however, are long-shots since the economy seems likely to continue to show respectable growth and because President Reagan remains adamantly opposed to any tax increase, apart from the $20 billion or so of additional revenue he has proposed in his 1988 budget. **********One likely substantive ''fix,'' however, will be substantially to repeal a provision in the new law granting vast new tax benefits to estates that contribute to employee stock ownership plans, or ESOP's. **********Whatever happens, however, there seems to be almost no chance that the newly-enacted basic tax rates themselves - 15 and 28 percent for individuals and 34 percent for corporations -will be raised before the next President takes office in 1989. **********''I do not think there is going to be any significant erosion of what was done last year,'' asserted an aide to Senator Bill Bradley, the New Jersey Democrat who was a principal architect of the 1986 law. ''I'm confident that the rate reductions scheduled to take effect in 1987 and 1988 will indeed become effective.'' **********A less visibly partisan Congressional operative, a staff member of the Joint Tax Committee, agreed: ''I don't think very much will happen at all this year,'' he declared. When asked what advice he had for taxpayers now planning their strategies, he added: ''I'd assume that the '86 Act is going to be around for a while.''  PROPOSED CHANGES IN TAX LAW  Among the changes that members of Congress have proposed be included in a ''technical corrections bill,'' to the tax act are:  * Easing the tax-exempt bond arbitrage penalties for localities issuing and rolling over short-term notes.  * Allowing taxpayers with deposits in insolvent financial institutions to deduct their full losses.  * Expanding a transition rule that exempts deep discount bond income earned by 15 large life insurance companies from repeal of the preferential 28 percent tax rate on corporate capital gains.  * Expanding a transition rule that allows purchasers of private aircraft made in Kansas, Florida, Texas and Georgia to take the investment tax credit.  * Allowing deductions for charitable donations to the University of Texas and Louisiana State University made in exchange for preferential seating at sporting events.  * Allowing steel companies to get partial refunds for unused investment tax credits.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/31/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Microsoft Buys Software Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/31/busin.body_text: **********The Microsoft Corporation announced its first significant software acquisition today, paying $14 million for Forethought Inc. of Sunnyvale, Calif. **********Forethought makes a program called Powerpoint that allows users of Apple Macintosh computers to make overhead transparencies or flip charts. Some industry officials think such ''desktop presentations'' have the potential to be as big a market as ''desktop publishing,'' which involves using computers to lay out newsletters and other publications. Microsoft is already the leading software supplier for the Macintosh. **********The personal software industry has been buzzing with acquisitions lately. Microsoft has purchased a 10-employee Berkeley company called Dynamical Systems and has invested in another company, Natural Language Inc. But the acquisition of Forethought is the first significant one for Microsoft, which is based in Redmond, Wash. Forethought would remain in **********Sunnyvale, giving Microsoft a Silicon Valley presence. The unit will be headed by Robert Gaskins, Forethought's vice president of product development.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/23/world.main_headline: Iranian, in U.N., Rebuffs Reagan On Cease-Fire
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/23/world.print_headline: Iranian, in U.N., Rebuffs Reagan On Cease-Fire
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/23/world.body_text: **********President Ali Khamenei of Iran rebuffed President Reagan today by failing to accept the United Nations Security Council's call for a cease-fire in the war against Iraq. **********The bearded Iranian President, in an emotional address to the 159-nation General Assembly, denounced the United States for its attack on an Iranian vessel Monday in the Persian Gulf and called the Reagan Administration's account of the incident ''a pack of lies.''  [ Excerpts, page A14. ]  Mr. Reagan, in his own speech to the General Assembly on Monday, had said that unless Hojatolislam Khamenei accepted the cease-fire ''clearly and unequivocally,'' the Security Council should adopt enforcement measures against Iran. Attack on Vessel Denounced **********As a result of the Iranian President's failure to make such a commitment, the United States and Britain both said today that the Security Council should carry out its threat to impose sanctions against Iran. **********President Khamenei's remarks on the helicopter attack prompted the United States delegation to walk out of the hall. ''I do not intend to sit passively by when our country is insulted, our President is pilloried and the truth is trampled,'' Herbert S. Okun, the deputy United States representative to the United Nations, who was leading the delegation at the time, said later. **********All but one member of the Iraqi delegation left the meeting earlier when the Iranian President entered to cries of ''Allah is Great'' from Iranian supporters in the public gallery. A Lengthy Invocation **********During his hour-and-a-half address, which opened with a lengthy invocation to ''God, the Beneficent and Merciful,'' and was scattered with religious allusions, the Iranian President dismissed the Security Council as ''a paper factory for issuing worthless and ineffective orders.'' **********He repeatedly denounced the United States as ''the Great Satan'' and accused Washington of seeking to overthrow Iran's revolutionary Islamic leadership in order to re-establish the same influence it enjoyed over the country in the days of the Shah. **********And he said the United States ''and its Saudi stooges'' were responsible for the violence in Mecca last month in which some 400 pilgrims were killed. Calls Iran Victim in War **********Speaking in Persian, President Khamenei presented his country as the wronged victim in the gulf war and called repeatedly for ''punishment'' of Iraq as the aggressor in a conflict that entered its eighth year today. **********''We long for peace more than anyone else, but we believe that peace, a lasting peace, can only be established in the light of punishing the agressor,'' he said. **********Despite the bitter and apparently uncompromising tone of most of his speech, which never mentioned the phrase ''cease-fire,'' the Iranian President did not completely close the door to further United Nations mediation efforts in the conflict. **********The Security Council unanimously approved a resolution in July calling for an immediate cease-fire, to be followed by the withdrawal of each side's forces behind recognized frontiers, an exchange of prisoners and the setting up an impartial commission to determine responsibility for the war. Praises Secretary General **********President Khamenei departed from his prepared text to praise Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar for his recent peace mission to Teheran to discuss carrying out the Security Council's peace plan. He described the talks as ''useful'' and said the Secretary General's subsequent report to the Security Council was ''objective and instructive.'' **********He accused the United States indirectly of ignoring positive aspects of this report. **********Afterward, Secretary of State George P. Shultz said the Security Council should now impose an arms embargo on Iran as it had promised to do if that country did not heed its cease-fire call and other peace proposals set out in the Security Council measure. **********Britain, which along with the United States, France, China and the Soviet Union, is a permanent Security Council member, also said the time has come for the Council to impose sanctions, known as ''enforcement measures,'' against Iran.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/28/world.main_headline: PAKISTAN, CITING RISE IN AIR RAIDS, SEEKS TO LEASE U.S. RADAR PLANES
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/28/world.print_headline: PAKISTAN, CITING RISE IN AIR RAIDS, SEEKS TO LEASE U.S. RADAR PLANES
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/28/world.body_text: **********Pakistan has made an urgent request to lease American radar aircraft to defend against border raids by warplanes based in Afghanistan, Administration officials said today. **********Dropping an earlier request to buy surveillance planes, Pakistan said for the first time that it would be willing to lease them instead. This would require American military personnel to operate from Pakistani territory, according to the Administration officials. **********But Pakistani officials assured Washington that the planes would not fly over Afghanistan and that the Americans would be safe. Could Avoid Congress **********By leasing the planes, Pakistan also would avoid a fight in Congress, where members opposed to American military aid on the ground that Pakistan is developing nuclear weapons would try to prevent the sale. India, which opposes Pakistan getting any planes for fear they might be used against India, is expected to react negatively to any lease arrangement. **********Administration officials agree that Pakistan urgently needs an air defense system, but said today that even if a decision was made immediately to lease the planes, it would take several months to put a system in place. These officials said they were still studying the Pakistani request and that no decision had been made. **********An American-Pakistani team that analyzed Pakistan's needs last year outlined several options. They included providing the Pakistanis with the E-3A Sentry, a modified Boeing 707 also known as Awacs; or the E-2C Hawkeye, a less-sophisticated and much cheaper plane, officials said. **********From certain areas of Pakistan, either plane would be able to detect flights taking off from Kabul, although the Awacs has a wider range, American officials said. **********The Pakistani request came in a letter dated April 16 from Prime Minister Mohammed Khan Junejo to President Reagan, A copy was given to Senator Gordon J. Humphrey, Republican of New Hampshire, during his recent visit to Pakistan. Although the letter has not been formally presented to President Reagan, a copy was forwarded to the State Department. **********In his letter, Mr. Junejo said there was an ''extremely urgent'' need for the American early warning system and asked President Reagan to consider leasing surveillance planes ''as soon as possible, preferably within a month or so.'' **********The letter did not say what type of radar plane Pakistan wanted, but Pakistani officials have said they prefer the Awacs. **********Pakistan would be willing to negotiate on joint American-Pakistani operation and maintenance of the planes until Pakistani personnel were fully trained, Mr. Junejo said. He added that the planes would be used along the border with Afghanistan, but safely away from areas subject to attack. **********''We do not anticipate any danger to the safety of the aircraft or the crew,'' he said. **********The Pakistani request was prompted by increasing concern among Pakistani officials over an increase in raids by Soviet and Afghan planes in recent months against civilians in Pakistani border towns. Hundreds have been killed and more than 1,000 wounded in the raids this year. The losses are three times greater than in the same period last year. Change in Situation Cited **********In his letter, Mr. Junejo said the raids had created a ''radically changed situation.'' He said the attacks had led to accusations that his Government was ''failing to defend its territory and the lives and property of its people in the absence of effective defensive measures.'' He said the accusations could erode public support for his Government. **********The Prime Minister also wrote that Pakistanis blamed the presence of three million Afghan refugees in Pakistan for the raids. **********When Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger visited Pakistan last October, he pledged that the United States would try to provide early warning radar planes to Pakistan ''as quickly as possible.'' But to lease military equipment, Mr. Weinberger must certify that it exceeds American military needs, which Administration officials acknowledge could pose a problem in this case. **********Pakistani officials had said they wanted to buy the planes to have complete control over their operation. But the main obstacles to that plan were the cost, the fact that the planes could not be produced and delivered for several years and the need to overcome Congressional resistence. **********In 1980, the United States leased Awacs to Saudi Arabia to aid that nation against possible air attack from Iran. The Reagan Administration was able to get Congressional approval to sell the planes to the Saudis in 1981, but only by a highly contested vote.  India Reviewing Nuclear Policy NEW DELHI, April 27 (Special to The New York Times) - India's Defense Minister, citing an ''emerging nuclear threat'' from Pakistan, said today that India might drop its ban on military uses of nuclear power. **********''Our response will be adequate to our perception of the threat,'' the Defense Minister, Krishna Chandra Pant, told Parliament. Mr. Pant, speaking at a debate on the military budget, said a Pakistani nuclear program was ''forcing us to review our options.'' **********Pakistan has denied it is developing nuclear weapons, although its top leaders have defended their country's right to use atomic power for peaceful purposes. Officials here say the concern about Pakistan has caused India to reconsider its often-repeated pledge not to produce atomic weapons. **********India exploded a nuclear device in a western desert in 1974 and Indian scientists have said that rockets for India's space program could be adapted to carry nuclear warheads. **********Still, New Delhi has not specifically declared that it will develop nuclear weapons, and military experts say such a move is unlikely.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/22/world.main_headline: Bonn Decision to Try T.W.A. Suspect Is Seen
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/22/world.print_headline: Bonn Decision to Try T.W.A. Suspect Is Seen
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/22/world.body_text: **********The West German Government is expected to announce this week that it will try a man suspected of hijacking a Trans World Airlines jetliner and not extradite him to the United States, according to reports in West German newspapers. **********The newspaper Die Welt said today that Justice Minister Hans A. Engelhard had already made the decision; other newspapers have carried similar reports in recent weeks. **********The fate of the suspect, Mohammed Ali Hamadei, who has been held in a West German prison since he was arrested in Frankfurt on Jan. 13, has been a troubling issue for Bonn. The United States has put pressure on Bonn to extradite him, because the hijackers who seized the T.W.A. jetliner in 1985 killed an American serviceman, Robert Stethem. **********Bonn believes that extradition would spell certain death for two West Germans, Rudolf Cortes and Alfred Schmidt, who were taken hostage in Beirut shortly after Mr. Hamadei's arrest.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/25/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; 3Com, Bridge Plan to Merge
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/25/busin.body_text: **********The 3Com Corporation and Bridge Communications Inc., both makers of computer network systems, said today that they would merge. The combined company would retain the 3Com name and have its headquarters at 3Com's Santa Clara, Calif., facility, while Bridge would become a subsidiary and continue operating from Mountain View, Calif. **********Under the proposed transaction, each outstanding share of Bridge would be exchanged for 1.4 shares of 3Com common stock, which would give current Bridge shareholders 42 percent of the combined company. Before trading was suspended, 3Com shares rose $62.5 cents today, to $16.625 in over-the-counter trading. Bridge shares closed at $23.50, up $1.875. For the quarter ended **********May 31, 3Com earned $3.2 million on sales of $31.6 million. For the quarter ended July 4, Bridge earned $1.8 million on revenues of $17.1 million. **********Analysts said the merger would benefit both companies, which offer similar products but at opposite ends of the market. Bridge products are marketed through a direct sales force, while 3Com uses value-added resellers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/19/busin.main_headline: G.E., Too, Gets Into the Game
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/19/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; G.E., Too, Gets Into the Game
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/19/busin.body_text: **********The General Electric Company is going modern by taking some curlicues out of its famous symbol and shortening its name to G.E. in its dealings with the public. The company, ranked as the world's third largest, in terms of its market value at midyear 1986, will still be known formally as the General Electric Company. **********''We're just updating something that has been around since the turn of the century,'' said Jack Batty, a company spokesman. Of the symbol, he said, ''We're making it a little more modern.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/27/world.body_text: **********United States and Spanish negotiators ended two days of talks here today without either side budging from past positions on the future of American bases. **********Spokesmen from both sides said each had only repeated previous statements in meetings at the Foreign Minstry. **********A Spanish official, who earlier in the week said his nation would ask for a timetable for an American withdrawal of its F-16 fighter planes, saod today that the issue was not brought up, leaving it for the next round of talks, scheduled here in September. **********All the officials, including the chief American negotiator, Ambassador Reginald Bartholomew, said they were confident an agreement would be worked out before a November deadline, when Spain must inform its ally whether it plans to renew a 30-year-old treaty that allows the bases. **********The American military presence in Spain has been a sore spot since the bases were established under Franco. Virutally every five-year renewal has gone to the last minute of bargaining, with tough talk by both sides. **********This time, the Socialist Government of Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez has linked a referendum last year on whether Spain should remain in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to a reduction of the American military, particularly the 72 F-16's at Torrejon Air Base near here. The referendum gave narrow approval to staying in NATO, and now many Spaniards expect to see the soldiers and planes go.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/07/world.main_headline: MARCOS AND WIFE LOSE CONTEMPT-ORDER APPEAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/07/world.print_headline: MARCOS AND WIFE LOSE CONTEMPT-ORDER APPEAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/07/world.body_text: **********Former President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines and his wife, Imelda, today lost an appeal of a contempt order stemming from their refusal to give documents to a grand jury investigating reports of corruption on arms contracts. **********The ruling, by a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, applied only to the question of supplying documents and not to testimony by the Marcoses. **********''We express no view with regard to any refusal on the part of the Marcoses to testify before the grand jury should they be given testimonial immunity,'' the court said. **********The panel, without dissent, ruled that Mr. Marcos and his wife, were not entitled to the immunity granted heads of state and were not shielded by guarantees against self-incrimination. **********The Marcoses were subpoenaed in January to testify and supply documents to a Federal grand jury in Alexandria, Va., that is investigating the handling of arms contracts involving American companies and the Philippine Government. **********Mr. Marcos moved to quash the subpoenas, invoking head-of-state immunity and the privilege against self-incrimination under both the United States and Philippine Constitutions. **********But the Marcoses have been granted immunity from prosecution in the United States based on the documents, and the panel said the Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination provides no protection from prosecution under foreign law. **********As a result, Federal District Judge Claude M. Hilton of Alexandria denied the motion to quash. **********Judge Hilton held the couple in contempt after their counsel said the documents would not be produced.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/07/world.main_headline: SENATE DEMOCRATS QUESTION PLAN FOR 'STAR WARS' ADVISORY INSTITUTION
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/07/world.print_headline: SENATE DEMOCRATS QUESTION PLAN FOR 'STAR WARS' ADVISORY INSTITUTION
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/07/world.body_text: **********A Pentagon plan to set up a research institute on ''Star Wars'' came under criticism today from Democratic senators who questioned whether it could provide independent advice. **********A senior Defense Department official told a Congressional panel that a federally financed institute was needed to provide independent advice on how best to manage the Strategic Defense Initiative program for research on a space-based missile defense. **********''We need, as it were, a Howard Cosell for the S.D.I.,'' said Brig. Gen. Malcolm O'Neill, a deputy director at the Strategic Defense Initiative Organization, who likened the independent advice to be provided by the new institute to the provocative comments of the sports commentator. **********A top industry official also backed the Pentagon proposal today at the joint hearing of panels of the Senate Armed Services and Governmental Affairs Committes. The president of the Martin Marietta Corporation and a former Pentagon official, Norman R. Augustine, said he believed a federally financed research center to help guide ''Star Wars'' was needed. The Matter of Influence **********But Senator Carl Levin, Democrat of Michigan, criticized the plan. He said the Pentagon's Strategic Defense Initiative Organization might have too much influence over the research center and suggested that it might not be truly independent. **********Mr. Levin also warned of a possible conflict of interest. He said some nongovernmental advisers to the Strategic Defense Initiative Organization had apparently encouraged the establishment of the new research institute and might seek high-paying jobs in it. Mr. Levin said a proposal under review by the Pentagon would pay the director of the institute $225,000 a year and other senior staff members an average of $110,000 a year. **********Some arms-control groups that oppose ''Star Wars'' also oppose the center because they are concerned that it would help institutionalize President Reagan's project. **********In a separate arms-control development, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted today in favor of a measure that would endorse the traditional, restrictive interpretation of the Anitballistic Missile Treaty. **********The vote was basically along party lines. Senator Nancy L. Kassebaum of Kansas was the only Republican to vote for the measure, although Senator Daniel J. Evans, Republican of Washington, said he might vote for a similar measure later after he has had more time to review the issue. **********The House, as expected, voted 245 to 181 in favor of an amendment to require the United States to adhere to key limits in the unratified second strategic arms treaty of 1979. The amendment is to a bill authorizing a military budget for fiscal 1988 of $288 billion. General Proposed Idea **********According to Defense Department documents made available by staff members to Mr. Levin, the basic idea for a new research institute was put forward by a retired Air Force general, Bernard A. Schriever, a member of a committee of outside experts that advises the Strategic Defense Initiative Organization. Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger endorsed the idea.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/05/busin.main_headline: Kodak Campaign Set On Nonconsumer Items
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/05/busin.print_headline: ADVERTISING; Kodak Campaign Set On Nonconsumer Items
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/05/busin.body_text: **********The J. Walter Thompson Company has designed an umbrella campaign for Eastman Kodak to use to promote most of its nonconsumer products. The theme is ''The new vision of Kodak'' and it is the first effort of its kind in the history of the company. **********The campaign covers seven lines of business and four subsidiaries, each of which in the past went its separate way with advertising. Now there is one look and the beginnings of a $50 million international print campaign that has already begun to appear in trade publications and will start showing up in business publications in May. **********The ads, all four-color, two-page spreads, will build on Kodak's fame in the consumer area to attract the reader's eye to copy on its efforts in business markets, health care and printing and publishing. The whole left-hand page accommodates the big block-letter headline, ''A Lifetime of Memories Captured by Kodak.'' The right-hand page, surprisingly, carries a photograph and information on an optical disk that carries 100,000 pages of information. **********Earlier this week at a news conference at the Marriott Marquis, where details of the ad campaign were disclosed, Kodak showed a new optical disk storage system that can store more than a trillion bytes of information.

Eastern said it had also eliminated another 60 positions that were vacant. An Eastern spokesman, Jim Ashlock, said the cuts were part of a sweeping budget review that could mean further layoffs. **********Eastern was acquired in November by the Houston-based Texas Air Corporation. [ Page A1. ]  Prime Minister Brian Mulroney has walked a political tightrope in the talks.  [ D5. ]  The accord establishes a model for the free-trade reforms America is seeking internationally. https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/29/busin.main_headline: ADT TAKES RAISED BID FROM HAWLEY OF BRITAIN
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/29/busin.print_headline: ADT TAKES RAISED BID FROM HAWLEY OF BRITAIN
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/29/busin.body_text: **********ADT Inc., the nation's leading supplier of fire and burglar alarms, yesterday accepted a $52-a-share takeover offer, worth $715 million, from Britain's Hawley Group Ltd. **********The agreement came just over a week after the Parsippany, N.J., security systems concern had rejected a $47-a-share, $635 million bid from the rapidly expanding services conglomerate. **********''We are extremely pleased that Hawley has recognized ADT's true value and momentum,'' said Raymond B. Carey Jr., ADT's 60-year-old chairman and chief executive. Mr. Carey will continue to run ADT, which was formerly known as American District Telegraph, and will become a member of Hawley's board. The tender offer is expected to begin next week. Earnings Rebounded Last Year **********ADT earned $23.2 million on sales of $519 million last year, when it rebounded from three years of decline that had resulted in write-offs and a loss in 1985. It has completely replaced its product line over the last five years and spent $70 million developing computer-controlled security systems, according to Mr. Carey. Such systems monitor a range of devices that detect entry, hazardous conditions and other security problems and alert watchmen when an unusual event is occurring. **********Wall Street's view that Hawley would need to sweeten its bid became apparent when ADT's share price rose to more than $50 in trading on the New York Stock Exchange in the three days following Hawley's Aug. 17 offer. ADT shares rose 75 cents yesterday, to $51.375, following the announcement of the agreement. **********The takeover will make Hawley the market leader in electronic security services in the United States, ahead of Honeywell Inc. and Wells Fargo & Company. Hawley bought the Electro-Protective Corporation in 1981 and expanded its presence earlier this year with the acquisition of Crime Control Inc. No Change in Management **********Mr. Carey said that he and Michael A. Ashcroft, Hawley's 41-year-old chief executive, ''respected each other instinctively.'' Yesterday's announcement indicated that ADT's management would remain intact. In addition, Mr. Carey said, provision has been made to continue a 10-year-old profit-sharing and investment plan that had resulted in more than 11 percent of ADT's shares being held by its employees. **********However, analysts do not expect Mr. Ashcroft to leave ADT with a free hand for long unless earnings continue to rise substantially. Mr. Ashcroft has the reputation of wringing higher profits from his acquisitions by putting their management under the surveillance of lieutenants who are paid according to how well they meet tight operating and financial guidelines. **********Hawley earned $83.2 million on sales of $841.8 million last year from its portfolio of service companies in cleaning and building maintenance, hospital maintenance and food supply, and security services. Series of British Purchases **********The deal is one of a string involving British penetration of the United States service sector in recent weeks. The WPP Group acquired the JWT Group last month for $566 million. And a week ago, Manpower Inc. accepted a $1.33 billion takeover bid from Blue Arrow P.L.C. **********Hawley is already unusually trans-Atlantic in its focus. American investors hold more than one-fourth of its shares, and operations in the United States account for two-thirds of its business. British analysts said that the bid for ADT was strategically sound, but the London stock market has reacted negatively to Hawley's plans to issue $400 million in preferred shares, with an annual dividend of roughly 6 percent, to help finance it. **********Hawley's share price quickly fell, from 170 pence to 154 pence, in trading on the London Stock Exchange following the Aug. 17 bid. The stock closed yesterday at 154.6 pence, up about a pence from Thursday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/30/busin.main_headline: Lack of British Interest Seen in Eurotunnel Sale
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/30/busin.print_headline: Lack of British Interest Seen in Eurotunnel Sale
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/30/busin.body_text: **********Despite a multimillion-dollar advertising campaign appealing both to national pride and to private gain, British private investors have apparently shown only limited interest in the shares of Eurotunnel, the British-French consortium that plans to build a tunnel beneath the English Channel. **********The offer to buy shares closed last Friday, and early tabulations indicate that as much as 20 percent of the shares available to British investors will be left unsold. The shortfall does not mean that the 31-mile tunnel, which would link Britain and France, will be halted because of a lack of financing. **********Banks and securities houses agreed to underwrite the $:770 million ($1.4 billion) equity issue two weeks ago, and they will buy any shares not purchased by the public. Moreover, the final counting of applications continued during the weekend, with the results to be announced on Monday. French Response Also Weak **********Yet the lukewarm reception for the shares is an embarrassment to Eurotunnel and a disappointment to its underwriters, suggesting a lack of investor enthusiasm and public support for a project that advertisements hailed as ''A Breakthrough for Britain.'' **********In France, where investors were urged to make a ''Rendezvous with History,'' the reception from private investors is thought to be not much better, although it is harder to measure the French response because the applications were being collected at hundreds of local bank branches. **********Throughout the effort to sign up underwriters, Eurotunnel and its advisers assured the financial institutions that private investors were very interested in the venture, giving the prospective underwriters the impression that there was little risk. For example, Dewe Rogerson Ltd., Eurotunnel's advertising and marketing consultant, reported that more than 550,000 people in Britain seemed certain to apply for shares. Many International Subscribers **********However, it appears that fewer than 150,000 people applied for the $:353 million ($635.4 million) worth of Eurotunnel shares offered in Britain. A similar amount is being sold in France, with the remainder sold as a private placement to institutional investors in the United States, Japan and the rest of continental Europe. The international private placement was reportedly fully subscribed. **********For British underwriters, who suffered big losses in a huge British Petroleum selloff a month ago, the Eurotunnel offering comes as another difficult new issue. Given tepid public demand for the Eurotunnel issue, it appears likely that the shares will fall a bit below the issue price of 350 pence ($6.30) when trading begins on Dec. 10. **********Eurotunnel tried to attract individual investors with free travel for long-term holders of its shares. In addition, the message to both individual and institutional investors was that the Eurotunnel, which will not open for six years, was an investment little affected by the recent stock market collapse. **********The Eurotunnel share prospectus, given its assumptions about cross-channel traffic and prices, forecast that by 1995 the original 350-pence investment could be worth $:24, or $43.20 at current exchange rates.
