https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/14/world.body_text: **********At the Iran-contra hearings today, Colonel North was questioned about the activites of David Walker, a Briton who was involved in covert military operations against the Nicaraguan Government. Following is an excerpts from that exchange, as recorded by The New York Times. **********REPRESENTATIVE THOMAS S. FOLEY, Democrat of Washington. David Walker is an international arms and security specialist who is a British subject. Is that right? **********COLONEL NORTH. That is my understanding. Yes, sir. **********Q. Did you authorize or have any discussions with him regarding activities inside Nicaragua? **********A. I did. **********Q. Did you authorize him to perform military actions in Nicaragua? **********A. I did. **********Q. What were those actions? **********A. David Walker was involved -his organization - as I understand it, in support of the Nicaraguan resistance with internal operations in Managua and elsewhere in an effort to improve the perception that the Nicaraguan resistance could operate anywhere that it so desired. **********Q. I'm talking about military actions, attacks on military aircraft of the-- **********A. Yes sir. **********Q. --Sandinista Government. **********A. Yes. **********Q. Did you directly authorize them? **********A. I don't - I didn't directly authorize anything. **********Q. Did you report that recommendation to Admiral Poindexter? **********A. I did. **********Q. Did he approve it? **********A. I reported what I thought was a, a good idea for certain expertise that the Nicaraguan resistance did not have as a consequence of insufficient training, insufficient operational capability.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/27/busin.main_headline: 'PREWAR' BUILDING RISES ON THE EAST SIDE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/27/busin.print_headline: ABOUT REAL ESTATE; 'PREWAR' BUILDING RISES ON THE EAST SIDE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/27/busin.body_text: **********At 30 East 85th Street, Donald Zucker is trying to create a prewar building - plaster walls and all. **********Those walls, however, are at once a bane and boon to the Manhattan developer. The general quality of the building's construction, from cherry wood floors to solid wood doors, has attracted interest. But the people who can afford $850 a square foot - the average cost in this 30-story condominium tower - are also the ones who want huge residences, not one-bedroom apartments. And 53 of the 104 units, as originally designed, are one-bedroom apartments. **********How is Mr. Zucker dealing with the problem? ''With a big hammer,'' he said. ''The head of my construction department looks at me like I'm crazy every time I come to him with a change. But people are willing to pay for it.'' **********Many requests have come from prospective buyers to knock down walls and combine apartments, and the number of units will be reduced to 90 by the time the building is ready in June, he said. **********They are also willing to pay for some of the most expensive new condominiums to rise recently on the Upper East Side, largely because of their Central Park views, lavish building materials and prime location at the southwest corner of Madison Avenue and 85th Street. About 40 percent of the building is sold. **********Conventional new condominiums in Manhattan sell for an average of $350 a square foot, but Mr. Zucker's building is expensive even in comparison with other exceptional buildings in prime locations. ''These prices are very, very, very high,'' said Yale Robbins, president of a namesake consulting and publishing concern that tracks trends in condominium sales. ''The top of the market in new construction comes in at around $700 a square foot.'' **********Three studios, measuring 620 square feet, run from $310,000 to $335,000. The 53 one-bedrooms, 845 feet to 1,100 feet, range from $400,000 to $670,000. Thirty-one two-bedrooms, 1,200 to 1,600 feet, cost between $570,000 and $1.6 million. Twelve three-bedrooms, 1,900 to 2,200 feet, are priced from $1.2 million to $1.7 million. One four-bedroom of 2,500 feet, with a 2,800-square-foot terrace, costs $1.75 million. **********On the top two floors, four custom-designed duplexes with four bedrooms and a maid's room off the kitchen are being offered for $5 million each. **********The apartments are expensive in part because Mr. Zucker paid $23 million early in 1985 for the 15,000-square-foot vacant parcel. ''I could never afford to pay that price if I didn't go with the absolute, top luxury job,'' he said. **********In addition, he purchased the air rights to three buildings to the south along Madison Avenue for $1.5 million, enabling the architect, Schuman Lichtenstein Claman & Efron of Manhattan, to create a larger, thus more cost-effective, structure. Mr. Zucker put the total cost of the building at ''well over $60 million''; the overall sellout price on the condominiums is $96,967,000. **********The salmon-colored brick building rises 11 stories along Madison Avenue and five stories on 85th Street, as required by local zoning regulations, before it steps back significantly to the tower above. At the top is a tapered glass roof, to be illuminated from within, serving as a beacon and concealing the water tower. **********''We tried to retain the feeling of the grand style of residential construction done in the early part of the 20th century, as epitomized by the residential towers along Central Park West and Fifth Avenue,'' said James Davidson of Schuman Lichtenstein. **********About 23,000 square feet of retail space on two floors will front on Madison Avenue. The ground floor will rent for $125 to $225 a square foot, and the second floor for $75 a foot. **********But there are elements in the building that seem to derive more from the 1980's style of splendor than pre-World War II apartments, such as the cherry wood floors in a herringbone pattern in the living rooms and bedrooms and the polished granite floors in the kitchens. **********The oversized picture windows were imported from the Netherlands; the glass and ash-blond kitchen cabinets came from France, and the kitchen sink from Germany. All the bathrooms have marble walls and floors and six-foot tubs with whirlpool baths. More than half of the apartments have balconies and 18 have terraces. **********A few things, however, were left out, such as a health club and a name. ''Prewar buildings never have names,'' said Louise M. Sunshine, president of the Sunshine Group Ltd. of Manhattan, the building's marketing agent. **********Monthly maintenance charges will range from $300 to $1,422. Pending expected approval by the city of an application for a tax abatement under the Section 421-a program, the real estate taxes on individual units will run from about $100 to $445 a month. Without that exemption, taxes would range from about $650 to $2,940.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/06/world.main_headline: Kuwait Expels Iran Envoys After Attack
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/06/world.print_headline: Kuwait Expels Iran Envoys After Attack
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/06/world.body_text: **********Kuwait said today that it was expelling five Iranian diplomats as tension mounted between the two Persian Gulf countries over Iranian missiles fired at Kuwait. **********Iran apparently fired another long-range missile on Kuwait early this morning, reports from Kuwait said. It was the third reported missile firing in four days. **********Kuwait, whose officials fear a spread of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's Shiite Moslem fundamentalist revolution, has supported Iraq in its seven-year war with Iran. **********Hostilities in the area have increased markedly since last Saturday, when Iraq renewed attacks on oil tankers. Today, Iraq said its warplanes hit their 14th and 15th Iranian tankers this week. No Indication of Casualities **********The Foreign Ministry Under Secretary, Suleiman Majid al-Shaheen, summoned the Iranian charge d'affaires to inform him that the five diplomats, out of a delegation of seven, must leave the country in a week. **********It is relatively rare for Arab countries, which seek to avoid the appearance of conflict, to expel diplomatic envoys. But Egypt and Tunisia have recently expelled Iranian diplomats, saying they were inciting local fundamentalists. **********Earlier, Mr. al-Shaheen called in the Ambassadors of the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council to complain about the incident. Kuwait filed a formal protest with the United Nations on Friday. **********Meanwhile the latest convoy of tankers, escorted by five American warships, made it through the Strait of Hormuz today without incident, reports in the region said. **********Two Liberian supertankers and an Iranian frigate followed the convoy, apparently for its protection against mines and other hazards. **********Kuwait's Defense Ministry announced the missile attack on Friday, but there was no confirmation from the Government or the state news agency of today's attack. **********But Kuwaiti residents said a loud explosion woke many people up about 5 A.M. **********''A lot of people in our community heard the explosion at five o'clock this morning,'' a Western diplomat said. Explosion Heard Wednesday **********An explosion was also heard in Kuwait on Wednesday morning, and diplomats said it was believed to have been a missile landing in nearby waters. **********There was speculation among the diplomats that the missiles might be Chinese-made Silkworms fired by Iran from a battery set up in the former Iraqi oil port of Fao, captured by Iran in early 1986. **********Kuwait is a target of Iranian wrath because it has backed Iraq in the war. Protection Arranged **********Kuwait's policy has also caused strains with its large Shiite Moslem minority - about a third of the population - many of whom are ethnic Persians with ties to Iran. A pro-Iranian Shiite underground has set off a series of bombs in Kuwait's oil fields, With Iraq resuming attacks on Iranian oil shipping, after a six-week lull awaiting response to a United Nations cease-fire call, Iran has vowed to attack Baghdad's economic supporters. **********After a series of Iranian attacks last year on ships using its harbor, Kuwait arranged protection for its oil fleet with both the Soviet Union and the United States, which allowed 11 tankers to be re-registered as American ships. **********Kuwait's Foreign Minister, Sheik Sabah al-Ahmed al-Sabah, a member of the ruling family, blamed Iran for the missile attack Friday in a letter to United Nations Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar. **********''Iran fired a missile at some residential buildings and industrial installations in the south of Kuwait,'' said the letter, released in New York. **********It said the missile on Friday and a raid on a Kuwaiti container ship were not the only attacks last week. **********''In fact, Kuwait has overlooked some of the Iranian attacks launched during that period and did not report them to you,'' the letter said. **********The Secretary General is to visit both Baghdad and Teheran shortly to press for a cease-fire resolution. **********Iran stressed again today that no peace was possible unless Iraq was punished as the aggressor in the war.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/02/world.main_headline: ATTACKS IN HAITI CONTINUE IN SLUM
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/02/world.print_headline: ATTACKS IN HAITI CONTINUE IN SLUM
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/02/world.body_text: **********While many downtown stores opened for the first time today since Sunday's aborted election, and life in much of Port-au-Prince continued to return to normal, residents of one section of the capital fled continued attacks from heavily armed thugs. **********It was the fourth day of attacks against residents of the neighborhood, Carrefour Feuille, a sprawling hillside slum on the southern edge of Port-au-Prince. The attackers - described variously as policemen, soldiers and remnants of the violent, shadowy former militia known as the Tontons Macoute - apparently sought to punish members of civilian groups organized here to protect voters. **********The thugs were said to have singled out the neighborhood for reprisals because it was reportedly one of the first areas in which the groups, known as vigilance brigades, sprang up. **********Many of those unable to afford a taxi to take family and belongings to other areas, or to escape the capital completely, as numerous people have done, have had to endure daily acts of terrorist violence here. 'Death Signs' on Doors **********In the narrow, rubble-strewn paths that separate the small cinder-block houses on the steep hillside, residents today told of shootings, beatings and arrests they say have continued sporadically since early Sunday. **********On some houses, red felt markers or other objects - which some called ''death signs'' - were stuck to doors, indicating, according to residents, places targeted for reprisals. **********On one narrow street a crowd of residents gathered to tell about their experiences. **********''Many people were beaten here,'' one man said, talking about Monday. ''It happened throughout the morning and afternoon.'' **********Another said: ''They came and arrested lots of people here. If you are a man over 16 years old, they'll take you away.'' Empty Homes **********''We ran away,'' a woman said. ''A lot of families just moved to the countryside.'' **********In a wealthier section of Carrefour Feuille, just down the hill, many large homes stood empty. **********One member of a rare family moving back said, ''We got out of here Saturday night, just after the first shots were fired.'' Family members said they had not heard a complete account of the neighborhood's suffering, but had decided to return anyway. **********In the tin-roofed houses of the poorer residents, however, traces of the violence were apparent. In one house, a one-and-a-half-year-old girl with a shrapnel wound in the leg whined while her father showed a reporter a wall blasted by explosives. Sunlight shone through the ceiling where gunfire had left large holes. Bullet-Pocked Walls **********In another house, a young mother, Paintite Bouche, pointed to her roof, saying a grenade had torn it apart Sunday night, leaving two women and two boys seriously wounded. All around, there were bullet holes on the unpainted cement walls. **********Many residents of Carrefour Feuille said they had no idea why their neighborhood had been singled out for continued violence while most of the capital was largely peaceful. Some foreigners said the area had been the birthplace of the vigilance brigades. **********Some residents said that the red felt markers on the doors of some houses indicated they were the homes of organizers of vigilance brigades. **********Reporters touring the area today were stopped briefly and questioned by a man who jumped out of a large truck. After explaining that they were Americans seeking to see as much of the city as possible, they were allowed to go. **********Neighborhood residents cautioned that the man was either a member of the Tontons Macoute or a plainclothes policeman. The reporters were urged to leave the area immediately.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/12/busin.main_headline: Dollar at New Lows After Tokyo Selloff
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/12/busin.print_headline: Dollar at New Lows After Tokyo Selloff
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/12/busin.body_text: **********The dollar sagged to new lows in fairly light trading yesterday. Dealers said that support from the Japanese and West German central banks, as well as profit taking following Thursday's huge declines, helped to prevent a deeper drop. **********Meanwhile, gold prices, which are closely tied to the dollar's performance, advanced again on the Commodity Exchange in New York, while silver edged down slightly.  [ Page 50. ]  Gold was quoted at $497.25 an ounce at 4 P.M. at the Republic National Bank in New York, up from $493.50 late Thursday. **********The bulk of the dollar's decline occurred during overnight trading in Tokyo, where dealers sold dollars in reaction to October's $17.6 billion trade deficit. Pushed Below 129 Yen **********The selloff, which immediately pushed the dollar below the 129-yen level it touched late Thursday in New York, was blunted by the Bank of Japan. ''Whenever the dollar sank to 128 yen, the Bank of Japan was in the market,'' said Richard E. Witten, a vice president in the foreign exchange department at Goldman, Sachs & Company. ''That happened throughout the session in Tokyo. '' **********Dealers in Europe and New York were reluctant to try to break that barrier, and the yen remained in a narrow trading range for the remainder of the day. **********In late New York trading, the dollar was bid at 128.30 yen, down slightly from Thursday's close of 129 yen. **********Rumored intervention by the West German Bundesbank also seemed to deter traders from pushing the dollar significantly lower against the mark. The dollar did break through 1.63 marks during trading in Europe, but dealers backed off when the Bundesbank appeared to intervene at the 1.6260-mark level. Lower Than Thursday Close **********The move bolstered the dollar slightly, and in late New York trading the dollar was bid at 1.6305 marks, marginally lower than Thursday's close of 1.6330 marks. **********Yesterday's small declines in the dollar came on top of Thursday's huge drop and left the dollar 2.2 percent lower against the mark and 3.1 percent lower against the yen than it was a week ago. **********Traders backed off from selling even more dollars yesterday, despite a report by Market News Service that an unidentified senior official of the Reagan Adminstration had said that the Administration remained opposed to supporting the dollar. **********The Market News Service report, which flashed across dealers' screens during late-morning trading in New York, said the official had also said that the Administration was disinclined to enter any new agreement with its trading partners that would attempt to stabilize exchange rates at any given level. Comment by White House **********A White House spokesman later said that, ''if the story is not quoting the President of the United States or the Secretary of the Treasury, it is not authoritative.'' **********That comment came well after traders had shrugged off the story. In the wake of Thursday's trade deficit figure, dealers have assumed that the Administration would like to see the dollar move lower and that it is not prepared to meet its economic allies until a further decline has occurred. **********Light holiday trading could create some bizarre gyrations for the dollar between now and the year's end, traders said. But the longer-term outlook is clear, they added. **********''It is still pretty obvious that the dollar still has another 5 to 10 percent to go on the down side,'' said Dan Brooks, vice president and chief foreign exchange dealer at the Bank of America's New York office. ''But the market is going to tip-toe down to those levels, partly because we are in places we have never been before.'' Drop to 120 Yen Predicted **********In the coming year, Mr. Brooks said, the Bank of America expected the dollar to settle in the mid-1.50-mark range and to bring about 120 yen. ''At those levels we will probably start hearing something from the Administration that even more declines won't materially help the trade balance,'' he said. **********Economists at the WEFA Group in Bala Cynwyd, Pa., are forecasting a dollar that will be about 7 percent lower against the mark a year from now, to around the 1.50 level. Like the Bank of America, the WEFA analysts expect the dollar to drop to about 120 yen. **********Those declines could well represent the end of a drop in the dollar that began in February 1985. **********But Craig Shular, director of currency and interest rate risk management at the Union Carbide Corporation, said the dollar was not likely to begin to rise in value immediately after it hits bottom. ''We are likely to have a rolling bottom for the dollar for a year or two,'' he added. ''It is going to take at least that long to have a big impact on the trade account.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/30/world.body_text: **********Several Federal agencies are pressing at least seven criminal investigations of the Nicaraguan rebels and their American backers, even as President Reagan is urging Congress to provide new aid for the contras. **********A review of the investigations has uncovered several previously undisclosed charges - so far unproved - involving the contras as well as investigations that had not been known. **********For example, Congressional sources disclosed this week that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had opened a criminal investigation to determine what happened to most of the $27 million for nonlethal supplies for the rebels that Congress approved in 1985. A General Accounting Office report published earlier said most of it could not be traced. **********Investigators also disclosed in the last several days that the G.A.O. had begun a separate inquiry into the whereabouts of millions of dollars that were apparently supposed to be funneled to the contras in Nicaragua from the sale of American weapons to Iran. **********Other open investigations, most of them previously known, focus on charges that the contras or their backers smuggled arms, trafficked in drugs, laundered money or violated the Neutrality Act, which bars Americans from involvement in military efforts against countries not at war with the United States. **********In addition to these inquiries, a special prosecutor and two Congressional committees examining the Iran-contra affair are investigating charges of illegality tied to the contras. New Aid Sought **********The investigations pose a dilemma for the Reagan Adminstration. As it pushes for additional support for the contras, the Administration is also compelled by statute to investigate reports that the rebels might have broken the law. The Administration is asking Congress for $105 million in aid for the contras for the fiscal year that begins next October. **********Investigators say President Reagan's outspoken public support for the contras has made it difficult for prosecutors and other Federal agents to carry on their work. Law enforcement officials have repeatedly denied accusations that, because of Administration pressure, their inquiries were unnecessarily slow or incomplete. **********The investigations are being conducted by a variety of agencies, including the Justice Department, the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Customs Service and the General Accounting Office, among others. Prosecutor May Take Over **********A number of the investigations are expected to be turned over to the special prosecutor in the Iran-contra case, Lawrence E. Walsh. In announcing his appointment as independent counsel, a three-judge panel asked Mr. Walsh to investigate the sale of weapons to Iran and the reports by the White House that millions of dollars in profits from the sales had been diverted to the contras. **********He was also given authority to study charges that the contras received other possibly illegal support in their war against the Sandinista Government in Nicaragua. **********These are the Federal investigations known to involve the contras or their supporters: *********** An investigation by the United States Attorney in Miami of charges that weapons were smuggled to the contras from a Florida airport in 1985. *********** An investigation by the same office of a Miami-based cargo carrier that has been involved both in the Iran arms sales and the secret efforts to supply the contras. *********** An investigation in Georgia of the sale of four small planes, including one reportedly sold to the contras in 1985. *********** A criminal investigation of what happened to the $27 million Congress granted to the rebels in 1985. *********** A separate investigation by the General Accounting Office of the Iran arms case. *********** A Federal investigation of charges that the Americans taking arms to the rebels also smuggled drugs. *********** An F.B.I. investigation of a burglary at the offices of a group that has opposed the Administration's policies in Central America. Arms Smuggling Charged **********The United States Attorney in Miami, Leon B. Kellner, has been involved in two of the most widely publicized investigations. **********The first, begun in 1985, involves allegations that a large quantity of weapons were smuggled to the contras from an airport in Fort Lauderdale. The purported shipment could have been a violation of the Neutrality Act. **********Early last year, prosecutors were confronted with charges from a man who asserted that he had helped in the shipment. The witness, Jesus Garcia, was then in prison awaiting sentence on weapons charges. **********With information from the F.B.I. and the statements by Mr. Garcia, Mr. Kellner's office opened an investigation that continued through 1986. A grand jury took the case last fall. **********The inquiry has been subjected to criticism from, among others, Senator John D. Kerry, a Massachusetts Democrat whose office has studied the case. He has said that the investigation moved too slowly and that valuable witnesses and evidence were ignored. **********But Justice Department officials, including Mr. Kellner, have denied the charges. They say the inquiry has been hindered because, in some cases, witnesses have offered one account to reporters and lawmakers, but are unwilling to provide the same account to prosecutors. Pressure by Meese Denied **********The officials note, for example, that no witness have been able to offer testimony indicating that they saw anything more than a few large weapons being loaded in Fort Lauderdale. News accounts have indicated that tons of arms were sent from the Florida airport. **********Mr. Kellner denied reports indicating that he had come under pressure from Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d to delay the investigation to prevent damage to the Administration's contra-support campaign. **********The second investigation by Mr. Kellner's office involves Southern Air Transport, a Miami-based cargo carrier involved in both the Iran arms sale and the secret efforts to supply the contras. According to law-enforcement officials, the Customs Service in Miami brought the case to Mr. Kellner late last year. **********The Customs inquiry, involving potential violations of Federal arms export laws, was prompted by the crash in Nicaragua last October of a C-123 cargo plane containing weapons meant for the contras. Crewman Seized by Nicaragua **********The only surviving member of the four-man crew, Eugene Hasenfus, was released by the Nicaraguan Government last month and has been extensively questioned by the Customs Service and the F.B.I. The special House committee investigating the Iran-contra affair questioned Mr. Hasenfus today. **********In interviews, Mr. Hasenfus has said he worked for the Central Intelligence Agency. Southern Air, formerly owened by the C.I.A., has acknowledged that it held a contract to service planes used in the operation. **********According to officials, F.B.I. agents have begun a separate investigation of the C-123 crash, although their inquiry has not yet resulted in a grand-jury review in Miami. **********The Customs and F.B.I. investigations were suspended for more than three weeks last autumn at the direction of Attorney General Meese. Mr. Meese said he sought the delay at the urging of Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter, then the national security adviser. **********The propriety of the delay is now under investigation by the Justice Department's Office of Professional Responsibility and by the F.B.I., officials disclosed. **********In Macon, Ga., the Customs Service and the United States Attorney's office have led an investigation into the sale of four small-engined planes, including one that was reportedly sold to contra forces in 1985. The short takeoff and landing planes were manufactured by Maule Air Inc. of Moultrie, Ga. One was bought in 1984 by a company then headed by a retired Air Force major general, Richard V. Secord. General Denies Wrongdoing **********General Secord has emerged as a leading figure in the dispute over arms sales to Iran and the diversion of funds to the contras. He is also reported to have had extensive involvement in efforts to supply the contras. **********According to published accounts, General Secord has acknowledged that his company sold the plane for $49,000 to the contras in 1985. But in an interview today, General Secord's lawyer, Thomas C. Green, said he had no knowledge that the plane had been sold to the contras. The general, he said, ''emphatically'' denies wrongdoing. **********Justice Department officials would not discuss other details of the case, although they said that a grand jury in Macon was trying to determine if exports laws had been violated in the sale. **********Congressional aides say the F.B.I. in Washington is also conducting a criminal investigation to find out what happened to the $27 million in ''humanitarian assistance'' Congress granted to the Nicaraguan rebels in 1985. The investigation followed a report last year by the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, that said investigators had been unable to determine what happened to nearly two-thirds of the money. **********According to the report, investigators found at least one instance in which money was spent on ammunition and grenades, a violation of the Congressional act that provided the aid. Arms Deal Investigated **********At the request of at least three lawmakers, the G.A.O. has begun a separate, extensive investigation into the Iran arms deal and what happened to the profits, some of which were supposedly intended for the contras. **********Officials on Capitol Hill said the G.A.O. had been asked to determine exactly what had happened to the money paid by Iran. Tens of millions of dollars from the sale are still unaccounted for. **********''The bottom line is that the G.A.O. is supposed to find out where the hell that money is,'' one official said. **********The drug-related investigation concerns evidence uncovered last year that the military supply operation to the rebels also smuggled drugs on the return trips. **********According to Administration officials, investigators in El Salvador acting on information from the D.E.A. learned that the American flight crews covertly ferrying arms to the rebels returned to the United States by way of Panama, a major drug transshipment center, to pick up cocaine and marijuana. The special White House Commission investigating the Iran-contra affair is studying this allegation, officials said. **********The Justice Department announced this month that it had requested the F.B.I. investigation into a burgarly last November at the offices of a prominent Washington political group that has opposed the Administration's policies in Central America. **********Organizations opposed to the contras are hoping that the bureau's investigation will be expanded to study 35 similar incidents that have been documented around the country over the last two years. The groups have said the break-ins might have been organized by conservative groups supporting the Nicaraguan rebels. **********For the moment, however, the Justice Department has said it will deal only with the break-in at the Washington offices of the International Center for Development Policy. The center has said that its files were ransacked.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/02/busin.body_text: **********The Holly Sugar Corporation, a leading producer of beet sugar, said Friday that Shamrock Holding Inc. and Brookehill Equities Inc. had expressed an interest in acquiring the company. Responding to requests for corporate information by Shamrock and Brookehill, Holly said it had hired Allen & Company and Salomon Brothers Inc. as financial advisers to evaluate and solicit bids. **********Holly said last month that it had received an offer from Arcanum 1 Partners and certain senior management of Holly to acquire the company. The offer was for $35 a share in cash and one share of a new preferred stock with a $90 redemption value and an annual dividend of $7.20 starting March 31, 1988. No total value has been placed on the offer. Holly has about 1.1 million shares outstanding. Brookehill and Moran, Moors, Grossman & deRose Inc. each currently hold a 10 percent in Holly. **********Holly's common shares closed at $105.75, down 25 cents, in trading Friday on the New York Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/12/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Chemlawn Sale Talks Widen
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/12/busin.body_text: **********The Chemlawn Corporation, the target of a unsolicited tender offer by Waste Management Inc., said today that it was discussing the sale of its business with other parties. The disclosure was made in a **********Securities and Exchange Commission filing. Chemlawn would not elaborate. **********Despite its recent drop in earnings, Chemlawn, the nation's largest lawn-care company, has a well-known brand name and a base of at least 1.5 million customers who can afford services such as lawn and shrub care. Those characteristics, analysts said, could attract a wide variety of companies looking to expand into home services. **********Chemlawn last week rejected Waste Management's cash offer of $27 a share, or $270 million. Waste Management began the offer Feb. 27. **********Separately, Waste Management said today that it had filed a motion to dismiss an earlier claim filed against it by Chemlawn. Waste Management also said that Chemlawn had offered to supply it with financial information if Waste Management ceased its tender offer for 120 days. Waste Management, which is based in Oak Brook, Ill., said it had refused. The offer is scheduled to expire March 25.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/04/world.main_headline: New Violence Erupts in Haiti As Election Council Bars
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/04/world.print_headline: New Violence Erupts in Haiti As Election Council Bars
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/04/world.body_text: **********Violence flared again today in Haiti hours after a dozen associates of Francois and Jean-Claude Duvalier, the former dictators, were rejected as presidential candidates. **********The national election headquarters in the heart of the capital was broken into and set afire, and gunmen sprayed machine-gun fire at a smaller election office, the office of a centrist presidential candidate and the home of a Senate candidate. **********Another fire heavily damaged a hardware store owned by one of the nine members of the National Electoral Council, which is organizing the elections. **********The former aides to Francois and Jean-Claude Duvalier had issued veiled threats of a violencet if their candidacies were rejected. One, Clovis Desinor, a former Finance Minister, raised the specter of civil war. **********One of the most enthusiastically supported provisions of Haiti's newly adopted Constitution banned key members of the family dictatorship from running for public office for 10 years. In announcing their candidacies in mid-October, the Duvalier aides charged that the Constitution was discriminatory. They challenged the electoral council to try to enforce the ban. **********In a statement read over Port-au-Prince radio stations Monday night, the electoral council declared that 23 of the 35 men who had registered as presidential candidates were eligible. It did not name the rejected candidates but, Mr. Rocourt said, it was clear ''they were out.'' **********Among those rejected, in addition to Mr. Desinor, a 73-year-old lawyer who campaigned for the election of Francois Duvalier in 1957 and served for more than 11 years as his chief financial adviser, were Lieut. General Claude Raymond, retired, a former Chief of Staff under both Duvaliers, and several other former army officers and Cabinet ministers. **********In a statement this afternoon, Mr. Desinor indicated he would not accept the rejection of his candidacy. He charged that the electoral council's decision had been dictated by an unnamed foreign power and that the council had violated Haiti's election laws by failing, among other things, to give him a chance to defend his record. He ended his statement with his name and the words, ''Candidate to the presidency.'' **********Gunshots in the night and mysterious killings have become a part of life in Haiti since the Duvalier dictatorship collapsed in February 1986. **********The army-dominated provisional Government of Lieut. Gen. Henri Namphy has refused to provide protection or administrative support to the electoral council, feeding speculation in Haiti that it wants the elections to fail. **********Alain Rocourt, the head of the Methodist Church in Haiti and treasurer of the electoral council, said that while flames swept through all three stories of the election headquarters, destroying records and equipment, he thought it would still be possible to hold the presidential elections as scheduled on Nov. 29. **********''The election will take place as planned unless we are physically unable,'' Mr. Rocourt said. **********In spite of daily death threats, Mr. Rocourt said: ''We are continuing. We are carrying on.'' **********Three weeks ago a presidential candidate was shot to death in front of the national police headquarters, across the street from the presidential palace where General Namphy has his offices, and in August the leader of a moderate political party was hacked to death in a rural churchyard. No arrests have been made. **********Soldiers firing at point-blank range killed more than 30 demonstrators in protests during the summer after General Namphy's Government briefly seized control of the electoral process. But since then the streets have been left to unidentified gunmen in civilian clothes who many Haitians assume are either former members or associates of the Tontons Macoute, the army of thugs that the Duvaliers used to terrorize Haiti. **********Mr. Rocourt said the electoral council wrote to the provisional Government on Oct. 16 and on Oct. 26 asking for protection of its offices around the country and its members and that the Government did not reply. **********''This shows the contempt the authorities have for the electoral council,'' Mr. Rocourt told a reporter for The Associated Press. **********As dawn broke today, witnesses said that a curious crowd was milling around the charred entrance to the smoldering election headquarters, but that there was no sign of security forces. **********Richard N. Holwill, the Deputy Assistant Secretary of State in charge of Caribbean affairs, said in an interview from Washington that the United States was encouraging the provisional Government to support the electoral council and provide ''the needed security.'' **********''We have every reason to believe at this time that they are trying to do so,'' Mr. Holwill said. He said the electoral council had not notified the Government that it was going to announce the rejection of the candidacies Monday night, ''so they were not prepared.'' **********It was not clear to him that the council had formally asked for protection, he said, adding that he was not going to try to ''second-guess'' whether security forces should have been posted at the election headquarters. **********This evening a spokesman said the Government was investigating the fire at national election headquarters and had instructed the ''appropriate authorities'' to take security measures ''to guarantee the progress of the electoral process.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/08/busin.main_headline: THE A.M. STATIONS GO FOR A FACELIFT
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/08/busin.print_headline: WHAT'S NEW IN RADIO BROADCASTING; THE A.M. STATIONS GO FOR A FACELIFT
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/08/busin.body_text: **********THE AM band has been the ugly member of the radio family since FM sprouted in the 1950's. FM sounded better; it had better programming; and its signal was clear enough to remain stable on most radios. **********AM has tried desperately to catch up, but so far it has had little success. In a 1984 survey of public opinion about AM radio, Coleman Research, then a Dallas market research firm, found that 65 percent of the public would listen to FM over AM even if the two broadcast the same programming. **********But now, with new broadcasting technologies available, new efforts are being made to put fresh powder on AM's old face. ''It is our objective to obtain technical compatibility with FM broadcasting,'' said David E. Parigoni, senior vice president of radio at the broadcasters association. **********For example, many AM stations, hoping that the Federal Communications Commission would adopt industrywide standards for stereo braodcasting, have bought equipment that makes it possible for them to send stereo signals. But no standards have been set, so the AM stations are broadcasting blind, knowing that their signals are being badly converted on some radio receivers. **********''Tens of millions of dollars have been spent on AM stereo, but AM stereo is still a pipe dream,'' said Bruce Bishop Sheen, a media analyst for Paul Kagan. ''Anyone is foolish who says that the future of AM radio is in stereo.'' The industry has had better luck setting voluntary standards that encompass all forms of AM broadcasting. In January of this year, the National Radio Systems Committee - a joint committee of the National Association of Broadcasters and the Electronic Industries Association - released a set of frequency standards that both AM stations and manufacturers of radios are expected to adopt. **********Following the standards, the broadcasters association says, would involve little more than a few inexpensive modifications to the audioprocessor that modulates the sound to a proper frequency. The result would be that each station would focus more tightly on a single broadcast frequency, thus decreasing the amount it interferes with other stations. **********Manufacturers, meanwhile, have agreed to modify their radios in order to pick up the standardized signals more clearly. ''Adopting the standards is essentially going from the shotgun approach of broadcasting to the rifle approach,'' said Mr. Rau of the broadcasters association. Even if the new standards succeed in improving the quality of AM's sound, winning back the audience will be an uphill battle. It is a battle that many independent AM station owners are not willing to fight. They are selling out, often at near-fire sale prices. **********Over all, the market is still putting a much bigger premium on FM. Prices often climb over $100 million for FM stations; analysts say that WADO, an AM station in New York that was sold last year, commanded the year's highest price: $15 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/21/busin.body_text: **********Gap Inc., responding to queries about a $8.625-a-share drop in its stock on Friday, to $47.25, said during the weekend that its third-quarter earnings could range between 40 and 55 cents a share, compared with 60 cents a share last year. **********Gap, one of the nation's largest apparel chains, said it was making the statement because of ''the volatility in our stock price and the decline in the stock's value, even though it is too early to make any definitive statements on our third-quarter results.'' **********Noting that consumer apparel sales in general had slowed this quarter, the retail chain said it was likely that many retailers, including itself, would adopt an aggressive promotional policy to stimulate sales. **********Because of this, Gap said, its gross margins in the second half would decline from last year's second half. **********But, based on a revised business plan that assumed a continuation of sluggish buying, Gap said it was still expecting sales and earnings this year to be ahead of last year. In 1986, Gap earned $68 million, or a $1.93 a share, on sales of $848 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/04/busin.body_text: **********The Gulf States Utilities Company said that its condition has ''significantly deteriorated'' and that its operating cash reserves would be inadequate by May unless it received additional financing or rate relief from state authorities in Texas and Louisiana. In its newly released annual report and 10-K filing, Gulf States said that bank lenders had notified it last month that no additional credit would be granted. In addition, Gulf States said the banks had requested the utility to begin making prepayments by the end of this month that exceed its estimated lease payments.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/30/busin.main_headline: Peru Is Closer To Bank Law
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/30/busin.print_headline: Peru Is Closer To Bank Law
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/30/busin.body_text: **********The Congress approved a bill today allowing the state to take control of private banks, opening the way for President Alan Garcia to sign the measure into law. **********The Chamber of Deputies decided after a 12-hour debate not to insist on changes to a draft approved by the Senate Monday. Mr. Garcia was expected to sign it into law within days. **********The proposal to take over 10 private banks and 23 finance and insurance houses has dominated Peruvian political life since Mr. Garcia announced it in July. The bill would allow foreign banks with offices in Peru to continue operating, but would prohibit others from opening branches. Opposition senators and local bankers argued that this discriminated against local banks. **********Peru's senior private bankers said they would take every legal measure to prevent the takeover of their businesses.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/17/busin.body_text: **********Albert J. Lowry, the best known and most successful of the get-rich-quick artists who flourished from the late 1970's well into the 1980's, apparently never absorbed the lessons of financial discipline and security that he preached. **********For nearly two decades, in late-night television commercials, best-selling books and seminars in hotel meeting rooms across the country, Mr. Lowry sold the dream of wealth. He made a fortune mixing a salesman's persuasiveness with detailed theories about real estate and finance. The combination attracted hundreds of thousands of would-be millionaires willing to pay for his thoughts. **********But last month, in a stunning reversal, Mr. Lowry, hounded by creditors, filed for Chapter 7 bankruptcy in Federal court here. With his business and personal life in disarray, Mr. Lowry asked a judge to liquidate his $1 million in assets to satisfy lenders, partners and suppliers seeking at least several million dollars. Hard Times for Promoters **********Interviews with former associates and business partners as well as court documents from numerous lawsuits involving Mr. Lowry paint a picture of a bright, gregarious entrepreneur - part self-promoter, part teacher. His woes reflect the hard times among the latest generation of those who tout what are commonly known as get-rich-quick schemes, as well as his own poor investments. **********Mr. Lowry, along with others in the field, dispensed tips primarily designed to capitalize through real estate investments on the high inflation of the late 1970's and early 1980's. **********Mr. Lowry's advice won some adherents. But it was criticized as unworkable for most of the people who packed his seminars. Then, as inflation subsided, his kind of advice, and that of others, fell from favor. **********Details of Mr. Lowry's past and career remain murky. But according to the stories he related to students and associates, it appears that his rise was as steep and impressive as his fall. Born in Canada and raised in an orphanage, Mr. Lowry came to the United States with only a few dollars. He parlayed meager investments into a fortune and considerable fame. **********In his heyday Mr. Lowry offered advice on everything from buying real estate with no money down to running a small business and re-establishing credit. If the promise of big profits never materialized for most of his students, peddling his theories proved lucrative for him and his associates. According to court documents, Lowry enterprises grossed more than $40 million between 1969 and 1985. Two years ago he claimed a net worth of at least $12 million. **********Mr. Lowry, who is 60 years old, does not have a listed phone number, and he did not respond to a letter requesting an interview. His bankruptcy lawyer, Stephen Snipper, did not return telephone calls. **********To his supporters, Mr. Lowry remains a genius whose ideas and ability to convey them helped thousands of people attain a degree of financial sophistication, if not wealth. They say the ''get rich quick'' label is unfair. **********''Al Lowry was giving people tried and true methods that worked then, and still work now, and that allow you to make money if you really want to,'' said Tony Hoffman, a former associate. **********Mr. Hoffman, who took a course from Mr. Lowry a decade ago, invested successfully in real estate and then joined Mr. Lowry as an instructor in his seminars and a top official in his company. He now runs his own financial advice concern. **********''Al Lowry has made more money for more people in this country than anyone,'' Mr. Hoffman said. Unsophisticated Investors **********Critics then and now have contended that the Lowry strategies, most notably for buying real estate with no money down, would not succeed for the unsophisticated but ever-hopeful investors to whom Mr. Lowry most often appealed. **********Even former associates who defend the soundness of his strategies say that Mr. Lowry was mainly a salesman whose talent lay in persuading people to pay up to $495 to attend his weekend seminars. Former associates, some of whom asked not to be named, also said he was a poor manager, his investment-advice enterprises often operated in chaos and his financial judgment was flawed. **********An outgoing man with a curly toupee, Mr. Lowry seemed driven by a desire to be liked by all who met him, colleagues said. They said this trait may have led him to agree to risky business deals with friends and acquaintances. Questionable Investments **********His big mistake, they said, was investing in questionable ventures such as a health club, a restaurant and a movie instead of sticking to real estate, the field he knew best. ''He made some bad business decisions that did not involve real estate,'' said John Hebestreet, a real estate specialist in Ogden, Utah, who worked for Mr. Lowry and is now suing him over a $30,000 debt. **********But Mr. Lowry also appears to have gone astray in real estate. In an interview with The Los Angeles Times in April, more than a month before his Chapter 7 bankruptcy filing, he acknowledged having lost millions in real estate at Lake Tahoe. **********Mr. Lowry's harshest critics now may be his creditors, several of whom say he has been extremely elusive in the last two years as they have tried to collect debts ranging from a few thousand to hundreds of thousands of dollars. **********In Reno, Gordon and Ann Rupert are suing Mr. Lowry for $5,000 they say he owes them for roofing work several years ago on an apartment building he owned there. In Los Angeles, the California First Bank, which has won a $600,000 judgment against Mr. Lowry for unpaid loans plus interest on his health club investment, suggested in court papers this spring that he might have hidden assets, perhaps by transferring property to his former wife, Darlene, during their recent divorce. Mrs. Lowry's whereabouts could not be determined. $11.68 in Checking Account Many creditors, in fact, are wondering what happened to the wealth and property of which Mr. Lowry boasted several years ago. His bankruptcy filing said he had $11.68 in his checking account. And he said that he owes the Internal Revenue Service at least $138,675.65. His $895,000 home, which is mortgaged, is listed as his only major asset. The man who liked to be called ''Mr. Real Estate'' listed only three small parcels of land. **********''In any case like this, a lot of questions are raised by the kind of information he has presented,'' said Eric A. Joe, a lawyer with Smith & Smith in Los Angeles, representing California First Bank against Mr. Lowry. **********Until the last few years, Mr. Lowry's life seemed to be a true rags-to-riches tale. As he told it, he labored in a steel mill, ice-skated professionally and worked as a butcher before leaving Canada for California. Settling in the San Francisco area, he got involved in real estate sales. On several occasions he handled offers to buy property from sellers with no money down. To his amazement, some were accepted, prompting him to try the same, with considerable success. By 1973, Mr. Lowry asserted, he had made his first million dollars on property in Oakland. Selling Advice to Beginners **********According to court documents, Mr. Lowry had hit on the idea of selling real estate advice to others in 1969. The undertaking expanded rapidly. He started advertising that he held a Ph.D. in business administration, although it could not be determined when or where he might have received it. **********''Others had offered seminars to professional real estate people,'' one associate said. ''The genius of Lowry was to offer the courses not to the professional but to the general public. No one had done that, and for a while he didn't have any competition.'' **********Each week, Lowry courses would be offered in as many as four or five cities around the country. For a week or two before the course, a newspaper advertising campaign would ballyhoo Mr. Lowry's theories. As the operation grew, he could afford to buy late-night television time, and he produced a 30-minute documentary-style commercial, ''How to Be Successful in America,'' narrated by E. G. Marshall, the actor. An Attractive Come-On **********In each city Mr. Lowry held an ''introductory'' meeting, at no charge, that he would conclude with a sales pitch for the paid seminar that weekend, which cost up to $495. Associates said Mr. Lowry's sales appeal was invariably successful, though the later seminar would typically not be taught by Mr. Lowry himself. **********Depending on the size of the city, the paid turnout could range from 50 to 400 people, Mr. Hoffman said. For their money they got two full days of detailed instruction on the ins and outs of foreclosure, financing and the like, as well as the chance to buy more Lowry instructional materials. **********His popularity peaked around 1979 and 1980. At that point high interest rates were spawning foreclosures, forcing some sellers in distress to accept no-money-down offers. Inflation was helping almost any real estate to appreciate in value. Book a Best Seller **********Mr. Lowry's book ''How You Can Become Financially Independent by Investing in Real Estate'' made the best seller lists. He followed it with ''How to Become Financially Successful by Owning Your Own Business,'' which Money magazine described in a May 1981 review as ''so comprehensive that it deserves to become a standard reference work.'' (The books were written with considerable assistance from a team of researchers, according to associates of Mr. Lowry.) But even during those good days, Mr. Lowry's operations had problems, colleagues said. Because he was on the road so much, there were administrative difficulties within his companies. Seminars would be arranged, promoted and then canceled at the last minute. Instructors and aides came and went, complaining of low pay and sometimes taking Mr. Lowry's materials with them to start competing enterprises. None among the colleagues to whom Mr. Lowry turned over administrative duties seemed to last more than a year or two. **********One former associate said that in the early 1980's Mr. Lowry lost $1 million because of two failed strategies masterminded by subordinates. In one, Mr. Lowry's company invested heavily in a plan to sell more materials to alumni of his courses, who proved largely uninterested. In another, the company tried to hire competing investment speakers and put them to work under Mr. Lowry's umbrella. The high salaries they demanded made the plan a big money loser. Seminars in Decline **********At the same time, with the investment climate changing and new competitors emerging daily, the seminar business began tailing off. By 1985, Mr. Lowry's main company, then called the Success Development Institute, had closed its doors, though Mr. Lowry continued on the lecture circuit. **********Mr. Lowry was still holding seminars this spring, though twice in the past year his creditors have used such public appearances to serve him with lawsuits. He also seems not to have lost his entrepreneurial zeal: He was recently spotted in an advertisement endorsing a weight-loss program.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/08/world.main_headline: A Slave Island Draws Descendants of Slaves
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/08/world.print_headline: A Slave Island Draws Descendants of Slaves
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/08/world.body_text: **********Exploring this low island in the mouth of Africa's largest harbor, a black American visitor mused, ''This island almost belongs more to America than to Africa.'' **********In the 1700's, this 400-foot-wide island was the major embarkation point along West Africa's 2,500-mile coast for slaves to the rice plantations of Georgia and South Carolina. **********Today, beneath a tangle of vines and tree roots, a visitor can discover the crumbling walls of a slave merchant's manor built by freed American slaves. The Americans had returned to Africa and settled in nearby Freetown. **********As interest increases in the United States about the African roots of American blacks, attention is focusing on long-deserted slave forts. **********''Even if it is sad, even if it is painful, knowing where you come from is important,'' the American Ambassador to Sierra Leone, Cynthia Shephard Perry, said recently as she stood in the roofless ruins of the manor house here. ''How depressing it is to know that the people who passed through here could have been my ancestors.'' **********To arrest the deterioration, Ms. Perry said she hoped to win private support to clear underbrush, to preserve the ruins, to pay for a caretaker and to open the island to regular visits. The American Embassy is going to install commemorative plaques. **********To generate interest, she plans to bring a group of black American college presidents here. **********Black American interest has also generated around another slave fort, Goree Island, off the coast of Senegal. In an effort endorsed by Ebony magazine and several members of the Congressional Black Caucus, a campaign began last summer to raise $4 million to buy a 19th-century American Consulate building and to make it a museum of black achievement. **********While Goree attracts ever greater numbers of tourists each year, Bunce Island has been steadily falling into abandon since 1807, the year Britain started suppressing the slave trade. Declared a Monument **********In 1947, the island was declared a historic monument here, but little effort was made to preserve the ruins. In 1974, a hurricane reduced the last intact building to a pile of bricks. **********Today, green monkeys, red ants and three-foot long monitor lizards are the island's principal inhabitants, said Joseph L. Opala, an American anthropologist who has mapped the ruins. **********Wielding a rusty machete, Mr. Opala recently led a group of Americans up the fort's ramparts. Rusted cannons bearing the crest of King George III still point to the open sea. **********At the limit of navigability for oceangoing ships, Bunce Island served as one tip of a triangular trade route. Slaves skilled in the cultivation of rice went from here to the American colonies. Carolina rice went to London. Ships filled with ballast and manufactured goods for African trade came here. **********Despite twin watchtowers, walls topped with broken wine bottles and a battery of 100-pound siege guns, the fort was repeatedly sacked in the 18th century. One who sacked it was Batholomew Roberts, a notorious Welsh pirate from the Caribbean known as Black Bart. **********Behind the ramparts stand the decaying brick walls of the manor house. The Americans who provided the skilled labor came to Sierra Leone after fighting on the British side of the American war for independence in return for their freedom. **********Built in 1795 in what Mr. Opala called ''tropical Georgian,'' the house had louvered shutters, a verandah and a fake ceremonial fireplace. Anxious to flaunt their new-found wealth, British slave traders landscaped parts of the island with a formal, terraced English garden and a two-hole golf course. **********Mr. Opala recounted that an abolitionist once rose from the dinner table, laid with china and crystal goblets, and saw from the window ''200 naked people chained in circles and eating from troughs of rice on the ground.'' **********At the end of Mr. Opala's tour, one black American visitor, David Graff, commented that Bunce Island reminded him of a visit to Dachau. **********''Not everything you visit should be fun and touristy,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/10/world.body_text: **********When gunfire erupted Wednesday night around the Quisilala cattle cooperative, Dominga Solana, 26 years old and quick, dived for cover. **********Miss Solana's arm was shattered by a rifle bullet, but she survived and is hospitalized. Her mother and three others at the cooperative, including a 15-year-old girl, were killed. **********''The contras came in shooting, and we had no soldiers to defend us,'' Miss Solana said from her hospital bed. ''They stole cattle and burned our houses.'' **********The raid at Quisilala, near the town of La Esperanza, 225 miles east of Managua, was the most recent in a continuing series of attacks by United States-backed rebels, known as contras, against civilian targets. A trip through the contested zone indicated that contra units operating here have not significantly changed their tactics despite strong pressure on them to do so. **********The contras' human-rights record has cost them important political support in Washington and elsewhere, and some contra leaders have vowed to take action to change patterns of abuse. Contra squad leaders recently trained in the United States were reportedly taught to avoid civilian targets and concentrate on engaging the Sandinista army. **********In this part of Nicaragua, the Sandinista Government is widely unpopular. Contra forces arriving here from bases in Honduras hope to build both a military and political base, according to diplomats. **********Yet in many towns in and around Chontales Province, residents have vivid stories to tell of atrocities they say have been committed by contra forces in recent months. **********''Naturally there are wounded soldiers too, but there is hardly ever a time when we don't have civilian victims here,'' said Dr. Javier Luna, director of the Camilo Ortega Saavedra Hospital in Juigalpa, where Miss Solana is a patient. **********In the small farming village of El Nispero, a group of more than a dozen residents waiting for transportation near the main road Sunday told how six of their neighbors were killed in a contra raid Dec. 9. **********Speaking separately, several gave nearly identical accounts of the attack. They said that a 9-month-old infant was bayoneted to death and that two elderly women were shot dead after being forced to lie on the dirt floor of their home. **********Also killed in the raid were two men cut down as they ran toward their homes and a pregnant woman who, villagers said, was shot in the stomach. **********''They took three of our people away with them, and who knows if they are alive or dead,'' a resident, Antonio Diaz, said. ''It was something terrible.'' Officials Use Caution **********Not all victims of contra attacks in this area are civilians. Area residents said, for example, that the seven people killed in an attack on the village of Colonia Rio Rama on Feb. 16 were not civilians, as reported in the official Sandinista press, but rather armed and uniformed Sandinista soldiers. **********The residents' version was confirmed by foreigners who regularly travel through the area. **********Some of the civilians who have been killed by contras in this area in the last few months were Government employees. Off the main roads, officials travel with caution. Some prefer to drive unmarked vehicles. **********''Contras maintain themselves here, and they have made this quite a hot area,'' said Marina Orozco, the Sandinista Mayor of Acoyapa. **********On Jan. 7, Miss Orozco set off from Acoyapa to the village of Santa Marta accompanied by a doctor, a dentist and two officials of the Agriculture Ministry. They had asked everyone in Santa Marta with medical or dental problems to be ready for treatment that day, and they were also planning to hear demands for land made by several groups of peasants. Caravan Is Ambushed **********After arriving in Santa Marta, the officials, as planned, sent the drivers of their three jeeps back to Acoyapa to pick up a cargo of barbed wire. The caravan was ambushed, and all three drivers, one of them a Sandinista soldier, were killed. **********A soldier based in Acoyapa, Jose Luis Gomez, confirmed the account, as did an aide to the mayor and two civilians who live in the town. **********In the grazing country south of Acoyapa, in the heart of Nicaragua's beef belt, contras have managed to disrupt life on some government cooperatives. Their leaders have argued that since the cooperatives produce food for the government supply system and are normally guarded with Sandinista weapons, attacking them is a legitimate tactic. Two Cooperatives Raided **********One area southwest of Acoyapa is now inhabited only by scattered families who farm small private plots and live off the land. Members of three such families told of two attacks on cooperatives. **********On Nov. 27, they and other area residents said, raiders struck the San Pancho cooperative 15 miles west of Acoyapa. According to four residents interviewed separately, the attackers burned several houses and kidnapped at least seven residents. The rest fled, and the ranch is now abandoned. **********The raid on San Pancho did not scare away the 10 Hurtado Lopez brothers who ran El Chaguite, a well-known cooperative two miles away. In interviews where they are now living in refuge, two of the brothers said they were not suspicious when a census taker visited on Jan. 11 and learned that only four people were at the ranch. Two Women Kidnapped **********But the next morning, they said, a band of contras attacked El Chaguite. According to their account, two brothers picked up rifles and tried to resist, but both were shot, one fatally. Two women, relatives of the men, were kidnapped, but both managed to escape 24 hours later when their captors were distracted by a passing Sandinista patrol. **********''We were walking the whole time, and they made us carry their equipment,'' said one of the women, Maria Elena Suazo, 17 years old. **********The Hurtado family has now abandoned El Chaguite and is gathered in Juigalpa, the capital of Chontales Province. **********''If things calm down and the situation is controlled, we'd like to go back,'' said the wounded brother, Noel Gomez Hurtado, 21 years old, who was lying in bed with his right leg in a cast from hip to toe. ''If you don't work, you don't eat.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/14/world.body_text: **********A car-bomb explosion wounded 18 people, 5 of them seriously, at a suburban Harare shopping center today. The Zimbabwean Government blamed South Africa. **********Forensic experts said the sophisticated bomb had been designed to spray out pointed red squares of metal, to cause as much damage and as many injuries as possible. **********''The bomb blast is part of the persistent efforts of the Pretoria regime to destabilize Zimbabwe and other front-line states,'' Information Minister Nathan Shamuyarira said. ''Our people should remain calm and vigilant. These acts are the work of the enemy of Zimbabwe and we have only one enemy, South Africa.'' **********Mr. Shamuyarira did not offer any evidence linking South Africa directly to the car bomb. He did say the South African Government had recently sent a protest notes to Zimbabwe charging that a land mine explosion in Transvaal Province in South Africa had been caused by guerrillas who had entered South Africa from Zimbabwe. **********Mr. Shamuyarira denied that any infiltration had taken place from Zimbabwe. He said, however, that it was the South African Government's method to hand over such protest notes shortly before making sabotage attacks. **********''It is a tactic South Africa always uses whenever they want to attack us,'' Mr. Shamuyarira said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/20/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: John W. Amerman was named yesterday as chairman and chief executive at Mattel Inc., ending an apparent contest for the top spot at the large toy company. **********John W. Amerman was named yesterday as chairman and chief executive at Mattel Inc., ending an apparent contest for the top spot at the large toy company. **********Since October, the company has been run by a three-man executive committee composed of Mr. Amerman, 55, who has been the president of Mattel International; Thomas J. Kalinske, 42, Mattel's president, and Raymond W. Ferris, 45, executive vice president and chief financial officer. The interim committee had been formed after Arthur S. Spear, 66, announced plans to retire as Mattel's chairman at the end of last year. **********Mattel, based in Hawthorne, Calif., said that Mr. Kalinske and Mr. Ferris would now report to Mr. Amerman. Lindsey Williams, 50, was named to replace Mr. Amerman as head of the international division. **********Mr. Amerman apparently won the top job on the strength of the international division's performance. David S. Liebowitz, an analyst at the American Securities Corporation, pointed out that the division was profitable while Mattel as a whole lost $951,000 last year. Mr. Liebowitz said he expected Mattel to be profitable this year. **********In announcing the appointment, Mattel said that under Mr. Amerman's guidance, the company became No. 1 or No. 2 ''in virtually all of the international markets in which the company has established marketing organizations.'' **********Mattel is the nation's second-largest toy company after Hasbro Inc. At the recent toy fair in New York, Mattel showed off its Captain Power and the Soldiers of the Future, one of several electronic toys designed to be used by children as they watch specific cartoon shows on television. And the company is still getting good mileage out of Barbie, now in her 28th year. ''Last year was the biggest year she ever had,'' said Spencer Boise, a Mattel spokesman. **********Mr. Amerman was turning down requests for interviews yesterday, Mr. Boise said. Mr. Amerman joined Mattel seven years ago as president of the international division. Before that, he had been president of the Warner-Lambert Company's American Chicle division. He had held several posts at the vice president level at Warner-Lambert and had also been an executive at the Colgate-Palmolive Company. Mr. Amerman graduated from Dartmouth College and its Amos Tuck business school.
