https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/26/busin.print_headline: ADVERTISING; Those Pyramid People Stretch Their Dollars
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/26/busin.body_text: **********The Transamerica Corporation built its skinny pyramid of a headquarters in San Francisco and then, so it should not be a total loss, converted it into its corporate symbol as well. It became a star of all company advertising. **********Next, to get more mileage out of its advertising budget, the insurance conglomerate chose the kind of semi-startling advertising that can garner press coverage, like a pop-up insert in a magazine. **********So Transamerica retained Della Femina, Travisano & Partners -hardly a publicity-shy organization. **********''Then,'' said Jerry Della Femina, the chairman, ''they hire a publicity firm just to cover the commercial, shooting people shooting the commercial. That's how they stretch their dollars.'' **********The latest spot, due to be shown starting Nov. 1, is called ''Egypt'' and shows the slaves building a pyramid under the lashes of middle management. Suddenly one slave stands up majestically from his fellows and eloquently proclaims that someday there will be a pyramid built for the public good, to protect people from catastrophe, to help people prepare for the future. **********Then he stops, thinks a minute and adds with equal eloquence, ''Naaaah!'' Mr. Della Femina acknowledges that this scene may have been inspired by a Steve Martin bit. **********It is likely that when you see this 30-second spot it will be on a Sunday. For three years the company has been following a Sunday strategy -stretching its limited ad budget by spending some 90 percent of it to reach the big Sunday TV audience.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/19/busin.main_headline: Anxiety in Mexico: Elections Are Near
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/19/busin.print_headline: Anxiety in Mexico: Elections Are Near
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/19/busin.body_text: **********Mexican businessmen, bankers, economists and investors are glancing nervously at their calendars these days. The ''Year of Hidalgo,'' with all its attendant dangers and potential for economic disaster, has come around again. **********The Year of Hidalgo refers to a conjunction of economics and politics that occurs every six years - a period of about 18 months when the Mexican president nears the end of his term and the maneuvering to succeed him reaches a peak. (It is named for Miguel Hidalgo, a hero of Mexican independence, because his image appears on bills and coins.) The Year of Hidalgo is traditionally a time when both Government spending and corruption rise in anticipation of the presidential elections and a change of administration. Public Works and 'Tortilla Bonds' **********In practice, that means rushing highways, hospitals, rural electrification, schools and other costly public works projects to completion so that candidates of the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party can reap credit and political benefit from them. Equally widespread is the wooing of voters with generous subsidies for basic foodstuffs, a practice known as ''tortilla bonds.'' **********But such largesse is an alarming prospect with inflation at a record 130 percent and accelerating, with foreign debt exceeding $100 billion and with the public-sector deficit amounting to nearly 17 percent of the gross domestic product. ''The last thing this country needs right now is for the Government to prime the pumps,'' said one private-sector economist who fears that populist electoral gestures and free spending could exacerbate the country's worst economic crisis in 50 years. **********In addition, there is the specter of the two previous administrations, both of which stumbled badly on economic policy during their last year in office. **********Shortly before his departure in 1976, Luis Echeverria devalued the peso for the first time in two decades, by 55 percent, and authorized the seizure of some landholdings. Jose Lopez Portillo, in his chaotic last year in office in 1982, nationalized the banking system and presided over a precipitous decline in the value of the peso and an increase in foreign debt. **********So as the succession unfolds, Mexicans are watching for signs that history will repeat itself and that President Miguel de la Madrid will bequeath his successor an economic situation even more depressed and unmanageable than the one he inherited in December 1982. Reasons for Optimism **********On the surface, some of the alarm seems unwarranted. Mexico has record foreign reserves, expected to reach nearly $17 billion by the end of the year, almost triple the figure of a year ago. The reserves were helped by a trade surplus of $4.5 billion for the first half of 1987 and receipt of the first portion of a $7.7 billion loan signed with foreign banks in March. **********Senior Government officials have vowed to ''sterilize the reserves,'' as they have put it, by holding them aside until needed and heading off aside until needed and heading off additional inflationary pressures. But many observers here fear that the Government will not be able to resist demands from party bosses to spend at least some of that money before the election. **********The ruling party, which has been in power since 1929 and has never lost a major election, is expected to name its presidential candidate before the end of October. Voters will go to the polls on the first Sunday of next July, and the new president, who is limited to a single six-year term, will be sworn in Dec. 1, 1988. Higher Oil Prices **********Additional temptation to spend lavishly exists because of the dramatic recovery in oil prices. Mexican Isthmus, a light grade produced for the export market, now sells for more than $20 a barrel, nearly 50 percent above the average price Government planners had anticipated at the start of the year and roughly double the price of a year ago. **********Mr. de la Madrid has sought to calm fears about economic policy by promising not to veer from the unpopular austerity program that has been the hallmark of his administration. In a steady drumbeat of public declarations, senior officials have assured the public that the mistakes of the past will not be repeated. **********''The Government of the republic intends for this transition to be orderly, transparent and in accordance with the law,'' Ignacio Pichardo Pagaza, the Comptroller General, said recently. ''Those phenomena popularly known as the Year of Hidalgo will not present themselves in the public administration.'' Concern About Money Supply **********Nevertheless, there are disturbing signs that things may not be proceeding as planned. According to the most recent figures, the money supply grew by a record 147 percent in the 12 months ending June 30. **********''It makes me uncomfortable,'' said a diplomat here who specializes in economic affairs, reflecting a sentiment shared throughout the business and banking community. Treasury notes and other Government paper accounted for much of that rise, leading some financial analysts to believe that the struggle for monetary and fiscal restraint has already been lost. **********In addition, large wage increases have been granted in recent months to Government bureaucrats whose loyalty and campaign efforts are essential to the ruling party. Members of some influential unions have also received wage increases well above the inflation rate. **********Some nervousness has also been generated by indications that the Government is tinkering with its exchange rate policy. The devaluation of the peso, while continuing, has slowed to the point that it is about to fall behind the inflation rate, and there are reports of a serious policy debate on the subject within the de la Madrid administration, with possible candidates for president on opposite sides of the fence. **********That is of concern to business groups because exports of products other than oil have been the most dynamic sector of the economy during the last 18 months. Such exports were up 41 percent in 1986 and an additional 30 percent in the first half of this year, in large part because the value of the peso has been kept low in relation to the dollar. Capital Leaving Again **********In addition, capital once again appears to be flowing out of the country. During the last nine months, several billion dollars that had been sent abroad has been brought home. **********But that was before the arrival of the Year of Hidalgo. In recent weeks, the rise of interest rates in the United States has begun to attract Mexican investors again, according to private-sector economists here. **********''People are concerned, and with some justification,'' one diplomat said, speaking of the way recent economic indicators are being read. ''They remember only too well that the last two administrations came apart completely and sank into incredible corruption during their last year.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/08/busin.main_headline: High Court Gets Pleas On Winans
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/08/busin.print_headline: High Court Gets Pleas On Winans
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/08/busin.body_text: **********The Supreme Court was urged today to uphold a disputed legal theory that has been one of the Government's most effective weapons in its crackdown against insider trading on Wall Street. **********The Court is reviewing the conviction of R. Foster Winans, the former Wall Street Journal reporter, and two associates of his who profited from trading in stocks that he was writing about. **********Solicitor General Charles Fried, the Government's top courtroom lawyer, warned the Justices that unless they upheld the conviction, there would be ''a cascading deterioration of honesty in the securities markets.'' Legal Theory Cited **********Mr. Winans's conviction was based largely on the misappropriation theory, which makes it a violation of Federal securities law to use nonpublic information for personal use. **********The theory, which has been widely used by the Government in major insider trading cases, such as those against the arbitrager Ivan F. Boesky and the investment banker Dennis B. Levine, has evolved through case law since 1981 and does not appear in the statute books. **********The theory was affirmed by the Federal District Court that convicted Mr. Winans; David Carpenter, his former roommate, and Kenneth Felis, a stockbroker. An appeals court upheld the convictions. **********But the Supreme Court's decision to review the case was seen by securities lawyers as a sign that many of the Justices had doubts about the misappropriation theory. Contentions by Defense **********With Washington's most prominent securities lawyers and top officials of the Securities and Exchange Commission in the court, Mr. Winans's attorney, Don D. Buchwald, told the Justices the Government had gone too far in this case. **********''This kind of wrongdoing, we submit, however one may view it, was not intended to be covered by the securities laws,'' Mr. Buchwald said. **********The Government contended that from October 1983 until early 1984, Mr. Winans told Mr. Felis and Peter N. Brant, another stockbroker, about the contents of Mr. Winans's forthcoming ''Heard on the Street'' columns. **********A company's stock price is often affected when the company is mentioned in the column. The Government contended that Mr. Winans and his associates had made about $700,000 in profits from trading on advance knowledge of the columns' contents. **********Mr. Buchwald admitted that the practice was unethical and violated policy at the newspaper, but he contended that it should not be considered securities fraud. **********But Mr. Fried said Mr. Winans and his co-defendants defrauded the newspaper by stealing its information. **********''The information was misappropriated at the time either when Winans himself traded on it or when he communicated it to others who traded on it,'' he added. **********Mr. Winans has been sentenced to 18 months in prison for securities fraud and mail and wire fraud. Mr. Felis was sentenced to six months in prison, and Mr. Carpenter was placed on three years' probation. Mr. Brant pleaded guilty to three counts of insider trading and has been cooperating with the authorities in the Federal investigation while he awaits sentencing. Justices Express Doubts **********At today's courtroom session, several Justices, including Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, frequently interrupted Mr. Fried to contest his contention that there had been violations of mail, wire and securities fraud laws. **********''What if there had been no Wall Street Journal work rule?'' Justice Rehnquist asked. **********Even if there were no rule, Mr. Fried argued, there was a clear understanding at the paper that making personal use of such information was prohibited. **********Justice Rehnquist also suggested that the Government's application of the law may have gone beyond the intent of Congress. **********''You're putting layers on it,'' he told Mr. Fried. **********Congress is currently considering legislation proposed by the S.E.C. that would for the first time define insider trading and codify legal theories already used in prosecutions.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/21/busin.body_text: **********Six weeks after Morgan Stanley & Company rankled investors by canceling a large trade the day after it crossed the tape, the New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that the trade would stand in its records, even though no money changed hands and the trade is unlikely to ever take place. **********Sharon Gamsin, the exchange's spokeswoman, said that as far as the exchange was concerned the trade was never canceled. But she added that ''it's not something we would do something about.'' **********''The transaction still exists on the tape,'' she said, ''but unless Morgan Stanley is challenged by one of its customers, essentially nothing will happen.'' **********The trade would have given Paul A. Bilzerian, the Tampa, Fla., investor, control of Pay 'N Pak Stores Inc. Morgan Stanley had second thoughts about the legality of arranging the trade and notified Mr. Bilzerian and more than 20 sellers that it was calling it off. **********The Rosewood Holdings Corporation, an investor group that includes Pay 'N Pak management, has since consolidated its control of the company, and most of the affected parties apparently have no wish to take Morgan Stanley to arbitration to enforce its $21.25-a-share offer. **********Rosewood's $21-a-share offer enabled many investors to recoup much of their investment and made them feel they had more to lose than gain from challenging Morgan Stanley. **********''People think twice about rupturing a relationship where a lot of future transactions are involved,'' said Jack Treynor, a professor of business at the University of Southern California. **********But the incomplete transaction has left a bad aftertaste with some. ''I'm sorry the stock exchange didn't fine them,'' said one of the 20 or so arbitragers who collectively lost at least $1 million in the deal. **********Financial experts remember only one other instance in which a trade was unwound. It involved the stock of Bausch & Lomb Inc. and occurred 15 years ago. Some investors obtained information suggesting that the company's soft contact lens business might be in trouble, and they sold their holdings. Salomon Brothers bought some of the shares but later retracted the trade, according to Professor Treynor. **********Professor Treynor said there were differences in the two cases. He described Salomon's position as: ''We're going to break this trade because people on the other side broke the law.'' **********''In Morgan Stanley's case,'' he said, ''they're saying we're going to break the trade, because we broke the law.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/29/busin.main_headline: U.S. Underwriters Face Losses on B.P. Offering
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/29/busin.print_headline: U.S. Underwriters Face Losses on B.P. Offering
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/29/busin.body_text: **********The stocks of the American securities firm involved in the $12.2 billion offering in the British Petroleum Company were hit with heavy selling yesterday in expectation of huge losses from the deal. **********The British Government, which is selling the B.P. shares, said it would decide today whether to go ahead with the offering, but has said until now that it intends to move forward. **********The American underwriters have pleaded that the deal be halted, and Canada's Finance Minister, Michael Wilson, issued a plea yesterday that the British reconsider because of the steep plunge in the B.P. share price. Canadian firms have a smaller role in the underwriting but could face losses, too. **********The underwriters agreed to buy the B.P. shares at 330 pence, or $5.68, each. Yesterday, the shares closed in London at 254 pence, or $4.37. **********The shares of Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. and Salomon Inc. closed sharply lower, while Morgan Stanley & Company fell sharply. because of mounting concerns over the size of the losses these firms are expected to suffer from the offering. Each of them have underwritten 10 million shares. **********Goldman, Sachs & Company, is a privately held partnership, but it would suffer the largest losses because it is committed to underwriting 12 million shares. **********Analysts said, however, that it did not appear the losses would impair the financial health of these firms. **********The British Government is selling its remaining 31.5 percent stake in B.P. in a deal that was underwritten before the stock market plunge. The underwriters agreed to pay the British Government a total of $:7.2 billion. $500 Million Loss for Firms That means that the American underwriters will absorb about $500 million in losses, several investment bankers involved in the deal said. **********Each of the firms would suffer about $120 million in losses, with Goldman, Sachs suffering a $150 million loss, the investment bankers said. **********For Morgan Stanley, that could prove painful, since the firm had $576 million in shareholder's equity at the end of 1986. It is possible, investment bankers said, that a portion of the paper losses could be regained if the the stock market rebounds. **********In yesterday's trading, Morgan Stanley's stock plunged $5.25, to $46.75 a share; Salomon's stock lost $1.375, to $17.875, and Shearson's stock fell 50 cents, to $13.875.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/28/world.main_headline: TOLL IN HAITI IS PUT AT 50 OR MORE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/28/world.print_headline: TOLL IN HAITI IS PUT AT 50 OR MORE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/28/world.body_text: **********Witnesses to a brutal battle last week have given grisly accounts of peasants and sharecroppers fighting with machetes and metal spikes in a clash that killed at least 50 people. **********Casualty counts differed widely, and some reports ranged up to several hundered. The battle between peasants demanding land redistribution and sharecroppers working for landowners occurred in Jean-Rabel, in a fertile valley in the remote northwest. **********Members of the Tet Ansam peasant group, which demands access to farmland in the village of 3,000 people, said they were ambushed Thursday and many of their comrades were killed by sharecroppers working for wealthy landowners. **********A Catholic missionary who is a director of Tet Ansam said Sunday that about 50 members of the group died in the clash and 300 were missing. Another 52 were being treated at Notre Dame Hospital for machete slashes and wounds from spikes, he said.  [ A spokesman for a team of military investigators said at least 100 people were believed to have died in fighting Thursday and Friday, Reuters said. The president of a local association of land-owning peasants, Cenifa Moness, said he had taken part in the burial of at least 100 people killed in the clash, Reuters said.  [ Evetil Achelus, a Protestant minister quoted by Reuters, said he had counted at least 300 dead along several miles of mountain road to Jean-Rabel. ]  Most of the victims were part of a group of about 700 Tet Ansam peasants who were walking to Jean-Rabel to help friends, according to the Tet Ansam director, who spoke on condition of anonymity, saying he feared reprisals. **********The Government said 10 people died, but a Government spokeswoman, Anaise Chavenet, who visited the village Sunday, said: ''People who participated in the fight say there are many, many dead. I think it's very possible. I can't say how many.'' **********The death toll was difficult to determine because some bodies had not been recovered from a ravine and some had been dismembered. Other victims disappeared after being wounded, members of Tet Ansam said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/10/world.main_headline: Tunisia Is Moving Delicately on Transition
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/10/world.print_headline: Tunisia Is Moving Delicately on Transition
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/10/world.body_text: **********A color photograph of Habib Bourguiba, youngish and smiling broadly, still hangs in the lobby of the Meridien Africa Hotel here, but for how long no one can say. **********His picture is being replaced in public by that of Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali, who deposed Mr. Bourguiba to become only the second President of Tunisia since independence 31 years ago. **********Mr. Ben Ali, the Prime Minister, removed the 84-year-old hero of the Tunisian independence early Saturday, apparently with the concurrence of the vast majority of senior Government officials and opposition leaders. **********The change appears to have been accepted quietly by Tunisians, who were aware from television and personal appearances of Mr. Bourguiba of the deterioration of his health. Mr. Ben Ali, who was named second in command on Oct. 2, said the elderly leader had become senile and incapable of continuing to govern Tunisia's seven million people. **********The new leader and his Government are handling the transition delicately. There has been no rush to remove Mr. Bourguiba's name from streets or institutions or to remove his pictures or statues. In addition, neither the former president nor the four ministers under house arrest with him - including his son, also named Habib - will face any criminal charges, trial or prison. The detainees were reportedly flown today by helicopter from the presidential palace to a presidential residence six miles south of the capital. **********''He will be kept in his villa and attended by doctors,'' said Kamil Cherif, director of international press relations for the Information Ministry. ''He will be treated with respect. After all, we've lived with him for 50 years, including the struggle'' for independence from France. A senior Western diplomat, asked if there would be any serious mass reaction to the removal of Mr. Bourguiba, replied: **********''It depends on how he's treated. Everybody's going out of their way to be kind to him. If that continues, there won't be that much feeling against the change.'' Approval From an Opponent **********Khemain Chamari, a lawyer and secretary of the Tunisian League for the Defense of Human Rights, said he had been a bitter opponent of Mr. Ben Ali, particularly during a recent crackdown on Islamic fundamentalists led by the former army general. But he said he supported the ouster of Mr. Bourguiba, with whom he also disagreed, because the former president wanted to expand the crackdown. ''We've got to work with them for a while, give them a chance,'' the lawyer remarked. **********Mahmoud Mestiri, who was appointed Foreign Minister on Saturday, said in an interview today with Reuters that the crackdown would go on. ''We are definitely going to continue our crackdown on fundamentalists,'' he said. But he added, ''Those who did not commit serious crimes and were condemned to four or five years will be released, maybe in a year.'' **********Mr. Ben Ali has not proposed any specific programs, but has promised to liberalize political laws to allow more freedom for parties, end some press censorship and run an open and democratic government. **********''He hasn't said exactly what all that means, how far he plans to go,'' the senior Western diplomat said. ''I don't know how wide the door will swing open, for example, to let exiles back in. **********''I expect democracy will come gradually. I'm not sure he's a full democrat, but he'll try and move in that direction.'' **********The diplomat said that during the month that Mr. Ben Ali was Prime Minister, ''he wasn't criticized at all; it was then that he began speaking of the need for a more open society.'' **********When Mr. Bourguiba wanted more trials, the diplomat said, ''Ben Ali said they shouldn't let this thing go too far, should not let it be an opening for repression.'' **********The diplomat said he also expected Mr. Ben Ali to turn the country more toward Arab tradition rather than the Western models favored by his predecessor.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/21/busin.main_headline: Advertising; U.S. News Goes After Ad Sales
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/21/busin.print_headline: Advertising; U.S. News Goes After Ad Sales
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/21/busin.body_text: **********AFTER a fairly thorough redesign, U.S. News & World Report last year spent the majority of its promotion dollars successfully going after increased circulation. **********With that accomplished, the emphasis is being switched this year to garnering more advertising at the expense of the competition, which is primarily Time and Newsweek but also includes, in U.S. News' mind at least, Forbes, Fortune, Business Week and The Wall Street Journal. **********The emphasis is needed. The magazine's advertising pages in 1986 dropped to 1,666, from 1,775 the year before, for Publishers Information Bureau revenues of $101.1 million, compared with $102.6 million. **********U.S. News was not suffering alone, and many of the magazines it considers competition were also having problems, since they feed mainly at the same trough, supplied by high-technology and computer companies, liquor and cigarette producers and insurance concerns. And most of those advertisers for one reason or another were pulling back on their ad spending.  * * * **********Yesterday at the fancy new offices here of U.S. News, a discussion on strategy to increase ad pages included Fred Drasner, president and chief executive of the magazine, who for many years was lawyer to Mortimer Zuckerman, the owner; Richard C. Thompson, publisher, who ended up as ad director after 20 years with Business Week; Vanessa Reed, promotion director, who formerly worked for People, TV Guide and Seventeen, and finally the agency guy, Gary M. Susnjara, chairman of DFS Dorland/New York. **********Their tactic is to go after advertisers who are already convinced of the viability of newsweeklies in particular, but also business magazines, and just have not been using U.S. News. That calls for a highly competitive ad campaign, and that is just what the agency has come up with. **********They want to show that U.S. News is a news and information publication, in contrast to Time and Newsweek, which they classify as news and entertainment magazines more widely quoted in Hollywood than in Washington and frequently picturing personalities on their covers, a practice that U.S. News shies away from. **********U.S. News wants to implant in the consciousness of agency and advertiser that, if a budget calls for two news magazines, they should make the second one U.S. News just to be different.  * * * **********For the sake of the campaign, Time and Newsweek have been labeled ''the clones.'' And the first ad shows two bespectacled men who managed to get seats on an uncrowded graffiti-free subway, one reading Time, the other Newsweek. But each cover is carrying a painting of Andrew Wyeth's long-secret model. ''See the clones'' reads the line over their heads, while ''See the light'' is above the head of the man to their left, who is reading U.S. News with the cover illustrating the middle class's struggle to hold on. **********Another ad, illustrating how the big two are frequently mentioned in the hills of Hollywood while U.S. News is on the lips of Washingtonians, is satisfied with two words: ''Clones'' and ''Clout.'' **********An ad showing four newsweekly covers, each with a personality on the cover, has the headline ''Clone candy.'' The page next to it shows a copy of U.S. News on a coffee table with a cover concerning an article on higher education. Its headline says, ''Brain food.'' * * * **********These ads and at least four more will appear in Advertising Age, Adweek, Marketing and Media Decisions and New York magazines, as well as on posters in subway stations, above subway entrances and in commuter railroad stations. **********The ad budget for the year is $1.7 million, up from $1.3 million last year. This will cover four months of advertising, two in the spring and two in the fall. **********According to Mr. Thompson, the aggressive posture on ad sales includes the addition of five new ad salesmen in the last six months to the eight salesmen and two managers already working in the New York office.   $ ? * * * **********Interesting point: While the competition has been using personalities on their covers, U.S. News has been using them in its advertising. And 1987 marks the first time in a decade that it has not. Last year's circulation-boosting effort featured such notables as Mayor Koch; Joseph Papp; Eileen Ford, the model mogul; Howard Cosell, and Mike Ditka, coach of the Chicago Bears. **********The campaign appears to have worked. While Time's total paid circulation was up 2.5 percent, to 4.7 million and Newsweek's was up 1.4 percent, to 3.1 million, U.S. News gained 9.7 percent, to 2.3 million. **********And, U.S. News management is quick to brag, it sold 85 percent of its subscriptions at the basic rate, while both of the others sold only 21 percent at the basic rate and the rest below it. Also, U.S. News sold 77 percent of its subscriptions without the inducement of premiums, while Time sold only 45 percent without them, and Newsweek, only 59 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/24/busin.main_headline: Tenneco Unit Sale To Castle & Cooke
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/24/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Tenneco Unit Sale To Castle & Cooke
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/24/busin.body_text: **********In a move to broaden its line of foods and to bolster its holdings in California real estate, Castle & Cooke Inc. said it would acquire substantially all of the operations of Tenneco West Inc., a subsidiary of Tenneco Inc. of Houston, for $236 million in cash and debt. **********The sale includes 40,000 acres of farmland and home sites. The profitable unit generated $350 million in revenue last year. Tenneco would retain mineral rights on the land and would keep 270,000 acres of leased farmland in California and Arizona.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/29/world.main_headline: SEOUL PARTY CHIEF BACKS DIRECT VOTE FOR THE PRESIDENT
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/29/world.print_headline: SEOUL PARTY CHIEF BACKS DIRECT VOTE FOR THE PRESIDENT
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/29/world.body_text: **********In a dramatic and unexpected concession to opposition demands, the chairman of the ruling party proposed today that South Korea's next president be elected through direct elections. **********The chairman, Roh Tae Woo, who is his party's choice to succeed President Chun Doo Hwan, said he also thought that the election laws should be changed to promote ''free campaigns.'' **********''The people's will must be placed above everything else,'' Mr. Roh said. ''The transfer of power will have to be realized peacefully in February 1988 by achieving constitutional reform for direct presidential elections at an early date.'' Dissident's Rights Addressed **********Mr. Roh also urged that the political rights of South Korea's most prominent dissident politician, Kim Dae Jung, be restored. **********The announcement represents a complete reversal of the positions that the ruling camp had been maintaining for more than a year. **********The proposals, made in a nationally televised address, were to be submitted later to President Chun and the governing Democratic Justice Party. It was not clear what the President's reaction would be, but, presumably, Mr. Chun already had been informed or Mr. Roh would not have made his announcement. 'No Choice' for Chun **********''This gives Chun no choice,'' a foreign diplomat said.  [ In Washington, the top State Department official responsible for Asian affairs expressed optimism about the proposals. The official, Assistant Secretary of State Gaston J. Sigur Jr., who visited South Korea last week, said, ''It certainly looks very encouraging.'' Page A10. ]  Mr. Roh, in his address, also said that if his recommendations were not accepted, ''I will resign from all my public positions,'' including his nomination as the ruling party's presidential candidate. **********Shortly after the address, Kim Young Sam, president of the main opposition party, said he ''wholeheartedly welcomed'' Mr. Roh's announcement, but he withheld further comment, saying it remained to be seen what President Chun would say. 'We Will Watch and See' **********''We will watch and see whether this means Chun Doo Hwan will sincerely carry out what we - meaning the people - want to have.'' **********Mr. Kim said the opposition would stop the demonstrations, He also warned that the protests would resume in August unless the proposal is put into effect, and he set a deadline of September for constitutional change, with elections to be held in October or November. **********It is not clear, however, how much control the opposition leaders have over students and church groups that have been involved in the unrest. Announcement Widely Welcomed **********Kim Dae Jung also welcomed Mr. Roh's announcement, and said he expected President Chun to accept it. **********That opinion was echoed by a National Assemblyman from the ruling party. ''Of course the President can say no to this, but I don't think he will,'' said the Assemblyman, Hyun Hong Choo, who often serves as an unofficial party spokesman. **********Mr. Hyun said many assemblymen from his party had ''felt this was the only way.'' ''The people will welcome this, and there's no way for the opposition to object,'' he said. An Important Breakthrough **********Mr. Kim also told Korean reporters that if there are indeed direct elections, he would abide by an announcement last fall that he would not seek the presidency himself. **********Mr. Kim, 61 years old, ran unsuccessfully for President in 1971, coming close to defeating then-President Park Chung Hee. Since that election, he has spent most of his time in prison or house arrest, or in exile abroad. **********Today's announcement was potentially the most important breakthrough in the political crisis that has gripped South Korea for the last three weeks, and which has been marked by some of the most intense and sustained street violence during the seven years that Mr. Chun, a former general, has held power. **********Mr. Chun intends to step down in February 1988. **********Unrest has been building for the last two months over the critical issue of how to change the constitutional process for selecting South Korea's national leader. Mr. Chun had suspended debate on the subject in April, but the disturbances grew in intensity this month, and he reversed himself last week and urged that talks resume. Direct Elections Sought **********Now, it appears that the ruling camp has decided on even further concessions that it hopes will bring the opposition Reunification Democratic Party into negotiations that it has thus far resisted. **********For many months, the opposition has insisted upon direct elections, while the ruling party had demanded that if the Constitution is to be changed, it should be in favor of a cabinet system headed by a prime minister. **********For his part, Mr. Chun had said that he would accept any compromise devised by the two sides, but he also made clear that he was satisfied with the existing Constitution, which calls for the president to be elected indirectly by a 5,000-member electoral college. **********The opposition has charged that this system is weighted unfairly in the ruling party's favor, and it has pressed for direct elections as being more democratic and also its only hope to gain power. An Unexpected Development **********That the ruling camp is now prepared to agree to direct elections throws an unexpected development into an already complicated political picture. It has long been widely assumed that the ruling camp would never accept direct elections because Mr. Chun's widespread unpopularity would make it unlikely that its candidate could win. **********Mr. Roh had been designated by Mr. Chun as the successor under the existing Constitution. It was not clear whether Mr. Roh would remain his party's presidential candidate under a system of direct elections. **********There had been persistent rumors in recent days that Mr. Roh would withdraw his nomination, but some members of the ruling party have said that this offer would not necessarily be accepted and that Mr. Roh would represent the ruling side under any system. **********The crisis has been fed in good measure by the street protests that have wracked Seoul and dozens of other South Korean cities since June 10, when the Democratic Justice Party nominated Mr. Roh as its presidential candidate. Riots Had Subsided **********But street fighting between riot policemen and anti-Government protesters has subsided in recent days, raising hopes of a lull as South Korea enters its rainy season and the summer recess begins on university campuses. **********In recent days, Kim Young Sam has hinted that he might be willing to meet with Mr. Roh to discuss an end to the crisis if the ruling side offered what he called meaningful proposals. **********Mr. Kim, who met last week with Mr. Chun, has been refusing to meet with Mr. Roh, arguing that true power rested with the President.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/07/busin.body_text: **********The after-tax profits of manufacturing corporations averaged 3.3 cents a dollar of sales in the final three months of 1986, down a tenth of a cent from the corresponding period a year before, the Commerce Department reported today. **********It said American manufacturers had sales of $579.3 billion in the fourth quarter, down from $593.9 billion in the corresponding period in 1985. Manufacturers' after-tax profits totaled $19.2 billion in the fourth quarter last year, compared with $20.1 billion the year before. **********These figures translated into profits of 3.3 cents a dollar of sales in the fourth quarter last year, down from profits of 3.4 cents a dollar of sales in the fourth quarter of 1985. In the third quarter of 1986, profits were also 3.4 cents a dollar on sales of $561.2 billion. **********The drop in profits was led in the durable goods sector by declines of more than 40 percent in the machinery, transportation and instrument manufacturing sectors. Most manufacturers of nondurable goods, with the exception of petroleum refiners, reported increases in profits in the same period.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/05/busin.body_text: **********The Emigrant Savings Bank, once one of New York City's most prominent housing lenders, has been sold to the real estate developers Seymour and Paul Milstein. **********There was no answer to telephone calls made over the weekend to Milstein Properties Inc., the brothers' development company in Manhattan. But Raymond V. O'Brien Jr., Emigrant's chairman and chief executive, said that the savings bank had been unable to meet capital requirements of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. **********''To meet those capital requirements, we had to raise money, even though we were operating profitably,'' Mr. O'Brien said. **********David Halvorson, the lawyer for the New York State Banking Department, which approved the transaction, said the Milsteins were granted ownership of Emigrant last week after agreeing to provide $90 million in capital to the institution. There was no additional purchase price for the savings bank, which has $3.4 billion in assets. **********''To the extent the Milsteins' money is now at risk, they have not gotten it for free,'' Mr. Halvorson said. Still, the fact that the Milsteins paid nothing to outsiders is a reflection of how bad the Emigrant's financial condition had become. Suffered in Early 1980's **********Like other New York savings banks, Emigrant suffered in the early 1980's from high interest rates and limits on what it could charge for loans. The savings bank, which was founded 150 years ago as a financial institution for Irish immigrants, has never fully recovered from its losses. **********At the time of the sale, its liabilities exceeded its assets by about $60 million, and the institution had been given net worth certificates from the Federal Government. The certificates are given by the Government to troubled institutions as capital that has to be repaid. **********Emigrant does, however, have what bankers would call an excellent ''franchise'': 27 offices in New York City, 500,000 depositors and 70,000 borrowers. **********Moreover, unlike many troubled savings and loans insured by the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, the difficulties of F.D.I.C.-insured savings banks such as Emigrant have resulted primarily from swings in interest rates, according to Allan Bortel, the head of savings institutions research at Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. **********Troubled F.S.L.I.C. institutions may have a ''black hole'' of bad loans, Mr. Bortel said, making institutions like Emigrant more attractive to a prospective buyer. He added that the Milsteins, by injecting new capital into Emigrant, had ''helped take the F.D.I.C. off the hook.'' **********Indeed, the Milsteins apparently believe that, managed well, the Emigrant network can be highly profitable. Will Become a Stock Company **********Buyers of other local savings banks have believed similarly of late. On Dec. 24, the Williamsburgh Savings Bank of Brooklyn was sold to the Republic National Bank of New York. And in recent years, the East River Savings Bank and the Bowery Savings Bank were sold. **********As in the case of the Williamsburgh bank, Emigrant will be converted from a mutual form of ownership to a stock company. The stock will then be transferred to the Milsteins, who will own 100 percent of the shares. **********Although a mutual savings bank is technically owned by its depositors, under New York law depositors do not get to vote on a sale of their institution if its net worth-to-assets ratio is less than 3 percent. In this case, the ratio is negative, so depositors will have no voice in the matter. **********The Emigrant's most senior managers, including Mr. O'Brien, will keep their jobs. The savings bank's 15 trustees will become board members of the new stock company, along with a representative of the Milsteins. **********Although it is unusual for a real estate developer to control a savings institution, this is not the first time it has happened. According to Mr. Halvorson, there are Federal and state laws intended to prevent property developers from using a savings institution to finance their own projects at favorable rates. **********For example, he said, loans to the Milsteins will have to be secured, and such loans will need the prior approval of Emigrant's independent directors. Expanding Real Estate Interests **********Although the Milsteins are probably best known for their real estate projects in New York City, they are also industrialists. **********Seymour Milstein, 66 years old, was formerly chairman and chief executive of the United Brands Company, the giant food products concern. His brother, Paul, 63, was president of United Brands. About three years ago, the Milsteins sold their interest in United Brands to Carl H. Lindner, a Cincinnati investor. **********Together with three of their sons, the Milsteins run an ever-expanding real estate business whose holdings include the Biltmore, Roosevelt and Milford Plaza hotels; three large apartment towers with 1,964 units near Lincoln Center; an apartment building at Third Avenue and 29th Street, and the Bank of America Building on the East Side. Although they do not rank with the top New York real estate developers in terms of holdings, the Milsteins are among the most active and aggressive. **********Their father, Morris Milstein, co-founded two building materials companies: the Circle Floor Company and the Mastic Tile Corporation of America. Both companies flourished in the postwar housing boom, and the brothers succeeded their father in running the businesses, which they used to build their real estate company.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/29/world.main_headline: Rights Group Reports Continued Abuses of Liberty in Turkey
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/29/world.print_headline: Rights Group Reports Continued Abuses of Liberty in Turkey
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/29/world.body_text: **********Despite steps taken by the Turkish Government to stop human rights abuses, violations of citizens' liberties still continue, according to a 1987 report issued last week by the Helsinki Watch Committee. **********The committee, which monitors compliance with the 1975 Helsinki accords, said that although citizens are now allowed access to human rights groups and there is greater freedom of the press, torture is still ''routinely practiced'' in police detention. **********''Our expectations for continued human rights progress in Turkey have not yet been fulfilled,'' the committee concluded in the 158-page report. **********The Turkish Embassy, in a statement Friday in Washington, described the report as ''overwhelmed by a mass of misinformation, misinterpretation and omission of material facts.'' **********Turks are to decide in a parliamentary election today whether to keep the Government of Prime Minister Turgut Ozal. A referendum passed in September, which allows previously banned politicians to take part, is one change hailed by Helsinki Watch. **********''There have been noticeable changes,'' the executive director of Helskinki Watch, Jeri Laber, said in a telephone interview. ''What hasn't happened is that violations have not been eliminated. There's been a lot of talk and very little implementation.'' The report was based on interviews with 100 Turks in June. **********Among significant changes is a ''kind of glasnost in the press, and greater freedom to criticize human rights abuses,'' said Ms. Lauber, one of the report's authors. But some reporters and politicians have been prosecuted for their opinions, it said. **********The report also said that Turkey had allowed the establishment of a Human Rights Association, which is now monitoring many problems, and that citizens were allowed, with some restrictions, to file complaints with the European Commission on Human Rights. **********Another sign of progress has been the lifting of martial law. But despite Government assertions to the contrary, police torture is ''widespread and common,'' the report said. **********It said the Kurds, an ethnic minority, are severely repressed by the Government, which deprives them of their ethnic identity by forbidding their language in official settings, or the practice of their customs. **********In its response, the Turkish Embassy said, ''Torture of detainees is a felony crime.'' It added, ''There is no ethnic discrimination in Turkey.''
