https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/12/world.main_headline: Honecker Flies Home, Leaving a Puzzle Behind
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/12/world.print_headline: Honecker Flies Home, Leaving a Puzzle Behind
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/12/world.body_text: **********Erich Honecker, the East German leader, ended his long-anticipated visit to West Germany today with a smile and a jaunty wave, and left West Germans confused over an off-the-cuff remark that the border between the Germanys could someday be like East Germany's border with Poland. **********After a final stop in Bavaria for political talks and a visit to the site of the Dachau concentration camp, Mr. Honecker swapped the West German Air Force Boeing 707 he had used for internal travel for a Soviet-made Ilyushin-62 and left Munich for East Berlin. **********The five-day visit, he declared, had been ''timely, useful and appropriate,'' and as he left he seemed considerably more jaunty than when he landed at Bonn Airport at the start of his visit on Monday, the first East German leader ever to visit West Germany. **********While the visit, as expected, produced few concrete agreements, it marked a milestone in the complex and sometimes bitter relations of two states carved out of one nation at the end of World War II. Shopping for Credits **********Though Mr. Honecker surrendered nothing of his basic premise that the division is permament, and the West Germans stuck to their constitutional commitment to reunification, at the end both sides agreed that the visit had contributed to the process of stabilizing and improving relations. **********For Mr. Honecker, too, the visit was a chance to shop for valuable new credits and trade from his wealthy capitalist cousins. Dining with captains of West German industry, touring the industrial centers of Essen and Dusseldorf or calling on Franz Josef Strauss, the leader of Bavaria, Mr. Honecker lobbied openly for more deals. **********Mr. Honecker left behind a lively debate over what he had meant Thursday when, on a sentimental visit to Neunkirchen, the Saar Valley town where he was born, he briefly parted from a prepared text to address the sensitive issue of the border between the two Germanys. **********Throughout his visit, Mr. Honecker had come under sustained pressure to loosen contacts across the border, and in particular to end the policy of shooting would-be defectors on sight. For most of his trip, Mr. Honecker, who oversaw the construction of the Berlin wall in 1961 as the head of East German security, made no direct response, stressing instead East Germany's fundamental tenet that Germany will never be one again and demanding recognition as a legitimate and sovereign state. **********In Neunkirchen, however, he said that because East Germany and West Germany belonged to opposing military alliances, ''it is only too understandable that the border is obviously not as it should be.'' 'Our Border Can Fall' **********But he said he believed that if the countries lived up to the communique signed in Bonn on Tuesday, ''then the day will come when the borders will not separate us but will unite us as the border between the German Democratic Republic and the Polish People's Republic.'' **********The tabloid Bild carried the statement under the banner headline, ''Sensation! Honecker: Our border can fall.'' But other newspapers, politicians and Western diplomats reacted with considerably more caution, noting above all that since the days of the Solidarity free trade union in Poland, East Germans and Poles have required notarized invitations and visas to visit each other's country. **********Some thought Mr. Honecker may have been referring indirectly to the East German policy on its West German border of shooting would-be defectors on sight. The practice came under sustained and bitter attack throughout Mr. Honecker's visit. **********Diplomats said the policy was evidently not in force on the Polish border, probably because if someone did find a reason to sneak across it illegally, he would be promptly sent back. **********Friedhelm Ost, the Bonn Government spokesman, said cautiously that Mr. Honecker's comment suggested that East Germany ''was moving in what we regard as the right direction.'' **********Mr. Strauss, the conservative Bavarian leader and Mr. Honecker's host in Munich, said in a toast to the East German today that ''we won't draw utopian or fantastic conclusions from your words, but see them as signs of hope for a better way into a more secure future.'' A 'Different' Border **********According to some Western diplomats, Mr. Honecker was essentially trying to suggest that the border between the Germanys was ''different'' because of their different military alliances, and not because East Germans desperately wanted to cross to the West. East German propaganda holds that the wall was thrown up to prevent reactionary assaults on the new socialist state. **********An ancillary suggestion, the diplomats said, was that the border could be made freer if the West Germans agreed to the ''fraternal'' customs of the Soviet bloc. The East Germans are bitterly opposed to Bonn's policy of accepting any East German defectors automatically as West German citizens. **********Mr. Honecker spent his last day in West Germany in Bavaria, the prosperous southern region governed by Mr. Strauss. Though a staunch conservative, Mr. Strauss took the surprising lead two years ago in organizing a major line of credit for East Germany, and since then he has built up Bavaria's trade links with a series of visits to the annual Leipzig trade fairs. **********At Dachau, the site of one of Nazi Germany's most terrible death camps, Mr. Honecker laid a giant wreath of red roses before a wall inscribed with the words ''Never Again'' in several languages and chatted to several survivors of the camp. **********Mr. Honecker, who spent 10 years in a Nazi prison for his Communism and lost many of his party comrades in concentration camps, paid tribute to those who struggled against Fascism and those who were its victims with ''special inner emotion.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/15/busin.main_headline: Texaco Asks Court To Review Ruling
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/15/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Texaco Asks Court To Review Ruling
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/15/busin.body_text: **********Texaco Inc. has asked the Texas Court of Appeals to reconsider an earlier ruling upholding the original verdict in its dispute with the Pennzoil Company. The dispute involves Texaco's purchase of the Getty Oil Company. Although the appeals court originally ruled against Texaco, it reduced the total damages by $2 billion, to $10.53 billion. **********Lawyers for Texaco said the request, which was filed Wednesday afternoon in Houston, was primarily a procedural matter intended to protect its position for a future appeal to the Texas Supreme Court. The appeals court turned down a previous Texaco request for reconsideration late last month. However, G. Irvin Terrell, an attorney for Pennzoil, said that Texaco was ''presenting exactly the same points of complaint which the court has twice before ruled have no merit.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/30/world.main_headline: In East Berlin, Dissenters Resist a Crackdown
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/30/world.print_headline: In East Berlin, Dissenters Resist a Crackdown
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/30/world.body_text: **********Candles were burning Saturday evening in Zion Evangelical Church, and bunches of flowers were tied to a metal fence outside. Young men and women were holding a protest vigil, while uniformed policemen patrolled outside and secret policemen mingled with the onlookers. **********The vigil began after the police raided the parish house Tuesday night, arrested two members of a peace and ecological group operating under church auspices and confiscated printing equipment as well as material produced by this equipment that was termed ''hostile to the state.'' **********The two men were freed today, but church advocates asserted this evening that the vigil would continue until the equipment was returned and until reported criminal investigations against seven church campaigners were halted. Outside East Berlin, many people who sympathize with similar peace and ecological groups were called to East German police stations for questioning and ordered to stay away from the capital. **********The crackdown, occurring at a time when a milder wind from Moscow is blowing through the Communist camp, bringing greater tolerance for criticism, has shocked East Germans and provoked debate within party circles, according to informed Communist Party members. **********At the same time, it has prompted a soul-searching among leaders of Protestant churches, under whose protection a widespread protest movement has sprung up in this tightly ruled country. Churchmen sympathize with most of the aims of the young critics of the regime but fear that some are taking shelter in their churches without sharing Christian ideals, even loosely interpreted, and are endangering the relative tolerance that dissidents have secured under the aegis of religion. The newsletter published by the Zion Church Peace and Environment Circle has been critical of what its members consider the restrictive human rights policies of the regime of President Erich Honecker, the party leader. Nevertheless, dissidents and churchmen believe that this week's police action was not so much aimed at this newsletter as at a more radical one known as Grenzfall that is not affiliated with the church but may have been produced on the same production equipment. **********''We have nothing to do with Grenzfall,'' said the Rev. Gunter Krusche, whose title of general superintendent makes him the equivalent of the Evangelical Bishop of Berlin. **********In an interview in his suburban residence, Bishop Krusche was careful not to disavow the views of the more radical paper, whose title means ''borderline case.'' But he expressed painful doubt over the effects of implicating the church in its publication. **********''Our critics say, 'Jesus was here for everybody, but you throw them out,' '' the Bishop reflected. ''We don't, but the church should stay the church. The task of the church is not the same as that of the political opposition.'' Obligation to Help Moderates **********Bishop Krusche, aware of the absence of other channels of free expression, said the church's functions included that of being a ''safety valve'' in a tightly controlled country. **********''But if we grant asylum, this also puts on obligation on those who take asylum,'' he continued. The obligation, he suggested, is to support the moderates against the hard-liners in an ideological struggle that he said is under way in East Germany as in the Soviet Union. **********Bishop Krusche depicted Mr. Honecker as a leader who is more pragmatic than ideological but is under pressure from hard-liners. **********While dissidents and the state were confronting each other on church grounds, an earlier intrusion into the Zion church was the subject of a trial that began Friday. **********Four members of a gang of young neo-Nazis who called themselves ''Skinheads'' faced an East Berlin court for having raided the church during a rock concert last month. They are accused of having beaten members of the audience with bottles, causing many injuries, and of having vandalized church property while shouting anti-Semitic and Nazi slogans.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/02/busin.body_text: **********Ridge Vineyards Inc., a California winery, has merged with an American subsidiary of the Otsuka Pharmaceutical Company for an undisclosed amount. Founded in 1959, Ridge is in the Santa Cruz Mountains. **********Otsuka, a $1.5 billion company based in Japan, produces pharmaceutical and nutritional products and has recently begun a small wine-making operation near Mount Fuji. The Ridge sale, announced on Wednesday, is Otsuka's first wine operation in the United States. **********William H. Curtiss, Ridge's president, said that the winery's four founding families had decided to sell because of pending changes in capital gains taxation and that Otsuka met their condition ''not to sell to anyone who wouldn't pledge to keep Ridge as Ridge.'' **********Ridge, which is known for its zinfandel and cabernet sauvignon, produces between 35,000 and 40,000 cases of wine annually. Paul F. Perret, president of Otsuka USA Inc., said the Japanese company already had several ventures with American companies.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/04/world.body_text: **********A Zairian stood recently in front of the rusting and empty cages of Lubumbashi's zoo, once the finest in central Africa. ''With Mobutu's economic policies, people have eaten all the monkeys,'' he said without humor. **********Mobutu Sese Seko, Zaire's President since 1965 and a close ally of the United States, presides over a vast African nation that is politically stable but is losing the race for economic development. **********Called the Belgian Congo until independence in 1960, Zaire covers a land mass equal to the United States east of the Mississippi. With 35 million inhabitants, Zaire is sub-Saharan Africa's second most populous nation, after Nigeria. An Economy in Shambles **********But Zaire now seems to be black Africa's classic case of mismanaged independence. **********In 1960, a visitor could drive across the country, from this capital on the banks of the Congo River, 200 miles from the Atlantic, to the game parks near Lake Tanganyika, 1,000 miles to the east, in two days. Today, the same drive takes two weeks and a four-wheel drive vehicle. Of 85,000 miles of roads at independence, about 12,000 miles are now passable. **********The collapse of the road system prompted the collapse of economic life in much of Zaire's interior. A farm exporter before independence, the nation now imports 60 percent of its food needs. Real wages are calculated to have fallen to 10 percent of their pre-independence levels. Half of all children die before the age of 5. The current gross national product is at about the level of 30 years ago. The Wealth of Mobutu **********A black elite has replaced the colonial white elite. The new elite has failed to develop the nation. But it has made Kinshasa's Mercedes dealership the largest in black Africa. **********''Corruption remains the most serious problem,'' according to a classified State Department briefing paper prepared for Mr. Mobutu's weeklong visit to Washington last December. ''Mobutu is reputed to be one of the world's wealthiest men.'' The paper went on to estimate his worth at more than $5 billion. **********Zairian officials did not respond to requests for interviews for this article. But in an interview with The New York Times during his visit to Washington in December, Mr. Mobutu said he and his nation were ''victims of disinformation.'' **********Some of Mr. Mobutu's overseas real estate holdings are public knowledge. They include chateaus in Spain and Belgium, a townhouse in Paris, a villa near Monte Carlo, an estate in Switzerland, a horse ranch in Portgual and a villa in the Ivory Coast. **********After his meeting with President Reagan, where he asked for easier terms in servicing his nation's $4.5 billion debt, President Mobutu rented a Concorde to fly his daughter to her wedding in Abidjan. Disastrous 'Zairianization' **********Although Zaire has one of Africa's largest markets and a liberal investment code, and has been trying to follow International Monetary Fund policies for most of the last four years, few foreign investors have come forward in recent years. One disincentive has been a sharp drop in earnings from Zaire's principal commodity exports -copper and cobalt. But many investors seem wary after watching economic policy zig-zag during 26 years of independence. **********After civil war in the early 1960's, many foreign investors were ''Zairianized'' in the early 70's. **********''The phone rang at 7:30 in the morning, and officials said they were coming over to take over my company,'' a wheat miller recalled bitterly. During the year under Zairian management, he said, his company milled 176 tons of flour, compared to 23,000 the year before. **********In other cases, Zairians took over missionary schools and hospitals and sold all the equipment, even the doors and windows. **********By 1975, many of the properties were returned to their previous owners. But many of the owners, disillusioned, sold their interests. **********Further surprises followed. In December 1979, President Mobutu declared that a new currency was in circulation. Hundreds of thousands of people lost their life savings. In 1984, as part of an International Monetary Fund program, the currency was devalued to one-fifth of its previous value. The Keys to Mobutu's Rule **********Mr. Mobutu's major achievement seems to be that, having forged a nation from 200 different tribes, he has endured as its head for 21 years. He has achieved this through a mix of personal charisma, political acumen and police repression. **********''Mobutu is a far more complex character than just someone ripping this place off,'' a Western businessman said. ''He is a consummate politician.'' **********From his beginnings as an army sergeant and newspaper reporter named Joseph-Desire Mobutu, he rose to army Chief of Staff at independence and rapidly eliminated all rivals for the supreme leadership. He adopted the name Mobutu Sese Seko Koko Ngbendu wa za Banga, which translates: ''The all powerful warrior who, because of his endurance and inflexible will to win, will go from conquest to conquest leaving fire in his wake.'' **********As a politician, Mr. Mobutu has a knack for co-opting enemies and shuffling his Cabinet to keep potential rivals off balance. **********The most recent example of co-optation is Nguza Karl I Bond, once a diehard opponent of Mr. Mobutu. Sentenced to death here for treason, Mr. Nguza testified in the early 1980's before a committee of the United States House of Representatives that was investigating reports that Mr. Mobutu had embezzled United States aid funds. **********Last year, Mr. Mobutu sent Mr. Nguza back to Washington - this time as Zaire's Ambassador to the United States. 'Torture Is Used Frequently' **********In 1984, in the last election here, Mr. Mobutu polled 99.16 percent of the vote. To make sure that the discontented eighty-four hundredths of 1 percent do not get out of hand, Mr. Mobutu maintains a highly effective police and intelligence system. **********According to a report issued last October by Amnesty International, ''torture is used frequently and on occasions extensively.'' **********The 1985 State Department human rights report on Zaire said: ''Suspects are often arrested and held for months without a hearing. Detainees with financial resources are known to buy their way out.'' **********Last March, the president of the Zairian League for the Defense of Human Rights was sent into internal exile. **********Zaire's state-run press rarely touches such topics and most Zairians know to steer clear of the police. **********''Because of the 'mouchards,' no one trusts each other,'' a Zairian journalist said of the police informers. **********Another Zairian said: ''Everyone keeps quiet. If I move, if I talk, they grab me.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/05/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Visa Will Join Plus Network
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/05/busin.body_text: **********In a move that could create a larger nationwide network of automatic-teller machines, Plus System Inc. said it would permit the 17,000 banks that issue Visa cards to join Plus, a network with 13,000 automatic tellers. Plus had been essentially a private network owned by 34 banks, but the Visa link means as many as a third of the nation's automatic tellers could eventually be part of Plus, which could grow to 20,000 tellers by 1990, according to system officials. **********Visa will also maintain its separate teller system, which is primarily a credit card network that provides loans in the form of cash advances to holders of Visa cards. Plus, in comparison, allows savings and checking account holders to make direct withdrawals from accounts. Under the agreement announced yesterday, Visa, which is a consortium of banks, will be entitled to appoint seven directors to Plus's 21-member board.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/23/busin.main_headline: Some U.S. Officials See Slower Growth
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/23/busin.print_headline: Some U.S. Officials See Slower Growth
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/23/busin.body_text: **********Because of increases in interest rates, turbulence over the dollar and impasses in making international policy, some Government officials say they expect the American economy to be weaker this year than they were predicting a few months ago. **********On Thursday the Administration will release a report that a senior Administration economist predicted might show little change from the slow, 2.5 percent growth of 1986. Even if the report produces one of its periodic surprises, many economists now see little hope that the Administration will be able to fulfill its own assurances of 3.2 percent growth for this year. **********Slower growth could worsen the Administration's already difficult budget negotiations with Congress, stop the decline of the Federal budget deficits and dampen efforts to help developing countries cope with their debts. The officials also see growth slowing in other major countries such as Japan and West Germany. Lower Target Seen **********''We haven't formally dialed back, but I think we probably will,'' said Edward M. Gramlich, deputy director of the Congressional Budget Office, which makes economic forecasts for Congress. Early this year, the C.B.O. predicted 3 percent growth this year, a little less than the 3.2 percent forecast compiled by three Administration agencies - the Office of Management and Budget, the Council of Economic Advisers and the Treasury's economics staff. **********''I'm still very comfortable with that forecast,'' said M. Kathryn Eickhoff, chief economist at the Office of Management and Budget. She said she saw the economy gaining momentum in the second half of 1987. **********But on Tuesday evening, an Administration-appointed governor of the Federal Reserve Board, Wayne D. Angell, told a gathering of conservative economists here, ''I know very well we are not going to be growing as fast as the O.M.B. projected.'' Mr. Angell said today that since early 1986 he had been expecting 2 percent growth this year, well below the average for the 12 officials who produce the forecast. ''I don't seem so out of step now,'' he said. **********Some prominent forecasters have already made sharp changes in their figures. Two weeks ago, the International Monetary Fund cut its estimates to show 2.3 percent growth for the United States and 2.7 percent for the world economy. Last October, the I.M.F. predicted 3.5 percent growth for the United States and 3.1 percent for the world. **********A consensus of private American economists whose forecasts are compiled in a newsletter called Blue Chip Economic Indicators shows 2.4 percent growth for the United States now, a reduction from 2.9 percent expected last September. Consequences of Slower Growth **********Such revisions seem minuscule, but economists and Government officials say that growth of 3 percent or more in the United States and in other major industrial countries, unlike 2 percent, provides the demand in world trade needed to pull along poorer countries and help them collect the funds they use to make payments on their debts. And in a world economy ever more interdependent, they say, the faster pace also helps the poorer countries feed growth of the industrial countries. **********''The scenario now shows positive but inadequate growth,'' a senior Administration official said. He attributed the slow growth to policy imbroglios among the major industrial countries - the American inability to assure continued reduction in the Federal budget deficits and West German and Japanese reluctance to adopt policies that stimulate their growth. **********Other officials said the sharp decline of the dollar was now jeopardizing the American contribution to faster growth - continued reduction in budget deficits. **********The deficit reached a record $220.7 billion in the fiscal year 1986. The Congressional Budget Office has been predicting a sharp decline in the figure for this year, to $175 billion. However, increases in interest rates caused by the latest declines of the dollar mean the Government must pay more interest on the national debt, so a C.B.O. official said the deficit this year could be $180 billion. **********Then, because of higher interest rates and because this year's deficit reduction includes increases in revenue from one-shot sales of Government loans and other assets, next year's deficit might be no smaller than $180 billion, he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/14/world.main_headline: REAGAN PLANNING TO SEEK MORE AID FOR THE CONTRAS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/14/world.print_headline: REAGAN PLANNING TO SEEK MORE AID FOR THE CONTRAS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/14/world.body_text: **********The White House is planning to ask Congress next month to provide additional military aid to the Nicaraguan rebels, should peace talks in Central America falter, senior Administration officials said today. **********A major purpose of additional aid would be to protect the rebels from Sept. 30, when the fiscal year ends, to Nov. 7, the deadline for a cease-fire in Nicaragua envisioned in a peace plan advanced by Costa Rica. **********But in Managua, the Vice President of Nicaragua said the Sandinista Government was ready to fulfill a key section of the peace plan - restoration of full press and political freedoms - only if the United States stopped aiding the rebels.  [ Page A8. ]  A Change in Direction One Administration official, speaking to reporters aboard Air Force One on the way here for two appearances by the President, noted that the Administration had always planned to seek more aid next month. ''Our current plan is still to go up in September,'' the official said. **********But the comments today mark a change in tone and direction by the Administration, which has been criticized by key conservatives for having announced its own plan for Central America last week in cooperation with Jim Wright, Democrat of Texas, the Speaker of the House. Two days later, five Central American presidents signed the Costa Rican-sponsored plan, which differs in some significant ways from the Reagan-Wright plan. **********Mr. Wright and State Department officials have both said that the Central American plan had become the focus of their attention. Other officials were also quoted as saying that military aid to the rebels was on the ''back burner'' because of uncertainty over how peace talks would progress. White House Takes Issue **********But today, the White House took direct issue with those statements. Asked if the White House now saw the plan proposed by President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica as pre-eminent, one official said, ''We have not agreed with that characterization.'' **********''We feel like the agreement we made last week is still the operative agreement,'' a White House official said. That agreement, he added, ''leaves clearly in place a deadline.'' **********In the White House view, the original Reagan-Wright plan still guides its policies. In particular, that means that the White House considers Sept. 30 to be the deadline for democratic changes in Nicaragua. **********Administration officials are particularly concerned about the period between Sept. 30 and Nov. 7. ''We've got an interregnum that we're going to have to deal with,'' a senior Administration official said. Other senior officials have said that the contras have enough money and supplies to carry them into November. Wright Declines Comment **********Speaker Wright, in an interview earlier this week, said the President had promised him he would not ask for military aid until after the Sept. 30 deadline in the Reagan-Wright plan. He and other Democrats actively involved in the Central American peace plan discussions declined comment today on the White House's remarks. **********The White House's disagreement with Mr. Wright came the day after President Reagan said in a nationally broadcast speech that the legislative and executive branches ''need to regain trust in each other,'' and that there ''is now a growing sense that we can accomplish more by cooperating.'' **********The White House is clearly annoyed at Mr. Wright's quick embrace of the Central American plan and alarmed at attacks from some Republican conservatives who accuse the Administration of selling out the contras. **********''We clearly want to send a message that the President has not walked away from the contras,'' a senior official said. Insertion in Reagan Speech **********The official noted that this growing concern within the White House was responsible for the insertion at the last moment of a sentence in the President's speech Wednesday night, declaring: ''We have always been willing to talk - we have never been willing to abandon those who are fighting for democracy and freedom.'' **********One important difference between the Reagan plan, and the one advanced by Costa Rica relates to deadlines. Mr. Reagan called for an immediate cease-fire and said that basic changes in the political structure of Nicaragua should be in place by Sept. 30, the day the current aid package of $100 million for the contras runs out. **********The Arias plan calls for a cease-fire, a free press and procedures for elections to be in place by Nov. 7. **********One Administration official referred to the contras several times as an ''insurance policy'' against delay and deceit by the Sandinistas. **********''We plan to address the funding issue in a way that will insure that support for the contras continues until we are all satisfied that there is a peace plan that will insure the peaceful reintegration and democratization of Nicaragua,'' he said. 'Game Plan' Not Yet Final **********The official said the Administration's ''game plan'' was not yet final. But he indicated that one possibility was a suggestion advanced by Senator Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas, that aid be granted on a conditional basis, pending the outcome of peace talks. **********In an interview with reporters, Howard H. Baker Jr., the White House chief of staff, said the President had not yet made a final decision on requesting more aid next month. One key question, he said, will be ''whether realistic progress is being made'' in peace talks. **********The Administration has long been critical of the Sandinistas and suspicious of their motives, and those feelings emerged today in a number of Administration comments. **********A senior Presidential adviser noted that Daniel Ortega Saavedra, the Nicaraguan President, was now in Cuba and asserted that he was ''getting his instructions'' on how to handle future peace talks. **********Asked why Mr. Ortega had agreed to sign the Arias plan, an Administration aide said it was because of ''economic isolation'' and mismanagement, pressure from neighboring democracies and the military threat of the contras. Interests of U.S. and Contras **********In a speech at the Buffalo Bill Wild West Arena in North Platte, Mr. Reagan, who is on his way to California for a vacation, referred briefly to the peace talks in Central America and stressed that any peace plan ''must be consistent with the interests of the United States and must be consistent with the intrests of those fighting for freedom in Nicaragua.'' **********In those comments, the President was clearly trying to distance himself from specifics of the Arias plan and leave open the possibility that he might reject an accord reached by Central American leaders. **********He spoke earlier in the day to community leaders at the Ted Long ranch. **********Discussing Mr. Reagan's Wednesday night speech, Marlin Fitzwater, the President's spokesman, said the President had wanted to discuss the Iran-contra affair in greater detail, but was talked out of that plan by his staff.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/23/world.main_headline: Missile Reportedly Fired by Iran Damages a Kuwaiti Oil Terminal
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/23/world.print_headline: Missile Reportedly Fired by Iran Damages a Kuwaiti Oil Terminal
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/23/world.body_text: **********Kuwait's main offshore oil terminal was seriously damaged in a missile attack today, and Kuwaiti and American officials said Iran was responsibile. **********It was the third missile attack in eight days on targets in Kuwaiti waters. All the attacks have been attributed to Chinese-made Silkworm missiles fired from Iranian-occupied territory in the Fao Peninsula of Iraq. **********The attack today occurred at the Sea Island export terminal and caused an explosion that could be heard in Kuwait city, more than 25 miles away. **********A dense cloud of black smoke rose over Sea Island, an artificial platform of concrete and steel pipes about 10 miles off Kuwait's major oil port of Al Ahmadi. Three workers aboard the platform, which usually has a crew of 20, were reported wounded. **********There was no immediate comment by Iran on the incident. **********The Sea Island terminal, connected by a system of pipes to the complex at Al Ahmadi, is vital to Kuwait's oil exports. It is the main installation for handling supertankers, which are too big to go into the shallower waters at Al Ahmadi. Fire Is Extinguished **********Film on Kuwait television tonight appeared to show extensive damage to the platform, but there was no immediate official assessment of how badly the terminal had been hit. **********Fireboats and tugs put out the fire on the terminal by afternoon, Kuwait Oil Company officials said. But by evening workers were trying to contain leaking crude petroleum. **********Kuwait's Defense Minister, Sheik Salem al-Sabah, a member of the royal family, identified the missile as a Silkworm fired from the Fao Peninsula, which Iran has seized from Iraq. He said Kuwaiti forces stationed on Failaka Island, about 20 miles offshore, saw the missile coming overhead. **********''This type of practice does not serve security and stability in the Arabian Gulf, but increases tension and escalates the conflict,'' the Defense Minister told the Kuwaiti press agency. **********In Washington, Pentagon officials also said the missile was an Iranian-fired Silkworm. Two Tankers Hit **********Last Thursday, a missile struck the American-owned, Liberian-registered tanker Sungari near Al Ahmadi. On Friday, another hit the American-registered Sea Isle City, part of the re-registered Kuwaiti oil fleet the American Navy is protecting, also in Kuwaiti waters. **********On Monday, in response to the attack on the Sea Isle City, the United States raided two Iranian platforms in the gulf, bombarding one with 1,000 shells. Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger charged that the platforms were used as command centers for Iranian speedboats harassing gulf shipping. Since then, Iranian leaders have issued vows of vengeance. **********In Beirut today, the pro-Iranian organization Islamic Holy War said Moslems in the gulf were preparing for suicide missions and threatened to mount terrorist attacks against the United States and Europe. **********''The coming few days will reveal to the world America's paper-thin ability to confront Moslems,'' said the typewritten statement delivered to an international news agency in Beirut. ''The conditions of the Europeans will not be any better.'' **********The message was accompanied by black and white photographs of two of the hostages Islamic Holy War is holding, Terry Anderson, an Associated Press correspondent, and Jean-Paul Kauffman, a French researcher. This is the customary method of authenticating the message. 'A Turning Point' **********''This is a kind of a turning point in the conflict because Kuwait is suddenly much more involved than it was a day ago,'' said a Western diplomat here. ''It is a most disturbing development.'' **********The attack, he said, will strike fear into the Kuwaitis because it shows the Iranians are now able to strike at will at the oil sites that are the basis of the country's vast wealth. **********Kuwait, fearing the export of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's Islamic fundamentalist revolution, has backed Iraq in the gulf war, contributing billions of dollars and allowing Iraqi military supplies through its ports. **********Kuwait drew the United States and, to a much lesser extent, the Soviet Union into the plan to protect its oil fleet, largely in the hope that the superpowers would then find a way to end the war. **********''Now Kuwait itself has become the target,'' the Western diplomat said. ''It's exactly the reverse of the outcome the Kuwaitis wanted. **********Americans too, he said, ''have been presented with quite a dilemma.'' **********''If they do anything it will mean a widening of their role and a widening of the gulf war. If they do nothing, Kuwait is open to attack, and it is quite clear this will not be the last attack. This is the choice they have.'' Kuwait Lodges Protest **********The charge d'affaires of the dwindling Iranian Embassy staff here -five of its diplomats were sent home last month after at least three Silkworms were fired toward Kuwait, one landing near the Foreign Minister's beach chalet - was summoned to the Foreign Ministry today. The State Minister for Foreign Affairs, Saoud Mohammed al-Osemi, told him that the ''heinous and perilous'' attack ''unveiled Iran's resolve to drag nonbelligerent countries of the region into this tragic war.'' **********Other Arab countries expressed support for Kuwait. **********In Bahrain, the Foreign Minister, Sheik Mohammed al-Khalifa, summoned the Iranian charge d'affaires to tell him that the attack had ''caused a deterioration in the situation in the gulf and aggravated tension in the region.'' **********The Saudi Defense Minister, Prince Sultan, called his Kuwaiti conterpart today to pledge support against any Iranian ''aggression.'' King Hussein of Jordan telephoned the Kuwaiti ruler, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, and President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt announced that his country was ready ''to assume its inter-Arab responsibilities toward brother Kuwait.'' **********What this might mean in practical terms was unclear. ''The likelihood is they will recieve messages of sympathy and nothing more,'' said a diplomat who has long served in the Arab world.
