https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/01/world.main_headline: TALK OF A PEACE CONFERENCE STRAINS ISRAELI COALITION
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/01/world.print_headline: TALK OF A PEACE CONFERENCE STRAINS ISRAELI COALITION
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/01/world.body_text: **********Israel's coalition Government came under new strain today because of tensions over a proposed international peace conference and the Israeli investigation into the Jonathan Jay Pollard spy case. **********Sources close to Foreign Minister Shimon Peres said today that Mr. Peres believed he had achieved enough of a commitment from King Hussein of Jordan - a commitment that the King would enter into direct negotiations with Israel under the umbrella of an international conference - to justify asking the full Israeli Cabinet to endorse the idea of such a conference formally. **********If the Cabinet rejects such a proposal, on which Mr. Peres might seek a vote within a few weeks, he would most likely try to break up the 31-month-old national unity Government and put the issue before the electorate in the form of new elections, officials of the Foreign Minister's Labor Party said. Report of 'an Understanding' **********Another Labor Party member, Energy Minister Moshe Shahal, said that ''it is no secret that there is a document, an understanding'' between Israel, Jordan, Egypt and the United States that was conveyed to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir two weeks ago by the United States. **********''It speaks about principles for direct negotiations that would start with an international conference and continue immediately to bilateral talks between those involved in the conflict - Jordan, the Palestinians and us,'' Mr. Shahal, a close associate of Mr. Peres, said. ''There has never been such a good time for Israel to start negotiations.'' **********Prime Minister Shamir, of the Likud bloc, returned today from a visit to Paris, where he tried to talk the French out of attending any such international conference. Immediately, he went on the offensive against Mr. Peres, warning the public that new elections would bring turmoil. **********''I don't feel the Government is nearing its end,'' Mr. Shamir said, ''because I don't want this to happen. There is no need for Israel to accept this Soviet idea of an international conference that would leave Israel alone against the rest of the world. I think it would be irresponsible and contrary to the national interest to throw ourselves into a whirlpool of elections and return the country, heaven forbid, to a period of inflation and instability.'' Pollard Report Is Expected **********Feeding the tension between Mr. Shamir and Mr. Peres was an announcement today by the Parliament's intelligence subcommittee, led by Abba Eban, that it had completed hearings into the Israeli Government's handling of the scandal involving Jonathan Jay Pollard, an American naval intelligence analyst sentenced to life imprisonment for spying for Israel, and would shortly issue its report. **********A source on the committee said the investigation had concluded that leading political figures, particularly Mr. Peres and Defense Minister Rabin, seriously mishandled the case. More than a few members of the Israeli Parliament and political commentators have noted that Mr. Peres and Mr. Rabin might be motivated to bring the issue of an international conference to a crisis in order to divert attention from such conclusions. **********Moreover, if an election were hastily called on the issue of peace, the Labor Party leaders could argue that it would be foolish to change the party leadership at a time when they had a good chance to defeat Likud, govern alone and advance the peace process. Peres's Achievements Unclear **********Labor Party legislators say Mr. Shamir will also not emerge unscathed from the investigation. **********It is not clear just what Jordanian concessions Mr. Peres has achieved. According to Labor officials, King Hussein has agreed to a working paper drawn up by Egypt, Jordan, Israel and the United States. **********According to Israeli officials, the paper stipulates that an international conference be convened by the Secretary General of the United Nations and that it include all ''parties'' to the conflict, as well as the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council - the United States, the Soviet Union, France, Britain and China. **********After a ceremonial opening, the conference would break up into direct negotiations between Israel and Jordan and a Palestinian delegation, and between Israel and Syria and Lebanon, should the latter two countries attend. **********It remains to be determined, however, who would represent the Palestinians. Labor Party sources insist that King Hussein has sent signals to the effect that he is ready to open talks without the Palestine Liberation Organization at his side. He has made similar declarations in the past, but has always backed away from entering talks without the P.L.O. **********The question of whether the Soviet Union would take part also remains open. Israel insists that the Russians and the Chinese can attend only if they establish diplomatic relations with Israel. Moscow is unlikely to meet this condition, or to accept only a ceremonial role at such a conference.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/23/world.main_headline: 3 Kuwait Oilfield Fires Precede Islamic Session
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/23/world.print_headline: 3 Kuwait Oilfield Fires Precede Islamic Session
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/23/world.body_text: **********As the foreign ministers of the Islamic Conference Organization met to prepare for a meeting of their nations' leaders, a shadowy group in Beirut took responsibility today for setting fire Monday night to three of Kuwait's oilfields. **********A message published today in the Beirut daily An Nahar from a group identifying itself as the ''Revolutionary Organization - the Forces of the Prophet Mohammed in Kuwait'' said: ''We threaten people who do not want to look at the right of the oppressed in Kuwait and tomorrow in Palestine.'' **********Three fires broke out at desert and offshore oil installations at about 11:30 Monday night. **********Iran has objected to the decision of the 46-member Islamic Conference Organization to hold its meeting here on the ground that Kuwait has been supporting Iraq in the Persian Gulf war. Several Iranian-influenced Islamic groups have threatened retribution.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/29/world.body_text: **********Robert Maxwell, a Scottish engineer freed by Libya last week from a 12-year jail sentence for ''economic espionage,'' flew out of Tripoli today, the Libyan news agency said. Mr. Maxwell, 38 years old, left the Libyan capital with his wife and son on a Maltese airliner, according to the report monitored here by the British Broadcasting Corporation. The plane was believed headed for Malta. Mr. Maxwell, jailed in 1982, was freed after appeals by his wife and British politicians.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/25/world.main_headline: SHANGHAI EMERGING FROM LONG ECONOMIC TORPOR
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/25/world.print_headline: SHANGHAI EMERGING FROM LONG ECONOMIC TORPOR
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/25/world.body_text: **********Despite the size of this sprawling city, its location and profusion of intellectual and technical expertise, Shanghai has stumbled almost blindly through the last three decades shackled by radical politics, neglect from the national Government and bureaucratic obstinacy. **********Now, spurred by an aggressive new Mayor, Jiang Zemin, Shanghai is emerging from its torpor. The lead that it is taking in economic experimentation appears unaffected by the latest crackdown on political dissent in China. **********The city has drafted plans to build huge industrial parks, construct a subway system to unclog roadways, rebuild the water and sewer sytems, finish a tunnel under and put a new bridge over the Huangpo River to link the two halves of town, re-equip factories laboring with obsolete Soviet-made machinery and vigorously pursue substantial foreign investment. **********''We have to do things we have never done before,'' said Yang Xirong, a consultant to the Shanghai Investment and Trust Company, the city's investment banking arm. **********''We can revise and change the way we have done things,'' the former banker said in an interview before the student unrest in Shanghai in December. Population Has Soared **********After Mao's armies took control of China in 1949, Shanghai quickly became one of the country's major industrial centers. With the growth of industry, the city's population soared, from about 5 million in 1949 to nearly 12 million by 1982. City services -water, sewerage, electricity, transportation - failed to keep pace with the expansion, a deficiency that is harshly felt today. **********While the rest of China scrambled to embrace Deng Xiaoping's call for economic change and development more than six years ago, Shanghai stubbornly wrapped itself in the political righteousness it claimed as the birthplace of the Cultural Revolution, Mao's violent effort to politicize every facet of Chinese life. **********As a consequence, the special economic zones - regions that accord special rights to foreign investors -like Xiamen and Shenzhen and cities like Canton have outstripped Shanghai in attracting foreign investment. **********Shanghai's municipal government now intends to shed the past in an effort to reassert itself. Traffic the Worst Problem **********''Shanghai's most serious problem is its traffic problem,'' said Fang Hailong, an engineer with the Shanghai Metro Corporation, offering an understatement of the daily warfare among pedestrians, bicycles, cars and trucks on the city's narrow streets. ''To build a subway is the way of solving this problem.'' **********In August the central Government gave Shanghai approval to build the subway. If the money can be raised, the first excavations will begin in 1988 on a nine-mile north-south line. If construction stays on schedule, the first subway cars will roll four years and $800 million later. Six more lines are envisioned after that. **********The subway is just one of half a dozen major capital projects the city needs just as a foundation for economic expansion. Across the Huangpo River, an underdeveloped industrial and residential expanse of Shanghai lies virtually isolated by inadequate access to the main city. Construction workers are struggling to finish a new tunnel, and the Government wants to erect a bridge across the river, a major undertaking that has yet to be financed. **********In addition, the city's water supply is unhealthy and insufficient, and piped water is unavailable in outlying reaches of the city. The sewer system is crumbling and needs to be replaced. Electricity is in short supply, and it is often impossible to make a telephone call across town. **********Work has begun on repairing the water and sewerage system, and a new telephone system is being installed by a Belgian company. Bureaucratic Changes Sought **********But it is not only the sagging public services that hobble Shanghai. Some officials argue that without fundamental changes in the Government bureaucracy and the tempering of political watchdogs from the Communist Party, there is little hope that the city can move forward. **********The Industrial and Commercial Bank recently began selling $27 million in two-year bonds to finance the expansion of municipally owned enterprises. The city has also placed $156 million in bonds on the Tokyo financial market to help finance construction projects. **********''We need money to modernize,'' said Huang Guixian, the manager of the Industrial and Commercial Bank. ''This is just an experimental period. The economy is being reformed, and finance is also being reformed. This is a step in the financial reforms. One can't get loans from the state easily. In order to break the practice of 'eating from one big pot,' we have to reform our ways.'' **********Shanghai has also tried to shake off its image as a difficult city for foreign investors. Several major foreign projects, including a Volkswagen assembly plant and a cooperative venture between China and McDonnell Douglas to assemble passenger planes, are under way. **********But many other foreign investors have been scared off to other parts of China because of the labyrinthine approval process required for any project. This, city officials insist, is changing. 'Reputation Is Not Very Good' **********''We know it is difficult to do business in Shanghai,'' said Chen Dingping, a senior vice president at the Shanghai Investment and Trust Corporation, ''not only from foreigners but from other agencies in other provinces and from Beijing. The Mayor has said we have to take serious measures to change the situation. The reputation of Shanghai is not very good. It has to be changed.'' **********Three new agencies are opening to streamline the approval process for foreign investors. The city has also been given the authority to approve all foreign investments up to $30 million. Any above that level need approval from the central Government. **********Although city officials talk about Shanghai's becoming a future Hong Kong or Singapore, they acknowledge that the transformation they seek will not be easy. Whether the city is successful will depend on continuing tolerance for the growing independence of economic centers. **********''It will take years,'' said Mr. Chen, of the Investment and Trust Coproration. ''But Shanghai has the education level, the experience. We have thousands of experts, technicians. We have a human capability much higher than other cities.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/17/world.body_text: **********Earlier this month, on the hard and mountainous terrain at Semdinli, a Turkish Army patrol walked into an ambush by Kurdish rebels and lost 13 men in half an hour of rifle fire. **********By the time the helicopters arrived, Turkish officers say, it was near dusk, and the 25 or 30 rebels had fled across the crags and ravines. **********Earlier this spring, in Tasdelen, near the Iraqi border, the rebels killed 12 villagers, including women and children, the Government and villagers said. This was because the 12 were related to village guards appointed by the Government and were thus collaborators. The Turks responded with an air strike in northern Iraq. #600 Dead in Insurgency Thus, in old and troubled lands, whose ways have not changed much in centuries, were the newest chapters written in an insurgency that, since August 1984, has claimed about 600 lives - more than a quarter of them in the military, about a third among the insurgents and the rest among civilians. **********The fighting, which traditionally revives in spring after winter's cold abates, has also focused attention on the plight of the nearly 20 million Kurds, splintered by clan and ideology, in whose name wars are being fought in three nations: Turkey, Iran and Iraq. **********Kurdish nationalism has survived over the centuries, but the Kurds, a transnational ethnic and linguistic group, have not in historical times achieved the status of a national state. **********The sporadic fighting seems both a spin-off from and a hostage to the Iran-Iraq war, which has eroded the control exercised by President Saddam Hussein's Government over northern areas of Iraq abutting the rich oilfields of Mosul and Kirkuk. **********The disintegration of Government control has helped revive the long-running insurgency of Iraqi Pesh Merga guerrillas led by Massoud Barzani and seeking autonomy for that country's 3.5 million Kurds - one-quarter of the population. Baghdad's war with Teheran has prompted both countries to support Kurdish dissidents against each other. **********Moreover, northern Iraq's lawlessness has offered a new base for the Kurdish Worker's Party led by Abdullah Ocalan, a Marxist rebel movement based in Damascus, Syria, whose support among Turkey's 8 million to 10 million Kurds seems limited and ambiguous. **********Additionally, Iran's Islamic revolution has spawned an Iraqi-backed insurgency by several Kurdish groups led by Abdolrahman Guassemlou seeking autonomy in three Iranian provinces on behalf of the nation's 5.5 million Kurds. The Iraqi and Turkish separatists are said to have a loose alliance; Iraqi and Iranian Kurds are divided by their sponsors' war. **********Iran is widely held in Turkey to be a conduit for the Soviet-made arms reaching Kurdish insurgents. This further sours relations between Ankara and Teheran that are strained by what some Turks see as Iranian efforts to stir religious ferment in Turkey, a secular nation whose population is 99 percent Moslem.  THE GOALS: A CHUNK OF EACH COUNTRY **********Kurds, a Western analyst said, have historically waged separatist campaigns in the countries in which they live rather than seek a homeland carved from all the nations in which Kurds reside. **********Thus, the Barzani forces in Iraq seek autonomy only for northern areas of Iraq, including the oilfields. The Barzani group differs from the Turkish Kurds, who are seeking a separate state in Turkey, because they acknowledge both the religion and the clan leaderships traditional to their followers, and Turkey's Kurds offer a Marxist analysis of their followers' plight. **********In Turkey, rebels are seeking to carve out a chunk of the east and declare it a Soviet-aligned state. There, the insurgency has brought an acknowledgment that the so-called Kurdish problem, woven at times in blood through Turkey's modern history, will not be wished away. **********''We do not think that there is a very easy solution as long as the Iran-Iraq war continues,'' said a Government intelligence expert in Ankara. ''And we have no optimism about an easy solution in the Iran-Iraq war.'' **********Moreover, said Lieut. Col. Sahap Tuncer, a military intelligence specialist based in Diyarbakir, the unofficial capital of Turkey's Kurdish-speaking area, ''It is not possible to achieve results with only military measures.'' **********The comment seemed to reflect a view that insurgencies are generally not won or lost on the battlefield alone. In many insurgencies, too, civilians seem to suffer most.  FOR THE VILLAGERS, TROUBLE ON 2 SIDES **********Last Jan. 22, separatist sympathizers in the village of Ortabag near the Iraqi border laid a bomb in the home of a 60-year-old shepherd accused of being a Government collaborator, and eight people died. **********The presence of insurgent sympathizers in the village, where Turkish troops are garrisoned, seemed to reflect an assessment by the Government intelligence specialist in Ankara, that the insurgents have some support, but that it is not widespread. **********The specialist estimated the insurgents' strength at no more than 1,000. Some put the figure much lower, and Colonel Tuncer said there were ''no more than 300 terrorists,'' as the insurgents are officially called. **********The murder of the shepherd underscored another reality confronting those who live in the 7,000 or so villages that freckle the mountains of eastern Turkey with flat-roofed settlements and small, tended tracts. **********''We know the villagers' problem,'' a young Turkish officer said. ''If they commit a crime'' by helping the rebels with food or shelter, ''we punish them,'' he said. ''But if they refuse to help, the rebels kill their families.''  A LAND OF CARAVANS ANB OF DIRECT DIAL **********On the roads that twist and wind here, a traveler might see a nomadic Kurdish family, horses piled high with bright rugs and copper cooking pots turned black by smoky fires. And there will be women toting babies in tasseled wraps embroidered with gold thread. **********Every 10 or 15 miles, there will be a military checkpoint, encampment or garrison, seeming to some foreigners to resemble an occupation force, but portrayed by the authorities as the front-line defense of national sovereignty - one strand of a counterinsurgency that keeps an estimated 40,000 troops in the East. **********On the roads, too, a traveler might see electricity pylons, spindly sentries on harsh lands, and telephone lines offering direct dial to distant places, and work camps on a new road retracing routes to Iraq and Iran that were plied centuries ago by traders in silk. **********In some villages, television has brought ''Dallas'' to people familiar with blood feuds, but not with high-rises or gaudy wealth. That, too, is a strand in a campaign to secure the hearts and minds of neglected people. **********The region's uncertainties - adding to those of a wider, strategic area troubled by the Iran-Iraq conflict - offered ''a problem we can solve through economic and social measures,'' said the intelligence specialist in Ankara. **********Thus, said Omer Eru, the official administrator of this small town sandwiched in a ravine, the authorities distributed food and wood worth the equivalent of $450,000 among 400 villagers last year. This year, he said, the budgeted figure is a little higher. **********''If you neglect the people, they might be caught by other ideologies,'' he said. As he sat down to give an interview, his jacket flapped open, revealing a pistol stuffed into his belt, as if to symbolize, in part, the ''other ideologies'' represented by the insurgents. **********Mr. Eru is a Government appointee, sent here from the west - a viceroy who seems not to share the ways of those he administers.  WHERE IT'S AN OFFENSE TO SPEAK THE LANGUAGE **********Because of a longstanding policy in the American-armed Turkish military, most of the troops garrisoned here have been sent from other parts of the country and do not speak the Kurdish language. Recently, acknowledging that this policy presents obstacles to intelligence-gathering efforts, the authorities deployed a 1,000-member special police commando unit trained not only in counterinsurgency, but also in the language. And that seemed to display anomalies. **********Since the founding of the modern Turkish state in 1923 on the rump of the Ottoman Empire, Kurdish has not been recognized as a distinct language. Some officials in Ankara try to portray it as a dialect of Turkish, although it is related to Farsi. **********It is an offense to speak the language, and recently, Turkey's leading singer, Ibrahim Tatlises, was arraigned and then discharged for speaking it during a concert. Stubbornly, however, the people of these lands have defied 64 years of linguistic repression; and their sense of separateness has, officials now acknowledge, been reinforced by Ankara's neglect. **********Recently, Turkish officials have broken the taboos of decades to speak more openly of the problems of the East, a poor area where joblessness is high. ''It is an illusion to think we are going to get rid of this problem overnight,'' said Gen. Necdet Urug, Turkey's Chief of Staff, in an interview with an Istanbul magazine. **********Privately, Turkish officers are prepared to acknowledge the notion of a Kurdish identity, but with the proviso that the people of this region recognize that they are Turkish citizens first and Kurds second. That, too, represents a change in official thinking, but does not imply a weakening of Turkey's traditional resolve to meet Kurdish revolt with harsher measures than are used by any of its neighbors. **********Before the latest period of military rule, from 1980 to 1983, the Marxist Kurdish Workers Party was said, in the lawlessness that gripped much of the land, to have declared ''people's free zones'' in cities like Diyarbakir. **********During the military takeover, as part of a national crackdown, 3,500 suspected Kurdish separatists were detained and 50 were sentenced to death. Thereafter, Western diplomats in Ankara say, many of the 560 suspects captured since August 1984 have been tortured to obtain information.  A CONFLICT OF FRUSTRATIONS **********But that brought only temporary respite. In August 1984, operating from camps inside Syria, the Kurdish Worker's Party revived its campaign, ambushing military patrols and, more recently, attacking villagers said to be associated with a system of self-defense supported by the military. **********The campaign, for both sides, seems mired in frustration. ''Since they use hit-and-run tactics, we expect them to come again,'' said Mr. Eru, the administrator of Uludere. The military, moreover, seems incapable of guarding against ambushes such as the attack at Semdinli April 28, which produced disproportionate casualties and illustrated the army's apparent inability to assert its superiority in arms and numbers over an elusive target. **********The campaign has wider implications, too, since it means that Turkey's four easternmost provinces are still under martial law, four years after the return to a qualified form of democratic rule elsewhere. That, in turn, embarrasses Ankara in its efforts to join the European Community. **********In addition, Turkish officials are angered at the facility with which Kurdish separatists operate in West European countries that are supposed to be Turkey's NATO allies against the Soviet Union. The Russians are seen in Ankara as long-range puppet masters in this region, exploiting Kurdish grievances to destabilize Turkey. **********Yet, the insurgents seem to be making little headway and there is scant indication that their Marxist ideology finds a widespread following among villagers, most of them Sunnis. **********''If they come to you and ask for something with guns, then you would give it to them,'' said Ekrem Alturk, a teacher in the village of Ortabag, ''but how can we approve of them when they kill our people?'' **********Last year, a Turkish intelligence source said, the separatists sought to establish a kind of ''liberated zone'' near the borders with Iran and Iraq to raise forces, butthat has not happened. **********Moreover, Syria is said to have closed some separatist camps near the border with Turkey and to have moved them to the Bekaa, Lebanon's eastern valley. Turkish air raids against northern Iraq are said to have forced the rebels to operate increasingly from Iran. The rebels' exiled leadership in Damascus is said to be riven by feuding over tactics and ideology.  A WORRY ON HORIZON: VICTORY BY IRAN **********Last month, seemingly in a shift of tactics, the rebels captured 11 villagers and spirited them across the border into either Iran or Iraq, apparently for training as insurgents, reflecting both their readiness to attack civilian targets and their ease of movement in terrain that favors them. **********Some Turkish officers say the military is seeking to take the offensive, sending out night patrols to thwart the rebels on their own turf. **********Other analysts and diplomats see a wider perspective, saying that Turkey's huge militarization of the east, close to Iraq and Iran, reflects not only the dictates of the insurgency, but also the deeper worries created by the war between its two neighbors. **********''The Turks have many things to fear from the Iran-Iraq war, but the worst scenario for them would be an Iranian victory,'' said a Western diplomat in Ankara. **********He said an Iranian victory would bring the Islamic revolution even closer to Turkey's most troubled areas and jeopardize oil supplies. Iraq sends between 900,000 and a million barrels of oil a day by pipeline to Turkey - two-thirds of its exports, and a major source of Turkey's own oil supplies. **********Were the war to spill over into the oil fields of northern Iraq, the Western diplomat said, ''it's difficult to see how the Turks could avoid getting directly involved.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/06/busin.main_headline: GUINNESS CHIEF REPORTED TO FACE PRESSURE TO QUIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/06/busin.print_headline: GUINNESS CHIEF REPORTED TO FACE PRESSURE TO QUIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/06/busin.body_text: **********The chairman of Guinness P.L.C., the big British brewer that is the target of a Government securities investigation, will face increasing pressure this week to resign, according to some of the company's large shareholders. **********Ernest Saunders, the 51-year-old head of Guinness, returned to work today from a holiday in Switzerland and will soon meet with company directors. That meeting will take place amid new allegations of questionable actions by the management of Guinness during its $3.6 billion takeover last year of the Distillers Company. **********The inquiry by Britain's Department of Trade and Industry is focusing on stock trading during the contested takeover battle for Distillers, which Guinness won over a rival bid from the Argyll Group P.L.C. Concern From Shareholders **********Mr. Saunders will meet with a special committee of outside directors, who have been hearing a rising chorus of concern from major Guinness shareholders. The directors have the power to dismiss Mr. Saunders. The company's stock price has fallen sharply since the Government investigation began a month ago, even though Guinness announced in mid-December that its pretax profits had grown to more than $350 million in the year ended last September. **********In December, the Guinness stock dropped to 288 pence, from 330 pence. Significantly, the stock rallied 12 pence, to 300 pence, or about $4.38 a share, last Friday on rumors that Mr. Saunders would soon be replaced. Today, Guinness shares fell to 294 pence. **********The concern of the Guinness institutional investors is that the widening inquiry could take several months, and that the company and its present management will remain under a cloud throughout, hurting the value of their Guinness holdings. Performance Praised **********The fund managers generally praise Mr. Saunders's performance at Guinness since 1981, when he became chief executive, and refuse to prejudge his actions in the Distillers takeover until the inquiry is concluded. However, several questioned the wisdom of allowing Mr. Saunders to remain chief executive. **********One fund manager, who asked not to be identified, observed, ''Guinness is a public company, and perceptions matter. And if its business prospects are brighter and market value are higher without Saunders than with him, he should go.'' **********Yet Mr. Saunders also has supporters. One fund manager said that despite apparent ''errors in judgment,'' Mr. Saunders ''deserves to remain as chairman unless it is actually proven he is guilty of misconduct.'' **********Some analysts stress that if Mr. Saunders were forced to resign, Guinness would miss his marketing and cost-cutting skills. ''Guinness is better off with Ernest Saunders than without him,'' said Martin Romm, an analyst at the First Boston Corporation in New York. **********Guinness has hundreds of institutional shareholders, although none owns more than about 5 percent of its stock. According to a company spokesman, the largest are Warburg Investment Management and Prudential Assurance, which supported Argyll's bid for Distillers. **********Many securities analysts had recommended Guinness shares before the investigation, but are now withholding purchase recommendations until the outcome of the inquiry. ''The main uncertainty is whether Ernest Saunders stays or goes,'' said Roderick McKelvie, an analyst for Fielding Newson-Smith & Company. **********Last week, the company's financial adviser, Morgan Grenfell Group, a leading London merchant bank, severed its ties with Guinness. The move by Morgan Grenfell came a few days after reports that Guinness had supplied funds for an $11 million purchase of its own shares around the time of the takeover bid, in a possible breach of British corporate law. **********Roger Seelig, one of Morgan Grenfell's top merger specialists, resigned from the firm last Tuesday, following allegations that he served as a go-between in Guinness's purported buying of its own stock. Guinness reportedly arranged for a nominee group to buy its shares and, afterward, the company bought its shares from the third party at above-market prices. Run-Up in Stock Price **********Purchases of Guinness shares could be significant because a sharp run-up in its stock price, before the two competing offers for Distillers closed, helped the Guinness cash-and-stock bid to prevail. Guinness has denied that it authorized the purchase of its own shares. **********The Observer, a London Sunday newspaper, reported Sunday that the finance director of Guinness, Olivier Roux, had authorized the questionable stock purchase. The paper also reported that it had evidence that Mr. Roux signed an $11 million bank check drawn on the Guinness account to pay for the transaction. Guinness has declined to comment on The Observer article.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/11/busin.print_headline: MARKET PLACE; STOCK OUTLOOK BY TECHNICIANS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/11/busin.body_text: **********MOST technical analysts believe the Dow Jones industrial average - after climbing past 2,000, 2,100 and 2,200 so far this year - is poised to scale the next century mark of 2,300. But others sniff a possible correction in the air.  After weathering a 20-point drop on Monday, the Dow caught its second wind yesterday and advanced 19.97 points, to 2,280.09, only a whisker below last Friday's record closing at 2,280.23. **********One prominent technician, Robert R. Prechter Jr. of Gainesville, Ga., has repeatedly told subscribers to his advisory letter that he expects the Dow to move above 2,300 ''before we see anything worthy of the name correction.'' Once that level is reached, he suggested, a ''swift and short'' reaction in stock prices would be likely.  * * * **********Friday evening, on his ''hot line'' telephone service for short-term traders, Mr. Prechter said that ''breadth, volume and rate-of-change statistics all suggest that a correction is approaching in the stock market.'' These technical indicators relate to the internal dynamics of the stock market. **********In an interview yesterday, however, he stressed his bullish long-term outlook for equity prices. ''For 90 percent of market participants,'' he said, ''the most intelligent thing to do is to stay fully invested.'' Mr. Prechter publishes The Elliott Wave Theorist, whose essential principle holds that stock prices move up and down in distinct waves to complete any single bull or bear market. He sees the industrial average topping out between 3,600 and 3,700 next year. In late February, when the Dow was at 2,240, Richard Eakle of Morgan Stanley & Company turned negative in his short-term opinion of the market. ''The stampede to own stocks since the beginning of the year has accelerated to a point where the market now appears ripe for a periodic shake-out,'' he said. **********He cited as particularly troublesome the widening gap between the Dow and its 200-day moving average, which represents an accumulation of prices over this period. He likened this gap to a rubber band that was stretched too far - an indication that, in his opinion, the advancing market was due for a pullback. **********Yesterday, Mr. Eakle said he believed any near-term decline would be contained in the 2,150-to-2,160 area of the Dow. For the longer term, he sees more sustained economic growth and improved corporate earnings ahead. Accordingly, his target is for the Dow to reach a high between 2,600 and 2,700 - probably in the third quarter of the year - and to finish this year ''on a weak note.'' **********Robert J. Nurock of Paoli, Pa., author of The Astute Investor, an advisory publication, believes a Dow target of 2,369 to 2,386 ''by late March or early April is viable.'' He reaches these highly specific figures by using stock charts and repetitive cycles. ''This technique is oriented more to distance than to time,'' he said, ''so that the cycles sometimes take longer to work out.'' **********Aside from the internal dynamics of the market, technical analysts peer into the future with the use of ''sentiment'' indicators related to investor psychology. Mr. Nurock, for example, employs a set of proprietary sentiment indicators, based on changes in trading patterns of stock-index options, to gauge near-term market movements. Inasmuch as these indicators continue to reflect investor skepticism about the durability of the market rally, he construes this as a positive for stock prices.  * * * **********Joseph A. Feshbach of Prudential-Bache Securities has evolved a somewhat related type of sentiment indicator. ''The unusual aspect of this market environment,'' he said, ''is that extreme optimism about the long-term secular case continues to coexist with a short-term psychology of caution.'' Thus, as long as the short-term mood of the investment community is oriented to a coming correction, he remains bullish. **********Mr. Feshbach's target is for the Dow to reach 2,400 by the end of April and 2,500 by the close of May. Once the market's short-term mentality switches to outright bullishness, he envisages trouble for stock prices. **********Laszlo Birinyi Jr. of Salomon Brothers has estimated that, because of the market's momentum and neutral sentiment readings, the Dow has the potential to rise to the 2,415 level. However, he does not place this forecast within a particular time frame, thereby adhering to the Wall Street admonition, ''If you give a number, don't give a date -and vice versa.'' **********Elsewhere, one sentiment indicator continues to flash a negative signal for stock prices - somewhere in the future. Investors Intelligence, a stock market service in New Rochelle, N.Y., tracks 135 investment newsletters to gauge adviser sentiment. ''Last week showed 53.7 percent bulls, 13.8 percent bears and 32.5 percent looking for a correction,'' Michael Burke, the editor, said. ''The recent low bearish reading is particularly negative.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/22/busin.body_text: **********The HCA Acquisition Company, the concern formed to purchase the Hospital Corporation of America, said today that it had dropped its $3.8 billion all-cash offer for the company. **********A statement released this afternoon said that the bid had been abandoned ''out of respect'' for the decision by the Hospital Corporation's board to reject the $47-a-share offer. The Nashville-based Hospital **********Corporation, the nation's largest hospital chain, was contacted on April 9 by two former executives of the Republic Health Corporation, Charles R. Miller and Richard E. Ragsdale, and a Dallas lawyer, Richard L. Scott, regarding their plan to purchase the company. However, both the company and analysts questioned whether the three men would be able to secure the necessary financing. In today's statement, Mr. Miller said that the financing for the purchase had been arranged dependent upon the acceptance of the offer by the Hospital Corporation board.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/06/busin.main_headline: Canada Split on Accord; Nationalism an Issue
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/06/busin.print_headline: 2 NATIONS SIZE UP TRADE PACT; Canada Split on Accord; Nationalism an Issue
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/06/busin.body_text: **********Canada was a sharply divided nation today as details of the free-trade agreement with the United States became known, with business generally supporting the pact and trade unions and nationalist groups adamantly against it. **********Business leaders were enthusiastic about the prospects of competing freely in the United States markets, which dwarf Canada's own, and they see the agreement as providing at least a measure of security against growing American protectionism. **********But opponents said the new system for regulating trade disputes gave no real protection against American industries' increasing propensity to seek trade penalties against imports, and they forecast severe damage to Canada as a result of changes in automotive trade arrangements, investment review practices and energy policies that Canada has pledged. **********All sides in Canada agreed that the pact had set the stage for the next general election and that its successful implementation appeared to depend on victory at the polls by the ruling Conservatives - the party that opened negotiations with the United States 16 months ago. The Conservatives have been trailing badly in opinion surveys, with their current standing rated by the leading polls at 25 percent of the electorate. But backers of free trade are gambling that the pact will revive the party's fortunes. **********The financial markets in Canada reacted today with modest enthusiasm to the agreement. Natural resource stocks advanced strongly, but banks and other financial institutions faltered. **********When Parliament began its week in Ottawa, it was evident that the agreement, reached at midnight on Saturday in Washington, is likely to become a highly contentious issue for Canada. This is consistent with the history of earlier efforts to negotiate free trade with the United States, which foundered three times in the past century. But the vehemence of the positions taken by the two opposition parties appears to leave scant room for compromise. **********After Prime Minister Brian Mulroney was greeted with a standing ovation from his supporters and described the trade agreement as a ''path for the daring,'' the two men who are vying to supplant him as Prime Minister in an election that must be held before September 1989 savaged the pact. John Turner, the Liberal leader, said Mr. Mulroney had ''put Canada up for sale,'' and Edward Broadbent, leader of the New Democratic Party, which has strong union backing, said the agreement would make Canada ''a satellite of the United States.'' Similar Reactions Elsewhere **********Beyond Parliament, the divisions were echoed everywhere. Quebec's Premier, Robert Bourassa, called the agreement ''excellent,'' as did Laurent Thibault, president of the Canadian Manufacturers Association, who said it would ''greatly enhance the prospects for manufacturing investment and jobs.'' **********But Shirley Carr, president of the Canadian Labor Congress, called the pact ''a national disgrace,'' and Bob White, president of the Canadian Automobile Workers, said the accord set Canada on course for ''a Rambo, dog-eat-dog society with no ability to maintain our social programs or to structure our own economy.'' **********The attitude of Mr. Broadbent, a Socialist whose party has consistently led both the Conservatives and Liberals in recent opinion polls, had been expected. But perhaps more significant for the prospects of the free-trade pact was the stance of Mr. Turner, a former Rhodes Scholar and Olympic athlete. **********Although the Liberals have generally maintained an open attitude on issues involving the United States, Mr. Turner took a position that might make it difficult for the Liberals to live with the agreement if they win an election. Items in Accord Assailed **********''It's 'Open Sesame,' 'Come and take us' - that's what this Government is saying,'' Mr. Turner said, referring to the accord's 10-year phasing out of all remaining tariffs, Canada's agreeing to remove restraints on energy exports, its decision to ease investment restraints and complex changes in the 20-year-old auto pact, which critics here fear will lead to job losses to the United States. As for setting up a new panel to rule on trade disputes, the opposition leader called it ''an absolute fraud'' because, he said, it did not exempt Canada from existing United States trade laws. **********Because the agreement is supposed to take effect in 1989, after ratification by Congress and Parliament, Mr. Mulroney faced difficult questions of political timing. His majority in Parliament assures the agreement of ratification, but his aides conceded privately today that few if any of the benefits he expects under the agreement, primarily in new manufacturing jobs, are likely to be visible before an election. Some analysts suggested a possibility that he might go for an early election, possibly next spring, to force the issue.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/13/busin.main_headline: The Glittery Gifts May Not Be Gold
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/13/busin.print_headline: WHAT'S NEW IN BUSINESS CELEBRATIONS; The Glittery Gifts May Not Be Gold
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/13/busin.body_text: **********PSYCHOLOGY and corporate image may play as large a role as budgetary concerns in this year's gift lists, according to Stuart Jacobson, author of ''The Art of Giving.'' ''You have to continue the highbrow giving'' - to the top officers of the company or largest clients, for instance - ''because you don't want it to appear as if the corporation has gone over the brink,'' he said. ''That's public relations.'' **********''In fact, I have more new clients this year,'' said Joanne Stone-Geier, corporate gift manager at Carson Pirie Scott in Chicago. The corporate gift departments at Bloomingdale's, Tiffany and other retailers agree that business is thriving. **********Along with public image concerns, two factors are contributing to this year's showing. First, corporate gift budgets were set long before Oct. 19; in addition, most companies that purchase large quantities of gift items made their choices before the market collapsed. These orders come in right after Labor Day, said Ms. Hemingway of Tiffany. **********But if gift-giving continues unabated, the amount spent per gift seems to be diminishing. ''There was a modified budget over all,'' said Dorothy Desir, corporate gifts coordinator at Bloomingdale's. ''People last year may have spent $70 per gift; this year they may have gone down by $5 or $10.'' **********Mrs. Stone-Geier saw a similar trend in her store, with some clients ''instead of spending $100, maybe spending $50.'' At Neiman-Marcus in Houston, corporate clients have tended to spend less lavishly ever since ''the bottom fell out of the oil barrel,'' said Mary Ann Schlein, the store's director of public relations. **********In New York, ''I am pleased to say that clients are all doing their giving,'' said Janie Holzman Klein, president of Creative Resources Inc., a corporate gift service. ''They may be cutting down on the expense, but they're not going to stop giving.'' **********Thus, ''we've gone out of our way,'' Mrs. Klein said, to replace expensive imported items with well-designed American items that serve a similar function but are more reasonably priced. ''For instance, we had a European ice bucket that was exorbitant and we found something manufactured here that's a third of the price, but the quality is also there.'' **********So is the spirit of fun. One of Mrs. Klein's most popular items this year is a $60 teddy bear, stuffed with $250,000 in shredded currency, and called, appropriately, a ''Grin and Bear It.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/13/busin.body_text: **********THE J. G. Durand Compagnie of Arques, France, is making its debut as an advertiser on American television with a line of low-priced crystal and a line of all-purpose cookware. It is an account that the principals of an ad agency on the verge of death almost died for. This is the story: Stephen Penchina and Arthur Selkowitz founded Penchina Selkowitz in 1982, and it really flourished, thanks largely to one account: the Burroughs Corporation. They gave it great advertising. **********However, Burroughs was such a big account and so much was demanded of the agency's principals that there was little time for them to go after new business. The Burroughs billings grew from about $4.5 million a year to $12 million, accounting for 60 percent of the agency's billings. **********Then suddenly Burroughs merged with Sperry to become the Unisys Corporation, with an introductory ad budget of $40 million. A number of agencies were invited to pitch for the business, including the incumbent and Young & Rubicam, the world's largest agency. **********As it turned out, the client was unable to withstand the Y.&R. juggernaut when that agency turned on its charm, promising much creative talent and a diversity of services. **********''Y.&R. was another ball game, another league,'' Mr. Penchina sighed last week. **********Overnight, to survive, Penchina Selkowitz had to reduce its work force to 4, from 23. These included Mr. Penchina, as the chairman, and Mr. Selkowitz, as the president. They were also forced to move to 5,000 square feet and six months' free rent on a sublet at 630 Third Avenue from twice the space at 875 Third. And the principals cut their pay to a quarter of what they had been making. **********Then, with survial as the spur, they hit the new-business trail. **********That led them to France and to taking a rented car from the Paris airport to Arques, two and a half hours away. They had been up all night flying. Mr. Penchina was sick with a heavy cold, so his partner drove. **********While doing about 70 miles per hour, Mr. Selkowitz fell asleep at the wheel. He awoke as the car was leaving the road just before it flipped over at least five times. Only their seat belts saved them, the police said later. **********As the car lay on its side, the first thing the driver said was, ''Are the storyboards all right?'' **********The next day, with his face bandaged as a result of glass cuts, he and Mr. Penchina won the account. **********Since that day the agency has picked up two other new accounts. **********One is Prentice Hall, part of the professional information group of Simon & Schuster, a Gulf and Western company. The agency will do image and product advertising for the group. Its activities focus on the legal, accounting and financial markets. **********The other is Yegen Associates of Fairlawn, N.J., described as the oldest and largest bank-services company. It handles consumer loans. **********Both Mr. Penchina and Mr. Selkowitz came to their own agency from the big agency scene, and both say they are disenchanted with the way the biggest agency in the business beat up on them. And, by the way, some other agencies tried to unseat other clients of Penchina Selkowitz. The disaster that followed, however, helped the two learn about truly nice people in the business. **********As part of their desperate new-business effort, Mr. Selkowitz wrote letters to heads of other agencies, asking them to send prospects his way if they could not serve them because of conflicts or any other reasons. This gamble paid off surprisingly well with several leads. The partners expressed particular gratitude to Peter Geer, chairman of Geer, DuBois, and David Altschiller, chairman of Altschiller, Reitzfeld.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/03/world.print_headline: DEATH TOLL AT 95 IN SAN JUAN BLAZE AS SEARCH GOES ON
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/03/world.body_text: **********The death toll in the New Year's Eve fire at the Dupont Plaza Hotel reached 95 today as workers continued to bring bodies out of the 22-story luxury hotel. **********The latest count was announced by Hector Rivera Cruz, Puerto Rico's Secretary of Justice, who added that a few more victims might still be buried in the thick rubble and badly damaged rooms. **********Searchers said that finding and removing the corpses, many burned beyond recognition, was time-consuming, especially because the searchers hoped to preserve evidence that might be useful to investigators. #27 Positively Identified Because so many corpses were so severely burned, only 27 have so far been identified, according to Police Superintendent Carlos Lopez Feliciano. **********The body of the general manager of the Dupont Plaza, Brooke Thompson, was identified among the victims, as was Manuel Marrero, a United States Secret Service agent. **********Among those missing and now presumed dead were 17 hotel employees. **********Also reported dead was Margaret Ahrens, according to The Associated Press. She was a prominent performer of contemporary music in New York. **********The A.P. also said the dead included Jose Rivera Janer, president of the newspaper El Reportero. He was a close associate of Gov. Rafael Hernandez Colon's in electoral campaigns and held high-ranking positions in the Governor's first administration, from 1972 to 1976. Two months ago he was named president of the struggling newspaper, which has close ties to the Popular Democratic Party. 'Good Possibility' of Arson **********Earlier today, Mr. Rivera Cruz said there was ''a good possibility that this incident will turn out to be arson,'' but he added, ''We have to finish our investigation before we can conclude that.'' **********Robert J. Creighton, the agent in charge of the New York office of the Federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, whose jurisdiction includes Puerto Rico, said in an interview today, ''We are definitely approaching this as a criminal investigation.'' **********Mr. Creighton said the investigators were focusing on labor unrest at the hotel as a likely motive. Some survivors said they had heard reports before the fire that there would be trouble in the Dupont Plaza that was related to labor problems. **********Union leaders have denied any union role in the fire and have offered a reward for information on the causes. Asked about the possibility of a political motive involving Puerto Rican independence, he said, ''We are certainly looking into that.'' Management's Role Studied **********Mr. Rivera Cruz said the possibility of criminal negligence on the part of the hotel's management was also under investigation. **********The hotel management said it had complied with proper safety standards. **********Throughout the day, teams of investigators, civil defense workers and others labored in the tropical heat amid the noxious odors in and around the ravaged building. Paramedics vaccinated teams that had had contact with the dead. **********The area around the casino and restaurant, where most of the deaths occurred, was opened to the press for the first time this morning. The scene was a mixture of the macabre and the normal. Macabre Scenes **********Two floors were gutted. At the outdoor bar, the pina colada machine was scorched, but several bottles of liquor were still standing in a neat row nearby, their labels legible. **********There were bloody towels on the adjoining beach, but a few yards away at the pool, palm trees were undamaged, plastic chairs were unmarred and paperback books, magazines and bottles of suntan lotion were strewn about the patio. A sign read: ''No Lifeguard on Duty - Swim at Your Own Risk.'' **********Bodies of some victims were found in hotel rooms today, according to workers. ''They died from smoke inhalation,'' said Rita Aparicio, an emergency medicine technician. ''The smoke went through the air conditioning system.'' Denial on Locking of Doors **********Other aspects of the case remained unclear. For example, a number of survivors said that when the fire broke out, some of the casino's exit doors were locked or barred by security personnel. Bruce Shulman, the Dupont Plaza's director, said today that ''the doors were not locked - people did exit.'' Reports to the contrary, he added, ''are being investigated.'' **********Mr. Shulman said also that three small fires that broke out in the 10 days before the disaster were reported to the police and that threatening letters sent to hotel managers in recent days had been turned over to the authorities. In response, he said, the hotel had hired 30 extra guards. **********Mr. Lopez Feliciano, the Police Superintendent, said later that he did not know whether his department had received any letters from the hotel or whether any action had been taken in regard to them. **********Mr. Shulman said he could not comment on the content of the letters, but he added that none specifically mentioned New Year's Eve. A Warning Over Radio?  In light of the controversy over warnings, Mr. Shulman was asked about a union commercial that was broadcast by Noti Uno, an AM radio station. The ad, according to Victor Negron, a Noti Uno reporter, may have been aired dozens of times in December. It told listeners that negotiations were under way between the hotel management and representatives of the teamsters union, and that the Dupont Plaza was ''not the best place to be at year-end.'' **********Mr. Shulman said he had not been aware of the ad, which only ran in Spanish. Mr. Negron commented that others who had heard it, ''didn't think of it as a warning.'' **********In answer to other questions, Mr. Shulman said the hotel has failed no safety inspections and has complied with all safety regulations. Sprinkler systems, he said, are in use only in three locations: a hallway off the kitchen, a ninth floor linen closet and a utility room off the ballroom. **********Asked about reports that oxygen may have routinely been pumped into the casino to keep gamblers from feeling sleepy, he replied: ''I don't know. Oxygen is an extremely flammable substance.'' Oxygen-pumping is a practice in some mainland casinos. **********At other gatherings, on the streets and in the cafes of San Juan today, there was continued speculation over who might be to blame for the fire. **********At noon Governor Hernandez Colon held a memorial service for victims of the blaze in the garden of his official residence, La Fortaleza. **********Afterward, he said that if the fire was ''sabotage,'' he believed it was related to labor strife and had not been an act of political terrorism. Union spokesmen later said they refused to accept that assessment at this point. **********Baltasar Corrada del Rio, the president of the New Progressive Party, which advocates statehood for this Commonwealth, said one negotiator involved in the hotel's contract talks had been arrested in 1975 on charges related to racketeering and terrorism. He suggested that investigators should explore the possibility of links. **********That negotiator, Jorge Farinacci, acknowledged today that he had been arrested in connection with the $7 million robbery of a Wells Fargo depot in 1983 in West Hartford, Conn., and that he has been released on $1 million bail. **********He also said, however, that he had not been involved in the robbery and hoped to ''have a fair trial where I will establish my innocence.'' **********He called Mr. Corrada del Rio's statement ''an unjust and irresponsible insinuation.'' ---- Soprano Presumed Dead Miss Ahrens, a soprano who was reported among the dead in the San Juan fire, was a prominent performer of contemporary music in New York, and an occasional composer. Her ''Agnus Dei,'' for two sopranos and handbells, was described as ''a confection of monastic Minimalism'' by a Times critic when she performed it at Merkin Concert Hall in 1983. **********She also performed often at the League of Composers/International Society for Contemporary Music and the Prism Chamber Orchestra. In New York she was heard in the music of Pierre Boulez, George Rochberg, Jean Barraque and numerous younger composers, as well as a special concert of music to words by Gertrude Stein in 1983. **********She also sang earlier music, sometimes appearing with original-instrument ensembles in little-known Baroque music. Her last performance here was in Mr. Barraque's ''Au dela du Hasard'' at the Guggenheim Museum, in November 1986. Z

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/17/world.main_headline: Fishing Yields Soviet a South Pacific Toehold
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/17/world.print_headline: Fishing Yields Soviet a South Pacific Toehold
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/17/world.body_text: **********This quiet archipelago of coconut palms, sandy beaches and tropical jungles makes an incongruous front in an East-West confrontation. **********Yet diplomats and analysts say Vanuatu and other South Pacific countries are entering the contentious world of superpower rivalries. **********Vanuatu, which was known as the New Hebrides until independence in 1980, signed an agreement in January giving Soviet fishing vessels access to its ports to buy bait and make repairs. **********It is the Soviet Union's first toehold in the South Pacific. Some Western diplomats say it represents a Soviet victory in a diplomatic and commercial offensive to expand into a region from which it had been excluded. **********Australia has warned that the Russians could try to use Vanuatu as a base to destabilize the region, and Adm. James A. Lyons, commander of the United States Pacific fleet, has ridiculed the description of the accord as commercial. ''They are certainly after more than fish,'' the admiral said. **********The Soviet interest in the islands apparently reflects the view of the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, that the Pacific will become increasingly important in global politics and economics. That view, which Mr. Gorbachev expressed in a speech last year in the Soviet Far East city of Vladivostok, corresponds to the growing expectation in the United States and Asia of a ''Pacific century'' in which the Atlantic basin will be eclipsed as a center of power and finance. **********By any measure, the South Pacific remains overwhelmingly in the orbit of the Western powers. But the Soviet Union may be making some progress. **********Eighteen months ago, the Soviet Union reached a fishing agreement with the island nation Kiribati, allowing Russians to fish in Kiribati's economic zone but not to go ashore. That pact expired last fall, but was soon followed by the accord with Vanuatu, which granted shore privileges. Vanuatu Got $1.5 Million **********Vanuatu has a reputation as the maverick of the region, but its motivation in signing the fishing agreement seems to have been financial more than political: This tiny, destitute nation earned $1.5 million from the deal. In exchange, eight Soviet fishing boats received the right to fish in Vanuatu's 200-mile exclusive economic zone, as long as they do so outside Vanuatu's 12-mile territorial waters. The boats may use Vanuatu ports to buy bait and supplies or to undergo repairs. **********Some foreign analysts have cautioned that this will enable the Russians to gather intelligence in Vanuatu and elsewhere in the region. ''This will be an intelligence gathering point,'' a diplomat here said. But he added, ''Of course, I'm not sure there's a lot of intelligence to gather here.'' **********Port-Vila, a sleepy capital city of 15,000 people, lacks a United States Embassy, among other things. **********Western governments worry that the Soviet fishing agreement eventually could lead to something more significant, possibly even a base. **********''They are touching land here, and the concern is that from small things great ones grow,'' the diplomat said. ''The Soviets are coming into an area in which there has never been any Russian influence, and that can't be a good thing.'' **********Sela Molisa, Vanuatu's Foreign Minister, said in an interview that the fishing agreement was purely commercial. But, when asked if Vanuatu would consider extending it to providing installations for Soviet naval vessels, if the price were right, he said that was possible. The Nuclear Arms Issue **********''If they gave us a good fee for our facilities, we would consider it,'' Mr. Molisa said. **********Officials of Pacific nations, as well as Western diplomats, say the Soviet Union has played its cards shrewdly. In particular, they say, it has burnished its image by signing an agreement to limit the scope of nuclear weapons and nuclear testing in the South Pacific. The United States, after some mixed signals, refused to sign. That upset the island nations, which manifest an anxiety about nuclear weapons that runs far deeper than concern in the West.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/27/busin.print_headline: PERSONAL FINANCE; Finding the Right Financial Planner
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/27/busin.body_text: **********WHEN the holiday spending spree is over, many people resolve to put their personal finances in order. But it is easy to be overwhelmed by the prospect, and avoid the task. Some people turn to friends and relatives for advice; others to books, magazines and newspapers. Yet another source of help is professional financial advisers, including brokers and financial planners. **********Financial planners are still less pervasive than brokers. While there is some overlap between the two professions, the concept behind the financial planner is someone who can help clients develop an overall financial strategy, not just select specific investments - although there are some who do that, too. Planners should be able to give such advice as whether to rent or purchase a home or how to determine the right amount of life, property and disability insurance, what kinds of investments are suitable and how to pay the minimum amount of income tax. They can also help in devising ways to reach specific goals: funding a child's education, for instance, or putting aside funds for retirement. **********''A financial planner is a generalist who offers advice on a broad number of areas of personal finance, and works with a team of specialists,'' said Marv Tuttle, a spokesman for the Institute of Certified Financial Planners in Denver. Thus they may work with brokers to set up investment portfolios, and with lawyers to draft wills and trust agreements to put an estate plan into effect. **********For the individual who decides a planner might be useful, there remains the task of selecting the right one. There is no good way to do it quickly. **********Consider the case of Mark A. Coffey, a New York musician. He has a lawyer and an accountant, but wanted someone ''to take an overall look at where I was going with my money, especially my taxes and my investments,'' he said. Mr. Coffey contacted the International Association for Financial Planning, a trade group in Atlanta, which sent him a list of six financial planners in New York. **********He interviewed all six by telephone and then visited two in their offices. He finally chose Claire S. Longden, who works with the brokerage firm of Butcher & Singer in Manhattan, because ''her credentials are good and she seemed to know a lot about the investment angle I was interested in.'' He said he also felt ''the chemistry was right.'' **********Experts emphasize the need to shop carefully because - unlike accountants and stockbrokers - financial planners are not subject to government regulation. A survey by the Consumer Federation of America found that fraud by financial planners cost Americans more than $500 million in 1986. At least as much money was misinvested ''because of self-interest and incompetent advice,'' said Barbara L. N. Roper, author of the study. **********The survey also found that only 10 percent of people who call themselves planners have completed a special course of study in planning, like the ''certified financial planner'' program offered by the College for Financial Planning in Denver. Some financial planners, however, have degrees in accounting, law or business. Even so, ''specific education in one subject doesn't guarantee overall competence,'' Ms. Roper said. **********Membership in the international association has doubled since 1982, to about 25,000, reflecting the growth in the industry as a whole, said Hubert L. Harris, president. ''The stock market crash this fall, a lack of confidence in the Social Security system and a general sense that the Government isn't up to the job'' are prompting people to look for ways to take charge of their finances, he said. **********Doctors, lawyers, owners of small businesses and others with specialized needs are well advised to seek planners who are knowledgeable in their areas. Problems repeat themselves, and planners with special expertise are most apt to keep current with the latest developments in their fields. Planners who have seen such changes before may also have a better sense of how to gauge the future. **********Like most professionals, financial planners are best found through recommendations from friends and business associates. While gathering names, ask why the planners are recommended. Find out whether they are easily accessible and whether they return phone calls. People can also get names from trade groups, as Mr. Coffey did. **********No matter who initially recommends the financial planner, it is a good idea to ask for references and to have a personal interview with at least two or three. Here are some questions to ask: *********** What are their credentials, in both education and experience? *********** What are their areas of special expertise? *********** What kinds of clients make up the bulk of their practice? *********** Who will do the work, the planner or an assistant? *********** What services will be provided? *********** How often do they meet with their clients? How much business do they transact over the telephone? *********** How do they keep themselves up to date on changes in the laws? **********In addition, ask to see a sample financial plan. And perhaps most important, find out how the planner expects to be paid. **********The overwhelming majority charge a fee for preparing a plan and also receive commissions from the products they sell. About 15 to 20 percent of planners receive only commissions; the remainder charge a flat fee. **********When financial planners get commissions on product sales, ''this creates a potential conflict of interest, because they promise objective advice but their objectivity may be compromised by their roles as salespeople,'' Ms. Roper said. (Stockbrokers, of course, are often in the same position.) SOME people find this argument persuasive. Ellen Aibel-Bierman, a realtor in Scarsdale, N.Y.,and her husband, Jordan, a New York lawyer, recently chose Steven Enright, of Seidman Financial Services in New York, as their adviser. High on their list was to find someone from whom ''we would get independent advice, free of any financial reward on his part,'' Ms. Aibel-Bierman said. **********Others dismiss the argument. When a financial adviser prepares a plan to sell products, and not to meet the client's needs, ''that's a question of ethics, not compensation,'' said Andrew M. Rich, president of AMR Planning Services in Plainview, L.I. **********No matter how it is figured, such advice does not come cheap. Simple financial plans for people earning $50,000 or less average $250 to $500; more sophisticated plans can cost $2,500 or more. The hourly rate for planners may range from $50 to $150 or higher, said Mr. Harris of the International association.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/19/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********''A Sense of Limits Grips Consumers'' (March 15) used approximately 1,500 words to describe the ''new'' conservative spending habits of consumers. Replete with quotes and the requisite graph, it dealt at length with the contention that the middle class ran out of things to buy. **********I contend that all the discussion of jaded, satiated, and bored consumers could have been eliminated in exchange for a brief statement, to wit, ''Consumers have realized that the I.R.S. will no longer subsidize personal debt to the tune of 18 percent to 24 percent, the norm for most major credit cards.''  ERIK SCHNACKENBERG   Fultonville, N.Y., March 17
