https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/03/world.print_headline: Japanese Rebuked for Rise in Trade With Hanoi
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/03/world.body_text: **********As the United States and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations prepare for new rounds of talks with Vietnam on missing Americans and the Vietnamese occupation of Cambodia, the Japanese are being criticized in this region for steadily expanding Hanoi trade. **********Asean has sought to isolate Vietnam economically so long as 140,000 Vietnamese troops remain in Cambodia. **********Within the last week, Vietnam reported it had sold its first crude oil exports to two Japanese firms, Nissho Iwai and C. Itoh & Company. At almost the same time a consortium of 90 Japanese companies announced it was building a trade center in Hanoi. **********Japanese businesses, sometimes acting with the help of the Japanese Communist Party, have been active in Hanoi for several years. Western diplomats in Hanoi say the businesses are positioning themselves to be Vietnam's dominant non-Communist trading partner when an unofficial but effective aid and trade embargo is lifted. **********Asean leaders say Japan's trade links undercut efforts to use the promise of improved economic ties as a way of getting Vietnam to compromise on its eight-year Cambodia occupation. In a formal protest in late April, envoys of the six Asean countries - Thailand, Malaysia, Singapore, Indonesia, Brunei and the Philippines - asked the Japanese Government to dissuade Nissho Iwai from giving unofficial economic assistance to Vietnam until Hanoi's forces are withdrawn from Cambodia. Japan has provided no official economic aid to Hanoi since Vietnamese troops toppled the Communist Khmer Rouge regime in 1979 and installed another Communist Government that has been more cooperative. **********Asean's protests over trade come as Indonesia's Foreign Minister, Mochtar Kusumaatmadja, who speaks for the Association on the Cambodia question, is about to visit both Washington and Hanoi to try to reopen stalled discussions with the Vietnamese. **********Also in May, Thailand's Foreign Minister, Siddhi Savetsila, will be going to Moscow to raise again the issue of Cambodia with his Soviet counterpart. The Soviet Union is Vietnam's main military and economic backer, and Asean wants Moscow's help in getting Vietnam to withdraw its troops. **********These trips follow a recent announcement in Washington that the Reagan Administration is prepared to send the former chairman of the Joints Chief of Staff, Gen. John W. Vessey, Jr., to Hanoi as a special envoy to hasten the resolution of the cases of more than 2,000 missing Americans. **********Hanoi-based diplomats say that Vietnam's recent actions may reflect political disagreement on how to deal with the United States. **********There are no trade or diplomatic links between Washington and Hanoi, although economists say over $20 million in American goods reaches Vietnam through third countries each year. **********Asean countries, led by Singapore, trade with Vietnam and Cambodia, although the amount of legal income is small. Smugglers supply the markets of Phnom Penh, the Cambodian capital, and to a lesser extent Vietnamese cities, where goods from relatives abroad often dominate some shops. **********Hanoi, facing severe economic problames, is now promising to make more of this private trade legal. Thai businesses have already expressed an interest in broadening commercial ties, arguing that their activities should not be linked to the Thai Government's demands that the 140,000 Vietnamese troops leave Cambodia first. **********All regional nations, most oil producers, have been watching the development of Hanoi's oil industry with interest. There are assumed to be substantial reserves off the coast of southern Vietnam in Vung Tau, but the Vietnamese, working with the Soviet Union, are hampered in exploration and drilling by a lack of equipment. **********Some economists believe significant quantities of oil are being lost or wasted. There are no pipelines, refineries or storage facilities in Vietnam. **********His report said that four Japanese companies - Nippon Kokan, Nippon Steel, Kawasaki Steel and Sumimoto Metal Industries - are thought to be negotiating with Vietsovpetro, a state oil company, for pipeline construction contracts.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/23/busin.body_text: **********Last fall, Robert M. Freeman was working out in a park in his hometown of Rye, N.Y., when he came upon a friend. And, as it had often before, the conversation between the two men turned to Wall Street's insider trading scandal. **********''He and I have had conversations about this general subject going back years,'' said the friend, Jules Kroll, head of Kroll Associates Inc., a firm that does investigations for companies. ''And philosophically we were on the same wavelength - that there was a crying need to limit the flow of information and to send a message within organizations that it was bad business to permit any kind of leakage of information.'' **********That tete-a-tete, in retrospect, is particularly ironic, since the 44-year-old Mr. Freeman, the partner in charge of Goldman, Sachs & Company's arbitrage department, was rounded up earlier this month in the ever-widening insider trading net. **********His arrest, taking place on Feb. 12 in his Broad Street office in the middle of a working day, sent a harsh chill through the already-flustered brokerage community, not only because of its timing but also because Mr. Freeman as a person and Goldman Sachs as a firm had always been considered the cream of the business. Comments by Executives **********''They are a completely honorable, reputable, straightforward house,'' said Robert Pirie, president of Rothschild Inc., another investment banking concern. ''I've never heard anyone challenge their integrity.'' **********Mr. Freeman gets equally high marks. ''I've known him for years and I've always had the highest respect for him as an individual and a professional,'' said Mr. Pirie. Added Thomas Murphy, head of Capital Cities/ABC and Mr. Freeman's next-door neighbor for nearly 10 years: ''He's a fine family man. Everything I know about him I like.'' **********The Justice Department and the Securities and Exchange Commission, which for nearly a year have been unraveling the activities of an insider trading ring the likes of which most people never imagined, paint a different picture. **********In the complaint that led to his arrest, the Government charged that Mr. Freeman had leaked confidential details about the takeover defense that the Unocal Corporation was going to use in fighting a hostile bid from T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman. The information, the complaint said, was given to Martin A. Siegel, who at the time was head of the mergers and acquisitions department at Kidder, Peabody & Company. Mr. Siegel quit a similar job at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. earlier this month and pleaded guilty to criminal insider-trading charges a day after Mr. Freeman and two other Wall Street executives were arrested. Government's Accusations **********In return for the details about Unocal, the Government asserted, Kidder, Peabody gave information to Mr. Freeman about a takeover attempt against Storer Communications that proved helpful to Mr. Freeman's personal trading account. **********Mr. Freeman, who is out on $250,000 bail, has denied the allegations, and Goldman, Sachs, where he has worked for more than two decades, is said to be vigorously helping in his defense. **********Wall Street sources, moveover, say an internal investigation of Mr. Freeman's dealings, conducted last week by Goldman, Sachs and others, has unearthed no wrongdoing. **********Goldman, Sachs has hired two former high-powered Federal prosecutors to represent the firm and Mr. Freeman. Paul J. Curran of Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hays & Handler is working with Mr. Freeman. Mr. Curran, United States Attorney in Manhattan from 1973 to 1975, ran for Governor of New York in 1982 but was defeated in the Republican primary. **********Lawrence B. Pedowitz of Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz is representing Goldman, Sachs. **********The case of the Goldman, Sachs partner and his troubles holds a special fascination for Wall Street, where there is a perverse sort of pleasure in the fact that even an upright organization such as the 118-year-old Goldman, Sachs can get caught up in something of questionable legality. **********Even more important, however, is the fact that other Wall Street firms seem interested in how Goldman, Sachs handles itself in this crisis. A Path Others Might Tread **********In an era when nearly every firm on Wall Street fears that it could come under suspicion, Goldman, Sachs is seen as sort of a legal pioneer blazing a defense trail that might have to be traveled by others in the future. **********''There are people rooting for Freeman,'' said one trader, explaining that Wall Street is particularly upset about the way in which Mr. Freeman and the two other executives were treated during their arrests. If Goldman, Sachs fights, many Wall Streeters reason, it may help slow down the storm that threatens to swallow up the financial community's reputation. **********Still, Wall Street has a sinking feeling about all that has been going on. Until now, United States Attorney Rudolph W. Giuliani has been on a hot streak, with a dozen Wall Street professionals implicated one way or another in the scandal. Many of them are buying themselves more lenient treatment by helping the Government with its case against others. **********The common belief in the investment community is that in the arrest of Mr. Freeman, as well as those of Richard B. Wigton of Kidder, Peabody and Timothy L. Tabor, formerly of Kidder, there was a message. But many are asking: for whom? A Message From the Firm **********Goldman, Sachs, too, seems to be sending a message - that it sticks up for its own. In this adversarial climate the firm, a newcomer to controversy, has closed ranks, permitting Mr. Freeman normal access to his office, as well as all the time he needs to consult with his lawyers. **********''He was doing exactly what he should have been doing,'' is reportedly the rallying cry for Mr. Freeman being heard around the halls of Goldman, Sachs these days. ''They sell and publicize what he did,'' said one Wall Street source, referring to the interdepartment cooperation that allowed Mr. Freeman to work alongside the firm's mergers and acquisition team. **********What was his job? And how did Mr. Freeman, manager of the Cardinals baseball team in the Rye Little League, find himself in the middle of an uproar? **********As head of Goldman's very small but very profitable arbitrage department, Mr. Freeman was active in betting on takeovers. Would X Company, for instance, be able to take over Y Company, and if it did how much was the stock worth? **********But there was more to the job than that. As head arbitrager, Mr. Freeman would be called upon by members of his firm's mergers and acquisition team to evaluate offers. Gauging Reaction of Others **********Mr. Freeman would, experts explained, give M.&A. the lowdown on how other arbitragers might react to certain moves being considered by a Goldman, Sachs client. **********''That is standard operating procedure,'' said one person familiar with the way Goldman handled takeovers. The same is true at most other brokerage firms, according to Wall Street experts. **********At this point Mr. Freeman, or any other arbitrager, would be prohibited from buying or selling the stock of Goldman's client or the other corporation involved. **********In the course of a day, these experts added, Mr. Freeman would normally be required to keep in touch with arbitragers at other firms. And Marty Siegel, who not only headed the mergers department at Kidder, Peabody but also was the informal head of its arbitrage department, would have been a natural source of information. **********In contested proxy battles, such as the one involving Goldman's client, Unocal, the firm's arbitrage department would have been even more active. Mr. Freeman, in his role as head of arbitrage, would have been expected to contact other ''arbs'' who held large amounts of Unocal stock and try to persuade them to surrender their votes to management. Teamwork Serving Clients **********Such cooperation, in the corporate view of Goldman, Sachs, is the type of teamwork that it feels is necessary to serve the client best. And in a firm that prides itself on the importance of all its professional employees, from the highest in rank to the lowest, that sort of ''gang tackling'' (as it has been called in the press) is lauded. **********Whether Mr. Freeman crossed over the ill-defined line between legal and illegal contact with the other arbitragers will probably be the hottest issue of the case. Goldman, Sachs, experts believe, will probably contend that even if Mr. Freeman surrendered information that he should not have, it was done innocently. **********The Government has apparently not yet released all the information it has on Mr. Freeman. In its complaint, the Government said it had received its information about the Goldman partner from Mr. Siegel, ''among other sources.'' **********Those sources have not yet been identified, but there has been some conjecture on Wall Street that Ivan F. Boesky, the apparent ringleader of the scandal, might have pointed the first finger. Mr. Boesky was penalized $100 million in November for trading on insider information and has agreed to plead guilty to an unspecified criminal charge. Secretive About Sources **********The Government has been so secretive about these other sources that even many of those intimately familiar with the case have no hint as to their identity. **********If Mr. Boesky is one of the other sources, however, that would mean that two people who have agreed to plead guilty to criminal charges have accused Mr. Freeman. And if that should be the case, Goldman, Sachs and Mr. Freeman are likely to argue that each did so to spread the blame. **********Goldman, Sachs, the conservative firm that still shuns clients wanting to attempt unfriendly takeovers, now finds itself in the unaccustomed position of taking a forceful lead in one of the biggest controversies ever to confront Wall Street. **********''Of course, people are uncomfortable that anyone could make such an accusation,'' said one source close to Goldman, Sachs. But, the source added, Goldman, Sachs is so annoyed at the way the matter was handled that ''it has rallied the firm'' to put up a strong defense.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/17/busin.print_headline: Major Decisions in Insider Trading Law
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/17/busin.body_text: **********Trading of securities by company executives based on inside information has been illegal throughout much of the history of corporate America. It was not until the 1960's that Federal authorities sought to broaden the notion of ''insider'' to include printers, financial analysts and journalists. Following are some of the major developments - before yesterday's Winans decision - in insider trading law.  1909: The United States Supreme Court establishes a rule that the director of a company must either disclose the inside information or abstain from trading. Although the case, Strong v. Repide, made it clear than an executive could not use privileged information for profit, it did not address the issue of who is an insider.  1934: Congress passes the Securities Exchange Act, which contains a key provision, Section 10, broadly outlawing certain forms of stock fraud. Based on Section 10, the Securities and Exchange Commission in 1942 adopts Rule 10b-5 making the fraud provisions applicable to purchases as well as sales of securities. Section 10 and Rule 10b-5 become the key provisions to prosecute illegal insider trading. Neither provision actually defines insider trading.  1968: The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in New York rules that anyone who possesses inside information of a consequential nature must either disclose it to all of the investing public or abstain from trading until that information is public. Acting on a tip that the Texas Gulf Sulphur Company had discovered a site near Timmins, Ontario, rich with copper ore, company officials traded heavily in the stock before disclosing the find. **********The officials were sued by the Securities and Exchange Commission and by shareholders, who contended that the executives had traded on inside information. In 1968, the Court of Appeals ruled against the executives, saying that anyone who possesses inside information of a consequential nature must either disclose it to all of the investing public or abstain from trading until that information is public.  1980: The Supreme Court reverses the insider trading conviction of Vincent F. Chiarella. In 1978, the S.E.C. said Mr. Chiarella, a printer at Pandick Press, had pieced together the names of corporate targets from confidential documents and then traded on that information. A Federal court, using Section 10 and Rule 10b-5, convicted Mr. Chiarella of 17 counts of securities fraud and sentenced him to one year in prison. **********The Supreme Court said there must be a confidential relationship, or fiduciary duty, between any defendant and someone else for there to be a violation of the securities law. Associate Justice Lewis F. Powell, writing for the Court, said Mr. Chiarella had owed no duty to the sellers of the stock he had bought.  1983: The Supreme Court rules that Raymond Dirks, a financial analyst, did not commit illegal insider trading by telling clients to sell their stock in the Equity Funding Corporation. Mr. Dirks had uncovered a huge fraud at Equity Funding in 1973. Rather than make his discovery public, he told clients to get rid of their stock in the company. Justice Powell, writing for the court, set certain limits on the insider trading law and said the S.E.C. was wrong to assume that anyone who receives an inside tip and trades on it violates those laws. **********Justice Powell said the duty of a person who receives an inside tip - known in securities jargon as a ''tippee'' - depends entirely on whether the source of the tip has breached a legal duty to the corporation's shareholders in passing the information along.

Moore McCormack, which made te sale as part of a larger restructuring, also said that Paul R. Tregurtha, its president and chief operating officer since 1978, had been elected to fill Mr. Brarker's positions. **********In 1985, the company's bulk transportation unit provided 11.6 percent of its $583.7 million in revenues and 15.8 percent of its operating profits of $117.1 million. Under the tentative agreement, Moore McCormack will receive a small amount of cash and will make payments to the bulk transport unit for a portion of the charter hire on its tankers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/22/busin.print_headline: ECONOMIC SCENE; Trade Theory From Harvard
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/22/busin.body_text: **********FREE trade has been a venerated economic principle in the United States going back 200 years. But there have been challengers. The first was Alexander Hamilton, who in 1791 argued for government policies that would encourage native manufacturing while protecting it from British exports. **********Britain was the world's great trading power then - a role that eventually passed to the United States, without much attention having been paid to Hamilton's theories. But now that Japan wears the crown, some professors at the Harvard Business School are trying to supply the theoretical framework for another challenge to free trade. **********The professors' views are not brand new. But the audience seems to be growing. Last week, for example, representatives of the auto, machine tool, chemical and semiconductor industries traveled to Harvard, in shifts, for workshops that lasted six days. A principal concern was the onslaught of low-cost, high-quality Japanese goods, and the professors, in effect, justified a tougher strategy to deal with the competition. **********''We are looking for an intellectual structure that reflects the real world, and this one does,'' said Andrew A. Procassini, president of the Semiconductor Industry Association, representing an industry that is losing badly to the Japanese. **********The Harvard theory comes in two layers, one involving trade strategy and the other Japan's manufacturing prowess. The latter has to be matched, the professors said. American factory costs have to come down, partly through joint research projects, such as Sematech, the semiconductor industry's embryonic effort. The technology that emerges from this research should be shared by competitors within an industry. This sort of factory technology sharing is rare in the United States. But the goal is to do away with competition at the factory level. Instead, each company in an industry would have expertise to build a state-of-the-art ''generic'' factory. Competition would be elevated to product design and to marketing. In addition, manufacturing efficiency would be enhanced through greater loyalty between customers and suppliers. Such loyalty comes easily to the Japanese, but is resisted by Americans. **********These manufacturing ideas are shared by the five principal members of the Harvard professorial group: Joseph L. Bower, Bruce R. Scott, Robert H. Hayes, Kim B. Clark and Richard Walton. The ideas also are being pushed by the Berkeley Roundtable on International Economics at the University of California. The Berkeley professors helped to run the workshops at Harvard last week. **********The trade part of their theory centers on the proposition that the law of comparative advantage, the main underpinning of free trade, is unrealistic. Here the professors disagree a bit among themselves. But the gist of their case is that, until Americans realize that free trade is a mirage, they will be reluctant to defend American industry. **********Comparative advantage holds that the natural tendency of any nation is to sell abroad the goods that it produces better than other nations. Even when two industrial powers such as the United States and Japan make many goods well, they tend to export the items that one is relatively better at producing than the other - for example, computers from America and small cars from Japan. **********Most American economists, and many business executives, still believe in the essential truth of comparative advantage and in the power of exchange rates to eventually reverse the American trade deficit. ''Show me something that has worked better than free trade and I'll sign up for it,'' said John Hackett, chief financial officer at Cummins Engine, which makes diesel engines. **********But the business school group, and particularly Mr. Scott, insists that comparative advantage is no longer a natural phenomenon. Mr. Scott argues that comparative advantage in modern society is created and manipulated. He says this is exactly what the Japanese do when they build up huge industries at home, protected by trade barriers, then ''dump'' excess production abroad at low prices. Their goal, Mr. Scott argues, is to systematically overpower industry after industry. **********But the business school professors oppose protectionist trade laws. They want a Government trade strategy that singles out priority industries for help. Semiconductors is one because electronic chips are widely used in American products. **********The Government would also push measures that gain American manufacturers ''fair access'' to Japan. Last year's semiconductor anti-dumping agreement, negotiated with the Japanese, is the type of pressure favored by the professors. **********That might not be Japan-bashing, but it certainly is economic nationalism in the Hamilton tradition - a nationalism that in an economy so central to world trade could, in the view of Robert B. Reich, another Harvard University economist, ''very easily transmogrify into protectionism.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/27/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********Regarding the ''Death of the Salesman'' (Prospects, Sept. 6), the practice of department store management dealing directly with resource management is hardly a new phenomenon. Its existence goes well beyond my 25 years in the women's apparel industry and, more to the point, has nothing to do with the present or future condition of the commission sales representative. **********Messrs. Fisher and Bernard would be less inclined to forecast the ''Death of a Salesman'' had they researched the activity at regional trade shows in Atlanta, Miami, Dallas, Charlotte, Chicago, Los angeles, and other cities where, five times a year, thousands of specialty store buyers (and some department store types as well) are sold and serviced by traveling sales representatives. **********Traveling sales professionals play a vital role in the sales and marketing plans of their firms. Contrary to your sources and their conclusions, their demise is not imminent. JOHN RUSSO  Ho-Ho-Kus, N.J., Sept. 16

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/24/busin.body_text: **********Ms. magazine, which has articulated the philosophy of the women's movement for 15 years, is getting a new chance to prove it can also be a commercial success. **********Yesterday, the magazine's co-founders, Gloria Steinem and Patricia Carbine, announced a successful end to their search for new money to turn around the publication, which had made a strong social and political statement but had fared poorly in the increasingly crowded women's magazine field. **********The magazine's future now rests with John Fairfax Ltd., one of Australia's largest publishers and the world's oldest media company still owned by the founding family, which maintains a 60 percent stake. **********Fairfax executives said they planned to maintain Ms.'s feminist editorial policy while providing money for the monthly to expand. **********''This is an opportunity for the magazine to grow,'' Ms. Steinem said. ''Ms. has been extraordinarily influential in this country over the last 15 years, but we've done it on very little money. This will be a very important and helpful change for the magazine.'' **********The involvement of Ms. Steinem and Ms. Carbine will not end with the change in ownership, for both will remain as consultants for five years. **********Ms., which now has a circulation of about 460,000, was first financed with a $1 million investment by Warner Communications Inc. But since 1979, it has operated as a tax-exempt foundation, supported by grants and contributions, because it has not been able to afford to promote itself aggressively to advertisers and potential readers. **********Earlier this year Ms. Steinem had said she was looking for a capital infusion of $10 million to $15 million, but neither party would disclose the terms of the deal yesterday. However, Ms. Steinem said, ''They are very good. We are pleased with them.'' **********The money from the sale of the magazine will go to the Ms. Foundation for Education and Communications. Ms. Steinem said that neither she nor Ms. Carbine would profit from the sale. **********Sandra Yates, president of Fairfax Publications (United States) Ltd., said that the two parties hoped to close the deal early next month and that Fairfax would begin a direct mail campaign to increase circulation by more than 40 percent within five years, to 650,000, and to lift advertising. **********''It's a title that has a lot of potential for growth, given the sufficient resources,'' Ms. Yates said. ''That has always been a problem for the people at Ms. We feel there is a market for a feminist publication and we will be looking to grow. And, it made significant business sense to us.'' **********Bolstered by strong sales of its 15th anniversary edition, Ms. magazine made a profit of $400,000 to $500,000 for the year that ended in July. Before that, Ms. had suffered from operating losses and from a decline in advertising pages as a growing number of publications began to address the subjects on which it was a pioneer. **********The incoming editor in chief, Anne Summers, said that Fairfax was committed to maintaining Ms.'s feminist policies, and that the magazine would now be able to take editorial positions on political candidates - something it was barred from doing while a tax-exempt foundation. **********Ms. Summers, a journalist who once headed the Australian Office of the Status of Women, added that Fairfax had not intended to expand into the women's magazine market until she became aware of the potential availability of Ms. She is in the United States now to begin Sassy, a Fairfax magazine for teen-agers that is scheduled to be introduced next March. **********Fairfax's publications in Australia are The Sydney Morning Herald, The Age in Melbourne, The Sun in Sydney and The Australian Financial Review. It also publishes in Australia, under licensing arrangements, such American magazines as Harper's Bazaar, Cosmopolitan and Good Housekeeping. It publishes Time magazine in Australia under a joint venture with Time Inc. **********The founding family that owns Fairfax recently began an effort to take the company private, but the bid is being contested by Robert Holmes a Court, the wealthy Australian businessman who has a stake in the company. **********Leo Scullin, a senior vice president and director of print at Young & Rubicam, said the Ms. investment could indicate that ''Fairfax is being a bit of a philanthropist.'' **********''This is not just an investment strategy by Fairfax,'' he said. ''The company has got to be a believer in the cause.'' **********Mr. Scullin said one logical route of expansion for Ms. might be overseas. **********Ms. Steinem said that in the magazine's search for capital, it had talked to many potential investors, including venture capital firms, media companies and wealthy individuals. ''They were what we referred to as Ms.'s suitors,'' she said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/27/world.main_headline: In Southeast Asia, Season of Upscale Giving
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/27/world.print_headline: In Southeast Asia, Season of Upscale Giving
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/27/world.body_text: **********Year round, there are plenty of statistics produced to chart the steadily rising prosperity of Southeast Asia's ''little dragon'' economies. But when Christmas comes, the affluence is measured in happy human faces. **********In Singapore this year, at least three little girls in the small island nation got $750 Barbie dolls with real mink coats for Christmas, according to an informal survey of department stores made by The Straits Times newspaper. **********Thousands of mothers and fathers got microwave ovens and other fancy kitchen machines, along with English porcelain, expensive Swiss watches and French designer leather goods. Even last-minute shoppers grabbing cosmetics for gifts spent up to $35 for each purchase. **********Singapore's 2.5 million people -housed in skillfully landscaped, high-rise, Government-planned ''neighborhoods'' on an island no bigger than Barbados - are rapidly reaching the living standards of Europe and the United States, where many of them are educated. Yuppie Banks **********And so young adults, the newspaper discovered, are giving each other museum-quality posters and abstract art. One store sold 5,000 framed reproductions during the Christmas shopping period. Another popular item among the young looks like a ''couch potato'' bank, a spud-shaped money box for Yuppies not in the least deflected by a stock market slide felt here as well as in New York and Tokyo. **********A Singapore merchant offered what he billed as the ''ultimate gift,'' a 1942 Wurlitzer jukebox updated with solid-state technology, including a built-in computer. ''Pure sound, pure investment, pure indulgence,'' the advertisement read, hitting the acquisitive instincts. **********All over Southeast Asia, where Christians are few except in the Philippines, Christmas has caught the imagination, at least in urban areas. That is true not only commercially but also, increasingly, in what the season means in fostering charity and good will. **********This week a Malaysian politician called on his Christian and non-Christian constituents to use the occasion to think about the unity of the nation. Moslem Malays are the region's most wary people when Christian festivals roll around, and Malaysia has recently passed through a period of heightened ethnic tensions. Displays of Lights Abound **********But mostly, Christmas in Southeast Asia means buying gifts and visiting department stores and hotels decorated with millions of lights. Canal and river boats are strung with lights, too. Now and then a floating Christmas party goes by, complete with music and a decorated tree sheltering gifts. **********Christmas trees, in the absence of real firs, are made of anything that will stack into a cone. One Thai hotel, true to its Oriental setting, has made tall ''trees'' of hundreds of Chinese fans. **********Here in Bangkok, Thais have been crowding shopping centers to buy Christmas and New Year greeting cards, as well as lavish boxes of imported chocolates and other delicacies to give to friends. Now and then a Santa Claus appears, to the terror of many Thai children unaccustomed to encountering big fat people with red faces, all that white hair and such noisy laughs. **********New Year's Eve, which the fun-addicted Thais have adopted with alacrity, is really only a rehearsal. Bangkok gets three New Year's days to celebrate: the Western one, the Chinese one and the Buddhist one. **********''We like that,'' a Thai woman mailing greeting cards said. ''We are always looking for reasons to give presents and have a good time.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/05/world.body_text: **********Some of Iran's senior religious leaders appear to oppose the ''human wave'' assaults in which thousands of ill-trained and ill-equipped Iranian troops cross the border to face ''martyrdom'' at the hands of the Iraqis. **********The strong indications of such a position come despite Iran's commitment to wage war against Iraq until the Baghdad Government is overthrown. The conflict is in its seventh year.  The human-wave assaults have been perhaps the most important component of Iran's strategy in its land war against Iraq, whose population is one-third the size of Iran's. They have apparently convinced Iraq and its neighbors that they have both the manpower and the will power to continue fighting indefinitely despite Iraq's vastly superior military arsenal. **********In a little-noticed news conference in Teheran last month, Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani, the Speaker of the Iranian Parliament who has emerged as the country's chief foreign policy maker, outlined a battle strategy of retaliatory strikes and limited offensives based on caution rather than fervor. Strategy Seen as Wasteful **********Hojatolislam Rafsanjani's remarks were the first clear, high-level articulation of the idea that the human wave assaults have been wasteful. It would be unlikely that he would make such remarks without the approval of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the Iranian leader. **********Surprise in an offensive is essential ''to prevent extensive casualties,'' Hojatolislam Rafsanjani said. ''When the enemy is alert, when he shoots a hail of bullets at our combat infantry and brings his firepower to bear, the casualties will go too high.'' **********He also cautioned that a major offensive should only begin when there is a good chance of winning. **********''When, for example, we suddenly want to bring several thousand human crusaders to the war zone, and use a vast amount of military resources, we must be relatively sure - there must be a relative consensus - of victory,'' Hojatolislam Rafsanjani said at the news conference, which was broadcast on the Teheran radio on June 4. **********He called for similar caution in retaliating against Iraqi attacks. ''When the Iraqis engage in mischief, we will respond to the extent we are prepared,'' he said. **********It is unclear whether the Parliament Speaker's call for caution and preparation will be translated into action. **********Commanders in the regular army have long urged better battle strategy and preparation to limit casualties, but the increasingly powerful Revolutionary Guards want to press the fight at any cost. Noticeable Iranian Weariness **********Ayatollah Khomeini continues to make statements exhorting young men to join the war effort. In a speech broadcast May 29, he said Iranians ''should not hesitate to join the front, and the front should not relax its activity.'' He added, ''Every day that this story is delayed, the more difficult it becomes.'' **********But Iranian war weariness has become more noticeable since the offensive near the southeast Iraqi city of Basra early this year, which resulted in large casualties on both sides, did not materialize into the ''final offensive'' that Iran's leaders have promised since 1983. That offensive was followed by another disappointing Iranian offensive in the north, which Iraqi forces quickly repulsed. **********''We know this has been a subject of constant debate, and Rafsanjani's remarks are significant,'' said Shaul Bakhash, professor of history at George Mason University in Fairfax, Va., who has written extensively about Iran. ''The issue has been resolved in favor of more cautious elements, at least for the time being.'' **********Even if Iran's leaders decide to end their ''human wave'' offensives, it does not mean that Iran will settle for anything less than the ouster of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/26/world.main_headline: REAGAN, FAULTING PEACE BID, INSISTS ON NEW CONTRA AID
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/26/world.print_headline: REAGAN, FAULTING PEACE BID, INSISTS ON NEW CONTRA AID
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/26/world.body_text: **********President Reagan, saying the Central America peace process faces ''inevitable complications,'' insisted today that he would push for renewed contra aid and suggested that the Nicaraguan Government's efforts toward democratization might turn out to be ''mere show'' and ''Potemkin reforms.'' **********The President spoke as the Senate approved $3.5 million in short-term, non-weapons aid for the Nicaraguan rebels to keep their forces intact during peace talks. **********When the House of Representatives approved the same aid package on Wednesday, Speaker Jim Wright predicted it would be the last United States aid the contras would ever get because of the regional peace agreement signed in Guatemala last month. Speech to Women's Group **********But in a speech today to the Concerned Women for America, a conservative group, Mr. Reagan excoriated the Sandinista Government with the strongest language he has used in months. He mentioned the Guatemala peace agreement only in passing, and then to predict that it would become bogged down in difficulties. **********The President made his speech only a few days after President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica, the principal author of the peace plan, visited Washington and asked Mr. Reagan and Congress to give the peace process a chance. Also in the last several days, the Sandinistas announced they would allow the opposition newspaper, La Prensa, and a Roman Catholic radio station to reopen free of censorship six weeks earlier than was called for in the Guatemala accord. 'Clear Shot Over the Bow' **********A White House official said the President's speech was a ''clear shot over the bow'' signaling the Administration's strategy for trying to win renewed military aid to the contras: Let the Guatemala peace process runs its course, declare the Sandinistas' moves toward democratization to be a sham and then ask Congress to approve $270 million in new contra aid, saying it is needed to press the Sandinistas for real democratization. **********''Anyone who does not insist on true democracy in Nicaragua is not serving the cause of peace,'' Mr. Reagan said, suggesting that the Sandinistas may not be interested in that. **********''Remember back when they were trying to tell us in certain areas of the media that Castro was the George Washington of Cuba?'' he asked. **********The end to news censorship in Nicaragua is ''a good beginning,'' he said, but ''only a beginning.'' **********''I can tell you,'' he added, ''aid to the freedom fighters must and will continue. The American people want it, justice demands it, and it is the only way to make the Marxist-Leninists in Managua sincerely talk peace.'' **********Officials insisted that they hadve made no final decision on when they would come forward with the new request for contra aid. On Monday a senior Administration official said the White House would wait until after Nov. 7, the deadline for the Guatemala plan to be carried out. But then a White House spokesman corrected him and said the official position is that no decision has been made. **********For weeks the White House has been trying to decide how to pursue the President's hard-line goals in Nicaragua while also seeming to support the Central American peace process, even though it is based on an agreement that Mr. Reagan has characterized as ''fatally flawed.'' **********Some officials are convinced that Congress will not renew aid to the contras as long as the Nicaraguans seem to be complying with the regional peace accord. At the same time, a White House official said, the President remains adamant. **********''We're caught in a box,'' the official said today. ''He won't be satisfied until we have a full American-style democracy there, and he doesn't think the Sandinistas are capable of that.'' **********Officials said Nancy Reagan had been urging her husband's senior aides to find a solution to the dilemma, ''to get him out of trouble on this issue,'' one official said. Worry About Harsh Language **********A senior White House official acknowledged that the President's harsh language might not be helpful to the White House when it does ask Congress for renewed contra aid. But he said Mr. Reagan and the national security adviser, Frank C. Carlucci, believed the harsh tone was needed to convince the contras that the United States has not abandoned them. That, the official said, would help keep desertion rates low. **********When the United States cut off all official military aid to the contras, in 1985 and 1986, the contra forces actually expanded dramatically. **********As he has before, Mr. Reagan set out a list of demands the Sandinistas must meet to satisfy him. **********''Open up the jails and let the thousands of political prisoners free, let the exiles come home, allow freedom of worship, free labor unions, a free economy,'' he said, repeating demands he has made before. **********But then Mr. Reagan added a new one. ''Dissolve the so-called neighborhood watch committees,'' he said, apparently referring to the Sandinista Defense Committees. Modeled After Cuban System **********The committees, called ''the eyes and ears of the revolution,'' operate in every neighborhood and help the Government maintain control. They distribute food ration cards, supervise registration for the military draft and monitor any dissident behavior. **********The Guatemala peace plan does not mention those committees, and officials believe the Sandinistas would be reluctant to disband them. Verifying that they had been disbanded would be difficult in any case, they added. The committees are modeled after a similar system in Cuba.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/25/world.main_headline: COMPROMISE SEEN IN U.S.-EUROPE TRADE FIGHT
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/25/world.print_headline: COMPROMISE SEEN IN U.S.-EUROPE TRADE FIGHT
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/25/world.body_text: **********The United States and the European Community appeared to be edging toward a compromise today in a conflict over feed-grain sales to Spain that has threatened to develop into an Atlantic trade war. **********''It looks like an agreement may be coming,'' a European official said early this afternoon as European and American negotiators were in a second day of talks at the office of the United States special trade representative, Clayton K. Yeutter, two blocks from the White House. Joining Mr. Yeutter on the American side was Agriculture Secretary Richard E. Lyng. **********The European Community delegation, led by External Affairs Commissioner Willy de Clercq and Agriculture Commissioner Frans Andriessen, is expected to depart over the weekend to present a compromise proposal to the community's Council of Ministers, which meets Monday in Brussels. **********The council, the political leadership of the 12-nation bloc, must give final approval to any agreement. Both sides have imposed a lid on information on the negotiations. Talks Are Broken Off **********The talks broke off at 3:30 P.M. without agreement, but both sides reported a narrowing of differences. ''We have been able to move closer together, but not to resolve the issue,'' a spokesman for Mr. Yeutter said. **********A European official said Mr. de Clercq now had to get fresh negotiating instructions from the Council of Ministers on Monday. To forestall American retaliation, an accord must be in place by Friday. **********A European official, reading from a statement, said: ''Each party will now proceed to the necessary consultations. The two parties will resume contact within the next few days in light of these consultations.'' **********The dispute focuses on demands by the United States for $400 million in trade compensation for American corn and sorghum exports lost as a result of Spain's entry into the community on Jan. 1, 1986. #200% Punitive Duties On Thursday, President Reagan signed an order that would impose punitive 200 percent duties on Jan. 30 on a wide range of European wine, cheese and other products if agreement is not reached on compensation. The duties would affect all 12 countries.  The Europeans, in turn, have threatened to hit back with a new high levy on American shipments of corn gluten feed, a byproduct of corn milling, that is fed to cows and chickens in Europe. **********The United States duties are to be assessed on European products, valued at about $400 million, that include low-priced wine, high-priced brandy, gin, canned ham, endives, olives, carrots and brie and some other cheeses. **********Because many of these products are popular with young American professionals, the conflict has been jocularly referred to as the ''yuppie trade war.'' A Potential Global Problem **********Trade analysts warn that the dispute, if not settled this weekend, contains the potential for serious global economic reverses. The United States has already served notice that if the Europeans retaliate for the high duties, the United States will do so as well. **********The dispute would also set back efforts to start a new round of trade liberalization, known as the Uruguay Round, which major trading nations agreed to last October.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/06/busin.body_text: **********IN 1984, the year American Express Publishing acquired Food & Wine magazine, the publication lost $2.8 million. ''This year,'' said the publisher, James S. Berrien, ''it will put about $1.5 million in the bank.'' **********That's the reason the magazine will for the first time turn to a full-fledged advertising campaign to sell itself to advertisers. **********Until now, Ron Prince, the 29-year-old marketing director, has been aiming the promotion with rifle-shot accuracy at the primary advertising targets: food, alcoholic beverages, automotive products and travel. He has been smoothing the way for his sales force with quarterly delivery of baskets, worth as much as $50, filled with food, wine and kitchenware. These go to about 350 advertiser and agency decision-makers on the level of those who don't answer their own phones. **********Those making smaller decisions are invited to join groups of 20 for a cooking lesson in the magazine's test kitchen and a dinner in the dining room afterward. About 20 of these sessions are held a month. **********Mr. Prince's budget in 1986 was $500,000 but that included the cost of audience research the magazine purchased. **********Mr. Berrien, 35, and his associate might well typify the audience the magazine is trying to reach. The publisher calls them ''the people who work hard and want to play hard.'' They are people who can knowledgeably discuss the better restaurants and good wine years. **********''We treat food as theater,'' Mr. Prince said. **********''This is a magazine about fun,'' Mr. Berrien said.  And the well-fed but trim twosome noted that part of the fun of dining out is listening in on conversations at neighboring tables. To understand that is to appreciate the new campaign that will break in Adweek and Marketing and Media Decisions later this month. **********It goes like this: on top of a picture of beautifully served food go such bits of dialogue as ''Sometimes I really think you go too far!'' ''What's the matter? All I said was, 'Don't you think I need an answering machine for my car phone?' '' **********Or ''Jean and Rodney are going to St. Barts. Kathy and Malcolm are going to Moorea. And the Wyatts are going to the Seychelles.'' ''Can't we find an obscure place that isn't known?'' **********The idea, Mr. Prince said, ''is to let advertisers eavesdrop on our readers.'' **********The print advertising campaign in the trade press, on which at least $250,000 will be spent during the rest of the year, will augment the freeloading events, not replace them. **********The advertising was created by Ogilvy & Mather, which gives good service to this relatively small spender since Ogilvy is also the prime agency of American Express and the company's other magazines, Travel & Leisure and New York Woman. **********The interesting thing about all three is that together they add very little to the company's bottom line, but, Mr. Berrien notes, their editorial raison d'etre is to get the reader to spend money for things that can be paid for with American Express Cards. **********Food & Wine had a 500,000 circulation rate base when acquired in 1984 and 505 pages of advertising. This year it has a 750,000 rate base and will have more than 750 pages of ads. **********Much of the growth is due to repositioning as the fun magazine for the younger and more affluent in a niche between Gourmet and Bon Appetit. The advertising theme line had been ''The magazine for young gourmets.'' With the new campaign it will become ''The one magazine that keeps up with changing tastes.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/05/world.body_text: **********The Soviet authorities commuted the death sentence of Karl Linnas, who had been convicted in absentia as a Nazi war criminal in 1962, before his death in Leningrad last Thursday, according to Mr. Linnas's attorney and his daughter, who arrived in New York yesterday. **********The attorney, Ramsey Clark, told reporters at Kennedy International Airport that the decision was made under a Soviet statute of limitations before Mr. Linnas's death at the age of 67 from heart and kidney disease. Under the law, the sentence is ''discretionary,'' he said. No public announcement of the commutation has been made by the Soviet Union. **********''I can not put the blame on anyone,'' Anu Linnas said of the medical treatment given to her father in the Soviet Union and in the United States, where he had been held prisoner for one year prior to his deportation 11 weeks ago. **********Anu Linnas brought her father's ashes back to the United States. **********In a prepared statement, she said she was allowed to see her father for 10 minutes to convey messages from family members, friends and supporters. **********''He smiled, looked up at the doctors and gave a thumbs-up sign,'' she said, adding that he spoke very little. She said she planned to continue her efforts to establish his innocence, adding ''the end of his life is not the end of the story.'' **********Mr. Clark said that they were told that Mr. Linnas was taken to Leningrad on June 22 after his condition deteriorated in an effort to give him ''the best medical attention.'' Mr. Clark said he had a written medical report, which he said would have to be translated.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/06/busin.main_headline: A History of Defying Public Policy By WILLIAM B. O'CONNELL; William B. O'Connell is president of the United States League of Savings Institutions.
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/06/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS FORUM: THE FINANCIAL ACCOUNTING STANDARDS BOARD; A History of Defying Public Policy By WILLIAM B. O'CONNELL; William B. O'Connell is president of the United States League of Savings Institutions.
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/06/busin.body_text: **********IN a quiet setting in Stamford, Conn., there is a group of seven men who make up the Financial Accounting Standards Board. Although this group has a profound influence on the economic life of the country, the members are not publicly elected, nor appointed by or answerable to any elected official body. **********Nonetheless, the board has issued rules that sometimes go against the expressed will of Congress. Over the years, the standard-setting body has had a long history of conflict with public policy. **********This thwarting of Congressional will continues today. In the late 1970's and early 1980's, Congress began to deregulate the nation's financial institutions, dismantling laws and regulations under which banks and savings institutions had operated since the 1930's. While the need for deregulation is widely accepted, it has not been established without costs and strains on the financial system. **********In an era of debilitating Federal budget deficits, financial institutions themselves have borne the brunt of the costs of deregulation. In response, Congress has on several occasions enacted measures designed to stretch these costs over a period of years, affording the nation's financial institutions the opportunity to work through these fragile times. **********The board has decided that it knows better than Congress and has determined that financial institutions should not be afforded the opportunities granted by law to adjust to a deregulated environment. It is ironic that many of the financial institutions that failed in recent years were reporting stellar performance under generally accepted accounting principles up to the time they collapsed. **********These are examples of the board's usurpation of the public policy-making role: *********** In the early 1980's, double-digit interest rates caused huge losses at many of the country's savings banks and savings and loan associations. In 1982, Congress passed the Net Worth Certificate program whereby the Federal deposit insurance agencies, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, were authorized to purchase capital certificates from affected institutions. This program was designed to buy time for such institutions to return to health when interest rates declined to more traditional levels. The wisdom of Congress was borne out by the fact that most of the institutions that were allowed to use the Net Worth Certificates have returned to health, saving the Federal insurance agencies billions of dollars. Although Congress mandated that such certificates would count as capital or net worth of the institutions that issued them, the board's staff determined in 1983 that they would not count as such. As a result, many institutions did not participate in the program, and some failed. *********** Agriculture is going through a tough period and this has translated into problems for the commercial banks that serve the farmers. In an effort to buy time for such banks in the same manner as had earlier been used for savings institutions, the 1987 Banking Act allows banks to write off losses on agricultural loans over a period of up to 10 years, rather than having to recognize them immediately. While the board has not addressed this question yet, we are assured informally by the staff that it will not go along with the Congressionally authorized forbearance. *********** Two-thirds of the savings institutions insured by the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation have an investment in that corporation's fund known as the Secondary Reserve. For years, institutions carried this investment on their books as an asset. Earlier this year, Federal regulators said they would have to write off this investment because of the weak condition of the insurance agency. The accounting board concurred and even took the remarkable position that the seizure of this asset by a Federal agency was an ordinary rather than an extraordinary accounting event - an important distinction in the rarefied world of accountants. Congress, however, rightly thought that the regulators' action represented an inequitable expropriation from the institutions that held the investment. In the Competitive Equality Banking Act, signed Aug. 10, Congress ordered that the appropriated investment be paid back over the next six years. Despite this action, the board refused to retract its position and allow institutions to restore the investment as an asset on their books. In so doing it dismissed the arguments of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, the primary Federal regulator for savings institutions. **********IT is unsettling to have a small private body of accountants overriding the Federal board, turning into supplicants board members who are appointed by the President and confirmed by the Senate. **********I am not advocating that weak banks or savings institutions be allowed to project a false sense of health. Any of the measures I have mentioned have been authorized by Congress and must be clearly disclosed to the regulators as well as to shareholders so they can see the condition of each institution with and without the helping measures that Congress has allowed. **********Nor am I advocating that the board, which was set up by the accounting profession to avoid government regulation, should be disbanded and accountants brought under Federal regulation. If the board is not more cognizant of the public policy implications of its actions, however, it risks that very outcome.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/24/busin.body_text: **********Japan's production of cars, trucks and buses declined for the fourth consecutive month in January, dropping 3.3 percent from a year earlier, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said today, linking the sluggish production to a slump in domestic sales. https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/18/busin.print_headline: WHAT'S NEW IN COLLEGE RECRUITING; Law and Medicine: Easier Access
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/18/busin.body_text: **********NOW may be the time to go to medical or law school. Applications are down significantly, and the schools are scrambling for candidates. In 1974, when medical school applications peaked, there were 2.8 applicants for each available slot; now there are just about 2 prospects for each seat. The peak for law schools was not until fall 1980, but the valley is just as deep. Applications to law schools declined about 17 percent between 1981 and 1985, according to William J. Kennish, consultant to the Law School Admissions Council, although they increased slightly in 1986. **********Some professional schools are trying to attract nontraditional candidates. The Mount Sinai School of Medicine in New York has been trying to lure non-science majors. ''A broader-based humanities education may produce physicians who are better able to relate to patients as people,'' explained Dr. Barry D. Stimmel, academic dean at Mount Sinai. This year the school began an ambitious humanities recruiting program. Colleges were invited to enroll five humanities sophomores in a pre-med curriculum of minimum science with students spending summers at Mount Sinai. Admission to medical study is guaranteed if they maintain a B average. **********Medical schools have sought minority students for two decades - with limited success - but that competition has really put the squeeze on predominantly black medical schools. **********''We look on the opening of medical schools as very positive, but it did make things more competititive for us,'' said Dr. David Satcher, president of Meharry Medical School in Nashville, which is 85 percent black. Meharry's recruiting efforts begin early. The college has a summer program for freshmen and sophomores at feeder colleges, and even a program for selected high schools. **********Over all, the number of medical school applicants has declined partly because of the high cost of a medical education and the increasing limits on doctors' incomes, Dr. Stimmel said. He added: ''In New York City it's not unusual to graduate owing $50,000. Government control and the rise of H.M.O.'s limit autonomy and income for physicians. There's been enough in the press that the message is finally getting across to medical school applicants.'' **********The effect of bad publicity is also felt by law school recruiters. ''We've been hurt by the notion bantered about that there are too many lawyers,'' grouses Suzy L. Golden, acting director of law school admissions at Golden Gate College. ''There probably is a glut, but if you're good, there are never too many.'' Golden Gate has cut the size of its entering class so it can afford to take only the better students. The entering class this fall at the urban San Francisco school is 130. In 1982 it was 300. **********Schools like the University of Toledo law school are banking on increased scholarships to stabilize enrollment. The Ohio school of 600 offers 15 full and 20 partial grants to new students, double the grants given in 1982. **********''One must be inventive,'' said Ms. Golden. ''Although the decline in applicants seems to be leveling off, we've all learned a lot. We've learned you've got to determine where your market is, who you are and what you have to offer.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/15/busin.main_headline: SOUTH AFRICA SALE BY FORD WILL GIVE BLACKS BIG STAKE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/15/busin.print_headline: SOUTH AFRICA SALE BY FORD WILL GIVE BLACKS BIG STAKE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/15/busin.body_text: **********The Ford Motor Company is poised to sell its South African interests in a complex deal that would give its predominantly black work force a major share of the business, but leave its products still available there. **********The company has been under intense pressure to pull out of the country to protest the Government's apartheid policies. The General Motors Corporation announced last October that it would leave after selling its operations to a group of investors led by local G.M. managers. Under G.M.'s plan, it would continue to sell automotive components to its former subsidiary. **********A Ford spokesman in Detroit confirmed today that talks had been held for several months with South African labor and community leaders regarding the ownership change for the subsidiary, the South African Motor Corporation, known here as Samcor. Subsidiary Merged in 1985 **********Ford, like G.M., has manufactured cars in South Africa for many years. In 1985 Ford merged a subsidiary of the Ford Motor Company of Canada with Amcar Motor Holdings, a unit of the Anglo American Corporation, a mining and industrial conglomerate. The merger left Ford with a 42 percent stake in Samcor, with the rest held by Anglo American. **********Samcor is one of the biggest car manufacturers in South Africa. At the time the merger took place in 1985, Ford was producing about 40,000 cars a year in South Africa, but the number has declined since then. **********More than 100 United States companies have left South Africa since October 1984, when black resistance to white rule led to civil unrest on an unprecedented scale in the country's black townships. **********Since then more than 2,500 people have been killed and last week a 12-month-old nationwide state of emergency was renewed. Leslie Boyd, chairman of Samcor and an executive director of Anglo American, confirmed news reports here today that Ford was negotiating with employees the transfer of a major share in Samcor to a trust for the benefit of its black workers. **********He said that Ford had agreed, however, to continue supplying Samcor with automobile components and allow the use of the Ford logotype, which has been seen on South African roads for 61 years. Samcor produces cars and trucks in Pretoria and makes engines and other components in Port Elizabeth. Two Seats on Company Board **********Mr. Boyd said that discussions were still at a ''formative stage'' and would give no further details of the proposed pullout. But industry sources said that talks with trade union leaders had revolved around the sale of 57 percent of Ford's stake in Samcor to its employees and the remaining 43 percent to the Anglo American Corporation. In addition, a report in the United States said the Samcor workers would receive two seats on the company's board. **********The Chrysler Corporation, the remaining member of the American Big Three United States auto makers, never had extensive operations in South Africa. **********Newspaper reports said the trade unions had reservations about the proposed deal because they feared it could leave them vunerable to layoffs without protection from Ford. **********When Ford and Anglo American formed Samcor and moved its headquarters to Pretoria nearly two years ago, thousands of jobs were lost at Ford's plant near the Indian Ocean port of Port Elizabeth. **********The Ford move, which has clearly been in the planning for several months, caused some surprise in business circles following the assurance by Donald E. Petersen, Ford's chairman, in Detroit only a month ago that Ford wanted to stay in South Africa. **********In an interview tonight Adrian Botha, executive director of the American Chamber of Commerce, said that he did not think that the Ford move would herald a major outflow of United States capital from South Africa. **********Mr. Botha said he did not see any connection between the Ford move and the decision by the Rev. Leon H. Sullivan to call for the total withdrawal of the remaining United States companies in South Africa. Mr. Sullivan is a black Baptist minister from Philadelphia who is the author of the Sullivan Principles, a code of nonracial conduct for companies. He is also a member of G.M.'s board. **********During the past 18 months more than 100 companies have left South Africa.
