https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/14/busin.body_text: **********In a move that likely surprised the entertainment industry, the Cahners Publishing Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Variety, the trade publication known as the bible of the industry. **********Cahners, the nation's largest publisher of specialized business and technical magazines, is part of Reed International, a British company. Its 52 titles include such journals as Publisher's Weekly, Professional Builder, Mini-Micro Systems and Plastic Business News. **********Cahners did not disclose the size of the deal, but it did say that Weekly Variety and Daily Variety together generated revenues of $20 million to $25 million in advertising and circulation last year. Generally trade publications have pretax profit margins of about 15 percent, a level that would mean Variety generated at least $3 million in pretax income. **********''Such dreamboat one-of-a-kind properties have been selling at 15 to 20 times pretax income,'' said John Suhler, a partner at Veronis Suhler, investment bankers specializing in the communications industry. That could put the Cahners purchase price at $45 million to $60 million or more. Cahners declined to commment, and so did Syd Silverman, the owner of Variety. **********The acquisition by Cahners will end an era of family ownership for Variety, which was founded in 1905 by Mr. Silverman's grandfather, Sime. Today three of Mr. Silverman's four children still work at the paper, housed in an unprepossessing Manhattan brownstone on West 46th Street, just a block from where Sime Silverman started. **********For 40 years Variety has been a staple of the entertainment industry, and it remains the only trade paper to report box-office grosses on a weekly basis for a vast number of the movie theaters in major American cities. **********Although Variety started as a film trade paper, it now also reports on the television, cable and music industries. Despite this diversification, its headlines and terminology - ''legs'' for a film that is a long-running hit and ''boffo'' for a box-office success - are part of the Hollywood language. **********For years, entrepreneurs eager to gain leverage and glamour in the entertainment business have tried to buy the publication. Among those rumored to have been interested in Variety recently was the Times Mirror Company. **********''The pressure escalated after the Broadcasting and Billboard deals,'' Mr. Silverman said yesterday in a telephone interview from his home in Westchester County. **********Times Mirror bought Broadcasting magazine for $75 million last November. Billboard Publications, which issues the leading trade journal in the music recording field, was bought for $100 million in March by Affiliated Publications, corporate parent of The Boston Globe. Family Members' Contracts **********Mr. Silverman emphasized that neither he nor his children were leaving Variety. He has a five-year contract with an option to renew, he said, and his four children, including one who is a college senior, all have five-year contracts. **********Mr. Silverman acknowledged that Cahners made the most attractive offer but added that he also liked the fact that there was no conflict of interest because Cahners has no broadcasting properties. **********''There is not a sale but a merger,'' Mr. Silverman said. ''This will make Variety stronger with all corporate resources.'' **********Noting that Cahners reports to its parent company in England, he said, ''That will take some of the pressure off us. There is someone between us and the muzzlers on Wall Street'' -an allusion to the pressure for quarterly earnings improvement. **********''But we will certainly do our share,'' he added. **********There are roughly 125 people on the Variety staff, with offices in New York, Hollywood, Toronto and Paris. Daily Variety has a circulation of 22,000, and Weekly Variety has a circulation of 33,000. The latter figure represents a decline of 4,000 in the last few years. **********Mr. Silverman attributed the circulation drop to cutbacks at the television networks, among other factors. However, some critics said yesterday that Variety faced more serious competition, not only from The Hollywood Reporter but from new publications such as Electronic Media, a relatively new weekly that is owned by Crain Communications. **********Cahners, based in Newton, Mass., generated $267 million in sales from its operations last year. The company does not break out magazine profits separately. **********Cahners also owns the Cahners Exposition Group, which puts on more than 200 trade shows worldwide, as well as R. R. Bowker, which publishes magazines and directories for libraries. **********Last year it acquired Technical Publishing from Dun & Bradstreet for $250 million. Technical Publishing owns 21 magazines aimed at business and professional readers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/08/busin.body_text: **********With Republicans refusing to participate, Democratic members of the House Ways and Means Committee began working alone today on a bill to raise $12 billion in new tax revenue to meet 1988 budget needs. Meeting behind closed doors for three hours, the Democrats tentatively approved a dozen tax changes that would meet about half of their goal. **********Only a few of the $6.3 billion in tax changes approved today were considered sweeping, including a three-year extension of the expiring 3 percent excise tax on local and long-distance telephone service. **********By and large, the proposals affect only certain taxpayers and businesses. Among them are new ''user fees'' for certain Government services, changes in the rules for corporate estimated taxes, elimination of scheduled reductions in estate and gift tax rates, and the curtailment of an estate tax loophole. Search Now Becomes Harder **********Democrats planned to continue work on the package on Thursday, expecting that the next $6 billion would be harder to find and the proposals more controversial. Their plan was to spend Thursday sifting through unused ideas from the Reagan Administration's original income tax overhaul proposals. But aides thought few would be adopted, given that they were rejected by Congress during the two-year tax overhaul debate. **********Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said he was disappointed that the Republicans had chosen not to participate. But he said the Democrats felt a responsibility to put together a $12 billion tax bill as part of an overall deficit reduction package in order to avoid $23 billion in automatic spending cuts as set forth by the recently modified Gramm-Rudman law. **********Republicans have sought to reduce the $12 billion revenue figure, asking the Democrats to cut more spending instead. But various Republican compromise offers were rejected today by House Democrats, and Republicans signaled their refusal to participate in drafting the tax bill. **********Representative John J. Duncan of Tennessee, the ranking Republican on the Ways and Means Committee, said Republicans prefer that the automatic spending cuts occur rather than ''disproportionately increasing the taxpayers' burden.'' Tough Going for Democrats **********Without Republican participation, the Democrats face what they admit will be a tough battle in getting a tax bill passed on the House floor, particularly if President Reagan refuses to bend from his strong stance against new taxes. **********''I'm not comfortable doing it,'' Mr. Rostenkowski told reporters. ''I would prefer to have bipartisan support. But I don't have the luxury of waiting.'' **********Asked whether he thought a bill could pass the House, he said, ''I don't know.'' **********''It could all end up being an exercise in futility,'' added Representative Brian J. Donnelly, a Massachusetts Democrat on the committee. **********Democrats are trying to fashion a tax package that would minimize objections from other Democrats and avoid the types of tax changes that would bring an almost certain veto from President Reagan. Many of the changes approved today by the Democrats came directly from Mr. Reagan's 1988 budget proposals. And the committee's decision to look at income tax changes followed recent suggestions by James C. Miller 3d, the Administration's budget director. **********Senior aides to Mr. Rostenkowski said the committee does not intend to consider major increases in excise taxes or increases in income tax rates, the latter of which President Reagan has repeatedly pledged to veto. **********Mr. Rostenkowski said he hoped to finish the tax bill by the end of next week, along with a bill that would make hundreds of ''technical changes'' to the Tax Reform Act of 1986. **********On the Senate side, the Finance Committee is set to begin considering similar legislation on Thursday, but no specific proposals were expected to be discussed until a later session. The Latest Changes **********These were among the changes approved today: *********** An extension for three years of the excise tax on telephone service, which had been scheduled to expire at the end of this year. *********** A requirement that employers pay a payroll tax on cash tips received by waiters and other service personnel. *********** A repeal of the current exemptions from highway trust fund excise taxes for buses and state and local governments. *********** A new user fee for each ''determination letter'' and ''private letter ruling'' issued by the Internal Revenue Service to taxpayers. *********** An increase in various fees charged by the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms. *********** An increase in various fees charged by the Customs Service. *********** An extension and expansion of the Internal Revenue Service effort to collect past-due Federal agency debts from taxpayers. *********** A freeze in the gift and estate tax rates at current levels, rather than letting them drop next year as previously scheduled. *********** A curtailment of a loophole in the estate tax law for sales of stock to Employee Stock Ownership Plans. *********** A modification of corporate estimated tax rules in a way that would force certain companies to speed up their estimated tax payments during the year. *********** An extension of the present Federal Unemployment Tax Act (F.U.T.A.) tax rate of 6.2 percent of the first $7,000 in wages paid to an employee for three years, through 1990, rather than a drop to 6.0 percent as previously scheduled. **********Also approved was a provision to give individuals and businesses some relief this year from more stringent estimated tax rules stemming from the 1986 tax act. This provision would actually mean a loss of revenue.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/25/world.main_headline: A Sri Lanka Compromise Reported Near
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/25/world.print_headline: A Sri Lanka Compromise Reported Near
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/25/world.body_text: **********Indian and Sri Lankan officials said today that separatist Tamil guerrillas had ''agreed in principle'' to a proposal that could end a bitter four-year ethnic conflict in Sri Lanka. **********The moves followed intense negotiations between the Indians and the Sri Lankans, notably an exchange of letters on the issue between Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi and the Sri Lankan President, J. R. Jayewardene, officials from both sides said. Agreement on the issue would mean that Mr. Gandhi and Mr. Jayewardene could sign an accord on the peace plan as early as next week, officials said. **********The package of proposals is said to involve key concessions by President Jayewardene, who appears to have compromised on his longstanding refusal to unite the north and east in an autonomous province. **********The Tamils would be expected to surrender their weapons and stop using the Indian state of Tamil Nadu, home to 52 million Indian Tamils, as a base for their activities. Tamil Population Is Split **********''It's very close to being tied up,'' one Indian official said. But he also cautioned reporters that ''the last part of the negotiations is always the trickiest.'' **********The 16.6 million people of Sri Lanka, an island nation off the southeastern tip of India, are split into two main ethnic groups, the majority Sinhalese, who for the most part are Buddhists, and the Tamils, a minority of about 15 percent who for the most part are Hindus. **********The Tamils of Northern and Eastern Provinces in Sri Lanka have been agitating for increased autonomy since 1956, when the Government acted to make Sinhala the official language. The Tamils have their own language. **********Open warfare began in 1983 when Tamils killed 13 soldiers and rioting followed in which more than 1,000 people were killed. Most of the victims were Tamils. **********The Tamils themselves are split. The north and east, where many of them live, are centers for separatism. However, another sizeable group of Tamils, in the south-central hill country, are not separatists. **********The chief of the main separatist guerrilla group, Velupillai Prabakaran of the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, arrived in New Delhi today on an Indian plane for a probable meeting with Mr. Gandhi over the weekend. India Has Acted as Mediator **********The Indian Ambassador to Sri Lanka, Jyotindra Nath Dixit, was also on his way here with details of the proposed accord, officials said. Mr. Dixit and other Indian Embassy officials have had intense talks with President Jayewardene and his aides. **********For several years, India has acted as mediator between the two sides. **********With the approval of the Sri Lankans, an Indian diplomat carried the latest proposals to Mr. Prabakaran at his guerrilla headquarters in the Tamil-dominated Northern Province. The militant leader has been there for several months directing rebel operations against Sri Lankan troops. The Government troops made major gains in an offensive this summer. **********Representatives of the Sri Lankan militants could not be reached for comment on the sudden developments. Officials here, who had been in touch with them, said they had ''responded positively.'' #70-Member Council Foreseen Mr. Jayewardene wants India to be a guarantor of the accord, which officials say envisions an amalgamation of Eastern and Northern Provinces with one chief minister or top elected official, one governor and 70 members in the unified provincial council. **********Thirty-six lawmakers are to be picked from Northern Province and 34 from Eastern Province under the accord, which would have to be approved in a referendum in the two provinces within one year. **********Mr. Jayewardene had resisted the plan to unite the two territories, arguing that the population of Eastern Province was equally divided among Moslems, Sinhalese and Tamils. **********But there are still questions of whether Mr. Jayewardene will be able to convince hard-liners in his ruling United National Party on his reported moves. One important leader whose cooperation is crucial to the success of the plan is the Prime Minister, Ranasinghe Premadasa, who cut short a visit to Japan to return to Colombo. **********Mr. Premadasa is identified with the militant group in the ruling party and has frequently criticized India's role in the Sri Lankan ethnic problem. **********Colombo had denounced a unilateral Indian airdrop of relief supplies on June 4 over the region around Jaffna, capital of Northern Province, calling the Indian action a violation of Sri Lankan sovereignty. Since then, however, the two sides have cooperated in sending food, medical goods and other relief material to the north, where supplies of consumer goods have been disrupted by the civil strife. GANDHI EXPECTED TO SIGN ACCORD **********COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, July 24 (Special to The New York Times) - Officials here said today that Prime Minister Gandhi would arrive Wednesday to sign an accord with President Jayewardene envisioning regional autonomy for the Tamils. **********President Jayewardene said Thursday in a tough speech to Cabinet members and legislators that anyone who disagreed with the proposals was free to resign.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/18/world.main_headline: U.S. Culture Impresario Is Leaving Moscow
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/18/world.print_headline: U.S. Culture Impresario Is Leaving Moscow
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/18/world.body_text: **********Continuing a long season of caviar-and-vodka leave-takings at the United States Embassy, Raymond E. Benson has stepped down from his post monitoring the frontier where Soviet culture and politics meet. **********His name is better known in Moscow's literary circles than in New York's, but it was Mr. Benson's knowledge and persistence that wrought the 1985 cultural exchange agreement sending the Bolshoi Ballet to the United States and bringing Vladimir Horowitz to Moscow, where the audience wept at the music he made. And at a time when members of Congress and Administration aides were clamoring for greater security, espousing the view of an embassy as a fortress, it was Mr. Benson, 60 years old, the head of the embassy's cultural and press offices, who did as much as possible to get himself out of the fortress. **********His excellent command of Russian and nuanced knowledge of Soviet culture was nurtured in of scores of evenings in Russian kitchens, of walks in the springtime mud of Peredelkino with writers like Anatoly Rybakov, of hours watching the crowds at the graves of Boris Pasternak or the balladeer Vladimir Vysotsky. ''Ray's little black book would be the best entry to contemporary Soviet culture,'' a Western European diplomat said. **********''He knew everybody,'' one of his American colleagues said. ''If there was a rumor of anything happening in the cultural world here, he could find out about it instantly.'' **********Mr. Benson is not the only senior diplomat who is leaving. Four of the top nine officers, including Richard Combs Jr., the charge d'affaires, and Adm. Ronald Kurth, the military attache, ended their tours this summer. Ambassador Jack F. Matlock Jr. and seven other top officers are new within the last year. This summer's turnover rate for the embassy over all is about 70 percent. **********For many of those leaving, the last two years were a professional and personal maelstrom, their duties defined by summitry and spy scandals, their family lives sprinkled with worries about spy dust, microwaves and Chernobyl. **********Like some of the others who have left, Mr. Benson told friends he felt a bit battered and disillusioned by the last year of turmoil. Just as the professional staff was recovering from its months-long trial of taking over the housekeeping chores after the withdrawal of the Russian staff last October, a furor erupted over breaches of embassy security. Many embassy officials complained that they were being made scapegoats for security agreements made years before. **********Mr. Benson made little reference to the demoralizing one-two punch of the last year, but showed a brusque pride in the way he and his colleagues had come through that period. **********''Imagine telling the bank officers in the Chase Manhattan building that from one day to the next they'll have no help keeping their building clean, that they'll have no drivers or runners, that the servants at their homes are gone, that they'll have nothing except water, light and central heating,'' he said. **********''Imagine telling them that one day and having them open for business the next,'' he said. ''That's what happened to us. That's what we did.'' **********Mr. Benson first saw the Soviet Union as a 5-year-old returning from the United States with his Russian-born parents in 1932. After a year, his parents separated, and his mother took him back to the United States. He returned here 42 years later. **********Mr. Benson has been well positioned to judge what Mikhail S. Gorbachev's policies mean for freedom of expression in the Soviet Union. **********''Lots of things have happened here that are more optical than real, more audible than substantive,'' Mr. Benson said of the recent changes in the Soviet Union. ''But some things are substantive. For 70 years, they were running along on an ideology that would, they said, effect change. To admit that this is not so is a staggering task.'' **********After his retirement, Mr. Benson will become a visiting professor at Middlebury College, heading an effort by a consortium of colleges to build a new Soviet-American student-exchange program.

He said American financial institutions were at a disadvantage in global markets because of an archaic regulatory system that too strictly limits their activities. But the Fed official argued against allowing commercial companies to enter banking. https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/23/world.print_headline: Pretoria to Stay in Atom Agency
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/23/world.body_text: **********Energy Secretary John Herrington of the United States said today that South Africa would remain in the International Atomic Energy Agency after Pretoria showed willingness to sign a treaty intended to curb the spread of nuclear weapons. **********Mr. Herrington said the American and Soviet delegations to the agency's general meeting here had ''reached common ground on the South Africa issue.'' A Nigerian-led effort to expel the Pretoria Government will now lack the support of the Soviet-bloc nations and enough votes, he said. **********President P. W. Botha of South Africa said Monday in Cape Town that his Government might soon sign the 1968 Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty. **********The United States and other Western nations opposed the expulsion move, saying it focused more on Pretoria's apartheid policies than on its nuclear policies. South Africa has not allowed inspections of its uranium enrichment plant and main nuclear research facility. **********Mr. Herrington met with Andronik Petrosyants, head of the Soviet delegation. The delegation agreed with the American view that ''it is better to have South Africa in the organization than out,'' said a person close to the United States delegation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/26/busin.body_text: **********RECENT headlines about the book industry have been telling tales of consolidations and mergers. But, quietly all across the land, small publishers have been springing up. Book publishing, after all, is easy to enter. All it takes is a title or two. But it is one thing to publish a book, another to get it into bookstores and into the hands of readers. **********Book distribution has always been a complex, competitive business. Now it seems to be growing more so. In 1985, almost 51,000 books were published in the United States, according to the R.R. Bowker Company, yet the typical chain and independent bookstores carry no more than 20,000 titles a year. **********The industry's mergers and consolidations have resulted in cutbacks in the number of sales representatives employed by publishers to canvas booksellers around the country. But those losses have been partly offset by a growing number of independent distributors who have set up shop to distribute the books of small publishers. **********Books pose distribution problems of a unique sort. Because each book is different, no two can be marketed alike and distributors must be able to discuss a range of titles. And books are ordered - or passed up - on the basis of whim, jacket design, pressure from salesmen or any number of other subjective criteria. **********Moreover, they are one of the few products returnable for full credit, much to the despair of the many publishers who would like to end that time-honored practice. **********Harcourt Brace Jovanovich tried to change it in 1981. It instituted a no-returns policy and tried to soften that blow by raising the discount it offered on the wholesale prices of its books. But it could not hold out for long: Wholesalers bought fewer of its titles, arguing that even the increased discount was not enough to offset the risk of buying on a no-return basis. Flawed as the existing system may be, industry officials say that booksellers will not take a chance on unknown authors or experimental novels unless they can return those books if they don't sell. **********To be sure, getting a book into the hands of a potential buyer has been a problem at least since the 1780's, when ''Parson Weems,'' decked out in his clerical coat, sold books door-to-door, traveling up and down the East Coast - while somehow finding the time to preach, play the fiddle and churn out his own fanciful biographies of George Washington, Ben Franklin and William Penn. **********But, with more books and publishers than ever before, the distribution problem is clearly growing.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/24/busin.body_text: **********The nation's economic growth accelerated in recent months and inflation subsided, the Government said in two encouraging reports today. **********The latest figures on the gross national product and consumer prices were significantly better than most analysts had expected. The data showed, among other things, that the economy strengthened in late summer, making it better able to survive any shock stemming from this week's stock market plunge. **********Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, called the data ''very good news,'' and added that ''growth was strong, inflation restrained.'' Most private analysts tended to agree, although the figures seemed to have little effect on the jittery financial markets. Heavy Spending Reflected **********According to the Commerce Department, the nation's gross national product, the total output of goods and services, expanded at a 3.8 percent annual rate in the July-September period. The gain, which reflected heavy consumer spending for cars and other durable goods, came after a 2.5 percent rate of G.N.P. growth in the April-June quarter and 4.4 percent in the first three months of the year. **********Meanwhile, the Consumer Price Index edged up by two-tenths of 1 percent in September, matching July for the lowest rise so far this year, the Labor Department reported. In August, the Consumer Price Index for All Urban Consumers rose five-tenths of 1 percent, feeding the fears of some analysts that inflation was heading again into worrisome territory. **********However, inflation fears heightened in the New York-northeastern New Jersey area, where the highest monthly price rise for women's and girls' apparel in 35 years helped to push costs up by eight-tenths of 1 percent.  [ Page 55. ]  #4.2 Percent Rise in Benefits Today's national price report also meant that 38 million Social Security recipients and other Federal beneficiaries would receive a 4.2 percent increase in benefits for 1988. This was the amount by which the Consumer Price Index for Urban Wage Earners and Clerical Workers climbed between the third quarter of 1986 and the third quarter of this year. **********Taken together, today's sets of figures were a source of considerable cheer to economists despite a setback in the balance of international trade, a further surge in the price of imported goods and a still-depressed national savings rate. **********''Over all, I think these were generally positive numbers,'' said Maria F. Ramirez, an economist at Drexel Burnham Lambert. She called the growth ''robust,'' noting that it was accompanied by such modest inflation that there was no longer any chance that the Federal Reserve would need to tighten monetary policy in the near future. **********At the Commerce Department, Robert Ortner, Under Secretary for Economic Affairs, suggested that Monday's stock market collapse, which he attributed mainly to ''market psychology and computerized trading,'' would probably have only a ''minor'' effect on the economy. **********''It may have some effect on consumer spending and/or on business investment,'' Mr. Ortner said in a prepared statement. ''But the size of the impact depends on how strong the economy is otherwise. If the economy were already weakening, the impact might be large, but in a strengthening economy the effect probably will be small.'' **********He also noted that, while the stock market was a fairly reliable predictor of the course of the economy, it had flashed a clear warning of only four of the eight postwar recessions and that, in 1962, 1966 and 1977, major drops in the market were not followed by recessions. **********Other economists, however, suggested that the plunge in stocks could cut economic growth by up to two percentage points over the next year. With the pick-up in activity this summer, the economy needs only to rise at a 2.1 percent annual rate in the current quarter to reach the Reagan Administration's target of 3.2 percent growth for the year. Food Offset by Energy **********The price report for September showed that a rise of five-tenths of 1 percent in the price of food - a fluctuation that once again stemmed mainly from the cost of fruit and vegetables - was largely offset by a downturn in energy prices and a smaller increase for shelter. **********''At least in the short run, this should cool people's fears of inflation,'' said Patrick C. Jackman, a senior Labor Department price official, of today's report. He predicted that, unless there was some special shock, such as a disruption of Middle East oil supplies, consumer inflation would be in the 4.5-to-5-percent range for this year, up from 1.1 percent last year and from an average of 3.9 percent for 1982 through 1985. **********The energy index, which had jumped 1.7 percent in August, fell five-tenths of 1 percent last month with fuel oil, natural gas, electricity and gasoline all showing declines, the Labor Department said. **********A sharp nine-tenths of 1 percent decline in the lightly weighted ''other goods and services'' category also helped minimize the price index's overall rise of five-tenths of a point. A major factor in the category's decline was a seasonally adjusted drop in tuitions, school fees, books and supplies. Before adjustment, however, tuition rose 5 percent. Housing Cost Unchanged **********The cost of housing, which accounts for 43 percent of the price index, was unchanged last month after a rise of six-tenths of 1 percent in August. Charges fell for out-of-town lodging and fuels and other utilities, including local and intrastate telephone service. **********Transportation costs, easing somewhat because of a sharp downward swing in motor fuels, rose two-tenths of 1 percent, after a seven-tenths increase in August. September's decline in gasoline, though small, was the first this year; prices jumped 21.4 percent in the eight months through August. **********The price of used cars also fell for the first time this year, but prices of new cars rose by the same one-tenth of 1 percent average that has prevailed so far in 1987. **********The index for apparel and upkeep rose 1.1 percent last month, reflecting the introduction of fall and winter merchandise. Medical care and entertainment costs both rose five-tenths of 1 percent. Few Big Food Increases **********Grocery store food prices climbed six-tenths of 1 percent after falling in July and August but, apart from fruit and vegetables, there were few big increases. A prominent exception was milk, which jumped 1.9 percent, the biggest increase since May 1980. **********Viewed another way, the price index report showed that commodities rose three-tenths of 1 percent last month while service inflation fell to zero from six-tenths in August. **********Before rounding, the price index's increase last month was 0.1751313, a level that, if maintained and compounded for 12 months, would produce an annual inflation rate of 2.1 percent. **********Before seasonal adjustment, the price index rose five-tenths of 1 percent, three-tenths higher than the widely cited adjusted figure. Mr. Jackman said he could not find in his records any previous month in which the difference has been so great. **********The price index for urban consumers now stands at 344.4, which means that a basket of goods and services that cost $10 in 1967 now costs $34.44. Hefty Rise in Final Sales **********Consumer spending played an important role in the $35.9 billion, or 3.8 percent, rate of increase in the third-quarter G.N.P., which included a hefty 6.2 percent advance in final sales while investment in inventories fell. This, said Mr. Ortner, was ''a combination that usually augurs well for activity in the coming quarters.'' **********New-car sales were the main reason for the sharp rise in consumer spending, but Mr. Ortner acknowledged that the 19.9 percent rate of increase for such sales was too torrid to be maintained. **********The slowdown in inventory investment mostly reflected a drop in new-car production. Lower automobile assemblies help cut dealers' inventories but trimmed about one-half point from G.N.P. growth. **********Growth in capital spending was also sizable, but residential investment slipped as higher interest rates cut into housing starts, today's report showed. Net Exports Down **********Real exports swelled to a rate of $430.6 billion, from $414.5 billion, but imports rose somewhat more. As a result, net exports of goods and services fell $5.2 billion further into the red, to a rate of $137.9 billion. **********However, it was a big jump in imports of oil, by $19.3 billion in the quarter, that more than accounted for the deterioration. Excluding oil, the real merchandise trade balance continued a strong improvement, Mr. Ortner said. The trade sector is increasingly counted on to drive the nation's economic expansion, taking over from the American consumer. **********Today's report also showed that the nation's savings rate - savings as a percentage of disposable income -remained at the second-quarter level of 3 percent. **********Inflation fell as gauged by two G.N.P.-related measures, as well as by the price index. The G.N.P. fixed-weighted price index climbed at a 2.7 percent rate in the third quarter, down from 4.1 percent in the spring. The ''implicit price deflator'' eased to a 2.4 percent rate in the September quarter from 3.5 percent in the preceding three months.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/27/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Bonds Regain Part of Losses
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/27/busin.body_text: **********Treasury note and bond prices yesterday recovered some of their losses of earlier in the week, as the Government completed a three-part, $25 billion note financing. **********Securities dealers said that demand yesterday for two-year and four-year Treasury notes sold earlier in the week was good enough to benefit yesterday's $7.25 billion auction of seven-year notes. The new 7 percent issue due in 1994 sold with an average yield of 7.04 percent, and was offered late in the day at about 7.03 percent. **********The modest rise of about one-quarter point in Treasury bond prices lent a good tone to the corporate and tax-exempt markets, where prices rose slightly. Corporate debt financings included at least five new issues totaling more than $600 million. 'A Lot of Money Around' **********''The seven-year auction had no bearing on any new bullish or bearish attitude in the market,'' said Daniel T. Napoli, president of Merrill Lynch Government Securities Inc. He said that trading activity in the Treasury market remained light, ''but the simple fact is that there is just a lot of money around.'' **********Charles F. Wills, director of fixed-income research at the Provident National Bank in Philadelphia, said that the recent pattern of modest, sustained economic growth does not point to any significant changes in interest rates. ''The big moves in rates are behind us'' he said, ''and good performance now will depend on technical analysis, things like credit analysis and reading indentures to select high-coupon bonds not likely to be refunded.'' **********Although several securities dealers said foreign demand for the seven-year notes was meager, they noted that Treasury bond prices benefited as the dollar stabilized against the yen. A few traders noted there were rumors that the Japanese Ministry of Finance had asked major Japanese trading firms to stop speculative selling of the dollar. **********Mr. Napoli said that ''there seems to be general agreement that the dollar will weaken,'' a perception that causes many foreign investors to concentrate on debt issues in currencies that are expected to appreciate or that offer higher yields than Treasury issues. ''But once there is some semblance of stability, we could see a rush back into the dollar'' and some greater overseas demand for Treasury issues, he said. Prediction by Baker **********According to some analysts, doubts about the dollar's stability may persist until there is more evidence -not just predictions - that the American trade deficit is contracting. Economists are now awaiting the April 14 release of the Commerce Department's February trade data. Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d recently predicted in a television interview that the American trade deficit would contract by $15 billion to $20 billion this year. **********By the time trading stopped in New York yesterday, the Treasury's closely watched 7 1/2 percent bonds due in 2016 were offered at 99 14/32, to yield 7.55 percent. The bellwether long-term bond was offered at 99 26/ 32 last Friday, and its yield remains well within the range of 7.42 percent to 7.61 percent that has prevailed since Feb. 11. **********Among new issues, the two-year and four-year offerings were trading with higher prices and lower yields than the averages set at their auctions earlier this week. The 6 3/8 percent issue due in 1989 was offered to yield 6.39 percent, down from 6.43 percent at auction Tuesday, while the 6 3/4 percent issue due in 1991 was at 6.72 percent, down from 6.79 percent Wednesday. Money Supply Rises **********Prices of debt issues were little changed after the Federal Reserve announced a $1.2 billion rise in the M-1 money supply measure, to $740.2 billion, in the week ended March 16. Although M-1 growth has been a robust 16.7 percent during the last year, it declined in February and has expanded more slowly in March. The M-2 money supply measure, which is more closely watched by Fed officials, also fell last month and is expected to show slow growth in March when complete monthly data is published April 16. **********Other Fed data showed that financial institutions borrowed an average of $432 million at the Fed discount window in the two-week reserve accounting period ended March 25, after excluding extended loans to troubled institutions. Borrowings were up from $383 million in the previous two weeks, but the increase was not large enough to suggest any change in monetary policy, analysts said. **********Following are the results of yesterday's auction of seven-year notes:  (000 omitted in dollar figures)       $   Average Price   99.772     Average Yield   7.04%     Low Price   99.772     High Yield   7.04%     High Price   99.881     Low Yield   7.02%     Accepted at low price   62%     Total applied for$26,944,383     Accepted   $7,325,769     N.Y. applied for   $24,553,778     N.Y. accepted   $6,553,778     Noncompetitive   $248,000     Interest set at   7%          The 7-year notes mature April 15, 1994.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/15/busin.main_headline: Sales of U.S.-Built Cars Fall 15 Percent in Period
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/15/busin.print_headline: Sales of U.S.-Built Cars Fall 15 Percent in Period
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/15/busin.body_text: **********Sales of new American-made cars fell 15 percent, to 193,139 units, in the first 10 days of April, the eight manufacturers reported today. Sales of light trucks rose 1.5 percent, to 97,687, partly offsetting the decline for automobiles. **********Over all, light-vehicle sales totaled 290,826, a decline of 10.1 percent from the 323,545 sold a year ago. There were nine selling days in the 1987 period, as there were a year ago. **********After seasonal adjustments, the annual sales rate for autos was 7 million, down from 8 million in the 1986 period and 7.5 million in the final selling period of March. Weaker Than Projections **********Analysts said the decline, after an apparent improvement at the end of March, seemed to signal that consumer demand for cars and light trucks was fundamentally weaker than the companies had forecast. The question, the analysts said, was whether the weakness was only temporary or a signal of a longer-term decline in demand for high-priced durable goods. **********''I'm beginning to think we are looking at some fundamental weakness in the market,'' said Edward J. Sullivan of Chase Econometrics. ''The effect of the new tax law was gone by March, and we should have seen stronger sales.'' **********But Susan G. Jacobs of Merrill Lynch Economics said she expected the sales lull to be temporary. ''I think the current sales pace reflects a hesitancy on the part of consumers as they adjust to the new tax law,'' she said. She added that she expected improved sales by late spring, with an annual sales rate of 7.5 million to 8 million cars a year. **********The General Motors Corporation suffered the biggest drop, as it has most of this year. G.M.'s sales of 98,792 domestic cars represented a 24 percent decline from a year ago. **********The Chrysler Corporation's car sales were down 12 percent, to 26,901 units, while the Ford Motor Company reported only a 2.5 percent decline, to 57,503. The American Motors Corporation sold 715 cars, a drop of 55 percent, while Volkswagen of America's sales were off 41 percent, to 1,100. **********Sales for Honda of America increased 58 percent, to 4,793, because of higher production at its Marysville, Ohio, plant. The Nissan Motor Company, which makes cars in Smyrna, Tenn., reported a gain of 45 percent, to 2,637. The Toyota Motor Corporation, which began making cars late last year in the United States, sold 698 in the early-April period. Truck Gains for Ford, Chrysler **********G.M.'s light-truck sales declined 11.6 percent, to 37,552, but both Ford and Chrysler reported strong gains in the period. Ford sold 38,647 vehicles, an increase of 11.3 percent, for a light-truck total that surpassed G.M.'s. Chrysler gained 17 percent, with 15,723 sales. **********For the year through April 10, 1,259,807 cars have been sold, a drop of 12.5 percent from the 1986 level. But light-truck sales of 946,760 represent an increase of 3 percent from last year's level and are an indication of the continuing shift by consumers from cars to such vehicles as mini-vans, which are classified as trucks. **********G.M.'s sales may improve as its new Chevrolet Corsica and Beretta models and a new full-size pickup move into the market. But for the year to date, its market share has declined to 51 percent, from 57.1 percent in the 1986 period. **********Ford's market share has grown to 28 percent, from 24.6 percent, and Chrysler's is up to 13.7 percent, from 13.2 percent. A.M.C.'s share has fallen to four-tenths of 1 percent, from 1.0 percent, and Volkswagen's declined to sic-tenths of 1 percent, from nine-tenths of 1 percent. **********Honda, however, has gained a 4.3 percent share, compared with 2.2 percent in the 1986 period. Nissan was up to 1.4 percent, from 1.0 percent, and Toyota has captured four-tenths of 1 percent of the domestic car market.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/16/busin.main_headline: STATE'S MERGER LAW SAID TO HURT STOCKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/16/busin.print_headline: STATE'S MERGER LAW SAID TO HURT STOCKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/16/busin.body_text: **********A 1985 New York State law that restricted hostile takeovers of companies based in the state initially cost shareholders at least $1.2 billion in the value of the stock they owned, a study by the Federal Government concludes. **********The study, conducted by a staff economist at the Federal Trade Commission, found that the stock of 94 publicly traded companies based in New York fell by 1 percent, or a total market value of $1.2 billion, in the days following the announcement in October 1985 by Governor Cuomo of his bill that would make hostile takeovers both more difficult to complete and more expensive. The decline occurred during a rise in the overall market. **********Officials of the trade commission acknowledged that the study did not analyze the long-term price effects of the legislation that was passed into law, but rather measured the short-term reaction of investors to the proposed restrictions on takeovers. 'Significant' Decline Cited **********The announcement of the Cuomo bill ''resulted in a highly significant'' statistical decline in the market value of the companies, said Laurence Schumann, the author of the study. ''Clearly, the bill was viewed by the market as harmful to shareholders.'' **********The study comes at a time when sentiment is rising in Congress to curb hostile takeovers on a national level, rather than just state by state. The insider trading scandal has uncovered abuses on Wall Street of the takeover process, prompting several Senate and House committees to consider legislation that would make hostile takeovers more difficult to complete. **********So far, the Reagan Administration has supported few changes in the existing takeover laws. In fact, the trade commission's study buttresses the preference by the Reagan Administration for less regulated markets, and further deregulation. Chairman's View **********''This study supports what I've been saying all along,'' said Daniel Oliver, chairman of the F.T.C., ''that Government intervention with the free market is the principal source of restriction on competition.'' **********In its study, the commission says that other research into hostile takeovers had shown that Federal and state restrictions - more than 35 states have restrictive takeover statutes - increase the price that raiders must pay for target companies. These studies have often been used as a theoretical basis for states imposing such restrictions, and a rationale for arguing that such measures help, rather than hurt, the shareholder. **********But Mr. Schumann argues that studying only successful takeovers fails to measure the impact of restrictive regulation on the broad spectrum of shareholders in companies that could become takeover targets. He adds that the market's reaction on all takeover targets to any possible legislation is a more accurate reflection of whether takeover curbs are advantageous or disadvantageous to shareholders. **********As such, the commission's study focused on all of the 94 publicly traded companies that fall under the jurisdiction of the 1985 New York State law - companies incorporated in New York that also maintain their principal executive offices in the state. That list included such major corporations as the International Business Machines Corporation, Macy's, Mobil, CBS, Corning Glass, International Paper, McGraw-Hill and Grumman. **********Both the effects of the bill and its constitutionality have yet to be proved, said Arthur Fleischer, a takeover attorney with Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson, ''because I don't think any major New York firm has become the object of a hostile takeover yet.'' #2 Key Curbs in Bill The Cuomo bill, passed by the State Legislature on Dec. 10, 1985, has two primary restrictions. It prohibits anyone who is buying 20 percent or more of a company's stock from ''engaging in any business combination'' with the company for five years, unless approved by the board of directors before the purchase. The bill also requires that in any takeover, all stockholders receive the same price for their shares. **********The Cuomo bill was in fact the second takeover proposal passed by the Legislature in 1985. Earlier that year, the Governor had vetoed a more restrictive bill on constitutional grounds. **********In its study, the F.T.C. noted that after the veto of the first bill on Aug. 13, the stocks of the 94 affected companies rose significantly, confirming that ''the bill was viewed by the market as harming shareholders, and was not in their best interest,'' Mr. Schumann said. **********The F.T.C. concluded that rather than protecting shareholders, the Cuomo bill tends to insulate incumbent managements and favors ''managers at the expense of shareholders.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/12/busin.print_headline: THE EXECUTIVE COMPUTER; When You Write by Committee
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/12/busin.body_text: **********Early in my writing career, I was approached by a film producer to convert Hemingway's ''Hills like White Elephants'' into a television script. Being neither a dyed-in-the-beard Hemingway fan nor an the answer toi the questu iiooonnnnthe advocate of television in its current guise as an entertainment medium, I reluctantly decided to part with a microportion of my soul in return for what promised to be sufficient remuneration to pay the rent for the better part of a year and then some. **********Accordingly, I wrote the script, making such adjustments to accommodate the production budget as switching the setting of the story from a train station in Spain to a Greyhound station in Arizona, where another story segment of the good program was to be shot. Then the gentleman in charge of production spent an evening in our apartment ''fine-tuning'' the results of my labors. **********I had the good sense to leave the dialogue intact, since it was written by Hemingway. The producer, however, felt it needed ''contemporization.'' His imaginative rewriting continued well past breakfast the following morning. By the end of all this, the short script, altered and revised completely a number of times, had returned to very nearly the exact state in which I had submitted it. Satisfied that it was now ready to be viewed and commented upon by the 32 other people involved in the effort, the gentleman left, manuscript in hand. **********I swore I would never again write by committee. **********This experience flashed through my mind as I opened a software package called For Comment ($195 for the IBM PC and compatibles from Broderbund Software, Inc., San Rafael, Calif. 94903, tel. 415-479-1170). For $995 one can buy the network version of the program, which will accommodate the output of as many as 16 separate authors. The number of reviewers that can be likewise accommodated is not limited by either package, although in both versions the comments of no more than 16 people can be collated with any given document. **********Billed as ''the first review processor,'' For Comment claims to be designed for the legal and teaching professions and those involved in corporate communications, the development of policy statements or any other matters requiring revisions, suggestions and comments by numerous people. My first reaction on hearing this news was that the program must be some kind of sentence-oriented Scrabble. Broderbund is, after all, a game company. It is best known for such digitized thrillers as Blade Runner and such computerized hobby kits as Print Shop, an electronic version of the old rubber-stamp type sets. But no, For Comment is a serious business program, albeit one designed for a specialized niche. **********The software consists of two separate programs packaged together. One program is for authors, the other for reviewers. The major difference between the two is that documents can be originated only through the authors' version. Once a manuscript such as a position paper has been composed, it can then be circulated among a number of reviewers for comment, in one of two ways. **********In offices where personal computers are linked by a local area network, or LAN, reviewers can access a For Comment document they are to study directly. The software supports six different networks, including the IBM PC Network, Novelle's Advanced NetWare and 3 Com's Ether Series. **********Where no network exists, the document is circulated among the reviewers by way of a ''floppynet,'' where a disk containing the document file and a separate floppy containing the reviewers' version of For Comment are passed around. The reason for the two disks is that the reviewers' portion of For Comment takes up 250K of disk space. A document with space-hogging review comments usually cannot be squeezed onto the same disk that the program occupies. Included with the program is an electronic routing screen on which reviewers can each enter a tick indicating that they have worked on the file. **********A WORD processor is needed for a writer to create a document for review. For Comment accepts entries directly from a score of popular word processing programs, including MultiMate, New Word, Nota Bene, Volkswriter 3, WordStar 2000 and WordPerfect, as well as entries presented in ASCII. Thus, an office whose word processing has not been standardized should encounter no major problems utilizing For Comment. However, when a transfer is made through ASCII, as is necessary in importing material from XYWrite, Leading Edge Word Processor and Microsoft Word, formatting will not be transferred along with the text. **********In whatever form the text is entered, once it is on disk, the electronic routing sheet can be made up. More than simply a directive to those who are to comment on the manuscript, the routing screen is a safekeeping device permitting three levels of security. Under the highest security, comments or revisions cannot be changed, even by the reviewer who made the notation. Only the original author of the document is free to discard suggestions or alterations. The provisions of the other two security levels are less stringent. **********Also available is a password security system, possibly a necessity in some LAN-equipped offices. Unfortunately, this system is based on simple five-character strings, and anyone reasonably familiar with computers and determined enough to pry could probably crack its code in relatively short order. **********For that matter, those who suppose any of the current crop of file encryption programs offer meaningful security beyond the level of ordinary office snooping should find the article ''A Survey of Data Insecurity Packages'' in the January 1987 issue of Cryptologia (published by the Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology, Terre Haute, Ind. 47803, tel. 812-877-1511) revealing. **********Once over the password hurdle, legally or otherwise, a reviewer working on a For Comment manuscript marks the document at the point where a note is to apply and enters his or her commentary, which can be up to 60 lines long, in a window that materializes on the lower half of the screen. A second reviewer remarking on the same point enters the further comment in the same place. This second remark appears in the window slightly indented from the first and delineated by a differently colored border. The date, but not the time, and the initials of the reviewer are appended to each comment made. **********The multiple windows utilized by For Comment limit the display of the document to a mere 10 lines whenever notes are inserted. From a visual viewpoint, this approach can make it difficult for a reader to maintain continuity while reviewing the text. Certainly the program is simple enough to learn and use. But employing such an electronic time-shift bull session without exercising considerable care and restraint could easily lead to a great deal of wasted time in producing a corporate communications version of the proverbial elephant designed by committee.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/08/world.body_text: **********A Moslem militia representative said today that Terry Waite, the kidnapped British church envoy, was apparently seen by a freed South Korean diplomat while the diplomat was a hostage in Lebanon. **********The militia representative said the diplomat, Do Chae Sung, who was released Oct. 27, had reported seeing a foreign captive who fit Mr. Waite's description. **********The militiaman said Mr. Do had described the hostage as a very tall, bearded man with his hair combed backward. The man was wearing a thick ring. **********''Do saw Waite,'' said the militia member, who has been a reliable source in the past. ''Do's description of the third captive applies to Waite more than any of the other hostages. None of the others is that tall and Waite wears a ring like that.'' **********British Embassy officials declined to comment. **********Mr. Waite, an envoy for the Archbishop of Canterbury, the Most Rev. Robert Runcie, vanished on Jan. 20 after going to Moslem West Beirut to meet the kidnappers of two Americans - Terry A. Anderson, The Associated Press bureau chief in Beirut, and Thomas M. Sutherland, the dean of agriculture at American University. **********In addition to seeing a captive resembling Mr. Waite, the militiaman said, the diplomat saw two other hostages - Roger Auque, a French photographer, and Rudolf Cordes, a West German businessman. **********The militiaman said that Mr. Do had communicated with Mr. Cordes and Mr. Auque, but that he got no response when he tried to talk to the man believed to be Mr. Waite.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/08/busin.print_headline: CONSUMER RATES; Yields Rise On Funds
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/08/busin.body_text: **********Yields on money market mutual funds were higher for the week ended yesterday, as they continued to reflect the steep increase in the Fed funds rate during the final weeks of 1986. Yields offered by banks and thrift institutions on certificates of deposit and money market accounts remained about the same in the week. **********Interest rates, which fell sharply in 1986, are expected to remain stable or move lower in 1987, according to analysts at the Mellon Bank. Yield declines last year cost depositors from 1.38 percentage points on a bank money market account to almost two percentage points on a five-year certificate of deposit. **********Cyrus J. Lawrence Inc., a Wall Street firm, believes that rates will decline in early 1987 as a result of the new tax law and its effect on loan demand. If loan demand declines, interest rates will fall. **********At the Treasury's weekly auction, the average discount rate for a three-month bill fell 15 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 5.53 percent, from 5.68 percent in the previous auction. Six-month bills declined by as much as 13 basis points, to 5.55 percent. C.D. Yields **********According to The Bank Rate Monitor's national index, the average yield for a six-month C.D. fell one basis point, to 5.91 percent, and the average yield of a bank money market account, which competes with money market mutual funds, was unchanged for the second consecutive week, at 5.44 percent. **********For certificates of deposit with longer maturities, yields on a one-year and two-and-half-year certificate of deposit declined one basis point, to 6.16 percent and 6.60 percent, respectively. The average yield for a five-year certificate was unchanged, at 7.15 percent. **********In the funds market this week, Donoghue's Money Fund Report said the seven-day taxable, compounded average yield for money-market mutual funds increased by three-quarters of a percentage point, to 6.38 percent, while the 30-day compounded average yield rose a little more than one-quarter of a percentage point, to 5.75 percent. **********The average maturity of securities held by the money market funds fell to 46 days from 48 days as portfolio managers shortened maturities to take advantage of the competitive rates available.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/10/world.main_headline: Iraq Declines to Accept Full Cease-Fire
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/10/world.print_headline: Iraq Declines to Accept Full Cease-Fire
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/10/world.body_text: **********Iraq has declined to accept a full cease-fire as demanded by the Security Council while Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar is in the Persian Gulf region on a peace mission, senior United Nations officials said today. **********Instead, President Saddam Hussein has promised only that the Iraqi Air Force will not attack Teheran while Mr. Perez de Cuellar is there. **********United Nations officials said they were disheartened by the sudden intensification of Iraqi attacks against Iranian tankers and other oil targets just as preparations for the Secretary General's peace mission were being completed this week. Plan Approved in July **********The Secretary General is to leave Thursday on a trip to Iran and Iraq to promote the Security Council plan, approved in July, to end the seven-year-old war between the two countries. **********The plan provides for an immediate end to hostilities, the return of forces behind recognized frontiers, an exchange of prisoners and the creation of a commission to attribute responsibility for the war. **********Iraq has said it will abide by the Security Council plan if Iran does. Iran has still not said clearly whether it will cooperate, but United Nations officials said the Secretary General was confident that Teheran would not flatly reject the call for a cease-fire. **********Mr. Perez de Cuellar will fly to Paris on Thursday, then proceed Friday to Teheran, where he will hold talks Saturday and Sunday. He plans to visit Baghdad on Monday and Tuesday. Proceeding Optimistically **********Since the Secretary General was originally invited to Teheran by the Iranian Foreign Minister, he assumes the Iranian authorities are at least ready to accept enough of the United Nations plan to insure that his trip does not appear a failure, aides say. **********The Secretary General was also said to believe that the Western naval presence in the gulf is helping the peace process by increasing Iran's sense of diplomatic isolation and putting pressure on the leadership there to accept the Security Council plan. **********In his annual report on the work of the United Nations released today, the Secretary General suggests that the international climate now favors sucessful mediation in the Persian Gulf, noting that countries are displaying ''a new pragmatism'' in dealing with their problems and showing ''a broadened appreciation that present regional conflicts entail unacceptable risks.'' **********Three of Iran's most powerful political figures - President Hojatolislam Ali Khamenei; the Speaker of Parliament, Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani, and the Foreign Minister, Ali Akba Velayati - have refused a request from the Secretary General to meet jointly with him, apparently because they do not agree on the Security Council plan, officials here said. Delaying Tactics Possible **********Those close to the Secretary General said he had acknowledged that Iran's divided leadership may try to play for time during his talks in Teheran, stretching out negotiations on various aspects of the peace plan and avoiding a clear commitment to end the war. **********As a result, the Secretary General plans to set tight time limits for the work of the various commissions that will be set up to oversee implementation of the United Nations plan, requiring them to complete their missions quickly. **********If he fails to make significant progress on his trip, the United States plans to go ahead in seeking a second Security Council resolution imposing an arms embargo on Iran. **********The Soviet Union, China and several of the developing countries on the Council are reluctant to adopt such sanctions, but United Nations aides say they believe the Council will do so if Iran and Iraq fail to abide by the cease-fire call. **********Although he does not want to turn the trip into an exercise in shuttle diplomacy between Teheran and Baghdad, Mr. Perez de Cuellar is also prepared to stay on for some days in the region if needed. **********With President Khamenei coming to the General Assembly later this month, the Secretary General would not probably need to stay very long since he can continue discussions with him then.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/02/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********Claudia Deutsch's ''Rubbermaid's Sad Succession Tale'' (July 5) contained so many diverse views and classic generalizations that it might help to review other possibilities:  A Sad Succession Tale?  Succession tales have board rooms sometimes had  Are often funny, though some seem quite sad,  But if succession would contain ''success''  It is truth and not tales we must assess.  Plans that have proven that they have gone sour  Are with us every day - in every hour - But luckily our plottings do not cease  When some, as proven failures, rest in peace.  We can be too old, or can be too young  And that's a fear keeps us off the top rung,  In corporate life, where that rife belief  Can principally be advancement's thief.  For others' failures, we may have to wish,  In order to sup from success's dish,  As many mouths seek to, their bellies, fill  Without their paying up their dinner bill.  RICHARD SHEMTOB  Greenwich, Conn., July 6

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/10/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********Citing working full time as a way of reducing poverty would be a perfect tautology if our minimum wage hadn't fallen so low in recent years. And the employment effect Michael Novak attributes to completing high school and staying married is laughably reminiscent of pioneer days, when many Great Plains people believed that breaking the sod brought increased rainfall. If all the poor woke up married and with high school diplomas, does Mr. Novak really think that seven million new jobs would coalesce out of the ether?  SIM GUREWITZ  Lincoln, Neb., March 31

Cmdr. Albert Schaufelberger 3d of the Navy. **********Commander Schaufelberger, 33 years old, of San Diego, was shot dead in May 1983 while sitting in his car outside a university. **********The two suspects played a tape recording at the radio station claiming responsibility in the name of the People's Liberation Front, one of five guerrilla armies battling the United States-supported Government since 1979. No one has been charged in the killing. **********On Thursday, another military judge granted freedom to three guerrillas held in connection with the 1985 slaying of six Americans, including four Marine guards assigned to the United States Embassy. **********Since Nov. 6, nearly 500 political prisoners have been freed under a new amnesty program enacted to comply with the regional peace plan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/08/world.main_headline: NEW LEBANON ALLIES: CHRISTIANS AND THE P.L.O.
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/08/world.print_headline: NEW LEBANON ALLIES: CHRISTIANS AND THE P.L.O.
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/08/world.body_text: **********Lebanese politics has always been renowned for its upredictable shifting alliances, but the latest marriage of convenience in Beirut is perhaps the most startling of all: The Christian Phalangist militia in Lebanon has forged an alliance with Yasir Arafat and the Palestine Liberation Organization. **********The same Phalangist militiamen who teamed up with Israel in 1982 to drive Mr. Arafat's Palestinian guerrillas out of Lebanon and who later massacred Palestinians in the Sabra and Shatila refugee districts have in the last few months begun aiding the return of the Palestinian guerrillas to Beirut, Israeli military officials said. **********''We take this matter very seriously,'' said Uri Lubrani, the Israeli Defense Ministry Coordinator for Lebanon, in an interview today. **********''We do not think it is the doing of the entire Christian community,'' he said, ''but rather that of a few key players who cannot see beyond the tips of their noses. They have very short memories, and what they are doing is playing with fire. We have not minced our words in telling them this, and we will not remain idle.'' Basis of the Understanding **********There are two pillars to the Phalangist-Palestinian entente, Israeli military sources said. **********The first is money. The Phalangists need cash, and Mr. Arafat, having been thrown out of both Tunisia and Jordan, has no other alternative than to invest his money in buying his way back to an independent base of operation in Lebanon. **********But for the Phalangists, the arrangement is apparently not only good business but also good politics. One of the basic laws of Lebanese politics is that ''my enemy's enemy is my friend.'' **********According to Israeli officials, several key Phalangist leaders, most notably Samir Geagea and Karim Pakradouni, perceive that their main enemies in Lebanon today are the Shiite Moslems. The Shiites are the rising force in Lebanon and a long-term threat to the historical Maronite Christian hegemony of the legal Lebanese political structure. **********Israel twice sent naval patrol vessels last week to turn back Cypriot ferries sailing from Larnaca, Cyprus, to Junieh, a Phalangist-controlled port just north of Beirut. Israeli officials said they suspected the ferries were being used by the Phalangists to take Palestinian guerrillas into Lebanon. **********Moreover, several Israeli experts on Lebanon are advising the Defense Ministry to consider temporarily blockading the Junieh port, or even severing Israel's longstanding ties with the Maronite Christians, in hope of creating better relations with the Lebanese Shiites. **********''Everyone knows how to switch sides in Lebanon but Israel,'' said Yosef Olmert, a Lebanon expert at Tel Aviv University. ''The Syrians went from supporting the Christians to the P.L.O. and back to the Christians. The Maronites were with the Syrians, then against them, then for them. Amal was with the P.L.O., now it's against it. Even the Hezbollah militia moves around. Only Israel does not understand the rules of the game.'' 'We Are Being Used' **********''Israel is always worried about undermining the Christians,'' Mr. Olmert went on, ''because they could be helpful in the future, particularly against the Syrians. The fact is, we are being taken for granted. We are being used. We have got to demonstrate to the Phalangists what we can do to them.'' **********The Phalangists have been cooperating with Mr. Arafat's guerrillas in several fields. According to Israeli military officials, the Phalangists, apparently with the support of the Lebanese President, Amin Gemayel, a Christian, have been selling Lebanese identity papers and passports to Palestinians to help get them through roadblocks. **********Millions of dollars have changed hands, according to Israeli officials. **********The Phalangists have also been providing the Palestinian guerrillas, along with weapons, a route into Lebanon from Cyprus via the port at Junieh. The P.L.O. cannot use the regular Beirut harbor and the airport because they are controlled by anti-P.L.O. Shiite Moslems. Smuggled Across Green Line **********From Junieh, the Phalangists are reportedly smuggling P.L.O. fighters across the Green Line, which divides Christian East Beirut from the Moslem West. Once across the Green Line, the Palestinian guerrillas can then join up with thier compatriots in the West Beirut refugee districts and in southern Lebanon, where they are fighting daily battles with Shiite militias. **********Israeli officials say the number of Palestinian guerrillas involved in these transfers are in the hundreds. Their importance is that they are all pro-Arafat officers and organizers who can lead the Palestinian manpower already in the refugee districts. **********Since Israel uprooted Mr. Arafat's guerrillas in 1982, the Shiites and the Syrians have been trying to keep the Palestinians out of the country and to assert their own unrivaled authority in West Beirut and southern Lebanon instead. **********By strengthening the P.L.O. fighters in Lebanon, the Phalangists apparently believe they are prolonging the street fighting between the Palestinians and the Shiites and between the Palestinians and the Syrians, Israeli military officials said. **********Prof. Clinton Bailey, an expert on Lebanon at Tel Aviv University, said the Shiites, backed by the Syrians and other Lebanese Moslems, ''have been putting heavy pressure on the Phalagists to change the Constitution and give the Moslems of Lebanon a greater share of legal power.'' 'A Natural Counterbalance' **********''Arafat is a natural counterbalance to this pressure,'' Professor Bailey said. ''So long as the Shiites and Syrians are preoccupied fighting with the Palestinians, no one can really mount an effective challenge to the Christians' predominant position in the Lebanese structure.'' **********The Christians' relationship with the P.L.O. also gives the Phalangists some important bargaining chips for the future. Israeli officials say the Phalangists can now offer to ''sell out'' the Palestinians in return for concessions from the Shiites and the Syrians. **********Only Tuesday, President Gemayel sent a delegation to Damascus seeking a meeting with Syria's President, Hafez al-Assad, who has been putting pressure on Mr. Gemayel to agree to constitutional changes that would grant more power to the Moslems. **********Professor Bailey said: ''I can now imagine Gemayel saying to Assad: 'Look, I have these new friends, the Palestinians. I can now hold out a lot longer than you think. Maybe you should meet me halfway.' '' **********Although the return of Palestinian guerrillas to southern Lebanon may not be perceived as an immediate threat by some of the Phalangists, for Israel it is. **********Today, the Palestinian guerrillas returing to southern Lebanon may be fighting the Shiites, Israeli military officials say, but tomorrow, or in six months, after another shift in Lebanese alliances, they could be involved in action against Israel. **********''We have to take it seriously,'' said Zeev Schiff, the military editor of the daily Haaretz. ''Because if the P.L.O. is back in Lebanon, it means that sooner or later we will be back too.''
