https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/19/world.main_headline: Head of C.I.A. Said to Plan Replacing 2 High Officials
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/19/world.print_headline: Head of C.I.A. Said to Plan Replacing 2 High Officials
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/19/world.body_text: **********William Webster, the new Director of Central Intelligence, has decided to replace the head of the Central Intelligence Agency's clandestine service and one of his senior deputies, according to a Congressional official. **********The official said Mr. Webster has told leaders of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence that he plans to replace the two men, Clair George, the Deputy Director for Operations, and Duane C. Clarridge, one of his deputies, who heads a special counterterrorism unit. **********The Los Angeles Times, quoting Administration and Congressional officials, reported today that the two officials would take early retirement or be dismissed. **********But Mr. Webster told the Omaha World-Herald today that he had ''made no decisions, drawn no conclusions'' on personnel changes. **********The Nebraska paper, which interviewed Mr. Webster at a conference in Colorado Springs, quoted him in its Sunday issue as saying that ''a lot of people in Congress have pointed up things that are troublesome, but there is not a complete enough record to take any action.'' **********A former Administration official with close ties to the C.I.A. said further that Mr. Webster had assured another agency official under fire that he would make no decisions until after the Iran-contra investigations were completed and all the facts had been gathered. **********Mr. Clarridge achieved his greatest prominence at the C.I.A. during the tenure of William J. Casey. For several years Mr. Clarridge was head of the agency's Central America task force, a post from which he supervised the early efforts to arm and organize the Nicaraguan rebels and mine Nicaraguan harbors. **********Mr. Clarridge was a central figure in arranging the logistics for the Iran operation, including the November 1985 shipment of arms to Iran. Mr. Clarridge has insisted that he believed he was sending oil drilling parts to Iran. **********But the Iran-contra panels heard private testimony from the Deputy Chief of Mission in Portugal that at least two cables were sent to Mr. Clarridge at C.I.A. headquarters saying that an attempt was under way to route missiles to Iran. Those cables are missing from the C.I.A. files, the committee said. **********Mr. George has overall responsibility for all clandestine operations undertaken by the agency. Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North testified that Mr. George knew generally about his efforts to aid the contras. Also, the C.I.A.'s station chief in Costa Rica, who ultimately reports to Mr. George, was closely involved with the contra rebels in 1986, an apparent violation of Congressional strictures and agency regulations. **********Mr. George has insisted he was not aware that Joseph Fernandez, the station chief, was actively assisting Colonel North's private supply network.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/03/world.main_headline: Israeli Officer Reported Slain By Guerrillas in Gaza Strip
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/03/world.print_headline: Israeli Officer Reported Slain By Guerrillas in Gaza Strip
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/03/world.body_text: **********Palestinian guerrillas shot and killed an Israeli Army officer today in the occupied Gaza Strip, a military spokesman said. **********The officer was shot several times at close range in his military vehicle in Gaza's market area, the Israeli radio said. He was rushed to a military clinic, where he died, the radio said. His name was not immediately disclosed.  [ Reuters quoted military personnel who identified the dead man as Lieut. Ron Tal, 22 years old. ]  Military authorities clamped a curfew on the area, closing the port and all entry points into Israel until further notice, an army spokesman said. Troops immediately began combing the area for suspects, an army spokesman said. **********Closing off the entire Gaza Strip is extremely unusual. Thousands of Gaza residents commute to Israel each day to work, and many others make their living as fishermen.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/18/world.main_headline: U.S. ENVOYS TOLD TO CONVEY DOUBT OVER LATIN PLAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/18/world.print_headline: U.S. ENVOYS TOLD TO CONVEY DOUBT OVER LATIN PLAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/18/world.body_text: **********Senior United States envoys to the five Central American nations were told at a meeting here today that they should convey Washington's deep concern about a regional peace plan adopted this month, Administration officials said. **********The principal concern, officials said, centers on American distrust of the Nicaraguan Government and whether it would abide by any agreement it makes. ''We don't think any of these people need to be convinced that the Sandinistas cannot be trusted,'' a State Department official said. **********But even as Administration officials repeated their wariness that the plan adopted by Central American leaders might help the Soviet-backed Sandinistas, there were signs today that the plan had also caused problems for the Nicaraguan Government. A Call to Costa Rica **********Diplomats said President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua recently telephoned President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica, the principal architect of the peace proposal, to explain why he traveled to Havana immediately after the accord was signed in Guatemala on Aug. 7. The diplomats said Mr. Ortega had complained that he had to get Fidel Castro's approval to ward off pressures from hard-liners in his own Government. **********''He said his purpose was to strengthen his internal position,'' an official knowledgeable about the events said. According to one diplomat, Mr. Ortega said he was principally concerned about challenges from Tomas Borge, Nicaragua's Interior Minister, who controls the country's internal security and intelligence organs. Abrams Leads Discussion **********Mr. Ortega was also seeking Mr. Castro's agreement to withdraw Cuban forces from Nicaragua to comply with the accord's provisions that all foreign forces eventually be withdrawn from the region, the official said. After the Ortega-Castro meeting, a communique was issued in which Cuba expressed its support for the Guatemala plan. **********The discussion by United States officials in Washington today was led by Elliott Abrams, the Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs. More than 30 officials analyzed the regional accord in detail. Mr. Abrams has described the accord as ''more a preliminary agreement than a final peace treaty'' and has cautioned that it contains many ambiguities. **********The Administration, which had earlier offered its own peace plan for the region, has been forced to confront instead the accord that was signed in Guatemala City by Guatemala, Nicaragua, Costa Rica, Honduras and El Salvador. A U.S. Campaign **********As part of its response, the Administration is trying an intense diplomatic effort to assess the accord and to shape it to its liking. The envoys are to return to their postings Tuesday to relay the American concerns before the Foreign Ministers of the five countries confer the next day in San Salvador. **********The accord signed in Guatemala is designed to resolve conflicts throughout Central America but is mainly focused on Nicaragua. It calls for scheduled cease-fires, an end to outside aid for rebel groups, the establishment of national commmissions to reconcile political differences, amnesties and movement toward full democratic rights. **********It is generally regarded as more favorable to the Sandinistas than the plan put forward this month by the Administration and Representative Jim Wright of Texas, the Speaker of the House. That plan calls for an end of military aid to Nicaragua as well as an end to military aid for the Nicaraguan rebels, and would seek an immediate suspension of emergency law in Nicaragua along with an immediate cease-fire. It envisions negotiations to restore full civil rights and elections in Nicaragua. Congress would be asked to resume aid to the rebels if there was no agreement on negotiations by Sept. 30. #1973 Accord Cited An Administration official said today that those attending the State Department meeting were given copies of the 1973 agreement negotiated between Washington and Hanoi and signed in Paris to end the Vietnam War. That agreement was used, the official said, as a case study of how an agreement with ambiguous provisions could be exploited and even ignored by a Communist government. In violation of the 1973 accord, North Vietnam overran South Vietnam and united the two parts of Vietnam under its banner in 1975. **********In connection with its stepped-up diplomatic effort to play a role in the shaping of any peace accord, the Administration hopes to have ambassadors in all five of the countries by early next month. The United States is now represented by ambassadors only in El Salvador and Honduras and by diplomats of lesser rank in Nicaragua, Costa Rica and Guatemala. **********Those attending the meeting today included Edwin G. Corr, Ambassador to El Salvador; Everett E. Briggs, Ambassador to Honduras; Todd Stewart, charge d'affaires in Costa Rica; John Moddernor, the charge in Nicaragua, and Jerry Lamberty, the charge in Guatemala. Deane R. Hinton and James Michael, the State Department's choices to be the Ambassadors to Costa Rica and Guatemala, also attended. The Administration has not signaled its choice for ambassador to Nicaragua to succeed Harry E. Bergold Jr., who was reassigned this summer. **********The envoys to each of the five countries discussed how the Guatemalan proposal would affect that country and how that Government viewed the proposal. Security Interests an Issue **********The meeting also focused on what senior officials have said are United States security interests in the region involving the Soviet Union. Earlier, one official was emphatic that Washington would not tolerate the introduction by Moscow of jet fighters into Nicaragua. ''That is a U.S.-Soviet issue,'' the official said. The Guatemala accord does not deal with that issue and officials have cited this as a major ambiguity. **********As the envoys gathered in Washington, the Administration renewed its denunciation of the Nicaraguan Government for breaking up protests over the weekend in Managua. **********''The suppression of these demonstrations and the arrests of these political leaders call into serious question the Sandinista Government's willingness to fulfill the commitments made by President Ortega to democratize Nicaragua,'' a State Department spokeswoman, Phyllis Oakley, said. **********''The arrests of these political and human rights leaders and the brutal manner and great speed with which the marches were suppressed, would seem to indicate that the Nicaraguan Government wishes to intimidate and oppress the opposition rather than fulfill its promises for democratization under the Guatemala agreement,'' she said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/29/busin.main_headline: Kodak-Fuji Rivalry Over Business Takes An Academic Turn
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/29/busin.print_headline: Kodak-Fuji Rivalry Over Business Takes An Academic Turn
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/29/busin.body_text: **********Like many American corporate giants, the Eastman Kodak Company battles its Japanese competitors in whatever marketplace they meet. Kodak recently carried that fight over to the university campus. **********Professing concern that an employee of its fiercest rival, the Fuji Photo Film Company, would be a classmate of some of its senior managers at the University of Rochester graduate business school, Kodak asked the university to rescind its acceptance of the Japanese student. **********The university, which grew to its present stature in part because of large donations from George Eastman, granted Kodak's request. A university official arranged for the student to be admitted to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. **********It was an unusual show of corporate influence even in the long, close relationship between American business and the nation's business schools. And it was even more striking because the University of Rochester's William E. Simon School of Business is known for its free-market principles, which advocate a minimum of regulatory constraint. **********The student, Tsuneo Sakai, is part of this year's contingent of employees sent by Japanese corporations to business schools in the United States to learn more about American business principles and practices. He was admitted to the Simon School for its two-year master's degree program beginning this fall. **********Kodak, which is based in Rochester, routinely sends scores of its up-and-coming employees to the same school for business degrees. **********This fall, for the first time, Kodak is enrolling about a dozen of its senior- and mid-level managers in the Simon School's full-time master's program in business. It apparently became alarmed when it learned of the admission of the Fuji employee, especially because of his work in the company's new products division. **********The Simon program is relatively small, with only 300 students, and Kodak executives were worried that, in the normal give-and-take of classroom discussion, Fuji would have indirect access to some of Kodak's most sensitive information. **********In a statement issued yesterday, Kodak said it had acted out of concern that its managers ''would feel inhibited in discussions and-or reviewing case studies for fear of revealing proprietary information.'' **********But it maintained it did not threaten or force the business school officials to reconsider their admissions decision. **********Kodak gave $625,000 for programs at the University of Rochester last year and announced earlier this month that it would give $36,000 annually toward a program to teach business executives to take creative risks. The university, which has about 4,550 undergraduates and 2,200 graduate students, received a large portion of its endowment from George Eastman, Kodak's founder. In terms of endowment, it is one of the nation's 10 richest universities. **********For its part, the Simon School helped to place Mr. Sakai in another widely known business school - the Sloan School of Management at M.I.T. - before rescinding his enrollment. **********The Simon School said it acted not only because Kodak was concerned but because it was worried ''about a possible constraint Mr. Sakai's presence might produce on the free exchange of information in the classroom.'' **********The school's official statement, read over the telephone by a spokeswoman, said that Mr. Sakai's background in product development ''produced an isolated incident in the history of the Simon School'' that, the statement said, ''in no way reflects any policy in place.'' **********Experts knowledgeable about American graduate business education and about the sharp competition between Japan and the United States businesses said that they knew of no other incident in which an American corporation had influenced a business school not to admit a foreign national. **********One prominent economist said he worried that publicity about the incident could create further ill will and be particularly controversial in Japan, where there is a keen sensitivity about being the target of what is seen as chauvinistic American criticism. **********Edward Lincoln, a research associate and expert on Japan at the Brookings Institution in Washington, said, ''It's certainly true that American businesses have been disturbed by the large number of Japanese nationals in American business schools and American scientific-research programs.'' **********''But,'' he added, ''I think there's a zero chance that any good business school would tailor its admissions policies to suit them.'' **********Officials of Fuji could not be reached for comment at the company's headquarters in Tokyo. A spokesman for the leaders of the company's United States subsidiary said that they did not know about the situation because Mr. Sakai was an employee of the parent company. **********One specialist on Japan said that although Kodak's apparent role was unusual, Fuji's decision to sponsor an employee like Mr. Sakai for a school so intimately connected with its primary rival has to be regarded skeptically as well. **********Russell Palmer, dean of the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania, said: **********''I don't see how a business school such as ours could get into trying to sort out all the potential conflicts that can arise in a business school student body. **********''We have people here, too, from American companies that are competing against each other. Everybody who comes here has free access to information. Our job is to disseminate information and spur learning, and hopefully, creativity.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/03/busin.body_text: **********A Shift at the Fed **********Paul A. Volcker will be succeeded by Alan Greenspan as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, ending months of speculation over the fate of one of the most powerful economic policy makers in the nation's history. Mr. Greenspan is considered unlikely to pursue a markedly different monetary policy, and he shares the free-market views of the White House. Yet the news stunned the financial markets, which had come to regard a third term for Mr. Volcker as highly probable. White House efforts to persuade Mr. Volcker to remain were apparently minimal. It is understood that Mr. Volcker would have accepted reappointment if the President himself had urged him to do so. But no such effort was made.  [ Page A1. ] **********The Volcker legacy is an economy that he freed of the long-brewing inflation that had turned virulent when he was taking office in the late 1970's. But the durability of his contributions as Fed chairman is uncertain.  [ A1. ]  Mr. Volcker was not taken seriously when he said he wanted out as Fed chairman, according to White House officials.  [ D27. ]  Mr. Greenspan's presence in Washington has scarcely diminished since his four-year tenure as head of the Council of Economic Advisers in the Ford Administration.  [ D1. ] **********The Greenspan appointment will mean continuity and change at the central bank, coming at a crucial time for the nation and for the world economy. Leonard Silk. Economic Scene.  [ D2. ] Markets **********The Volcker decision caused turmoil in the financial markets. Although his successor, Alan Greenspan, was roundly praised, the accolades were not enough to reassure the markets. Besides their aversion to change, traders worried that Mr. Greenspan might be more tolerant of inflation if it meant faster economic growth.  [ D1. ]  In the credit markets, the the Treasury's 30-year bond dropped by more than 3 points.  [ D15. ]  The dollar plunged although intervention by the Fed and the Bundesbank was reported. Spot gold prices jumped $13, to $460 an ounce.  [ D20. ]  Stock prices retreated broadly. The Dow Jones industrial average ended 10.01 points lower, at 2,278.22.  [ D8. ]  In the futures markets, prices of precious metals and commodities rose.  [ D20. ] **********A Congressional panel examining insider trading plans to focus on the role of Dennis B. Levine's supervisors at the four different Wall Street firms where he worked. Mr. Levine testified for four hours in a closed session.  [ D1. ] **********H. F. Ahmanson delayed the sale of up to $1 billion in mortgage-backed securities because of rising interest rates.  [ D5. ] The Economy **********New-home sales soared 7.6 percent in April. Analysts said the rise represented a panic response by buyers to fears about higher mortgage rates.  [ D1. ]  A rise in military purchases enabled factory orders for manufactured goods to edge up 0.2 percent in April.  [ D2. ] **********A proposal to end an antitrust exemption for insurers is being supported by a coalition of consumer, labor and banking groups and leading Democratic senators.  [ D1. ] Companies **********A new, $35-a-share bid for Caesars World will be made by Martin T. Sosnoff, according to someone close to the investor. The bid is an attempt to dissuade Caesars World shareholders from accepting a management offer that is about 25 cents a share lower.  [ D1. ] **********Fujitsu and I.B.M. have largely resolved their dispute on a 1983 accord on I.B.M.-developed operating systems, according to a prospectus filed by the Japanese computer giant.  [ D5. ] Technology **********Ultra-thin films are being viewed in new ways that promise important developments in computer and other technologies. The thin film allows many more transistors, diodes and capacitors to be crammed onto silicon wafers.  [ D6. ] **********The Federal ban on lead in gasoline means consumers will pay about 2 cents a gallon more. The higher price is a result of expensive production methods used to meet the new standard.  [ D6. ] Today's Column **********Prices of biotechnology issues steadied after Monday's selling avalanche touched off by Genentech's setback on the drug T.P.A. But analysts remain cautious. Market Place.  [ D8. ]

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/29/world.main_headline: Israel Sets Standard Fee For University Students
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/29/world.print_headline: Israel Sets Standard Fee For University Students
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/29/world.body_text: **********Israel's Cabinet today set university tuition fees at $1,350 for all students, reversing a previous decision that was widely viewed as a discriminatory effort to charge Jewish students less than Arabs. **********The differential tuition rates would have given a discount of $500 to students who had served in the army. A universal draft at age 18 applies to all Jewish Israeli men and women, except the deeply religious, who would not normally attend the state-run schools where the tuition applies. The great majority of Israeli Arabs do not serve in the Israeli Army. **********The original decision, made last month, would have set tuition at $1,050 for those who had served in the army, while others paid $1,550. The decision sparked widespread student protests, and university officials declared they would not follow the Government's guidelines. **********Officials of the financially-ailing universities, who say tuition must be raised to at least $1,600 if they are to survive, criticized today's vote. **********The cabinet also voted to allocate an additional $4.5 million to the country's schools of higher education, which was far below the $17.5 million the universities had requested. **********The universities have an overall debt of some $90 million, which they say is due to reductions in Government funding.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/08/busin.main_headline: Talking Deals; Sale of Bowery: The Debate
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/08/busin.print_headline: Talking Deals; Sale of Bowery: The Debate
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/08/busin.body_text: **********THE small group of investors that took over New York's Bowery Savings Bank have cause to celebrate. Less than two years after spending $100 million to acquire the once-troubled Bowery, the owners will double their money by selling the savings institution to H.F. Ahmanson & Company of Los Angeles for $200 million. **********But the sweet payoff, announced Monday, has put the original transaction, in which the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation ceded ownership to the investors, in a new light. A number of banking experts are wondering whether the F.D.I.C. gave away too much and whether it should have cut the investors in at all. **********''Why couldn't the F.D.I.C. have bought the Bowery, rehabilitated it and sold it itself at a profit?'' asks George G.C. Parker, a professor of banking at Stanford Business School. **********''What the F.D.I.C. said was, 'We'll take over all the garbage, we'll give you the good stuff, and you get all the profit,''' said Paul Nadler, a professor of banking at Rutgers University in Newark. ''It was an absolute rape of the public.'' **********In exchange for agreeing to take over the Bowery in the autumn of 1985, the bank's current owners requested and won nearly $275 million in cash assistance and guarantees from the F.D.I.C. The guarantees, worth $115 million, involved the assumption of certain problem loans and the indemnification of a certain amount of losses on better-quality loans left with the bank. **********The guarantees and the $160 million cash contribution made the F.D.I.C.'s commitment nearly triple that of the investor group. Even so, the insurer will not share in the sales proceeds. The Bowery owners who will profit include Richard Ravitch, former chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority; Laurence A. Tisch, chairman and chief executive of CBS Inc., and Warren Buffett, the Nebraska financier. **********For years, the F.D.I.C. has maintained that when it bails out an institution like the Bowery, no public money is used. L. William Seidman, the F.D.I.C.'s chairman, repeated that point in an interview yesterday. ''The money that is involved is the result of the banks' paying premiums to the F.D.I.C.,'' Mr. Seidman said. ''There is no tax money involved.'' **********But increasingly, bank experts outside the F.D.I.C. are taking a broader view. At the Wall Street firm of Ryan, Beck & Company, for instance, Michael Horn, a savings institution specialist, agreed that the F.D.I.C.'s rescue funds come from insurance premiums. But those premiums, Mr. Horn noted, are an operating expense that affect what banks charge consumers and businesses for loans. Professor Parker, meanwhile, argued that the public does have an interest in how the F.D.I.C. negotiates bailouts in light of what he called the implicit Government backing of the insurance corporation. **********In any case, the F.D.I.C. said it had no alternative but to shape the deal with Mr. Ravitch the way it did. ''We shopped the Bowery for three years; no one wanted it,'' said William M. Isaac, former head of the agency. And H. Rodgin Cohen, the Sullivan & Cromwell attorney who represented the Bowery, said the F.D.I.C. would have been in an even worse position had it rejected the Ravitch group. **********''The profit the F.D.I.C. made was the avoidance of losses it would have incurred if it had to give the bank to someone else, who would have asked for even more assistance,'' Mr. Cohen said. **********Of course, the case of the Bowery was not the first time the F.D.I.C. had poured millions of dollars into a troubled institution to keep it afloat. And, significantly, the F.D.I.C. has driven a harder bargain in the past. In the collapses of First Pennsylvania, Continental Illinois, Bank Oklahoma and, most recently, the First City Bancorporation, for instance, the F.D.I.C. made sure it would be compensated for its contributions by receiving either warrants or stock in the troubled bank. **********It is becoming increasingly clear, banking experts say, that the F.D.I.C. does have alternatives to selling out to private bidders. One is simply to liquidate the institution, a choice that, in the Bowery's case, might have produced no greater losses for the F.D.I.C. than the route it took. The F.D.I.C. could also run a troubled institution itself, a route that will become increasingly viable under new laws regarding regulators' powers. **********For now, though, the F.D.I.C. seems intent on resorting to private-sector ownership as often as possible. **********While the F.D.I.C. has a fiduciary duty to the banks that pay its insurance premiums to strike the best deal possible, it risks alienating prospective buyers if it demands too much. Striking a balance will be the hard part as the number of failing banks rises.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/13/busin.body_text: **********Apple Computer Inc. today introduced an updated version of the Apple IIe personal computer that has as features an expanded keyboard with a built-in numeric keypad, improved training materials and the company's new platinum color scheme. **********Available immediately, the updated IIe will retail for $829, and an upgrade kit to give it the performance of the new IIgs model will be available this month for $499, plus dealer installation. **********The IIe, long the workhorse of Apple's product line, is the best-selling personal computer to elementary and secondary schools and has had strong sales in the home computer market as well.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/16/busin.main_headline: Swiss Aid VW In Fraud Case
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/16/busin.print_headline: Swiss Aid VW In Fraud Case
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/16/busin.body_text: **********Swiss investigators said today that they had seized documents in connection with a suspected currency fraud that cost Volkswagenwerk A.G., the West German auto maker, as much as $260 million. VW has said computer programs were erased and documents faked. **********Today's statement is the first official confirmation that the inquiry has spread beyond the borders of West Germany. **********Christian Crasemann, prosecutor in the Swiss town of Meilen, said the police had seized documents relating to a Frankfurt currency broker, Joachim Schmidt, from about 10 finance companies. He refused to name them. Mr. Schmidt, who has not been seen since news of the VW case broke, is accused of fraud and falsification of documents.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/24/world.main_headline: Haiti Leaders Schedule Local Elections in August
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/24/world.print_headline: Haiti Leaders Schedule Local Elections in August
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/24/world.body_text: **********The military-civilian council that governs Haiti scheduled local elections for Aug. 23 in a decree published today. **********The act provoked criticism from leaders who said the Government was usurping the authority of the Provisional Electoral Council, an independent agency that has the job of planning and holding elections. **********Haitians are to vote for mayors and two deputy mayors in the country's 140 municipalities and for members of the administrative councils of the 555 rural communal districts. **********National elections are tentatively scheduled for Nov. 27 for the presidency and the members of Parliament - 74 representatives in the House of Deputies and 27 senators. The president is to be installed in February on the second anniversary of the ouster of President Jean-Claude Duvalier. **********Louis Roy, one of the writers of Haiti's new Constitution, was among those who criticized the action. ''The Government is taking the initiative to organize the elections itself,'' he said. ''That's a gross violation of the Constitution.'' **********Court Blocks Duvalier Case **********GRASSE, France, June 23 (Reuters)- A French court refused today to hear an embezzlement case against Mr. Duvalier, crippling efforts to recover millions of dollars that Haiti's new rulers say he stole. **********A civil tribunal said it had no jurisdiction over acts committed by Mr. Duvalier while President and was not competent to hear a suit brought by Haiti. Mr. Duvalier now lives in exile in Mougins, near Grasse.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/13/world.main_headline: THE WORLD OF THE IMMIGRANT: LOW-PAYING JOBS AND OVERCROWED HOUSING
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/13/world.print_headline: THE WORLD OF THE IMMIGRANT: LOW-PAYING JOBS AND OVERCROWED HOUSING
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/13/world.body_text: **********After Joaquin Romero succeeded in getting himself from El Salvador to a Latin American neighborhood of Los Angeles, one of his first acts was to pay a smuggler to bring his wife and two young daughters here. **********For almost $4,000, he bought them a travel package that included plane tickets on a direct flight from San Salvador to Tijuana, Mexico, then a risky overland trip across the border, and finally a truck ride to the smuggler's safe house in Los Angeles. **********The airplane, Mercedes Romero told her husband later, was full of Salvadorans paying the same smuggler for similar services. **********Los Angeles is the capital of Salvadoran immigrants to the United States. By most estimates, more than a quarter-million Salvadorans, refugees of that country's civil war but also of its poverty, live in the metropolitan area. Routes to United States **********Like Mercedes Romero and her children, tens of thousands have made the journey illegally through Mexico. Many pay alien-smugglers. Others enter with the help of the American church-based sanctuary movement, which has vowed to defy the Reagan Administration's position that most Salvadorans who have entered the United States have done so for economic reasons and therefore are not political refugees. **********Demographers and Central America specialists say the tide of Salvadorans coming to this country has swelled in the last five or six years. According to the Urban Institute in Washington, which made estimates for the Department of Health and Human Services, there are between 500,000 and 850,000 Salvadorans in the United States. **********Los Angeles ranks first among cities with between 250,000 and 350,000; Washington is second with 80,000 to 150,000, followed by New York and San Francisco, each of which has 60,000 to 100,000. The institute's estimates were derived from interviews with social service agencies in those cities. **********A spokesman for the Immigration and Naturalization Service, Duke Austin, said that the agency did not know what proportion of all Salvadorans in this country were illegal aliens, but that it estimated that half a million Salvadorans were here illegally. Amnesty for Some **********Recent changes in American immigration policy provide an amnesty for illegal immigrants who arrived before Jan. 1, 1982, thus excluding the Romeros and many, if not most, Salvadorans here. Many are reluctantly making plans to return. The Romeros said they would remain and try to gain political asylum or some other legal status. **********''We all are worried about what might happen because the situation in El Salvador remains the same, if not worsened,'' Mr. Romero said. **********The Romeros live near downtown Los Angeles in the Pico-Union district, an area dotted with Salvadoran restaurants and travel agencies and home to the largest concentration of Salvadorans in California. **********Mr. Romero, a 35-year-old janitor at a suburban condominium, first came to the United States in 1981 on a temporary visa to obtain medical treatment for a wound in Miami. He said he had been ''shot by members of the National Army in El Salvador'' while he was photographing Government human-rights abuses for a human-rights agency of the Roman Catholic Church. He returned briefly to El Salvador, then came to Los Angeles in 1982. 'I Couldn't Work' **********The visa that Mr. Romero obtained from the United States Consulate in San Salvador was only for himself, not his family. ''The consulate said if they got visas, too, we would all stay here and not return,'' Mr. Romero said. ''That is what I wanted to do,'' he admitted. ''I couldn't work in El Salvador without being persecuted'' for his human-rights activities. **********He had heard that California had job opportunities and that ''the area we could live in without any barriers of language was Los Angeles.'' He also knew his best hopes of reuniting with his family depended on their crossing over through Mexico. **********The smuggler, known to them as Julio, separated Mrs. Romero and her daughters at Tijuana, sending the mother with a companion on a dangerous hike through the border mountains, while Anna, then 7, and Marta, then 4, were supplied with false American birth certificates and driven through the Border Patrol checkpoint. **********Today the Romeros have a third child, Arnulfo, 4, born in this city. Mrs. Romero, 33, works at a Chinese restaurant. Though they are living with relatives here - 10 people in a one-bedroom apartment - they regularly send money to family in El Salvador. ''We have a roof and food, but our people in El Salvador do not have security,'' Mr. Romero said. Brutal Repressions **********Eduardo Canjura and his wife, Maria, came to Los Angeles only two years ago. Mr. Canjura, a 44-year-old bricklayer, said he was driven from his small village by lack of work, but arrived in San Salvador in 1980 to find brutal repressions. ''Someone, I don't know who, put the finger on me, said I was a subversive,'' Mr. Canjura said. **********What followed was a months-long nightmare of imprisonment and torture at the hands of the army, he said. After he gained release in a general amnesty, an American sanctuary group heard of his story and helped spirit him out of the country with a Mexican visa. **********Eventually the family was reunited here. Mr. Canjura works at odd jobs found by Caracen, a Central American relief agency, and Mrs. Canjura has joined the legion of illegal domestic workers in Southern California households. They live happily, they said, in Santa Monica in an apartment building that is slightly run down, but just steps from the same ocean beach where other Californians live the good life. **********''There are many good people who help us a lot, and we are like little ants just trying to get by,'' Mrs. Canjura recently told a visitor.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/07/busin.snippet: LEAD: LONG ago Adele Fendi told her daughters:
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/07/busin.main_headline:
ITALY: HOST FOR THE ECONOMIC SUMMIT - A LAND OF FAMILY BUSINESSES;
Inside the House of Fendi
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/07/busin.print_headline:
ITALY: HOST FOR THE ECONOMIC SUMMIT - A LAND OF FAMILY BUSINESSES;
Inside the House of Fendi
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/07/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: LONG ago Adele Fendi told her daughters: **********LONG ago Adele Fendi told her daughters: **********''You girls are like five fingers on a hand; you only work well when you're together.'' Over the years, Paola, Anna, Franca, Carla and Alda Fendi used that advice to build an empire of furs, leather designs and ready-to-wear clothing into one of the most exclusive fashion enterprises in the world. ''Le sorelle Fendi,'' who range in age from 46 to 56, have been making fashion history for the last 20 years. **********Since 1965, when they began their collaboration with the Paris-based designer Karl Lagerfeld, who also designs their ready-to-wear clothing, they have changed the way wealthy, stylish women wear fur. **********They have dyed their furs rich, unheard-of colors like purple, emerald green and apricot. They rejuvenated the matronly mink coat and promoted such lesser-known skins as weasel, ferret and squirrel. They braided pelts and mixed them up; sable with opossum, fox with rabbit, mink with mole. Using new techniques, they quilted and crocheted furs, patterning them in designs inspired by Impressionist paintings and Eskimo prints. They also revolutionized the feel of fur coats, making them so light that they could be folded into an overnight bag. These moves gave Fendi a reputation as the most innovative furrier in the world. **********So exclusive is the Fendi label that a three-quarter-length honey-colored Russian sable coat in the 1987 collection will retail in the United States for about $200,000. A respected Roman furrier, who preferred not to be indentified ''out of respect'' for the sisters, claimed that she could sell a similar coat for about $110,000. **********''The Fendis and I buy our pelts at the same auctions so we pay about the same price for materials,'' the competitor said. ''The Fendis, however, can charge about twice as much because of their name.'' **********The Fendis also helped take the stiffness out of the old-fashioned sturdy leather bag. While shops like Gucci were concentrating on making traditional designs, the Fendis were coming out with purses that were soft, pliable and roomy. Their distinctly untraditional collections featured bags that were woven and meshed in bright, alternating colors, others that combined unlikely materials such as ribbed rubber with sumptuous calfskin. Leather bags with the double-F logo are selling in the $200-$400 price range at Bloomingdale's stores in New York. **********Their most recent success has been Fendi perfume, which costs $160 an ounce (eau de toilette is priced at $32 for a 1.7 ounce bottle) and was introduced in 15 Bloomingdale's stores this year. According to Joseph F. Ronchetti, president of Elizabeth Arden, the perfume's distributor, Fendi fragrance had sales of $1 million in its first five weeks on the shelves, which he called a record for new perfume promotions. **********With 100 Fendi boutiques worldwide and collections in 500 department stores producing sales of $170 million last year, up 20 percent from 1985, the sisters still defer all plaudits to ''Mamma,'' who died in 1978. It was she, they say, who instilled in them the esprit de corps that is the foundation of their business. ''We're used to being together; we've had a lifetime of playing together, amusing ourselves together,'' said Carla. ''Working together now is a joy.'' **********THE women were born and raised in the business. In 1925, Adele Fendi and her husband, Edoardo, opened a small boutique and workshop in Rome specializing in quality leather goods and fur designs in ''poor pelts'' like squirrel and Persian lamb. Their craftsmanship and unique designs earned them a following and as their business grew, so did their family. Each daughter entered the trade buried deep in the folds of a lace-lined bassinet, which had become a fixture at the shop. **********Early on, the girls learned the meaning of family unity. If one did something wrong, all were punished. Yet over the years, they developed specialties: Paola, the company president, is the expert in furs. Anna is the creative one. Franca manages leather designs and directs boutiques in Rome. Carla handles public relations and advertising. Alda works closely with Mr. Lagerfeld on fur styling. **********The five, who together own the company, meet at least once a week to review all activities. Contested decisions are always made on a majority-rules basis, with each sister having an equal vote. ''There is never a question of egos or who's in command,'' said Mr. Ronchetti. ''They function absolutely professionally as a team. There are no prima donnas.'' Arguments occur, of course, especially during creative sessions. But Carla insists there are no rivalries or jockeying for position. Instead, she says, the only objective is to to maintain a successful family enterprise. **********This sentiment, it seems, has permeated the roots of the family tree. Of the 500 Fendi employees in Rome - 2,000 worldwide - 20 are family members. All but one husband has entered the business, 11 grandchildren are in the company, and three granddaughters have introduced their own less-expensive ''Fendissime'' collections of furs, ready-to-wear clothing and handbags. Other new product lines include ''Fendi Uomo'' for men and a new Fendissime baby line to be introduced in the next year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/03/world.body_text: **********Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia, has asked President Reagan to collect six years of records from negotiations on medium-range nuclear missiles, warning that he would ask for the entire history of the Geneva talks if the United States and Soviet Union concluded a treaty eliminating those weapons. **********In a letter made public by his staff today, Mr. Nunn, who heads the Senate Armed Services Committee, wrote that the committee could not rely simply on the testimony of Administration officials during ratification hearings in trying to determine the intent and background of such a treaty. **********Mr. Nunn's letter continued a dispute with the White House that has its origins in a disagreement over the interpretation of the Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty. **********The Administration has adopted a broad interpretation of that treaty, which it says would allow the testing of ''Star Wars'' anti-missile systems. Mr. Nunn and some other Senate Democrats support a narrower interpretation that would preclude such testing. **********In his letter on the arms negotiations, he said if his committee decided that the treaty, which would also cover shorter-range missiles, is not specific enough, it might have to seek amendments or additions ''to insure that future administrations will adhere to interpretations advanced by the Reagan Administration.'' **********Mr. Nunn wrote, ''It is not my intention to delay consideration, but the Senate will have to review the six-year-long negotiating record very carefully and that will obviously be time-consuming.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/15/busin.main_headline: U.S. TRADE DEFICIT DECLINED IN MARCH AS EXPORTS SURGED
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/15/busin.print_headline: U.S. TRADE DEFICIT DECLINED IN MARCH AS EXPORTS SURGED
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/15/busin.body_text: **********A surge in exports, to the highest monthly level in six years, helped to narrow the United States trade deficit to $13.6 billion in March, the Commerce Department reported today. **********Nevertheless, the nation's import bill was the highest ever recorded for a single month. **********Today's report, which showed a decline of $1.5 billion in the deficit in March from February, was generally regarded by economists as additional evidence that the huge American deficit in merchandise trade is on the wane and that the improvement is likely to continue. 'The Worst Is Behind Us' **********''I think we're getting clear evidence that the worst is behind us,'' said William V. Sullivan Jr., senior vice president for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. **********But the analysts and the Commerce Department cautioned that the figures remain highly volatile and noted that the overall trade deficit in dollar terms was no lower than the average for January and February. **********At the White House, Marlin Fitzwater, the Administration spokesman, called the decline in March ''good news'' and said the trade data ''indicate that the nominal trade deficit is gradually declining.'' Nominal refers to the dollar value of goods as opposed to the volume of goods as measured by unit counts. **********On Capitol Hill, where Democrats control both chambers, the reaction was considerably less upbeat. The House Speaker, Jim Wright of Texas, said that the news was chilling and that it underscored the need for rapid action to pass comprehensive trade legislation. ''Treading water is not making the shoreline,'' Mr. Wright said. A Peak in Late 1986 **********Nearly all private economists agree that in terms of volume the trade deficit peaked during the second half of 1986 and has fallen since then by about 20 percent. The current debate centers on whether the dollar-denominated deficit - the one reported today - has also turned down. **********Mr. Sullivan thinks it has, even though he observed that March is usually a strong month for exports. But Walter M. Cadette, a vice president at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, said today's report did little to prove such assertions. **********''Things look very much the same as before,'' Mr. Cadette said. ''There seems to be a gradual improvement in volume terms, but you're getting an offsetting deterioration in the terms of trade, which is a fancy way of saying the price of imports is going up.'' **********The dollar's sharp fall against the yen and most European currencies in the last two years has made American exports more readily marketable abroad while making foreign goods more expensive here. This, given enough time, inevitably causes the trade deficit to shrink. **********But the adjustment is rarely smooth or its timing predictable. The J-Curve **********One important reason is that, in a phenomenon described by an economic principle called the J-curve, the short-term effect of the dollar's decline is a rise in the reported deficit, not a decline. This happens because the higher total price of imports tends, for many months, to overwhelm the reductions in volume. **********Eventually, when order pipelines must be refilled and consumers may have changed their spending patterns, the J-curve effects wear off. Analysts said today that with the yen having fallen from about 150 in March to about 140 today, the United States will be even more competitive in the months ahead, even though the Commerce Department's figures may not clearly reflect this. **********The financial markets registered no strong reactions to the trade-deficit report, although the consensus seemed to be that the numbers had fallen a bit short of expectations. Vague disappointment about the trade report was cited as the dollar fell worldwide and bond prices were modestly lower. It was also one of several factors cited for the mixed day in the stock market, which ended with the Dow Jones industrial average dropping 4.19 points, to 2,325.49. Exports Highest Since March '81 **********Exports rose to $21.1 billion in March, 20.6 percent above the January-February average and the highest level since March 1981. Manufactured goods accounted for 81 percent of the increase. **********Imports, rising to a record $34.7 billion, climbed only about half as fast as exports - 11.2 percent from the January-February average. Manufactured goods accounted for 80 percent of the gain. **********The American trade deficit with Japan eased a modest $118 million from February to March, with the bulk of the gain accounted for by higher exports. Trade with Japan accounted for 36 percent of the overall American deficit. **********The deficit with Canada improved by $424 million, entirely reflecting higher exports. The department also said it had undercounted exports to Canada by about 20 percent last year. It said that it was considering ways to make its figures more accurate and that one possibility was to use Canadian import data instead of American export documents. Expanded Gap with Europe **********But the trade deficit with Western Europe expanded during March to $2.5 billion, from $1.9 billion. The deterioration against West Germany alone was $547 million, to $1.6 billion. **********The trade imbalance in manufactured goods narrowed by 7.1 percent, to $11.7 billion, while the nation's bill for imported crude oil and petroleum products eased slightly, to $3.2 billion. The agricultural surplus shrank to $193 millon, from $279 million, as imports grew faster than exports. **********Jerry J. Jasinowski, chief economist for the National Association of Manufacturers, called today's trade figures ''quite good, better than at first sight.'' **********He said the numbers, combined with information from constituents, ''show we're having some success'' in raising export levels, which according to most analysts is the key to redressing the trade imbalance.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/08/world.main_headline: Shultz Confirms Funds From Brunei Vanished
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/08/world.print_headline: Shultz Confirms Funds From Brunei Vanished
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/08/world.body_text: **********Secretary of State George P. Shultz confirmed today that a large sum of money, reported to be $10 million, from the Sultan of Brunei had disappeared. **********Speaking to reporters on his plane at the beginning of his trip to Africa, Mr. Shultz said, ''It is a mystery just what happened to that money. And I don't believe that we in the State Department can say.'' **********The Secretary declined to identify Brunei as the contributing country, but Administration officials have said that at the request of Elliott Abrams, Assistant Secretary of State for Latin American Affairs, the Sultan of Brunei contributed funds for the use of the Nicaraguan rebels. **********Mr. Shultz said: ''We tried to track it. We were informed that it hadn't been deposited. Of course, we wanted to know and follow it because we wanted to see that it would be used for humanitarian purposes, for which it was raised. And then, suddenly, subsequently, we were told that it had been deposited but it wasn't there anymore.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/05/world.main_headline: CONTRA SAYS C.I.A. SUPPLY PROGRAM IS FLAWED
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/05/world.print_headline: CONTRA SAYS C.I.A. SUPPLY PROGRAM IS FLAWED
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/05/world.body_text: **********A Nicaraguan rebel leader complained today that the Central Intelligence Agency program to deliver military supplies to the contras was not working properly. **********The rebel leader, Adolfo Calero, said that although the situation was improving, there had been ''problems with transport equipment which we got, mechanical defects that have to be fixed.'' **********He said the difficulties could be resolved ''any day now,'' but added, ''In the meantime, we are using our old jalopies.'' **********At a news conference, Mr. Calero also denied that he or other contra leaders controlled or had access to any bank accounts in Switzerland or the Cayman Islands. A Senate intelligence committee report last week said that such accounts were used to funnel profits from arms sales to Iran to the contras. The report indicated that Mr. Calero may have controlled three of the accounts himself. **********Millions of dollars placed in those bank accounts are missing. Senate Report Disputed **********Mr. Calero said he never thanked Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, the former National Security Council aide, for any diversion of funds from Iran to those accounts. The Senate report said contra leaders had been ''appreciative.'' But Mr. Calero said, ''I can't have expressed appreciation for money we haven't received.'' **********Disputing another assertion in the Senate report, Mr. Calero said, ''Mr. North never told me that we would get funds from Iran, from Israel or from any other place.'' **********Asked about reports that Arturo Cruz, a key civilian contra leader, intended to resign from the United Nicaraguan Opposition, the rebel coalition, Mr. Calero said he would not comment ''until I hear Arturo Cruz speak himself.'' The resignation threat stems from intense infighting within the coalition, which Mr. Cruz reportedly contends is unfairly dominated by the leaders of the Nicaraguan Democratic Force, the rebel army headed by Mr. Calero. Some Equipment Is Denied **********Contra leaders have been unhappy since the C.I.A. resumed supplying the rebels with military equipment last fall because they believe the agency has parceled out the equipment too slowly, according to Administration officials familiar with the program. **********The agency has refused to give the contras much heavy or sophisticated equipment, such as trucks and surface-to-air missiles. One reason is that Congress has an opportunity later this month to rescind $40 million of the $100 million in aid approved last year. That is not likely to happen, most Administration officials contend. But if that aid is rescinded, the agency has concluded, the contras probably could not maintain or make good use of the equipment. **********Mr. Calero said that the rebels had been given some surface-to-air missiles since the resupply operation began, but that more were needed. He said his troops also needed machine guns, mortars, grenade launchers, light antitank weapons, rifles and ammunition. More cargo planes and helicopters for medical evacuation and transport were needed as well, he said. **********Despite that, Mr. Calero said that 6,000 rebel troops had penetrated deep inside Nicaragua and had encountered only minimal reistance from the far larger Sandinista army. In December, American officials said almost none of the contra troops were inside Nicaragua because the Sandinista army had effectively blocked them from crossing the Honduran border. Now, Mr. Calero asserted, his forces are facing ''only random resistance from the Sandinista forces, and only 300 men have been forced back to the border.'' **********Members of Congress and others have said the contras will have to make significant military gains if they expect to get any more American aid. **********Despite the reports about the diversion of profits from arms sales to Iran to the contras, and the supply of tens of millions of dollars by Saudi Arabia and other countries, Mr. Calero said the contras got only $1 million last year in addition to the $27 million for nonlethal supplies given by the United States.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/06/world.main_headline: China Says It Downed A Vietnamese Fighter
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/06/world.print_headline: China Says It Downed A Vietnamese Fighter
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/06/world.body_text: **********China said today that its Air Force shot down a Vietnamese jet fighter this afternoon after it twice intruded into Chinese air space. **********The official New China News Agency said the Vietnamese MIG-21 had intruded nearly 20 miles over southern China. The brief report did not say how the plane was shot down, nor did it gave the fate of the pilot. **********The officer on duty at the Vietnamese Embassy in Beijing said he had no information about the report. **********China and Vietnam have been skirmishing along their common border since 1979, when they fought a 17-day frontier war. **********The news agency said China's Foreign Ministry had ''made representations'' to Vietnam's Ambassador about the plane's intrusion. ''The Vietnamese authorities must adopt practical measures to put an end to such incidents or they will be responsible for all the consequences,'' the agency said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/29/world.main_headline: Terror Suspects Urge Release of Germans in Beirut
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/29/world.print_headline: Terror Suspects Urge Release of Germans in Beirut
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/29/world.body_text: **********A Lebanese terrorist suspect and his brother, both in jail here, have written to relatives in Beirut urging them to free two West Germans who have been held hostage there for three months, according to a senior West German official. **********The official, who has close knowledge of the case, said the terrorist suspect, Mohammed Ali Hamadei, and his brother, Abbas Ali Hamadei, made it clear in their joint appeal that there would be no movement on their legal situations until the two West Germans were freed. **********Mohammed Hamadei, 22 years old, was arrested in Frankfurt Airport on Jan. 13 carrying three bottles containing the explosive methyl nitrate. His older brother, Abbas, was detained on Jan. 26 and led the authorities to a bigger cache of methyl nitrate on the French frontier. **********In an apparent retaliation for the arrests, gunmen in Beirut seized two West German business representatives, Rudolf Cordes and Alfred Schmidt. Senior officials in Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Government said they believed the kidnappers were probably Hamadei relatives and were linked to the Party of God faction in Lebanon, a pro-Iranian group. **********The United States has demanded the extradition of Mr. Hamadei for his suspected role in the hijacking of a Trans World Airlines jet to Beirut in 1985 that resulted in the killing of an American passenger. Bonn has hesitated to honor the American extradition request, fearing that to do so would lead to the killings of the captives in Beirut. **********In their letter, the official said, the brothers said they were being treated well in prison and that Mohammed Hamadei probably would not be extradited to the United States if the two Germans were freed. But they stressed that the first move was up to those holding Mr. Cordes and Mr. Schmidt. **********Through other channels in Beirut, the Kohl Government has also made it known to the kidnappers that it has no intention of freeing the two brothers in an exchange, according to the official. **********There has so far been no response by the kidnappers to the Hamadei letter, the official said. **********Syrian troops now control most of West Beirut, and at one point the Government of President Hafez al-Assad offered to conduct a military strike to free the two hostages, a Western intelligence official said. Bonn was said to have rejected the move as too risky. **********While reluctant to extradite Mohammed Hamadei, Bonn officials are considering putting him on trial in West Germany for the T.W.A. hijacking, for which he could receive a life sentence if convicted. Information from Mr. Hamadei has enabled the French authorities to arrest several people from the Middle East thought to have been implicated in several bombings that shook Paris in September, officials there say. **********But the ostensible link between the pro-Iranian Hamadei clan and Shiite fundamentalists in France has led to a questioning of the French theory that the September bombings were aimed at freeing Georges Ibrahim Abdallah, an imprisoned Lebanese terrorist chieftain. **********Mr. Abdallah is a Maronite Christian from northern Lebanon who led a Marxist-Leninist terrorist group. Western intelligence officials said the Maronite group would seem to have little in common with such pro-Iranian Shiite groups as the Hamadei clan and the Party of God.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/13/busin.print_headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES; Federal Home Loan Bond Issues
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/13/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Home Loan Banks are offering three bond issues totaling $2.862 billion through securities dealers. All three issues are at par. **********A $1.092 billion issue due May 25, 1988, carries an interest rate of 7 3/8 percent, or about 10 basis points more than Treasury issues of similar maturity. https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/24/world.main_headline: 5 Soviet Generals Die In Crash of an Aircraft
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/24/world.print_headline: 5 Soviet Generals Die In Crash of an Aircraft
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/24/world.body_text: **********Five Soviet generals who served on the General Staff or in command positions of a Soviet Army group have been killed in an air crash, the Defense Ministry newspaper said today. **********The newspaper, Krasnaya Zvezda, said the generals perished ''in an aviation catastrophe'' Oct. 19. The newspaper did not give the site or cause of the accident, but there were indications the craft was a helicopter. **********The following were killed: *********** Col. Gen. Vladimir P. Shutov, 63 years old, was the highest ranking officer. A World War II veteran, he had served since 1975 as deputy chief of the armed forces General Staff Chief Directorate, which handles major staff policy matters. *********** Maj. Gen. Erlen V. Porfiryev, 51, was a field officer who had recently been appointed chief of staff of the southern group of forces in Hungary. *********** Lieut. Gen. Yuri I. Ryabinin, 53, held a responsible post on the General Staff, Krasnaya Zvezda said. He previously served as a field officer. *********** Lieut. Gen. Kirill N. Trofimov, 66, rose through the Defense Ministry administrative hierarchy and since 1977 had served as the military's deputy chief of communications. *********** Maj. Gen. Vladimir S. Bardashevsky, 49, was recently assigned to the General Staff. His post was not given. **********The pilot was identifed by the newspaper as Capt. Aleksei N. Gurenkov and the flight technician as Lieut. Aleksandr I. Goncharov. Both perished.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/22/busin.main_headline: Signature Magazine Plans to Cut Rate Base

That was announced yesterday by Ron Galotti, Signature publisher. **********He said the move would reduce the subscriber list to hard-core readers before the magazine's ''rebirth'' next September as Fodor's Traveler.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/06/world.main_headline: Quebec Journal; Under the Fleur-de-Lis, All Canada Hails Levesque
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/06/world.print_headline: Quebec Journal; Under the Fleur-de-Lis, All Canada Hails Levesque
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/06/world.body_text: **********Rene Levesque's memory was honored here today not only by those who shared his dream of nationhood for Quebec but also by the leaders of the Canada he rejected. **********On a day when blustery winds whipped across the St. Lawrence River, thousands watched the cortege as it wound its way slowly through the old walled capital of French Canada. Mr. Levesque, who was 65 years old when he died of a heart attack Sunday, was given what was widely referred to here as a state funeral, complete with honor guards, a lying-in-state, and a service in the Quebec Basilica that was accompanied by passages from Mozart's Requiem. His coffin was covered with the fleur-de-lis flag of Quebec. A private burial followed in a suburban cemetery. **********The organizer of the funeral was the Quebec provincial government, which was headed by Mr. Levesque as Premier from 1976 to 1985. But it was a small token of how much easier matters have become between French and English Canada in recent years that nobody was heard to object to the idea of a state occasion being held by Quebec, nor even to the fact that only a solitary Canadian maple leaf flag, fluttering at half-staff above a copper-green roof in the old city, was visible among the blue-and-white banners of Quebec. A Rite of Reconciliation **********In much of English-speaking Canada, accounting for nearly three-quarters of this nation of 25 million people, the funeral was seen as a rite of national reconciliation. Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, abed with flu on Wednesday, flew from Ottawa to lead a contingent of federal officials who walked behind the cortege. With him was a cluster of English-speaking politicians, including the premiers of at least two provinces that aligned themselves against Mr. Levesque's goal of independence for Quebec. **********The paradoxes might have pleased Mr. Levesque, although the pomp of the ceremony probably would not. A chain-smoking former journalist and inveterate poker player who carried a pack of cards in his pocket to some of the most important political showdowns in Canada's recent history, the separatist leader was known almost as much for his impatience with the trappings of office as for his conviction that Quebec could never be ''maitre chez soi'' - master of its destiny - as long as it remained part of Canada. **********In television commentaries, in Mr. Mulroney's eulogy before leaving Ottawa, in editorials across the country, English-speaking Canada hailed Mr. Levesque, at the end, as a man who had helped bind the country together - by forcing it to face up to Quebec's differences. In this view, an accord signed this year between Mr. Mulroney and the new Quebec government of Premier Robert Bourassa, by granting Quebec constitutional status as a ''distinct society'' and by winning the province's pledge to remain part of Canada, healed wounds that have festered since French Canada came under British dominion with the fall of Quebec in 1757. **********One person who signaled that he was uneasy with this view was Mr. Levesque's great political adversary, former Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, who battled with the separatist leader for 20 years over the independence issue. Mr. Trudeau appeared briefly at the lying-in-state in Montreal, attracting angry words from at least one Levesque supporter. But he stayed away from the funeral, perhaps conveying anew what he has said before - that those who think that Mr. Mulroney has buried the independence issue are deluding themselves. Applause in the Streets **********Mr. Trudeau's view is that the new constitutional accord, by encouraging Quebec to assume broader powers, will give fresh life to a separatist movement that was defeated in a Quebec referendum in 1980 and further rebuffed when Mr. Levesque's Parti Quebecois was ousted from office in an election in 1985. In support of his case, Mr. Trudeau, who retired as Prime Minister in 1984, has cited the fact that prominent separatists -Mr. Levesque among them - took heart from the ''possibilities'' for enlarging Quebec's role at the expense of the national Government that opened up with the new pact. **********In the streets of Montreal and Quebec City this week, and in the scarlet-paneled chamber in the National Assembly here where Mr. Levesque's body lay beneath a mural showing the French king's officials in council in Quebec in 1663, there were voices suggesting that Mr. Trudeau could be closer to the mark than Mr. Mulroney. Amid the powerful emotion stirred by Mr. Levesque's death, crowds in both cities lined up until past midnight to view the coffin, applauded it as it was driven through the streets, and, in Montreal, broke into the singing of a Quebec nationalist anthem, ''Gens du Pays.'' **********''Rene's death has revived everything,'' said Colette Bouchard, a Quebec City music teacher who used her lunch hour today to file past the bier. Mrs. Bouchard, a woman in her 40's who worked as an election organizer for the separatist party, said she believed that Quebec's seven million people had been ''reluctant to make the big jump'' that Mr. Levesque asked of them in the 1980 referendum, but would emerge from the ''pause'' of the Bourassa period to push once again for independence. **********Similar views were expressed by others in the line, including a senior Quebec government official, a university professor and an off-duty cook. But the word that recurred more than any other in discussing Mr. Levesque was ''fierte,'' meaning pride, a commodity of special importance among people who felt for decades that they were second-class citizens in Canada. **********''You know, he believed in us, and that gives me more pride and confidence, I guess,'' said Pierre Herve, in his 20's, after watching the coffin pass slowly along the Grande Allee, in the heart of the old city. He added, ''We loved the fellow.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/14/busin.main_headline: Market Place; A Bull Market For Gold Bugs
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/14/busin.print_headline: Market Place; A Bull Market For Gold Bugs
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/14/busin.body_text: **********FEW groups of investors have been as estatic over the soaring stock market this year as the gold bugs, who normally view any positive economic news as a disaster. Have the investors in gloom and doom suddenly been converted into optimists? Hardly. Rather, the gold bugs view each record-breaking advance in stock prices as a step closer to the inevitable end of the bull market. **********When that happens, the gold bugs expect a mass flight of capital out of ''paper stores of value'' and into such tangible assets as precious metals. **********Some of this thinking has also gained adherents among institutional stock portfolio managers, who have increasingly been using gold futures as well as options on these contracts this year to hedge, or insure, against a market correction. **********Many metals market analysts say this is why gold, silver and platinum soared with the stock market in the first quarter; soured when equity prices meandered aimlessly in the second quarter, and then rebounded with the record advances of stocks during the current quarter. **********While this theory seemed to be contradicted by yesterday's drop in precious metals prices as the Dow Jones industrial average reached yet another high, brokers said the decline in gold, silver and platinum largely reflected light profit taking by managed commodity funds whose trading strategy is determined by computer. **********''Until recently, it was assumed that the stock and precious metals markets generally had to move in opposite directions,'' said Jeffrey M. Christian, whose CPM Group Ltd. serves as consultants on the precious metals markets to Goldman, Sachs & Company. ''This was never a hard and fast rule. Similarly, the fact that precious metals have tended to move in tandem with the stock market does not mean the gold bugs have had any change of heart.'' **********Rather, Mr. Christian said, this year's odd linkage between the stock and precious metals markets ''can be explained by the belief held by an increasing number of stock investors here and abroad that it may be prudent to own some gold as a hedge. This view has become more pronounced as the stock market took off into uncharted heights this year. The preferred hedging medium of the institutional portfolio managers has been options on gold futures, while the gold bugs still favor owning physical metal in the form of bullion coins or bars.'' **********Any increase in prices and activity of gold options and futures serves to bolster the physical market in bullion. Another and quite unexpected factor that supported gold in the first quarter was the sudden explosion in silver prices after seven years of decline. **********''We tend to think that silver prices followed gold and not the other way around,'' Mr. Christian said. ''Similarly, the upturn in platinum prices in recent weeks has also put a strong plank under gold prices.'' **********Aside from the gold bugs who expect a stock market debacle and the institutional portfolio managers who are simply hedging against a more modest correction, precious metals prices have also benefited from strong technical factors. **********The current upward cycle in gold began in March 1985, when the spot price fell to $282 an ounce, Mr. Christian noted. That was the metal's lowest level since the record high of $850 reached on Jan. 21, 1980. Spot gold closed at $458 yesterday, up $56 an ounce since the start of 1987. **********By comparison, spot silver, which hit a record high of $50.35, also on Jan. 21, 1980, reached a low of just under $5 last summer, traded at $5.43 at the start of this year and closed yesterday at $7.65. Platinum's record price of $1,050 an ounce was posted in early March 1980; its low since then was $250 set in March 1985. Platinum traded yesterday at $620, compared with $470 at the start of 1987. **********The strike by South African gold miners, which began last Sunday, has had only a minimal effect on the gold market so far, in part because there is no shortage of gold. The gold chain that someone will buy today may contain metal mined a few months or a few centuries ago. The strike has not interrupted the flow of gold into the market, or the rate at which the metal is absorbed by industrial users, investors and financial institutions. **********Fred R. Demler, metals analyst at Drexel Burnham Lambert, also noted that the output of gold from new and old mines in North America, Australia and other regions has been rising steadily each year, while South African mine production and ore qualities have been declining. Before the strike, South Africa had been expected to produce about a third of the 1987 global mine output of 1,800 metric tons of 32,150 ounces each.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/19/busin.main_headline: Crude Oil, Off Sharply, Rallies to Close Higher
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/19/busin.print_headline: FUTURES/OPTIONS; Crude Oil, Off Sharply, Rallies to Close Higher
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/19/busin.body_text: **********Crude oil futures took a roller-coaster ride today on the New York Mercantile Exchange, posting sharp losses early, then recovering to close higher in a late rally, traders said. **********December crude finished 24 cents higher, at $18.64 a barrel, but earlier it had been down 35 cents, at $18.05. A late-day buying wave swept through the market in the final 30 minutes of trading, bolstering prices. **********''Most of the buying was short-covering, buying back of positions sold earlier, after December crude traded down to $18.05, near technical support,'' said Carol DiNicolo, an oil futures specialist at GPR Inc. Oil Report Called 'a Surprise' **********December crude oil dropped to its lowest level since mid-April following Tuesday's report by the American Petroleum Institute that United States crude oil and heating oil supplies had increased in the already oversupplied market. **********''The A.P.I. report was extremely bearish because no one expected a build in distillate stocks,'' said Linda Simard, an oil futures broker at E.D. & F. Man International. ''It took everyone by surprise.'' **********But technical traders, who interpret charts of price movements, saw buy signals in the steep losses and rallied the market in late afternoon. **********December heating oil closed 0.26 cent lower, at 54.94 cents a gallon, while December unleaded gasoline closed 0.31 cent higher, at 49.40 cents a gallon. Lumber Futures Down **********Lumber futures closed sharply lower at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange as the January contract finished down $4.70, at $171.20 per 1,000 board feet. **********Prices slumped in reaction to a report that United States housing starts fell 8.2 percent in October, the largest decline since August 1984. **********Tight supplies of physical copper continued to support futures prices as Comex copper closed with strong gains. The December delivery rose 3.80 cents, to 103.90 cents a pound.
