https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/06/world.main_headline: U.S. Denies a Report Of Meeting With Iran
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/06/world.print_headline: U.S. Denies a Report Of Meeting With Iran
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/06/world.body_text: **********A State Department official tonight described as ''completely inaccurate'' a British newspaper report asserting that American and Iranian Government officials met secretly in Swtizerland last week to discuss the Persian Gulf. **********The Observer newspaper reported the meeting in its early Sunday edition, which attributed the account to a ''well-placed Iranian source.'' **********''We have checked into the report and there is nothing to it,'' a State Department official said. ''It is without foundation.'' **********The newspaper reported that the American delegation included advisers to Vice President Bush and Secretary of State George P. Shultz. The Iranian delegation was said to have been led by Mohsen Rafsanjani, son of the Hashemi Rafsanjani, the Speaker of the Iranian Parliament. **********The Observer also said that the delegations discussed American hostages in Lebanon and prospects for closer relations between the two countries.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/18/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Wells Fargo Fee Settlement
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/18/busin.body_text: **********A judge has approved a settlement in which Wells Fargo & Company has agreed to partly refund bounced-check fees to thousands of customers. The settlement also calls for the bank to provide $1 million for consumer education in financial management, and allows the bank to raise its $10 charge for overdrafts next year. **********The settlement also applies to customers of the Crocker Bank, which Wells Fargo acquired last year. The class-action suit was filed 10 years ago by customers who contended the bank was overcharging them for checks drawn on insufficient funds. Similar suits have since been filed against every major bank in California. **********Under the settlement, customers who lacked overdraft protection, and can document charges dating to 1973, can apply for a 30 percent refund of the amount paid. All customers can apply for an $18 credit to cover a year's annual fee on a credit card that includes overdraft protection. A Wells Fargo spokesman said the bank would not specify the total amount to be paid in refunds.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/14/busin.body_text: **********Eastern Airlines is turning its famous and profitable shuttle into an autonomous division with its own budget, work force, fleet and management, an Eastern official said yesterday. **********Some analysts interpreted the step as a way to permit Frank Lorenzo, chairman of the Texas Air Corporation, to sell the shuttle or put it under the control of Texas Air, Eastern's parent company. **********Edward Starkman, an airline analyst at Paine Webber, said the step was a means of ''positioning'' the shuttle for disposal. He added that it was another signal to Eastern's unions that if management did not get cost reductions it would dispose of more of the airline's assets. Controls Landing Slots **********Mr. Starkman said that if the shuttle was put on the block a number of airlines would be interested in it because it controls many landing slots at La Guardia Airport and at National Airport in Washington. Slots are difficult to obtain at both airports. **********In addition, the shuttle is one of Eastern's more profitable operations, ferrying thousands of passengers daily between Logan Airport in Boston and La Guardia and National with hourly flights. **********Mr. Lorenzo, who won control of Eastern last fall, is waging a bitter struggle with the carrier's unions over cost reductions and has said that Eastern's assets would be deployed elsewhere if an agreement could not be reached. **********The company announced on Wednesday that it was eliminating 3,500 jobs to cut costs. Better Performance Predicted **********John W. Nelson, vice president of marketing at Eastern, said the steps to turn the shuttle into an airline within an airline were taken to improve its performance and its ability to compete. **********He said that the shuttle's customers would continue to see improvements, such as roomier seats, but that they would have no sense that an autonomous division was being formed. **********Mr. Nelson said the shuttle's pattern of hourly flights made it different from the airline's other operations. ''This has to operate somewhat like a clock,'' he said. ''It makes all the sense to manage it more closely.'' **********Mr. Nelson also said that since the shuttle operates in such dense markets and has competition from Pan Am, ''it was deserving of some special attention.'' **********He said that John Siefert, who became vice president of the shuttle division in August, would have autonomy to develop the strategy and business plan for the shuttle. Mr. Siefert is to report to Joseph B. Leonard, executive vice president and chief operating officer of Eastern. **********In most ways the shuttle will act independently of Eastern. In heavy maintenance of its planes, for example, it will now contract the work to Eastern, making payments to it.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/22/busin.body_text: **********Seeking to bolster its profits, the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company has begun charging a fee for withdrawals made through its cash machines and, according to banking industry officials, has planned to dismiss 2,500 employees by the end of March. **********John F. McGillicuddy, the bank's chairman, last week told senior officials about those layoffs, about 9 percent of the work force, according to analysts and officials at other banks. Since September 1986, the bank has reduced its work force by 2,900 people. Manufacturers would not confirm the reports. **********Manufacturers is not alone in cutting staff. In September, Chemical Bank announced it would dismiss 2,000 people, roughly 10 percent of its staff. And in November, Citibank cut 1,000 jobs in New York alone. Analysts said all the banks are reacting to a shrinking loan market and intense competition from foreign banks. Impact of Charges **********Many other banks have turned to their automatic teller machines as a source of revenue. Nationwide, about a third of all banks that have such machines charge a fee for withdrawals. Deposits and requests for balances are generally not assessed a fee.  Manufacturers Hanover, in a letter to customers several weeks ago, said that a fee of 25 cents a withdrawal would be assessed if the combined average monthly balance in savings and checking accounts was less than $1,000. A customer could also avoid the charges by maintaining a combined balance of at least $2,000 in all his or her accounts, including certificates of deposit. Whether the charges will deter the bank's customers from frequent use of the machines is not yet clear. **********Executives at other banks, who asked not to be named, said they expected to soon begin charging New Yorkers 25 to 75 cents to make cash withdrawals from automatic tellers. Consumer Groups Object **********When automatic teller machines were introduced nearly a decade ago, they were hailed by bankers as a watershed technology that would lower the cost of banking and allow banks to postpone charging consumers for the rising costs of banking services. **********Consumer groups have condemned the imposition of fees on the use of the machines, noting that they discriminate against customers with lower balances. **********''We oppose it vehemently,'' said Elgie Holstein, director of Bankcard Holders of America, a Washington-based public-interest group. ''Having suckered in sufficient numbers of consumers to use these machines, the banks propose to sock people with additional costs to patronize them.'' **********Citibank, one of the first big banks in America to use automatic tellers and one of the biggest boosters of the concept, went so far as to force certain low-balance consumers to use automatic tellers. That experiment was abandoned when consumers revolted. But Citibank has charged fees all along for cash machine use by low-deposit customers. Charges at Chase **********After Citibank, Manufacturers Hanover is the third large New York City bank to charge its customers for cash withdrawals from automatic tellers. Chase Manhattan tried the idea earlier this year, then switched to a flat monthly charge of $10 for customers with low balances. **********Around the country, where similar fees have been imposed, bankers are facing growing consumer discontent. But the initial indications are that they plan to continue the charges. **********While the cost of operating the machines is a fraction of what it costs to train and pay tellers, the banks still bear operating costs. **********For example, the machines must be filled with money, operators must be hired to handle customer inquiries, and the vestibules where the machines are situated must be heated, air-conditioned and cleaned. Unprofitable Accounts **********The charges imposed reflect ''the cost of the machines and the unprofitability of the low-balance accounts,'' said Robert Hutchinson, a senior vice president at Manufacturers. **********The Marine Midland Bank and Chase Manhattan charge 75 cents a withdrawal in upstate New York when their customers withdraw money from their accounts using machines in other banks - which are tied together in several networks. Other banks, like Chemical, allow customers of low-cost checking programs to make a number of free automatic-teller withdrawals and then charge 75 cents a withdrawal. **********When pay-per-use does become standard at New York City cash machines, bankers said, it will probably be similar to fee arrangements set up in recent years for checking accounts. That is, just as customers who maintain high balances get free checking, high-balance customers will not pay for automatic tellers. **********By comparison, customers who maintain lower balances - who typically pay for checking at present - will begin paying to use the automatic teller. Withdrawals from cash machines, in short, will be treated like writing a check. Pitfalls of the NYCE System **********If the issue is just now reaching a culmination, one reason is the so-called New York Cash Exchange. Better known as the NYCE system, this network of 4,500 automatic tellers in 18 states has been a blockbuster success, allowing large New York City banks to compete more effectively against Citibank, which has its own proprietary teller-machine network. The systems allows consumers to get cash day and night at thousands of locations. **********For many banks, however, participation in NYCE has proved costly. Because the machines seem to be everywhere, many customers have begun to make smaller and more frequent withdrawals. Although the average NYCE withdrawal is $66, many customers have taken to withdrawing $20 here, $20 there in a daily regimen that bankers said had become extremely costly to them. **********Banks pay a fee of 13 cents to 19 cents whenever one of their customers withdraws money from the machines of another bank under the NYCE system. Some banks pay the fee to the bank whose machine is used, while other banks pay the fee to NYCE. **********For instance, Chemical pays Chase if a Chemical customer uses a Chase machine. But Chemical would not receive a fee if a Chase customer used a Chemical machine. The fee would go to the NYCE system. This disparity is leading many banks to consider imposing charges. **********''Customers don't care which machines they use, and for some banks it can be a hefty cost,'' said an analyst at one of the major New York City banks.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/22/busin.body_text: **********Fuji Heavy Industries Ltd., the Japanese maker of Subaru automobiles, said today that it had formed a company to sell American-made products in Japan. **********The Subaru World Trading Company will operate at first through 70 Subaru dealerships in Japan. Later, it will expand to 1,000 outlets, offering catalogues from at least 10 United States mail-order firms, the company said. **********Products available through the network will include gifts, novelties, sporting goods and fitness equipment. https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/09/busin.print_headline: MARKET PLACE; MUTUAL FUNDS LOOK TO BRITAIN
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/09/busin.body_text: **********MUTUAL FUNDS that invest overseas find it virtually impossible to ignore Japan, since that nation accounts for 51 percent of the total equity capitalization of foreign markets. Moreover, Japan has provided handsome profits.  On a relative basis, however, some funds have been placing greater stress lately on investments in Britain, where market capitalization is only one-fourth that of Japan. **********At the end of 1986 the $100 million Transatlantic Growth Fund had 41.2 percent of its assets in Japanese securities. **********''Since that time, we have trimmed commitments across the board, so that the Japanese portion of the portfolio is now 31 percent,'' Henry B. W. de Vismes, president of the fund, said in London. ''During this period, we increased our stake in British companies from 13.5 percent to 22 percent. Among other things, we became concerned with the rising unemployment in Japan.'' **********Last week the Government announced in Tokyo that Japan's unemployment rate rose in January to 3 percent of the labor force - the highest level since monthly reporting began in 1953. **********Since this year began, the T. Rowe Price International Fund, with assets of $883 million, has kept Japanese holdings at 30 percent of its portfolio. **********''But we have become more aggressive toward investments in Britain,'' said George Murnaghan, a vice president of the Baltimore-based fund. ''At present Britain accounts for about 20 percent of the portfolio - up from 12.1 percent at the end of December. Our view of the Japanese market is that its stocks should not be trading at 50 times estimated earnings for 1987.'' **********The $750 million Scudder International Fund also is relatively underweighted in Japan, where the fund's 25 percent commitment remains about the same as one year ago. Meanwhile, its holdings in Britain climbed to 14 percent from 8 percent. **********''One attraction of the British market is that the political environment increasingly seems to be favoring the Conservative Party,'' said Herve van Caloen, who manages the European portion of the Scudder fund's portfolio. **********Scudder International's major holdings there include Burton Group, a retailing company, and I.C.I., the giant chemical producer, along with Rio-Tinto-Zinc, a mining company. Scudder's holdings in Japan range from Fanuc, a manufacturer of robots, to Sony and Nippon Electronics. **********Stock markets in the United States, Japan and Britain all shared one thing in common last week: They advanced to record highs. **********Last year Japan experienced its lowest rate of economic growth in the 1980's, and profits at the manufacturing level are estimated to have dropped by one-third. Japan's export-oriented industries, with their work force reductions reflected in the nation's unemployment rate, came under pressure because of the yen's sharp rise against the dollar in the last 18 months. **********Why, then, has the Japanese stock market been toppling records? ''The reason is an excess of savings over the level of investment that was channeled into the stock market,'' explained Mr. de Vismes of the Transatlantic Growth Fund. ''In effect, there was no other local alternative outlet.'' **********His fund concentrated its investments in domestic Japanese sectors, emphasizing housing, construction and merchandising companies that stood to benefit from efforts to stimulate the economy. **********In Europe, the strong currencies of West Germany, the Netherlands and Switzerland are working to the advantage of Britain, according to Mr. de Vismes. His fund has added B.A.T. Industries and Rank Organization while increasing its investment in British stocks already in the portfolio. **********''We prefer to invest in economies where we see strong earnings momentum, and that situation often occurs when a nation's currency is weak against its trading partners,'' said Mr. Murnaghan of T. Rowe Price International. **********In Britain, the Price fund's major positions include Reed International (publishing), Metal Box (container manufacturer) and De La Rue (printer of bank notes), along with British Aerospace. **********All money managers, of course, do not operate with the same strategy. Wallace Wormley of the $570 million Prudential Bache Global Fund is free to invest anywhere in the world. His two largest country commitments are Japan - 35 percent -and the United States - 30 percent. And with good reason: ''I manage aggressively,'' he said, ''and this generally means utilizing markets that are very big and very liquid.'' **********But even Mr. Wormley has increased his British holdings over the past year to 17 percent from 5 percent of the portfolio. His two largest stock positions are Digital Equipment and Apple Computer.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/16/world.body_text: **********Soviet television broadcast an interview today with Secretary of State George P. Shultz, in which he defended American arms positions, complained about Soviet espionage and criticized the Soviet presence in Afghanistan. **********In the 30-minute interview, with Valentin Zorin, a well-known commentator, Mr. Shultz said that his visit had improved chances for an arms accord and that the United States wanted to live with the Soviet Union in peace. But occasionally, he parried pointed questions from Mr. Zorin. **********Mr. Shultz's remarks were faithfully translated, until he began talking about Afghan resistance. He had raised the issue by saying that the Soviet military intervention was an illustration of why Americans mistrusted the Russians. **********''We cannot understand that,'' he said. ''Afghanistan is no threat.'' **********The remark was translated, as was his comment that the Soviet Union had 120,000 troops in Afghanistan, a figure rarely mentioned in the Soviet Union. **********But the translation halted as he said of the Afghans: ''It has been a devastating war. They don't want you there. They want peace with you, but they don't want you occupying their country.'' **********Although the Soviet press has become more open in discussing the war, most Afghans are being described as welcoming the Soviet troops. **********When Mr. Zorin asked about ''spy mania'' in Washington, Mr. Shultz said the new embassy compound here was riddled with eavesdropping devices. **********''I don't know what it is going to take to fix that building,'' he said, and complained of Soviet efforts to penetrate embassy security. **********Mr. Zorin said the espionage dispute seemed to be part of a pattern of disrupting relations just when arms control talks were warming up. **********Mr. Shultz responded that the Soviet side had played a role in disturbing relations, and he mentioned the arrest last year of Nicholas Daniloff, the American reporter, on spying charges. **********When Mr. Zorin asked whether Mr. Shultz was under attack from others within the Reagan Administration for his positions on arms control, he said the fact he was in Moscow showed he had President Reagan's support. **********Soviet television, as part of the greater openness under Mikhail S. Gorbachev, has been giving Western leaders relatively uncensored access. Last month Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher jousted with three interviewers for 50 minutes, giving a Western view of the Soviet military threat that must have astonished viewers. **********Her interview provoked so much public comment that one of the interviewers wrote an article in the weekly newspaper Moscow News conceding that she had got the better of the exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/08/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Kaiser Steel Settles With Shareholders
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/08/busin.body_text: **********The Kaiser Steel Corporation said today that Bruce E. Hendry, a Minneapolis investor, would be elected chairman and chief executive of the company as part of a settlement between Kaiser's management and a dissident group of preferred shareholders. **********The settlement ends a fierce battle for control of the troubled company's board, which will be expanded to nine members to include Mr. Hendry and two of the shareholder group's other nominees. Kaiser, based in Fontana, Calif., also announced that a lawsuit filed against Mr. Hendry, charging him with violating Federal securities laws, would be dropped, along with other litigation associated with the board elections. **********As chairman, Mr. Hendry will replace Monty H. Rial, who will remain on the board. Charles S. McNeil will remain as president and chief operating officer but will be dropped from the board. Mr. Rial and other Kaiser executives control the steel and coal company's common stock through the closely held Perma Resources Corporation, a mining concern in Colorado Springs. **********Mr. Rial has been charged by some preferred shareholders with questionable dealings involving Kaiser and other companies in which he has an interest. But Jeffrey Desautels, a Kaiser spokesman, said that the transactions in question had been reviewed by outside auditors, who rendered fairness opinions. **********Mr. Hendry and his supporters won the right to elect a majority to Kaiser's board after the company failed to pay two quarterly dividends and missed payments to retire the preferred stock. **********Mr. Rial had said in November that he would resign as chairman if the company-backed slate was elected. But Mr. Hendry's slate of six nominees won the election last month, according to results certified by an independent election inspector. Although the company disputed the results, it began meeting with Mr. Hendry to negotiate a settlement. **********Under the settlement, Kaiser's board will include Mr. Hendry and two colleagues, William K. Dimeling and Lawrence Perlman. It will also include three members from a slate of preferred stock nominees supported by Kaiser's management, as well as Mr. Rial and two directors elected by common stockholders.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/27/busin.snippet: LEAD: The giant fall in stock prices that took individual investors by surprise was also a bolt from the blue to many corporate insiders.
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/27/busin.main_headline:
MARKET TURMOIL;
Few Signs of Prescience By Company Insiders
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/27/busin.print_headline:
MARKET TURMOIL;
Few Signs of Prescience By Company Insiders
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/27/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: The giant fall in stock prices that took individual investors by surprise was also a bolt from the blue to many corporate insiders. **********The giant fall in stock prices that took individual investors by surprise was also a bolt from the blue to many corporate insiders. **********At companies across the business spectrum, the officers, directors and major shareholders - the people defined by law as ''insiders'' - had been substantial buyers of their concerns' shares in the last few months. The buying was particularly noticeable in financially sensitive issues like savings and loan associations, banks and insurance companies. All have suffered substantial declines in the last 10 days. **********For analysts who monitor trading by insiders for clues to investment strategies, the failure of insiders to sound a clear warning of the market selloff is troubling. **********''They completely missed it,'' said Norman G. Fosback, editor of The Insiders, a newsletter published in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Favorable readings on insider buying had led Mr. Fosback to run the headline ''Bullish -Bullish - Bullish'' in the letter of Oct. 16, the day the market suffered its first 100-point decline.A Bearish Reading **********The Vickers Weekly Insider Report, another newsletter, had found bearish readings in September, as insiders were making three sales for every purchase. It tracks only transactions of 100 or more shares on the exchanges and 500 shares or more in the over-the-counter market. More recent numbers, from the eve of the selloff, were more bullish. **********Investors watch insiders on the theory that the people closest to companies possess the best information about business prospects and on average make the most informed buy and sell decisions on common stocks. **********Whether that theory needs reworking is unclear. If the break in stock prices carries no bad news for business - like the sharp corrections of October 1978 and 1979 - then insiders' apparent optimism on business fundamentals could be vindicated. But if the collapse in stock prices signals major trouble for the economy, as some economists argue, then corporate officers and directors will have been as taken by surprise as other investors were. **********Edwin A. Buck, who edits the Vickers Weekly, called the most recent figures on insider transactions ''very bullish.'' He expected the week ending today to show only about 1.5 insider sales for each purchase, a ratio that traditionally has been positive for the market.A Small Sample **********Mr. Fosback reported a ''sharp acceleration of buying'' in the week just before the collapse, though the sample of reports filed so far by insiders with the Securities and Exchange Commission is very small. By law, insiders have up to 40 days to report their trades. **********''You would have to say this is a good harbinger for the market's long-term health,'' Mr. Fosback said. ''Insiders are fundamentally, not technically, oriented. They see good bullish fundamentals.'' **********Among companies attracting surges of inside buying through late September was Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. At Harcourt, which borrowed heavily this year in a recapitalization to escape a raider, the company's chairman, William Jovanovich, bought 437,000 shares in late September at close to $10. The shares closed yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange at $3.75, down, 87 1/2 cents, near last week's low of $3.625. Two other Harcourt insiders bought a total of about 45,000 shares at about $10. **********''The insiders are telling us the economy is great,'' said Mr. Buck of the Vickers Weekly. ''They're saying that the things in the headlines - the budget deficit, a weakening dollar, the balance of payments - won't affect the economy that much. They see value and they're buying.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/18/world.body_text: **********ABOARD U.S.S. LA SALLE, in the Persian Gulf, Dec. 17 - Iranian gunboats attacked and set afire a cargo ship flying the Maldivian flag in the Persian Gulf today. An American warship nearby sent observation craft to the scene but did not otherwise become involved in the episode. **********The guided-missile destroyer Chandler, which on Saturday helped rescue crew members from a Cypriot-flagged oil tanker in the same area, sent a helicopter and a small boat to the scene today, but the crew abandoned ship without the American Navy's help. **********Officials on board the La Salle, which is the command ship for American forces operating inside the gulf, said that no assistance was needed. The cargo ship was carrying sulfur from Saudi Arabia out of the gulf, and the crew was able to leave on lifeboats. **********Last Saturday, the oil tanker was spilling flaming fuel into the water, and the crew had to be removed by the Chandler's helicopter and by a helicopter chartered by a CBS News crew filming the episode. **********A few hours after the first attack on the Maldivian cargo ship Island Transporter, the Iranians again opened fire on the ship, on a firefighting salvage tug that had retrieved the crew, and on a CBS News helicopter that was in the area again today. Attention Focused on U.S. Role **********It was not clear where the Chandler was at the time of the second attack. **********The two episodes have drawn renewed attention to the role being played by American warships on patrol in the gulf, where they are allowed to intervene only when American-registered merchant ships or Navy warships are under attack or in imminent danger, or to aid mariners in distress by saving them after attacks. **********According to shipping executives in the gulf, the initial attack on the cargo ship today occurred around dawn, when gunboats approached and fired rocket-propelled grenades at the ship, damaging the ship's crew quarters and starting a fire. **********The Chandler, which was in the area at the time, is believed to have known that the attack was beginning. The Chandler, not the merchant vessel, was first to air a call for assistance on civil maritime frequencies. **********The ship carried a crew of 27, all of whom escaped safely. No injuries were reported in the incident.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/30/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Bilzerian Holds 9.9% Of Singer
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/30/busin.body_text: **********Paul A. Bilzerian, who has made repeated takeover attempts but never ended up owning his targets, disclosed yesterday that he owned 2.1 million shares, or 9.99 percent, of the outstanding common stock of the Singer Company. **********Analysts who did not want to be identified said that Mr. Bilzerian's disclosure had helped drive up the stock price of Singer, a medium-sized military contractor, allowing him to recoup his paper losses on the stock, which they estimated at about $20 million. **********Mr. Bilzerian, who could not be reached for comment, told Reuters that he had paid an average of $43 for each of his Singer shares. He acquired them over the past several months, with half bought in the last 10 days. **********The stock dropped $10, to $34.625, in the market plunge Oct. 19, and continued to fall in later days, meaning Mr. Bilzerian could have suffered heavy losses. Stock Gains $9.75 **********After his announcement yesterday, the stock closed at $42, up $9.75, in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange - a rise that presumably wiped out most of Mr. Bilzerian's losses. **********Mr. Bilzerian said that he would soon decide whether to go ahead with an offer for Singer but that he did not as yet have a financial adviser. He said he had not yet talked with Singer management. **********F. Gordon Bitter, senior vice president and chief financial officer of Singer, said the company would have no immediate comment. **********In the past Mr. Bilzerian has bought large stakes in Cluett, Peabody & Company, the Hammerhill Paper Company, the Allied Stores Corporation and Pay 'N' Pak Stores Inc. In each case another company ended up acquiring the target. The 36-year-old investor ended up with big profits for himself and his partners. An Attractive Target **********If Mr. Bilzerian's aim is to attract a potential buyer for Singer, he chose an excellent company, several analysts said. **********Michael Gardner, the aerospace analyst for Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc., said that Singer would be attractive to about half a dozen aerospace companies and that they might want to assume the role of a friendly suitor brought in to fend off Mr. Bilzerian. **********He said that Singer could add ''little pockets of technology'' to such giants as the Boeing Company, the Lockheed Corporation, the Northrop Corporation, the General Electric Company, the Rockwell International Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation. **********He added that the company was a leader in making navigation and guidance systems and flight simulators and that it had other divisions that could be spun off to offset some of the purchase price. **********Mr. Bilzerian has said he is not interested in managing a company but rather seeks financial control. An Earlier Suitor **********He is not the first to make a pass at Singer. **********T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman, disclosed last August that his Mesa Limited Partnership had bought a 4.4 percent stake in Singer. **********In order to defend itself better against acquisitions, Singer moved its executive offices from Stamford, Conn., to Montvale, N.J. The move was made to seek the protection of a New Jersey law that prevents takeovers from being completed for five years without the approval of the target company's directors. **********The announcement yesterday said that the 9.9 percent stake in Singer was owned by Bilzerian Partners Ltd., a limited partnership made up of Mr. Bilzerian and the Bicoastal Acquisition Corporation, a company wholly owned by Mr. Bilzerian. **********Singer, which for 135 years was known mainly for its sewing machine operations, spun off the division last year. Now, more than 80 percent of its business is related to aerospace.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/20/busin.main_headline: New York City Insures Some of Its New Bonds
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/20/busin.print_headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES; New York City Insures Some of Its New Bonds
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/20/busin.body_text: **********To ease the burden of high interest rates, New York City is making its first use of muncipal bond insurance. The insured bonds, with principal and interest payments guaranteed by two separate firms, are part of a $451.9 million financing announced yesterday. Proceeds of the financing will be used to refund outstanding bonds, producing budget savings of $3.7 million in the current year, $16.2 million next year and $33 million over the life of the new bonds. **********Interest rates announced yesterday by underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company are tentative and may be changed, depending on market conditions. For uninsured bonds, backed only by the city's full faith and credit, yields ranged from 5.40 percent for bonds due in 1988 to 6.75 percent in 1992 and 7.20 percent in 1995. Bonds insured by the Financial Guaranty Insurance Corporation were offered with yields ranging from 7 percent in 1996 to 7.70 percent in 1999. **********Among bonds with longer maturities, yields for uninsured bonds ranged from 8 percent in 2000 to about 8.65 percent in 2010. Bonds due in 2004 through 2006 were insured by Bond Investors Guaranty Inc. and were offered with yields of about 8.25 percent. **********The insured bonds, which are popular with some individual buyers and certain tax-exempt mutual bond funds, have top-notch ratings of triple A from Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation. Bonds backed only by the city's full faith and credit are expected to carry medium-grade ratings of Baa-1 by Moody's and BBB+ by S.&P. **********City officials said they had decided to buy insurance for some of the bonds to broaden the market for them. Bond insurance is widely used by other local governments around the country. **********The willingness of insurance companies to back New York City debt is one more sign of the financial community's increasing confidence in the city's ability and willingness to repay its debt. A few years ago, when securities dealers were considering using insurance for city bonds, one major insurer said it would not write a policy for the city.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/08/world.main_headline: Webster Takes A Strong Hold As C.I.A. Chief
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/08/world.print_headline: Webster Takes A Strong Hold As C.I.A. Chief
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/08/world.body_text: **********William H. Webster has moved to assert himself in his first three months as Director of Central Intelligence, tightening control over covert actions and ending a system under which some officials bypassed superiors to report directly to his predecessor, according to Reagan Administration officials. **********Since replacing William J. Casey, who died May 6, Mr. Webster has set up a committee of senior agency officials to review proposed covert actions to make sure that all viewpoints are considered before recommendations come to him. Significantly, the panel is headed by an official outside the agency's clandestine service. **********But Mr. Webster has not yet made any startling personnel changes at the C.I.A., and officials there are still anxiously studying his every move for clues to the direction he plans to set. 'Making Some Subtle Changes' **********According to knowledgeable officials, Mr. Webster, who was formerly Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, wants to continue in his new job after the next President takes office 16 months from now. That gives him, as a Presidential appointee, a relatively short time to build a record attractive to either a Democrat or a Republican. **********''He has been quietly and deliberately making some subtle changes that do not upset the apple cart but have the effect of changing the place,'' said Robert M. Gates, Deputy Director of Central Intelligence. **********Despite some urging from Capitol Hill, Mr. Webster has decided to move slowly in replacing any of the senior officials about whom questions were raised in the Congressional investigations of the Iran-contra affair. He has appointed a special counsel to review the agency's role in the affair and has said he will make no decisions until he receives a report. **********Several intelligence officials said Mr. Webster had shown his independence from the White House early on, with the development of the Persian Gulf policy. The C.I.A.'s analysts, officials said, regarded Iran's threat to respond to the American escort operation more seriously than others. Mr. Webster was a forceful advocate of his agency's position, even though it undercut Administration policy. **********''That immediately conveyed that he was going to protect the independence and integrity of his analysts' judgments,'' an intelligence official said. **********Some officials said Mr. Webster was not opposed to covert operations and that such operations, including support for the Angolan rebels, were continuing. But it is clear that Mr. Webster wants to address one criticism of the agency that emerged from the Iran-contra investigations: that covert actions were initiated without a thorough review of the consequences. **********Mr. Webster's approach, officials say, includes a more rigorous assessment before a covert action is begun and more frequent reviews of operations in progress. **********While most officials with knowledge of the C.I.A. spoke favorably of Mr. Webster's first few months, he has some critics. They point to the fact that he has already taken some time off from work, among other things. **********Some of them suggested that he was paying too much attention to the trappings of office, noting that one of his first moves was to obtain a long-range jet for the C.I.A. that could be used for trips by its senior officials. **********But, Bill Baker, director of public affairs for the C.I.A., said the agency had operational uses for the aircraft. **********As for his work record, Mr. Baker said the Director often began his day with a 7:30 breakfast and left for home late in the evening. ''Whenever you get a new guy in an organization, you get a lot of tea-leaf reading,'' he said. ''That can lead to mis-impressions.'' A Change in Supervision **********The part of the agency most deeply implicated in the Iran-contra affair was the operations directorate, supervised by Clair George. One directorate official, Alan Fiers, acknowledged that he had remained silent while others in the Administration gave Congressional testimony he knew to be misleading. Two agency officials in Central America, the Costa Rica station chief and chief of base in Honduras, have acknowledged to C.I.A. investigators that they initially lied about their ties to the Nicaraguan rebels. **********Under Mr. Casey, Mr. Fiers, chief of the agency's Central America task force, reported to the Director, bypassing several levels of managers. Under Mr. Webster, Mr. Fiers is supervised through the normal chain of command. **********Mr. Webster has said he will make no decisions about what to do with the operations directorate officials mentioned in the Iran-contra investigations until he receives recommendations from Russell J. Bruemmer, the special counsel he named to study the matter. **********Disclosures during the Iran-contra affair about the operations division have almost guaranteed that Mr. Webster will be watching it more closely, a task that may prove difficult. The F.B.I., which Mr. Webster headed for nine years, has a long history of elevating decisions to the desk of the Director. On the other hand, the C.I.A.'s directors have, in the words of a former senior agency official, found that to penetrate a culture where secrecy is deeply rooted, they needed to be ''entrepreneurial'' in finding out what was being done in their name. **********Administration officials said Mr. Webster had taken a greater personal role than did Mr. Casey in examining the intricacies of the C.I.A. operations. **********''He wants to know what's going on a day-to-day basis,'' one official said. **********Congressional and Administration officials say Mr. Webster will need to steer a narrow course. But he needs to take some decisive actions after the Iran-contra affair to win the support of the Congressional intelligence committees and avoid more sweeping restrictions proposed by lawmakers. **********And, they said, if he moves too quickly, he risks damaging morale at an agency buffetted by both the Iran-contra investigations and some well-publicized failures in recent years. **********One possible clue to his actions in the next year can be found in 1978, when he took over the F.B.I. 'He Would Not Be Stampeded' **********The bureau had been subjected to several years of bad publicity over its involvement in domestic surveillance and break-ins. Early in his tenure, Attorney General Griffin B. Bell sent Mr. Webster a list of 68 agents involved in possible wrongdoing and subject to discipline or dismissal. **********As the months went by, Mr. Webster came under increasing pressure to make a decision. ''He would not be stampeded,'' recalled Lee Colwell, a Webster aide at the time. ''He was very concerned that we deal with facts, and not stories in the newspaper.'' **********In the end, Mr. Webster announced that he would dismiss two supervisors and give letters of censure to two others. He later reversed his decision on one of the supervisors, taking into account his cooperation with Justice Department investigators. **********As for the field agents involved, Mr. Webster announced in December 1978 that it would be ''counterproductive and unfair'' to punish agents for following orders they believed were lawful.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/09/busin.main_headline: Market Place; The Setbacks In Retail Sector
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/09/busin.print_headline: Market Place; The Setbacks In Retail Sector
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/09/busin.body_text: **********THE recent flurry of takeover proposals in the retail industry has proved of fleeting interest to investors. The stocks of three target companies - Dayton Hudson, Zayre and Alexander's - rose on the takeover announcements but have lost value in the last few days. **********And some analysts are not so sure the declines are simply the result of an underlying caution about the takeover efforts. With the national retail chains reporting their September results yesterday, Monroe Greenstein, analyst for Bear, Stearns & Company, said: ''The market's attitude, besides its caution about the bids being made, is based on sluggish retail sales. September's sales weren't bad at all but if you combine them with August, they do not appear strong. This means that the current third-quarter earnings will be coming down for some of the big companies.'' **********As for the merger pitfalls, Mr. Greenstein said: ''Look at Dayton Hudson. After the Hafts raised their bid to $68 a share from $65, the market dumped on the stock, so that now it's down $10 a share.'' This seemed to show that the market did not think the Hafts could be successful. **********Mr. Greenstein said he did not think that the decline in retail stocks was the result of a general Wall Street downturn. ''Retailing stocks tend to underperform the market as a whole,'' he said. ''And when you combine that with disappointment over sales and the way such retailing highfliers as The Gap and The Limited have tumbled, you have some big declines in the retail sector.'' **********Mr. Greenstein said that the August-September sales figures show ''there is some backup of fall inventories.'' He added: ''Stores overbought on sweaters and now they've got them up to their eyeballs. But what they really want are lots more acid-wash miniskirts and jackets. No one wants all those sweaters and everyone wants the acid-wash stuff.'' **********Yet with all the skepticism over the takeovers, there is a sense among analysts that new efforts will soon be made. The Hafts are seeking a proxy fight to oust Dayton Hudson's board, which had rejected the original $65 bid and the $3-a-share increase earlier this week. The company told analysts that it wanted to remain independent and had no interest either in restructuring or recapitalizing. It now appears that two determined forces are maneuvering for new positions. **********Some of the skepticism about the merger proposals is based on the strength of the targets. ''You have to question why the Hafts think they could or should acquire a well-established company like Dayton Hudson, which has done so many things to improve its businesses,'' said Arthur B. Britten, a New York retailing management consultant. ''Most likely if the Hafts succeed, they will break up the company, which would pay for all the money and trouble it took. That would be typical these days and that's why Dayton Hudson will fight it.'' William N. Smith, an analyst for Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, said: ''The market has been trashing the retail stocks and tarring all companies with the same brush. Some companies are doing very nicely. **********''As to Dayton Hudson, the general investors have soured on both the seriousness of the Hafts and also on their ability to finance their $68-a-share offer. Nonetheless, the Hafts seem to be more serious about acquiring Dayton Hudson than they have in the past. But the financing of the $68 bid makes it all seem pretty rich, maybe too rich.'' Dayton Hudson's stock fell $1 yesterday, to $58, on the New York Stock Exchange. **********The other takeover moves, at the Zayre Corporation and Alexander's Inc., developed earlier this week. Edward J. DeBartolo Jr., a leading shopping-center developer, informed Zayre that he planned to add at least another 78,000 shares to his undisclosed kitty of Zayre common. Yesterday, Maurice Segall, Zayre's chairman and chief executive, said, ''I have neither heard from Mr. DeBartolo on the phone or received any more letters from him.'' Zayre's stock dropped $1 yesterday, to $32.50. **********As for Alexander's, the situation seems to have stabilized. Donald J. Trump, the developer, and Interstate Properties Inc., another developer, said on Wednesday that they had agreed for a year to act jointly in buying or selling the 43 percent interest in the common stock of Alexander's that they hold together. **********A few days before, when they appeared to be moving to compete with one another for the 15-store chain that holds valuable real estate, the stock rose. But with their new friendship, the stock fell for two consecutive days. It closed yesterday at $54.50, down $1.875.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/08/busin.body_text: **********IS the current international economic and security system, the ''Pax Americana,'' still ''robust,'' as the Japanese economist, Masahiro Sakamoto, maintains, despite unstable exchange rates, huge trade imbalances, enormous world debts, sluggish growth and persistent overcapacity and unemployment? **********Or do these severe strains mean, as Paul Streeten, professor emeritus at Oxford and Boston Universities argues, that the ''Pax Americana,'' established at the end of World War II, is breaking down and needs to be replaced by a new international order? **********Mr. Streeten, who spoke this week at Harvard University, proposes some key institutions for a safer and more effective international system: *********** An international central bank capable of creating liquidity and global reserves at a pace that would be neither inflationary nor deflationary. *********** An international income tax that would be levied automatically and progressively on all countries. *********** An international body to provide information for private and public decisions on long-term investments in plant and equipment, to help prevent lurches from scarcity to excess capacity in steel, shipbuilding or other industries. *********** An international investment trust, to channel capital from rich surplus countries to the developing countries. **********Mr. Streeten thinks it is foolish, in a world desperately short of capital, to urge Japan to cut its savings, increase its consumption and invest more at home. **********Could such an organization be kept from becoming a bureaucratic monstrosity? Recognizing that ''the stupidity of an organization is proportional to the cube of the number of its members,'' Mr. Streeten suggests establishing a ''council of wise men and women'' to monitor the system. **********The greatest obstacle to establishing the sort of system that Mr. Streeten proposes would, of course, be the surrender of some national sovereignty and the transfer of sufficient power to the decision makers who would manage the system. **********As difficult as that problem is on economic and financial matters, it would be even harder in the national security area. To be sure, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization exists as a military arm of Pax Americana. But, both within and outside NATO, Pax Americana, as military-cum-economic system, has depended on the willingness of the United States to assume the role of leader or ''hegemon,'' as Britain did in the century from the end of the Napoleonic wars until World War I. The Pax Britannica broke down because of the excessive burdens on the hegemon. **********Yet, despite the heavy burdens that some economists, including Mr. Streeten, fear are causing the Pax Americana to break down, the United States retains its hegemonic power. **********Why is this? Part of the explanation may be America's well-established habit of leadership, its dominance in nuclear arms, its heavy scientific and technological outlays and the preference of Japan, West Germany and other countries that the United States keep its military and economic responsibilities, for the sake of their own security and that of the system as a whole. **********Part of the reason why the existing system survives may indeed be the great difficulty of constructing a system reliable enough to take its place, in the face of the continuing threat from the Soviet Union. **********However, there are ironies in America's retention or even increase in its power, despite its apparent economic weaknesses. **********America's attributes as dominant power appear unique in the history of hegemonies. In the past, as Professor Streeten noted, the dominant nation has had four attributes: an export surplus, a capital surplus, industrial dominance and great military power. But America is retaining its hegemonic power, not in spite of its loss of the first three attributes, but because it has become the biggest trade deficit country, the biggest consumer of foreign goods, the biggest net capital importer - ''the borrower of last resort.'' As enormous importer and borrower, America has become crucial to the operation of the world economy. **********But the extremely high levels of United States trade deficits and capital imports, which have sustained the Pax Americana in the 1980's, may not be able to go on much longer, as America's foreign debts rise higher and higher. The shakiness of financial markets today, in the realization of United States dependence on continued capital inflow, have caused widespread anxieties that the tremors could cause the walls of the existing system to crumble. Can the system be reconstructed? One way out would be to combine the sort of new international institutions Mr. Streeten proposes with continued American leadership that Mr. Sakamoto and other Japanese, as well as the Europeans favor, especially in the military area. **********But to keep the system stable, the United States may have to reduce its economic burdens, and that will depend on the willingness of other countries to assume a greater share of the costs - and on the outcome of arms negotiations with the Soviet Union. **********The Russians have been carrying a military burden proportionately twice as great as the United States in relation to gross national product and would also like, as Mikhail Gorbachev has made clear, to reduce its military burdens to relieve the strains on its economy.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/02/world.main_headline: Democrats Fail in Senate Bid To Delay U.S. Escorts in Gulf
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/02/world.print_headline: Democrats Fail in Senate Bid To Delay U.S. Escorts in Gulf
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/02/world.body_text: **********Senate Democrats tried to win support today for a resolution seeking a delay in President Reagan's Persian Gulf escort plans, but Republicans successfully blocked the attempt. **********The nonbinding resolution would have criticized President Reagan's plan to protect 11 Kuwaiti tankers by reregistering them so they could have American captains and flags, and thus be escorted in convoys protected by the United States Navy. **********The resolution said ''the proposed reflagging of Kuwaiti tankers should be placed in abeyance'' until all diplomatic efforts had been exhausted. Those should include a conference of major buyers and sellers of Persian Gulf oil and United Nations-sponsored efforts to end the Iran-Iraq war.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/26/world.main_headline: THE JEANS SHOOPE ADN BUSY BUTIKS OF VACI STREET
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/26/world.print_headline: BUDAPEST JOURNAL; THE JEANS SHOOPE ADN BUSY BUTIKS OF VACI STREET
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/26/world.body_text: **********Janos Kadar, for 30 years the leader of the Communist Party, is so proud of Vaci Street that last year he took his guest, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, for a walk along it to show him the smiling face of Hungarian consumerism. **********There is no better symbol of what one of Mr. Gorbachev's predecessors, Nikita S. Khrushchev, on a similar visit to this country, called goulash Communism than this pedestrians-only shopping street in the center of the capital. Vaci Street is where a Communist Government has set out to prove that one does not have to be a capitalist to consume like one. To critical Hungarians, the proposition is a long way from valid, in quality more than in quantity, but all concede that Vaci Street puts up a good show. **********Instead of the arid pyramids of cookie boxes, stacks of the unread collected works of Lenin and the national Communist leader or rigidly aligned bolts of gloomy fabrics that fill so many shopwindows in the lands of centralized economies, Vaci Street celebrates Hungarian flair. Elegance Is the Keynote **********The facades of the business houses along the old-established street that parallels the Danube have been refurbished and their Art Nouveau curves given a lift. Such details as street lamps, telephone booths, mailboxes and manhole covers have been expensively recreated to recall a past that makes even young Hungarians nostalgic and Western tourists regret the flashy modernity of their cities. From Vorosmarty Square along four blocks to where Vaci Street meets the approaches of Elizabeth Bridge, old-style elegance is the keynote. **********Gerbeaud, the sumptuous empire-style coffeehouse on the square, has been given its old name, although ''Gerbeaud'' never lost popular currency while the dogmatism of an earlier period effaced it officially. Ageless women still meet of an afternoon for more buttercream torte and coffee submerged under whipped cream than is good for them and to sport hats that flattered them in days gone by. **********From a concert-ticket agency, the shrill sounds of Western rock fills the square, and young Hungarians crowd before its windows to demonstrate rhythmic enthusiasm. A screen vibrates with the latest video clips of a British or American pop star who is scheduled to fill a sports arena to its rafters for a concert appearance. **********The windows of Western airline offices display views of their capitals, Alps or shores that are now accessible to Hungarians. Even Aeroflot, the Soviet airline, graces Vaci Street with an elegantly styled series of windows. #4 Stories of Fashions The modern Fontana department store has four stories of mainly imported fashions of what is the bottom of the line in Austria or Italy. They draw eager shoppers here, despite prices that represent far greater shares of normal earnings than the same items would in the West. A week's wages is the average price for a pair of jeans. **********The outlet of Adidas, the West German sportswear maker, has been besieged by shoppers since it opened last month. The lines are almost as long as those where people wait in hope of a piece of sausage or cheese in the stores of neighboring Rumania. **********But Vaci Street would be much less attractive if it were not for the shops that are hardly visible from the street. Behind almost every building are courtyards full of shops ranging from tiny to small where more or less private entrepreneurs display their wares. **********Even between two of Aeroflot's windows, a sign in an entrance way invites women to Richi Modell boutique, a fashion shop of mini-size. The word ''boutique'' and similar foreign terms that private shop owners use to make their establishments seem jet-set has aroused the anger of Hungarian language purists. They want Hungarian terms or, at a minimum, spellings like ''butik.'' A Basement 'Jeans Shoope' **********This unusual bit of xenophobia in a cosmopolitan nation has not dampened the ardor of one of Vaci Street's real drawing cards, the Blue Man Super Jeans, a basement ''jeans shoope,'' as a sign proclaims. **********Fontana, a state store, also has a foreign name, said Istvan Gomori, Blue Man's manager, so why change a brand name that has become a name to be reckoned with among the young of the Communist countries? **********To the taped sounds of country and western, jeans, denim jackets and overalls, all designed by the seven-member cooperative that founded the brand and the store five years ago, sell like hot paprika. **********At the corner of the square, a young magician is playing tricks with a reluctantly disappearing pigeon, drawing more applause than coins. Two folk singers draw laughs with their lyrics and antics and better receipts than the magician in a washboard that serves as their till. **********Among the glitter, peasant women in traditional black stand out. They hawk their embroidered blouses, tablecloths, napkins and the like, as well as chess sets and other wooden wares carved by their husbands. **********The goods are known to be smuggled, but the police do not interfere. The vendors are members of the Hungarian minority from Rumania, who have slipped the work of months of long nights past Rumanian customs guards. With their earnings, they buy food, clothing and other essentials to take home to impoverished Rumania. **********Saddened as Hungarians are by the plight of their fellow countrymen, they do not seem displeased when a visitor remarks that Vaci Street illustrates differences between Hungary and its Eastern neighbors. They would be happier yet, some suggested, if Vaci Street were even more like the shopping streets of its neighbors to the West.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/04/world.main_headline: China Says It Will Stop Arms for Iran
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/04/world.print_headline: China Says It Will Stop Arms for Iran
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/04/world.body_text: **********China has again told the United States that Beijing will try to stop its weapons from reaching Iran, a senior American official said here today. **********The official, Michael H. Armacost, Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, said that he and senior Chinese leaders had discussed the Reagan Administration's view that China was continuing to sell weapons to Iran, including surface-to-ship Silkworm missiles. **********Mr. Armacost, who arrived Sunday, said that Silkworm missiles, which were used recently in attacks on a United States-registered oil tanker and on a Kuwaiti oil-loading installation, ''represented a special concern to us.'' **********The Chinese have consistently denied selling missiles to Iran. On Monday, Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang derided as ''completely groundless'' suggestions that China was shipping arms to Iran. 'Unfair' to Shift Responsibility **********''It's unfair to shift the responsibility of the intensification of the tensions in the Gulf region to China,'' Mr. Zhao told foreign reporters at a reception in the Great Hall of the People. **********Mr. Armacost said, however, that the Chinese had restated that they would try to block the reshipment of Chinese weapons to Iran by third countries. ''There was a repetition of their intention to prevent the diversion of Chinese-origin equipment to Iran,'' he said. **********American officials have said that China sells about $1 billion worth of arms to Iran each year. Recently, however, Iran's use of Silkworm missiles in its attacks in the Persian Gulf have strained U.S.-Chinese relations and have resulted in the Administration's decision to cancel talks on increasing technology transfers to China. **********Mr. Armacost said the Silkworm ''has a range and capabilities which permitted it to be used in a way which internationalizes the conflict.'' **********''It is being directed at flagships that are engaged in peaceful commerce,'' he said. **********He would not comment on whether China was providing weapons training to Iran but said, ''It's a good question.'' **********During the visit, which ended today, Mr. Armacost met with Foreign Minister Wu Xueqian, Deputy Foreign Minister Zhu Zizhen and Deputy Prime Minister Tian Jiyun. **********Despite his expressions of concern over arms sales to Iran, the Under Secretary said that bilateral relations remained essentially sound. ''I think there are some current problems in the relationship,'' he said. ''I don't think it has affected the fundamentals.'' **********He said that among the other issues discussed with Chinese officials were the continued presence of Vietnamese troops in Cambodia, the Soviet presence in Afghanistan and American concern about human rights in Tibet. **********Mr. Armacost reiterated the American position that Tibet is a part of China and that the United States does not support the political activities of the exiled Tibetan religious leader, the Dalai Lama, who has called for the independence of Tibet. But he said the issue of human rights remained a concern. **********''We distinguished that status on the position of Tibet from expressing our views on human rights here, as in any part of the world,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/25/world.print_headline: TANGQIAO JOURNAL; A 1,000-YEAR-OLD CULTURE WITH FEW TOMORROWS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/25/world.body_text: **********On a chipped sheet of blackboard leaning against the cinnamon-colored dry-mud wall, Tian Rujun chalked the poem ''Seeking a Recluse in Vain,'' by the ninth-century poet Jia Dao:  Let's ask the lad beneath the pine tree.  He said: My master has gone to gather herbs.  He is somewhere on this mountain,  But so thick are the clouds, I know not the place. **********''Can you read this?'' Mr. Tian asked, turning toward the 18 children seated on thick-plank benches behind wood desks. Small hands popped up, severing the shafts of sunlight that eased the dimness of the chilly classroom. In hill-country Hunan-flavored Chinese, a young girl clattered through the simple stanza. **********''Now, who can write it in Miao?'' he asked. Four pupils slowly scratched the syllables of the Miao language beneath the Chinese ideograms. A Vanishing Culture **********In this village skewered into a twist of granite hills, children of the Miao, a small ethnic nationality unrelated to China's Han majority, study the Chinese language, poetry, history and ways of life. A glancing swipe at their mother tongue is the most these children, and Miao children elsewhere in these harsh hills, will ever learn of their heritage in school. **********For here, as in other parts of China where peoples of non-Chinese heritage dwell, the distinct culture of the Miao is fast vanishing under an unstated but unmistakable policy of national homogenization. **********''The Miao, in my opinion, will die out,'' said a northern Chinese who has spent a year studying poverty here in western Hunan Province. ''It's taboo to say that, but it''s true.'' **********There are but five million Miao in China, a million of whom live in Hunan. More than 1,000 years ago, a group of Miao, known as the Meo or Hmong in Southeast Asia, migrated northward to these impenetrable hills, then covered with trees. A History of Rebellion **********Independent, fiercely resistant to control, this area of western Hunan pulsed with rebellion time and again. Kang Xi, the Qing dynasty emperor of the late 17th and early 18th century, told his sons, ''Even the Miao can be controlled through compassion.'' **********Nonetheless, Qing emperors built an impressive chain of 500 stone forts and garrisons through these mountains to contain Miao rebellions against Chinese rule. The last uprising, or at least the last one acknowledged, came in 1942 as the Miao sought to retrieve land appropriated by local Chinese. **********The isolation of the Miao here allowed their culture and oral tradition to flourish. Magic and superstition, elaborate folk tales and hill songs invigorated village life, according to contemporary accounts. **********Today, much of Miao culture here has been suppressed and displaced by the mores and habits of China's dominant ethnic Hans. An official in the minorities affairs department of Hunan's provincial government, Ma Liangsheng, offered only one example of remaining Miao culture that is still permitted. **********''They can keep their own customs,'' he said. When pressed what customs in particular, he replied: ''Their festivals. They have their own festivals, and during the festivals they have their own celebrations.'' Educating Against 'Superstition' **********During the political violence of the Cultural Revolution that ended in 1976, he said, no festivals were permitted. Now, he said, ''We oppose superstition - we educate them against it.'' **********In some ways, the Miao are freer than most Chinese from legal strictures. Miao women tend to marry starting at the age of 17, while Han women are supposed to wait until they are 20. And couples from ethnic minorities like the Miao are usually allowed to have at least two children, while Han couples are officially limited to a single child. **********But a Miao who works in the prefectural government, Wu Housheng, was blunt about the culture's demise. **********''There is nothing printed in Miao,'' he said. ''There is no Miao dictionary. The written Miao language is an experimental language. If the leadership does not give enough funds it will be difficult to popularize the language more.'' **********In Mr. Tian's schoolhouse here, as in other schools in villages throughout this prefecture, Miao is used only in the first year of primary school to help introduce the children to the spoken and written Chinese language. In all other primary and secondary education, standard Chinese, as Mandarin is now called, is the language of instruction. Traditional Costumes **********On market days, Miao women and a few men trek hours over hill paths from inaccessible villages to market towns like Shanjiang, about 10 miles northeast of here as the cormorant flies, carrying bamboo baskets. **********Most women over 30 wear the traditional deep-blue tunic with embroidered bibs and black trousers. Most also wear the syoumai, a 40- or 50-foot length of black or blue-black gauzelike material that is wrapped around a woman's head until it looks a bit like a squat barrel. Some women jangle with silver necklaces and bracelets. **********The swarms of women banter over pork prices or the quality of factory-made cloth; there are few of the consumer goods available here that are seen in less remote areas. **********''One of the biggest problems here is to shake off poverty and to make Fenghuang not so poor,'' said Ou Daiming, a deputy director of this area of 300,000 people. ''It is a poor district and we have to build up the confidence to catch up with advanced areas. According to published statistics, the average yearly income is 395 yuan.'' That is about $106. **********''But actually,'' he added, ''the annual income is about 280 yuan,'' about $75. **********The northern Chinese investigator, who did not wish to be named, offered a less sanguine view of economic progress. **********''I've talked to many officials who are very pessimistic about the future of the area,'' he said. ''They saw no future. In one village I visited, every two people have to share one quilt. And they said they have only enough food for half the year.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/26/world.main_headline: CHIRAC, HIS COCLEAGUES SPLIT, ATTACKS RIGHTIST 'DEMAGOGY'
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/26/world.print_headline: CHIRAC, HIS COCLEAGUES SPLIT, ATTACKS RIGHTIST 'DEMAGOGY'
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/26/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Jacques Chirac, with his political allies deeply divided over how to deal with the growing strength of the far right National Front Party, has publicly repudiated what he called ''intolerance and sectarianism'' in France. **********In a speech to a rally of 40,000 supporters Sunday night, Mr. Chirac denounced what he called the ''demagogy of a certain political discourse,'' a clear reference to the National Front, whose increasing appeal in France has been largely based on a highly nationalistic, anti-immigration program. **********But, while trying to distance himself from the far right, which has the backing of an estimated 10 to 13 percent of the electorate, Mr. Chirac implicitly rejected calls in his own ruling Rally for the Republic Party to repudiate the National Front. **********Never mentioning the National Front by name, Mr. Chirac called for a ''union'' of the right, a phrase that was widely described among political commentators here as an effort to win back the electorate that supports the extreme right's policies. A Week of Debate **********Mr. Chirac's speech came after a week of intense, often public debate within his Rally for the Republic Party, the largest conservative group in France, prompted by calls from some officials in his Government to risk losing next year's presidential election rather than cooperating in any way with the National Front and its leader, Jean-Marie Le Pen. **********The debate itself reflected the deep concern being felt by many in this country over the slowly increasing support being won by Mr. Le Pen, who has already declared himself as a candidate in next year's presidential election. **********The debate inside Mr. Chirac's party was set off last week by Michel Noir, the Minister of Foreign Trade, who wrote in a front-page article in Le Monde that to cooperate with Mr. Le Pen would be to condone ideas similar to those of the French groups that collaborated with the Nazi occupiers during World War II. **********''A politician's responsibility is not only to win elections,'' Mr. Noir wrote. ''It is also to insure that societies do not forget the values on which they are built.'' Draws Sharp Criticism **********Mr. Noir's remarks drew sharp criticism from within Mr. Chirac's party, one of whose leaders, Interior Minister Charles Pasqua, publicly repudiated him, saying ''the role of a minister is to direct his ministry.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/11/world.main_headline: Hanoi Says It Keeps No Live Americans Missing in the War
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/11/world.print_headline: Hanoi Says It Keeps No Live Americans Missing in the War
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/11/world.body_text: **********A Presidential envoy who visited Hanoi last week said today that Vietnam insisted it did not have control over any living Americans missing in action from the war. **********Nevertheless, the envoy said, Hanoi suggested the possibility that there might be some in Southeast Asia, and the United States and Vietnam agreed that Hanoi would step up its effort to find missing Americans or their remains. **********The envoy, John W. Vessey Jr., a retired Army general and former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said he would not speculate on whether there are Americans being held involuntarily in Vietnam. **********''There are certainly all sorts of evidence to show that some might be there, but yet it has been a long time since the end of the war,'' General Vessey said. **********He said that while the Vietnamese insisted that ''there are no live American prisoners under the control of the Vietnamese Government,'' they ''acknowledged that there are some wild parts of their country.'' **********''The suggestion is that it is possible for there to be live Americans in Southeast Asia, not under the control of the Vietnamese Government,'' he said. ''That is the inference that I draw. They did not say that.'' Three Days of Talks He talked with reporters at the White House after briefing President Reagan on his three days of talks in Hanoi with Vietnamese officials on the issue of Americans missing in Vietnam. He was appointed President Reagan's special envoy on the matter last January. **********He said the United States and Vietnam agreed that Hanoi would speed its efforts to find missing Americans or their remains, and that Washington would send experts to Hanoi to look into ''humanitarian concerns that the Vietnamese have,'' such as war orphans and people incapacitated by the fighting. **********''We agreed that we would address these as humanitarian concerns and not link them to broader political issues, such as normalization of diplomatic relations, resumption of trade or economic aid,'' he said. **********More meetings will be held in Hanoi at the end of the month on the issue of the missing and the humanitarian issues, he said. **********There are 2,413 Americans missing in action in Indochina, 1,776 of them in Vietnam. **********General Vessey said Vietnam had agreed to pursue 220 cases involving missing Americans, including 70 cases on which the United States has compelling evidence that an American was alive after being reported missing. **********''We have people who were seen parachuting close to their forces, most probably captured,'' he said. ''Those men did not return, nor have their remains been returned.'' In another case, a picture of a wounded American was published during the war in a Vietnamese newspaper, yet he did not return and his remains have not been recovered.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/16/busin.main_headline: Advertising; Manning Already Back At Work at Thompson
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/16/busin.print_headline: Advertising; Manning Already Back At Work at Thompson
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/16/busin.body_text: **********Burton J. Manning was already at work at the J. Walter Thompson Company yesterday, before the WPP Group could make an official announcement of his return and appointment as chief executive of the worldwide agency. **********WPP, a relatively small British marketing services company, is acquiring JWT Group, Thompson's parent. It is eliminating JWT as the holding company for all four JWT components but apparently has no plans to change the chief executives of the other three. **********But Don Johnston's positions as chief executive of the Thompson agency as well as of JWT are gone. Mr. Manning said yesterday that Mr. Johnston was ''helping with the transition.'' **********Mr. Manning, who said he ''agonized for quite a while'' about returning, agreed partly because of WPP's assurances that there will be no decrease in either the professional services or creative support provided to clients and that all money saved would come from areas in which there was waste. **********Asked whether he would bring back any other former Thompson executives, he would only say, ''I am going to do everything I can to bring stability and return the company to the course it was on last year.'' **********Mr. Manning, 56, is a native Chicagoan who began his agency career at the Leo Burnett Company and worked his way up as a copywriter. He had been with Thompson 19 years when he left a year ago. Since then he has been a partner at Jordan, Manning, Case, Taylor & Grath. Now he is back and has been reunited with his old secretary, Elaine Catsicas, who had been with him when he was chairman and chief executive of J. Walter Thompson U.S.A. and vice chairman of the worldwide agency.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/13/world.main_headline: CHINA OUSTS UNIVERSITY SCIENTIST WHO ADVOCATED BROADER RIGHTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/13/world.print_headline: CHINA OUSTS UNIVERSITY SCIENTIST WHO ADVOCATED BROADER RIGHTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/13/world.body_text: **********A Chinese scientist who became a hero among thousands of students who demonstrated for greater democracy over the last month was dismissed today as the Communist Party moved to reassert control over intellectuals with unacceptable views. **********The scientist, Fang Lizhi, a vice president of the University of Science and Technology in Hefei, was charged by the Communist Party's Central Committee with having ''defamed the party's leadership'' and having ''slandered the socialist system.'' A denunciation of him was read to university officials in Hefei, the capital of Anhui Province. **********The university's president, Guan Weiyan, was also removed from office for failing to restrain his subordinate and for being ''responsible for the nationwide bad influence'' caused by the student unrest in the university. **********The official New China News Agency said Mr. Fang and Mr. Guan would both be assigned positions as research fellows at the institute of physics in the Academy of Science. **********Mr. Fang, a 50-year-old astrophysicist, was frequently hailed by student protesters for advocating broader rights in China and for his defense of intellectual and academic freedom. Rumors of Political Upheavals **********The two dismissals came amid rumors of other upheavals. **********Speculation focused on the political future of Hu Yaobang, the General Secretary of the Communist Party, who has sometimes been cited as a possible successor to Deng Xiaoping, China's senior leader.
