Mr. Hu has failed to appear in public for several weeks and has missed three public events at which he was expected to be present. **********In announcing the removal of Mr. Fang from his post, the official press agency said he ''attempted to shake off the party's leadership and depart from the socialist road in running his school and his ideas have resulted in vicious consequences in the university.'' **********The first in the recent tide of student protests began in Hefei on Dec. 5. Students, who were upset by the refusal of local officials to allow them to nominate their own candidates for the local legislative body, marched through the streets of the provincial capital. **********Although at the time Mr. Fang said he disapproved of the students' public protest, he defended their march as a right guaranteed under the Chinese constitution. As a result of the protest, local officials delayed the election so students could nominate their own candidates. In the election late last month, one of the student candidates was elected, as was Mr. Fang. 'Atmosphere of Democracy' **********In an interview with the Beijing Review less than a month ago, Mr. Fang stressed the role of universities as free-thinking institutions. **********''The emergence and development of new theories necessitate creating an atmosphere of democracy and freedom in the university, an atmosphere promoting the cultivation of intellectual ideology,'' he was quoted as having said. ''In the university environment, there should be nothing that can only be upheld and that allows no questioning of why it must be upheld.'' **********In announcing the dismissals, Zhou Guangzhao, a vice president of the Academy of Science who also holds a seat in the party's Central Committee, attacked Mr. Fang's view, saying, ''The university's leading body must be reorganized to insure the leadership of the party and the state.'' **********The secretary of the Anhui Provincial Party Committee also denounced the scientist. ''Fang Lizhi advocated bourgeois liberalization, defamed the party's leadership and party officials, negated the achievements of the party over the past decades, and slandered the socialist system,'' he said. ''He also sowed discord among the party and the intellectuals, especially the young intellectuals.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/22/world.main_headline: Elections in Haiti: A Struggle and a Feud
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/22/world.print_headline: Elections in Haiti: A Struggle and a Feud
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/22/world.body_text: **********Holding elections in Haiti, after nearly 30 years of dictatorship, was expected to be a difficult task. But it has become even more difficult because of a feud between Lieut. Gen. Henri Namphy, the head of Haiti's provisional Government, and the nine-member Electoral Council that has been trying to organize the elections. **********Haitians and Western diplomats find fault with both sides, but they say the heaviest burden lies on General Namphy, who they say has refused to lead and has lately demonstrated more concern for his own pride and the welfare of the armed forces than the national interest. **********The United States, which is giving Haiti more than $100 million in economic aid this year, placed its hopes on General Namphy, and he has proved an embarrassment. He has been unresponsive to appeals to put his full weight behind the presidential elections scheduled Nov. 29. Recently, he kept the American Ambassador here, Brunson McKinley, waiting several days for an appointment. Promises and Responses **********General Namphy promised when he became head of the provisional Government nearly two years ago to lead Haiti to elections. But every step he has taken on that path, including the fundamental one of establishing a timetable, has come only in response to the frustrated cries of Haitians protesting in the streets. **********For weeks he ignored pleas for protection and various other kinds of help from the Electoral Council before taking steps a few days ago to provide a bit more security and some help with distributing ballots and ballot boxes. **********In three public appearances in the last two weeks, General Namphy has not so much as mentioned the elections. His most visible acts have been to formally name himself commander in chief of the armed forces and to promote four colleagues to general ranks, apparently in an effort to entrench his position and theirs before a new president takes office. **********General Namphy has often spoken admiringly of the democratic system. But he obviously resents criticism and privately expresses utter contempt for civilian political leaders, from community leaders to presidential candidates. He has persistently refused to meet with them and discuss their mutual visions for Haiti. Welcomed in Interim **********Most Haitians welcomed General Namphy as interim leader. Though he had managed a successful career under the founder of the dictatorship, Francois Duvalier, and his son, Jean-Claude, General Namphy was remembered as having somehow remained independent and uncorrupted. **********For a long time, many Haitians said General Namphy was not moving swiftly toward democracy and not aggressively rooting out Duvalier loyalists from Government posts because he was boxed in by powerful figures from the old regime. **********But his staunchest supporters began to question his intentions after he tried to push aside the civilian Electoral Council and put responsibility for running the elections in the hands of the army, an organization that historians say stole the last elections in Haiti in 1957 for Francois Duvalier. He backed down after a few days of bloody protests. **********General Namphy portrays himself and the army as above reproach, and those who have been in touch with him say he was deeply offended by the distrust demonstrated in the rejection of his elections maneuver by nearly every civic and religious organization in the country. Council Kept Its Distance **********Restored to its constitutionally endowed position of supremacy over the elections, the nine-member Electoral Council distanced itself from General Namphy and his principal colleague in the Government, Maj. Gen. Williams Regala. Furthermore it began publicly criticizing them for failing to maintain order in Haiti so that fair elections could be conducted. General Namphy became enraged. He fell silent and left the council to fend off death threats and attacks on its facilities. **********The Electoral Council has been far from flawless. The council members, including several lawyers, a businessman and a clergyman, have little administrative experience. They have reportedly bickered among themselves and been reluctant to take advice from American, Canadian and French diplomats and technicians, and they have failed to develop a comprehensive elections plan. **********Some council members have been criticized for having had connections with the Duvaliers. But they seem to be earnestly trying to bring off the elections, and no one has accused them of acting unscrupulously. They deny that they intended to insult General Namphy and say they feel they have showed restraint. **********General Namphy clearly feels otherwise. Several Western diplomats say they believe that he finally began to extend some cooperation to the Electoral Council not because of international dismay or diplomatic pressure but because the council softened the tone of its messages and began rather politely asking for help rather than demanding it.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/07/world.main_headline: Far-Reaching Economic Changes Stir in Bulgaria
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/07/world.print_headline: Far-Reaching Economic Changes Stir in Bulgaria
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/07/world.body_text: **********Bulgaria, the Soviet Union's most orthodox disciple, has ended a period of apparent hesitation that followed the accession to power of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, and plunged into a far-reaching program of political and economic overhaul. **********If the changes in the organization of Government, the Communist Party and the economy that have been announced in often vague terms since late July are fully carried out, this country is likely to emerge as the most thoroughly revamped of the Communist-ruled nations. **********But while some administrative restructuring appears to be genuinely under way, changes in the basic institutions that run the state and economy have not yet appeared. ''Glasnost'' -the word is the same in Bulgarian and Russian - and ''democratization'' still appear to be no more than widely used catchwords without Bulgarian contents. **********In a series of interviews, senior officials dwelled on one main theme. They said Bulgaria had gone as far as it could along the lines of a traditional, centrally planned Soviet-style economy. Subjected to frequent changes since the 1960's, this system, they said, has succeeded in raising a backward, agrarian economy to one based on a mix of industry and agriculture, and has greatly improved the nation's standard of living. 'Intensive Development' Sought **********''We have no reason to be displeased with our development so far,'' said Ivan Iliev, who heads an important commission newly formed in the party's central committee to develop economic and social policies. ''But now we must transform our economy from extensive to intensive development.'' **********''Parkinson's Law is valid in any management structure,'' said Ognyan Panov, director of the Institute of Social Management, the party's leading management expert, who spent a year studying at Stanford University. ''The present management did not want to give up its power. We started in 1980 to try to give more power to the lower levels. It didn't work. We have to change totally.'' **********The changes, as outlined in a 95-page program speech by President Todor Zhivkov, the party's 76-year-old General Secretary, in a hastily called meeting of the Central Committee on July 28, will introduce ''self-management'' throughout the economy. **********The term, the specifics of which remain to be defined, means that each industrial enterprise will make its own production and sales decisions, raise its own capital through commercial banks that are to be created, elect its own management and distribute its revenues as it wishes. Indebted to Soviet Union **********All officials emphasized that central planning would continue, but acceptance of the plan by enterprises would no longer be compulsory. **********Bulgarians and diplomats expressed uncertainty on how such enterprise independence can be achieved in a country deeply indebted to the Soviet Union, which takes 60 percent of Bulgaria's exports. Another 20 percent of Bulgarian exports go to the other member countries of Comecon, the Soviet-bloc trading organization. **********''When the Government undertakes an obligation in Comecon, it must get the consent of the enterprises,'' said Atanas Paparizov, director general of the Trade Ministry and Bulgaria's negotiator in its application for admission to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. ''It will have to pay the difference if it obliges the enterprise to export to Comecon goods that it could have sold elsewhere.'' **********The officials stressed that economic overhaul was made necessary by rapid technological development throughout the world. They conceded that change alone cannot close the technological gap that separates East from West. Some New Competition **********''This is the most complex issue,'' said Mr. Iliev. ''For the last 20 years the gap has been increasing. We can't hide this truth, the party and state leadership knows this.'' **********''The Eastern markets are now approaching those of the West in competitiveness,'' said Mr. Paparizov. ''They want quality, not only quantity.'' **********Mr. Iliev illustrated the reasons for Bulgaria's declining growth rate, which has sunk from more than 11 percent a year in the earlier stages of industrialization to a yearly average of 3.7 percent from 1981 to 1985. **********''For example, we use as much ferrous metal, as much electricity per capita as any developed country, but our results are considerably lower. Our quality, technology and equipment are less good. Our capacity to introduce more raw materials, more manpower is exhausted. **********''Our old methods of management were good enough when we had more resources to inject. No more. We have to give up our old methods. We need new technologies, higher labor productivity and structural changes in the economy.'' Wave of Restructuring **********Mr. Iliev's new job is in itself an example of the wave of restructuring that has swept through Government and the party. Until Aug. 18, he was a Deputy Prime Minister and chairman of the State Planning Commission. **********On that day, the National Assembly abolished the positions of eight Deputy Prime Ministers, dissolved four government councils that had been acting as superministries since last year, and scrapped the State Planning Commission, three major ministries and three state committees of ministerial rank. **********At the same time, five new ministries, each combining the functions of several old ministries or equivalent bodies, were created. Administration Revamped **********Parliament also revamped the administration of this country of nine million by abolishing the basic units of regional government, 28 districts, and creating in their place 9 provinces. **********Stoyan Mihailov, the Party Secretary who heads the Central Committee's department on ideological, cultural and press policies, said the Government and party reorganization would reduce the number of party functionaries by as much as two-thirds. **********''They are not in danger of unemployment,'' Mr. Panov said. He added that training programs were being organized to prepare those displaced for other jobs. **********Mr. Iliev said he placed his hopes for improving the economy on existing joint research programs within Comecon for Bulgaria's own scientific advances and increased transfers of Western technology in selected fields. He said newly liberalized rules for joint ventures would attract such transfers. Reflectively, he added: ''The Soviet Union might transfer technology from military to civilian production. Then our dependence on Western technology will be liquidated. In the military sphere, the Soviet Union and the West are not so different.'' Some Resistance Encountered **********Official pronouncements stress that the Communist Party's monopoly on power - ''the leading role of the party,'' in the language of Communist states - would be enhanced rather than weakened. To redefine this concept under the new rules, an exceptional party conference is being prepared for December. By then, officials said, revamping of the state and economic machinery will be completed. **********However, the changes have encountered a certain amount of resistance. **********''There are managers who oppose increased self-management,'' said Mr. Mihailov, the Party Secretary. ''It gives them more responsibility. With higher centralization, there was always the excuse that the organization above was in charge.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/10/busin.body_text: **********Sir George Jefferson, 66-year-old chairman of British Telecommunications P.L.C., said today that he would retire Sept. 30. He will be replaced by Iain Vallance, the chief executive. A company spokesman said **********Sir George's departure was not connected with recent criticism of the phone company's service record. There have been technical problems and service delays, partly as a result of an engineers' strike. **********British Telecom, previously owned by the Government, was sold to the public in 1984.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/26/busin.body_text: **********When the United States and Japan reached an agreement on the semiconductor trade last summer, it was hailed by political and industry leaders. President Reagan called it ''an important step toward freer and more equitable world trade.'' **********But the Reagan Administration seems likely to impose sanctions this week on Japanese companies for violating the pact. **********The accord had two aims: one was to help American manufacturers of semiconductors gain access to the Japanese market; the other was to prevent Japanese chip makers from dumping (selling chips for less than the cost of production) in the United States and third-country markets. **********The agreement established a price-monitoring system. The Commerce Department set minimum prices at which Japanese manufacturers could sell their computer chips. These ''fair market'' values were based on production information supplied by the Japanese companies. **********The official prices were intended to give chip makers in the United States an opportunity to compete fairly without predatory pricing by the Japanese. Then the Commerce Department found that the Japanese were selling chips below cost to gain a bigger market share and were subsidizing their semiconductor operations with profits from other company businesses. **********Japan also agreed to set up procedures to assure American makers of access to the Japanese market. The American share was supposed to grow by several percentage points a year. To accomplish this, Japan agreed to establish an organization to provide sales assistance, workshops and programs to foreign companies and to promote joint ventures. **********The Japanese still insist that they are doing their part, and United States trade officials note that the chip agreement did provide for sanctions in case of violations. **********''We still think it's a good agreement if it's enforced,'' said Gary Holmes, a spokesman for the United States trade represenative.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/21/world.main_headline: Sharjah's Emir Regains Rule After Brief Ouster
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/21/world.print_headline: Sharjah's Emir Regains Rule After Brief Ouster
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/21/world.body_text: **********The ruler of the Gulf emirate of Sharjah, Sheik Sultan bin Mohammed al-Qasimi, has been restored to power four days after his brother ousted him, the Emirates News Agency said today. **********Rulers of the seven-member United Arab Emirates met last night and confirmed Sheik Sultan, who is 43 years old, as the emirate's legitimate ruler, the agency reported. **********The brother who had tried to oust him, Sheik Abdel-Aziz, has been named Crown Prince, the agency added. **********Sheik Abdel-Aziz, 48, announced Wednesday he had his family's support to replace Sheik Sultan, who he said had plunged the emirate into a $1.4 billion debt through mismanagement. **********Sheik Sultan, who was on a private visit to London, flew to neighboring Dubai to seek to rcover his post. **********The news agency dispatch included a brief statement from the Supreme Council, which groups the rulers of the seven emirates, saying there was a need to preserve stability and security in all parts of the country. **********The United Arab Emirates overlooks vital oil export shipping lanes in the southern Persian Gulf.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/06/world.main_headline: FIRST DAY: BLUE SHIRTS, RED TIES, DARK TALES
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/06/world.print_headline: FIRST DAY: BLUE SHIRTS, RED TIES, DARK TALES
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/06/world.body_text: **********WASHINGTON, May 5 - **********As members of the Iran-contra investigating committees gave their opening speeches today, praising themselves for their hard work and bipartisan spirit, Senator Howell Heflin of Alabama slipped out to roam the halls and sip some coffee. Was he bored already? ''If it were all that intriguing,'' the Democrat drawled, ''I'd be in there listening.'' **********Mr. Heflin, a former judge with a square jaw and a generous girth, has a folksy persona and a catchy cadence that seems destined to win him the sort of attention Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. got during the Watergate hearings. Dressing for Occasion **********He laughed about how many legislators, including himself, had dressed in blue shirts and red ties to look good for the television cameras, and were seizing their moment in history with sonorous speeches about ''the dark cloud'' hanging over the democracy. **********''Some of the company's all right,'' he said, as he strolled away, ''and some of it isn't.'' **********But if the morning was not particularly gripping - with most people, even in the Capitol, more interested in talk of Gary Hart's problems than Ronald Reagan's -the afternoon offered its share of drama and humor. **********As Richard V. Secord, a retired major general with a low-key style and unapologetic tone, offered examples of the involvement of William J. Casey and Vice President Bush in the affair, the audience in the Senate caucus room was drawn in by the snippets of plot and dialogue, of aliases and clandestine meetings in his personal thriller. A Small Warning **********''I'm sitting on the edge of my chair,'' said Representative Henry J. Hyde, Republican of Illinois. ''I just wish I had popcorn.'' **********Senator Daniel K. Inouye of Hawaii, chairman of the committee, took a moment before lunch to warn his colleagues not to make the same mistake he had made during the Watergate hearings. **********Thinking that his microphone was off, the Democrat had muttered ''What a liar'' after the testimony of John Ehrlichman, a top aide to President Nixon. In return he was denounced as ''that little Jap'' by John Wilson, the attorney for H. R. Haldeman, the White House chief of staff. **********''Watch your chitchat, each microphone is live and hot,'' he said today with a rueful smile. ''I've had that experience before.'' **********Everywhere on Capitol Hill, from office televisions to a loudspeaker outside the caucus room, the hearing was a constant background noise. Tourists began lining up outside the Russell Senate Office Building before 9 A.M., and were rotated in, a dozen at a time, for one-hour shifts. **********''This would be like Watergate,'' said James Lindell, a high school student from Washington State, ''except that Richard Nixon didn't have a good man like Oliver North to destroy the evidence.'' **********Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., a member of the House Iran-contra committee who was chairman of the House Judiciary Committee when it voted articles of impeachment against Mr. Nixon, agreed it was different, for a different reason. **********''You're dealing first of all here with a President who's very charming, popular and was once the target of an attempted assassination,'' the New Jersey Democrat said. 'Flagellating Ourselves' **********''People will say we're flagellating ourselves but, of course, that's a process that the American people know how to deal with.'' **********It was a day for those on the committee to establish their personas - knowing that some of them would catch the imagination of the public and others would not. **********Senator Inouye gazed solemnly forward. Senator Sam Nunn, a Georgia Democrat, held his chin in his hand. Representative Lee H. Hamilton, a Democrat from Indiana, chewed on his glasses. **********Arthur L. Liman, the New York lawyer who is the Senate committee counsel, was a legal Buddha, tucking in his chin and smiling wryly as he watched in silence. **********By contrast, John W. Nields Jr., the House counsel, was all nervous energy and facial twitches, looking like a hyperkinetic schoolchild caught in a long history class. **********Although the quiet in the hearing room was almost total at times -as Mr. Secord re-created dialogue with Mr. Casey, the former Director of Central Intelligence, and Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North - there were lighter moments as well. **********When Mr. Nields asked Mr. Secord what the word ''Copp'' meant in a secret memo, the witness said it had been his pseudonym. **********''I chose it because it was the author's name in a book I happened to be reading at the time,'' he said. ''I didn't have time to look in the telephone book for a name. That's the normal way we do it.'' **********After he had told of many acronyms and shifting company names for operations designed to help the Nicaraguan contras, Mr. Secord was asked what he meant by the term ''CD,'' when he said that his operation would be ''wiped out'' financially except for its ''CD.'' **********''It means certificate of deposit,'' he said, causing the audience to laugh. **********Some lawmakers dealing with the less showy business of Capitol Hill were drawn to the caucus room to hear about what Senator Heflin called a tale of ''rogue elephants, Persian rug merchants, loose cannons, soldiers of fortune, privateers, profiteers, believers, hostages and contras.'' **********Senator Alan Cranston, Democrat of California, sat in a back row among the spectators for a while, but said as he left that he had no regrets that he did not get on the Senate committee. ''I'd rather deal with the future than the past,'' he said. **********Ed McKenzie, a history teacher from Phoenix, said the session was like a world history lesson. ''We heard about arms dealers in Canada and front companies in Panama and drug enforcement agents from Europe helping hostages in Lebanon,'' he said. ''When you hear about the millions unaccounted for when you're on a teacher's salary, it boggles your mind.'' **********From behind black sunglasses on which parts of the Gettysburg Address were printed, 15-year-old Louisa Lee of Edison, N.J., offered a more terse opinion of the opening day: ''Pack of lies.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/09/world.main_headline: SOUTH AFRICAN REBEL LEADER CALLS FOR WIDENING OF 'ARMED ATTACKS'
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/09/world.print_headline: SOUTH AFRICAN REBEL LEADER CALLS FOR WIDENING OF 'ARMED ATTACKS'
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/09/world.body_text: **********Oliver Tambo, president of the African National Congress, called today on South African blacks to widen their struggle against apartheid beyond their townships to include attacks on strategic targets in white-controlled towns and cities. **********Mr. Tambo, in statements marking the 75th anniversary of the Congress, the most prominent of the black nationalist groups seeking to overthrow Pretoria's system of apartheid, also appealed to South African whites to unite with blacks. **********In a radio address, Mr. Tambo said that the objective of the Congress must be to ''create mass revolutionary bases'' in black areas throughout South Africa. **********''It is also vital that each mass revolutionary base must have its combat forces, which will act both to defend the people and to mount armed attacks against the enemy beyond the given area and throughout the country,'' Mr. Tambo said. Attitude on Whites **********He said that it was not the organization's intention to attack white civilians and stressed that the Congress was fighting for a nonracial democracy and not for retribution against whites. **********Mr. Tambo said that the South African authorities were not nearly ready to negotiate with his group. But political commentators said that the Congress, while vowing to step up its campaign of violence, had acknowledged that it could not expect a military victory against South Africa's overwhelmingly superior military might and must instead use a combination of strategies to topple the Pretoria Government. **********''We must pay the greatest possible attention to the mobilization and activization of the white population,'' Mr. Tambo said, ''which should fuse with and become part of the motive forces of the democratic revolution. Our white compatriots have to learn the truth that it is not democracy that threatens their future. Rather it is racist tyranny which poses a dire peril to their very survival.'' **********Mr. Tambo's statement, made in a speech, at a news conference and in an address prepared for Radio Freedom, the Congress's radio station, appeared to be an attempt to appeal to two separate audiences. Two Approaches Contrasted **********On the one hand, he seemed to be stoking militancy within black areas of South Africa. On the other, he appeared to be offering a more moderate position to the international community, which the Congress believes is crucial in pressing the white-dominated Government to dismantle apartheid. **********Mr. Tambo said that the Congress's use of violence inside South Africa and its campaign for external pressure in the form of sanctions by foreign countries were both necessary to persuade the Pretoria authorities to negotiate with the Congress to end apartheid and bring about majority rule in South Africa. **********Mr. Tambo said that the Congress's military wing, Umkhonto we Sizwe, or the Spear of the Nation, would coordinate fighting forces that ''must necessarily be based among the people and drawn from the people themselves. They must be inspired by the sole objective of acting against the racist regime in furtherance of the aim of engaging in people's war.'' **********The exiled black nationalist movement, which has its headquarters in this capital city, turned from peaceful protest to violence after South Africa banned the organization in 1960. It has gained growing international recognition as black unrest has increasingly gripped South Africa over the last two and a half years. Meeting With Shultz **********Mr. Tambo is to meet later this month with Secretary of State George P. Shultz. He said the planned meeting represented a ''recognition'' on the part of the Reagan Administration that there could be no solution to South Africa's problems without an understanding of the positions of the black majority. **********Some commentators say that it is difficult to assess the precise strength of the Congress, the depth of its influence in South Africa or the degree to which it controls the actions of militant youths in the townships. **********However, although the South African authorities have dismissed the Congress as unsuccessful, they have justified their increasingly severe crackdown on their opponents as necessary to counter a revolutionary onslaught and thwart planned attacks by the Congress.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/12/world.main_headline: U.S. Official Issues Warning On Losing 'Intelligence War'
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/12/world.print_headline: U.S. Official Issues Warning On Losing 'Intelligence War'
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/12/world.body_text: **********The director of the National Security Agency has said the United States will lose the ''intelligence war'' unless the flow of leaks to journalists is stanched and Government agencies stop treating security problems with ''disdain.'' **********The official, Lieut. Gen. William E. Odom, in a speech Saturday to the Association of Former Intelligence Officers, did not fault any specific news articles, and he acknowledged that the primary problem arises from officials' willingness to reveal classified information to reporters. **********He said repeated compromising of Americans in foreign diplomatic posts suggests the extent of the threat from hostile intelligence services. But, he said, policy makers have resisted tighter security procedures.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/16/busin.main_headline: Placid Seeks to Lessen Banks' Role
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/16/busin.print_headline: Placid Seeks to Lessen Banks' Role
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/16/busin.body_text: **********Attorneys for the Hunt brothers' Placid Oil Company filed the outline of a bankruptcy reorganization plan today that attempts to lessen the role of its bank lenders in shaping the final repayment plan. **********The filing is the initial step in what is expected to be a lengthy process, and much could change in the final version. **********The banks' collateral is so diminished in value that it does not match the size of their loans. Consequently, the Hunts argue, the difference should no longer be considered a secured debt. Rather, the banks should become unsecured creditors on that portion of their loans for which there is no collateral. Unsecured creditors would be repaid over 10 years, the filing states. Confidence Expressed **********''We're talking about a debt plan that has a chance of being approved by the court over the objection of the banks,'' said Henry W. Simon Jr., a bankruptcy attorney for Placid, in an interview last week. Mr. Simon said that he was confident that a plan to pay creditors could be worked out ''almost immediately - with the exception of the Placid banks.'' **********However, an attorney for the First Republicbank Corporation, R. Paul Wickes, minimized the importance of today's filing and questioned whether Placid would pursue the tactic announced in the plan. **********''The threat of such a plan is absolutely run-of-the-mill,'' he said. ''Of course, we are a long way away'' from seeing whether Placid clings to such an attempt, he added. **********Placid, which is owned by the trusts of the three Hunt brothers of Dallas, filed for bankruptcy protection last August. The brothers' two largest companies, Placid and the Penrod Drilling Company, had previously filed a $13.8 billion lawsuit against 23 creditor banks, of which 18 were lenders to Placid. **********In today's filing, Placid said that the banks' interest in their collateral was currently worth less than $500 million. At the time of the bankruptcy, the collateral was worth $350 million to $400 million. The value has increased since then as oil prices have risen. $810 Million Owed Banks Still, the banks were owed $810 million, which includes interest, on the day of the bankruptcy filing. **********With only a portion of the debt covered by the collateral, the remaining balance should be treated as unsecured, Placid said. This would mean that the banks would be counted along with nearly 3,000 unsecured creditors. **********With many of them considered friendly to Placid, the reasoning goes, the banks' power to shape the reorganization plan would be diluted. Likewise, banks would not be entitled to any interest that accrued after the bankruptcy date, the filing said. **********Additionally, the plan called for the Internal Revenue Service to be paid over six years; the I.R.S. has filed a $550 million claim against Placid for back taxes. In the priority of debt payments, the I.R.S. is second to secured creditors, but before unsecured creditors.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/03/busin.body_text: **********With a bid that competes with a management buyout proposal, an investor group led by Sumner M. Redstone, the theater chain owner, emerged as a suitor for Viacom International Inc. yesterday. **********The Redstone group offered $44.75 a share in cash and preferred stock, or about $2.1 billion, for the 80.4 percent of Viacom it does not already control. The offer nominally exceeds the $44-a-share bid, totaling $2.35 billion, by the company's management to take the diversified media concern private, although the management group had also agreed to assume about $550 million in Viacom debt. **********Several arbitragers said that Viacom's management would again have to increase its own offer, which the company's board has already accepted. After making an initial proposal last September, the management group raised its offer twice to gain the deal's approval, but this is its first bout with a competing suitor. **********For some time, Wall Street had anticipated a bid from Mr. Redstone, who has steadily increased his stake in Viacom over the last year. National Amusements Inc., a company owned by Mr. Redstone, is currently Viacom's largest shareholder, with 19.6 percent of its common shares. **********At stake are Viacom's many attractive media holdings, including affiliated television stations; television programming, like ''The Cosby Show''; cable systems, and two cable services, MTV: Music Television and Showtime/The Movie Channel. **********Mr. Redstone asked Viacom for a response by 5 P.M. on Friday. He indicated that he would consider other options if the response was not favorable. That could include a tender offer or buying additional stock. **********Viacom's management, led by Terrence A. Elkes, president and chief executive, declined to comment on the Redstone offer yesterday. Stock Up $2.50 **********On Wall Street, Viacom's stock rose $2.50, to close at $43.875, indicating that arbitragers and analysts viewed the bid as serious. **********The Redstone group's offer, which consists of cash and preferred stock, is similar to that made by the Viacom management, with some significant differences. **********For each share of Viacom, Mr. Redstone's holding company, Arsenal Holdings Inc., is offering $37.50 in cash, or 50 cents more than the management proposal; a fractional amount of exchangeable preferred stock with a face value of $7.25, 25 cents more than the management bid, and the same fractional amount of convertible preferred stock of Arsenal Holdings, valued by one arbitrager at about $1.75. **********In filings yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Redstone said the offering would consist of $400 million in equity provided by Arsenal Holdings and $2.25 billion to be provided by a consortium of banks led by the Bank of America. The Bank of America itself has agreed to put up $562 million of that sum, the filing said. No Junk Bonds in New Bid **********Mr. Redstone argued that his offer was better for shareholders because it included more equity and because it did not depend on the high-yield, high-risk securities that were a crucial part of the Viacom deal. Viacom's management would depend on $1 billion in such ''junk bonds'' to complete its buyout. **********After the Redstone deal, shareholders would own 20 percent of a company that had $400 million in equity, compared with a company that had only $81 million in equity under the management deal. **********Mr. Redstone also argued that, by using bank financing, he was substantially reducing the interest expenses involved in an acquisition. **********One arbitrager noted that replacing junk bonds with bank debt could make the preferred stock more valuable. Not only might it trade at a higher price because the underlying company would be better financed, but it could also prove more valuable when the convertible preferred stock was converted into common stock. Leveraged Buyout Bid Criticized **********According to Mr. Redstone's filing, the determination of Viacom's management to proceed with a leveraged buyout apparently angered him. The filing disclosed a letter to Allan R. Johnson, chairman of a special committee of Viacom's board, in which Mr. Redstone wrote that he was convinced ''Viacom and its board had engaged in a series of acts that were contrary to the interest of the company's shareholders.'' As examples, he cited a ''poison pill'' provision, ''greenmail'' and ''golden parachutes.'' **********Some sources familiar with the offer added that it was likely Mr. Redstone could complete the deal in six to eight weeks. But other industry experts said they thought the transfer of licenses could result in the deal taking significantly longer, even as much as six months. **********While the transfer of television station licenses requires Federal Communications Commission approval, Mr. Redstone indicated that he would put the stock of Viacom in a trust while the transfer of licenses was taking place.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/20/world.main_headline: VISIT BY ALFONSIN PEACEFULLY ENDS ARGENTINE MUTINY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/20/world.print_headline: VISIT BY ALFONSIN PEACEFULLY ENDS ARGENTINE MUTINY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/20/world.body_text: **********President Raul Alfonsin went to an army base this afternoon and persuaded rebellious officers there to surrender, ending a four-day mutiny. **********In a dramatic end to the military crisis over human-rights abuses, the President then returned by helicopter from the military base on the northern outskirts of the capital and told 200,000 wildly cheering people in the central Plaza de Mayo that the mutineers had given up and that they would be detained and submitted to justice. **********''The house is in order, and there is no bloodshed!'' he shouted from the balcony of the rose-colored presidential palace to the crowd before him and to the nation watching on television. 'Celebrate Easter in Peace' **********''The men in uprising have backed down,'' Mr. Alfonsin said. ''In line with that which has been called for, they will be detained and put to justice.'' **********He told people to ''go home and kiss your children and celebrate Easter in peace.'' **********Then he turned and began to embrace the smiling Cabinet ministers, politicians and military leaders sharing the balcony with him at the end of the crisis that began in the western city of Cordoba on Wednesday when an army major refused to appear in court to answer charges of rights abuses. Outpouring of Popular Support **********Three and a half hours earlier today, the President made the surprise announcement from the same balcony that he was going to the school to seek the surrender of the rebels. **********He told the people to wait for him, promising that ''if God wills it, and all the Argentines are with us,'' he would find a solution to the crisis. **********Mr. Alfonsin said the support that had been given to Argentine democracy by the political opposition, labor, business and other groups had demonstrated to the mutineers and the world the country's ''definitive decision to live in democracy.'' **********The President then boarded a helicopter for the short trip to the rebels' enclave - an infantry school in the Campo de Mayo military base 20 miles north of downtown Buenos Aires. Thousands of civilians were gathered outside the school, shouting anti-military slogans. The authorities repeatedly urged them to leave the area and go downtown to await the President, but people continued to arrive. **********Mr. Alfonsin said later that he had spoken with the mutiny leader, Aldo Rico, a lieutenant colonel who was dismissed from the army Friday after the infantry school takeover. No details of the discussion were announced. 'Dirty War' Amnesty Sought **********The rebels, whose number was put at somewhere between 50 and 350, took over the school to demand an amnesty for killings and other human-rights abuses committed by the armed forces during the military's ''dirty war'' campaign against leftists in the mid-1970's. The rebels, said to be mostly captains, repeatedly asserted that they continued to recognize the authority of the President and were not seeking a coup. **********The takeover near the capital came after mid-level officers in an army unit in Cordoba, 400 miles west of Buenos Aires, rebelled in support of the Maj. Ernesto Guillermo Barreiro, who refused a summons from a Federal court to be questioned about abuses committed at a detention center in Cordoba in the 1970's. **********Major Barreiro was promptly dismissed from the army, but he remained holed up in the barracks in Cordoba, protected by sympathetic comrades. On Friday, however, Major Barreiro fled the barracks, and the other rebels in Cordoba ended their action. It was not known whether they had been detained, nor was there information on the whereabouts of Major Barreiro. **********He is among about 280 military men, roughly one-third of them on active duty, who face human-rights charges in civilian courts around the country. Troops Moved Slowly **********On Friday, the army Chief of Staff, Gen. Hector Rios Erenu, declared his loyalty to the Government and said he intended to use troops to put down the rebellion in the Campo de Mayo. **********The next two days were spent in ponderous troop movements by units of the II Army Corps stationed north and west of the capital, but by this morning most of the force, estimated at 1,000 to 2,000 men, was still camped about 25 miles north of Campo de Mayo. **********Government officials implied that the delay was an effort to allow the rebels to surrender peacefully. The Government repeatedly denied that it was negotiating with the rebels. **********Comments from some members of Mr. Alfonsin's Radical Civic Union, however, indicated that there was a problem in convincing some mid-level officers to agree to attack the mutineers. Rumors of Army Changes **********Several hours after the crisis came to an end, Government officials said General Rios Erenu, 14 other generals and 30 colonels would retire or be dismissed. The sources suggested that this was the result of their hesitation or reluctance to deal with the crisis. **********At the same time, one demand of the rebels was the replacement of General Rios Erenu. They claimed he had never adequately explained their position on the human rights trials to the President. **********In addition to the demand for an amnesty for all of the military, the rebels appeared to be seeking to focus attention on the longstanding assertion within the army and navy that middle- and lower-level officers should not be punished for things they did under orders from superiors. **********When the President went to the base this afternoon officials made it clear that he was taking the matter into his own hands as Commander in Chief. The highest-ranking army officer with him was Gen. Augusto Vidal, described as holding a military training position. General Vidal, officials said, took the rebel leader, Mr. Rico, into custody. General Vidal was also rumored as the probable next army Chief of Staff. **********The air force chief, Brig. Gen. Ernesto Crespo, was also conspicuously present at the President's side during the day, and the navy made statements of support for the Government.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/28/world.main_headline: Far-Right South Africans Decide To Leave Dutch Reformed Church
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/28/world.print_headline: Far-Right South Africans Decide To Leave Dutch Reformed Church
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/28/world.body_text: **********About 2,500 right-wing dissidents today walked out of a meeting discussing the liberalization of the Dutch Reformed Church, the main Afrikaner church that justified the creation of apartheid. **********At the meeting in Pretoria attended by more than 3,000 from the right wing, the dissidents voted by a margin of 4 to 1 to form a new all-white church and accused the Dutch Reformed leadership of embarking on a ''new course of liberalism'' by criticizing apartheid policies and seeking to open the church to all races. **********But 500 to 800 of the dissidents voted not to quit, electing instead to work from within to oppose the ''liberal moves.'' **********Meeting in Pretoria in Skilpad Hall, where the far-right Conservative Party was established five years ago, the dissidents added momentum to the right-wing backlash against the Government of President P. W.Botha. Impact Yet to Be Determined **********Prof. Johan Heyns, head of the Dutch Reformed Church, who has led efforts to desegregate the church, said the effect of the walkout would be determined by the number of people who followed the dissidents out of the church. **********''It is a sad event and both an act of disunity regarding the church and an act of disobedience regarding scripture,'' he said. **********Professor Heyns, who emphasized that he regarded the action as a walk-out, said the move illustrated the close link between religion and Afrikaner nationalism. ''But this is not a basis for a church,'' he added. **********Both Mr. Botha, who is an active member of the church, and Dr. Andries P. Treurnicht, leader of the Conservative Party and a former Dutch Reformed minister, were reported to be deeply concerned about the break. Appeal to Dissidents **********In a statement issued on Tuesday, Dr Treurnicht indicated sympathy with the dissidents, but appealed to them not to break with the church before exhausting other options. **********The dissidents, organized as the Continuation Committee of Dissatisfied Members and led by Prof. Willem Lubbe, have rejected recent moves by the church to unite with its black, Indian and mixed-race ''daughter churches'' and to distance itself from apartheid. **********Professor Lubbe said the new church would be called the Afrikaner Reformed Church and predicted that it would win wide support nationwide. **********A breakaway had been regarded as inevitable after the Dutch Reformed Church's general commission rejected the dissidents' objections on Tuesday. Seeds Sown by New Policy **********The breakaway from the 1.7-million-member church, which includes most members of the National Party Government, came after weeks of negotiations between Dutch Reformed leaders and the dissidents over a policy document that criticized apartheid and which was adopted at a synod last year. **********The document, which some saw as a turnabout in church policy, for the first time described apartheid as scripturally unjustifiable and racial discrimination as a sin. But the document stopped short of declaring apartheid a heresy as have its ''daughter churches'' and the World Alliance of Reformed Churches.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/05/world.main_headline: Mexico Opposition Parties See a Rare Opportunity
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/05/world.print_headline: Mexico Opposition Parties See a Rare Opportunity
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/05/world.body_text: **********It is an uphill struggle that virtually no one here believes can be successful. But Mexico's two major opposition parties, one on the right, the other on the left, are preparing for the presidential campaign and election as if they really expect to win. **********''The country faces its gravest situation since 1930, and the middle class, working class and peasantry are increasingly dissatisfied with the Government and the system,'' said Heberto Castillo, who political analysts here believe is likely to emerge as the candidate of a new left-wing coalition. ''They are all thinking of a change, though they don't quite know what.'' **********The right-of-center National Action Party, a strong advocate of free enterprise and Roman Catholic values, differs with the leftist coalition on virtually every point of ideology. But it offers a remarkably similar analysis of Mexico's political situation and the oppportunities it presents for the opposition. **********''There is a climate of discontent and a growing abyss between the people and the Government,'' the party president, Luis H. Alvarez, said in an interview here. ''All the elements for change are in place. Our challenge is to reach out to the great majority, which has been silent and nonparticipative, and convince them that it is the obligation of all Mexicans to create a different Mexico.'' Election Set for July **********The governing Institutional Revolutionary Party, which has been in power since 1929 and has never lost a presidential, senatorial or gubernatorial election, is expected to name its presidential candidate before the end of October. Voting is scheduled for July, and the new President, who is limited to a single six-year term, will take office on Dec. 1, 1988. **********With inflation and the foreign debt both at record levels, the normally weak and divided opposition believes the governing party, known as the PRI, is vulnerable in a way it was not during the 40 years of general prosperity that preceded the current economic crisis, which began in 1982. The parties are also stressing their internal democracy in contrast to the Institutional Revolutionary Party, whose candidate is hand-picked by the incumbent President. **********''The PRI's burden of culpability and errors is so heavy that it hardly matters who carries it,'' Mr. Alvarez said. ''Any good intentions of even the best candidate the PRI can offer will be asphyxiated under the weight of the obligations that already exist.'' **********In the past, the National Action Party has been weakened by a reputation of being strong in the north but not truly national in scope and by internal differences, which prevented it from offering a candidate in 1976. But the party, which won 16 percent of the vote in 1982, will hold an open convention in November, at which delegates will choose among several young, articulate and aggressive candidates, including Jesus Gonzalez Schmall, a member of Congress and the party's spokesman on foreign affairs. Left Usually Splintered **********The traditionally splintered parties of the left, which have never won more than 10 percent of the national vote, have already achieved what they see as a major advance. In an open primary election scheduled for Sunday, they choose a single candidate to represent five parties and part of a sixth, gathered under the banner of the new Mexican Socialist Party. **********In hopes of improving its chances, the new party, whose members range from Trotskyists to non-Leninist Socialists, has gone to great lengths to shed anything that would give it a sectarian image. It has dropped the hammer and sickle from its banner, the party platform favors retention of private property ''up to a certain size,'' and Mr. Castillo, the architect of the fusion, has even been addressing businessmen's groups in search of support. **********''The left must understand the difference between the ideal and the real, between what it aspires to and what is possible,'' Mr. Castillo said in a recent interview. ''Some people on the left may not like that, but I am a scientist whose specialty is designing bridges, so with me there is no such thing as dogma.'' **********Thus far, the PRI has given no indication it is worried about electoral challenges, especially not those mounted from the left. When reporters recently asked Fidel Velazquez, a labor leader who is a pillar of the governing party, about the Mexican Socialist Party, he replied, ''Five times zero is still zero.'' Hopes for Leftist Candidate **********But that attitude could change if Cuauhtemoc Cardenas, leader of the Democratic Current, a dissident faction in the governing party, emerges as the candidate of the unified left. Mr. Cardenas, former Governor of the state of Michoacan, is the son of a former President who founded the PRI and is revered by Mexicans for his populist economic policies and strong nationalism. **********Mr. Castillo said that contacts with Mr. Cardenas have been initiated and that he hoped to persuade members of the dissident group to take a place under the left-wing umbrella. Mr. Castillo said that if he won the Socialist nomination and Mr. Cardenas later broke with the PRI and joined the leftist coalition, ''I would be disposed to cede my place to him'' as the sole candidate of the left. **********''I talk to them every day and tell them their place is here,'' Mr. Castillo said. ''They have no future in the PRI, but if they are to work with us, I hope they hurry. As things now stand, they haven't said yes and they haven't said no.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/14/world.main_headline: With Tamil Conflict, Myths Die Out
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/14/world.print_headline: With Tamil Conflict, Myths Die Out
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/14/world.body_text: **********As heavy fighting once again ravages the Jaffna Peninsula of Sri Lanka, forcing people who had just begun to enjoy peace back into precarious shelters, many Sri Lankans and Indians are also witnessing the destruction of myths and the ethnic alignments they supported. **********Through more than a decade of rising ethnic tensions, culminating in four years of guerrilla war, both sides of the conflict seemed clear. **********Tamil militants in the Northern and Eastern Provinces - drawn from a group representing about 15 percent of the population - were fighting for a Tamil homeland. **********Arrayed against them were Sri Lanka's ethnic majority, the Sinhalese, who controlled the Government and the armed forces. Off to the side stood the country's Moslem minority, regarded as an ethnic group here, and another community of Tamils in the tea plantations, unrelated by history or caste to the Jaffna Tamils. View of the Sinhalese **********To most Sinhalese, the sides were never equal. Behind the Tamil militants, they saw India - the 50 million ethnic Tamils of Tamil Nadu state across the narrow Palk Strait, and beyond them a Government in New Delhi that allowed the guerrillas to train and live on Indian soil. **********Over the last few years, when Tamils died in Jaffna at the hands of Sri Lankan troops, especially in cases involving civilians, there was outrage in Madras and New Delhi. When Tamil militants arrived for sporadic talks with Sri Lankans in foreign cities, they were escorted by Indians. **********When the Sri Lankan Army embarked on an offensive five months ago against the Tamil guerrillas of the Jaffna Peninsula, the Indians dropped relief parcels to the rebels. **********Today, Indian troops are killing Tamils in Jaffna, some reportedly civilians, and the strongest of the Tamil armies, the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, has turned its guns and propaganda on the Indians. Now Resented by Tamils **********New Delhi's forces are now combatants, resented by Tamils as well as Moslems and Sinhalese, and seen by all of them as intruders. A high Government official said some Tamil militants who have fallen out with the Liberation Tigers are hiding in Hindu temples in the largely Sinhalese city of Colombo, where they feel safer than in the north. **********The majority of Tamils are Hindus, and the Sinhalese, Buddhists. But this is not a religious conflict; there are Christians in both groups. **********In Sri Lanka, sympathy has strengthened among Tamils for the rebels in areas where they are fighting, to the consternation of Indians. **********The once-solid front among the Sinahalese inside and outside Government, is crumbling as dissension has grown over the invitation of Indian forces into the country. Several Cabinet ministers, among them officials who once advocated a more conciliatory attitude toward the Tamils here, are now critical of the Indian-Sri Lankan accord of July that brought the Indian peacekeeping force to Sri Lanka. Around the country there have been assassinations, thought to be by a radical Sinhalese nationalist group, of Sinhalese local Government officials who had openly supported the accord. **********At the same time, President J. R. Jayewardene, whom Indians not long ago said they found difficult and unpredictable to deal with, has suddenly become a public defender of New Delhi's policies and its troops. **********For the Liberation Tigers and their leader, Velupillai Prabakaran, the world has turned upside down several times this year. A few weeks ago, his Liberation Tigers had been promised a control of a new governing council for northeastern Sri Lanka. **********But then he overplayed his hand, apparently ordering his guerrillas to drive ethnic Sinhalese from their homes in territory he hoped to control in the Eastern Province. The violence that followed left more than 200 Sinhalese dead and villages in ashes. **********Mr. Prabakaran is now a hunted man, pursued by both Sri Lankans and Indians.  VIOLENCE IN SRI LANKA: A CHRONOLOGY  July 24, 1983: Rioting between Sinhalese and Tamils breaks out in Colombo, the capital, and spreads to other cities. The death toll is put at 140.  May 14, 1985: Guerrillas believed to be Tamil separatists attack Anuradhapura; more than 150 Sinhalese are killed.  May 3, 1986: President J. R. Jayewardene blames Tamil guerrillas for explosion that destroys an Air Lanka plane at Colombo airport, killing 16 passengers.  April 17, 1987: Tamil guerrillas ambush five vehicles carrying civilians near the town of Alut Oya. Most of the 127 people slain are Sinhalese.  April 21: At least 110 are killed and 200 hospitalized after a bomb explodes at a bus station in Colombo.  May 26: Sri Lankan Army begins drive against Tamil rebels in an attempt to break the rebel hold on the Jaffna Peninsula.  June 2: Tamil guerrillas stop a bus near the town of Arantala, killing 29 Buddhist monks and at least three other civilians.  June 4: Despite protests from Colombo, Indian planes drop 25 tons of food and other humanitarian supplies into Jaffna, which the Sri Lankan Government had placed under blockade.  June 28-30: Sri Lanka and India sign an accord intended to grant more autonomy to the Tamil minority. Indian peacekeeping forces begin to land in northern Sri Lanka.  Aug. 18: President Jayewardene escapes assassination attempt in Parliament building which kills 2 and injures 17.  Oct. 5: Eleven captured Tamil rebels commit suicide while in police custody.  Oct. 7-8: Series of attacks by Tamil guerrillas in eastern Sri Lanka leaves at least 188 dead. India orders its troops to ''use all the force at our command'' to halt violence, and large-scale fighting against the Tamil guerrillas breaks out.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/17/world.main_headline: La Paz Journal; Standing for Revolution, He'll Sit With the Rich
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/17/world.print_headline: La Paz Journal; Standing for Revolution, He'll Sit With the Rich
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/17/world.body_text: **********The ground-floor cafe of the Club de La Paz is Bolivia's smoke-filled room, a place both shabby and fashionable where, it is said, everybody meets and everything is decided. **********There were the coups, for example - although this country, which is among the continent's leaders in that category, has been remarkably free of such worries of late. **********It was also in the Club de La Paz, in the mid-1970's, that journalists began to approach the man known as Klaus Altman, a cafe regular, and ask whether it was true that he was Klaus Barbie, who was sought for Nazi war crimes. He was. **********And it is the place where Juan Lechin Oquendo, the capitalist-baiting labor leader - he regularly proclaims that Bolivia has been sacked over the years by foreigners and the country's own capitalists - has had frequent chats this year over juice and coffee with his good friend Mario Mercado, one of Bolivia's most important businessmen. Contradictions in Style **********Such contradictions in style have been one of the constants in the life and politics of Mr. Lechin, who just stepped aside as leader of the Bolivian Workers' Federation, the labor organization that was born of the 1952 revolution and is often ranked just below the military in power. **********Mr. Lechin is an erect, silver-haired man with an equally silver moustache whose only hint of proletarianism is the open-necked shirt under his elegant sports jacket. He gave his age as 72 years old in an interview last November. Some people say he is a year or two older. **********In a recent interview, he said that anyone wanting to know a man's age should ask his female friends, not the man himself. **********As he likes to point out, he is younger than Victor Paz Estenssoro, now serving his fourth term as President. Mr. Paz will officially turn 80 in October, although Mr. Lechin says the President is already 80. Tin Industry Nationalized **********Mr. Lechin, Mr. Paz and a handful of other leaders of the Nationalist Revolutionary Movement made the revolution that first brought Mr. Paz to the presidency in 1952. **********Together, on Oct. 31, 1952, Mr. Paz and Mr. Lechin signed the decrees nationalizing the holdings of the tin barons, the small group of men that developed and controlled 80 percent of Bolivian mining. Tin, until recently, was responsible for most of Bolivia's foreign exchange. **********The Bolivian Workers' Federation, known by its Spanish acronym, COB, was founded the year the revolutionary forces came to power. Its most important component was the Mineworkers' Federation, of which Mr. Lechin had been executive secretary since 1944. **********He ran both labor groups and at the same time served in the 1952 Government, first as Minister of Mining, later as Vice President. Neither Mr. Lechin nor anyone else in a position at that time to complain saw any conflict of interest in his wearing all those hats. **********''Here, the unions don't just seek economic ends,'' he said in explanation. ''For 40 years the miners have sought to fortify the state.'' Opponent of President **********Today, however, President Paz is trying to turn Bolivia away from statism and toward a more open, free-market economy. At the same time, the collapse of the international tin market has forced Bolivia to close the largest tin mines and dismiss three-fourths of the miners, which, in turn, has greatly debilitated the Mineworkers' Federation. **********Some critics of the President see this as a sellout to his revolutionary past, but Mr. Lechin, now in strident opposition to Mr. Paz, said the President's heart was never in the revolutionary process, that he agreed to nationalization only because the mine workers pushed him along. **********Although Mr. Paz has been widely praised for halting the wild inflation that dominated Bolivia when he returned to office two years ago, Mr. Lechin asked rhetorically which was better: ''That people die from hunger, or that we have economic stability?'' **********Mr. Lechin, whose father was of Lebanese descent, studied at what he called an expensive high school, the American Institute run by the Methodist Church. But family financial difficulties prevented his going to the university. 'Talk to the Rich' **********It was as a result of those early ties to the affluent, he said, that he would ''not refuse to talk to the rich.'' **********Always an avid player of team sports, he said it was his soccer skill that got him a job as a secretary in the mines of Simon I. Patino in 1929. He made one of the company teams on a Sunday and got a job on Monday. **********He left the mines in the mid-1930's to fight in the Chaco War against Paraguay, then worked in a variety of other jobs before being appointed to a municipal government post in the mining district. **********He said it was then that he began to defend the interests of miners, who had not previously been able to face the mine managers and discuss wages and benefits. **********In the long career that followed, he survived one attempt to hang him and two imprisonments of several months each. He also went into exile about 15 times. He was saved from hanging, he said, when miners came out to demonstrate and those holding him decided he was too heavy for any of the branches on the trees. **********Although foreign analysts of Bolivia tend to characterize him as a loose-cannon leftist, Mr. Lechin said he was ''nationalistic and revolutionary.'' 'Policy of Independence' **********''I am not a Communist,'' he said, ''but I follow a policy of political and economic independence for this country. I want a state independent of the United States.'' **********The main thing he did not like, he said, were the ''trans-nationals or big private enterprise.'' **********Saying it was time to devote himself full time to creating his own political party, Mr. Lechin gave up leadership of the miners last year and of the Workers' Federation this year. But he lost the fight at the federation convention last month to name one of his longtime followers as his successor. **********Instead, the federation delegates elected Simon Reyes, a Moscow-line Communist. Some analysts predicted that Mr. Reyes would move cautiously and bring more predictability to the Bolivian labor movement. **********Mr. Lechin implicitly agreed with that when he said that Mr. Reyes's election was a result of ''an alliance of the right of Bolivia, beginning with the Government.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/08/busin.body_text: **********The government of President Jaime Lusinchi today approved an agreement with creditor banks to reschedule $21 billion of public sector debt. **********After a special session of the cabinet, Finance Minister Manuel Azpurua told reporters the accord had been unanimously endorsed, and that the documentation would now go to the country's 450 creditor banks for their approval. **********Once the banks approve the rescheduling, a date will be set for the signing, which must take place before Oct. 1. **********Cabinet approval of the agreement came after a month of discord within the ruling Democratic Action party, with some leaders complaining publicly that the terms were not favorable to Venezuela because they included no new credits.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/03/world.main_headline: Santiago Journal; Death Threats Offstage, but the Show Goes On
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/03/world.print_headline: Santiago Journal; Death Threats Offstage, but the Show Goes On
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/03/world.body_text: **********Through more than 14 years of military rule, many of Chile's theater groups have been islands of criticism and opposition. **********Even in the middle and late 1970's, before much of the press began to show signs of independence from the regime, the country's political situation was being examined with a mixture of bitterness, pathos and humor in a dozen or so small theaters scattered around Santiago. **********That tradition, some actors and directors say, is why 78 of them recently received written death threats, accused of being ''spearheads of international Marxism.'' **********Monday was the deadline set by the group calling itself ''Command 135 -Trizano Cultural Action Pacification'' for the theater people to leave the country. Instead, they have promised to stay and, despite a warning to keep quiet, have made the threats public - along with their fears. Actors Rally to Their Cause **********Actors from three continents, including Christopher Reeve, best known for his role as Superman, came to Chile in recent days in support of the threatened theater people. Hundreds more sent messages of support. **********On Monday night, as the midnight deadline neared, the visitors and the threatened group shared the makeshift stage of a tin-roofed warehouse converted into a disco. About 2,000 supporters, some literally sitting on the rafters, listened to the music and the speeches as several hundred others jostled outside with police officers and organizers, who said the building would hold no more. **********The Government of Gen. Augusto Pinochet has not commented on the threats, and the theater people have not publicly accused the Government of responsibility. But it is generally assumed that ''Trizano'' - the meaning of the word is not clear - is a right-wing extremist group of the type that have had ties to Government intelligence groups. **********When a visiting Spanish actor, German Cobos, said Monday that he considered the threats ''a form of state terrorism,'' some of the Chilean actors broke into applause. **********The Government threw a partial roadblock into the plans for the Monday night solidarity performance, which had been scheduled for a gymnasium owned by the basketball federation. At the last minute the Government said the gymnasium could not be used for a non-sports event. Actors Told to Flee **********Leaders of the actors' union, who had planned the show, learned of the decision only when they arrived at the gymnasium shortly before starting time and found policemen lined up to turn people away. Eventually, they were able to piece the evening together at the warehouse and disco known as El Garage Internacional. **********The actors and directors said the threats began to arrive on Oct. 30. Twenty-five people reported receiving individually addressed copies of a typed letter. In addition, six theater groups received letters that were presumed to cover all the members of each group, 53 people in all. **********The recipients were advised to flee the country by Nov. 30 or face the possibility of being killed. Some of the actors reported that a later letter to some of them said the threat was intended for those ''who are or would like to be members of clandestine parties,'' apparently a reference to the Communist Party and its armed affiliate, the Manuel Rodriguez Patriotic Front. **********Edgardo Bruna, a stage and television actor who is also president of Sidarte, the actors' union, said he thought the theater people had been singled out because ''since the coup, Chilean actors have had a tradition of telling through our plays what is going on in our country.'' **********He said that actors, like many journalists, politicians, human rights workers and others, had been threatened before but that this was the first threat on such a broad scale. **********Among those threatened before who also received letters this time were Nissim Sharim and Delfina Guzman, leading members of Ictus, a theater group that has performed political works since the 1960's and has won acclaim on foreign tours. Bombs have been discovered twice at Mr. Sharim's house, and both he and Ms. Guzman have reported receiving dozens of threatening telephone calls. **********The most recent play of Ictus, ''Lo Que Esta en el Aire'' - ''Something in the Air'' - is about people who disappear after being detained by authorities. Nearly 700 people have disappeared that way in Chile, most during the first four years of the regime, but five members of the Communist Party have been reported missing since September. Cheerful and Fearful **********The atmosphere was both party-like and fearful when several dozen theater people filed into La Comedia, the home theater of Ictus, for a news conference on Monday. **********Monica Echeverria, a theater director, said she was concerned that the congenial mood might mislead the visitors. In fact, she said, ''we are very afraid.'' **********Mr. Bruna said lawyers for the threatened theater people had gone to court and obtained an order for protection. As a result, the national police agreed to guard the Sidarte headquarters and to send patrol cars periodically by the homes of those threatened. **********In the days after they learned that Mr. Reeve was coming, many of the actors could not resist expounding on the idea that the personification of the comic book hero was flying to their rescue. **********An opposition newsmagazine picked up the theme when it posed a simple question on an otherwise blank page in this week's issue: ''Why is Superman really coming?'' **********On the next page, it showed Superman flying away with General Pinochet cradled in his arms. **********Mr. Reeve, who has won critical acclaim in other roles, was not amused. **********He said this was ''a very serious situation that goes beyond comic books,'' adding, ''I'm here actor to actor, worker to worker, friend to friend.'' My concern is with human rights. No actor should have to perform under these conditions.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/19/world.main_headline: PERES AND RUSSIAN MEET ON PEACE PARLEY PLAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/19/world.print_headline: PERES AND RUSSIAN MEET ON PEACE PARLEY PLAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/19/world.body_text: **********Foreign Minister Shimon Peres of Israel met with the Soviet Ambassador, Yuri V. Dubinin, Sunday night and asked whether Moscow would be willing to play only a limited role in an international peace conference on the Middle East, Israeli officials said today. **********The 90-minute meeting, which was not announced beforehand, was ''constructive and even warm,'' Mr. Peres told Israeli journalists today. **********The meeting took place at the end of a weekend in which Mr. Peres and Mr. Shultz discussed in detail American-Israeli cooperation on the peace process in light of an agreement, worked out by Mr. Peres and King Hussein of Jordan, that would restrict the authority of an international peace conference. It also followed a speech in which Mr. Shultz gave contradictory signals on the American position on the advantages of convening an international peace conference. Israeli Demands **********Speaking of the meeting held Sunday night, an Israel official said: ''Peres asked the Soviets whether they would agree to play not a ceremonial role but a limited role in the international conference.'' What Mr. Peres is seeking, he apparently told Mr. Dubinin, is that the Russians meet two long-held Israeli demands: the re-establishment of diplomatic relations and some concessions on the emigration of Soviet Jews. **********He also repeated the conditions outlined by Jordan, Israel and the United States, that a short preliminary conference would lead immediately to direct talks between Israel and a Jordanian-Palestinian delegation. **********Israeli officials said Mr. Dubinin repeated the recent statement by Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, that the absence of diplomatic relations was ''not normal.'' **********Soviet officials declined comment on the meeting. **********Meanwhile, Administration officials sought to clarify remarks made by Secretary of State George P. Shultz last night on the American position toward a peace conference. **********On the one hand, Mr. Shultz appeared to give a strong Administration endorsement to the idea of an international conference. On the other hand, he tried to distance himself from the idea, saying that neither President Reagan nor he was committed to such a conference, nor would they ask others to make a commitment now. **********Part of the difficulty in interpreting Mr. Shultz's message was that even though his speech had been rewritten several times, he spoke from notes and not from a prepared text. **********''It was not a commitment to a conference in principle,'' one Administration official said. ''It was a qualified endorsement of the idea of a conference. Then you have to fill in the blanks.'' The official added that Mr. Shultz intentionally gave what he called ''a mixed message,'' in an attempt to give the United States the maximum flexibility and to remain outside of Israel's current domestic crisis.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/27/world.body_text: **********The first of the victims of Britain's worst mass murder was buried in a village graveyard today near the town where a gunman, Michael Ryan, shot and killed 15 people and then took his own life. Eric Vardy, a 51-year-old deliveryman, died at the wheel of his vehicle. Other victims were to be buried later this week. An appeal fund to aid victims and their relatives topped $320,000, with Queen Elizabeth II reportedly among the donors. No date has been announced for Mr. Ryan's funeral.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/08/busin.body_text: **********Employees of the World Bank, lashing back at the bank's American president, have brought a class action suit against the institution to delay dismissals of hundreds of economists and other highly skilled professionals, the demotions of hundreds more and position changes for most. **********The complaint, disclosed by Washington lawyers for the employee-elected Staff Association, is the most serious challenge yet to an all-encompassing, $100 million reorganization by Barber B. Conable.
