A former Congressman from upstate New York, Mr. Conable has been the World Bank's head since last August. **********One of the bank's officials, Jacques de Groote, a Belgian who is one of the 12 executive directors, has also challenged the plan with a widely circulated complaint to Mr. Conable, and several senior officials have quit, despite the bank's expressed desires that they stay. **********And because of the preoccupation of the employees with defending their jobs, the bank's principal business of processing loans to developing countries is languishing, according to senior management of the bank as well as other employees. **********The complaint brought by the Staff Association was filed before an institution of the bank known as the Administrative Tribunal, which is made up of prominent attorneys of seven member countries and entirely independent of the bank's management. In matters involving international institutions, American courts have little jurisdiction. **********''It's in their hands,'' Peter Riddleberger, a bank spokesman, said of the tribunal. As for the bank's management, he added that ''it's preparing its response.'' **********Mr. Conable ordered the reorganization in part to make the bank more efficient for the expanded role in managing world debt problems that Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d designated for it in October 1985, through a policy that has come to be known as the Baker plan. Orienting the bank away from lending for development projects and toward assistance of countries' general economies was a top objective of the Baker plan, ''Frankly, I think the reorganization has been botched,'' said Vanessa Ruiz, a partner in the Washington firm of Sloan, Lehner & Ruiz, which represents the employees. End to Turmoil Seen **********''The staff is in an uproar,'' said Edward V. K. Jaycox, an American who is a vice president and head of the steering group that designed the reorganization plan. But he said the turmoil should end by September and that the bank would be stronger, less bureaucratic and more responsive to its debtor-country clients. **********The World Bank is one of Washington's biggest bureaucracies, a sibling of the much smaller International Monetary Fund and is sprawled along Pennsylvania Avenue in 17 locations identified by letters of the alphabet. Its payroll exceeds 6,000, with mostly well-educated personnel, 75 percent of whom are foreign. In its 1987 fiscal year, which ended June 30, the bank lent $17.6 billion, $1.3 billion more than in 1986. Today, its board approved an administration budget for 1988 of $690 million, $7 million less than in 1987. **********The bank's adversary in the reorganization, the Staff Association, represents all workers but is quite different from a conventional labor organization. It elects a new head annually from the middle levels of the bank's staff, and its current chairman served as a senior economist specializing in West Africa and is assured of returning to a similar position. **********The reorganization, along with the acrimony over it, is impeding the bank's efforts to fulfill its Baker plan mission. ''Nobody's pulling the debt plan together,'' said C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics in Washington, one of several research organizations that has been receiving job inquiries from economists at the bank. ''It's been a year, and all I can see is reorganization.'' A Cascading Process **********Among other things, the reorganization plan establishes four senior vice presidents, in place of two. The senior vice presidents appoint their immediate subordinates, who then pick their own, and the process continues, in a cascading process from top to bottom through the bank hierarchy. ''The scheme is tainted by the system of subjective choice,'' the complaint says. **********In August, ''round two'' of the process will begin, and will continue through September. Employees who are not selected are encouraged to search throughout the bank for a department that will take them. But some will be disappointed. Management has ordered the elimination of 390 positions and has set aside $101.3 million for those employees' separation pay and pensions and for other purposes of the reorganization, such as retraining.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/30/busin.print_headline: CONSUMER RATES; Yields Rise On C.D.'s
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/30/busin.body_text: **********Yields on certificates of deposit rose slightly last week as auctions of Treasury bills were again postponed. **********The Bank Rate Monitor's national index showed an increase of 1 basis point in the yields on six-month, one-year, two-and-a-half-year and five-year C.D.'s., to 6.66 percent, 7.04 percent, 7.45 percent and 7.95 percent, respectively. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. **********''Bidding for C.D. deposits is becoming more intense among banks looking for new long-term money,'' said Robert Heady of The Bank Rate Monitor. **********Rates for bank money market accounts, which compete with certificates of deposit, were unchanged at 5.60 percent. **********The Treasury's auctions were canceled for the second consecutive week because Congress had failed to raise the Federal debt ceiling. As a result, the Treasury auctions will experience a substantial increase in volume when they resume. **********Meanwhile, total assets for taxable money market mutual funds reached an all-time high last week, rising $1.9 billion, to $228.3 billion, according to Donoghue's Money Fund Report. Of that increase, consumer funds were up $1.2 billion and institutionally held funds increased about $627 million. **********The seven-day taxable compounded average yield for a money market mutual fund stood at 6.13 percent, a drop of 6 basis points from last week. The 30-day yield was down a basis point, to 6.21 percent, in the same period. **********The average maturity of securities held in portfolios by the money market funds was 45 days, unchanged from last week. **********In the tax-free funds, assets were down $629 million, to $64.2 billion. The compounded yield on seven-day funds rose 10 basis points, to 3.77 percent, while that for 30-day funds declined 2 basis points, to 3.75 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/09/busin.body_text: **********The Reagan Administration's rebuff of Brazil's debt plan was seen here today more as a blow to the credibility of Finance Minister Luiz Carlos Bresser Pereira than as a serious obstacle to future talks. **********Financial experts said influential Brazilian officials had expressed skepticism about the viability of Mr. Bresser Pereira's bond plan even before he met today in Washington with Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d. **********One well-placed official said that Brazil would now focus on obtaining new money to permit the country to balance its external accounts. He added that Brazil would be unable to lift its partial debt moratorium until a new agreement is worked out with the 14-bank advisory committee that represents the country's 600 or so creditors. **********Other officials speculated that, with the country trapped by political and economic uncertainty until work on a new constitution is concluded later this year, the Government may opt for a limited restructuring of its commercial debt this fall and leave a long-term debt package until next year. **********Although President Jose Sarney had endorsed the Finance Minister's non-conventional approach to Brazil's foreign debt problem, political blame for its apparent demise is now expected to fall principally on Mr. Bresser Pereira's shoulders, according to the financial experts. **********Significantly, since he announced it last week, Mr. Bresser Pereira has received little public support for his plan from within the majority Brazilian Democratic Movement Party, while some conservative newspapers here have strongly criticized it.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/20/world.body_text: **********More than 20 men armed with machine guns, mortars and grenades attacked the presidential palace in the black homeland of Ciskei early today but were repulsed by guards, the authorities said. **********Ciskei officials said the assault was staged by soldiers from a rival homeland, Transkei. The Ciskei officials said President Lennox Sebe and his family were not injured. The fighting seemed to be the most dramatic display of long-running hostility between the two nominally independent tribal homelands. **********The chief Government spokesman, Headman Somtunzi, said guards killed one of the attackers, wounded at least one other and captured one of their leaders, a former Ciskei military officer. **********Ciskei, which has been feuding with Transkei for several months, announced Wednesday that all Transkeians in its territory must leave by Aug. 31. Disguised Troop Carrier **********Transkei's Foreign Minister, Caleb Songca, said his Government knew nothing about the attack on the palace. **********Mr. Somtunzi said the attackers arrived at the palace gate in a disguised Transkei troop carrier, a jeep and at least one private car, apparently trying to bluff their way into the compound in the Ciskei capital of Bisho. **********He said gunfire broke out, and palace guards captured Maj. Nkosinathi Sandile, formerly Ciskei's military security chief. **********Major Sandile was presented by the Transkei authorities at a news conference there last month. He said he had been caught while leading a mission to abduct Lieut. Gen. Charles Sebe, the brother of Lennox Sebe, who escaped to Transkei last September from a Ciskei prison where he was confined in 1983 in a coup plot. Asylum in Transkei **********Charles Sebe was given asylum in Transkei. **********President Sebe blamed Transkei for staging the prison break that freed his brother. He also blamed Transkei for abducting his son, Maj. Gen. Kwana Sebe, who was kidnapped a half hour after the jail break. **********Mr. Somtunzi said the attackers arrived at the palace about 2 A.M., while other reports said the shooting broke out about 3:30 A.M. The South African Broadcasting Corporation said gunfire lasted for at least 30 minutes and could be heard in the nearby white community of King Williams Town. **********The SABC said three of about 23 attackers managed to get into the palace compound. It said some of the windows of the official residence were shattered, but the building suffered no serious damage. **********Reporters said the area around the palace was cordoned off after the attack, roadblocks were set up and ground troops and helicopters were deployed in a search for attackers who escaped. Abandoned Troop Carrier **********Police said the troop carrier used in the attack was abandoned near the palace, with a load of weapons inside. **********Ciskei and Transkei are two of four tribal homelands designated as independent by South Africa under its policy of racial segregation. They are not recognized by any other nations. The white authorities established both homelands for members of the Xhosa tribe, but their rulers are divided by personality and historical rivalries. **********Transkei's leaders covet Ciskei and other territories, and Ciskei has accused them of seeking to undermine President Sebe. **********Both border the Indian Ocean on South Africa's southeast coast, about 50 miles apart with the port city of East London lying between them. Further inland, as little as 15 miles separates their borders. **********The two homelands, where most of South Africa's 6 million Xhosas hold citizenship, are impoverished one-party states led by strongmen who cooperate with the white authorities in South Africa. **********By law and custom, South Africa's 5 million whites control the nation's economy and maintain separate districts, schools and health services under the Government policy of apartheid, which establishes a racially segregated society in which the 24 million blacks have no vote in national affairs.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/30/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; BELL AND HOWELL STOCK RISES $3.75
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/30/busin.body_text: **********Shares in the Bell and Howell Company rose sharply today on news that a group led by Robert Bass, a Texas investor, had acquired an 8.9 percent stake in the company. The stock jumped $3.75, to $57.50, on the New York Stock Exchange on speculation that the large information services company was a takeover target. **********In its filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the investor group said it bought 511,500 Bell and Howell shares over the last two months, paying between $44.25 and $56.02 each and expanding its holdings to 786,800 shares. Mr. Bass, of Fort Worth, has made several recent investments in media-related concerns, including the Taft Broadcasting Company.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/03/world.main_headline: SOVIET MONITORING OF PHONES IS CITED
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/03/world.print_headline: SOVIET MONITORING OF PHONES IS CITED
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/03/world.body_text: **********The Soviet Union maintains an elaborate system for eavesdropping on sensitive United States Government communications from Soviet-bloc embassies here, according to intelligence authorities. **********The authorities, who include both present and former officials, say the Russians are using embassies and residences on high points in and around Washington to intercept communications, particularly those from microwave relay stations. These stations carry long-distance telephone traffic from Government offices. It Works Both Ways **********The interception of communications works, of course, both ways. The United States has a secret agency, the National Security Agency, charged with the interception of foreign communications, including those of the Soviet Union. There have been reports that listening equipment on top of the American Embassy in Moscow is being used for that purpose. **********Several members of Congress are urging the Reagan Administration to scrap a 1969 agreement that allowed the United States and the Soviet Union to build new embassies in each other's capitals. **********In Washington, the Soviet Union was given a parcel of land on Mount Alto, one of the highest points in the city. In addition to having a clear view of the Pentagon, the State Department and the White House, the Mount Alto compound also has a good view of the Naval Security Station in northwest Washington, a center for secret naval communications. **********Legislators who want to remove the Russians from Mount Alto also favor razing the new American Embassy building under construction in Moscow, on the ground that it is filled with Soviet listening devices. **********Intelligence experts say that even if the Russians were forced to move from Mount Alto, they would still be able to intercept from embassies and residences in the region. **********''One should not think that just by depriving the Soviets of Mount Alto they would not be able to intercept our communications,'' a Government authority on security said. East European Activity Noted **********Another official, referring to the other Soviet-bloc missions, said, ''They are surrogates of the Soviets in intelligence gathering.'' **********Several officials mentioned as prime listening posts an East German residence on a ridge in Arlington, Va., overlooking Washington, and the Cuban interest section in the Czechoslovak Embassy, two miles from the White House. **********The East German residence is one-third of a mile from the Pentagon. the Polish Embassy, like the Czechoslovak Embassy, is on a hill known as Mount Pleasant overlooking the White House. Moreover, the two diplomatic missions are between the White House and a microwave relay point in northwest Washington near Tenley Circle. **********The Russians use diplomatic compounds elsewhere in the United States to collect intelligence in a similar fashion, the officials said. Microwave traffic along the East Coast is reportedly collected by listening stations at Soviet residential compounds in Glen Cove, L.I., and on the Maryland shore. The officials said a Soviet residence in the Riverdale section of the Bronx and the Soviet Consulate in San Francisco were ideal for microwave interception because of their elevation. Issue of Microwave Interception **********Telephone transmissions travel by microwave or by satellite, as well as by land lines. The Russians are able to intercept much of that, officials say, from an electronic complex at Lourdes, Cuba. **********But the Cuban installation cannot intercept microwave transmissions that travel close to the earth. An expert on intelligence, James Bamford, said the interception of microwave beams required receivers near the relay or repeater stations, which are placed every 30 miles or so to account for the curvature of the earth. **********''Microwaves travel mostly in a straight line between the stations,'' he said. Mr. Bamford and other experts said interception devices did not have to be within a direct line of sight of a relay tower. The beams have side lobes that extend a half a mile or more outside of the direct beam and can be detected. **********A former American official said the present Soviet Embassy in Washington was surrounded by taller buildings that made eavesdropping difficult. **********''Mount Alto lets them do a large volume uninterrupted by lots of interference,'' he said. Reagan Pledge Held Meaningless **********An American University professor who has written on electronic intelligence, Jeffrey T. Richelson, said of the 350-foot Mount Alto, ''It is electronically quieter up there.'' **********Because of the reports that the new American Embassy being built in Moscow is riddled with bugging devices, President Reagan has pledged that the Russians will not be allowed to move into the new embassy on Mount Alto until the United States is satisfied it has a secure embassy in Moscow. But State Department officials say this is meaningless since the Russians already occupy residences on the Mount Alto site, as do the Americans on the Moscow site. **********The National Security Agency, which is also responsible for protecting American communications, has been trying to foil Soviet eavesdropping. Among plans being considered are encoding the signals that travel through the atmosphere or using telephone cables or fiber optics. **********''The way it works now,'' a former official said, ''is that when you pick up a telephone in the Pentagon to make a call, you have no idea how it is going to be transmitted.'' Calls Switched Automatically **********Automatic switching equipment routes the call by land line, satellite or microwave, depending on which method is most efficient at the time. **********Even if a call is sent by land line, it may eventually be transferred to a microwave relay tower at either Tenley Circle or Waldorf, Md., another center for microwave transmission. **********To counter this problem, the National Security Agency has developed a secure telephone that it hopes to place in Government offices and those of military contractors. The device, which encodes a conversation at the sending end and decodes it at the receiving end, is said to be cheaper and less unwieldy than its predecessors. The National Security Agency would like the Government to buy 500,000 such phones. **********But for now, the growing sentiment on Capitol Hill is merely to expel the Russians from Mount Alto. Representative Richard Armey, Republican of Texas, who is sponsoring legislation to scrap the 1969 agreement that designated Mount Alto as the site, has distributed more than 500 lapel buttons saying, ''Reclaim Mt. Alto.'' **********Some security officials said it would be better to allow the Russians to remain at Mount Alto and use the money to protect sensitive communications.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/21/busin.snippet: LEAD: AT least half of typical bank customers would consider switching their savings and checking accounts to another bank if that bank sold mutual funds, according to a recent survey by Market Facts Inc., a Chicago research firm.
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/21/busin.main_headline:
INVESTING;
Buying Mutual Funds at the Bank
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/21/busin.print_headline:
INVESTING;
Buying Mutual Funds at the Bank
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/21/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: AT least half of typical bank customers would consider switching their savings and checking accounts to another bank if that bank sold mutual funds, according to a recent survey by Market Facts Inc., a Chicago research firm. **********AT least half of typical bank customers would consider switching their savings and checking accounts to another bank if that bank sold mutual funds, according to a recent survey by Market Facts Inc., a Chicago research firm. **********Afraid of losing customers, banks all over the country - including the Zion Bank in Utah, First Tennessee, Chemical Bank in New York and Continental Illinois in Chicago - have teamed up with mutual fund organizations such as the Dreyfus Corporation, Fidelity Investments and Federated Securities. Chemical began offering its customers mutual funds because of the ''tremendous demand'' for them, said Gary M. Sherman, senior vice president. Investors can now buy mutual funds at almost two-thirds of the country's largest banks. **********Buying mutual funds through a bank provides individuals with convenience and, in some cases, comfort. Depositors can make their investments in stock and bond funds at the same place they bank. And instead of talking to a disembodied voice over a toll-free telephone line, they can sit down with someone they know at their local branch. If a problem arises with a statement, they can discuss it, in person, with someone from the bank. **********But there are costs and limitations involved in such arrangements. Like stockbrokers who sell mutual funds, bankers want to earn the greatest profit on the service. Consequently, many banks are inclined to offer their customers mutual funds that carry a sales ''load'' of 4 to 5 percent of their investment, the bulk of which the bank keeps. A survey by Alliance Capital Management found that 57 percent of the banks provided their customers with load funds last year, up from 31 percent in 1985. Of course, some banks provide no-load funds, such as those offered by Dreyfus and Fidelity, as well. **********Individuals tend to trust their banks. As a result, they expect the bank to provide the best or the most well-known funds. But banks may be more concerned with earning the highest commission and, therefore, like the typical stockbroker, offer only those funds that promised the most profit to the salesman, not necessarily those that offered the best returns to investors. **********Individuals may also face additional costs if they invest in mutual funds through a bank or thrift institution. The banks want to establish relationships with these consumers. At Manufacturers Hanover Trust, for instance, an individual is required to open an account with the bank before he can invest in some of the funds. **********Of course, the Glass-Steagall Act prohibits banks from distributing or promoting mutual funds, activities that are considered risky and better placed in the domain of investment banks. But they can manage the assets or serve as a shareholder agent for funds distributed by other organizations. Depositors at Citibank branches, for example, can pick up information on the Landmark Funds Broker Dealer Services. And Manufacturers Hanover depositors have access to funds managed by Dreyfus and Federated. **********Obviously, buying mutual funds through a bank makes sense chiefly for people who do not know how to or do not want to initiate their own investing program - those who have long depended on brokers or financial planners. ''We're all trying to see how we can reach them,'' said Howard Stein, chairman of Dreyfus, which has attracted $1.2 billion through arrangements with 190 banks. **********Those who know what they want can do their own research, decide on a fund, pick up the phone and deal directly with organizations such as Fidelity, T. Rowe Price Associates or the Vanguard Group. Those who do not know might walk into one of the 35 banks - including the First Interstate Bank of Wisconsin and the Wilmington Trust Company in Wilmington, Del., - that recently agreed to offer the Liberty funds designed by Federal Securities to be offered to bank customers. The family of Liberty funds includes a money market fund, a tax-exempt money market fund, a traditional growth stock fund, a municipal bond fund, a corporate bond fund and a fund investing only in securities of the Government National Mortgage Association. **********Individuals pay a sales commission of 4 1/2 percent to invest in most of the Liberty funds; the bank keeps 4 percent. The two money market funds have no commission, said James F. Getz, senior vice president of Federated. **********In addition, individuals pay the bank an annual distribution fee of half of 1 percent of the value of their account. On top of that, the customer pays Federated management fees that range upward from three-quarters of 1 percent. **********Individuals, especially if they are paying a sales commission, should demand information detailing how their funds have done over three- and five-year periods, preferably the data prepared by Lipper Analytical Services, an independent monitoring firm. Individuals investing in a growth stock fund or a Ginnie Mae fund, for example, should ask the banker for performance data on similar funds so they can compare results. **********No one yet knows how successful these bank/fund managers, as a group, have been in attracting customer dollars. None of the trade groups keep statistics. The seven funds that Landmark Funds Broker Dealer Services distributes through Citibank have attracted almost $800 million, according to Philip W. Coolidge, vice president of Massachusetts Financial Services, Landmark's parent. Chemical Bank said that a tax-free bond fund managed by its subsidiary had attracted $120 million. **********But its relationship with Fidelity has not been a ''rip-roaring success,'' Mr. Sherman said. ''Equity funds are not an easy sell,'' he said. Many people believe bank customers are more inclined to invest in safer, fixed-income securities.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/07/busin.body_text: **********Trading begins today in Japan's over-the-counter market for newly issued shares of the Avon Products Company, an offshoot of the American cosmetics concern. **********Trading in the new Avon stock follows a public offering last Tuesday of 27.1 million shares at a price of 1,080 yen a share through underwriters led by the Nomura Securities Company. **********The sale, which represented a 40 percent interest in Avon Products Company, raised about 29 billion yen, or $216.4 million, making it the third-largest initial public offering of stock in Japan since 1984, and the largest in the over-the-counter market in that period. **********The financing was a reminder of how, in the Tokyo market, company share prices are much higher relative to earnings than in the American market. At 1,080 yen, slightly more than $8 a share, Avon Products Company sold in Tokyo at about 62 times its 1986 earnings per share and 43 times its estimated 1987 earnings. On the same day, the American parent company Avon Products Inc. closed at $23 a share on the New York Stock Exchange, or about 10 times its per-share earnings of the last 12 months.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/20/busin.main_headline: Odd Takeover Bid Ends In Ouster at Keystone
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/20/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Odd Takeover Bid Ends In Ouster at Keystone
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/20/busin.body_text: **********The Keystone Medical Corporation, a small company involved in drug and diagnostic testing, is not well known outside its field, and last week it baffled the Ragen Corporation with a press release announcing an unsolicited tender offer. **********In the release, Arnold B. Finestone, president and chief executive of Keystone Medical, said the Columbia, Md., company would offer to acquire Ragen, a maker of electronic equipment in North Arlington, N.J., in a one-for-one exchange of shares as a way to broaden its business base. That began a mysterious series of events that have still not been completely explained. **********Last Wednesday, two days after the initial press release, Keystone issued a statement ''disavowing all news releases made on Oct. 12.'' It said the Keystone board had never considered such an acquisition and had not authorized any discussion. **********Then, on Friday, Keystone said that Mr. Finestone had been dismissed -relieved of all corporate duties, including his position on the board. **********''We're a little shaken here, to say the least,'' the telephone operator at Keystone said. No Keystone executives were available to speak about the incident. Calls were referred to John Thomas, a lawyer at Marcus & Marcus, a Philadelphia law firm representing Keystone, who did not returns calls. Sylvia Dresner of Brown Boxenbaum Inc., Keystone's public relations firm in New York, referred calls to Mr. Thomas. **********At Ragen, Ronald Jerome, who handles investor relations, said the incident was being reviewed by the company's lawyers. Mr. Jerome said Ira Lopata, Ragen's chief executive, received a phone call from someone at Keystone last Monday, but he did not know who called. **********At Keystone, James L. Goddard, chairman, was named acting president to succeed Mr. Finestone. Dr. Goddard is a former Commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration. Keystone's major product, developed by a subsidiary, is a quick preliminary test that can be used in the workplace to detect the use of abusive drugs.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/22/busin.main_headline: Kirshenbaum & Bond Begins With One Client
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/22/busin.print_headline: ADVERTISING; Kirshenbaum & Bond Begins With One Client
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/22/busin.body_text: **********Richard Kirshenbaum, 26 years old, and Jonathan H. Bond, 29, who as freelancers were responsible for the moderately controversal print campaign that has been running for Kenneth Cole shoes, have started Kirshenbaum & Bond, with the shoemaker as their first client. **********One ad for Cole chides Imelda Marcos, a shoe enthusiast, for having so many shoes but no Coles. Another shows the bottom half of the Statue of Liberty with this alleged Cole quote: ''We salute a great American woman. Despite her taste in footwear.'' Still another ad features a quotation from Mr. Cole, ''Would you rather be in their shoes?'' under the pictures of President Corazon C. Aquino of the Philippines, Ivan F. Boesky and President Reagan. That one brought a cautionary note from the White House telling the admen that tradition forbids use of American Presidents in ads. Last month a full-page ad, illustrated with only a single packaged condom, had this Cole line: ''Our shoes are not the only things we encourage you to wear.'' **********The two men - Mr. Kirshenbaum, the copywriter, and Mr. Bond, the account man - met at Korey, Kay & Partners. The former, most recently at J. Walter Thompson, had also worked at David Deutsch Associates. Mr. Bond did some time at Jordan, Manning, Case, Taylor & McGrath. He most recently was at Sacks & Rosen. **********They can be found - in their incorporated state - at 310 Madison Avenue, near 42d Street.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/26/world.main_headline: WORRIES FOR DEMOCRACY ON THE RISE IN HONG KONG
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/26/world.print_headline: WORRIES FOR DEMOCRACY ON THE RISE IN HONG KONG
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/26/world.body_text: **********Apprehensions are growing among some residents of this capitalist enclave that China and Britain together are choking off the prospects for a democratic future for Hong Kong. **********To those who are calling for a democratic political system in Hong Kong, recent events suggest two unfortunate conclusions: that Hong Kong needs democracy now more than ever, and that Hong Kong is now less likely than ever to get it. **********''It looks as if both London and Beijing have taken the position that they will move so slowly as to be imperceptible'' in increasing democratic participation, said Peter B. Harris, chairman of the political science department at the University of Hong Kong. **********Hong Kong, a British territory managed by a British-appointed Governor and other appointed British and local officials, will revert to China in just a decade's time. Some people feel that unless they extract democratic concessions from Britain now they will be unable to get them from China for the period after 1997. Review Is Awaited **********British appointed officials will review the territory's political system this year. But the latest indications are that a significant move toward direct elections of legislators is unlikely to result. **********If directly elected legislators seem less likely now, the bulk of the population seems to be taking the situation with equanimity. The residents of this upwardly mobile jumble of skyscrapers and warrens tend to regard the important things in life as including shark's fin soup, expensive wristwatches and a growing bank account, while public-opinion surveys place politics quite low on the list of priorities. **********Yet concern over the present system has mounted in recent weeks because of several incidents in which officials were accused of ignoring public opinion. This could not be proved, for in the system it is difficult to gauge what the public wants. Nevertheless, the resentment has lingered and infected the political debate over direct elections. **********One of the most recent disputes was caused by the disclosure last month that the Hong Kong Government has been censoring films, apparently without legal authority, for 34 years. The most common objection to the censored films was that they would offend China. Some questionable films reportedly were even sent to the New China News Agency, Beijing's unofficial embassy in Hong Kong, for assessment. **********The Government's reaction to the disclosure has been to propose a bill that would correct the defect and provide clear authority for censorship. New Press Law Irks **********Another dispute was caused by a revised press law that provides for fines and up to two years' imprisonment for publishing ''false news which is likely to cause alarm to the public.'' The press in Hong Kong has reacted bitterly. The Chinese-language Hong Kong Daily News, for example, printed an obituary for freedom of the press in the spot normally reserved for its editorials. **********''People are getting more and more frustrated with the Legislative Council going against people's wishes,'' said Albert W. Y. Chan, a Canadian-educated local politician. Like many others in the democratic movement, Mr. Chan suggests that Britain has betrayed the territory. He argues that London places more emphasis on good relations with Beijing than on leaving Hong Kong with democratic protections. **********The concerns of those favoring direct elections were amplified by a cautious inaugural speech this month by Hong Kong's new Governor, Sir David Wilson. Sir David, wearing the traditional white starched uniform of a British colonial governor, warned: **********''If there is to be change, it should be prudent and gradual. It must not disrupt the steady progress we have been making, nor the stability which we prize.'' **********Sir David's sentiments where echoed last week by Deng Xiaoping, China's paramount leader, in comments to Hong Kong leaders visiting Beijing. In the strongest caution so far from China against bold moves toward democratic institutions, Mr. Deng said: **********''The political system in Hong Kong cannot copy that in the West. The present system has gone through one and a half centuries. It is not proper to copy completely the parliamentary system in Britain or the United States and to judge whether this is democracy or not.'' Democracy Provokes Suspicion **********It is not clear whether more people were dismayed by that rebuff to the democratic movement, gladdened by it, or bored by it. From an American perspective, it is striking how suspicious people here are of democracy, because of the turmoil and instability it spawns. **********''Hong Kong might be the only place in the world where, in a free election, the population conceivably would vote not to have a democracy,'' a company chairman mused recently over lunch. **********A poll conducted in late January for The South China Morning Post, a local newspaper, reported that only 6 percent of those interviewed favored the direct election of all legislators. Over all, 34 percent favored the direct election of at least a few legislators, 52 percent opposed any direct elections, and 9 percent had no opinion. **********In a more telling hint at local priorities, only 3 percent of those surveyed said they were ''very interested'' in what electoral system was chosen. Thirty-nine percent said they were ''not at all interested,'' and 43 percent said they were ''slightly interested.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/17/world.main_headline: SOUTH KOREA VOTE BACKS CANDIDATE OF RULING PARTY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/17/world.print_headline: SOUTH KOREA VOTE BACKS CANDIDATE OF RULING PARTY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/17/world.body_text: **********Roh Tae Woo, the candidate of the Government party, registered a surprisingly sturdy victory today over a divided opposition in South Korea's first genuine presidential election in 16 years. **********But Mr. Roh's triumph was tarnished, and perhaps seriously tainted, by opposition charges of across-the-board cheating and ballot-rigging in the election Wednesday. **********The accusations, most of them difficult to confirm independently and some exaggerated, were nonetheless accepted as articles of faith in dissident circles. Fear of Street Protests **********That belief raised a great risk that South Korea's streets would once again become battle grounds between the police and anti-Government militants who say they will not accept Mr. Roh's victory as fairly earned. **********Unofficial tallies carried on the state-run Korean Broadcasting System showed Mr. Roh with 36.5 percent of the votes after more than 85 percent of them had been counted through early afternoon. **********Far behind were the rival opposition leaders, Kim Young Sam, with about 27 percent, and Kim Dae Jung, with about 26 percent. Another candidate, Kim Jong Pil, had about 8 percent, and a minor party figure, Shin Jeong Yil, had about 3 percent. Hard Words on Both Sides **********People in the opposition camp warned that they would mount sustained protests, and some spoke of revolution to bring down a Government that they call a military dictatorhip. **********For its part, the ruling Democratic Justice Party implied that the Government was prepared to take a hard line. A spokesman, Kim Chung Wi, said in a statement that street demonstrations planned for Friday would be considered ''an act that can hardly escape the people's censure and the just judgment of law.'' **********It appeared that immediate stability depended a good deal on public perceptions of whether the election was by and large fair. That might take a little while to emerge as South Koreans debate whether to accept the fraud charges or to blame opposition politicians for splitting the vote and letting Mr. Roh slip past. **********The answers are likely to determine whether large numbers of ordinary citizens join hard-core anti-Government activists in the streets, and then whether the disorders grow severe enough to prompt military intervention. **********The election returns so far show a surprisingly large spread in Mr. Roh's favor, considering the fact that many political analysts had considered the race to be close. In fact, one analyst said in the days before the balloting that he saw a ''40 percent probability'' that the real contest was between Kim Young Sam and Kim Dae Jung. Mr. Roh showed unexpected strength across the country. In Seoul, which has 25 percent of the electorate and where he had been expected to finish third, he was instead running a narrow second to Kim Dae Jung. **********His plurality of 2 million votes, as of this morning, may bolster charges that the election was rigged, especially from the two Kims and their ardent followers, who had believed that there was no honest way for them to lose. **********On the other hand, the Kims combined had a lead of 3.3 million votes over Mr. Roh, lending credence to complaints -from supporters as well as critics -that it was their inability to set aside personal ambitions that had led to electoral disaster. **********Together, they had about 53 percent of the vote, surpassing the 46 percent that Kim Dae Jung had captured in the last true election, in 1971, when he ran against President Park Chung Hee in a two-man race. **********Final figures from Wednesday's balloting are expected this afternoon. Roh Was Named as Successor **********Mr. Roh (pronounced no), a former general who joined in the 1980 coup that created the present Government of President Chun Doo Hwan, had hoped to inherit the country's highest office by appointment. Mr. Chun, a longtime ally, had designated him as his successor last June. **********But that touched off angry street protests, which spread across South Korea and forced the Government to yield to opposition demands for a direct presidential election and other democratic changes. **********As it turns out, South Koreans have acquired through elections the same leader they would have inherited had there been no demonstrations or changes in the Constitution. **********But Mr. Roh's advisers insist that he will be different from Mr. Chun, despite their similar backgrounds. He will be less authoritarian and more willing to listen, they say, arguing that the events of June made him realize that a more conciliatory leadership style was required for a country of growing prosperity and pluralism. No Statements by Major Rivals **********Mr. Roh, who is to take office Feb. 25, said in a statement this morning that he would strive for ''stability and reconciliation'' and he extended an olive branch to the opposition, saying, ''I will be most willing to listen to their advice.'' **********But he nonetheless took an indirect swipe at his opponents, whom he had denounced during the campaign as bent on bringing chaos to South Korea. He alluded to that theme by calling his triumph ''a victory of the great ordinary people who chose democratic reform with stability and national development without chaos.'' **********At a news conference today, Mr. Roh reiterated a pledge late in the campaign to hold a vote of confidence on his record after the 1988 Seoul Olympics. **********A spokesman for Kim Young Sam said this morning that the Roh victory had been achieved through ''long-planned election rigging,'' which he said led to at least three million votes being ''stolen.'' The spokesman, Kim Jae Kwang, said the ruling camp had campaigned in an ''atmosphere of terror,'' and announced that Kim Young Sam's forces would ''cooperate with dissident organizations'' in resisting the new Roh government. **********Kim Dae Jung had not issued a statement or held a news conference as of this morning. **********A major federation of dissident church and human-rights groups, the National Coalition for Democracy, lost little time in announcing Wednesday that the balloting had been rigged. **********''What took place today was a fraudulent election that was so obvious and of an extent that we have never seen before,'' the group said. It seemed likely that similar statements would come soon from the opposition politicians. **********A rallying point for anti-Government activists could be the Kuro ward office in a working-class section of Seoul south of the Han River, which snakes through the capital. Ballot Box Is Moved **********In one of the more suspicious incidents Wednesday, a woman discovered that election officials were trying to move a ballot box from the ward office, more than six hours before the polls closed. The officials explained that they were simply taking 4,200 absentee ballots to a central counting place. **********But it was not clear why they decided to move the box so early, putting it on the back of an open truck, covering it with packages of dehydrated noodles and pretzels and leaving without any election monitors on hand to guarantee that nothing untoward happened. **********Four young men from Kim Dae Jung's party hurried to the large courtyard outside the ward office and seized control of the box. For hours they sat on it, arms locked, to prevent anyone from taking it. **********In the meantime, other opposition figures rushed to scene and demanded explanations from district leaders. They forced a senior election official, Kang Shil Won, to stand before them in a mock trial, grabbing him by the scruff of his neck and demanding, ''Confess your sins.'' **********Through the day, the Kuro ballot box became an opposition symbol of electoral rigging, and about 2,000 people maintained a vigil in the courtyard through the night. Dozens of Episodes Listed **********The National Coalition for Democracy printed lists outlining dozens of episodes in which they accused the Government or ruling party of fraud. These included switching ballot boxes, using ink that smudged easily to invalidate ballots, and relying on a variety of other techniques such as registering people who were dead, had moved or were under age. **********Other charges were that volunteer observers at polling places had been beaten in some precincts by thugs said to have been hired by the Democratic Justice Party. In turn, the ruling party asserted that more than a dozen of its members had been kidnapped, beaten and kicked by pro-opposition forces. **********Early today nine people were seized by dissidents for purported election fraud and were taken to Kim Dae Jung's headquarters. There, they were forced to kneel and to keep their heads down as they ''confessed'' to their crimes. **********Most of the charges, however, were difficult to verify. For example, allegations of ''relay voting'' repeatedly arose. This is a payoff system in which people are bribed to keep a flow of unmarked ballots in constant circulation for potential use by the ruling party. **********Many anti-Government activists said they had heard of incidents of relay voting, but relatively few actually saw it. Doubts About Some Charges **********Doubts about the many accusations were raised by the leader of an international observer team, one of several foreign groups that had come to watch the election. **********''There does not appear to be, based on what we've seen, widespread election day fraud,'' said Steven Schneebaum of the International Human Rights Law Group. **********Mr. Schneebaum stressed, however, that the observation was confined to election day itself. It did not include the many charges of earlier corruption, including rampant spending by the ruling camp and television coverage on the state-run network that was often biased.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/01/world.main_headline: Turkish Press: Dailies in Display of Freedom
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/01/world.print_headline: Turkish Press: Dailies in Display of Freedom
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/01/world.body_text: **********Turkey's eight main daily newspapers, some with a panchromatic flourish of news and some with near-naked flesh, hit the streets each day in a robust display of freedoms gathered since the military withdrew from power four years ago. **********Nearly all are anti-Government, taunting Prime Minister Turgut Ozal to the point of exasperation. The newspapers' editors like to suggest that they have become the custodians of political opposition and the barometer of democratic revival. **********A debate simmers over the newspapers' effectiveness in molding opinion in this land, where the ruling party monopolizes television and radio to the extent of planning pro-Government commercials for rented home videos. **********A Western diplomat said the newspapers, with a total circulation of around 3 million among the nation's 55 million people, have not kept pace with population growth, while television has spread across the nation. **********''What the referendum made clear,'' the diplomat said, referring to a vote Sept. 6 that narrowly restored political rights to leading former politicians, is that television is very important. ''The Turkish public by and large does not read newspapers.'' **********Thus, the diplomat argued, while the press campaigned virtually unanimously for the restoration of political rights in the referendum, the result offered only a slender victory. **********Those suggestions seem to make journalists bristle. ''The other side of the story,'' said Erturul Ozkok, the Ankara bureau chief of Hurriyet, the country's biggest daily, ''is that at the beginning of the referendum campaign, there was a large proportion of people who wanted to vote 'no' to the lifting of the political bans.'' **********Noting that Prime Minister Ozal wanted to keep the bans, he characterized the press's unanimity in opposition to him as ''a great triumph for Turkish democracy.'' **********Moreover, Mr. Ozkok said in an interview, the formal opposition in Parliament was enfeebled by internal division, so the press ''assumed the role.'' Press Reaches 'the Influential' **********''The press is influential,'' he said, ''because in Turkey we have a political caste, a political elite which is very powerful in forming peoples' opinions. The press reaches these people.'' The debate sometimes wallows in sleazier concerns. Some newspapers, for instance, are restrained only by strict antipornography laws from extending the acreage of female nudity adorning their pages. Others have slid from positions of prestige by trying to match that appeal to potential readers. ''The press,'' said Ilnur Cevik, editor of the English-language Turkish Daily News, ''has lost its reliability, its credibility, because most of the news that they come up with usually comes out wrong.'' He apparently excluded his own publication from the assessment. **********Yet in a land scrutinized by others for clues to its ability to implant democracy after three military interventions in less than 30 years, the bigger issue seems to be not so much the quality as the freedom most editors say they now enjoy. **********During the generals' last period of supremacy, from 1980 to 1983, most newspapers were fettered, closed for varying periods, and under constant scrutiny. **********Laws still prohibit the advocacy of Communism or separatism, or criticism of the period of military rule. Journalists are forbidden from endangering Turkey's relations with other countries. **********The ABC television series ''Amerika,'' which depicted an America under Soviet rule, was withdrawn after Soviet protest. #2 Magazines Seized Two Istanbul weekly magazines were seized this year because of articles about the Kurdish minority, a sensitive matter because authorities do not acknowledge a separate Kurdish identity. **********Some restrictions, said Hassan Cemal, editor of Cumhuriyet, the most respected daily, have led to what he called contradictions. The law, for instance, might outlaw the encouragement of Communism, he said, but pro-Communist weeklies are published.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/08/world.main_headline: NORTH'S AIDES LINKED TO AUSTRALIA STUDY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/08/world.print_headline: NORTH'S AIDES LINKED TO AUSTRALIA STUDY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/08/world.body_text: **********Several former military and intelligence officers who helped Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North ship weapons to Iran and Central America were closely associated with the co-founder of an Australian financial concern that collapsed in 1980, according to an Australian Government investigation. **********The collapse of the financial concern came amid charges that it had laundered money earned from weapons and illicit drug sales. **********Among those linked to the failed Sydney-based concern, Nugan Hand Bank, and its co-founder, Michael J. Hand, was Richard V. Secord, a retired Air Force major general who helped Colonel North conduct airlifts of weapons to the Middle East and Central America, according to the four-year-old Australian investigation. **********The Australian study, parts of which are still secret, was conducted by the Commonwealth-New South Wales Joint Task Force on Drug Trafficking and was completed in March 1983. Although it is not new, the study is receiving scrutiny again in Washington because of the details about activities and movement of weapons around the world by many of the same figures involved in the Iran-contra affair. Congressional Interest **********The Australian report, which has stirred Congressional interest, also concluded that several former Central Intelligence Agency officials and contract operatives, among them Theodore G. Shackley, Thomas G. Clines and Rafael Quintero, were involved in military and intelligence-related activities with Mr. Hand and other top officers of the Nugan Hand concern. **********The Tower Commission report on the Iran-contra affair and other published reports have linked all of these men to operations in the Middle East and Central America directed by Colonel North, the National Security Council aide dismissed last November. **********Mr. Secord and the other men in the network are the focus of a Senate Foreign Relations Committee investigation. The Australian study, a Congressional aide said, provides additional evidence that will help the committee determine whether this group simultaneously functioned over the years as official Government intelligence agents while also conducting legal and illegal operations for profit. **********''Given the recent revelations about these men, I am greatly concerned,'' said Senator Edward Zorinsky of Nebraska, a member of the Foreign Relations Committee, hours before he died of a heart attack Friday. Clues Seen in Study **********Investigators with the Senate and House Select Committees on Iran also are interested in what the Australian study says about Mr. Secord and his network. The study could provide clues to help them understand why Colonel North turned to Mr. Secord. **********The Australian study does not demonstrate that Mr. Secord, Mr. Shackley, Mr. Clines or Mr. Quintero smuggled weapons or narcotics. It does, however, say that these men were close to Mr. Hand, a former Army Green Beret and military intelligence officer who served in Laos during the late 1960's with a C.I.A.-owned airline named Air America. It was the same period in which Mr. Secord played a large role in directing Air America's operations. Mr. Shackley and Mr. Clines were the two top officers of the C.I.A's Laotian station during this period as well, the report said. Mr. Hand, the report said, later worked with these men while he was directing his merchant bank, which he established in the early 1970's with Francis J. Nugan, an Australian. **********The Joint Task Force study was one of four that has been published in Australia since the bank collapsed after the death by suicide of Mr. Nugan in late January 1980 at 37. Six months later, Michael Hand, then 38, disappeared and has still not been found. Agreements and Disipute **********Two other Australian studies confirm the Joint Task Force findings. But the most recent investigation, a Royal Commission study published in 1985, disputes some of the Joint Task Force conclusions. **********During the seven years it was in business, according to the Joint Task Force study, the Nugan Hand bank was engaged in a wide range of legitimate and illegal activities conducted from offices and mail drops in 13 countries in two hemispheres, including the United States, the Cayman Island, Hong Kong, Taiwan, the Philippines and Thailand. The report named 26 reputed drug dealers and provided a schedule of drug traffickers. **********Although reluctant to draw conclusions, the report noted that Mr. Hand did extensive business with American intelligence officers in Southeast Asia in the late 1960's and early 70's, and said there was ''evidence'' that ''Hand retained his U.S. intelligence ties through the 1970's and probably the 1980s.'' The evidence, however, remained classified. **********The Joint Task Force was told by an American witness that Mr. Hand was involved in deals, including a profitable 1976 shipment of 10 million rounds of ammunition and 3,000 weapons, including rifles and machine guns, that went from Boston, through Africa, ''and were eventually delivered to U.S. intelligence supported forces in Angola.'' #1976 Sale to Iran Mr. Hand and his bank, the report said, also took part in the movement by the United States Navy of a ''spy vessel'' to the Iranian Navy in 1976. **********Mr. Hand was said to have taken part in both of these transactions with Edwin P. Wilson, a former C.I.A. agent and head of a secret Navy intelligence group called Task Force 157. Mr. Wilson was arrested in 1982 and later convicted of selling arms and 20 tons of plastic explosive to Libya. **********The report said Mr. Wilson was close to Mr. Secord, Mr. Shackley, Mr. Clines and Mr. Quintero through their participation in intelligence and secret military operations for 20 years. **********Mr. Wilson, the report said, loaned Mr. Clines $500,000 to start a company that ostensibly distributed oil drilling equipment around the world and had offices in Houston. The company, A.P.I. Distributors Inc., also employed Mr. Shackley and Mr. Quintero, the report said. A.P.I. shared office space in Houston with a company controlled by Mr. Wilson, Around the World Shipping and Chartering, which United States officials said was instrumental in smuggling the explosives to Libya. Millions in Deposits **********Mr. Hand and his bank, the Australian study said, did business with Mr. Clines, Mr. Shackley and Mr. Quintero. But the report did not elaborate on the details of the business arrangements. **********The report did note, however, that Mr. Clines deposited ''millions of dollars'' in the Nugan Hand bank. **********On the day that the body of a co-founder, Francis Nugan, was discovered in Australia, said the report, Maurice Bernard Houghton, a top Hand officer and former American special forces team leader, arrived at Mr. Wilson's office in Geneva. According to an unidentified witness, Mr. Houghton left a travel case, then departed. In April, the report said, as the Nugan Hand affair began to cause a stir in Australia, Tom Clines and Rafael Quintero arrived at Mr. Wilson's Geneva office. **********According to the witness, both men ''expressed some concern over what might be in the bag and Tom said that he wanted to take the bag from me.'' The witness said he refused, but the others persisted. ''Eventually the bag was opened in all our presence.'' **********Mr. Clines and Mr. Quintero, the report said, studied the documents inside and removed one. ''During the search, Richard Secord's name was mentioned and Clines said, 'We've got to keep Dick's name out of this.' '' **********Numerous attempts were made to reach Mr. Secord, Mr. Shackley, Mr. Clines, and Mr. Quintero to discuss the Australian Joint Task Force report, without success. The lawyer for Mr. Clines and Mr. Shackley said their clients could not comment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/12/world.main_headline: SRI LANKA REBELS AND INDIAN TROOPS FIGHT FOR 3D DAY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/12/world.print_headline: SRI LANKA REBELS AND INDIAN TROOPS FIGHT FOR 3D DAY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/12/world.body_text: **********Tamil guerrillas attacked Indian peacekeeping forces in the Jaffna Peninsula today with mortars, machine guns and rocket-propelled grenades, according to Sri Lankan Government radio, and the Indians responded with heavy counterattacks. **********According to Government television reports tonight, 120 Tamil fighters have been killed and a unknown number wounded since Thursday night, when the Indians began to disarm and capture guerrillas defying a peace accord. The Government reported on Saturday that 10 guerrillas had been killed fighting the Indians. **********The Sri Lankan radio said two Indian soldiers were killed today by a land mine in Jaffna. Six or eight Indians -the number is now in dispute - were killed Saturday in the Jaffna area. Sri Lankan authorities reported that at least 19 Indians were wounded today. Enforcing Peace Accord **********Indian Army troops and police officers are in Sri Lanka to enforce the peace agreement that country signed with India in July. Under the agreement, Tamil militants were to turn in their weapons in return for amnesty and a place in the political process which has been dominated by Sri Lanka's Sinhalese majority. **********Several hundred Tamils have been captured by Indian troops in the north and east. More than 800 pounds of explosives plus two barrels of gelignite were reportedly seized this weekend in the Trincomalee area, where a munitions factory was also destroyed. Six Tiger camps were raided in Batticaloa. **********Reliable information on the fighting and the casualties on both sides is sketchy and hard to get. The Indians have put Jaffna under indefinite curfew, making movement in the city impossible, and the only casualty figures available come from sketchy reports on Sri Lankan radio and television. Third Day of Gun Battles **********Indian troops ordered civilians in Jaffna to report to designated centers for safety as the peacekeeping forces went into their third day of gun battles with the Tamil militants. **********As Indian troops moved more aggressively into Tamil areas in the Jaffna Peninsula and in the Eastern Province districts of Trincomalee and Batticaloa, refugees from those areas continued to arrive in Colombo and other towns in safe areas. **********More than 10,000 refugees have fled Eastern Province, according to early figures from the Rehabilitation Ministry. In addition, about 15,000 people from the countryside have sought shelter in Trincomalee, which is now under Indian control. **********Nationwide, it is believed that more than 100,000 people have been displaced by four years of guerrilla warfare. The Government had hoped to begin moving them back home after the peace agreement was signed on July 29. Those hopes have now been set aside. **********The latest refugees arriving here, interviewed in temples and other makeshift centers, said Tamil guerrilla bands appeared to have been engaged in an organized campaign over the last two weeks to drive ethnic Sinhalese from areas over which Tamils seek political control. **********A reporter visiting a Buddhist child-care center pressed into service as a refugee camp met a 22-year-old epileptic woman still in a state of shock after her mother was reported burned to death. Another young woman, all her possessions resting on a grass mat, was trying to care for a 14-day-old baby. **********Refugees, almost all of them Sinhalese from rural villages in the Trincomalee or Batticaloa areas, also said that in many cases Indian peacekeeping troops had stood by while settlements were attacked by Tamil guerrillas, who burned their homes and drove them into the jungle. **********Several refugees said they had recognized Indian uniforms or heard people speaking English, not usual among Tamil crowds. They also said Tamil militants had often arrived in villages during curfew hours, sometimes in what appeared to be Indian Army vehicles. **********A 38-year-old refugee from the village of Mihindupura, six miles from Trincomalee, said that when he ran to a military outpost to report an attack on his village by about 40 armed men, he found the Sri Lankan officers he was seeking surrounded by Indian soldiers, who would not let him approach them. **********The man, Wimalaratne, said when he protested, he was pushed back by an Indian soldier with the butt of a rifle. He pulled back his shirt to reveal a bruised and swollen shoulder. **********He is now searching for his wife and children, who had fled toward north-central Sri Lanka, he was later told. All around him were other refugees with similar stories of broken families. **********Another refugee, from Silmapura village, said that as he and dozens of his neighbors fled a Tamil attack on their homes after dark last Monday, Indian troops in the path of their escape fired, killing two people before letting the refugees pass. **********All refugees said, however, that there had been no serious problems with the Indian peacekeeping forces before the end of September, when the Liberation Tigers began violent campaigns against less militant Tamil separatists and against Sinhalese people living in traditional Tamil areas. Role of Tigers' Leader **********Details now beginning to come together indicate that a first round of violence beginning at the end of September may have been ordered by the leader of the Tigers, Vellupillai Prabakaran, after he failed to force the Sri Lankan Government to accept his nominee to head a newly created regional council for the north and east. **********A second round of violence, leaving more than 200 people dead, began Oct. 5 after 14 Tamil Tigers, who had been captured while trying to travel to southern India, committed suicide by swallowing cyanide to avoid being taken into Sri Lankan Government custody. Among the 14 were several important guerrilla leaders. **********Indian troops are reported to have been caught off guard by the outbreaks. They may have also been hampered in their response by rules requiring that military action had to be approved through a chain of command stretching back to New Delhi.  New Delhi Deplores Killings NEW DELHI, Oct. 11 (Special to The New York Times) - An Indian Government spokesman today deplored the killing of as many as 8 Indian soldiers and paramilitary policemen Saturday and declared that India would ''deal appopriately'' with such violence. **********In the southern Indian city of Madras, which has been the political headquarters of the guerrilla groups, the police today raided offices of the Liberation Tigers and seized communication equipment that had enabled the militants to maintain links with Jaffna, the Press Trust of India said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/01/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********Rimmer de Vries states that ''when high inflation in a foreign country pushes up local currency selling prices, say by 50 percent, then a 50 percent depreciation of the dollar against that currency leaves the United States competitive position unchanged.'' (''Taking the Dollar's Measure,'' Forum, Jan. 11). The opposite applies: The United States exporters' position is enhanced where local inflation erodes the competitiveness of local producers. **********That aside, do we read too much into trade-weighted and purchasing power parity analyses, when only 10 percent of the foreign exchange market is accounted for by trade? Would not some method based on financial variables (i.e., supply and demand for assets) in conjunction with a merchandise index serve better to determine an appropriate value of a currency?   EDWIN P. ALTOMARE   Assistant Vice President   Mercantile Bank   St. Louis, Feb. 2

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/13/busin.body_text: **********Takeover efforts swirling around the Holly Sugar Corporation intensified today when the Imperial Sugar Company offered to buy its larger rival in a deal valued as high as $108 million, topping a $102 million bid made last week by an investor group. **********Holly's directors considered both proposals today at a special meeting in New York. The annual meeting of the company is to be held Tuesday at its Colorado Springs headquarters. **********Ron Barusch, a New York lawyer who is advising Holly, said early today that ''there's been no response'' by the board to either offer. He declined to speculate on which bid Holly might favor. **********The offers for Holly, the nation's second-largest sugar beet processor, follow a series of buyout bids that failed over the last five years. Most of those bids from investor groups came in the last year and collapsed for lack of financing. Bid by a Similar Company **********The bid from Imperial, based in Sugar Land, Tex., is the first from an operating company in a similar business and therefore must be weighed differently by Holly, said Marjorie Crough, a securities analyst with Value Line Inc. in New York. **********She suggested that Plum Associates, an investor group led by Peter R. Harvey, an Illinois businessman, might sweeten its bid. But neither bid ''is a sure thing,'' she said, in view of Holly's history. ''There's been so many deals that fall apart,'' she said. **********In Imperial's merger proposal, each Holly share would be exchanged for $68 cash and stock in the combined company, which would be sold to an employee stock ownership plan at $29 each. Afterward, Holly stockholders and the ESOP would each own 23 percent of the company, with the rest apparently owned by Imperial stockholders. The Kempner family owns 92 percent of Imperial. **********Plum Associates, which owns 7.4 percent of Holly, proposed a $91-a-share tender offer for 66 percent of the company's stock. For the rest, Plum would exchange an undetermined number of preferred shares with a market value of $91. Sugar Cane Used by Imperial **********Imperial's roots stem from a sugar plantation of the Civil War era that was acquired by the Kempner family at a distress sale in 1907. Imperial processes sugar from cane rather than beets. The company earned $3.5 million on sales of $247 million in 1985, the latest year for which figures are available. **********The company is named after New York's Imperial Hotel, which was admired by the company's founders, I. H. Kempner of Galveston, Tex., and W. T. Eldridge of Sugar Land. **********The turmoil at Holly comes as the company's prospects look brighter. In its fiscal year ended March 31, the company's profit doubled, to $4.9 million, on sales of $317 million. Holly holds long-term contracts with beet growers and is aided by Federal price supports. **********''We think Holly is a fine company, and we think the combination would be a good one,'' said Isaac Herbert Kempner, 55 years old, a grandson of Imperial's founder. In the event of a merger, Imperial would shift its business strategy and become a marketer of sugar refined from both cane and beets, he said. Bidding Invitation Is Cited **********Although Holly has been a takeover target for some time, Mr. Kempner said Imperial decided to make its first acquisition attempt only after being invited to enter the bidding by an outside director of Holly. He declined to identify the director. **********Asked if he expected Plum to increase its bid, Mr. Kempner said, ''Not having done this before, I'm not sure what to expect.'' **********Discussions with Holly's managers have been under way for several weeks, he said, declining to specify when they began. **********Representatives of Plum Associates met throughout the weekend with Holly executives, according to Franklin Chu, a managing director for L. F. Rothschild & Company of New York, which has agreed to arrange financing for Plum's offer. **********Mr. Chu declined to say if Plum had revised its proposal as a result of the talks. But because of continuing discussions, he said, Plum will keep its offer - which had been set to expire today - on the table. **********In August Holly ended an agreement with a management buyout group led by Michael Buchsbaum, its former chairman, to buy the company for $133 million. In postponing the bid, he mentioned death threats against him and his family. Winner of a Proxy Battle **********Mr. Buchsbaum gained control of Holly in a proxy fight in 1981, and in 1982 he tried to take the company private in a leveraged buyout. That deal and two others proposed by major investors were also aborted. **********Brookehill Equities Inc., a New York investment concern, and Shamrock Holdings Inc. of Burbank, Calif., each own about 9 percent of Holly. In the past, Brookehill and Shamrock said they might try to seek control of the company. **********Executives of Shamrock and Brookehill did not return telephone calls today. **********The sugar industry has long been buffeted by volatile commodity prices and more recently by declining consumption as people turn to non-caloric sweeteners, said A. C. Greene, director of the Center for Texas Studies at the University of North Texas in Denton. **********Mr. Greene said the Kempner family, which built its first sugar refinery in 1895, helped build sugar ''into the industry it is now.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/17/world.body_text: **********A senior Sandinista official said today that his Government was preparing to declare a cease-fire in its war with United States-backed rebels. **********''It will be a sovereign and unilateral act by the Government of Nicaragua,'' said the official, Deputy Interior Minister Luis Carrion Cruz, who is a member of the ruling Sandinista National Directorate. ''We are not considering a negotiation with the leadership of the counterrevolution.'' **********Mr. Carrion said the Government would seek to contact chiefs of rebel units in Nicaragua and to offer them amnesty under terms of the new Central American peace accord. He said these lower-ranking rebel leaders could negotiate ''independent of what the counterrevolutionary leadership decides.'' **********Mr. Carrion's formula preserved the Sandinistas' longstanding refusal to meet with top leaders of the rebels, known as contras. But it left open the possibility that they would agree to meet with lower-level contras, who might act with tacit approval from their superiors. **********A spokesman for the contras, Bosco Matamoros, dismissed Mr. Carrion's announcement as ''a very clear effort to divide and conquer.''
