https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/23/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS FORUM: FINDING THE RIGHT URBAN POLICY; The Cities Need Federal Help
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/23/busin.body_text: **********HARDLY anyone wants to talk about cities these days. President Reagan has largely ignored them. He's cut budgets for urban services and housing. He's talked half-heartedly about ''free market'' solutions like enterprise zones and housing vouchers, but he hasn't committed much political capital to either. **********As a result, cities are raising taxes and fees (in highly regressive ways), reducing services further, and turning to their often-strapped state governments for help. A recent survey showed that one-third of our cities expect their main revenue sources to shrink this year; more than half are slicing capital spending. **********The Administration's position is that what is good for business is good for our cities. If cities make themselves attractive to businesses, the argument goes, we won't need urban policies. A little chamber of commerce boosterism, a few tax breaks, and a smidgen of deregulation are all that is necessary. Wrong. That dog won't hunt. Many urban problems simply don't yield to ''free market'' solutions. The evidence is clear. Poverty and unemployment in cities, especially in minority communities, continue at unconscionable levels. The homeless are not merely drunks, drug addicts and former mental patients. They are increasingly the working poor who have slipped through Mr. Reagan's much-touted ''safety net.'' Even middle-class families are finding housing harder to afford. Urban roads and waste facilities continue to deteriorate as we put off repairs. **********True, stagnant economic growth over the past 15 years makes it politically more difficult to pay for Federal urban programs. But much of the decline in urban programs is due not to lack of money, but to priority shifts, especially in favor of defense spending. Cities have been the centers of economic progress and remain critical financial and service hubs today. Moreover, suburbs are now facing many of the same problems that we have associated with big cities. There is a growing political constituency for active, throughtful programs: three-quarters of our people live in metropolitan areas; polls show that not only do voters want better urban services, but they are willing to pay higher taxes to get them. **********The Democrats, whose constituency has historically been urban, have little to be proud of. After all, they dominate Congress and have signed off on the changes that have occurred since 1981. It is crucial that the Democratic Presidential candidates not ignore the cities. **********In an Iowa debate next month, those candidates will be asked to lay out their urban platforms. What they say may determine the flavor of a critical national debate over urban policy. I hope they answer four major questions: **********FIRST, what are you going to do about urban poverty? Some of the poor are trapped in the morass of welfare and welfare dependency. Others toil, often full time, in low-wage jobs and remain poor. Proposals are now on the table to change our welfare system, including ''workfare'' and the nationalization of Aid to Families with Dependent Children. Other proposals deal with the working poor and call for increasing the minimum wage and new training programs. How can we help employable people make the transition from welfare to work? How can we generate better-paying jobs to reduce the number of working poor? **********Next, what will you do about housing? We face a dreadful housing situation for the poor (including the homeless) and near-poor. Not only has Mr. Reagan dismantled subsidized housing programs, but as many as one million units built or rehabilitated during the 1970's will probably be withdrawn from the subsidized housing market. Here is a classic example of the clash between laissez-faire policy and the realities of urban housing markets. President Reagan's offer of a few vouchers to people in markets in which housing is either scarce or too expensive is a sham. What is the Federal Government's proper role in building and allocating housing? Who will pay for livable, affordable housing? Who will build it? **********Third, should we restructure our Federal system? Ronald Reagan's ''new federalism'' turned most of the responsibility for domestic programs over to the states, without the money to pay for them. Cities, which had a pipeline to the Federal Government, have had to fend for themselves and beg at state houses. Many cities have adopted innovative ways to pay for services and to increase employment. Others have been devastated by economic events. A rethinking of how urban aid is to be organized is in order. Is the present system working well? If not, how would you revise it? **********Finally, and most fundamentally, how will you change government priorities in order to meet the needs of cities? All of this, in the end, is a question of priorities. What will you cut elsewhere in the budget and how will you pay for these programs? Will you raise taxes to pay for highways, housing and poverty aid? It is time to face some very tough choices. **********Most people want better and more efficient urban programs. They also want fresh approaches, not a rehashing of old, tired efforts. This means that we need to reshape policies that reflect today's economy and the next decade's social needs. **********The Democrats have a chance to seize this opportunity and bring forward compassionate and far-sighted programs. We will be watching and listening, both in Iowa and beyond.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/30/world.main_headline: France in Fall? Election Jitters and Seekers of Seers
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/30/world.print_headline: France in Fall? Election Jitters and Seekers of Seers
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/30/world.body_text: **********It is perhaps by definition a season of uncertainty when the 100 most famous clairvoyants and soothsayers of France gather in an expensive Paris hotel for a congress. The publicity surrounding the Salon de la Voyance reveals that the rational France that gave birth to Descartes has lately produced as many seers as doctors. **********The television reporters have had fun earnestly asking the palm readers who is going to be the next President of France. **********It may be the slow slide to the right in the ownership and control of French television or it may be the inherently cautious and conservative nature of those who claim to read the future, but the fortunetellers seem to have their eye on one of the two most likely candidates of the right -Prime Minister Jacques Chirac or Raymond Barre, an erstwhile Prime Minister. **********''It will certainly be the right,'' said Francois-Charles Rambert, a plump, 31-year-old medium who asserted in an interview that he had several Cabinet ministers as confidential customers at his chambers on the Rue St. Honore. ''We all see it.'' Autumn's Air of Uncertainty **********It is not only the incipient campaign for the presidency, which will end in a spring election, that seems to have sown an accent of doubt in a Paris autumn that has been extravagantly sunny, succumbing only gradually to a chill and gray that will presumably vanish just about when the voters go to the polls. **********There is genuine uncertainty about who will win - not everyone believes the palm readers - and the business community is not heartened by the strong lead in the opinion polls taken by President Francois Mitterrand, a Socialist. ''Nothing can really be decided before the election,'' a top French banker said with a sigh. ''All big decisions are on hold.'' **********The banker voiced a widespread feeling that the strong political institutions Charles de Gaulle gave to France in 1958 were being irrevocably weakened by the power-sharing experience between a Socialist President and a Prime Minister of the right. ''The old system was better,'' he said, mourning the apparent passing of the quasi-monarchal presidency. **********Something more profound, though, is gnawing at the loose community of politicians, journalists and writers who set the tone of things, who determine what gets talked about. They seem to be worried that France is not keeping up with the rest of the world, and they measure themselves almost obsessively with their neighbors in West Germany. Exercise in Awkwardness **********The possibility that France is in decline has been thoroughly debated for several months. As intellectual fashion is tenacious here - as mandatory in its own way as, say, rising hemlines - every politician was obliged to answer the question whether France was in economic, possibly even spiritual, decline. **********This was an awkward exercise. A Socialist, for example, was reluctant to concede that any decline had occurred between 1981 and 1986, when both President and Prime Minister were from his party; a Chirac partisan, by contrast, was tempted to liken France to an airplane that had been miraculously pulled out of a nose dive thanks to the right's parliamentary victory in March 1986. **********The professorial Mr. Barre, a man of the right but a challenger to Mr. Chirac for the presidency, deftly refused the word ''decline,'' coining instead one to be found in no dictionary: ''sinistrose.'' Were it a word, it would be a noun connoting a gloomy and menacing condition. **********''The general climate at the current moment,'' said Mr. Barre on one of the in-depth television interviews that so determine political rhythms and fortunes in France, ''is a climate of sinistrose. The French seem to me worried, disoriented, disenchanted.'' **********The only politician who has embraced the ''decline'' theme with unalloyed enthusiasm is Jean-Marie Le Pen, leader of the far-right National Front. He apocalyptically warns that France is condemned to ''a fatal decadence'' if it does not throw out a lot of third-world immigrants. Keeping Up With the Germans **********Decline in comparison to what? The answer comes through consistently: West Germany, a country where people evidently work harder, strike less, have lower inflation, less unemployment and bigger incomes. **********''They pull together like a real team!'' exclaimed a French steelworker who with a group of his comrades went to visit a Ruhr Valley steel plant where incomes and productivity were 30 percent higher than on his side of the Rhine. The visit was featured on French television in footage that had almost pedagogical overtones. **********The French preoccupation with Germany is hardly new, but it has a keener edge to it falling amidst a bad patch of pessimism. It has been aggravated by the milestone visit to West Germany by the East German leader, Erich Honecker, which rekindled French fears about German reunification, and by the imminence of a superpower accord that will remove American missiles from West Germany, which rekindled other fears about neutralization. **********''Germany is our closest ally,'' said a senior French official, ''but at the same time our views and their views on so many issues - defense, ecology, the analysis of the Soviet Union - are so diametrically opposed. We sit here, on the balcony as it were, watching things happening there and we have so little control over them.'' **********The obsession with Germany slips out in little ways. In a long interview with the newspaper Le Monde, Jean-Pierre Chevenement, a Socialist from the party's left wing, announced this month that he would be a candidate for the presidency if Mr. Mitterrand decided not to run for a second term. Yet two-thirds of the interview was about Germany, not France. Twin Themes **********Mr. Chevenement was at once zealous about forging closer military ties with Bonn but irritable that the inflation-conscious Germans had virtually transformed the European Monetary System into a ''mark zone.'' France, he said, needed a more reflationary policy that would increase employment and check the ''catastrophic'' loss of industry here. **********Then, in a sentence that caught twin French fears - decline at home, neutralism abroad - Mr. Chevenement observed: ''There will be no 'European Europe' with a dismantled and sick France any more than there will be one with a neutralized Germany.'' **********The French like to talk about ''les incertitudes allemandes,'' German uncertainties. They are made even worse by the less familiar phenomenon, ''les incertitudes francaises.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/07/busin.main_headline: New Yorkers & Co.; A Man With 2,478 Solutions To the Deficit Awaits a Call
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/07/busin.print_headline: New Yorkers & Co.; A Man With 2,478 Solutions To the Deficit Awaits a Call
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/07/busin.body_text: **********While Congressional committees were picking away at the Federal budget last week, looking for $30-odd billion to cut in the inconclusive war on the Federal budget deficit, J. Peter Grace was flying around the world calling them clowns. **********''They aren't serious,'' he says. ''If they were, they would have called me.'' **********And Peter Grace would have told them, too, just as he has told thousands of others in the last three years, exactly how to cut twice that much without raising taxes a nickel. And then he would have told them how they could go back and do it again next year, for a total of $120 billion, quick, rather than the iffy $76 billion to which the Administration and Congress have tentatively agreed. All Government has to do is to act more like a private business, he would say. W.R. Grace Has Own Problems **********Not like his own business, mind you. Mr. Grace serves as chairman, president and chief executive of W. R. Grace & Company, the conglomerate founded by his grandfather 133 years ago. Last year W. R. Grace lost $472 million on sales of $3.7 billion. **********While much of the red ink came from a restructuring, Grace has drifted downward for years. Earnings for 1985, the year before the overhaul, were less than half what they had been in 1981. But the company, with three good quarters this year, expects to return to profitability when the totals are added up next month. **********So Grace may not be the model. Rather, Congress should adopt the policies recommended by the phalanx of business executives whom Mr. Grace assembled at President Reagan's urging to examine waste in the Federal Government. **********These 2,000 business leaders studied the Federal bureaucracy from top to bottom from 1982 to 1984, then produced 21,000 pages of studies. Official Washington knew them as the President's Private Sector Survey on Cost Control, but to the rest of the world they were the Grace Commission. **********They discovered that those who serve in the military or work in the Federal civil service retire after many fewer years on the payroll than their counterparts in private industry. And pensions run generously to 75 percent of pay, compared with 50 percent or less in the private sector. **********As a result, Uncle Sam spends six times as much on the pension of a civil service employee, and eight times as much for military retirees, as the best private company spends on its workers. $19 Billion Could Be Saved Reform just that one item and save $19 billion a year, the commission reported. And save even more in the future, because the Government has already agreed to pay pensions that will cost $500 billion - but has set aside no money yet to cover the bill. If you were serious you would also add employees-to-be, but who's counting? Not Congress, Mr. Grace said. Not the Federal Government. **********''That's intellectually dishonest,'' Mr. Grace said. ''It's stealing from the young people of the future.'' **********If the Government can't stomach that reform, Mr. Grace has 2,477 other recommendations, ranging from higher fees in national parks to better cash management techniques for Federal money. Some are being pursued, but none would save nearly so much as the pension changes. Taken together, though, they would reduce the Federal budget gap by more than $420 billion over three years. The Tycoon of 42d Street **********All these ideas to trim the budget are sitting on the shelf, and no one from Capitol Hill even called. **********That's because sometimes it is hard to decide whether Mr. Grace, with his budget-cutting notions, is crazy like a fox, or just crazy. **********For one thing, there is his demeanor. At the age of 74, after 42 years as chief executive of W. R. Grace, he can be seen bouncing through the headquarters on West 42d Street with a mischievous glint in his eye, thumbing his nose playfully at the assistants who try to keep him on schedule in his international travels, tugging his vest down over his tummy without quite popping the buttons. **********In an office overlooking Bryant Park, he has surrounded himself with mementoes of his family: an oil portrait of his father and predecessor, photos of his five daughters, snapshots of family gatherings at one of his four houses and porcelain statues of dogs of all description. Smoking pipes, dozens of them, clutter two desks, the bookshelves and the window sill in the bathroom. **********It is the office of a tycoon, a patriarch. Today Mr. Grace controls only 1 percent of the enterprise that bears his grandfather's name, but he rules it like a fief. He is a holdover from another day, sustaining himself by force of personality. The Grace Coalition **********Then there is his method of waging war on waste. With no visible result, he has spent thousands of hours, and hundreds of thousands of his own and his company's dollars, crisscrossing the country with his message, preaching to the converted in hundreds of business audiences. **********He has enlisted Jack Anderson, the newspaper columnist, as his Sancho Panza in a grass-roots organization known as Citizens Against Government Waste. He has enrolled 164 members of Congress in what he calls the Grace Caucus. **********But Congress, the target of his assaults, pays no attention. As recently as mid-November, Congress dismissed the idea of pension reform and a suspension of automatic increases in Social Security payments - the largest items by far on the Grace Commission's list - as politically unworkable. **********That sounded familiar to Mr. Grace. When his commission delivered its report in 1985, Washington generally pooh-poohed him. He doesn't understand politics, said senators and representatives, lobbyists and Cabinet members. The people who receive Federal pensions vote, they said. The people who receive pensions from private businesses don't elect the board of directors of their company. **********But Peter Grace is in for the long haul. He has outlasted several successors presumptive at W. R. Grace. He endures; they pass from the scene. A Lesson From New York City **********And Mr. Grace has seen government get its comeuppance. He served as a volunteer adviser to Mayor Abraham D. Beame in 1975 as the Mayor struggled without success to prop up New York City's worm-eaten municipal budget. **********''Walter Wriston called me one night when I was on a business trip in Tennessee,'' Mr. Grace recalled. Mr. Wriston at the time was chairman of Citibank and leader of a bankers committee with which the city was negotiating for additional credit. He had a message for Mr. Grace to deliver to Mayor Beame: ''Tell your boy that we aren't going to roll over his loans,'' Mr. Grace remembers Mr. Wriston saying. **********The banks' refusal touched off a panic. Municipal bonds collapsed. Corporations with headquarters in New York accelerated their plans to leave the city. **********''That scared the boys at City Hall,'' Mr. Grace said, with more than a hint of satisfaction that a bunch of politicians had been taught a financial lesson. Nothing else would move them, but the threat of bankruptcy set them to hacking and hewing at the municipal budget. Thousands of police officers, firefighters and sanitation workers lost their jobs, ending the notion that employment with the city meant employment for life. A state agency was given control of the city's finances. **********''Things got better,'' Mr. Grace said. ''The politicians were scared enough to balance the budget. Now the Mayor of New York can spend his time in Nicaragua telling them how to run their Government.'' Federal Problem Is Different **********Though New York overcame its fiscal problems in less than a decade, the Federal Government cannot solve its budget crisis the same way, Mr. Grace said. ''In the first place, they can't go broke,'' he said. ''They can always print more money.'' That explains why the stock market crash has not frightened the Federal Government into a more serious effort to eliminate the deficit, by, for instance, reforming Federal pensions and postponing cost-of-living increases for Social Security recipients. **********Mr. Grace thinks the only way to change the spending habits of ''the yellow bellies'' in Washington is for the voters to frighten members of Congress. **********''Moynihan starts getting sensible when Giuliani says he might run against him,'' Mr. Grace said, referring to the Democratic Senator from New York and to the United States Attorney in Manhattan, widely considered a possible opponent next year. **********''Write to Congress,'' he advises the business audiences that hang on his every word. ''If you don't think that'll do it, run for Congress. That ought to scare 'em.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/13/busin.main_headline: A Lion in Winter on Wall St.
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/13/busin.print_headline: A Lion in Winter on Wall St.
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/13/busin.body_text: **********Many investors are boasting these days that they sold stocks before the market collapsed on Oct. 19. But few of them are now stepping forward to be big buyers of stocks again. **********Roy R. Neuberger, one of the legendary risk-takers of Wall Street, is an exception. In the selling panic of Oct. 19 and 20, the founder of Neuberger & Berman, a brokerage and money management firm, was in the market doing what he loves best - trading stocks. He was making rapid-fire decisions to buy stocks that others were dumping, often selling them just hours or days later at quick profits. **********A week earlier the 84-year-old Mr. Neuberger was cooling his heels on the sidelines. Alfred Feinman, a partner at Glickenhaus & Company in New York, said that Mr. Neuberger had nervously confided to him over lunch on Wednesday, Oct. 14, that he had less exposure to stocks than he had had in years. He had thought there was too much speculation in the market, and long-term interest rates of more than 10 percent had convinced him stocks were headed for trouble. Opportunities for a Trader **********The big slide in prices, however, has convinced him there now are plenty of opportunities, for a trader at least. While he is not involved in the direct management of the firm, he visits the office every day, walking more than 40 blocks from his apartment on upper Fifth Avenue to his midtown office. Last week, he sent a memo to the firm's staff, suggesting that now is a good time to buy stocks. **********For years, portfolio managers at his own firm, which manages billions of dollars in pension assets, and other managers, such as Mr. Feinman, eagerly sought Mr. Neuberger's views on the stock market. At major market turns, they have found that he is more often right than wrong. **********''He's performed over the years,'' Mr. Feinman said. Investment Responsibilities **********Mr, Neuberger not only gives out advice to other professional investors and trades for his own account, but also manages the pension fund of a major corporation, said to be the Eastman Kodak Company, and invests 10 accounts for his family. He declined to provide the names of stocks he has been buying recently. **********''I dislike giving tips,'' he said. But he said his portfolios are ''heavily invested'' in stocks. He has been buying stocks of companies that have ''negligible'' debt, large cash positions and strong balance sheets. **********Mr. Neuberger is one of the most active traders on Wall Street. ''If I can make 5 or 10 percent in 15 minutes, you bet I'll do it,'' he said. Yesterday, barely 15 minutes into a meeting in his office, he became nervous when his 24-year-old assistant failed to bring him information on the market. He then walked to his desk and called up information on the Dow industrials from a Quotron machine. **********As Mr. Neuberger has grown older, he has stepped up his trading. **********''I like to trade,'' he said. ''It's a substitute for tennis and other extracurricular activities.'' 'A Good Time to Take a Risk' **********Mr. Neuberger thinks that now -unlike late summer and early fall, when interest rates were climbing and stock prices were at what he considered unjustified levels - is a ''good time to take a risk on the buy side.'' Because he is a trader instead of a long-term investor, he is not as concerned with economic factors as other investors are. This is his kind of market because ''the speculators and gamblers,'' as he calls some traders, ''have moved to the sidelines.'' And he has found many more stocks selling at price-earnings ratios below the market average. **********If the Dow Jones industrial average dropped below the low set on Oct. 19, Mr. Neuberger would be worried. ''I think it would signal the probability of a depression,'' he said. But he thinks that is not likely to happen. **********However, he is prepared to bail out. Should the stock market weaken or if it appears the economy is headed for a recession or worse, he said he would sell his stocks or sell short enough stocks to offset the positions he continues to hold. Perspective on History **********These days Mr. Neuberger's perspective on history makes his views even more intriguing to colleagues. He took his first job on Wall Street in 1929. Thus, his opinion about these rocky times is even more valued. While he sees the obvious similarities between now and the 1920's, he also thinks there are many differences. **********For one, the panic selling of the 1920's was a result of individual investors selling to meet margin calls. This time, he said, the major investors are the billion-dollar pension funds. And he believes they will not dump stocks in a wholesale fashion. **********''They are a safeguard in a panic,'' he said. **********The pension funds are also not likely to be big sellers because they did not have high levels of stocks in their portfolios in October. Many pension accounts had only about 50 percent of their entire funds invested in stocks, Mr. Neuberger said. And that leads him to suspect that, as a group, ''they're just as likely to buy as sell.'' Less Pessimistic Now **********Although Mr. Neuberger spent much of last summer convinced the economy was on the path to a 1930's-like depression, he is not as pessimistic today. ''We're not even sure to have much of a recession,'' he said. He also believes that the panic of the stock market plunge has given the Federal Government the chance to make the necessary changes to forestall a worldwide depression. **********However, he thinks the targets for cuts in the budget and trade deficits are the wrong ones. Mr. Neuberger believes there should be a tax on gasoline of 50 cents a gallon, another tax on imported oil and huge cuts in military spending. **********''This is the way to change history and insure us against a depression,'' he said. Started Investing for Art's Sake **********Mr. Neuberger originally went to work as a trader on Wall Street to make money so he could invest in works of living artists who had not yet been widely recognized. They included Edward Hopper, Jackson Pollock and Willem de Kooning. **********Today, most of his collection is with the Neuberger Collection in Purchase, N.Y. He is an honorary trustee of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. **********But trading stocks still takes up most of Mr. Neuberger's time. The volatility of the marketplace, which can be a nightmare for some investors, provides him with more trading opportunities. Investors who do not trade their portfolios can get into trouble, he feels. **********''Trading is safer than people think,'' he said, ''and investing can be dangerous.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/12/world.main_headline: SHULTZ SAID TO WARN REAGAN OF CASEY'S VERSION
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/12/world.print_headline: SHULTZ SAID TO WARN REAGAN OF CASEY'S VERSION
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/12/world.body_text: **********Secretary of State George P. Shultz angrily confronted President Reagan last November after learning that the Director of Central Intelligence was about to make innaccurate statements to the Senate about the provision of arms to Iran, a senior Reagan Administration official said today. **********The official said the meeting and simultaneous discussions at the Justice Department led to an investigation that uncovered the diversion of profits from the Iranian arms sales to the Nicaraguan rebels, known as contras. **********According to the official, Mr. Shultz went to the President on Nov. 20 after he was told of serious inaccuracies in the planned testimony of William J. Casey, then the Director of Central Intelligence, to the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence. **********Mr. Casey, the official said, was prepared to tell the committee in testimony the following day that no senior American officials had advance knowledge that Hawk antiaircraft missiles were transferred from Israel to Iran in November 1985. **********The official said Mr. Casey was prepared to tell the committee that American officials thought that the shipment was of oil-drilling equipment. In fact, according to recent disclosures from Congress and elsewhere, Mr. Casey, Mr. Shultz and others knew at the time of the shipment that the missiles had been provided to Iran in hopes of winning the release of American hostages held in Lebanon. **********The Administration official, who spoke on condition that he not be named, confirmed details of the meeting between Mr. Shultz and the President that were disclosed in the Thursday issue of The Washington Post. **********Although it provided few details on the meeting, the report said Mr. Shultz ''informed the President that some of the statements being made about the Iran arms affair would not stand up to scrutiny.'' **********The report said that Mr. Shultz also told Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d ''of his feelings on this matter.'' **********Over the next few days, the Attorney General organized an investigation that turned up information about the diversion of funds to the contras. **********According to a senior Administration official, Mr. Shultz was first told of Mr. Casey's planned testimony by Under Secretary of State Michael H. Armacost and Abraham D. Sofaer, the State Department's legal adviser. **********Mr. Armacost and Mr. Sofaer, the official said, had been briefed on the tesimony by Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter, who was then the White House national security adviser and helped prepare the statement.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/23/world.body_text: **********Four men charged with hijacking a Pan Am jetliner in Karachi last September are expected to go on trial soon along with a suspected accomplice, according to Government officials. **********Diplomatic sources said that after a six-month investigation the Pakistani authorities had established a link between the hijackers and the terrorist group led by Abu Nidal, who has been linked to other terrorist attacks in the Middle East and Europe. **********The five defendants face possible death sentences on the charges stemming from the incident, in which four Arabic-speaking gunmen entered the Karachi airport dressed as regular security agents and riding in a van disguised as an official security vehicle. **********They held the plane and its 389 passengers and crew members for 16 hours before spraying the darkened cabin with bullets, killing 21 people and wounding more than 100. Weak Link to Abu Nidal **********A Pakistani official said recently that investigators had uncovered evidence that Abu Nidal had a role in the incident, but he said that there remained an element of uncertainty about this connection and that it was not determined whether it could be established in court. **********The captives also named a sixth man identified as the ''controller'' of the operation, the official said, but ''with whom he was affiliated remains a question mark.'' **********The official said the ''controller'' was found to have entered the country with a false passport some time before the hijacking and left a day or two before it occurred. Before leaving, this person was said to have acted with others to scout the airport, rent a van, purchase weapons and obtain fake airport security uniforms. **********''What is quite clear is that these hijackers had been trained specifically for an operation of this kind,'' the official said. **********Little has been disclosed about the identity of the men who hijacked the jet other than that they were from Palestinian refugee districts in Lebanon and entered Pakistan separately in the weeks before the hijacking. They carried false passports and stayed at separate hotels before converging to carry out the hijacking.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/23/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Clarendon Bids For Argonaut
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/23/busin.body_text: **********The Argonaut Group Inc. said today that the Clarendon Group Ltd. had offered to acquire the Los Angeles insurance company, for $52 a share, or about $600 million. **********Argonaut said its board would consider the Clarendon offer and other ''financial alternatives'' Thursday. In April, Argonaut called an earlier $37-a-share bid from Clarendon inadequate. **********The offer sent Argonaut's shares up $8.625, to $49.50, in over-the-counter trading. **********Clarendon is a privately held insurance company based in Bermuda. Its interest in Argonaut had sparked speculation that Clarendon was after Argonaut's 10 percent stake in Kidde Inc., a consumer and industrial products company. But Clarendon said its bid had **********''nothing to do with Argonaut's holding in Kidde.'' **********Clarendon has described its interest in Argonaut as friendly. The company already owns an unspecified number of Argonaut's shares, believed to be less than 5 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/03/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Murdoch Moves To End Obstacle
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/03/busin.body_text: **********Rupert Murdoch has moved to eliminate one of the last remaining barriers in his attempt to gain control of Australia's largest broadcasting and publishing properties, the Herald and Weekly Times group. **********Mr. Murdoch's bidding vehicle, News Ltd., took steps to end an inquiry by Australia's radio and television licensing watchdog into its $2.3 billion bid, about $1.52 billion in United States currency, for the group. **********The lawyer for News Ltd. asked the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to adjourn the inquiry indefinitely because the newspaper group would meet Wednesday to consider disposing of its assets in broadcasting to Australian citizens.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/25/world.body_text: **********During yesterday's session, Secretary of State George P. Shultz was questioned on historical comparisons involving the Iran-contra affair. **********REPRESENTATIVE DICK CHENEY, Republican of Wyoming. . . . Frankly, Mr. Secretary, one of the things that concerns me about these proceedings is that we develop sort of a hot house atmosphere. We've got . . . the best reporters in the business and some of the most distinguished members of Congress focused on these series of events. But it's sort of a mutually reinforcing kind of an operation. There's a strong incentive on the part of both groups to dramatize these events. They are important events, I don't mean to downplay them at all, but sometimes our intense focus upon the problem we're analyzing, I think obscures some relevent comparisons, if you will, to other periods of time or other events in other Administrations. **********. . . There's a tendency for us to talk about a grave constitutional crisis. Some of my colleagues are fond of saying this is the worst thing that's happened in this country since Watergate. And I must say I have trouble with those arguments, that notion that this is a crisis strikes me as inappropriate. If it ever was a crisis, it ended last December when the President put an end to those policies that are under investigation here. And to the extent that we're focused on enforcing the Boland Amendment, we have to remind ourselves periodically that the Congress repealed that law over a year ago. **********I look at the arguments about Watergate which some of my colleagues on this committee are fond of pulling out as a relevant analogy -and I must say I don't see any relevant comparison at all. I think the analogy is grossly overdone. But you served in the Nixon Administration and went through those difficult years as well, and I just wonder if you would agree with my judgment that what we have here is a radically different set of circumstances, and not a political crime but rather fundamental disputes over policy. And whatever the motives of the individuals involved might have been, and whether we agree or disagree with their policies, it's clear that it was a policy struggle, not a struggle for domestic political advantage, if you will. **********And it's also clear that this President responded very aggressively when he found he had a problem. And contrary to running the so-called coverup that was part of the Watergate incident, this President's done anything but that. He's made available even his own diary to the members of this committee, appointed the Tower Commission, cooperated in every single respect with our activities. I wonder if you might comment . . . **********A. I believe that the Watergate problems were not so much about the burglary as they were about the coverup. That was the essence of the Watergate problem. In this case, we had a set of events involving an initiative toward Iran that were undertaken, broadly speaking, given the finding that we know about, with attention to proper legality. And something happened in the course of that by way of fund diversion which the President didn't know about. And as the events started to tumble out and then especially when the President - and the President set in motion a very quick investigation by the Attorney General, as he began to sense that something was wrong - very quickly -and then when he found something was definitely wrong, he put it out immediately. And has gone in just the opposite direction of a coverup. It was - you have been inundated with materials. **********And to some extent, I think some of the materials that have been put in the hands of the Congressional committees, it's unwise to do it. But at any rate, the President has gone all-out to see that all of the facts are available. And I think it's to his everlasting credit that that was his immediate instinct. And I think, as a matter of fact, with a great deal of - has been revealed by these investigations and I personally have been astonished at some of the things that have come out. But the basic structure of what happened - the Iran initiative, the distortion and the fund diversion -that was brought out long ago. And I think that's the essential set of facts here, and that remains what you have before you. And you've been seeking as to find out why did that happen, who knew about it and all of that. **********But the basic facts have been -were set out by the President's direction back in whenever that was in November.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/28/busin.print_headline: MARKET TURMOIL; Pickens Sees Plunge Spurring Takeovers
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/28/busin.body_text: **********Depressed stock prices could lead to new corporate takovers ''within a week or so,'' T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman, said here today. **********Mr. Pickens, who was here to speak at a symposium on corporate takeovers, told 700 executives, ''If companies were attractive targets when the Dow was at 2,500, they will be even more attractive with the Dow at 1,800.'' Noting that some merger proposals had already been made following the market plunge, Mr. Pickens said deals could be shaped within days. **********He declined to speculate on particular companies or industries that could provide attractive opportunities and would not say whether he was considering making offers. **********Mr. Pickens spoke at a seminar sponsored by the General Electric Credit Corporation, which brought together business executives from around the Southeast. **********He said companies purchased recently in mergers or leveraged buyouts were not in more danger of failing than they were a week ago. ''These deals are made on anticipated cash flow, and the market has nothing to do with cash flow,'' Mr. Pickens said. **********''When you have this kind of dramatic activity in the stock market, you have people who say, 'I'm not willing to do any financing until I see which way this thing is headed,' '' Mr. Pickens said. That could hold down takeover activity. ''But I don't think that is going to last very long,'' he added. ''If the market is going to be down, it's going to be down. If it's going to go sideways for a while, so be it. We've had markets like that before. And then you start building back from a new basis.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/29/world.main_headline: ARCHBISHOP IS GIVEN ASSURANCE OF WAITE'S SAFETY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/29/world.print_headline: ARCHBISHOP IS GIVEN ASSURANCE OF WAITE'S SAFETY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/29/world.body_text: **********The Archbishop of Canterbury said today that he had been assured that his envoy, Terry Waite, was safe in Lebanon and was continuing his mission to free foreign hostages. **********Mr. Waite has not been seen since he left his West Beirut hotel Jan. 20. **********A church statement by the Archbishop, the Most Rev. Robert Runcie, said: ''These assurances have been conveyed to the Church of England from leaders of the Druse community who are Mr. Waite's hosts during his mission to Lebanon. These leaders held conversations today with leaders of the Shiite community.'' **********''They have now informed the Archbishop's office in London that Mr. Waite is continuing his discussions and will return on the completion of his mission,'' the statement said. **********Mr. Waite, 47 years old, began his fifth visit to Lebanon on Jan. 12. Kuwait's official press agency reported Monday that the kidnappers with whom Mr. Waite was negotiating had placed him under house arrest.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/18/world.body_text: **********Maj. Gen. John K. Singlaub, a retired United States Army officer who has played a major role in advising and raising money for the Nicaraguan rebels, is now spending much of his time on what he describes as a treasure hunt in the Philippines. **********The nature of General Singlaub's activities here is not entirely clear. The general and some associates, who include several American military veterans, have received a Government permit to hunt for treasure. They are said to hope to find the ''Yamashita treasure,'' a hoard of gold, jewelry and artifacts said to have been plundered by the Japanese during World War II and hidden in the Philippines. **********But various Philippine sources say General Singlaub, formerly Chief of Staff of United States forces in Korea and later the chairman of the World Anti-Communist League, a private group, may also be engaged in efforts to foster anti-Communist groups here. **********A senior Philippine military officer who said he had been tracking General Singlaub's activities here said today that he believed the general was engaged in ''intense psychological operations'' to lay the groundwork for unofficial counterinsurgency programs. **********As speculation about General Singlaub's purpose here has intensified, he appears to have avoided contacts with the press. Efforts to contact him at an office here were unsuccessful. Visiting as 'Private Citizen' **********Officials of the United States Embassy and the presidential palace said they believed that General Singlaub was engaged only in treasure hunting. **********Allan Croghan, an embassy spokesman, said the general was here ''as a private citizen'' and had no connection with the United States Government. **********Teodoro Locsin, an assistant to President Corazon C. Aquino, said he believed General Singlaub was ''obsessed'' with treasure hunting. He said he had requested permits to hunt treasure in 209 locations and had received permission to hunt at one site, which was not specified. **********An American diplomat said that ''wacky as it may seem'' he was convinced that General Singlaub was really here for the Yamashita treasure. It is named for Gen. Tomoyuki Yamashita, the Japanese military commander during the World War II occupation, who was executed for war crimes in 1946. **********According to Philippine and American sources, Ambassador Stephen W. Bosworth approached Philippine officials last year in behalf of General Singlaub's attempt to gain a treasure-hunting permit. Meetings With Business Groups **********But several Philippine sources say General Singlaub has also been meeting with various right-wing and business groups, giving them the impression he is representing the United States Government. He has reportedly encouraged his listeners to defend themselves against the Communist insurgents and the leftists who, some have asserted, hold positions of influence in the Government. **********General Singlaub has reportedly also met with Government officials, including Juan Ponce Enrile, who was then Defense Minister. Mr. Enrile was ousted by Mrs. Aquino in November and is now a leading opposition figure. **********In an interview today, Mr. Enrile said he had met General Singlaub twice, in March or April 1986 and again last fall. ''He was asking me about security for his treasure hunting,'' Mr. Enrile said. ''That's about it.'' **********The latter meeting aroused speculation in local newspapers because it came while dissident military officers appeared to be threatening a coup against President Aquino. **********The senior military officer, who declined to be identified by name, said General Singlaub appeared to be making ''intense psychological preparations for launching a counterinsurgency campaign.'' He said the general was offering ''methods and models of how to fight Communism if the Government does not.'' **********He said the suggestions ''center mainly on self-protection.'' Possibly a 'Cover Activity' **********The officer said he did not believe such activities were a threat to national security, adding that he felt that the country could benefit from having ''a broad anti-Communist party.'' He suggested that a treasure hunt could be ''a complementary activity or a cover activity'' for this project. **********Gen. Luis Villareal, head of the National Intelligence Coordinating Agency, said he believed that the treasure hunt was intended to raise money for anti-Communist activities. **********General Villareal, the president of the Filipino Anti-Communist Movement, an affiliate of General Singlaub's group, said the treasure-hunting operations included American veterans of the Korean and Vietnam Wars. **********But both he and the senior military officer said they did not believe General Singlaub was either importing or training mercenaries. **********''That's all false, and I ought to know,'' General Villareal said. He said General Singlaub had given no funds to anti-Communist groups here. **********One well-placed military source said: ''Singlaub comes in and out of the country. He can even land at Clark without our knowing it.'' He was referring to Clark Air Base, a major American installation here. Offers of Weapons Reported **********One man involved in the activities of groups loyal to the former President, Ferdinand E. Marcos, said Americans whom he believed to be associates of General Singlaub had offered weapons and communications equipment to pro-Marcos forces. **********But General Villareal said General Singlaub had turned down requests to meet with the Marcos loyalists. **********General Singlaub has established himself in the Manila office of a Hong Kong-registered company called Nippon Star. The company opened an office last year in a building owned by Raymond Moreno, an associate of Gen. Fabian C. Ver, who was the armed forces Chief of Staff under Mr. Marcos. **********General Singlaub, 65 years old, has served in three wars and was wounded in two, winning 29 medals. **********He retired under pressure in 1978 after criticizing decisions by President Carter to reduce the number of troops in South Korea and to bar production of the neutron bomb. The Korean troop withdrawal plan was later reversed. Tales of the Treasure **********The Yamashita treasure has spawned its own mysteries and legends since the end of the war. In various accounts the loot has been estimated at tens of billions of dollars and is said to have been stashed in 172 locations around the Philippines, marked on a ''super-secret Japanese map.'' **********The treasure is said to be cursed, and tribesmen who have found caches of gold are said to have met with misfortune. There are also stories of a three-foot-high golden Buddha whose hollow stomach was filled with jewels; legend has it that the figure ended up in the hands of Mr. Marcos himself. **********Some former associates of Mr. Marcos say he told them that his own huge wealth came from having discovered the Yamashita treasure.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/27/world.main_headline: A Greek Drama: Tourists vs. Turtles
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/27/world.print_headline: ZAKINTHOS JOURNAL; A Greek Drama: Tourists vs. Turtles
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/27/world.body_text: **********The sea turtles are coming again this year. And that, said Christos Pastras, between bouts of wind-surfing and collecting the $4 fee on his beach umbrellas, is a good thing. **********''We love the turtles,'' he said. ''They eat all the jellyfish.'' Not that all his compatriots on this Ionian island agree. Some Greeks, he said, feel that the sooner the turtles -an endangered species called Caretta caretta, or loggerhead - stop coming, the sooner people will be able to build hotels now proscribed by turtle conservation laws. **********And that, Mr. Pastras thought, would be a bad thing. **********The two positions resemble the bookends of a debate about the 200-pound loggerhead, which has long nested on the island. It is a reptile endowed variously with grace in the water and clumsiness on land, and a future that collides with humanity's pursuit of such basics as money, suntans and outboard engines. Between Tourism and Tradition **********''Sometimes they kill them,'' Mr. Pastras said, referring to the foes of the sea turtles and the tactics used to drive the animals away, ''Yes, I think they kill them.'' **********Others see the survival of the turtles threatened in a different way, squeezed, like many things on Greek islands, between the economic gains of tourism and the trauma it often brings to tradition. Here, as in some parts of neighboring Turkey, the turtles are losing in a bitter conflict between preservationists and would-be developers of hotels and mass tourism. **********Each year, said the president of the Society for the Protection of the Sea Turtle, Tomas Arapis, the number of loggerheads making it back to Zakinthos - drawn like spawning salmon by urges not fully understood - is reduced by about a fifth. **********''There are other reasons,'' he said, ''like pollution in the Mediterranean. But we believe the main reason is the pressure of increased tourism.'' Laying Eggs on the Beach **********The female loggerhead, he said, takes about 30 years to reach maturity and readiness for maternity. She then lumbers ashore at night to dig a hole in the beach and lay about 120 eggs, which she covers with sand. The eggs are incubated by the heat of the sand. About 55 days later, the hatchlings scramble out of the hole and dash to the sea. **********An American environmentalist living in Greece, Katherine Butterworth, said the sea turtles laid their eggs three times a season, every 18 days from June to August, but did not usually nest every year. **********They are sensitive creatures, Mr. Arapis said. They dislike bright lights and noise, and shy from beaches cluttered with bright hotels and discotheques and tourists intent on taking a nocturnal snapshot of a nesting turtle. Some, thus, lay their eggs at sea, where they do not hatch. **********And then, Mr. Arapis said, there is the umbrella issue. Renting umbrellas, as Mr. Pastras does, makes money. But driving the umbrellas into the nesting beaches - a practice Mr. Pastras says he avoids - can smash eggs. A Dwindling Population **********Then there are the motorboats that churn the waves and maim turtles, and the hotel lights that bewilder the hatchlings so they never make it to the sea, and new trees that snare hatchlings in their roots, and a host of other problems that, a year ago, prompted some environmentalists to suggest that the turtles would not make it back this year to Laganas beach, their principal nesting ground here. **********But they have returned, albeit depleted. Once, according to Miss Butterworth, there might have been 1,200 to 1,500 turtles here each season; now the estimate is around 700. **********And the turtles are girded with laws that are difficult to enforce -prohibiting nighttime visits to the beaches where they nest and halting development along whole stretches of sand. **********In some parts of Laganas Bay, no new building is permitted, provoking anger from landowners who want a slice of profit from the tourism that has blossomed since the airport here was declared suitable for international flights three years ago. A few years before that, Zakinthos was a different place, and the five-mile sweep of Laganas beach was quiet, save for the wind. Britons Descend **********These days, the island's native population is estimated at 30,000. Each holiday season, however, about 50,000 foreigners, mostly Britons on package tours, fly in aboard aircraft whose flight paths bring them swooping low and loud over a nesting area that is supposed to be still and silent for the turtles. **********A whole section of Laganas beach, the part where Mr. Pastras runs his umbrella business, is said to have been abandoned by the turtles. It now boasts instead a turtle information kiosk, built by the Sea Turtle Protection Society. **********''About 30 percent of the people on the beach ask us for information,'' said Martin Muellauer, an Austrian volunteer turtle protector sporting the insignia of the World Wildlife Fund. ''The rest don't seem to care.'' **********As for the local people, he said, gesturing toward a part of the beach where building is prohibited, ''They are very hostile toward us.'' **********Yet, in other parts of Laganas Bay, on beaches whose names the environmentalists do not want too widely known, those who seek to protect the loggerhead nurture a hope that it may be possible to shelter a limited population of the reptiles from humanity's urge to grow rich and despoil. **********''There must be a critical point when the overall number of loggerhead turtles becomes too small to sustain the species,'' Mr. Arapis said. ''We don't know if we have already got to that point.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/08/world.body_text: **********The police restored order at a prison in Brussels today after 50 people were injured in rioting by inmates, officials said. A police spokesman said about 100 inmates at the Forest Prison smashed furniture and lit fires Friday night. He said order was restored after a few hours when police entered the jail and freed four guards who had been taken hostage. Inmates were said to be protesting preferential treatment of British soccer fans awaiting trial on charges stemming from the 1985 Heysel Stadium riots.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/23/busin.main_headline: PHONE EXECUTIVE RISES TO CHIEF'S JOB AT ALLTEL
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/23/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; PHONE EXECUTIVE RISES TO CHIEF'S JOB AT ALLTEL
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/23/busin.body_text: **********Joe T. Ford began his career in the telephone industry by selling ads in the Yellow Pages. Yesterday he was elected chief executive of the Alltel Corporation, a major telephone company. **********Mr. Ford, 49, who has been Alltel's president, succeeds Weldon W. Case as chief executive. Mr. Case, 66, remains chairman, and Mr. Ford will continues as president. **********Alltel provides local telephone service in 19 states in the Middle West, East and South. Based in Hudson, Ohio, the company resulted from the 1983 merger of the Allied Telephone Company and the Mid-Continent Telephone Corporation. **********Mr. Ford was president of Allied, which had its headquarters in Little Rock, Ark., and Mr. Case led Mid-Continent, which he founded in 1960 from a network of five small Ohio telephone companies. **********Mr. Case grew up in a family that ran the Western Reserve Telephone Company in Hudson. That was one of the five that went into Alltel. **********Mr. Ford said Alltel had ''done very well,'' alluding to its million customers, $700 million in revenues and 5,900 employees. He said the company would continue to make acquisitions in the telephone business and look for opportunities in such related fields as cellular radio. **********In a statement, Mr. Ford said, ''Weldon Case and I agree that our fundamental strategy must be to continue to strengthen our core telephone business while selectively expanding into new communications-related markets.'' **********Mr. Ford began in the telephone industry after graduating from the University of Arkansas. After working as a Yellow Pages salesman, he got into the rate-case business, handling relations with public service commissions. Meanwhile, he participated in politics and was a member of the Arkansas Senate from 1967 to 1982.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/22/busin.main_headline: Piedmont Invites Suitors to Its Door
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/22/busin.print_headline: WEEK IN BUSINESS; Piedmont Invites Suitors to Its Door
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/22/busin.body_text: **********Piedmont's board is seeking any and all suitors. USAir started the bidding war by offering $68 a share in cash and stock. Then Norfolk Southern offered $65 in cash, and USAir came back with an offer of $71 in cash for half of Piedmont and $73 a share in cash and stock for the rest. Norfolk said it would not match that offer, but Piedmont said it would entertain other offers. Analysts say a deal with USAir makes sense for Piedmont, because their air routes are complementary. They speculate that that Norfolk, a railraod company that holds about 20 percent of Piedmont, is interested more in the higher stock price a bidding war might bring than in actually acquiring the airline. **********UAL changed its name to Allegis in hopes that it would change its image as the parent of United Air Lines. The company also has car rental, hotels and food services.  * * * **********The Group of Seven industrialized nations is meeting this weekend in Paris in an attempt to stabilize world currency markets by establishing reference zones of trading for member currencies. The United States, which officially says the dollar needs to fall further, albeit in more orderly fashion, is expected to object to any measures that would halt that drop. **********Japan cut its discount rate again, to 2.5 percent, a record low, under pressure from the United States. The dollar has fallen particularly hard against the yen, and officials want Japan to stimulate its economy even further to improve the trade balance. West Germany is also likely to agree to American demands for stimulation shortly after the G-5 meeting.  * * * **********The economy grew just 1.3 percent in the fourth quarter, below the 1.7 percent originally reported and less than most analysts and economists had expected. The sluggishness was attributed to a cut in business inventories, an indication that this quarter will be better as companies restock. But few are predicting any great spurt, and Paul A. Volcker, the Fed chairman, agreed that growth was likely to be held to between 2.5 and 3 percent for all of 1987. . . . Housing starts fell two-tenths of 1 percent in January, a better performance than most analysts had expected after a banner year in 1986. . . . Industry operated at 79.7 percent of capacity in January, up slightly. . . . Personal spending fell a record 2 percent, although income remained stable.  * * * **********Stocks soared - again. With a record 54.24-point spurt on Tuesday, the Dow industrials began a climb that left it at a record 2,244.09, before falling back Friday. Still, it finished at 2,235.24, up 51.89 for the holiday-shortened week. Traders seemed to be grasping at any reason to bid prices higher, despite the insider scandals.  * * * **********The Big Board told its members to tighten their procedures to try to reduce the number of securities violations. The rules require member firms to review internal supervision, report all customer complaints and certify that employees have not violated securities laws. **********Dennis B. Levine was sentenced to two years in prison and fined $362,000 for his role in the scandal. Mr. Levine is cooperating with prosecutors, and that reduced his sentence. **********Drexel Burnham was accused by Staley Continental of trying to ''extort'' it into a leveraged buyout in violation of securities laws. Drexel denied the charges.  * * * **********Brazil suspended interest payments on its debt, saying it was all but bankrupt. It had been making headway on its interest payments - it suspended principal payments four years ago - but a Government austerity program that had started to increase the trade surplus backfired, leaving Brazil with little hard currency. Economists are worried that the suspension could signal a flare-up in the debt crisis.  * * * **********Ford earned $3.3 billion in 1986, more than G.M. and Chrysler. It was the first time in more than 60 years that Ford led the Big Three in net income. Analysts cited cost-cutting methods and the newfound popularity of several Ford models. In the fourth quarter, Ford earned $795 million, up 31 percent from the 1985 quarter.  * * * **********A banker was charged with embezzling $44.9 million from the Mitsubishi Bank of California to pay off gambling debts and to play the stock market. Hirotsugu Mizuno, a former manager in corporate finance, is also accused of conducting about $1 billion in fraudulent transactions to cover up the scheme between 1980 and 1984.  * * * **********Japan wants chip production to be cut back to ease American charges that Japanese manufacturers are ''dumping'' chips in the American market. But Japan put no bite in its ''instruction,'' and analysts are doubtful manufacturers will comply in a meaningful way.  * * * **********BancTexas was bailed out by the F.D.I.C. and a merchant banking group in an unusual arrangement that gave the merchant group control of the bank's loan portfolio and assets. The move allows the F.D.I.C. to help banks at a lower cost to the insurance fund.  * * * **********Robert Foman is giving up day-to-day management responsibilities at E. F. Hutton. Although he will retain his title of chairman, most of his duties will be transferred to Robert P. Rittereiser, the chief executive.  * * * **********Miscellanea. Irwin L. Jacobs renewed his bid for Borg-Warner, threatening a tender offer if a merger pact is not reached. . . . J.C. Penney is beginning a home TV shopping service. . . . Martin Marietta pleaded guilty to defrauding the Pentagon of $1.35 million. . . . Alan Bond, the Australian financier, admitted making misleading statements about the value of securities of his Hong Kong unit, and trading was suspended there. . . . Kodak will sell the retail division of Fox Photo, which it bought last year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/20/busin.main_headline: MODERN MERCHANT: Jean-Louis Dumas-Hermes; Dressing Hermes for Success
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/20/busin.print_headline: MODERN MERCHANT: Jean-Louis Dumas-Hermes; Dressing Hermes for Success
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/20/busin.body_text: **********IT is early evening on one of the last Saturdays before Christmas, and customers at the Hermes shop here on the rue Faubourg St. Honore are standing two and three deep at the scarf counter. Salesgirls in dark blazers tirelessly unfurl square after square of brilliantly colored silk, patterned with peonies, toucans, and bold geometric shapes. **********The crowd in the wood-panelled shop, which sells everything from hunting attire and luggage to fragrances and silk ties, is the usual holiday mix - mostly Parisian, with fewer of the usual American and Japanese tourists. **********But if the clientele looks younger and decidedly more chic than it did a decade ago, and if the crowd looks bigger, much of the credit goes to one man: Jean-Louis Dumas-Hermes. **********Since becoming chairman 10 years ago, Mr. Dumas-Hermes, a fifth-generation member of the family that founded the company in 1837, has worked to give Hermes (pronounced air-MEZ) a younger image, so that its goods would appeal to say, Lady Di, as much as to the Queen Mother. **********Now the company's products are recognized status symbols. Its silk scarf, which sells for $140 in the United States, and its four-in-hand silk tie at $65, adorn yuppies of all nations. **********''He revolutionized the market for Hermes by repositioning the products without changing the quality,'' said Stanley Marcus, ex-chairman emeritus of Neiman-Marcus, which was among the first to carry Hermes merchandise in America after World War II. **********Indeed, by restructuring, bringing in outsiders and commissioning bolder ads, the 49-year-old chairman not only rejuvenated the image of Hermes, he invigorated sales. Worldwide sales this year at the privately held company are expected to hit $200 million, up from $50 million in 1978. **********SWEEPING into the Paris store, a space-age carbon fiber briefcase in one hand, Mr. Dumas-Hermes, just back from a store opening in San Francisco, addressed the salespeople by name and asked excitedly, but discreetly, how many scarves have been sold. **********Hermes says its sells a silk square every 20 seconds. The record for a single day on rue Faubourg St. Honore, the flagship store of its 210 shops and outlets, is 1,200. On this day it is 886. **********Upstairs in his office, a sanctuary that adjoins a roof garden filled with fruit trees, the dapper chairman talked about tradition and transformation at his 150-year-old company. **********Founded as a harness-making business by Thierry Hermes, the great-great grandfather of Mr. Dumas-Hermes, the company got into travel specialties and golf accessories when the founder's grandson, Emile-Maurice, took control in the 1920's. **********Emile-Maurice also opened the first branch stores in French resort towns, further linking the Hermes name with luxury and leisure. The retail outlet on rue Faubourg St. Honore opened in 1922. **********Surrounded by this lore, Mr. Dumas-Hermes said in his lightly-accented English, he got his Hermes education unconsciously: ''We would all gather around the lunch table every day and my father would talk about 'that-beautiful-silk-scarf-please-don't-eat-with-your-hands.' That sort of thing.'' **********As a young man in Paris, his ambition was to travel, his avocation was jazz. So in the 1950's, after studying political science and law, he began a brief career as a drummer, a job that took him to Scandinavia and Czechoslovakia. ''I was a brilliant impresario,'' he joked, improvising on imaginary drums as he spoke. ''We each got 50 francs a night.'' **********He later traveled through Iran and was a contributing editor to the Pakistan Times. In 1961, he took his compulsory officer training in Algeria. All the while, he gently resisted the pull of Hermes. ''I had nothing against it,'' he said. ''I just had another life.'' **********In the early 1960's, when his father, Robert Dumas, then company president, told him it was time to come home to Hermes, he agreed. But first he spent a year in New York, in the Bloomingdale's buyer training program. (His wife, Rena, whom he married in 1962, got a job in a New York architecture firm.) It was at Bloomingdale's, Mr. Dumas-Hermes says, that he ''discovered the importance of being a merchant.'' At home, at Hermes, he said, ''we were proud to sell, but far more proud to produce.'' **********When he finally arrived at Hermes in 1964, he says, his first lesson was in humility. His father sent him to the Drouot antiques auctions to choose prints for scarf designs, but not one of his selections was ever used by the designers at Hermes. **********He was more successful as head of manufacturing, and by 1971 was managing director. Seven years later, the family voted him chairman. **********His ascendancy surprised him, he says. He is, after all, the fourth, not the first, child in his family. He never assumed things would automatically go his way at the house of Hermes, where the family was not obliged to be part of the company. His own son and daughter, he adds, have no plans to join Hermes. ''Look, we're not the Fendi sisters,'' he said, referring to the Italian family that has built a leather and fur dynasty. **********AS the new chairman at a time when business was slow, Mr. Dumas-Hermes began to tinker with structure. He set up a holding company and developed divisions for fragrances, watches and manufacturing. **********More recently, he reclaimed United States distribution rights for the fragrances from Beecham Products, and signed an agreement with Italian manufacturer Benetton to produce its perfumes. **********He also looked for outside talent. Several family members still hold upper-level positions at Hermes: A sister-in-law, Michele Dumas, is managing director; two cousins, Patrick Guerrand and Bertrand Puesch, are vice chairmen; his wife, architect Rena Dumas, designs the stores. **********But while Mr. Dumas-Hermes appreciates this family legacy, his aim is to run an effective organization. ''The family brings a certain spirit to the business, but it doesn't mean they are entitled to do something,'' he said. ''We try to get the best we can for the job.'' **********For Mr. Dumas-Hermes, that has meant hiring non-family members, among them Gilles du Val, the marketing director, and local managers to direct foreign markets. In the United States, the local talent is Chrysler Fisher, who was hired away from Neiman-Marcus in the early 1980's to head up American operations. **********Under Mr. Fisher, Hermes's American operations started a direct marketing program that includes mail order, 800-numbers and ''how-to'' scarf and tie brochures. To help generate mail-order sales, it also brings craftsmanship demonstrations to smaller American cities with no Hermes outlet. The marketing seems to work. United States sales doubled from 1985 to 1986 and now account for 12 percent of Hermes's worldwide revenues. **********Such companywide restructuring helped Hermes grow worldwide, analysts say. But Mr. Dumas-Hermes's image-polishing helped even more. **********He began looking for an updated image soon after he became chairman. ''I'm afraid we may have been a bit brutal in our assessment, when they asked for an opinion,'' said Francoise Aron, a partner at Hermes's ad agency, Eldorado, and a friend and former schoolmate of Mr. Dumas-Hermes. ''We told them straight that we all knew Hermes, but that it wasn't for anybody who was considered a trend-setter.'' **********ELDORADO worked with Hermes to fix that. In 1979, the silk scarf appeared in French fashion magazines on a ''nana'' (the French equivalent of ''chick'') wearing a Lee Rider denim jacket and Hermes gold earrings. The aviator sunglasses in her pocket reflected a Parisian mansard skyline. Hermes had been jerked up to date. **********The agency, which also handles advertising for Benetton, followed up with ads featuring such company classics as the Kelly handbag done in bright green or red ostrich skin. (The original Kelly, a calfskin bag named for the late Princess Grace of Monaco, is still popular at $1,900.) And last spring, it launched a controversial campaign for the company's Bel Ami fragrance. British women's magazines were scandalized by the ads, which feature a Gustav Klimt sketch of a reclining nude, and British shops were reluctant to use the counter displays. But Hermes has stuck with its ads, and are calling the campaign a success. **********Mr. Dumas-Hermes has other goals for his company, including the doubling of sales in its apparel business. He also wants to exert more control over production and distribution by assuming ownership of certain plants the company uses. **********Just as important, Mr. Dumas-Hermes says, are the things the company will not do. It will not, for example, license the Hermes name. Nor are there plans to go public. ''We have enough money to finance our own growth,'' he said. **********Despite his company's rich history, Mr. Dumas-Hermes likes to talk about his company's place in the modern world. He mentions that there are robots in the printing plant, that the carbon fiber in his new Hermes briefcase is the same as on the exterior of France's Ariane rocket, that the new leather workrooms will be near La Villette, Paris's center for science and technology. ''I don't care about the past,'' he said. ''I am excited by a future based on the past.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/13/world.main_headline: A COPTER LIFELINE ON ECUADOR'S RIVER OF DEATH
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/13/world.print_headline: A COPTER LIFELINE ON ECUADOR'S RIVER OF DEATH
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/13/world.body_text: **********When a series of earthquakes struck this northeastern region last week, ''it felt like everything was going to end,'' said Aviola Atiz, one of the survivors. **********This village, the last stop on a flight by a relief helicopter that carried an American reporter into the heart of the devastated zone, is one of a number where survivors are totally dependent on helicopters for supplies. **********Officials said 75,000 people in the province of Napo had been cut off from commercial centers by the flooding that followed the earthquakes. The helicopters are flying out of the air base at Lago Agrio, the main distribution center for relief supplies. More Mud Than Vegetation **********A military relief worker aboard one of the helicopters said the worst destruction could not be seen. ''There are whole small villages that were taken by the floods,'' he said. ''They have disappeared.'' **********Bob Moss, an American businessman and amateur radio operator who flew along the the Quijos River this morning, said: ''It looks like someone took those mountains and shook them good. In some areas there is more earth and mud than vegetation.'' **********The International Red Cross has said 300 people are dead and 4,000 missing in the stricken region. Many residents have scattered and it is impossible to determine how many of the missing will eventually be counted among the dead. Dead for Lack of Care **********Col. Ramiro Silva, who is in charge of air relief at the Lago Agrio base, said fatalities could reach 1,000. He put the number of dead now at 400 to 600. **********''San Francisco, San Andres and a lot of small villages of a few families have disappeared,'' he said. ''We don't know how many. We are concentrating our efforts along the river but we also have the rest of the province to worry about. People are isolated and need supplies.  ''There are a lot of people who have not had services for a long time. There are babies and small children who have died for lack of care. We're very limited here.'' Colonel Silva has three Super Puma helicopters for the supply missions and two smaller helicopters for reconnaissance, to gather information on where more supplies are needed. More Helicopters Needed **********He said at least two more Super Pumas and more supplies, such as plastic covering and medicine, were needed. Fuel for the helicopters is also in short supply, he said. **********As the helicopter settled on a clearing near this village, Rafael Guacon ran forward and immediately began unloading bags bulging with rice, sardines, tuna and candy. **********''You have to take some back,'' he shouted to the relief workers. ''There are families on the other side of the river cut off from us.'' **********Twenty bags were quickly reloaded and Mr. Guacon jumped aboard to lead the pilot to survivors across the river, who had laid wood atop thick mud to cross into a small ravine where the helicopter landed. The wood would be easily swept away by rains that threatened to fall later today. **********''On Friday when the river flooded it sounded like five planes taking off and the mud rose 10 feet,'' Mr. Guacon said. **********A woman who lives nearby, Ligia Guzman, said she and her family had been saved because they lived relatively far from the river. **********''The floods took everything along the river,'' she said, her small baby swaddled in blankets and asleep in her arms. ''The mud is high and it's beginning to smell like dead bodies or animals. I don't know how many died -everyone along the river.'' Weather Delays Rescue **********Farther south along the Quijos in places like Reventador, El Salado and Santa Rosa de Quijos, greater numbers of people lived near the river and the casualties were higher, officials said. By late this morning, bad weather made it impossible to land there. **********Maj. Richard Wakefield, an American pilot who is part of an exchange program in Quito and who is making three flights a day to carry out refugees, said the quakes had caused extensive damage. ''The road they say is destroyed,'' he said. ''It is gone.'' **********The Quijos has doubled in size and its clear water has turned into a muddy, swift current. No trace remains of a long cement bridge over the river near the village of Lumbaqui, where people had gathered to be evacuated. **********Small mountains to the side of the river drop off to the east into the jungle, where casualties were minimal but where people are cut off from supplies, officials said. **********The quakes ruptured the country's main oil pipeline, suspending all exports and severely limiting domestic gasoline supplies. Five large tanks near Agualagrio were empty today. **********A spokesman for the American Embassy said it was taking requests for aid, but was unaware of any for more aircraft. Maj. Miguel Argudo, in the Office of Civil Defense in Quito, which is managing the relief effort, said the Government at first believed the three helicopters were sufficent but now realized more were needed.
