'There's Nothing Here' **********This morning, when a helicopter took off from Lago Agrio with supplies for five villages, it was loaded so heavily that it began to waver from side to side and the pilot made an unexpected landing. Seven journalists were asked to disembark and wait while the helicopter made one relief stop and lightened its load. **********At every small patch of earth where the helicopter landed, survivors would appear from thickly forested mountains and run toward the relief workers. The force of the downdraft from the helicopter would often lift the tin roofs of nearby houses to reveal small, sparsely furnished rooms. **********''There's nothing here,'' shouted a peasant above the roar of the helicopter when it stopped at the small village called San Pedro de los Cofanes. He said that 20 families lived in the area and that no one he knew had been killed. **********At another stop, a man shouted that medicine was needed, but there was none to be dropped today. **********Colonel Silva said later that there did not appear to be any seriously injured people still in the region, but that survivors needed ''preventive'' medicine because many were living in the open in an area still being shaken by tremors. #1,500 Are Evacuated Some 1,500 people have already been evacuated to Quito and small towns north of Lago Agrio. Dozens of others stand in long lines at the small airport in Lago Agrio waiting for C-130's to take them to join family members in Quito. **********Commercial flights are still operating to Lago Agria, but many of the refugees have no money for a ticket. **********In addition to the river towns, Colonel Silva said, villages east of the river such as Shushufindi and San Francisco de Orellano are also in need of food, gasoline and other aid. **********He said that some of the jungle area in the east could be supplied over a long, circuitous land route and that possibly more air operations could be run from another air base. For the moment, however, the Lago Agria base is the only one being used.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/26/world.main_headline: IRANIANS FLEE TO TURKEY AND DREAM OF U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/26/world.print_headline: IRANIANS FLEE TO TURKEY AND DREAM OF U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/26/world.body_text: **********On most days, outside American diplomatic missions here and elsewhere in Turkey, small knots of people gather -sometimes whole lines of them -clutching documents, some false, and harboring dreams, some in vain. **********A Western official sought briefly for a comparison and then came up with ''Casablanca,'' the film featuring Humphrey Bogart and depicting the Moroccan city filled with fugitives from Nazis - seeking, as one character puts it, the flight to Lisbon and ''a Clipper to America.'' **********Those who gather here by the hundreds of thousands are also seeking refuge. **********But they are Iranians fleeing the Islamic revolution - draft-dodgers, business executives, members of religious minorities including Jews and Bahais, and still others fleeing because of past associations with the Shah. **********Their plight presents a problem without apparent solution. Increasingly, Western officials acknowledge, Western countries, including the United States are reluctant to accept them. **********Turkey has reportedly begun forcing back those Iranians found arriving by horse and truck along the smuggler trails of the mountainous eastern border. But they continue to flee and a business has flourished here. **********Here, in the teeming, tumbledown streets of Aksaray district, as in Signor Ferrari's Blue Parrot Club in ''Casablanca,'' a fugitive may purchase many things: a passport with a replaced photograph (estimated cost: $800); a whole new passport (estimated cost $2,000); forged documents attesting to the existence of a family -fictitious - in the United States, or bogus stamps and seals to lend an official appearance to a false credential. **********Sometimes those who prey on Iranians take the money and disappear. **********A fugitive from Iran, a Western specialist said, might buy passage on a vessel not scrutinized by Turkish port officials, or pay for the temporary distraction of an airport immigration official. It is even whispered that an Iranian man might arrange for an American woman to become his wife and thus allow entry to the United States. **********Turkey has become a reluctant host to the fugitives because it borders Iran and because it does not require Iranians to hold entry visas. **********''Turkey used to be a point of transit for the Iranians,'' a Western said. ''Now it's getting to be a cul-de-sac.'' Another specialist estimated the number of Iranians arriving in Turkey each month at between 5,000 and 10,000. **********But no one seems to know for sure how many Iranians overall have crammed this already bulging city. The minimum estimate by Westerners is 400,000, the maximum 1.5 million. The Turkish Interior Minister, Yildirim Akbulut, put it at 15,000 to 16,000 -a figure regarded as fiction to protect Turkey's awkward position between conflicting pressures. Iran Fears Gathering of Foes **********Iran, a Western diplomat said, does not want Turkey to harbor its foes and malcontents, fearing the growth of an exiled political and military opposition. **********But, a relief official said, Western nations - while leery of Iranians themselves - do not want Turkey to close its doors. Additionally, the Turks, suspicious over Iranian efforts to sponsor Islamic fundamentalism in this secular state, are said to anguish over who some of the Iranians are. **********''It would be no problem at all for Iranians to infiltrate all kinds of people in the stream of fugitives, including fundamentalist agitators,'' a Western specialist said. **********Last year, people thought by diplomats to be Iranian hit men gunned down in Istanbul's streets several people said to be collaborators of the Shah. **********But many Iranians in Turkey seem to boast of a less prominent status. Outside the United States Embassy in Ankara the other day, for instance, two sets of strangers met up to discuss a common goal: visas to America. **********One man, slightly stubbled and accompanied by a woman he said was his married daughter, said he was seeking a visa for her to join a husband already in America. Then, he said, he would return to Iran, where an unmarried daughter was in college, and seek a visa to the United States for her and himself when she had graduated. 'Now There's Nothing' **********Speaking to a reporter but unwilling to be identified, he seemed to show a kind of nostalgia. ''Once we could buy everything,'' he said. ''Now there's nothing. All the country's money goes for bombs for the war. All the young men are at the front. All the professional people have gone.'' **********He gestured toward a young woman. ''Here, you can see her hair,'' he said. ''She wears jeans. At home, she is persecuted if she does not cover herself and wear traditional dress.'' **********The number of Iranians seeking entry to the United States at American missions in Turkey seems to have peaked in 1985, when around 29,000 applied for visas. The figure fell in 1986 to 18,000, according to the U.S. Consulate in Ankara, and is expected to drop a bit this year. On average, 75 percent of the applications are rejected. **********Yet, like flood water pressing on a flawed dam, many Iranians seem to show a persistence and ingenuity in seeking ways to the West. Until last year, for instance, the East German airline Interflug did not require visas for Iranians boarding flights to East Berlin from Ankara. So Iranians would board the planes, and, once in East Berlin, they would cross to West Berlin. **********That loophole has been closed now, and other West European countries, which used to permit fugitives to remain on their soil while their applications for residence were processed, no longer do so, a Western diplomat said. Refugee Proof Required **********''They would come with all kinds of stories - how they had paid $2,000 to be spirited in trucks through Bulgaria to places in Western Europe where the borders are porous - like Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg - or the French-Belgian border,'' the diplomat said. ''On the way they would destroy their passports and claim asylum. Now, if there's no prima facie evidence that they are genuine refugees, they are sent back.'' **********The number of Iranians formally settled as recognized refugees in the West may be higher this year, the official said, because Western countries including Canada and Sweden have shown interest in ''taking the cream.'' **********In the first three months of this year, about 570 Iranians acquired formal refugee status. **********In the movie ''Casablanca,'' there were also unwanted people, locked in intrigue, clawed by those selling promises and passages. And, as the movie's narrator puts it in the opening scenes, the destiny of many is simply ''to wait, and wait, and wait.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/24/world.main_headline: Freetown Journal; 'Little Beiruts' Multiplying in Africa
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/24/world.print_headline: Freetown Journal; 'Little Beiruts' Multiplying in Africa
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/24/world.body_text: **********Fleeing Lebanon's civil war, increasing numbers of Lebanese are emigrating to West and Central Africa, sometimes bringing with them the political violence of the Middle East. **********In Freetown, officials charge that the country's wealthiest businessman, an African-Lebanese with close ties to the Shiite Moslem militia Amal, tried to finance a coup attempt last spring. At the time, police officers discovered a weapons cache in the man's villa that included rocket launchers, M-16 and AK-47 automatic rifles and 49,000 rounds of ammunition. **********In Bangui, capital of the Central African Republic, about 40 Lebanese Shiites were expelled last summer after a member of their community hijacked an Air Afrique flight in July and demanded to fly to Beirut. **********In Monrovia, Liberia, a Lebanese Christian woman says she no longer goes to the local Lebanese club on Saturday nights. ''After a few drinks the Hezbollah and the Amal start fighting,'' she said, referring to supporters of rival Shiite groups in Lebanon. A Wave of Thousands **********The violent incidents cast a spotlight on the thousands of Lebanese who came to Africa in recent years to make money in peace. **********These immigrants followed in the tradition of the first modern wave of Lebanese immigrants, Maronite Christians. The Maronites started coming to West Africa a century ago to escape being drafted into the armies of the Ottoman Empire. Some boarded boats thinking they were bound for South America. **********More recently, Lebanon's decade-old civil war and the crash of the Lebanese pound this year have converted the traditional ebb and flow into a one-way flood. **********Long one of the largest non-indigenous groups in West Africa, the Lebanese have become increasingly prominent. In many cities, the Lebanese are increasingly resented by local Africans. **********In the Ivory Coast, the number of Lebanese has jumped from 25,000 a decade ago to about 100,000 today. Senegal and Sierra Leone are believed to have about 25,000 each. **********Abidjan's commercial heart, the Rue de Commerce, is known as Little Beirut for the predominance of Lebanese-owned shops. One of the largest apartment buildings overlooking the Ivory Coast capital's lagoon is called Nabil, which in reverse spells Liban, the French word for Lebanon. **********Last winter, Abidjan's night skyline was marked by Christmas lights strung on a hotel tower in the shape of a gigantic cedar of Lebanon. Beirut Flights Scheduled **********In Sierra Leone, a nation of 3.5 million people, the Lebanese population has become so large that Middle East Airlines inaugurated a weekly flight between Freetown and Beirut last June. **********In shop after shop, Lebanese owners sit behind cash registers, sometimes sipping cups of thick Turkish coffee while they oversee African shop clerks and attend to African customers. **********Lebanese dominance in retail trade has caused racial flare-ups. In January, when students rioted in the provincial town of Kenema, they looted the Lebanese school. In August, the immigration authorities turned away 21 Lebanese arriving on an airplane from Beirut. **********''As far as the Sierra Leoneans are concerned, the Lebanese have come here to exploit us,'' said Franklin Bunting-Davis, editor of an independent Freetown newspaper, New Shaft. **********''This has a lot to do with race,'' he continued. ''There are Gambians here; there are Senegalese. But no one says anything because we are all black. But the Lebanese with his little shop is seen as exploiting us.'' A Prop to the Economy **********The Lebanese, however, see themselves as providing an essential economic service with their expertise in commerce and small trade. Mr. Bunting-Davis acknowledged that if the Lebanese were expelled, the effect would be an economic disaster for Sierra Leone. **********Farid Raymond-Anthony, a Sierra Leonean lawyer of Lebanese descent, lamented the predicament of the Lebanese immigrant in Africa. **********''I was born here, all my friends are here, I speak Krio,'' he said, referring to Sierra Leone's lingua franca. **********''But I go across the river to another town, and I could have arrived yesterday from Lebanon,'' he added. ''It's too bad you can't get blacker with the more time you spend in Africa.'' **********The coup attempt last spring jolted many Sierra Leoneans awake to the fact that their country, a major exporter of gold and diamonds, has become a miniature battleground for Middle East politics. Alliance With Nabih Berri **********Jamil Said Mohammed, the businessman believed to have financed the coup attempt, has long been a major contributor to the Amal militia of Nabih Berri, the Lebanese Justice Minister. The son of a Lebanese merchant and a Sierra Leonean woman, Mr. Jamil was a childhood friend of Mr. Berri, who was born in Bo, Sierra Leone. **********In the past, Palestinian bodyguards supplied by Mr. Berri provided security for Mr. Jamil at his hilltop residence here, which is equipped with a swimming pool and tennis courts. Last year, after a shooting incident at the residence, three guards were expelled. This year, when Mr. Jamil visited Lebanon, Mr. Berri arranged a hero's welcome. **********Apparently because of Sierra Leone's wealth and its liberal immigration policy, this ramshackle capital has gained a reputation along Africa's west coast as a center for Middle East intrigue and diplomacy. **********Last year, Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, visited here. Today, the P.L.O. maintains an office and a medical team here as good-will gestures. **********On Campbell Street, next to the French cultural center, a Cultural Center of the Islamic Republic of Iran recently opened. New Contact With Israel **********Sierra Leone, largely a Moslem country, broke relations with Israel in 1973. But in the last year, two ministers visited Israel. After these visits, the Israelis agreed to develop a national bus service for Sierra Leone and to build about 4,000 low-rent housing units here. **********Indeed, some Sierra Leoneans see the Israelis as a counterweight to the Lebanese. **********President Joseph S. Momoh's predecessor, Siaka Stevens, employed Lebanese security guards. After the coup attempt last spring, Mr. Momoh sent six of his security guards to Israel for training. **********The spillover of Middle East political violence into the region has not gone unnoticed by some companies doing business here. **********After the Air Afrique hijacking in which a French passenger was shot to death, UTA, the French airline, tightened security on its African routes. Now, company security agents are posted at airplane doors where, in a final security check, they frisk passengers and search all carry-on luggage.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/18/world.main_headline: THE IRAN-CONTRA GRAND JURY IS FOCUSING ON FUND-RAISER
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/18/world.print_headline: THE IRAN-CONTRA GRAND JURY IS FOCUSING ON FUND-RAISER
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/18/world.body_text: **********The grand jury in the Iran-contra affair has questioned witnesses in recent days about their knowledge of a conservative Washington fund-raiser and his role in providing millions of dollars for Nicaraguan rebel groups, according to lawyers with knowledge of the inquiry. **********They said that a Nicaraguan lawyer who had extensive knowledge of the rebels' financing, Carlos Morales, testified before the grand jury this week and had been questioned about the lobbyist, Carl R. (Spitz) Channell, and groups linked to Mr. Channell. **********The leader of the largest rebel army, Adolfo Calero, has appeared before the grand jury four times and has also been extensively questioned about his dealings with Mr. Channell, the lawyers said. The grand jurors were said to be particularly interested in one specific grant to the contras of about $1 million said to have been raised through Mr. Channell. 'Inordinate Interest' **********It was Mr. Morales who helped Mr. Calero set up dummy corporations in Panama that were used to funnel private aid to the contra rebels. **********One lawyer with knowledge of the grand jury said the special prosecutor in the case, Lawrence E. Walsh, had shown ''inordinate interest'' in recent weeks in Mr. Channell's activities and his ties to contra leaders. Mr. Walsh is overseeing the grand jury. **********Investigators said several weeks ago that they would review Mr. Channell's actions. ''And he is obviously becoming more and more of a concern as the investigation goes on,'' a lawyer said. **********A public relations specialist hired by Mr. Channell, Jared S. Cameron, said his client had been interviewed by Mr. Walsh's staff. He said he was uncertain whether Mr. Channell had yet appeared before the grand jury. Money Said to Go for Weapons **********''I know from speaking to him that he feels that he has committed no crime,'' Mr. Cameron said.  A former fund-raiser for Mr. Channell, Jane E. McLaughlin, spent several hours testifying before the grand jury earlier this month, according to someone with knowledge of her testimony. **********Ms. McLaughlin said in an interview that she believed the fund-raising operation was used to purchase weapons for the contras, and she has provided Mr. Walsh with documents offering a detailed breakdown of Mr. Channell's aid operations. **********Mr. Channell is the president of the National Endowment for the Preservation of Liberty, a group that has come under intense scrutiny for its efforts to raise millions for the contra supply effort. Mr. Channell worked closely with Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, the National Security Council aide who was dismissed in the wake of the Iran-contra affair and who often met with donors. Immunity Vote Expected **********As the grand jury investigation progressed, Congressional officials said the House and Senate committees looking into the Iran-contra affair were expected to vote Wednesday to grant limited immunity to Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter, President Reagan's former national security adviser, who was dismissed. **********The immunity would be granted under an agreement with Mr. Walsh that would require Admiral Poindexter to testify before the committees about his role in the case. Investigators have said that he was aware of plans to divert millions of dollars to the contras from the sale of arms to Iran. **********Another former national security adviser, Robert C. McFarlane, has reportedly been exhaustively questioned on at least four separate occasions by investigators working for Mr. Walsh. Aid Was Prohibited **********According to lawyers with knowledge of the inquiry, the grand jury is exploring the relationship among Mr. Channell, Colonel North and contra leaders to determine if laws were violated in raising money for the contras. **********From October 1984 to October 1986, the Government was prohibited by Congress from giving direct military aid to the rebels. Individuals are banned from providing arms under the Neutrality Act and other laws, and Federal rules prohibit tax-exempt contributions from being used for arms. **********Mr. Calero has repeatedly been called before the grand jury and asked about Mr. Channell, the lawyers said. **********In a letter recently made available to a reporter, dated Dec. 5, 1985, Mr. Calero wrote to Mr. Channell - ''My dear friend Spitz'' - and thanked him for his support of the contra movement. 'Please Help Us' **********''We need $50,000 through the holiday season,'' Mr. Calero wrote in asking for support for the families of contra fighters. ''Please help us to sustain those who have stayed behind so that those of us on the front lines can survive.'' **********He ended, ''God bless you for your past efforts and constant faith in us.'' **********Mr. Morales's role in the contra supply effort has also intrigued investigators, the lawyers said. There has been no public allegation that Mr. Morales violated any laws. Mr. Morales gave Mr. Calero access to a Miami bank account as a vehicle to receive millions of dollars in funds from private sources wishing to assist the contras. **********In addition, Mr. Morales assisted Mr. Calero in organizing three Panamanian dummy corporations that controlled five other bank accounts in Panama and the Cayman Islands to help channel funds. **********Mr. Calero has said that he gave the bank account numbers to several influential people who offered to help raise private funds, including Colonel North and Richard V. Secord, a retired Air Force major general who was instrumental in the contra supply effort. **********In another aspect of the affair, a Government official confirmed a report in The Washington Post today that Colonel North negotiated an arms-for-hostages deal alone with an Iranian middleman on a secret mission last year to Teheran, but that the deal was ended at the insistence of Mr. McFarlane, who was also on the trip.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/05/busin.main_headline: When Travelers Can't Get Off the Ground
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/05/busin.print_headline: PERSONAL FINANCE; When Travelers Can't Get Off the Ground
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/05/busin.body_text: **********AS increasing numbers of travelers take to the skies, spurred in part by the airline industry's deeply discounted promotional fares, there has been an accompanying rise in flight delays and cancellations. The summer travel season is expected to compound the problem. **********Since Federal lawmakers are among the nation's most frequent fliers, they have had ample experience with the aggravation that delays can produce. Their experiences have doubtless proved an incentive to the many pending Congressional proposals that would force the airlines to publicize delays and cancellations. **********''The airlines are where the phone company used to be,'' complained Representative Peter A. DeFazio, an Oregon Democrat. ''Their attitude is, we don't care, and we don't have to care.'' **********Last week, Representative DeFazio and Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, an Ohio Democrat, introduced a bill that would require airlines to disclose their policies regarding passenger rights in the case of flight delays and cancellations, overbooking, and lost and delayed luggage. **********As a practical matter, the major domestic airlines already set forth their policies on such matters in a document called the conditions or contract of carriage, an agreement between the passenger and the airline that is considered to be an extension of the ticket and supposed to be available where tickets are sold. **********But few passengers are aware that the document exists, and typically the airlines say in it that they take no responsibility for failure to operate a flight according to schedule and are not liable for any consequential damages. **********''I think people would be appalled to discover that once they purchase a ticket, they forfeit all rights,'' said Representative DeFazio. **********Indeed, the present rules offer little protection to travelers whose plans have been disrupted. With few exceptions, airlines are not required to make amends, even if flight delays or cancellations mean that passengers miss important events - such as business meetings, weddings, or funerals - that were the very reason for flying. **********While airline tickets clearly spell out the consequences if passengers fail to arrive for a flight on time, there is no equivalent responsibility for the airline to deliver passengers to their destination on time. **********''Most people do not understand that airlines do not guarantee their schedules,'' said Cornish F. Hitchcock, legal director of the Aviation Consumer Action Project in Washington. **********Dissatisfaction over flight delays and cancellations accounts for the largest single group of consumer complaints received by the Department of Transportation. Last year, the Department received 12,741 consumer complaints and 3,683 - almost 30 percent - concerned ''flight problems,'' according to Hoyte B. Decker Jr., head of the Department's consumer complaint division. (By contrast, there were 2,583 complaints about baggage, 1,909 complaints about refunds and 1,037 complaints about overbooking.) And the problem of flight delays is worsening. In the first nine months of 1986, the most recent figures available, the Department of Transportation received 1,133 complaints about flight cancellations, or almost twice as many as in the last nine months of 1985. In the first nine months of 1986, complaints about flight delays rose almost 50 percent from the last nine months of 1985. **********Even though there are no formal rules about an airline's responsibility for canceled or delayed flights, there are some practical steps you can take if you find yourself stranded at the airport. Assuming the problem is not due to bad weather that has disrupted the entire air travel system, but rather to some fault of the airline's, such as an equipment breakdown, you should first ask to be placed on the next available flight to your destination. **********Typically, the airline will try to place you on one of its own planes rather than on a competitor's. But if another airline has space available on a flight leaving in one hour, and the next flight on your airline will not leave for five hours, ask that you be placed on the other airline. Your airline is not required to comply, but it might do so as a matter of good will. **********Similarly, if you are flying coach but the only space on the next flight is in first class, ask to be upgraded and placed on that flight. But before boarding, make sure that the airline will absorb the price difference. **********Usually, an airline will pay for amenities such as phone calls, meals and hotels only if your trip is interrupted in mid-flight, rather than delayed or canceled at the outset. Such decisions are likely to be made by airline personnel on the spot, rather than in formal company documents. **********''If a flight is canceled or late, a lot of discretion is given to local management,'' said Stephen D. McGregor, a spokesman for American Airlines. **********But even if these amenities are not automatically offered, they may be forthcoming if you insist on them. ''Even though you don't have any more rights than anybody else, what you get may depend on how assertive you are,'' said Ed Perkins, editor of Consumer Reports Travel Letter, a monthly newsletter. ''You may have to make a total nuisance of yourself.'' **********If you get no satisfaction from the agent handling your flight, ask to speak with the station manager or general manager. Be reasonable, but let that person know that if your demands are not met, you intend to write to the top management of the airline and to file a complaint with the Department of Transportation. **********The Department says it prefers to receive complaints by telephone so it can handle them promptly; the number is 202-366-2220. But the agency cannot force an airline to take a particular action in your case, so do not count on much practical help. You will have the satisfaction of having your complaint counted in the department's annual compilation of gripes against particular carriers. **********MR. DECKER, of the Department's consumer complaint division, suggests you also send a written complaint to the president or chairman of the airline. Keep your letter brief, and be explicit about what you expect in compensation - whether it is a letter of apology, reimbursement for out-of-pocket costs, a refund on your ticket or a free ticket for future travel. ''The key thing is to say exactly what you want,'' Mr. Decker advised. ''People get so steamed up over what has happened to them that they often forget to say what they want.'' **********You can also send a copy of the letter to the Aviation Consumer Action Project, which may be able to intercede with a carrier. The group has also published a short booklet, ''Facts & Advice for Airline Passengers.'' It is available for $2 by writing to ACAP, Box 19029, Washington, D.C. 20036.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/30/busin.body_text: **********The United States has asked Taiwan to revalue its currency upward to help the Reagan Administration fight protectionist bills and reduce its large trade deficit, officials said today. If the Taiwan dollar rose against the American dollar, American goods would be cheaper for Taiwanese buyers, and Taiwanese goods would be more expensive for American consumers, helping redress the current trade imbalance.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/03/busin.body_text: **********United States and European trade officials failed to reach a final agreement today in talks about the long-running dispute about government subsidies for the Airbus aircraft consortium. **********The United States has long complained that Airbus, which is backed by Britain, France, Spain and West Germany, was providing unfair government subsidies that enabled it to sell aircraft at cut-rate prices. Airbus competes with the Boeing Company and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation in the market for large passenger aircraft. **********Airbus and the European governments say that all government loans will eventually be repaid and do not represent unfair subsidies. **********''Things are coming along,'' a negotiator for the European Community said after the meeting here. ''There is a good atmosphere. But there are still several points of disagreement.'' United States negotiators were not available for comment. Further negotiations are scheduled to be held in Brussels on Dec. 11.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/29/busin.print_headline: MARKET TURMOIL; Fed's Goal: A Calming Effect
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/29/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Reserve, in its role as guardian of the nation's financial system, has emerged as the first arm of Government to respond actively to the steep drop in the stock market. **********While Congress and the Securities and Exchange Commission have begun inquiries into the cause of the market decline, and the President has suggested a willingness to compromise to cut the budget deficit, the Fed has acted both openly and behind the scenes to soothe the nerves of financiers and prevent a full-fledged panic. **********Yesterday, for example, the Fed bought dollars in the foreign exchange market to prevent a rapid decline in the value of the currency. **********It has also stepped in earlier than normal in recent days to buy Treasury securities temporarily, thereby adding cash reserves to the financial system. On Tuesday, it even announced a day in advance its intention to supply reserves. A Cushioning Effect **********''The Fed has no obligation to protect stock market profits - that is not its job,'' said Richard Hoey, chief economist at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. ''But it does have an obligation to limit the secondary effects of a decline in stock prices.'' **********To reduce the impact of those declines on the financial system, the Fed has adopted a two-pronged approach to assure bankers, companies and the public that there is no need to panic and curtail their regular business activities. A stop in the normal flow of borrowing and lending brought on by the stock plunge would almost certainly result in a recession. **********On the one hand, the Fed has assured banks and securities firms that money will be made available to carry them over short-term squeezes brought on by the turmoil in the financial markets. **********The first public sign of the Fed's attitude came early on Oct. 20 - the day after the Dow Jones industrial average fell 508 points - when it issued a statement affirming its ''readiness to serve as a source of liquidity to support the economic and financial system.'' Continued Lending Urged **********To supplement that statement, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York met last week with executives of leading New York banks, urging them to lend to securities firms that are credit-worthy but have suffered a temporary cash shortage during the market downturn. **********Without these steps to encourage the financial community, the Fed would run the risk that banks might worsen the situation on Wall Street by denying loans to credit-worthy securities firms whose borrowing needs are only temporary. Or worse yet, banks might respond to losses on loans to some firms, and a surge in their loans to credit-worthy securities dealers, by cutting back on lending to other sectors of the economy. **********Another aspect of the Fed's crisis management has been its encouragement of a modest decline in interest rates on overnight loans among banks. These rates have declined to about 6 5/8 percent yesterday, down from an average of 7 percent between Oct. 20 and Oct. 27 and about 7 1/2 percent in the four weeks before Oct. 20. **********Although the decline is much less than the drop in other short-term rates, it is seen in the market as a clear sign of Fed policy, relieving the fears of higher interest rates that prevailed earlier this month. **********''I think the Fed's strategy is clear - the only questions are about tactics and how it will orchestrate an easier monetary policy,'' said Dana B. Johnson, a financial economist at the First National Bank of Chicago. ''The Fed will try to be as stimulative as it can, but it has to beware of the risk of a free fall in the dollar and the thinking of people in the markets who still seem to worry about inflation.'' **********Mr. Hoey of Drexel Burnham said that during periods of turmoil, when the demand for safe, liquid securities like Treasury bills is exceptionally strong, the Fed has no choice but to provide liquidity and stabilize the markets. ''You may say in hindsight that there was excess liquidity provided, but that is a necessary price you have to pay,'' he said. Policy Concerns Some **********Some analysts are concerned that the Fed is doing too little in response to the downturn in stocks. **********''The Fed is following the market, not leading the way to a much more aggressive lowering of interest rates,'' said Roger A. Craig, a manager of the fixed-income portfolio at the Banc One Asset Management Corporation, in Columbus, Ohio. ''The downturn in the economy is going to be much more severe than the Fed seems to expect.'' **********Exactly how much economic growth will be reduced, and whether the slowdown will amount to a full-fledged recession, is a matter of debate. Because nobody knows whether the stock market decline will endure or how it will affect consumer and business spending, many analysts expect the Fed to wait a while before it acts more aggressively to ease monetary policy. **********''Given the risk of recession and deflation there's a good case for easing,'' said Mr. Johnson of First National of Chicago, ''but I expect the Fed will wait until it can announce a coordinated move to reduce interest rates by the G-7 countries, or else there is a definite deficit-reduction package out of Washington.'' G-7 refers to the Group of Seven, the leading industrial democracies that meet regularly to coordinate economic policies. **********Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Manhattan Bank, explained that even if the economy softens in the coming months, the Fed need not act now as if it is facing an imminent recession.  HOW THE FED ACTS TO CALM THE FINANCIAL MARKETS  The Federal Reserve deals on a low-key, day-to-day basis with certain banks and securities firms. Since the market collapse, the Fed has been moving to insure that the nation's financial system has enough money to support the economy's needs. The central bank has done this in a way that the financial markets could not overlook its intentions.  FEDERAL RESERVE BANK OF NEW YORK  Temporarily buys securities from some of the 40 banks or securities firms that it recognizes as primary dealers in the Treasury securities market. Fed receives Treasury securities and sends payment to bank or securities dealer. **********Although transactions are temporary, ranging from overnight to three days, Fed has been renewing them when they mature. If the transactions were not renewed, Treasury securities would be returned to banks and dealers, and payment they received earlier would return to Fed.  40 PRIMARY DEALERS  Payment goes to bank's reserve account at New York Fed. This adds to bank's resources, putting it in a better position to make more loans. More money in the system also leads to lower short-term interest rates. (Transactions made with securities firm have the same result, because firm receives Fed's payment through its account at commercial bank.) **********Result: Availability of extra credit and lower interest rates help sustain economic activity despite drop in stock market and strains it has created in financial system.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/30/busin.main_headline: Federated Names Chief For Foley's Store Chain
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/30/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Federated Names Chief For Foley's Store Chain
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/30/busin.body_text: **********Federated Department Stores Inc. has named John B. Utsey chairman and chief executive of one of its major department store chains, the Houston-based Foley's. **********Foley's has 38 stores in Texas, Oklahoma, Arizona and New Mexico that generated sales of $1.1 billion last year. **********Mr. Utsey, 48, currently Foley's vice chairman, is succeeding Lasker M. Meyer, 61, who is retiring after 28 years with Federated. **********Mr. Meyer, a native of Houston who attended Rice University, worked for Foley's throughout his career except for two years when he moved to Brooklyn as chairman of Federated's Abraham & Straus. **********Mr. Meyer was president of Foley's when he left for A.&S. and when he returned in 1982 he assumed the post of chairman. **********Mr. Utsey, also a native Texan, has worked for Foley's since he joined as an executive trainee in 1961. He too had a sojourn in New York - after graduating from Baylor he went to New York University, where he received a master's degree from the School of Retailing. **********Mr. Utsey, a spokesman said, was out in the Foley's stores checking the post-Thanksgiving shopping and was not available for comment on his new position. **********He was named Foley's president in 1980 and became its vice chairman in January 1987 when Foley's and another Federated division, Sanger Harris, were merged. **********Federated said Mr. Utsey would join Michael Steinberg, Foley's president, in forming the division's two-person top-management team, which will report to Donald J. Stone, a vice chairman at Federated. **********Federated, based in Cincinnati, operates some 650 department stores and other retail businesses with $10.5 billion in annual revenues.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/09/world.main_headline: HOUSE APPROVES DELAY IN GULF DUTY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/09/world.print_headline: HOUSE APPROVES DELAY IN GULF DUTY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/09/world.body_text: **********In a symbolic move, the House today approved a measure to delay the Reagan Administration's plan to fly American flags on Kuwaiti oil tankers and to provide the ships with a naval escort. **********The measure, which was adopted by a vote of 222 to 184, called for a 90-day delay in carrying out the plan. **********It stated that there was no immediate need to proceed with the plan, which it said could ''draw the United States into the Persian Gulf war.'' **********The House vote, which followed party lines, was symbolic because the Administration's plan is scheduled to start in mid-July and there is not enough time to block the plan. **********The measure, was sponsored by Mike Lowry, Democrat of Washington, as an amendment to a bill providing funds for the Coast Guard. In order to become law, the Senate would also have to agree to such an amendment to the Coast Guard spending bill. If that happened, President Reagan could veto the bill. **********The amendment by Mr. Lowry was a way for the Democrats to distance themselves from the reflagging proposal while avoiding direct opposition to the plan. Move to Block Plan Defeated **********Earlier today, the House voted against a move to block the plan. By a vote of 283 to 126, it defeated an amendment by Charles E. Bennett, Democrat of Florida, that would have prevented the registration of 11 Kuwaiti oil tankers under the American flag. **********The debate in the House was emotional as critics of reflagging drew comparion to the deployment of Marines in Beirut and defenders of the plan accused the critics of playing politics. **********Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin and chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, said the adoption of the Lowry amendment was a needed ''shot across the bow'' of the Administration that registered Congressional unhappiness with a hastily constructed initiative. 'Timidity' Is Charged **********The House minority leader, Robert H. Michel of Illinois, angrily attacked the amendment by Mr. Lowry as an act of ''timidity'' by the Democrats. **********Military officials said today that the original military plan for naval escorts did not envision providing protection to tankers acting as shuttles. **********Administration officials said Kuwait now planned to use one of 11 reflagged tankers as a shuttle. In addition, Kuwaitis also plans to charter at least two American-owned ships that would also serve as shuttles in the gulf, according to government officials. **********But Administration officials insisted that said arrangements could be made to provide protection to the shuttles without putting a strain on the escort service.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/13/world.main_headline: Israeli Visa Policy on Arabs Keeps Families Apart
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/13/world.print_headline: Israeli Visa Policy on Arabs Keeps Families Apart
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/13/world.body_text: **********This summer, about 45,000 Arabs will cross the Jordan River on special visas that allow them to spend three months in Israel. **********For many of them, the summer may be the only time they can spend at home with their families. They are among the thousands of Palestinians whose wives, husbands, children or elderly parents are permanent residents of East Jerusalem and the occupied territories. But their applications for residency, based on requests for family reunification, have been denied by the Israeli authorities. **********''I can count the number of months I have spent with Ibtisam, my wife, since we were married,'' said Said El-Atawneh, a 27-year-old farmer from a small village in the West Bank, quickly calculating with his fingers. ''It is three months each year, for five years - that is 15 months.'' Wife Lives With Parents **********In between her visits to their farm in Tarqumiye, near Hebron, his wife lives with her parents in Syria, Mr. El-Atawneh explained. **********''I cannot just leave and go to her,'' he said. ''My job, my house, my land -everything is here.'' **********The exact number of people in similar straits is difficult to ascertain. After the 1967 war, Israel tried to unite families that had been separated in the fighting, and enabled about 50,000 people to join families in the West Bank, said Elice Shazar, a spokeswoman for the Israeli Army Civil Administration, which runs the daily affairs of the West Bank. Approved 20 Percent of Requests **********In recent years, Israeli military officials said only hundreds out of thousands of applications submitted annually had been approved. In the West Bank, the only area for which precise figures were made public, 20 percent of 2,500 requests made last year were approved, double the number approved in 1985, Ms. Shazar said. The rest must ask for the visas and see their families as visitors. **********The reasons for approving some residency requests while rejecting others are unclear. **********''There are no criteria,'' Ms. Shazar said. ''Each decision is made on an individual basis. Humanitarian issues are taken into account, but again, each case is weighed on its own merits.'' Rejected 12 Times **********But Bishara Hajel, a Jerusalem-born businessman who lived abroad for many years but whose wife and five children now live in Ramallah, said his request for residency had been rejected 12 times. He said Israeli security personnel had promised to help him if he served as an informant, but he refused. Ms. Shazar said she could not discuss the case. **********''This is blatant administrative abuse, without even the justification of a security angle being involved,'' said Jonathan Kuttab, a Palestinian lawyer. ''If security were the problem, these people would not even be allowed in the country.'' **********One military official suggested that Palestinians take the problem of family reunification ''into account'' when deciding to marry. 'Open the Floodgates' **********This is not an option, however, for many young Palestinian men and women, whose marriages, often to cousins within the same family, have traditionally been arranged by parents and whose families are dispersed throughout Jordan and other Arab countries. **********Israeli civil rights advocates have condemned the policy, saying it is a transparent attempt to control or at least slow the rapid growth of the Palestinian population in Jerusalem and the occupied territories. The numbers involved are small, but military officials said there is a fear a liberal policy might ''open the floodgates'' and result in a great surge in applications. **********Palestinians are quick to charge Israeli authorities with hypocrisy, by pointing to the Government's intensive efforts to reunify the families of Soviet Jewish immigrants whose relatives have been denied permission to emigrate.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/03/busin.main_headline: SEARS SET TO CLOSE 5 DISTRIBUTION SITES
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/03/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; SEARS SET TO CLOSE 5 DISTRIBUTION SITES
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/03/busin.body_text: **********In yet another move to improve its ailing retailing unit, Sears, Roebuck & Company said today that it would consolidate its distribution operations, closing five facilities. **********Separately, Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., the brokerage unit of Sears, said today that it had been censured by the Securities and Exchange Commission for failing to report 38 cash transactions of more than $10,000 to the Treasury between 1983 and 1985. **********Sears said that closing the distribution centers would save it $150 million a year beginning in 1991, although it said it would report a one-time charge of $20 million in this year's first quarter. Analysts said the closings would improve Sears's margins and would allow the company to respond quickly to consumer demands. **********''They are being out-finessed by the smaller guys, so they have to build in a more streamlined organization,'' said John S. Landschulz, an analyst at Mesirow & Company in Chicago. ''They are now thinking efficiency.'' Sears will close its Chicago operation on April 30, affecting 1,800 employees. Later, Sears said, it would close its facilities in Boston, Atlanta, Memphis and Minneapolis. These sites employ about 3,700 people. **********Sears said the Boston facility is scheduled to close in 1988. The company said the other facilities would not be closed before 1989. **********Sears said it would offer early retirement and other benefits to the affected workers. **********Sears stock gained $1 a share today, to $52.25, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. **********Meanwhile, Dean Witter settled the proceeding with the S.E.C., involving unreported cash transactions totaling slightly more than $1 million, without admitting or denying guilt. The brokerage agreed to put into effect new procedures for cash transactions of more than $3,000. **********Under Federal law, cash transactions of $10,000 or more must be reported to the Treasury in an effort to detect money-laundering schemes. However, the S.E.C. noted that it was not accusing Dean Witter of deliberately helping to launder money.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/26/world.main_headline: 'OVER NIAGARA IN BARREL?' 'I THINK IT'S ENTIRELY APT'
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/26/world.print_headline: 'OVER NIAGARA IN BARREL?' 'I THINK IT'S ENTIRELY APT'
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/26/world.body_text: **********The question of a cover-up of the Iran-contra affair figured significantly in testimony yesterday by Assistant Attorney General Charles J. Cooper. Here are some excerpts. **********SENATOR WILLIAM S. COHEN, Republican of Maine. As I understand it, you said that, based upon your under understanding of the statements by Colonel North, Mr. McFarlane, Admiral Poindexter, an attempt was under way to construct a false and misleading chronology as to the fundamental facts involving United States participation in the sale of arms to Iran. Is that your conclusion? **********A. We certainly now know that to be the case, yes, sir. **********Q. And when Mr. McFarlane talked about gilding the President's record, that was a reference to try to insulate the President from having any role in the sale of the weapons to Iran? **********A. I'm, I'm not acquainted with that reference. **********Q. Mr. Leon, I think, engaged in an appropriate metaphor. He said it was as if you were riding down a fast-moving river or stream. And I think that was an appropriate way to describe it. I would change it a bit and conclude that Colonel North and the others were attempting to take you over Niagara Falls in a barrel with that particular chronology they were providing you. A. I think that's entirely apt.  Q. You think that's apt? **********A. I certainly do. **********REPRESENTATIVE LOUIS STOKES, Democrat of Ohio. Let me ask you this, Mr. Cooper - Is there any doubt in your mind today that the chronologies that you were first given in November of 1986 were designed to cover up the 1985 November Hawk sales to Iran? **********A. Yes, I believe they were designed to portray a fictitious portrayal of those events. **********Q. And had Director Casey given to Congress the testimony in that Nov. 20 draft, he would have perjured himself, would he not? **********A. No, sir, I don't know that to be the case. He would have reported to the Congress a fact that was not true, but whether he would have reported to the Congress a fact he knew that it was untrue is a different question. Somebody, however, would have been responsible for - ultimately responsible - for providing to the Congress a fact known to be untrue, which would be perjury. **********Q. Even the testimony as of the 21st of November, the revised testimony, as you look back at that testimony, was it complete and factual - that testimony which was given to us? **********A. No, sir, it was not, I'm sure it was not complete, although I think that insofar as it did - at least I was quite confident when I left the C.I.A. that those facts that it did report were factual or I had no inkling that they were not factual. **********Q. And lastly, when you and the Attorney General interviewed Colonel North, he was not under oath at that time, was he? A. No, he was not.  Q. Based upon your testimony here today, would you agree or evaluate the testimony that he gave you at that time as being false? **********A. I believe it was false in some respects, yes sir. **********Q. Based upon everything you know about Colonel North as a result of your contact with him, your interview of him, let me ask you this - would you believe him under oath? **********A. Congressman, I would not, but I personally don't believe an oath in any way enhances the obligation of truthfulness. **********Q. In effect, you are saying you would not believe him, whether he is under oath or not. **********A. That's - well, I have to regretfully say that, yes sir, I have to say that. **********Q. Thank you very much, Mr. Cooper. Thank you, Mr. Chairman.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/10/world.body_text: **********A jet fighter fired warning shots at a Soviet bomber today after the plane violated Japanese airspace, the Defense Agency said. It was the first time in at least 33 years that a Japanese plane had fired on a Soviet aircraft. **********The pilot of the Japanese jet fired several bursts from a 20-millimeter cannon, with about 100 bullets in each burst, an agency official said. The bullets could have shot down the plane if they had hit it, the official said. **********Two Japanese F-4EJ jet fighters scrambled from a base in Naha, Okinawa, after radar showed an unidentified plane flying toward Japanese airspace, he said. The Japanese fighters broadcast warnings to the Soviet plane by radio, but they were ignored, he said. One of the fighters fired warning shots as the plane entered Japanese airspace near Okinawa. **********The agency official said the plane did not leave Japanese airspace until several more warning bursts were fired. The official identifed the Soviet plane as a medium-range TU-16 Badger bomber. He said the bomber, one of four heading north, entered Japanese airspace twice for a total of 11 minutes, starting at 11:24 A.M.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/03/world.body_text: **********Chile's military Government announced today that it was lifting a two-year-old nighttime curfew in Santiago, the latest in a series of steps designed to improve the country's image abroad. **********Two days ago President Augusto Pinochet announced that a state of siege in effect since September would expire next week. He also announced that the Government would permit most of Chile's several thousand political exiles to return home over the next 90 days. **********In a brief announcement today, the security authorities said the curfew was being suspended with immediate effect in Santiago and the coastal province of San Antonio, the only regions in which it was still being applied. The curfew, between 2 A.M. and 5 A.M., had been in force since November 1984.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/10/world.body_text: **********Negotiations between the Guatemalan Government and rebels on ending a 25-year-old civil war broke up late today. The participants issued a statement calling the talks satisfactory, but there were no indications of progress. **********Spaniards familiar with the talks said they were hampered almost from the start on Wednesday by disputes over procedural matters. The sessions took place behind closed doors in an undisclosed location. **********The Spaniards said the rebels were upset by the presence of three uniformed Guatemalan military officers in the room. Guatemalan Government representatives said the three were there as advisers. **********The talks followed an unexpected announcement in Guatemala City a week ago that a meeting would be held in Madrid, and that a cease-fire would be in effect while the talks went on. It was the first time the two sides had sat down with each other. **********When the meeting ended, the participants issued a short communique embracing peace and democracy and saying the talks were held in a ''satisfactory climate.'' The statement said the meeting ended by mutual consent. There were no immediate indications whether future meetings would be held. Nothing was said about the cease-fire agreement. **********The talks were aimed at ending hostilities in Central America's longest civil war and were convened in compliance with the regional peace plan signed in August by leaders of five Central American nations. **********The participants had announced they would hold a news conference at the close of the talks. But tonight, a Spanish official said they had decided not to. ''They're reluctant to meet the press because they have nothing to report,'' the official said. ''The best they can do is try and put a good face on the closing statement.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/14/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Treasury Prices Up Modestly
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/14/busin.body_text: **********Treasury prices rose modestly yesterday as traders and investors waited for two key economic statistics on foreign trade and inflation. **********By late in the day, the closely watched 8 7/8 percent Treasury bond due in 2017 was offered at 90 9/32, up 13/32, to yield 9.89 percent. Yields of several other less actively traded Treasury issues dropped slightly below the 10 percent level reached late last week. **********The economic data for this week include today's announcement of the nation's trade deficit for August. On Friday, the Commerce Department is expected to announce the Producer Price Index for September. Forecasting a Deficit **********Many analysts noted that the trade deficit normally declines in August and have been forecasting a deficit of about $14.5 billion, down from a record $16.5 billion in July. But participants in the foreign exchange and credit markets are unsure about the reaction to such a change. The dollar was slightly stronger in New York yesterday, rising to 143.865 yen and 1.8220 West German marks. **********''I don't think a $14.5 billion deficit is anything to get bullish about,'' said the head of Treasury trading at one New York City bank. Analysts who share this cautious attitude said that a drop to that level was still higher than the $14 billion deficit in August 1986, and might still suggest that the dollar needs to decline further to help increase exports and limit imports. **********Other analysts, however, say a contraction to $14.5 billion is a move in the right direction, and will give the financial markets reason to begin anticipating further reductions in the trade deficit and diminished fears that the dollar's value will fall. Trade Data Uncertainty **********The uncertainty about the trade data, and the markets' response, was one reason why activity in the Treasury market was subdued yesterday. **********''In order to get a significant upside move in bonds, there needs to be more retail participation, and right now they just don't see any reasons to buy,'' said Joseph Kelly, national sales manager for government securities at Prudential-Bache Securities. He said that customers with large losses from previous purchases were waiting to see stability in bond prices before making new commitments. **********But amid the gloom and doom that accompanied the rise in bond yields to nearly 10 percent, from 8 3/4 percent in mid-August and 7 1/2 percent in late March, some analysts see conditions developing that will eventually produce a major bond market rally. **********Lawrence A. Kudlow, chief economist at Bear, Stearns & Company, estimated that within a few months, ''the markets will begin to recognize that over the longer run inflation isn't rising much above 4 percent and the Treasury bond yield can begin to decline towards 8 percent within 18 months.'' **********In a speech at the Financial Industry Conference sponsored in New York by Bear, Stearns, Mr. Kudlow explained that the ability of Congress to restrain spending growth sharply to about 3 1/2 percent annually the last two years from more than 10 percent the previous five years had gone unappreciated by the financial markets. **********In addition, he said the bond markets should be encouraged by recent comments from Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d ''indicating that the Treasury recognizes the threat of inflation and will permit the Fed to continue reducing money supply growth.'' The willingness of Treausry officials to use commodity prices as one guide to economic policy-making ''is another reason to anticipate a more disciplined, anti-inflation economic policy that should be good news for the bond market,'' Mr. Kudlow said. **********In the Treasury bill market, rates on outstanding bills were little changed. But at the weekly auction of new bills, which was delayed one day because of the Columbus Day holiday, the average rate for new three-month bills was up nearly 1/2 percentage point, to 6.96 percent. Six-month bills sold at an average of 7.34 percent, up about 3/8 percentage point. Rise in Short-Term Rates **********The sharp rise for the three-month rate reflected the general increase in all short-term rates the past week, as well as the unusually low rate at last week's three-month bill auction, which was the first issue sold with a 1988 maturity. **********Elsewhere in the short-term sector, fears of a temporary, but sharp rise in overnight interest rates around the end of the year have created an extraordinary difference between interest rates for two-month and three-month securities. Based on the experience of the last two years, when year-end ''window dressing'' of financial statements caused overnight interest rates to soar as high as 30 percent, lenders have demanded sharply higher rates for three-month money compared with two months. **********In the Euro-dollar market, the world's largest market for bank deposits, two-month bank deposits were quoted yesterday at about 8 1/16 percent, with three-month deposits at 8 13/16 percent. That difference implies that the market expects interest rates of about 20 percent during a four day period at year-end. **********Following are results of yesterday's auction of new Treasury bills:  (000 omitted in dollar figures)             3-Mo. https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/19/world.main_headline: GANDHI'S PARTY ROUTED IN STATE ELECTION
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/19/world.print_headline: GANDHI'S PARTY ROUTED IN STATE ELECTION
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/19/world.body_text: **********An opposition coalition was headed for a landslide victory tonight over Prime Ministe Rajiv Gandhi's Congress Party in legislative elections in the northern state of Haryana. **********The rout was all the more stinging for Mr. Gandhi because it occurred in a region that has traditionally supported the Congress Party. **********The Prime Minister needed a victory today to stem growing criticism of his Government, which has been hurt by charges of military kickbacks and other scandals, restiveness within his party and declining political support. **********Congress Party officials, who are concerned that the party is losing ground nationwide, especially among minorities and poor groups, were said to be stunned by the scale of the defeat. **********The alliance of the pro-peasant People's Party and the right-wing National People's Party had won 42 of the 51 races decided as it surged toward a two-thirds majority in the 90-member house. It was reported leading in 30 other constituencies. Communists Win 2 Seats **********As counting continued tonight, the Congress Party had won only two races and was leading in seven others. Communists won two seats and unaffiliated independent candidates five. **********Elections were held for only 87 seats; three races were halted when candidates died. **********A senior Congress Party leader said the party had lost because of bitter infighting. The defeat, he added, ''cast a shadow on all of us.'' **********Hemvati Nandan Bahuguna, the president of the People's Party, said, ''This is the final notice from the people of India to Mr. Gandhi to quit.'' He noted that the Congress Party had lost seven statewide elections in the last two years in eastern and southern India. It had also lost to a moderate Sikh party in the Punjab in the fall of 1985. Leader Is Hospitalized **********The alliance in Haryana was led by Devi Lal, a former Chief Minister of the state and a veteran of India's independence movement. Allies and critics alike acknowledged that the 73-year-old Mr. Lal virtually carried the campaign on his own, drawing huge crowds and strong support with his sharp attacks on Mr. Gandhi and the Congress Party. **********Mr. Devi Lal was himself reported to have crushed his Congress Party rival by nearly 30,000 votes in his constituency of Meham. Aides said he was briefly hospitalized for exhaustion this evening and was resting near New Delhi. **********Mr. Lal, who conducted his campaign from a van he named the Victory Chariot, assailed his opponents for corruption, promised to write off loans to farmers and accused the central Government of favoring Punjab over Haryana in providing irrigation water, a key issue in the small but prosperous farming state. **********A key factor in the election was anger in Haryana over what was regarded as New Delhi's inability to subdue Sikh terrorists in the Punjab and protect Hindus there. In a television broadcast, Pranoy Roy, a former adviser to the Prime Minister who runs an opinion research organization, said this became apparent when areas bordering the Punjab voted heavily for the alliance's candidates. Cabinet Ministers Lose **********At least seven state-level Cabinet ministers were defeated and several others were reported trailing. **********Official sources sought to play down the effect of the defeat on Mr. Gandhi, pointing out that he had campaigned for only two days. They said the Prime Minister had been irritated by the infighting in the party and had allowed local bosses to run the campaign, with little direction from him. **********Mr. Gandhi's leadership of the party is unlikely to be challenged seriously, the sources said, and they described him as ''cheerful'' despite the defeat. **********Mr. Gandhi has a huge majority in national Parliament, where the Congress Party controls 402 of the 542 seats. He also need not hold general elections until 1989, when his five-year term ends.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/05/busin.body_text: **********James C. Cotting  Chairman of Navistar **********James C. Cotting, 54 years old, assumed the chairmanship of the Navistar International Corporation earlier this year, after bringing the giant truck manufacturing company back from the edge of bankruptcy. He had joined the company in 1979, when it was still known as International Harvester, as chief financial officer. **********Mr. Cotting is known as a hard-driving executive and a tough but congenial financial negotiator who has shepherded Navistar through three major debt restructurings. The company is now embarked on an ambitious acquisition strategy designed to broaden its holdings beyond the cyclical trucking business. **********He is a Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Ohio State University, where he studied international politics on a Navy scholarship.  Robert G. Kirby  Chairman of Capital Guardian **********To those who know him, 62-year-old Robert G. Kirby is the consummate ''value'' investor. As chairman of the Capital Guardian Trust Company, a Los Angeles-based concern that manages $15 billion, Mr. Kirby has rarely been one to dart in and out of the market. Instead, over a 35-year career Mr. Kirby has tried to spot companies with outstanding earnings potential over the long run. **********Mr. Kirby, who graduated from Harvard Business School, joined the Capital Research and Management Company in 1965, and he and two other executives later founded a sister company, Capital Guardian Trust, to work for retirement trusts, endowment funds and other institutional accounts. Among Mr. Kirby's most prominent clients is Stanford University, where he is a part-time lecturer at the Graduate School of Business. **********As a professional investor who also manages a family of mutual funds, Mr. Kirby has done slightly better than the average mutual fund manager, according to Lipper Analytical Services Inc., which tracks mutual fund performance. **********Mr. Kirby, who lives in California, spends his weekends driving race cars.  John R. Opel  Former chairman of I.B.M. **********John R. Opel, 62, retired as chairman of I.B.M. last year and is currently chairman of the executive committee of the company's board. He is also chairman of the board of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, a one-year position to which he was appointed in December. **********Mr. Opel began at I.B.M. in 1949 as a salesman, and he rose through the sales side of the organization rather than its technical side. During his tenure in the company's top two spots (chief executive as well as chairman), he presided over some of the broadest changes in I.B.M.'s history, including I.B.M.'s entry into the personal computer market and the resulting reorientation of the company's product line toward powerful desktop computers connected by sophisticated telecommunications systems. **********Such technology, particularly the personal computer, has been the chief tool of program traders, who can nearly instantaneously buy and sell huge blocks of stock to take advantage of even the slightest price discrepancies between stock traded on the New York Stock Exchange and derivative financial instruments such as stock options and stock index futures traded on the Chicago futures markets. **********A 1948 graduate of Westminster College in Fulton, Mo., Mr. Opel holds an M.B.A. degree from the University of Chicago.  Howard M. Stein  Chairman of Dreyfus **********At 20, after two years at the Juilliard School of Music, Howard M. Stein went to Broadway to play the violin. **********He concluded that this was no way to make a living and found a job at Bache & Company (now Prudential-Bache) selling stock. There he soon decided that the management of investments might be more rewarding. So, according to the Stein legend, he proposed such a department to Bache, which rejected the idea. **********He took the proposal to Jack Dreyfus, head of Dreyfus & Company, then just a brokerage firm. Mr. Dreyfus liked the idea and bought the tiny Nesbitt Fund, changing its name to Dreyfus, with Mr. Stein, then 25, as head of the fund. **********Mr. Stein, who is now 61, loaded up on Polaroid stock and it took off, along with Dreyfus. He bought heavily into American Motors, then another hot stock, and Dreyfus's fame spread. **********In the 1970's, Mr. Stein helped develop the money market fund and worked hard for legislation to create tax-exempt municipal bond funds. Today, with $39.5 billion under management, Dreyfus is only slightly smaller than the $40 billion under management just before the market slide last month. **********The reason, Dreyfus watchers say, is that the company has been accumulating cash for six months. **********Mr. Stein, who earned $1.6 million last year, is described by friends as fully recovered from open-heart surgery about a year and a half ago. Until about five years ago he spent considerable time at a French-style country home in Westchester County, but lately he can be found at home in Southampton, L.I., in a big waterfront home that used to belong to Woody Allen.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/17/busin.body_text: **********Eurotunnel, the British-French consortium that plans to build a tunnel underneath the English Channel, announced today that major financial institutions had agreed to underwrite a crucial share issue to raise more than $1 billion for the project. **********The successful underwriting of the share offering, valued at $:770 million, or more than $1.3 billion, assures that Eurotunnel will have the money it needs to build the 31-mile link between Britain and France. **********Indeed, the financing is a milestone for the proposed tunnel. It removes the last major obstacle to starting construction on a tunnel that has been the centuries-old dream of politicians and entrepreneurs and that is seen today as an important step in the further economic and political integration of Europe. **********''It's all done - the money is guaranteed for Eurotunnel now,'' said Rory Macnamara, a London merchant banker working with Eurotunnel on the share offering. ''It's an extraordinary financing for an historic project.'' **********The Eurotunnel financing is also regarded as a breakthrough in raising private funds for huge public works projects. ''This pioneers the concept that the private sector can finance large public utilities,'' said Rupert Darwell, an analyst at Savory Milln Ltd., a London brokerage house. **********The success of the equity underwriting was crucial to the future of the project because the 198 banks that put up the bulk of the financing for the tunnel - $:5 billion, or nearly $9 billion, in loans - stipulated that Eurotunnel could not get access to the loans unless the equity funding was in place. The consortium is scheduled to begin digging the tunnel next month. **********The willingness of London financial houses to make underwriting commitments on the Eurotunnel issue had been in doubt, not only because of the recent stock market collapse, but also because the underwriting came just two weeks after the British Government sold off its 31.5 percent stake in the British Petroleum Company for more than $12 billion. Underwriters in Britain and elsewhere suffered heavy paper losses in that sale. Massive Marketing Blitz **********Still, the Eurotunnel officials pressed ahead, spending the last two weeks trying to convince securities houses, insurance companies and fund managers that the prospects of a tunnel scheduled to open in 1993 would not be much affected by today's skittish stock markets. **********The marketing blitz included a $12 million newspaper and television advertising campaign and a continuous series of luncheon and dinner meetings with financial institutions, headed by Eurotunnel's co-chairman, Alastair Morton, along with Mr. Macnamara, other Eurotunnel officials and the company's bankers and brokers. **********The last-minute drive proved worthwhile as many reluctant financial institutions were eventually persuaded to back Eurotunnel. **********''We feel very pleased here,'' said David Freud, a corporate finance specialist at Warburg Securities, Eurotunnel's lead broker. ''A few weeks ago, a lot of people said this issue would never succeed.'' Strong Support in France **********The Eurotunnel financing is an international offering, although $:707 million, or about $1.23 billion, of it is being underwritten in London and Paris. The overseas issue of $:63 million, or about $110 million, is a private placement that is being sold to major investment institutions in Japan, Europe, the Middle East and the United States. **********The fate of the Eurotunnel financing was clearly going to be decided in the City of London financial district. In France, the other major financier of the project, the backing for Eurotunnel has always been assured. The French Government strongly supports the project and the French financial community is more more tightly controlled by the Government than is the case in Britain. In Britain, Eurotunnel had to win financial support in the marketplace. **********Eurotunnel today priced the 220 million investment units - composed of one French and one British share - at 350 pence, or about $6.10, each. Individual investors can apply for shares until Nov. 27, and trading in the shares, listed on the London and Paris stock exchanges, will begin on Dec. 10. They will not be traded on any exchange in the United States. 'A Unique Solution' **********The British Government's handling of the huge British Petroleum issue, the other major financing in London since the mid-October market plunge, was praised today by John Phelan, chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, who is visiting London. Mr. Phelan said the Bank of England's formula of putting a ''floor price'' underneath the shares to calm the financial markets was ''a unique solution'' that ''seemed to be working well.'' **********The markets had feared that the flood of B.P. shares would have a devastating effect on prices. **********Since then, share prices have steadied and the investors' price on the new B.P. shares has remained above the 70 pence a share that the British central bank has guaranteed to pay. The underwriters, however, had agreed to pay 120 pence a share. **********Whether the Bank of England has to honor its commitment on the B.P. floor price in the next several weeks depends largely on the performance of still-volatile stock markets, analysts said.
