https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/20/busin.main_headline: Trading Frenzy Strikes In Financial Contracts
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/20/busin.print_headline: FUTURES/OPTIONS; Trading Frenzy Strikes In Financial Contracts
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/20/busin.body_text: **********Chicago's financial futures pits, where stock index futures are traded, were rocked today by the same sort of pandemonium that erupted on Wall Street. **********At the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, trading volume reached a record high. More than 673,000 contracts were traded, compared with a previous high of 637,665 contracts traded last Thursday. **********The Standard & Poor's 500 stock-index futures contract had its biggest percentage drop ever. ''You'll be able to tell your grandchildren about this in 20 years,'' one trader said, as he was leaving the S.&P. pit. **********At the Chicago Board of Trade, nearly twice as many Treasury bond futures contracts were traded today as the average daily volume. An estimated 600,000 contracts were sold, compared with 300,000 to 350,000 contracts on average days. **********But while trading of Treasury-bond futures was described as ''very orderly'' by market participants, stock-index futures and options leaped wildly. **********At the Chicago Board Options Exchange, for example, the swing in prices was about 20 times greater than the swing on an average day. ''It was pure pandemonium,'' said Philip B. Hubbard, president of the Chicago Research and Trading Group Ltd. ''The prices were moving so quickly.'' **********Rumors were flying that several prominent brokerage houses were unable to meet the exchange's margin calls. During the day, the Merc made three such calls but all were ''met in full,'' according to a spokesman, While some of Chicago's traders appeared ''grim, white-lipped and determined,'' according to one observer, others appeared to have made fortunes from the stock market's dramatic decline. They bought options that give them the right to sell stocks at a fixed price at a future date. Because of the stock market's decline, the price specified by the option may be much higher than the current market price. ''Fortunes have been made as well as lost today,'' observed one Merc official.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/20/busin.main_headline: Crazy Eddie Deficit In Inventory Found
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/20/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Crazy Eddie Deficit In Inventory Found
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/20/busin.body_text: **********The new managers of Crazy Eddie Inc. said yesterday that they had discovered an inventory shortfall estimated at $45 million and that the consumer electronics retailer expected a ''substantial'' third-quarter loss. **********It was not immediately clear whether the shortfall was the result of poor management, inaccurate bookkeeping or theft of merchandise. **********''We were surprised,'' said Elias Zinn, president and chief executive of the company, based in Edison, N.J. ''We have no indication now what caused this.'' **********The preliminary estimate of inventory was $45 million less than the $126.7 million reported by the previous management in its most recent filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the company said. The S.E.C. filing was made by management led by the company's founder, Eddie Antar. **********Earlier this month the company's directors stepped down after Oppenheimer-Palmieri Fund L.P. and Entertainment Marketing Inc. began a proxy campaign to oust them. The new board ousted not only Mr. Antar but virtually all of Crazy Eddie's management, including a number of Mr. Antar's relatives. The new board is led by Mr. Zinn and by Victor Palmieri, a turnaround specialist. **********The new management alerted the S.E.C. about the inventory discrepancy yesterday. The S.E.C. has been investigating company affairs but has not indicated the subject of the inquiry. **********The new management undertook the inventory of Crazy Eddie's merchandise in part because it suspected a shortfall. **********Meanwhile, Crazy Eddie received a new $20 million credit line from Fidelity Bank of Philadelphia yesterday. The money will be used to replenish and upgrade inventories for the holiday season, company officials said. In the last months under its old management, Crazy Eddie had about $100 million in credit lines. **********Shares of Crazy Eddie, which traded at more than $20 at one point after the company went public three years ago, stood at $1.81, down 56 cents, in over-the-counter trading yesterday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/19/world.main_headline: SEOUL ADMITS DISSIDENT DIED OF BRUTALITY AT POLICE HANDS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/19/world.print_headline: SEOUL ADMITS DISSIDENT DIED OF BRUTALITY AT POLICE HANDS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/19/world.body_text: **********The national police director said today that police brutality caused the death of a dissident student last week, and he announced the arrest of two officers and apologized. **********The official, Kang Min Chang, said at a news conference that the student ''suffocated to death'' Wednesday when his throat was pressed against the edge of a bathtub as the two officers stuck his head into the water in an effort to extract statements. **********Mr. Kang said the student, Park Jong Chul, 21 years old, who had been accused of anti-Government activities, had refused to talk during the questioning at a special police investigation center in Seoul. **********The two officers, Lieut. Cho Han Kyong, 38 years old, and Sgt. Kang Chin Kyoo, 33, have been charged with homicide through brutal acts, Mr. Kang said. He said Col. Chun Suk Rin, who is in charge of Counter-Communism Investigation Group No. 2, had been relieved of his post for failure to supervise his subordinates. An Apology **********Mr. Kang said that as the man in charge of the police, he ''sincerely offers my apology to the family of the student and the entire people for the incident.'' **********He said the entire police force was ''deeply reflecting on the regrettable tragedy,'' which he said ''resulted from some overzealous investigators despite the institutional device banning brutal acts against suspects.'' **********It was the first time in years that police had acknowledged such treatment of a political detainee, although dissidents have said the police have used torture against them. **********In an initial report, the police asserted that Mr. Park, a 21-year-old linguistics student at Seoul National University, died ''of shock'' from questioning, but they denied there had been torture. **********Press reports quoted doctors as saying Mr. Park's stomach was filled with water and his body was bruised.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/25/busin.body_text: **********Last year's slump in crude oil prices caused May production of Texas crude to fall to its lowest level in 43 years - below two million barrels a day - according to preliminary figures issued today by the Texas Railroad Commission. The commission, which regulates the Texas oil and gas industry, said oil production averaged 1.97 million barrels a day in May, down 30,000 from April and 230,000 less than in May 1986. Commissioner Jim Nugent attributed the fall to last year's price slump, noting that 20,000 oil wells and 7,000 gas wells had been taken out of production in Texas over the last year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/28/world.main_headline: PARIS PROSECUTOR SEEKING LENIENCY IN TERRORIST CASE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/28/world.print_headline: PARIS PROSECUTOR SEEKING LENIENCY IN TERRORIST CASE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/28/world.body_text: **********A French prosecutor, rejecting a plea for severity by a lawyer representing the United States, today asked the court trying a terrorism suspect to hand down a ''moderate'' sentence, saying France could be held hostage if it made him a ''martyr.'' **********The prosecutor's request, made in a crowded, silent courtroom here this afternoon, seemed to confirm widespread reports that the Government was seeking to accord lenient treatment to the suspect, Georges Ibrahim Abdallah, who is on trial for complicity in the killings in 1982 of an American and an Israeli diplomat. **********The Government is believed to be concerned that a harsh sentence for Mr. Abdallah could reduce the chances of freeing French hostages in Lebanon and might lead Middle East extremists to resume a terror bombing campaign that was carried out here last year by a group seeking Mr. Abdallah's release. Refers to U.S.-Iran Deal **********The prosecutor, Pierre Baechlin, in a 20-minute statement that referred to the Iran arms sales and the resulting inquiries in the United States, asked for a maximum 10-year sentence for Mr. Abdallah. **********According to French law, Mr. Baechlin, whose request is seen here as reflecting the Government's view, could have asked for life imprisonment. **********Mr. Baechlin's request does not bind the court's panel of seven judges, who are expected to pronounce a verdict Saturday, but it is rare for a French court to impose a sentence longer than the one sought by the prosecutor. 'Agony in My Heart' **********''With agony in my heart, I have come to beseech you, to beg you, to ask you not to pronounce against the accused a sentence of more than 10 years,'' Mr. Baechlin said. **********''Every condemnation transforms the condemned person into a martyr to his own people and transforms France into a hostage,'' Mr. Baechlin went on. ''We are fighting against terrorism with ridiculous weapons. **********''Every night, like everybody else, I see the faces of French hostages in Lebanon. You must render a judgment that is in the interest of everybody.'' **********French legal specialists who are observing the trial have said that if Mr. Abdallah receives a 10-year sentence, he could be paroled within a year or two, given that he has already served nearly two and a half years in prison and that a part of his sentence is likely to be suspended. **********The trial, being attended every day by four American diplomats and officials, has from the beginning been surrounded by an intense atmosphere of speculation - fueled by reports in the press - that the French Government would seek a way of releasing Mr. Abdallah quickly, hoping that, in exchange, a rash of bomb attacks that terrorized France last year would not resume. **********Mr. Abdallah, who is believed to head a terror group calling itself the Lebanese Armed Revolutionary Faction, is specifically accused of complicity in the murder of Charles Ray, an American military attache in Paris, and Jacov Barsimantov, a second secretary in the Israeli embassy. **********A group demanding Mr. Abdallah's release claimed responsibility for a series of five terror explosions in Paris last September that killed 10 people and wounded 162. The satirical weekly Canard Enchaine, which has a reputation for political exposes, reported two days ago that the French Government had been negotiating through Arab intermediaries to gain the release of a hostage, Jean-Louis Normandin, being held in Lebanon. The Government, according to the newspaper, has been told that a moderate sentence for Mr. Abdallah is a condition for the release. 'Small Flame of Hope' **********In his plea today, Mr. Baechlin seemed to make a reference to the disclosure in the newspaper, saying, ''We cannot extinguish the small flame of hope that has been lit in Lebanon during the last few days.'' **********Mr. Baechlin's comments followed a plea by Georges Kiejman, the lawyer representing the United States, who specifically asked the court to ignore what he called the Government's preferences in the case and to judge it solely on the basis of the ''judicial facts.'' Lenient Treatment Criticized **********''You do not have to enter into the machinery of the state,'' Mr. Kiejman said. ''Your duty is to render justice and not to render service.'' **********Mr. Kiejman, in a plea lasting more than 2 hours, told the court that lenient treatment of Mr. Abdallah would be a reward to terrorists. **********''I am aware that terror attacks can touch us and those close to us,'' he said. ''But we have to put an end to the belief of some terrorists that France has become a sanctuary for them.'' **********The Abdallah trial has been closely followed here, in part because of widespread concerns that a conviction of Mr. Abdallah would lead to a resumption of the terror bombings. The trial is also unusual because of the presence of the United States, represented by Mr. Kiejman, which decided last year to became a civil plaintiff against Mr. Abdallah to head off the possibility that the French Government might not try him at all. **********Addressing the American role, Mr. Baechlin, in his plea today, referred to the ''disarray'' in the United States caused by revelations that the Reagan Administration sold arms to Iran in an attempt to secure the release of American hostages in Lebanon. **********After Mr. Baechlin's plea, Mr. Abdallah's defense lawyer, Jacques Verges, said the dossier on Mr. Abdallah was ''empty.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/08/busin.body_text: **********Western Europe's economy will grow at a disappointing rate through next year, economists predict, with the increase too weak to put a dent in Europe's stubbornly high 11 percent unemployment rate. **********Many economists voice frustration that even though inflation has been brought under control and corporate profits are strong, a number of negative factors, such as lackluster capital spending, will limit Europe's growth to just 2 percent this year and next. **********''Economic growth in Europe has been anemic,'' said Jean Cheval, chief economist for Banque Indosuez in Paris. ''Two percent is dismaying because it leaves unemployment at a very high level.'' 'Eurosclerosis' **********If Western Europe's growth is indeed just 2 percent next year, it will be the ninth straight year of growth below 3 percent for the region and its 400 million people. Western Europe has had double-digit unemployment since 1983, and its economy must grow by close to 3 percent a year for its jobless rate to start dropping. **********All this has left economists and government officials groping for a cure for what is being termed ''Eurosclerosis.'' **********Economists have suggested that the causes of this economic ailment include the influence of strong unions, government regulation of business, the general lack of an entrepreneurial culture and a preference for financial investments over capital investments. **********Leaders in France, Britain and elsewhere in Europe have responded by lowering taxes, fighting union demands and reducing regulation. Some economists said such moves would enable Europe's economic growth to average 2.5 percent a year in a few years, but they said growth would remain below that level for the next year or two because of the weak dollar and government efforts to maintain budget discipline. **********''Europe can be an economic engine for the world, but it won't be this year,'' said one economist with the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, a 24-nation group based in Paris. ''Europe has a lot of potential, but its policies are still kind of restrictive.'' A Recession Is Unlikely **********Even with Europe's slow-growth outlook, few economists predict it will fall into a recession this year or next. The only chance for a recession, forecasters say, is if oil prices soar or if the dollar plunges further, which would hurt European exports to the United States by making them more expensive. **********''If the dollar falls to 1.50 German marks by the end of this year, there could be a recession in Europe,'' said J. Paul Horne, an international economist for Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company in Paris. The dollar has fallen to just below 1.80 marks, from more than 3.20 marks in early 1986. **********One piece of good news is that Italy and Great Britain, long the laggards of Europe, have been able to escape the economic torpor. Both are expected to grow by 3 percent or more this year, although economists forecast they will grow by less than that next year because London and Rome are reining in their economies out of fear of burgeoning trade deficits and rising inflation. **********On the other hand, France and West Germany, Europe's two largest economies, are barely moving. With their Governments seeking to maintain budgetary discipline, the two nations are expected to grow by 1.5 percent or less this year. 'Rags and Riches' **********''The story in Europe this year seems to be rags and riches,'' said David M. Mars, European economist for S. G. Warburg Securities in London. ''Next year, everyone might be a little closer to one another in terms of growth.'' **********The O.E.C.D. predicts that Germany and France will grow by 2 percent next year, Britain by 2.25 percent and Italy by 2.5 percent. The O.E.C.D., which uses one of the world's most sophisticated economic computer models, forecast that Western Europe's overall economy will grow by 2 percent in both 1987 and 1988, with inflation running at 3.75 percent this year and 3.5 percent next year. **********Some forecasters, such as Geoffrey Horton of DRI Europe, are more optimistic and say Europe's economy will expand by 2.5 percent next year. Last December, the O.E.C.D. predicted that Europe's growth would be 2.5 percent this year and next, but it revised that forecast to 2 percent partly because the fall of the dollar has hurt Europe's exports more than expected. **********''Two percent growth doesn't look quite so bad when you remember that Europe is in the fifth year of an economic recovery,'' said Mr. Horne of Smith Barney. Focus on West Germany **********In comparison, the O.E.C.D. expects the United States to grow by 2.5 percent this year and 2.75 percent next year, which does not appear to be much better than the projections for Europe. Nevertheless, the recovery of the United States from the 1981-82 recession has been markedly stronger than Europe's and its unemployment rate has fallen to 6 percent. **********Many economists think the key to faster growth in Europe is getting West Germany, which has a small budget deficit and almost no inflation, to stimulate its economy, especially its domestic demand. Devastated by the plunge of the dollar and a bitterly cold winter, West Germany's economy declined in the first quarter before rebounding moderately in the second quarter. **********If West Germany grows faster, its people will in theory demand more goods from other European countries. That process could also benefit the United States, which has urged West Germany and Japan to stimulate their economies in the hope that the demand for American products would increase and the American trade deficit would decline. **********Backed strongly by Washington, the O.E.C.D. has urged West Germany to bolster its economy by lowering taxes and increasing its budget deficit. But Chancellor Helmut Kohl has been reluctant to cut taxes more than the reduction of 14 million marks already scheduled for 1988 because of resistance from leaders of the German states, who worry about losing revenues from Bonn. **********''The Germans don't want to play the role of locomotive of Europe,'' said Mr. Cheval of Banque Indosuez. ''They don't want to increase their deficit. They are always scared of rekindling inflation.'' Devaluations Possible **********Though West Germany's economy may have caught a cold last winter, France's and Italy's economies were more vigorous. One result was that French and Italian consumers and companies imported so many goods from West Germany - which had a trade surplus of $57 billion last year - that those two nations developed a huge trade deficit with the Federal Republic. **********Mr. Mars of Warburg Securities predicted that Italy's new Government would push later this year to change the European Monetary System so that the lira would be devalued against the West German mark. In addition, many analysts say the French Government will move to devalue the franc against the mark. But, knowing that devaluations are embarrassing, Paris is not expected to act until after next spring's presidential elections. **********Mr. Cheval of Indosuez predicts that the French economy should pick up steadily because its trade deficit has been improving in the second half and real wages are rising more slowly than in most nations. **********''France is the slow man, not the sick man, of Europe,'' Mr. Cheval said. Italy Tries to Slow Down **********Italy, with its flashy entrepreneurs and industrial empires, has been the fast man, but it apparently needs to slow down to catch its breath. In recent months, Italian officials have become worried about a large budget deficit, rising inflation and a worsening trade balance. **********On Aug. 28, the Italian Government announced it would raise its bank discount rate as well as taxes on consumer goods and gasoline. These moves are likely to help reduce Italy's 1988 growth to less than this year's levels. **********Like Italy, Britain has also had some worries about an overheated economy, with the inflation rate above 4 percent and imports outstripping exports. London preceded Italy in raising interest rates to slow down its economy. **********Britain has been one of Europe's fastest-growing economies thanks to the boom in London's financial markets, the pound's 15 percent drop last year against most European currencies and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's moves to reduce taxes and regulations. Higher Rates Criticized **********Worries about overheated economies are warranted, many economists say, because the factory capacity utilization rates in several countries are approaching their former peaks. But many economists criticize the remedy used - higher interest rates - which will slow growth at a time when in their view, more growth is needed to help Europe's 19 million unemployed. **********Juergen Donges, vice president of the Institute of World Economics in Kiel, West Germany, said high interest rates often ''encourage companies to invest in risk-free financial investments rather than in new plant and equipment with the risks of strikes and other problems.'' **********Philippe Sigogne, the director of the French Institute of Economic Analysis, added, ''With the low costs of raw materials nowadays and with capacity utilization rates fairly high, business should be doing more to increase its capital investment.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/05/busin.main_headline: A FLORIST STARTS A BROOKLYN RENOVATION
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/05/busin.print_headline: ABOUT REAL ESTATE; A FLORIST STARTS A BROOKLYN RENOVATION
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/05/busin.body_text: **********For the last 25 years Martin J. Orlofsky has sold chrysanthemums and gladiolus in his flower shop in downtown Brooklyn, at the corner of Fourth and Flatbush Avenues, while the area around him has ridden an economic roller coaster. **********When he founded the family business in 1949 - his shop at that time was a block away - the downtown area was a ''triple A'' retail center, ''the Times Square of Brooklyn,'' Mr. Orlofsky said. Later, he remembers, John V. Lindsay, while running for Mayor, used photographs of the same section to depict the dangers of urban decay. **********Now downtown Brooklyn is bouncing back, with the help of the impending mixed-use Atlantic Terminal redevelopment project as well as other commercial and residential buildings planned or under construction. And Mr. Orlofsky has become part of that revival as the converter of the vacant 10-building complex -in which his store, Midtown Florist, is situated - into 39 rental apartments. **********''I've had a million opportunities to go into real estate, and I always said, 'Look, I'm in the flower business,' '' said Mr. Orlofsky, 62 years old, taking a recent break in the back office at his store, where flies buzzed, a fan stirred the humidity and one of his six sons ordered flowers over the phone. ''But this was different. This affected my business.'' **********He was referring to an auction by the city early in this decade of the adjoining brick apartment buildings, which date from the late 1800's. Mr. Orlofsky, competing against experienced developers, won the one-acre property for $325,000. **********Then, as now, Midtown Florist was the sole tenant - either retail or residential - in the dilapidated V-shaped complex, which measures 70,800 square feet and rises four stories at one of the busiest and most visible intersections in downtown Brooklyn. **********The structure, whose $6 million conversion was designed by Leonard Colchamiro, a Brooklyn architect with a 10 percent interest in the development, is still, after a year of construction, a windowless brick shell. But the cornices and lintels have been restored, the innards gutted and the few crumbling walls rebuilt. **********By early fall, residents should begin moving into the relatively spacious apartments, which will consist of 20 two-bedroom duplexes, measuring 1,000 square feet; 18 two-bedroom floor-throughs, also 1,000 square feet, and one studio of 550 square feet. The rents are expected to range from $1,100 to $1,300 for the two-bedrooms, while the studio will lease for about $750. **********Midtown Florist, which has a staff of 70 and revenues of $4 million a year, will expand by 3,000 square feet. Some 11,000 square feet of retail space on the ground floor will be renovated and leased to nine stores for about $35 a square foot. **********The apartment complex, to be called Times Plaza, was designed so that all tenants will go through one lobby in a building on State Street, the only residential street bounding the site. There, a wide staircase will lead to a private 6,000-square-foot landscaped plaza, nestled behind the buildings, from which tenants will gain access to their apartments. **********To help shield residents from the frequent sirens, extra thick windows will be installed. In addition, sprinkler systems will be hooked up in every building. Mr. Orlofsky, who lives in Merrick, L.I., with his wife, Stella, said he planned to turn the building into a cooperative in five or six years. **********Mr. Orlofsky's young career as a developer - it has left his wife and three of his sons in charge of the flower shop - will not end here. Behind the rental apartments, which occupy a half-acre, the other half of the property now functions as a parking lot and a storage area for building materials. Construction will begin there in January on a four- to six-story building that will contain about 40 condominiums. Prices for the units, scheduled for occupancy in early 1989, have not been set yet, **********Financing for the rental project, in the form of a $4.5 million construction loan, came from the Community Preservation Corporation, a special lender that, with the backing of 32 city banks, provides mortgages for the rehabilitation of housing in aging New York regions. **********''The Times Plaza buildings,'' said Mary Brennan, a vice president at the corporation, ''should break the ground for the neighborhood's revitalization, leading other developers to build in the Fort Greene area.'' **********That kind of real estate contagion is already palpable. Several speculators and two major developers have sought an interest in Mr. Orlofsky's project. One, shortly before the financing came through, offered to reimburse him for funds already spent on the development and add another $5 million for control of the site. The florist said no. ''Sure, I want to turn a profit - the bottom line is always important,'' said Mr. Orlofsky, who has 18 grandchildren. ''But this is a labor of love. I'm so proud of how we restored these buildings. This is my baby.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/21/world.body_text: **********More than 100,000 Sikhs rallied in the state of Punjab today in support of secular political leaders who face a challenge from religious figures for leadership of India's Sikhs. **********At the rally, in Longowal in the southern Punjab, the Sikhs expressed faith in the leadership of the state's Chief Minister, Surjit Singh Barnala, and rejected a recent move by the Hindu sect's five head priests to excommunicate Mr. Barnala for refusing to obey their directives. **********The priests, who took office a few weeks ago, are allied with factions that favor secession from India. Many Sikh scholars say the priests overstepped their authority. **********The rally was called by Mr. Barnala, and moderate Sikhs joined with other leaders in urging Sikhs to go to Longowal and support him. Their presence was itself a rejection of the excommunication order, under which Sikhs are supposed to shun Mr. Barnala. **********It was not clear, however, whether the rally would strengthen Mr. Barnala, or whether he could continue to count on the political support of his colleagues in the Punjab legislature. He was supported at the rally by 39 of the 47 legislators in his wing, enough for him to withstand a challenge for the time being. He is also supported by Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/15/busin.body_text: **********Production at the nation's factories, mines and utilities, bolstered by a rebound in oil and gas drilling and gains at auto plants, surged eight-tenths of 1 percent in July, the biggest increase in 15 months, the Federal Reserve said today. **********The increase in industrial production, the sixth in a row, followed upward revisions of output in the last three months. The June increase was revised to four-tenths of 1 percent, from two-tenths of 1 percent, the Fed said. **********''Industrial production continues to rise, providing a strong degree of optimism for the underlying strength of the economy,'' the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said in Santa Barbara, Calif., where President Reagan is vacationing. Rise in Exports Cited **********Analysts said the big July increase showed that American industry was recovering from two years of sluggishness caused by high foreign trade deficits. They gave credit for the upturn to a rise in American exports. In a separate report, the Government said that exports increased in June but that the trade deficit grew to an apparent record of $15.7 billion because of a huge rise in imports. **********July's increase in industrial output was the largest since a gain of nine-tenths of 1 percent in April 1986, and pushed the increase in production for the past 12 months to 3.9 percent. **********''The industrial output figures are bigger than I thought they would be,'' said Lawrence Kudlow, chief economist for Bear, Stearns & Company of New York. ''They are another signal of the strength of the economy.'' **********But Maury Harris, chief economist for Paine Webber Inc. in New York, said the sharp rise might overstate the strength in the industrial sector. Production figures are based in part on employment data gathered by the Labor Department. Mr. Harris said that July's increase in manufacturing employment was inflated by faulty seasonal adjustments. **********The gain in July production reflected in part a 2.2 percent rise in output at auto plants, the result of gains in vans and light trucks, which offset a drop in passenger cars. Auto production fell to an annual rate of 6.7 million units, down from 6.9 million in June. Mine Output Climbs **********Other strength in July came from a 1.1 percent rise in mine output, reflecting increases in metal mining and coal production, as well as a gain in oil and gas activity. **********Production in manufacturing rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in July following an increase of three-tenths of 1 percent in June. The strength has pushed manufacturing output 4.2 percent higher than it was a year ago. **********Production of durable goods, items built to last three or more years, rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in July, while output of non-durable goods increased nine-tenths of 1 percent. **********Production at electric and gas utilities rose six-tenths of 1 percent in July, compared with an advance of one-tenth of 1 percent in June. **********The report said that strength in industrial production has come from the output of equipment and materials. But production of construction supplies and military equipment, two areas of strength in 1986, have shown little gains so far this year. **********The various changes left the total index at 129.8 percent of its 1977 base of 100.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/11/busin.main_headline: DOW'S LOSS IS 0.42 AFTER BONDS DROP
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/11/busin.print_headline: DOW'S LOSS IS 0.42 AFTER BONDS DROP
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/11/busin.body_text: **********Stock prices fell a bit yesterday, depressed again by the weak dollar and sharp climb in interest rates. **********The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 0.42, to 2,338.78, after hovering a few points higher than that for most of the day. But the 1,072 declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange decisively outnumbered the 512 issues that advanced. **********Although the Dow average broke the 2,400 barrier for the first time on Monday, when it climbed to 2,405.54, the closely watched indicator changed direction the next day, plunging 44.60 points in one of its biggest drops ever. For the full week, the Dow lost 51.56, after rising 54.54 points the week before. **********''It's been a disappointing week in terms of follow-through on last week's gains,'' said Brian Luedtke, a technical analyst at Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood Inc. in Minneapolis. ''The hardest-hit sectors have been interest sensitive, such as the utilities, where the Dow utility index closed at 204.34 and is lower than at the beginning of the year. At the same time the Dow has soared more than 440 points.'' Broader Indicators Drop **********Broader indicators were also lower. The New York Stock Exchnage composite index fell 0.37, to 165.72, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index also declined 0.37, but to 292.49. **********Volume on the Big Board dropped to 169.5 million shares, from 180.3 million on Thursday. **********''We are looking at continued volatility as the market starts to experience what we call 'in-place consolidation,' or a tight trading range,'' Mr. Luedtke said. ''Even though there's a temptation to jump on the bandwagon after a couple of strong sessions, there's not the same urgency that existed only a couple of months ago.'' **********The stock market yesterday closely followed the pattern of trading in bonds and in the dollar. After opening lower, the Dow continued to decline until prices turned mixed when the credit markets recovered somewhat. The turnaround was short-lived, however, as both bond prices and the dollar again sagged. **********The dollar fell against the yen despite central bank intervention. **********In the credit markets, interest rates rose because of the steep drop in the dollar and fears that the Federal Reserve might have to tighten its policy to check the currency's fall. There was also increased nervousness about inflation and a lack of buying by overseas investors. **********Among individual issues, I.B.M. rose 1, to 145, while General Motors climbed 2 3/4, to 86. The auto company's executives told Wall Street analysts that they expected the company to hold onto its 40 percent share of the car market. **********Gold stocks climbed again as the price of gold reached its highest levels in six months. Hecla Mining, for example, rose 1 1/4, to 22 3/4, and Dome Mines was up 1/2, to 14 1/4, with both issues hitting new 52-week highs. **********Technology stocks rose in a positive reaction to Thursday's news news that the semiconductor industry's book-to-bill ratio in March reached its highest level since 1984. Digital Equipment picked up 4 1/2 to close at 166 1/8 and Texas Instruments was up 3 1/8, to 199 7/8. **********Hospital Corporation of America soared 3 1/2, to 41 5/8, in heavy trading. Late Thursday, the nation's largest hospital chain said that it had received a takeover offer of $47 a share. **********Holly Sugar dropped 2, to 108. On Thursday, the stock had shot up 6 1/2 after Shamrock Holdings, an investment concern controlled by the Roy E. Disney family, said it was considering an offer to buy the one million Holly shares it does not already own. **********Other decliners yesterday included UAL, which fell 1 1/8, to 72 1/8; Eastman Kodak, which slipped 1 3/8, to 75 7/8, and Southwestern Bell, which fell 2, to 108. **********On the American Stock Exchange, the Amex market value index dropped 1.15, to 338.08. In over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index fell 1.06, to 430.93.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/09/world.body_text: **********In opening a disputed top-secret radar station to Western inspection, the Soviet Union appears to have run the risk that it might provide new ammunition for those who charge it with treaty violations in order to show its eagerness for an East-West accord at a critical time in arms control negotiations. **********The Kremlin, in making its decision to open its Krasnoyarsk site to a Congressional delegation over the weekend, seems to have calculated that the gains would outweigh any political or military losses. **********The Reagan Administration has insisted for years that the partly built ''phased array'' radar station violates the 1972 Antiballistic Missile treaty, and Washington has often cited this as one of the more egregious examples of Soviet cheating on past treaties. **********In opening the installation for inspection, Moscow has not succeeded in putting an end to the charge, but it has made itself seem more interested in resolving the vexing radar issue than in risking the failure of the ABM treaty. **********A clear political risk is that the Reagan Administration might ignore the bid for a dialogue and simply cite the new Krasnoyarsk findings as evidence to back up its charges. **********However, the inspection indicated that the worst fears of American military experts about the site appear to be unfounded. **********Although the half-built radar clearly raises questions about the Soviet Union's adherence to the letter of the ABM treaty, close inspection suggested the site is more benign than menacing - that it is potentially a mediocre early warning radar rather than a hardened bunker for coordinating antimissile war. Private Lobby Effort **********The Soviet decision was also probably influenced by arms-control advocates in the United States who lobbied vigorously for the disputed site to be opened. **********More than a year ago, the Natural Resources Defense Council, a private group based in New York, raised the issue in meetings with Soviet officials. The group runs a program to monitor the Soviet nuclear test site in Soviet Kazakhstan and has good access to Russian officials. **********In April, Representative Thomas J. Downey, a Long Island Democrat, also pressed Soviet officials in Moscow about the radar. **********Mr. Downey and the N.R.D.C. eventually joined forces in a weeklong trip to the Soviet Union to pursue a variety of arms-control issues; the visit culminated in the Krasnoyarsk tour. Not a Sure Thing **********Despite such positive forces and factors, the visit was far from a sure thing. Dr. Yevgeni P. Velikhov, vice president of the Soviet Academy of Sciences and leader of the Soviet group that accompanied the American delegation to the radar, said on the way to the site that he initially had believed that the chances of a visit were only 5 to 10 percent. **********On one technical level, the Russians had little to lose since top-secret photos from American spy satellites had already raised many questions about the radar's purpose. Spotted from space more than four years ago, the radar is clearly pointed northeast - a direction well suited for tracking enemy warheads and less than optimal for tracking satellites, the rationale offered by the Soviet Union. **********For years, the Pentagon has said that the Krasnoyarsk site violates a prohibition in the ABM treaty against deploying high-powered, early warning radars anywhere except along a nation's periphery. **********This criticism escalated in April, when the first space photos of Krasnoyarsk, taken by a French civilian satellite, were released publicly. Private military experts quickly used these images to confirm the Pentagon's judgment - that the radar was pointed northeast and was thus a probable violation of the ABM treaty. Visit Lessened Fears **********What the recent inspection did was to lessen the West's worst fears about the site. The Reagan Administration has charged that the radar is intended to track incoming enemy warheads, at the very least for early warning of nuclear attack, and possibly for help in waging defensive wars meant to destroy enemy missiles and warheads, an ABM application known as battle management. Either use would violate the ABM treaty. **********But inspection showed the site to be half-built and shoddy, with no apparent future as a hardened bunker for waging antimissile wars. At best, it might someday be a humdrum early warning radar with some limited satellite-tracking capability. **********One of Moscow's potential losses in the visit involved the breach of military secrecy. A major goal of hiding what seem like mundane facts about military hardware is to deny potential foes firm knowledge of the strengths and weaknesses of a nation's war machine, thus increasing doubts over whether aggression could be successful. **********In an unusual break with such principles, the American delegation that toured the site was allowed to take more than 1,000 photos inside and outside the giant radar, many of which will undoubtedly be subject to detailed analysis by the Pentagon. Moreover, that flood of information could reveal a kind of blueprint to many other Soviet installations since the Krasnoyarsk radar is similar to several so-called ''phased-array'' radars under construction in the Soviet Union. Erosion of ABM **********Even so, having seized the initiative by opening the site to foreigners, the Soviet Union now stands ready to score more political points than it ever could with its previous posture of stony silence and vehement denial. **********Most importantly, increased candor over Krasnoyarsk seems to bespeak a desire to stop the erosion of the ABM treaty, ostensibly a long-term Soviet goal based on its opposition to President Reagan's ''Star Wars'' antimissile program. **********It also stands to strengthen the hand of House liberals like Mr. Downey, who have promoted a number of arms-control measures over the objections of the Reagan Administration. Votes on many of these measures will soon be pending, including limits on nuclear testing, antisatellite weapons and ''Star Wars'' spending. The fate of these initiatives on Capitol Hill may well be influenced by the new show of Soviet openness.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/04/busin.main_headline: THE AX FALLS ON EQUAL OPPORTUNITY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/04/busin.print_headline: THE AX FALLS ON EQUAL OPPORTUNITY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/04/busin.body_text: **********IT seemed like a great idea last October, when the subject first came up. Black Agency Executives, an association of black directors of social service agencies in New York City, would invite about 60 black corporate executives of major national companies to a conference in April. The talk would be of fund raising, of board memberships, of management techniques, of all kinds of subjects on which the two groups could offer mutual assistance. **********The idea has since been scuttled. ''The ranks of blacks in corporations have been so decimated there just wouldn't be enough people to come,'' says John N. Odom, B.A.E.'s director. **********Across the country, black managers have been losing their jobs at an accelerated pace. Executive recruiters report that resumes from discharged black managers are flooding their offices, while assignments to recruit them - or anyone at the middle management level - are few and far between. **********So far, black engineers, sales managers and others in jobs that deal directly with products have been spared. And most experts say that lower-level black workers, many of whom are in unions, have fared no worse than their white counterparts in the wave of firings sweeping the country. **********But blacks in public affairs, community relations, human resources - all of the staff-support areas that have become havens for blacks and women trying to make it into the mainstream of corporate America - are finding their jobs, and their paychecks, gone. ''For years, blacks and women were steered into jobs that were not central to the organization,'' said Mary Anne Devanna, research director at the Columbia Business School's Management Institute. ''Now these are precisely the jobs that are being eliminated.'' **********Members of an increasingly angry black managerial community feel the dismissals have dealt them a one-two punch. They see themselves and their colleagues, far more than white women, back at square one in their careers, often after decades of employment with the same company. And since many of the fired managers were responsible for recruiting and guiding entry-level blacks through the corporate shoals, they say the trend bodes extremely ill for younger black would-be managers. **********''The whole country has gone backwards in the sense of equal opportunity,'' said Sheila Clark, 38, a black single parent who last month lost her job as director of career development at CBS Inc. ''It's like a door opened and suddenly it shut in your face.'' **********Although the corporate ax is falling on managers of all colors and races, black executives say it has fallen disproportionately hard on them as a group. According to David L. Vaughn, president of the National Urban Affairs Council, the number of executive jobs in the New York metropolitan area has shrunk by about 9 percent in the last couple of years. Well over half of the jobs that were eliminated, he says, had been held by blacks - a percentage that far exceeds black representation in managerial jobs. **********Other black executives cite similar figures. ''Mergers and acquisitions have cut the legs out of the movement of blacks in the corporate world,'' says Sullivan Robinson, head of Associated Black Charities, a 59-member federation of New York social services agencies. ''Corporate America has made a decision to whiten up again. It can't be coincidental. The numbers are just too extreme.'' **********Although specific numbers are impossible to unearth, most employment experts say it is because of weak information-gathering methods, not because the figures are wrong. ''We have little information about what's happening in specific occupations and little information about minorities, so hard data related to both are really hard to come by,'' explains Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics. **********But calls to several universities, management associations, and executive search firms turned up a widespread perception of a vicious cycle: Black executives are often promoted to head Equal Employment Opportunity compliance and other minority-related areas, and because these jobs have little immediate impact on corporate bottom lines, they are the first to go in any cutback. ''Companies wind up so worried about quarterly profits that they cut out not only fat but fundamentally important social commitments,'' says James A. F. Stoner, professor of management at Fordham University's Graduate School of Business. **********The pressure seems to be off from Washington. Many companies report that inspections by the Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs, a major enforcement arm for anti-discrimination regulations, are far less thorough than they were in previous Administrations, and that the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission is not living up to its rules. **********Clarence Thomas, chairman of the E.E.O.C., insists that ''the facts belie any such statements'' and that this year his agency filed a record number of lawsuits and class actions on behalf of individuals who charged discrimination. **********But blatant discrimination is not the issue in American business today, most blacks contend. And business experts tend to agree more with the perceptions of the black community than with the E.E.O.C. ''Politically, there is no longer a guardian angel for affirmative action,'' said Paul Hirsch, a professor at the University of Chicago. **********Newly unemployed blacks are more blunt. ''There's a consensus that E.E.O. was never really a part of the corporation, just something that had to be done under a different Administration,'' said Joseph E. Burgess, 51, a former assistant vice president of human resources at the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company who was, in his words, ''reorganized out of a job'' in February. IN A sense, corporations can argue a degree of color-blindness in their widespread staff cuts. The huge number of mergers in recent years has meant wholesale elimination of duplicate jobs of all types, along the theory that no company needs two controllers or two heads of investor relations. **********At the same time, manufacturing companies are facing an unprecedented flood of low-priced import competition, and have been slashing their payrolls in an attempt to get costs low enough so that they can compete effectively. Airlines, telecommunications companies, and other companies operating in newly deregulated environments are finding unfamiliar price competition threatening their existence if they do not get costs down. **********The fickleness of management theory has also had a deleterious impact on staff jobs, including E.E.O.-type positions. In the last decade, management consultants, professors and other self-styled experts preached the virtues of formal strategic planning, psychologically oriented training programs, internal consulting groups, and other staff support functions. Corporations listened and acted accordingly, with the result that these staff jobs flourished in number and salary. **********Now, though, theories along the lines of those espoused by Thomas J. Peters and Robert H. Waterman Jr. in the best-selling ''In Search of Excellence'' have glorified companies with super-lean headquarters staffs and with decision-making done by the line managers, the people who actually run the manufacturing operations or market the products. **********The overall result has been a nationwide downsizing of corporate staffs, usually described as trimming the fat from management. And, black executives charge, it is their jobs that are most often classified as ''fat.'' **********Although corporations will not give specific numbers, they deny this. ''It is absolutely true that American companies are slimming down and cutting costs,'' said Ford Slater, manager of special issues, planning and communications for the General Electric Company. G.E., he says, reduced its overall payroll by 100,000 people - 25 percent of its work force - from 1981 to 1985. **********Mr. Slater insists that ''while the total number of G.E. managers and professionals has declined, the percentage of minorities and women in those categories has stayed about the same, or even increased.'' He predicts that G.E.'s acquisition of RCA -at $6.28 billion, the largest non-oil merger in history - will not have a disproportionate effect on black executives, either. **********James C. Doyle, Met Life's vice president of employee relations, also bridles at any suggestion that the company might treat blacks more shabbily than whites. ''The line managers have taken over the routine work of E.E.O. They prepare their own affirmative action plans and do their own contact with the Government agencies checking compliance,'' he said. ''So we've been able to eliminate supervisory layers at headquarters. But we've had no change in the percentage of minorities that are managers.'' **********Even companies that have publicly announced plans for sizable slim-downs say that blacks need not be disproportionately alarmed. ''Our cutbacks will show no lessening of commitment to affirmative action, E.E.O. or any of these areas,'' says a spokesman for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, which announced on Dec. 18 that it would cut 27,400 jobs. BUT black leaders and academics seem unconvinced by corporate protestations. Though few cite instances of blatant discrimination, or even of a ''last in, first out'' approach to firing black executives, they say that for the past 20 years, educated, articulate blacks have been steered into jobs in which they deal primarily with minority issues. And they say that the Reagan Administration's lack of emphasis on monitoring compliance with the E.E.O.C.'s antidiscrimination rules, has enabled companies to cut those jobs with little fear of repercussions. **********''Some corporations are still somewhat dedicated to helping minorities, but there is no push from the Government compared to what it once was,'' said Ernest A. Richardson, a 61-year-old black consultant who two years ago left a 20-year career with the St. Regis Corporation after he and Champion International, the company that took over St. Regis, reached what he calls a ''happy understanding'' that the affirmative action programs that he ran would be pushed down to the branches. **********Mr. Richardson was not fired, and he says his consulting company is doing quite well. Still, in one way he is typical of black executives who are paying a high price for career decisions that, they say, white-dominated corporations strongly urged them to make years ago. Mr. Richardson's degree is in accounting. It was at St. Regis's suggestion that he switched his career to minority relations. **********That story is repeated again and again among black professionals, says Mr. Vaughn of the Urban Affairs Council. ''Throughout the 1970's, black people, even those with engineering degrees, were lured into managing affirmative action programs and the like,'' he says. ''They were told this was a way to get a foot in the door, they can switch over later. But the fact is, there is no mobility of blacks in corporate America today.'' **********For a time, blacks had reason to believe that these jobs represented their best shots at the top. ''In most companies, the first black to get a vice presidential position was within the human resources sector,'' said Ronald Anderson, director of minority relations at the University of Chicago's Graduate School of Business. ''So many blacks felt this was a place where you could really rocket off. They didn't realize it had become a black managerial ghetto, that these jobs, with their great salaries, would hurt their careers down the road.'' **********Other blacks readily gave up line jobs to take an active role in E.E.O. James Nixon, whose job as director of ITT's equal opportunity operations ended with the New Year, started off as a nuclear engineer with another company, G.E. In the mid-1960's, G.E. asked him to be part of a nationwide effort to study its E.E.O. programs. ''I recommended that they have a headquarters organization for this, and they agreed,'' the 53-year-old executive recalled. ''So I became the head of E.E.O.'' **********G.E., Mr. Nixon says, made no attempt to stereotype him. In fact, in 1973 he moved out of E.E.O. and became a sales manager for G.E. in Detroit. But he, too, wound up back in E.E.O. work, when ITT, the giant telecommunications conglomerate, lured him away from G.E. with offers of high status and big bucks. ''ITT decided to upgrade its E.E.O. effort,'' he said. ''They made me an offer I couldn't refuse.'' **********Since then, Mr. Nixon has seen his E.E.O. department at ITT reduced from 18 people to 6 and now, to none. But much of that interim reduction, he says, was a result of increased automation and productivity on his staff's part. **********In any event, he is philosophical rather than bitter about how his career turned out. ''My attitude is, I play the game and I play it well, and when the game is over I look for another game,'' he says. ''The saying is, 'When white America gets a cold, blacks get pneumonia.' But we fought our way into this managerial group. What makes us think we're immune to its problems?'' **********But Mr. Nixon's attitude is not a typical one within the black community, or among black managers at ITT. Harold Anderson, who is now in his mid-40's, was with ITT for 15 years, most recently as manager of public affairs. A few months ago, when he realized he was likely to lose his job, he left the company to join the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture in Harlem at a considerable cut in salary. **********''I was about to become the only male head of household to be cut in my department,'' Mr. Anderson said. Was this because he is black? ''I don't want to think that about ITT, but I have a suspicion. For a while, Federal statutes for E.E.O. kept minorities a pretty protected class at ITT, but with the Reagan Administration's de-emphasis of E.E.O., ITT no longer saw fit to make this a special group to protect.'' **********ITT calls that supposition ridiculous. ''If it was Harold's perception that any group was treated as a special group to protect, he is wrong,'' said James P. Gallagher, director of public relations, who headed the department Mr. Anderson worked for. ''We had a percentage by which we had to reduce head count. I told Harold that his responsibilities would no longer be handled by this department. I've recently had to tell four or five white people the same thing.'' **********Those fired blacks who are still pounding the pavements are finding it hard to give corporate America the benefit of the doubt. They are particularly angry about what they see as unfair stereotyping of their skills. ''God forbid you say you had anything to do with women or minorities, you're told that's passe,'' said Ms. Clark of CBS, who has an M.B.A. in human resources. ''When you say that's not your entire background, they don't want to hear it. If you're black they think you can't do anything but affirmative action.'' Mr. Burgess of Met Life, who also has a master's degree in human resources and development and is an elected member of the Yonkers City Council, has similar complaints. ''We E.E.O. professionals are recruiters, consultants, and career counselors, and we know corporate chemistry maybe better than anyone else in the company,'' he said. ''But these skills are not considered transferable in the case of blacks. They look at us and say, 'You're just an E.E.O. person.' '' THE answer for a growing number of middle-aged corporate blacks is to start their own companies. Mr. Nixon's employment contract still has a few years to run, so he could stay with ITT if he wished. He doesn't wish - instead, he is taking a lump sum and starting a consulting/ venture capital company aimed at helping other blacks start their own businesses. ''I've been preaching for 11 years that blacks have to get into entrepreneurship,'' he said. ''So I'm going to help them do it.'' **********Many younger blacks still have their sights set on the corporate world. But they are far less likely, experts say, to try to rise through the personnel or public affairs route. ''Blacks coming out of business schools have recognized that this is a trap and are saying they want nuts-and-bolts experience,'' said Mr. Anderson of the University of Chicago. **********Some companies say they would welcome an infusion of minority talent into their technical ranks. ''We are terribly concerned about the future source of brilliant engineers and scientists, and we recognize that one of the great untapped pools is women and minorities,'' said Mr. Slater of G.E., who adds that his company awards scholarships to promising minority students and subsidizes the salaries of black engineering and science teachers. **********Black executives themselves also express some well-tempered optimism. ''The good news is that blacks are being recruited into mainline positions, but the bad news is that it is very slow,'' says Mr. Anderson. Added Mr. Richardson, the former St. Regis manager: ''There will never be a return to what affirmative action and E.E.O. once was, but if you have it and you really believe in yourself, you're going to make it - if not to chairman of the board, into upper management.'' **********Academics say the prognosis may be even better than that. ''If you think of equity and efficiency as major concerns in corporations, and you think of a pendulum swinging between the two, you realize that what is happening now is that the pendulum is swinging toward efficiency,'' said George Milkovich, a professor of human resources at Cornell University's School of Industrial and Labor Relations. ''But the concern for equity will come back.'' **********If corporations do not give blacks parity, society will force them to, Mr. Milkovich adds. ''Neither labor law nor civil rights happened in a vacuum,'' he said. ''Society reacts, and politicians react to societal pressure. And nothing rivets corporate attention like the threat of a $40 million lawsuit or fine.''  BLACK FUNDRAISERS GO BACK TO SQUARE ONE **********Ask Sullivan Robinson, head of Associated Black Charities, what fund raising is like these days, and her frustration almost overwhelms the questioner. ''This February, we're introducing a Black History Makers award, and I need corporate underwriting,'' she says. ''I went to call my old mainstays. What happened? I learned that Richard Neblett, who was in charge of corporate contributions at Exxon, had been fast-tracked to retirement. The black man who had handled contributions at Chase Manhattan was doing something else. Wesley Streeter, my main contact at RCA, is gone.'' **********The downsizing of headquarters staffs and the wholesale elimination of entire job categories typically filled by blacks have had repercussions far beyond the world of black executives. Directors of charitable organizations and social service programs aimed at the black community are finding that some of their best fund-raising contacts are no longer on the scene. The result, they say, is that when corporations re-evaluate their charitable contributions, black charities often do not make it past the first cut. **********''In the late 60's and early 70's, corporations were really helpful in terms of funding to social services agencies,'' said John N. Odom, director of Black Agency Executives, an association of black directors of social service agencies in New York City. ''But now, organizations like ballet groups and art museums are doing better than they have in the past, while social services, particularly for minorities, are doing worse.'' **********Black charities have been among numerous sufferers in the tightening of charitable purse strings in corporations. ITT, for example, has eliminated a program for funding athletics for black youths. In fact, Harold Anderson, who had been liaison for that and similar programs, has been let go. **********But the company insists that his continued presence would have made little difference. The reason: ITT's much-publicized telecommunications joint venture with France has meant that revenues flowing directly to the corporation will be appreciably cut. ''We've always made contributions as a percentage of sales, and we're eliminating about $6 billion in sales through the joint venture,'' said James P. Gallagher, director of public relations. ''So we've cut back on contributions programs across the board, black and white.'' **********Similarly, General Electric executives insist that the merger with RCA, and resulting staff cutbacks, will not have a disproportionate impact on black charities. ''I would expect that the grand total of charitable contributions for RCA plus G.E. would be down somewhat next year from 1986, but minority-related contributions might actually go up as a percent,'' said Ford Slater, G.E.'s manager of special issues, planning and communications. **********But even if the overall flow of corporate dollars to the black community remains sizable, it will represent cold comfort to individual fund raisers. Most have spent countless hours maintaining contacts with specific individuals in large corporations so that, when those companies choose from the myriad causes needing financial support, their names are likely to be high on the list. ''I now have to find new liaisons, establish new rapports,'' says Ms. Robinson. ''And that takes years.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/18/busin.print_headline: ADVERTISING; Beta Carotene Ads By Smith/Greenland
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/18/busin.body_text: **********Hoffmann-LaRoche has begun a multimillion-dollar ad campaign through Smith/Greenland to educate the public to the benefits of beta carotene, the food substance from green leafy vegetables and orange vegetables the consumption of which seems to cut down on the incidence of cancer. **********The pharmaceutical company is calling it a public-service campaign, but it does manufacture beta carotene for the pharmaceutical industry. **********The first ad in the campaign has the headline ''Beta Carotene just another health fad? Or does it help reduce cancer risk?'' It has been produced in single-page and two-page-spread versions. **********For the first phase of the campaign, on which the company may ultimately spend $4 million, there are 10 magazines on the schedule that will carry the ad from late March through May. They are American Health, Family Circle, Good Housekeeping, Health, Hippocrates, The New York Times's Good Health supplement, People, Prevention, Reader's Digest, Self, Shape, Sunset and Time.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/07/busin.main_headline: The Careful Aim of the Beretta Clan
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/07/busin.print_headline: ITALY: HOST FOR THE ECONOMIC SUMMIT - A LAND OF FAMILY BUSINESSES; The Careful Aim of the Beretta Clan
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/07/busin.body_text: **********THE inhabitants of this little town at the foot of the Alps started making guns some 500 years ago. It was a natural thing to do: The steep valley walls were loaded with iron ore, and the old Venetian Republic often went to war. **********Weapons are still the major product here, because traditions die hard in families like the Berettas. Having almost certainly armed the Venetian sailors that defeated the Turkish fleet at Lepanto in 1571, the Berettas are now supplying the Pentagon with handguns to replace the legendary Colt .45. **********The Berettas claim to be the world's oldest industrial dynasty. Indeed, a document in the Venetian state archives shows that on October 3, 1521, the Republic's arsenal paid Master Bartolomeo Beretta 296 ducats for 185 harquebus barrels (a harquebus was an early version of a portable gun). The company's senior management can be traced in a continuous line through 13 generations back to Master Bartolomeo. **********Like some other family businesses in Italy, Beretta has mixed conservative business practices with innovation in design and manufacturing techniques. As a result, the company is neither very big nor immensely profitable. But it survives - and occasionally prospers - by concentrating on one kind of product and insuring that at least a few of its guns are the best that money can buy. **********''Certain lessons have been handed down over all these years,'' said Ugo Gussalli Beretta, the clan's current leader. ''We have developed an understanding of quality, and we have learned how to make progress sweetly, always on a steady course, not with big, quick steps.'' **********This kind of strategy can have its drawbacks. Last year, Beretta's Italian operations scored a net profit of about $1 million, down about 20 percent from 1985 and less than 1 percent of total sales. **********Mr. Beretta ascribes the poor performance to several factors. The dollar's drop has made the company's best-quality guns extremely expensive in America. The global market in hunting guns has been flooded by cheaper, less deluxe models. The Italian market has dropped by 30 percent over the past few years as the Government places increasingly severe restrictions on hunting in the face of depleted game. **********''The Bourse might be a bit impatient with us,'' Mr. Beretta said, ''but when shareholders are primarily relatives you have a certain stability because they are ready to make sacrifices.'' Relatives own 64 percent of Beretta's stock - the rest was sold 15 years ago to the Fabrique Nacional de Liege, a Belgian arms company, to raise capital and protect against takeover attempts. **********The company remains committed to making high-quality rifles and shotguns for hunting. ''We will continue doing what we do best,'' said Mr. Beretta, ''and the market factors will turn themselves around - they always have.'' The market for hunting guns had just about disappeared in America about 15 years ago, he points out, but game-management policies as well as social and political changes reversed that trend. **********CERTAIN family traditions help the Berettas avoid some of the pitfalls of family-run operations. The business is not run democratically. ''There has always been a 'capo' whose word was final,'' Mr. Beretta said. And the rule of primogeniture has never been applied: First-born sons have been passed over several times in favor of more qualified younger siblings. Ugo Beretta's 80-year-old uncle, Giuseppe, is president of the company, though he is virtually in retirement, and about 20 family members hold jobs at Beretta. **********But family tradition has not prevented innovation at the factory that produces 250,000 guns a year from a sprawl of buildings on either side of a rocky stream here. Beretta leads the industry in experimenting with the uses of aluminium alloys in gun parts, for example. **********The modern methods, though, are balanced by a long-term view. ''Signor Ugo,'' as Mr. Beretta is known, never ignores the lessons of history. ''Weapons companies have always been prime candidates for nationalization,'' he said. ''Right now the government favors the private sector, but who knows about 10 or 50 or 100 years from now?'' **********He is cautious about military sales generally. The Pentagon's 1984 decision to buy 320,000 Beretta 92SB-F 9-millimeter pistols for use as a standard sidearm produced a pile of exceptional publicity for Beretta (which also supplies the Texas Rangers.) But over all, Beretta is keeping the military side of the business to 20 to 30 percent of sales, as it has been for several years. **********Mr. Beretta, a dapper but strongly built man, says that is because the arms market is unpredictable. Indeed, Congress decided in 1986 that when the contract is completed in three years, the Pentagon will have to test a range of sidearms - as it did in 1984 - before continuing to buy the Beretta. **********Beretta's careful approach extends to its American operation, Beretta U.S.A. To satisfy Congressional rules that a certain percentage of goods covered by a Pentagon contract must be made in America, Beretta makes 9-millimeter pistols at a factory in Accokeek, Md. It is a relatively small-scale operation. ''We had the choice of raising more capital to set up a bigger operation, but we decided to do only as much as we knew we could do well,'' said Mr. Beretta. **********That is an attitude the modern world, with its push for growth every quarter, has not always favored. But the Berettas have the luxury of looking back, a long way back, and of knowing it is not explosive growth, but quiet staying power, that pays off.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/07/world.body_text: **********Vernon A. Walters, the United States representative at the United Nations, arrived in Damascus today on a mission designed to repair American relations with Syria. **********Mr. Walters was promptly received by President Hafez al-Assad. Damascus radio monitored here said the discussions covered the latest developments in the Middle East and matters related to relations between the two countries. It did not not give details beyond reporting that the meeting was attended by the Syrian Foreign Minister, Farouk al-Sharaa. **********The Walters visit is the result of a recent exchange between President Reagan and President Assad, the first since Washington recalled its Ambassador in Damascus, William Eagleton, last October to protest Syria's purported involvement in terrorism.  [ The State Department confirmed that Mr. Walters arrived in Damascus, for what officials described as exploratory talks to see if an improvement was possible in relations between the two countries. Some officials expressed the hope that if the trip went well, the Administration would consider sending Ambassador Eagleton back to Damascus. From Damascus, Mr. Walters will head to Tokyo and Beijing to continue lobbying for an American-led initiative at the United Nations in an effort to help end the Iran-Iraq war, the officials said. ]  Attempt on Israeli Airliner The United States action followed Britain's decision to sever all ties with Syria after Britian said it had clear evidence of complicity by Syrian intelligence agents in an abortive attempt to plant a bomb aboard an Israeli airliner at Heathrow airport.
