https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/17/world.main_headline: Pakistan Denies Any Link To Atom Arms Plot in U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/17/world.print_headline: Pakistan Denies Any Link To Atom Arms Plot in U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/17/world.body_text: **********The Government of Pakistan denied today that it was involved in any way in an attempt to export a steel alloy from the United States illegally for possible use in making nuclear weapons. **********The denial, in a statement by the Foreign Ministry, follows the arrest in Philadelphia last Friday of a Canadian of Pakistani origin, Arshad Z. Pervez, on charges of trying to circumvent American export laws to acquire the alloy for shipment to Pakistan. Mr. Pervez is also accused of offering bribes to American officials. **********American law enforcement agents said Mr. Pervez had led them to believe that the material - 50,000 pounds of a special steel compound produced by the Carpenter Steel Corporation in Reading, Pa. - was intended for Pakistan's nuclear program. Members of Congress, concerned that Pakistan may be proceeding with nuclear weapons research and development, are seeking to withhold aid from the Government of President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq if this is the case. **********Pakistan has said repeatedly that it is not developing nuclear weapons, although it is developing peaceful uses of nuclear power. It repeated the denial today. **********The Foreign Ministry said the United States Embassy had requested an appointment to discuss the implications of the Pervez case with the Government, but a date had not been set. Afghan Issue Is Cited **********Pakistani officials said they were the target of Soviet or Afghanistan-sponsored campaigns to discredit them because this country provides bases for seven guerrilla armies fighting the Kabul Government. Pakistan's role is important to United States efforts to weaken the Soviet-backed Kabul regime through support of the guerrillas. **********American officials in Pakistan said they would not comment on the Pervez case or on the larger issue of Pakistan's nuclear program. But the former Ambassador in Islamabad, Deane R. Hinton, warned Pakistan against nuclear weapons development in several speeches and interviews before his recent departure. **********He cautioned Pakistanis not to view nuclear development as a matter of national pride in the face of India's testing of a nuclear device 13 years ago. Some Pakistanis regard this issue as a test of sovereignty, particularly in relations with the United States. **********In its statement today and in answers to questions put to a Foreign Ministry spokesman, the Government described Congressional criticism regarding the Pervez case as propaganda against Pakistan. It called the charges against Mr. Pervez ''baseless'' but added that it would be up to the American courts to decide the case. **********Whatever the decision, Pakistan said, the Government, its agencies and private Pakistani companies had ''no connection whatever with Pervez.'' **********A Foreign Ministry spokesman, who was not identified, said Pakistan was concerned that this case was getting publicity on the eve of Congressional hearings on aid. Disinformation Is Seen **********''This is not the first time such a coincidence has taken place,'' the spokesman said. He said it was beginning to look as if a disinformation campaign was under way against Pakistan so American aid would be adversely affected. Congress is considering a six-year aid package worth $4 billion. **********Today, some Pakistanis who have been following the country's nuclear program closely said there was skepticism about the Government's denials in the Pervez case because of certain unanswered questions. **********Among these are why such a large quantity of the steel alloy was ordered, and where the foreign currency needed for the purchase would have originated if not from Government sources. **********The credibility of Pakistan's denials was diminished earlier this year, many contend, by the publication in India and Pakistan of articles purporting to be based on an interview with the man thought to have masterminded a Pakistani nuclear weapon, Abdul Qadeer Khan. In the interview with an Indian journalist, Kuldip Nayar, and a Pakistani editor, Mushahid Hussain, Mr. Khan refused to answer yes or no to a question about whether Pakistan had a nuclear weapon. He was quoted as having said, however, that Pakistan had proved wrong those who doubted its ability to produce one. **********Mr. Khan later denied he had said this. Mr. Mushahid subsequently resigned as editor of the newspaper, The Moslem. But Mr. Nayar stands by his article.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/29/busin.main_headline: Real Estate; The Shifts In Branch Banking
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/29/busin.print_headline: Real Estate; The Shifts In Branch Banking
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/29/busin.body_text: **********AT one time an important indicator of a bank's strength was the number of branches it operated. But the high cost of running a branch and the rise of automatic teller machines and banking by phone have spurred some institutions to reduce their retail locations. Even banks that are opening new branches are making do with much smaller space. **********Chemical, Manufacturers Hanover and Citibank are among the major institutions in New York that have closed branches over the last few years. Last winter Chase Manhattan, in what was believed to be the largest consolidation in recent years, announced that it would eliminate 47 of its 231 branches in the metropolitan area within 18 months. **********''A review of the system showed that some branches were unprofitable and redundant,'' said Kenneth A. Mills, a Chase spokesman. ''In some areas there were two or more branches within a few blocks of each other, and in other places, like White Plains, where there were six branches, there were more locations than the population could support.'' **********Of the 47 Chase branches to be closed, 33 are in retail spaces that the bank leases and 14 are in buildings that the bank owns. **********In some places, Chase has allowed leases to expire; at others, it is subleasing or selling the space. So far, the bank has sold six properties, three to other banks. Of the spaces to be sublet, other banks will take nine. **********According to Joseph Schlang, a real estate broker who specializes in bank space, the high cost of renewal leases is a prime contributor to the consolidation programs at some banks. **********''In Manhattan, some deals were signed when the space was $20 a foot,'' said Mr. Schlang, who came out of retirement a few years ago to found Bank Locations, a real estate brokerage firm that specializes in bringing together banks that want to give up branch space and those looking to expand. Today rent can be four times that. **********One way that banks justify the cost of new branches is with smaller operations, and electronic banking has made this possible. Before electronic aids, retail bank operations demanded 5,000 to 10,000 square feet. Today banks are signing deals for 3,000-to-4,000-square-foot spaces. **********But space aside, banks still need good locations. Mr. Schlang said that banks looking to expand could expect to pay between $75 and $100 a square foot in Manhattan. **********While Chase is consolidating its branch operations, other banks, like Apple Bank for Savings, are expanding. Still others, like Bankers Federal Savings, are planning to expand. **********''Smaller banks are going for the smaller business customer, the entreprenuer, and giving him attention and time,'' said Illene Burack, Mr. Schlang's associate in Bank Locations. ''Those banks are expanding in areas like the East Village in Manhattan, and Flushing and Astoria in Queens, where there has been a tremendous influx of new residents and small businesses.'' **********Apple Bank expects to open its first branch in Queens, at 3506 Broadway in Astoria, by the end of the year. The 7,000-square-foot branch will be only a few blacks from where Chase is closing a branch, at 30-30 Steinway Street. **********''We have grown tremendously in the last few years,'' said Anthony M. Ronda, vice president for marketing for Apple Bank. ''We have been putting our earnings into the development of new locations,'' **********Late last year the bank acquired the Eastern Savings Bank, increasing its branches to 23 from 16. Since then, Apple has opened a branch on Long Island. That branch and the new one in Queens will bring the number of its retail locations to 25. Mr. Ronda said the bank was hoping to expand in Queens and Long Island. **********Raymond A. Lein, president of Bankers Federal Savings, said the closing of its main retail location at 24 John Street last month was not an indication that the bank was consolidating but a sign that it was ready to expand. **********''We had run out of space there,'' he said of the building that Bankers Federal had recently sold. ''But we are moving to keep up with the needs of our depositors. In that respect, our future lies in the expansion of our branch operations.'' **********In its John Street building, its administrative offices were squeezed into 7,000 square feet above the ground floor. This week the bank's offices were moved to 13,000 square feet of space in an office building at 110 Williams Street. **********The bank operates two branches in Manhattan, two in Flushing and one in Brooklyn. Mr. Lein said that the bank, which was established in 1890 as the Bank Clerks Cooperative Building and Loan Society, is converting from a mutual to a stock institution. The bank plans to use some of the capital from the stock sale to open branches.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/19/busin.main_headline: Chairman of ADT In Role of Defender
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/19/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Chairman of ADT In Role of Defender
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/19/busin.body_text: **********Raymond B. Carey Jr., president and chairman of ADT Inc., disagrees vehemently with analysts and others who characterize his company's financial performance as lackluster. **********''Anyone who takes anything more than a casual look at the company's financial results will be able to see the momentum that this company has built in the last few years,'' Mr. Carey said yesterday in a telephone interview. **********ADT, the market leader in supplying security systems, is the target of the Hawley Group, the British conglomerate that on Monday made a $635 million bid to acquire the New York-based company. **********Mr. Carey said ADT officials were talking with Hawley executives. ''We can't really discuss the bid right now,'' he said. **********He described ADT as a company with an eye on technology and respectable growth. The company manufactures and maintains sophisticated burglar and fire alarm systems, principally for businesses. It commands about 30 percent of the market, according to analysts' estimates, ahead of Honeywell Inc., Wells Fargo & Company and Hawley. **********ADT's financial results have not excited analysts. The company's $23.2 million profit last year, on sales of $519 million, was below the peak in 1982. **********''We have been building our new Focus product line over the last two years,'' Mr. Carey said. ''That has been successful, but it has had an effect on our earnings and on our margins. But analysts and others need to look at the long-term picture. When you see what that investment will mean for the company in the long term, you see that we are on a growth course. I am absolutely delighted with the progress we have made.'' **********Mr. Carey, who is 60 years old, came to ADT in 1970 and has been chairman, chief executive and president since 1973. Before that he was a group vice president of the Robert Morse Corporation in Montreal, and before that he was an executive at the General Dynamics Corporation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/31/busin.main_headline: A Second Stake In Del E. Webb
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/31/busin.print_headline: A Second Stake In Del E. Webb
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/31/busin.body_text: **********Hecco Ventures, an investment partnership here, said today that it owns a 9.1 percent stake in the Del E. Webb Corporation and that it might seek control of the Phoenix-based gaming and real estate concern. **********In response, Webb said that it would meet with Hecco officials within two weeks. **********The move by Hecco comes a week after a Hong Kong-based group said it held a 9.3 percent stake in Webb and would seek to acquire as much as 50 percent. Also last week, Webb said it was considering a restructuring and a sale of assets. **********In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission today, Hecco said it had bought 733,000 Webb shares for $16.1 million. Webb's stock rose $1.625 a share, to $25.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/08/world.main_headline: Chirac Blinks in Facedown With Culture Minister
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/08/world.print_headline: Chirac Blinks in Facedown With Culture Minister
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/08/world.body_text: **********Francois Leotard, France's popular and ambitious Culture Minister, appears to have scored a significant tactical victory over Prime Minister Jacques Chirac in a campaign to establish himself as a major conservative leader - and perhaps Mr. Chirac's heir - before the presidential elections next year. **********In a telegram made public today, Mr. Chirac told Mr. Leotard, leader of the small Republican Party, which is part of France's right-wing ruling coalition, that he can stay on in the Government after all. The Prime Minister's move came after Mr. Leotard rejected an ultimatum Saturday night to either stop campaigning for himself and his party or resign his Ministerial post, but pledged that his public remarks in the future would be intended to help the Government as a whole. **********The telegram was generally seen as a climb down by Mr. Chirac, who was incensed when Mr. Leotard publicly told his supporters last week not to vote for the Prime Minister in the first round of next year's two-ballot presidential election. Instead, Mr. Leotard said, they should support either him, if he runs, or the former Prime Minister, Raymond Barre, Mr. Chirac's principal conservative rival. **********''Leotard didn't give way,'' Lionel Jospin, secretary of the opposition Socialists, said today. ''It was neither resignation nor submission,'' commented Jean-Pierre Soisson, a Republican Party leader. **********The public quarrel between Mr. Leotard and Mr. Chirac is significant in several respects. For four days now, Mr. Leotard has held part of France in suspense while he debated whether to plunge the ruling coalition into a major crisis by walking out. His photogenic features have appeared in a number of newspapers and on television screens. By neither surrendering nor resigning, Mr. Leotard has demonstrated his distance from Mr. Chirac and re-emphasized his party's claim as an independent political body that, while in the alliance with Mr. Chirac's neo-Gaullist Rally for the Republic, retains an image and views of its own. **********The dispute also illustrates Mr. Chirac's weakening grip over his coalition Government as the elections approach. If President Francois Mitterrand, France's Socialist head of state, runs again, he will be the clear favorite. Among conservative competitors, Mr. Barre is ahead of Mr. Chirac. **********Against competition like this, Mr. Leotard can have little hope in next year's presidential race, but he is only 45 years old, and time is on his side. If Mr. Chirac fails to win the presidency, many expect a realignment of right-wing forces in France and a search for new leadership. **********Mr. Leotard has said his aim is ''to do for the Republican Party what Mitterrand did for the Socialists - make it the biggest party in France,'' and he predicts that it could overtake Mr. Chirac's party to become the principal right-wing body in 10 years. **********But even if it doesn't, the party has already proved to be a powerful springboard, one that propelled its last head, Valery Giscard d'Estaing, to leadership of the right and the Presidency. **********Mr. Leotard is regularly voted the most popular Minister in the Government. He cultivates a Kennedyesque image, appearing youthful, vigorous and modern in outlook. A keen athlete, he frequently runs in marathons. **********With 60 seats in the French Parliament, Mr. Leotard heads a group of eight Republican Ministers, all close in age and outlook. The Ministers are known as ''Leo's Gang'' because of their loyalty to their leader. **********The son of a highly placed civil servant, Mr. Leotard entered a Benedictine monastery at 22, an experience that left him with a penchant for quoting scripture and a taste for the Gregorian chant, the ritual plainsong used in the Roman Catholic Church. **********Later, Mr. Leotard attended the prestigious Ecole Nationale d'Administration, where he became a friend of Laurent Fabius, France's last Socialist Prime Minister, and then entered the civil service. **********Mr. Leotard joined the Republican Party in 1975. In 1977, he became Mayor of Frejus, his hometown in southeastern France, and two years later won a seat in Parliament.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/18/busin.body_text: **********A Federal judge yesterday rejected a motion to throw out a lawsuit brought in 1981 by a Peruvian commodities trading company against the Hunt brothers of Texas and leading brokerage firms. The ruling means that the suit will be heard in Federal court beginning Feb. 3, 1988. **********The motion to dismiss was brought by five defendants in a lawsuit filed by Minteco S.A., which is owned by the Peruvian Government, against 24 defendants that included Herbert, Lamar and Nelson Hunt; Merrill Lynch & Company and Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. **********The suit contended that the defendants conspired to manipulate the silver and silver futures markets such that the company lost more than $200 million over three months in late 1979 and early 1980. The company is seeking more than $600 million in relief. **********The motion was filed by the five defendants on Aug. 3, but Judge Morris Lasher of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York said the evidence in question was enough for a jury to resonably find that the defendants ''participated in a conspiracy to manipulate silver prices.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/09/world.main_headline: AFRICAN STUDENTS IN BEIJING MARCH IN OUTRAGE AT A RACIAL SLUR
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/09/world.print_headline: AFRICAN STUDENTS IN BEIJING MARCH IN OUTRAGE AT A RACIAL SLUR
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/09/world.body_text: **********About 200 chanting African university students, reacting to a racial provocation, marched more than 12 miles across Beijing from their campuses to the capital's embassy district today to protest an apparently fraudulent letter slurring their behavior and manners. **********More than 100 policemen, on foot, on motorcycles or in police vans, unsuccessfully tried to halt the protest march. All public demonstrations without a police permit have been banned in Beijing since Chinese students recently took to the streets to demonstrate for greater freedom. **********The demonstration today was the latest in sporadic protests over the last five years by African students, who have been invited to study on scholarships at Chinese universities and technical schools. Many African students have complained of being targets of shouted insults and rude behavior by Chinese students and other citizens. Attack on a Student Reported **********Several African students said they saw the letter, which was photocopied and surreptitiously distributed on several campuses, two days ago. On the same day, they asserted, a Chinese student attacked a Sudanese student in the Beijing Hotel downtown. **********''We are walking towards our great aim on a broad road opened to advanced and civilized world,'' said the letter, which was written in English and contained numerous errors in grammar. ''It doesn't mean however, that we will feed the whole uncultured Africa with the results of our efforts and we will allow any Negro to hang about our universities to annoy Chinese girls and to introduce on our academic ground manners acquired by life in tropical forests, offending our traditional hospitality and broad mindedness.'' **********The single-page letter warned that if the African students did not ''correct'' their behavior, ''new and even harder lessons of 'friendship' will follow.'' It added: ''They will be based on the experience of Americans, who know very well what to do to curb the Negroes in their country.'' Official Disclaimers **********The letter was signed, ''Students Association.'' Photocopies were also reportedly sent to some African embassies. **********The official New China News Agency, in denying the letter's veracity, reported that it had not been written by any official Chinese student organization, but had been circulated ''to cause friction between Chinese and African students.'' **********According to the press agency, a spokesman for the All-China Students Federation ''expressed strong indignation over the vicious trick of undermining Sino-African friendship.'' **********Previous demonstrations by African students have embarrassed the Chinese, who have sought to widen their diplomatic role in Africa and who maintain military and special diplomatic missions there. **********Last May, a riot erupted in Tianjin when hundreds of Chinese hurled stones at Africans holding a noisy party. In June, several hundred African students demonstrated in Beijing to protest the incident. The Chinese blamed foreigners for instigating the Tianjin riot. 'We Are Going Back' **********In 1983, a student from Burundi was attacked by workers at the Friendship Hotel in Beijing and had to be hospitalized. The workers were punished later. **********Today, as the protesting African students marched toward the Moroccan Embassy in the eastern part of the capital, they chanted and sang. **********''We are going back!'' a chant leader called. ''Africa!'' the marching students responded. Other students punctuated the rhythmic chant with whistle blasts. **********''You are not allowed to disturb security,'' a policeman declared over a loudspeaker mounted on a police car. ''You should obey the traffic policemen's orders.'' **********''We want to go back to Africa,'' one student marcher said. ''We come here in the name of friendship. If there is no friendship we cannot stay in the country.'' **********The Moroccan Ambassador, Abderrahim Harkett, who is the dean of the African diplomatic corps, was greeted with cheers and chants of ''Africa! Africa! Africa!'' when he emerged from his embassy to meet the students. Presenting Grievances **********Two students, one speaking English and the other French, presented the grievances of the demonstrators to the ambassador. **********''Our main objective here in China, which is studies, is also troubled,'' a student told the ambassador. ''The contents of this letter just manifest what has been happening in the past here in China. Why should we stay here in these universities to study when they don't want us.'' **********The leader said some African students were boycotting their examinations in protest against the letter. **********''I know that this problem is not a new problem,'' Ambassador Harkett told the students. ''It not only concerns African students but African diplomats. This morning I contacted the Ministry of Foreign Affairs for them to insure to me that the security and dignity of African students is maintained here in China.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/01/busin.main_headline: Cash-Rich Funds Hold Out for Fire Sale
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/01/busin.print_headline: INVESTING; Cash-Rich Funds Hold Out for Fire Sale
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/01/busin.body_text: **********MONEY managers who had built substantial cash positions as a defensive strategy before the stock market's collapse were in no hurry last week to return to buying common stocks. Even in the face of prices that would have appeared irresistible a month ago, the prevailing feeling among some of the country's more conservative investors, some of whom had as much as 50 percent of their portfolios in cash, was that the risk of a further decline outweighed any opportunity. **********''There are some great bargains, but we are saying, 'Give 'em to us cheaper,' '' said Samuel D. Hale, president of Hillside Associates, a Los Angeles firm that manages about $150 million. Mr. Hale, like most of the other managers who were interviewed, describes himself as value-oriented, which means that he buys stocks according to fairly strict standards measuring the price in relation to the company's earnings, cash flow, book value and other factors. **********But like many such players, Mr. Hale is holding back from buying bargains. The potential for a further market decline has become an overriding concern. **********''The market as an entity isn't undervalued; we're only back to fair valuation in terms of the averages,'' Mr. Hale said. ''Bear markets don't stop at fair valuation. They go to undervaluation.'' To tempt Mr. Hale, the Dow Jones industrial average would have to hit the 1,300 level, he said. **********Pessimism about the market's future was echoed, in degrees, at a number of firms. A common theme was fear that political and economic forces were locked at cross-purposes, with no resolution in sight. ''My assumption has always been that somehow or other the Western world muddles through,'' said Marc B. Franklin, who handles about $100 million in discretionary accounts at Bateman Eichler, Hill Richards in Palm Desert, Calif. ''My inclination is to believe that we will muddle through even this.'' **********Yet he has bought little in the last two weeks. Mr. Franklin's accounts on average entered the market break invested in secondary stocks that he regarded as undervalued, with, typically, 20 percent in cash reserves. The cash was ''wildly inadequate'' in the circumstances, he said. Mr. Hale, who held substantial cash in many accounts, concurred. ''The things that I thought were dripping with value in the over-the-counter market have imploded,'' he said. **********As the prices of large companies rose, many value-oriented managers had turned to smaller companies that appeared more attractively priced. In the last two weeks, the declines in smaller, more thinly traded stocks have exceeded the Dow average's slump, jolting even cash-laden managers. ''We were off 16 percent for the month,'' said Chuck Royce, president of the Quest Advisory Corporation, which acts as investment manager for the Pennsylvania Mutual Fund. The firm's accounts averaged about 30 percent cash reserves at the start of October. **********''By all traditional measures of value, if you assume only a moderate economic slowdown, some smaller companies' stock prices represent extraordinarily good value,'' Mr. Franklin said. But he believed some sectors still appeared substantially overvalued, such as cable television operators and biotechnology concerns. ''Is Genentech really worth $2 billion?'' he asked. **********Absent a washout that carries everything to low valuations, Mr. Franklin and some other managers are worried that too many investors remain complacent. ''You know what was really eerie?'' asked a West Coast investment adviser, who did not want to be identified. ''When the market dropped 500 points that day, I got calls from people who asked if we were buying for them. That isn't how it is at the bottom of a bear market. Then they say, 'I'm glad I'm out and don't ever put me back in.' '' Mr. Hale of Hillside concurred. ''At bear market bottoms, you see awful bargains that no one will want to buy,'' he said. **********Daniel R. Long 3d, president of Corbyn Associates, in Baltimore, which manages about $150 million, holds about 60 percent of the average account in cash and equivalents, some raised during the 508-point plunge on Oct. 19. Mr. Long said he had not been a significant buyer either for managed accounts or for the Greenspring Fund, which the firm manages. ''We think we'll have plenty of opportunity to buy,'' Mr. Long said. **********At the Janus Capital Corporation, in Denver, which directs about $1 billion, the main mutual funds were holding about 30 percent cash in early October - and 50 percent to 60 percent cash by last week, according to the firm's president, Thomas Bailey. Mr. Bailey said the funds retained securities such as telephone stocks and some pharmaceutical companies, where he believes much of the risk has been removed by lower prices. But he has not been a buyer. ''The best thing we can do for the clients is to manage the portfolios on a conservation-of-capital basis,'' he said. **********Jerry Carret, chief investment officer at Carret & Company, in New York, said his firm's accounts held up to 25 percent cash largely because the firm had not yet redeployed gains from takeovers and restructurings. Last week, Carret had ''started to nibble at a few things,'' he said. ''The good stuff is getting down to levels where people are looking for a horrendous depression, which is possible but I don't think is likely,'' he added. **********At Quest Advisory, Mr. Royce said: ''We're buying with our fingers crossed. We're finding the absolute kind of values that weren't present six months ago. We're buying companies selling very close to cash per share, with reasonable yields and real businesses that have sustained earning power. We can't tell when the market will bottom.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/09/busin.main_headline: STEEL PRICES HOLD FIRM, DESPITE RETURN OF USX
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/09/busin.print_headline: STEEL PRICES HOLD FIRM, DESPITE RETURN OF USX
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/09/busin.body_text: **********The nation's leading steel producers say that steel prices have remained firm despite the re-entry of the USX Corporation into the market. Some steel executives also predicted that prices would increase slightly this year, after years of going down. **********''We believe that price levels will be at least as good as last year and maybe a little better,'' said Walter F. Williams, chairman of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's third-largest steelmaker. ''It's about time that we, with all our efforts at cost reduction and quality improvement, that we get paid for the value added that we are putting into our product.'' **********Officials of large steel companies said their optimism is based on the fact that USX's return to the market will be gradual and that the nation's largest steelmaker has been reducing capacity. Also, the weaker dollar will continue to help fend off imports, they said. Analysts' Viewpoint **********Industry analysts see the situation differently, contending that the resumption of production at USX earlier this year after a six-month work stoppage is almost certain to create intense pressure among producers to discount prices. They say that the USX effect will begin to be felt in the market by midyear. **********They also see price-cutting pressure coming from an expected drop in demand from the automobile and oil industries. Many analysts have forecast that steel prices will fall this year by 2 to 5 percent. **********''The steel companies are saying that prices are holding up and that there is no difficulty,'' said Karlis M. Kiris, an analyst at Paine Webber Inc. ''But there is some nervousness. We are expecting prices to go down again this year. The only way prices can remain firm is for the steel companies to be willing to give up market share. And they are unwilling to do that.'' Depressed Prices **********Since 1984, steel prices have been depressed because of increased foreign competition, sagging demand and continued overcapacity. Steel companies have had huge losses and have responded by cutting operating expenses, trimming personnel and upgrading their operations. **********The current firmness in prices has come as a surprise to steel customers, who had anticipated declines following the acceptance of a new labor pact by union workers at USX. Analysts and customers had believed that USX, previously with about 18 percent of the nation's shipments, was certain to cut prices in a push to regain its market share. **********But USX's chairman, David M. Roderick, maintained that the company would not cut prices. He told reporters last month that the company intended to re-enter the market at the prevailing price level. **********''We are actually surprised by the price situation,'' said a top executive of a major steel company, who asked to remain anonymous. ''The USX people have behaved themselves very well and there hasn't been any discounting yet.'' **********Paul O'Hara, director of steel purchasing for the Ford Motor Company, said: ''Spot prices haven't started to move yet. Warehousers thought the prices were going to drop in January and February. But that hasn't happened yet.'' Some Supplies Are Tight **********Some customers said that the firmness in prices is in part a result of a surge in demand in recent months for cold-rolled steel, which is used in automobiles, appliances and furniture. **********''The supply of cold-rolled is tight right now,'' said Robert J. Klein, executive vice president of Worthington Industries, a metals fabricating company that is a large buyer of steel. **********''I haven't seen any change in prices so far after the strike,'' Mr. Kein said. ''That might very well change because some steel producer might try to break the pricing structure. But right now, prices are firm.'' **********The absence of USX's steel operations from the market bolstered the results of its competitors. The LTV Corporation, the nation's second-largest steelmaker, which is in bankruptcy reorganization, reported improved market conditions as a result of the USX shutdown. Also, troubled Bethelehem Steel reported a fourth-quarter profit for the third time in 20 quarters. **********Analysts point out that USX lost out on orders for delivery in the first quarter, since the shutdown did not end until January. They said that the second and third quarters would be a better test of pricing conditions, since USX's sales representatives had been trying for months to win orders for delivery then.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/13/world.main_headline: SOME GAINS IN WEST AFRICA'S WAR ON THE DESERT
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/13/world.print_headline: SOME GAINS IN WEST AFRICA'S WAR ON THE DESERT
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/13/world.body_text: **********A reddish orange cloud rose up in the north, blocking the early morning sun and bearing down on Gabriel Ouedraogo, who hurried from the fields to the shelter of a toolshed. **********''It's the desert,'' the farmer said as grains of sand carried by the storm cloud crackled against the shed's metal roof. **********Ten years ago, this was a wooded plain. Today it is a patchwork of fields dusted with sand and blotches of land turned bald by overgrazing, overcutting and overcultivating. War on Desertification **********Ten years ago this month, delegates gathered in Nairobi, Kenya, for a United Nations conference on desertification, in which marginal fields and pastures are turned into barren wasteland by human abuses, such as cutting down too many trees, and such natural factors as erosion. **********At the end, the delegates drew up a sweeping program aimed at stopping desertification by the year 2000. **********Behind the bold plan were memories of a 1973 drought that killed 100,000 to 250,000 people and 3.5 million cattle in the Sahel region of West Africa. That focused the greatest attention on the Sahel, an area encompassing nine countries: Burkina Faso, formerly known as Upper Volta, Cape Verde, Chad, Gambia, Guinea-Bissau, Mali, Mauritania, Niger and Senegal. #300 Missions in a Year Today, as it was 10 years ago, the Sahel is the largest area in the world to be threatened by a loss of arable land. **********Today, the Sahel receives the largest amount of foreign aid per capita of any region in the world. In one year alone, Burkina Faso, a nation of 7 million people, received 300 aid missions to improve rural water supplies. **********After a decade of various efforts, the results are mixed. **********Scientists say desertification is continuing. The Niger, Shari and Senegal rivers have dropped markedly since the late 1960's. Lake Chad has shrunk to about 800 square miles from 9,650 square miles in 1972. A Development Challenge **********But development experts say they have learned more effective ways of helping people in the Sahel slow the degradation of their land. **********Barely touched by a few decades of French colonialism, the traditional societies of the Sahel's fragile nations present an enormous development challenge. **********Spreading over an area 10 times as large as Spain, the Sahel has roughly the same population, 37 million. But, World Bank statistics list the total value of the Sahel's annual output of goods and services as just 4 percent of that of Spain. Pressures on a Fragile Land **********''It is hard to ask someone who is hungry to plant trees,'' said Mahamane Brah, executive secretary of the Permanent Interstate Committee for Drought Control in the Sahel, which represents all of the region's countries. **********The Sahel's growing population puts constant pressure on the fragile land, a transition zone between the Sahara in the north and the humid savanna in the south. In the Sahel, the average annual growth rate of the population is 2.6 percent, compared with nine-tenths of 1 percent for Spain. **********''The demographic growth is a major problem,'' Mr. Brah said in an interview in his office in Ouagadougou, the Burkina Faso capital. ''Where a family of five used to support itself on five acres, they now have two. The land no longer rests.'' 'Families Keep Going' **********In the fields here, Mr. Ouedraogo has seen more and more families move to Boussouma in recent years. They are fleeing the sand and exhausted land of northern Burkina Faso. **********''Now the families keep going to the south,'' he said, talking quietly in the glow of a kerosene lamp as the storm of sand and dust raged outside the tool shed. **********But even to the south, along the 50-mile stretch of road between here and Ouagadougou, the landscape is broken by patches of bare clay. **********Voracious goats chew all the greenery within reach, sometimes even leaping onto the lower branches of trees to eat the leaves. Trucks from Ougadougou drive out here to collect firewood for the city's burgeoning population. Reforestation Efforts **********In the last 20 years, the Sahel's urban population has quadrupled. The cities are now surrounded by ever-widening ''halos'' of deforestation, said Mr. Brah, whose group's slogan is ''A Green Sahel.'' **********''Before, in Timbuktu or Bamako, you could find wood one mile outside the city,'' he said, referring to Mali's two largest cities. ''Now you can go 30 miles before finding trees.'' **********Reforestation is a key component of anti-desertification programs that have been drawn up recently by each of the Sahelian countries. **********However, in a region where wood provides 80 percent to 90 percent of energy needs, progress to preserve and replant trees has been slow. Spreading the Word **********Each year, Sahelian nations strip trees from an area of 1,000 to 1,500 square miles, and only reforest a tenth of that, Mr. Brah estimated. **********Using radio, posters and women's groups to spread the word, Burkina Faso has one of the region's most ambitious wood-conservation programs. The Government promotes energy-efficient wood stoves, uses a state wood supply agency to limit abuses by woodcutters, urges citizens to mark family celebrations by planting a tree, and calls on volunteers to help plant the ''forest of the revolution.'' **********Despite this effort, Burkina Faso each year deforests about 230 square miles of land and replants only about 85 square miles, the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization says. **********''We found that forestry programs do not work very well if they are not integrated with agriculture and animal husbandry,'' Anne de Lattre, director of the Club du Sahel, said in a telephone interview from Paris. The Club coordinates Western donor aid to the region. Lack of Trained People **********She said that international donor funding to the Sahel had increased by an average of 4 percent a year over the last decade. But she said half of that went to ''survival'' assistance, largely for food and support for budgets. **********To Helmut Eger, a West German adviser to the Drought Control Committee, the problem is not lack of money, but of projects, and a need for outside experts, who are discouraged from working here by the difficult conditions. **********''I have never worked in a place where there are so many medical evacuations'' of aid workers due to the tropical heat and insect-bites, he said. Mr. Eger noted that during the dry season the low temperature in the Sahel, even at night, often is 100 degrees. **********''Almost every European here knows someone who has died - malaria, hepatitis A, hepatitis B,'' he said. **********Boussouma is one of 160 villages in Burkina Faso where West German technicians are overseeing a project to counter the degradation of farmland by slowing the runoff of water and soil nutrients. They are doing this by helping farmers such as Mr. Ouedraogo to revive the traditional Sahelian practice of building 12-inch-high stone dikes across their fields. **********As the rain lifted and the sun broke out, Mr. Ouedraogo, who works with Mr. Eger as an agricultural extension agent, ventured forth with the West German to show a visitor the village fields. **********Rivulets carrying away topsoil scored the fields without dikes. In the others, rich chocolate soil had clotted behind the dikes, and rainwater was soaking into the earth. **********''In two-and-a-half-acre test plots without the dikes, we get 1,000 pounds of soybeans,'' Mr. Eger said. ''With the dikes, the harvest is 2,500 pounds.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/29/world.main_headline: A GUARANTEE, AND AN ERA, FADE AWAY IN ZIMBABWE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/29/world.print_headline: HARARE JOURNAL; A GUARANTEE, AND AN ERA, FADE AWAY IN ZIMBABWE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/29/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Robert Mugabe is moving cautiously to abolish guaranteed white seats in Parliament in his drive to turn this multiparty democracy into a one-party state. **********When independence arrived in this country, formerly known as Rhodesia, the minority whites were guaranteed 20 seats in the 100-member Parliament for seven years to assure them of at least a residual political role in a land they once ruled. **********The seventh anniversary of Zimbabwe's independence this month meant that the guarantee of white seats, contained in a British-drafted constitution, could be abolished with the support of 70 members of Parliament. There is virtually no doubt in this southern African nation that Mr. Mugabe will have the guarantee of white seats scrapped. The only questions are when and how. **********The suspension from Parliament earlier this month of Ian D. Smith, the last white Prime Minister of Rhodesia, effectively ended a political career that spanned nearly four decades and foreshadowed the demise of the white seats. Mr. Smith fought independence by leading his white followers into a fierce conflict with black nationalists. Opposed Pretoria Sanctions **********The suspension was voted because Mr. Smith called Zimbabwe's decision to impose economic sanctions against South Africa ''stupid,'' and urged Pretoria to fight international pressure to dismantle apartheid. **********Mr. Mugabe has long said that the guaranteed white seats gave whites representation far out of proportion to their numbers. There are 110,000 whites in this nation of eight million. **********Mr. Mugabe's Zimbabwe African National Union-Patriotic Front has 66 seats in Parliament and is confident that it can get the four votes needed to abolish the white seats, perhaps when Parliament reconvenes in June. **********It had been thought that talks intended to merge the ruling party and the minority party of Joshua Nkomo, the Prime Minister's longtime political enemy, would easily provide the 70 votes needed. But the Prime Minister recently said the talks had failed. Mugabe Moving Cautiously **********Government officials said they were confident that some Nkomo supporters, along with some of the five white independent legislators and the sole white member of Parliament in Mr. Mugabe's party, would vote to scrap the white seats. **********The Prime Minister has said he wants to set aside the white seats immediately. But he appears to be moving cautiously. **********Zimbabwean and foreign political analysts said Mr. Mugabe must weigh several concerns. Most whites are politically apathetic, they said, but it would be in the Prime Minister's interest to keep at least some ''token'' whites in Parliament in recognition of the minority's economic dominance. **********It would also show that Mr. Mugabe was continuing his policy of racial reconciliation, the analysts said, and play well before foreign audiences. Few Whites Upset **********Few whites appear to be concerned about the coming transition, having anticipated it for some time. Life for many whites is still sweet by any standards in a country with socialist goals but capitalist underpinnings. **********After independence perhaps 100,000 whites left, most of them for South Africa. Now they are slowly returning, and many acknowledge that their worst fears about a black-ruled country have not been realized. **********The swimming pools and sprawling homes of a wealthy white elite, waited on by black servants, punctuate the landscape of this tidy capital city and highlight the economic power whites retain. These whites are cosmopolitan, with foreign bank accounts and large commercial holdings. They see their political future not in voting but in lobbying Government ministries that oversee their special interests. **********Another white culture, including blue-collar workers, is struggling to make ends meet, however. These whites apparently felt threatened by the black government. But they now appear resigned, and the talk these days among both the elite and the working class is not so much about politics as about the rising cost of living, crime and the ailing economy. **********The Government must also decide how the 20 seats, once vacated by whites, would be filled. There must be a full 100-seat Parliament until 1990, when the constitution may be rewritten and the next election is scheduled. **********An early general election has been all but ruled out, according to Government officials, because it would require costly administrative tasks. One official said the Justice Minister was considering an electoral college made up of black members of Parliament that would elect legislators, black or white, to the 20 seats. Smith Seen as Disruptive **********Mr. Smith, 68 years old, a craggy-faced man who has remained outspoken and unrepentant, is portrayed by many whites here as discredited and disruptive to race relations. **********In 1985, in the first general election since independence, Mr. Smith's party - its power eroded by a mass defection of legislators - won 15 of the 20 white seats. Blacks saw his unexpected victory as whites choosing confrontation over cooperation, and Mr. Mugabe was visibly angered. **********White independent members of Parliament supported Mr. Smith's suspension. Mr. Smith could not be reached for comment. **********Mark Partridge, a member of Mr. Smith's party, the Conservative Alliance of Zimbabwe, said Mr. Smith's suspension highlighted the ''dual approach'' among whites. **********''There is one approach that says the Government is corrupt, with nepotism and tribalism,'' Mr. Partridge said. ''These Europeans say the best way to look after our rights is not to stand up for principle.'' **********''The other approach - our approach - is that the Government is inexperienced but not unintelligent,'' he added. ''Things must be based on reason and principle, and, where we can't go along with something, we must say so.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/31/world.main_headline: ACCORD IS ELUSIVE ON STRATEGIC ARMS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/31/world.print_headline: ACCORD IS ELUSIVE ON STRATEGIC ARMS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/31/world.body_text: **********Despite hints of flexibility by American and Soviet officials, an agreement to reduce long-range arms is not yet within grasp, Administration officials say. **********In a joint announcement today, the United States and the Soviet Union signaled that both sides did not want to settle for an agreement banning only medium- and shorter-range missiles. **********The announcement stressed that the two sides wanted to work toward a more important agreement reducing long-range arms that could be signed during a visit by President Reagan to Moscow in 1988. But several difficult hurdles remain. Principal among them is a profound disagreement over the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty - a matter that Soviet officials still say must be resolved before a treaty on long-range arms can be completed. Differences on Method **********Even if the two sides could resolve this critical question, there would still be significant differences over how to cut long-range arms. **********On the ABM treaty, the gulf between the two sides still appears wide, though Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the ''tone'' of the dialogue seemed more positive. **********Under the latest position advanced by Moscow, the Soviet Union insists that each side promise not to withdraw from the ABM treaty for 10 years. The United States has offered to observe the treaty through 1994, though some Administration officials have hinted that Washington might be flexible on this count. **********After his meetings with Mr. Shultz and Mr. Reagan, Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze said this dispute over the period of adherence to the treaty remained. **********A further question is what to do after the pledge not to withdraw from the treaty has expired. U.S. Wants 'Star Wars' **********The United States wants a green light at this point to proceed with the deployment of a space-based missile defense. American officials also stress that the two sides would remain bound to the terms of the new treaty reducing long-range arms after adherence to the ABM treaty was dropped. **********But Soviet officials today reportedly repeated their argument that each side should be free to build up their arsenal of long-range arms if the ABM treaty is abandoned. **********The key issue has been how the ABM treaty should be interpreted. **********Last month, Soviet officials said they had proposed that each side adhere to the traditional, strict interpretation of the ABM treaty, which restricts the testing and deployment of anti-missile systems. So far, the Reagan Administration has insisted on the right to interpret the treaty broadly so as to allow an expanded pattern of ''Star Wars'' testing. Moscow Flexibility Seen **********One senior Administration official asserted today that Moscow might be flexible on this issue. He asserted that Mikhail S. Gorbachev's letter to Mr. Reagan did not repeat earlier Soviet language about strengthening the ABM treaty and stressed the importance of agreeing on a period of non-withdrawal from the treaty. Nor does the letter explicitly restate an earlier Soviet proposal that experts meet to clarify what testing is allowed in space, though one official said the letter appeared to allude to this possibility. **********This, he asserted, showed that nailing down a period of non-withdrawal from the treaty was more of a priority for Moscow than securing American agreement to a strict interpretation. **********But another senior Administration official disagreed with this interpretation. He said that the letter did not signal any basic change in the Soviet position on interpreting the treaty, but he added that the Soviet position was simply ''packaged'' in a way that was more subtle than some previous proposals. **********Mr. Shevardnadze told reporters the two sides did not talk about treaty interpretation today, but he asserted there was no change in the Soviet position. **********On long-range arms, Viktor P. Karpov, head of the arms control section of the Soviet Foreign Ministry, was said to have rejected today the American demand that a limit of 4,800 be set on the number of warheads on ballistic missiles.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/21/busin.main_headline: FOUNDER JOINS BID FOR CRAZY EDDIE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/21/busin.print_headline: FOUNDER JOINS BID FOR CRAZY EDDIE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/21/busin.body_text: **********In a surprise move, Eddie Antar, the founder and chairman of Crazy Eddie Inc., came out of seclusion yesterday to join the Belzberg family of Canada in a $187 million offer to buy all of the stock of Crazy Eddie and take it private. **********The offer raised eyebrows on Wall Street, which had already been confused by Mr. Antar's sale last November of about 30 percent of his stake in the company and his subsequent resignation in January as the electronics retailer's president and chief executive officer. Analysts have also been troubled by Crazy Eddie's declining profitability. **********When Mr. Antar resigned, rumors circulated that he had been ill. But he appeared at a Crazy Eddie board meeting yesterday morning and informed the company's directors of the offer. A letter then officially notified the company that Newco, an entity formed by Mr. Antar and the First City Capital Corporation, an investment company owned by the Belzbergs, would offer shareholders $7 a share in cash as part of a negotiated merger transaction. **********The stock was initially offered to the public in September 1984 at $8 a share, and after dropping, it climbed as high as $21.625 in 1986. Last November Mr. Antar sold more than 1.5 million shares at prices ranging from $15 to $19. **********The bidders said that they already owned 14 percent of Crazy Eddie's 31.3 million common shares outstanding. Mr. Antar owns 11 percent and the Belzbergs the remainder. **********The board of Crazy Eddie, based in Edison, N.J., said only that it would consider the unsolicited offer. A company spokesman said yesterday afternoon that a committee of outside directors had been appointed to review the offer and would shortly appoint a financial adviser. Neither Mr. Antar nor the Belzbergs could be reached for comment. Crazy Eddie Stock Soars **********Crazy Eddie stock closed up $2.625, at $7.875, in over-the-counter trading yesterday. The fact that the stock price closed higher than the offer suggested to some that another bid from the group could be forthcoming. **********''I think that the offer is just the first gambit in a game to put the stock in play,'' said Barry Bryant, retail analyst for Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. ''I think the stock may well go to $10. But what Eddie Antar is up to can range from really wanting to buy the company to trying to liquidate the family holdings. The Belzbergs, I think, just see it as an undervalued stock and therefore an opportunity.'' **********In New York's frenetically competitive electronics market, Crazy Eddie, long the exponent of television come-ons with its ''Prices Are Insane'' slogan, recently has suffered a falling stock price, declining Christmas business in its older stores and Wall Street skepticism, much of it attributed to the mysterious withdrawal of Mr. Antar. A Mystifying Withdrawal **********The company's founder has become inaccessible to analysts, some of whom had earlier recommended his company with considerable enthusiasm, and a three-man ''office of the president'' created after his resignation has also not been available to outsiders. **********The combination of Mr. Antar's unexplained withdrawal and his recent disposition of some of his holdings in the company he founded in 1975 was a source of much discussion among analysts yesterday. **********After a stunning success in building the retail chain to more than 30 stores in the Middle Atlantic area, Mr. Antar not only resigned from the high posts but sold a large block of his stock at a considerable profit, Stock Price Declines As sales at Crazy Eddie's older stores fell 9 percent last Christmas and the company pulled back on a home-shopping plan announced last December, the stock value fell sharply. And now Mr. Antar's return with an offer to take the company private at less than half what he had sold the stock for in November appeared to Wall Street observers to raise many questions. **********''We on Wall Street got so that we began to feel that the expression 'anything is possible' was just a cliche,'' said Mr. Bryant of Drexel Burnham. ''But now, if you consider Eddie Antar's absence, his motives and his stock sales, I guess the cliche is reality.'' **********A number of shareholder lawsuits have been filed against both Crazy Eddie and Mr. Antar in connection with his share sale last fall. Lawyers said yesterday that they expected the move by Mr. Antar to buy the company would start a new round of suits challenging the offer. A Troubling Fiscal Year **********In the fiscal year ended March 1, Crazy Eddie's net income fell 19.7 percent, to $10.6 million, or 34 cents a share, from $13.2 million, or 48 cents a share, the year before. Sales, however, rose 34.4 percent, to $352.5 million, from $262.3 million, reflecting the opening of several stores. **********The profit erosion resulted from rapidly growing competition from Newmark & Lewis, The Wiz and Trader Horn, among others. Matching prices promoted by Crazy Eddie, the competitors also used gimmicks like free boat rides, contests and unusual store-opening hoopla. But like Crazy Eddie, they appeared to be in a trap of constant price cutting from which they were not entirely eager to escape. It meant customers. **********In their offer, the bidders said that they would allow the company's senior management to participate in Newco's equity. They said that they had retained Bear, Stearns & Company to assist them in arranging financing. **********The Belzbergs in recent years have invested in a number of American companies and later sold their holdings at a good profit.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/30/world.main_headline: SENATE PANEL URGES LEVELING OF EMBASSY IN SOVIET
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/30/world.print_headline: SENATE PANEL URGES LEVELING OF EMBASSY IN SOVIET
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/30/world.body_text: **********The Senate intelligence committee today unanimously recommended the demolition of the chancery building for the new Moscow embassy, saying it was compromised by Soviet listening devices. **********The panel's report on the State Department's security procedures at the existing embassy and at the new embassy complex is not binding. But senior members of the intelligence panel said the Senate Appropriations Committee would move soon to cut off the money needed to complete the chancery. **********''It's time to stop the buck-passing and to make a decision to start over,'' Senator David L. Boren, Democrat of Oklahoma, who is chairman of the intelligence committee, said at a news conference. He said the panel had voted 15 to 0 to approve the 18-page report. **********The cost of the embassy project, which includes apartments and other quarters, is estimated at $192 million. The chancery, where sensitive business is conducted, was expected to cost $65 million, of which $23 million has already been spent. **********Administration officials disclosed today that an initial sweep of the present Moscow embassy room used for sensitive conversations - the bubble room - has found no listening devices. American intelligence analysts suspect that Soviet agents planted devices in that room after being allowed to enter secure areas by Marine guards who now face espionage charges. Bubble Rooms Shipped to U.S.  Administration officials said the bubble rooms in Moscow and Vienna are being dismantled and shipped to the United States at a cost of millions of dollars. The officials said it could take months to complete minute examinations of the contents and structures of the rooms before they could be certain whether Soviet agents left behind any eavesdropping equipment. **********At a meeting this month with Secretary of State George P. Shultz, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, scoffed at reports that Soviet agents had entered the embassy, Administration officials said. According to one account of the conversation provided by an American official, Mr. Gorbachev assured Mr. Shultz that there had been no entry into the embassy. **********Mr. Gorbachev's remark was considered highly unusual by counterintelligence experts, who noted that in no case in recent memory had the Soviet Union offered a similar reassurance. **********Administration officials said they were proceeding on the ''worst-case'' assumption that significant damage resulted from the Marine guards' purported espionage. The major evidence that Soviet agents were permitted to enter the embassy was a statement to investigators, since recanted, by Cpl. Arnold Bracy, one of the Marines accused of spying. Serious Harm May Have Resulted **********Robert Lamb, the senior State Department official responsible for embassy security, said in an interview today that he still thought the case had caused serious harm. But he said it would probably be months before intelligence experts could be precise about the scope and nature of the damage. **********The Senate intelligence committee report, based on testimony at three closed hearings, said the worst-case assessments presume that Soviet agents had access for hours at a time to ''the most sensitive areas of the embassy.'' **********That would give the Russians time to penetrate all the locks and alarms, forcing intelligence analysts to presume that all documents and communications had been compromised. **********The report blames the State Department for many of the security shortcomings that lead to embassy guards' alleged espionage, and to the compromise of the new chancery building. Report's Recommendations **********It called for polygraph examinations of each Marine ending a tour abroad and ''counterintelligence'' investigations of any rules infraction, like black-market currency dealings or socializing with local women. The report was also sharply critical of the alarm system in the Moscow embassy, saying the reliance on the honesty of the Marines left the compound with a ''single failure point.'' **********More generally, the report said that the security and building aspects of the State Department were ''fragmented and scattered in at least three different major organizational units.'' **********It called on the State Department to combine all of the units into one, and have them report directly to the Secretary of State. **********The most detailed criticism was reserved for the new embassy. In 1972, the Nixon Administration agreed to permit the Soviet Union to prefabricate off-site the concrete slabs at the new embassy. American officials did not insist on the right to inspect the work while the concrete was being poured. **********Beginning in 1979, the State Department began finding listening devices in the building. Construction was not halted until 1985. Today, Senator William S. Cohen, the Maine Republican who is vice chairman of the intelligence committee, said it would take two to three years for the intelligence experts to determine whether the building could be salvaged. ''We're not going to wait two to three years to find out the building is one giant antenna,'' he said. **********Senator Cohen also said he favored legislation to eject the Soviet Union from its new embassy, which is on one of the highest points in Washington. The Russians have not occupied the chancery of that building, but are using its apartments at a site intelligence officials say is ideally suited to intercept electronic communications. **********Other recommendations in the report include removing foreign employees from other United States embassies worldwide and shortening the Marine guards' tour of duty.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/09/world.main_headline: Kemp, in Honduras, Assails Latin Peace Plan
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/09/world.print_headline: Kemp, in Honduras, Assails Latin Peace Plan
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/09/world.body_text: **********Representative Jack F. Kemp opened a campaign today to persuade Central America's leaders that the peace plan they signed last month is in his words ''fundamentally flawed'' and ''a recipe for disaster'' in the region. **********Mr. Kemp, a New York Republican who is seeking his party's Presidential nomination, arrived in Honduras this morning along with more than 50 leaders of conservative groups. **********Accompanying the group from the United States was Adolfo Calero, a leader of the Nicaraguan contra rebels. **********Mr. Kemp said the trip was also intended ''to let Congress and the White House know we are not willing to relax our efforts to continue aid to the freedom fighters.'' Seeks Aid for Contras **********Mr. Kemp, along with Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, is the author of a bill to provide $310 million in assistance to the contras over the next 18 months. Congressional authority to provide military aid to the contra forces is due to expire Sept. 30. **********Under a peace plan signed by the leaders of Costa Rica, Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras and Nicaragua last month, cease-fires are to begin in both Nicaragua and El Salvador on Nov. 7 and outside assistance to insurgents in Central America is to stop. **********Reagan Administration officials have expressed at least lukewarm support for the peace plan. They have said that they might seek additional aid for the contras if the plan, which includes pledges by the Nicaraguan Governments to declare amnesty and lift restrictions on dissent, were to falter. **********For Mr. Kemp and other conservatives, the primary flaw in the peace plan is that while it calls on the United States to halt assistance to the Nicaraguan rebels, it allows the Soviet Union and Cuba to continue to supply the Nicaraguan Government. Doubts From Honduran **********Late this afternoon Mr. Kemp met with President Jose Azcona Hoyo of Honduras. Mr. Kemp said Mr. Azcona told him he did not believe Congress needed to end aid to the contras to comply with the peace plan. **********''He told us that he thinks aid to the contras should continue until the Nicaraguan regime fulfills its pledges to democratize,'' Mr. Kemp said, and added, ''The President does not expect a totalitarian Marxist Government will be able to change between now and Nov. 7.'' **********Speaking with Mr. Kemp and members of his group, the United States Ambassador to Honduras, Everett E. Briggs, said a cutoff of aid to the contras would lead to the consolidation of power by Nicaragua's Marxist rulers, and that in turn would lead to a new influx of refugees from Nicaragua to Honduras. The situation, he added, would be dangerously destabilizing ''to Honduras's pro-American Government.'' **********United States officials estimate there are already as many as 110,000 Nicaraguan refugees in Honduras. **********This morning, Mr. Kemp and Mr. Calero visited a contra base in Honduras, which has not acknowledged the presence of rebel bases on its territory. Reporters were barred from the visit.
