https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/09/world.main_headline: SCHLESINGER SAYS MOSCOW BUGGING MEANS EMBASSY MUST BE REBUILT
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/09/world.print_headline: SCHLESINGER SAYS MOSCOW BUGGING MEANS EMBASSY MUST BE REBUILT
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/09/world.body_text: **********The new United States Embassy must undergo a major reconstruction because it is riddled with bugging devices so sophisticated that American intelligence agents do not fully understand them, the American assigned to investigate the problem said today. **********The investigator, James R. Schlesinger, a former Secretary of Defense and former Director of Central Intelligence, said the Soviet bugging devices represented ''a higher plateau of technology'' than the United States had seen. He indicated that Soviet intelligence services are ahead of the United States in this area. **********Mr. Schlesinger estimated today that building new secure areas would cost ''many tens of millions of dollars'' and require renegotiation of a contract with the Soviet Government. Simultaneous Occupancy **********In a preview of recommendations he plans to make to Secretary of State George P. Shultz, Mr, Schlesinger said that much of the uncompleted eight-story office building, or chancery, can be salvaged, but only for diplomatic work that does not require a high degree of security. **********Under a 15-year-old Soviet-American agreement, the two sides are to occupy their new chancery structures - the Soviet Union has nearly completed one in northwest Washington - at the same time. If the American structure has to be rebuilt, this could indefinitely postpone Soviet occupancy of its new office building. **********The brick American office building is part of a new embassy complex that has already cost an estimated $190 million. The apartments, commissary, restaurant and recreational facilities are already in use and are not affected by the security problems, but the diplomats walk to work in the old embassy, a nearby block of aging, converted apartment buildings. Bugs in the Beams **********Mr. Schlesinger was asked to investigate the chancery building last year, as American intelligence experts continued to discover listening devices implanted in precast concrete pillars and beams. **********Since the spring, some members of Congress have been expressing outrage at the bugging and have suggested that the building be demolished. The Administration has declined to comment on the fate of the building until Mr. Schlesinger makes his report. **********Today, Mr. Schlesinger faulted American officials for ''naivete'' and ''complacency'' in allowing Soviet workers to prefabricate concrete components of the new building away from the construction site. **********He said X-ray machines were used to screen the concrete slabs brought to the site, but that the Soviet Union had developed listening devices invisible to conventional screening. **********Mr. Schlesinger, who was assisted in his study by American intelligence agencies and private consultants, seemed impressed by what he called ''ingenious'' Soviet advances in eavesdropping technology. A New Detection Device **********''This is one of those areas in which there is, to say the least, no technological gap between the United States and the Soviet Union,'' Mr. Schlesinger said. ''If there is a technology gap it tends to run the other way. The United States is more capable in some respects of producing certain types of devices, but the Soviet Union has been more ingenious in exploiting the technology.'' **********''Their tradecraft has been impressive,'' the former C.I.A. director added. ''Were it not for the fact that we had a new detection device, this would have gone undetected.'' **********He did not describe the special features of the bugging devices except to say that they were invisible to X-ray machines used to screen building materials at the embassy site. **********Much remains unknown to American security experts about the honeycomb of devices, he said, including how the network was supposed to work, whether it was operational, whether all of the devices have been discovered, and whether they could be neutralized by American technology. The Prudent Choice **********Because it would take years to answer those questions, he said, the prudent choice would be a major overhaul. **********Mr. Schlesinger said the rapidly rising sophistication of Soviet eavesdropping technology also raises more serious concern about the physical security of embassy buildings. If unauthorized people get into a building to plant devices, he said, it is no longer clear that the bugs can be detected in an electronic sweep. **********Mr. Schlesinger said that if the Soviet Union cooperates in renegotiating the 1972 agreement under which embassy construction was begun, it would still take at least two and a half years before the building could be occupied. **********Without such cooperation, he said, the date when American diplomats could begin using the new offices ''might even be decades in the future.'' Risk for U.S.-Soviet Relations **********Mr. Schlesinger said senior Soviet officials he talked to this week seemed to appreciate that a failure to cooperate would damage Soviet-American relations and prevent Soviet diplomats from occupying their own newly built embassy building in Washington. **********He said that in his meetings with Soviet officials he also raised the issue of financial compensation for the bugging damage, but ''did not proceed very far.'' **********The Soviet Union insisted, as part of the 1972 agreement, on having much of the building prefabricated away from the site, arguing that this was the usual procedure in the Soviet Union. Mr. Schlesinger said a review of records found that American officials did not strongly resist, and filed few protests during the course of construction. **********''As one looks at the agreement in retrospect, there is no conclusion that can be drawn other than that it was a mistake to create conditions in which Soviets were allowed to precast elements of this facility off site,'' he said. ''That created an opporunity, I might even say a temptation, that no one engaged in that line of business was likely to be able to resist.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/05/world.body_text: **********The Communist leadership of Albania, moving gradually out of a long period of self-imposed isolation, will establish diplomatic ties with West Germany this month, according to officials in Bonn and Washington. **********This and other diplomatic moves by Albania seem to be opening the country more to the West, while maintaining coolness toward Soviet-bloc nations. But there seems to be no prospect of a warming toward the United States. **********In a speech June 25 in Tirana, the capital, President Ramiz Alia said negotiations begun three years ago between Albania and West Germany were ''being concluded.'' **********At the same time, Mr. Alia invited Britain to open talks on establishing diplomatic ties, saying it was time to unfreeze the relationship after a break between the two nations 41 years ago. Mr. Alia said the British would find ''a readiness to talk.'' Dropping Reparations Claims **********His disclosure of the imminent diplomatic ties with West Germany and the prospect of talks with Britain appears to indicate that Albania has given up a series of extravagant claims for reparations from West Germany and demands for the unilateral return of Albanian gold sequestered by Britain, France and the United States at the end of World War II. **********A decade ago, Tirana was insisting that West Germany owed $4.5 billion in damages from the wartime occupation of Albania by Hitler's armies, a claim the Bonn Government rejected. Though paying no reparations, West Germany is apparently preparing to make some generous investments in Albania. **********The issue of the Albanian gold, valued at about $36 million, is complicated by a British claim for compensation arising from the Corfu Channel incident, in which 38 sailors were killed when two British destroyers struck mines near the coast of Albania in 1946. Britain later won a World Court decision awarding it compensation, but Albania disclaimed responsibility for the mining. **********The incident led to the breach in relations between the two nations. The United States ended relations with Albania about the same time, in protest against harassment of American diplomats by the newly established Communist Government. **********Talks between London and Tirana on the gold and the Corfu Channel claim began two years ago, but now President Alia seems to be saying the two Governments should move on and discuss resumption of diplomatic relations. Keeping Superpowers Apart **********Britain will take up the Albania issues with the United States before sounding out Tirana on Mr. Alia's overture, an Administration official said. In the last dozen years the United States has periodically proposed a dialogue with Albania leading to re-establishing ties, but has been rebuffed by Tirana. The Soviet Union has made similar proposals and has also been rebuffed. **********Like his predecessor, Enver Hoxha, who died in 1985, President Alia seems determined to keep the two superpowers at arm's length, while steadily broadening contacts with smaller countries in the East and West. The rationale for this, repeatedly articulated by Mr. Hoxha and now by Mr. Alia, is the assertion that both the Soviet Union and the United States grossly interfered in Albanian affairs in the past and would like to do so again. **********In the last four years, Albania has greatly improved relations with Italy, France, Greece, Algeria, Rumania and, more recently, Turkey. In each case, Albania has sought to improve its foreign economic ties and to bring more modern technology into the country. **********For instance, with the Turks, whose forefathers ruled Albania for 500 years until 1912, the Alia Government has concluded agreements on trade, tourism, exchanges of parliamentary delegations and cooperation between the universities of Ankara and Tirana. Criticism of Yugoslavia **********In light of this gradual emergence from a shell of hostility toward much of the rest of the world, the only anomaly in Albania's current foreign relationships involves neighboring Yugoslavia. **********In his speech June 25, Mr. Alia heaped scorn on the Belgrade Government, saying, ''Yugoslavia is to blame for the fact that bilateral relations are burdened by complex and insoluble problems.'' He then referred to the problems of Kosovo, the autonomous region of the Yugoslav republic of Serbia, which has been the scene of repeated nationalist demonstrations by ethnic Albanians who constitute the majority of the region's population. There are almost two million ethnic Albanians in Yugoslavia, most of them residing in Kosovo. Albania's population is three million. **********Belgrade's reaction to the Alia speech was generally one of dismay and bitterness. **********The paradoxical aspect of the Yugoslav-Albanian relationship is that while excoriating the Belgrade authorities, the Tirana Government continues a flourishing trade and other contacts with Yugoslavia. A Principal Trading Partner **********Yugoslavia is Albania's principal trading partner, selling a variety of manufactured goods and buying petroleum and electrical power. Last year Yugoslavia completed its part of a railway line linking Albania's small rail system to the railroads of the rest of Europe.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/20/busin.body_text: **********Philip Joanou, the chairman and chief executive of Dailey & Associates, Los Angeles, will be recognized for developing the concept for the advertising industry's anti-drug campaign. On Thursday he will accept one of the 1987 Awards for Private Sector Initiatives from President Reagan. **********Mr. Joanou will take the award on behalf of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, at whose 1985 board meeting he first proposed what has become one of the largest public- service efforts in the history of the advertising industry. Some $1.5 billion of advertising space and time is expected to be donated over three years to dry up the demand for illegal drugs. **********The ceremony will be held in the Rose Garden at the White House.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/30/busin.main_headline: Sears to Acquire Eye Care Chain
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/30/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Sears to Acquire Eye Care Chain
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/30/busin.body_text: **********Sears, Roebuck & Company said it planned to acquire Eye Care Centers of America Inc. for $52.4 million. Eye Care, based in San Antonio, said that Sears had agreed to pay $2.50 a share for the company's common stock. Edward A. Brennan, chairman of Sears, said the acquisition was part of a plan to expand Sears's presence in specialty retailing. **********Eye Care operates 41 optical stores in Arizona, California, Louisiana, New Mexico and Texas, under the names Eye Pro Express, 20/20 Eyecare and Eye Masters. The stores offer eye-wear products and prescription lenses. Jack V. Gunion, chief executive of Eye Care, would retain his post. Completion of the transaction is subject to approval by Eye Care shareholders and other conditions, Sears said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/13/world.main_headline: Timing of U.S. Effort to Sell Missiles Said to Have Hurt Influence in Gulf
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/13/world.print_headline: SAUDI ARMS RETREAT; Timing of U.S. Effort to Sell Missiles Said to Have Hurt Influence in Gulf
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/13/world.body_text: **********By seeking to sell Maverick air-to-ground missiles to Saudi Arabia and then abruptly withdrawing the proposal Thursday, the Reagan Administration appears to have erected a new hurdle in its efforts to restore American credibility in the Persian Gulf. **********Politicians, lobbyists and even some Government officials say they believe that the Administration blundered badly, timing the proposal poorly and miscalculating Congressional reaction. The episode has also underscored the worsening relations between the Administration and Congress on foreign-policy issues. **********Further, it has exposed continuing problems within the executive decision-making process as the Administration enters its final 18 months. **********Despite overwhelming Congressional opposition to the planned sale, the National Security Council, the State Department and the Defense Department had agreed that sticking with the proposal and possibly losing in Congress would be less damaging to American interests in the Persian Gulf than backing away from a longstanding commitment to Saudi Arabia. 'Widespread Frustration' **********This was especially true, officials argued, at a moment when the Saudis were close to granting American requests to permit Saudi-based early warning electronic surveillance aircraft, known as Awacs, to patrol a larger part of the gulf as part of American efforts to protect shipping. **********Middle East experts at the Pentagon and State Department also felt ''widespread frustration,'' one official said, that their advice was ignored by the White House. **********The specialists, having been bypassed in the secret arms sales to Iran, were trying to design a policy to repair American credibility in the Persian Gulf and felt they needed to demonstrate a steadfast American commitment to the security of the gulf in the midst of the Iran-Iraq war. **********''It's a question of our reliability,'' said Richard W. Murphy, Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs, who called the Congressional opposition to the proposed sale a ''slap across the face.'' 'The Wrong Signal' **********President Reagan said, ''This action precipitated by Congress sends exactly the wrong signal.'' **********The White House, which said it would re-introduce the plan later, reportedly felt that more conflicting signals would be sent to gulf states by pushing ahead in the face of inevitable defeat. **********Under the law, Congress has 30 days in which to block a proposed arms sale. Resolutions of disapproval, introduced in the House by Lawrence J. Smith, Democrat of Florida, and in the Senate by Bob Packwood, Republican of Oregon, had gained enough co-sponsors to override a Presidential veto. **********Officials said it was too early to tell whether the withdrawal would affect Saudi policy. Arab nations in the gulf have hesitated to give overt military support to the United States, partly for fear of exposing themselves to attack or sabotage by Iran. No Plans for U.S. Bases **********A Pentagon official said, for example, that there were no plans to seek basing rights in gulf states for American fighter planes that could protect American ships. ''That's not very realistic to expect,'' he said. **********Much of the Congressional opposition to the missile sale was generated by the impression that Saudi Arabia had failed to cooperate militarily with the United States. **********On May 17, after an Iraqi plane attacked the United States frigate Stark in the gulf, killing 37 seamen, Saudi pilots declined an air controller's request to intercept the jet. Peak of Anxiety **********But Administration officials argued that the Saudi pilots behaved properly. They said the Saudis were under orders to defend only their own territory and Awacs aircraft. **********The trouble was, the Administration submitted the sale plan to Congress just 12 days after the attack on the Stark, at the peak of anxiety over gulf policy. An official said the submission, which had been scheduled for the week before the Stark incident, had been delayed at Congressional request. **********In any event, he added, no Congressional opposition to the missile sale had been raised during informal discussions dating from last November. **********The 1,600 Mavericks that were to be sold are more advanced versions of missiles that had been approved for sale in 1984, but were not actually purchased by the Saudis. **********The Saudis already had about 2,600 Mavericks of an earlier design, in which each missile is guided by a television camera, limiting its use to daytime and clear weather. 'Going to Cut and Run?' **********The later version relies on an infrared sensor, which detects heat emissions and can be used at night and in bad weather. **********But the Mavericks are not the real issue, one senior official said. ''What is building here is a fundamental political choice on the part of the United States,'' he said. ''Are we going to continue to be engaged east of Suez, or are we going to follow the British? Are we going to stay, or are we going to cut and run? It's a very fundamental decision, which people are not addressing because it's a very painful one.'' **********It is made more painful by a decline in Congressional confidence in the Administration. ''There is a very great deal of concern, and among some people it edges over toward alarm, that we have no foreign-policy decision-making system,'' said Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York. ''The possibility of awful mistakes looms on every horizon.'' **********On arms negotiations with Moscow, he said: ''There is a feeling that they're going to rush to a summit and sign an agreement, any agreement. You hear that among conservative Republicans. From liberal Democrats you hear they're going to rush to war. There are very few points in the spectrum where there is not great anxiety.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/30/world.main_headline: Outlook for Mozambique: A Drought and a Civil War
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/30/world.print_headline: Outlook for Mozambique: A Drought and a Civil War
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/30/world.body_text: **********The rusty ferryboat, loaded with Red Cross supplies and too many passengers, made a serpentine course on what they call the River of Good Signs, chugging past flamingoes and pelicans and lone men in dugout canoes. The boat pulled up to a flat, muddy bank lined by a crowd of people suddenly gathered under the coconut palms. **********There were young mothers so thin they could scarcely nurse their infants, men whose thin legs stuck out from tattered shorts, children with hollow eyes and distended bellies. They are the displaced people of Mozambique's ongoing civil war. They are here amidst the stucco ruins of a Portuguese settler's farm to be sustained by gifts of Western grain, clothing, soap and medicine. **********By any standard, Mozambique, torn by the decade-old civil war, is in desperate shape, badly in need of sustenance from the outside. **********Contrary to dire forecasts made here some months ago, when Mozambique's Marxist Government asked for emergency food supplies, famine does not seem to have been widespread - at least not in the areas where information can be collected. **********Since the Government's appeal to the United Nations early this year, thousands of tons of donated food and supplies have reached people who might not have survived otherwise.  No Sign That War Is Near End **********But if large-scale starvation has been averted so far, Mozambican officials and aid workers emphasize that the war, combined with unusually dry conditions of the last several months, still threatens millions of people. They expect many, especially children, to suffer hardships including severe malnutrition, and they see the possibility of many deaths. **********At the same time, the war, which pits a little known anti-Communist guerrilla force called Renamo against the Government headed by President Joaquim A. Chissano, shows little sign of diminishing in intensity, much less ending anytime soon. **********Neither side seems able to decisively defeat the other. Most diplomats, aid workers and some officials here say that leaves Mozambique, as a stricken country, perpetually insecure, close to bankrupt, full of suffering and dependent on outside help for the survival of many of its citizens. **********''The country is practically destroyed,'' an adviser to President Chissano said. **********''When we got independence in 1975, we believed that Mozambique was a rich place where we could create a peaceful, prosperous country. The opposite has turned out to be the case.''  Maputo Turns to West But Old Ties Continue **********To try to deal with the crisis, and to correct what officials now freely admit were the mistakes of a rigid adherence to Marxist policies, the Mozambican Government has made a basic change in its foreign policy orientation. Officials now try to balance continuing close ties with the Soviet Union, East Germany and Cuba with greater cooperation with the West. **********This has produced one of the few bright spots in the situation. The Government, helped by Western donors and a host of voluntary agencies, has shown it can put into place a huge relief operation reaching a large number of the areas affected by drought and war. **********''We don't know about the populations that are inaccessible, and there are areas that are unreachable in this country,'' said one relief worker. ''But if anybody in the accessible areas is starving, it is not because of a lack of food.'' **********''It would be because they were moving from one place to another and died of exhaustion while on the way,'' the worker, Kim Balduc, a representative of the United Nations Disaster Relief Organization, said in her office in Maputo, the capital. **********A United Nations report compiled in February says that as many as 3.5 million people, roughly one-quarter of Mozambique's entire population, are ''severely affected'' by the civil war or drought, meaning that they are unable to produce or buy enough food for themselves. **********The report says one million people have been displaced from their homes by the war, many of them resettled in camps such as Karunga, where relief food can reach them by truck or riverboat convoys, most often guarded from guerrilla attack by the Mozambican Army. **********''This is not like Ethiopia, where there were mass camps with people starving,'' said Vincent Nicod, the head of the International Committee of the Red Cross in Zambezia Province, where Karunga is situated. The reference was to the catastrophic Ethiopian famine of 1984-85. **********''Here it is all on a small scale and very spread out,'' he said. ''You don't have huge numbers in one place, but maybe 25 people here or 100 there. They are small groups who are forced to move from one place to another, and these people are often in very bad shape.'' **********Mr. Nicod said 20 to 25 percent of the children newly arriving in resettlement camps were suffering from severe malnutrition. He compared that with a ''normal'' African rate of 5 to 7 percent. In the village of Maganjadacosta, not far from here, some 18 children in a newly arrived group of 300 died of measles this month. Aid workers said the high death rate from the disease might be linked to their hunger-weakened state.  Thousands Are Brought By the Army to a Camp **********This flat, arid area of cashew trees and elephant grass along the River of Good Signs has for several months been receiving refugees from farther west and north, particularly from towns along the Zambezi River, which cuts Mozambique into northern and southern halves. **********More than 13,000 people have been brought to this sprawling camp, where entire villages of straw huts and straggly vegetable fields have been created under rows of coconut trees. The people here have fled what many call ''bandit'' attacks, referring to the rebels. Many have been brought here by the army in an apparent effort to deny Renamo recruits from the local population. **********Some people say they lived in the bush with little to eat but roots for several weeks after attacks on their villages. A group of 400 new arrivals in Karunga, waiting for some old clothing, blankets and bars of soap to be distributed to them by the Red Cross, clearly showed signs of hardship. Children were commonly infected by scabies. Many of them were obviously malnourished. Young mothers sat listlessly on the ground holding onto skinny babies. **********''You can always tell the new arrivals,'' Mr. Nicod of the Red Cross said. ''They have nothing to eat, almost nothing to wear, no tools, cooking utensils, household goods. But they recover quickly and seem to be doing pretty well after a few months.'' **********One of those new arrivals was Luis Santos Mpicha, a 26-year-old-man in ragged clothing. He said the guerrillas attacked his village in the Micaunde district in July. Mr. Mpicha, who spoke to a reporter in the presence of Government representatives, described the ''bandits'' as young men without uniforms. He said they had long hair, tied up in small braids, beads around their necks and earrings. He said they attacked the village one day at dawn, stole food and supplies, and forced some villagers to carry bags apparently to a base camp some distance from the village. They set fire to some homes and shops and beat some villagers, he said. **********When the village was retaken by Government soldiers in mid-August, Mr. Mpicha said, they picked up villagers, many of whom had fled into the surrounding bush, and brought them to Karunga. **********As Mr. Mpicha talked, a group of soldiers, singing and banging machetes against the side of their truck, arrived in the camp. With them were about a dozen people who had apparently taken refuge in the bush after a guerrilla attack. A few sparse items of furniture and a tattered bag or two were unloaded from the truck and the new arrivals marched off to be registered by the camp's officials. **********The soldiers' commander called himself Jaguar, and he appeared to be drunk. He stayed in the camp for about half an hour, from time to time standing in the front of the 400 bedraggled new arrivals and leading them in chants of ''the struggle continues,'' the major Government slogan in its fight against the guerrillas.  Travel in Countryside Is Considered Precarious **********Residents of Maputo, Mozambique's Portuguese-built capital city, which shows few overt signs of the war, give a common example of the insecurity prevailing in the surrounding countryside, as guerrilla activities have increased during the last two years. **********From Maputo's port, which is operating at one-third of its capacity, distant purple hills on the horizon mark the borders of Swaziland and South Africa. But, though the hills are only about 40 miles away, few people attempt the trip by road. It is simply not considered safe to venture that far from Maputo. **********Indeed, the war, according to many accounts, has virtually sliced this long, coastal country into fragments, making most road travel outside of the major towns precarious. **********Renamo, which is also known as the National Resistance Movement, or M.N.R., its Portuguese initials, has commonly attacked relief convoys taking donated grain to affected areas. The American aid organization CARE, which oversees the transport of relief food with a fleet of 348 donated trucks, has seen 12 of its vehicles put out of operation in such attacks. **********International aid workers say one nothern province, Niassa, has been virtually cut off from the rest of Mozambique, with the only access to the area for relief supplies being across the border with Malawi and back into this country near the border town of Mandimba. **********But about three weeks ago, the supply route was interrupted when rebels attacked Mandimba. Recent Western visitors to the town say that it was virtually levelled. **********The guerrillas have in the last two or so years managed to destroy all of the bridges across the Zambezi. Some river towns, such as Caia, Luabo and Mopeia, were recaptured by Government troops earlier this year after several months in rebel hands. But refugees from those areas say their towns suffered widespread damage and were largely uninhabited. **********Renamo has, officials here say, managed to reduce rail transport from Africa's interior to Mozambique's Indian Ocean ports to a fraction of its normal level. **********The Government, with the help of troops from Zimbabwe, has managed to open a corridor from the Zimbabwe border to the port of Beira, for three trains a day in each direction. Officials and aid workers say the line is more secure now than it has been in several years. **********That achievement has been met by other moves toward restoring normal economic life. In Maputo, for example, Western businessmen are discussing deals with a Government newly receptive to foreign investments. The American company Edlow International has signed an agreement to mine titanium sands on the coast of Zambezia province, with protection provided by the army, diplomats here said. **********However, the two other railroad lines in the south and north of the country have been entirely closed down, as Renamo has apparently sought to destroy one of this country's major traditional functions - to provide access to ports for the landlocked African countries to the west.  Early Days of Rebellion: Support From Rhodesia **********The war dates back to early days of Mozambique's independence from Portugal in 1975, when the newly empowered Marxist government here provided support to black groups fighting the white minority government in what was then Rhodesia, now Zimbabwe. **********In response, the Rhodesian white minority government provided arms to the newly formed Renamo, which has been in the field in this country ever since, and is estimated now to have as many as 25,000 armed followers scattered throughout the country, not enough to take power, but enough to wreak havoc. **********In the war, taking place in a country without reliable transport or communications, each side has accused the other of massacres. In July, more than 380 people were reportedly killed in an attack on the village of Homoine. The Government blamed the deaths on the rebels. **********It is an article of faith in Mozambique, and in such surrounding countries as Zimbabwe and Tanzania, who have sent troops to help in the war, that support for Renamo comes from South Africa, which would appear to be the only country in the region with an interest in undermining an unfriendly neighboring government. But the Mozambican authorities have been unable to provide conclusive proof of this. **********The United States has chosen to distinguish between Renamo, which receives no direct American aid, and Unita, the major anti-Government resistance group in Angola, the other former Portuguese colony in Africa torn by civil war. Unita does receive military aid from the United States as well as South Africa. **********In the resettlement camp of Ilova, a flat, dry stretch of reed homes, Mussa Alberto Bres, who is blind, sits by the banks of the River of Good Signs and sings African songs for some visitors. **********Mr. Bres, whose village of Elalano was attacked by rebels last year, was led through the bush to safety by a friend. **********He sang mostly love songs, such as one about the man whose mistress lived in the next village. **********But there were also songs of war. In one, Mr. Bres sang, ''If the army had no bazookas or rifles, I would be dead.'' fdtx'fj

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/23/world.main_headline: PRIESTS ARE TARGETS AS THEY STAND UP FOR CHANGE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/23/world.print_headline: BACOLOD JOURNAL; PRIESTS ARE TARGETS AS THEY STAND UP FOR CHANGE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/23/world.body_text: **********Bishop Antonio Y. Fortich was seated in a white T-shirt eating lunch when a young priest walked up to him with a newspaper folded open to the letters column and began to read. **********''You have run out of good will in Bacolod City,'' the young priest read. ''Your credibility is zero. Your life is at stake from both right and left.'' **********The Bishop, 73 years old, paused as he raised a spoonful of rice, looked up at the priest and grunted a brief acknowledgment. **********''You have espoused liberation theology and the 'preferential option for the poor,' which is another euphemism for Marxist ideology,'' said the letter, which was addressed to him by a right-wing group. 'Don't Need You' **********The Bishop grunted again, and was joined this time, as in a liturgical response, by the other priests seated with him under a buzzing ceiling fan. **********''We don't need you as our church leader in Negros,'' the letter concluded. ''We don't want you and your Communist clergy here.'' **********Bishop Fortich finished his lunch without further comment. The letter was only the latest in many that have been seen to him and his priests in recent weeks. **********As he headed out for his nap, he passed through a small sun-baked courtyard where two weeks before a hand grenade, thrown just after midnight, landed a few feet from his bedroom, spraying shrapnel across walls, windows and doorways. Subject of Contention **********As the island of Negros, like much of the nation, moves toward a sharper confrontation between right and left, the activities of the Roman Catholic Church have come under fire. **********The Philippine church, in a nation in which 85 percent of the people are adherents, has for years taken a high-profile role in politics and social conflicts. **********In remote areas where an often abusive military can be the sole Government presence, parish priests often provide assistance in everything from medical care to the organizing of economic cooperatives. **********Now military officers, conservative plantation owners and right-wing extremists are assailing the church, while within its own ranks a debate is under way over its proper social role. Under Threat From Vigilantes **********The more energetic priests have come under threat from anti-Communist vigilante groups, and in Negros alone four churches have been set afire since March. **********Several planters on the island's sugar estates have begun to boycott church services and withhold the donations that keep their social programs alive, in protest over the priests' advocacy of land redistribution and other benefits for the poor. **********''If the church continues with its leanings, the time will come when it will have no more parishioners,'' said a member of one of the several newly formed right-wing associations in Negros, the Concerned Citizens Group to Fight Insurgency. **********''It's really bad,'' said Esteban Coscolluela, a planter who heads another group, the Negros Foundation for Peace and Democracy. ''I am very close to God, but I have not been going to mass lately.'' Divisions Are Sharpening **********He added, ''For us, priests who turn away from their work toward Communism have very weak theological backgrounds or they're sexually frustrated.'' **********The church's advocacy of social change and the role of its grass-roots Basic Christian Communities are sharpening divisions within the clergy itself. **********One Negros priest, the Rev. Ruperto Palma, who is said to have close links with the military, recently accused 35 of his colleagues on the island of being Communists. Bishop Forich took advertisements in newspapers to deny the accusation and demand a retraction. **********In Manila, the Catholic Bishops Conference of the Philippines issued a statement in January opposing the widespread membership of priests and nuns in organizations deemed to be leftist. It said it was ''inconsistent with Gospel values'' for churchmen to be involved with organizations that espouse violence or class struggle. Social Conditions Cited **********Bishop Fortich said in an interview that social conditions had driven some of his priests to sympathize and even cooperate with the rebels. Ultimately, several of them abandoned ministries for arms. **********The Bishop said he could understand the frustrations of such men over social injustices and military harassment. But he tells them: ''You are on your own. I'll pray for you. I respect the option you have chosen, but you are no longer priests.'' **********In a measure of the prominent role played by the church, Bishop Fortich headed a national committee that monitored compliance in the 60-day cease-fire with Communist rebels last winter. His secret contacts with some of the rebel priests had been among the Government's earliest peace feelers. Prodded From Vatican **********The conflict involving the church touches on larger questions about the role of the clergy in a divided nation where social disparities have fueled a Communist insurgency. **********As priests who shared the daily problems of the poor became increasingly active, prominent churchmen also joined a growing opposition to Ferdinand E. Marcos, who was ousted as President last year. **********Now the church is undergoing a period of reassessment, prodded by instructions from the Vatican to avoid partisan politics. **********According to Manila's Auxiliary Bishop, Teodoro Bacani, a ''cleansing of the ranks'' is needed to restore the church's credibility. **********Jaime Cardinal Sin, the Archbishop of Manila, recently acknowledged ''conflicts among church leaders'' that had grown out of the involvement of the clergy in opposition to Mr. Marcos. **********Although calling for church neutrality, the Cardinal has openly sided with President Corazon C. Aquino both in a recent constitutional plebiscite and in the legislative elections this month. Veritas, a weekly newspaper associated with the Cardinal, published an endorsement of 10 of Mrs. Aquino's candidates shortly before the May 11 vote. Pressure for Moderation **********Other church leaders, like Bishop Fortich, point out that the hardships that affect their parishioners, which gave rise to a socially active church, have not disappeared with the change of government. **********What has changed is the increased pressure on the church to moderate its conduct. ''Nowadays if you work with the poor you're a suspect,'' he said. ''If you espouse land reform you are destabilizing the status quo. If you support human rights you're a subversive. So my problem now is, What kind of work can I do and not be called a Communist?''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/07/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Reserve Board may soon order banks and thrift institutions to give consumers more information about the terms and conditions of home equity loans, Martha Seger, a Fed member, said today. **********''We definitely are committed to improving the disclosure for home equity lines of credit,'' Miss Seger told the House Banking Committee's consumer affairs subcommittee. **********She said, however, that most lenders treat borrowers fairly and that the Fed has to date received no complaints from consumers about home equity loan practices. **********She said the Fed would consider recommendations next month prepared by the agency's staff on how to improve the disclosure requirements for such loans, in which the borrower's equity in his house serves to secure the loan. **********The pledge of Fed action came as the House subcommittee began weighing draft legislation that would go further than the Fed in cracking down on home equity loan abuses. **********Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat who is on the Banking Committee, said he backed even stiffer legislation that would prohibit lenders from calling a home equity loan unless it was delinquent or from making loans that initially permit interest-only monthly payments, leading to progressively larger payments as the loan matures. **********He also asked Congress to limit interest rate increases on outstanding loans to no more than two percentage points a year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/21/busin.main_headline: Economic Scene; The Pressures On Inflation
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/21/busin.print_headline: Economic Scene; The Pressures On Inflation
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/21/busin.body_text: **********OIL prices tumbled this week, pushed down by the market's pessimism about the world's ability to absorb current output levels of crude and refined products. In addition, world demand for commodities is far from booming. But within a pattern of reasonable balance, individual countries, whether developing or developed, are capable of generating inflation. **********Lawrence A. Veit of Brown Brothers Harriman & Company concludes that, at best, the industrial nations of the capitalist world will ''muddle through a few more quarters of deficient growth until some combination of more stimulative policies and underlying demand reignites the engines of expansion.'' **********The Brown Brothers Harriman forecast puts the growth of real gross national product for the member nations of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development as a whole at 2.5 percent this year and 3.1 percent next year, with the predicted rate of inflation averaging 3.4 percent in 1987 and 4 percent in 1988. **********The gradual advance of the industrial countries would mean only modest growth for the members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, whose combined real G.N.P. is forecast to rise by 2.5 percent in 1987 and 3 percent in 1988. **********The combined output of the non-OPEC developing countries is projected to grow at an annual rate of 4.5 percent both this year and next. But, because of extreme differences in the ''inertial'' inflation among the developing countries, and their wide spread from stringency to laxity in fiscal and monetary policies, their expected rates of inflation differ widely. **********Mexico, whose consumer price index rose by 57.8 percent in 1985 and 84.5 percent in 1986, is expected, according to Mr. Veit, to hit 110 percent in 1987 and 120 percent in 1988. Argentina, whose inflation was reined in to 81.9 percent in 1986, is forecast to climb again to a 125 percent rate in 1987 and 1988. Brazil, with inflation of 166.2 percent last year, is expected to climb to a 300 percent rate in 1987 and 1988. **********While the spread in inflation rates among O.E.C.D. countries is much narrower, wide differences are still exhibited, depending mainly on national economic policies. In 1986, the lowest inflation was in West Germany, where consumer prices dropped by two-tenths of 1 percent, and the highest was in Australia, where prices rose 9.1 percent. The overall O.E.C.D. average increase in the consumer price index was just 2.7 percent, with the United States near the bottom, at just 1.1 percent. **********The Veit analysis puts the O.E.C.D. inflation average for 1988 at 4 percent, with the United States forecast to rise by 4.5 percent. Some American economists, such as those at Salomon Brothers, are now putting it as high as 6.5 percent. **********The argument that the United States rate will shoot higher starts with the lagging effects of a cheaper dollar. Allen Sinai, chief economist of Shearson Lehman Brothers, names five effects of a lower dollar on United States inflation. **********They are: the direct effect on prices of imported goods such as autos and consumer electronics; an ''umbrella'' effect on American-made goods where competing import prices have risen; higher business costs for American companies resulting from more expensive purchases abroad; rising precious metals and commodities prices stemming from the increased purchasing power of strong-currency countries, and a strengthened American industrial sector, as the lower dollar, by stimulating exports, adds to demand-side pressures and makes it easier for businesses to pass on price increases. **********The sharp fall in the dollar this week exacerbated worries of higher domestic inflation ahead. How far the dollar falls will depend to a degree on how the Group of Five major industrial countries acts to carry out the currency agreements reached in Paris in February through central bank interventions and coordinated macroeconomic policies. **********The most important determinant of the dollar's future value may be actions on the United States budget deficit. But here the outlook is gloomy. The Congressional Budget Office this week predicted that the deficit would ease this year but grow again to nearly $200 billion next year unless Congress and the President make good their promises to stanch the red ink. They are still stalemated and prospects of a significant compromise are not bright. **********Another major cause for anticipation of higher United States inflation is the expectation of a catch-up of wages to faster-rising prices. Consumer prices rose at an annual rate of 5.4 percent in the first half of this year, but wages rose by only 2.2 percent, so living standards went down. A new study by Olivier Jean Blanchard for the Brookings Institution made the case for some catch-up, showing that 40 percent of the upward adjustment of wages to rising prices is complete after one year and 65 percent after two years. **********But, in specific cases and time periods, there is no iron law binding wages to prices, or vice versa. The bargaining power of corporations versus organized and unorganized labor will determine the speed and degree of the wage rise. For instance, a battle between labor and management, regarded as likely to have national significance, is now being waged between the International Paper Company and the combined forces of the United Paperworkers International Union at a strikebound mill in Jay, Me. As a result of conflicts over wages and company demands for givebacks, the mill has been closed since June 16. **********That strike typifies the battle building in the United States over stepped-up inflation and who benefits or suffers from it.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/10/world.main_headline: Worry Grows That Korean Army Might Intervene in the Elections
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/10/world.print_headline: Worry Grows That Korean Army Might Intervene in the Elections
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/10/world.body_text: **********Serious concern has been raised here that South Korea's military might step in to cancel next week's presidential election or to nullify its results if the opposition wins. **********The concern, expressed by people familiar with the South Korean military, is based on reports that elements in the army, notably those responsible for domestic surveillance, have discussed possible action. Question of Reprisals **********It is also rooted in the perception of some political analysts that the ruling-party candidate, Roh Tae Woo, is doing less well than his strategists had hoped. Should he lose, several experts said, some senior army officers are likely to fear possible reprisals from a government led by either of his major opponents, Kim Young Sam and Kim Dae Jung.  [ In Washington, a senior State Department official warned against efforts to subvert the elections. The official, Gaston J. Sigur Jr., Assistant Secretary of State for Asian affairs, appeared to be directing the warning at the South Korean Government and military. Page A9. ]  ''There are people in this Government and ruling party who feel they cannot lose the election,'' a knowledgeable specialist in South Korean military affairs said. Army intervention, either before or after the election, ''is being discussed,'' he said. **********''Lots of these people do not have moral compunctions about doing something like this,'' he said. ''It's a practical consideration - can they get away with it?'' **********He cautioned that he was aware only that discussions were under way and did not know if any decision had been made. There have been no indications of unusual movements by the South Korean armed forces or, for that matter, evidence of action of any kind. **********The Government of President Chun Doo Hwan, which came to power through a coup by army generals in 1980, has stated several times in recent months that the military would stay out of politics. **********''The decision might be to do nothing initially, to let the opposition take over and see what they do,'' the military affairs specialist said. ''They may not have made up their minds.'' **********Several informed analysts said that if there was a move to call off the Dec. 16 election, it would probably not occur without the knowledge of Mr. Chun, who led the 1980 coup. **********It has long been taken for granted that the army worries greatly about Kim Dae Jung, whom many officers regard as a Communist sympathizer. But some analysts suggest that there is concern as well about Kim Young Sam, even though he is regarded as more moderate and has gone out of his way to reassure the army. In September, for example, he accepted a Government invitation to watch a demonstration of a new tank. **********To bolster his presidential campaign, however, Kim Young Sam recruited support from former Gen. Chung Sung Hwa, who was ousted as army chief of staff on Dec. 12, 1979, in a rebellion by the Chun group, which included Mr. Roh. The general was later reduced in rank to private and reportedly even tortured. Pledge of No Reprisals **********According to political analysts, senior army officers who aided Mr. Chun, or owe their present positions to him, worry what might happen to them if Mr. Chung was to have influence on a Kim Young Sam government. **********Campaigning today in the country's southeast, Mr. Kim pledged there would be no reprisals, a promise also made many times by Kim Dae Jung. But both men also stress the need to investigate the Chun coup and the massacre by soldiers that it produced in May 1980 in the city of Kwangju. **********Rumors of possible army intervention in South Korean political life are not uncommon, and they usually amount to nothing. But with election day only a week away, tensions are running high. **********There are also keen memories here that Mr. Chun in the past has considered injecting the army into civilian situations. In June, at the height of street protests that led to the present presidential elections, he was reliably reported to have come close to calling in troops to maintain order, but was then persuaded to back off. **********One reason, according to some experts, was resistance in the army itself to being used that way. Most officers, it is said, firmly believe that their top priority is to defend the country against North Korea and that they have no place in domestic politics, even in the name of stability. **********Moreover, several analysts said, ordinary South Koreans would regard cancellation of the election as unjustified and would react strongly. **********Concern about jeopardizing the 1988 Olympic Games in Seoul would be another consideration for the Government, as would the reaction of the United States, which has repeatedly warned against army intervention.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/14/world.main_headline: U.S. Won't Aid U.N. Population Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/14/world.print_headline: U.S. Won't Aid U.N. Population Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/14/world.body_text: **********Over strong Congressional and internal objections, the Agency for International Development announced today that it was again withholding its contribution to the United Nations Fund for Population Activities because of charges that the fund supports coerced abortion in China. **********The move, strongly supported by opponents of abortion, is mandated under a 1985 amendment that bars Federal money for groups that support coerced abortion or sterilization. This is the second year in a row the agency has held back $25 million from the fund because of the charge involving China. **********The agency's acting administrator, Jay F. Morris, said the decision, which had been expected for some time, was made because of strong evidence that China's policy of encouraging one child per family is coercive. He cited hundreds of Chinese radio broadcasts in which officials speak of banned second pregnancies and ''penalty measures'' for the conception of a second child. **********Chinese officials have repeatedly denied that their programs force abortions. No Evidence of Coerced Abortions **********The United Nations supports census efforts in China which may indirectly help coercive programs, Mr. Morris said. He said the Chinese census efforts gave the Beijing Government information that it might use to plan coercive family planning. **********But a top agency official said internal agency experts strongly opposed a cutoff in United States money. A 1985 report by the agency found some abuses by local Chinese officials but no evidence that China's central Government or the fund supports coerced abortions. **********Senator Daniel K. Inouye, Democrat of Hawaii, the original sponsor of the 1985 amendment, wrote to Secretary of State George P. Shultz last month calling the accusations against the fund absurd and urging Mr. Shultz to resist ''political pressures'' brought by opponents of family planning. **********The United States Bureau of Census has itself trained Chinese demographers through its International Statistics Training Program, Senator Inouye wrote. He cited Mr. Shultz's own testimony before the Senate Appropriations Committee in 1986 that ''it is our understanding the Chinese Government does not sanction coerced abortions.'' **********''This is more about votes in Peoria than women in China,'' the agency official said. In Opposition of Family Planning **********At the United Nations today, the fund's executive director, Nafis Sadik, attributed America's decision to lobbying by Americans who oppose all family planning. **********She said the loss of American money would force the fund to cut programs in sub-Saharan Africa, the one region of the world where population growth is still rising and far outstrips food production. **********''We absolutely deny the charges,'' Dr. Sadik said. ''We are particularly concerned with the critical situation in sub-Saharan Africa'' where she said the fund ''is trying to respond to Africa's increasing demands for family planning and maternal and child health care.'' **********The agency first withheld money from the fund because of the China charge in 1985, deducting $10 million of a $46 million contribution - an amount roughly equal to the fund's spending that year in China. **********The agency witheld all $25 million of the appropriated American contribution to the fund last year, promising to spend the money on American-sponsored programs abroad. **********The fund will spend $155 million this year in 133 countries. Its projects in China include programs to produce and import contraceptives, training for family-planning experts and help for Chinese census programs. **********Mr. Inouye wrote that staff members of the Senate subcommittee on foreign operations concluded during an April trip to China that the central Chinese Government did not support coercive family-planning measures. **********Mr. Inouye wrote, ''We do not know of any documentary evidence of a program of coerced abortion in China.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/13/world.main_headline: ARMS PROTESTERS STAY AT U.S. BASES
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/13/world.print_headline: ARMS PROTESTERS STAY AT U.S. BASES
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/13/world.body_text: **********Participants in the free-wheeling peace camps that have grown up outside American nuclear bases in Western Europe plan to continue their nonviolent protests despite the new treaty between the United States and Soviet Union. **********Members of camps in Italy, the Netherlands, Belgium, Britain and France, wearing hitchhikers' clothes and carrying knapsacks, said at a news conference here on Wednesday that they would continue to monitor the sites covered by the treaty on intermediate-range missiles until the bases were returned to peaceful uses. They called on the two superpowers to keep the European public informed on the dismantling of the bases. **********The protesters convened in a small room at the International Press Center, across from the European Community headquarters. They wore sandals and old sweaters, and some still smelled of the wood fires of their encampments. They read their reports from battered school notebooks and had to borrow coins to photocopy their final communique. Movement Started in England **********The informal movement began with a women's encampment at the Greenham Common cruise missile base in England and in five years has spread to the other countries in which American missiles are deployed, as well as to France. In most cases the participants have set up tents or bought houses just outside the bases and try to obstruct work or to monitor the military activities. Many live on welfare or unemployment payments. **********There is no central organization, but the hundreds of people in the camps often exchange information and visit each other's sites. In many cases, they have drawn thousands of protesters to their demonstrations. They have mastered the fearsome vocabulary of nuclear deterrence, know the names and, they say, the numbers of the weapons, and produce detailed reports that they give to anyone who asks. **********''We don't trust anybody,'' said Margaret Johnson, who has divided her time in the last four years between the five permanent peace camps in England and Scotland. ''We don't work with any power, but we make known what we know to everybody.'' A Variety of Factions **********The politics of the camps can be confusing to outsiders. At the Woensdrecht missile base in the Netherlands, for example, there were at one time 10 camps around the chain-link fence, for groups ranging from gay women to Roman Catholics to Quakers to draft resisters. There was even a group whose policy of puncturing the tires of military trucks separated it from the more strictly nonviolent alignments. **********Lorenzo Porto and Tulio Vaccaro, two bearded young men from the Comiso cruise missile base in Sicily, described their movement there in a mixture of French and English laced with Italian. They said they had collected money in the cities to buy land around the base so it could not be expanded, had organized demonstrations with workers in the surrounding vineyards and had taken pictures of the truck-mounted cruise missiles when they were taken on maneuvers. **********''The pictures were not very good because the caribinieri, they always run after us,'' Mr. Vaccaro said. He said he had been arrested twice on charges of espionage. **********Many of the participants said they feared the missile bases would be turned over to aircraft capable of carrying nuclear bombs or to other military uses not covered in the treaty.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/04/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;  Chapter 11 For Air Atlanta
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/04/busin.body_text: **********Air Atlanta, the three-year-old airline that was the brainchild of a black businessman, Michael R. Hollis, filed for protection from its creditors today under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. All of its flights were grounded immediately, and its workers were laid off. **********The airline, which had obtained more than $80 million in financing from several large corporations, including the Equitable Life Assurance Society, Aetna Life and Casualty, CSX, General Electric Credit and E. F. Hutton, had been in financial difficulties almost from the beginning. **********The airline had tried to establish a niche by appealing to business travelers with first-class seating and service at coach prices. **********Air Atlanta officials said late today that they hoped a reorganization plan would allow the airline to resume limited operations as early as Monday. **********The airline had been unable to pay a number of debts, most notably its landing fees and rent at Atlanta's Hartsfield International Airport. **********Air Atlanta served eight cities in the East and South, along with Detroit, from its Atlanta hub.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/04/busin.body_text: **********Loans Lend a Hand **********''The basic business loan picture is improving,'' says Lacy H. Hunt, chief economist for CM&M Group in Philadelphia, and that alone is something to cheer about as the new year begins. For most of 1986, large banks held about $250 billion in short-term commercial and industrial loans, a level that reflected a weak economy. Now, says Mr. Hunt, these loans are approaching the $265 billion level. **********The rising loan level is good news. When demand for short-term funds rises, it means companies are borrowing money to pay dividends, meet payroll requirements and purchase equipment. ''It is an indicator of business activity and business confidence,'' says Mr. Hunt. **********And at least two other factors support the encouraging loan picture. ''There are signs that industrial activity is beginning to pick up, such as the rise in manufacturing employment,'' said Mr. Hunt. And inventory investment, which has undergone a dramatic liquidation since 1984, is also rising. Inventory-building is not only a sign of business confidence, it also spurs more borrowing, he says. ''Typically, increases in inventory investment lead to higher credit demands.'' Foreigners Phone Toll-Free **********About 400 companies worldwide offer toll-free calls for customers. ''And the number has been rising by about 20 percent a month,'' said Robert K. Baulch, manager of international marketing for A.T.&T., which sells the global service to about 120 American companies. Right now, phone companies in 15 countries offer international toll-free calling to customers in those nations. By the end of 1987, 10 more countries in Asia, Europe and South America will join that list. **********But, at $1.60 a call, reaching new customers around the world is not an inexpensive proposition for American companies, even though, according to Mr. Baulch, toll-free service can increase a customer's willingness to call sevenfold. The key industries involved - catalogue, travel and services businesses -will also have to make some changes in the way they do business, he says. Companies, for example, will have to set up operations to receive calls at all hours of the day - in a dozen languages. Shipping From a Tiny Isle **********Because of new laws and favorable taxation - no corporate tax, no estate duty, no capital gains tax and a mere 20 percent personal income tax - the Isle of Man, off the coast of England in the Irish Sea, is competing with the Netherlands, West Germany and the United States to become a major world shipping center. **********The isle now has 40 ships registered. But it is not stopping there. ''In the next 12 months there will probably be 100 ships on the registry,'' predicts Capt. Geoffrey Davis, chief marine surveyor for the isle.  So far, the Isle of Man has been luring shipping companies from elsewhere in Britain. That's because crews cost 30 percent less to hire on the isle and office expenses are 50 percent lower there. But because registration fees on the isle are also low, shipping companies from other countries may start to set up headquarters on the tiny island. Captain Davis says, however, that unlike Liberia and Panama, the Isle of Man is ''not a flag-of-convenience registry.'' Shipping safety-and-health standards will be high, he says, and rigorously enforced. False Teeth That Fit **********An estimated 30 million Americans have no teeth in one or both jaws, and about 10 percent of them cannot wear dentures for either physical or psychological reasons, says Craig Rodriguez, vice president of Nobelpharma USA, an American subsidiary of Swedish Nobel Industries. **********Now, he says, some of these people may have something to smile about: a 20-year-old Swedish technique called the Biotes process. The technique, which has the approval of the Food and Drug Administration and the provisional blessing of the American Dental Association, has now been tested on 9,000 Americans. **********The process uses three screws. The first is surgically screwed into the jawbone. It is made of titanium, and thus integrates with the bone to form ''an irreversible bond,'' said Mr. Rodriguez. A second is screwed on top of the first so that it comes up to the gum line. A third holds the tooth in place. This tooth can be used as an anchor to hold a bridge or a complete denture. The final screw can be removed if the tooth or denture needs to be replaced. The cost of an upper or lower denture created with this process is about $8,000, but, says Mr. Rodriquez, ''it may last 20 years or more.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/30/world.main_headline: IN PARIS CABS, LE HOT SEAT AWAITS THE MUGGER
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/30/world.print_headline: IN PARIS CABS, LE HOT SEAT AWAITS THE MUGGER
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/30/world.body_text: **********Most times they ignore you. Sometimes, if they pick you up, they bend your ear with their right-wing views. Occasionally they spray you with tear gas. And now they propose to electrify you. **********Parisian taxi drivers, in search of protection against thieves and muggers, have come up with the ''blazing seat,'' an electric cushion slipped under the passenger seat, attached to a powerful battery. At the touch of a button, the Israeli-made device delivers 52,000 volts of low-tension electric current to the back of the spine. It works. **********''I just shot straight up and let out a tremendous yell,'' said Jon Silverman, a Paris-based correspondent who asked to try it out a few days ago for a BBC report. ''Gave myself a terrific bruise on the shin when my head hit the front seat as I jumped up to escape the shock. I don't think it's a good idea.'' **********The device is slightly more powerful than the police weapon known as the stun gun, which delivers about 40,000 to 50,000 volts. Drivers' Union to Install Device **********If it has its way, a Parisian taxi drivers' union proposes to install the device, which costs about $1,100, in most of the 14,300 cabs of the city. Already five taxis are equipped with it. The supplier, Lucien Cornescu, who represents a company called Recomex, says another 1,000 devices are on order. **********The hot seat's main champion, Norbert Ben-Arous, the secretary general of an organization representing the owners of about 20 percent of Parisian taxis, says the project is forging ahead.''In France anything that is not forbidden is allowed,'' he said today after emerging, slightly pale, from a live demonstration for the world press at the Place de la Concorde. **********Aides to Prime Minister Jacques Chirac, who is also Mayor of Paris, privately ridiculed the idea. The police are skeptical. Some medical authorities, asked to assess the dangers of the device, have certified it will not kill cardiac patients. **********''In France anything that is not forbidden is allowed,'' he said today after emerging, slightly pale, from a live demonstration for the world press at the Place de la Concorde. **********Spurred on by the murder two weekends ago of a woman who drove a cab, drivers insist they need stronger protection. But judging from the litany of horror stories Parisians tell of their daily duel with taxi drivers, this view is not widely shared. **********Complaints range from the common impression that most drivers spend much of their time going home - routinely dismissing a fare because ''it's not on my way'' - to the many times a customer is curtly told, ''There are no cars, call later,'' after a 15-minute wait on the phone for a radio-dispatched taxi. It is not uncommon to see taxis parked at bistros during rush hours as drivers enjoy a leisurely meal. **********Even if the indifference can be digested, uglier behavior shocks. **********An American passenger was left 50 feet from her hotel the other day, and her suitcases deposited on the sidewalk, so the driver could respond to a radio call for a more lucrative fare. **********In another case, a driver's dog - a common phenomenon in the front seat - assaulted a French passenger, Jean-Francois Kahn, as he reached past the muzzle to pay the fare. And Patrice de Nussac, a French journalist, says he watched a friend take a beating from a gang of taxi drivers when he asked one of them to move his double-parked taxi on the Champs-Elysees. **********Parisian drivers are also known to spray passengers with the ever-present bottle of tear gas at the slightest provocation. **********And pettiness abounds. Take the no smoking signs that some cabbies insist apply only to passengers, not drivers, or the prohibition on rolling down windows. For riders of African or Arab origin, it is common to be ignored and occasionally struck with a racist epithet as the taxi rolls by. **********To be sure, taxi drivers have their own complaints. Fares are low. Taxes are high. Noise is incessant. People take taxis when they should walk, they say. ''The traffic is awful,'' complained Paul de Angelis, the son of a taxi driver who has driven a Parisian cab himself for 17 years ''A few years ago I could take in as much as 30 fares a day. Today I average 13 to 15.'' **********Above all there is the danger, Mr. Ben-Arous says, and the police confirm that some 40 assaults on taxi drivers are reported each month. The recent killing was the 19th of a taxi driver since 1979. ''We are not like sheep, waiting to be slaughtered,'' Mr. Ben-Arous said.  [ In New York, according to the Taxi and Limousine Commission, there were about 260 robberies of cab drivers a month in 1986 and 1987, and there have been 10 killings so far this year. The commission chairman, Gorman Gilbert, said the use of the electric-seat device in New York would require commission approval. He did not say whether such approval would be likely. ]  Mr. Chirac's staff in City Hall says there are other ways to protect drivers. One is a bulletproof bubble installed around the driver, and another is a safe deposit box in which the money can be locked, or a communications systems that connects the taxi to a police station. It was even suggested that riders buy an electronic credit card and pay with it. **********Predictably, drivers say none of the proposed alternatives is any good. ''Most turned down the bubble, even though we offered to subsidize it,'' said Jean-Pierre Richer, the traffic director at the Paris police. ''They like to gossip with the clients. It helps with the tip.'' Instead, the taxi drivers want subsidies to purchase the hot seat. **********What about accidental use or angry drivers settling even simple arguments by sending some ''juice,'' as Mr. de Angelis calls the electric current, to the back seat? **********''No way,'' Mr. Ben-Arous said. The device has a three-step trigger mechanism. A driver turns it on with a button, arms it with another and triggers it with a third. It unlocks in case of an accident. Besides, taxi drivers ''can tell when a guy has bad intentions,'' he argued. ''Good family men have nothing to worry about.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/24/busin.body_text: **********Nicholas F. Brady, the Wall Street investment banker President Reagan has named to head a special task force that will investigate this week's dramatic stock market plunge, said today that he believed the main cause of the collapse was overvalued common stocks in the United States and the rest of the world. **********''The principal reason for the drop was that common stocks all over the world are overvalued,'' he said in a telephone interview. **********Alluding to the record close of the Dow Jones industrial average at 2,722.42 on Aug. 25, he said, ''If the market had come down from 2,700 by thirty-seconds of a point, or sixteenths, over a period of time, you wouldn't be writing about this.'' **********He added, ''The real question is why it went so far so fast.'' Got Call Thursday Afternoon **********Mr. Brady said he had received a call on Thursday afternoon from Howard H. Baker Jr., the White House chief of staff, asking him to take on the investigation. He plans to arrive in Washington Monday to meet with Mr. Baker to determine how the task force will operate and who its other two members will be. **********President Reagan announced the creation of the task force Thursday evening in a televised news conference, saying he wanted its recommendations within 30 to 60 days on any changes that might be necessary in stock market operations. **********Mr. Brady, who is chairman of Dillon, Read & Company, a Wall Street investment firm, said that he expected the panel to be interviewing a number of market experts and specialists and that no decision had been made yet on whether the task force would work out of Washington or out of New York. Echoes President's Remarks **********Echoing some of Mr. Reagan's remarks during that news conference, Mr. Brady said that he did not believe fundamental economic factors were to blame for the frenzied stock selloff that sent the market down 235.48 points last week and then a record 508 points on Monday. ''To me, the underlying economic conditions are fine,'' Mr. Brady said, noting Government reports released today that showed the economy grew by 3.8 percent in the third quarter and that inflation remains moderate. **********Mr. Brady said that he does not expect the task force to deal with the economic situation, but rather to examine technological changes in the operation of the stock market, the globalization of securities markets and the new types of trading instruments that have been developed in the last 10 years. **********''It may well be that the conclusion is that in a world of electronic and technological advances, when people come to the same conclusions all at once, you've got a lot of problems on your hands,'' he said. ''You may need some system for slowing it all down or for helping people to understand that nothing is dramatically wrong.'' Thoughts, Not Conclusions **********Mr. Brady emphasized that these were general thoughts, not conclusions. He said his first job would be to organize a staff and then to collect and analyze the data on stock market operations, adding that he saw no difficulty in completing the job within 60 days. **********Asked if he believed the task force had been given a mandate to soothe the public's concerns about the stock market gyrations, Mr. Brady said that he would be happy if this was an offshoot of the panel's work but that he did not view it as an end in itself. ''Calmness is built from understanding,'' he said. ''The worst part of any sickness is the hour you spend waiting in the doctor's office thinking about how the world might end.'' **********Mr. Brady said it was hard to envision what types of recommendations the panel might make without knowing yet what its members would find, but when pressed for the types of things that might emerge, he said that, for example, if the panel concluded that market volatility was the result of so many players simultaneously making the same trading decisions, one possibility might be to recommend building more liquidity into the system. **********''We are in a financial world and we are talking about money,'' he said. ''When you are talking about a 1,000-point drop in the market in a very short period of time, I don't think any kind of general solution would necessarily impress anybody.''
