https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/22/jobs/.print_headline: How You Can Survive A Corporate Upheaval
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/22/jobs/.body_text: **********LEAD: DESPITE a corporate takeover, merger or downsizing, most employees can take steps to improve their chances of survival inside their company or in the job market. The important thing, said David Smith, managing director of the New York office of Korn/Ferry International, an executive-search firm, is ''to heed warnings and come up with options to a number of 'what if' scenarios. **********DESPITE a corporate takeover, merger or downsizing, most employees can take steps to improve their chances of survival inside their company or in the job market. The important thing, said David Smith, managing director of the New York office of Korn/Ferry International, an executive-search firm, is ''to heed warnings and come up with options to a number of 'what if' scenarios.'' **********Before Howard Glassroth was told that he was going to lose his position as associate director of corporate communications at Standard Oil Company of Ohio, he quietly let outside contacts know that he was in the market for a job. ''I stopped short of a formal job search because I didn't know whether or how soon my job would be eliminated,'' Mr. Glassroth said. ''But the informal calls got me in the habit of doing something I'd neglected - staying plugged into community and professional networks, which are essential once you're let go.'' **********When British Petroleum, Standard Oil's major shareholder, replaced Standard's top management, Mr. Glassroth saw the handwriting on the wall, which is the first step to surviving a transition, according to experts. ''People think, 'It can't happen to me because my job or department is too valuable,' and waste time when they could be developing new skills or starting a job search,'' said Prof. Ralph Kilmann, director of the program in corporate culture at the University of Pittsburgh's Graduate School of Business. **********Executives who learn that a change is imminent should lobby for either a golden parachute, a contract that insures future income for a specified time if a company's ownership changes, or guaranteed severance pay, according to John D. Erdlen, president of Management Dimensions Inc., an outplacement and career-counseling firm in Wellesley, Mass. Key players in the company who are not part of management can also negotiate deals if they take the initiative. ''Both can take advantage of management's fear that the good performers will leave before they're ready to have them leave,'' he said. **********Company management is often secretive about impending changes, but the rumor mill is full of valuable information if you know how to sort it out, according to Prof. Robert J. Bies at the Kellogg Graduate School of Management at Northwestern University, who has studied how managers deliver bad news. ''Decide if the sources are reliable, what the common themes of the rumors are and then look for evidence that supports what you hear, including what you read in the newspaper,'' said Professor Bies. Bosses often put off delivering bad news, so if you get a signal that jobs in your department may be in jeopardy, the best survival response is to ask for a clarification so that you can take steps to preserve yours or find a new position. **********Making sure that those who have power over your job fate know who you are, what you've done and what you can do for the company is a smart move, say outplacement counselors. One way to do this is by giving your manager an up-to-date resume that reflects your contributions and experience at the company. You might want to include letters of recognition from clients, articles that have appeared in trade journals about your accomplishments and outstanding performance appraisals, Mr. Erdlen suggested. Another avenue is to introduce yourself to managers on the transition team and give them a copy of your internal resume. **********An option for those who work for a large company is to investigate transfer possibilities. When Ken Washburn learned that the textbook college publisher he worked for was being merged with another division, he called managers at the parent company who knew him and asked them to keep their eyes open for other positions he might transfer into. ''I knew there would be a lot of duplication of effort, and I also realized that our division was being subsumed by the other, which meant their people would get first consideration,'' Mr. Washburn said. In the end he wasn't asked to relocate or leave since there were enough colleges in the Boston area to support two sales representatives.Priorities Change **********Sometimes no matter how valuable an employee has been to an organization, he finds himself out of a job because management's objectives and priorities are different. When CBS made its first staff reductions in September 1985, Robert Ferrante, a news producer, was given a day to vacate his office. ''I wasn't surprised because I knew there was fat in the news operation, especially my area, special events,'' he said. ''Despite that, I hadn't been out looking because I wasn't under pressure to find a job.'' Taking time off to evaluate the direction of your career is a good idea if you have a financial cushion, experts say. Since Mr. Ferrante's contract was still in effect for six months, he began to ponder his 28 years in broadcasting. ''The fact that a technology-intensive field like mine means fewer and fewer people are needed to do the job became clear to me,'' Mr. Ferrante said. ''And I decided to let people know that I wanted to consider job options in the communications field outside of broadcasting.'' A year after he left CBS, Mr. Ferrante became director of communications for the Democratic National Committee. **********While financial support from a former employer in the form of a contract or severance pay takes the pressure off accepting the first job offer that comes along, emotional support from family, friends and former colleagues makes a big difference in how psychologically smooth the transition is. ''I was surprised by who came to my rescue and who didn't,'' Mr. Glassroth said. ''My family and broadcasting colleagues I hadn't seen in years were terrific, but my coworkers at Standard Oil wouldn't even return my calls. It was as if I had a disease they were afraid of catching.'' **********Nonetheless, Mr. Glassroth optimistically pursued his job hunt and a master of business administration program for executives. Within two months of his departure, he was offered two positions. He turned down one because it involved a relocation, and took the second, which was a better position with a higher salary than his previous position, only to be told 48 hours after accepting it that the company was being sold. Now, almost a year later, he is still without a job. ''The longer you look, the more important emotional support becomes,'' he said. **********The people most likely to survive a merger or reorganization are those who are adaptable. ''A willingness to accept a lower salary or take on new responsibilities can make the difference of whether you're kept on,'' said Professor Kilmann. ''For those who are let go, a willingness to relocate, learn new skills or consider related job fields increases their chances of finding a new position.'' **********Mr. Washburn is glad he weathered the merger of his publishing company. ''It wasn't easy because we all had to accept new ways of doing things,'' he said. Now his line of books has expanded and so have his sales. ''I feel more secure than I ever have,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/25/world.main_headline: Slain Diplomat's Wife Says French Ignored Lead
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/25/world.print_headline: Slain Diplomat's Wife Says French Ignored Lead
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/25/world.body_text: **********The wife of an American military attache who was slain here in 1982 testified today that she had given the French police a lead in the case that they failed to pursue. **********The woman, Sharon Ray, testified at the trial of Georges Ibrahim Abdallah, who is considered a founder and leader of a terrorist group called the Lebanese Armed Revolutionary Faction. He is accused of having planned and ordered the killings of Mrs. Ray's husband, Lieut. Col. Charles R. Ray, in January 1982, and of Yacov Barsimantov, an Israeli diplomat here, two and a half months later. **********The French lawyer for Mrs. Ray and the United States Government, civil plaintiffs in the case, also accused the police of failing to investigate Colonel Ray's killing thoroughly and said the French secret service had withheld pertinent information because of ''other national interests.'' **********Both Mrs. Ray and her lawyer, Georges Kiejman, implied that for complex political motives the French authorities have been reluctant to press the case against Mr. Abdallah. **********Mr. Abdallah is also charged in the attempted murder in 1984 of Robert Onan Homme, the United States Consul General in Strasbourg, who was shot several times but survived. **********Officials say the United States Government has become a civil plaintiff in the case because of concern that Colonel Ray's slaying was not fully investigated and that Mr. Abdallah might be treated more leniently than he deserves as a result. **********When the second day of the trial opened today in a heavily guarded court building near Notre-Dame Cathedral, Mr. Abdallah was absent. He walked out of the court on Monday, denouncing ''Yankee imperialism.'' **********He sent a brief message today saying there was ''no reason'' he should appear and describing himself simply as ''an Arab fighter.'' **********The trial is being conducted without a jury by a special seven-judge court set up for terrorism cases. Under French law, Mr. Abdallah cannot be compelled to attend the proceedings, but he remains represented by lawyers. Introduced by a Priest **********In her testimony today Mrs. Ray said a priest at Notre-Dame, the Rev. Olivier Jouvenez, had introduced her and her husband to a group of young immigrants, including a Lebanese youth who later visited their home but refused to sign a guest book. She said she had told the police about the encounters - ''I said maybe one of those boys did it'' - but said Father Jouvenez told her later that the police had not asked him about the youths. **********Under cross-examination by Mr. Kiejman, Inspector Dikran Tchividjian of France's anti-terrorist squad, who investigated the Ray and Barsimantov slayings, said he was ''completely in the fog'' about the cases until 1984, when the French secret service provided information about the Lebanese Armed Revolutionary Faction, including pictures of suspected members. **********He said the information they gave him was from 1982. According to French press reports, it was given to the French secret service by the Israeli secret service, which already suspected Mr. Abdallah, immediately after the Barsimantov slaying. **********''For two and a half years the investigation was considered marginal compared to other national interests,'' Mr. Kiejman told the court.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/05/world.main_headline: U.N. COUNCIL BARS ARAB RIGHTS GROUP
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/05/world.print_headline: U.N. COUNCIL BARS ARAB RIGHTS GROUP
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/05/world.body_text: **********In a rare show of unity, representatives of traditionally hostile Arab nations have joined to fight the recognition of an Arab human-rights group. **********The group, the Arab Organization for Human Rights, has applied for consultative status with the United Nations Economic and Social Council. The group was set up in 1983 in Cyprus because its founders were not sure they would be welcome in the Arab world. **********Consultative status, of the second category, would give the group the right to submit written statements to the Council and be granted hearings. **********On Friday, the Council's Committee on Nongovernmental Organizations decided to put off the candidacy until 1989, for lack of consensus. **********The problem is that some Arab countries consider any charges of rights violations as interference. **********An American delegate, Kyle Scott, said ''legitimate human rights organizations continue to be denied status with the United Nations due to the objection of a few countries who are not pleased with this type of activity.'' Works With Other Rights Groups **********The Arab Organization for Human Rights, which is now based in Cairo, is working with Amnesty International, the Arab Lawyers' Union and other rights groups. **********In the Economic and Social Council, the Soviet Union aligned itself with the Algerian observer in expressing reservations about the Arab group, which has been critical of the treatment of Yahia Abdennour, president of the Algerian League of Human Rights. He was jailed for a time and then put under house arrest several months ago. **********Oman, the only Arab member of the Council, was neutral at first. Arab opponents of the rights group were able to persuade Oman to oppose it. **********Arab opposition is said to stem from the fact that most Arab countries have not ratified the international human-rights conventions. Enemies Banded Together **********At one meeting of the Council, according to one observer. Syria and Iraq, sworn enemies, banded together with Algeria to back Oman. Iraq said the Arab group was an instrument of aggression against the Arab nations. Syria said the group would be used by political opposition groups against Arab governments. **********Only the Swedish representative, Anne-Marie Sundbom, stood up to the Arab offensive against the rights group and proposed that it be accorded membership, be it without the right to be heard. Since recognition is by consensus, the unusual alliance between Oman and the Soviet Union was sufficient to deny the application. **********''We will bow to the sovereign decision of the committee and be back for recognition in 1989,'' said Abderahman Youssoufi, assistant secretary general of the Arab Lawyers' Union and a member of the board of trustees of the human-rights group. **********''I'm sure in the meantime, the cause of human rights will have made substantial progress in the Arab world, thanks to the action of our organization.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/20/world.main_headline: Soviet Tells U.S. It Plans to Ease Laws Curbing Jewish Emigration
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/20/world.print_headline: Soviet Tells U.S. It Plans to Ease Laws Curbing Jewish Emigration
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/20/world.body_text: **********Soviet diplomats told the United States this week that important regulations used to prevent Soviet Jews from emigrating were being eased and that an amnesty was possible for some political and religious prisoners, according to a State Department official. **********The official, Richard Schifter, Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights and Humanitarian Affairs, also said that he ''was left with the impression that the abuse of psychiatry was being ended.'' Change in Psychiatric Hospitals **********He noted in an interview that the Soviet authorities announced several weeks ago that psychiatric hospitals now under the jurisdiction of the Ministry of Internal Affairs, which is also in charge of the police, were being transferred to the Ministry of Health, where they may be less useful for incarcerating dissidents. **********But Mr. Schifter added that the Russians had made no commitment to increase the rate of emigration, which is severely restricted for all Soviet citizens. Since the early 1970's, however, some Jews, Armenians and ethnic Germans have been permitted to leave. **********Beginning in April, about 800 Jews have been permitted to leave each month, more than during recent years but considerably fewer than the 51,000 who left at the peak of emigration in 1979. **********The issue has enormous weight in Soviet-American relations. It was raised this week by both President Reagan and Secretary State George P. Shultz during their talks with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze in Washington. Detailed discussions were held by a special Soviet-American working group on human rights, led by Mr. Schifter and Yuri Reshetov, a deputy director of the Soviet Foreign Ministry's department of humanitarian and cultural affairs. **********Rights organizations are planning large demonstrations for the expected visit here by Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, later this year for a meeting with Mr. Reagan. Signs of improvement in the rights field, such as those provided this week and some gestures expected in the cases of a few prominent individuals, are seen by American officials as part of a Soviet effort to defuse the protest. **********Mr. Schifter and others in the State Department regard the Soviet steps as part of a mixed picture. **********''You can see both the movement and the limits of the movement,'' Mr. Schifter said. ''They're going to take certain steps that will significantly ameliorate conditions without in any way changing the fundamental Leninist structure of the state.'' **********For example, Mr. Schifter reported, Soviet officials said that in their current revision of the criminal code, they were considering a repeal of a law on ''anti-Soviet defamation,'' which has often been used against dissidents. An amnesty might also be given those serving sentences under that law. **********But a harsher measure, providing a maximum sentence of seven years in prison and five in exile for ''anti-Soviet agitation and propaganda,'' would stay on the books, Mr. Schifter was told. **********Soviet officials also predicted that other statutes would be eased. **********''The impression we were left with is that they are going to relax on the code sections which make it a crime to engage in unauthorized religious activity,'' Mr. Schifter said. ''They may amend the criminal code and may grant amnesty to people convicted under these sections.'' **********The Soviet authorities have long used psychiatric hospitals to imprison political dissidents and complaining workers, but Mr. Schifter said, ''I was left with the feeling that that was really moving.'' **********He said he had told Soviet officials that he hoped that ''sluggish schizophrenia,'' an all-purpose diagnosis used to incarcerate dissidents, would be stricken from the list of diseases. **********Soviet officials indicated that changes were coming in the emigration procedures, he said. **********Would-be emigres are often refused exit visas because they are deemed to possess state secrets or because a relative who is staying behind declines to sign a statement of permission. The authorities were blocking the departure of one man and his family because his daughter-in-law's mother refused to let her leave, Mr. Schifter said. **********''They indicated that there may be a relaxation in the veto power of relatives,'' he said. **********''One area I believe there will be movement,'' he added, ''is in the area of secrecy determination.'' The Soviet authorities have so broad a definition of secrecy that one man, for instance, was turned down because he had built swimming pools for army officers' clubs. **********But Mr. Schifter said a review commission recently established in the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet seemed to give some hope of progress in this regard. Soviet officials told him that the commission had reversed visa denials in 12 cases, and that many of the broad secrecy decisions were being made by over-zealous, lower-level bureaucrats. **********Foreign Minister Shevardnadze also alluded to this in his news conference Friday, when he said: ''The fact that this commission has to do a great deal of work means that we do have some bureaucrats remaining. However, my partners here in America have agreed that bureaucrats also exist in this country.'' **********Mr. Schifter said Soviet officials had not addressed restrictions built into a new emigration law that went into effect this year. The measure limits emigration to those with immediate family members abroad, which human rights campaigners estimate eliminates about 90 percent of the Jews who have expressed an interest in leaving. **********The Soviet authorities are reviewing cases of those previously refused exit visas, and Mr. Schifter said an average of 80 percent of the 800 Jews who are leaving each month fall into that category. Only 20 percent are new applicants, raising fears among American officials that once the estimated 10,000 to 11,000 ''refuseniks'' are processed, most new applicants will be refused and emigration will again fall to a trickle.

Geier Jr., chairman and chief executive, disclosed that the holding company and its agencies are in the midst of developing proprietary research that will be used in making advertising. **********There is nothing new about that, but unlike most advertising research, it will not be based on historical data but rather ''in prognostication of the future behavioral needs of the consumer.'' It should be in use by next year, he said. **********That was but one of the thoughts delivered to shareholders before the mandatory viewing of current advertising from around the world. https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/29/busin.snippet: LEAD: FOR a variety of reasons - ranging from embarrassing trading losses to costly overseas expansion programs that sap earnings - investment firms have recently been among the poorest stock performers on Wall Street.
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/29/busin.main_headline:
MARKET PLACE;
Possible Play In Brokerages
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/29/busin.print_headline:
MARKET PLACE;
Possible Play In Brokerages
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/29/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: FOR a variety of reasons - ranging from embarrassing trading losses to costly overseas expansion programs that sap earnings - investment firms have recently been among the poorest stock performers on Wall Street. **********FOR a variety of reasons - ranging from embarrassing trading losses to costly overseas expansion programs that sap earnings - investment firms have recently been among the poorest stock performers on Wall Street. **********For example, Shearson Lehman Brothers brought a public offering of its stock in early May at $34 a share; the shares now sell around $28.50. The giant Merrill Lynch & Company is selling around $34 and had been lower in the wake of its quarter-billion-dollar trading loss in mortgage securities; its 52-week high was $46.75. Some brokerage stocks are now selling at considerbly less than two times their book value. **********Such sad stock performance, in a market that despite the current doldrums is still up substantially this year, has led some experts to wonder if some publicly traded brokerage houses will soon become takeover targets. Ironies abound in this situation. For one thing, many investment houses have been the beneficiaries of the fees, commissions and trading profits from the recent merger mania. Merrill Lynch, for one, has been carving out a profitable niche in leveraged buyouts. **********For another, the expansion programs undertaken by many big American firms are designed to make them more competitive with the aggressive Japanese firms, which are making big inroads in New York and London. Yet those ambitious expansions weaken stock prices, making the American houses vulnerable to takeovers - by the Japanese, as well as by some big European banks. **********According to Lawrence W. Eckenfelder, an analyst for Prudential-Bache Securities in San Francisco, the names most mentioned as potential takeover targets are Paine Webber Inc. and E. F. Hutton & Company. At about $29.50 a share, Paine Webber is about $10 below its 52-week high and is selling at 1.25 times book value. Hutton, at about $36.50, is way below its high of $52.25 and is selling at 1.4 times book. Such prices may lure a buyer, some experts believe. ''A reasonably profitable, well-positioned broker,'' Mr. Eckenfelder noted, should be selling ''at two and a half or three times book.'' **********Still, he said that rumors about Paine Webber and Hutton have been floating around for six years, and nothing much has happened. He added, though, that there had been some recent sniffing at Hutton. ''I heard that Chrysler Credit at least took a look at Hutton, and Transamerica, I know, looked at Hutton,'' the Prudential-Bache analyst said. **********There is little doubt that Wall Street's firms are attractive to foreign and American investors alike. The Nippon Life Insurance Company owns a big chunk of Shearson; the Sumitomo Bank has part of Goldman, Sachs; Europeans have stakes in Drexel Burnham Lambert and the First Boston Corporation. Domestically, the Primerica Corporation's plan to buy Smith Barney, Harris Upham for $750 million, which was announced this week, is only the latest example of a large American company buying a Wall Street firm to expand into financial services. Sears, Roebuck has Dean Witter Reynolds; Travelers has Dillon, Read, and General Electric owns 80 percent of Kidder, Peabody. **********Foreign companies like American investment houses for the entree they can provide in this country. Domestic buyers, such as G.E., snap up Wall Street firms to diversify into financial services. **********And despite the shortcomings of some individual companies, the brokerage industry turned in admirable results last year. According to the Securities Industry Association, pretax net income for the industry in 1986 was $5.51 billion, a 33.1 percent gain from 1985. **********In addition to Paine Webber and Hutton, a few other Wall Street firms are grist for the takeover rumor mill. Merrill Lynch's name, for example, pops up frequently, although Mr. Eckenfelder estimated that, with 105.6 million shares outstanding, Merrill could cost an acquirer up to $6 billion. **********Another firm that has been mentioned is Bear, Stearns & Company, now trading for about $16.50 a share. A official of the firm said that a complete takeover was unlikely, because management controls much of the stock. Yet, he thinks there may be some action. ''A takeover would be too complicated,'' according to this source, who asked not to be identified. ''But Bear, Stearns is very primed for an equity infusion from the Japanese.'' **********One firm that several experts mentioned is L. F. Rothschild Inc., which has been undergoing a management shake-up. At about $12.50 a share, Rothschild is actually selling below its $12.80 book value, Mr. Eckenfelder noted. He said he had not heard ''any rumors'' about the firm, but ''it has 250 retail brokers,'' is strong in the capital markets and has an international presence. Rothschild ''is not a major force,'' he said, but if an acquirer were to pay two times book, it would get a respected firm for only about $400 million. **********Perrin Long, who follows the industry for Lipper Analytical Services, does not see that happening. ''The new management wants the opportunity to show what it can do,'' he said, adding that ''unless the price was tremendous,'' the company would fight a takeover tooth and nail. **********Mr. Long said he had not picked up any hints that any brokerages might be acquired. ''I don't think anyone is going to take over Merrill,'' he said. Not that brokerage stocks will be immune to the speculation. ''A. G. Edwards went up like gangbusters'' after the Primerica-Smith, Barney announcement, Mr. Long said. Edwards is a big regional firm based in St. Louis.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/03/world.body_text: **********Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar told member countries today that the United Nations must start borrowing in financial markets for the first time to avoid the threat of insolvency next year, largely as a result of the failure of the United States to pay its dues. **********Without such borrowing and additional budget contributions from member governments, he said, the United Nations would run out of money next August, assuming the United States again pays about half what it owes and makes a payment at the end of next year. **********In a report titled ''The Financial Crisis of the United Nations,'' he predicted that the organization would have a deficit of more than $100 million in 1988 and said the ''financial, political and institutional viability'' of the organization is ''in jeopardy.'' **********He asked the General Assembly for authority to borrow up to $50 million on international financial markets at commercial interest rates to tide the organization over until all members pay what they owe. Extra $100 Million Asked **********If the Assembly agrees, it would be the first time the United Nations has borrowed on commercial markets. **********The Secretary General also asked member states to give an additional $100 million to the United Nations Working Capital Fund. The fund, established in 1981 with $100 million to meet financial emergencies, has been exhausted. **********In addition, Mr. Perez de Cuellar asked permission to ''sell'' the debts of the United States to other member countries for cash. Under this plan the United Nations would effectively ask other governments to pay the outstanding United States contribution, giving noninterest-paying bonds in return. The bonds would be redeemed when the United States pays its dues. **********A vote on the proposals is expected next week. **********In 1981 and 1985, the Secretariat, which operates the United Nations, sought permission to borrow commercially as several agencies, including the World Bank and the International Labor Organization, are allowed to do. But member states refused, maintaining that interest on the debt would increase the organization's costs. U.S. Budget Efforts **********Some United Nations officials said they suspected that the member nations also did not want to increase the organization's financial independence. **********The United States is by far the largest United Nations debtor, owing $342 million. It is behind on its payments for this year and last year because of Congressional mistrust of the United Nations and efforts to cut the Federal deficit. **********The Secretary General noted that the United States has promised to pay $90 million this month toward the roughly $200 million it owes for this year. **********Most of the other countries in arrears have not paid due to financial difficulties. The Soviet Union recently agreed to pay its total debt to the United Nations, about $250 million. Report Cites Spending Cut **********Without more income, he predicted that the United Nations would run out of money next August. He estimated that expenditures would exceed income by $37.4 million in the third quarter of 1988 and by $72.6 million in the final quarter. **********In his report he said spending had been cut by 7.8 percent this year and that savings would exceed the target of $146 million. The biggest part of these savings have come through cuts in salaries and staff expenses, he said, including a recruitment freeze, deferral of cost-of-living adjustments and reductions in overtime, travel and the use of consultants. **********Last month member countries owed $279.2 million, or 36.9 percent, of the United Nations headquarters budget of $756 million for this year. Together with arrears of $177.2 million from previous years, the organization is now owed $456.4 million. The headquarters budget pays for New York operations. **********The report said that only 66 of the 159 member states had paid their entire contribution to the United Nations. Of the 93 members in arrears, 44 owe more than their 1987 assessment, 7 owe an amount equal to the contribution due this year and 42 owe less.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/05/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********''Losing a Market to a High-Wage Nation,'' (Forum, June 14) is only partly right in its explanation as to why German textile machinery manufacturers have beaten us in the competition for leadership of the international textile machinery market. Another basic factor is the different priorities among governments, universities and their students. **********Upon graduation, where do our brightest engineers go? Not to the textile machinery manufacturers. Instead, they can go to a defense contractor who, with cost-plus contracts, can pay more, and with the stimulus of research contracts, can offer more exciting challenges. **********We must channel incentives for our brightest and most ambitious students toward old-fashioned productive uses, or we'll never be winners in the marketplace. EUGENE L. KILIK  New York, June 14

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/26/world.main_headline: AT AGE 8, COUNTERCULTURE'S VOICE HAS CHANGED
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/26/world.print_headline: WEST BERLIN JOURNAL; AT AGE 8, COUNTERCULTURE'S VOICE HAS CHANGED
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/26/world.body_text: **********The morning news conference at the Tageszeitung takes place around a long kitchen table. Potatoes and oranges lie under a nearby aluminum stand where at lunchtime two cooks with iridescent red hair whip up a tolerable pasta and salad. **********The conference starts punctually at 10:30 with an outside journalist giving a critique of that day's ''Taz'' (pronounced tots), as the organ of West Germany's counterculture is known. Self-criticism is a lively and even turbulent tradition at a publishing commune that started in 1979 as a vociferous champion of various leftist causes but has lately mellowed and, some say, gone professional. **********With maturity has come a considerable resonance beyond its core readership of university students. Just as the once-disruptive Green Party has slowly worked its way into the fringes of the West German power structure, so the Green-friendly Taz claims a growing clientele of lawyers, doctors and other professional people and it is not infrequently quoted in the establishment press. **********There is no hierarchy at the Taz -everyone from the cook to the newly appointed business editor gets the same $775 a month - and no one was really in charge of today's meeting of two dozen editors and reporters in their 20's and 30's. The thrust of a local radio journalist's criticism was that the Taz's Monday news pages were pretty similar to those of other dailies. A Point About Coverage **********As the agenda drifted to new business, Imma Harms, whose interests make her roughly the science editor, interrupted, wanting to know why the arrest of the leadership of the French terrorist group Direct Action was not on the front page. She made her point several times during the meeting, concluding, ''I would suggest that those of us who are interested should form a group and talk about it.'' **********It is a fair bet that the Direct Action arrests would have been given a lot bigger play had they broken in the Taz's infant years. For the newspaper emerged from the angry, fearful and disoriented mood of the West German far left as it was recovering from the crushing of the Red Army Faction terrorist group in 1978; the moral line at the time between ''resistance'' and violence was often a blurry one. **********A meridian was thus crossed last November when the Taz splashed across its front page an open letter to the Red Army Faction written by the brothers of Gerold von Braunmuhl, a high-ranking Foreign Ministry official assassinated by the terrorist group outside his home in Bonn. **********The letter rebutted the Marxist-Leninist jargon of the terrorist group's communique justifying Mr. von Braunmuhl's assassination, ending: ''Stop. Come back. Have the courage to reconsider your murderous intellectual apparatus. Your arguments don't find their targets -only your bullets do. You have done the most horrible and senseless thing.'' Letters Are Mostly Approving **********In response, the Taz was inundated by letters from readers and - suggestive of a shift in sentiment on the West German left - they mostly approved of the newspaper's decision to print the statement in big type on the front page. **********In the hallways of the Taz's cluttered offices, various editors and reporters acknowledged that the paper had lately taken a more detached attitude toward the left - a small step toward a more professional kind of journalism. ''A committed journalism assumes a state of innocence,'' commented Antje Bauer, who handles news about Europe. ''But today we see it's not possible to present things as simply as one once did.'' **********The newspaper's coverage of the Middle East remains openly sympathetic to the Palestine Liberation Organization. And the picture of America painted in the Taz is still a highly critical one; in a recently published interview an East German scientist argued the case for the charge that the AIDS virus was developed by military researchers in the United States. **********''We all love New York and San Francisco,'' observed Kuno Kruse, one of the seven remaining ''founding father'' journalists still on the Taz's staff of 170. ''But Washington is our political foe.'' East Germany Is Unfriendly **********The Taz has correspondents in Moscow, Paris, London, Johannesburg, Jerusalem, Rome and Madrid, but the East German Communist authorities just across the Berlin wall have refused to accredit anyone from the paper. The newspaper has long been a stout supporter of dissident groups inside East Germany. **********The Taz now sells 60,000 copies across West Germany. Two years ago, the newspaper's circulation had dipped dangerously, but a fresher layout and its aggressive coverage of the Chernobyl nuclear catastrophe and the AIDS epidemic have revived sales. **********The Taz's egalitarian salary structure enables it to survive with only 10 percent of its costs covered by advertising, but established publications that pay two or three times as much regularly steal star reporters. There seems, though, to be no shortage of young journalists attracted by the enormous freedom that goes with writing for the Taz. **********''If I write an article, no one can change its tendency,'' said Mr. Kruse. ''But over the years a lot of people have themselves changed and the paper has changed with them. But not because anyone has ordered that the line should change.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/16/world.main_headline: Russians See Moscow Vs. Washington on TV
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/16/world.print_headline: Russians See Moscow Vs. Washington on TV
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/16/world.body_text: **********Millions of Soviet television viewers woke up this morning to hear their country portrayed as the world's worst violator of human rights in an unusual two-hour broadcast that broke a bit of new ground for glasnost. **********Between American commercials for cornflakes and home-power tools, viewers of the live broadcast, linking Moscow and Washington, watched American lawmakers and Soviet officials assail each other over Soviet restrictions on emigration, religion and censorship. **********They saw an American woman break down in tears because she has been completely cut off from her Soviet husband. They heard a brief but pointed account of the use of psychiatric hospitals to punish political nonconformists. **********''We all know perfectly well that for most of this century the Soviet Union has been a hell for human rights,'' declared Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, in remarks the Soviet interpreter failed to translate until they had been repeated a third time. Previews of Soap Operas **********The broadcast was the second in a series of live satellite encounters between Congress and members of the Soviet legislature, but the first to tread such sensitive ground. It was broadcast at 6:30 A.M. in the Soviet Union and at 11:30 P.M. Eastern time Wednesday night in the United States by ABC News. **********Despite the early hour, the broadcast was publicized in the newspapers and on the prime-time newscast and it was hard to find anyone in Moscow who had not watched it. **********The exchange was shown here along with American commercials, public service announcements on alcoholism and teen-age drug abuse, and previews of soap operas, which, though untranslated, provided Soviet viewers with a dazzling glimpse of American wealth and a reassuring hint of social ills. **********Many Soviet viewers interviewed today were clearly startled and discomfited by the public airing of their isolation from the Western world. Growing Soviet Self-Confidence **********The decision to broadcast the exchange live and uncut seemed to reflect a growing self-confidence on the part of the Soviet Union concerning its handling of human-rights issues, a sense that it has found a reasonably presentable case after years of simply refusing to discuss its domestic affairs. **********The Soviet approach now is to admit some abuses, insist that they are gradually being corrected, and steer the conversation to what Soviet citizens would consider shortcomings in American society - unemployment, homelessness and social inequality. **********The discussion was preceded by two films prepared by ABC News and Soviet television. The Soviet film stressed constitutional rights and cited American social ills. The ABC film included a short clip of Yuri Orlov, the emigre human-rights campaigner, urging Soviet citizens, in Russian, not to be afraid of ''more radical reforms,'' and of Lev Timofeyev, a former political prisoner, warning that ''glasnost'' rests on ''the nice words'' of the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev. **********As soon as the film was over, Soviet officials announced that two longtime Jewish dissidents mentioned in it, Natan and Etya Tkach, were free to leave.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/23/busin.body_text: **********When the airline industry was deregulated in 1978, the unfettered market was expected to give rise to scores of low-cost carriers that would create a bonanza for consumers, put the existing companies on the defensive and even run some of them out of business. **********But things have not turned out that way at all. In most cases, it has been the upstarts that failed. And despite mergers that did away with such old-line carriers as National and Republic, many of the remaining airlines have become more powerful than ever. **********Consumers, meanwhile, have been left with fewer choices and higher rates on some routes. In many cases, nonstop flights are no longer available. In the deregulated environment, airlines have concentrated on high-volume cities, and many routes are now served by only one or two major carriers, which has often resulted in higher fares. **********Indeed, thanks to mergers and the disappearance of so many upstart carriers, the large, established airlines now control more than 90 percent of the traffic. Door Is Shut **********Indeed, there has been such a high failure rate among young carriers -including Air One, People Express and McClain Airlines - that many in the industry believe the door to new entries is virtually shut. **********Only two upstart airlines of any size remain, America West and Midway, and they see little prospect of others joining them. **********''I cannot envision a business plan or strategy that would get people to invest in a startup,'' said Michael J. Conway, chairman and chief operating officer of America West, which has its main hub and headquarters in Phoenix and a smaller hub in Las Vegas, Nev. **********Julius Maldutis, an analyst at Salomon Brothers, said investors had become leery of putting up money for new airlines because of their abysmal record. 'No Way' **********To start a new airline now would take about $100 million, he said. ''Can you see venture capitalists throwing in $100 million?'' he asked. ''No way.'' **********Virtually all major airports are now dominated by one or two airlines. Because they control most gates and the most desirable landing times, there is very little room for a new competitor to enter the business. **********''Every major city is hubbed, every gate is used, every ticket counter is occupied, and no one wants to give anything to anybody,'' David R. Hinson, chairman of Midway, said. ''We don't want anybody else to play.'' **********The surviving upstarts generally try to avoid battles over pricing and service with the major carriers -many of whom have slashed their operating costs. Avoiding Conflict **********''We've been successful by avoiding conflicts,'' Mr. Conway of America West said. ''You don't get into a slugging match with airlines that are developed.'' **********His airline has concentrated on markets that the big carriers have overlooked or rejected. For example, America West provides the only nonstop service between Phoenix and the Baltimore-Washington area. **********When America West has had to contend with a major carrier, the going has been rough. For instance, it formerly had to use one of American Airlines' gates at Los Angeles airport. That meant America West planes sometimes had to stand in line waiting while American's crews gave their own planes priority. **********Even if a new airline can put together the financing, lease a few planes and find a suitable airport, its chances of surviving its early years are slim. Startup Period Shortened **********Alfred S. Altschul, vice president of finance at Midway Airlines, which is based in Chicago and flies mostly to the East and South, recalled that in the early days of deregulation, new carriers had two to three years to gain a foothold, before large carriers reacted to the competitive threat. **********The upstarts in those days had lower operating costs and could often undercut the fares charged by the largely unionized big carriers. **********Now, however, many of the big airlines have reduced their costs through two-tier wage structures and by using more efficient aircraft. **********Meanwhile, Midway's pilots have been organized by the Air Line Pilots Association and last week its flight attendants voted to be represented by the Association of Flight Attendants, despite determined opposition from management. Big Airlines Fight Back **********The major carriers are now quick to respond when an upstart challenges them in an important market. Indeed, they have mastered the art of selling just enough discount tickets to keep their seats filled, while getting higher prices for the rest. **********Mr. Altshul estimates that an upstart would need a fleet of about 20 planes to quickly establish a network around a hub from which it could offer competitive service. **********Given this scenario, it is hardly surprising that many industry experts saw the end of People Express -which was absorbed early this year by Continental, a subsidiary of the Texas Air Corporation - as the end of an era. **********This year, the large airlines demonstrated their strength by pushing through a series of fare increases. Even Continental, the low-cost carrier that had so often acted as the spoiler in recent years when others tried to raise their prices, has changed with the times. In recent months, Continental has initiated or supported fare increases.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/02/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: Investors hoping for higher prices often invoke the imminent arrival of a new wave of buyers, to push quotes upward. ''Wait until the public starts buying,'' is one standby. Now some analysts - covering the United States stock market and international gold markets - say, ''Wait till the Japanese buy. **********Investors hoping for higher prices often invoke the imminent arrival of a new wave of buyers, to push quotes upward. ''Wait until the public starts buying,'' is one standby. Now some analysts - covering the United States stock market and international gold markets - say, ''Wait till the Japanese buy.'' Their hopes depend, in varying degrees, on a topping of the Japanese stock market and a bottoming of the dollar against the yen. **********On a visit to Japan, Joseph A. Feshbach, of Prudential-Bache Securities, was convinced that money managers there are ''itching to buy our stock market,'' he said in a recent report. Once the Japanese believe that the dollar has made its low, he said, ''the potential is explosive.'' **********Steve H. Hanke, chief economist for Friedberg's Commodity & Currency Comments, says that the oriental equities markets drew speculators away from the metals markets. ''When the equities markets cool down, I think you'll see a rush back into the metals markets,'' he said. If the Japanese stock market has topped, he added, other investors seeking a ''safe haven'' might also head for gold and platinum. **********John Brimelow, director of international research at the Keane Securities Company, agreed. If Japanese equities weaken, ''a small percentage of that money going into gold would make a difference,'' he said. But an official of a major American investment bank mentioned reports of heavy Japanese buying of stocks on margin and questioned whether a break in prices in Tokyo would leave debt-heavy investors with much capital to redeploy.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/09/busin.body_text: **********RONALD K. SHERMAN joins Calet, Hirsch & Spector today as president. In doing so, he is once again in the company of Glen W. Fortinberry, chairman and president of Ross Roy Inc., Detroit, the parent company of C.H.&S. The two had worked together in the Detroit office of J. Walter Thompson until 1975, when Mr. Fortinberry became president of the agency's Eastern establishment, including the New York office, and Mr. Sherman became general manager in New York. **********On Friday Mr. Fortinberry described Mr. Sherman as a catalyst who encourages great creative work, which is exactly how J.W.T.'s chairman, Don Johnston, described him when he took over Thompson's New York operation. **********Larry Spector, 55 years old, whose only title at C.H.&S. has been chief executive, will now assume the title of chairman of the management committee. Neil Calet and Peter Hirsch will continue as vice chairmen and co-creative directors. **********Mr. Sherman, now 43, was previously vice chairman of Wells, Rich, Greene, which he joined in 1982 as president of the division made up of New York and Detroit. This move was natural enough since by that time W.R.G. was the Ford Motor Company's corporate agency and Ford was also a J.W.T. client. Also at Thompson, Mr. Sherman was president of its entertainment division. **********Brooklyn-born, Mr. Sherman graduated from Choate and Princeton and began working for Thompson while still earning his M.B.A. at Columbia. Among his other activities these days is the chairmanship of the International Film Festival, one of a multitude of bestowers of awards for advertising creativity.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/06/world.main_headline: U.S. NAVY COPTER IS FIRED ON BY A SHIP IN THE PERSIAN GULF
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/06/world.print_headline: U.S. NAVY COPTER IS FIRED ON BY A SHIP IN THE PERSIAN GULF
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/06/world.body_text: **********A United States Navy helicopter was fired on today by a merchant ship in the southern Persian Gulf, the Pentagon said. The helicopter took evasive action and was not hit. **********The incident, which officials said was the first time in memory that American forces had been fired on in the region, occurred as the helicopter, based on the destroyer O'Bannon, was conducting routine operations. **********The identity and country of registry of the merchant ship, which fired a surface-to-air missile at the helicopter, are not known, according to a Pentagon statement. The Defense Department said it was investigating the incident. Misses by 500 Yards **********The helicopter, an SH-2 used for antisubmarine warfare, saw the missile coming and moved out of the way, the Pentagon said. The missile missed by about 500 yards. The helicopter was three miles from the merchant ship when the missile was fired and was about 38 miles from its mother ship. **********A Pentagon official said the helicopter did not identify itself to the merchant ship, either before or after the shooting. After the shooting, the O'Bannon tried unsuccessfully to hail the ship and to pursue her. **********It is not uncommon for merchant ships in transit to and from Iran or Iraq to be attacked in the Persian Gulf, including by helicopters, the official said. The merchant ship may have thought she was being attacked, he said. **********Although the Navy helicopter was armed with torpedos, it would not have responded to the attack by shooting back under these circumstances, the official said. **********The O'Bannon is one of five Navy ships assigned to the Middle East Force, which has the Persian Gulf region as one of its operating areas. The ships often watch over American merchant ships in the gulf. In one episode last May, one of the Navy ships warned off an Iranian vessel that was approaching an American merchant ship, fearing the Iranians were planning to come alongside and inspect the American vessel.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/29/busin.body_text: **********For a little more than two years, computers for scientific and technical users have been the hottest sector in the industry, sending manufacturers scrambling to keep up with demand. Though sales are still soaring, the manufacturers' ranks have so swelled that industry leaders and analysts alike say a shakeout is inevitable. **********Used primarily by high-tech designers and researchers, the machines typically perform tasks at speeds approaching those of the top-of-the-line supercomputers made by Cray Research Inc. Yet they are priced closer to the Digital Equipment Corporation's VAX minicomputers and have thus been dubbed mini-supercomputers. They usually sell for between $200,000 and $1 million, compared with $5 million or more for a Cray. **********First offered by the Convex Computer Corporation less than three years ago, the mini-super is expected to achieve sales of $1.1 billion to $1.9 billion by 1990, according to analysts, easily making it the fastest-growing segment of the computer industry. **********As many as 20 companies have now joined the mini-super race, with vast sums of venture capital bet on the outcome. The situation is comparable to the proliferation of personal computer makers in the early 1980's, analysts say - there are just too many players. **********''Demand has grown in line with our expectations, but the list of suppliers has grown too fast,'' said Jeffry Canin, an analyst with Hambrecht & Quist in San Francisco. **********Indeed, the shakeout may have already begun. Losses at Floating Point Systems Inc. of Beaverton, Ore., which pioneered the mini-super with its add-on array processors for the VAX, have prompted a management shake-up, layoffs and reductions in salary. Two other suppliers - American Supercomputer Inc. and Denelcor Inc. - have closed their doors. **********When the dust clears, said Richard A. Shaffer, the editor and publisher of The Technologic Partners Computer Letter, only one or two of the mini-super manufacturers will still be around. ''There are too many baby companies to survive when they become adults,'' he said. Quest for Differentiation **********In this environment, the suppliers are hustling to differentiate themselves, either by the breadth of applications of their machines or by their price/performance ratio, with boasts such as one-fourth the performance of a Cray for one-tenth the price. **********One company banking on maximum applicability is Convex of Richardson, Tex., which has an arsenal of more than 100 software programs written for its machines by other companies. Convex introduced the first stand-alone mini-super in 1984, basing it on the design architecture of the Cray supercomputer. That architecture employs vector processing, which permits an array of data to be handled simultaneously, resulting in much faster execution than the step-by-step approach of conventional computers. **********Although a Convex machine cannot run programs written for the Cray, the similarity of architecture makes it easy to adapt the software, according to Robert Paluck, Convex's president and chief executive officer. (A San Diego-based company, Scientific Computer Systems, actually offers a mini-super that can run Cray programs unmodified, prompting analysts to call the machine a Crayette.) But customers are less interested in innovative architecture or performance benchmarks than in getting a specific job done, Mr. Paluck said. ''A company has typically already chosen its applications software, so you don't even get in the door without it,'' he said. Customers want to make certain that a given machine runs that software and ''how you do it -whether you use squirrels in a cage or vector processing - doesn't matter,'' he said. Difficult for Newcomers **********It will be very difficult for companies entering the market late to convince major software producers to write for their machines, Mr. Paluck said, which will in turn handicap their sales. He predicted these difficultties would be apparent by the end of the year. **********While no one denies the importance of software, other companies are betting that innovative architecture will give them an edge. The front-runner among these is the Alliant Computer Systems Corporation of Acton, Mass., which uses a technology called parallel processing. That system carves up standard programs and distributes the parts to as many as eight processors, allowing many calculations to be performed simultaneously. **********The technology allows the Alliant machine to perform certain types of tasks very rapidly. In addition, the machine's architecture permits customers to start small and build a system as their finances allow. ''We can offer a line of products starting at $250,000,'' Ronald H. Gruner, Alliant's president and co-founder, said. ''Later, customers can add processors to the same machine - it's a level of incremental growth not available from anyone else.'' **********Alliant's sales strategy has been to start small. By concentrating on niche markets it became profitable within three years of its December 1982 founding. ''A mistake many start-ups make is they don't realize there are segments of the market they can focus on very profitably right out of the gate,'' Mr. Gruner said. Credibility an Issue **********In the long term, however, a mini-super manufacturer must sell to mainstream corporate customers, who, in addition to performance and the ability to run existing applications software, require a high level of credibility from their suppliers. Accordingly, some of the companies are forming strategic alliances with large established computer manufacturers to help them get in the door. **********For example, Cydrome Inc., which expects to ship its first mini-super by midyear, recently signed a marketing agreement under which Prime Computer of Natick, Mass., will distribute and service the product. Prime, a maker of minicomputers, has invested in Cydrome, which was founded in May 1984 and is based in Milpitas, Calif. **********''Fortune 500 companies have, over the last five years, developed a short list of companies to deal with -I.B.M., Digital and others,'' said Andre O. Schwager, Cydrome's president. ''The only way in is through one of these distribution channels.'' **********Such alliances are important on a technical level because a mini-supercomputer ''has to fit into the ways customers are using computers today,'' Mr. Schwager said. ''Most big companies today are already in technology overload. They don't need bits and bytes - they need solutions.'' Giants Expected to Join In **********But joining hands with a major manufacturer is also a recognition of what many say is the inevitable entry of the giants into the market. The International Business Machines Corporation has introduced a vector-processing attachment for its 3090 series mainframe machines, and Digital is expected to add similar capability to the VAX within two years. **********In the meantime, Floating Point announced last month that it had entered an agreement under which Digital would market systems combining the VAX with Floating Point's attached-array processors. **********''There is a temptation for I.B.M. and Digital to increasingly offer vector capability in their machines,'' John Harte, Floating Point's vice president for sales and marketing, said. ''But we're specialists - we think we can stay sufficiently ahead and offer something more than DEC can themselves.'' **********While analysts attribute Floating Point's ills to its late entry with a stand-alone mini-super, Mr. Harte said the company had suffered from severe discounting by the newer companies and a slowdown in military spending. He expects both of those factors to ease in 1987. **********But still more competition is on the horizon at the low end of the market. Manufacturers of so-called super-work stations, such as Dana Computer Inc. of Sunnyvale, Calif., now promise performance approaching that of the mini-supers in a package hardly bigger than a PC. **********If they achieve the performance ''they're talking about,'' Mr. Harte said, ''they will be very competitive for all of us.''
