https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/30/world.body_text: **********A Soviet man who has waited eight years to join his American wife in the United States said today he has been told he will be allowed to leave. **********The Russian, Matvey Finkel, said officials have told him he would receive formal permission next week to go to the United States with his wife, Susan Graham of Spokane, Wash., and their infant daughter. **********At least two other Soviet citizens married to Americans, Svetlana Braun and Sergei Petrov, have been promised fresh reviews of their cases, according to members of a group that has been working to reunite the families. **********Members of the group said Soviet officials have also begun, for the first time, to discuss the case of Galina Goltzman Michelson, who has been denied permission to join her husband since he defected more than 30 years ago. In meetings with American diplomats, Soviet officials have refused to even talk about that case, reflecting the strong resentment that surrounds defectors from this country. **********The moves appear to be the first gestures in a pre-summit meeting human-rights ritual. Soviet officials have customarily made concessions to American human-rights demands in the months before high-level meetings. **********Mr. Finkel said he presumed that the permission he is to receive is intended to warm the atmosphere before Secretary of State George P. Shultz and the Russian Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze meet in the United States next month to discuss a summit meeting. **********The most common explanations given for refusing to permit emigration are that a citizen knows state secrets or has failed to get the permission of close relatives. **********Mr. Finkel has been refused the right to emigrate on grounds he might have learned state secrets during his year of compulsory military duty 15 years ago. **********Mr. Finkel and Ms. Graham met when she was an exchange student here. They were married in 1979. **********According to Mr. Finkel, there are currently nine Soviet-American couples awaiting reunification.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/14/busin.main_headline: Simmons Aide Fills Chief's Post at NL
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/14/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Simmons Aide Fills Chief's Post at NL
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/14/busin.body_text: **********J. Landis Martin, a top legal adviser to Harold C. Simmons, the Texas investor, has been named president and chief executive of NL Industries, which Mr. Simmons controls. **********Mr. Martin, 41 years old, is a senior partner with Kirkland & Ellis, a law firm with offices in Chicago, Denver and Washington. NL is a petroleum services and chemical company based in New York that employs about 10,000 worldwide. **********In March, Theodore C. Rogers, 52, resigned as chairman and chief executive of NL Industries and Mr. Simmons took those jobs. Mr. Simmons will remain chairman. Mr. Martin will also become chairman and chief executive of NL Chemicals. **********''This is the only career change I've made,'' said Mr. Martin, who has been with Kirkland & Ellis for 14 years after graduating from Northwestern University School of Law. Speaking of his new duties, he said, ''This is something I've always had in the back of my mind, something I thought I would enjoy.'' **********Mr. Simmons has been a client of Kirkland & Ellis for 20 years and Mr. Martin met the Texan after he joined the law firm. While he may have helped him with legal problems, turning around NL may prove more difficult. **********NL announced the election of William H. Welch, 57, as president and chief operating officer of NL Petroleum Services in Houston. Fred W. Montanari, 52, executive vice president and chief operating officer of NL Chemicals, will continue to be responsible for day-to-day operations of the chemical unit. **********Mr. Martin said the petroleum services part of the company was depressed with no certainty of a comeback any time soon. **********''We're going to focus more on costs,'' he said. ''Our objective is to be on a positive cash flow basis at the current level of activity.'' **********He added that acquisitions were ''always a possibility - that may be something we'll be doing in the future.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/14/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Dow Quitting South Africa
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/14/busin.body_text: **********The Dow Chemical Company is selling its manufacturing plant in South Africa, saying that persistent racial unrest made it senseless to do business there. **********Dow said today that it would sell the Mer-National pharmaceutical plant in Clayville, 40 miles northeast of Johannesburg, to the South African business conglomerate Premier Milling Group for an unspecified price. The plant employs about 125 people. Dow will retain its 75-employee sales operation in South Africa. **********Fifty-one American companies have pulled out of South Africa since the beginning of last year, many to protest the white-minority Government's system of racial segregation, according to the Investor Responsibility Research Center in Washington. **********Paul F. Oreffice, Dow's president and chief executive, said Thursday in a speech in nearby Saginaw that there were political and social pressures to sell the pharmaceutical plant but that the final decision was based on business considerations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/05/busin.body_text: **********In a move reflecting concern that banks may be assuming too much risk in Eurobond activity, the Bank of England has proposed a role for itself in regulating that market. **********The proposal, released Tuesday, was quickly criticized by market participants, who warned that the Eurobond business could move away from London if regulations became too strict. The Eurobond market evolved in the 1960's as a regulation-free environment where banks and securities dealers could arrange large financings for companies and nations. Trading now totals an estimated $2 trillion a year. **********The British central bank's proposal outlines capital requirements for banks that underwrite new Eurobond issues. **********It also wants to assess whether a lead underwriter is financially fit and has enough expertise to distribute new issues. It would also want banks to discuss with regulators their plans to underwrite new issues. **********An official at an American securities firm, said: ''The Bank of England has to remember that the Eurobond market isn't a British market but an international market. **********I'd be perfectly happy to move to Luxembourg.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/13/world.main_headline: CANADIAN INQUIRY CRITICIZES TIMES REPORT ON JOSEF MENGELE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/13/world.print_headline: CANADIAN INQUIRY CRITICIZES TIMES REPORT ON JOSEF MENGELE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/13/world.body_text: **********The Government inquiry into the presence of Nazi war criminals in Canada today criticized a report in The New York Times in January 1985 that said that Josef Mengele, accused of complicity in 400,000 deaths at the Auschwitz concentration camp, was reported to have made an application in Buenos Aires in 1962 for a visa to enter Canada. **********The 1,000-page report of the Canadian inquiry commission devoted a 15-page chapter to the Mengele charge and concluded that it had not received ''a shred of evidence'' to support the Times article. The report was also critical of Sol Littman, representative in Canada for the Simon Wiesenthal Center in Los Angeles, whom the commission identified as the primary source for article in The Times. **********The article appeared to have played a major role in the decision by Prime Minister Brian Mulroney to appoint the commission in February 1985. The Government order establishing the inquiry under Justice Jules P. Deschenes of the Quebec Superior Court began with a reference to the concerns aroused in Canada by the report that Mr. Mengele ''may have entered or attempted to enter Canada.'' Documents Are Cited **********Two weeks earlier, the Times report, by Ralph Blumenthal, received wide publicity here. The article cited United States Army intelligence documents obtained by the Wiesenthal Center as indicating that Mr. Mengele may have been arrested and released in the American zone of Vienna in 1947 and may have sought a Canadian visa from Buenos Aires under a pseudonym in 1962. **********The Deschenes report said the commission had investigated the possibility thoroughly and found no evidence to support it. It said that there was no Canadian immigration ofice in Buenos Aires in 1962, and that the Department of Immigration in Ottawa, to which any application would have been passed, had no record of any application under Mr. Mengele's name or any of the pseudonyms he was known to have used. Interviewed in November **********The report said that counsel for the inquiry had interviewed Mr. Blumenthal in New York in November 1985. It quoted the Times reporter as saying that he had ''access to no other documents'' than those released in the United States. This appeared to be a reference to the Army materials obtained by the Wiesenthal Center that the report said had been inspected and found to ''make no reference whatsoever to a Buenos Aires approach by Mengele.'' **********The report said that Mr. Blumenthal, in the interview in New York, had also said that there were no ''other records'' to support his article, and had added that ''with the benefit of hindsight'' his report might appear ''a bit loose.'' The reporter was quoted as saying that the purported Mengele visa application was first brought to his attention by Mr. Littman. **********Mr. Blumenthal said the Canadian report ''mischaracterizes the tenor of the story, which fairly reflected the state of information available at the time.'' He continued: ''The article was based on declassified documents and on other information provided by the Wiesenthal Center. Subsequent disclosures of fact since the story appeared in January 1985, and the Canadian Government investigation now cast doubt on any connection with Canadian immigration authorities.'' **********The commission said it had been advised by lawyers for The Times 10 days after the Blumenthal interview that the reporter would not be permitted to appear as a witness before the commission, that he would not sign an account of his conversation with the commission's investigators and that ''there would be no further communication.'' **********''The commission regrets the refusal of The New York Times to cooperate with it,'' the report added. ''Subsequent events, however, have robbed that refusal of its potentially negative effects.'' **********This appeared to be a reference to the Canadian Government's finding that reports of the Mengele visa application were not true. **********Last year, an international team of forensic experts determined that a skeleton buried near Sao Paulo, Brazil, was the remains of Mr. Mengele, who was reported to have drowned in 1979.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/21/busin.main_headline: AN UNLIKELY LAB FOR FREE MARKETS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/21/busin.print_headline: AN UNLIKELY LAB FOR FREE MARKETS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/21/busin.body_text: **********ON a continent known for protectionism and government control over the economy, Chile's controversial effort to create a market economy is finally showing signs of success after a drastic collapse in 1982 and 1983. **********Despite the burdens of a repressive dictatorship that has made the country a pariah of the international community, rock-bottom prices for copper, its chief export, and a $20 billion foreign debt, Chile's economy should expand for the fourth consecutive year in 1987. Not surprisingly, the group of economists who have advised Chile's military Government since it overthrew President Salvador Allende in a bloody coup in 1973, is calling the turnaround a vindication of its free-market policies. **********The economists, known as the Chicago Boys because so many of them were graduated by the University of Chicago, viewed its task as confronting not only the heritage of the Socialists and Communists of the Allende Government but also the old conservative farming and industrial elite, which had been accustomed to subsidies and protected markets. **********Their policies, based on low tariffs on imports, drastic cuts in Government spending and bureaucracy and streamlining state-owned corporations with the idea of selling them to the public, have finally produced results. Still, some analysts question the merits of some of the free-market policies and wonder whether Chile's poor have actually shared in the economic revival. **********The Chicago Boys can tick off a number of healthy economic trends to support their case. Chile's inflation-adjusted gross national product grew 5.7 percent last year and Wharton Econometrics predicts it will grow by 4.7 percent this year. Unemployment fell to 8.8 percent last year, down from 12 percent in 1985, and 21 percent 1982. Currently, about 4 percent of the labor force is enrolled in public works programs down from 8 percent during the 1982-83 recession. **********But the country's single biggest success story is the expansion of exports. Once Chile's only significant export, copper now makes up less than half the value of all exports. Chile still produces and exports more copper than any other country but with copper prices depressed and other exports growing, copper is less important than in the past. **********Most of the growth has come in fresh fruit and other farm and fisheries products. Exports totaled $4.2 billion last year, up about 10 percent from 1985, providing a trade surplus of $1.3 billion. **********The Government predicts exports will grow to $7 billion in 1990, even though copper prices are not expected to improve significantly. Chile hopes to greatly expand exports of wood products from the south of the country, where trees grow more rapidly than most places in the world, with the possibility that wood products could rival copper in export importance by the end of the century. **********Even Chile's manufacturing industries, which traditionally turned out products exclusively for domestic consumption, are beginning to become exporters. Jorge Frauenberg, manager of the Tecno Industrial Company, a maker of home appliances, said that his company had recently found markets for its refrigerators in smaller countries in the Western Hemisphere and Asia. **********Because of the 1982-83 recession, which produced hundreds of bankruptcies and Government intervention in the banking system, the state still controls much more of the economy than it wants to control. But the trend is toward privatization or re-privatization. **********One of the things the Chicago Boys learned along the way is that it is difficult to privatize big state-created corporations when there is no major foreign investor waiting to buy. Employee stock purchases and the investments of the private social security plans have become important in a number of these efforts. **********Critics of Gen Augusto Pinochet Ugarte's regime find some things to praise in the re-ordered economy. Still they would like to introduce measures to cushion the country, and especially its poor, from the vagaries of global economics. **********Andres Zaldivar, a Christian Democrat who is viewed as a potential Presidential candidate in the uncertain future, said the figures show ''that the economy is successful, compared to the rest of Latin America.'' He added that he did not think there would be ''profound changes in the management of the economy regarding private enterprise or the market, no price controls and no resumption of bank nationalizations.'' **********''But there are hidden problems,'' said Mr. Zaldivar, ''that will come up as soon as a civilian government takes office. There will have to be a strong correction in social policy because any civilian government will face demands for better salaries, more jobs and housing.'' **********ALEJANDRO FOXLEY, a leading Christian Democratic economist, said he was ''not a believer in naive laissez-faire economics'' but that the Christian Democrats, if they took office, would have ''eclectic'' policies and maintain a market orientation. He said that a too rigid approach to economics caused Chile's G.N.P. to decline more steeply in relation to other Latin American nations when commodities prices dropped at the beginning of the decade. **********''Ask yourself what would have happened with Japanese imports into the United States if Congress had had to confront an unemployment rate of 30 percent,'' said Mr. Foxley. ''That is what happened here and no one was listening.'' **********Jose Pinera, Chile's labor minister from 1978 to 1981, argued that if the economic situation of the poor had worsened it could be attributed to the world commodities crisis, not to Chile's specific policies. There is some support for this view in a World Bank study of five Latin American countries, which concluded that Costa Rica and Chile had made the most effort to cushion the poor from the collapse of commodity prices. **********While rejecting challenges to their economic wisdom, the economic brain trust that has served the Pinochet regime acknowledges there was a large contradiction in trying to implant economic liberalism under a military dictatorship. **********Pablo Barahona, a Chicago graduate and former minister of economy, said the situation in 1973 had been ''so chaotic, so radical, so extreme that I would say easily 80 percent of the people found it completely legitimate for the armed forces to take power, and completely legitimate that the armed forces put down the centers of resistance.'' **********He said it was about 1977 before the economists began to realize they had philosophical differences with those who envisioned a ''fascist'' political structure. That became apparent, he said, when the economists began to suggest - and were rebuffed - that the Government should divest itself of its newspaper and television channel because Government ownership of the media was inconsistent with a market economy. **********Sebastian Pinera, a banker and brother of the former labor minister, said he feared the political question would come to obscure the real economic accomplishments. **********''The problem,'' he said, ''is that free-market economics has come to be associated in the minds of many people with dictatorship.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/23/busin.body_text: **********A lumber agreement with the United States, in which Canada agreed to impose a 15 percent export tax on softwood exports, has been approved by the House of Commons. **********Legislation putting into effect the Dec. 30 accord passed by a vote of 92 to 33. **********Canada agreed to impose the tax, after heated negotiations, to avoid punitive duties after the United States Department of Commerce upheld charges from the United States lumber industry that Canadian lumber was unfairly subsidized. **********The United States industry complained about the legislative delay, although the export tax has been collected since Jan. 8. **********By creating an export tax, Canada receives $600 million (Canadian), or $450 million (United States), in revenue. The money is being distributed to the lumber provinces, mainly British Columbia. **********Canadian officials have asked the United States to increase exemptions from the tax, but Washington refused to consider the request until the legislation passed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/15/busin.body_text: **********Debt **********The Commonwealth of Puerto Rico is offering about $430 million in tax and revenue anticipation notes due July 29, 1988, priced to yield 5.60 percent, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs. The issue is rated Mig-1 by Moody's and SP-1+ by S.&P. **********The Development Authority of Burke County, Ga., is tentatively offering $50 million of 9 3/8 percent pollution control revenue bonds due in 2017 at 100, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs, for Georgia Power Co.'s Vogtle project. For certain investors the bonds are subject to the alternative minimum tax. The issue is rated BBB by S.&P., with a Baa-2 rating by Moody's expected. **********The Federal Home Loan Banks plans to announce today the interest rates for a three-part financing totaling $4.375 billion. Investors will be offered $2 billion of one-year bonds due Dec. 27, 1988; $1.635 billion due Dec. 26, 1989, and $740 million due Dec. 28, 1992. **********Manor Care Inc. has filed for up to $100 million of senior subordinated notes due in 1997 through Drexel Burnham Lambert. **********Virginia Electric and Power Co. has filed for $300 million of mortgage bonds.  Ratings **********Bank of New England Corp.'s commercial paper rating was lifted to Prime-1, from Prime-2, by Moody's. **********Iowa Public Service's senior debt rating was lowered to A, from AA-, and its preferred stock rating to A-, from A+, by S.&P. The utility's commercial paper rating was also cut, to A-1, from A-1+. **********MCA Inc.'s senior debt rating was lowered to A, from A+, and the subordinated debt rating to A-, from A, by S.&P. **********Washington Post Co.'s senior debt rating was lifted to AA, from A+, and its commercial paper rating raised to A-1+, from A-1, by S.&P.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/24/world.body_text: **********Seven children and three women drowned today when an overloaded ferry boat sank at Tongi near Dhaka, fire brigade officials said. The officials said the boat was carrying about 200 passengers, beyond its capacity of 100, when it sank in the Torag River 12 miles north of this capital.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/18/world.body_text: **********Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, says that his troops have ousted Chad's forces from a disputed border zone and that the seven-year-old war is over, Libya's official press agency said today. **********But Chad's Ambassador to France called the Libyan leader's statement ''a flagrant manifestation of dishonesty.'' **********''By these words, Qaddafi wants to impose on Africa and the international community his policy of 'fait accompli,' of annexation and of expansion into Chad,'' said the Ambassador, Ahmad Allam-Mi. **********JANA, the Libyan press agency quoted Colonel Qaddafi as telling a rally Wednesday night that the war ''is over after the dogs of war were pushed out of Aozou, destroyed in Al Sarra.'' **********RASHEIYE, Lebanon, Sept. 17 (Reuters) - Libya has recruited at least 1,000 Druse fighters from the Bekaa in eastern Lebanon to fight Chad, Moslem militia officials said today. **********They said an officer would be paid a monthly salary of $1,000, a sergeant $800 and a soldier $600, and that a unit of about 1,000 Druse recruits was due to leave for Libya from the Damascus airport next week.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/25/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********''Hiring Mediators Instead of Lawyers'' (Personal Finance, Sept. 20) warrants a response. What both consumers and referral sources should keep in mind is that a skilled matrimonial lawyer need not create the debilitating warfare and chaos between clients intimated by Jay G. Baris. Rather, such a professional can integrate the technical and negotiating skills necessary to bring divorcing parties to a negotiated settlement that is finely tuned for their particular needs and issues. This ''problem solving'' approach is vastly preferable to an acrimonious, expensive resolution by litigation, which should be the last alternative. **********Secondly, mediation by a neutral professional, skilled in both the technical aspects of divorce as well as the emotional dynamics of divorcing and negotiating, can be of great assistance to the divorcing parties. They then shape and fine tune the terms of their own divorce, which would be legally resolved without contest. Regrettably, there are few mediators who have the grounding in both the law and psychology necessary to perform this delicate role in a way that produces all relevant information and fully satisfies the ''reasonable expectations'' of each party. **********The most effective model for divorce mediation is for each of the parties to have separate legal counsel who coaches them through the mediation process, but who is not present during the mediation meetings. **********In my experience, only about 15 percent of divorcing couples are suitable for the intense emotional interplay inherent in divorce mediation. **********PAUL D. PEARSON  Former President,   Massachusetts Chapter,   American Academy   of Matrimonial Lawyers  Buffalo, Oct. 2

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/15/world.main_headline: PENTAGON OFFICIAL, LIKED TO CONTRA AID, TO RETIRE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/15/world.print_headline: PENTAGON OFFICIAL, LIKED TO CONTRA AID, TO RETIRE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/15/world.body_text: **********The Defense Department's senior official concerned with Central American affairs, Nestor D. Sanchez, will leave office on Jan. 31 amid reports from Administration and Congressional sources that investigators are questioning the nature of his role in the Iran-contra affair. **********Robert Sims, the Defense Department spokesman, said today that there was ''nothing unusual at all'' about the retirement, adding ''he told me he just wants to go home to live on his farm in Leesburg,'' Va. **********But some other Defense Department officials said Mr. Sanchez was being eased out because the investigations of the controversy were getting uncomfortably close to his activities. So far, the Pentagon has not been linked to the controversy in any major way. **********Mr. Sims and some other Pentagon officials said Mr. Sanchez, who will be 60 this year, was planning to retire anyway. Mr. Sims added that Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger is ''sorry to see him go'' and plans to ''commend his service.'' 'Just a Matter of When' **********In an interview this evening, Mr. Sanchez said he was not surprised at speculation that he was leaving office because of the investigations. But he added: ''I've been talking about retiring for some time, and it's just a matter of when. No time's a good time. But I have some personal matters that I must attend to.'' **********He added that although he would not be surprised if he is called as a witness in the Iran-contra inquiries, no one has called him yet. He said he had not been involved in anything improper. **********Mr. Sanchez was a Central Intelligence Agency officer for 30 years before becoming Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for Inter-American Affairs in 1981. **********He was responsible for formulating Defense Department positions on Central American policy, and presented those positions as its representative at interagency meetings that included officials from the State Department, the Central Intelligence Agency and the National Security Council. Monitoring of Aid Effort **********Officials said Mr. Sanchez monitored official and unofficial military aid to the anti-Sandinista forces in Nicaragua known as contras, including private shipments that had significant Government involvement during the period that Congress prohibited direct military assistance. **********After a flight with arms for the contras was shot down over Nicaragua on Oct. 5, officials said Mr. Sanchez was instrumental in planting a false report that was widely reported by American news organizations, asserting that the aircraft was on a private mission and had no Government connection. **********Only one member of the plane's three-man crew, Eugene Hasenfus, survived. The Sandinista Government convicted Mr. Hasenfus of espionage but released him last month. **********Mr. Sanchez acknowledged that he and others in Government were aware of the covert arms shipments but added ''I didn't know the origin of them.'' Report of Cover Story **********As part of the cover story devised after the crash, officials said, the Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, Elliott Abrams, intended to ask Gen. John K. Singlaub, a retired officer who was then in the Philippines, to take responsibility for the plane. General Singlaub, who was involved in various covert operations while in the Army, had more recently organized and helped to finance several legal, open shipments of nonlethal supplies to the contras. **********The reports about General Singlaub's purported involvement appeared in print, however, before Mr. Abrams could reach him, the officials said. Mr. Abrams has denied this account. **********After he returned to the United States, the general held a news conference in Washington and angrily denied any involvement with the flight. **********Numerous officials said Maj. Gen. Richard V. Secord, a retired Air Force officer, had arranged with associates for the flight in which Mr. Hasenfus was shot down. General Secord is also under investigation. Relationship to Retired Officers **********Pentagon officials as well as acquaintances of Mr. Sanchez outside the Government said he had monitored the operations of both General Singlaub and General Secord, but they asserted that he had not directed them. **********In other activities, Mr. Sanchez appeared to have been caught in a dispute between his former associates at the C.I.A. and his present colleagues in the Defense Department over how to train the contras in guerrilla operations and what sort of strategy they should adopt. **********The C.I.A., according to Pentagon officials, wanted to train the contras in conventional infantry tactics and to persuade them to fight decisive engagements with Sandinista forces with the intention of seizing territory and forming a provisional government. **********In contrast, the officials said, military officers argued that the contras were so poorly led and equipped that they would have little chance against the more numerous, better trained Sandinistas. **********For the moment, the officials said, the C.I.A. has had the better of the argument, and the Defense Department has been relegated to a supporting role.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/10/busin.body_text: **********Argentina's Economy Minister, Juan Sourrouille, said today that the ''narrow interest'' of creditor banks was holding up an accord to stretch out debt repayments. He warned Argentina might break off negotiations. **********Speaking to the International Monetary Fund's Interim Committee meeting, Mr. Sourrouille said Argentina had given ample proof that it was negotiating seriously with the banks. **********''Today, with that same responsibility, we are clearly stating that it will be impossible for us to continue negotiating on that basis,'' he added. **********A monetary expert who heard Mr. Sourrouille's speech while seated near Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d said that Mr. Baker turned to one of his advisers to ask for the names of banks that Mr. Sourrouille referred to.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/15/world.main_headline: U.S. TO CHALLENGE SOVIET OVER HELP FOR NICARAGUANS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/15/world.print_headline: U.S. TO CHALLENGE SOVIET OVER HELP FOR NICARAGUANS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/15/world.body_text: **********The United States plans to complain formally to the Soviet Union about reported plans for a buildup of the Nicaraguan military with Russian help, Administration officials said today. **********The Administration also moved quickly today to use disclosures by a Nicaraguan military defector to press its case in Congress for financial aid for the Nicaraguan contras. **********Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said the United States would express its concern to the Soviet Union and ask about assertions by the defector, Maj. Roger Miranda Bengoechea, that Moscow intends to increase arms shipments to Nicaragua and base MIG-21 fighter aircraft there. Sandinistas Delay Talks **********A faint hope for progress in negotiations for a cease-fire between the Nicaraguan Government and the rebels faded today after the Sandinistas delayed a second round of talks in the Dominican Republic.  [ Page A10. ]  Mr. Fitzwater said of Major Miranda's charges: ''We think it's very serious. We are registering our concern with the Soviet Union through diplomatic channels.'' **********He said that the ''introduction of MIG's and other advanced kinds of hardware, we think is clearly destabilizing and a threat to the other countries in the region.'' **********It will be the first time the United States has explicitly brought Major Miranda's disclosures to the attention of the Russians, although they were made before the meeting last week between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Defector Meets Legislators **********A senior United States official said the Administration had generally confirmed Major Miranda's information well before Mr. Gorbachev arrived in the United States. The State Department arranged for Major Miranda to be interviewed by reporters on Thursday, Mr. Gorbachev's last day here. **********But Administration officials denied they had withheld Major Miranda's charges from the summit agenda so that they could be used more effectively afterward to persuade Congress to provide new aid for the contras. **********Major Miranda's assertions that despite a Central American peace plan, the Sandinista Government in Nicaragua is planning to build up its armed forces with Soviet help were being presented forcefully by the Administration as evidence of the need for Congress to provide new contra financing. Major Miranda was brought to Capitol Hill today to meet privately with several legislators of both parties. 'Strong Impact' Is Hope **********''We hope that these revelations will have a strong impact,'' Phyllis Oakley, a State Department spokeswoman, said. ''Those who have favored aid to the democratic resistance in the past on the grounds that the Sandinistas are trying to subvert democratic government and are, with the help of the Soviet Union, building up a military force of unprecedented strength, will not be surprised by these revelations. Those who remain unconvinced must consider the testimony of a former high-ranking Sandinista official.'' **********Lieut. Gen. Colin L. Powell, the national security adviser, conferred with members of Congress today over the Administration's proposal for further aid to the contras. Some members of Congress, including several opponents of contra aid, conceded today that the Miranda disclosures would be of immeasurable help to the Administration in seeking to persuade Congress to approve new aid. **********A Senate version of a catchall spending bill contains about about $16 million in new aid for the contras through the end of February. There is no new contra aid in the House version of the bill and a conference committee to reconcile the difference was set up today. The negotiations between the House and Senate over the bill are expected to be highly contentious, with the contra aid issue at the top of the list of things to be resolved. **********Mr. Reagan has threatened to veto any measure that does not contain some non-arms aid to maintain the contras as a fighting force. **********The House Speaker, Jim Wright, who has been a central figure in the contra aid issue, seemed angered over the Miranda disclosures, which were largely confirmed over the weekend by Humberto Ortega Saavedra, the Nicaraguan Minister of Defense and the brother of President Daniel Ortega Saavedra. **********Referring to the charges that Nicaragua intends to put as many as 600,000 men under arms by 1990, Mr. Wright said that was a ''preposterous'' idea but that it would help efforts to renew contra aid. In the past, he has persuaded the Nicaraguan Government to temper its actions so as not to inflame Congress and today he complained, ''The Sandinistas have had a history of snatching defeat from the jaws of victory.'' **********Senator Peter V. Domenici, a New Mexican Republican and a supporter of additional contra aid, said: ''I was very proud of the Sandinistas over the weekend. They made it very easy for us.'' **********Representative Vic Fazio, a California Democrat, said the Miranda disclosures would make the Administration's task easier. **********The House Republican leader, Robert H. Michel of Illinois, said the disclosures meant that Congress would have to consider whether President Ortega ever meant to comply with the Central American peace plan signed last August. **********President Ortega tried today to minimize the damage done by his brother's confirmation of some of Major Miranda's charges. Mr. Ortega told reporters that his brother was incorrect in saying such a buildup would occur because it was only a proposal. Major Miranda was a top aide to Humberto Ortega. **********General Powell said today that the United States would pursue ''rather quickly'' a suggestion by Mr. Gorbachev last week that the Soviet Union would drastically reduce its aid to Nicaragua if the United States ended its support for the contras. **********Over the weekend, General Powell said that Mr. Gorbachev made the remarks during a stroll with President Reagan and offered few details except to suggest that the level of Soviet aid could drop to simply providing police equipment. General Powell called the Gorbachev statement ''cryptic.'' **********Administration officials offered conflicting statements today as to how the information provided by Major Miranda was used by the President or other officials in talking to Mr. Gorbachev or his party last week. **********A State Department spokesman said Mr. Reagan did not raise the issue as the discussion between the two men on Nicaragua was extremely brief. Mr. Fitzwater first said that the matter was not raised because the agenda for the summit had already been set. ''It wasn't part of the prepared agenda,'' he said at a briefing today. **********But when pressed, he reversed himself and said that the Miranda information played a role in the President's discussions with Mr. Gorbachev. **********Another White House official said Mr. Reagan was aware of Major Miranda's assertions during his talks with the Soviet leader but did not raise any of the specifics.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/24/busin.body_text: **********Asher B. Edelman, the New York financier, said yesterday that a group he heads would probably reduce the price later this week of an $880 million hostile offer for the Telex Corporation. **********Mr. Edelman declined to disclose a new price but said in an interview that the likely revision had been motivated by an uncertain market for high-yield junk bonds, which would be used to finance the deal. **********For the second time this month, Mr. Edelman said that the tender offer for the stock would be extended, this time to Wednesday at midnight. **********Mr. Edelman orginally made a $65-a-share offer 10 days before the market collapsed on Monday, Oct. 19. After the offer was made, the stock topped $70 a share. **********Since then, however, it has dropped precipitously. After yesterday's announcement, Telex fell on the New York Stock Exchange by $1 a share, to $48.50. **********Eileen Keller, a spokeswoman for Telex, a telecommunications company in Tulsa, Okla., said Mr. Edelman's group, the TLX Acquisition Corporation, had initiated discussions last Friday that continued on Saturday. The talks ''related to the possibility that TLX would terminate its tender offer and support Telex's proposed recapitalization,'' Ms. Keller said. Mr. Edelman said that the talks had never gone beyond a very preliminary stage.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/14/world.main_headline: SHULTZ VISITS EMBASSY SEDER FOR NOTED SOVIET DISSIDENTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/14/world.print_headline: SHULTZ VISITS EMBASSY SEDER FOR NOTED SOVIET DISSIDENTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/14/world.body_text: **********In even the most tranquil times, the first night of Passover is full of turbulent emotions for the Jews who have been trying to emigrate from the Soviet Union. The words ''next year in Jerusalem,'' pronounced during the traditional seder, have both a hopeful and a hollow sound. **********Tonight, however, at a time of ferment and liberalization inside Soviet society, the yearning took on a new intensity and a grander scope as Secretary of State George P. Shultz attended the beginning of a seder at Spaso House, the American Ambassador's residence, for about 50 of the most prominent and longstanding would-be Jewish emigres and their families. **********Many who were at the seder had been in prison or Siberian exile for calling on Washington to put pressure on Soviet authorites to relax the emigration restrictions affecting all Soviet citizens. **********Mr. Shultz, an Episcopalian, wore a white yarmulke as he went to every table, shook every hand and exchanged a few words with practically everyone. He seemed in awe of these tough, cheerful, resolute men and women bearing names familiar to him from the lists he presents at every meeting with high Soviet officials. **********These were names that have been emblazoned on the signs carried by demonstrators in the West for more than a decade: Aleksandr Lerner, Vladimir Slepak, Viktor Brailovsky, Ida Nudel, Iosif Begun, Naum Meiman, Abe Stolar, Yevgeny Yakir, Arkady Mai and others. **********''There are a lot of famous people in this room,'' Richard Schifter, Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights and Humanitarian Affairs, told Mr. Lerner, a computer scientist who has been seeking an exit visa since 1971. In that time, his daughter has emigrated to Israel and his wife has died. **********Mr. Shultz presented a handsomely bound copy of the Haggadah, the ritual readings and prayers that accompany the Passover meal, to Mr. Begun, a sinewy dissident who was just released from his third term in prison in February but has still not received permission to leave the Soviet Union. **********Mr. Shultz then gave Mr. Slepak a framed photograph of the Slepak grandchildren, who live in the United States. Mr. Slepak, with a gray beard and a ruddy face, has the look of a prophet; he has been waiting 17 years for an exit visa and has served several years in exile. The picture had come from Mr. Slepak's two sons, Alexander and Leonid, who emigrated years ago. **********''A picture is better than nothing,'' Mr. Shultz said sympathetically. ''We have four grandchildren. They've just been at our house for a couple of weeks. We're very grandchildren-oriented.'' Mr. Slepak replied, ''I'm so moved by your attention.'' **********Indeed, they were all moved. ''I think he made an extremely important gesture,'' said Mr. Brailovsky, a mathematician who was exiled for five years in Kazakhstan. ''This is something that never occurred before. It came at a very important time when we, as perpetual optimists, see an opportunity for the solution of our problem.'' A Concert Is Allowed **********Another hint of improvement was the news, announced by Vladimir Feltsman, a virtuoso pianist, that ''after eight years of silence'' imposed on him after he applied to emigrate, he was being allowed to give a concert in Moscow on April 21, at Tchaikovsky Hall. **********Not everyone was as sanguine, however. Some cited an article in the newspaper Sovetskaya Rossiya in early April asserting that the reason Western leaders wanted the would-be emigres out was what that they possessed state secrets. Some said they saw in this the seeds of a campaign to smear the Jewish dissidents with espionage charges. **********No Secretary of State had done anything like this before. In the past, when Mr. Shultz and his predecessors were in Moscow for high-level talks on arms control, they calculated that meeting dissidents would sour the atmosphere and damage the talks. **********Nor was Mr. Shultz's visit timed for Passover. It was just coincidental, officials said, that his arrival today fell on the eve of Passover. For the last two years, the embassy has held a seder for Jews who have been refused permission to emigrate, and when Mr. Shultz was asked if he wished to attend, he agreed. **********Jewish emigration, having reached a high of more than 51,000 in 1979, has fallen to a trickle in recent years, with a slight rise last month. **********The kosher food and wine was brought in on Mr. Shultz's plane. About 75 people, one-third of them Americans, were seated at round tables in the ballroom of the mansion that serves as Ambassador Jack F. Matlock's residence. 'We Are With You' **********The blessing was said over the wine by Michael Einik, an economics officer at the embassy, who conducted the seder. Then Mr. Shultz said a few words before departing for further evening meetings with Soviet officials on arms control. He did not stay for the main ceremony. **********''We never stop,'' he told the would-be emigres. ''And if our hopes are disappointed, we keep on. We think about you, we pray for you, and we are with you. On every occasion we meet with the Soviets we will always bring this subject up, and they know it.'' **********''Whether it seems to be a time of hope or a time of disappointment,'' Mr. Shultz said, ''our effort is always there. But we never give up, we never stop trying, never give up, never give up.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/06/busin.main_headline: TRADING SURGE PUSHES THE DOW BEYOND 2,200
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/06/busin.print_headline: TRADING SURGE PUSHES THE DOW BEYOND 2,200
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/06/busin.body_text: **********The Dow Jones industrial average broke another ''century'' mark yesterday, closing above 2,200 for the first time. **********With blue-chip issues making a strong showing, the session was also the second most active in the history of the New York Stock Exchange as 256.7 million shares changed hands. On Wednesday, another heavy day, 222.4 million shares were traded. **********The surge of trading yesterday also carried broader-based market indexes to record highs. **********The Dow closed up 10.26, at a record 2,201.49, in a session that saw it open strongly, lose steam in the early afternoon and pick up strongly in the final hour and a half of trading. Meanwhile, the 1,500-share New York Stock Exchange composite index gained 1.05, to a record 160.36, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was up 1.52, to a record 281.16. Advancing issues on the Big Board outnumbered declining stocks, 1,039 to 604. Dow Is Up 16% This Year **********In the 25 trading days this year, the Dow has soared a phenomenal 305 points, or 16 percent. By comparison, for all of last year the 30-stock blue-chip index gained 349 points, or 22.6 percent. **********Larry M. Wachtel, market strategist at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., said there was no specific news yesterday to account for the advance. **********But at least two factors apparently eased Wall Street's worry about interest rates, helping stocks of rate-sensitive industries. For one thing, demand was stronger than expected for this week's Treasury refunding, a development that sent rates lower yesterday and lifted bond prices sharply. In addition, there were new rumors of a Japanese rate cut, perhaps as early as next week. Possible Causes for Gain **********''Some could say the Treasury's $29 billion refunding auctions helped market sentiment because its issues were absorbed without any impact on interest rates,'' Mr. Wachtel said, ''or that the expected cut in the Japanese discount rate buoyed not only the autos, but the overall market.'' **********But Mr. Wachtel dismissed the view offered by some experts that the market's midsession retreat was caused by the unsupported reports that Terry Waite, the Church of England envoy, had been killed or wounded in Lebanon. **********''At these market levels we should expect pullbacks, and perhaps welcome them,'' he said, ''because mini-corrections tend to wring out some of the emotional buying and, indeed, give everyone a needed pause to reflect.'' **********While yesterday's trading was very heavy, the volume still fell far short of the record 302.4 million shares traded Jan. 23. **********''Contributing to the heavy volume was the sharp shift in market direction during the session,'' said William M. LeFevre, market strategist at Advest Inc. ''At 1:30, for example, the Dow was up 19.12 points, its intraday high. An hour later, it was down 8.02 points, a swing of more than 27 points, before resuming its advance.'' **********Asked how long the market's current rally would continue, Mr. LeFevre said, ''Who knows?'' He pointed out that International Business Machines, General Motors and American Telephone and Telegraph - three top blue-chip stocks consistently run down by analysts in recent weeks - helped lead yesterday's advance. **********G.M.'s stock, reflecting rumors that the big auto maker planned to buy back some shares and raise its dividend, led the Big Board's most-active list, rising 1 5/8, to 80, on a turnover of almost 5.7 million shares. A.T.&T. placed second, gaining 3/8, at 24. I.B.M., trading ex-dividend, jumped 2 7/8, to 136 7/8, and was fourth most active. **********Other auto stocks were also strong: Ford advanced 2 1/2, to 79 1/2, and Chrysler gained 1/2, to 50 1/4. **********Monte Gordon, research director at the Dreyfus Corporation, said he was uneasy about the market's behavior after the advance resumed in the last 90 minutes of trading. **********''True, the market, as measured by the major indexes, did manage to close above 2,200, but just by a squeak,'' Mr. Gordon said. ''The recovery had none of the powerful drive that marked trading earlier in the day.'' Liquidity May Be High **********But Mr. Gordon was not yet ready to predict a significant downturn, particularly because of high investor liquidity, which has been a primary ingredient in the market's rise this year. Much of this excess cash resulted from year-end stock selling by investors seeking to take advantage of favorable tax treatment under the old tax law. **********''When will we see a real correction?'' he continued. ''Only when the perception of the market changes. Despite the vulnerability of the market at current levels, we haven't seen any significant change in attitude, and there is still a lot of available investment cash outside the market.'' **********Among yesterday's biggest gainers were two broadcasting companies that had lagged behind others in this recently popular industry. Capital Cities rose 5 1/2, at 308 1/2, and Taft Broadcasting climbed 4 3/4, to 121 3/4. **********A. H. Robins, which is under protection of Federal bankruptcy laws, soared 5 1/4, to 24 1/2. American Home Products has offered to buy the beleaguered pharmaceutical company. **********In the technology group, Texas Instruments rose 3 7/8, to 159 3/8; Digital Equipment 3 3/4, to 150 3/8; Cray Research 3 1/4, to 116 1/2, and Advanced Micro Devices 2, to 23. G.& W. Gains 3 **********Gulf and Western rose 3, to 73 1/4, on improved earnings and support by several brokerage houses. Abbott Laboratories, the market leader in blood screening tests, rose 1 1/4, to 59 1/4, on expectations that the Government may recommend expanded testing for AIDS antibodies. **********Among the day's biggest losers were Teledyne, down 6, to 309 1/4; Unilever N.V. 4 3/4, to 241 3/4; Upjohn 2 3/8, to 111, and CBS, off 1 7/8, at 145 1/2. **********Demand for many small stocks was also strong. The American Stock Exchange index soared 3.58 points, to a record 314.98. In the over-the-counter market, the Nasdaq composite index rose 2.58 points, to 405.70, but still below the record 411.16 on July 3. https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/13/world.main_headline: Indian Security Forces Kill 5 Described as Sikh Extremists
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/13/world.print_headline: Indian Security Forces Kill 5 Described as Sikh Extremists
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/13/world.body_text: **********Security forces killed five suspected Sikh extremists they encountered while on patrol, and terrorists shot and killed two people, the police and news reports said Saturday. **********Both actions occurred Friday night in Punjab State, where Sikh militants are fighting for a separate homeland from predominantly Hindu India. **********A police officer said the five suspected extremists had been slain in a fight with federal paramilitary forces and state police near Katora village, 220 miles northwest of New Delhi. **********He said that the five had been hiding in a deserted brick kiln when the security forces challenged them and that the suspects had opened fire first. **********The United News of India reported that Sikh separatists killed two other Sikhs Friday in Kot village near Amristar, the Sikh holy city in Punjab.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/03/world.body_text: **********The Government and leftist rebels announced today that they would meet next week in Madrid in the first peace talks held in the 25 years of political violence here. **********Julio Santos, spokesman for President Vinicio Cerezo, told reporters, ''On Tuesday a delegation from the Government of Guatemala will be in Madrid for the conversations.'' **********Leftist rebels announced in a communique that they would meet with Government officials on Wednesday to ''search for peace'' and that a cease-fire had been agreed on by both sides to begin tonight and last for the duration of the talks. The statement was from the Guatemalan National Revolutionary Union, which includes three guerrilla groups. **********But Guatemala's Defense Minister, Gen. Hector Alejandro Gramajo, said, ''The army will not respect the unilateral cease-fire announced by the guerrillas.'' **********The talks are part of a Central American peace plan signed by the presidents of Guatemala, Nicaragua, El Salvador, Honduras and Costa Rica in Guatemala City on Aug. 7. **********Mr. Cerezo's one and a half-year-old Government, the first civilian administration since 1970, has said the rebels must put down their weapons for there to be a dialogue. The military has opposed talks.   SALVADORAN TALKS PLANNED **********SAN SALVADOR, Oct. 2 (Reuters) - **********El Salvador's Government and its leftist guerrilla foes have confirmed that they will hold peace talks in San Salvador on Sunday despite apparently irreconcilable differences on how to end their conflict. **********Deputy Communications Minister Roberto Viera said today that details on the complicated logistics of safe-conduct for the guerrillas had been arranged in a meeting of Government and rebel representatives in Guatemala City Thursday. The issue had threatened to delay the talks.

Directors also said Williams's commercial real estate company, the Williams Realty Corporation, was for sale. **********Under the agreement, the partnership would pay Williams $250 million in cash at closing for Agrico, plus a deferred consideration of between $100 million and $250 million, based on Agrico's performance, to be paid within five years. The Williams Companies' other major businesses include pipeline transmission of natural gas and petroleum, the processing of natural gas liquids and interstate telecommunications.
