https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/06/world.main_headline: Rebel Officer Urges Struggle Against Aquino
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/06/world.print_headline: Rebel Officer Urges Struggle Against Aquino
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/06/world.body_text: **********The leader of the failed military rebellion, in his first public statement since the Aug. 28 uprising, called on Filipinos today to support him in his struggle against the Government of President Corazon C. Aquino. **********In a radio statement telephoned to the station from an undisclosed hiding place, the rebel leader, Col. Gregorio Honasan, called opposition to Mrs. Aquino ''an initial necessary step'' to save the nation from what he described as a drift toward the abuses of the former President, Ferdinand E. Marcos. **********Mrs. Aquino's spokesman, Teodoro Benigno, issued a response calling the rebels ''self-appointed messiahs and demagogues'' whose uprising was ''a naked power grab by a man using honeyed words to mask the military dictatorship he would set up.'' Call to 'Face the Music' **********The armed forces Chief of Staff, Gen. Fidel V. Ramos, calling himself ''an older brother to Greg,'' said in his own radio address that Colonel Honasan should ''come back and face the music as a military professional.'' **********Colonel Honasan, ending his remarks on an emotional note, switched from English to the national language, Tagalog, to urge his listeners to ''lift up our heads, wipe the tears from our eyes, strengthen our hearts and be true to ourselves, the nation and most of all to God.'' **********Some listeners said they were deeply affected by that part of the address. The extent of Colonel Honasan's civilian support is unknown, but there have been no indications of a groundswell here. He appears still to have considerable support ththinheheililarary,owowever. 'No Intention' of Killing Aquino **********The colonel said that he had not intended to kill Mrs. Aquino, as she has charged, and that he called off his rebellion to halt mounting military casualties. **********''We had no intention of harming the President or her family,'' he said. ''It was politically untenable to do so against a leader that is perceived to be popular, sincere and committed, no matter how misguided and incapable she might be.'' **********A separate unsigned document purporting to come from Colonel Honasan's group and delivered to news organizations set forth a vaguely worded nine-point program of government by what it described as a seven-member ''Ruling Junta of the Nationalist Provisional Government under the Armed Forces of the Philippines.'' **********It was the second such document purporting to come from a military junta. Colonel Honasan did not mention such a group in his address. **********A diplomat who has had close relations with Colonel Honasan's group said the language of the document seen today appeared to reflect the thoughts and writings of one of his confederates in the mutiny. 'A Heaven on Earth' **********The document called for a ''Democracy of the Masses,'' which would bring ''a heaven on earth'' once ''the man of the masses accepts the truth that in the final analysis he is the problem.'' **********Stressing justice and clean government, the document called in general terms for an improved legal and penal system, college education for all, a more independent military and a more courteous bureaucracy. **********It appeared to oppose capital punishment, saying, ''Many criminals are sick, and a person should not be penalized because he is sick.'' **********In the interests of reconciliation among national minorities it proposed the designation of the fez, often worn by Moslems, as the national hat. **********According to Mr. Benigno, the presidential spokesman, Colonel Honasan, if he took power, would ''topple President Corazon Aquino, demolish democracy, stifle popular will, defile our Constitution, strike down our judiciary, scuttle Congress and set himself up as the messiah.'' Rebels 'Held Back' **********In his 15-minute radio statement, which the station, DZRH, said was received on a clear telephone line apparently from within Manila, Colonel Honasan maintained that the rebels ''held back our punches'' and avoided assaults on pro-Government troops. **********''It may have been a fatal tactical error on our part but it was a gamble we were prepared to take to save more lives,'' the colonel said. **********''The mounting casualties on both sides made us decide to withdraw and regroup but we have made our point,'' he said, adding that many other military units had supported the mutineers. **********He acknowledged that decisive action by the troops of General Ramos had been a factor in the daylong fighting brought on by the rebellion. **********Mrs. Aquino has said 53 soldiers and civilians were killed and hundreds were wounded in the fighting, in which the rebels were repulsed from the presidential palace, two military camps and two broadcast complexes. Colonel Escaped **********The Government says more than 1,100 rebel soldiers were captured or surrendered. Colonel Honasan escaped, as did other officers identified as leaders of the mutiny. **********Today there were still indications that considerable support remained for the rebel soldiers within the military. **********At Villamor Air Base, headquarters of the Philippine Air Force, troops reportedly told Vice President Salvador H. Laurel that they favored an amnesty for the mutineers. A soldier who stood up to voice support for military leaders was said to have been booed by others in the audience of 1,500. **********In his radio address, General Ramos acknowledged that ''we have a big problem here in the armed forces of the Philippines involving morale and discipline. We senior commanders are trying to inform all our soldiers what really happened.'' Comparison to Marcos Regime **********Colonel Honasan said the Aquino Government, which he helped install by spearheading a military revolt against the Marcos regime in February 1986, had betrayed his expectations in its military policies, and by allowing corruption, nepotism and politics to swamp any useful programs. **********''The incumbent administration has consciously taken the same direction as that of the then-popular Marcos administration at the start,'' he said. ''This we cannot allow, and we shall not allow it.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/24/world.main_headline: Secret U.S. Army Unit Had Role in Raid in Gulf
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/24/world.print_headline: Secret U.S. Army Unit Had Role in Raid in Gulf
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/24/world.body_text: **********The United States helicopters that shot at an Iranian mine-laying ship in the Persian Gulf late Monday night were from a secretive Army unit, Task Force 160, trained for special, unconventional operations behind enemy lines. **********The unit, the size, arms and equipment of which are secret, is part of the Army's First Special Operations Command, with headquarters at Fort Bragg, N.C. Other elements are the Rangers, the Special Forces, better known as Green Berets, and the Delta force. **********The helicopter unit provides tactical transport and gunship support for Ranger commando raids, Green Beret guerrilla operations, or Delta force attempts to rescue hostages. Longer-range transport would come from the Air Force's Special Operations Wing. How They Got to the Gulf **********An account of how the Army helicopters got to the Persian Gulf and what they have done was pieced together from Administration officials who asked not to be named, from briefings and a press pool report filed from the gulf yesterday. **********Task Force 160's helicopters were sent from their base at Fort Campbell, Ky., to the gulf in June at the request of the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Adm. William J. Crowe Jr., who had become concerned about maritime guerrilla warfare. **********Admiral Crowe, who commanded the Mideast Force of United States warships in the gulf 10 years ago, became anxious after an Iraqi fighter fired missiles at the American frigate Stark in May, killing 37 sailors. He worreid that American warships might be vulnerable to attack by Iranian speed-boats; if they got too close, a warship might not be able to depress her guns quickly enough to hit the intruder. Aircraft Termed Answer **********Aircraft that could range well out from the ships seemed to be the answer. But Navy helicopters are rigged for minesweeping and anti-submarine operations, or for transport, and Navy aviators are not trained to attack with gunships. **********At first, Admiral Crowe asked the Marine Corps to take on the task with Harriers, airplanes that can take off and land vertically, in the same space used by a helicopter. But Gen. P. X. Kelley, then Commandant of the Marine Corps, demurred because the logistics effort would have been immense. **********Admiral Crowe turned to the Army, which subsequently assigned an undetermined number of gunships from Task Force 160. The aircraft were described as small, two-seater gunships that the maker, Hughes Aircraft, has claimed are the quietest helicopters in the world. **********The OH-6 helicopters are fitted with sensors and navigation devices that enable them to fly low and to hit targets at night. Their weapons include machine guns and rockets, and they can fly at 135 miles an hour with a range of 380 miles. #2 Based on Frigate Jarrett To prepare for duty in the Persian Gulf, the Army pilots trained with Navy ships off the coast of Virginia, then were flown with the gunships aboard Air Force cargo planes to the gulf. There they were distributed among the ships in the fleet, two of them being based aboard the frigate Jarrett. **********Meanwhile, Admiral Crowe visited the Persian Gulf earlier this month and discussed with Rear Adm. Harold J. Bernsen, the commander of the American force there, the possibility of actions like that which took place this week. Admiral Bernsen told him the helicopters were ready. **********Under the rules of engagement, Admiral Bernsen is authorized to order his forces, including the helicopters, to fire if he determines there is ''hostile intent,'' meaning the threat of imminent use of force against ships flying American flags. **********Hostile intent was defined as maneuvering by a ship or aircraft so that it could fire a missile, drop a bomb or use gunfire. A radar lock-on by a ship's fire control system was also defined to constitute hostile intent. Defined as Hostile Act **********The rules of engagement define a ''hostile act'' as one in which an aircraft, ship or land forces launch a missile, shoot a gun or drop a bomb. Admiral Bernsen said the Iranian ship had committed a hostile act by laying mines in an anchorage used by American warships. **********In Monday's episode, the admiral suggested that the Iranian ship, called Iran Ajr by the Pentagon but Rakhsh by reporters who boarded her in the gulf, had been under surveillance since she left port at Bandar Abbas, an Iranian naval base at the eastern edge of the gulf. **********He said the ship was tracked across the gulf by radar but that the mines were spotted, evidently by aviators who flew close to the ship, when the crew removed a tarpaulin covering them. **********When night fell, the Iranian ship was kept under surveillance by two Army helicopters from the frigate Jarrett. The pilots could see the minelayer through night vision goggles that are powered by tiny amounts of light from stars or a manmade source. Stopped for 34 Minutes **********About 11 P.M. on Monday, Persian Gulf time, the pilots reported they had seen the Iranian crew drop one or two mines over the side of their ship. The admiral ordered the helicopters to open fire, which they did with machine guns and rockets. **********The Iranians stopped laying mines for 34 minutes, then resumed. This time the helicopters cut loose with a barrage that set the Iranian vessel afire and left it dead in the water. As reported earlier, three Iranians were killed, four were wounded and two are missing. **********A press dispatch described ''a ship pocked by machine-gun fire and stained with blood. Windows in the bridge were shattered, rooms ransacked and personal belongings were strewn about the living quarters.'' The gunfire pierced oil barrels and the mines on deck. **********''Two large holes on the port and starboard sides of the hull and an angled six-inch wide gash that ripped through the deck near the bow'' indicated where the ship had come under rocket attack, the report said. An American naval officer, stepping over shattered glass on the bridge, was quoted: ''I wouldn't have wanted to be on this ship last night.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/16/world.main_headline: ARMS DEALERS LINKED TO U.S. POLICY SHIFT
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/16/world.print_headline: ARMS DEALERS LINKED TO U.S. POLICY SHIFT
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/16/world.body_text: **********For more than a year before the Reagan Administration began to consider selling arms to Iran, many of the arms dealers who eventually helped carry out the change in policy had been planning among themselves to sell American arms to the Teheran Government, according to American and Iranian sources and documents. **********The discussions suggest that the official policy of the United States may have been heavily influenced by earlier plans of arms brokers who had their own commercial aims. **********One of these brokers, Manucher Ghorbanifar, was planning in early 1984 to sell United States weapons to Iran, even though such sales were officially banned by the United States, according to associates. **********In 1985, Mr. Ghorbanifar became the major source of intelligence about Iran for the United States. His observations and advice helped persuade the White House to proceed with the arms sales, even though the Central Intelligence Agency had decided he was unreliable, American officials said. Hearings May Study Dealers **********The Administration's dependency on these middlemen is likely to be a focus of Congressional investigations of the Iran affair, since no arms dealers or middlemen were interviewed in the first set of hearings last year. **********Even without evidence from these men, the still-secret Senate report on the matter criticized the Administration for depending on arms brokers, officials said. **********Senator Dave Durenberger, Republican of Minnesota and chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee when it put together its report, said the report showed that the Administration had been taken in by a combination of ''someone else's foreign policy and the avarice of arms dealers.'' **********What made this arrangement possible, officials said, was that the desire of the arms brokers to make deals and reap large profits meshed with the Administration's desire to be told by them that Iran would bring about the release of American hostages held in Lebanon if weapons were delivered to Teheran. 'No Suggestion of Risks' **********In a recent interview Gary Sick, who handled Iran affairs at the National Security Council under President Jimmy Carter and is now at the Ford Foundation, said that a White House memo dated Jan. 17, 1986, giving the rationale for the arms sales, ''has no suggestion of downside risks, of the implications, no sense of broader policy concerns.'' **********''The policy makers had no good answers for freeing the hostages,'' Mr. Sick added. So the arms dealers, who are ''entrepreneurs who believe in the ability to cut a deal,'' he said, came along ''with a policy, and that becomes your policy.'' **********President Reagan has said the Iran initiative began in mid-1985, while Robert C. McFarlane, the former national security adviser, has told Congress it was in July 1985 that he first discussed with Mr. Reagan the possibility of selling arms to Iran, according to Congressional officials. U.S. Sponsorship Sought **********The Senate report, according to Congressional sources, says that the first discussions among some of the dealers and an Israeli official who later became involved in the Administration's Iran arms deals took place late in 1984. But earlier that year, in April or May, some of the same arms dealers planned during meetings in London to sell United States arms to Iran. **********In those discussions they said they hoped they could arrange for official United States sponsorship of the sales. One dealer said he had heard indications that the United States might soon consider changing its policy, according to an arms dealer familiar with the discussions who asked not to be identified, and to Ali Noorizadeh, an Iranian journalist based in London who was present for some of the discussions. **********These early 1984 discussions included three Iranian exiles involved in the arms trade, Mr. Ghorbanifar, Albert Hakim and Cyrus Hashemi, according to these sources. Mr. Hakim and his companies helped handle the proceeds from the sale of United State arms to Iran last year authorized by the Reagan Administration, and Congressional investigators believe his companies may have taken large commissions from the sales. **********Mr. Hashemi, who died last July, was involved in the early stages of the Government-sponsored arms sales but then became entangled in an unauthorized arms deal. 'Americans Ready to Sell Arms' **********Mr. Noorizadeh said Mr. Hashemi told him after a meeting with Mr. Ghorbanifar in London in April 1984 that the two men planned to ''go and buy weapons through Albert Hakim in the U.S. and sell them to Iran.'' **********In London the next month, Mr. Noorizadeh said, Mr. Hashemi told him that ''Hakim said that the Americans are ready to sell arms to Iran, they're thinking of trying to win some friends in Iran.'' **********Since the early 1980's, Mr. Hakim has tried to do business with Iran and to persuade the Reagan Administration to improve relations with Iran, according to former employees of Mr. Hakim, including Herman Neidhart. **********At the time of his discussions in London, Mr. Hakim was in business with retired Maj. Gen. Richard V. Secord, who has emerged as a key figure in the Iran affair. Mr. Hakim and his lawyer both declined to comment. Link to Iran Rescue Mission **********Mr. Hashemi and Mr. Hakim were already known to American intelligence agencies. They had been involved in sensitive intelligence activities for the United States in 1980, including the ill-fated attempt in April 1980 to rescue the American hostages in Teheran, a mission that also involved Mr. Secord, according to associates. **********In November 1984, Mr. Ghorbanifar had separate discussions in Hamburg, West Germany, with a former top C.I.A. official, Theodore G. Shackley, according to several participants. At the meetings, they talked about freeing the hostages in Lebanon, arms sales to Iran and improved relations between the two countries, the sources added. **********Mr. Shackley sent a memo about the meeting to Administration officials and suggested that Mr. Ghorbanifar might serve as an intermediary between the United States and Iran, according to the sources. **********It is unclear what happened to the memo, but one of the people who became aware of it in early 1985 was Michael Ledeen, a Government consultant and a friend of Mr. Shackley, the sources said. Ghorbanifar Tied to Israeli **********In the spring of 1985, Mr. Ledeen was working as a consultant for the National Security Council and met in Israel with, among others, Mr. Ghorbanifar and Yaacov Nimrodi, an Israeli arms dealer. Mr. Ledeen's advice when he returned to Washington helped the Administration decide whether to proceed with the arms sales to Iran. **********The Senate report, according to Congressional officials, notes that in late 1984 Mr. Ghorbanifar also had discussions in Israel with three others who later became involved in the United States arms sales. They were Mr. Nimrodi, Al Schwimmer, a founder of Israel's aircraft industry, and David Kimche, a high Israeli official. **********Mr. Ghorbanifar, according to officials, told the Israelis that arms were needed to strengthen the standing of moderate elements in Iran.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/28/busin.main_headline: Technical Workers Snarled by Tax Law
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/28/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY: PRINTOUTS; Technical Workers Snarled by Tax Law
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/28/busin.body_text: **********Scores of engineers, designers, computer programmers, systems analysts or other similarly skilled workers who make a living as independent consultants are planning to march on Washington tomorrow to protest a tax amendment that hurts them, confuses their employers and apparently puzzles the Government as well. **********The amendment, Section 1706, was introduced by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, in the closing hours of the debate on the Tax Reform Act of 1986, and took effect Jan. 1. It removes ''safe harbor'' provisions that had allowed some of these workers to take advantage of tax benefits as independent employees while working, in essence, as full-time employees of a company. The Government estimates the section will generate an extra $60 million in tax revenues in the next five years. **********Why Section 1706 zeroed in exclusively on technical consultants is unclear, but the effect has been to throw the industry into turmoil. Some companies have stopped hiring independent technical consultants until the confusion is resolved, and ''third party'' brokers who secure independent consultants for companies are examining their status under the new law. **********The Internal Revenue Service issued a guideline for employers last week, then almost immediately revised it, and it appears the revisions are not over yet. **********Richard Kelly, general counsel for the Technical Consultants National Association, said the amendment was ''disastrous'' and called for its repeal, saying it would adversely affect at least 500,000 independent high-tech consultants and the companies that employ them. The group filed a lawsuit against the Commissioner of Internal Revenue in Federal District Court in New York last week.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/01/busin.body_text: **********WHEN you're having trouble solving a problem, attacking the perception may be the next best thing. **********In another attempt to cope with its reputation for building low-quality cars, last month General Motors doubled the length of its warranty period. The announcement started a warranty war in Detroit. And while the immediate outcome appears to be a stalemate, the incident is an indication both of how serious the General Motors Corporation's sales problems are and of how determined Ford and Chrysler are to prevent G.M. from regaining its old market dominance. **********Warranties are becoming an increasingly important marketing tool in a wide variety of industries (See box). But Detroit's new, longer warranties will add costs and risk resentment when consumers discover how limited they actually are. **********With all three manufacturers offering extended warranties, analysts said that any additional marketing clout had been canceled out. ''When G.M. went with six and sixty and the others responded, they neutralized each other from a marketing standpoint,'' said J. David Power, president of J. D. Power & Associates, a market research firm. **********General Motors touched off the skirmishing late in January when it announced that it would extend the powertrain warranty on its 1987 model cars from three years and 36,000 miles to six years and 60,000 miles. In addition, the company would extend the warranty on body rust to six years and 100,000 miles. AUTO industry analysts called the move an effort by G.M. to divert attention from the company's recent quality problems, such as diesel engines that failed prematurely and transmissions that needed frequent repair. Analysts generally said that the longer warranties should be looked upon as a sales incentive that does not cost as much as rebates or subsidized interest programs, which run into hundreds of dollars a car. ''G.M. made the move because they were the ones who had the problem with their quality reputation,'' said Harvey Heinbach, an analyst with Merrill Lynch. Both the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation have claimed to have the best quality among the domestic producers and have surveys to back the claims. Significantly, G.M. has not attempted to refute them. Poor quality is just one of the problems that has sent G.M. into a sharp decline in recent years. The auto maker has had trouble establishing a distinctive image, and many of its new car lines have flopped. **********Last year, Ford surpassed G.M. in earnings for the first time since 1924. Ford reported 1986 earnings of $3.3 billion while G.M. earned only $2.95 billion. And this year may be a repeat: so far, G.M.'s sales have been 33 percent below last year's level. **********Warranties aside, how much have American auto makers improved their cars? Most experts agree that the American companies have narrowed, but not closed, the quality gap with most imports. Measurement is difficult because no one agrees on a definition of quality. Confidential auto industry surveys that measure ''things gone wrong'' with new cars consistently put the Japanese on top. IN A measure of consumer satisfaction with automobile performance conducted by the J. D. Power firm, the Japanese companies averaged 134 on an index where the overall average was 100, while the American industry stood at 90. **********Chrysler officials say that soothing customer apprehension was the reason they began offering a five-year, 50,000-mile extended warranty in 1982. The company had just barely avoided bankruptcy and was still awash in bad publicity. **********Since that offer, Chrysler's share of the market for American cars has grown from 11.9 percent to 14.2 percent last year. Some Chrysler executives credit chairman Lee A. Iacocca's punchy ''best built, best backed'' television commercials with finally goading G.M. into touching off the warranty war. Buyers who know little about automobiles are the most likely to be swayed by an attractive warranty, Mr. Power said. **********Ford has had a growing reputation for improved quality in recent years and was not eager to go beyond its existing three-year, unlimited mileage powertrain coverage. Nevertheless, ''we had to keep our dealers competitive,'' said Ross Roberts, marketing manager for the Ford Division. Ford matched G.M. at six years and 60,000 miles and Chrysler followed with seven-year, 70,000-mile coverage on cars and light trucks as well. All have the 100,000-mile corrosion warranty. **********But all three will have to bear the added cost of longer warranties. How much more? The auto companies usually refuse to say anything about warranty costs because the figures could be used by competitors to back claims of higher quality; they declined to respond to inquiries on the recent warranty extension. Sources close to G.M., though, say the company is estimating its cost for the extension at about $85 a car. Costs for the other companies should be comparable or less, they added. **********The modest cost has as much to do with the fine print on the warranties as improved car quality, industry watchers say. The Big Three warranties only cover the engine, transmission and parts that transmit power to the wheels, usually the most durable components in a car. Notably uncovered after the one-year, 12,000-mile basic warranty runs out are suspension and breaking systems, power assists and heating and cooling systems. And the extended warranties require the owner to pay $100 each time warranty work is done. **********''There's not much cost because there's not that much coverage,'' said Maryann Keller, an analyst with Furman Selz Mager Dietz & Birney. ''These are limited warranties covering the parts of the car that don't blow up very often.'' DETROIT executives argue that the new warranties are a good value for customers because they protect against catastrophic failure of the most expensive parts of a car and are now long enough that the typical new car buyer - who usually trades in a car within five years -will be covered for as long as he owns his automobile. **********But one senior industry offical said surveys have shown that most people would prefer a warranty that covers the car's ability to function, not just certain components, even if the coverage were for a shorter period. ''What people really want is three and 36 on everything and no baloney,'' he said. (Some European manufacturers offer that type of protection.) Indeed, some analysts say that by emphasizing the length of the warranty coverage and consigning the limitations to the fine print, the auto companies risk irritating buyers when a car breaks down and they find that the part involved is not covered. ''A lot of people are going to misinterpret what is covered and what is not and feel a little cheated when the warranty doesn't deliver,'' said Thomas F. O'Grady, a marketing consultant. Big Three executives say that the new warranties are planned as a permanent part of their marketing plans, and that the coverage will not drop back to previous levels after a few years, as happened in the late 1960's. And, they said, the longer warranties will put pressure on the importers of Japanese cars to match the extended coverage. **********Importers, their margins squeezed by the increase in the value of the yen, are not eager to add anything to their costs. They say they hope the quality reputation of Japanese cars is good enough that buyers will not demand longer warranties. **********The Japanese affiliates of both G.M. and Chrysler have also refused to lengthen the warranties on the Japanese-made cars sold under American brand names. That means, for example, that a Chevrolet Sprint will have a three-year, 36,000-mile powertrain warranty, while a Celebrity will have the longer protection -which may create some confusion in the showroom. **********The importers of high-priced European cars already use longer, fuller warranties as marketing tools. Mercedes-Benz, for example, provides four-year, 50,000-mile coverage on almost everything and makes roadside assistance part of the plan. An extended warranty helps justify the purchase of a car costing $25,000 or more, said an official of an importer of German cars. People who pay that much money for an automobile like to be coddled, he added.  AN OLD TECHNIQUE APPLIED IN NEW WAYS **********When Richard W. Sears sold watches and jewlery by mail order in 1887, he had to persuade farmers to purchase his goods sight unseen. His catalogue promised refunds on unsatisfactory merchandise. The strategy worked. Eventually, the Sears, Roebuck & Company warranty slogan would become the most famous of its kind -''Satisfaction Guaranteed or Your Money Back.'' **********The objectives of warranties have changed little since 1887. But in recent years, chemical, electronics and even credit card companies have made increasing use of warranties as a marketing tool. **********American Express, for example, will double the manufacturer's warranty (up to an extra year) on any product bought with its card. The program began in 1986 as a four-month experiment; but it was so popular that the company extended it until the end of 1987, and it may become permanent. About 75,000 warranty submissions have been filed. Items purchased under the program range from computers to curling irons. ''One woman wanted to know if the warranty applied to her live- stock,'' said Sarah Mullen, a company spokeswoman. ''We told her we could not cover her cow.'' **********Manufacturing companies are also finding innovative ways to apply warranties. The Monsanto Company guarantees the apparel, upholstery and carpet that contain the company's nylon fibers. The warranty period ranges from one to five years. The company investigates claims, for such things as discoloration of rugs or torn clothes, to determine where the fault lies. ''Most claims are valid,'' said Earl Bransfield, a Monsanto vice president. ''We're looking for repeat business, and this is a positive marketing tool.'' **********Service industries have also discovered new uses for warranties. At Holiday Inns, for example, if the hotel manager cannot solve a customer complaint - insufficient towels or a broken television, for example - then the hotel will return part or all of the cost of the room. The Holiday Inn on the Cayman Islands in the Caribbean goes further: it guarantees the weather. Guests who buy a weekend scuba-diving package are reimbursed if bad weather prevents them from getting their scheduled dives.  - JAMES HIRSCH

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/01/busin.body_text: **********Australia's Hooker Corporation would acquire 80 percent of financially beleaguered Sakowitz Inc., the Houston-based retailer, under an amended plan of organization filed in Federal Bankruptcy Court. The remaining 20 percent share of Sakowitz, which went into reorganization under Federal bankruptcy laws in August 1985, would go to certain creditors, according to the plan. The plan, the second submitted under Chapter 11, must be approved by creditors. Sakowitz is the nation's last remaining high-fashion speciality retailer controlled by a founding family member.

Icahn's bid for USAir suffered a major setback when the Department of Transportation rejected Trans World Airlines' application to acquire USAir. But USAir said it had asked Federal officials to order T.W.A. to sell its holdings.  [ Page 35. ]  A.T.& T. asked to be freed of most remaining regulations. Freeman of Goldman, Sachs traded in stocks in his own account before they became takeover targets, according to sources with knowledge of the investigation of the head of Goldman's arbitrage department. https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/08/world.print_headline: IRAN-CONTRA HEARINGS: TENSION AND HIGH DRAMA; HEATED EXCHANGE: WERE FUNDS 'BEGGED FOR' OR 'OFFERED'?
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/08/world.body_text: **********Exchanges between Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North and John W. Nields Jr., the chief House counsel, often grew heated at the hearings yesterday, as Colonel North passionately defended himself and his cause. These exchanges occurred during questioning about Colonel North's authority for his actions, and about the practice of soliciting money for the contras. **********Q. Mr. McFarlane has testified that he gave you instructions not to solicit money from foreign countries or private sources. Did he give you those instructions? **********A. I never carried out a single act - not one, Mr. Nields - in which I did not have authority from my superiors. I haven't, in the 23 years that I have been in the uniformed services of the United States of America ever violated an order - not one. **********Q. But that wasn't the question. The question was -. A. That is the answer to your question. Q. No, the question was did Mr. McFarlane give you such instructions? A. No. I never heard those instructions. Q. And I take it that it was your understanding, from what you've just said, that quite to the contrary, you were authorized to seek money from foreign countries? **********A. I was authorized to do everything that I did. Q. Well, again, that isn't the question. A. I was authorized to have a meeting, in this particular case in specific by Mr. McFarlane, for the purpose of talking to the man about a suggestion that had been made to him by others, and to encourage that process along. And I did so. I had already provided to Mr. McFarlane a card with the address of an account, an offshore account which would support the Nicaraguan resistance. And thank God, somebody put money into that account and the Nicaraguan resistance didn't die - as perhaps others intended. Certainly the Sandinistas and Moscow and Cuba intended that. And they didn't die, they grew in strength and numbers and effectiveness as a consequence. And I think that is a good thing. **********I get the sense that somehow or another we've tried to create the impression that Oliver North picked up his hat and wandered around Washington and foreign capitals begging for money, and I didn't do that. I didn't have to do it because others were more willing to put up the money than the Congress because they saw well what was happening to us in Central America, and the devastating consequences of a contra wipeout and an American walkaway and write-off; to what was going to happen to this country and to democracy elsewhere in the world. **********I didn't have to wander around and beg. There were other countries in the world, and other people in this country, who were more willing to help the Nicaraguan resistance survive, and cause democracy to prosper in Central America, than this body here. And that is an important factor in all of what you do, counsel, and in what this committee is going to do. It's got to be part of your assessment, as to why is it that other countries in the world were willing to step up and help in a desperate cause when we were not willing to do so ourselves. **********That has got to be something that is debated not just by pulling people before this group and hammering at them and haranguing them and reducing it to pettiness. It has got to be something that the American people come to understand, how desperately important it was not just to us, not just to Ollie North and not just to President Ronald Reagan. It was important to these other people who put forth that money. And I didn't beg them, they offered. And that's important, sir.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/23/busin.main_headline: New York Borrowing Is Smallest Since 1974
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/23/busin.print_headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES; New York Borrowing Is Smallest Since 1974
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/23/busin.body_text: **********New York State is offering $2.6 billion of notes due March 31, 1988, with a yield tentatively set at 4.85 percent through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers. **********Underwriters said that the notes were oversubscribed at a yield of 4.85 percent and that they might reprice the issue this morning, depending on market conditions. **********The state's spring borrowing, which is traditionally the largest financing of the year in the tax-exempt market, was reduced from $3.5 billion a year ago and was the smallest since 1974. **********Although the reduced size will reduce the state's interest expense, market participants noted that the interest rate on the notes was one-half to three-quarters of a percentage point higher than it would have been if the sale had taken place at the beginning of this month. But no sale was possible early in the month, because the Legislature and Governor did not agree on a budget for the year ending March 31, 1988, until April 11. **********To reduce the size of the financing, the state made about $350 million of income tax refunds in the fiscal year 1986-87 rather than the current year, arranged to record some income receipts (such as $121 million from the Mortgage Agency) in the current year instead of last year and transferred funds from the state insurance fund reserve. The State Comptroller, Edward V. Regan, said in a report published Monday that not all the tactics used to reduce the borrowing would be available next year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/12/busin.body_text: **********SEMICONDUCTOR stocks rank among the most prominent victims of the recent market collapse, which sliced the value of leading chip makers almost in half. But some Wall Street analysts suggest the selling has been overdone. **********''There are no signs of any slowdown in chip ordering nor is there any weakening in pricing,'' said Adam F. Cuhney of Kidder, Peabody & Company. ''What you are witnessing in part is the wave of anxiety washing through high-technology stocks.'' **********This anxiety stems from a sudden reassessment of economic prospects for 1988 in the wake of the stock market's plunge. Slower-than-expected economic growth is now the accepted view at many investment firms. At worst, there is even the specter of a possible recession next year. **********''We believe the semiconductor industry is very well positioned for whatever the future holds,'' said Mona Eraiba of Salomon Brothers. ''We expect this sector to outperform the general economy, and if any slowdown materializes, it will most likely be very mild and the impact on suppliers will be very limited.'' **********Mr. Cuhney carries a ''buy'' opinion on Intel, Motorola and Texas Instruments and Ms. Eraiba expects these same stocks to outperform the market over the next six to twelve months. Both analysts rate National Semiconductor as a ''hold.'' Ms. Eraiba said, ''However, we like the stock at these prices.'' But Thomas P. Kurlak of Merrill Lynch is more cautious on prospects for the group. ''These stocks appear fairly priced,'' he said. ''We think they will move in line with the overall market for the next three to six months.'' **********On Oct. 14, Mr. Kurlak lowered his investment opinion on the stocks from ''buy'' to ''neutral.'' He said: ''At that time, the high stock prices for semiconductor companies already had discounted the 1988 recovery. Also, we believed that inventory re-accumulation by customers had run its course and that bookings essentially had moved onto a plateau.'' **********And late last week, in anticipation of a slower-growth economy, he scaled back next year's earnings estimates by an average of 25 percent. His new estimates for the 1988 calendar year call for earnings of $3.85 a share for Texas Instruments, $2.70 a share for Motorola and between $1.60 and $1.80 a share for Intel. For National Semiconductor, the analyst projects profits at 50 cents a share for the fiscal year ending May 1988 and at 85 cents the following fiscal year. **********Ms. Eraiba of Salomon Brothers carries higher earnings estimates for 1988. Her estimate on Motorola, for example, remains at $3.75 a share. **********In yesterday's trading on the New York Stock Exchange, Texas Instruments rose 67.5 cents a share, to $41, while National Semiconductor gained 37.5 cents, to $11.75. Motorola fell 50 cents, to $40. The most active issue in the over-the-counter market, Intel, rose 67.5 cents, to $22.75. **********This contrasted with the spectacular performance of these issues in late September, when they rose swiftly to record high prices. At that time, many money managers were changing the makeup of their portfolios by selling interest-sensitive stocks like electric utilities and buying cyclical issues like the semiconductors that were seen as beneficiaries of an improving economy. The price of Texas Instruments surged to $80.25 and Motorola fetched as high as $74 in the closing days of September. Similarly, National Semiconductor climbed to $22.25 and Intel traded at $41.75, after adjustment for a recent 3-for-2 stock split. **********On Wall Street, semiconductor stocks have a reputation of behaving like a feast-or-famine group. From June 1983 until October 1986 these issues underperformed the general run of stocks and, for part of this period, they actually were in a bear market of their own. Between 1983 and 1985, for example, Texas Instruments saw the price of its shares cut in half. **********Stuart M. Johnson of Wertheim Schroder & Company believes that semiconductor issues, in a sense, are being punished in the market on the basis of their past performance during a business downturn. ''This was notably true in 1985 and 1986, when few companies except for Motorola escaped losing money,'' he said. ''But today the industry is in far better shape. There has been no buying binge by customers and the chip makers themselves are in far better financial condition.'' **********He sees the shares of Intel, Motorola, National Semiconductor and Texas Instruments as ''offering excellent value.'' Mr. Johnson is not predicting a recession, but he noted that ''the semiconductor industry has never been in a better position to weather a recession.'' **********At E.F. Hutton & Company, Edward C. White Jr. ranks Motorola and Intel as his two favorites. ''Motorola is more broadly based in its operations than most semiconductor companies,'' he said. ''Intel has a major new product family of microprocessor chips that make it possible to build powerful personal computers and work stations at lower costs.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/17/world.main_headline: Barbara Walters Gave Reagan Papers on Iran
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/17/world.print_headline: Barbara Walters Gave Reagan Papers on Iran
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/17/world.body_text: **********Barbara Walters provided the White House with documents reporting that an Iranian arms merchant believed that Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North had diverted profits from the sale of arms to Iran to the Nicaraguan insurgents, a senior White House official said today. **********The official's comments were part of a general White House confirmation that President Reagan had received two documents with information on the sales from Ms. Walters, a television journalist for ABC News, in December and January. The comments confirmed an account published in today's Wall Street Journal. **********The White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said the documents had been presented to the White House after Ms. Walters interviewed the arms merchant, Manucher Ghorbanifar, and Adnan Khashoggi, a Saudi businessman, last December. He said that he had no knowledge of how they had reached the President. **********At the same time, Mr. Fitzwater said the President had ''tentatively'' decided to hold a news conference, but he would not indicate when. Officials have been trying to provide Mr. Reagan with enough time to prepare for such a session, which would be his first since Nov. 19. **********On the matter of the documents, Mr. Fitzwater said he had been told ''that they had nothing new in them in terms of material information that would cast new light on the case.'' **********Both documents were turned over to Peter J. Wallison, the White House counselor, who made them available to the Tower Commission's investigation of the Iran-contra affair. **********The senior White House official said that the documents, for the most part, recounted comments by Mr. Ghorbanifar in an interview with Ms. Walters for the ABC News program ''20/20.'' ABC News released a statement in New York today that said Ms. Walters's ''transmission of her information to the President was in violation of a literal interpretation of news policy.'' **********''ABC policy expressly limits journalists cooperating with Government agencies unless threats to human lives are involved,'' the statement said. ''Ms. Walters believed that to be the case.'' **********In The Wall Street Journal article, Richard Wald, a senior vice president of ABC News, said that a memorandum outlining Mr. Ghorbanifar's private statements had been sent to the White House at the arms merchant's request. **********Ms. Walters's office referred telephone calls today to Mr. Wald. A secretary in his office said he was in a meeting and not available for comment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/19/world.print_headline: THE IRAN-CONTRA REPORT; DENIABILITY OVER ACCOUNTABILITY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/19/world.body_text: **********The committees described what they called a ''lack of accountability'' at the heart of the Iran-contra affair. **********The confusion, deception and privatization which marked the Iran-contra affair were the inevitable products of an attempt to avoid accountability. Congress, the Cabinet, and the Joint Chiefs of Staff were denied information and excluded from the decision making process. Democratic procedures were disregarded.   . . . **********That is what happened in the Iran-contra affair: *********** The President's N.S.C. staff carried out a covert action in furtherance of his policy to sustain the contras, but the President said he did not know about it. *********** The President's N.S.C. staff secretly diverted millions of dollars in profits from the Iran arms sales to the contras, but the President said he did not know about it and Poindexter claimed he did not tell him. *********** The Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff was not informed of the Iran arms sales, nor was he ever consulted regarding the impact of such sales on the Iran-Iraq war or on U.S. military readiness. *********** The Secretary of State was not informed of the millions of dollars in contra contributions solicited by the N.S.C. staff from foreign governments with which the State Department deals each day. *********** Congress was told almost nothing -and what it was told was false. **********Deniability replaced accountability. Thus, Poindexter justified his decision not to inform the President of the diversion on the ground that he wanted to give the President ''deniability.'' Poindexter said he wanted to shield the President from political embarrassment if the diversion became public.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/20/busin.main_headline: Upheaval in the Financial World: Baker Talks To Germans About Dollar
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/20/busin.print_headline: THE MARKET PLUNGE; Upheaval in the Financial World: Baker Talks To Germans About Dollar
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/20/busin.body_text: **********Against the backdrop of sinking stock markets and a bitter dispute with West Germany, Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d met today with top German economic officials in Frankfurt and, according to a statement from his office, agreed to work with other countries to keep currency rates ''around current levels.'' **********The meeting followed four days of angry criticism by Mr. Baker of increases in German interest rates. He said the actions by Bonn violated the spirit of an earlier agreement by the leading industrial countries to help the world economy grow. During the weekend, another American official had said that the Treasury would not get in the way of any market-driven decline of the dollar against the mark. A Market Move by Bonn **********Financial analysts said German officials apparently placated Mr. Baker today by pumping money into the German credit market, an action they said should ease upward pressure on interest rates. In New York, the dollar declined today against the mark, to 1.7775 marks, from 1.8015 on Friday. **********An Administration official said tonight that Mr. Baker would be returning to Washington, cutting short a visit to Europe that began Sunday and had been planned to last a week. The official said that in view of the steep drop in the stock market, Mr. Baker decided that, as the Administration's top economic official, he ought to be on hand to coordinate any Administration response to the market turmoil. **********The issue of rising German rates is crucial to Mr. Baker. Those increases are widely believed to have been contributing to rises in American rates, which are frequently cited as a provocation for the stock market's plunge. Mr. Baker's initiative is the only one the Administration has taken as yet to deal with the market turmoil. **********Speculation built in Washington and in the markets that Mr. Baker, the Germans and the finance ministers from other industrial countries would convene an emergency meeting, as they have done in the past. But senior officials in both the United States and in Europe said nothing was planned, and one said, ''I'm not sure it is necessary,'' No Fed Action Seen **********The Treasury Department has been denying that it wishes to see the dollar decline somewhat against the mark, but Wall Street analysts said they saw no evidence of attempts by the Federal Reserve, the Government's agent for currency trading, to arrest the decline of the dollar today by buying dollars. **********''The Fed certainly isn't in there,'' said Steven E. Cerier, foreign exchange economist at Manufacturers Hanover Bank. ''That suggests Baker has not given the Fed permission to intervene, particularly against the mark.'' **********Mr. Baker had left Washington on Sunday for what the Treasury said was a long-scheduled visit to Sweden, Belgium and Denmark. He and the German officials met in an airport hotel for three hours, officials said. **********A statement released by Mr. Baker's assistant secretary for public affairs, Margaret D. Tutwiler, said: **********''Today Secretary of the Treasury James A. Baker 3d and Finance Minister Gerhard Stoltenberg and Bundesbank President Karl Otto Pohl had a very positive, private meeting in Frankfurt, Germany, which had been agreed upon early last week.'' **********''The parties agreed to continue economic cooperation under the Louvre agreement and its flexible application including cooperation on exchange rate stability and monetary policies. **********''They are consulting with their Group of Seven colleagues and are confident that this will enable them to foster exchange rate stability around current levels.'' **********The statement referred to basic policies of coordination reached last Feb. 22 at the Louvre Palace offices of France's Finance Ministry. The policies were accepted by the United States, Japan, Germany, France, Britain and Canada, and subsequently by a seventh country, Italy, that was absent. Those countries are referred to as the Group of Seven.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/24/busin.body_text: **********The United States economy should grow at a moderate rate this year, accompanied by rising inflation and a slight drop in the unemployment rate, economists for some of the nation's biggest corporations predicted today. **********The National Association of Business Economists said that its latest survey of 280 members found growing optimism that the nation would avoid a recession in 1987 as it shakes off two years of sluggish growth. **********''The general feeling is that instead of hovering just on the horizon, the recession has been pushed further into the future,'' the association's president, Jerry Jordan, said. **********Mr. Jordan, chief economist for the First Interstate Bancorp of Los Angeles, said that only 17 percent of the economists surveyed believe a new recession will start this year, down from 32 percent three months ago. **********Instead, 40 percent of the economists now say that a recession is more likely in 1989. Thirty-four percent said the recession will begin next year. The Reagan Administration is not forecasting a recession before 1992, a full decade since the last downturn in 1981-82. **********The economists predicted that the nation's gross national product will grow 2.8 percent this year, compared with last year's rate of 2.1 percent. **********They said that consumer prices, which rose just 1.1 percent last year, will climb by 4 percent in 1987. **********Unemployment, which averaged 7 percent in 1986, will average 6.8 percent this year, the economists said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/27/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; . . . But Wherehouse Appears Uninterested
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/27/busin.body_text: **********It should be no surprise that Louis A. Kwiker, the chairman of Wherehouse Entertainment Inc., has so far expressed little interest in a $92 million takeover offer from Shamrock Holdings Inc. **********In 1979, when he was recruited as a music consultant to help revive the record retailer, based in Torrance, Calif., the company was so short of capital that it could not pay its bills. The crisis escalated when Wherehouse's founder, Lee Hartstone, died, and his estate ordered the company's sale. **********Instead, Mr. Kwiker, who was president and chief operating officer then, obtained control of the company with a financing package that was helped by the establishment of an employee stock-ownership plan. **********Mr. Kwiker has since accelerated the company's growth by raising $66.25 million in public stock and debt offerings. Proceeds were used to open new stores and acquire others, which boosted overhead and crimped profits in the last two years. **********''I think of him as a strong coach,'' said Keith R. Benjamin, an analyst with Silberberg, Rosenthal & Company in New York. ''He's been on a losing streak, and he's getting his team ready for the playoffs.'' **********And Mr. Kwiker, who is a marathon runner, clearly wants to reap the long-term rewards himself, the analyst said. **********The 51-year-old chief executive has declined to return repeated phone calls seeking comment on the offer from Shamrock, an investment company based in Burbank, Calif. **********Mr. Kwiker, who earned $314,452 last year, started his career as a corporate lawyer in New York after graduating from the University of Michigan. He then worked for two music companies and, later, started a consulting company in Detroit. **********In an article in the September issue of Chain Store Age Executive, an industry publication, Mr. Kwiker described his management style as ''the philosophy of the ant and the elephant.'' He said a chief executive's efforts could be compared to an ant trying to move an elephant by causing a disturbance. **********He has prodded Wherehouse through an internal training program, Wherehouse University, and through stock incentives. Stock ownership is a requirement of employment. The company's 4,000 employees, who operate 200 stores that are primarily in California, now control stock options for 468,577 of the company's 4.5 million shares. **********''Our belief is that people work differently when they own something,'' Mr. Kwiker said in the article.  ''He's worked very hard to clean this company up,'' said Mr. Benjamin, the New York analyst, ''and he's got a shot at becoming the dominant chain in California.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/07/world.main_headline: ARGENTINE ARMY, AFTER HALF-CENTURY AS THE POWER, FINDS ITSELF UNDER SIEGE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/07/world.print_headline: ARGENTINE ARMY, AFTER HALF-CENTURY AS THE POWER, FINDS ITSELF UNDER SIEGE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/07/world.body_text: **********An Argentine Army captain arrived at a meeting a few days ago wearing a parka and carrying his military jacket over his arm, folded so the insignia and medals could not be seen. **********''It's because of the psychological encirclement,'' he said as he took off the parka and put on the jacket, explaining that the army was so unpopular that he did not want to be seen in uniform on the streets downtown. **********''Psychological encirclement'' is the term military men here use to describe what they say they are confronting. The 177-year-old army, which has dominated power and politics for most of the last half-century, feels that it is under siege by a society that it believes is reacting ungratefully to the armed forces' role in putting down leftist subversion during the 1970's. A 'Boiling Kettle' **********A foreign diplomat in contact with top military officers said the unhappiness within the armed forces, particularly the army, over their declining status was so great that it had the potential to turn into a ''boiling kettle.'' **********The Congress completed action last week on legislation to greatly reduce the number of military officers facing trial in connection with the killings, kidnappings and other abuses committed during the counterinsurgency. But military officers, politicians and others with military contacts said in interviews they doubted that would be enough to satisfy the military. **********The man in the parka and three additional army captains, all in their 30's, talked about their grievances in a three-hour interview granted on the condition that their names not be published. All four said they had taken part in the takeover of an infantry school at the Campo de Mayo military base near here during a series of army rebellions over Easter. **********The mutinies were quieted after President Raul Alfonsin intervened, but they resulted in a shakeup of army leadership. An estimated three-fourths of the officer corps had refused to obey orders from that leadership to move against the rebellion. **********Immediately after the crisis, the President initiated the legislation that is intended to limit the trials to those who were involved in drafting the orders that led to the disappearance of an estimated 9,000 people and the torture of many more during the ''dirty war'' against leftists. **********The captains, who said they had not been charged in any of the human-rights cases, expressed difficulty in accepting that the toll from the counterinsurgency was that high, or that the campaign may have been directed against people who had not been engaged in violence. The 9,000 figure refers to those estimated to have been detained by the police or the military and who have never been seen again; it was produced by an investigative commission created by Mr. Alfonsin. Recalling President's Order **********One of the captains recalled the military's contention that the Government of President Isabel Martinez de Peron, before it was overthrown by the military in 1976, had ordered the armed forces to annihilate the guerrillas. While the meaning of those orders has been the subject of sharp debate in recent years among civilians, the captain said that to a military officer, ''there's no doubt what that term means.'' **********Another of the captains said the legislation just passed by Congress ''is perhaps a step forward from the perspective that it will diminish the parade of military officers before the courts and all of that, but it does not go to the depth of the question. That is, plainly and simply, that the country should say, 'There was a war here; the armed forces were engaged in it as the result of a political decision, under constitutional orders; and a political solution, not a juridical one, is what must be found now.' '' **********He and the other captains, who defended the events of the 1970's as necessary for the national good, said their complaints went beyond the question of the trials and were based on the fear that the continued existence of the army itself was at stake. They asserted that some members of President Alfonsin's party, the Radical Civic Union, and some human-rights advocates wanted to dismantle the army. **********Dr. Ricardo Felgueras, staff director of the Senate Defense Committee, who deals regularly with the military, said this fear was widespread within the army and not only among those who took part in the mutinies. He acknowledged that some in the party have said privately that the country might not need a military, but he didn't indicate what might have been proposed to take its place. 'Most Serious Problem' **********Dr. Felgueras also asserted that some of the problems have originated within the army, which he said was racked by self-doubt. **********''The most serious problem of the Argentine Army,'' he said, ''is that it doesn't know what it exists for. At this point, there is virtually no possibility of external conflict, not with Brazil, Chile or Britain, but this is an army that is accustomed to running something -industry, the Government, the instruments of repression. So now, mentalities have to be changed.'' **********Dr. Felgueras said that, as a result of the April rebellions, the army was still ''fractured'' by a split between high-ranking officers and those of the rank of lieutenant colonel and below. The captains that were interviewed. however, indicated that the new chief of staff, Gen. Jose Dante Caridi, had shown the capacity to quickly understand the source of the internal unrest. **********The Alfonsin Government has said it wants to reduce the size of the armed forces and to make them more modern and professional. At the same time, the Government wants to create a military that is more responsive to civilian authority and less inclined to intervene in politics. **********One step that the Government recently took was to have the entire officer corps swear allegiance to the Constitution. In the past, military men that were being sworn in or that were being promoted swore allegiance to the country and flag, but not to the Constitution. Impact on the Budget **********But, so far, the greatest impact of the Government's policies on the armed forces has been in budget reductions. A year ago, the Defense Ministry said that the military budget had been cut about one-third in the preceding three years, and that military spending as a percentage of the nation's annual output of goods and services was about half the level in 1983 - down to slightly more than 2 percent from 4.6 percent. **********The budget restraints have led to complaints within the military that there is not enough money to buy or maintain equipment, or even to conduct regular exercises. The captains, for example, asserted that the army would not be prepared should it be needed for an operation, such as against drug traffickers. **********They also said their salaries of about $250 a month were not only far below the levels of the years under military government, but also the levels of the last constitutional government. They contended that the salaries, which are well below those paid to middle managers in the private sector, could adversely affect morale and lead to the loss of top officers, further weakening the military. **********The armed forces are thought to have about 75,000 men, half of the number that fought the war with Britain in 1982 over control of the Falkland Islands, which are called the Malvinas here. The officer corps has been reduced by attrition, and the ranks by a dramatic drop in conscription. **********The captains also complained about what they characterized as a press campaign to discredit the military. **********A foreign diplomat said that for all of these reasons, the armed forces feel defanged. **********The captains said that the takeover of the infantry school was the result of frustration that had been brewing for a long time, and that the previous army leadership had not been responding to it. Warnings of 'Instability' **********The leader of the Campo de Mayo uprising, Lieut. Col. Aldo Rico, had written a letter two months earlier to his immediate superior, the commander of the 12th Infantry Brigade, warning that the possibility of trials, the low salaries and equipment shortages, and the criticism by the press were creating a ''dangerous instability'' in the army. **********Colonel Rico urged his superiors to demand a full amnesty on the human-rights charges, even though he said amnesty was ''ignominious'' for a military that ''fought a just and necessary war'' - a position supported by the four captains. He asserted that an amnesty was necessary to preserve constitutional order, and he said that the army should not delay while other officers were imprisoned, but that it should ''confront the problem in a decisive manner.'' **********As many as 450 active-duty and retired officers could face trial on charges brought by human-rights groups. It is not yet clear how many would be freed from the prospect of trial under the new legislation. **********So far, 10 men have been tried and given prison sentences. This includes five former military commanders.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/04/world.main_headline: INDIAN FLOTILLA IS TURNED BACK BY SRI LANKAN NAVAL VESSELS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/04/world.print_headline: INDIAN FLOTILLA IS TURNED BACK BY SRI LANKAN NAVAL VESSELS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/04/world.body_text: **********An Indian flotilla of fishing boats bound for northern Sri Lanka with food and medicine for ethnic Tamils abruptly called off its mission tonight and turned back after Sri Lankan naval vessels barred it from proceeding. **********The Indian action, averting what diplomats and others had feared might become a military confrontation between the two countries, came after more than four hours of tense negotiations aimed at defusing the crisis atmosphere of the last several days. **********Adding to the dangerous atmosphere were reports that several Indian warships were stationed in India's territorial waters near the likely scene of confrontation, ready to move if Sri Lanka had done anything provocative. #19 Unarmed Fishing Boats Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India had directed the creation of the flotilla to bring relief to Tamil areas subjected in recent weeks to aerial bombardment and naval shelling in a Sri Lankan Government offensive against Tamil separatist guerrillas. **********While Indian and Sri Lankan officials discussed possible compromises, the 19 unarmed fishing boats laden with medicine and food and carrying more than 100 journalists, remained anchored in the dark seas off the tiny Sri Lankan island of Kachchativu. **********Their location was about midway in a 30-mile stretch of the Palk Strait between the two countries' shorelines. Officials Denounce Colombo **********At about 9 P.M., when it became clear that the negotiations had failed, Indian officials denounced what they termed Colombo's ''deliberately negative and destructive'' response. They then turned the boats around and headed back to Rameswaram, an ancient port city from which the flotilla had set out early in the afternoon. **********The episode marked one of India's most dramatic confrontations with a small neighboring country in recent years. Diplomats said they feared that despite the intentions to avoid hostilities, there had been a danger of losing control at a time of growing mistrust between the two countries. **********An Indian spokesman in New Delhi said tonight that the decision to back down was made because of an ''implicit threat'' from the Sri Lankan Navy. But Colombo maintains that at no time was there a threat of force, arguing that for Sri Lanka to do so would invite retaliation and and almost certain defeat. Sri Lankans Are Elated **********Sri Lankan officials were thus elated that they had thwarted what they feared could have been a humiliating violation of national sovereignty by a country with vastly superior military forces. **********In New Delhi, the Government said the developments of the day show ''that the Government of Sri Lanka is determined to continue denying the people of Jaffna their basic rights'' and that India would not remain ''indifferent spectators'' to such problems. **********India asserts that hundreds of civilians died and many more face starvation when Sri Lanka undertook a major military offensive in the peninsula against the Tamil guerrillas, who are fighting for an independent nation on the island. Guerrillas Control Peninsula **********The Sri Lankan Government asserts that fewer than 50 civilians died in the offensive, even though it succeeded in securing a 20-square-mile section of the peninsula previously held by guerrillas. The guerrillas in fact control most of the peninsula. **********The widely contradictory claims on casualties have not been verified because Sri Lanka has barred reporters, diplomats and others from inspecting the damage from its offensive. **********Army officials acknowledged that in their sweep, they had taken 3,500 Tamil youths into custody, virtually the entire young male population of the sector that was the target of the offensive. **********The planned Indian relief mission had marked the first time that India had proposed to intervene directly in Sri Lankan affairs. **********Sri Lanka is dominated by ethnic Sinhalese, who are Buddhists. **********It was uncertain tonight whether the confrontation that ended in the Palk Strait might spur a new effort to mediate the Sri Lankan ethnic conflict. India has served as the mediator over the last year, but its ability to offer itself as a neutral negotiator appeared to be in doubt.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/22/busin.body_text: **********Leon Finley - a founder of the law firm of Finley, Kumble, Wagner, Heine, Underberg, Manley, Myerson & Casey -has left to join another New York firm, Baer, Marks & Upham. **********Finley, Kumble, which was ranked as the nation's fourth-largest law firm as recently as September, is expected to close by year's end. **********Mr. Finley becomes the third partner for whom the firm was named to leave within two months. In October, Andrew N. Heine resigned to join Curtis, Mallet-Prevost, Colt & Mosle. **********And, Neil Underberg, along with 15 other Finley lawyers, left to join Whitman & Ransom. **********Mr. Finley, who will become of counsel, leads a group of 11 lawyers in the move to Baer, Marks, where they will join that firm's corporate law department.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/11/busin.body_text: **********JOSH D'AVENZO, a salesman in Hicksville, L.I., is no novice at investing in limited partnerships: he has invested in three since 1980. Yet, Mr. D'Avenzo makes it a point to study carefully the structure of any program he is offered, in order to see just how the profits are divided. **********''The general partner put the deal together, for which he's entitled to something,'' Mr. D'Avenzo said. ''But it's my money and the other limited partners' money that is really getting the deal to go. We should be getting a very big share in the program.'' **********The concern expressed by Mr. D'Avenzo is typical of that felt by many purchasers of limited partnership units these days, with tax revision having reduced the tax benefits long associated with this investment category. The economics of a transaction are now generally the driving element, and any conflicts - actual or potential - between the general partner and the limited partners should be especially considered before participating in such a partnership. **********Limited partnerships are a form of business organization used in fields such as real estate, oil and gas, and equipment leasing that consists of two basic entities. The general partner is usually the sponsor and manager of the project, while the limited partners invest all or most of the money, are liable only for the amount of their investment and are not involved in day-to-day management. **********A total of $16.7 billion worth of units in these partnerships was sold last year, a decline of 12 percent from 1985, according to Robert A. Stanger & Company, which provides limited partnership statistics and research. In 1987, however, Stanger believes that sales will advance between 8 and 12 percent, bringing still more investors who seek an above-average return into the partnership market. ''Both the general partner and the limited partners are seeking to maximize the short-term economic potential of the assets, as well as the long-term value,'' said Joseph Kavanau, executive vice president of Concord Assets Group, which sponsors limited partnerships that invest in shopping centers. ''So, economically, they're in bed together.'' **********Regardless of the motivation that brings the parties together in a limited partnership arrangement, there are certain aspects of a typical deal that pull them apart. And those factors - which are another reason that limited partnership investing is more complex than investing in stocks or bonds - ought to be understood before engaging in this activity. **********''For the most part, the limited partner shares identical interests with the general partner,'' said Christopher L. Davis, president of the Investment Partnership Association, the trade association for partnerships. ''However, spelled out in the partnership agreement are important distinctions that can involve distribution of the income stream and the allocation of the capital gain when an asset is sold.'' **********In a usual arrangement, the limited partners may receive between 90 and 99 percent of the benefits during the holding period of the partnership as cash distributions, with the remainder going to the general partner. At a successful liquidation or refinancing about 10 years later, the limited partners may get their investment back, plus a specified cumulative return of around 6 to 15 percent annually - along with 75 to 90 percent of whatever additional proceeds remain. Of course, there are often management fees to the sponsor and commissions to brokers that significantly reduce the amount of a limited partner's funds available for investment. **********A probable point of conflict between the two occurs when the general partner sells assets to the limited partnership. ''Where you're buying an asset from the general partner, how do you know you're paying a good price?'' asked William Turchyn, senior vice president of E. F. Hutton & Company. ''And what incentive is there for him to hang around and make it successful?'' **********Another danger could be in situations in which the sponsor operates a number of different corporations, with some doing business with affiliated limited partnerships. For example, if the general partner of a partnership also owns a mortgage loan company that lends money to this partnership, limited partners would have every right to wonder which of these entities is paramount to the sponsor. And if the sponsor is general partner in a group of limited partnerships, which one would come first when an attractive selling or buying opportunity arose? **********Another problem between a general partner and the limited partners could revolve around the sponsor's efforts to end the partnership arrangement too early. This possibility might develop when a sponsor is so anxious to obtain its contracted share of the capital appreciation that it terminates the partnership faster than necessary. **********These and other instances in which the interests of general and limited partners do not coincide indicate that individuals should be cautious when investing in limited partnerships. Financial advisers suggest that the sponsor's fee schedule, experience, track record and goals be carefully weighed in advance. It may be too late once you are already a limited partner.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/02/world.main_headline: BEIRUT MOSLEMS CLOSE RANKS FOR PEACE BID TO CHRISTIANS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/02/world.print_headline: BEIRUT MOSLEMS CLOSE RANKS FOR PEACE BID TO CHRISTIANS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/02/world.body_text: **********Lebanon's main Moslem and Druse leaders, whose rival militias fought pitched battles on the streets of West Beirut only a week ago, announced today that they had closed ranks and had prepared a program that they would offer to the country's Christians in an effort to halt 12 years of civil war. **********The announcement was made by Prime Minister Rashid Karami after he and four other officials held two days of intensive talks with high-ranking Syrian Government leaders in Damascus. **********Also taking part on the Lebanese side were Hussein al-Husseini, the Speaker of Parliament; Education Minister Selim al-Hoss; Justice Minister Nabih Berri, and Public Works Minister Walid Jumblat. **********Mr. Berri heads the mainline Shiite Moslem movement Amal, whose fighters were pitted against Mr. Jumblat's Druse forces in six days of major clashes in the Moslem part of the Lebanese capital.
