Gunmen Are Off the Streets **********The Moslem and Druse leaders taking part in the new initiative were the same ones who had asked President Hafez al-Assad of Syria to rush thousands of Syrian troops to West Beirut to end the bloodshed. **********The discussions in Damascus were designed to provide a solid political foundation for the security dragnet carried out by Syrian Army units, who have driven the gunmen off the streets of the Moslem part of the capital. **********At 22 checkpoints that they and Lebanese policemen have set up in West Beirut, Syrian soldiers have been handing out leaflets, apparently in an effort to explain the objective of the Syrian intervention and to win popular support for it. At the same time, they have put up posters on walls along the streets, urging the public to help in tracking down ''hoodlums and looters.'' **********One leaflet said, ''We in Syria see the interest of Lebanese as the same as that of the Syrians.'' Another said, ''There will be no more snipers to destroy civilization and kill innocent people.'' #300 Reported Killed According to police statistics, more than 300 people were killed during February in street gun battles, other violent incidents and fighting around Palestinian districts here and in southern Lebanon. In the Palestinian quarters, the fighting has been between Shiite militiamen and guerrillas of the Palestine Liberation Organization. **********A police spokesman said a car bomb with 300 pounds of explosives was seized today in the Barbir quarter west of the Green Line, which separates the Moslem sector from Christian East Beirut. **********The bomb was dismantled before it could go off and the driver was arrested, the spokesman said. The man was identified as Rida Ahmed Zneit, a Moslem from eastern Lebanon. **********The car had crossed from East Beirut and was to have been planted in a crowded area in West Beirut, the spokesman said. **********The Moslem radio station Voice of the Homeland asserted that the driver had ''confessed'' that his instructions for planting the booby-trapped vehicle had come from oficials in the Lebanese Forces, a Christian militia. Christians Object to Deployment **********Militia commanders and other Christian leaders have voiced strong objection to the deployment of Syrian military units in West Beirut. **********In discussing the program prepared today in Damascus, Prime Minister Karami said, ''Agreement has been reached on a draft plan for political reforms.'' He said the program would be offered for consideration at negotiations with the Christian side. **********A team of political and military experts appointed by President Amin Gemayel, a Christian, has been holding consultations with the Syrian Vice President, Abdel Halim Khaddam, on ways to bring about reconciliation among the Lebanese factions and re-establish unity in the Lebanese Government. The team is led by a former Foreign Minister, Elie Salem, who is now a political consultant to President Gemayel. For several years, Syria has been the main power broker in Lebanon, and sometimes the mediator between factions. Moslems Boycott Cabinet **********The decision to negotiate with Christian leaders is the first positive sign since Moslem and Druse officials and politicians began a boycott of Governments meeting led by Mr. Gemayel. The boycott was called after Mr. Gemayel rejected an earlier Syrian-sponsored pact for political restructuring. **********The Moslem and Druse leaders are known to be pressing for an equal share in government with the Christians. They want the president's powers to be shifted to the Cabinet so Moslem and Christian ministers can exercise the executive authority collectively. **********The conciliatory mood in Damascus today was not matched in southern Lebanon, where rival factions within the Amal movement fought each other today on the main highway linking the ports of Sidon and Tyre. The highway was closed to traffic for several hours. **********A statement by the Amal leadership denied news reports that an uprising had occurred within Amal, Lebanon's largest Shiite militia. **********There were no immediate reports of casualties. The confrontation was between supporters of Mr. Berri and supporters of a breakaway faction led by Hassan Hashem. Mr. Hashem, once the No. 3 figure in Amal, was relieved of all his posts during elections to the group's leadership a year ago. **********In a statement, Mr. Hashem said his followers had beaten back gunmen who laid siege to his home village of Al Marwaniye near Tyre.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/26/world.main_headline: Chief of C.I.A. Covert Operations, Criticized in Iran Affair, Resigns
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/26/world.print_headline: Chief of C.I.A. Covert Operations, Criticized in Iran Affair, Resigns
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/26/world.body_text: **********Clair George, chief of covert operations at the Central Intelligence Agency, submitted his resignation today effective at the end of the year, the agency said. **********Mr. George has been criticized by senior senators over his performance in the Iran-contra affair, but it could not be learned whether his resignation was forced or voluntary. The agency described it as retirement. **********Mr. George, whose title is Deputy Director for Operations, has been an intelligence officer for 32 years. **********William H. Webster, Director of Central Intelligence, issued a statement saying Mr. George had ''served his country and this agency with courage often overseas and often in the most demanding circumstances.'' **********Mr. Webster, who took over as head of the agency this year, has said that any personnel changes would not be made until the agency's internal review of the Iran-contra affair was complete. He affirmed that policy in July after reports in the press that Mr. George would be dismissed or allowed to take early retirement. **********A C.I.A. official confirmed today that Mr. Webster planned to keep Robert M. Gates as Deputy Director. Gates's Role Was Questioned **********President Reagan nominated Mr. Gates to be Director of Central Intelligence last February, but withdrew his name after questions were raised about his activities in the Iran-contra affair. The Congressional Iran-contra report named Mr. Gates and others in the agency as having received information, before it was made public, on the possibility that money from arms sales to Iran was being diverted to the Nicaraguan rebels. **********The Congressional hearings on the affair demonstrated that C.I.A. officials aided in air supply operations and provided other military assistance to the Nicaraguan rebels when it was against the law. **********The station chief in Costa Rica, Joe Fernandez, who was directly responsible to Mr. George, testified that he believed his actions were authorized by his superiors. Mr. George, in closed testimony that was declassified and made public, said he did not know that Mr. Fernandez and others were giving military help to the rebels. Senators' Criticism **********David L. Boren, Democrat of Oklahoma, the chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, and William S. Cohen, Republican of Maine, the vice chairman, said that if Mr. George did not know of agents' activities, he should have known and should have stopped them. The Senators were members of the Iran-contra panel. **********Mr. Fernandez also testified that, under instructions from Mr. George, he had not responded fully to questions asked by President Reagan's special review board. Mr. George denied giving such instructions. **********The C.I.A. provided little background about Mr. George's career. It said that he had been with the agency for 32 years, that he had taken over agency operations in Greece in 1975 after the station chief, Richard Welch, was assassinated, and that he had been head of the C.I.A.'s office of congressional affairs before becoming Deputy Director for Operations in 1984. **********Mr. George graduated from Pennsylvania State University and was station chief in Beirut before going to Greece. Friends said he was in his middle 50's.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/19/world.main_headline: ENGLAND'S GREEN AND PLEASANT LAND, SPLIT IN TWO?
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/19/world.print_headline: BOLTON JOURNAL; ENGLAND'S GREEN AND PLEASANT LAND, SPLIT IN TWO?
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/19/world.body_text: **********In the days of Empire, Bolton's smokestacks were towering red-brick symbols of the prosperity earned by spinning textiles for the world. There were about 200 textile mills and enough jobs and money for everyone. The spinning jenny was invented here; William Hesketh Lever cut his first bar of soap here. **********Today, 114 of the mills still stand, but only five or six of them produce textiles. A few have been converted to other uses, but most stand empty, unlikely to have new tenants soon. And Bolton, 220 miles northwest of London with a population of 260,000 and an unemployment rate of nearly 16 percent, reflects many of the problems of the north of the country. **********In recent weeks, what is called the ''north-south division,'' stoked by Labor Party politicians in what is expected to be a national election year, has become a matter of national debate. **********Last month, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher visited Bolton and told a friendly audience that things here looked fine. She was quoted as saying that ''I don't think there is anything like the north-south divide that people like to think.'' **********But in Bolton, which generally votes Labor like most northern industrial areas, the north-south division is taken as fact, in terms of economics and in terms of attitude. Neglect by the 'Soft' South **********The issue is hardly new. In the 1930's George Orwell, who wrote a book about this area called ''The Road to Wigan Pier,'' perceived ''a real difference between North and South, and there is at least a tinge of truth in that picture of Southern England as one enormous Brighton inhabited by lounge-lizards.'' **********Paul Woodmansey, Bolton's chief of industrial development planning, said ''the southerner is considered 'nesh,' '' a local word he defined as ''soft.'' **********Another factor is the perception in the north that it is ignored by the centers of power in London. When a city public relations official was told that there was unusually heavy snow in London, she said: ''That's why we're getting so much of it on TV. We can be snowed in for days up here and there is nothing.'' **********Northerners say London's neglect is manifest in the region's jobless rate. The Government admits that unemployment in the north remains much higher than in London and the southeast, where the rate is about 9 percent. But the Conservatives note that the northern jobless rate is leveling off. **********Labor Party officials, on the other hand, emphasize that since Mrs. Thatcher came to power in 1979, unemployment has soared in the north and hundreds of thousands of manufacturing jobs have vanished. They say that most of the several hundred thousand new jobs created in the country have been in the service industries in London and the southeast. **********Ian Symons, a Bolton industrial development planner, says that what happened to his city is clear. After World War II, other countries began to compete in textiles, but the textile jobs lost here were made up by a growing engineering equipment industry. Then that began to weaken, and Bolton's unemployment rate jumped to about 16 percent in 1980 and has stayed there, while the national average is about 13 percent. **********In recent years, the increase in service jobs in London and the south has outstripped efforts in the north to replace the old, moribund industries. North Seen as Bad Risk **********One reason, Mr. Symons said, is that Bolton no longer had any natural advantage, like the damp atmosphere that prevents textile thread from snapping under tension. And part of the problem is ''pure ignorance about what happens up here,'' he said. ''We're seen as a bad risk by the banks. The north is a risk, the south is the place to invest.'' **********Even Government programs to create new industry have hurt Bolton. Recently, an elevator manufacturer moved out of Bolton to set up near Liverpool, which has 19 percent unemployment, and where the company got a better deal under a Government redevelopment program. **********Northerners are rankled by Government proposals for major projects principally benefiting the south, like the plans to build a third airport for London and to dig a tunnel between England and France. **********Peter Thurnham, the only Conservative Member of Parliament from Bolton (the other two are Labor), defends the Government's position by noting that Government has promised to help expand the Manchester airport, which wants more international business, and that the Channel tunnel, widely known as the Chunnel, would be built with private investment. **********But Bob Howarth, the chairman of the Labor-controlled borough council, said that although the Chunnel is mostly a private enterprise, ''the Government is promoting it, a huge investment in the most inconvenient corner of our country.'' **********''The Government is London-based and London-centered and seems biased against the north,'' he added. Of Mrs. Thatcher's visit, he said: ''I'm pleased to see she's visiting the north. She's probably the most London-based Prime Minister we've had in a long time.'' **********At the Job Center, a municipal unemployment agency near Town Hall, an jobless graphic designer, Alex Kaicald, said the south cared little for the problems of the north. ''It's an example of 'I'm all right, Jack,' '' he said. ''I'm all right down here. I don't feel it.'' **********Other unemployed men gathered at the center said they had heard that under the Thatcher Government, the average national wage had risen to about $250 a week, but most of the jobs posted at the Job Center paid less than half that. **********John Watson is in charge of a Government program to study crime in Bolton, which has been increasing. Much of it, he said, is a result of unemployment, especially among young people. The practice of smashing and emptying the coin-operated meters found on some home heating systems is increasingly common, as are muggings. Life Without Superficiality **********Twenty-five years ago, David Buxton, a business consultant, came here from the London area to try to make a living. One of the things that put him off in the south, he said, was that ''I'd go for a walk and someone would be working in the garden and I used to say hello and they usually fell over.'' **********He continued, ''Up here if you don't say hello you'd be unusual.'' **********Mr. Buxton, now head of the Chamber of Commerce, added: ''A lot of people in the south think people up here are rough and uncultured. Well, there are some very cultured people, with lovely houses, artistic interests. The appreciation of life is richer, divested of superficiality. No veneer. People in the south feel they have to put on a face, to say things in a roundabout way. Up here, it's just straight.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/09/busin.main_headline: MOUNTING CONFLICT OVER TRADE LOOMS FOR U.S. AND JAPAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/09/busin.print_headline: MOUNTING CONFLICT OVER TRADE LOOMS FOR U.S. AND JAPAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/09/busin.body_text: **********The United States and Japan are headed for their most serious trade confrontation of the postwar period, Government officials and many private analysts believe. **********Frustrations have stiffened attitudes on both sides of the Pacific, making compromises less likely on a whole range of issues from semiconductors and supercomputers to the letting of contracts for an $8.5 billion airport construction project at Osaka. **********''This may be the year in which the string runs out on Capitol Hill,'' warned the United States trade representative, Clayton K. Yeutter. ''The level of frustration with Japan is higher than I have ever seen it.'' Outlook for Approval **********Although President Reagan would probably veto legislation forcing trade retaliation against Japan, Mr. Yeutter warned in an interview that a veto could become ''irrelevant'' should such legislation clear overwhelmingly, as is now indicated. **********Resentment is being fed by the widening trade imbalance. Last year's deficit in trade with Japan was $58 billion, about one-third of the overall United States trade deficit of $170 billion. Some analysts believe it could get even bigger this year. **********''Japan is not going to get a sympathetic audience from anybody in the U.S. or from anybody in the world,'' said Senator John C. Danforth of Missouri, the ranking Republican on the Senate Finance Committee. **********And Representative Marcy Kaptur, Democrat of Ohio, said: ''There is a hardening inside the Congress. The point has been reached where people want us to take strong action. I think the Japanese are laughing behind their hands wondering why we didn't do anything a lot earlier.'' **********But Japanese resistance to American trade demands is also strengthening - mainly because the dramatic shift in the yen-dollar relationship has hurt export industries and has brought a new phenomenon to Japan: rising unemployment. **********Last week Japan reported that unemployment rose in January to 3 percent, the highest level since monthly reporting began in 1953. Japan's Growing Anxiety **********Although this is less than half the American jobless rate, the Japanese figure, which means nearly 2 million workers are unemployed, has caused a deepening anxiety that is reflected in less resilient Japanese positions at the trade bargaining table. **********One of the big worries is that Japanese corporations' expansion in the United States and elsewhere overseas is leading to a ''hollowing out'' of the industrial base in Japan. A recent Tokyo report predicts that domestic employment opportunities will shrink by 600,000 jobs by the year 2000, leading to an acute unemployment crisis. **********S. Bruce Smart Jr., Under Secretary of Commerce for international trade administration, who recently returned from negotiations in Tokyo on semiconductors and supercomputers, said he found the Japanese positions were ''clearly a lot tougher than ever before.'' **********He said, ''We should be careful to recognize that the Japanese are under some internal pressure, but we must continue being just as aggressive and forceful as we have ever been.'' Most-Urgent Trade Issues **********The most-pressing trade conflicts are these: *********** Semiconductors: Japan agreed last July to open its market to sales of American computer chips. The target was $2 billion of additional exports in five years. The Japanese also agreed to help assure that Japanese companies would quit dumping chips in the United States and third-country markets at less than fair value. ''Clearly we are very disturbed that Japan has not fulfilled its obligations under that agreement,'' said Mr. Yeutter. Washington could retaliate if the Japanese do not come into better compliance by the end of this month. *********** Kansai Airport: The Japanese are building an island in Osaka Bay as the site of a huge airport to serve the Osaka region. But American and other foreign companies are effectively barred from any of the major construction work. The United States may react by barring Japanese companies from bidding on airport construction projects in this country. Legislation to do this has been introduced by Senator Frank H. Murkowski, an Alaska Republican. *********** Supercomputers: The Reagan Administration has begun a formal investigation of Japanese barriers to imports of these huge and unusually fast computers, which cost up to $20 million each. Despite its acknowledged technological lead over Japan, the United States has only 23 percent of the Japanese supercomputer market, compared with 86 percent in the rest of the world. The investigation could lead to a formal trade complaint and eventual retaliation. *********** Auto parts: This country's annual deficit in auto parts trade with Japan has grown to roughly $7 billion a year. Although an agreement was reached in 1980, the Japanese have bought only $200 million of American parts. The agreement called for purchases of $300 million in 1981 alone. Now the United States is again pressing the Japanese for greater access, this time within the framework of what have become known as the Market-Oriented Sector Selective talks. So far the Japanese have promised only to provide information - a breakdown of the broad categories of Japanese purchases of auto parts from American companies. Competitive Edge Sought **********Trade tensions with Japan are rising despite the acknowledgement by many people in the United States that the loss of American competitiveness is at least as important an element in the trade imbalance as unfair trade practices by Japan or any other country. Some analysts here see Japan as an all-too-easy scapegoat for American shortcomings. **********''Japan is the metaphor for the loss of our competitive edge,'' commented Steven R. Saunders, a former assistant United States trade representative and now a trade consultant with some Japanese clients. ''We don't understand that our demands are perceived, from the Japanese point of view, as a kind of extortion.'' **********The Japanese Embassy's economic counselor, Yoshidji Nogami, noted a ''growing feeling in Japan that the trade problems between the two countries are rooted in the U.S. situation.'' **********Against the mounting acrimony, some analysts still see a turn for the better in the trade situation, and they fear that excessive American pressure would be counterproductive. Prediction of Improvement **********''I believe we are going to see a trade improvement in the coming months,'' said Robert Z. Lawrence, senior fellow at the Brookings Institution. ''It is clear that the Japanese are beginning to be hammered in third-country markets in terms of price competitiveness.'' **********He cited comparisons of Japanese and American export prices compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, showing that Japanese prices are now 5 percent higher than American prices. In March 1985 they were 20 percent lower. **********''Japan bashing will not help in this environment,'' said George R. Packard, dean of the School of Advanced International Studies of Johns Hopkins University and director of the Edwin O. Reischauer Center for East Asian Studies. ''It will cause more resentment, make it more difficult to get concessions and trouble the waters for Nakasone.'' **********Japanese officials report that Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone is tentatively planning a visit to Washington in April to see President Reagan and make a fresh effort to ease the trade tensions.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/11/world.main_headline: OLIVE GROVE BRINGS ARABS AND JEWS TOGETHER
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/11/world.print_headline: OLIVE GROVE BRINGS ARABS AND JEWS TOGETHER
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/11/world.body_text: **********A simple grove of olive trees brought Arabs and Jews together today to protest the Israeli Government's plan to uproot trees long tended by the Arabs. **********Against the backdrop of a rusted barbed-wire fence surrounding a minefield from the 1967 war, hundreds of people from the two groups gathered at the olive groves here in the Jerusalem suburbs and shook hands. It was the first time they had reached out to one another in such a heartfelt fashion in the memory of members of the two crowds that quickly, easily became one on the breezy hillside. **********''I want to see you in my house,'' Nahum Megged, a professor from Hebrew University, told Hassan Abu Assala, an Arab municipal worker. A Symbolic Sapling **********They hugged each other minutes after two 10-year-old girls, one from each group, had prepared a new olive tree for planting. **********The sapling symbolized a joint pledge to appeal to the Government to spare the trees, though it has expropriated the land. **********After winning a court fight over its claim to the land, the Government committed the 75-acre tract to parkland and began replanting the olive trees with pines. The pines, some of them already planted, are also intended to prevent the Arab farmers from reviving their claim to the land by way of continued informal tending of the olive grove. **********''Why would they do such a silly thing?'' Mr. Megged asked. **********Colleagues in the crowd said it was a matter of the politics of territoriality. After taking over the territory from Jordan after the 1967 war, Israel expropriated more than 500 acres of the Arabs' land, including other olive groves, for public purposes. **********''Where can we go? Show us the place we can go!'' an Arab resident said over the loudspeaker whose sound drifted down toward the olive trees. A Rare Sight **********''I've never seen anything quite like this,'' said Yehuda Litani, Middle East news editor of The Jerusalem Post, as he watched the crowds mix, smile and exchange greetings. He said such an unusual mingling might happen occasionally in a rural area, but never here in the Jerusalem metropolis. **********''I'm here as a resident,'' he said, applauding the good will and beaming when the Mayor of Jerusalem, Teddy Kollek, arrived to support the protest. ''Neighbors are working together, standing together in what seems to be a matter of justice,'' the mayor said. ''I hope that we will succeed.'' A few of the Arabs were facing Mecca and praying when the Jews marched up from their neighborhood and crossed the hilly no man's land where the olive trees grow. Some of the visitors came from the East Talpiot community that was built on expropriated Arab lands. **********''It's great to see the praying, yes?'' said one Jewish visitor. **********''These roots can either bring friendship or hatred,'' said Abu Assala, an Arab greeting a Jew. ''It depends on us.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/13/world.main_headline: U.S. TRIES TO EASE ISRAELI ANNOYANCE ON IRAN DISCLOSURE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/13/world.print_headline: U.S. TRIES TO EASE ISRAELI ANNOYANCE ON IRAN DISCLOSURE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/13/world.body_text: **********The United States has assured Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir that the White House's disclosure last week of documents describing Israel's role in the decision to sell arms to Iran was not intended as a criticism of Israel's actions, a White House official said today. **********The message, conveyed orally to Mr. Shamir on Sunday by Thomas R. Pickering, the United States Ambassador to Israel, was described as expressing the personal sentiments of President Reagan. It was sent after Israeli officials expressed annoyance that the disclosures in Washington emphasized Israel's role in helping to persuade the Reagan Administration to sell arms to Iran. No Prior Notification **********On Thursday, after reports about the Senate Intelligence Committee's draft report on the Iran affair began to circulate, the White House began releasing excerpts from two declassified documents that underscored Israel's behind-the-scenes maneuvers in the Iran operation. On Friday the White House made public the texts of the two papers. **********According to State Department officials, White House officials, in their rush to make the documents public, had failed to follow the normal diplomatic courtesy of informing a friendly government ahead of time that it might be embarrassed by the disclosures. Paper Prepared by North **********One of the two documents was a ''finding'' by Mr. Reagan on Jan. 17, 1986, authorizing the arms sales to Iran. **********That document did not mention Israel. **********However, Israel was highlighted in the second document, a memorandum for Mr. Reagan that accompanied the finding and summarized the reasons for adopting it. The memo was prepared by Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, the former National Security Council aide who was a central figure in the secret Iran operation. **********The three-page memo began by saying that ''Prime Minister Peres of Israel secretly dispatched his special adviser on terrorism with instructions to propose a plan by which Israel, with limited assistance from the U.S., can create conditions to help bring about a more moderate government in Iran.'' **********Shimon Peres, who is now Foreign Minister, turned over the job of Prime Minister to Mr. Shamir last October. **********The memo also said that Israel and Iran had agreed ''that the hostages will be immediately released'' after the first 1,000 of 4,000 TOW antitank missiles were shipped. **********The release of the White House documents coincided with the formal announcement on Friday that Mr. Shamir would be making an official visit to Mr. Reagan on Feb. 18. **********In addition, President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt is expected in Washington a week after Mr. Shamir, White House officials said. **********The disclosures may also have a bearing on the Middle East tour of Richard W. Murphy, Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern Affairs, who is trying to revive the dormant Arab-Israeli peace negotiations. Mr. Murphy has held talks in Israel, Jordan, and Egypt and is now in Saudi Arabia. **********''It couldn't have been worse timed,'' a State Department official said of the release of the documents. Rumors of 'a New Camp David' **********There have been persistent rumors in the Middle East that the Administration was trying to promote ''a new Camp David'' by having Mr. Shamir and Mr. Mubarak meet with King Hussein of Jordan and Mr. Reagan. But White House officials said there was no plan to bring the leaders together in Washington. **********Reports on the Senate committee document and on the two White House documents have been featured in the Israeli press. The theme in Israel, as in the United States, was that Israel initiated the Iran operation and continuously sought to persuade the Reagan Administration to sell arms to Iran. **********That suggestion clashed with the repeated Israeli contention that the United States had asked Israel for help in freeing the hostages in Lebanon and that Israel had not initiated the Iran operation. **********Mr. Shamir, in a statement on Sunday before he met with Ambassador Pickering, said of the reports about the Senate committee document that ''everything attributed to Israel has no basis in reality.'' 'Not an Attempt to Point Fingers' **********Today, a high State Department official said that once the White House documents were made public, the Administration realized the potential for damage in relations with Israel. **********''Tom Pickering was told to tell Shamir that the White House release of the documents was not an attempt to point fingers and accuse Israel of anything, but that so much partial and incorrect information had been leaked out, and the President had a commitment to get everything out to the public, that the White House felt it was important to get them on the record,'' he said. **********Nevertheless, several State Department officials have privately expressed sharp criticism of the Israeli Government for its efforts to convince the United States that the Iranian intermediary, the arms dealer Manucher Ghorbanifar, could be trusted. **********Americans involved in the operation have said the Israelis told American officials that Mr. Ghorbanifar had assured them that in return for arms, all the American hostages would be freed. Disinformation Campaign Denied **********''The Israelis had their own agenda with Iran, and they drew us into it,'' a State Department official said. ''Whether they were tricked by the Iranians is for them to answer.'' **********Despite the fact that all the hostages were not freed, the United States continued to provide arms to Iran in the hope that they would all be eventually released, officials have said. **********In another matter, Secretary of State George P. Shultz denied today that the Administration had provided misleading or incomplete intelligence information to Iraq. **********An article in The New York Times today said American intelligence agencies had provided both Iran and Iraq with deliberately distorted or inaccurate intelligence information. **********Speaking to reporters on his plane on route from Lagos, Nigeria, to Abidjan, Ivory Coast, Mr. Shultz said, ''So far as I know any intelligence we've given to Iraq has been dead on the mark.'' **********He said he had ''no information about any intelligence exchange with Iran.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/19/busin.main_headline: TUNING IN TO A 'PERSIAN JOHNNY CARSON'
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/19/busin.print_headline: WHAT'S NEW IN FOREIGN LANGUAGE TELEVISION; TUNING IN TO A 'PERSIAN JOHNNY CARSON'
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/19/busin.body_text: **********IRANIANS in Southern California rarely stay up to watch Johnny Carson these days. Instead, they get up to catch Parvis Afshar, the Iranian version of America's late-night comedian. Each weekday morning at 7 a.m., KSCI in San Bernadino broadcasts Mr. Afshar's ''Sima-E-Ashena,'' an hour-long Persian-language show of news, commentary and interviews. **********For the more than 235,000 Persians who are said to watch it, the show is an important source of information. For KSCI, it is a growing source of revenues. **********Non-Spanish foreign language programming is small potatoes compared to Spanish programs. The Television Bureau of Advertising does not even keep tabs on it, other than to estimate its total advertising revenues at less than $1 million last year. **********But what it does have going for it is a wide-open market. ''Spanish is pretty well saturated, but the other ethnic communities are starting to come into their own,'' said Michael Draznin, director of public relations at KSCI, which transmits shows in 16 non-Hispanic languages, including Armenian, Arabic, Hebrew, Vietnamese, Thai, Filipino and Russian. ''Hispanic media broke the ice about 10 years ago,'' added Greg Sullivan, a sales representative for KSCI and for San Francisco's KTSF. ''It is easier for us to walk in the door.'' **********Indeed, until recently the non-Hispanic foreign-language stations barely got any advertising at all. When KTSF was founded more than 10 years ago, it allocated time to foreign language broadcasts ''to serve people not served by the standard broadcast fare,'' said Michael Sherman, station manager. Until two years ago, the foreign broadcasts ran at a loss. But in the past year, the station has seen revenues soar from its foreign language programs, some of which are now profitable. **********Similarly, WCIU in Chicago's foreign language broadcasts, which represent about 60 percent of its air time, are ''somewhat profitable,'' according to Peter Zomaya, general manager. **********Local shops and restaurants remain the major sources of advertising revenue for foreign-language stations. Some of the stations also sell blocks of time to the groups that produce the foreign-language shows, on the theory that they have excellent ethnic contacts and can easily resell the time. **********But increasingly, stations are taking a more aggressive tack in seeking advertising. For example, KTSF has placed ads in trade publications billing itself as the way to reach the Asian population.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/22/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********In ''A Falling Dollar Can Only Help'' (Business Forum, Nov. 8), the economist Meghard Desai blames American multinational enterprises for the country's trade deficit. This is a commonly held view, particularly among economists. **********There may be many things wrong that multinationals are responsible for, but the trade deficit is not one of them. The facts are just the reverse. If it were not for the multinationals, the United States would be running a significantly larger trade deficit. **********In 1983, the latest Commerce Department data that I have available with me, the United States exported $202 billion worth of goods and services and imported $262 billion, for a deficit of $60 billion. American multinationals, which are included in these totals, exported $155 billion worth of these goods and imported just $121 billion, thus running a trade surplus of $34 billion! **********Projecting these numbers to 1987, on the assumption that similar relationships held, even if the American multinationals had balanced trade with the rest of the world, let alone a surplus, the trade deficit would have been closer to $300 billion, rather than the current $160 billion. ANANT K. SUNDARAM  Assistant Professor, The Amos Tuck School of Business Administration,  Dartmouth College  Hanover, N.H., Nov. 9

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/23/busin.body_text: **********Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. dismissed about 100 employees late last week, a spokesman for the company said yesterday. The privately held securities firm has about 11,000 employees. **********The spokesman, Steven Anreder, said about 50 workers had been let go from the systems section, which operates computers for the company. **********About 50 other workers were dismissed from the operations section, or back office, which performs the daily accounting activities for securities transactions. **********Mr. Anreder said the layoffs were not related to the market collapse last month. **********''Department heads have been told to review expenses carefully in view of industry conditions,'' Mr. Anreder said. **********''At the most, no more than 2 percent of the total firm's personnel might be terminated as a result of these departmental reviews, slightly more than normal at year-end.'' **********Bonuses are also expected to be smaller this year than in previous years, Mr. Anreder said, but he declined to say by how much.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/20/world.body_text: **********A car bomb exploded in a department store parking garage here today, killing 15 people and wounding 39, the authorities said. **********A telephone caller said the Basque separatist organization E.T.A. was responsible, the Spanish news agency EFE reported. **********The bombing is the deadliest to be claimed by E.T.A. since it began its violent campaign for independence in 1968. Before today, the Basque group had taken responsibility for killing nearly 600 people, but most of their victims were police officers, Civil Guards and military officers.  [ Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez cut short a visit to Brazil to return to Spain, Reuters reported. He told reporters in Salvador, Brazil: ''This attack is of a different style than what we have seen to date. It is an attempt to force the Government to change tack. But we will not give in to indiscriminate violence. We shall continue fighting terrorism with all the means we have.'' ]  The explosion caused a ceiling to collapse in a shopping area of the Hipercor department store in central Barcelona and started a fire that filled several levels of the parking garage with smoke, the police said. **********The civil governor of Barcelona, Ferran Cardenal, said seven men, five women and three children were killed. **********Governor Cardenal said the bomb-laden car was parked on the first level of the department store's underground parking area. **********The wounded were taken to hospitals to be treated for burns and smoke inhalation, hospital officials said. Hospital officials told Spanish national radio that at least five of those hospitalized were in critical condition. **********The Spanish news agency said a man claiming to speak for E.T.A. told the Barcelona newspaper Avui 30 minutes before the blast at 4:15 P.M. that a bomb would go off in the store. **********A spokesman at the store said police officers and private security guards began searching the store minutes before the blast. The store was not evacuated. **********The worst blast previously claimed by E.T.A. was a car-bomb attack in Madrid last July 14 on a bus carrying more than 50 Civil Guards. Twelve guards died in the attack and 20 were wounded. **********E.T.A., the initials of the Basque words for Basque land and liberty, seeks independence for the Basque region in northern Spain. It has taken responsibility for seven attacks in Barcelona, which was named last October as the site of the 1992 Summer Olympic Games.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/12/world.body_text: **********Secretary of State George P. Shultz today called the Israeli spy case ''very disheartening'' and said a decision by the Israeli Government to investigate would have ''a cleansing effect.'' **********Testifying before the Foreign Operations Subcommittee of the House Appropriations Committee, Mr. Shultz also confirmed reports that all United States officials in Israel had been ordered to have no contact whatever with Col. Aviem Sella or with the Tel Nof Air Base, which he commands. **********Colonel Sella has been indicted by a Federal grand jury on charges of espionage in the case of Jonathan Jay Pollard, a United States Navy employee who has been sentenced to life in prison for giving intelligence information to Israel. **********There has been considerable anger in Washington over the subsequent promotion of Colonel Sella to commander of one of Israel's major bases, and over the promotion of Rafi Eitan, a former Israeli adviser on terrorism who reportedly ran the spy operation, to head Israel's state-owned chemical industry. These promotions came after the Israeli authorities insisted that the spy affair was a ''rogue operation,'' not authorized by high officials. Promotion in Rank Delayed **********According to a State Department official, the Israelis were also planning to promote Colonel Sella in rank, to brigadier general, but delayed that after protests by the United States Embassy in Tel Aviv. **********The annoyance with Israel has been compounded by the Justice Department's reported discovery that Mr. Eitan and two other Israelis lied after they were given immunity from prosecution on the assurance that they would provide complete, truthful accounts of the spy operation. Because the Justice Department believes they did not do so, officials said, it has asked the court to withdraw their immunity and plans to seek indictments against them. **********Despite these problems, Mr. Shultz urged a continuation of the strong Israeli-American relationship. ''I do think it is important for us always to keep in mind the fundamentals,'' he said, ''and to manage a problem in a manner that doesn't wind up with us shooting ourselves in the foot in any way, because our relationship with Israel is a very important one.'' **********''I am deeply distressed about the Pollard case,'' he said, ''and I think it is very disheartening to find that Israel has been spying on the United States.'' **********''Perhaps it hurts especially when it's Israel,'' he added. **********Speaking before the Israeli decision to conduct an investigation was announced, Mr. Shultz urged an inquiry. **********''I think the process of investigation, although it is painful, in a democracy has a cleansing effect,'' he said, ''and perhaps would help all of us who are deep friends of Israel to handle the situation.'' **********In New York, the chairman of the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations, Morris B. Abram, welcomed the Israeli decision to investigate, calling it ''the kind of response one would hope for and expect from a vital and functioning democracy.'' **********''All governments make mistakes,'' Mr. Abram said in a statement, ''but democratic nations have a responsibility and a capacity to examine what went wrong and to take corrective actions.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/10/busin.main_headline: PICKENS GROUP GIVES UP DIAMOND SHAMROCK BID
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/10/busin.print_headline: PICKENS GROUP GIVES UP DIAMOND SHAMROCK BID
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/10/busin.body_text: **********T. Boone Pickens today abandoned his third attempt to acquire the Diamond Shamrock Corporation, leaving analysts uncertain about whether he intends to attempt yet another bid or will turn his sights on a different energy company. **********The decision by Lucky Partners, an investor group headed by Mr. Pickens, came hours after Shamrock's directors voted Sunday night to formally reject its offer to buy all of Shamrock's shares for $15 a share, or $2.06 billion. Pickens Assails 'Connivance' **********Mr. Pickens accused Shamrock's board of having ''barricaded itself within a fortress of anti-takeover defenses.'' He also criticized the Prudential Insurance Company of America for ''connivance'' with Shamrock in preventing shareholders from voting on his offer. **********Prudential was given veto power over any takeover offer when it invested $300 million in Shamrock on Feb. 2. A Shamrock spokesman said the company had no comment on Mr. Pickens's attack. **********A Prudential spokesman, Joseph Vecchione, said, ''Our willingness to make the investment and the nature of the investment speak for themselves.'' **********Shamrock today proceeded with its plan to purchase 20 million of its shares for $17 each, and to split into two independent companies within 90 days. Shamrock directors initially valued the plan at about $17 a share. **********The company said Sunday that rising oil prices would make its two separate businesses - one in refining and marketing and the other in exploration and production - more attractive to investors when they become independent. Profit Expectations Rise **********Many analysts agreed, adding that Roger R. Hemminghaus and Charles L. Blackburn, the executives who will head the new companies, had raised Wall Street's profit expectations for the companies at a crowded breakfast meeting in New York on Friday. **********William H. Bricker, who yielded the chief executive post to Mr. Blackburn Feb. 2 and intends to step down as chairman after the companies are broken up, did not attend the meeting. **********Analysts said that with Mr. Blackburn, a former executive of the Shell Oil Corporation, running the energy and production unit, its stock should trade for more than $12 a share after the refining and marketing unit is shed. Institutional Investors Sell **********Yet the pullout by Mr. Pickens evidently dampened investors' enthusiasm. Shamrock shares lost 37.5 cents, closing at $14.50 today. The stock was the most heavily traded issue on the New York Stock Exchange, with 2.4 million shares exchanged. Professional traders said many institutional investors were selling their stock rather than participate in Shamrock's restructuring. **********Shares of the Mesa Limited Partnership, which controls 85 percent of Lucky Partners, were unchanged today at $16.75. **********In its statement, Mesa said it had officially ended its January offer to buy 20 million Shamrock shares for $15 each, in cash. The offer was to expire Wednesday. **********It termed its Feb. 4 cash bid to buy all of the company for $15 a share a ''proposal.'' David H. Batchelder, a Mesa official, said in a telephone interview from Mesa's headquarters in Amarillo, Tex., that the board's refusal to hold a shareholder vote meant the proposal was dead. **********He declined to comment on Lucky Partners' next move. The group owns 5 million Shamrock shares it bought late last year at an average price of $13 a share. Shamrock has 109.8 million common shares outstanding. Rumors About Enserch **********The group has several options, including a court challenge of Shamrock's position or the sale of its Shamrock stake at a modest profit in the open market. Mr. Batchelder put the group's average total cost, including expenses from three takeover bids, at $14 a share. **********Some analysts said they were checking rumors that Mr. Pickens had abandoned his quest for Shamrock in favor of a new target, the Enserch Corporation. Enserch shares rose 87.5 cents, to $21.125, with nearly 900,000 shares traded, on the New York Stock Exchange. **********The Dallas-based energy company has about 1 trillion cubic feet of proven natural gas reserves. It also owns a gas transmission company with 1.2 million customers in north Texas and Oklahoma. **********Phone calls to Enserch's executive office, after regular business hours, were not answered.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/11/world.main_headline: A Lone, Lonely American on the Soviet Coast
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/11/world.print_headline: A Lone, Lonely American on the Soviet Coast
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/11/world.body_text: **********There are times when the loneliness of being the only American living on the Pacific coast of the Soviet Union gets to Bill Turner. **********To overcome the frustration and touch of fear that grip him, Mr. Turner heads into the coastal headlands on his bicycle, exploring quiet inlets and mountain lanes that few Westerners have seen. **********''When I stop to think, it's a bit stunning and frightening to realize I'm the only native English-speaker living in the Soviet Far East,'' he said. Mr. Turner works in this port city at the southeast tip of the Soviet Union, 55 miles from Vladivostok, as the American manager of the Marine Resources Company, a joint Soviet-American fishing venture founded 10 years ago. **********The nearest American presence in the Soviet Union is in Moscow, 4,500 miles to the west. Japan rests tantalizingly nearby, but can be reached only by a 52-hour ferry ride or by plane from the Soviet city of Khabarovsk, a 16-hour train ride from Nakhodka. **********Nakhodka seems to treat its resident American with an ambivalence familiar to foreigners who work in Moscow. **********''I have no problem with official relationships,'' Mr. Turner said on a recent afternoon as he showed an American reporter around town. ''In fact I get along well with the authorities, but when it comes to socializing, I'm a leper.'' **********Before moving here, Mr. Turner, who is 33 years old, worked for five years as a marine resources representative aboard Soviet fish-processing ships in the North Pacific. **********He said the duty, which included four- to six-month spells of working with Soviet crews aboard ships with minimal comforts, hardened him for the current assignment but did not fully prepare him for the isolation that comes with being a foreigner on Russian soil, particularly in a provincial city. **********''I got to know many of the sailors, some quite well,'' he recalled. ''We spent hours aboard ship talking, often in intense discussions. But when I run into some of those same men in Nakhodka, it's clear they no longer feel they can be my friend.'' **********One of Mr. Turner's predecessors -he is the sixth American assigned to the Nakhodka office - tried to break the social ice by playing on the local basketball team. There was only one problem: Although one of the starting players, the American was not allowed to accompany the team when they played in other cities, all closed to foreigners. **********Mr. Turner stays in touch with the outside world by the company phone and telex, which he must use sparingly because of the cost, and by mail, which takes two to four weeks to reach him. **********Marine Resources, established by a Seattle businessman, James Talbot, has weathered the ups and downs of Soviet-American relations in the last decade. **********The company is a 50-50 partnership, unlike new joint ventures being encouraged by Moscow, in which the Soviet side retains 51 percent control. **********The business brings together American fishermen along the Pacific coast of Canada and the United States with Soviet processing and storage vessels. **********The catch, which totaled more than 300,000 metric tons last year, is distributed in the Soviet Union and exported to foreign markets, including the United States and Japan.

TOO MANY CHOICES? ONE FUND BUYS ALL
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/10/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: CONSUMERS in an affluent society face an abundance of choices, sometimes too many. **********CONSUMERS in an affluent society face an abundance of choices, sometimes too many. **********Too many telephone companies, too many shades of pink lipstick, too many mutual funds. **********Mutual funds have proliferated to such an extent, that some people are seeking guidance in choosing among them. That has spelled opportunity for investment organizations. In the past two years, a number of firms have revived the 1960's fund-of-funds approach, in which a money manager invests in a variety of mutual funds, rather than directly in stocks or bonds. **********In addition to mutual funds, some trust account managers and private partnerships have adopted this approach. A no-load mutual fund wooing the small investor might require a minimum investment as low as $250, while a private partnership with a wealthy clientele might seek a minimum of $1 million or more. **********Investors pay a price to have a mutual fund to pick other funds for them. Many of these funds tend to produce below-average investment results. And some funds have layers of management fees, which make them more expensive than direct investments in mutual funds. **********The Vanguard Group was one of the first organizations to revive the fund-of-funds concept when it offered its STAR Fund, which invests in shares of Vanguard's other mutual funds, in 1985. Vanguard said its customers had become confused trying to choose from more than 40 mutual funds. ''We wanted to simplify the choice,'' said Jeremy G. Duffield, senior vice president. **********Similarly, executives at T. Rowe Price Associates decided to start two such funds after the number of their mutual funds increased to 24, up from 10 in 1982. The two new funds, which are still in registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission, will invest in shares of Price's growth-stock funds and income-oriented funds. **********Individual investors who don't want to be restricted to the mutual funds offered by one organization have other choices. Scudder Fund Distributors recently began offering investors the Rodney Square Multi-Manager Fund. The Rodney Square Management Corporation of Wilmington, Del., manages the fund, which includes three separate stock portfolios managed, in turn, by nine investment management firms. **********In addition, the FundTrust series, distributed by Furman Selz Mager Dietz & Birney Inc., offers funds that invest in income funds, growth-stock funds, aggressive growth funds, and growth and income funds. The Republic National Bank of New York, the investment adviser, invests each fund in shares of 10 to 12 other mutual funds. **********Too much diversification can be a bad thing. The more diversified a fund is, the closer it comes to matching the average performance of all stocks. After management fees and stock trading commissions are subtracted, the performance can easily slip below the average. ''By definition, they are overly diversified,'' said Michael Lipper, president of Lipper Analytical Services. **********The performance of Vanguard's STAR Fund, for instance, has been ''reasonable but not stellar,'' Mr. Duffield acknowledges. ''We are not promising spectacular performance, just good steady performance over the long term.'' **********The Vanguard STAR fund advanced 14.75 percent during the 12 months ended April 30, according to Lipper. In comparison, the average balanced mutual fund gained 15.66 percent in the same period and the stock market, as measured by the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, was up 22.62 percent. Similarly, the FundTrust funds also underperformed their respective sectors. **********Still, Michael Hirsch, senior vice president of Republic, argues that these funds will fare better in a down market or over long market cycles. **********Then, there is the thorny issue of management fees. While Vanguard and T. Rowe Price do not charge an additional fee on top of the underlying mutual funds fees, some others do. FundTrust, for example, has an expense ratio of about 1.7 percent, almost twice the amount an investor would pay using some stock mutual funds. And customers of banks that use mutual funds, such as those offered by Evaluation Associates, a consulting firm in Westport, Conn., might pay fees of as much as 1.5 percent of their account, almost three times what some trust customers pay. **********The fund-of-funds approach is being promoted to big investors, too. There has been a proliferation of private partnerships that invest in stocks, bonds, options, futures and other financial instruments, such as those managed by Cumberland Partners and New York investors George Soros, John Oppenheim, Martin Perelman and Julian Robertson. **********Typically, these aggressively managed partnerships, or ''hedge funds,'' have been available only to wealthy individuals. Their excellent results - compound annual returns of twice the S.& P. 500, according to a study of 75 partnerships by Tremont Partners - have made them attractive investments for a number of new investors. But the hedge funds usually charge a fee that can be as high as 20 percent of the profits. **********Firms such as Tremont in Stamford, Conn., and Stolper & Company in San Diego are setting up partnerships that invest in seven to ten other partnerships. Minimum investments range from $250,000 to $1 million. For a fee, Tremont and Stolper select the hedge funds, monitor their performance and provide the portfolio accounting for investors. Stolper's president, Michael Stolper, estimated that as many as 25 of these partnerships of partnerships might be in formation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/16/busin.body_text: **********Hard experience has taught the nation's bankers to be skeptical of Congress. Still bitter about the moratorium on expanded banking businesses that was imposed by Congress last summer, they have started a new lobbying campaign to defend their industry's interests on Capitol Hill. **********As the leading banking groups seek to drum up grass-roots support from their members across the country, they have turned to slogans such as ''Kill the moratorium; let banks compete'' and ''Keep the promise'' - a reference to a Congressional promise that the industry would be allowed to resume seeking expanded powers in such profitable businesses as securities underwriting, real estate and insurance, after the moratorium expires March 1, 1988. **********Until last summer, bankers had found comforting allies in the large regulatory agencies - the Federal Reserve Board, the Comptroller of the Currency and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation - that had slowly expanded their freedom to enter new businesses. But the moratorium, embodied in the Competitive Equality Banking Act of 1987, abruptly stopped that process. Aftermath of Stock Plunge **********Many members of Congress have promised that they would oppose any extension of the moratorium, but others have hinted recently that, under certain circumstances, an extension might be necessary. **********In the face of such uncertainty, the bankers are not taking any chances, especially in the aftermath of the stock market's collapse last month. They fear that market dislocation may persuade a jittery Congress to play it safe, especially in a Presidential election year, and indefinitely extend the moratorium while avoiding some politically hard decisions. **********The moratorium hits at the heart of the banking system's hope for future profitability. In recent years bankers have seen their primary markets of consumer deposits, consumer loans and top-quality commercial loans invaded by less-regulated institutions such as mutual funds, insurance companies and brokerage firms. **********While the moratorium was primarily aimed at removing the regulatory agencies from the process of setting new banking policy, it was seen as a major political defeat for bankers, illustrating their lack of influence in comparison with other lobbies. Bankers See Discrimination **********''Bankers take the moratorium very personally because they see it as discriminating against them,'' said Ed Yingling, head of government relations at the American Bankers Association. ''We had a summit meeting recently involving all the major bank trade groups, and all agreed to join this fight to stop any extension of the moratorium.'' **********March 1 is still more than 100 days away, as an A.B.A. newsletter titled Countdown points out. Still, the bankers feel they have good reason to be concerned, based on past experience and current rumblings in Congress. **********In the mid-1960's, for example, Congress imposed a ''temporary'' interest-rate differential that let the thrift industry pay consumers one-quarter percentage point more on passbook savings accounts than banks paid. That regulation was extended many times and was not removed until 17 years later. **********Some prominent members of Congress are sending signals that they do not intend to be forced to abandon the moratorium next year simply because last summer's legislation stipulated that it should not continue beyond March 1. Approach to Restructuring **********''The decision to restructure'' the banking industry ''should not be dictated by the artificial time frame established by the moratorium,'' said Edward J. Markey, a Massachusetts Democrat and chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee's subcommittee on telecommunications and finance. **********He said that any serious thinking about changing the structure of the banking system ''must take into account what happened to the equity markets in October.'' **********He added, ''If Congress needs more time to evaluate these issues, it must consider extending the moratorium.'' **********Senator Timothy E. Wirth, Democrat of Colorado, is another lawmaker who has put the bankers on notice that he may not support an automatic end to the moratorium. **********Although the Senate is seeking to produce legislation that would open new businesses for commercial banks, Mr. Wirth said, that process may not be completed by March 1. Lifting the moratorium might unleash deregulatory forces that could prove difficult for Congress to reverse, he added. A Similar Possibility Hinted **********Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, has outlined a similar scenario. He sees a possibility that Congress might want to impose a temporary extension of the moratorium to give it time to finish legislation that would restructure the entire industry. But Senator Dodd has said he hopes the moratorium will not be extended. **********Bankers regard even these modest rumblings as potential disasters. **********After having failed to secure important deregulation moves from Congress for years, the banking industry had found that the Federal Reserve, the Comptroller and the F.D.I.C. were willing to move for regulatory changes. **********Major banks such as Citicorp, Chase and Bankers Trust received approval from the Fed to begin dabbling in new underwriting businesses such as commercial paper, mortgage-backed securities and industrial revenue bonds. The Fed is also seeking comment on a proposal to let bank holding companies engage in certain new real estate activities. Legal Challenges Expected **********But the moratorium and a lawsuit filed by the securities industry have stopped that deregulatory movement in its tracks - at least until next March 1. And even if the moratorium expires, Mr. Yingling concedes, it could be years before legal challenges to the new banking powers are decided in the courts. **********''It's inevitable that all these cases are going to go to the Supreme Court,'' Mr. Yingling said. **********Moreover, while the banking industry has found Wall Street lobbyists to be formidable opponents, it faces even stronger foes when it considers trying to secure authority to offer real estate and insurance services. **********''I think it's likely that the moratorium on getting into securities may be allowed to expire, while the moratoria against real estate and insurance may be kept on,'' said Steven Verdier, chief lobbyist for the Independent Bankers Association.
