https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/07/world.body_text: **********The editor of a literary magazine has been sentenced to seven years in prison for defaming China's socialist system, the daily China Legal News reported today. It was the first reported criminal case in China's campaign against Western liberalism. **********The Legal News did not say when the editor, Liu De, of the magazine Jiannan Literature in Mianyang City in Sichuan province, was sentenced. **********The newspaper report said Mr. Liu, 29 years old, was unhappy with his job and ''desperately pursued and preached the so-called 'democracy' and 'freedom' of capitalist countries.'' **********It said that in a lecture to a technical school, the editor ''uglified the socialist system,'' criticized China's economic changes and called on the audience to ''take immediate action and join in a common struggle.'' **********The newspaper did not say when the lecture was given. **********The month-old campaign resulted earlier in the forced resignation of the Communist Party chief Hu Yaobang, the demotion of the party propaganda chief and the expulsion from the party of three prominent intellectuals. **********Calls for democracy and greater freedom were widespread when thousands of students demonstrated in the streets of at least 11 cities in December and early January.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/12/world.main_headline: FRENCH STRIKES FADE, THOUGH UNIN PLEDGES TO PRESS RAIL WALKOUT
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/12/world.print_headline: FRENCH STRIKES FADE, THOUGH UNIN PLEDGES TO PRESS RAIL WALKOUT
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/12/world.body_text: **********Most trains ran on schedule today and electrical service returned to normal as thousands of striking workers began returning to their jobs. **********The transportation tie-ups and power blackouts that had irritated the French for four weeks, producing long delays and severe economic losses, seemed largely to disappear. **********The slow restoration of service, taking place over a cold winter weekend, was not yet complete. But Government officials predicted that the succession of public-sector strikes, the worst here in nearly 20 years, would soon come to an end. **********''The social situation in the public sector should be unblocked by Monday or Tuesday at the latest,'' Alain Juppe, the Government spokesman, said after most of the unions agreed to a Government offer of salary increases totaling less than 2 percent over the next year. **********While train service was roughly 70 percent of normal and no electricity stoppages were reported today, the largest of the labor unions, the Communist-led General Confederation of Labor, vowed to continue the strikes. A Vow to Continue Rail Strike **********Leaders of the union said they would maintain the strike on the railroads, which began as a wildcat action and has lasted for nearly four weeks. They said they would no longer cut electricity service but would campaign for salary increases through such other actions as refusing to stop service to delinquent customers. **********The slow and sporadic return to work today came amid signs of growing public irritation at the series of public-sector strikes carried out by workers whose salaries and working conditions are widely seen as among the best in France. **********Over the last few days, the frustration at the strikers had produced the beginnings of a spontaneous revolt pitting merchants against the labor unions. **********Groups of merchants in several cities marched in the streets on Friday and Saturday to protest the electricity cuts. In Lyons, France's second-largest city, one baker set up a wood stove on the sidewalk and used it to bake some loaves of bread in order to dramatize his irritation at the electricity cutoffs, which he said were ruining his business. **********Groups of citizens occupied neighborhood power company offices to protest the intermittent electricity cuts. **********Leaders of the neo-Gaullist Rally for the Republic, which is the political party of Prime Minister Jacques Chirac, have called for more demonstrations against the strikes to take place on Monday, though it was unclear the protests would go ahead following the return of many workers to their jobs. Split in Labor's Ranks **********The slow drift back to work by workers at the non-Communist unions reflected a split among the striking employees that has weakened the movement ever since it began. A substantial number of union workers refused their stewards' strike call altogether.intermittent work stoppages in the Paris subway and bus systems. It then spread last week to the state-run electricity and gas companies. **********With the C.G.T. the only union still favoring a continuation of the strike, the Government seemed virtually assured of the ability to maintain a relatively high level of service on the vast railroad network and in the power company. **********The strikes produced long delays in transportation and colossal traffic jams in the major French cities, but they did not cause such severe disruptions of normal life that the Government was forced into major concessions on the key issue of salary increases.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/27/busin.body_text: **********Integrated Genetics Inc., a biotechnology company in Framingham, Mass., said yesterday that it had developed a longer-acting form of tissue plasminogen activator, a drug that might be used to treat heart attack victims. **********The company said that it had modified the structure of the T.P.A. molecule to remove one of the sugars attached to the protein chain. Because the modified T.P.A. stays in the bloodstream longer, lower doses could be used, reducing harmful side effects. **********It could also mean that T.P.A. could be administered by a single injection, rather than in a continuous intravenous solution. Still, clinical testing must be done before the drug can be approved for use, a process that could take years. **********T.P.A. is expected to be one of the first major drugs produced by genetic engineering. However, an advisory committee of the Food and Drug Administration earlier this year recommended against approving the drug until more data are gathered. The decision dealt a setback to Genentech Inc., which has been ahead in developing T.P.A. **********Improved versions of T.P.A. from competitors could also hurt Genentech. Several companies are working on such second-generation T.P.A.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/23/world.main_headline: QADDAFI IN A WARNING TO U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/23/world.print_headline: QADDAFI IN A WARNING TO U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/23/world.body_text: **********Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, said in an interview broadcast yesterday that he was willing to permit Soviet nuclear missiles to be based in Libya. **********''Libya will in fact declare that it is a Communist country and join the Warsaw Pact and deploy Soviet missiles on the coast of the Mediterranean,'' the Libyan leader said in an interview with NBC News. The portion of his statements that was broadcast did not indicate that such a decision had been made, and NBC News characterized the remark as a threat. **********''When we become one military camp, nothing will be prohibited,'' Colonel Qaddafi said. ''That means when Libya becomes a Communist country, then that's final. The United States knows if it continues its aggression this could lead Libya to join the Soviet side, and that's going to overturn the balance of power in the region.'' **********It was not the first time that Colonel Qaddafi has discussed the possibility of an alliance with the Warsaw Pact. But it apparently was the first time that he had said Soviet missiles could be stationed on Libyan soil or that he would give his approval to a Soviet naval base at Tobruk, on the Mediterranean. **********There was no indication that the Russians would take up such an offer. In the last year, the Kremlin has distanced itself from some of Colonel Qaddafi's activities. **********Colonel Qaddafi's comments were made almost a year after American jets bombed Libya in retaliation for the bombing of a Berlin discotheque that was a popular gathering place for American soldiers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/26/busin.body_text: **********The Treasury Department said today that it was ''very pleased that the commercial banks have responded so quickly and positively'' to Argentina's appeal for new loans. **********In a statement, the Treasury said the commitment to date of 96 percent of the $1.95 billion the country requested ''represents one of the highest percentages ever achieved for any debtor nation in such a short period of time.'' **********The Treasury said the commitment showed that, despite the decision by United States banks to increase their loss provisions for such loans, the banks remained willing to make loans. **********The statement also said that the commitment demonstrated the utility of Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d's plan to assist underdeveloped countries that are large debtors. That plan has been criticized because of its provision for banks to step up their lending.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/15/world.body_text: **********As anti-Government protests in Panama enter their sixth week, demonstrators are finding that they confront not only uniformed soldiers and the riot police, but also paramilitary squads of armed civilians. **********On some occasions, the squads have appeared to be acting in cooperation with the police. Witnesses have identified prominent members of the ruling Democratic Revolutionary Party as participants in paramilitary activities. **********The squads were first seen at the end of June, when a business complex owned by a prominent opposition leader was set afire. Riot police officers stood by. **********Since then, civilian gunmen have made a practice of shooting at caravans of anti-Government demonstrators. In one case, a bullet penetrated a car and lodged in the driver's headrest, only an inch from her head. Many Wounded or Imprisoned **********During a protest here Friday, armed civilians joined uniformed officers in destroying parked cars apparently owned by demonstrators. **********The Friday confrontation left an unknown number of protesters wounded or imprisoned. Most of the wounds were from shotgun pellets. Doctors attending one gunshot victim, Tatiana Gonzalez, a 22-year-old student, counted more than 60 pellets in her body, including a dozen that pockmarked the left side of her face. **********''I'm willing to go back out and demonstrate right now,'' Miss Gonzalez said in an interview. ''I know we don't have any weapons and they are the army. But now I hate them more than ever.'' **********The vigor with which the police suppressed Friday's protest drew a strong rebuke from the Roman Catholic hierarchy, which has sought to maintain good relations with both sides. ''The form of repression on Friday was beyond all limits of proportion and justice,'' said Archbishop Marcos Gregorio McGrath.  THE INFILTRATORS **********Among the protesters are police agents apparently sent to monitor demonstrations from within. Opposition leaders say the infiltrators also seek to provoke violence. **********After Friday's protest, two police agents entered an uptown hotel where military intelligence officers maintained an office. One was carrying a large protest banner and the other wore a cap with the word ''Justice'' emblazoned on the front. **********As the two men approached the hotel, where protesters rarely venture, police officers smiled and patted them on the back. When they entered the suite used by intelligence officers, they were greeted by laughter and loud applause.  ANGER OUTSIDE THE CELLS **********Government leaders, especially Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the military leader, have characterized the demonstrators as well-to-do white bigots angered that blacks and Indians now hold positions of power in Panama. **********''The demonstrators are white because those people don't like blacks,'' General Noriega said over the weekend. **********But on Sunday at the Modelo Prison, where hundreds of Panamanians lined up under a blazing sun to visit friends and relatives who had been detained, blacks and Indians were the overwhelming majority. **********When jailers opened the gates the visitors surged forward, clutching bags of food and other provisions for their loved ones. Those who managed to enter were allowed five-minute visits. **********One woman had to be carried away after she collapsed in tears upon seeing her son through the screen that separates visitors from inmates. A youth waiting to see his brother muttered under his breath, ''This is the kind of human rights Noriega loves to talk about.''  PAIN IN THE PURSE **********According to bankers and businessmen, Panama is suffering grave economic losses from the continuing protests. They say that tens of millions of dollars have been withdrawn from the national banking system, and that millions more that were to have been deposited have instead been placed elsewhere. **********''With this situation of uncertainty, I cannot in good conscience allow my clients to put funds in the national bank,'' said an investment counselor who last week directed a client to withhold a $12 million deposit earmarked for the Government-run bank. **********Panama's economy is based on service and banking sectors that depend on public confidence. That confidence has been steadily eroded during June and July, and it fell dramatically last week when the president of the national bank, Luis Alberto Arias, resigned. He gave no reason for leaving his post and has avoided interviewers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/10/busin.body_text: **********The First Interstate Bancorp today abandoned its effort to acquire the BankAmerica Corporation, ending one of the longest and bitterest takeover battles in banking history. **********First Interstate said it was dropping its bid because actions taken by BankAmerica to sell off its assets and raise new capital made the San Francisco bank a less desirable takeover candidate. ''The continuing dismemberment of this institution no longer justifies our current offered price,'' Joseph J. Pinola, the chairman and chief executive of First Interstate, said in a statement. **********But BankAmerica could face renewed takeover efforts if its situation does not improve, though it seems the immediate threat is over. First Interstate said in its statement that it would ''continue to monitor closely'' the activities of BankAmerica. **********New York's Citicorp has expressed some interest in buying all or part of BankAmerica but would likely require special legislation to avoid prohibitions on interstate banking. However, Willie Brown, the Speaker of the California Assembly, who had proposed such legislation, which would have allowed Citicorp to bid against First Interstate, said today that his bill was no longer necessary. **********Despite today's development, BankAmerica's problems are not over. The troubled bank lost $518 million in 1986 and faces at least two more quarters of operating losses, in the opinion of most analysts. **********BankAmerica, the nation's second-largest banking company after Citicorp, still has $5 billion of problem loans. **********Moreover, BankAmerica is a far different organization than it was when First Interstate made its bid in October - stronger and trimmer in some ways, but without some of its most profitable assets. It remains to be seen whether BankAmerica has mortgaged its future by selling off such profitable assets as its Charles Schwab & Company discount brokerage and an Italian subsidiary for a short-term profit boost that was needed to stave off First Interstate. **********BankAmerica's chairman and chief executive, A. W. Clausen, said in a statement today that First Interstate's action ''is definitely in the interest of BankAmerica and all its shareholders.'' **********''We will now be able to focus all our attention on the job of turning BankAmerica around in 1987,'' he added. Mr. Clausen defended the bank's restructuring, saying the program would have been undertaken ''whether or not there had been a merger proposal.'' **********First Interstate officials were not immediately available for interviews. In the past, some officials have indicated that the bank holding company, which already owns banks in numerous Western states, would seek to acquire a bank in Texas. **********Analysts and banking industry executives have been saying that First Interstate's chances of success were growing dimmer because of BankAmerica's restructuring. The final blows apparently were the sale of the Schwab brokerage last week to a group headed by Mr. Schwab, and the coming offering of up to $1 billion in securities announced by BankAmerica. **********These actions, in addition to lowering the worth of the company to First Interstate, helped strengthen the capital of BankAmerica, presumably alleviating some of the concerns of Federal regulators who would have had to approve such a merger. Still, First Interstate's Mr. Pinola, a former BankAmerica executive who has been pursuing the merger with a singular zeal, was not expected to give up easily. But the retreat is a personal victory for Mr. Clausen over Mr. Pinola, his former employee. **********First Interstate, which is based in Los Angeles, has been pursuing BankAmerica since 1985 and made a formal bid last October. The takeover, which would have been for more than $3 billion in securities, would have created a huge multistate bank almost equal in size to Citicorp. Offer Forced Departure **********The bid was the final straw that forced the ouster of BankAmerica's chief executive, Samuel H. Armacost, and the return of the former chief, Mr. Clausen. Mr. Clausen and the board at first tried to put off First Interstate by asking it to withdraw, all the while beginning the restructuring program designed in part to make a takeover unfeasible. **********First Interstate declined to withdraw and eventually filed required documents with the Federal Reserve Board and the Securities and Exchange Commission to bypass BankAmerica's directors and go directly to shareholders with an exchange offer. **********The battle became increasingly nasty, with employees and politicians becoming involved. At one point BankAmerica officials accused Mr. Pinola of ''reckless'' behavior and said that securities he offered in exchange for BankAmerica's common stock were a joke. Even today both sides fired parting shots, issuing biting statements aimed at the other side. **********First Interstate's retreat was also seen as a victory for San Francisco, which is worried that it is falling behind Los Angeles as a business center and did not want to see its largest bank taken over. ''I'm very pleased and delighted to hear it,'' San Francisco's Mayor, Dianne Feinstein, said today. ''I think it's a bellwether signal in the recovery of the bank.'' Shareholder Gains Seen **********First Interstate had argued that the acquisition, for securities it valued at over $20 a share, would have been a good one for BankAmerica's shareholders, whose stock had been selling at $12 before the offer was made and whose dividends had been eliminated. First Interstate contended that, in addition to restoring dividends, merger-related accounting practices and economies of scale would have allowed it to strengthen BankAmerica far more quickly than BankAmerica could improve on its own. **********The announcement of the withdrawal came after the close of trading today. BankAmerica shares closed unchanged at $13.875; First Interstate finished off 50 cents at $56. **********BankAmerica had argued that the securities offered by First Interstate were worth far less than $20 and that the combined bank would be under-capitalized. Moreover, BankAmerica had said that First Interstate was planning to use BankAmerica's own assets to finance the takeover and that First Interstate shareholders would have shared the benefits of a turnaround at BankAmerica that rightfully belonged only to BankAmerica shareholders. **********First Interstate had not yet received permission from the S.E.C. or Federal Reserve for its hostile tender offer and both agencies had asked for refinements to First Interstate's application. **********However, to gain Fed approval, First Interstate might have had to offer more of its common stock, instead of preferred shares or debentures, which could have made it more difficult for it to pay. However, First Interstate said today that it believed it would have received approval had it continued to press its offer. **********In any case, the need to refile its Fed application and answer the S.E.C.'s questions made this a natural time for First Interstate to re-evaluate whether to keep going or pull back.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/19/world.main_headline: NEW HEAD IS NAMED FOR BEIRUT SCHOOL
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/19/world.print_headline: NEW HEAD IS NAMED FOR BEIRUT SCHOOL
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/19/world.body_text: **********The new president of the American University of Beirut, Dr. Frederic P. Herter, says that despite continued troubles in Lebanon, the independent private university still has ''a major role to play in forming leaders of the Middle East.'' **********Dr. Herter, 66 years old, said that although security had improved since Syrian forces moved into West Beirut two months ago, he would not take up residence on the Beirut campus ''until Lebanese Government people I know well say it is safe.'' **********But he said he might make occasional visits, with security arranged beforehand. **********A professor of surgery at the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, Dr. Herter succeeds Dr. Calvin H. Plimpton, who is retiring but will remain on the Beirut school's board of trustees. The previous president, Malcom H. Kerr, was slain at his office on Jan. 18, 1984. 'Dual Leadership' **********For the foreseeable future the university will function under ''dual leadership,'' a system begun by his predecessor, Dr. Herter said in an interview last week. He said he would operate from the New York office and spend more time on development and fund-raising tasks while a Lebanese who is the dean of arts and sciences, Lutfy Diab, lives on campus and has ''the thankless, almost impossible job of running the day-to-day affairs.'' **********The most serious problem facing the university is ''faculty attrition,'' the new president said. The school has lost many high-ranking staff members over the last couple of years because of the sharp devaluation of the Lebanese pound, the rising cost of living and, above all, the physical dangers. **********In 1985, there were 125 foreigners, including 70 Americans, in the 450-member faculty, he said, but today the faculty is down to about 400, with only a dozen foreigners, including two American women. One is the wife of Thomas M. Sutherland, the dean of agriculture, who has been held hostage since June 9, 1985, by Islamic Holy War, the extremist Shiite group that claimed responsibility for killing Mr. Kerr. **********The university administration has warmly welcomed the recent show of strength by the Syrians, according to Dr. Herter. He specifically cited their actions to disarm local militias, curb the display of religious fanaticism, search for arms on the campus and briefly detain 18 student militants. Founded in 1866 **********Founded by in 1866 by American Protestant missionaries and chartered by the State of New York, the university became a model of liberal Western education in the Arab world. It is governed by a board of trustees composed of prominent Arabs and Americans, and many of its 27,000 alumni hold key positions throughout the Middle East. **********Chairman of the university's board since 1985 and a trustee since 1977, Dr. Herter says his ''love affair with A.U.B.,'' as the school is familiarly known, began when Dr. Plimpton invited him to lecture at the Middle East Medical Assembly there in 1959. **********The new president spoke with cautious optimism about the university, emphasizing that this year there was a record enrollment of 5,300 students. He said 85 percent of the students were Lebanese; in the past, half came from other Arab countries. **********''This says that despite the hell Lebanon is going through, one of the most important passions of the Lebanese is education,'' he said, ''and they want the best for their children.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/12/busin.body_text: **********Foreign trade barriers are exaggerated as a cause of the United States trade deficit, a survey of the export performance of rapidly growing companies shows. **********The study by the management consulting firm McKinsey & Company for the American Business Conference, a coalition of mid-size American companies whose profits and sales growth top 15 percent, found that such concerns' exports have risen more than five times faster than those of other American companies in the last five years. It attributed the growth to the companies' emphasis on technology, innovation, marketing and management; their willingness to establish a presence abroad, and their urge to compete on quality as well as cost. **********''Notwithstanding assertions made to Congress that foreign markets are closed to U.S. products, American firms can show strong growth and high profits from foreign sales by following common sense business strategies,'' said Arthur Levitt Jr., chairman of the business conference coalition and chairman of the American Stock Exchange. **********''The foreign trade barriers are at most 10 to 15 percent of the problem of our trade deficit and do not constitute barriers to success in exporting,'' William Lilley 3d, president of the business conference group, said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/30/busin.main_headline: A.T.&T. REPORTS IT LOST $1.17 BILLION IN QUARTER
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/30/busin.print_headline: A.T.&T. REPORTS IT LOST $1.17 BILLION IN QUARTER
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/30/busin.body_text: **********The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it lost $1.17 billion in the fourth quarter because of a $3.2 billion charge taken to reduce its work force and consolidate operations. **********The quarterly loss, though expected, was the largest posted by A.T.&T. since it agreed to divest itself of the regional telephone operating companies in 1984. **********A.T.&T. finished the year with a small profit, however. Net income for the year was $139 million, or 5 cents a share, down 91.1 percent from $1.56 billion, or $1.37 a share, in 1985. **********Last month, A.T.&T. announced that it would elminate 27,400 jobs and take the $3.2 billion charge to cover early retirement and severance costs, write-downs in the value of some assets and the expenses for consolidating operations. **********Most of the charges were taken in the fourth quarter. In the comparable 1985 quarter, A.T.&T. earned $364 million, or 32 cents a share. Fourth-quarter revenues decreased 4.1 percent, to $8.53 billion, from $8.89 billion last year. ''Our earnings from operations were essentially flat; our costs too high, and our results mixed,'' James E. Olson, A.T.&T.'s chairman, said in a statement. ''We are taking decisive actions to strengthen our core businesses by eliminating costs,'' but ''it will take some time to digest these changes.'' **********Last year A.T.&T. suffered a decline in income from equipment rentals and a leveling-off in sales of equipment to other telephone companies. **********Revenues for the year dipped 1 percent, to $34.09 billion, from $34.42 billion in 1985. Costs and expenses rose 7.4 percent for the year and 33.8 percent for the fourth quarter. **********A.T.&T. has also sustained heavy losses from its efforts to establish itself in computers and information processing. Analysts estimate that the company's Information Systems Group lost about $800 million last year. Bell Atlantic **********The Bell Atlantic Corporation, the Phildelphia-based regional telephone company, said yesterday that its earnings in the fourth quarter rose eight-tenths of 1 percent, to $271.9 million, or $1.37 a share, from $269.7 million, or $1.34 a share, last year. Revenue rose 11.9 percent, to $2.60 billion, from $2.33 billion a year earlier. For all of 1986, earnings were up 7 percent, to $1.17 billion, or $5.85 a share, from $1.09 billion, or $5.47 a share in 1985.
