https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/29/world.main_headline: FACTS DISPUTED IN SALVADOR SCHOOL RAID
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/29/world.print_headline: FACTS DISPUTED IN SALVADOR SCHOOL RAID
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/29/world.body_text: **********Two people who seized an elementary school here on Thursday were not leftist guerrillas, as Salvadoran officials have repeatedly asserted, but instead were a desperate army deserter and his companion, according to Western diplomats. **********The case has taken on importance here because, in what some foreign diplomats are calling a propaganda ploy, the Salvadoran Government continues to contend that the young man and the woman who seized the school and more than 900 students are leftist rebels. **********There appears to be little evidence to back up that claim, however. **********The Government invited foreign diplomats on Friday afternoon to hear an official account that blamed the attack on the guerrillas. 'This Is Cynical' **********Three senior army officers who were at the scene during the takeover said that the two armed people had asked to fly to Nicaragua and that they had been distributing rebel propaganda. **********But several diplomats left the meeting accusing the Government of a heavy-handed effort to manipulate public opinion. And three Western diplomats were highly critical today of the Goverment's decision to keep repeating the claims. **********''This is cynical and it bothers me,'' one Western diplomat said. ''The guerrillas had nothing to do with this and the Government knows it.'' **********The main rebel front group has disclaimed responsibility for the incident, in which no one was injured. The pair surrendered after holding the school for a day. Soldier Called Rebel Infiltrator **********The rebels have stepped up urban attacks, and at first it did not seem inconceivable that gunmen fleeing police units might have seized the school. **********But in a broadcast on the rebels' Venceremos radio, the guerrillas of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front denied any connection and derided the Government for trying to blame them for the assault. **********The guerrillas said the takeover was carried out by an army deserter. The Government maintains that the soldier was a rebel infiltrator who deserted his army unit four days ago. **********Several children who were held in the school were terrified by the threats of the panic-stricken young soldier. Both the soldier and his companion pointed their automatic rifles at children and threatened to shoot, school administrators and children said. **********One school administrator said the soldier appeared drunk or drugged. **********Salvadoran officials said the man and woman would be put on trial.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/07/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS AND THE LAW; Parties Who Are Not Clients
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/07/busin.body_text: **********WHEN the township of West Windsor, N.J., decided that it needed a new sewer system, it asked its law firm, Schragger, Schragger & Lavine, to draw up papers for competitive bidding on the project. **********The R. J. Longo Construction Company won the contract, but in the midst of construction the company discovered that it could not proceed because it had not been granted a right-of-way easement for the sewer system. **********Earlier this summer, a New Jersey court declined to dismiss a lawsuit brought by R. J. Longo against the law firm, located in Lawrenceville, N.J. The court said that the lawyers had a ''special fiduciary duty'' to the construction company, even though they had no contractual relationship with it. **********The case is one of a growing number of actions brought against lawyers by plaintiffs who are not clients but who nonethless assert either malpractice or related charges, such as negligence or fraud. **********''We were able to successfully cite cases that look to some sort of behavior that created a loss that was foreseeable,'' said William A. Feldman, a lawyer representing R. J. Longo. ''So it wasn't necessary for the company to have a contract with the lawyers.'' **********In real estate, securities, estate planning and other areas, judges are finding that lawyers owe a special duty to people who are not their clients. And in settings involving negotiations over contracts, lawyers are also learning to be wary of giving advice to parties other than clients, lest they be accused of negligence or malpractice. **********''Courts are much more willing to say, 'Hey, surprise, this guy is really your client,' '' said Stephen Gillers, professor of legal ethics at the New York University School of Law. ''Or else they are willing to invent new types of relationships to extend a lawyer's liability where there used to be no legal relationship.'' **********The most visible of these lawsuits are those brought against large firms. Disgruntled investors recently filed a suit against a venerable New York firm, Fried Frank Harris Shriver & Jacobson, over its role in counseling Ivan F. Boesky, the Wall Street speculator implicated in the insider-trading scandal. **********But more common are the smaller suits involving negotiations between parties in which the lawyer's role becomes blurred. **********In April, for instance, the Federal District Court in Washington declined to dismiss an action brought by Alice C. Nelson naming J. Michael Slocum, a lawyer representing a company that had given a loan to Ms. Nelson. The court said that Ms. Nelson could sue Mr. Slocum for malpractice even if he had no contract with her, because he had volunteered to provide a legal explanation of documents involved in the settlement of her loan. **********A week after that decision, a New York court ruled that a lawyer representing the husband in a divorce proceeding could be sued for fraud by the wife, who was not a client. The lawyer, Paul H. Wein, was accused of misrepresenting the value of marital property. **********Still, not all courts that have considered the issue are willing to extend liability. Judge Frank Easterbrook of the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit, in Chicago, upheld a lower court ruling last year that dismissed a lawsuit brought against both a law firm and an accounting firm. **********The lawyers and accountants were sued by purchasers of bonds issued by the Michigan Baptist Foundation Inc. The bonds, which had not been registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission, eventually went sour. **********In dismissing the suit, Judge Easterbrook said the lawyers had no duty to the purchasers and were not ''required to tattle on their clients in the absence of some duty to disclose.'' He also noted that even if the firm had committed malpractice, it had no special duty to warn the buyers about the bonds. **********That view is similar to the rule on legal malpractice adopted by courts through most of this century. Historically, in order to sue for malpractice, a person had to be ''in privity'' - that is, in some sort of contractual relationship - with the lawyer. **********Until recently, courts and scholars, taking the position that privity was routinely required, quoted the view of a leading barrister of his day, Lord Henry Brougham. While defending Queen Caroline in 1820 against charges of adultery, he said, ''An advocate, in the discharge of his duty, knows but one person in all the world, and that person is his client.'' **********But times have changed, according to Professor Gillers. ''No matter how nostalgic it makes lawyers, no matter what deep patriotic emotions it stirs up for the profession, it is simply no longer true,'' he said. ''Lord Brougham would not be able to get malpractice insurance today. He would probably be bankrupt. Lawyers must now know many clients.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/17/world.main_headline: AUSTRIANS SEEM TO CUT SUPPORT FOR WALDHEIM
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/17/world.print_headline: AUSTRIANS SEEM TO CUT SUPPORT FOR WALDHEIM
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/17/world.body_text: **********Chancellor Franz Vranitzky will make a symbolically important visit to Washington this week amid signs that political support for President Kurt Waldheim has eroded in Austria since the Justice Department listed Mr. Waldheim as being barred from entering the United States. **********The Justice Department's action on April 27, which effectively bans Mr. Waldheim from traveling to the United States because of his presumed implication in Nazi war crimes in the Balkans, has had a powerful effect in Austria. Politicians and journalists say Mr. Waldheim's spreading unpopularity threatens to undermine the functioning of the country's new coalition Government. 'Nobody Likes a Loser' **********A senior Vienna editor, whose newspaper originally backed Mr. Waldheim, summed up a mood developing in Austrian political circles. ''It's sliding toward how to get rid of him,'' the editor said. ''Nobody likes a loser, and Waldheim is looking like a loser.'' **********Unrest is growing in Chancellor Vranitzky's Socialist Party, which opposed Mr. Waldheim when he ran as the candidate of the People's Party a year ago but which was obliged to muffle its criticism of him after the two big parties formed a coalition in March. **********In a parliamentary debate on the affair last week, Socialist deputies conspicuously avoided applauding the People's Party leader and Deputy Chancellor, Alois Mock, who characterized the Justice Department decision as ''an unfriendly act'' made under the pressure of ''selfish and intransigent interest groups'' in the United States. A Question of Priorities **********Socialist deputies initially balked at a motion that backed the Government's defense of President Waldheim against ''unjustified accusations,'' and one backbencher, Josef Czap, said that sooner or later it would have to be decided whether Austria was more important than Mr. Waldheim. **********In an interview, Mr. Vranitzky went out of his way to distance himself from Mr. Waldheim. The Chancellor said there was sharpening criticism of the President's handling of the issue and shook his head emphatically when asked whether Mr. Waldheim had lived up to his pledge to be an activist head of state who would inspire a moral renewal in Austria. **********''I believe that he fulfills his functions,'' Mr. Vranitzky said, ''but beyond that, considering the unique situation he's in, he is extremely busy with the other matter.'' It was a delicate allusion to the international controversy that has engulfed and isolated Mr. Waldheim, 68 years old. **********Asked whether the President ought to resign to spare Austria further embarrassment, Mr. Vranitzky said, ''That Waldheim comes to this decision - you must ask him.'' **********In a society that lends great importance to titles, it was noteworthy that the Chancellor never once referred to Mr. Waldheim as ''President.'' An Expression of Dismay **********The Austrian Chancellor nonetheless expressed dismay at the American order banning Mr. Waldheim, saying he had hoped that foreign policy considerations and Austria's traditional pro-American orientation would have outweighed the Justice Department's deliberations and ''internal American aspects'' of the Waldheim case. **********When the Justice Department took its action against Mr. Waldheim, placing his name on a list of those to be excluded from entry, it cited evidence that he had ''participated in activities amounting to persecution'' of Jews and others in Greece and Yugoslavia during World War II, when Mr. Waldheim was a lieutenant in the German Army. **********Mr. Vranitzky, a 49-year-old former banker and basketball star, said he would be pleased if President Reagan would reconsider the decision when the two meet in Washington on Thursday, but he added that he did not think this was likely. The Chancellor is to arrive in New York on Tuesday evening for a three-day visit. Cordial Welcome Predicted **********The isolation and political eclipse of Mr. Waldheim, whose presidential post is largely ceremonial, has enhanced Chancellor Vranitzky's position as Austria's chief representative abroad. The American Ambassador to Austria, Ronald S. Lauder, predicted that Mr. Vranitzky would be cordially welcomed in Washington. **********''We want to show the Chancellor that this is directed against Kurt Waldheim and not against the Austrian people,'' Mr. Lauder said, referring to the decision to ban Mr. Waldheim from entering a country where he lived for decade when he was Secretary General of the United Nations. **********On Friday, a high-level Justice Department delegation, which included Neil Sher, the head of the section that argued for putting Mr. Waldheim on the list of those to be excluded from entry, explained the decision to Austrian officials. The Americans reportedly stressed that Mr. Waldheim was in ''a position to know'' about war crimes in the Balkans. **********But the American delegation brought no new historical documents that directly implicated the Austrian President in war crimes. According to a source close to the talks. this considerably irritated a senior Austrian official, Tomas Klestil, who nearly broke off the meeting in anger. **********As he seeks to clear his name, Mr. Waldheim has lodged a libel suit here against the president of the World Jewish Congress, Edgar M. Bronfman, who recently accused the Austrian President of having been ''part and parcel of the Nazi killing machine.'' **********But few politicians take the suit seriously, and Chancellor Vranitzky, when asked about it, dismissed the legal move with a shrug of the shoulders. 'The Ruin of My Life's Work' **********Even within the conservative People's Party, a vocal minority has started to argue in private that Mr. Waldheim has become an unbearable burden for this small neutral nation. And in the Socialist camp, Bruno Kreisky, the former Chancellor, caught a sentiment of exasperation by saying in a magazine interview that ''the Waldheim affair has robbed us of the international reputation that we have striven since 1945 to build.'' **********''I stand before the ruin of my life's work,'' said the former Socialist Chancellor, who advanced Mr. Waldheim's career. **********The parliamentary debate last week was widely described as a watershed in Austria's postwar political life, because for the first time a head of state, traditionally accorded a respect bordering on the reverence once given Hapsburg monarchs, was openly and quite personally criticized. **********A young deputy from the anti-establishment Green Party, Andreas Wabl, caused an uproar when he unfurled a swastika from the podium and declared that he was ashamed that Austria's President had served under that banner. Austrian television refused to show the Greens deputy's protest. **********More grave in political terms was a sarcastic attack on Mr. Waldheim by Jorg Haider, leader of the nationalistic Freedom Party, which had until recently been one of the President's stoutest defenders. Although bitterly lashing out at the United States, Mr. Haider poked fun at Mr. Waldheim's ''embarrassing failures of memory'' and his vacillation in summoning a historians' commission promised a year ago. **********A charismatic populist, Mr. Haider is seen as a politician with a finger on the nation's pulse. Some say his abandonment of Mr. Waldheim may be more significant than the impatience with the President in Austria's two biggest parties. **********Despite the quickening domestic controversy, politicians and journalists in Vienna said they did not expect Mr. Waldheim to resign soon, and several argued that it would be bad for him to buckle now under what could be portrayed as outside pressure. **********Paul Grosz, a representative of the small number of Jews in Austria, said at a news conference last week that he opposed a resignation by the President because it might foster anti-Semitism and ''a stab-in-the-back legend'' in Austria.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/02/busin.body_text: **********Efforts by the House Ways and Means Committee to begin drafting a tax bill today were scuttled after Republicans disputed the need to raise $12 billion from new taxes and refused to consider any specific revenue-raising proposals. **********Meeting with Democrats behind closed doors for nearly two hours, the Republicans raised the possibility that they might not participate in any future committee deliberations unless the $12 billion revenue goal were lowered and spending were cut more instead. **********Democrats, appearing surprised and frustrated by the Republicans' move, said that they would try to persuade Republicans to participate but that they were prepared to draft a tax bill alone if necessary. A Setback for Rostenkowski **********''To say I'm disappointed would minimize my dilemma,'' said Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who is chairman of the Ways and Means Committee. ''I'd like to have them participate. But the bill's got to be written.'' **********Under legislation signed by President Reagan over the weekend, if agreement cannot be reached on a way to reduce the Federal budget deficit by $23 billion, spending cuts of that amount would automatically take effect. **********Mr. Rostenkowski said the committee needed to complete work on the tax bill by Oct. 15 to keep to the budget timetable and avoid the automatic spending cuts. He said the committee would begin work on the tax bill on Wednesday - with or without the Republicans. **********As has become the norm for tax bills, hundreds of lobbyists gathered this morning in the cavernous House Ways and Means hearing room for the start of the committee's work. But neither the lobbyists nor the pool of television cameras got even a glimpse of the tax debate. As soon as the committee members assembled, they voted to move into closed session - as they have done increasingly in recent years in writing tax legislation. Resistance From Republicans **********According to the original plan, the committee was to have voted today on a list of 19 revenue-raising ideas prepared by the committee's staff. Democrats described the proposals as the ''easy ones'' because they were considered the least controversial. **********The list, raising a total of $8 billion, included many of the revenue proposals contained in President Reagan's 1988 budget recommendations, extensions of expiring excise taxes, and two previously introduced bills that were jointly sponsored by Mr. Rostenkowski and the committee's ranking Republican, Representative John J. Duncan of Tennessee. **********But Democratic and Republican members at the session said Republicans refused to talk about any specific proposals, including the President's revenue ideas. Instead, the nearly two-hour session focused on Republican complaints that Democratic leaders had set the overall revenue targets too high and the spending cuts too low. If they could not participate in setting the overall revenue numbers, then they did not want to participate in determining how to raise the money. **********''We were put in a budgetary straitjacket,'' Representative Bill Archer, a Texas Republican, said in an interview after the meeting. $8 Billion Goal Sought Representative Hal Daub, a Nebraska Republican, said that if the revenue target were reduced to $8 billion, many of the Republicans would be willing to participate. But Democrats gave no indication that they were about to bend. **********In a letter to Mr. Duncan, Mr. Rostenkowski expressed disappointment over today's Republican reaction, particularly because 12 of the 13 Republican members had voted last week for the automatic deficit reduction revision to the Gramm-Rudman law. **********''It is my hope that our deficit reduction efforts will continue in a bipartisan fashion,'' Mr. Rostenkowski wrote. He asked Mr. Duncan to meet with Republican members and ''to prepare a list of alternatives or additions to the proposals I put before the committee today. These can be either revenue proposals or additional spending cuts within the committee's jurisdiction.'' **********Over the years, Ways and Means Republicans have repeatedly complained about the minimal role they have played in the Democrat-controlled committee's deliberations. And the initiative for today's revolt appeared to be their own. Mr. Daub said the White House had no part in it. **********These were among the proposals in the committee's 23-page list of options: *********** Extending the Medicare payroll tax to all state and local government employees. *********** Requiring employers to pay Social Security tax on cash tips received by waiters and other employees. *********** Eliminating the Social Security tax exemption for certain student earnings. *********** Increasing the coal excise tax. *********** Imposing a $1-a-ticket excise tax for international travel. *********** Imposing user fees for ''private letter'' rulings from the Internal Revenue Service and for certain services provided by the Customs Service and the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms. *********** Extending the 3 percent telephone excise tax, scheduled to expire at the end of this year. *********** Freezing the current estate and gift tax rates, instead of allowing them to drop next year as previously scheduled. **********The proposals stemming from the legislation previously introduced by Mr. Rostenkowski and Mr. Duncan included revising the corporate estimated tax rules and curtailing an estate tax loophole relating to sales of stock to employee stock ownership plans.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/26/world.main_headline: TAMIL LEADERS GO TO INDIA FOR TALKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/26/world.print_headline: TAMIL LEADERS GO TO INDIA FOR TALKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/26/world.body_text: **********India summoned Tamil extremist leaders here for secret talks this week and urged them to negotiate a settlement with the Sri Lankan Government, officials and other sources said today The guerrillas reportedly answered that they would not talk with the Colombo Government until it stopped attacks on Tamil strongholds in the northern Jaffna Peninsula. **********An Indian official familiar with the talks here said Indian officials had told the Tamils, ''There is no alternative to talks.'' **********Tamil separatist groups have been blames for terrorist acts that have claimed hundreds of lives in the last week. 'Escalation of Violence' **********As Sri Lankan planes and soldiers were reported to be bombing Tamil hideouts for the third straight day, a three-member delegation representing the largest extremist group, the Liberation Tigers for Tamil Eelam, held talks with India's Internal Security Minister and other officials. **********An Indian Foreign Office statement late tonight ''strongly'' condemned ''the escalation of violence represented by the recent aerial attacks and the military measures undertaken by the Sri Lankan Government.'' **********It also said India had denounced the recent killing of civilians in Sri Lanka. **********The rebels want to carve a separate Tamil-dominated nation, or eelam, out of northern and eastern Sri Lanka. **********India has turned down Sri Lankan demands to crack down on the militants, although it raided their offices and briefly arrested several leaders last year and seized some weapons. Colombo says India supplies arms to the terrorists and has allowed them to set up training camps in Tamil Nadu, the southern Indian state dominated by Tamils. Guerrillas Weakened **********India has denied the charges, and diplomatic sources say that many camps have since shut down. **********A rebel official said in a telephone interview from Madras, the southern Indian city, that the militants ''will not participate in the peace process until the Sri Lanka Government abandons her policy of military terrorism against the Tamils.'' **********Sources close to the guerrillas say they have been weakened by the recent attacks. **********The rebel spokesman said the Tamil delegation also insisted at its talks with Indian officials that Colombo must stop attacking the Tamils and end a three-month economic blockade of the city of Jaffna, the main commercial center of the Tamil-dominated northern province. Talks 'From Strength' **********The Liberation Tigers and another major guerrilla group denied involvement last week in the massacre of 127 bus passengers in Sri Lanka and the bomb blast in Colombo that killed more than 100 people. **********A Sri Lankan diplomat in New Delhi said his Government did not wish to negotiate with the Tamils until it had ''broken the back of the terrorists.'' **********He said the Government wanted to ''hold talks from a position of strength.'' **********An Indian official said that denials by the militants of a role in the slayings of civilians had not convinced New Delhi. **********Last week, President J. R. Jayewardene's ruling United National Party urged India to arrest the extremists based in Tamil Nadu. But an Indian lawmaker close to the radicals said the Government would not ''want to push them to the wall.'' **********The lawmaker, V. Gopalswamy, said that Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi needed to handle the issue tactfully because it presented a tricky domestic political problem for him. Mr. Gandhi's allies control Tamil Nadu and they have supported the militants. **********India stopped mediating the Sri Lankan conflict after the warring sides stepped up their violence in December. Sri Lanka first rejected and then said it was prepared to consider an Indian peace plan that envisaged, among other things, the merger of parts of the Northern and Eastern Provinces.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/25/busin.body_text: **********A computer makers' trade group is challenging a Customs Service decision that could cost the companies millions of dollars a year in tariffs. **********The group, the Computer and Business Equipment Manufacturers Association, is angry about the Customs Service's decision to classify printed circuit boards with microprocessors on them as unfinished computers rather than electronic parts. Finished and unfinished computers imported from Japan are subject to a tariff, while electronic parts are not. **********The 24-page Customs decision, which was circulated in the electronics industry last month, was based on a dispute with the Intel Corporation over how to classify circuit boards that the company imported. A Longstanding View **********Customs officials said the decision confirmed a longstanding view by Customs that such ''mother-boards'' were, in essence, computers without covers or peripheral attachments. However, because that view had not been widely known or enforced, the decision surprised computer makers. They are asking the Treasury Department to reverse the decision. **********''Our members tell us they have been importing these things for 15 years and they have always been classified as parts,'' said Charlotte LeGates, a spokeswoman for the Washington-based computer trade group, which has 33 members, including the American subsidiaries of several major Japanese companies. **********Computer makers are especially concerned that wording of the Intel decision also seems to reclassify unfinished disk drives and other equipment as finished peripherals, according to David Rose, trade relations manager for customs and licensing at Intel, which is not a member of the trade group. **********Two years ago, the decision would not have much of a difference. But changes in tariffs since then - especially President Reagan's decision to place a 100 percent tariff on some Japanese products in April - now make the classifications a multimillion-dollar concern for many companies, according to Ms. LeGates. Changes in the Tariffs **********Both electronic parts and computers from Japan were formerly subject to equal tariffs. But in 1986 the United States dropped its tariff on electronic parts as part of an agreement with Japan and Canada that eliminated tariffs on a broad range of American electronic products in Japan. Today, finished and unfinished computers from Japan carry a 3.9 percent tariff and finished peripherals a 3.7 percent tariff, while the parts are tariff free. **********Since the 1986 agreement, Customs officials have begun to look more closely at how electronics importers classify their goods. Intel and some smaller importers were told that circuit boards had been improperly labeled as tariff-free parts. But enforcement was apparently sporadic. **********''We don't see everything, so it's possible lots of people were bringing them into the country under the wrong classification and getting away with it,'' one Customs official conceded. In addition, enforcement had been uneven because of disagreements within the Customs Service about whether circuit boards with microprocessors should be classified as computers in all cases. **********The stakes increased sharply in April after the United States retaliated against Japan for dumping of semiconductors by placing 100 percent tariffs on a variety of Japanese products. The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, for instance, has complained that tariffs on circuit boards it makes for the International Business Machines Corporation have jumped to 104 percent. **********According to the Computer and Business Equipment Manufacturers Association, the Customs ruling places so many products under the sanctions that the Administration's target of applying the 100 percent tariffs to $180 million of Japanese imports will be quickly exceeded. **********American companies are also concerned that the Customs Service's decision will increase trade frictions and might be seen by the Japanese as a violation of the 1986 tariff agreement with Canada and Japan. ''One fear we have here is that Japan could retaliate by restoring its tariffs on completed computers, peripherals and parts,'' Intel's Mr. Rose said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/18/busin.main_headline: Honda Expansion: U.S. Exports a Goal
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/18/busin.print_headline: Honda Expansion: U.S. Exports a Goal
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/18/busin.body_text: **********The Honda Motor Company today announced a four-year plan to expand its American production to the point where it could export about 50,000 cars to Japan each year. **********Honda executives said the No. 4 domestic car maker would build a second car assembly plant in central Ohio for about $380 million to increase its domestic production by 42 percent, spend $150 million to expand its American engine plant and bolster its local research and development. **********As a result, the company's American branch will be able to produce an additional 150,000 cars a year, the executives said. That would put Honda in a position to export 70,000 cars a year, more than any American company exported in 1987. Effect of the Weaker Dollar **********The move reflects both Honda's concern about protectionist sentiment in the United States and the dollar's fall in value against the Japanese yen. Jeff Leestma, a Honda spokesman, said that the weaker dollar had eliminated the cost advantage of building autos in Japan. **********He said it now costs about as much to build cars in Japan and ship them to the United States as it does just to build them here. **********The expansion, which was encouraged by incentives from the State of Ohio, and other spending plans will raise Honda's capital investment in American manufacturing by about $1 billion, to $1.7 billion, and add about 3,500 employees to its Ohio workforce by 1991. **********''With all these efforts, we will develop our U.S. operations to the point that we will have a self-reliant, integrated motor vehicle company capable of competing in the world marketplace,'' said Tadashi Kume, president of Honda Motor, at a news conference in Columbus, Ohio. **********Honda will build the new plant in East Liberty, Ohio, near its first operation in Marysville. The new plant is scheduled to open in 1989 and would bring total American production to 510,000 cars a year, from the current 360,000. By comparison, Honda's Japanese operation made 500,000 cars last year and is projecting 550,000 for 1987. 'A Shot at Third Place' **********If, in 1991, Honda were to sell 440,000 American-made cars and its import quota of 420,000 Japanese-made vehicles in the United States, the company would still trail the Chrysler Corporation, which sold 1.2 million vehicles last year. But John Hammond, an analyst with J. D. Power & Associates, an auto research concern, said that some of Honda's increased sales might come at the expense of the No. 3 domestic auto maker. **********''They've got a shot at third place,'' Mr. Hammond said of Honda. ''The next step is to move their world headquarters to America. I've heard rumors that they're considering it.'' 'Transplant Factories' **********Mr. Hammond noted that Honda, like other Japanese auto makers, began making cars in the United States to get around the import quotas devised by the Japanese Government in the late 1970's and to insulate itself from swings in currency exchange rates. **********He argued that these ''transplant factories'' made sense when the strong dollar made it cheaper to build in Japan, so they make even more sense since the dollar fell 50 percent against the yen over the last two years. **********''Their principal market is the United States,'' Mr. Hammond said. ''You don't shift manufacturing facilities around the world simply on the basis of short-term movement in exchange rates. Volkswagen tried that in the '70's and was hurt.'' **********In 1982, Honda became the first Japanese auto maker to build cars in the United States. Since then, the Nissan Motor Company and the Mazda Motor Company have followed its lead, and the Toyota Motor Company plans to begin production in the United States in 1989. A spokesman for Toyota, which outsells Honda in the United States, said it planned to build as many as 200,000 cars a year by 1990. Plants Where the Sales Are **********Mr. Hammond said that Toyota might increase its production, but that Nissan had other problems to solve before it could increase its investment in the United States. He added that other Japanese auto makers, such as the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation, were less formidable as American manufacturers. **********Mr. Leestma of Honda said that the company had long believed in building cars in the countries in which they are sold. ''We have over 60 manufacturing facilities in over 30 countries,'' he said. **********Mr. Leestma indicated, however, that the cars that Honda would export to Japan would be models that are made only in the United States. **********Honda said the new Ohio factory would be able to produce several models, including its Acura division's two high-performance luxury cars, the $20,000 Legend and the $15,000 Integra. But in August 1989, the first car that rolls out of the East Liberty plant will be a Civic, which costs $8,000 to $12,000. **********Civics and Accords are also produced in Marysville and are imported as well. Economic Contribution **********Tetsuo Chino, the president of Honda North America Ltd., said the company would increase the share of domestic components in its American-made cars from about 50 percent this year to about 67 percent in two years and to 75 percent in 1991. **********Honda employs nearly 5,000 auto workers in the United States and said it will have 8,650 in 1991. The company will also increase the number of engineers in the United States to 500 in 1991, from about 180 now. **********The rural East Liberty site was chosen after the State of Ohio sold its Transportation Reseach Center there to Honda for $31 million. The center had been rented to a number of auto companies for use as a test track. **********The site, which is about five miles from Marysville, had no substantial industry before Honda arrived. A Honda spokesman said that most of the employees had been locally recruited. **********Ohio granted Honda other incentives, including tax abatements and state money to train new employees. **********Honda's employees in Marysville have twice rejected organizing efforts by the United Automobile Workers, which some analysts said contributed to the company's decision to build its second plant nearby.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/03/busin.main_headline: Dow Off 10.01 as Volume Edges Up
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/03/busin.print_headline: Dow Off 10.01 as Volume Edges Up
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/03/busin.body_text: **********Stock prices retreated broadly yesterday as investors sold heavily in the face of a weak dollar and a declining bond market resulting from the news that Paul A. Volcker would not return as chairman of the Federal Reserve. **********After the midmorning announcement that Alan Greenspan had been nominated to succeed Mr. Volcker, the Dow Jones industrial average fell by more than 20 points. By 11 A.M., however, the Dow had regained ground to a gain of more than 3 points. **********By the close, the Dow was 10.01 points lower, at 2,278.22, depressed by continuing weakness in the dollar and bonds. 153.7 Million Shares Exchanged Volume on the New York Stock Exchange edged up to 153.4 million shares, from a slow 149.3 million shares on Monday. **********''Now, the uncertainty about Mr. Volcker is gone, which should prove encouraging for the market for the month of June and on into the summer,'' said Gene Seagle, director of technical research at Gruntal & Company. **********Mr. Seagle said the market's reaction suggested Mr. Greenspan was an acceptable choice on Wall Street. ''Under his leadership there now should be more stress on economic growth than on fears of inflation.'' **********But other analysts, noting the confidence that the financial community generally had in Mr. Volcker, said the real test for equities would be today after Wall Street has had a chance to digest the news of the Volcker-Greenspan switch. Other Indexes Down **********The broader market was also lower yesterday with declines outnumbering advances by 926 to 622. Other, broader-based indicators were only narrowly weaker. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 1.37, to 288.46, while the New York Stock Exchange composite index dipped 0.71, to 162.77. **********Analysts noted that the market was again being affected by takeover news after a sharp decline in such activity as a result of Wall Street's insider-trading scandal. They said this trend was generating renewed interest in equities. **********Yesterday, Gillette was the second-most-active Big Board issue, rising 1 3/8 points, to 32 1/4, on a volume of nearly 3.4 million shares. Among the takeover rumors circulating about Gillette was that Sir James Goldsmith, the British investor, or others were accumulating the stock. Harcourt Advances **********Harcourt Brace Javonovich Inc., which announced a recapitalization plan last week to thwart an unwanted takeover offer, rose 2 3/8, to 56 5/8. **********Among key blue chip-stocks, G.E., which was recommended by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., rose 1 1/2, to 52 7/8. But I.B.M. fell 2 3/8, to 157 1/4, and Merck dropped 2, to 154 1/2. **********Precious metals stocks ended strong. ASA Ltd. rose 2 3/8, to 60 3/8; Callahan Mining gained 2 3/8, to 31 1/4; Newmont Mining added 2 1/4, to 100, and Homestake Mining rose 2 points, to 36 1/2. **********H. F. Ahmanson & Company fell 1 3/4, to 19 1/2, after an analyst at Goldman, Sachs & Company lowered his earnings estimate for the savings and loan. The company said that it would postpone selling up to $1 billion in mortgage-backed securities because of rising interest rates. **********On the American Stock Exchange, the Amex market-value index fell 0.66, to 325.66, as declines ran ahead of advances by about a 3-to-2 ratio. **********In over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index dropped 1.41 points, to 413.60.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/24/busin.main_headline: U.S. Assesses Damage In Soviet-Linked Theft
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/24/busin.print_headline: U.S. Assesses Damage In Soviet-Linked Theft
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/24/busin.body_text: **********A Customs Service official said today that a plot to sell supercomputer designs to the Soviet Union might have succeeded in getting some information to the Russians before it was stopped Thursday with the arrest of three men. **********''We're trying to find out what did get out,'' Rollin Klink, special agent in charge of the Customs Service's San Francisco office, said today. ''The theft has been going on for over a year, so I don't know what left.'' **********Mr. Klink also said that there might be more arrests. Purported Price Is $4 Million **********The three California men arrested Thursday are accused of planning to sell designs for an extremely powerful supercomputer to the Soviet Union for $4 million. Federal officials said that they had recovered tapes and disks containing design information, so it is unclear if material did get to the Soviet Union. **********The Federal officials said it would be ''extremely detrimental'' to the national security of the United States if the designs for the computer got into Soviet hands. Such a high-speed computer could be used to intercept and decipher American communications or, in a war, to detect and help intercept American missiles. **********The men arrested Thursday were Kevin E. Anderson, 36 years old, a software designer; Ivan Pierre Batinic, 29, also a software engineer, and his brother Stevan, 30, a mechanic. Until September Ivan Batinic had worked at the Saxpy Computer Corporation of Sunnyvale, Calif., the company from which the designs were purportedly stolen. **********The three are believed to have conspired with Charles McVey, 57, who the authorities say diverted technology to the Soviet Union for a long period beginning in the 1970's. Mr. McVey was arrested in Canada in August and is awaiting extradition. Analyzing Signals **********Saxpy, a young company, in May began selling a computer that can perform up to one billion calculations a second. The machine is considered especially useful in analyzing electronic signals such as those from sonar and radar. **********Such computer speeds previously were available only on the most powerful machines made by Cray Research Inc, but several companies now produce extremely high-speed machines, making it more difficult for the authorities to control access to sensitive technology. In addition, many fledgling computer companies do not have the elaborate security precautions of the big military contractors. **********''It's my understanding that the company was targeted by the Soviets,'' John P. Viola, chief financial officer of Saxpy, said in an interview. **********Ivan Batinic, a French national, was a software engineer at Saxpy for 15 months. According to the Government's complaint, the company put him on probation in May because his performance was not satisfactory and dismissed him in September. **********Mr. Viola said that Mr. Batinic often volunteered to work alone at night, and he could have taken computer disks and tapes. The company did not have a 24-hour security guard. **********Federal officials said today that the investigation began in August when Ivan Batinic and Mr. Anderson were searched at the customs station in Vancouver, British Columbia, and found to be carrying more than $15,000 in $100 bills. They said the money was given to them by a man named Carlos Julio Williams. Arrest in the Yukon **********About two weeks later, a Canadian police officer arrested Mr. McVey in a small town in the Yukon Territory. Canadian authorities said that he carried a Guatemalan passport with the name Carlos Julio Williams Beltran, as well as a computer manual and chart belonging to Saxpy. **********Federal agents said that an informant met with Mr. Anderson and their conversations were monitored by agents. They also said that agents traced Mr. Anderson as he visited Mr. McVey in jail in Canada and also when he went to Malta. Mr. Anderson told the informant that he had been to the Soviet Union to arrange the sale, the Federal agents said. **********Federal officials said that during a search they found Saxpy manuals, tapes and about 50 computer disks in a storage locker in Fremont, Calif., that belonged to Mr. Anderson.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/09/busin.main_headline: CRUDE OIL PRICES SPURT; OPEC MOVES ARE CITED
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/09/busin.print_headline: FUTURE MARKETS; CRUDE OIL PRICES SPURT; OPEC MOVES ARE CITED
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/09/busin.body_text: **********Prices of crude oil surged well above $18 a barrel yesterday on world markets, their highest levels since last Jan. 31. **********The gains came as members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries continued to signal their determination to return to a system of official prices. There were reports that Saudi Arabia's production for the first week of the month was just 3.1 million barrels a day, substantially below the 5 million a day it was said to have been producing last month and below its official OPEC quota of 4.1 million. **********On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the near-month futures contract for crude oil closed at $18.57 a barrel, up 32 cents. On the London-based spot market, West Texas Intermediate, the American bellwether crude oil, traded at $18.45 a barrel, up 20 cents, while Brent North Sea crude oil, the British blend, was at $18.25 a barrel, also 20 cents higher. **********Prices of petroleum products have also risen to levels not seen since last winter. The near-month futures contracts for heating oil and unleaded gasoline both rose a cent. **********Analysts said the market's advance over the past week reflected a growing confidence that OPEC would adhere to its new agreement to restrain oil production and impose fixed prices. But they also said there was still much skepticism about OPEC's chances of success. **********Frank Kneuttel of Prudential-Bache Securities expressed some doubts, saying OPEC was not only trying to move to a fixed-price system - compared with the individualized trading arrangements for different customers its members have had for the last 18 months - but also trying to make the shift as the season of high oil demand, the winter, is ending.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/09/busin.body_text: **********Apple Computer Inc. said today that it had promoted Charles M. Boesenberg to senior vice president and group executive, United States sales and marketing. Mr. Boesenberg, 38 years old, succeeds William V. Campbell, who in April was named president of Apple's new applications software subsidiary. **********''Chuck has quickly become a significant contributor to Apple's sales and marketing strategies,'' said Delbert W. Yocam, Apple's chief operating officer. Mr. Boesenberg, who will report directly to Mr. Yocam, joined Apple in January as vice president of United States sales. Before joining Apple, Mr. Boesenberg was vice president and general manager for the Data General Corporation's operations in Europe, the Middle East and Africa. **********Earlier, he had spent 10 years with the International Business Machines Corporation in sales and marketing management positions, most recently in the national marketing division. He has a B.S. in mechanical engineering and an M.B.A. from Boston University.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/01/busin.main_headline: Advertising; New Data On Modern Maturity
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/01/busin.print_headline: Advertising; New Data On Modern Maturity
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/01/busin.body_text: **********OF the nation's three largest-circulation magazines - TV Guide, Reader's Digest and Modern Maturity - one is particularly saddled with what it considers a misconception of its audience. **********The troubled one is Modern Maturity, the six-a-year publication of the American Association of Retired Persons. With its February-March issue Modern Maturity will increase its circulation rate base 10.1 percent, to 17.4 million, and it is well on its way to becoming the country's largest magazine. **********Many magazines consider themselves misunderstood by media departments of ad agencies for one reason or another. Modern Maturity considers itself caught in the middle of a seeming reverse generation gap. **********As explained yesterday by Ina S. Josephson, national sales manager, and Cary Silvers, director of research, the media people at agencies are prone to perceive the over-50 set as washed up. **********''Young agency people really are turned off by that crowd,'' said Franchellie Cadwell, president of Cadwell Davis Partners, the magazine's agency for a couple of years. ''They're afraid to think about it. Just the opposite of the yuppies. **********''Even after you impress them with your numbers, they say, 'Uh-huh,' then don't do anything about it.'' **********In hopes of making older readers easier to take, the magazine commissioned a $60,000 study by the Daniel Yankelovich Group that compared the wants, needs, desires and pastimes of the over-50 group with those of the 39-to-49 set that media people can more easily relate to. **********The study found more similarities than differences. And Modern Maturity's annual trade campaign and a new audio-visual presentation will be based on it. The A-V made its debut yesterday at a luncheon at the Romeo Salta Restaurant. The advertising begins Jan. 4 in the advertising trade press. **********The presentation, which will be taken on the road after three New York luncheons, will hit Chicago, Detroit, Los Angeles, San Francisco, Atlanta and Dallas, which could be called advertising's grand circuit. Ms. Josephson calls the presentation ''missionary work.'' **********The print advertising is being billed as a primer on how to advertise to seniors and, indeed, will be bound together and published as a booklet when the campaign ends. The ads all refer to the Yankelovich study. **********Some of the headlines are: ''Talk about romance,'' ''Don't make a long story short,'' ''Entertain them'' and ''Treat them like your brother not your mother.'' **********The tagline, a carry-over from last year, is: ''The beginning of a new lifetime.'' **********The fact that the readers of the magazine are pretty much the same as much younger consumers is also important to the publishers of Modern Maturity. They want to break out of the niche that has the magazine type-cast as a publication that is only for diet-conscious folks and that therefore gets ads only for such things as salt-free or sugar-free products, instead of a food company's whole product line. **********Mr. Silvers, having studied the data at the Publishers Information Bureau, guesses that of total food company ad budgets, only about 15 percent is for dietary products of one kind or another. He does not want his magazine's ad revenues limited like that. **********The publication, which has only carried advertising for seven of its more than 30 years, will run 259 ad pages this year, for total revenues of $42.8 million. **********Neither Ms. Josephson nor her publisher, Peter Hansen, is talking about Modern Maturity becoming America's largest-circulation magazine, but it is a distinct possibility for 1988 since it grows by an average of 250,000 each issue. Ms. Josephson said they would wait for Audit Bureau of Circulations data before they did any crowing. **********Let us not, however, forget Parade, the magazine that is carried as a newspaper supplement and that has a rate base of 32.8 million. **********The magazine is one of the benefits to joining the American Association of Retired Persons, where annual dues are only $5 and where membership brings discounts for travel and car rentals as well as access to health and other insurance plans.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/19/world.main_headline: IRAQ ASCRIBES A KEY DEFEAT IN '86 TO MISINFORMATION FROM THE U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/19/world.print_headline: IRAQ ASCRIBES A KEY DEFEAT IN '86 TO MISINFORMATION FROM THE U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/19/world.body_text: **********A leading Iraqi official has asserted that misleading intelligence information provided by the United States led last year to a major Iraqi defeat in the war with Iran. **********The official, Taha Yassin Ramadan, the First Deputy Prime Minister, also said Iraq's leadership believed that American arms sales to Iran and the giving of false intelligence to Iraq were part of a policy to prolong the war and increase United States influence in the region.  [ Heavy fighting continued in the war. Iran asserted that its troops had advanced to within 400 yards of an oil refinery south of the city of Basra, while Iraq continued its heavy bombing of Iranian cities and supply lines. Page A8. ]  U.S. 'Lack of Morals' Assailed In an interview on Saturday, Mr. Ramadan said his country was outraged by ''the lack of morals on the part of the U.S.'' He said the denial of weapons to Iraq while Washington was secretly shipping arms to Iran was ''a treachery and conspiracy that started from the very first day'' that Iraq and the United States restored diplomatic relations in November 1984. **********Mr. Ramadan said Iraq lost Fao, a unused oil port on the Persian Gulf near the border with Kuwait, in February 1986 because of misleading intelligence reports provided by the United States. **********''A few months before the Iranian offensive we detected movements of Iranian troops, but the U.S. kept on telling us that the Iranian attack was not aimed against Fao,'' he said. ''Even when the battle started the Americans kept on sending us reports that it was not the big offensive.'' U.S. Explanation Dismissed **********The Iraqi official said that when Iraq complained, the United States said it had provided Iraq with the only information that was available. ''Who can possibly believe that?'' Mr. Ramadan asked. He called the American response ''totally unacceptable.'' **********It was reported last month that the United States had provided intelligence to Iraq in an effort to offset the effect of American arms shipments to Iran. Last week it was reported that Washington had knowingly provided incorrect or misleading data to both sides.  [ The C.I.A. has emphatically denied providing faulty intelligence to Iran or Iraq. Intelligence sources in Washington said, however, that the data sent to Iran was misleading, and that in one instance it overstated the strength of the Iraqi forces in an effort to prevent Teheran from mounting an attack. The sources said information delivered to Iraq was deliberately incomplete, although several Administration officials insisted that what was given was accurate. ]  Iraq's President, Saddam Hussein, resumed diplomatic relations with the United States two years ago after a 17-year break over American support for Israel. Iraq has also drawn closer to pro-Western Arab countries like Jordan and Egypt, which backed it in its war against Iran. But the revelations of the United States' secret shipments of arms to Iran seem to have shattered whatever confidence in Washington that Iraq had developed. U.S. Objectives Outlined **********Mr. Ramadan, who is acting as head of Government while President Hussein devotes most of his time to the war, said the American arms sales to Iran and misinformation to Iraq were part of the same premeditated policy aimed at increasing American influence in the regions to achieve two goals: **********First, he said, the United States wanted to prolong the war in order to use the Iranian threat to scare the Gulf Arab states, including Kuwait and Saudi Arabia, into accepting American intervention and allowing more United States military bases in the region. **********Second, he said, the United States was seeking to buy back its influence in Iran. **********The Iraqi leadership has never abandoned its hard-line opposition to a negotiated settlement with Israel, but in the mid-1980's the heavy economic and military burden of the war led Iraq to normalize relations with the United States. **********But Iraq also sought a balanced relationship with the Soviet Union, and during the last year, relations between Moscow and Baghdad warmed up as the Soviet Union expressed support of Iraq's efforts to seek a peaceful end to the war. **********Despite Iraq's anger against Washington's actions, Iraqi leaders and some Arab diplomats say they beleive that the revelations of Washington's Iran arms dealings have strengthened Iraq's political standing in the Arab and Islamic world. **********''The revelations of the U.S. secret with Iran, and the role of israel in the affair, have provided another factor of strength to Iraq since it has proved its longstanding argument that Iran was not and could not be an ally of the Arab world,'' Mr. Ramadan said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/03/busin.body_text: **********Near berth 132, the Port of Los Angeles is building a terminal for the Mitsui O.S.K. Line's huge container ships. Up the channel a bit the port is expanding a complex to accommodate the flood of Japanese auto imports. And just inland, the finishing touches are being put on a facility to speed the transfer of cargo between ships and rail and truck lines. **********The improvements are being made to help this port do what ports have always tried to do - move goods more quickly and efficiently. But there is an urgency to these changes, and a flurry of others, born of shifting trade patterns, improving transportation technology - and growing competition. **********All ports are moving to deal with the same general forces. Faced with attracting fewer steamship lines carrying greater cargo loads, port authorities are taking a more active role in the development of facilities and land management. To insulate themselves against currency fluctuations and trade legislation, they are working harder to diversify the cargo they handle. **********Perhaps most important, ports are becoming more aggressive in marketing themselves to shipping lines, importers and exporters to insure that they survive what experts describe as a continuing consolidation. Major Program in New York **********In New York harbor, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is spending half a billion dollars over five years to deepen channels for container ships to 40 feet from 35 feet, buy stronger cranes to lift the containers and provide significantly more space for container storage, according to Robert Steiner, the deputy director of the port. **********The Baltimore port is in the midst of a $400 million dredging and capital improvement plan, and in the last two years has doubled its international advertising budget, to $500,000. New Orleans just introduced a program to guide development there into the next century. **********''Just as the big steamship lines are going to get bigger, the big ports are going to get bigger,'' said Roy Perry, a consultant and former head of the Los Angeles and Tacoma, Wash., ports. Thomas Dowd, professor of port and marine transport management at the University of Washington in Seattle, said, ''If you're not highly competitive, you're not going to be around for long.'' **********Every port's situation is somewhat different. The export-oriented ports of the Northeast, including New York, are stagnating because of the decline of manufacturing in that region and the effects of years of a strong dollar. Ports on the Gulf of Mexico are struggling with the oil slump. Import-oriented harbors, by contrast, especially on the West Coast, are generally flourishing. Los Angeles Port Booms **********The changes being wrought at America's ports are particularly visible here in Los Angeles. The point of entry for many of the goods destined for the huge, affluent Southern California consumer market, and one of the hubs of the growing Pacific Basin trade, the Los Angeles port, along with its neighbor in San Pedro harbor, the Port of Long Beach, has become one of the nation's busiest, fastest-growing and most profitable. **********''We've found ourselves in a much more complex, competitive environment,'' said Steven P. Resnick, the marketing director for the Port of Los Angeles. **********Driving many of the changes is the rise of intermodalism - systems by which huge cargo containers can be transferred between ships and rail or truck lines. Intermodalism has become the transportation method of choice for many shippers since the deregulation of rail and truck rates in 1980 made it much less expensive. **********The effect of the closer links between sea and land transport systems has been to decrease the number of port calls a ship makes. Often, it is cheaper for a ship to make just one or two stops, and have import cargo routed by land to other destinations. Coast-to-Coast Competition **********Cargo now flows to harbors that can move it most quickly and inexpensively, which are not necessarily those closest to the destination. So Los Angeles often finds itself competing not just with neighboring Long Beach, but with New York or New Orleans or Seattle. ''That's the real competitive factor,'' Mr. Dowd said. **********The most visible result has been investment in intermodal facilities. The Los Angeles port, along with Long Beach and the Southern Pacific Corporation, is building a 160-acre, $62 million intermodal rail yard, one of the largest of its kind, at the edge of San Pedro harbor. It will allow many shippers to transfer containers between sea and rail lines without transporting the containers 20 miles by truck to downtown rail yards. **********''Both ports recognized that whatever it costs, they have to have one,'' Mr. Dowd said of the intermodal complex. **********Without it, they would have been at an increasing competitive disadvantage. Tacoma, for example, which built on on-dock intermodal yard in 1981, has in the last several years won a growing share of West Coast container traffic, especially that headed to the Midwest and the East Coast. Managing the Land **********The rise of containerized shipping, which has grown to dominate the industry in the last 20 years, and the demand for efficient loading and unloading have also placed a premium on land management. Land around most harbors is scarce, and must be allocated and leased by port authorities to insure most efficient use of the space and to keep cargo moving the fastest. **********Most of the space is set aside for containers. They carry high-value cargo, such as television sets and clothes, rather than bulk commodities like coal, and the competition is most fierce for them. **********Container traffic in Los Angeles grew nearly 14 percent last year and is projected to rise steadily for many years. The new $30 million terminal for Mitsui is just one example of how the port is coping with the increase. **********Another $43 million is being spent on two other new container terminals that will be used by other lines. Each will have the most up-to-date cranes and conveyor systems to keep the containers moving rapidly, and added space for container storage. Moving Inland **********To make room for the containers, auto storage facilities are being moved farther inland, as have smaller operations such as a grain storage terminal. **********Port managers are lucky in at least one respect: They can create more space by dredging and using the fill to build new wharves. The Los Angeles port is creating a new 350-acre pier by deepening part of the harbor. **********Port officials said, however, that it was no longer enough to have good facilities and efficient operations. Such complexes need a hard sell, because other ports boast of similar improvements. **********''You can't just take someone out to lunch anymore and expect to get their cargo,'' Mr. Dowd said. ''Now you have to come in with a computerized study of cargo movement.'' Offices Overseas **********Almost all big ports have marketing offices in foreign cities. Los Angeles has representatives in Tokyo, Taipei, Seoul, Hong Kong, Singapore, London, Copenhagen and Melbourne, Australia - and is hoping to open offices soon in Rio de Janeiro and in Santiago, Chile. ''We're as competitive in the international arena as an I.B.M. or a Boeing,'' said Mr. Resnick, the port's marketing director. **********In the case of Los Angeles, the improvements and the marketing appear to have paid off. Last year, 51.1 million tons of cargo moved through the port, up 13 percent from the year before. Revenues, which are generated by land rentals and a tariff on cargo, increased 24 percent, to $115.5 million. Net income of $58 million was 19 percent higher than in 1985. (As a municipal agency, all profits are plowed back into port's capital improvements.) Just as important as overall growth, in the view of some port officials, is winning a greater share of the relatively weak export trade, in preparation for the possibility that a weaker dollar or protectionist legislation might curtail imports. ''I want to refocus us to exports,'' Mr. Resnick said. **********Last year, he said, Los Angeles was successful in winning a bigger portion of cotton exports to the Far East. The traditional West Coast exports have been bulk commodities like scrap metal and coal, which fuel industry in Japan and throughout Asia. Last year, bulk commodity exports increased 35.5 percent in Los Angeles. **********While Los Angeles, Long Beach and a few others gain market share in a wide range of imports and exports, smaller ports, including San Diego and San Francisco, are losing ground. That is prompting some experts to suggest that smaller harbors start thinking about specializing in certain cargos to survive. Structural steel, for example, is an unattractive import for many big harbors because it takes up too much space. But for a smaller port without much other business, it might make sense.
