https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/17/world.body_text: **********The Chinese Government ordered four southern provinces to act urgently to stop the flow of Vietnamese settlers from China to Hong Kong, the New China News Agency said today. **********A Chinese official in Hong Kong was quoted as saying that the executive body of China's central Government ordered the provinces to step up marine patrols. **********Orders were also issued to punish severely anyone encouraging the settlers to flee China and to squelch rumors of an amnesty for refugees in Hong Kong. **********A Hong Kong official said last week that some of the Vietnamese reaching there had mentioned such rumors as a reason for the exodus.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/14/busin.body_text: **********State and Federal telephone regulators could not agree today on whether to increase the $2-a-month ''subscriber line charge'' residential customers pay for local phone lines. **********An advisory committee of state regulators and Federal Communications Commission members worked most of Thursday afternoon trying to agree on a plan in time for this afternoon's scheduled meeting. **********But agreement could not be reached between F.C.C. members, who want to raise the charge, and state regulators, who are resisting that approach. The meeting was rescheduled to next month, but no date was set. **********The dispute is over the charge subscribers pay toward the cost of the wire that connects a customer with the phone company's central office. Those line costs are shared with long-distance callers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/20/world.body_text: **********Despite the plummeting stock market, his wife's illness and the military action in the Persian Gulf, President Reagan was described by White House aides today as ''surprisingly upbeat.'' He was ''bouncy and buoyant,'' even cracking jokes, though he was coming out of an extraordinarily difficult weekend. **********White House officials were looking over the weekend ''for signs that he might be distracted, depressed'' because of the events of the last several days, a senior aide said. ''But we didn't see them.'' **********A few hours after his wife underwent breast cancer surgery on Saturday, the President had to decide on what sort of action the United States would take in the Persian Gulf. **********Then today the stock market had its second worst fall since World War I. Mr. Reagan handled all these events with the ever-present optimism that, friends and associates say, is at the root of his personality. Optimistic on Economy **********Speaking at the swearing-in of Commerce Secretary C. William Verity this afternoon, Mr. Reagan spoke optimistically about the economy in general. But he did not mention the stock market. **********Later the White House issued a statement saying Mr. Reagan was concerned about the market but remained confidant that the economy was sound. When he arrived at Bethesda Naval Hospital this evening to visit his wife, he had a broad grin on his face as he held up a get well sign. **********The President ''certainly isn't enjoying any of this,'' a senior White House official said. ''But those here who might have worried that he would not be able to hold up have been proved wrong, thankfully.'' **********Officials say the President has depended on his wife even more than usual in the last year or so, after some of his closest aides left Government and the Administration became mired in the Iran-contra affair. That is one reason that word of Mrs. Reagan's illness brought more than the normal disquiet at the White House. **********But in this case, as in others, Mr. Reagan assumed ''that all things will turn out well, even in those circumstances when it really looks like they might not,'' a friend said. 'Confident, Comfortable' **********The President waited until after he had been told the results of his wife's surgery before making a decision to order an attack on Iranian offshore platforms in the Persian Gulf. He briefed Congressional leaders on the decision Sunday night, just a few hours before the attack was mounted. **********''During the meeting he was confident, comfortable,'' said Representative Thomas S. Foley, Democrat of Washington, who was present. **********At his weekly lunch with senior staff members this afternoon, ''he was in remarkably good spirits, given everything,'' said an official who attended. ''He was cracking jokes, telling stories. He was obviously feeling good about the progress of his wife.'' **********At the lunch, one participant said, ''There was a lot of interest in what was going on in the stock markets.'' **********''The President got mixed analyses,'' an aide said. 'He was showing what I would call tempered concern.'' In the evening, another aide said, ''He is watching it closely.'' **********But a senior official said the President's view of the stock market's precipitous fall was consistent with his ''generally Pollyanna-ish attitude toward most things.'' **********''It was sort of, 'This too shall pass.' ''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/16/busin.main_headline: AREA RETAIL SALES BEST IN 3 YEARS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/16/busin.print_headline: AREA RETAIL SALES BEST IN 3 YEARS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/16/busin.body_text: **********In 1986, a year that saw the closing of two major retail chains, Gimbels and Ohrbach's, retail sales in New York and the surrounding suburbs were the strongest in three years. **********Increased purchases by affluent consumers were cited for the year-to-year average sales gains of 6.9 percent in the city and 6.7 percent in the metropolitan area. But buying was markedly slower on the part of middle- and lower-income shoppers, who were under pressure from debt and employment concerns, retailers said. Sales results covering last month and the fiscal year ended Jan. 31, were obtained in a monthly spot-check of some of New York's major retailers. **********Over all, retail business in the area gained from a booming stock market, the increased activity in the legal and medical professions and in such fields as communications, technology and finance, as well as from increased numbers of foreign tourists. **********''If anything, New York business benefited from the city's unique complexion, the many people who live here, work here and travel here,'' observed James Posner, a retail marketing consultant. Strong Business in New York **********Indeed, executives of chains with major stores in other cities said that their New York business last year reflected larger increases than their stores in other cities. **********''Bloomingdale's sales rise was greater in Manhattan than in such other cities as Boston, Washington, Philadelphia, Dallas and Miami,'' said Julian Taub, Bloomingdale's vice president for planning. He cited the continuing renovation of the Bloomingdale's flagship store and the increased number of foreign visitors to the city. **********Saks Fifth Avenue had a double-digit sales rise in its New York store that made it ''among the five or six top performing stores in our chain of 44,'' said Paul Leblang, senior vice president, marketing. **********At Lord & Taylor, which operates 46 stores, the New England stores had the biggest gains, with the New York area group close to them, said Marshall Hilsberg, the chairman and chief executive. ''Business was generally good, stronger in the first three quarters than in the last, but that quarter was quite acceptable and above our plan.'' **********The year's sales strength came in the middle rather than in the latter months for most retailers. In January, the fiscal year's final month, the average sales gains were up only 3.7 percent in the city and 5 percent in the area, compared with the year earlier. This followed a rather disappointing December - a season when business usually explodes - but that month's median gains were only 3.8 percent higher in the city and 5.8 percent in the area. In the hot summer months, however, when retail sales should subside, the rises in the city were 8.2 percent in July, 13.2 percent in August and 12.6 percent in September. **********In 1985, the top stores had smaller sales gains of 1.2 percent in the city and 2.6 percent in the area, while in 1984 the rises were 6 percent and 6.7 percent, respectively. Two-Way Scramble **********A two-way scramble developed during the year among the big retailers, for disparate reasons. **********R. H. Macy, seeking to sharply increase sales and profits to accelerate payments on its leveraged-buyout debt, intensified its price-cutting efforts. As a result, major rivals, such as Abraham & Straus, Stern's and others, found themselves were swept into a continuous price-slashing competition. **********And the closings of the 10 Gimbels department stores and six Ohrbach stores generated an intensive effort among the remaining chains to win the $300 million-plus in sales that were set loose. Much of it, merchants said, was picked up by smaller retailers catering to lower-income customers. **********''Generally, business was pretty good during the year and a very decent one in 'comparable' stores, those that are at least a year old,'' said Lawrence Stone, president and chief executive of the Stern's department stores. Stern's has acquired two Gimbels store sites, in Yonkers and Garden City, L.I., and will reopen them as Stern's stores soon. ''But the environment was as competitive as in any recent year. It's nonsense to say, as some claim, that because they had their inventories well in line, it wasn't a highly promotional year. Macy's took care of that.'' **********But another retail executive, who requested anonymity, said: ''The higher-priced stores did well, but for everyone else it was a hard year. The consumer was generally a reluctant shopper. Heavy price-cutting hurt profit margins. It appears that those stores with a definite merchandising point-of-view did well but the others struggled.'' Strong Merchandise Categories **********Among the better-performing retailers, business last year was mostly good to strong in all merchandise categories. In home goods, top sales were in linens, blankets and sheets, china, glass and giftware, and non-electric housewares. But among department stores consumer electronics had disappointing sales compared with 1985, when gains were huge, mostly because of the great popularity of video cassette recorders and compact disk players. In soft lines, 1986 was ''a good dress year,'' as Mr. Stone of Stern's put it, and good sales were recorded in shoes, brand names, women's sportswear and men's wear. **********But the lack of any perceptible sales boom from the Gimbels-Ohrbach disappearance and the much better showing of stores catering to the affluent may indicate that New York, especially Manhattan, is moving further into a higher-priced market, according to Mr. Posner, the consultant. **********''New York is unlike any other city, because it has little or no presence from the major, mass-volume chains like Sears, K Mart or Penney's,'' he said. ''But it is seeing great, upscale growth, from such specialty retailers as the Limited, Polo and the Italian chains. Manhattan, in particular, seem to be going that way. The ultimate mecca for international and domestic tourists may be becoming one for the affluent residents, too.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/11/world.main_headline: Montreal Journal; A City's Blacks, No Longer Merely Les Invisibles
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/11/world.print_headline: Montreal Journal; A City's Blacks, No Longer Merely Les Invisibles
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/11/world.body_text: **********Anthony Griffin could scarcely have guessed that an argument with a cab driver here last month would end with Mr. Griffin dead in the parking lot of a police station, victim of a police bullet in the forehead. Much less could he have known that this would become a landmark in the troubled history of one of Quebec's forgotten minorities. **********Mr. Griffin, 19 years old, was one of 120,000 blacks in this city of 2.8 million, a member of an ethnic group that traces its origins back to the establishment of French settlement. According to a recent history of blacks in the province, the first black man to set foot here, Matthew da Costa, came in 1632 with Samuel de Champlain, the French navigator who founded Quebec; da Costa spoke the Micmac language, essential in Champlain's dealings with Indians. **********That footnote, little known in this province of 6.5 million, lends irony to the situation developing in the last 20 years, as Caribbean migrants have multiplied. According to community leaders, being black in Quebec has meant standing on the sidelines of the ethnic struggle here, the push by Quebec's French-speaking majority for broader language and political rights. **********''In Quebec, it is being French-speaking that counts,'' said Dorothy Williams, a historical researcher who works at the Negro Community Center, the oldest of a dozen or more black organizations. ''It's not a question of the black man having got lost; the fact is, he was never found.'' Charged With Manslaughter **********Since the Griffin shooting on Nov. 11, the problems of blacks in Quebec have received wider attention than they received in years. The incident prompted the establishment of an official inquiry, under the Quebec Human Rights Commission, into relations between police forces across the province and racial minorities; and the policeman who killed the black teen-ager, Constable Allan Gosset, has been charged with manslaughter. **********Neither measure satisfied blacks; most demanded a murder charge and questioned whether the Human Rights Commission was capable of a fair inquiry. Ilma Lynton-Holt, executive director of the Negro Community Center, founded 70 years ago, said this was a ''runaround.'' **********According to the police, the incident began with a radio call from a taxi driver complaining that a passenger, Mr. Griffin, was refusing to pay. A police computer check at the scene showed that he was wanted in connection with breaking and entering; he was driven to the police station, where he tried to flee. According to the first police account, Constable Gosset, 38, called on him to halt, then fired; later, the police acknowledged that the youth had stopped and turned around before being killed. **********Constable Gosset was suspended without pay. But it was 10 days before he was charged, and by that time 2,000 protesters, including many whites, had marched on the Palais de Justice. Public concern was heightened after the disclosure that Constable Gosset, a 16-year police veteran, had been accused of a previous racial assault, involving a Ghanaian professor who said he was beaten by the officer in 1981. Then, the police paid an out-of-court settlement of $1,500. Only Surviving Child **********Emotions in the Griffin affair were heightened by the fact that the youth was the only surviving child of a Jamaican immigrant, Gloria Augustus. But among blacks, the incident was seen as the culmination of a pattern of disregard among the authorities going back many years. Many of the problems involve the police; others involve charges of discrimination in housing, in public and private employment and in schools. **********In Canada, Montreal is far from the only city that has had to absorb a growing nonwhite population. Since a change in immigration policy in the late 1960's, hundreds of thousands of people from Asia and the Caribbean have settled here, changing major cities like Montreal, Toronto and Vancouver, and spreading out to more remote communities across the Atlantic provinces and the prairies. There are close to 500,000 blacks and perhaps 1.5 million Asians in Canada. **********If the going has been rougher for the immigrants in Montreal, black leaders believe it may be because the city has been absorbed with the fight for advancement of French Canadians, a minority within the country at large but overwhelmingly preponderant in Quebec. The fight, recurrent for a century, ignited in earnest in the 1960's, just as the black community began to grow with migrants from Jamaica, Grenada and Haiti. **********The largest of the black groups in the city are the 40,000 Haitians, coming in as refugees. Although speaking French as a mother tongue has made assimilation somewhat easier - all six of the black police officers in the city are from Haiti - the Haitians have also proved in some respect to be the most assertive, clashing more often with the police and city authorities. **********According to Ms. Lynton-Holt, 42, the new arrivals changed a group that traced its roots to slaves brought here from Africa and the Caribbean in the 18th and early 19th centuries, and to American blacks, some of them also slaves, who fled here between the Revolution and the Civil War. Close-knit and conservative, the blacks worked as porters on the railroads, as domestic servants, rarely coming to public attention. University Protest in 1969 **********Before the Griffin killing, the only major upheaval occurred in 1969, when Caribbean students at Sir George Williams University, protesting against a biology professor who had given low marks to black students, occupied the university computer center, then burned it down. But that outburst, resulting in millions of dollars in damage, did little to advance the black cause among whites; this time, blacks say, white sentiment is strongly on their side. **********One ally is Marvin Rotrand, a 36-year-old city council member who sits on the Police Commission. Mr. Rotrand, a member of an insurgent political movement that swept City Hall elections in November 1986, is spearheading a drive to open up the police complaints procedure, to insure that civilians, not police officers, are in control. **********Mr. Rotrand says he believes that many French Canadians, particularly in the police force, are having trouble adjusting to the idea of Quebec as a multiracial society. In part, he and black leaders say, this is because Quebec educational policies for decades pushed the children of black immigrants into English-speaking schools, a policy reversed in the 70's. **********Mr. Rotrand recalled how his father, survivor of 30 months in Auschwitz, had struggled for acceptance as an immigrant in Montreal after the war. ''Then, too, Quebecers prided themselves on being a particularly tolerant society,'' he said. ''But I've always thought that that was a lot of hokum. In these things, people here are much like everyone else; it takes time for them to adjust.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/15/world.main_headline: REAGAN REJECTS SALVADORAN PLEA ON ILLEGAL ALIENS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/15/world.print_headline: REAGAN REJECTS SALVADORAN PLEA ON ILLEGAL ALIENS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/15/world.body_text: **********President Reagan today turned down a plea from the President of El Salvador to give temporary refuge to thousands of Salvadorans living illegally in this country. **********The State Department said the United States had decided that it could not make an exception to the new immigration law, despite an impassioned request President Jose Napoleon Duarte made last month. **********Illegal aliens from El Salvador have already begun returning home because they cannot legally be hired in this country. But in a letter to Mr. Duarte, Mr. Reagan said, ''It is unlikely that a large-scale exodus of Salvadorans will occur.'' Mr. Reagan also quoted the United States Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization as saying, ''There will be no large-scale deportations as a result of the new law.'' **********Mr. Reagan's letter was given to Mr. Duarte by Edwin G. Corr, the United States Ambassador to El Salvador. 'Not Surprised' by Ruling **********In Washington, the Salvadoran Ambassador, Ernesto Rivas-Gallont, said in an interview that he was ''saddened but not surprised'' by the decision. **********''We do not want to jeopardize our excellent relations with the United States,'' Mr. Rivas-Gallont said. ''But we feel our main obligation is to our fellow countrymen and women. We will continue to pursue avenues that would allow Salvadorans to remain in the United States for such time as necessary until the situation in El Salvador becomes normal. Then we can program an orderly return of our people.'' **********The new law, the Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986, prohibits employers from hiring illegal aliens, but offers legal status, or amnesty, to illegal aliens who can prove that they entered the United States before Jan. 1, 1982, and have lived here continuously since then. Economic Impact Feared **********In a letter dated April 10, Mr. Duarte asked Mr. Reagan to let the Salvadorans remain temporarily in this country. He said that ''the massive return of Salvadorans from the United States would add to the already disastrous levels of unemployment and economic crisis'' in his country. **********He said 400,000 to 600,000 Salvadorans, representing about 10 percent of his country's population, had entered the United States illegally since January 1982 and thus would not qualify for amnesty under the new law. Mr. Duarte said these people sent home remittances of $350 million to $600 million a year. **********In his letter to Mr. Duarte, President Reagan said he had asked Secretary of State George P. Shultz ''to bring your concerns to the urgent attention of the Department of Justice and the Immigration and Naturalization Service, and to work with them to insure that the effects you fear do not occur.'' **********Administration officials said it was unlikely large numbers of Salvadorans would return home, even though the new law was designed to encourage the departure of illegal aliens. **********Under the law, employers may continue to employ illegal aliens who were hired before Nov. 6, 1986, when President Reagan signed the immigration bill. But these aliens are locked into their current jobs; they cannot legally be hired by any other employer. **********Elliott Abrams, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, said last month that he supported Mr. Duarte's request. But Administration officials said it had been opposed by other Presidential appointees, including Mr. Nelson, Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d and Michael H. Armacost, the Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs. **********Mr. Duarte had asked Mr. Reagan to defer the deportation of Salvadorans by giving them a special status known as ''extended voluntary departure.'' The Justice Department has granted a similar dispensations to people from Afghanistan and Poland and, on a more limited basis, to Ethiopians. **********The rejection of Mr. Duarte's request is likely to intensify interest in legislative proposals to defer the deportation of Salvadorans. Such bills have been introduced by Representative Joe Moakley of Massachusetts and Senator Dennis DeConcini of Arizona, both Democrats. Most Seeking Asylum Rejected **********Many Salvadorans have applied for asylum in the United States, but few applications have been approved. In the last fiscal year, the immigration service granted asylum to 55 Salvadorans and denied 1,149 applications. **********To qualify for asylum, an alien must show ''a well-founded fear of persecution on account of race, religion, nationality, membership in a particular social group, or political opinion.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/04/busin.main_headline: SOUTH AFRICA REACTS ANGRILY TO SULLIVAN CALL
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/04/busin.print_headline: SOUTH AFRICA REACTS ANGRILY TO SULLIVAN CALL
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/04/busin.body_text: **********The South African Government reacted angrily tonight to a call by the Rev. Leon Sullivan for American companies doing business in South Africa to quit the country within nine months. **********Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha said the Philadelphia minister's decision was ''neither in the interests of the workers nor of the United States itself.'' **********In an interview, Mr. Botha continued: ''The South African Government cannot allow itself to be threatened in this way. The Reverend Sullivan suffers from a persecution complex for which, apparently, nothing can be done.'' **********A spokesman for the African National Congress, the main guerrilla-backed nationalist movement fighting to end white rule, welcomed Mr. Sullivan's decision. **********''Good for him,'' the spokesman said. ''We welcome this very much and hope that this will now be followed by full sanctions against South Africa by the U.S. Government.'' **********Last month the Pretoria authorities told Mr. Sullivan that he must cancel a planned five-day visit to South Africa ahead of the May 31 deadline that he had set last year for the eradication of apartheid laws, failing which he would recommend that United States companies cease operations in South Africa. **********Adrian Botha, South African executive director of the American Chamber of Commerce, which represents about 200 United States companies still operating here, including more than 170 that have signed the Sullivan Principles, said he did not believe Mr. Sullivan's move would lead to an exodus of American-owned companies. **********During the last 18 months more than 100 United States companies have pulled out of South Africa, but the exodus has subsided in recent months. **********''We are disappointed,'' the Chamber of Commerce leader said. ''We felt that the Sullivan Principles had been a positive force for change and had done much to improve the quality of life of the disadvantaged in South Africa. I believe U.S. companies here will continue with the Sullivan program. I do not anticipate a sudden turning-off of the tap on social responsibility programs.'' **********American business in South Africa has been criticized by the Pretoria authorities in recent weeks for engaging in a program of civil disobedience against apartheid laws - particularly residential segregation. **********The Sullivan Principles call specifically for corporate defiance of apartheid laws. **********But the United States companies responded to official pressure by reaffirming their intention to continue settling black employees in suburbs intended only for whites in defiance of the law. **********Harry Schwarz, finance spokesman for the reformist Progressive Federal Party, called the Sullivan move ''a short-sighted decision not calculated to encourage peaceful change.'' **********Mr. Schwarz said, ''Whether it is the intention, or not, this move will encourage violent change and will not be helpful in the creation of a pro-Western and democratic economic and political order to follow the present regime.'' **********He said companies were leaving, although they cited political motives, for largely economic reasons because profits had fallen with the recession in the South African economy. **********Meanwhile, the three-year-old anti-apartheid United Democratic Front, the biggest extraparliamentary opposition to apartheid rule, has outlined its plans for two weeks of protest and work stoppages between June 12 and 26 in a bid to rally opposition to renewal of the 12-month-old nationwide state of emergency. **********The emergency was declared on June 12 last year in a bid to suppress three years of internal black resistance to white rule.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/11/world.main_headline: PART I: RESPECT FOR HUMAN EMBRYOS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/11/world.print_headline: THE VATICAN ON BIRTH SCIENCE  TEXT OF VATICAN'S DOCTRINAL STATEMENT ON HUMAN REPRODUCTION; PART I: RESPECT FOR HUMAN EMBRYOS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/11/world.body_text: **********Following is the text a Vatican doctrinal statement, ''Instruction on Respect for Human Life in Its Origin and on the Dignity of Procreation: Replies to Certain Questions of the Day,'' issued yesterday: **********Careful reflection on this teaching of the Magisterium and on the evidence of reason, as mentioned above, enables us to respond to the numerous moral problems posed by technical interventions upon the human being in the first phases of his life and upon the processes of his conception.  1. What respect is due to the human embryo, taking into account his nature and identity? **********The human being must be respected - as a person - from the very first instant of his existence. **********The implementation of procedures of artificial fertilization has made possible various interventions upon embryos and human foetuses. The aims pursued are of various kinds: diagnostic and therapeutic, scientific and commercial. From all of this, serious problems arise. Can one speak of a right to experimentation upon human embryos for the purpose of scientific research? What norms or laws should be worked out with regard to this matter? The response to these problems presupposes a detailed reflection on the nature and specific identity - the word ''status'' is used - of the human embryo itself. **********At the Second Vatican Council, the Church for her part presented once again to modern man her constant and certain doctrine according to which: ''Life once conceived, must be protected with the utmost care; abortion and infanticide are abominable crimes.'' More recently the Charter of the Rights of the Family, published by the Holy See,  [ 23 ]  confirmed that ''Human life must be absolutely respected and protected from the moment of conception.''  [ 24 ] **********This Congregation is aware of the current debates concerning the beginning of human life, concerning the individuality of the human being and concerning the identity of the human person. The Congregation recalls the teachings found in the Declaration on Procured Abortion: ''From the time that the ovum is fertilized, a new life is begun which is neither that of the father nor of the mother: it is rather the life of a new human being with his own growth. It would never be made human if it were not human already. To this perpetual evidence . . . modern genetic science brings valuable confirmation. It has demonstrated that, from the first instant, the programme is fixed as to what this living being will be: a man, this individual-man with his characteristic aspects already well determined. Right from fertilization is begun the adventure of a human life, and each of its great capacities requires time . . . to find its place and to be in a position to act.''  [ 25 ]  This teaching remains valid and is further confirmed, if confirmation were needed, by recent findings of human biological science which recognize that in the zygote * resulting from fertilization the biological identity of a new human individual is already constituted. **********Certainly no experimental datum can be in itself sufficient to bring us to the recognition of a spiritual soul; nevertheless, the conclusions of science regarding the human embryo provide a valuable indication for discerning by the use of reason a personal presence at the moment of the first appearance of a human life: how could a human individual not be a human person? The Magisterium has not expressly committed itself to an affirmation of a philosophical nature, but it constantly reaffirms the moral condemnation of any kind of procured abortion. This teaching has not been changed and is unchangeable.  [ 26 ] **********Thus the fruit of human generation, from the first moment of its existence, that is to say from the moment the zygote has formed, demands the unconditional respect that is morally due to the human being in his bodily and spiritual totality. The human being is to be respected and treated as a person from the moment of conception; and therefore from that same moment his rights as a person must be recognized, among which in the first place is the inviolable right of every innocent human being to life. **********This doctrinal reminder provides the fundamental criterion for the solution of the various problems posed by the development of the biomedical sciences in this field: since the embryo must be treated as a person, it must also be defended in its integrity, tended and cared for, to the extent possible, in the same way as any other human being as far as medical assistance is concerned.  2. Is Prenatal Diagnosis Morally Licit? **********If prenatal diagnosis respects the life and integrity of the embryo and the human fetus and is directed towards its safeguarding or healing as an individual, then the answer is affirmative. **********For prenatal diagnosis makes it possible to know the condition of the embryo and of the fetus when still in the mother's womb. It permits, or makes it possible to anticipate earlier and more effectively, certain therapeutic, medical or surgical procedures. **********Such diagnosis is permissible, with the consent of the parents after they have been adequately informed, if the methods employed safeguard the life and integrity of the embryo and the mother, without subjecting them to disproportionate risks.  [ 27 ]  But this diagnosis is gravely opposed to the moral law when it is done with the thought of possibly inducing an abortion depending upon the results: a diagnosis which shows the existence of a malformation or a hereditary illness must not be the equivalent of a death-sentence. Thus a woman would be committing a gravely illicit act if she were to request such a diagnosis with the deliberate intention of having an abortion should the results confirm the existence of a malformation or abnormality. The spouse or relatives or anyone else would similarly be acting in a manner contrary to the moral law if they were to counsel or impose such a diagnostic procedure on the expectant mother with the same intention of possibly proceeding to an abortion. So too the specialist would be guilty of illicit collaboration if, in conducting the diagnosis and in communicating its results, he were deliberately to contribute to establishing or favoring a link between prenatal diagnosis and abortion. **********In conclusion, any directive or program of the civil and health authorities or of scientific organizations which in any way were to favor a link between prenatal diagnosis and abortion, or which were to go as far as directly to induce expectant mothers to submit to prenatal diagnosis planned for the purpose of eliminating fetuses which are affected by malformations or which are carriers of hereditary illness, is to be condemned as a violation of the unborn child's right to life and as an abuse of the prior rights and duties of the spouses.  3. Are Therapeutic Procedures Carried Out on the Human Embryo Licit? **********As with all medical interventions on patients, one must uphold as licit procedures carried out on the human embryo which respect the life and integrity of the embryo and do not involve disproportionate risks for it but are directed towards its healing, the improvement of its condition of health, or its individual survival. **********Whatever the type of medical, surgical or other therapy, the free and informed consent of the parents is required, according to the deontological rules followed in the case of children. The application of this moral principle may call for delicate and particular precautions in the case of embryonic or fetal life. **********The legitimacy and criteria of such procedures have been clearly stated by Pope John Paul II: ''A strictly therapeutic intervention whose explicit objective is the healing of various maladies such as those stemming from chromosomal defects will, in principle, be considered desirable, provided it is directed to the true promotion of the personal well-being of the individual without doing harm to his integrity or worsening his conditions of life. Such an intervention would indeed fall within the logic of the Christian moral tradition.''  [ 28 ] 4. How Is One to Evaluate Morally Research and Experimentation* on Human Embryos and Fetuses? **********Medical research must refrain from operations on live embryos, unless there is a moral certainty of not causing harm to the life or integrity of the unborn child and the mother, and on condition that the parents have given their free and informed consent to the procedure. It follows that all research, even when limited to the simple observation of the embryo, would become illicit were it to involve risk to the embryo's physical integrity or life by reason of the methods used or the effects induced. **********As regards experimentation, and presupposing the general distinction between experimentation for purposes which are not directly therapeutic and experimentation which is clearly therapeutic for the subject himself, in the case in point one must also distinguish between experimentation carried out on embryos which are still alive and experimentation carried out on embryos which are dead. If the embryos are living, whether viable or not, they must be respcted just like any other human person; experimentation on embryos which is not directly therapeutic is illicit.  [ 29 ] **********No objective, even though noble in itself, such as a foreseeable advantage to science, to other human beings or to society, can in any way justify experimentation on living human embryos or fetuses, whether viable or not, either inside or outside the mother's womb. The informed consent ordinarily required for clinical experimentation on adults cannot be granted by the parents, who may not freely dispose of the physical integrity or life of the unborn child. Moreover, experimentation on embryos and fetuses always involves risk, and indeed in most cases it involves the certain expectation of harm to their physical integrity or even their death. **********To use human embryos or fetuses as the object or instrument of experimentation constitutes a crime against their dignity as humman beings having a right to the same respect that is due to the child already born and to every human person. **********The Charter of the Rights of the Family published by the Holy See affirms: ''Respect for the dignity of the human being excludes all experimental manipulation or exploitation of the human embryo.''  [ 30 ]  The practice of keeping alive human embryos in vivo or in vitro for experimental or commercial purposes is totally opposed to human dignity. **********In the case of experimentation that is clearly therapeutic, namely, when it is a matter of experimental forms of therapy used for the benefit of the embryo itself in a final attempt to save its life, and in the absence of other reliable forms of therapy, recourse to drugs or procedures not yet fully tested can be licit.  [ 31 ] **********The corpses of human embryos and fetuses, whether they have been deliberately aborted or not, must be respected just as the remains of other human beings. In particular, they cannot be subjected to mutilation or to autopsies if their death has not yet been verified and without the consent of the parents or of the mother. Furthermore, the moral requirements must be safeguarded that there be no complicity in deliberate abortion and that the risk of scandal be avoided. Also, in the case of dead fetuses, as for the corpses of adult persons, all commerical trafficking must be considered illicit and should be prohibited.  5. How is one to evaluate morally the use for research purposes of embryos obtained by fertilization 'in vitro'? **********Human embryos obtained in vitro are human beings and subjects with rights: their dignity and right to life must be respected from the first moment of their existence. It is immoral to produce human embryos destined to be exploited as disposable ''biological material.'' **********In the usual practice of in vitro fertilization, not all of the embryos are transferred to the woman's body; some are destroyed. Just as the Church condemns induced abortion, so she also forbids acts against the life of these human beings. It is a duty to condemn the particular gravity of the voluntary destruction of human embryos obtained 'in vitro' for the sole purpose of research, either by means of artifical insemination of by means of ''twin fission.'' By acting in this way the researcher usurps the place of God; and, even though he may be unaware of this, he sets himself up as the master of the destiny of others inasmuch as he arbitrarily chooses whom he will allow to live and whom he will send to death and kills defenseless human beings. **********Methods of observation or experimentation which damage or impose grave and disproportionate risks upon embryos obtained in vitro are morally illicit for the same reasons. Every human being is to be respected for himself, and cannot be reduced in worth to a pure and simple instrument for the advantage of others. It is therefore not in conformity with the moral law deliberately to expose to death human embryos obtained 'in vitro.' In consequence of the fact that they have been produced in vitro, those embryos which are not transferred into the body of the mother and are called ''spare'' are exposed to an absurd fate, with no possibility of their being offered safe means of survival which can be licitly pursued.  6. What judgment should be made on other procedures of manipulating embryos connected with the ''techniques of human reproduction''? **********Techniques of fertilization in vitro can open the way to other forms of biological and genetic manipulation of human embryos, such as attempts or plans for fertilization between human and animal gametes and the gestation of human embryos in the uterus of animals, or the hypothesis or project of constructing artificial uteruses for the human embryos. These procedures are contrary to the human dignity proper to the embryo, and at the same time they are contrary to the right of every person to be conceived and to be born within marriage and from marriage.  [ 32 ]  Also, attempts or hypotheses for obtaining a human being without any connection with sexuality through ''twin fission,'' cloning or parthenogenesis are to be considered contrary to the moral law, since they are in opposition to the dignity both of human procreation and of the conjugal union. **********The freezing of embryos, even when carried out in order to preserve the life of an embryo - cryopreservation - constitutes an offence against the respect due to human beings by exposing them to grave risks of death or harm to their physical integrity and depriving them, at least temporarily, of maternal shelter and gestation, thus placing them in a situation in which further offenses and manipulation are possible. **********Certain attempts to influence chromosomic or genetic inheritance are not therapeutic but are aimed at producing human beings selected according to sex or other predetermined qualities. These manipulations are contrary to the personal dignity of the human being and his or her integrity and identity. Therefore in no way can they be justified on the grounds of possible beneficial consequences for future humanity.  [ 33 ]  Every person must be respected for himself: in this consists the dignity and right of every human being from his or her beginning. *********** The zygote is the cell produced when the nuclei of the two gametes have fused. ************ Since the terms ''research'' and ''experimentation'' are often used equivalently and ambiguously, it is deemed necessary to specify the exact meaning given them in this document. **********1) By research is meant any inductive-deductive process which aims at promoting the systematic observation of a given phenomenon in the human field or at verifying a hypothesis arising from previous observations. **********2) By experimentation is meant any research in which the human being (in the various stages of his existence: embryo, fetus, child or adult) represents the object through which or upon which one intends to verify the effect, at present unknown or not sufficiently known, of a given treatment (e.g. pharmacological, teratogenic, surgical, etc.).

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/22/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********I would like to add a layman's logic to ''What the Bears of Summer Sensed'' (Nov. 8), concerning the stock market drop. Discounting the ''poetry'' of technical explanation, I assume profit drives the market. When the Dow Jones industrial average reached 2,700, few forecasters predicted more than an 11 percent gain to 3,000 into 1988. **********This profit potential was at high risk, not only because of overvaluation of stocks in terms of cost to dividends (which reads as speculative excess) but because of the time span to the next election. Could the party in power cover that stretch with good news? That looked unlikely. I suspected that the Republicans and the Federal Reserve would prompt a correction this year to avoid one happening the summer before the '88 elections. Common sense said get out now.  ROBERT BRYDEN Guilford, Conn., Nov. 9

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/04/busin.body_text: **********Poland and its Western creditor banks have agreed to reschedule almost all the country's commercial bank debt, totaling more than $8 billion, Austria's Creditanstalt bank said today. **********Banking sources said that the deal deferring repayments, worked out in Vienna last week, was effectively an admission that Poland stood no chance of repaying anything but the interest on its debt until well into the 1990's. **********Creditanstalt said in a statement that the agreement covered 95 percent of the principal that Poland is due to repay to the banks up to 1993. **********Under the agreement, which will take effect early next year, Poland will repay its credits over 15 years. Western bankers said that Warsaw had also been given lower interest rates by the banks. **********Poland borrowed heavily in the 1970's in a drive to modernize its economy with Western technology. Its hard-currency debt is expected to exceed $35 billion by the end of this year. **********Apart from its commercial loans, Poland has huge debts with Western Governments.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/13/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: THE recent jump in interest rates did not change Wall Street's opinion of the home building companies - analysts had long since soured on the group. But many are recommending individual building and construction-related companies where special factors may push stock prices higher. **********THE recent jump in interest rates did not change Wall Street's opinion of the home building companies - analysts had long since soured on the group. But many are recommending individual building and construction-related companies where special factors may push stock prices higher. **********''Our position is that it is too late in the cycle to be positive on the group,'' said Jonathan Goldfarb, building analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company. **********This year's caution comes after years of stellar stock performance by the group. From 1982 through 1986, an index of 15 building stocks climbed fivefold, according to Mr. Goldfarb. But this year, these stocks have lagged behind the market's strong advance. And many have even fallen since interest rates first jumped in March. Rising interest rates hurt the homebuilding market by making mortgages more expensive; they also raise builders' costs. From mid-April through mid-August, the stock of the U.S. Home Corporation was off 27 percent and the Pulte Home Corporation was down 5.4 percent. For the second quarter, the building stocks were the worst-performing sector of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. **********Professional investors have been selling the shares. ''Portfolio managers are saying, 'I'm not going to fool around being cute, I'm out of them,'' said Barbara T. Alexander, managing director at Salomon Brothers in New York. **********Few on Wall Street expect the home building stocks in general to provide decent relative returns in the next few years. Many, however, such as Laurence H. Hirschhorn, vice president at the First Boston Corporation in New York, are negative on the group, but positive on individual stocks. He said he had ''never had more buy recommendations in my career.'' **********Investors are cautious or even negative about the building stocks because they perceive that the construction and housing cycles are at or past their tops. ''The fundamentals of the industry are now peaking,'' Mr. Goldfarb said. Inflation-adjusted construction spending, he added, rose to 9.1 percent of the gross national product last year from 7.7 percent in 1982. The analyst expects the figure to fall this year and settle near 5 to 6 percent in 1988. **********Home building in the last few years has been quite strong. Every year since 1983 housing starts have totaled more than 1.7 million, the high end of the normal range, First Boston's Mr. Hirschhorn said. A sustained period of above-average construction such as that is ''extraordinary.'' **********Ms. Alexander said that housing starts would suffer this year because of the problem of ''affordability.'' The cost of new homes is up 12 percent in the first half of 1987, prices of existing homes are up 6 percent, consumer income is up only a bit and mortgage rates are up two percentage points since March. These factors, she said, are ''worse than at any time, other than a few years ago, in the last 20 to 25 years.'' **********Despite the affordability problem, most Wall Street analysts are recommending some ''special situation'' stocks. Mr. Hirschhorn, for instance, favors Armstrong World Industries. The company has increased earnings because of the changes made by Joseph L. Jones, chief executive for the last five years. He has cut costs and sharpened Armstrong's focus by measuring employee productivity by contributions to profits, not sales volume. Mr. Hirschhorn expects the company to earn $3.15 to $3.25 a share this year, up from $2.54 last year. **********Mr. Hirschhorn also favors the Sikes Corporation, which makes ceramic floor tiles. Demand for these tiles has doubled in the last decade, he said, in part because ceramic tiles are now used in hallways, kitchens and other rooms besides bathrooms. He expects the company to earn 95 cents a share this year and $1.30 in 1988. **********Analysts consider the Masco Corporation one of the true growth stocks of the building group. The company has enjoyed expanding earnings for 30 consecutive years and has completed several acquisitions of manufacturers of furniture, plumbing products and bathroom and kitchen fixtures. **********Mr. Goldfarb expects the company to earn $1.95 a share this year, up from $1.56 last year. Next year he is looking for $2.30. The stock is selling at a price-earnings multiple roughly equal to the market's; Ms. Alexander thinks it merits a higher one. **********Merrill's Mr. Goldfarb is recommending stocks of five building-related companies: AFG Industries, Masco, Morgan Products Ltd., Payless Cashways Inc. and Stanley Works. **********AFG makes flat glass used for, among other things, windows in new homes. Demand for it this year has been surprisingly strong. And AFG, Mr. Goldfarb said, should outperform other similar companies in growth and profitability. He anticipates annual earnings growth of 30 percent. The stock sold last week at $28 a share. Its earnings multiple is lower than the overall market's and Mr. Goldfarb thinks it should be at a premium. **********Mr. Goldfarb also likes the stocks of two companies involved in home alterations and repair: Morgan Products, which distributes windows and doors, and Stanley Works, which makes tools and equipment for the do-it-yourself crowd. **********Of course, home building stocks are closely tied to interest rates. Investors who think that rates will be lower rather than higher in the next few months might consider betting against the herd, Ms. Alexander said. Because the building stocks have dropped so low, they would rebound sharply if rates fell.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/12/world.main_headline: INTRUDER ATTTACKS 2 OFFICERS OUTSIDE LONDON PALACE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/12/world.print_headline: INTRUDER ATTTACKS 2 OFFICERS OUTSIDE LONDON PALACE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/12/world.body_text: **********A man attacked two officers with a knife and hammer in the Kensington Palace garden early today but did not get inside, where the Prince and Princess of Wales and other members of the royal family slept, the police said. **********The masked intruder was tackled and handcuffed before he could breach the wall around the 17th-century red-brick palace in southwest London, Scotland Yard reported. The two policemen suffered minor injuries. **********Scotland Yard said the intruder, Bela Mark Stifter, a 27-year-old unemployed man from Reading, 35 miles west of London, had been charged with being equipped for theft and causing bodily harm to the two policemen from the Royalty and Diplomatic Protection Group. **********Kensington Palace, on the western edge of Kensington Gardens near Hyde Park, has been the London home for princes, princesses, dukes and duchesses since the mid-18th century. **********Buckingham Palace said the Prince and Princess of Wales and their two sons, Prince and Princess Michael of Kent and the Duke and Duchess of Gloucester were in their apartments in Kensington Palace when the incident occurred at about 1 A.M. Didn't Penetrate Secure Area **********''We can only point out that the intruder did not manage to get into the secure area of Kensington Palace,'' said a Buckingham Palace press spokesman, John Haslam. **********Princess Margaret, who is the sister of Queen Elizabeth II and also lives at Kensington Palace, is vacationing on the Caribbean island of Mustique. The Prince and Princess of Wales flew to Portugal later today on an official visit. **********Scotland Yard said Patrolman Mark Moraviec had spotted a man wearing a ski mask ''in the gloom close to a garden wall'' and had challenged him. The man threatened the policeman with a hammer and started walking away quickly, but the policeman chased him and called for help, Scotland Yard said. **********Within seconds, Patrolman Moraviec and Christopher Durward-Akhurst, the other policeman, who had rushed to the scene, tackled the man. **********''A violent struggle took place in which both officers were hit on the head with a hammer,'' Scotland Yard said. After being disarmed of the hammer, ''the man produced a bowie knife, and another fierce struggle ensued in which both officers were further injured,'' it said. Dog 'Was Not Required' **********The masked man was overpowered, handcuffed and taken to Kensington police station for questioning. **********Parolman Moraviec, 25, suffered a hammer blow to the chin, and Patrolman Durward-Akhurst, a dog handler, had minor injuries. Scotland Yard said his dog, Tribune, was with him at the time ''but was not required.'' **********Security for the royal family received a thorough overhaul, including $4.5 million worth of new equipment, after an unemployed drifter, Michael Fagin, climbed a drainpipe and got into Queen Elizabeth's bedroom at Buckingham Palace in 1982. **********Despite tighter security, there have been several incidents at royal residences, the latest earlier this month when a man scaled 15-foot gates to enter the Queen's estate at Sandringham in eastern England while she was there.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/17/busin.body_text: **********For exotic fruits, these are the glory days. Increasingly, shoppers who were once content with bananas and oranges are now purchasing fruits they can barely pronounce and never heard of until recently - exotics like the star-shaped carambola, the prickly lychee and the grapefruit-like pummelo. **********Such fruits have been staples for several years in ethnic markets and fancy specialty stores in New York, Chicago and other big cities. Now, however, more and more mainstream retailers - including such giant supermarket chains as Safeway and A.&P. -are beginning to stock them. **********''The turnaround in receptiveness of the average consumer and grocer has been 100 percent in the last five years,'' said Chris Rollins, director of the Fruit and Spice Park in Homestead, Fla., a showcase for locally grown exotica that is operated by Dade County. ''As time goes by, these items get more accepted,'' said Fred DeVries, a consultant at Marketing Standards Inc. in Grandville, Mich. ''The producers are having a tough time filling the demand.'' **********The demand, food experts agree, has been fueled by a number of changes in the American palate. Consumers have become more sophisticated about food and more adventurous. In particular, the experts say, consumers are constantly on the lookout for new ingredients for a healthful diet. **********The growing fascination with exotic fruits comes at a time when retailers are relying more than ever on the produce section of the supermarket, a section that in 1985 contributed an average of 8.2 percent to total store sales and 21 percent to net profits. A way to attract customers, retailers have found, is to keep a wide range of items on the produce shelves. There are 200 items in the average section now, nearly triple the number in the early 1970's, said Nancy Tucker, a nutrition specialist with the Produce Marketing Association, a trade group based in Baltimore. **********Many of the new items are exotics. A typical Safeway store, for example, now carries kiwis, winter melons, Mandarin oranges, persimmons and kumquats, said Felicia DelCampo, a company spokeswoman. **********''We have experimented with a lot of different exotic fruits,'' said Michael Kemp, the produce manager for the Des Moines division of Super Valu Stores Inc., a chain of about 200 supermarkets in Iowa, Nebraska and Illinois. In general, he said, the experiments have paid off. Just a few years ago, he said, ''if we could sell 10 cases of kiwi in a week, that would be a treat. Now we're moving that many a day and better.'' **********''People get tired of eating apples and oranges and bananas all the time,'' Mr. Kemp added. ''I got a jar of kiwifruit preserves in my refrigerator and my kids love it.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/06/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; ROBINS VALUATIONS FAR APART
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/06/busin.body_text: **********Lawyers representing the A. H. Robins Company and some 200,000 women who say they suffered infertility or other injuries from its Dalkon Shield birth control device offered sharply divergent estimates of the value of the claims in a bankruptcy hearing here today. **********The estimates, which ranged from about $700 million to $7 billion, underscored the bitterly conflicting views that had foiled the repeated attempts of Judge Robert R. Merhige Jr. to get the lawyers to fashion a compromise. **********The arguments, and the expert testimony scheduled over the next few days to support them, will form the basis for a ruling by Judge Merhige on whether Robins can proceed with its plan to emerge from the Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection it sought in August 1985 and be acquired by the Rorer Group Inc. Terms of Reorganization Plan **********Robins's reorganization plan includes the creation of a $1.75 billion trust fund to cover the claims by women injured by its intrauterine device. It also would leave Robins's shareholders with Rorer stock worth $30 a share, or $735 million. **********Critics of the plan say it offers too little protection to those injured by the birth control device and too much to the Robins family, which owns 41 percent of the shares, and other shareholders. ''There's no reason under the law for them to get anything if it jeopardizes the recovery of the victims,'' said one lawyer who was observing the proceedings on behalf of a group of claimants. **********Judge Merhige was optimistic after yesterday's presentations that a solution to the long struggle was at hand. ''I think I see the way to go,'' he said in his chambers during an afternoon break, before sequestering himself for a chat with Blackwell Shelley, a bankruptcy judge who aided in the hearings. Meeting of Lawyers Is Set **********At Judge Merhige's urging, lawyers from the parties are meeting tonight to see whether any progress can be made toward an agreement. **********If Judge Merhige determines that the fund is too small, Robins would not be allowed to submit its plan to its creditors and carry out its sale to Rorer, a company based in Fort Washington, Pa., that would become the nation's sixth-largest non-prescription health care company were the takeover completed. Robins makes a wide variety of health care products including Robitussin cough medicine and Chap Stick lip balm. **********Robins's plan could be amended based on Judge Merhige's findings and the new disclosure statement encompassing it presented for his approval as early as next week. Otherwise, a trustee could be appointed to wind up the company's affairs and distribute whatever funds are available to its creditors, including the Dalkon Shield victims. Either way, however, procedural steps and appeals are expected to delay payment of compensation for at least a year. **********James C. Roberts, Robins's lead counsel, said today that 30,000 women have compensable injuries and that 3,000 others could be expected to assert future claims. Based on settlements and court judgments in earlier cases, the company projected that future claims would range between $698 million and $1.215 billion. Company Estimate Attacked **********That analysis was blasted by John Walsh, a Washington lawyer representing a committee of claimants' lawyers. ''Their evidence is going to be an attempt to rewrite history,'' Mr. Walsh said. ''A capped fund of $1.75 billion simply cannot deal with the effects of this calamity.'' **********Mr. Walsh did not specify in his opening statement the number of women who should receive compensation, but he said that the total amount would run between $4 billion and $7 billion. The estimates by Robins and Mr. Walsh bracketed others offered by attorneys representing Robins's shareholders and creditors and its insurer, the Aetna Casualty and Surety Company. **********Aetna's estimate was especially intriguing to the scores of lawyers who packed the courtroom. John Harkins Jr., Aetna's attorney, said that its experts calculated 90,000 women would be entitled to more than nominal payments, on the theory that they would be able to show a plausible connection between the Dalkon Shield and injuries they had suffered. Insurer's Estimate **********''We see the value ranging between $2 billion and $2.5 billion, depending principally on whether the court will require medical proof of Dalkon Shield use,'' Mr. Harkins said. Some claimants' attorneys noted that Aetna's figure was close to Robins's total value as indicated in the Rorer bid. **********They also noted that such a figure would extract the maximum sum possible for Robins and perhaps limit Aetna's own costs. Aetna is a defendant in many of the Dalkon Shield suits. Some victims have charged that it directed early efforts by Robins to defend itself against claims in the 1970's and in doing so prolonged the exposure of the public to the device. **********Mr. Walsh pounced on Aetna's estimate in his presentation, saying, ''That estimate at the very least establishes a base below which the court should not go.''
