https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/28/world.main_headline: A Soviet Voice Of Innovation Comes to Force
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/28/world.print_headline: A Soviet Voice Of Innovation Comes to Force
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/28/world.body_text: **********Cloistered in a research institute in Siberia, a Soviet economist whose views were once considered too radical for public consumption has been openly challenging some of the fundamental principles on which Soviet society and the economy have been based for years. **********The economist, Tatyana Zaslavskaya, said in an interview today at a Soviet-American conference here that she was still not sure if the budding changes under Mikhail S. Gorbachev would succeed. But she said she was optimistic that the Kremlin was no longer guided simply by what she called a strong drive to ''pacify'' the Soviet population. **********''In comparison with the Khrushchev era, much has changed,'' she said. ''There are no longer the dark masses which could be ruled easily, whose minds could be controlled. There are thinking people, who have been educated in how socialism ought to be, and they want it that way.'' **********In the hourlong interview, Miss Zaslavskaya talked about her current project, revising the 50-year-old Stalinist concept of social structure, and shared her views of the current state of the Soviet economy, some of the views startling even by the more liberal standards of Mr. Gorbachev's ''glasnost'' campaign. New Set of Laws Prepared **********She also said a new set of laws intended to set Mr. Gorbachev's initiatives in motion had been completed and was being disseminated among Soviet officials before publication. **********She said she had not yet read the laws in their final form, but she does not expect them to include food price increases, a controversial proposal that she has strongly supported. **********Although she is not a policy maker, Miss Zaslavskaya said she had personal contacts with Mr. Gorbachev, the Communist Party General Secretary, and her opinions are thought to influence the party's economic strategy. **********The soft-spoken Miss Zaslavskaya heads the 50-member Department of Social Problems at the Soviet Academy of Science's economics branch in Novosibirsk. For years, she has been one of the most innovative thinkers in Soviet economics, along with her mentor, Abel Aganbegyan, but her writing was published rarely, and then only in restricted forums. **********Under Mr. Gorbachev, Miss Zaslavskaya has won new public recognition. But she still lives in a shared cottage in Novosibirsk and has little contact with foreigners. Her visit here as part of the official Soviet delegation for the Chautauqua conference is her second trip abroad. 'Some Trouble' in 1983 **********In the interview, Miss Zaslavskaya seemed slightly ill at ease, twisting a tassel from her shawl around her right forefinger as she acknowledged that publication of one of her reports in the West had caused her ''some trouble.'' She was referring to a report she delivered in 1983 to a meeting of economists she organized at her institute. **********''We came to the conclusion that the situation was critical and there was no hope for change under the existing state mechanism,'' she said. ''If you're traveling on an ocean liner, which was going along quickly and then began to lose speed and stopped altogether, there is nothing else to do but go down to the boiler room and find out what's wrong with the engines.'' **********These seem like obvious conclusions, but Miss Zaslavskaya said that they had been ''fairly revolutionary'' for the time and that her work was judged too ''disruptive'' for publication. She said she was shocked when excerpts appeared in Western newspapers five months later. **********''There was a big investigation,'' she said with a small laugh. ''But thanks to the fact that it got out into the West, it was widely read in the U.S.S.R., and all of our leaders read it, too.'' **********Miss Zaslavskaya said she had more hopes for Mr. Gorbachev's changes than those initiated by Khrushchev, who was later deposed. **********''Khrushchev acted in a revolutionary manner, but he was often like a clumsy bear,'' she said. ''The present leadership is not only intelligent, but rational.'' A New Social Model **********One sign of her optimism is a plan to publish by early next year a book that challenges the Stalinist model of the three-class society - peasants, workers and intelligentsia - and seeks to replace it one of her own, which asserts that Soviet power created new social strata not envisioned by classic Marxist-Leninist theory. **********At the top of these ''strata'' - Miss Zaslavskaya will not call them classes - are the bureaucrats who run the Communist Party and Government. Below are the intelligentsia, followed by physical laborers and ''those who cannot be classified simply by where they work.'' **********''These are the pensioners, small nations of the north, the hippies, the vagabonds, people without passports,'' she said, listing groups that are given little attention by the authorities or whose existence is simply not recognized. **********Within those broad strata, she said, she had identified 75 subgroups. **********Arguing in favor of increasing food prices, which are heavily subsidized, Miss Zaslavskaya said subsidies for meat alone cost the Kremlin about $120 billion a year. Subsidies cannot be maintained indefinitely, but price rises must be accompanied by wage increases, she said. **********''There should be dozens of appearances by experts who will explain why this is absolutely necessary, who will explain that all of this will be compensated for,'' she said. ''It is critical that it not be taken by the population just as the latest attempt to lower their standard of living.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/19/world.main_headline: U.S. HAS SPENT $9 BILLION ON MISSLES IT HAS AGREED TO SCRAP
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/19/world.print_headline: MISSLE ACCORD; U.S. HAS SPENT $9 BILLION ON MISSLES IT HAS AGREED TO SCRAP
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/19/world.body_text: **********The United States spent nearly $9 billion designing, building and deploying the nuclear missiles that would be scrapped under the terms of an arms limitation treaty with the Soviet Union. **********William Arkin, who compiles nuclear weapons data as part of a project for the Natural Resources Defense Council in Washington, detailed the costs in a note for the October issue of the Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists. He called the Pershing 2 and ground-launched cruise missiles ''expensive bargaining chips'' that will be withdrawn if the treaty being discussed this week by American and Soviet leaders in Washington comes to fruition. **********Mr. Arkin's figures are based on published budget documents. He said today that it is more difficult to estimate Soviet expenditures on missiles covered by the treaty governing medium- and shorter-range missiles, but that he believes the Soviet Union spent a comparable amount to deploy its SS-20 mobile intermediate-range ballistic missiles and shorter-range weapons. **********''We should have just paid them to remove their missiles,'' he said somewhat facetiously of the American investment in missiles, which was begun in the 1970's as part of a NATO strategy aimed at persuading the Russians to dismantle SS-20's and other nuclear missiles aimed at Europe. **********Mr. Arkin said that the Pentagon had spent $3.45 billion on the ground-launched cruise missiles, made by the General Dynamics Corporation, and $2.46 billion on the Pershing 2, made by the Martin Marietta Corporation, excluding the costs of the nuclear devices that the missiles carry. Only $254 million more is left to be spent before the production programs end, and this money is probably already pledged to the firms. **********To buy the nuclear explosives, the Department of Energy has spent more than $1 billion for approximately 485 cruise-missile warheads, and $350 million for about 120 maneuvering re-entry vehicles and nuclear warheads used by the Pershing 2. **********The United States spent $628 million for six cruise-missile bases and five Pershing bases. Training and other expenses probably put the total above $9 billion. There will be some savings in the years ahead as lifetime operating costs are avoided, Mr. Arkin said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/22/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY; ELECTRONIC DEVICES TRACKING PAROLEES
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/22/busin.body_text: **********WITH more criminals being released on probation, understaffed law enforcement departments have begun to use electronic monitoring devices to keep track of them. The program, only two years old, might also have an influence on sentencing practices, some court analysts believe. **********''Right now judges say that often they only have a choice between prison and nothing, but technology can expand those options,'' such as allowing for the sentencing of felons to house arrest or to longer periods of probation, said James K. Stewart, director of the National Institute of Justice, a research arm of the Justice Department. **********The devices, most of which are placed around wrists and ankles, are finding growing acceptance among correction officials. Some critics, however, have voiced constitutional questions about the concept. **********The origin of the electronic monitoring devices was a bit unusual. Judge Jack Love of Albuquerque, N.M., came up with the idea in 1979 after reading an article in the comic strip ''Spiderman,'' in which a villain attached an electronic bracelet to the hero's wrist to track his whereabouts. **********The high-tech skulduggery led Judge Love to discuss the idea with several computer companies, but found no interest. At Honeywell, however, Judge Love, who wanted no stake in any enterprise, met Michael Goss, a marketing representative, who saw merit in the concept. **********Mr. Goss left Honeywell in 1983 and started a company to develop the electronic bracelets. In 1985, BI Inc. of Boulder, Colo,, bought Mr. Goss's company and the first use of the device was made that year for parolees in Michigan. **********Now, more than a dozen companies offer electronic monitoring equipment, which is used by 45 correction agencies, up from 10 last year. Across the country, more than 1,000 parolees, defendants under house arrest or those on probation are being monitored. **********Criminologists expect more jurisdictions to use the systems as officials become more familiar with the technology and as state and local governments, many already under pressure to relieve overcrowded jails, seek alternatives to incarceration. Concern over the spread of AIDS in prisons has also intensified efforts to find alternative sentencing measures for nonviolent offenders. **********The most widely used system is the electronic bracelet or anklet. The offender wears a waterproof, battery-operated transmitter, the size of a pack of cigarettes, which regularly emits an encoded signal. A receiver in the offender's home detects the signal when the transmitter is within 150 feet and reports this information over telephone wires to a so-called host computer in the correctional facility. The information is used to confirm that the offender was at home during specified times. **********Two industry leaders, BI and Correctional Services Inc. in West Palm Beach, Fla., sell host computers for about $15,000. Each host computer can be linked to 200 receivers. The companies also offer transmitters and bands that are tamper-resistant: If they are cut off or damaged, the central computer will alert officials. **********For example, last year Nassau County probation officials, using electronic monitoring devices for nine offenders on probation, discovered through their host computer that one man had not been home on three evenings. He later admitted making nocturnal trips to the home of a woman friend a quarter-mile from his house. This violated his probation and he received a 90-day jail sentence. **********Correction officers hope that the devices will also serve as a constant reminder to the offenders of their arrest, and thus restrain them from breaking the rules of their release. But many believe that the technology is still too new to predict its behaviorial effect on users. **********However, in a study on electronic monitoring, Joseph B. Vaughn, a research associate at the Criminal Justice Center at Sam Houston State University in Huntsville, Tex., said, ''In a small number of cases, the monitor has become a symbol, reminding the person continuously of his transgression, and a crutch, providing the person with an excuse not to participate in activities.'' **********Some critics of the program say that such electronic monitoring constitutes oppressive surveillance, and that public officials should move cautiously before adopting the technology. Civil libertarians have raised constitutional questions about the program, but no court challenges have yet been filed. **********Other critics question the reliability of the devices. Most of the systems use the telephone exchanges, some of which are not sophisticated enough for the monitors. **********For example, some exchanges use modern switching equipment and can handle pulses emitted from the Touch-Tone telephones used in the monitoring program, while others use older equipment and could have trouble transmitting the electronic signals. **********Another potential problem is the effect of some large metal appliances in the home, which may block signal transmission or create an electromagnet field. This can also occur in steel trailers or in stucco houses. **********But advocates of electronic monitoring contend that the technology is vital to help overworked parole and probation officers, many of whom individually monitor 300 people. According to the Department of Justice, 70 percent of convicted felons are released on probation, and 1.9 million people currently live outside of prison under some form of supervision. **********Some entrepreneurs, who say the transmitters are stigmas - like electronic scarlet letters - have developed monitors to track offenders without attaching devices to their bodies. **********One system relies on computerized voice identification. At the beginning of the supervision period, a computer makes a record of the offender's voice. To insure that the offender is at a designated location, the computer is programmed to call the person at a specified time and request that a series of phrases be repeated. They are then matched with the earlier recording. Vox Tron Systems Inc., in New Braunfels, Tex., has been selling voice-identification computers since the end of last year. **********Another system uses visual verification. Since last November, Luma Telecom Inc., a subsidiary of Mitsubishi Electric Sales America Inc. of Santa Clara, Calif., has sold telephone units that transmit black-and-white still pictures of the callers on a three-inch diagonal screen. The company says the system provides a more personal touch by permitting the offender and official to see each other. **********Other companies are trying to enter the market with products that serve two functions. Behavioral Systems Southwest of Pomona, Calif., is developing a wristwatch that has an algorithm function to generate a four-digit code number. A host computer will call the offender and instruct that the time and code number on the watch be entered into the computer by pressing the corresponding numbers on a Touch-Tone phone. The code numbers, which change every minute, have been synchronized with the computer. ''Everytime the telephone rings, the person will think he's being checked on, even if he's not,'' said Ted Nissen, the company's president. **********And Mr. Nissen has not forgotten fashion - black watches for men, white for women.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/03/busin.main_headline: VOLCKER FEARS INFLATION IF DOLLAR KEEPS FALLING
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/03/busin.print_headline: VOLCKER FEARS INFLATION IF DOLLAR KEEPS FALLING
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/03/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Reserve Board chairman, Paul A. Volcker, warned today that the dollar's decline in currency markets was approaching worrisome levels that threatened a revival of inflation and a rise in interest rates. **********Although Mr. Volcker stopped short of asserting that additional depreciation of the dollar would be entirely unwelcome, he did appear to counsel the Reagan Administration against efforts to ''talk'' the dollar down to spur world growth and thereby narrow the country's record trade deficit. **********''A declining dollar at some point has high costs and risks,'' Mr. Volcker told the Joint Economic Committee of Congress. ''It generates inflationary pressures.'' Moreover, he added, ''Uncertainties about the future direction of currency values could dampen the willingness of others to place or maintain funds in the United States - funds upon which, for the time being, we are utterly dependent'' to finance much of the deficit in the Federal budget. Mr. Volcker's views, well known in the credit markets, did not have much impact there, although Treasury notes and bonds fell by as much as 3/8 point.  [ Page D21. ]  Increased Risk of Inflation In response to questions, the Fed chief said that while nobody could tell at what particular point a fall in the dollar was no longer benign, the risks of inflation had clearly increased because of the higher prices of imported goods. ''We are at more dangerous point now,'' Mr. Volcker declared. **********In an appearance lasting more than two hours, Mr. Volcker also made these points: *********** The ''buoyancy'' of financial markets these days should be used to strengthen balance sheets and not be dissipated in ''excessive leveraging and financial risk-taking.'' *********** The trade deficit, which fell sharply in December, seems to have ended its deterioration, ''but signs that the corner has been turned are not yet decisive.'' *********** There is evidence of a developing ''impasse'' over third world debt. *********** Taiwan was a particular culprit on trade. He said that it maintains restrictive import practices that are ''certainly not appropriate today.'' **********As he has done on numerous occasions, Mr. Volcker emphasized the importance of reducing the American budget deficit, which is closely tied to the trade deficit, because foreigners would not be able to buy Treasury securities without the money they obtain by selling their goods in this country. **********He also renewed the American call for West Germany and Japan to spur their economies so they consume more of both their goods and ours. **********When the committee's chairman, Paul S. Sarbanes, a Maryland Democrat, suggested that these countries might have already done enough, by cutting their central-bank lending rates, Mr. Volcker said he worried ''that their growth momentum is in danger of being too little, rather than too much.'' Impact of Weak Dollar **********But it was the weak dollar and its implications for renewed inflation that seemed of equal concern to Mr. Volcker today. Although he said he did not see any immediate inflationary threat - in fact, he referred to ''a sense of cumulating movements toward price stability'' in the manufacturing sector - he noted that there were real risks of an eventual surge in the price level. **********''My concern is that when you get pressures this year, which are more or less inevitable, from rising import prices and from the higher oil price, if that's maintained'' he said, ''the Consumer Price Index won't look as good.'' He added, ''Can we avoid that feeding back into wage and other cost trends and building in cumulative inflationary pressures?'' **********In a separate development today, Senator Lloyd Bentsen, Democrat of Texas, circulated to colleagues the outline of what he declared a bipartisan comprehensive trade bill that is expected to be introduced as early as this week. Mr. Bentsen, the new chairman of the Finance Committee, said that John C. Danforth, Republican of Missouri, was the principal co-author.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/24/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Telex Seeks Other Suitors
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/24/busin.body_text: **********The Telex Corporation disclosed that it had held negotiations with unidentified third parties interested in acquiring the company for more than the $65 a share offered by the New York investor Asher B. Edelman in a hostile bid. **********In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Telex, a computer products company based in Tulsa, Okla., said its board had authorized an investigation of ''possible alternatives'' to Mr. Edelman's offer, including a sale of the company to a third party, a management-led buyout, or a recapitalization. **********Telex told the S.E.C. that it was unable to take a position on Mr. Edelman's offer because of the ''present unsettled state of the stock markets generally and the recent volatility in the market price of the company's common stock.'' **********Mr. Edelman told Reuters today that he had no plans to revise or drop his offer. **********Telex's stock, which fell to as low as $34 a share early this week, closed today at $50.75, up $3.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/04/world.main_headline: Tankers in Gulf: Big Targets, but Hard to Sink
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/04/world.print_headline: Tankers in Gulf: Big Targets, but Hard to Sink
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/04/world.body_text: **********Although belligerent forces in the Persian Gulf have been attacking ships at a rate of about four a day during the last week, relatively few tankers have sustained heavy damage. Experts say the reason is that neither Iran nor Iraq can afford frequent use of the expensive munitions needed to destroy large tankers. **********Despite the battering inflicted on gulf shipping by machine-gun fire, small cannon and rockets, crew casualties have been comparatively light, and most damage has been easily repaired. **********A Defense Department spokesman said intelligence officials had been unable in most cases to determine which missiles were used in the attacks. But other military informants noted that the Iranian Revolutionary Guard is essentially a guerrilla organization, and that its small boats, armed with light guns and infantry anti-tank missiles, were unsuited to naval warfare except for harassing operations. **********Iran is believed to have about three American-made Harpoon anti-ship missiles, as well as an unknown number of Chinese-made HY-2 (Silkworm) adaptations of the Soviet SS-N-2 Styx anti-ship missile. Iraq is fairly well supplied with Soviet missiles and the potent French-built Exocet AM-39. These missiles are all devastating. The Exocet, for instance, can ram a 400-pound explosive warhead deep inside a ship just above the waterline before exploding. Difficult to Shoot Down **********An anti-ship missile can be launched by an airplane, helicopter, small vessel or shore installation from distances up to about 40 miles from their targets. Flying a few feet above the ocean surface at nearly the speed of sound, they track their targets with radar and are very difficult to evade or shoot down. **********But anti-ship missiles of this class are costly and difficult for the gulf antagonists to acquire. A single Harpoon missile, for instance, costs well over $1 million, and industry experts say the price of an Exocet is probably about $250,000. Moreover, even the battle-tested Exocet - it was the missile used against the American warship Stark in the gulf in May - can easily fail to destroy a large tanker, experts say. **********Naval architects and shipping officials who asked that they not be identified said a typical 1,000-foot tanker was not easy to sink; in some respects, it may be even less vulnerable to attack than a warship. **********The steel plating covering the hull of such a ship varies in thickness from 22 millimeters on the sides to 26 millimeters along the bottom, a little under and a little over one inch, which is ample for stopping most machine-gun bullets. Rockets of any caliber can easily penetrate such plates, but a missile explosion inside a tanker is muffled by the crude oil that fills cargo compartments, and crude oil is unlikely to catch fire, even when exposed to a warhead explosion. **********If a missile should blow a huge hole in a 1,000-foot tanker's hull, the effect, a Coast Guard expert said, would be to flood one of up to 17 cargo compartments. This would merely lower the ship in the water without putting it in danger of sinking. Weapons Relatively Cheap **********But although the use of anti-ship missiles in the Persian Gulf has been rare, attacks using small missiles, including infantry anti-tank rockets, have occurred often. Such missiles can cause extensive damage to a merchant ship's bridge or crew quarters, and the weapons are relatively cheap. An American Light Antitank Weapon (LAW), a shoulder-fired missile, costs $348, and a Soviet equivalent, the ''rocket-propelled grenade,'' is believed to carry a comparable price tag. **********Iran's hit-and-run naval forces are also believed to carry some American missiles with greater ranges and striking power, including the Dragon and the TOW, both wire-guided missiles designed to penetrate tank armor. (The TOW figured in American efforts to bargain for the release of hostages held by Iranian-backed terrorists in Lebanon.) The TOW, with a warhead six inches in diameter, can be fired at targets up to two miles away. **********Industry experts acknowledge that in some cases, tankers could face mortal danger from even small missiles. **********''I'd hate to be on a gasoline tanker if a missile hit an empty compartment,'' one said. Such a compartment, he explained, might contain an explosive mixture of gasoline fumes and air, and even a small missile might set it off. Some gasoline is still being shipped through the gulf, he said, although most tankers transport crude oil. **********Under international law, tankers of more than 40,000 tons net displacement are required to flush oxygen from empty crude oil compartments, thereby eliminating the explosion hazard. This is done by sending exhaust gas from diesel engines, rich in fire-quenching carbon dioxide, into the empty oil tanks. Double Hulls for Liquid Gas **********Tankers carrying liquid petroleum gas, which is very flammable, must be built with double hulls, in which the inner hull is separated from outer hull plating by up to two feet. This separation, experts say, would probably reduce the explosion hazard posed by a missile's impact. **********In common with other ships, tankers are vulnerable to hits on their engine rooms and stern steering machinery. Although these areas are relatively difficult for gunners to hit, they are essential to a ship's operation. **********In any case, operators of oil tankers are profoundly worried by the situation in the gulf. **********''A lot of us have discussed options for strengthening the defenses of tankers against missiles and projectiles,'' one said, ''but in the end, we haven't come up with anything practical. The main consolation is that a tanker is in the danger zone for only two or three days. We all just keep hoping to continue to squeak through.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/22/world.main_headline: U.S. Praises Soviet for War Games' Role
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/22/world.print_headline: U.S. Praises Soviet for War Games' Role
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/22/world.body_text: **********State Department officials praised Soviet officials today for cooperating fully last month with the first ''on demand'' inspection by American military officers of a Soviet military exercise on Soviet territory. **********They said the Russians had promptly complied with the American request to carry out a snap inspection of a Russian military exercise in Byelorussia. **********The request was made under an agreement concluded last year in Stockholm on measures aimed at building trust on military matters between the Soviet bloc and Western countries. **********The officials said United States Army officers were allowed to monitor the exercise closely. Agreement's Provisions **********The Stockholm agreement, signed by 35 nations, requires each signatory government to provide greater openness about military activities. Each side must present a schedule of its exercises and announce individual maneuvers that involve at least 13,000 troops or at least 300 battle tanks. Observers are to be invited to exercises that involve 17,000 troops or more. **********The accord also provides for a limited number of on-site inspections when any nation has doubts about compliance. **********American and other Western officials have previously observed Soviet military exercises at the invitation of Soviet officials. But the inspection carried out last month was the first one on Soviet territory in accordance with a treaty under which American officials could not be refused entry. **********The United States requested the snap inspection last month, after the Soviet Union provided notice of an exercise that it intended to hold involving 16,000 troops and 425 tanks. Visit Was a Test Case **********Americans wanted to make sure that the Russians had provided accurate information about the size and scope of the exercise. They also saw the inspection as an important test case of the verification provisions in the accord. **********''We were very keen to do it right the first time to set the right precedent,'' a State Department official said. ''That was achieved.'' **********According to the State Department analysis, which is expected to be made public, the Russians answered the request within 24 hours, as required. **********A team of four American Army officers flew from Stuttgart, West Germany to Minsk in the Soviet Union in an American aircraft along with Soviet navigators. They arrived within 36 hours of the American request, as required by the agreement. At Minsk, the American team was met by two Soviet generals and translators. A U.S. Request Is Met **********One difference about how to carry out the inspection was settled in favor of the Americans at the very start. In seeking the inspection, the United States had requested the use of two Soviet helicopters to monitor the military exercise. In its official response to the American request, the Soviet Union had offered one helicopter. **********But in Minsk, the American team insisted on two helicopters, as well as vehicles, and that request was met. **********In the Soviet exercise, one tank division simulated an attack from the south. A motorized infantry division defended against that attack. **********The Americans were allowed to use maps, cameras, binoculars and tape recorders. ''The team walked tank lines, visited units and photographed equipment and personnel without interference,'' the State Department analysis said. **********The Americans were not allowed to enter or fly over some sensitive facilities in the area. But this was in keeping with the terms of the agreement. **********The Americans determined that the Russians had complied with the pact. **********Specifically, the Americans determined that the Russian exercise was not larger than forecast by Moscow. Had the exercise involved 17,000 troops, Moscow would have been obliged to invite Western observers, which Moscow had not done. Indeed, according to the American team, the exercise was actually somewhat smaller than forecast.

Ungermann, president of Ungermann-Bass, said his company would consider the proposal but indicated it would say no. Bertil D. Nordin, president of Digital Communications, declined to comment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/29/busin.print_headline: ADVERTISING; Elle Team Ventures Far Afield
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/29/busin.body_text: **********WITH the United States version of the French fashion magazine Elle booming, the partners in the publishing joint venture have decided to give it another go. Their next effort will be a movie magazine, a category that has had its share of publishing failures. **********But this time the property, called Premiere, has been well tested, at least in France, where Hachette Publications brought it to 400,000 circulation in the last couple of years. As in the case of Elle, the French editorial material will be made available to Murdoch Magazines, which will use what it considers relevant. **********John B. Evans, president of the Murdoch organization, estimates that 60 percent of the French content will be used over here. But that is all up to the editor, Susan Lyne, who was in the movie business before serving as managing editor at both New Times and The Village Voice. **********Mr. Evans envisions the magazine as a Rolling Stone for motion-picture fans, tapping into the same kind of passion for movies that Rolling Stone does for music. It will certainly not be a fan magazine, he said, but rather a celebration of the craft. And all of the material used from the French side will deal with American movies. **********The first issue of the American monthly is due out in June, with 300,000 copies to be put on newsstands. A four-color page will go for $8,550 and black-and-white for $6,250. **********Initially, all circulation will come from single-copy sales (at $1.95 each) because of the difficulty of getting good lists of subscription prospects. Subscription lists will have to be built slowly though bingo cards in the magazine, publicity and promotion. **********With so many affluent young adults taking films and their directors so seriously these days, it's no wonder that publishers see great possibilities for an advertising medium. **********Back in 1972, Time Inc. examined the possibilities of such a publication at the same time it was considering a magazine on personal finance and two other publications. It went with Money. **********The category's worst recent failure involved The Movies, a publication that deserved better. It was brought out in 1983 after three years of effort by Joe Armstrong, former publisher of New York, New West and Rolling Stone. It died after five issues, because its Texas angel declined to go beyond his initial $2.5 million investment. Ironically, Mr. Armstrong failed to get additional capital from Daniel Filipacchi of Hachette. **********Another attempt was made in 1979 by Alyse M. Kobin and Andrew Fox, whose magazine was also called Premiere and was distributed free at New York theaters for three issues. The business was then sold and the name was changed to In Cinema. It lasted about two more years, according to Ms. Kobin. Too little advertising, she understood. **********In 1982 Chelsea House Publishers put out Coming Attractions, which lasted for more than a year until lack of advertising pulled down its curtain. **********Mr. Evans of Murdoch said that Premiere would not have a publisher or an ad director and that those functions, as well as others on the business side, would be handled by Carolyn Wall, executive vice president of the Murdoch unit, and Joseph Cece, director of magazine development. **********The American version of Elle was started in the fall of 1985. In its first 12 months it carried 1,082 advertising pages, according to Mr. Evans, who said that the April issue had closed and that the first four months have 602 ad pages, with April alone carrying more than 190, which is 50 pages more than expected. Just for the Elle of it.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/14/world.main_headline: MOSCOW FAMILY CALLS OFF ITS PROTESTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/14/world.print_headline: MOSCOW FAMILY CALLS OFF ITS PROTESTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/14/world.body_text: **********The family of an imprisoned Jewish dissident called off public demonstrations today after plainclothesmen attacked protesters again on a Moscow pedestrian mall. **********Boris I. Begun, the son of the dissident, Iosif Z. Begun, said tonight that the family would press the case with Soviet officials, but would not resume the public protests that had turned into violent confrontations in recent days. **********Soviet officials said today that Mr. Begun would be released promptly if he agreed to sign a statement appealing for clemency and promising not to engage in anti-Soviet activities. **********His son said he would not rule out such a solution, but said he was sure his father would not sign anything that disavowed his written criticism of the treatment of Jews in the Soviet Union. #8 Protesters and 20 Reporters The demonstration today, the fifth this week, involved 8 protesters and was witnessed by about 20 foreign reporters. It was broken up by more than 80 plainclothesmen. **********Three demonstrators were arrested, including Boris Begun, who was sentenced to 15 days in jail. In an unusual arrangement, Mr. Begun was told that he and the others could wait until Monday to begin serving their sentences. **********Vladimir Pimonov, a journalist for a chess magazine who said he was not taking part in the demonstration, was attacked by plainclothesmen when he came to the aid of a protester. He said he was taken to the hospital with bruises on his neck, chest and legs, and released this afternoon. **********Soviet commentaries today portrayed the violence this week as the work of Western correspondents who had orchestrated events to stir up anti-Soviet hatred. **********''They want to see Begun kept in prison and to use the situation to fan anti-Soviet sentiments,'' Dmitri Nikitin, a commentator for the press agency Tass, wrote tonight. **********Today plainclothesmen concentrated much of their force on Western journalists, smashing television cameras and taking three American journalists to a nearby militia station, where they were detained for more than two hours. Crackdown Follows Releases **********The crackdown on the demonstrators contrasted with a week of unusually favorable Western comments on Soviet actions, brought on by the mass release of political prisoners. **********On Tuesday, the chief Foreign Ministry spokesman, Gennadi I. Gerasimov, said that the Soviet Union had pardoned 140 prisoners serving time for political crimes, and that a similar number of cases were being reviewed. **********The prisoner release was mentioned in the Soviet press for the first time this morning, in a single paragraph at the end of a brief report in the Communist Party daily newspaper Pravda. **********There were varying explanations today of why the crackdown had come after a period of apparent domestic change that began with the release of Andrei D. Sakharov from internal exile in the city of Gorky in December. **********One possibility was that Soviet officials had decided to draw a clear line between criticism directed to an audience of Westerners or intellectuals and open displays that would seem to show a slackening of authority. **********Others suggested that the crackdown was intended to pacify forces in the leadership, including police and security officials, who are unhappy about the increased tolerance of dissent. **********Mr. Gerasimov said the plainclothesmen who attacked the demonstrators at the Arbat, the pedestrian mall, were ''vigilantes'' operating without official approval. But a Western reporter who followed two dozen of the men after the violence today watched them board a bus with militia license plates. **********The American Ambassador, Arthur A. Hartman, said today that the crackdown was a case of the authorities reverting to form. **********''What's remarkable here is that the first day's demonstration was permitted,'' he said in an interview, referring to a demonstration Monday that was not disrupted. The violence later, he said ''is just the way those authorities carry out their normal duties.'' **********Mr. Begun is one of several prisoners who has refused to sign the statement demanded by the authorities, according to Western human rights groups. Another dissident who has refused, dissidents said, is Anatoly Koryagin, a psychiatrist who was imprisoned for exposing the use of Soviet mental hospitals to punish dissenters.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/19/busin.print_headline: CONSUMER RATES; AN UPTURN IN YIELDS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/19/busin.body_text: **********Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds rose for the week ended yesterday, reviving speculation about a general upward trend in interest rates. **********Among factors that could contribute to further rate increases would be the Federal Reserve, which has thus far taken a neutral stand; further deterioration in the foreign-exchange value of the dollar, and a strengthening of the economy. **********Analysts at Fidelity Bank in Philadelphia believe that by midyear the economy might show enough of a pickup that inflation concerns could be revived. They also believe interest rates may have risen enough by then to signify an end to nearly two and a half years of near-steady declines. **********The Bank Rate Monitor's national index indicates that the average yield for a six-month C.D. was up three basis points, to 5.95 percent, and the average yield of a bank money market account, which competes with money market mutual funds, was up a basis point, to 5.42 percent. **********At the Treasury's weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, often an influence on what banks and thrift institutions pay on money market accounts and C.D.'s, bill rates were mixed, with no large gains for the first time in four weeks. The three-month bill dropped by six basis points, to 5.66 percent, and the six-month bill rose one basis point, to 5.70 percent. **********Yields also rose on certificates of deposit with longer maturities, with a two-and-a-half-year C.D. up one basis point, to 6.59 percent, and the one-year and five-year certificates up two basis points, to 6.17 percent and 7.15 percent, respectively. **********In the funds market, Donoghue's Money Fund Report said the seven-day compounded average yield for taxable money market mutual funds increased six basis points, to 5.48 percent, while the 30-day compounded average yield declined by one basis point, to 5.48 percent. **********The average maturity of securities held by money market funds decreased to 47 days, from 48 days. **********Assets of taxable money market funds declined $348.4 million, to $223.1 billion. Assets in consumer funds fell $4.5 million, to $164.9 billion, and assets of institutional funds were down $344.4 million, to $58.1 billion. Assets of tax-free funds fell $105.5 million, to $67.1 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/25/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Nasdaq's Architect To Join Hambrecht
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/25/busin.body_text: **********Gordon S. Macklin, architect of Nasdaq, the computerized share price information system for over-the-counter stocks, said yesterday that he would become chairman and co-chief executive of Hambrecht & Quist, the San Francisco-based investment firm. **********Mr. Macklin, 58 years old, has been president of the National Association of Securities Dealers. Nasdaq said it will name a committee this week to look for a new president. **********At a news conference in New York, William R. Hambrecht, the founder of Hambrecht & Quist, said Mr. Macklin will begin work in San Francisco in July and will participate in virtually all of the firm's businesses - sales and trading, underwriting, venture capital and asset management. Hambrecht & Quist, a specialist in the financing of emerging companies, fell on hard times two years ago because of the downturn in high technology. **********Mr. Macklin is among the best-known names in the securities field. In addition to being the paid head of the N.A.S.D., Wall Street's self-regulatory body, Mr. Macklin was for 20 years a senior executive of McDonald & Company, the big investment firm based in Cleveland. **********Mr. Macklin was the principal force behind Nasdaq, the acronym for the N.A.S.D.'s automatic quotation system. Created 17 years ago, shortly after Mr. Macklin's arrival at the N.A.S.D., Nasdaq is a computerized information system that permits competing dealers in over-the-counter stocks to display on computer screens around the country the shares they are offering for sale and the bids they are seeking. It allows investors to execute trades in little-known stocks with the press of a button. **********With more than 150,000 computer terminals tied to the Nasdaq system, the over-the-counter market has become the third largest in the world, after the New York and American stock exchanges. **********''Nasdaq was a major technological advance in information transfer,'' said Stephen Figlewski, a professor of finance at New York University. ''Before Nasdaq, trying to find out who was making markets in which stocks and at what price was difficult.'' **********Indeed, some securities experts believe that the Nasdaq allowed the over-the-counter market to come of age, competing directly with the New York and other physical exchanges for companies and investors. And while no one foresees the complete elimination of exchanges like the Big Board, Mr. Macklin predicted yesterday that trading would increasingly be done automatically. **********''All of the major exchanges have on the drawing board sophisticated automatic systems that may initially supplement traditional floor trading but eventually could replace it,'' Mr. Macklin said. **********Perhaps more impressive than the companies on Nasdaq, securities experts say, has been the rise in trading volume on the system. Equal to about one-third of the volume on the Big Board in 1976, Nasdaq volume has recently been about 80 percent of New York Stock Exchange daily volume, according to the N.A.S.D. **********Mr. Macklin's latest project has been to take Nasdaq international, forming what he and others have called a global trading system. Last April, for example, the London Stock Exchange undertook an experiment with Nasdaq in which 200 stocks were traded on both Nasdaq and the British exchange's automated system. The next step? Many securities experts believe that Mr. Macklin's successor at the N.A.S.D. will attempt a linkup with the computerized trading system in Singapore.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/14/world.main_headline: East German Tells West Berlin No
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/14/world.print_headline: East German Tells West Berlin No
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/14/world.body_text: **********The East German leader, Erich Honecker, announced today that he would not attend a celebration in West Berlin marking the 750th anniversary of the foundation of Berlin. **********A terse item carried by the East German press agency cited a letter written last summer by the Mayor of West Berlin, Eberhard Diepgen, ''as well as other conditions'' as explaining Mr. Honecker's inability to attend the ceremonies on April 30. **********On Sunday a right-wing daily in West Berlin, Berliner Morgenpost, published the text of a letter that Mayor Diepgen wrote last July to West German state premiers urging them not to take part in official ceremonies in East Berlin. **********Both Mayor Diepgen and Western diplomats said they believed Mr. Honecker had seized upon the letter as a pretext for bowing out of a potentially difficult encounter. **********The Soviet Union was said to be concerned that Mr. Honecker would have had to appear on a platform with the West German Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, and President Richard von Weizsacker, thereby reinforcing Western arguments that West Berlin is legally linked to West Germany.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/11/busin.print_headline: ADVERTISING; Gillette Consolidates Personal Care Agencies
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/11/busin.body_text: **********The Gillette Company's Personal Care division has consolidated its ad agencies, a move that has been good for N. W. Ayer and bad for Young & Rubicam. **********Lowe Marschalk, one of the Interpublic Group of Companies, is also losing its Personal Care business. **********Ayer is getting Right Guard deodorant products and the Silkience hair care line from Y.&R. It is also getting Toni Home Permanence from Lowe Marschalk. Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn is getting Foamy and Brush Plus shave products from Lowe Marschalk, still the agency for Braun USA, marketer of electric shavers and small appliances. **********But Ayer is losing Aapri, a facial scrub, because of a potential conflict with its Avon client, and Y.&R. is also losing Good News Toiletries. Neither Good News nor Aapri has been reassigned.
