https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/02/world.main_headline: 'No Illusions' as U.S. Talks With Vietnamese Start
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/02/world.print_headline: 'No Illusions' as U.S. Talks With Vietnamese Start
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/02/world.body_text: **********A long-sought meeting between President Reagan's special envoy on Americans missing in action in Vietnam and newly installed Vietnamese leaders began here today, but with scant hopes of real progress on either side. **********''I have no illusions,'' the Foreign Minister Deputy Prime Minister, Nguyen Co Thach, told reporters this afternoon at the French-built palace that is the Government guest house. He was waiting to greet the envoy, Gen. John W. Vessey, Jr. General Vessey, the former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, was an officer in the Vietnam War. **********Mr. Thach said there was no chance the United States would be permitted to open a technical office in Hanoi to speed up the process of searching for missing Americans unless Hanoi gets an office in Washington. The two countries have no diplomatic relations, or interest sections in each other's capitals. 'Two-Way Traffic' **********Mr. Thach said an American request for such an office would mean that he would ''have to reciprocate.'' **********If such a request were made, he said: ''I will raise my desire to have an office in Washington. So you see it is a two-way traffic.'' **********General Vessey declined to answer when asked if he was authorized to make such a request. **********At the same time, Vietnamese officials said today that they were intending to broaden the talks to include ''humanitarian issues'' of their own. **********The opening session lasted barely an hour today, and recessed until Sunday morning, when the meeting may end, or be adjourned to Monday, if there is enough reason for further talks. **********Diplomats here from both Western and Soviet-bloc nations are virtually unanimous in saying that Vietnam attaches a very high priority to gaining American recognition. They say they are watching the talks for signs of whether or not communication between Washington and Hanoi can be improved under the government of a new Vietnamese communist party general secretary, nguyen van linh. **********Hanoi has sent conflicting signals to Washington in the last few years. Discussions on resolving the cases of more 2,400 Americans missing in action in Indochina, 1,776 of them in Vietnam, began to make substantial progress in 1985 under the American leadership of Richard Childress, the National Security Council's director for Asian affairs. In January 1986, when joint excavation of crash sites had almost become routine, Vietnam said it had ''Started the clock'' on a two-year deadline to resolve the issue once and for all. **********But within a few months, while in the throes of preparing for leadership changes and scrambling to institute economic reforms, Vietnam suddenly turned negative toward the United States. By the fall of 1986, when remains were last returned to the United States, all but superficial communication had stopped. Hanoi's Conclusion **********Southeast Asian diplomats familiar with developments in Vietnam say that Hanoi had concluded it was getting nothing in return for its cooperation, despite its protests that this was a strictly humanitarian gesture. **********President Reagan, under pressure from a lobby calling for action on the issue of the missing, appointed General Vessey his special envoy in January. It took until the end of may for Vietnam to agree to this visit. **********General Vessey came to Hanoi today with Mr. Childress, Ann Mills Griffiths, executive director of the National League of Families of American Prisoners and Missing in Southeast Asia, David Lambertson, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Asia and the Pacific, Robert Kingston, former director of the Joint Casualty Resolution Center in Hawaii, and Stephen Croker, an aide to General Vessey. **********Diplomats here say the visit can be used by the Vietnamese as a demonstration of American interest, whether or not anything is achieved in the talks. Who comes to whose court is traditionally of great importance in many Asian societies.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/05/busin.main_headline: Japanese Back Project Including Chrysler Plant
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/05/busin.print_headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES; Japanese Back Project Including Chrysler Plant
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/05/busin.body_text: **********The City of Detroit has lined up Japanese investors to finance the early stages of a $1.2 billion economic development project that includes a new assembly plant for the Chrysler Corporation. **********''Name recognition is extremely important in foreign markets, and Detroit is certainly well known in Japan,'' said David J. Sellers, vice president at Chemical Bank, which recently completed an $80 million financing for the city. Commitments to invest the $80 million were arranged with a group of Japanese banks, he said. Detroit's interest payments would be subject to Federal income tax for American investors. **********Japanese financiers have a precedent for participating in borrowings from the center of America's automobile industry. In 1982, the Mitsubishi Bank provided a letter of credit backing $500 million of Michigan notes. At the time, the state's economy was depressed, partly because American automobile companies were hard hit by Japanese imports. **********The $80 million will be used to buy land, demolish existing buildings and construct roads and sewers in a 636-acre zone that includes Chrysler's aging Jefferson assembly plant. When completed, the zone will include new housing, a new two-million-square-foot plant to be built by Chrysler, and related businesses. Later this year Detroit expects to sell long-term bonds backed by the increased real estate taxes generated by the new development. **********Bella I. Marshall, Detroit's finance director, said that the development plan includes Chrysler's promise to build a new plant on the land provided by the city. The state is helping provide new housing and roads, she said, and the Federal Government is also providing funds. **********The unusual financing arranged by Chemical calls for quarterly interest payments set at one-half of a percentage point above the offered rate for three-month bank time deposits in London. The notes mature in three and a half years, but the city will borrow money over an 18-month period as it is needed. **********The securities, called general obligation distributable state aid notes, are not rated but are backed by Detroit's full faith and credit as well as state aid payments to the city.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/30/busin.main_headline: Dresser's Energy Focus Emphasized by New Bid
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/30/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Dresser's Energy Focus Emphasized by New Bid
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/30/busin.body_text: **********John J. Murphy, president, chief executive and chairman of Dresser Industries, has underscored his company's focus on the energy industry with the announcement that Dresser plans to acquire the N. W. Kellogg Company. **********Kellogg, a unit of the Henley Group, is a leading engineering and construction company whose customers are the world's energy producers. **********Under Mr. Murphy's guidance, Dresser, an oilfield service company based in Dallas, has kept its eye on energy as its main business despite the slump in the industry that has hurt everyone, including Dresser. **********Mr. Murphy was not available for comment, but Herb M. Ryan, director of investment relations, said Dresser's earnings had been ''extremely poor.'' But he added: ''We've seen a lot of red ink for the last three years. But we broke into the black a few months ago and that leads us to believe that the worst is behind us.'' **********Dresser is positioning itself as a provider of high technology and highly engineered products for the oil industry, and it expects this strategy to bring in higher profits. Kellogg fits into that plan as a builder of petrochemical, refinery and other energy-related projects based on proprietary technology. **********The oil industry ''has been an excellent business in the past,'' Mr. Ryan said, ''and it will be an excellent business again. It will create exceptional opportunities for the 90's and beyond, although we don't have any better vision than anyone else has.'' **********Dresser is so certain of its long-term strategy that it has been divesting itself of several non-energy businesses, such as a hand-tool company and a maker of cranes and hoists. **********Mr. Murphy said in a statement that the Kellogg acquisition was ''another major step in our program to increase our focus on energy-related businesses.'' Dresser plans to finance the Kellogg acquisition - it will pay $100 million in cash and assume some Kellogg debt - from internal funds. **********Mr. Murphy, 55, has been president of Dresser since 1982 and chairman and chief executive since 1983, succeeding John V. James. Mr. Murphy joined the company in 1954 as a technical service engineer. **********Mr. Murphy received a mechanical engineering degree from the Rochester Institute of Technology and an M.B.A. from Southern Methodist University.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/06/world.body_text: **********Pvt. Wade E. Roberts, an American soldier who defected to the Soviet Union last April, arrived early today in the United States, where he faces charges of desertion, officials said. **********The 22-year-old Army private left the Rhein-Main Air Base outside Frankfurt on a United States Air Force plane Thursday evening, according to Walter Nebgen, a spokesman for the V Army Corps in Frankfurt. **********Private Roberts's West German companion, Petra Neumann, who is pregnant, did not fly to the United States with him, the spokesman said. **********The soldier, who is from Riverside, Calif., flew from Moscow to Frankfurt Wednesday with Ms. Neumann. **********American military police took him into custody on a Frankfurt street several hours after he arrived, military spokesmen said. Lieut. Col. John Dye, another spokesman for the V Army Corps, said Private Roberts did not resist arrest. He said the soldier faced desertion charges. **********Private Roberts said, however, that he had been told by American officials in the Soviet Union that he would be prosecuted for a lesser charge, absent without leave.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/11/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor:  I was saddened to read your story about the Binghams (''The Binghams, After the Fall,'' Dec. 21), not by their plight - for they are strangers to me - but by what has happened to one of my favorite newspapers, The Louisville Courier-Journal. **********For me, growing up in Kentucky in the 1960's, this newspaper wasn't just a liberal beacon; it represented the very best in intelligent, informative journalism. It was so different, and so much better than the other local newspapers. The supply of Courier-Journals was limited in Covington, where I grew up, and I would frequently take a one-hour bus trip to Cincinnati just to buy a copy. **********The Louisville Courier-Journal gave me a lifelong addiction to newspapers. I have traveled and lived in many parts of this country but I never found a local newspaper that could compare with its quality. I shudder that The Courier-Journal is no longer independent, but is now part of the Gannett chain. Perhaps there is some hope that Gannett won't turn The Courier-Journal into another USA Today. But I have little hope that The Courier-Journal will maintain the special quality that it had under the Binghams. **********Perhaps Mr. Bingham was right, that his family couldn't afford to maintain the newspaper and it was best to take profits while they could. It is, after all, as the current editor of The Courier-Journal put it, a crass world. JOHN E. CASNELLIE  Rochester, N.Y., Dec. 21

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/02/world.main_headline: U.S. IS SAID TO FIND MINES MOORED IN LANES TO KUWAIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/02/world.print_headline: U.S. IS SAID TO FIND MINES MOORED IN LANES TO KUWAIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/02/world.body_text: **********About a dozen moored mines have been found by American specialists in shipping lanes to Kuwait in the last three days, according to Pentagon officials. **********There were conflicting reports as to whether they had been destroyed. **********The use of moored mines is a new development in the long war between Iraq and Iran. It comes at a time when the United States Navy is preparing its first escort of Kuwaiti tankers, reregistered under the American flag, into the gulf sometime next week. **********The United States signed an agreement with Iraq Tuesday with procedures designed to avoid military incidents such as the Iraqi air attack on the United States frigate Stark in mid-May, which killed 37 crewmen. Shipping Routed Around Mines **********The mines were found moored in international waters in the busy Al Ahmadi channel. Kuwait has declared a 10-mile exclusion zone around the mines and is rerouting shipping. **********Defense Department sources say the mines, which are assumed to have been placed in the channel by Iranians, are more a nuisance than a threat, but they cannot be ignored. **********Kuwait has supported Iraq against Iran and Iran's forces have frequently attacked ships bound for Kuwait. **********Four ships have struck mines in the gulf since mid-May but none have sunk. It was thought at first that some of the mines were free floating, dropped by the Iranians, or perhaps that they had broken loose elsewhere. Iran Has No Minelaying Ships **********It is not known when or how the mines were placed. Iran does not have special minelaying ships, but it does have speedboats that have been operating in the upper gulf. Pentagon officials would not speculate if these were used. **********A 19-member team of mine specialists based at Charleston, S. C. - in the Persian Gulf to study the mine threat - discovered the mines. **********Measures can be taken to neutralize or destroy them but it is uncertain whether this has been done. A Pentagon official said he believed the mines had been destroyed, but a Navy officer said they were still in place, with their sites marked to warn ships. **********The Pentagon said another nine-man team of mine specialists from Little Creek, Va., was on the way to the gulf. The new team has advanced sonar devices that provide easier and more accurate identification and location of mines or other obstacles. **********A Pentagon spokesman indicated that 30 miles of the Al Ahmadi channel needs to be surveyed and swept if additional mines were found. Old Soviet-Design Mines **********The mines have been described by a Pentagon spokesman as MO-8 moored contact mines, which can be planted to a depth of 350 feet. The mine, which holds 250 pounds of explosives, is an old Soviet design turned over to North Korea during the 1950-53 Korean War. **********The North Koreans have manufactured their own version of the mine, and those found in the gulf are said to be of North Korean manufacture. **********Mine experts consider the MO-8 to be primitive. Unlike modern mines, which can be activated by a variety of means such as sound, pressure or disruption of a magnetic field, the Korean mine can only be detonated by contact with an object, such as a ship. **********Experts here said that, if needed, the United States could deploy specially equipped mine-sweeping helicopters to help deal with the mine threat, as was done three years ago when mines were found in the Red Sea. **********According to these sources, five MH-53E Sea Dragon helicopters are available to go to the gulf. Such helicopters, however, are considered more suited for sweeping advanced mines rather than the moored contact type found off Kuwait. **********The use of American crews and equipment may not be necessary, as Kuwait is reported to have asked Saudi Arabia for assistance in mine sweeping. **********The Netherlands is also reported to have offered to assist. Kuwait is believed to be considering the purchase or lease of European mine sweepers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/27/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS: EARNINGS; Net Rises for Oil Companies
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/27/busin.body_text: **********Leading oil companies reported sharply higher earnings from exploration and production operations in the third quarter compared with the depressed levels of a year ago, after a rise of nearly 40 percent in crude oil prices since then. **********But this was tempered by lower results in refining and marketing operations. Consequently, companies with major refining and marketing operations like the Exxon Corporation and the Mobil Corporation found the third quarter a continuation of a difficult year. Exxon, the nation's largest oil company, reported yesterday that third-quarter net income was up only slightly, because of markedly lower profits in refining and marketing, and Mobil showed a slight decline in the third quarter after taking into account a one-time loss last year. **********The Shell Oil Company, the Atlantic Richfield Company, the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, Unocal Corporation and the Pennzoil Company all reported higher profits.  Exxon **********Exxon said its third-quarter net was $1.065 billion, up 1 percent from $1.055 billion a year earlier, or 75 cents a share compared with 73 cents. For the first nine months, profit was down 15 percent, to $3.28 billion, from $3.88 billion, or from $2.68 per share in 1986 to $2.31. **********The decline in profit over the first nine months would have been sharper if the company had not cut back on capital and exploration expenditures, which were $4.2 billion this year, down 25 percent from the comparable period in 1986. But capital spending was up in the third quarter over the same quarter last year. **********Third-quarter revenues were $21.9 billion, up 27 percent from $17.2 billion. **********In a statement, L. G. Rawl, Exxon's chairman, said, ''Refined product margins continued to be depressed, as product price increases have not kept pace with higher crude costs.'' Crude oil prices averaged $6.50 a barrel higher in the third quarter of this year than last, he said, resulting in higher earnings from exploration and production operations. **********The company reported third-quarter profits from domestic refining and marketing operations of a scant $7 million, down from $106 million a year ago. For foreign operations, the third-quarter net was $53 million, down from $357 million. **********Many companies have suffered from crude oil prices rising faster than product prices, analysts said. Dillard Spriggs, of Petroleum Analysis Ltd., said: ''Downstream margins have been very niggardly for all companies. The exploration and production business is doing well, the chemical business is doing well compared with last year, but refining and marketing is down from last year.''  Shell **********Shell's net more than tripled, to $420 million, from $133 million. Revenues rose 41 percent, to $5.65 billion, from $4.01 billion. **********''Major factors in the improvement were a partial recovery of crude oil prices from a seven-year low, and a record performance in our chemical business,'' said the company president, John F. Bookout. Net income for the quarter from oil and gas exploration and production rose more than ten-fold, to $262 million, from $25 million a year earlier. **********Production costs were lower in the first half, Shell said, but profit margins on refined products fell, as did natural gas prices. **********''We are pleased with our strong third-quarter performance, but the substantial improvement only appears dramatic when contrasted with the severely depressed third quarter of 1986,'' Mr. Bookout said. **********The company is owned by the Royal Dutch/Shell Group.  Mobil **********Mobil said its third-quarter earnings were $319 million, up 75 percent from $182 million a year earlier, or 77 cents a share, compared with 45 cents a share. But results last year were pushed down $150 million by a loss on the sale of the Container Corporation of America; excluding that transaction, Mobil's results were 4 percent behind the year-ago period. **********Revenues were $14.4 billion, up 27 percent from $11.3 billion a year earlier. **********Allan E. Murray, Mobil's chairman, noted that exploration and production results had risen because of higher prices for crude oil and higher natural gas production, but refining and marketing profits fell.  Occidental Petroleum **********Occidental Petroleum, which is not heavily engaged in marketing and refining, reported third-quarter earnings of $46 million, or 20 cents per share, up 18 percent from $39 million, or 12 cents per share, a year earlier. Sales rose 14 percent to $4.2 billion from $3.7 billion. **********Boosted by higher crude oil prices, earnings for the company's oil and gas division were $58 million, compared with a loss of $3 million a year earlier.  ARCO **********ARCO reported that third-quarter earnings more than tripled, to $315 million, or $1.71 a share, from $102 million, or 56 cents a share. Sales rose 25 percent, to $4.4 billion, from $3.53 billion. **********Lodwrick M. Cook, chairman and chief executive, cited the same factors. ''Crude oil prices were higher in the third quarter compared with a year ago, leading to significantly improved results from our oil and gas operations,'' he said. ''Results also benefited from higher earnings from Arco Chemical Company and higher crude oil and natural gas liquids production. These increases were partially offset by lower earnings from refining and marketing operations.'' **********Gas and oil exploration and production net rose to $235 million, from $41 million in the same period last year. Earnings for refining and marketing dropped to $30 million, from $94 million.  Unocal **********Unocal reported third-quarter net income of $28.9 million, or 25 cents a share, up 33 percent from $21.8 million, or 19 cents a share. Revenue totaled $2.58 billion, up 35 percent from $1.91 billion.  Pennzoil **********Pennzoil had net income of $2.8 million, with no earnings per share after payment of preferred dividends, compared with a loss of $10.1 million a year earlier. But Pennzoil's year-earlier earnings had included a $23.1 million charge; excluding that, the company would have made a profit of $13 million in that period. Revenue was $449.7 million, up 6 percent from $426.1 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/14/busin.body_text: **********Robert Y. Empie, the embattled Oklahoma banking commissioner, was cleared today of wrongdoing but announced that he would resign June 30. **********Mr. Empie, whose term would have expired in 1990, had been under fire since March 9, when Gov. Henry Bellman suspended him with pay after accusing the 67-year-old banking commissioner of using inside information to sell or attempt to sell stock in the United Oklahoma Bank or its holding company, United Oklahoma Bank Shares. Mr. Empie was president of that bank before being appointed banking commissioner in 1979. **********In a document signed today, Mr. Bellman and Mr. Empie agreed that an investigation ''establishes that there was no wrongdoing on Empie's part.'' Praise From Governor **********The Governor, who could not be reached for comment, also praised Mr. Empie in the agreement for having served Oklahoma ''with integrity as bank commissioner for more than seven years, contributing needed professional and practical banking experience.'' **********During Mr. Empie's tenure as banking commissioner, 51 Oklahoma banks have failed, beginning with the collapse in 1982 of the Penn Square Bank of Oklahoma City. **********The only stock that was sold involved about 7,000 shares in the estate of his deceased mother, Mr. Empie said, adding that, ''it only amounted to about $5,800.'' **********The announcement came just before the expiration of a deadline set by the Governor for Mr. Empie to request a hearing to protest his suspension. **********''I think such as exercise would have been farcical,'' Mr. Empie said. ''The hearing would have been presided over by an attorney appointed and reimbursed by my accuser.'' A lengthy court fight, he added, would have left him ''an embittered old man, and I don't relish that.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/29/world.main_headline: PROTEST AND ROCK FETE ARE TESTS OF GLASNOST
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/29/world.print_headline: IN MOSCOW, A NEW ERA?; PROTEST AND ROCK FETE ARE TESTS OF GLASNOST
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/29/world.body_text: **********A joyous rock concert and an angry public demonstration in the last few days have pushed out new boundaries for spontaneous public behavior and protest in Soviet society. In different settings and for reasons that could hardly have had less in common, a group of Crimean Tatars seeking to redress grievances and the audience at a Billy Joel concert threw away the rule book that has governed public activities in the Soviet Union for decades. **********Together, the Crimean Tatars and rock fans pushed Mikhail S. Gorbachev's drive for ''glasnost,'' or ''openness,'' to a point that clearly left the authorities anxious. It seemed to amaze the participants themselves. **********The Tatars, who want to regain the Crimean homeland from which they were exiled by Stalin in 1944, marched noisily outside the Kremlin for more than 24 hours over the weekend. **********A few months ago it would have been almost inconceivable for a human rights protest to occur in the heart of the capital without the participants' being quickly whisked away by the police. **********In this case, the demonstration ended when the Crimean Tatars were promised they could meet with President Andrei A. Gromyko on Monday. A few days earlier, Mr. Gromyko had been named to head a commission to examine the Tatar's complaints. **********After they met with Mr. Gromyko, Tatar delegates expressed disappointment over what they said was a failure by the Government to guarantee a sympathetic inquiry into their case. Russians Danced in the Aisles **********At the rock concert, held Sunday night at the Olympic Stadium, thousands of people, energized by the presence and music of Billy Joel, bolted from their seats an hour into the performance and started dancing in the aisles and pressing around the stage. **********Many of the people there said they had never witnessed, much less taken part in, such a breakdown in the normal decorum at a public performance. The scene was repeated Monday night.  Following a series of less disruptive demonstrations in recent months in Moscow and Leningrad by unrelated groups, the latest events suggested that both citizens and the Government were feeling their way toward unexplored territory, unsure how far they could go. **********One indication of the uncertainty was the reaction of Soviet concert organizers, who first upbraided Mr. Joel's associates for letting things get out of control, then later assured the Americans everything was O.K. Audience Breaks Out of Trance **********As the people in the audience, who sat almost motionless through the first part of the concert, broke out of the trance that seems to affect Soviet spectators at public events, many people looked around in astonishment at the scene and their own role in it. **********Although such behavior at rock concerts would be routine in the West, spontaneous behavior at public events is absent in the Soviet Union. What made the behavior all the more striking was that many of those dancing and gesticulating wildly were people in their 30's and 40's, who normally would be likely to condemn such conduct. **********It was as if emotions and energy that had been pent up for years were suddenly released. **********News of the Crimean Tatar protest and the raucous behavior at the concerts, although not reported in the Soviet press or on television, was widely known around Moscow in hours. **********Tass reported on Mr. Joel's tour and his first concert in a terse, four-paragraph dispatch. ''His first performance was a great success,'' it said, giving no further description. Ambivalence Toward Tatars, Too **********In the case of the Tatars, too, there was evidence of ambivalence. **********The appointment of the commission was a major concession, as well as the first time the Government had announced an official public inquiry into decisions by Stalin. **********Since Mr. Gorbachev took office in 1985, there has been a revival of the effort begun under Nikita S. Khrushchev in the mid-1950's to question Stalinism. **********Stalin ordered the deportation of the 200,000 to 250,000 Tatars from the Crimea to Central Asia in 1944, after the German Army had been pushed back. The charge was that the Tatars had collaborated with the Germans. **********Saturday, when the 300 demonstrators gathered near the Kremlin Wall, they tried to march around St. Basil's Cathedral and into Red Square but were stopped by the police in a scuffle that in previous years would certainly have developed into violence. Both Sides Sense New Rules **********But this time the Tatars and the police in particular seemed to understand that they were operating under new rules. The encounter ended peacefully. **********Pravda, apparently reflecting party and Government uncertainty about the Tatars, condemned the demonstration but urged no retaliation. **********The Government has moved slowly but steadily toward a more tolerant attitude toward public demonstrations since a series of human rights protests were violently dispersed. **********Since then, Jews seeking to emigrate to Israel have held demonstrations in Moscow and a Russian nationalist organization called Pamyat, or Memory, was allowed to march near the Kremlin in May. The group, which some critics feel is xenophobic with anti-Semitic overtones, has met with Boris N. Yeltsin, the Moscow party leader. **********In the spring, there were several public demonstrations in Leningrad's St. Isaac's Square, where people pressed for increased efforts to preserve historic buildings. The leader of the group tried to become a candidate for the Leningrad City Soviet, the equivalent of City Council. **********Where the Government will draw the line in all this is unclear. Mr. Gorbachev, responding to the fear of Russians who see spiraling disorder, assured them in February, ''Democracy is not the antithesis of order.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/01/busin.main_headline: Market Place; Adviser Picks No-Load Funds
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/01/busin.print_headline: Market Place; Adviser Picks No-Load Funds
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/01/busin.body_text: **********MONEY managers typically pick stocks or bonds for their client portfolios. But Brouwer & Janachowski, an investment advisory firm in San Francisco, invests in no-load mutual funds for the most part in managing money for its clients. **********''We analyze mutual funds much the same way other professional investors analyze securities,'' Kurt Brouwer, one of the founding partners, said. ''We visit the funds, we talk to their personnel and, in effect, kick the tires. Back in the office, we do comparative computer studies on all types of funds, looking at management performance, portfolio volatility, risk measurements and other factors.'' **********''Managing money with mutual funds allows us to utilize the top investment brains in the business,'' he added. ''Furthermore, no-loads provide us with immediate portfolio diversification and the ability to rifle in on a specialized area.'' **********Mr. Brouwer and his partner, Stephen Janachowski, are sold on the fund concept of investment management, and their particular vehicles are no-load funds, which do not burden shareowners with sales charges. The firm manages $90 million, mostly for wealthy individuals, private businesses and several San Francisco area law firms. Its stated goal is ''to do reasonably well in up markets and to preserve capital in down markets.'' **********The firm says it believes in a ''balanced'' investment approach using equity funds and bond funds, along with money market funds for the cash portion of an account. ''At present, we are more conservative than we have been at any time within the last three years,'' Mr. Brouwer said. ''In fact, for a new account, we might keep as much as 50 percent in money market funds. For individual clients, we also have been buying some municipal bond funds offered by Benham Capital Management.'' **********Examples of no-load equity funds used by the firm are the Partners Fund, with Neuberger & Berman Management as its investment adviser, and the Evergreen Total Return Fund, advised by Saxon Woods Asset Management. **********Mr. Brouwer gave some statistics to illustrate why both funds, in his view, represented a sound investment approach. For the five years ended last March 31, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index showed a total return - market appreciation plus reinvested dividends - averaging 26.3 percent annually. Comparative results were average annual returns of 24.4 percent for Partners and 27.8 percent for Evergreen. **********''But look at their results when the stock market experienced a down quarter, such as occurred in the third quarter of 1986,'' Mr. Brouwer said. ''The S.&P. 500 was down 7 percent, while Partners was off 5.9 percent and Evergreen was down just under 1 percent. Furthermore, during the latest five-year period, both funds displayed a lower volatility than the broad market index - and that's something we like to see.'' **********Brouwer & Janachowski has also used the Mutual Shares Corporation, managed by the Heine Securities Corporation, for equity investments. This fund is temporarily closed for sales, but it, too, has carved out an enviable record. For the five years ended with the first quarter of 1987, Mutual Shares had an average annual return of 26.3 percent - exactly the same as the S.&P. 500 - but its volatility reading was lower. And in last year's third quarter, it outperformed the broad index with a decline of 2.6 percent. The fund's specialty is investing in various forms of corporate restructuring. **********No-load funds are far from becoming an extinct species - an estimated 350 ''pure'' no-loads are in business - but the trend increasingly has been for many mutual funds to exact some form of sales charge. This may take the form of a front-end load of perhaps 4.75 percent, or a redemption charge imposed if the shareholder cashes in before a specified period, usually five or six years. **********''I think that, if portfolio managers of a load fund provide good results for their shareholders, you can justify a sales charge,'' Mr. Brouwer said. ''But all too often the customer is faced with buying a load fund that a brokerage firm happens to be pushing at the time - and somehow the broker is apt to soft-pedal any inherent risks in the fund.'' **********Both Mr. Brouwer and Mr. Janachowski started out as account executives at Merrill Lynch and later worked for Boettcher & Company in Denver. Prior to setting up their partnership in mid-1985, they were affiliated with Birr, Wilson & Company in San Francisco. Since they opened up shop, a typical balanced account shows an average annual return of 27.7 percent, compared with 31.1 percent for the S.&P. 500, an index that is solely in equities. **********Mr. Brouwer has some opinions on the art of investing that apply to individuals as well as money managers. ''I think it is wrong to try to time the market,'' he said. And, putting his practice into words, he is writing an investment book for people who make their own market decisions.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/20/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Official To Leave A.T.&T.
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/20/busin.body_text: **********James D. Edwards, a central figure in the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's push into the computer business, said yesterday that he was leaving A.T.&T. to run a small company called Telwatch Inc. **********Mr. Edwards, 46, was hired by A.T.&T. in 1983 to put management systems in place at its Western Electric subsidiary as the company prepared for a life of competition after deregulation. It was one of the rare instances in which an executive from outside was hired for a top spot in A.T.&.T. management. **********Two years later Mr. Edwards, who was a senior vice president, was asked to form a computer division out of a variety of units scattered throughout A.T.&T. After two years in the struggling computer division, he took a new assignment - studying how the company could sell all its products more effectively. **********A.T.&T. has had difficulty getting a foothold in the computer business. Asked how he thought the division was faring, Mr. Edwards replied: ''There's a great deal of pressure on any competitor to I.B.M. or Digital Equipment. I certainly wish them well at A.T.&T. In the vernacular, they are getting their act together.'' **********Telwatch makes systems for management and control of voice and data communication equipment. Mr. Edwards will be its president and chief executive. A.T.&T. is a large customer of Telwatch and resells some Telwatch products. **********Telwatch, a private company based in Boulder, Colo., is expected to have sales this year of $10 million to $20 million. It is backed by Salomon Brothers Venture Capital in New York and Hill, Kirby & Washing Partnership in Boulder. **********''This was a chance to go on my own, to put my personal imprint on a smaller company in a market I think I know,'' Mr. Edwards said. **********Mr. Edwards, a summa cum laude graduate of Princeton with a degree in economics, began his career at the International Business Machines Corporation. He recalled yesterday that his job there was the equivalent of running a small company. He was head of an independent business unit involved with biomedical systems. **********Mr. Edwards also worked for the Xerox Corporation as vice president of pricing and planning in its information systems division. Before joining A.T.&T., he was president of the instrument group of Bausch & Lomb Inc.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/27/busin.print_headline: 8.1% Rise in Tool Orders Is Called Disappointing
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/27/busin.body_text: **********New orders for American-made machine tools climbed 8.1 percent, to $165.2 million, in March after a slight decline in February, according to a report to be released today by the National Machine Tool Builders' Association. However, when measured against figures from March 1986, orders were down 23 percent. **********Also, the association noted, orders for the first quarter of this year fell 24.5 percent, to $464.7 million, from the corresponding period last year. **********Officials of the trade association said that the pace of orders was disappointing. For several months industry officials and analysts have shared the view that little meaningful improvement was likely this year, and the March figures reinforced that view. Cutbacks, Sluggishness Cited **********The association report attributed the year-to-year decline to the effect of corporate reductions in capital spending and a general sluggishness in manufacturing. **********''The figures we are seeing today are in large part due to the steady loss of both total market and market share that the American tool industry has suffered over the last few years,'' James A. Gray, the association's president, said. ''Long before the current public awareness of the threat posed by excessive imports, this industry felt the bite of the invasion of foreign products.'' **********Despite recent Federal initiatives to retard the flow of imports through voluntary restraint agreements with major foreign machine tool producers - Japan and South Korea -tool makers remain pessimistic about a recovery this year. **********''Even with the trade agreements, there are too many strikes against us,'' said the vice president of marketing for a major machine tool company. **********Machine tools are power-driven devices used to shape metal parts, from tractor gears to vacuum-cleaner motors. Their sales are considered an important indicator of capital spending by producers of metal products, particularly the auto and aerospace industries. Imports account for about 43 percent of the $4.3 billion machine tool industry. Foreign Competition Troublesome **********The machine tool industry has been plagued in recent years by intense competition from foreign producers, weak prices and flat order levels, and in recent months by a downturn in automobile production and reduced capital spending. As a result, many machine tool companies have furloughed workers and curtailed production. **********The association said that orders for metal cutting machines, which include lathes and boring mills, rose 20 percent in March, to $124.4 million, from February figures. Metal-cutting machines account for about 75 percent of the industry. But orders for metal forming machines fell 17.1 percent in March, to $40.7 million. **********Machine tool shipments for March were up 23.9 percent, to $181.6 million, from the levels posted in February. The March shipment figures represent a 27 percent drop from the year-ago figures. **********March shipments of metal cutting tools rose 38.8 percent, while shipments of metal forming tools fell 7.5 percent from their February levels, the association reported. **********Machine tool backlogs for March fell to $1.19 billion, from $1.2 billion in February.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/25/world.main_headline: MAKEUP OF A NEW AFGHAN REGIME IS SEEN AS BARRIER TO PEACE EFFORTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/25/world.print_headline: MAKEUP OF A NEW AFGHAN REGIME IS SEEN AS BARRIER TO PEACE EFFORTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/25/world.body_text: **********Despite a narrowing of differences in the Geneva talks on the Afghan war, officials said a disagreement over who should run the Afghan Government continued to block a resolution of the conflict. **********Pakistani officials, Western diplomats and Afghan guerrilla leaders also said the makeup of a new Afghan Government had not been addressed in Geneva and had been discussed very little in other Pakistan-Soviet talks. **********In Geneva, the United Nations negotiator, Diego Cordovez, hailed discussions that ended March 10 as a breakthrough because the two sides made concessions on a timetable for withdrawing Soviet troops. **********Officials said the Soviet Union was now willing to withdraw its forces within 18 months compared with its earlier timetable of four years. Pakistan reportedly said it could accept a withdrawal of seven months, more than its initial demand of three to four months. Ostensibly, the Only Issue Ostensibly, the timetable remains the only issue left to be negotiated. Earlier, agreement was reached on having the United States and the Soviet Union guarantee an end to ''outside interference'' in Afghanistan. **********But Afghanistan experts as well as the leaders of the Afghan guerrilla groups said also that the disagreement over the timetable for withdrawal masked a more contentious issue likely to be extremely difficult to resolve peacefully. **********The key issue, they said, is who will be running the Government in Kabul during and after the Soviet troop withdrawal, and whether the guerrillas will accept it and lay down their arms, at least temporarily. **********According to a western diplomat close to the talks, disagreement on the composition of the Kabul regime ''lies at the guts of the problem,'' because if the guerrillas continue fighting, they may be in a position to disrupt the withdrawal. The guerrillas are not taking part in the Geneva talks to end the war. Linkage to Refugee Issue **********Pakistani officials said also that if there was no acceptance of the Government by the Afghan guerrillas, three million Afghan refugees in Pakistan may not be willing to return to Afghanistan.The officials added that any solution to the Afghan war must enable the refugees to return. **********But Pakistani and other officials familiar with the negotiations said that there have been few, if any, discussions among the parties even on the subject of a possible interim government that would run the country while the Soviets are withdrawing. **********The Pakistan Foreign Minister Sahabzada Yaqub Khan, was again in Moscow recently, but a Pakistani official said the issue of the composition of the Kabul Government ''has not really been discussed in any great depth.'' **********Diplomats close to the situation said they doubted whether Soviet leaders have come to the point where they would be willing to jettison the Communist regime as a price for getting out of Afghanistan. **********But some people here who criticize Pakistan's support of the guerrillas disagree. 'Prepared to Ditch Friends' **********For example, Mushahid Hussein Syed, a left-wing journalist who has frequently visited Afghanistan, said it was his impression that the Russians were ''prepared to ditch their Communist friends in Kabul'' and withdraw their troops in less than a year's time. **********Mr. Hussein, until recently editor of The Muslim, an Islamabad-based daily paper, interviewed the leader of the Soviet-backed regime, who is known as Najib, during a trip to Kabul last month but said he saw no explicit indication of this. **********Guerrilla leaders said they would not stop fighting until the Communists were ousted. But Pakistanis fear that even an 18-month Soviet withdrawal, coupled with a cutoff in aid to the guerrillas, would give the Soviet troops enough time to inflict damage on the insurgents. Stockpiled Weapons a Concern **********At the same time, Soviet officials are known to be concerned that the guerrillas have stockpiled enough weapons -some experts said they could fight for two years or more after an aid cutoff -to oust the Kabul regime once Soviet troops get out. **********The Kabul regime and Mr. Najib have embarked on a drive to establish a ''government of national reconciliation'' to withstand an attack by the guerrillas once the Russians leave. **********So far, experts here and in Peshawar, the Pakistani listening post on the Najib's reconciliation efforts have failed, and that no guerrilla leaders of any significance have defected to his camp. **********Pakistani officials said that Kabul would have to be more flexible in sharwould have to be more flexible in sharing power with non-Communists before its ''national reconciliation'' program is taken seriously. They said they would not press the Afghan guerrillas or Afghan refugees to accept the Government. **********But a senior Pakistani official said also that it was Pakistan's desire to allow to withdrawal without having the Communist regime be overthrown. ''We are quite clear that there has to be an honorable peace,'' said the official. **********''A superpower is not going to be humiliated in Afghanistan,'' he continued. ''Afghanistan in the future should also not become the kind of a base that in any way threatens Soviet security.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/25/busin.body_text: **********The Anadarko Petroleum Corporation said that the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company had terminated its contract with the natural gas company after the two sides failed to agree on price. Anadarko said its subsidiary, Pan Eastern Exploration, and Panhandle Eastern had tried to renegotiate the terms of about 40 previous gas contracts since March 18. **********Panhandle Eastern said the gas contract would be terminated on Aug. 12. Anadarko said that the contract covered about one trillion cubic feet of proved natural gas reserves, or about 57 percent of the company's total reserves.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/02/busin.main_headline: CHRYSLER ACTS IN FALSE MILEAGE CASE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/02/busin.print_headline: CHRYSLER ACTS IN FALSE MILEAGE CASE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/02/busin.body_text: **********Lee A. Iacocca, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, said today that the company had acted in a way that was ''dumb'' and ''unforgivable'' by selling cars that had been driven while their odometers were disconnected. **********Mr. Iacocca's remarks came as the auto maker began a program to counter the unfavorable publicity generated by its indictment last week for selling 60,000 cars as new, although they had been driven - and in some cases, damaged. As part of the program, Chrysler will give new cars to as many as 40 owners of the affected models. Other owners will be offered longer warranties with broader coverage. **********Chrysler was indicted by a Federal grand jury, and two of its executives were indicted on criminal charges in the matter. The indictment said that Chrysler had failed to tell car buyers about the accumulated mileage or the repairs. **********The indictment covers an 18-month period from July 1, 1985, to Dec. 31, 1986. The Justice Department asserted, however, that odometers had been disconnected for decades and that millions of cars had been sold with inaccurate mileage readings. **********Chrysler's program to compensate customers will apply only to owners of cars sold within the last three years. Public Opinion Cited **********The company has argued that it did nothing illegal, and it continued to do so today. But Mr. Iacocca said Chrysler was being damaged in ''the court of public opinion.'' **********''Our big concern is for our customers, the people who had enough faith in Chrysler to buy a vehicle from us,'' Mr. Iacocca said. ''These charges and the press reports about them are causing some of those customers to question that faith, and we simply cannot tolerate that.'' **********Chrysler's initial reaction to the indictment was to denounce it as ''outrageous.'' Mr. Iacocca made it clear that today's more conciliatory approach had been prompted by concern that the public reaction would soon cut into car sales. He said a ''quick survey'' of 1,000 people had indicated that 69 percent of those over 29 years old were aware of the indictment. Sales Seem Unaffected **********A spot-check of Chrysler dealers in the New York and Detroit areas, though, produced few complaints about lagging sales. ''We've had a few customers come in who had read about it in the newspapers but no loss in sales,'' said Richard Brahs Jr., a sales executive at Stamford Dodge in Stamford, Conn. **********Bert Meimar, service manager at Farmington Hills Chrysler-Plymouth in Farmington Hills, Mich., added: ''I've had a few mention it, but nothing serious. It's still too new to judge.'' **********According to the Federal indictment, executives at Chrysler assembly plants routinely took new cars off the assembly line and drove them for as much as 400 miles with the odometers disconnected. In addition, the indictment charged, some cars were damaged in the testing and were only superficially repaired before being shipped to dealers to be sold. **********Mr. Iacocca said the company had done two things to make potential buyers wary of the company's cars. ''The first was just dumb,'' he said. ''We test-drove a small percentage of our cars with the odometer disengaged and didn't tell our customers. **********''The second went beyond dumb and reached all the way out to stupid,'' he added. Forty cars that had been seriously damaged in accidents were repaired and sold as new. ''Simply stated, that's unforgivable, and we've got nobody but ourselves to blame,'' he said. **********Mr. Iacocca said he had been personally unaware of the disconnecting of odometers until last October, when he was notified of the Justice Department investigation by Gerald Greenwald, chairman of Chrysler Motors. However, he said, Chrysler's lawyers had assured him that the practice was legal. New Cars to Be Offered **********To make amends, Mr. Iacocca said, the owners of the 40 damaged cars will be offered new cars of a comparable model. He said the owners would be notified by mail starting Thursday. **********Those whose cars were driven with the odometers disconnected will be given a seven-year, 70,000-mile warranty, extending the five-year, 50,000-mile warranty in effect when their cars were made. The warranty coverage will be broadened to include components that are not a part of the usual power-train warranty offered by the domestic auto companies. **********The owners will be notified by next week, he said, as will the owners of cars that were not driven before being sold. Mr. Iacocca said the company's records extend back only about three years, meaning drivers of older Chrysler cars and trucks will not be notified or included in the extended warranty.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/29/world.body_text: **********The Malaysian Government, saying it feared a racial explosion, closed three newspapers today, including the country's liveliest English-language daily, The Star. **********In the last two days, 63 politicians and leaders of citizens groups have been detained in a sweep against critics of the administration of Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad. Among them is Lim Kit Siang, leader of the main opposition party, Democratic Action. **********Racial tensions between the country's Moslem Malay population, which controls the Government, and a large ethnic Chinese minority, which has played a big role in the national economy, rose suddenly over the last few weeks. **********Many Malaysians say relations have been steadily deteriorating for a year or two as programs intended to enhance the lives of Malays begin to have some negative effects on other communities. But the immediate crisis was provoked by a Government decision to assign administrators who are not fluent in Mandarin to Chinese-language schools. Broken Promises Charged **********Chinese Malaysians, who place a high value on education, say this contravenes promises made to their community. There have been school boycotts and an unusual show of solidarity between opposition Chinese politicians and those who are part of the governing coalition, the National Front. **********About half of Malaysia's 16 million people are Malays and 37 percent are Chinese. The rest are of Indian or Sri Lankan Tamil descent in peninsular Malaysia, and of Kadazan, Dayak or other indigenous ethnic groups in East Malaysia, on the island of Borneo. Malaysia's official religion is Islam, and a Malay is guaranteed the prime ministership under the Constitution. **********Prime Minister Mahathir has faced increasing criticism from his own colleagues over what his detractors describe as an intolerance of dissent. In April, he came close to being replaced as head of his party, the United Malays National Organization. The party leader automatically becomes head of government under the present political system. **********Gen. Haniff Omar, Inspector General of the Malaysian police, said at a news conference today that six opposition members of Parliament were among the 63 arrested. The six were ordered held without trial under the Internal Security Act, introduced by British colonial authorities to contain a Communist insurgency in 1948. Prominent Lawyer Held **********Also arrested were Chandra Muzaffar, head of the country's most influential public-action group, Aliran, and Karpal Singh, a prominent lawyer who has defended many critics of the Government. Lecturers, environmentalists and comsumer advocates were also detained. **********Prime Minister Mahathir told Parliament that the arrests were needed to keep the peace. **********Officials of the The Star, the Chinese-language Sin Chew Yit Poh and the Malay-language weekly Watan said they had been ordered by the Home Affairs Ministry to stop publication as of Thursday. Under Malaysian law, the Government can revoke a license to publish without giving detailed reasons. **********The Star, which is owned by the Malaysian Chinese Association, a party allied to Dr. Mahathir's, was the most independent of the country's English-language papers. Among its columnists was Malaysia's first Prime Minister, Tunku Abdul Rahman. Now a highly regarded elder statesman, he had become an outspoken critic of Dr. Mahathir.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/03/world.main_headline: BLACK NATIONS' TRADE ROUTE SEEKS TO BYPASS SOUTH AFRICA
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/03/world.print_headline: BLACK NATIONS' TRADE ROUTE SEEKS TO BYPASS SOUTH AFRICA
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/03/world.body_text: **********The patched and potholed two-lane road leading to this sleepy border post on the frontier with Zimbabwe gives little hint of grand design or bitter struggle. **********On a sweltering four-hour drive from the Indian Ocean port of Beira, only the awkward Crocodile armored personal carriers of the Zimbabwean Army, the lone helicopter rattling overhead or the odd roadblock suggest the route's strategic role. But even these are common enough on a continent troubled by many wars. **********Otherwise the landscape along the 180-mile road as it rises gently from the tropical coastal wetlands to the fertile highlands across the center of Mozambique is a series of idyllic images - thatched granaries and huts in fields of ripening corn, tall stands of eucalyptus trees, Africans trekking by the roadside or seeking refuge from the midsummer sun under spreading acacias. Loosening the Bonds **********A single railroad track winds alongside the road and a rare freight train chugs by at a laborious pace, a clutch of waving workers hanging from the battered caboose. **********The placid scene belies the momentous political and economic role that has been assigned the road, railway and the oil pipeline alongside. Known collectively as the Beira corridor, the installations have become the focus of an ambitious and high-stakes bid by South Africa's black-ruled neighbors to loosen the economic bonds that have effectively made them hostages to apartheid. **********The arithmetic is simple. The countries bordering South Africa channel almost 70 percent of their combined foreign trade through South African ports, a fact that leaves them vulnerable to serious economic dislocation in any sanctions war with Pretoria. Other Outlets Languish **********They used to have other outlets to the sea - the Benguela line to the Angolan coast, the Tazara railroad to Tanzania, the Mozambican ports at Maputo, Beira and Nacala. But all have fallen victim in varying degrees to wars, poverty, neglect and mismanagement. That has left South Africa, with its modern and efficient ports, to handle the bulk of regional traffic. **********Two years ago, the nine-black ruled nations of the Southern African Development Coordination Conference -Mozambique, Angola, Swaziland, Lesotho, Botswana, Zambia, Zimbabwe, Malawi and Tanzania - and a group of West European donors decided to revive at least the Beira corridor as a alternative route to the outside world. **********The project is of primary importance to Zimbabwe, which now sends 90 percent of its trade through South Africa, and to Mozambique, whose devastated economy would receive badly needed income and development from the revival of Beira, its second city. The corridor would also offer a shortcut to the sea for part of the trade from Zambia, Botswana, Malawi and even the Zaire copper belt. **********Nobody has suggested that the Beira route could free the Southern African countries from the potent economic draw of South Africa, whose $80 billion gross domestic product dwarfs the combined output of all the conference's nine nations. It will take at least several years before Beira can carry a relevant part of traffic from the front-line nations, and the most optimistic projections are that the corridor may reduce the trade the bordering nations send through South Africa from the current 70 percent to about 40 percent. Rebels Remain Active **********A major question hanging over the route is posed by the rebels of the Mozambican National Resistance, called Renamo for short. With Pretoria's help, the rebels have ravaged vast tracts of northern Mozambique. **********Security has improved since Zimbabwean troops began patrolling the corridor in 1985, but officials in Maputo said guerrillas still mine the railroad, road or pipeline from time to time. An official in Beira said that only four days earlier the rebels blew up some track, but he said trains were running again within hours. **********Chancy though the project is, the corridor has assumed a symbolic importance at least as great as its economic or political potential. The young black governments of Southern Africa feel they are faced with constant efforts by South Africa to destabilize them through military and econonmic pressures. And these nations, sensitive to the indignity of demanding sanctions by the outside world while remaining in economic thrall to Pretoria, see in the development conference and in the Beira project a chance to assert their independence and defiance. **********Western donors, primarily the Netherlands, Britain, Norway, Denmark, Sweden, the European Community and the United States, have responded with substantial pledges toward the $280 million corridor project. From the East bloc, only East Germany has made any contributions. But nowhere has the corridor roused the enthusiasm that it has in Zimbabwe, which has by far the healthiest economy in the region after South Africa. 'Our Route to the World' **********In Zimbabwe's press the corridor has been hailed as the ''survival landline'' and ''our route to the world.'' President Robert Mugabe has committed more than 6,000 troops to safeguarding the route. Zimbabwean business executives have formed a Beira corridor group to pump private capital into projects ranging from the renovation of Beira hotels to raising new warehouses. **********The enthusiasm is bolstered by some purely capitalistic considerations. According to Denis Norman, former Agriculture Minister and chairman of the group, upgrading the shorter route to Beira would save Zimbabwe $85 million in transport costs. **********In Mutari, a provincial center at the Zimbabwean end of the corridor, business executives reported a boom in anticipation of the increased traffic. Prices of houses have tripled as entrepreneurs have moved in hoping to cash in on the expected demand for everything from rental cars to vacation resorts in Beira, once the playground of white Rhodesians seeking white beaches, prawns and sin. **********''Beira's more than just a port for us,'' said a garage owner in Mutari who has invested in a fleet of rental cars. ''A landlocked country like ours dreams of access to the sea, and Beira was traditionaly our outlet.'' That was before the Portuguese colonialists turned power over to the Frelimo Movement in 1975 and the Marxist Government closed its border with white-ruled Rhodesia. **********With the flight of the Portuguese, the demise of tourism, the rapid collapse of the Mozambican economy and the spread of the insurgency, Beira fell on hard times. Broken shop windows, vacant cafes and faded signs in what was once an elegant city center and abandoned kiosks along the broad beaches testify to the city's past affluence. Few Cars in the Streets **********The liveliest place on the main square is the externally ornate jail, from whose barred windows prisoners shout to friends and relatives outside. There are no taxis and few cars in the streets. **********A population once estimated at 300,000 has been swollen by 50,000 refugees from the terror in the countryside, and jobs are few. The biggest employer outside the port, a cement factory, closed for lack of supplies. Essentials are rationed. Electricity was cut for 165 days last year when the guerrillas blew up a row of pylons leading to the city, and a local generator manages only weak, sporadic bursts of power. Water supplies are equally inconstant; a guest at a comfortable government guest house is given a bucket of water at bedtime. **********The road to the capital, Maputo, is too dangerous to travel without military escort, leaving the Boeing 737's of the state airline, LAM, as the primary link between the country's two main cities. The competition for seats is fierce, and ordinary travelers often lose out to officials or foreigners with hard currency. **********But people here talk of the future, not the present. ''You can imagine the importance of this project to us,'' said Francisco Masquil, the young Governor of Sofala Province, which includes Beira and half the corridor. ''Beira is a city of the future. The new developments will have a very big impact. It will bring life back along the line.'' **********The future is most evident for now at the port, where the clatter of construction and the squads of workers offer a stark contrast to the moribund town outside. A team of Dutch engineers supervises the renovation of several berths, all more than 50 years old and crumbling dangerously. On March 1, the Amsterdam Port Authority is to take over all port operations. Ambitious Plans for Port **********At his headquartes by the entrance to the port, Rui Fonseca, director of the Beira Corridor Authority formed by Mozambique to coordinate financing of the project, outlined ambitious plans to raise the port's capacity from 1.3 million tons to 2 million this year, then to 3.5 million in three years and to more than 5 million tons by 1990, to deepen the channel and to raise the railroad's capacity from the present 2,500 tons a day to 8,000 tons. **********Zimbabwe National Railroads is replacing whole stretches of track, and Mozambique is looking to donors -preferably Washington, Mr. Fonseca said - for 100 new locomotives. **********The Beira corridor group is gearing up to restore two of Beira's old luxury hotels, to install modern communications equipment and to build new warehouses. Beyond that there are plans to upgrade sewers, restore power and water, and resurface the road to Zimbabwe. **********Zimbabwean farmers are looking hungrily at the land alongside the corridor, some of Africa's most fertile, for new plantations and farms that would serve to bolster security and feed Beira. The Zimbabwean troops, who patrol the road, ride each train, keep constant watch over the pumping stations along the pipeline and patrol by helicopter from a base at Chimoio, halfway up the corridor, have already had a marked effect. **********A Zimbabwean businessman who had seen the area from the air said the corridor was a lush green strip of thriving farms to which peasants had returned since the patrols began. **********Over a lunch of chicken and rice in Chimoio, a Mozambican marveled, ''This is the only place in the country where you can get all the chicken you want.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/13/world.print_headline: CHARLESTOWN JOURNAL; HERE'S TO NELSON AND HIS BRIDE AND TO NEVIS, TOO
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/13/world.body_text: **********Two hundred years ago, on a flawless, sunny afternoon, Adm. Horatio Nelson, one of Britain's greatest naval commanders, married the daughter of a colonial judge on this speck of a Caribbean island. **********The event was one of the most dramatic in the rather unspectacular history of the island, and this week it is being recalled with a round of parties, sporting events and a re-enactment of the ceremony. Foreign diplomats and government officials have joined in, and the United States and Britain have sent warships that are riding at anchor in the harbor. **********It was all meant to be good fun, and that is the way it has turned out. But on small islands, as in small towns, things have a way of getting complicated. **********Nevis, which has a population of perhaps 9,000 and has been steadily losing its best young people because they cannot find good jobs on the balmy but economically depressed island, lies at the eastern edge of the Caribbean. It is part of the recently independent nation of St. Kitts-Nevis. **********The Nelson anniversary celebration began as an idea of the Nevis Historical and Conservation Society, which is made up mainly of American and British expatriates and islanders who regularly associate with the 200 or so expatriates. They say they thought they could capitalize on the historic wedding as a way of getting some publicity for the island and maybe attracting some tourists. Nelson Role Hard to Fill **********Some Nevisians grumbled, however, that a black island that had endured slavery and colonialism should not be lionizing a couple of white colonials. Others contended that Nelson, like Alexander Hamilton, who was born here in 1757, had never done anything for Nevis and that therefore there was no reason for Nevis to do anything for Nelson. **********Amba Trott, the son of a Nevisian mother and an American father, found people reluctant to perform in his musical comedy, ''Horatio,'' which called for an all-black cast. Most of all, no one wanted the part of Nelson. **********Finally, a 26-year-old former policeman named Dennison Murrain, who says he was once so furious about slavery that he went around looking for whites to beat up, agreed to be Trott's Nelson. And the play was an enormous success. **********Mr. Murrain, like several others, said he joined in because he began to see commercial benefits for Nevis. ''I felt this was a moment we could take advantage of,'' he said one evening at the Longstone Bar, where he was helping out as a bartender. **********Simeon Daniel, Nevis's 52-year-old Premier, took part in many of the Nelson events, but he, too, seemed lukewarm to the anniversary. ''We cannot change the history we have,'' he said. ''We have to accept it. If it can be used to our benefit I see no reason we shouldn't exploit it.'' **********Nobody seemed concerned that Nelson's marriage to Fanny Nisbet, a young widow with a 5-year-old son, eventually went sour and that he abandoned her after beginning a notorious affair with the wife of a British diplomat. **********Nevis has been living in the sunset since about the time of the Nelson wedding. It had one of the first hotels in the Caribbean and the great plantation houses were a swirl of dinner parties and dances when Nelson arrived to patrol the West Indies. **********But the sugar market fell away and the abolition of slavery in the early 1830's made working the island's stony fields prohibitively expensive. Nevis became an island of peasant farmers and fishermen that these days is not nearly able to feed itself. **********The re-enactment of the wedding took place Wednesday on another flawless, sunny afternoon under the same huge kapok tree where Nelson and Miss Nisbet said their vows. An English couple, Colin MacMillan and Caroline Hayward, who had been married a few hours earlier in a small church in Charlestown, played the bride and groom, he in tricornered hat and knee britches and she in a sprigged muslin gown and lace-trimmed bonnet. **********They had vacationed on Nevis earlier, learned the anniversary was coming up and decided that having their own wedding coincide ''would be a rather nice link with England.'' They were delighted with the request to star in the re-enactment, which was the third wedding ceremony for them, counting the legal one in London. **********The festivities got going last Sunday with a horse race. A dozen thoroughbreds had been shipped in from Puerto Rico, but the winner of the final was a native-born bay of somewhat vague lineage and the crowd went wild, dancing and singing about the victory in verse. Lord Nelson Regrets **********On Wednesday morning hundreds of young people turned out on the main pier to watch couples mimicking the ballroom dances of slave owners, a greased pole contest and a swimming race in which a local boy beat a team of English seamen. **********Not all of the invited foreign guests turned up. The Englishman to whom Lord Nelson's title has descended, a police detective sergeant from a suburb of London, said he could not afford the air fare. The Nevis historical society offered to send him a plane ticket, but the deal fell through when the sergeant insisted his wife's fare be paid, too. **********The French, whose fleet Nelson defeated along with that of the Spanish in the Battle of Trafalgar, declined with a curt response. ''Not for Nelson,'' said a French diplomat. **********Most visitors seem to think of Nevis as a kind of unspoiled paradise. But the British sailors had a different view. **********''No discos, not many bars,'' said Clive Moonesamy, a 26-year-old Mauritian who now calls Scotland home. ''The place is dead.''
