https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/21/busin.main_headline: U.S. Shifts Policy On A.T.& T. Bid
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/21/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; U.S. Shifts Policy On A.T.& T. Bid
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/21/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Government said yesterday that it had reached an agreement with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company that would allow regulated telephone carriers to bid on a huge contract to modernize the Government's telephone system. **********In return, A.T.& T. agreed to drop a complaint it filed last week with the General Services Administration's contract board of appeals. The complaint protested stipulations in the contract proposal that, A.T.& T. contended, would not allow regulated telephone carriers to make a bid. **********After A.T.& T. submitted its complaint, the Government suspended the June 30 bidding deadline, indefinitely delaying the project. The contract is expected to be worth more than $4.2 billion for the winning consortium. **********Officials at the G.S.A., which oversees the Government's telephone system, said yesterday that the new bidding deadline would be July 30. The Government plans to award the contract by the end of the year, and G.S.A. officials said the project should proceed on schedule, more or less. **********G.S.A. officials have said that the new system, which is expected to be in full operation in 1990, would save the Government about $10 million a month in telephone costs. **********To achieve these savings, the G.S.A. decided to accept only bids that had fixed prices for telephone service. The G.S.A. later amended its request for proposals to exclude telephone companies regulated by the Federal Communications Commission, which determines phone rates for these companies through tariffs. **********Under the agreement announced yesterday, the G.S.A. will accept bids that are based either on a fixed price or a fixed-price tariff. Such a tariff must be approved by the F.C.C. and the carrier would agree to waive the right to seek tariff increases. In addition, the carrier must oppose any increase in the fixed-price tariff at no additional cost to the Government.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/28/busin.main_headline: Taking a Cue From the Euromarkets
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/28/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS FORUM: DOES THE U.S. NEED SUPERBANKS?; Taking a Cue From the Euromarkets
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/28/busin.body_text: **********THE recent Treasury proposal on ''superbanks'' rightly acknowledges that banking and financial services is a global industry that the United States cannot expect to dominate in the future simply because it dominated in the past. If our banks are to compete in the coming decades, they will need to be freed of some of the regulatory strictures that have hampered their growth. **********Financial regulation should strive to achieve a balance - to pay a reasonable price for security but not to pay too dearly. Unfortunately, current policy has struck a bad balance. New omnibus legislation, scrapping three key regulations while retaining other safeguards, would give the United States a more efficient financial services industry with greater international competitiveness. **********While the Treasury Department does not have a formal plan, it is widely supposed that top policy makers envision a system in which 5 to 10 major banks would compete with existing huge banks in Japan, West Germany, Britain and France. The superbanks would be owned in part or in full by industrial companies or bank holding companies, would expand into areas such as securities underwriting and would form interstate networks that would greatly increase their asset bases. **********Under current law, banks can do none of these things. The Bank Holding Company Act limits nonbank ownership of banks. The Glass-Steagall Act prohibits banks and their affiliates from engaging in corporate securities underwriting and dealing. And the McFadden Act limits interstate branching of banks. If the superbank concept is to become a reality, these three regulations will have to be amended. **********But lowering regulatory barriers is opposed by a wide array of interests. Opponents often claim that the quest for underwriting profits might induce banks to lend money to risky companies in hopes of bringing the companies' securities to market at a higher price. And if banks managed pension money, the critics say, they would be tempted to stuff the accounts with overpriced securities to assure the success of an underwriting deal. Finally, the critics assert that an unsuccessful underwriting operation could threaten the solvency of the entire bank, and that Federal deposit insurance would encourage excessive risk taking. **********In fact, loosening the restrictions would stimulate competitive forces, promote cost reductions, expand the set of available financial services and permit banks to diversify their sources of income (potentially reducing their risk of operation). **********How would the United States financial system work without Glass-Steagall? It would resemble in many ways the Eurobond market, where larger American banks underwrite securities through foreign affiliates. The Euromarket provides strong evidence that participants will behave prudently even when market entry is unrestricted and underwriting practices are largely unregulated. **********DISCIPLINE in the Eurobond market is provided largely by market forces and the participants' concern with maintaining a reputation for fair and equitable dealing. Thus, participants have brought mostly high-quality issues to market, developed market mechanisms to assure that new issues will be fairly priced and moved quickly to establish efficient, computerized clearing procedures to promote the secondary market. **********Further, as the Eurobond market shows, conflicts of interest can be managed successfully - primarily by separating the banks' various functions. For example, no money manager whose reputation is riding on his performance is going to allow an underwriter to stuff his account with overpriced securities. Moreover, strict separation of functions would insulate the bank and its deposit-taking activities from the possible depredations of individual affiliates. **********We could also expect to gain from interstate banking, which to a substantial degree already exists in the United States. Telecommunications and computer technology have increased efficiencies of scale in financial services. While Americans traditionally fear extreme concentration in banking, the more likely result would be industry tiering - money center banks would offer national distribution of financial services while a large number of regional and local banks would offer specialty services within their markets. **********By spreading their deposit bases as well as their lending activities, banks would reduce the risks of local and regional concentration that they now face. With a wider deposit base, Continental Illinois might not have felt the need to expand its interbank activities so aggressively, and it would not have been so vulnerable to a run by depositors. If Texas and Oklahoma banks could have expanded their lending activities outside their states, they would not be so weakened by the energy shock. By making international banking services more readily available throughout the nation, banks might also promote the export capabilities of small- and medium-size companies. **********Altering public policy regarding banking and financial institutions is a high-stakes game of balancing numerous, powerful political forces. But the evidence from numerous empirical studies, from United States banks' overseas activities and from foreign banking practices suggests that the Treasury is on the right course. Further deregulation would make the financial system more efficient and competitive, with a minimal risk to society.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/23/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; AMERICAN EXPRESS HAS GAIN
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/23/busin.body_text: **********Two of the nation's leading financial services concerns, the American Express Company and the Morgan Stanley Group, yesterday announced higher earnings for the fourth quarter of 1986. **********American Express, which has operations in travel-related services, international banking and insurance, said that net income in the quarter edged up 1.7 percent, to $277.2 million, or $1.25 a share, from $272.6 million, or $1.19 a share, in the comparable 1985 quarter. Revenues were up 21.8 percent, to $4.08 billion, from $3.35 billion. **********''The earnings comparisons at American Express for the fourth quarter were a lot better than the numbers indicate,'' said Larry Eckenfelder, an analyst at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. ''On an operating basis, American Express could have reported a gain of about 10 percent were it not for certain nonrecurring items.'' **********He noted that in the fourth quarter of 1985 there was a net nonrecurring gain of 7 cents a share from the sale of the company's Fireman's Fund subsidiary. **********For the full year, American Express said earnings rose 54.4 percent, to $1.25 billion, or $5.55 a share, from $809.6 million, or $3.55 a share, in 1985. Revenues were up 23.6 percent, to $14.65 billion, from $11.85 billion. **********James D. Robinson 3d, the company's chairman and chief executive, said that 1986 was the first year in which annual net income had surpassed $1 billion. **********American Express attributed its strong earnings gain for the year to record results in travel-related services and a solid performance by its Shearson Lehman Brothers brokerage subsidiary, which was helped by active equity markets. **********In trading on the New York Stock Exchange, American Express shares rose $1.25 yesterday, to $69.375. Morgan Stanley **********Morgan Stanley, citing gains from merger and acquisition activity and equity underwriting, said earnings in the fourth quarter rose 73.2 percent, to $58.2 million, or $2.31 a share, from $33.6 million, or $1.69 a share, in the fourth quarter of 1985. **********Revenues for the fourth quarter were up 14.7 percent, to $629 million, from $548.4 million. **********Mr. Eckenfelder said Morgan Stanley's earnings were ''terrific'' but that the comparison was a bit misleading because the company had a lower tax rate in the latest quarter. ''If the tax rate were adjusted, earnings in the latest three months would have been in the $1.80-to-$1.90-a-share range,'' he said. **********For the full year, Morgan Stanley said, earnings nearly doubled, to $201.3 million, or $8.42 a share, from $105.9 million, or $5.32 a share. Revenues moved up 37.4 percent, to $2.46 billion, from $1.79 billion. **********Shares of Morgan Stanley climbed $3.25, to $72.75, yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/02/world.main_headline: Reagan Takes a Poke at Gorbachev on Nicaragua
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/02/world.print_headline: Reagan Takes a Poke at Gorbachev on Nicaragua
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/02/world.body_text: **********President Reagan, apparently countering Mikhail S. Gorbachev's remarks in a televised interview about the Soviet role in Afghanistan, declared today: ''The simple people of Afghanistan pose no threat to Soviet territory. They don't now. They never have.'' **********On Monday, Mr. Gorbachev made a similar remark referring to United States support for the Nicaraguan rebels, saying: ''I have to smile when I hear that the security of the United States is being threatened by the Sandinista regime. That's not serious. It certainly is not serious.'' **********Both issues, the Soviet combat role in Afghanistan and United States support for the contras, are on the agenda for discussion at the summit conference next week. **********With three speeches on summit-related issues in the last week, including today's address to several thousand Duval County high school seniors and their parents, Mr. Reagan has stated most of his broad summit-conference bargaining positions. And in an interview with NBC News that was broadcast Monday night, Mr. Gorbachev stated most of his. Found It 'Interesting' **********The White House said Mr. Reagan watched ''parts'' of the Gorbachev interview ''and found it interesting.'' **********Asked today how he thought Mr. Gorbachev did on television, Mr. Reagan said: ''I'll concede to him. He's a guest.'' **********He added, ''I've had a respect for him ever since I met him.'' **********Later, when a high school student asked him if he was upset about Mr. Gorbachev's ''rising popularity,'' Mr. Reagan said: ''No, I don't resent his popularity or anything else. Good Lord, I co-starred with Errol Flynn once.'' **********In his speech, Mr. Reagan repeated his demand ''for the Soviets to set a date certain for withdrawal'' from Afghanistan. But he did not discuss the reciprocal Soviet demand, that the United States end support for the Afghan rebels. Criticism of Soviet Union **********He criticized the Soviet Union and its allies for ''continuing to pour billions of dollars in guns, planes, bullets, tanks and other assistance into Nicaragua'' even as ''the five Central American countries search for peace.'' He did not refer to his plan to ask Congress for new military aid for the Nicaraguan rebels early next year. **********Mr. Reagan's speech was similar in form and tone to several he has given in the last two weeks. But missing this time was the centerpiece of most of the previous speeches: a strong endorsement for the Strategic Defense Initiative, his plan for a space-based missile defense. **********But when the speech ended and six students chosen by the school board were permitted to ask questions, one of them asked the President to repeat his support for the Strategic Defense Initiative, popularly known as ''Star Wars.'' **********''Oh, I'd be delighted,'' Mr. Reagan said with a smile, and then explained what the proposed missile defense system would do. Finally, he noted that after World War I, when poison gas warfare was banned, ''everybody kept their gas masks anyway.'' **********As for the Strategic Defense Initiative, Mr. Reagan said, ''I think of this as a gigantic gas mask.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/18/world.main_headline: Greek Police Break Up An Anti-U.S. Protest
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/18/world.print_headline: Greek Police Break Up An Anti-U.S. Protest
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/18/world.body_text: **********The police fired tear gas and water cannon to disperse leftist demonstrators after an annual march on the United States Embassy here tonight to protest purported collusion between Washington and the colonels who ruled Greece from 1967 to 1974. **********The police said 12 people - eight protesters from a group of 2,000 whose banners proclaimed them to be anarchists and four policemen - were injured in the clash. **********The march of an estimated 100,000 protesters through central Athens demonstrated a depth of anti-American sentiment that has implications for recently opened negotiations on the future of United States military bases in Greece, a NATO ally. **********Some protesters tonight chanted slogans like, ''Out with the murderous bases!'' The United States maintains four major bases and a string of minor military installations in Greece, with some 4,500 Americans stationed at them. **********The annual march commemorates the military suppression of an uprising against the junta in 1973 at the Athens Polytechnic. Twenty-two people died in the uprising. **********For the past three days, Greek politicians have laid wreaths at the college to commemorate the students' revolt.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/27/busin.body_text: **********The Eastman Kodak Company said today that it would acquire a 16 percent equity interest in Genencor Inc., a biotechnology company based here that specializes in industrial products. Genencor, formed in 1982 as a joint venture between Genentech Inc. and Corning Glass Works, was spun off in 1983 and has been owned equally by the founding companies and Staley Continental Inc. since 1984. **********New stock would be issued to cover Kodak's stake in the company, which it can increase during 1987. Further terms were not disclosed, but Kodak said that it had agreed to a multimillion-dollar, multiyear commitment to research and development projects related to the use of Genencor's enzymes as food additives and in other applications. Genencor is a private company with more than 100 employees, and it does not release financial data. **********Kodak's investment in Genencor closely follows the announcement that it would sell its shares in ICN Pharmaceuticals Inc., a company based in Costa Mesa, Calif., that is best known for an antiviral drug, Ribavirin. Kodak has also taken stakes in the Amgen Corporation, the Immunex Corporation, the Cetus Corporation and Engenics. Analysts estimated that it had invested more than $100 million in biotechnology.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/12/world.main_headline: Four Haiti Candidates Unite And Demand Regime Resign
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/12/world.print_headline: Four Haiti Candidates Unite And Demand Regime Resign
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/12/world.body_text: **********The four leading presidential candidates united today in opposition to the army-dominated provisional Government and, in a hardening of their position, demanded that the Government step down. **********The four candidates had previously insisted that any new elections must be carried out by an independent body and had declared their refusal to participate in elections run by the Government. They acted as a protest against the violent disruption of the presidential election nearly two weeks ago, which caused it to be called off. **********Until today, however, the candidates had been unable to form a united front against the Government of Lieut. Gen. Henry Namphy because three of the candidates had been unwilling to demand the Government's resignation. **********In a statement today the three candidates - Marc Bazin, a 55-year-old economist; Gerard Gourgue, a 61-year-old lawyer and human rights activist, and Louis Dejoie 2d, a 59-year-old building contractor - indicated that they had shifted their position to join the fourth candidate, Sylvio C. Claude, a 55-year-old Baptist minister. New Election Date **********They said they acted in response to the Government's announcement this week that it had set a Jan. 17 date for a new election and arranged a new calendar of election activities. **********The four candidates said that by taking these steps before the establishment of a new electoral council, which under the constitution is supposed to oversee all aspects of an election, the Government had ''confirmed, once more, its deliberate will'' to take an illegal and unconstitutional position and ''lead the country to catastrophe.'' **********In an interview today, Information Minister Gerard Noel, the chief Government spokesman, expressed indifference to the candidates, whom Western diplomats and many Haitians estimate are supported by more than 80 per cent of the country's voters. **********''They are free to participate or not participate in elections,'' he said. ''It doesn't interest the Government to know who is a candidate and who isn't.'' 'The Big Stick' **********Asked for the Government's reaction to the suspension of United States military and most economic aid to Haiti after the aborted election, Mr. Noel replied: ''It's not the first time it has happened in the history of this country that the great powers impose with the big stick their views of the situation.'' **********The Nov. 29 election was halted after soldiers and thugs in civilian clothes shot at and attacked people on the streets and in polling places. At least 34 people are believed to have been killed. **********Mr. Noel said that a Government investigation had been started into the election violence, but he said he did not know if arrests had been made. 'A Communist Threat' **********In contrast to the views of United States officials and other diplomats here, Mr. Noel said there is ''a permanent agitation'' and ''a Communist threat'' in Haiti. **********General Namphy, who became head of the provisional government when the dictatorship of Jean-Claude Duvalier collapsed 22 months ago, disbanded the original nine-member electoral council that had organized the election on Nov. 29. He acted hours after the voting was halted. **********Most of the civic and religious organizations that had appointed members to the original council have refused to name replacements. The Government tonight announced the formation of a council with its own appointees, none of who appeared to be well known.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/14/world.main_headline: CASEY SAID TO HAVE OFFERED NORTH $1 MILLION OF HIS OWN FOR CONTRAS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/14/world.print_headline: CASEY SAID TO HAVE OFFERED NORTH $1 MILLION OF HIS OWN FOR CONTRAS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/14/world.body_text: **********Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North reported that William J. Casey, the former Director of Central Intelligence, once volunteered to give $1 million of his own money to the Nicaraguan rebels, Robert C. McFarlane testified today. **********Mr. McFarlane, a former national security adviser to President Reagan, said Colonel North had reported the offer to him in a joking fashion. Mr. McFarlane said that he was not sure whether to believe that the offer, which was apparently made in 1985, was genuine, but that the comment ''was expressive of a relationship that surprised me'' between Colonel North and Mr. Casey. **********Indeed, Mr. McFarlane said in testimony today, he has begun to believe that Colonel North may actually have been working for the Central Intelligence Agency. Colonel North was a close friend of Mr. McFarlane and served as one of his deputies on the National Security Council. Question by Senator **********Mr. McFarlane made his disclosure in response to a question from Senator William S. Cohen, Republican of Maine. **********''Can I ask you, whether you ever suspected that Oliver North was taking instructuons, not from you, but from the D.C.I.?'' Senator Cohen asked, referring to the Director of Central Intelligence. ''Yes, sir,'' Mr. McFarlane replied. Asked why he suspected Colonel North was working for the C.I.A., Mr. McFarlane said, ''I became aware in the fall of 1985 that Ollie had more contacts with the Director than I had realized.'' Offer of $1 Million **********Mr. McFarlane said he had been particularly struck that Mr. Casey had mentioned the $1 million offer to Colonel North, who was the chief Administration fund-raiser for the contras. **********Mr. Casey, who died earlier this month, made a fortune as a Wall Street legal expert before managing President Reagan's 1980 election campaign and becoming Director of Central Intelligence in 1981. **********Senator Warren B. Rudman, Republican of New Hampsire and vice chairman of the Senate committee, said Mr. McFarlane's suggestion that Colonel North might have worked for Mr. Casey ''was the most interesting answer of the day.'' **********Senator Rudman said he and Senator Cohen had agreed to question Mr. McFarlane about the relationship ''because of information we have.'' He declined to say what the information was. **********As a further indication that Colonel North enjoyed a special tie to Mr. Casey, Senator Cohen noted that the committees had evidence that the C.I.A. station chief in Costa Rica had been ordered to ''report to North.'' Question of North's Power **********Mr. McFarlane's suggestion about Colonel North's link to Mr. Casey cast new light on one of the major puzzles of the Iran-contra affair - how a relatively junior official like Colonel North was able to wield so much authority. **********Senator David L. Boren, Democrat of Oklahoma, said he believed Colonel North was not working for Mr. Casey but instead had turned to Mr. Casey when Mr. McFarlane had placed limits on his activities to aid the contras. **********''He was not Mr. Casey's agent, but used Casey as a way to get around Mr. McFarlane,'' said Senator Boren, who is also chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/23/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY; Corporate Help Grows for Entrepreneurs
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/23/busin.body_text: **********WHEN Raymond Kurzweil asked the Xerox Corporation for venture capital in 1982 to develop a computer that could transcribe spoken English, the company did not take long to respond. **********''We saw right off that the proposed technology would have an immediate impact on our business so we signed him up,'' said Richard J. Hayes, who heads Xerox's venture capital operations. Xerox quickly decided to invest $1 million in Kurzweil Applied Intelligence Inc. of Waltham, Mass. **********That reasoning makes sense to an increasing number of large corporations, according to venture capital experts. Venture Economics Inc., an information services company based in Wellesley, Mass., estimates that the nation's industrial giants invested a record $300 million in start-up companies last year. **********The primary goal of most of these corporate venture capital investments is to identify new technologies and the products based on them that have a strategic fit with the company. In Kurzweil's case, Xerox followed its initial investment with an additional $3.9 million. With that financing and $17 million from more traditional venture capitalists like Oxford Partners and Regional Financial Enterprises, Kurzweil has emerged as a leader in electronic voice recognition and a source of Xerox products. **********Xerox, which has non-exclusive rights to use Kurzweil's technology, already markets Kurzweil's VoiceRAD, a device that converts the oral observations of radiologists examining X-rays into electronic notes in a computer. It also plans to use voice recognition in office products. **********In many cases though, the 20 to 25 percent return on equity averaged by successful venture capital funds has been as significant a lure as the chance to gain access to new technology. Indeed, the likelihood of a substantial financial return has become the primary consideration of some of the most successful corporate venture capitalists, such as the General Electric Company. G.E. has backed several notable computer start-ups, including Tandem Computers and Stratus Computer Inc. and now has $260 million in the venture fund it started nearly 20 years ago. **********Technology experts say that the trend toward corporate venture capital funds underscores a grudging recognition by some big companies that many new technologies need to be incubated in an entrepreneurial environment that is tough to maintain inside a corporate bureaucracy. **********''Corporations have great difficulty managing internal start-ups because the management standards that work in the existing culture are totally inappropriate for a company in formation,'' said Zenas Block, the associate director of the Center for Entrepreneurial Studies at New York University. ''Small companies can make decisions faster and get technology from the lab to the marketplace at a much quicker pace.'' **********Large corporations have adopted a variety of strategies to protect internally developed ideas from bureaucracy, including the establishment in some cases of venture capital funds intended for use by entrepreneurial employees. The Eastman Kodak Company, for instance, directs a substantial portion of its four-year-old $80 million venture capital fund to internally developed ideas that are ''outside the core business,'' said Frank Strong, senior vice president and general manager of Diversified Technology, a Kodak business group that includes Eastman Technology Inc., the venture company. **********When the start-up companies are successful in developing products, Kodak may then buy the companies. That is how Kodak, based in Rochester, added to its product lines lithium batteries and a device that provides overhead projection of the image on a personal computer screen. **********But venture capital experts say that many large corporations have learned it is hard to acquire truly independent start-up companies. **********''Large companies have had terrible luck in acquiring leading technology concerns because you just can't buy entrepreneurial brains,'' said Mark Radtke, president of Venture Economics. ''So they got smart and said, 'Maybe we don't have to own the company to get what we want.' '' **********For whatever mix of reasons, even such high-tech giants as the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, which operates perhaps the world's largest corporate research facility, Bell Laboratories, now have active venture capital arms. **********A.T.&T. makes all of its venture capital investments through Edelson Technolgy Partners L.P., which was started by A.T.&T., the 3M Corporation and Gulf and Western about three years ago. The fund is operated by Harry Edelson, a former Wall Street securities analyst. **********Mr. Edelson's main concern is return on investment but he said that he also looks for business opportunities for his investors. **********A.T.&T. recently struck a major business deal with one company in which Edelson had invested, the American Telephone and Electronics Company. A.T.&E., which developed a wristwatch pager, has chosen A.T.&T. to provide the international telephone network for the service. **********Each month, Dr. Christian F. Horn, president of Grace Ventures, a division of W.R. Grace & Company, compiles a list of technologies that he reviews as potential investments. The list is circulated throughout the company to give division managers a perspective on emerging technologies. **********Grace has invested in 40 companies, including Oral Research Laboratories, which has developed a dental rinse called Plax that reduces plaque on teeth; the Micro Linear Corporation, which makes analog and digital semiconductors, and Biosis, a producer of pest control products. **********It is not always clear how helpful these arrangements are for the start-up companies. Analysts believe that General Motors' investments in five machine vision companies may have weakened several of them in the long run by skewing their product development toward G.M.'s needs shortly before G.M. decided to cut back its spending on such equipment. **********But other entrepreneurs see major corporations as especially valuable backers that can give them an advantage in marketing new technology.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/22/world.main_headline: BOOK BY AIDE TO MITTERRAND CAUSING A STIR
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/22/world.print_headline: BOOK BY AIDE TO MITTERRAND CAUSING A STIR
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/22/world.body_text: **********When Jacques Attali, who is widely known in this country as President Francois Mitterrand's closest adviser, published an admiring biography of Siegmund Warburg, the head of the German-British Warburg banking dynasty, many in this country detected a paradox. **********It was strange, they said, that Mr. Attali, a Socialist economist, would make a hero of a leading capitalist banker, a member of a profession as widely distrusted by French populist tradition as tax collectors. **********Some said the book showed that Mr. Attali was not really a Socialist or, more likely, that Socialism had lost its ideological sting in France. **********But Mr. Attali, whose book on Mr. Warburg, ''A Man of Influence,'' will be published in the United States this year by Adler & Adler, says he sees no contradiction between his conspicuous political role and the scholarly interests that have led him to write 11 books on often rather academic subjects. A Writer First **********Sitting behind an antique desk in his office next to Mr. Mitterrand's, Mr. Attali asserted that he is above all a writer and a scholar, rather than a political figure. ''A writer cannot be identified with anything other than his own work,'' he said. ''I cannot be shrunk to my political ideas.'' **********''I wanted to tell a story, like a novelist, and I was fascinated by this one,'' he said of his interest in the Warburg banking dynasty, with its origins in the 16th century. **********When ''A Man of Influence'' was published more than a year ago, it was a literary event in France, topping the nonfiction best-seller list for some time. Presumably, some of the book's success was due to a certain public fascination with Mr. Attali, a kind of symbolic outsider now close to the heart of political power. **********Indeed, Mr. Attali's closeness to Mr. Mitterrand, and his reputation as a man of ideas, gave the epithets used in the French press to identify him a certain hackneyed ring. He has been called the ''shadow intellectual,'' the ''great pooh-bah,'' the ''hidden face of the Elysee.'' **********Mr. Attali in this sense reflects the image of Mr. Mitterrand, who has himself written 12 books. The Elysee Palace under Mr. Mitterrand, even more than under other presidents, has an air of attachment to intellectual life. **********Mr. Attali has written books on economic history, on music, and on the development of timepieces, all of them efforts, he said, to understand history by looking at a single theme over a long period of time. And his appreciation of Mr, Warburg, whom Mr. Attali calls ''the prince of finance, the adventurer of the century,'' seems to reflect some deep historic similarities between the two men that transcend labels and particular beliefs. Both From Jewish Families **********Despite obvious differences, there are clear parallels in the lives of the banker and the socialist economist that drew Mr. Attali to his subject. **********The biography of Mr. Warburg, who died in 1982 at the age of 80, traces the German-Jewish banker from his flight from Nazi Germany to England only months after Hitler took power; it then recounts his extraordinary success as a transplanted wartime financier of the Allies and creator of the postwar banking and monetary systems. **********Mr. Attali was born 43 years ago in Algeria, where his Jewish father, a wealthy merchant, studied Spinoza and instilled ambition in his children. Mr. Attali, who clearly relishes being friendly with the rich and powerful of this world, came to France when he was 12 and began a dazzling climb through the leading French institutions of higher learning, including the Ecole Nationale d'Administration, the most exclusive and clubby of them all. **********When, after a career as a university teacher, Mr. Attali was appointed special adviser to the newly elected Mr. Mitterrand in 1981, much was made of his age - he was 37 at the time - as well as his Sephardic Jewish origins and the fact that he continued to write books in his spare time. **********Mr. Attali says that several aspects of the life of Siegmund Warburg seem consistent and even supportive of his own political ideas, even though Mr. Warburg was no socialist. **********''He was not a conservative,'' Mr. Attali said. ''He was mainly fighting for civilization, I would say. He was very demanding of both himself and of others, and I would way that that is a socialist ideal. It is an ideal that I share.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/23/busin.body_text: **********The stock market surrendered virtually all of Tuesday's near-record advance yesterday, as the Dow Jones industrial average plunged 51.13, its fifth-worst point decline ever, to close at 2,285.94. **********What interest rates gave the market as they declined Tuesday, they took away yesterday. Bond prices fell sharply, especially in the afternoon, insuring there would be no replay of the previous day's stock-buying spasm. On Tuesday the Dow soared 66.47 points, with more than half of the gain occurring in the last hour. Yesterday the Dow dropped 37.78 points in the last hour. **********''If the market had closed at 3 o'clock both days, there would be no story,'' one trader said. **********Instead, the story this week has been of the market's changing moods as investors have been whipsawed by unusual volatility. Treasury Notes and Bonds Drop **********The stock market's swings in the last two days have been strongly influenced by credit market activity, and yesterday the price of Treasury issues dropped sharply, particularly after the two-year United States notes were auctioned at 1 P.M. Traders were disappointed by the weak demand for the notes and worried that Japanese portfolio managers will not be avid buyers of Treasury issues. Credit market participants said they were also worried about the possibility of further declines in the dollar against the Japanese yen.  [ Page D25. ]  The worries that appeared as interest rates rose in the credit markets were compounded by the release of the Government's durable goods report, which showed a stronger-than-expected rise of 3.4 percent. That raised the prospect of a strong economy and an environment of high interest rates and inflation. **********Today's scheduled release of gross national product figures contributed to Wall Street's anxiety. **********Some Wall Street experts had expected stocks to build on Tuesday's rally, or at least hold steady. But others, who noted that Tuesday's big gain was dominated by the blue-chip issues, suspected that institutionally backed program trading was responsible for much of the advance. Computer ''buy'' programs were set off by the disparity between the value of futures contracts based on baskets of major stocks and the actual cash value of those stocks. Yesterday, this argument goes, the spread reversed and ''sell'' programs kicked in. **********''This market has no liquidity,'' said Jack Rubenstein, an associate director at Bear, Stearns & Company. ''When the market takes a direction, everyone goes in that direction.'' 'Let's Lighten Up' **********In trying to explain the turn in investor sentiment, Mr. Rubenstein commented: ''They said, 'Let's lighten up; let's not take any chances. Tuesday they gave me 67 points. That's enough.' '' **********Some traders said they were not perturbed by the way the market has been acting and predicted that the Dow would settle in a roughly 200-point trading range, from 2,200 to 2,400. One trader noted that the Dow is so high that its gyrations are magnified: ''We're talking points here, not percentages.'' **********Still, ''the volatility is very unsettling,'' said Jack Salomon, the chief technical analyst at Bear, Stearns. ''It's a little bit too wild.'' The New York Stock Exchange's composite index sagged 2.95, to 162.55, and the S.& P. 500-stock index dropped 5.88, to 287.19. Volume on the Big Board was 185.9 million shares; on Tuesday it was 191.3 million. Only 562 stocks gained ground as 1,053 were losers for the day. **********Most of the stocks that make up the Dow Jones industrial average lost ground. I.B.M., up 7 points Tuesday, lost 2 3/4 yesterday, as most technology stocks ran out of steam. Digital Equipment lost 3 1/8, to 164 3/4, in wild trading. But Unisys continued to do well, gaining 3 3/8 points, to 116 1/2; analysts and investors alike have been attracted by its earnings. **********Elsewhere, it was announced that Merrill Lynch and executives of Supermarkets General, which is being pursued by the Haft family, planned to take the company private at a price of $46.75 a share for 85 percent of the stock. Supermarkets General jumped 4 3/4, to 45 7/8, and was the most active issue, with more than 4.3 million shares traded. **********The American Stock Exchange index fell 1.89, to 327.07, and in over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq index eased 0.40, to 418.16. **********Allegheny Beverage, on the Amex, jumped 4 3/4, to 10 3/4, after announcing that it would sell its Service America food unit for $500 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/19/busin.body_text: **********Housing construction showed surprising strength in January, helped by unusually mild weather at the beginning of the month, the Government reported today. **********As a result, building activity remained above the 1.8-million-unit mark for the second consecutive month. **********The Commerce Department said that new homes and apartments were built at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.81 million units in January, down only two-tenths of 1 percent from December, when construction activity had posted a giant 10.4 percent increase. Decline Had Been Forecast **********Analysts, who had been forecasting a significant decline in January, said that mild weather helped increase the figures, just as it had in December. **********But they also said that the housing industry, which had been expected to weaken this year, is showing more strength than expected. **********David Seiders, chief economist for the National Association of Home Builders, said further declines in interest rates in January helped to spur demand for homes. **********For all of last year, construction activity rose 3.7 percent, to the highest level in eight years, as the housing industry enjoyed the lowest home mortgage rates of this decade. Rates dropped further in January to a nationwide average for fixed-rate loans of 9 percent with some parts of the country reporting mortgage rates as low as 8.5 percent. Rate Forecasts Revised **********While analysts had been predicting rates would continue dropping until early summer, some have revised those forecasts in light of recent increases in interest rates brought on by declines in the value of the dollar. **********Richard Peach, senior economist at the Mortgage Bankers Association, said he now believed mortgage rates would probably hold steady where they are now, instead of declining another half percentage point as he had originally thought. **********Most economists are forecasting that single-family construction will continue to rise in 1987, aided by favorable mortgage rates, but that this increase will be offset by a significant decline in multifamily construction caused by adverse impacts from the new tax law and high rental vacancy rates. **********James Christian, chief economist for the United States League of Savings Institutions, predicted that housing construction will total 1.7 million units this year, down from 1.81 million units started last year. **********January's report showed that construction of single-family homes remained strong, rising 2.4 percent from December, to an annual rate of 1.26 million units. But construction of multifamily units fell by 5.5 percent, to an annual rate of 551,000 units. **********Building permits, considered a good sign of future activity, plunged 11.6 percent in January, to an annual total of 1.69 million units. It was the biggest monthly decline since March 1984, but analysts said the weakness was overstated. They noted that permits had risen a huge 18.4 percent in December as California builders rushed to take out applications before Jan. 1, when higher fees took effect. **********The Northeast, the hottest housing region last year, saw construction rise 7.5 percent in January, to a rate of 330,000 units, followed by a 1.8 percent increase in the Middle West, where starts increased to an annual rate of 404,000 units, the highest rate since December 1978.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/28/world.body_text: **********As students take to the streets of South Korea, social campaigners go to jail in Singapore and politicians in China wrestle over a path to development, many East Asians are re-examining in an age of turbulence the clear-headed teachings of an ancient sage: Confucius. **********The director of the Institute of East Asian Philosophies here and head of a national Committee on Confucian Ethics, Wu Teh Yao, says he does not find this surprising. Professor Wu, a Chinese-born scholar in his 70's, tasted the learning of West and East before focusing on the study of a political system close to his roots. **********''Confucianism is neither a philosophy nor a religion - though it has the elements of both,'' he said in an interview at his National University of Singapore office. ''It is a way of life.'' **********As such, he said, a study of Confucianism can serve Asians struggling to weigh Western values against their own beliefs and Westerners trying to understand the philosophical underpinnings of East Asia. **********Though Confucius was born in the sixth century B.C., his thoughts, collected by disciples in the Analects, have refreshing relevance, Professor Wu said. Confucianism is a humanistic system, devoted to man's relationship to man, not to God. It emphasizes harmony with nature, respects intellect and education and cautions against greed and corruption, although not frowning on the accumulation of wealth. 'We Are Tolerant' **********''If you were to piece it all together, you would find it is an all-pervading unity,'' he said. ''There is no supernatural, no required ritual, no credo to embrace. **********''I am a Christian and a Presbyterian elder,'' Professor Wu said, but I am also a Confucian disciple.'' **********''Take a man like Zhou Enlai,'' he added. ''He was a Communist; there is no doubt. But inside - in his behavior - he was very Confucian.'' **********Professor Wu, who writes about Confucianism for English-speaking audiences and supervises the translation of Chinese classics into bei hua, a simplified, modern Chinese, says he believes the purest forms of Confucianism are found in South Korea, Japan and Taiwan. **********Interest is also picking up in China, he said. Plans for Conference in China **********On Aug. 31, Professor Wu and more than a hundred experts from around the world are to meet at the birthplace of Confucius, in Qufu, China, for a four-day conference on the development of Confucian learning and its influence on society. **********''The study of Confucius has never stopped in China,'' said Professor Wu, a graduate of Nanking University who also has an M.A. from the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy and a Ph.D. from Harvard. **********''During the Cultural Revolution, scholars may have been put on ice,'' he said, ''but they were often allowed free time to do their research. They put it in writing afterwards. We have an academic gold mine there now.'' **********Apart from its relevance to Asian tradition, Confucianism is also being studied, Professor Wu said, ''to counterbalance the impact of values from the West, particularly those of rights and individualism.'' **********''The Confucian system stresses obligations, not rights, and group spirit, not individualism,'' said Professor Wu. But that does not mean it condones authoritarianism or militarism, he added. If a leader loses the people's trust, the right to rule is forfeited, he said. **********''In all human societies, once the tummy is full, you begin to think,'' said Professor Wu, adding that a paper was now being written at the institute on the place of protest in a Confucian society. **********''So, whoever is going to rule, even in Japan or China, will have to pay attention to the people's needs and wishes,'' he said. ''That goes back basically to the trust of the people. In a modern sense, that is the expression of democracy.''
