https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/10/busin.main_headline: TOSHIBA DETAILS TRAIL OF CRIME IN SALE OF MACHINERY TO SOVIET
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/10/busin.print_headline: TOSHIBA DETAILS TRAIL OF CRIME IN SALE OF MACHINERY TO SOVIET
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/10/busin.body_text: **********In a rare look at the inner workings of Japanese corporate crime, the Toshiba Corporation explained in detail today how a subsidiary had signed secret agreements with Moscow, twice duped Japanese authorities, silenced its employees when they complained of illegalities and burned documents once investigators were on its trail. **********The account, following an internal investigation by Toshiba, was released as part of the company's effort to head off a threatened ban on shipments of Toshiba products to the United States. **********Company officials said the disclosures supported Toshiba's contention that no one at the parent company knew of the sale of submarine technology, which Pentagon officials say has greatly helped the Soviet Navy to reduce the operating noise of its undersea fleet. A Behind-the-Scenes Look **********American officials said they were unsure whether Toshiba's strategy would work. But they were fascinated by the unflattering behind-the-scenes look that Toshiba offered. **********Cultural differences notwithstanding, one Commerce Department official commented, the report shows that Japan ''has a few things to teach General Motors, but it has more to teach Ollie North.'' **********In fact, there are striking parallels between the actions taken by executives of the Toshiba Machine Company and those of Washington bureaucrats who have complained recently of annoying legal constraints that prevented them from getting their jobs done. Instructions to Employees **********Told in 1980 that the sale of the milling machines to the Russians violated Japanese export controls, the president of Toshiba Machine, Masanobu Hisano, instructed his employees ''to do what had to be done to get the business,'' the report says. When it became clear that the model names of the equipment about to be exported to the Soviet Union would cause suspicion, the machines were renamed for the benefit of Japanese licensing officials. **********And when the pyramid of lies began to collapse, Toshiba Machine managers systematically combed their files and burned anything that raised too many questions about the deal. **********''The Japanese don't seem to like shredders the way we do,'' observed Donald J. Zoeller, who headed the Toshiba investigation for Mudge, Rose, Guthrie, Alexander & Ferdon, the New York law firm that wrote the report. **********Mr. Zoeller's team provided a wealth of details about the transaction, but the outlines of the deal described in the report closely follow past accounts of how the Russians obtained eight state-of-the-art machine tools, capable of producing subtly contoured marine propellers. **********At the same time, the report -based on more than 40 interviews with Toshiba employees and a review of thousands of company documents - left several questions about the Toshiba scandal unanswered. **********For example, the report appeared to contradict accounts given by officials of Kongsberg Vaapenfabrikk, the state-owned Norwegian arms company that provided specializied minicomputers known as numerical controllers. These guide the action of the giant machine tools. **********According to Kongsberg, its highest company official involved in the deal was Bernhard John Green, a British national, who supervised sales to the Soviet bloc for the company. But lawyers at Mudge, Rose say at least one of Mr. Green's superiors was involved in early negotiations. **********As many American officials had predicted, the report clears the Toshiba Corporation, which commissioned it, of any responsibility for watching over the actions of Toshiba Machine. The Toshiba Corporation owns 50.08 percent of Toshiba Machine. **********Toshiba Machine ''operated on a day-to-day business basis solely on its own,'' Mr. Zoeller said, as Toshiba officials in the audience nodded in agreement. The corporate parent was deceived by its subsidiary until late last spring, he said. **********That finding is critical to Toshiba's argument that punishing the entire company with an import ban would be ''unfair, discriminatory and counterproductive,'' as one Mudge, Rose lawyer said today. Company officials also contend that an import ban would put American jobs in jeopardy. Nobuo Ishizaka, chairman of Toshiba America Inc., denied that the company was lobbying to derail sanctions, which will be considered in a House-Senate conference on the trade bill this month. **********Rather, he said: ''our American employees are concerned about their livelihood; they are entitled to bring that up with Congress. I do not call that lobbying.'' **********While Toshiba says it should not be held responsible for past actions of its subsidiaries, it appeared to be reversing its hands-off management practices. Along with the investigative report, the company made public a 62-page ''Strategic Products Control Program,'' mandatory for all its subsidiaries, that sets rules for technologically sensitive exports. **********The rules will be administered by a staff at the parent company's Tokyo headquarters, and the subsidiaries will be subject to spot audits to assure they are obeying the rules. **********Mr. Ishizaka called the program a model set of guidelines, and he urged other Japanese companies to adopt it. While the Commerce Department publicly commended the move this afternoon, Congressional staff members working on the Toshiba case suggested the company was not in a position to lecture its industrial colleagues. **********The details provided by Toshiba today provide some insights into how Japanese companies deal both with Soviet officials and with political and competitive pressures at home. **********For example, two employees of Toshiba Machine, one a designer and the other a manager, apparently objected to the technology diversion. One of the employees ''was instructed that the proposed transaction was in the best interest of the company and that he should serve the company's interest,'' according to the report. That argument prevailed, and the employee later agreed - apparently unwillingly - to be the project manager for the sale. **********The report also indicates that the Soviet Government, while in need of Toshiba Machine's cooperation, did not trust the company. When Toshiba Machine's engineers arrived at the Baltic Shipyard in Leningrad to install the first four of the eight machines eventually delivered, they were allowed to touch only two of them. The other two apparently were installed by Soviet technicians, who watched the Japanese at work each day and then toiled in a separate building at night, putting together the other two. Toshiba engineers were never allowed in the other building.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/27/world.main_headline: EAST BERLIN RAIDS STAGED ON CHURCH
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/27/world.print_headline: EAST BERLIN RAIDS STAGED ON CHURCH
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/27/world.body_text: **********East German security agents, making raids on unofficial Christian advocates, detained at least 21 people and broke into the homes of several others in a three-day crackdown, church people said today. **********Nineteen of those arrested were released after three hours of negotiations between church leaders and the authorities, West German television reported. **********The crackdown began with a raid on a church library Tuesday night, followed by more arrests after a protest vigil on Wednesday. **********Starting early today, the authorities rounded up several other religious campaigners, many of them living in the Prenzlauer Berg district of the city, where the church that was raided is situated, the church people said. 'Caught Red-Handed' **********The official East German press agency, in a first brief report, said today, ''Seven people were caught red-handed producing material hostile to the state.'' **********The press agency and West German television said two people had been charged. The church people who described the crackdown said most of those who had been arrested had been released. **********Church negotiators pledged to strive to prevent further ''spectacular actions'' like the protest vigil, but only on the condition that the campaigners were released immediately, West German television reported. **********Those initially detained were said to include Barbel Boley, a disarmament advocate who served a month in prison in 1983, and the graphic artist Martin Hoffmann, the church people said. **********Mr. Hoffmann is a son-in-law of the writer Christa Wolf, who has won acclaim in East Germany as well as in the West, and who has often challenged the views of the Communist state. **********In Bonn, West German officials condemned the actions and said they would do nothing to help East-West relations. **********Diplomats said the raids and arrests were signaled in a hard-line speech last month by the Communist Party's chief ideologist, Kurt Hager, in which he called for firmer action against those who sought to opppose the state. Church Is Raided **********The crackdown began when uniformed police and plainclothes security men forced their way into the dilapidated Church of Zion in the center of East Berlin on Tuesday. **********The agents detained five people who were working in the cellar library, used as a meeting place for unofficial church-linked disarmament and environmentalist groups. **********They confiscated printing materials and copies of two underground publications , the church people said. **********About 150 advocates, who until the raid had enjoyed a brief period of comparatively mild policing, gathered in the church on Wednesday night to protest against the raid. **********Police and security agents surrounded the building and arrested about 10 of them as they left mounted a vigil in the grounds of the church after the meeting.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/29/busin.body_text: **********The Senate Banking Committee today approved the nominations of Alan Greenspan as the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board and David S. Ruder as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission. **********The committee voted unamimously to send Mr. Greenspan's nomination to the Senate for a vote and approved Mr. Ruder's nomination by a 17-to-3 vote. **********Mr. Greenspan would succeed Paul A. Volcker, who is going to head a commission that will study the quality of public service; Mr. Ruder would succeed John S. R. Shad, who became Ambassador to the Netherlands last month. **********There was no opposition to Mr. Greenspan, but three Democratic members of the committee objected strongly to Mr. Ruder's appointment. Senator William Proxmire of Wisconsin, the chairman; Senator Terry Sanford of North Carolina and Senator James R. Sasser of Tennessee said they were concerned that Mr. Ruder would not vigorously enforce securities laws and was not sufficiently worried about hostile takeovers. **********''When that professor brings to the chairmanship no record of any concern about securities fraud or the abuses involved in insider trading, it is impossible for this Senator to vote to confirm his nomination,'' Mr. Proxmire said in a statement.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/05/world.main_headline: U.S. Examines Reports of Drug Crimes by Noriega
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/05/world.print_headline: U.S. Examines Reports of Drug Crimes by Noriega
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/05/world.body_text: **********The Justice Department is investigating Panama's military leader on suspicion of involvement in money laundering and other drug-related crimes, according to a Federal law enforcement official with knowledge of the inquiry. **********The official said a Federal grand jury in Miami was overseeing the investigation, which he said had turned up ''large amounts of evidence'' to back up the allegations against the Panamanian leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. **********The grand jury's investigation, which was disclosed today in The Los Angeles Times, is focusing on charges that General Noriega has been skimming off a portion of the proceeds from illicit drug shipments through Panama, the official said. **********The investigation is expected to further strain relations between the United States and General Noriega, who is, in effect, the leader of Panama. The general has blamed the United States for violent demonstrations in recent weeks by opponents of his regime. No Comment on Charges **********The Panamanian Embassy in Washington had no comment today on the charges against General Noriega. In the past, the general and his military colleagues have denied reports of wrongdoing. **********The Federal law enforcement official said the grand jury, working in conjunction with the Drug Enforcement Administration, was still far from deciding whether to start criminal procedures against the general. **********There is insufficent evidence now to consider an indictment, the official said. He noted that even if indicted, General Noriega would almost certainly refuse to be extradited and tried in the United States. **********American intelligence agencies have gathered extensive evidence indicating that General Noriega maintains tight control of drug and money-laundering activities by his associates in Panama's military. Evidence of Opium Processing **********Reagan Administration officials say the United States has intelligence showing that in the early 1980's, General Noriega held a major financial interest in an opium-processing plan that was discovered, according to a Congressional committee, in operation along the Panamanian-Colombian border. **********Officials said last year that there was also evidence tying General Noriega and members of Panama's military to financial involvement in a small airline charter company that flies weekly money-laundering missions in and out of the United States. **********The Federal law enforcement official said the Miami grand jury was considering evidence that General Noriega demanded as much as 1.5 percent of the proceeds from drug shipments through Panama, which is a major transshipment point for illicit drugs being transferred from Latin America to the United States. **********The payoffs, the official said, would represent millions of dollars each year. According to the official, the payments are, in effect, protection money for the drug traffickers, who are permitted to go about their business without police interference. **********The Panamanian Government has been shaken in recent weeks by street violence after statements by a retired colonel that General Noriega was involved in corruption. **********In what he said was a fit of conscience, the colonel, Roberto Diaz Herrera, General Noriega's former deputy, accused the general and others of political assassinations and election fraud.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/01/busin.main_headline: Why Warrants Are Back in Style
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/01/busin.print_headline: INVESTING; Why Warrants Are Back in Style
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/01/busin.body_text: **********THE allure of stock warrants - basically rights that allow investors to buy common shares for an extended time at a fixed price - tends to rise and fall with speculative fervor. The game offers both big rewards and high risks. Indeed, many holders of warrants have done quite well in the recent Wall Street surge. But not all warrant holders have struck gold; many issues covered by warrants are smaller, obscure companies bypassed by the bullish crowd. Stock options, another speculative play, have done much better, on average. **********However, in some ways, warrants are often more attractive than options. While both represent a right to buy stock at certain prices, the longest life of a listed option is nine months. Many warrants have years to run, enabling an investor to place a relatively low-cost, long-term bet on a company. **********When the bet is successful, a warrant payoff -like an option payoff - can far exceed the returns on the related common stock. In the last year, ICN Pharmaceuticals, which trades on the New York Stock Exchange, ran from $10.25 to as high as $34. But in the over-the-counter market, the ICN warrants, which entitle the holder to buy the common at $9 through May 1989, shot from $4.25 to $26.25. The gains: 231 percent for the stock, 517 percent for the warrants. Of course, the volatility sword can cut both ways: By last week, ICN common had fallen about 28 percent from its peak, to $24.50, while the warrants had sagged 39 percent, to $16. And that was a modest drop compared with the routs in some other warrants tied to falling stocks. **********The warrant on MCI Communications, which enable the owner to buy the common at $27.50 until August 1988, have traded as low as 6 cents in recent weeks, as the stock drifts just over $6. For the warrant, that is a loss of more than 99 percent since 1983, when the stock topped $28. **********The market in warrants is a bazaar of unique -and sometimes puzzling - creations. They are usually issued by lesser-known companies as part of financings: to lower interest rate costs or raise equity sale prices by offering investors a kicker. Many warrants are issued by companies whose stocks are not covered by options. A warrant may give the holder a right to buy a full share at a certain price, or a partial share. The exercise price may change at various dates - $8 until 1988, for example, $9 after that. Some warrants may be called back by the company at certain prices before expiration. Expirations may be extended or other terms adjusted. In addition, stock bought by some warrants can be paid for with bonds, preferred stock or another senior security of the issuer, at face value. If such securities are trading below par, this can create a discount in the effective exercise price. **********''You are buying them for leverage, looking for more bang for your buck,'' said Allan S. Lyons, executive editor of Value Line Convertibles, a survey covering convertible securities, including about 95 actively traded warrants. Warrants, on average, are three and a half times as volatile as common stocks, according to Mr. Lyons, but ''only one-third as risky as the typical option.'' The difference is largely a product of the differing lifetimes of the securities - infinite, in theory, for a stock, years for a warrant, months for an option. **********Mr. Lyons looks for ''favorable leverage - where the warrant will move up faster than it will go down on equal moves in a stock.'' Usually such favorable leverage can be found in an inexpensive, but long-lived, warrant on a stock trading not far below the exercise price. ''If the stock goes up 10 percent, the warrant may go up 100 percent,'' Mr. Lyons said. ''But if the stock goes down 10 percent, the warrant may only go down 40 percent.'' This is because investors will still pay something for the warrant on the chance the stock will recover. **********As an example, Mr. Lyons cited the warrant on the Clabir Corporation, a small holding company trading at about $7.63 on the New York Stock Exchange. The warrant, quoted at 69 cents on the American Stock Exchange, enables the owner to buy a share of Clabir's Class B common at $9.34 until July 1991. However, using Clabir's $3.31 preferred in payment cuts the effective exercise price to $7.85 - just about the common's current level. ''On a 25 percent rise in the stock, we calculate the warrant would go up 175 percent,'' Mr. Lyons said. ''On a 25 percent drop, we think the warrant would go down only 35 percent.'' **********Warrants on three interest-sensitive Big Board issues were cited recently by Value Line Convertibles as timely buys: the Federal National Mortgage Association (Fannie Mae), exercisable at $44.25 until February 1991, trading over the counter at about $14.50, versus $42.25 for the common; Mortgage and Realty Trust, good for 1.5 shares at $20 a share until January 1992, trading at $3.13 on the Amex, versus $22 for the common, and Student Loan Marketing Association (Sallie Mae), exercisable at $100 until August 1991, trading over the counter at $13.75, versus $72.75 for the common. **********But Sidney Fried, editor of the R.H.M. Survey, covering warrants, options and low-priced stocks, described warrants on Fannie Mae and Sallie Mae as ''just trading vehicles,'' lacking the spectacular leverage of a low-priced warrant. Indeed, Mr. Fried finds the 500 issues that his 25-year-old service monitors overpriced as a group. ''The play in warrants comes when a market turns down sharply and warrants go down to pennies,'' Mr. Fried said. ''Then, if there are enough years left in the warrant and the company survives, you can get some tremendous leverage. The real play is great patience.'' **********Mr. Lyons said that warrant premiums appear to be relatively higher now than those on options, reflecting speculative interest.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/25/world.body_text: **********Li Peng, a 59-year-old Soviet-educated engineer, was named Acting Prime Minister of China today. He succeeds Zhao Ziyang, who gave up the post to devote himself full time to his duties as head of China's 46-million-member Communist Party. **********With his appointment, Mr. Li, who was recommended for the post by Mr. Zhao, is virtually assured of being named China's Prime Minister on a permanent basis when the National People's Congress gathers next spring, its fourth meeting since the Communist state was founded in 1949. **********The elevation of Mr. Li continues the process of rejuvenating China's leadership begun by Deng Xiaoping, China's senior leader, at last month's Congress of the Communist Party. During that meeting, every elderly party leader was dropped or retired from the Central Committee in favor of younger, better-educated officials. **********As China's new head of Government, Mr. Li, who was named to the ruling standing committee of the Politburo on Nov. 1, faces many problems, including management of an enormous, unwieldy and often unresponsive Government bureaucracy, uncontrolled inflation, growing urban and rural unemployment and rapidly rising consumer expectations. In addition, industrial productivity is stagnant, attempts to control population growth are floundering and agricultural production stopped increasing three years ago. Increase of Living Standards **********The extent of these problems has been largely obscured, however, by the sweeping reordering of China's economy since 1978, which has freed farmers from the limits of collectivized agriculture and has brought urban residents a dramatic increase in their standard of living. **********''A lot of things are waiting to be done, and the tasks facing us are not easy,'' Mr. Li was quoted by the official New China News Agency as saying upon his nomination. ''We should tackle them in a bold, prudent and earnest way.'' **********Mr. Li, who has been a Deputy Prime Minister, was named Prime Minister in an acting capacity by the standing committee of the National People's Congress, the country's legislature, which has been meeting here for two weeks. Mr. Zhao declared his intention to resign as Prime Minister this month after being named General Secretary of the party. **********Mr. Zhao has called for a greater separation of the Communist Party from the administration of government, a task that now will be largely entrusted to Mr. Li. A Civil Service System **********As part of this effort, a form of civil service system is to be introduced to select officials for administrative posts. Under the current system, the party cell in each ministry or local government agency selects individuals for specific jobs, often regardless of whether they are properly trained for the post. **********Mr. Li brings to his new position a wealth of experience in government, including management of China's power industry, as Minister of the State Education Commission and often as the senior official in charge of natural disasters and disturbances. **********Sun Jingwen, the vice chairman of the China National Petrochemical Corporation and a member of the legislature's standing committee, hailed Mr. Li's appointment as Acting Prime Minister. Mr. Sun, who was quoted by the New China News Agency, said that Mr. Li ''was always in the forefront of handling firefighting, rescue work, student demonstrations and other emergencies.'' **********Because of his Soviet training, some Western diplomats here have been wary in their evaluation of Mr. Li, a concern noted by the New China News Agency today in making public his official biography. in response to the question of whether he is ''pro-Soviet'' in his views, the press agency quoted Mr. Li as saying: ''I am a Chinese and a member of the Chinese Communist Party. I act only on the party's line and in the interests of my country.'' **********But these Western diplomats have expressed less anxiety about Mr. Li's possible warmth for Moscow, than his lack of enthusiasm for the economic policies pushed by Mr. Deng and Mr. Zhao.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/01/world.main_headline: THIRD MARINE GUARD FROM U.S. EMBASSY IN MOSCOW ARRESTED
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/01/world.print_headline: THIRD MARINE GUARD FROM U.S. EMBASSY IN MOSCOW ARRESTED
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/01/world.body_text: **********The Marine Corps has arrested a third enlisted man who served as a guard at the American Embassy in Moscow on suspicion that he violated regulations against social contacts with Soviet women, the Pentagon said today. **********The enlisted man, Staff Sgt. Robert S. Stufflebeam, who was arrested Sunday at Camp Pendleton, Calif., has not been charged with spying, and it was not clear if his suspected relations with Soviet women were related to the cases of two marines accused of spying after they had similar encounters. **********The arrest of the third marine in the broadening case came as a second marine was formally charged with espionage and as the State Department stepped up its inquiry into security at the embasssy in Moscow. The department named the Ambassador to Thailand, William A. Brown, to head its investigation. **********The pattern of fraternization by Marine guards with Soviet women has raised questions about the discipline in the unit assigned to protect embassies around the world and about the State Department's supervision of the young single men who serve as guards, officials said. **********All three of the marines arrested were guards at the embassy during overlapping periods in 1985 and 1986. **********One Government official said Cpl. Arnold Bracy, whose arrest last week signaled that the case was broad and had severely damaged the embassy's security, had been demoted by the Marine Corps while he was in Moscow because he met socially with a Russian woman. **********The departing Ambassador to Moscow, Arthur A. Hartman, said Monday that fraternization was a breach of regulations and that, had he known of it, he would have viewed it as a ground for sending a Marine guard home. **********Corporal Bracy was formally charged today with spying. The charge, which will be adjudicated in a court-martial, asserts that he acted as a partner with a marine arrested in December, Sgt. Clayton J. Lonetree. **********Corporal Bracy and Sergeant Lonetree are charged with letting Soviet agents into the embassy and providing them blueprints of embassy offices, bags of secret documents and names of American intelligence agents. Charges Based on Statement **********The charges against Corporal Bracy are largely based on his statement to investigators, in which he also implicated Sergeant Lonetree, who had previously made a statement incriminating himself, according to Sergeant Lonetree's civilian counsel, William M. Kunstler. **********But Corporal Bracy has recanted his initial statement, according to Mr. Kunstler, who has called Sergeant Lonetree's statement a fabrication. **********The two men are accused of working as spies for a Soviet agent as a result of having been enticed by Soviet women with whom they had sexual relations, according to Pentagon officials. **********The fact that they were compromised in this fashion led to a broad investigation of the other marines who stood guard at the embassy in the same period in 1985 and 1986. This investigation led to the arrest of Sergeant Stufflebeam on Sunday, according to the Pentagon spokesman, Robert B. Sims. **********Sergeant Stufflebeam, 24 years old, of Bloomington, Ill., who was an assistant commander of the guard detachment in Moscow, ''is suspected of having associations with Soviet women on several occasions,'' Mr. Sims said. Contacts Must Be Reported Regulations call for the guards to report all contacts with foreign citizens, Mr. Sims said. Direct involvement of Sergeant Stufflebeam in the Bracy-Lonetree espionage case has not been established, he said, but the possibility is under investigation. **********All marines now assigned to Moscow have been recalled for new assignments, but questions remain about their supervision. **********Marine Corps officials have privately suggested that the State Department's security officer at the embassy, who was directly in charge of the marines, had not kept a tight rein on them. **********A State Department spokeswoman, Phyllis Oakley, said today that the Marines' detachment commander, a non-commissioned officer, reported to three civilian embassy officials - a regional security officer and his two assistants. **********She said all personnel involved in embassy security were being examined in the investigation of the spying episodes. But she said the civilian officials in charge of security had not been recalled as part of the investigation. She said it was possible that the individuals who held these jobs in 1985 and 1986 were posted elsewhere, but she said that she did not know this with certainty and that the State Department would not make public their names. **********According to charges of espionage filed against Sergeant Lonetree and Corporal Bracy, they acted together to allow Soviet agents to go inside the embassy's most secure areas, including its communications room, where cryptographic information is stored, and the offices of the military attache. **********Ambassador Brown, recalled from Thailand temporarily to head the State Department's investigation, is a career Foreign Service officer who once served in Moscow as an economics officer. He will supervise a review of embassy security in which ''the performance of all involved is under review,'' Ms. Oakley said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/10/world.main_headline: REAGAN REJECTS SOVIET PROPOSAL TO CURB A-TESTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/10/world.print_headline: REAGAN REJECTS SOVIET PROPOSAL TO CURB A-TESTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/10/world.body_text: **********The United States has rejected the latest Soviet compromise offer on limiting nuclear testing, Administration officials said today. **********The State Department was interested in having Secretary of State George P. Shultz explore the offer in Moscow next week, but President Reagan decided that there should be no further talks on testing until the Russians agreed to new monitoring measures for two existing but unratified treaties limiting nuclear explosions. **********Arguments surrounding Mr. Shultz's visit continued today as 70 senators backed a nonbinding resolution urging him to cancel his trip in view of the dispute over bugging at the American Embassy in Moscow or find another, secure place for the talks. Instructions Given by Reagan **********Mr. Reagan's decisions on nuclear testing and other arms issues, contained in a secret Presidential directive, were disclosed as officials discussed his instructions to Mr. Shultz. **********The officials said Mr. Shultz would seek to clarify the Soviet position on reducing medium-range missiles, the most promising area in the arms talks. The visit was set after Mikhail S. Gorbachev announced readiness last month to negotiate a separate agreement on the medium-range missiles. **********The State Department was rebuffed on ''Star Wars,'' and its position on strategic arms was rejected. Mr. Shultz wanted to stretch out the period during which the United States would not withdraw from the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty or deploy ''Star Wars,'' but the President insisted on a shorter period ending in 1994, officials said. At the Iceland summit meeting, President Reagan offered not to withdraw from the treaty until 1996 if the Russians would also agree to eliminate ballistic missiles. **********In another rebuff to the State Department, the President's instructions also change the American position on reductions of long-range nuclear weapons, spreading cuts over seven years instead of five, as discussed between President Reagan and Mr. Gorbachev in Reykjavik last October. Mr. Shultz was not granted the flexibilty to negotiate less restrictive limits on Soviet land-based missiles or to remove the proposed ban on mobile missiles. **********For the State Department, the instructions to Mr. Shultz present a mixed picture. **********On medium-range arms, the United States does not intend to advance new ideas, which would require prior consultation with the allies. Rather, it intends to clarify the Soviet position. **********One clarification to be sought concerns hints that Moscow might agree to the total elimination of medium-range missiles. The hints were made by Yuli M. Vorontsov, the Soviet negotiator in Geneva, who reportedly questioned the military value of of having each side keep 100 warheads outside of Europe under a previous agreement. **********The Americans say he did not make clear whether the remaining medium-range missiles were to be eliminated under the pact now being negotiated or in a subsequent accord. **********The United States also favors the elimination of all medium-range missiles, on the ground that this would reduce verification requirements since there would be no need to monitor production and storage. **********The United States will also seek to clarify the Soviet position on the issue of limiting shorter-range missiles, with a range of 300 to 600 miles. **********The Soviet Union has said that as soon as a medium-range accord is signed, it will withdraw shorter-range missiles introduced into East Germany and Czechoslovakia when the United States deployed its Pershing 2 and cruise missiles in 1983-84. **********In a separate offer, the Soviet Union proposed to freeze such missiles. **********In addition, Viktor P. Karpov, a Soviet arms control official, has hinted to Western diplomats that Moscow might be prepared to eliminate the shorter-range missiles altogether. **********''The Soviets have three offers in play,'' said Kenneth L. Adelman, director of the Arms Control and Disarmament. ''I think that one of the things we will accomplish might be to find out what their position is.'' **********The United States insists on the right to match the 130 Soviet shorter-range missiles. **********On nuclear testing, Andronik M. Petrosyants, chairman of the Soviet State Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Atomic Energy, suggested last month that there be simultaneous negotiations on the ratification of the two existing treaties that already limit the size of explosions to 150 kilotons and on additional testing limitations. Under this Soviet approach, a total test ban would be the ultimate goal. **********The American position has been that monitoring of the two treaties, signed in 1974 and 1976, must be improved and that they must be ratified before there can be further talks. **********Mr. Shultz has been told to adhere to this position, officials said, although he will be able informally to discuss the subject of subsequent negotiations and to welcome the Soviet suggestion that a total test ban be deferred. **********On the issue of limiting ABM systems, the State Department also suffered a partial rebuff, officials said. **********The State Department had suggested that there be no withdrawal from the 1972 treaty for five years, to be followed by three years of additional discussion before deployment of space-oriented ABM systems could begin. **********The Pentagon recommended that the United States ask for a ban on deployment ending in 1994, when ''Star Wars'' systems could be deployed. **********Officials said today that President Reagan had decided that the United States should propose a period of nonwithdrawal ending in 1994. **********On long-range, or strategic, arms, the new American position is that the reductions should be carried out over a period of seven years, and not five years as previously proposed. The State Department opposed the change; the military favored it. **********The United States has dropped its proposal to eliminate ballistic missiles.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/02/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Bidders Would Sell Burlington Assets
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/02/busin.body_text: **********Asher B. Edelman and Dominion Textile Inc., who have joined in a bid for Burlington Industries, said that they expected to sell unspecified assets or businesses if they gained control of the company. The disclosure was made in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission in which the partners also said they had raised their stake in Burlington to the equivalent of 9.5 percent, from 8.7 percent. **********The Edelman-Dominion group, which has offered $60 a share, or $1.5 billion, for the remaining Burlington shares, told the S.E.C. that ''no final determination'' had been made regarding the asset sales. Burlington, which is based in Greensboro, N.C., and is the nation's largest textile concern, said that the offer was under consideration by its board. Between April 24 and 30, the group bought 236,300 Burlington shares for $55.50 to $58.375 a share.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/01/busin.body_text: **********A New Floor For the Dollar? **********The dollar fell beneath what had widely been perceived as the floor values established in February when the seven major Western trading partners met in Paris. Their agreement, known as the Louvre accord, is now widely perceived as being rewritten, if not abandoned. Officials of the nations have never disclosed many details of the accord, and they were continuing to insist that their goal remained currency stability. The central banks bought dollars during the week, but with restraint, causing many economists and traders to conclude that the goal now was an orderly decline of the dollar. The dollar reached a postwar low of 137.20 yen and a seven-year low of 1.721 marks, rallied a bit, then steadied.  * * **********Stocks showed signs of healing. After a grim Monday that took the Dow Jones industrial average down 156 points, the Dow had three days of solid gains, including a 91-point advance on Thursday, and ended the week up 42.77, at 1,993.53. Perhaps even more encouraging, the buying spread beyond the blue chips to include thousands of the badly battered over-the- counter issues. Bargain-hunting no doubt accounted for much of the rise, but Wall Street also seemed relieved that officials in Washington were at least talking about the economy's problems. **********Bond prices lost the momentum of the previous week's spectacular gains. Stronger stocks seemed to draw away money and there was uneasiness about the shifting relationships between the world's currency values and interest rates. Late in the week, the yield on the Treasury's long bond was slightly more than 9 percent and the three-month bill was yielding a bit above 5 percent.  * * * **********Britain went ahead with its $12.2 billion sale of British Petroleum shares, despite pleas from underwriters and officials of foreign governments that it not send such a huge amount of stock into the troubled markets. The Thatcher Government moved to prop up the price by committing the Bank of England to buy back shares, for about $1.20 a share. The shares began trading Friday at about $1.50. However, the underwriters had paid $2.06 before the market collapse and they still face hefty losses. Four American firms - Goldman, Sachs; Salomon, Morgan Stanley and Shearson Lehman - are among the underwriters.  * * * **********The reckoning from Black Monday began on Wall Street. L. F. Rothschild said it had lost $44 million this month and was seeking an infusion of capital. There was also talk that the firm was for sale. Charles Schwab, the discount broker, said it had suffered a $22 million loss, largely from one corporate customer's failure to meet margin calls. Santangelo & Company, an American Exchange specialist that handled volatile issues, was persuaded by the size of its losses to sell out to Spear, Leeds & Kellog, a larger specialist. **********Continental Illinois will take a $90 million charge for losses of its recently acquired options clearinghouse unit. The fallout from that piece of news was particularly heavy in Washington where some Congressmen questioned what any bank, especially Continental, was doing in such a risky business. A costly bailout by Federal regulators saved Continental from failure three years ago.  * * * **********The Westin hotel chain will be sold to a group that includes the Basses of Texas and the Aoki Corporation of Japan. The $1.53 billion deal is the last in a series of asset sales by the Allegis Corporation. The sales leave the company with United Airlines and $3.9 billion. Stockholders will get about $50 a share in a special distribution. **********Beryl W. Sprinkel won't be leaving the White House after all. The chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers had resigned but will now be staying on indefinitely to help deal with the turbulence in the markets. His position is being elevated to Cabinet rank for the first time. Mr. Sprinkel has been the chief adviser for seven years and his economic views are known to differ from those of Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d. For one thing, Mr. Sprinkel would like to abandon efforts to manage exchange rates, preferring to let the dollar take its chances in the market place.  * * * **********The leading indicators slipped in September by one-tenth of 1 percent, the first drop since January. Much of the decline came from a quirk in the workweek component, but the index was also pulled down by the weakening of stock prices that began in September. The stock plunge will undoubtedly deal a blow to the October index. In the past, three straight months of declines in the indicators have often heralded a recession . . . Orders for durable goods rose 1.1 percent in September but sales of new homes fell 5.2 percent.  * * * **********Steel showed its new-found vigor as USX, Bethlehem and LTV moved into the black for the third quarter, after losses in the 1986 period. Among the auto makers, G.M. avoided an operating loss by a change in accounting procedures, and reported that net income more than doubled. Ford profits rose 1 percent and Chrysler's 7.6 percent. **********Chrysler's gain failed to deter its cost-cutting efforts. It intends to shut one plant and lay off 3,500 white-collar workers before year-end. Trimming jobs was also on the mind of Norfolk Southern's management. The railroad will eliminate 5,000 positions by 1990.  * * * **********Wall Street's retreat from municipal bonds gathered steam with E. F. Hutton saying it would close operations in five regional offices and dismiss about 40 people. Three other Wall Street houses have reduced or eliminated their municipal operations as competition with banks makes profits hard to get. But one bank, Continental Illinois again, said it was quitting the business.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/12/world.main_headline: Priests Increasing Rapidly in the Third World
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/12/world.print_headline: Priests Increasing Rapidly in the Third World
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/12/world.body_text: **********Someday priests from Asia and Africa might have to look after Roman Catholics in countries that once sent off boatloads of missionaries, according to Vatican documents showing that the number of priests is rapidly growing in third world countries while declining in Europe and the United States. **********Over the last decade young men in South America, Africa and Asia have been joining the priesthood at a rapid pace that notably exceeds the rate of population growth, indicating that the priesthood is exercising a special appeal in those regions. But elsewhere, there are not enough new recruits to compensate for the number who are dying or leaving the priesthood. **********If the geographical shift in the clergy continues, a recent report by the Central Statistics Office of the church predicted, ''in a not distant future it will be necessary to redistribute new priests in areas others than where they were born.'' **********This report and other statistical studies recently released by the Vatican show that on a worldwide basis the church appears to have recovered from the manpower crisis it suffered in the 1970's. In general, far fewer men are now leaving the priesthood, and the number of men studying for the priesthood rose 41 percent in the last decade, with the fastest growth taking place since 1980. But the new priests are coming from new places. **********Although the United States continues to produce a large number of priests, it is the only major exception to a global trend toward improved recruitment. **********In 1985, the latest year for which the Vatican has statistics, 533 diocesan priests were ordained in the United States, a figure second only to Poland, which ordained 703. But between 1970 and 1985, the number of young men studying for the priesthood in North America dropped by 43.7 percent, according to a study published by L'Osservatore Romano, the Vatican newspaper. **********Worldwide in that 15-year period, the population of seminaries dropped through the mid-1970's but registered an overall gain of 16.5 percent after a sharp turnaround. Big Increase in Africa **********In Africa and South America, the number of seminarians increased by 88 percent between 1970 and 1985. With substantial growth in India, Korea, Japan and the Philippines, Asia registered an increase of more than 55 percent in the seminaries. **********L'Osservatore Romano calculated that in 1995 about 15 percent of the world's priests would come from Africa, compared with 5 percent in 1970. Instead of producing half the Catholic clergy, Europe will have only a quarter, and North Americans will drop from 19 percent of all priests in 1970 to about 7 percent. **********The regions where the clergy is growing fastest also have the populations that are expanding most rapidly, but the Vatican statistics show that the increase in the number of men beginning priestly studies substantially exceeds the rate of population growth. **********For instance, in Africa, where the church is strongest in Zaire and Nigeria, there were 10 seminarians for every million inhabitants in 1970, while in 1985 there were 18. In South America the ratio doubled. In the same period in the United States, the number of seminarians per million inhabitants dropped from 64 to 30.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/23/busin.main_headline: Japanese Cited In Sales of Forklifts
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/23/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Japanese Cited In Sales of Forklifts
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/23/busin.body_text: **********An American manufacturer and four labor unions today filed a petition accusing Japanese companies of selling forklifts at unfairly low prices in the United States, bringing yet another product into the ever-widening arena of Japanese-American trade friction. **********The company filing the petition, the Hyster Company of Portland, Ore., said the moves had forced some American companies out of the business and others to import from Japan or South Korea, leaving Hyster as the last major company that makes the equipment in the United States. **********The petition was filed with the Department of Commerce and the United States International Trade Commission. If the Government agrees there has been dumping, duties will be placed on Japanese forklift imports. **********Japanese companies are expected to fight the charges. ''We definitely are not dumping lift trucks,'' said Ted Jackson, vice president of sales for Nissan Industrial Equipment in Memphis, which sells the Nissan forklift in the United States. He said prices had been depressed throughout the world because of an excess of supply over demand. **********The unions joining Hyster in the petition are the United Shop and Service Workers and the Independent Lift Truck Builders Union, both representing Hyster workers; the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, representing workers at a Caterpillar Tractor Company plant in Dallas, Ore, and the International Union, Allied Industrial Workers of America, representing the Clark Equipment Company workers in Battle Creek, Mich. Both Clark and Caterpillar have announced plans to close their forklift plants and import Korean products. **********The dumping charges center on lift trucks powered by internal combustion engines, rather than electricity. These machines, which sell for $14,000 to $65,000, constitute the bulk of the $1 billion-a-year lift market in the United States. **********The Japanese manufacturers now have 50 percent of the world market of those forklifts, Hyster said. **********Mitchell I. Quain, a machinery analyst for Wertheim & Company in New York, said Japanese companies have used many automobile components in their forklifts, enabling them to take advantage of the economies of scale they get from their auto operations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/23/world.main_headline: United Iran-Contra Report Expected From the 2 Panels
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/23/world.print_headline: United Iran-Contra Report Expected From the 2 Panels
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/23/world.body_text: **********With the Iran-contra hearings nearing a conclusion, the chairman and vice chairman of the Senate select committee said today that they expected the Senate and House committees to be able to present a united report this fall with a statement of facts that is acceptable to all members. **********''We're never going to have all the pieces,'' said the chairman, Daniel K. Inouye, Democrat of Hawaii, ''but we've got enough pieces to present a pretty complete picture of what happened. **********''We will know the story, the major facts,'' said Warren B. Rudman, the vice chairman. ''I've never tried a major case that went to the jury where there weren't conflicts and missing pieces.'' **********Senator Rudman, a Republican, is a former prosecutor and Attorney General of New Hampshire. **********Mr. Inouye and Mr. Rudman were interviewed over breakfast in the Capitol with reporters and editors of The New York Times. Committees Recess for Day **********After two dramatic weeks of testimony from the principal witnesses, Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North and Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter, the committees were in recess today. **********On Thursday and Friday, they will hear testimony from Secretary of State George P. Shultz. Then, the panels will complete the hearings with testimony over the next two weeks from Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger and Donald T. Regan, the former White House chief of staff. **********The two Senators said they and the other members of the committees would take an active role in preparing the final report and would not, as many Congressional panels do, leave the conclusions to the staff. **********Where some conflicts between different witnesses' testimony cannot be resolved, they said, they will present the discrepancies and allow readers to draw their own conclusions. **********The individual members of the panels will have the opportunity to file separate statements if they disagree with or wish to elaborate on the consensus findings. A Wish for Smaller Panels **********Senator Inouye said he had no real regrets over how the hearings and investigation had been conducted. But he said that if he had known from the beginning that the Senate and House committees would hold the hearings jointly, he would have insisted on smaller panels. **********With 11 senators and 15 representatives wanting to question witnesses, the sessions have lasted longer and been more repetitive than would have been the case with fewer members. On the other hand, Senator Inouye said, ''it would have been a disaster'' if the panels had held separate hearings. **********Senator Rudman said he was sorry that Colonel North and Admiral Poindexter had not earlier been granted immunity from prosecution based on their Congressional testimony and had not been required to testify last spring. **********The committees withheld granting the witnesses immunity at the request of the independent counsel, Lawrence E. Walsh. Senator Rudman said he believed the interest of the country in getting the facts quickly should have outweighed Mr. Walsh's need to gather evidence for possible prosecution. **********The committees did not grant the colonel and the admiral immunity so they could testify in public until this month. The two men can still be prosecuted on the basis of evidence obtained independently from their testimony. **********Senator Inouye said the long-term lesson he thought should be learned from the testimony was that Presidents stand to gain much more than they stand to lose by working with Congress. In this case, he said, if leaders of the Congressional intelligence committees had been informed in advance about the Iran arms sales, they could have dissuaded President Reagan from proceeding and saved him from serious political embarrassment. **********Senator Rudman agreed with that assessment and added that the Iran-contra affair illustrated the folly of advocating one policy in public and conducting another one in private. Legislation Suggested **********One of the goals of the committees is to suggest new procedures to lessen the chances of repeating the mistakes of the Iran-contra affair. **********With that in mind, Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, the Democratic majority leader of the Senate, today suggested legislation that would require more precise and timely notification of Congress regarding covert operations conducted by Government agencies, including the National Security Council. **********The committees have tentatively decided not to call several people whose testimony they had expected to take in public. Among them are Robert M. Gates, deputy director of the Central Intelligence Agency, and Michael A. Ledeen, formerly a National Security Council consultant who helped with the original negotiations that led to the arms sales to Iran. **********Both men were questioned in private, and depositions from those sessions are to be made public soon. But staff assistants said the committees had decided not to call them and several others for public testimony because they had no further questions that were not covered in the depositions.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/17/busin.main_headline: BOESKY FUND PARTNERS TO WAIT YEAR FOR MONEY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/17/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; BOESKY FUND PARTNERS TO WAIT YEAR FOR MONEY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/17/busin.body_text: **********Limited partners in the arbitrage fund of Ivan F. Boesky will have to wait for at least a year before getting any money back under a plan announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission. **********The S.E.C. allowed Mr. Boesky's two securities firms to withdraw from the business of broker-dealers. That decision frees their net capital for the investment partnership, Ivan F. Boesky & Company L.P., to repay its bondholders $640 million. However, the S.E.C. action placed severe restrictions on the repayment of the limited partners. **********The commission forced the two securities firms, Seemala Partners L.P. and IFB Managing Partners L.P., to freeze the assets they will have left after paying out the $640 million plus interest. **********These remaining assets are estimated at $278 million and are to be frozen for one year. All claims from lawsuits resulting from insider trading cases against Mr. Boesky that are filed during that time are to be combined into a single case in a Delaware court. **********The limited partners invested about $335 million in the arbitrage fund. Not only do they stand to lose roughly $50 million, but they could be liable for additional claims from the suits against Mr. Boesky. **********The S.E.C. placed the restrictions on the brokerages after it received two letters from lawyers in a class-action suit against Mr. Boesky. They objected to proposed terms under which Seemala would have distributed up to $70 million to limited partners by this May. During this delay, an independent accounting firm will tally the assets of the arbitrage fund. **********Partners in the investment firm included prominent people and companies. Among them were National Can; Gould Inc.; Rapid-American; Eli Broad, chairman of Kaufman & Broad; Lewis Lehrman, owner of the Rite Aid drugstore chain, and Martin Peretz, editor in chief of The New Republic magazine. Guinness P.L.C. put in the biggest single amount, $100 million.

Ferris, chairman of UAL Inc., scheduled a news conference in Manhattan Thursday after the company's annual meeting of stockholders. It would be Mr. Ferris's first such meeting since United Airlines' pilots offered three weeks ago to buy the huge carrier for $4.5 billion. UAL said the carrier was not for sale.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/17/busin.body_text: **********In a move to defuse tensions over supercomputer trade, Japan's Government announced today that it was changing its bidding procedures for supercomputers. **********The United States has complained that American companies have been unable to sell supercomputers to the Japanese Government partly because of complicated and discriminatory bidding procedures. **********The new bidding system, to be introduced Aug. 1, would require all Government agencies to declare their intent to buy or lease a supercomputer in the official Government gazette. **********American officials welcomed the announcement. ''We worked out these changes with them in Tokyo a month ago,'' said Douglas Newkirk, assistant United States trade representative for General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade Affairs, in a telephone interview from Washington. ''They're satisfactory to the United States and should provide American companies a fair opportunity to compete from the beginning of the process.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/21/busin.body_text: **********Schlumberger Ltd., the oilfield service and electronics company, said today that its first-quarter earnings plunged 96 percent, reaching $5 million, or 2 cents a share, from $148.2 million, or 51 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenues fell 24.8 percent, to $1.1 billion, from $1.46 billion. The company blamed the oil industry's slump. **********The 1986 results included a one-time charge of $44.68 million, stemming from discontinued operations of the Fairchild Semiconductor Corporation subsidiary. **********Schlumberger said that, although North American revenues from its wireline, seismic and testing service division fell 58 percent from last year's first quarter, they increased 6 percent from its fourth quarter. **********Last month, under pressure from Washington, Schlumberger canceled a plan to sell 80 percent of Fairchild to Fujitsu Ltd. The Government said that such a merger would be a step toward Japanese control of the American semiconductor industry and thus would endanger national security.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/10/busin.main_headline: Economic Scene; Latin Market Ebbs for U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/10/busin.print_headline: Economic Scene; Latin Market Ebbs for U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/10/busin.body_text: **********THE United States is slowly increasing its exports, whittling away at the nation's huge trade deficit. If that deficit is to be dissolved, however, buyers must still be found for tens of billions of dollars of new sales abroad. In the past, whenever American exports expanded, Latin America always stepped forward to purchase a big share of the additional goods. This time the Latin buyers are gone. **********Through decades of economic hardship, Latin America steadfastly purchased 15 percent of all the merchandise - the vast array of consumer products, machinery and equipment - that the United States sold abroad. Since the 1960's only Canada and Western Europe have purchased more than the Latin Americans. Even today Latin America keeps its third-place ranking, although its purchases have finally begun to flag. They fell from a postwar high of 18.7 percent of America's exports in 1981 to 13 percent at an annual rate in this year's first quarter. **********The debt crisis is the culprit, of course. The Latins can no longer borrow and spend in a big way. And the borrowing almost certainly won't resume in the next five to 10 years, which is when the United States must somehow find the buyers to bring down its $144 billion trade deficit. **********''We cannot expect that our trade problems are going to be alleviated in Latin America, as they once were in the 1960's and 70's,'' said Henry Kaufman, chief economist at Salomon Brothers. Added Lawrence Veit, international economist at Brown Brothers Harriman & Company, ''The era of financing American exports with lending has ended.'' **********That fact helps explain why there is so much emphasis on getting Japan and West Germany, and also Taiwan, to consume more American goods. No one else has the extra buying power of these nations. Last year their current account surpluses -the money they earned from trade and other foreign transactions - totaled $137 billion. If Japan, Germany and Taiwan can be persuaded to lead the way in consuming American products, displacing Canada and Latin America, they will in effect turn over this big current account surplus to the United States. **********But there are broader implications in the forced retreat of the Latins. Without the lending crutch, Latin America now has to pay for its imports with earnings from its own exports, particularly exports of manufactured products. These exports are already beginning to grow, coming chiefly from Brazil and Mexico. **********In fact, the United States is buying from Mexico and Brazil enough oil, machinery, auto parts, shoes and other consumer goods to develop a trade deficit with Latin America over the last four years. That deficit is running at an annual rate of about $14 billion this year. The Latins are using the surplus money to pay some of the interest on their nearly $400 billion in foreign debt. **********The new earning power might someday prompt Latin America to look elsewhere for imports. The fear is this: If the Latins are going to pay for foreign purchases with the profits of their own exports rather than with loans from American banks, why should they feel obligated to buy American goods in the future? They could just as easily spend their hard-earned money on Japanese and European products - a development that has not even begun to show up in the trade statistics. **********''The danger is still far down the road,'' said C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics in Washington. For the moment, the dollar's weakness has given American products an advantage over goods priced in Japanese yen or West German marks. This is reflected in recent Latin buying practices. Purchases of American products have been inching up over the last three years. **********As part of the program to reduce the trade deficit, the Reagan Administration wants Latin America to sell more of its exports to Japan and Europe instead of to the United States. But that sentiment does not extend to Latin purchases abroad. There is great reluctance among American officials to loosen the grip on the Latin consumer. **********The current solutions to keep Latins as buyers of American goods involve a return to the old borrow-and-spend formula. Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d wants the World Bank and American, European and Japanese commercial banks to lend a total of $29 billion to 15 major debtor nations, including 10 in Latin America. The money would be used to ease debt payments, thus giving the countries easier access to private borrowing. **********Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, has proposed a similar plan, but with $42 billion in debt relief. And the Japanese Government last spring pledged a $20 billion Latin rescue fund. So far none of these plans has made much headway. **********Meanwhile, Brazil and Mexico have increased their manufacturing capacity, partly with the help of American direct investment and also with a growing amount of Japanese investment, although this still totals less than $8 billion. Mexico in particular is benefiting from laws that encourage the assembly of products for export to the United States. Fifteen Japanese-owned assembly plants are already operating in Mexico, and as many more are expected to open this year. **********''By the 1990's Latin America might solve its debt problem by becoming a manufacturing center,'' said David Hale, chief economist at Kemper Financial Services. While that process unfolds, the Latin countries are not likely to be of much help as a marketplace for Americans struggling to sell more products abroad.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/30/world.main_headline: Palestinian Journalist Dies of Wounds in London
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/30/world.print_headline: Palestinian Journalist Dies of Wounds in London
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/30/world.body_text: **********Ali Naji Awad Adhami, a Palestinian cartoonist who was shot in the head while walking on a London street last month, died in Charing Cross Hospital today, a hospital spokesman said. **********Mr. Adhami, one of the most controversial journalists in the Middle East, was shot by a lone gunman outside the London office of the Kuwaiti newspaper Al Qabas on July 22. **********Policemen investigating the shooting uncovered a huge cache of arms and explosives in Hull in northeast England Aug. 12. Scotland Yard said the weapons were intended for terrorist attacks around Europe. **********The police arrested a Jordanian man in the arms raid. The Jordanian, Ishmail Hassan Sowan, a 28-year-old university researcher, was charged with possessing explosives and firearms. **********Scotland Yard said Mr. Sowan was a member of the Palestine Liberation Organization. The P.L.O. denied any involvement in the shooting of Mr. Adhami or any connection with Mr. Sowan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/18/world.print_headline: Nicaragua Reports Repulsing Attackers In Northern Battles
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/18/world.body_text: **********Nicaragua said today that 27 rebels had been killed in attempts to capture three towns in a surge of fighting in the embattled north of the country Thursday. **********A Defense Ministry statement said 12 of the American-backed rebels, known as contras, were killed in an attack on San Jose de Bocay, site of a key military base 100 miles northeast of Managua in Jinotega Province. The statement said six Nicaraguan civilians were killed and 19 Government soldiers were wounded. **********A statement Thursday said that 19 soldiers were killed. But the statement made public today made no mention of Government dead, and a Defense Ministry spokesman said the earlier report was wrong. **********The ministry said 15 rebels were killed in attacks on Ciudad Antigua and San Fernando on Thursday in neighboring Nueva Segovia Province. **********Contra spokesmen said Thursday that they had temporarily occupied San Jose de Bocay, destroying military installations and an airstrip in what they called one of their most important victories since they began fighting to overthrow the left-wing Sandinista Government in 1982. **********The Government denied this, saying that no damage was reported to military installations and that the contras were beaten back. It said most of the fighting took place more than 1,000 yards outside the town.

Mathews, employees at the naval base at China Lake, Calif. **********A method of producing cumulus rain clouds was patented this week for the Navy.
