https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/10/world.main_headline: Manila's Push for Common Policy On U.S. Bases Surprises Its Allies
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/10/world.print_headline: Manila's Push for Common Policy On U.S. Bases Surprises Its Allies
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/10/world.body_text: **********An unexpected bid by Manila to forge a common Southeast Asian policy in support of American military bases in the Philippines has brought consternation to neighboring capitals, according to regional officials and private analysts meeting here to discuss Pacific security. **********The Philippines Foreign Minister, Raul Manglapus, has just completed a tour of three of Manila's partners in the Association of Southeast Asian Nations - Thailand, Malaysia and Singapore -ostensibly to assure them that a meeting of the group can take place safely in Manila in December. **********Indonesia and Brunei are also members of the association. **********Regional governments are worried about the volatility of the atmosphere in Manila. On the eve of Mr. Manglapus's trip, explosives were found in the conference center where the meeting, the third in the association's 20-year history, is to be held Dec. 14-16. **********But most governments in the region have decided to go ahead with the Manila meeting as a vote of confidence in the Government of President Corazon C. Aquino. Region's Support Important **********''It is very important for the region to support her,'' Jusuf Wanandi, director of Jakarta's Center for Stratetic and International Studies and a member of the Indonesian Parliament, said in an interview today. ''This is a signal of her credibility.'' **********Mr. Wanandi and others attending the 16th Williamsburg Conference on Asia and the Pacific said they were taken by surprise by Mr. Manglapus's apparent effort to get regional backing for the continued presence of the American bases. **********Non-Communist Southeast Asian nations agree more or less that a United States military presence is desirable now for a range of reasons. But several governments, including those of Malaysia and Indonesia, do not want to harm their relations with the Nonaligned Movement, a major grouping of developing countries, and other organizations by making a public statement on this issue. **********Asean nations are also committed to establishing what they call a ''zone of peace, freedom and neutrality'' in the region. The American bases have posed a problem for this concept, but there is reluctance to see them go because of the large Soviet military presence at Cam Ranh Bay in Vietnam. Shift in Power Feared **********''If the Americans left, who would fill the gap?'' Mr. Wanandi asked. ''The Soviet Union? China? Japan? It could create a whole new balance of forces in the region.'' **********Filipino commentators attending the Williamsburg Conference said Mr. Manglapus's aim might be to internationalize the issue of the American use of Clark Air Base and Subic Bay Naval Station. This might help Mrs. Aquino extricate the issue from an emotional nationalistic debate in the Philippines. **********Negotiations to renew American leases on the bases begin next year. **********Discussions about the economic, political and military situation in the Philippines played a major part in the conference, in which more than 50 government officials, diplomats, business leaders and scholars from Pacific rim countries took part. The annual conferences are named for the site in Virginia of the first meeting, in 1971. **********Participants in this year's conference, sponsored by the Asia Society of New York and Malaysia's Institute for Strategic and International Studies, came from the United States, Japan, China, Australia, New Zealand, Canada and South Korea. Hong Kong is also represented, along with all the members of Asean except Brunei. **********The United States delegation included Michael H. Armacost, Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs; David F. Lambertson, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for East Asia and the Pacific, and Cyrus R. Vance, who was Secretary of State in the Carter Administration. Mr. Vance is co-chairman of the conference.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/21/busin.body_text: **********Amfac Inc., a diversified company with operations in distribution, retailing, hotel and land development, said today that Ronald R. Sloan had been removed as its president and chief executive officer. Henry A. Walker Jr., the company's chairman, has resumed his former positions as president and chief executive officer. Neither Mr. Walker nor Mr. Sloan was available for comment, and the company offered no explanation for Mr. Sloan's ouster. In a statement, Mr. Sloan said he ''will continue to serve as a director so long as I feel my presence will assist the shareholders in achieving their objectives.'' **********Amfac is reviewing proposals for restructuring the company and expects to reach a decision in mid-December, a spokesman said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/09/world.main_headline: Hong Kong, Wary of China, Sees Its Middle Class Fleeing
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/09/world.print_headline: Hong Kong, Wary of China, Sees Its Middle Class Fleeing
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/09/world.body_text: **********Four decades after their parents and grandparents swarmed from revolutionary upheaval in China to the safety of Hong Kong, a wave of young Chinese professionals is again fleeing Communism, packing their bags for Canada, the United States and Australia. **********With less than 10 years to go before Hong Kong is returned to the Chinese motherland, more and more of the British territory's brightest lights are deciding that they do not trust China to allow Hong Kong to remain capitalist, decadent and efficient. **********This year more than 10,000 will say farewell to the ''fragrant harbor,'' as this city is known in Chinese, and dolefully brace themselves for Canadian winters and other hardships still only dimly understood. **********''People used to ask me vague questions about the future,'' said Wong Shikeung, a traditional fortuneteller whose premises attract middle-class Chinese. ''Now they ask more focused questions: 'Should I stay in Hong Kong after 1997?' or 'Will foreign countries offer brighter career prospects?' '' Date for End of British Rule **********On July 1, 1997, it will be the marriage of the century: China, one of the most regulated societies in the world, enormous and sluggish; and Hong Kong, a monument to laissez-faire, a tiny, pulsating territory that already economically dominates a broad swath of southern China. **********The amalgam will have far-reaching implications for all of China, and even now, 10 years before the nuptials, expectations of what it will bring are transforming Hong Kong. **********But it is an arranged marriage, and one that gives the 5.6 million inhabitants of Hong Kong deep reservations. The apprehensions, which seem to be a particular preoccupation of the middle class, are compounded by the belief that Britain and China are conspiring to thwart the emergence of democracy, so that Hong Kong will not develop political institutions that could challenge Beijing. The colony is now governed by officials appointed by Britain. **********Iris W. Y. Lam, 30 years old, a slender, curly-haired banker with an easygoing manner reminiscent of her stu-dent days at the University of Southern California, is one of those leaving. ''My dad was in Shanghai in 1949, when the Communists took over,'' she said. ''The Communists promised people freedom then, but they lost everything.'' **********Miss Lam, who leaves next month for Toronto, worries about finding a new job and regrets having to leave the world she knows in Hong Kong. But she has no doubts about the wisdom of her decision to emigrate. In time, she says, she will find new friends, or old friends will join her. So far this year, five good friends have left Hong Kong, and she says others are planning to leave as soon as they have earned a little more money. ''Everybody is thinking about leaving,'' she said.  The Rush for Visas And a New Life **********Miss Lam is just a face in the crowd of emigrants, another professional leaving behind a vacant office and an empty bank account at a time when the fall of the stock market underscores the uncertainty and volatility that will accompany the integration of the two economies. **********No one knows just how big the exodus is, because Hong Kong does not keep emigration statistics. The Commission for Canada in Hong Kong, which gets more applications for immigration visas than any other Canadian diplomatic mission, issued 16,000 immigrant visas in the first nine months of 1987. That compares with 8,800 in all of 1986, although part of the increase this year is the result of a backlog of applications from last year. Australia granted 5,200 immigration visas in the 12 months that ended June 30, compared with 4,460 in the same period a year earlier. **********The United States Consulate in Hong Kong issued 7,585 immigrant visas last year, and the numbers have been fairly steady since then because of strict limits. Meanwhile, about 15,000 people from Hong Kong are studying in the United States, apparently more students proportionally than from anywhere else. **********Until the end of September, the United States limited to 600 the number of Hong Kong-born people who could receive immigration visas in any year, not counting spouses and minor children of American citizens. Many more visas were granted because many recipients were spouses or underage children of Americans, and because many were born in China but now live in Hong Kong. The limit was raised to 5,000 in the fiscal year that began Oct. 1. The United States gives preference to family members of Americans and to those with special skills. **********Some of those going abroad will return to Hong Kong in a few years, clutching their new foreign passports. But emigration advisers say that as 1997 nears, more and more of the emigrants, especially younger ones, say they will build their lives abroad. Over the Decades, Rise and Fall of Tensions **********The latest worries are part of a long history of tensions between Hong Kong and China. Lord Napier, the British officer who more than 150 years ago sought to wrest Hong Kong island from China, was mocked and given a Chinese name meaning ''laboriously vile.'' Britain obtained Hong Kong only by defeating China in the 1839-1842 war that forced the Chinese to accept the opium trade. **********More recently, the Communists have sometimes seemed ready to take back Hong Kong by force. In 1962 a wave of 70,000 refugees suddenly poured across the border from China to Hong Kong in a 25-day period, straining the territory's resources and raising concern that China had finally begun an unorthodox invasion. Just five years later, China encouraged riots in the center of Hong Kong that for six months shook the territory to its core. While the Bank of China branch in Hong Kong used loudspeakers to call on the people of Hong Kong to overthrow the imperialists, the British drowned out the incitements with loudspeakers broadcasting the thunderous screech of Chinese opera. **********Now China is again expanding its influence in Hong Kong, although in a more cooperative manner. Businesses based in China have acquired real estate and corporations in Hong Kong apparently worth well over $5 billion, while others are issuing stock on the Hong Kong market. The Bank of China is snatching business from other institutions by offering highly competitive terms, and it is building Hong Kong's tallest office tower for its new headquarters in the territory. **********The head of the New China News Agency branch in Hong Kong, Xu Jiatun, is China's top official in Hong Kong and functions as the ''shadow governor,'' the counterpart of Britain's top official, Sir David Wilson. Ironically, neither Mr. Xu nor Sir David speak the Cantonese dialect of Chinese spoken by 98 percent of Hong Kong's population. **********The main reasons for China's expansion of influence in Hong Kong seem to be to gain experience in capitalism generally and Hong Kong particularly, and to reassure residents that China does not plan radical changes in Hong Kong's way of life after 1997. **********Although the brightest young professionals are unconvinced, many of Hong Kong's manufacturers are optimistic that China will allow Hong Kong to remain a place to make and keep money.  The Sun Is Setting On British Influence **********As Chinese influence has expanded, British influence has declined. Last year, for the first time, Americans outnumbered Britons among the expatriate residents of the territory. The Hong Kong Chinese who hope to emigrate seek visas to America or Australia more than to Britain. And the old British companies that dominated commerce are being replaced or acquired by Hong Kong Chinese concerns. The tai-pans, or big bosses, had names like Jardine, Dent, Sassoon and Swire. Now the inheritors of the tradition of the greatest of the tai-pans - William Jardine, founder of the Jardine Matheson trading company, known to the Chinese as ''iron-headed old rat'' - have names that trip English tongues: Pao Yuekong, Li Kashing, Siu Yatfoo, Wu Yingseung. **********The British tai-pans still flourish, of course. But as a final indignity to the old order, a New York lawyer, Brian M. Powers, was appointed this year to be the next tai-pan of the Jardine Matheson group. In a relatively formal society, the 38-year-old Mr. Powers is a maverick. He calls people by their first names unless they are over 70 years old and worth more than $1 billion.  The Border Blurs For Shopping and Play **********Hong Kong is changing in another important way; it is becoming a part of China. For much of the postwar period, tight Chinese entry restrictions made it extremely difficult to cross the border and prevented information from flowing to the outside world. In the late 1960's China-watchers in Hong Kong assessed the violence of the Cultural Revolution partly by noting the number of bodies drifting down the Pearl River from China. **********Hong Kong is becoming more integrated with cities like Shenzhen, on the China side of the border. Working-class families in Hong Kong take advantage of lower prices in China by crossing the border for doctor and dentist appointments and to shop for vegetables on the weekends. Middle-class families cross the border to tee off on Shenzhen's golf course. And students attend university in Guangdong Province, both because tuition is low and as a way to ingratiate themselves with their future rulers. **********Among those who are neither middle class nor wealthy, there is some apprehension about the future, but it is tempered by the feeling that they have little to lose and that there is not much they can do about it. In addition, some with strong nationalist feelings believe that Hong Kong belongs to China and should be ruled by Chinese rather than foreigners. **********A few people in Hong Kong seem to welcome the Chinese takeover; they are particularly represented in labor unions, newspapers and independent high schools that have long been associated with the Communists. **********The jitters about 1997 are concentrated overwhelmingly in the middle class - which numbers somewhere less than a quarter of the population -particularly among young people who have been educated abroad. They may have more to lose and may feel they can do something about it - leave Hong Kong. **********Not all the Chinese who go abroad will be welcomed. Reports abound that Chinese criminal gangs known as triads are expanding overseas from Hong Kong as 1997 approaches. The Hong Kong police force says it has no evidence that this is so, but a report this summer by California's Attorney General, John K. Van de Kamp, warned that Chinese triads are believed to control 20 percent to 30 percent of the heroin smuggled into the United States.  The Passport Merchants: Profits From Fear **********''People leave Hong Kong because of fear,'' said Horatio C. S. Cheung, the director of a nonprofit organization that advises people on how to get a foreign passport. ''They came to Hong Kong with nothing, worked hard and accumulated some wealth. They don't want to lose it.'' **********That fear has spawned more than a dozen businesses that, like Mr. Cheung's, help people emigrate. Tucked in the phone book between Ice Skating Rinks and Importers & Exporters is a category called Immigration & Naturalization Consultants, with 14 listings. They charge hundreds or even thousands of dollars to help someone obtain a foreign passport. **********Even some foreign countries see the alarm in Hong Kong as a source of funds. The island nation of Mauritius in the Indian Ocean offers a passport in exchange for an investment of about $50,000. Industrialized countries are more expensive. Canada, which primarily admits people who are joining relatives or have special skills, offers immigration visas for some investments of $200,000 or more. **********The fear of China's takeover strains the fabric of life in other ways. ''The 1997 issue has an indirect influence on marriages, although not a major one,'' said Elsie Lam, a marriage counselor in Hong Kong. Families are being separated so that a member with a visa can be sent abroad to get a toehold in the hope of bringing the rest of the family later. In freewheeling Hong Kong, where there has been little compunction about extramarital liaisons, the separation of spouses reportedly has led to a boom in such affairs. **********Chinese parents are even relaxing their standards about their children's marriage partners. Parents usually want their children to marry other Chinese, preferably those who trace their origins to the same region of China. But these days ''gweilos'' - ghostly people, as foreigners are called - are in demand on the marriage market. ''Marrying another Chinese is important,'' said a woman in her 20's, ''but getting a foreign passport is even more important.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/08/busin.main_headline: Pickens Is Considering A Big Stake in Singer
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/08/busin.print_headline: Pickens Is Considering A Big Stake in Singer
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/08/busin.body_text: **********Reaching again for a large military supplier, the Texas oilman T. Boone Pickens announced today that his Mesa Limited Partnership owns the equivalent of 4.4 percent of the Singer Company and may buy up to 15 percent of the aerospace and electronics manufacturer. **********The announcement came 11 days after the Boeing Company, the giant aircraft maker and military contractor, said Mr. Pickens was seeking Government approval to buy up to 15 percent of its shares. **********Industry analysts said that, in contrast to the situation with Boeing, which has a market value of nearly $8 billion, Mr. Pickens could easily finance the purchase of all of Singer's 21 million shares. They said a takeover could cost as much as $1.3 billion. Shares Rise $4.625 **********The price of Singer's common stock jumped $4.625 today, to $51.50, with more than a million shares traded on the New York Stock Exchange. The stock had traded as low as $37.625 as recently as June 30. **********Boeing's shares, meanwhile, lost 87.5 cents in active trading, closing at $51.25. **********Joseph B. Flavin, Singer's chairman and chief executive, declined to comment on the Mesa announcement, which was made before trading began. Mr. Pickens did not return phone calls to Mesa's headquarters in Amarillo, Tex. **********A Boeing spokesman, Harold Carr, said the company was unaware of Mr. Pickens's intentions toward Boeing or Singer. ''There is no indication that Mesa has lessened its interest in Boeing,'' he said. He declined to comment on whether Boeing had considered acquiring Singer, which is based in Stamford, Conn. **********Mr. Pickens is under pressure to produce additional income to cover an expected shortfall of $100 million between Mesa's cash flow and its commitment to pay $306 million in annual cash distributions on its common and preferred units. **********He said earlier that payments would be continued at current annual rates of $2 on common units and $1.50 on preferred units, through the first quarter of 1988. Mesa has invested in several energy-related companies this year, including the Amerada Hess Corporation and Burlington Northern Inc., but sold most of the stakes without making large profits. Focus on Military Units **********Singer has increasingly focused on its electronics and aerospace business since Mr. Flavin, 58 years old, became chief executive in 1975. It ranks 26th among military contractors to the Pentagon. Last year, it spun off its famous sewing machine operations - formed in 1851 by Isaac Singer and his lawyer, Edward B. Clark - to its shareholders. **********Singer's navigation systems help to guide military helicopters, the B-1B bomber and the space shuttle, and its tactical controls are applied in submarines and aircraft. Its flight simulators, once used primarily by the military, are increasingly being marketed to commercial airlines for pilot training. **********In jettisoning the sewing-machine business, Singer's revenues and profits both fell last year. It earned $58.5 million, or $2.63 a share, a 28.9 percent decline from the all-time company high of $82.3 million, or $4.30 a share, in 1985. Sales fell 29.1 percent, to $1.7 billion from $2.4 billion. **********In the second quarter, ended June 30, Singer took a charge of $45 million to cover cost increases on several military contracts. It lost $20.2 million in the quarter, compared with a profit of $21.8 million, or 98 cents a share, a year ago. Sales rose 4 percent, to $435.8 million. Bargains Among Contractors **********Mr. Pickens earned more than $400 million for Mesa in a series of unsuccessful takeover attempts in the oil industry between 1982 and 1985. His forays prodded the industry into a wave of mergers. **********Many analysts noted that, with a tightening Pentagon budget and narrowing profit margins, the military industry is in a position somewhat analogous to the oil industry of a few years ago. In the last year, Lockheed, Chrysler, Emerson Electric, Honeywell and Loral have made important acquisitions in the military-supply business. **********Paul H. Nisbet, an aerospace analyst with Prudential-Bache Capital Funding in New York, said Wall Street had driven the stock prices of many military contractors below their real values. That, in turn, has created the kinds of bargains that have attracted Mr. Pickens. **********Philip W. Friedman, a military industry analyst with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. in New York, said that Boeing, Chrysler, Allied-Signal and General Dynamics were among the potential bidders for Singer. **********Mr. Friedman noted that a buyer might want to sell Singer's nonmilitary businesses, which include power tools, vacuum cleaners and other floor-care products, as well as gas meters, regulators and instrumentation devices. Those units together earned $32.9 million before taxes last year, on sales of $294.5 million. **********''Singer is a prime candidate for a takeover,'' said Jon D. Gruber, head of Gruber Capital Management in San Francisco. ''My guess is Mr. Pickens wants to be a catalyst.'' **********Mr. Gruber said the company could command a price as high as $62 a share. Takeover Seen as Easy **********Catherine Montgomery, an energy analyst with Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette in New York, said that if no other bidders emerged, Mr. Pickens could ''easily manage'' to finance a Singer takeover. Mesa has more than $300 million in cash and credit lines of more than $600 million. **********Some analysts, however, said Mr. Pickens was more likely hoping to profit from a run-up in the stock. **********''I can't conceive of him making an attempt to acquire Boeing or Singer,'' said Rosario S. Ilacqua, an energy analyst with Nikko Securities in New York. ''To me, this is a continuation of the company's strategy to invest in undervalued situations.'' **********In its statement, Mesa said it had asked the Federal Trade Commission for approval to acquire up to 15 percent of Singer's shares. The partnership must wait up to 30 days before it can buy additional shares. **********The company said it owned a combination of Singer common shares and options to acquire common shares equal to 4.4 percent, or 922,240, of Singer's 20.96 million common shares outstanding. **********Analysts said Mesa would probably have to pay an average of nearly $55 a share, or $121 million, to acquire another 2.2 million shares. That would bring its total to 15 percent of Singer's stock.  AT A GLANCE: Singer Co. https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/24/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Private French TV Franchise Sold
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/24/busin.body_text: **********The French press magnate Robert Hersant and the Italian television producer Silvio Berlusconi have won the franchise to run France's private television Channel Five. The Hersant-Berlusconi bid was one of two for the network. The other was from Sir James Goldsmith, publisher of the Express magazine group. **********The National Commission for Communication and Liberties said that it had awarded the concession to a company in which Mr. Hersant, publisher of the Figaro newspaper group, and Mr. Berlusconi each own 25 percent. A Canadian television group Videotron is also a small shareholder.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/08/busin.body_text: **********A unit of the Tucson Electric Power Company said that it had been given clearance by Federal regulatory agencies to increase its stake in the Citadel Holding Corporation to 24.9 percent, from 9.5 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that was disclosed Friday, the unit, Santa Cruz Resources Inc., said it had talked with Citadel managers about buying the additional shares from the company. The two companies have also discussed possible board representation. Santa Cruz told the S.E.C. that ''no agreement has been reached.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/08/world.body_text: **********Adm. William J. Crowe Jr., Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, conferred today with the Saudi Arabian Defense Minister, Prince Sultan. The official Saudi press agency said the discussions, attended by the kingdom's Chief of Staff, Gen. Mohammed al-Hammad, and commanders of the armed forces, centered on improving military ties between Saudi Arabia and the United States. Admiral Crowe arrived Friday night for a three-day visit.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/15/busin.body_text: **********Against today's report of a growing trade deficit and new declines in the dollar, the Japanese-American hostility over trade seemed to intensify. Agriculture Secretary Richard E. Lyng said the two countries could be hurtling toward an accidental trade war, while a senior Japanese official said the trade deficit was America's problem, not Japan's. **********As the Friday deadline neared for the American imposition of stiff retaliatory duties on imports of Japanese semiconductor goods, American officials were ruling out a compromise of the sort that ended the countries' previous conflicts over trade. The President's special trade representative, Clayton K. Yeutter, said today that the conflict could be resolved in ''a relatively short period'' after the trade sanctions take effect. Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige has spoken in terms of months. **********But before then, officials warn, something could get out of control. **********''They are not going to start a trade war with us, with the amount of dollar trade they have with the United States,'' Mr. Lyng said at a briefing with reporters. ''But we may start a trade war with them accidentally. It's because they make the country so angry. If they make Americans angry enough it will cost them dearly.'' **********With one eye on a Congress that is pondering tough legislation against ''unfair'' imports, Mr. Lyng said: ''The access to that market has to be open. Otherwise there will be further steps to restrict access here. We're not afraid to do it.'' **********Mr. Lyng and Mr. Yeutter are planning a trip to Japan next week in what could be a new escalation of the conflict. ''On beef and citrus we're asking for total elimination of quotas,'' Mr. Lyng said.  The Japanese are bargaining hard for a truce in the semiconductor fight. They have sent their second-highest trade official, Makoto Kuroda, to make their case. Installed in a situation room on the fifth floor of the Watergate Hotel with a sizable staff, Mr. Kuroda has been granting interviews to American journalists and making the rounds of Administration officials. He saw Mr. Yeutter today. **********But Mr. Kuroda makes little room for new Japanese concessions. ''Imposing restrictions on us will not resolve the big issue,'' he said. ''The trade deficit problem is clearly your problem. Other people say it's the result of the Administration's economic policies.'' This alluded to American budget deficits, which some economists blame for the trade deficit. **********Meanwhile, Mr. Kuroda calls for American understanding of changes that Japan has already made in its economy, partly in response to American pressure. ''The situation has already changed,'' he said. ''Just please open your eyes, your ears to what is happening in our market.'' **********Mr. Kuroda said the Japanese were offended by American charges that Japan does not follow up on assurances it makes to stimulate its economy and to end barriers to imports. **********''The Japanese are proud of keeping their promises,'' he said. ''It is bad to hear our best allies telling us we are not trustworthy.'' **********But Mr. Yeutter told reporters: ''Policy-making in Japan must go beyond planning to execution. The marketplace is reflecting a dissatisfaction with governments implementing their proposed programs. **********''For example, just this past week the Government of Japan indicated it was prepared to move forward with a dramatic domestic demand package, and yet the marketplace did not respond favorably to that. It seems to me that the market participants have indicated that they have to see it before they believe it.'' **********''The semiconductor agreement was the accidental trigger of a crisis that was waiting to erupt,'' said C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics here. ''There are two reasons: There's no improvement of the trade deficit in sight, and the plan to stabilize the dollar isn't working.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/29/busin.body_text: **********Milton J. Petrie, chairman of the Petrie Stores Corporation, based in Secaucus, N.J., said he had purchased a 5 percent stake in Deb Shops Inc. for $14.4 million. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Petrie said he had acquired the Deb Shops shares, at an average price of $18.95 a share, for investment purposes only. The stock closed at $19.50 today, up $1.125 a share, in over-the-counter trading. Mr. Petrie told the S.E.C. that he would review his investment and might change his present course. Deb Shops is a Philadelphia-based women's specialty apparel chain, with 231 stores, primarily in the East.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/18/busin.body_text: **********SINCE he was going to Hattiesburg, Miss., to attend his son's nuptial event on Friday, Henry Kornhauser, chairman and chief executive of Kornhauser & Calene, left behind a videotape of his dramatic announcement of management changes at the agency. The tape did not answer questions, of course, but those who have just been promoted seemed quite willing to. **********There was Neve R. Savage, a 42-year-old bearded Briton and former Wells Rich Green executive, who after only six months at K.& C. has been promoted to vice chairman, marketing and account management. **********William Nicholson, 42, a financial man who came from Cunningham & Walsh a year ago, has now been made chief operating officer and corporate secretary. **********Robert Forgione, 56, nine months away from his own production company, has been promoted to executive creative director. **********And brand new to the agency - but also bearded, also a Briton and fresh out of FCB/Leber Katz Partners but formerly at Wells Rich - is Dennis Barham, 49, who is the new vice chairman, creative director. **********John Calene, who has been president and director of creative services since K.& C.'s founding in 1980, is in negotiation with the agency as to what his future will be there, according to Mr. Nicholson. Mr. Kornhauser and Mr. Calene each own just under 40 percent of the agency's stock. The agency is billing about $122 million a year. Its clients include American Home Products, Church & Dwight, J. P. Stevens, National Westmister Bank and California Home Brands, a pet food company that has never advertised before. **********Mr. Barham, who had been an executive vice president at W.R.G. back in England, was chairman, chief executive and creative director of the Leo Burnett Company when it went to sixth-largest agency from 14th. **********What can we expect from an agency under Mr. Barham's creative direction? Well, he thinks American advertising is dull and overly rational, if that is a clue.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/13/busin.main_headline: Mattel to Make Toys for Disney
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/13/busin.print_headline: Mattel to Make Toys for Disney
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/13/busin.body_text: **********Mattel Inc. said today that it would design and make a line of infant and preschool toys for the Walt Disney Company. **********Terms of the licensing agreement were not disclosed. **********Toy buyers will first look at the Disney-brand line in January. Mattel officials said they would decline to disclose the products under development until then. Disney, based in Burbank, Calif., has for years awarded licensing deals for its well-known characters to outside manufacturers. A rival, MCA Inc., parent of Universal Studios, has its own toy company to make products based on movie character spinoffs. **********For Mattel, the deal renews a relationship with Disney. The toy maker was one of the original advertising sponsors for the ''Mickey Mouse Club,'' a Disney television show. In fact, in 1956 Mattel came out with its first product with a television tie-in: the Mouseguitar. Mattel, based in Hawthorne, Calif., already makes three lines of preschool toys.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/20/busin.body_text: **********About 8,000 employees of Safeway Stores Inc. in northern Texas will join the ranks of the unemployed on Friday. The chain is selling or closing 131 of its Dallas division stores, along with processing and distribution systems in the Dallas suburb of Garland. Safeway announced the action April 3, saying it was part of the company's restructuring in order to become more competitive.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/06/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: AN apparatus for the photographic detection of eye defects, especially among children, was patented this week for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. It is already being manufactured under license. **********AN apparatus for the photographic detection of eye defects, especially among children, was patented this week for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. It is already being manufactured under license. **********Patent 4,669,836, assigned to NASA, was granted to John R. Richardson, a staff member at the Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Ala., and Joseph H. Kerr, a retired employee. Mr. Kerr has organized and heads the Medical Sciences Corporation in Wedowee, Ala., which is producing the equipment, called Visiscreen 100. **********Mr. Kerr said by telelphone that the invention had been used in eye tests on 20,000 students in 23 states. The eight-foot-long apparatus has a hood to hold the subject's head, a camera and a flash unit. Beams from a lamp, reflected on the subject's nose and cheeks, show an operator when the head is properly positioned.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/10/busin.body_text: **********A Federal grand jury today indicted a reputed organized crime figure for evading taxes on income from business he did with MCA Records Inc. **********Salvatore J. Pisello, 64 years old, was indicted for evading more than $187,000 in income taxes, said Richard A. Small, the acting attorney in charge of the Los Angeles Police Department's Organized Crime Strike Force. **********He said Mr. Pisello was the first person indicted in a continuing investigation of payoffs and organized crime influence in the recording industry. **********MCA executives could not be reached for comment, but the company previously said it had not been aware of Mr. Pisello's background and was cooperating with the investigation. **********The indictment said Mr. Pisello had earned nearly $600,000, primarily by arranging sales of recordings as a consultant for MCA.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/28/busin.main_headline: Strategist's Top Deal Is Rexnord Acquisition
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/28/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Strategist's Top Deal Is Rexnord Acquisition
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/28/busin.body_text: **********Jeffrey Steiner, chairman and chief executive of Banner Industries, a diversified manufacturer in Cleveland, has taken the final steps to acquire Rexnord Inc. for about $525 million. The move is the biggest financial maneuver taken by Mr. Steiner, who is 50, since he came to Banner in 1984. **********An analyst for McDonald & Company in Cleveland, Harry W. Millis, said he thought that Mr. Steiner's intent had always been to create a much larger operation through acquisition, putting Banner in a much stronger position. **********''As long as the operating management stays in place at Rexnord, there should be no major difference in the operating style of the whole business,'' Mr. Millis said. ''It should continue to be very successful.'' **********Rexnord, a much bigger company, with sales in 1986 of about $1 billion, serves a variety of worldwide industrial markets with mechanical and electronic components and systems, including power transmission, molded plastic components and specialty chemicals. It is based in Brookfield, Wis. **********Analysts say it is unlikely that Mr. Steiner will interfere in the day-to-day operations at Rexnord. They see Mr. Steiner as a financial strategist rather than an executive interested in operations. **********A prime example of Mr. Steiner's preference for strategy over operations was his decision to move Banner's executive offices to New York. This move has left the company, whose headquarters remains in Cleveland, in the operational control of Samuel J. Krasney, Banner's founder, previous chief executive and current chief operating officer. **********Mr. Steiner became Banner's chairman and largest stockholder in October 1985 after he bought a 25 percent share of the company from Mr. Krasney. Mr. Krasney said that with options, Mr. Steiner's position in Banner could reach 30 percent. **********Mr. Krasney said Banner, with annual sales of about $150 million, would probably keep looking at other companies with growth opportunities. **********Banner said its definitive agreement to acquire Rexnord would put Rexnord's chairman and chief executive officer, Donald Taylor, on the Banner board. Mr. Krasney said there was a possibility that a second seat on the board would go to another Rexnord executive. **********Before joining Banner, Mr. Steiner was president and managing director of Cedec S.A., a Paris-based engineering concern that he founded in 1975. **********Mr. Steiner, who was born in Australia, has been married twice and has four children.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/23/world.body_text: **********He is the ''third Kim,'' a specter of a bygone regime who had faded from national consciousness but who now might be the wild card in South Korea's approaching presidential election. **********Kim Jong Pil, for four years Prime Minister under President Park Chung Hee, is running for president. It is a question of honor, he says, a belated and unexpected chance to ask Korean voters to ''pass judgment'' on the Park Government's 18 years of economic growth and political repression. **********''I believe that we emancipated the Korean people from the yolk of poverty,'' Mr. Kim said, discussing the period from 1961, when he helped General Park stage a military coup, to 1979, when President Park was shot to death by his intelligence chief. **********''In the 1970's we were able to embark upon the process of industrialization,'' he said. ''I consider that period one in which we laid the foundation for democracy, and now in 1987 we should provide a stepping stone from which real democracy can come into being.'' **********By deciding to run in an election that had seemed unthinkable until South Korean politics was suddenly turned upside down this summer, Mr. Kim, 61 years old, has stirred worries among leaders in the Government and the ruling Democratic Justice Party. **********They fear he will take votes from their candidate, Roh Tae Woo, and have sent people to try, unsuccessfully, to talk him out of the race. **********Estimates of his potential strength range from 5 percent to 10 percent of the vote. That could be enough to hurt Mr. Roh in a close race, especially if it includes both of the other two Kims -the better-known Kim Dae Jung and Kim Young Sam. They are the mainstream opposition leaders. **********Kim Jong Pil, a well-tailored former army colonel, is married to the niece of Park Chung Hee. During his years in government and business, he managed to amass considerable wealth. He is also a persuasive speaker, one analysts say will appeal to older, more prosperous Koreans, particularly businessmen who lost privileges that they enjoyed under the Park regime. Abortive Run for President **********After Mr. Park was assassinated Mr. Kim tried to run for president, his opponents then being the other two Kims. But before an election could be held there was another military uprising, led by Maj. Gen. Chun Doo Hwan. **********All three Kims were banned from political activity, and Kim Jong Pil, commonly referred to as J. P., had much of his wealth confiscated by the new Chun Government. **********For two years, from 1984 to 1986, he lived in California. Now he is back, and has begun touring the country, addressing supporters as he prepares to form a new political party. The coup that he helped engineer long ago was justifiable, and was therefore different from Mr. Chun's, he insists. **********It is widely assumed that his new party will absorb many of the 20 members of the National Assembly that belong to a minor opposition group of old Park loyalists, the Korea National Party. Many political experts also say they believe Mr. Kim is not interested in winning, an unlikely prospect at best, but to establish himself as a force to be reckoned with in future elections. **********''In my heart and mind, I was quite sure that the time would come for me to speak out,'' he said. ''And now, as you see, that time is here.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/19/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Pham Van Dong and President Truong Chinh, the last founders of the Vietnamese Communist Party still in power in Hanoi, were removed today by a vote of the National Assembly. **********Their departure ends more than half a century of unbroken party and government leadership by colleagues and contemporaries of Ho Chi Minh. **********The two men replaced today had resigned their party Politburo seats in December, when Mr. Chinh was apparently also forced out as General Secretary of the Communist Party. Mr. Dong had said publicly he wanted to retire. **********Mr. Dong, who is 81 years old, was replaced as Prime Minister by Pham Hung, formerly Interior Minister, and Mr. Chinh, 80, was succeeded as President by Vo Chi Cong, a Deputy Prime Minister and former Agriculture Minister. Both newly elected officials are in their mid-70's, and both had played major political roles in North Vietnam's war against South Vietnam in the 1960's and early 70's. New Party Chief in Charge **********The choices were the least surprising of several possibilities that have been discussed in the region since the Sixth Party Congress in December, when Nguyen Van Linh was named the new party leader, putting him in the country's most important job. Mr. Hung and Mr. Cong have ranked as No. 2 and 3 in the Politburo hierarchy since then. **********Foreign Ministers of the non-Communist Association of Southeast Asian Nations, meeting here today with their counterparts from the United States, Canada, Australia, New Zealand and the European Community, said they foresaw no new policies in Hanoi as a result of the leadership changes. **********Before the final steps in a yearlong political reorganization in Vietnam were announced today, Secretary of State George P. Shultz told the annual conference of the Asean nations -Thailand, Malaysia, Singapore, Indonesia, Brunei and the Philippines -that it was ''imperative to keep pressure on the Vietnamese to end their occupation'' of Cambodia. **********Mr. Linh, 71, the first party leader not to have been part of Ho's inner circle, is considered an economic pragmatist who was apparently influenced by the prosperity of the south while serving as Hanoi's top official there during the war against South Vietnamese and American forces. **********The election of Mr. Hung as Prime Minister suggests that Mr. Linh could be meeting resistance from hardliners. Mr. Hung, a security expert who took command of the Central Office for South Vietnam in 1967, stayed on after Hanoi's conquest of Saigon in 1975, in a period when the policy of the unified nation was to crush the south.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/13/world.print_headline: Sudan Cuts Sentence for Aide Who Helped Ethiopian Jews
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/13/world.body_text: **********A court has reduced the sentence given to former Vice President Omar el-Tayeb for his role in transporting thousands of Ethiopian Jews through the Sudan to Israel. **********Last year Mr. Tayeb was given a 30-year term and a life sentence, to be served consecutively. The Appeals High Court reduced his sentence Saturday to 10 years. **********Judge Zaki Abdel-Rahman said the earlier sentences reflected the political climate in the Sudan in April 1986, after the coup that deposed President Gaafar al-Nimeiry. Mr. Tayeb served in the Nimeiry Government. **********At the trial, prosecutors said Mr. Tayeb and others had conspired with the United States Air Force and the Central Intelligence Agency to fly more than 10,000 Ethiopian Jews out of Sudanese drought-relief camps to Israel between 1981 and 1984. **********Arab nations criticized the airlift, charging that the Sudan was aiding Israel, which is technically at war with all Arab countries except Egypt.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/05/busin.main_headline: Dow Edges Up 5.82 as Volume Slows
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/05/busin.print_headline: Dow Edges Up 5.82 as Volume Slows
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/05/busin.body_text: **********The stock market had another see-saw session yesterday, but managed to end slightly higher on a day that saw trading fall off sharply. **********The Dow Jones industrial average gained 5.82 points, to 2,286.22, having spent most of the day in minus territory. The blue-chip indicator had opened strongly, apparently on the back of some computer-generated buy programs, but investor concern about the weakening dollar, and declining bond prices, took its toll, and only some last-minute buying enabled the Dow to end higher. **********The last two sessions on Wall Street have been nothing to write home about. On Friday, the Dow lost 5.96. So in the last two trading days the Dow has lost 0.14. **********''It looks as if the market is trying to decide if the yen has stabilized against the dollar,'' said J. Warren Hall, head of portfolio management for the National City Corporation in Cleveland. He said the yen ''seems to be trying to get a grip between 138 and 140'' to the dollar, adding, ''If it succeeds, I think we'll get a rally.'' Rising Profits Foreseen **********Until that happens, Mr. Hall predicted, the stock market ''will dance to the yen drum.'' For the long term, however, he believes that rising corporate profits will propel the Dow higher, especially, he said, because ''we do not think inflation is going to take off.'' **********Some traders suggested that the market's recent performance in the face of uncertainty about the dollar and interest rates was not all that bad. ''This market should be down 100 points today,'' one said. **********Volume was comparatively light. Only 140.6 million shares traded hands on the New York Stock Exchange, compared with 160.1 million on Friday. On the Big Board, 761 stocks gained and 830 dropped. A holiday in Japan apparently cut into the American trading. **********The Big Board's composite index gained 0.58, to 163.22, and the S.&P. 500-stock index added 1.33, to 289.36. Elsewhere, trading was also tame. Both the American Stock Exchange market index and the Nasdaq index of over-the-counter trading gained a measly 0.01. The Amex index closed at 325.18 and Nasdaq's at 418.45. Church's Climbs **********There was some interesting Big Board action, however. Church's Fried Chicken rose 1 1/8, to 11 3/4, after an investment group that includes former Church's executives made a $12.25-a-share bid for the company. The deal is worth about $469 million. International Controls rose a sharp 5 1/4 points, to 39 3/4, on a $40-a-share takeover offer from the Synergy Group of Farmingdale, L.I. International Controls already has one offer on the table, for $32 a share, from a group that includes the Bear, Stearns brokerage. This raises the possibility of a bidding war for International Controls. The company, according to Mark Walsh, a Morgan Stanley analyst, ''could support a higher price, as a leveraged buyout.'' At the $40 offer, the deal is worth around $160 million. **********Sante Fe Southern Pacific was up 1, to 42 1/4, on persistent takeover rumors and on a buy recommendation by Oppenheimer & Company. The Henley Group, which bought 5.03 percent of Santa Fe stock as an investment last year, refused to comment on reports that it was buying more. **********Railroad sources said that a hostile takeover seemed doubtful in view of the company's difficulties in getting the Interstate Commerce Commission to approve a merger of the Santa Fe and the Southern Pacific, first proposed in 1984. It was rejected last year as anti-competitive. **********The airline stocks were mixed. T.W.A. lost 1/2, to 24; Delta gained 7/8, to 48 1/4. UAL, which has been losing ground steadily since it became apparent that a takeover of the carrier by its pilots' union may not be in the cards, fell another 2 7/8, to 65 1/2. **********But NWA Inc. jumped 3 1/2, to 65, although trading was light. ''It's up big, on no volume,'' one trader said. ''That means there are no sellers. Someone is terribly anxious to buy the stock.'' But analysts could give no reason for the move, and a spokesman for the company in Minneapolis, said management never comments on stock action. New High for I.B.M.  I.B.M. continued to shine, and hit a new high at 163, up 2 3/8. The stock has been roaring ahead, generally pulling the entire technology sector with it. **********The autos backed off a bit, with the exception of Chrysler, which rose 1/2, to 40. The stock traded at a new high of 41. Ford, which exploded from 81 to 98 last week after reporting record earnings, eased 1/2, to 97 1/2. G.M. lost 3/8, to 91 1/4. All three are trading at or near their highs.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/10/busin.main_headline: Bonds Continue to Fall; Traders Still Pessimistic
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/10/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKET; Bonds Continue to Fall; Traders Still Pessimistic
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/10/busin.body_text: **********Bond prices slumped further in active trading yesterday, pushing yields to their highest levels in nearly two years, as dealers remained deeply pessimistic about a wide range of economic issues. **********No one event spurred yesterday's sell-off. Traders are still worried about the future course of the dollar on foreign exchange markets and about a possible sharp increase in inflation. Moreover, in the current environment they are also questioning their ability to drum up retail interest in bonds, even with the recent sharp rise in yields. **********That sentiment was pervasive among market participants yesterday. The anxiety was heightened by the awareness that the Treasury is to announce the size of its quarterly refunding in a little more than two weeks. **********''I don't know how it is at other houses, but all I have been asked to do all day long is to sell securities,'' said Alfred G. Roth, senior vice president and head of the government securities department at Thomson-McKinnon Securities Inc. ''We haven't seen any buying at all today. Investors are on the sidelines because they are getting paid a premium to do nothing. All they have to do is wait to be shown increasingly better yields.'' 30-Year Treasury Security By late in the day, the Treasury's bellwether 8 7/8 percent 30-year bond was quoted at a bid of 89 1/8, down nearly half a point for the day, to yield 9.913 percent. The yield level, already the highest on a 30-year Treasury security since November 1985, is almost certain to pierce 10 percent in the very near future, analysts said. **********''Ten percent on the long bond is gone,'' said one trader at a major investment bank. ''Now the market is looking at 10 1/8 percent.'' **********Roger A. Froehlich, president of Technical Dimensions, a bond market forecasting and advisory service firm, said, ''We feel that long-term prices formations are indicating sustained selling for months, probably into 1988.'' **********Yesterday's pessimism about interest rates and the bond market's weakness carried over into the stock market. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 34.26, to 2,482.38, ending the week with a loss of 158.78 points, or 6 percent.  [ Page 45. ]  Although the 30-year issue resisted breaking through the 10 percent yield level yesterday, the Treasury's 9 3/8 percent 20-year bonds did. Late in the day, the 20-year issue was bid at 94 5/8, down 1/4 for the day, to yield 10.010 percent. Short-Term Rates Mixed **********Short-term interest rates were mixed. Three-month bills were quoted at a late bid of 6.75 percent, up 11 basis points, or hundredths of a point. But six-month bills declined by 2 basis points, to a bid of 7.28 percent, and one-year bills declined by 6 basis points, to a bid of 7.57 percent. **********The activity capped a sorry week for the fixed income markets. At the close of business on Oct. 2, the 30-year bond was yielding 9.68 percent, nearly 25 basis points below yesterday's close. **********Although short-term interest rates have not risen as much as long rates, their rise has been enough to make a further increase in the discount rate by the Federal Reserve practically a foregone conclusion, analysts said. **********''Even though the picture on inflation and the dollar is better now than it was on Sept. 4, when they last raised the rate, the markets have set up another hike,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist at Shearson Lehman Brothers. ''I would be surprised if the Federal Reserve banks have not asked for another increase.'' **********Last month the Fed raised the discount rate half a point, to 6 percent. **********The apprehension currently gripping the bond market is not universally held. Some analysts said that the sell-off has been overdone, and that all the market needs is one significant event to generate a major rally. **********''The sentiment in the bond market strikes me as being far too bearish right now,'' said Lawrence A. Kudlow, chief economist at Bear, Stearns. ''We may be much closer to the peak on long-term rates than people realize. The fundamentals are improving, particularly on the policy side, regarding the dollar and the Federal budget. Evidence that inflation is slowing, a clear downward break in industrial raw material prices for instance, would probably trigger a strong, quick rally.'' **********A fear that rates may indeed go higher very soon may have been the driving force behind the issuance of a number of new corporate offerings yesterday. **********In the corporate market, underwriters led by Merrill Lynch offered $300 million of triple-A rated General Electric Corporation 9 3/8 percent extendible notes. The notes have a final maturity in 2007 at a price of 99.80, yielding 9.452 percent to 1990. After that, noteholders can sell them back to the company at par. **********Elsewhere, Salomon Brothers acted as lead manager on a $200 million 5-year note offering from the Ford Motor Credit Company. The 10.20 percent notes, which mature in 1992, were offered at par, or about 68-hundredths of a percentage point more than Treasury notes with a similar maturity. **********Finally, the Commonwealth Edison Company offered $200 million of five-year and 30-year first mortgage bonds through Morgan Stanley. Half of the bonds are due in 1992 and were priced to yield 10.40 percent. The remaining $100 million of the issue matures in 2017 and was priced to yield 12 percent. Underwriters said the shorter maturity is noncallable, while the longer issue is nonrefundable for five years.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/20/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Trade Commission has asked the Justice Department to prosecute Donald J. Trump, the New York developer and investor, for making use of a ''parking'' agreement to facilitate an acquisition. **********Under such agreements, investors typically get an investment bank to buy stock in a target company for them. That way they can avoid requirements that they disclose any acquisition intentions. Such disclosures would drive up the price of their quarry's stock. **********Many potential acquirers have made use of such agreements, but none has ever been litigated, said Arthur Amolsch, editor and publisher of FTC: Watch, a biweekly newsletter that reported the F.T.C. request in its current issue. **********Reached this evening, Mr. Trump said of the F.T.C. decision, ''We look forward, along with many other people and companies, to showing that this is total nonsense.'' **********It was not known whether the Justice Department, which is thought to be dubious about its chances of succeeding in the case, will actually bring it. The commission was itself divided on the issue, apparently voting, 3 to 2, to refer the case. **********Purchasers of stock for takeover purposes may use parking agreements, also referred to as put-call agreements, to avoid having to make public disclosures after a certain percentage of a company's outstanding shares is reached. In this arrangement, an investment bank buys stock that the potential acquirer has an option to buy. If Government approval of a combination is denied, the investor generally reimburses the investment banker for any losses. Bally Case Discussed **********The newsletter did not mention which of Mr. Trump's acquisitions was at issue, but it was thought to be that of the Bally Manufacturing Corporation, a hotel and casino owner he took over this year. **********Under the Hart-Scott-Rodino Act of 1976, potential acquirers must provide notice of their intentions to give the Government time to mount an antitrust challenge. Otherwise, a merger might be consummated and could then be difficult to reverse. **********Any prosecution would entail a civil case in which the penalty would be a fine.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/13/busin.body_text: **********After several failed efforts to expand its military electronics business, the Loral Corporation has catapulted itself into one of the biggest companies in the field. **********Loral, a New York-based electronic equipment manufacturer, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the aerospace division of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company for $640 million. **********The acquisition would combine two of the best-known companies in military electronics, a field that is expected to play an increasing role in military projects, ranging from fighter planes to missile systems. **********The sale by Goodyear comes after a bruising pursuit of the company last fall by Sir James Goldsmith, the British financier who amassed an 11.5 percent interest in Goodyear before selling his shares back to the company in November. Goodyear responded to his share accumulation with a sweeping restructuring that included a huge share repurchase to be financed by stripping the company of its energy holdings, in addition to the aerospace business. **********For Bernard L. Schwartz, the chairman of Loral, the acquisition fulfills a longstanding quest to forge a stronger presence in the highly profitable military electronics business. ''I'm on a personal high to have accomplished such a quantum jump,'' Mr. Schwartz said. The acquisition will make Loral one of the largest forces in military electronics. Once the sale is completed, the company's sales will more than double, to about $1.6 billion. At the same time the company's work force will swell from the current 8,000 workers to more than 16,000. Mr. Schwartz said that no personnel changes are planned for Goodyear Aerospace, whose main operations are in Akron, Ohio, and in Phoenix. **********Analysts said that the companies' lines of business and products would complement each other. For example, Goodyear Aerospace makes simulation and training equipment for the Navy and Air Force, while Loral makes similar equipment for the Army. Also, Loral produces airborne antisubmarine warfare track-ing systems. Goodyear Aerospace makes similar systems to be used underwater. **********With a couple of recent exceptions, ''Loral has done a phenomenal job in making acquisitions,'' said Jon D. Gruber, an analyst with Montgomery Securities. ''It is a well-run company. Mr. Schwartz's record there inspires a lot of confidence.'' **********Loral makes radar units, field radios, jamming equipment and other electronics gear. For the six months that ended Sept. 30, the most recent period for which figures are available, the company reported net income of $25.2 million, or $1.07 a share, on sales of $310 million. For the comparable period of 1985, the company earned $23.1 million, or 97 cents a share, on sales of $292 million. Prices on Stocks Advance **********Loral's stock was up 62.5 cents yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, closing at $40.375. Goodyear's stock was up 50 cents on the Big Board, closing at $44.75. **********Goodyear Aerospace had sales of about $695 million and estimated pretax earnings of about $55 million. The division makes high-technology systems for military use such as reconnaisance and radar systems and electronic warfare systems. **********Much of Loral's growth has come from a series of seven smaller acquisitions since 1980, including its purchase two years ago of both Hycor Inc. and the military equipment division of the International Business Machines Corporation's Rolm division for $90 million. **********But the company has been looking for a major expansion for some time. Loral was thwarted last year in a $980 million bid for Sanders Associates Inc., a New Hampshire military electronics company, when it was outbid by the Lockheed Corporation, which paid $1.18 billion. Loral also failed to acquire the Sperry Aerospace Group, which was bought by Honeywell Inc. **********And last summer, Loral was eliminated from the field of bidders on an $8 billion electronic warfare system for future tactical aircraft to be flown by the Navy and, eventually, the Air Force, according to Wall Street analysts and Government officials. Prominent Takeover Targets **********Although they have, encountered problems and erratic earnings progress, military electronics properties have been prominent takeover targets in recent months. High-technology sectors such as military electronics are widely viewed as a principal growth area even if military spending over all plateaus. **********Last October, for example, the Emerson Electric Company agreed to buy the Hazeltine Corporation, a producer of electronic equipment, whose main customers are the Defense Department and Government agencies. **********The Boeing Company and the General Dynamics Corporation are said to be looking to expand their military electronics business. At the same time, the Grumman Corporation, TRW Inc. and Fairchild Industries have been rumored to be takeover targets. **********Some analysts criticized today's acquisition, saying Loral was assuming too much debt. ''The company's books would have more than $700 million in debt and only $350 million in equity,'' one analyst said.. **********Loral was not alone in bidding for Goodyear's aerospace holdings. The Martin Marietta Corporation also made an offer, Goodyear officials said. **********Still on the block are Goodyear's Celeron division, an oil and gas concern engaged in constructing a 1,750-mile pipeline linking offshore California wells to Texas refineries.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/07/world.main_headline: Iran-Contra Panels Are Continuing Their Inquiry, Official Says
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/07/world.print_headline: Iran-Contra Panels Are Continuing Their Inquiry, Official Says
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/07/world.body_text: **********The chairman of the House committee on the Iran-contra affair said today that the staffs of the select committees had not finished their investigation and would continue to pursue leads in the weeks before a final report in October. **********''For almost every single witness, there are questions that we don't know the answer to that we probably should know the answer to,'' said the chairman, Lee H. Hamilton, an Indiana Democrat. **********He continued: ''We have an enormous amount of work to do. There are a lot of depositions to be taken, a lot of leads that we have not pursued as fully as we should.'' **********Staff members said many of the witnesses who testified before Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North and Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter would be recalled, to give new sworn depositions and to respond to questions arising out of the North and Poindexter testimony. Questions on Israel's Role **********Mr. Hamilton said the investigators would also try to resolve unanswered questions about the role played by Israel in the arms sales to Iran and about the secret financial transactions that accompanied the arms sales and the tranfer of some profits to the contra rebels in Nicaragua. **********The House and Senate select committees completed their public sessions on Monday. Today they finished three days of closed hearings in which they heard testimony from officials of the Central Intelligence Agency. Transcripts are to be made public next week after being declassified. **********Mr. Hamilton, who was interviewed by reporters at a breakfast meeting, said that in preparing their final recommendations the committees would have to avoid two extremes. **********If the panels present ''a checklist of 150 items,'' he said, the report will ''lose a lot of its force and impact.'' Legislation Won't Help **********But if it contains nothing but ''safe attitudes and glittering generalities,'' he added, no one will pay attention. **********Mr. Hamilton said, and many other members of the committees from both parties agree, that by and large the abuses of the government process exposed by the Congressional investigation were not susceptible to correction by new legislation. **********That is in contrast to the attitude in Congress after the Watergate investigations in the 1970's. Then, Congress passed legislation regulating campaign financing and restricting the warmaking power of Presidents, among other measures. **********''This was a failure of people, not of the system,'' said Warren B. Rudman, a New Hampshire Republican and the vice chairman of the Senate committee. ''You cannot pass laws that will improve on human judgment.'' 'Resist the Temptation' **********The leading Republican on the House committee, Dick Cheney of Wyoming, made a similar point in his summation speech this week. He said: ''I would urge my colleagues to resist the temptation to enact legislation designed to guarantee that no future President makes the mistakes that Ronald Reagan made in this instance. In my opinion, there is no justification for further restrictions on the power and flexibility of future Presidents.'' **********Many of the legislators said they expected that the mere exposure of flaws in the way foreign policy was conducted in the Reagan Administration would keep future Presidents from making the same mistakes. ''The inoculation of the airing and the condemnation of the behavior will have some effect in preventing this kind of thing from happening soon again,'' said Representative Thomas S. Foley, Democrat of Washington. **********But one step does appear to be supported by a majority on the committees: a tightening of the requirements under which a President must inform Congress of covert actions. **********Under law, Presidents are supposed to tell specified members of Congress before secret intelligence operations are begun. If Congress cannot be told in advance, because there is no time to do so or because the risk of exposure is too great, then Congress must be told in a ''timely'' fashion. Criticism of Reagan **********The Iran arms sales continued for more than a year without notification of Congress. Some legislators have suggested that notification be required within 48 hours. **********Representative Foley, who is the House majority leader and whose views thus carry much weight, said he did not oppose a 48-hour notification requirement. But he said he doubted it would make any difference in the case of the Reagan Administration. **********''This President asserts the Constitutional right to deny Congress access to foreign-policy information,'' Mr. Foley said. ''There is only a limited degree to which we can assure that a President doesn't ignore the law.'' **********Most of the Republicans on the select committees favor abolishing the separate Senate and House Intelligence Committees and replacing them with a smaller joint committee. They argue that Presidents would be more likely to share secrets with Congress if fewer legislators and staff assistants had access to them. Joint Committee Unlikely **********''The willingness of Administration officials to share highly classified information is directly related to their confidence that we can keep a confidence,'' Mr. Cheney said. **********But such a joint committee does not appear to be in the offing. Neither the House nor the Senate are likely to be willing to give up having their own intelligence panels with their own leadership and staffs. **********Perhaps more important, many senior lawmakers do not believe a joint intelligence committee is a good idea. **********''Intelligence committees cannot function unless they are surrogates for the rest of the House and the Senate,'' said Mr. Foley. ''You can't have one or two people getting all the information because that would not reflect the confidence of the whole House or the whole Senate.'' **********Representative Henry J. Hyde, a Republican from Illinois and a member of the Iran-contra committee, is the chief House sponsor of legislation to establish a joint intelligence committee. He said he was fighting long odds. **********But even if he succeeded, he said, it would not solve the main problems that surfaced during the hearings. **********''It's the people who are crucial,'' Mr. Hyde said. ''You have to have people who understand that you can't run a foreign policy against Congress. If Congress won't agree with you, you have to try to change Congress. You don't run a policy out of the back door.''
