https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/25/busin.main_headline: A LEVERAGED MACY'S WAITS FOR THE REWARDS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/25/busin.print_headline: A LEVERAGED MACY'S WAITS FOR THE REWARDS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/25/busin.body_text: **********IN early 1985, Edward S. Finkelstein, chairman of R. H. Macy & Company, the nation's fourth-largest department store chain, found himself increasingly preoccupied with two problems. Some of his most talented executives were restless; a few were leaving for better-paying jobs with more authority at other retailers. And Macy stock was moving up in a way that suggested the possibility that someone was planning to launch a hostile takeover. **********After pondering several possibilities, Mr. Finkelstein decided that a leveraged buyout would be the best way to address the problems. Following some backing and forthing on the price, shareholders overwhelmingly approved the $3.6 billion deal last July. **********Seven months later, Mr. Finkelstein is ready to declare the new Macy's a success. Financial results for the the first quarter after the buyout, ending Nov. 1, were well above expectations; sales increased 16.4 percent, to $1.23 billion (thanks in part to the opening of two new stores), and instead of the $28 million loss foreseen at the time of the buyout, Macy lost only $8.6 million. **********More importantly, the buyout seems to have prompted a healthy change in corporate culture. ''There's no question in my mind that it is working well because we have unleashed an entrepreneurial spirit here,'' said Mr. Finkelstein. **********Despite that rosy assessment, it is far too early to judge the success of the Macy deal, one of the largest leveraged buyouts ever. In a leveraged buyout, a group of managers, supported by outside investors, borrows a great deal of money to buy the company; the loans are secured with the assets and future earnings of the company being bought. Ultimately, the managers hope to take the company public again at a far higher price. The financial community expects Macy to go public again as soon as it has paid down enough of its debt to start showing regular profits. According to forecasts made at the time of the buyout, that would be in the early 1990's. PROPONENTS of leveraged buyouts argue that they are healthy because they increase management's financial stake in the company's success or failure. But critics contend that is a breach of fiduciary responsibility for the company's management to, in effect, mortgage the company's assets so that they can buy the company. And in some cases, managers have taken a company private, done some fast financial shuffling and taken the company public again, netting tremendous gains without really strengthening the company. **********The Macy deal illustrates some of the advantages and disadvantages of the leveraged buyout approach. Many employees have responded to the buyout with increased enthusiasm and a spirit of cooperation. But some are already showing signs of restlessness. Investors must wait five to seven years for the deal to begin paying off, and there is no guarantee that Macy will perform well enough to generate rich rewards. During that time, there may be little chance for advancement, since managers who have invested heavily in the buyout are unlikely to leave. **********Leveraged buyouts are also supposed to free a company from Wall Street's constant demands for short-term results. But the enormous debt used to finance a leveraged buyoutn can be just as difficult to cope with. Walter K. Levy, who runs his own retail marketing consulting concern, says that in moving from a public to a private corporation, Macy ''substituted the pressure from Wall Street for pressure from its lenders.'' **********Mr. Finkelstein financed the deal by borrowing $3.5 billion from a group of banks led by Citibank, Manufacturers Hanover and Bankers Trust. He has now launched a cost-cutting campaign and a push for quick profits that have led some employees to begin referring to him as ''Crazy Eddie'' - a reference to the electronics discounter whose ads promote an image of frenzied selling activity. Some Macy executives believe that under the buyout the company may have changed for the worse, seeking quick profits at the expense of risk-taking in an industry where caution can be fatal. **********In implementing the buyout, Mr. Finkelstein sought to make it easy for employees to participate. Employees were allowed to cash in their Macy stock and invest the proceeds in the equity pool being assembled for the buyout. There were three classes of investors. Division heads contributed about $200,000 apiece, senior vice presidents about $75,000 to $80,000 and vice presidents and merchandise administrators about $18,000. Altogether, 345 executives contributed a total of $17.9 million, giving them a combined 20 percent share of the company. Mr. Finkelstein's stake alone is 4.7 percent. **********Along with Macy executives, the deal had some prominent backers, including Laurence A. Tisch, chairman of CBS Inc. and the Loews Corporation, who bought a 15 percent stake in the company, and Alfred Taubman, a leading shopping-center developer, who bought a 5 percent stake. **********During the transition, Finkelstein and Macy president Mark S. Handler met with groups of executives to explain his goals for the new company. After the meetings, a number of executives decided they would not function well in the new environment, and either resigned or declined to become investors. Most were executives in their mid-50's who said they were concerned that they would have to work longer and harder under the new structure. **********For those who invested in the buyout, the potential rewards looked rich indeed. Projections made at the time of the buyout called for Macy's sales to increase between 8.7 and 11 percent annually over the next eight years. (Over the past five years, sales have grown by an averaged of 13.5 percent annually). On that basis, Macy would register net losses annually until 1990, when it would have a $30 million profit; profits would increase from then on. If the forecasts turn out to be accurate, someone who contributed $70,000 to the equity pool would have stock worth about $3.5 million to $4 million at the end of a five- to seven-year period. A $17,500 investor could hope for as much as $1.5 million. **********The prospect of such handsome payoffs has apparently generated important attitude changes among most Macy senior executives. A spirit of cooperation, many say, has replaced one of internal competition. Harold Kahn, head of Macy's California division, for example, said that since the buyout he has made a practice of phoning the chief executives of other Macy divisions to discuss the success or failure of various product lines. **********To inject a little entrepreneurial spirit into the sales ranks, Macy recently began putting all of its salespeople on commission. (Traditionally, only salespeople in such big-ticket areas as home furnishings worked on commission.) Mr. Finkelstein hopes that the change will improve customer service, which has been a weak spot, as it is in many other large stores. **********The commission system paid an unexpected dividend: store managers now will devote their breaks to working the sales floor as a way of picking up extra cash. As a result, they have more direct contact with customers and get valuable feedback on their likes and dislikes. **********In the immediate aftermath of the buyout Macy executives seemed to withdraw into a bunker, curtailing contact with their own suppliers and other retailers as they plotted out their next moves. Mr. Finkelstein explained that he didn't want his employees to be distracted during this critical period. Macy began withholding monthly sales figures normally shared within the industry, because, Mr. Finkelstein said, he wanted his employees to concentrate on profit, not market share. EAGER to cut costs wherever possible, Macy reviewed every expense looking for potential savings. It cut back on advertising expenses and began consolidating support services such as finance and accounting. Even the traditional Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade, a centerpiece of the holiday celebration in New York since 1924, seemed to be in danger of cancellation. **********To begin paying down its debt, Macy sold its full or partial interests in eight shopping centers last month, netting $400 million. Macy retains partial interest in three shopping centers. At the same time, however, Macy has continued its policy of opening new stores, particularly in the Sunbelt, even though sales in the Sunbelt have been disappointing since the recent slump in energy prices. **********Caution has become a watchword, some within the company complain. Mr. Finkelstein had made Macy successful by constant innovation: He lured legions of young, affluent and fashion-consious customers with chic merchandise, abundant inventories and imaginative counter displays. Since the buyout, Macy has been taking fewer risks - selling only what it already knew would sell and cutting back on product lines to save inventory costs. And its advertising, which had pushed upscale goods at full price, began to emphasize discounts, in a throwback to a former bargain-basement image. ''For the first time, I see evidence that Macy is becoming more promotional,'' said Roger Barrer, co-president of Alexander's Inc., the New York discounter. ''When you see them practically offering two men's suits for the price of one, you know they are pushing hard for volume and cash flow.'' **********Macy, like many other retailers, is increasing its emphasis on private-label goods, such as its Christopher Hayes and Loft & Brownstone mens clothing lines. Made to Macy specifications, such goods offer a higher profit margin than brand-name items. Private-label goods now account for nearly 25 percent of total sales. Macy recently announced plans to offer its private label goods to other, noncompetitive retailers. **********While the moves are designed to make Macy profitable, not everyone has been happy under the new structure. Executive recruiters report an increase in inquiries from Macy executives, including some who invested in the buyout. ''The improved results are encouraging a lot of Macy people to believe that they are going to make it, pay off the debts and eventually cash in when the company once more goes public,'' said Herbert Mines, a former Macy senior vice president for human resources who now runs his own New York recruiting concern. ''But Macy insiders say that the drive to do that is causing management to focus on the short term rather than on the long term as it used to. A lot of people like it and are pitching in. But some don't and they want out.'' **********According to Mr. Mines, executives who have invested from the $18,000 to the $80,000 level are the most restless about the projected five- to seven-year wait for the deal to pay off. ''That means that in addition to the fact that there's always the possibility that this won't work out well, they are concerned about the lack of advancement implicit in the investment made by their superiors,'' Mr. Mines said. ''If the bosses are locked in, the underlings can't move up, can they?'' **********It seems fitting that Mr. Finkelstein, 61 years old, ended up as a principal owner of Macy. A 40-year veteran of the company, Mr. Finkelstein became chairman and chief executive in 1980. His success in transforming Macy's image from stodgy to trendy and its performance from erratic to solidly profitable gave Mr. Finkelstein the reputation as one of the nation's top retailing executives. Macy is now the nation's fourth-largest department store company; only May, Federated and Dayton Hudson are larger. **********Nonetheless, he was still just an employee. Mr. Finkelstein's buyout proposal offended Jack I. Straus, the former Macy chairman and descendant of Isidor and Nathan Straus, who had bought the business from the heirs of Rowland H. Macy in the late 19th century. Mr. Straus died in 1985, before the buyout was completed. Other members of the Straus clan were also unhappy that an executive who came up through the ranks wanted to lead a takeover of the company. But family opposition to the buyout never got beyond the grumbling stage, because they owned only 1.5 percent of Macy stock at the time the proposal was made. **********''When Jack was here, Macy's stock was selling for $10 a share, and Mr. Straus's holdings were worth only about $10 million,'' said Mr. Finkelstein. In 1986, en route to the buyout, he said, ''That stock went up to $50 a share, so that his holding rose to $50 million.'' **********''He really had nothing to complain about,'' says Mr. Finkelstein. Now, Mr. Finkelstein will have to hope that he can do as well for the new owners, including himself, as he did for the Straus family.  THE HIGH COST OF GOING PRIVATE  Macy's average annual net interest expense before and after leveraged buyout in July 1986  1981-85: $76 million  1987-91: $625 million

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/24/busin.body_text: **********There's hardly anything drabber and more basic than a battery. But now that another competitor has entered the rapidly expanding market, battery makers are emphasizing gold and copper - as well as rebates, coupons and some new technology - to try to insure that their brand goes into the watches, toys, radios and other electronic gear that have made batteries a big business. **********Until recently, the $2.5 billion domestic battery market was dominated by Duracell USA and the Eveready Battery Company, with a fistful of smaller players. Life was relatively peaceful - and profitable. **********Then the Eastman Kodak Company entered the picture last July, with batteries made by Matsushita, the Japanese electronics giant. **********''It has turned into quite a war,'' said Eugene G. Glazer, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds. ''The battle, however, is marketing, since there is no real clear superiority.'' **********To defend or increase market share, battery makers are using more advertising, more in-store promotions and more consumer discounts - all of which have cut into their bottom lines, according to analysts and industry officials. **********The manufacturers seem convinced that it is a market worth fighting for. With the profileration of electronic gadgets, sales of alkaline batteries are expected to grow about 10 percent a year in the next decade. Alkalines are the largest-selling, the longest-lasing and the highest-priced commercial batteries. The production cost of a C cell alkaline, the size used in many flashlights, is estimated to be less than 50 cents, but they sell at retail for up to $1.75. **********The sales growth and the high profit margins caused Kraft Inc. to keep its Duracell division last summer, despite the company's highly publicized back-to-basics restructuring in which it spun off all its other nonfood businesses. **********The business is attractive enough that the Ralston Purina Company was willing to pay $1.42 billion last June to acquire Eveready from the Union Carbide Corporation. A Strategic Fit **********Both Ralston and Kraft thought that batteries fit in nicely with their distribution channels for consumer packaged goods. Batteries also fit well with Kodak's film distribution in drugstores and grocery chains. **********To differentiate itself from Duracell and to a lesser degree from Eveready's Energizer alkaline brand, Kodak has gold-plated its contact tips, the part of the battery through which electricity passes to the device. **********Because gold does not tarnish, which would impede the passage of electricity, it is widely used by computer, aerospace and telecommunications makers. But battery experts are not convinced that gold tips are a benefit in consumer devices such as audio cassette players. **********''They probably don't use that much gold to make a difference and even if they did, the average consumer would not be able to tell the difference under normal conditions,'' Robert A. Powers said of Kodak's batteries. He is an industry liaison for Case Western University, and until last year was the director of technology for Eveready. ''To be really effective, you'd have to have gold tips inside the device, and most devices don't.'' Testing the Products **********It can be difficult to sort out the conflicting boasts of the manufacturers. Consumer Reports did its last test on consumer batteries in 1983, long before Kodak entered the scene and before Eveready and Duracell introduced their current generation of batteries. **********Each manufacturer cites independent tests showing that its brand is the longest lasting - under the right conditions. For example, Kodak outperformed Duracell in a test of C cells in flashlights. Duracell outlasted Kodak in a test involving a toy bird. **********''Unfortunately, the consumer remembers how long it lasted in the commercial, not in a test,'' said Ralph J. Brodd, formerly a battery researcher for the Amoco Corporation and now a manager of a lithium battery project at Gould Inc. **********Performance aside, Kodak has what it calls ''perceptual'' reasons for using gold. ''Gold is a precious metal that means high quality,'' said Martin H. Adams, the vice president and general manager of Ultra Technologies, as Kodak calls its battery division. ''It serves a marketing and product-enhancement purpose.'' **********Kodak has already captured about 5 percent of the market, at the expense of the small players and Duracell. That leaves Duracell and Eveready with about 45 percent each. Currency a Factor for Kodak **********Kodak does not disclose sales or earnings for the division. But analysts expect batteries to be a costly venture for Kodak, which is based in Rochester. One problem: the rising yen, which makes Matsushita's batteries more expensive for Kodak. Indeed, some analysts say Kodak will run into the same currency problem that recently forced the General Electric Company to break its ties with Matsushita, which produced color televisions for G.E.. **********''The yen has got to be hurting Kodak's bottom line,'' said Mr. Glazer of Dean Witter. **********Duracell, the maker of the ''copper top battery,'' which contains no copper except on the case, contends that its product has an advantage over Kodak's because of a design change made two years ago. That change, which Eveready also made, eliminated an interior wall, providing more room for the battery's active ingredient and extending the battery's life. As with many other things in the battery industry, it is a matter of contention as to which company came up with the improvement first. **********While technology gets attention, it is advertising that is clearly the most important batttery battleground. According to industry officials, battery makers spent $40 million on advertising just in the fourth quarter of 1986. Each year, the Christmas season, with its toys and gifts, makes the fourth quarter the biggest period for battery sales. **********While a price war does not appear imminent, cash rebates, coupons and bonus packs abound. Store aisles are crowded with battery displays. **********''Since Kodak entered, there have been so many displays everybody is tripping all over them,'' said the buying executive of a Chicago-based grocery chain, who asked not to be identified. Battery makers have been offering big discounts on the price retailers must pay for the displays, he said. The Effect on Profits **********The profit situation is mixed. Duracell, based in Bethel, Conn., is expected to report operating income for the last quarter of 1986 of about $54 million, down substantially from $82.6 million in 1985. Sales grew, to about $925 million, from $854 million in 1985. Duracell's earnings have been hurt by a third-quarter special charge of $26 million for closing South African operations, as well as other charges related to changes made at its plants. **********Duracell has also been suffering from discounted ''gray market'' sales in this country of batteries produced by its Belgian subsidiary that were intended for sale abroad. The problem was particularly acute before the dollar began dropping against European currencies. **********Eveready, on the other hand, expects a record year, but analysts say its promotion efforts will hurt its showing. Recently, Eveready added two free batteries to its four-pack of AA batteries and provided a free nine-volt battery with the purchase of another one. In 1985, the most recent year for which totals are available, Eveready reported operating income of $120 million on worldwide sales of $1 billion. **********So far, there is no sign that any of the battery makers are wavering in their competitive zeal. Kodak officials say the heavy advertising will continue for some time - industry officials are interpreting that to mean another year - or until it commands 15 percent of the market. Cooperative Tactic **********One tactic increasingly being used is cooperative marketing and promotional efforts with the makers of electronic devices. Eveready, for example, donated 80,000 battery-filled flashlights for the closing ceremonies of last year's July 4 festivities in New York. And until last year, Eveready played up the fact that Kodak had recommended Eveready batteries for Kodak cameras. **********Meanwhile, a new area of competition could open up as the battery makers work hard to perfect a lithium battery for widespread commercial use. Lithium batteries are now used in cameras and computers, but current technology does not allow them to be made in the common AA, C and D sizes. Compared with alkalines, lithium batteries deliver more power, have a longer shelf life and are less affected by temperature and moisture. **********''It offers some great possibilities,'' Ron B. Medinger, director of marketing for Eveready, said of lithium.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/23/world.main_headline: AQUINO DEMANDS MILITARY VICTORY OVER INSURGENTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/23/world.print_headline: AQUINO DEMANDS MILITARY VICTORY OVER INSURGENTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/23/world.body_text: **********President Corazon C. Aquino said today that her peace initiatives had failed and that the time had come for military victory over Communist insurgents and right-wing terrorists. **********Taking the strongest stand on military policy in her year-old presidency, she said, ''The answer to the terrorism of the left and the right is not social and economic reform but police and military action.'' **********Her statements, at a graduation ceremony for the Philippine Military Academy at Baguio, 130 miles north of Manila, appeared to mark an evolution of her approach from reconciliation to confrontation. 'I Want This Victory' **********''I told you when we were discussing the peace initiatives that when they fail, as we feared they would, and when it becomes necessary to take out the sword of war, that I want a string of honorable military victories,'' she told military commanders at an alumni association. ''I want this victory.'' **********She offered her ''solemn oath'' that the Communist insurgency and other threats would be defeated by the end of her term in five years. **********Speaking to troops from a grandstand where a bomb killed 4 people and wounded more than 30 last Wednesday, she said, ''As I came to power peacefully, so I had hoped to keep it.'' 'Insolent Rejections' Cited **********''God knows I have tried,'' she said. ''But my offers of peace and reconciliation have been met with the most bloody and insolent rejections by the left and the right. **********''It is clear that the forces of the extremes will not leave us in peace to achieve the recovery and progress we so badly need.'' **********It was at last year's graduation ceremony that she set forth her offer of reconciliation to rebels, backed by a warning of military action. **********In Washington in September she told Congress that she was offering an olive branch to her opponents but was prepared if necessary to take out ''the sword of war.'' **********The olive branch was exemplified by a cease-fire in December and peace talks with members of an 18-year-old Communist insurgency. Last month, the Communist side refused to extend the two-month truce, and sharp fighting has resumed. **********At the same time, peace talks with Moslem rebels and with a small tribal insurgency in the Cordillera Mountains are deadlocked. In the last week, 108 people were reported killed in more than 30 clashes, making for what the Philippine News Agency called the bloodiest week since the Communists returned to the battlefield. The clashes included two rebel ambushes in which 37 soldiers were killed, and shootings of policemen in Manila. **********The bomb explosion Wednesday occurred at a dress rehearsal for today's ceremony. It destroyed about half of the roof of a specially built grandstand. **********Military officials said they had detained one officer and three enlisted men for questioning. **********After first blaming the Communists, military officials said the explosion might have been the work of the same disgruntled soldiers who were behind the takeover of a television station in January. 'Death Holds No Fear for Us' **********Mrs. Aquino called the bombing an attempt on her life and drew applause when she said, ''To our enemies, let me say that nothing will intimidate this President.'' **********''Death holds no fear for us, neither for the commander in chief nor for the soldier in the line,'' she said. **********Making pointed references to unity as she addressed her divided armed forces, she said: ''One nation, one armed forces, acting with the energy and direction of a single hand, will smite the foe, on the left and on the right.'' **********She said this unified armed forces would ''permanently end all threats to freedom before my term as President is over.'' ''This is my solemn oath,'' she said.  Criticizes U.S. on Aid In her address to commanders, Mrs. Aquino also criticized what she said was slow delivery of American military aid and expressed irritation with American criticism of her counterinsurgency policies. **********''I have asked our military ally for the hardware to achieve these objectives, but they have given us advice instead,'' she said. **********This appeared to be a reference to criticism this week by Assistant Defense Secretary Richard L. Armitage, who said Mrs. Aquino's counterinsurgency policy suffered from wishful thinking and a lack of rigor.  [ In Washington, a Pentagon spokesman, Lieut. Col. Keith Schneider, said Mr. Armitage's remarks accurately reflected the Pentagon's position on the situation in the Philippines, but he would not comment further on Mrs. Aquino's remarks. ]  Security at the ceremony was especially tight because of Wednesday's bombing. **********Mrs. Aquino remarked that she had traveled ''to many parts of our country, and I have walked freely among our people, protected by little more than their affection.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/17/busin.body_text: **********Taxpayers are reacting with confusion, anxiety and frustration to the elaborate new W-4 wage withholding form being distributed to the nation's 100 million employees. **********The Tax Reform Act of 1986 requires American workers to fill out for employers a new W-4 so that the amount withheld from their weekly paycheck is adjusted to reflect the sweeping changes in the new tax law. Without the adjustment, some taxpayers will find too little is withheld, which could lead to penalties. Others will find the Government withholding too much of their pay. **********The new four-page W-4 package is twice as long as the old version. While much of the worksheet is fairly straightforward, some taxpayers may have difficulty estimating itemized deductions and other tax benefits for this year, and adjusting the figures to the new tax law. **********Q. Why is new W-4 form four pages long, instead of half a page, as in the past? **********A. The W-4 ''certificate'' that workers hand in to employers is still the same half-page length. It is the accompanying worksheet and instructions that have been expanded. Part of the reason is that the worksheet contains space for calculations that workers previously had to make on scratch paper. The Internal Revenue Service also felt that by making the form more comprehensive, taxpayers would be able to more accurately calculate the amount of withholding. **********Q. What is the deadline for filling out the forms? **********A. The official deadline is Oct. 1, but the I.R.S. and tax advisers recommend that individuals fill out the form as soon as possible. Q. Why the hurry?  A. Because workers may end up having too much or too little withheld from their weekly paycheck. If too little is withheld early in the year, they will have to request additional withholding later to compensate. That means living with smaller paychecks later in the year. If not enough tax is withheld during the year, the taxpayer may be subject to a penalty. **********Q. What happens if a taxpayer decides to avoid the hassle of filling out the worksheet and simply claims the same number of allowances as in the past? **********A. There is no hard and fast rule. After completing the worksheet, many people may well find that the proper amount of tax will be withheld if they claim the same number of withholding allowances as in the past. But many individuals, even those whose financial situation has not changed, will find otherwise. **********The reason is that the new law has made so many dramatic changes that affect the number of withholding allowances claimed. For one thing, the value of each withholding allowance - which is tied to the personal exemption - has been increased to $1,900 this year, from $1,080 last year. **********However, many of the tax benefits that allowed workers to claim extra withholding allowances on W-4's have been curtailed or eliminated. For example, many people who used to claim extra withholding allowances because they contributed to an Individual Retirement Account may not be able to claim them any longer because of new restrictions on I.R.A.'s. **********As a rule, the more withholding allowances claimed before, the more likely the withholding will be out of line now. **********Q. Can a worker claim as many allowances as desired? **********A. Workers can claim fewer withholding allowances than they are entitled to, but never more. The correct number can be found by filling out the worksheet. **********Q. Is there anything wrong with claiming too few withholding allowances, especially if a worker likes getting a big tax refund check each year. **********A. Most Americans do, in fact, get a refund, because they have more tax withheld than they owe. But electing to have much more money withheld than will ultimately be owed in taxes is a bad investment. The Government offers no rewards for being so diligent. ''Why would anyone want to give the Federal Government what is effectively an interest-free loan for one year by grossly overpaying?'' said Jack Salomon, a senior tax partner at the accounting firm of KMG Main Hurdman. **********Q. Should completed forms be sent to the I.R.S.? **********A. No. The completed form should be returned to employers. They will then adjust the amount withheld from paychecks based on the new number of withholding allowances. **********Q. Do workers give the employer the entire four-page form? **********A. No. They give the employer only the bottom portion of the first page, which is the ''Employee's Withholding Allowance Certificate.'' The rest of the four-page worksheet should be kept for the taxpayer's records. The employer does not need it. **********Q. After employers make the proper adjustments to paychecks, is a copy of the W-4 sent to the I.R.S.? **********A. The employer is required to furnish a copy to the I.R.S. only if a worker claims more than 10 withholding allowances. The I.R.S. reserves the right to review these forms and is believed to do so on a random basis. A $500 penalty can be imposed if a worker tries to claim excess withholding allowances without a reasonable basis for doing so. **********Q. Once the form is handed in, can changes be made later? **********A. Yes. The number of withholding allowances can be changed anytime, by turning in a new W-4 to employers. **********Q. If a taxpayer is married and has a working spouse, should each fill out a separate worksheet and hand in a separate certificate to employers? **********A. Working couples filing jointly should fill out only one worksheet to figure the total number of withholding allowances to claim. The exemptions can be split between the two spouses in any fashion. **********But the I.R.S. and private tax practitioners recommend that the higher-earning spouse claim all the allowances and the lower-earning spouse claim none. By so doing, the total amount withheld from both paychecks will be more in line with the tax ultimately owed. **********Although only one worksheet is used in figuring a couple's withholding allowance, each spouse is required to turn in his or her own separate withholding certificate to the respective employer. **********Q. Is filling out the form as difficult as it looks? **********A. Taxpayers with very simple financial situations - such as one-income families with little investment income and few deductions to claim - will only need to fill out five lines of the form. The most difficult part of the form is estimating the amount of deductions to be claimed this year, taking into account the new law changes. **********Q. Starting from the beginning of the worksheet (on pages 3 and 4), what are the some of the more difficult items? **********A. On page three, line B, the term ''Special Allowance'' may be confusing, since there is no comparable item on income tax returns. It is merely an adjustment devised by the I.R.S. that will prevent certain taxpayers from having too much tax withheld from their pay based on the general withholding formula. The instructions on page 2 specifies who should claim the special allowance. **********Q. How do workers know if they need to complete more than the first five lines of the worksheet? **********A. Following line ''E'' on page 3 are clear and specific criteria as to whether a worker ''must'' or ''should'' complete the rest of the worksheet. If the worker fits the ''should'' category and chooses not to fill out the rest of the worksheet, he or she might have too much withheld from paychecks. This category consists of people who expect to claim special tax benefits, including itemized deductions, I.R.A. deductions and the child-care tax credit. Q. How does a worker estimate **********''adjustments'' on line F so early in the year and in light of the new tax changes? **********A. As a rule, workers can ignore ''qualified reimbursed employee business expenses,'' since the deduction will typically be offset by the cash reimbursement from employers, said William A. Crump, a tax manager at the accounting firm of Laventhol & Horwath. Besides, few people will be able to predict these amounts with any accuracy. **********As for ''qualified alimony payments,'' anyone with a divorce decree will know about how much they will have to pay their ex-spouse this year and whether it is deductible. **********''Business and investment losses'' are extremely difficult to estimate, particularly in light of the many changes made by the new tax law in these areas. Fortunately, most people with these losses rely on professional tax help. For those with tax shelter losses who do not go to a tax preparer, only 65 percent of these losses can be used to offset wages or other income in 1987 under the new law. **********''The penalty on early withdrawal of savings'' is usually a small item that can generally be ignored, since few people are likely to know if they will incur one of these penalties. **********As for ''qualified contributions to an I.R.A. account or Keogh plan,'' workers should list the amount to be contributed that will qualify for a deduction. They should keep in mind the new restrictions on I.R.A. deductions. **********Q. How about itemized deductions? **********''Medical expenses'' are obviously hard to predict. Any estimate is deductible only to the extent it exceeds 7.5 percent of adjusted gross income. **********In computing ''state and local taxes,'' the figure on the 1986 return will help. To come up with a rough estimate. Mr. Crump recommends multiplying last year's state and local income tax liability by the percentage increase in wages this year. As a rule, taxpayers should keep real estate taxes even with last year. But they should not include sales taxes, since they are no longer deductible. **********In calculating interest deductions, taxpayers should bear in mind the new law's limits. Consumer interest, for example, is only 65 percent deductible in 1987. **********Mr. Crump said most people can probably ignore ''miscellaneous expenses,'' since most people do not have enough to qualify for a deduction anyway.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/10/world.main_headline: The Summit; Reporter's Notebook: Moscow on Madison Ave.
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/10/world.print_headline: The Summit; Reporter's Notebook: Moscow on Madison Ave.
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/10/world.body_text: **********As East meets West this week, it is often difficult to discern who is winning the game of political exploitation. **********For his part, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, has been having a rendezvous with public relations, and he has proved himself a virtuoso at both making history and turning it to his use. **********''He's taken over this town,'' said Robert S. Strauss, the Democratic Party leader, who had a long talk with the Soviet leader at the White House state dinner Tuesday night. ''He's working this country like it hasn't been worked before. It's a hell of a P.R. show.'' **********But many American politicians are doing their best to use the Soviet leader to their advantage as well. **********Perhaps the best example is the Vice President, who has been invited to breakfast with Mr. Gorbachev at the Soviet Embassy on Thursday, along with a few of his friends. **********Several of the guests George Bush has chosen to take along just happen to be from Iowa and New Hampshire, the first two major primary states. **********Besides Mr Bush and his wife, Barbara; Secretary of State George P. Shultz and his wife, Helena, and Mr. Bush's chief of staff, Craig Fuller, other guests at the breakfast for 10 include John H. Sununu, the Governor of New Hamphire and chairman of the Vice President's New Hampshire campaign; Cooper Evans, a former Republican Congressman from Iowa and a Bush supporter, and Robert Brooks, the principal of the Valley High School in West Des Moines. **********There were also published reports today that a camera crew from Mr. Bush's campaign would be joining the network crews, but the campaign refused to confirm or deny this report. **********''We feel like it is so blatantly political it defies description,'' said Kate Boyle, a press aide for Mr. Bush's major rival, Bob Dole. **********But Mr. Gorbachev is keeping track of all the possibilities for Ronald Reagan's successor, and so after a meeting with nine Congressional leaders at the embassy today, he pulled aside Mr. Dole - who has been ambivalent about the arms treaty -and talked with him privately for 10 minutes in an anteroom. As the Kansas Senator left, Mr. Gorbachev smiled and wished him good luck on his Presidential race. **********''Thank you,'' Mr. Dole replied. ''I'm winning.'' Jack Kemp's spokesman, John Buckley, said the New York Congressman was not feeling left out. ''This is the most skillful Soviet leader in many generations,'' Mr. Buckley said. ''He's skillful enough to know who will give up on the Strategic Defense Initiative and who he shouldn't waste his breath on.''  A Stern General Bends **********The stern facade of the security forces around Mr. Gorbachev cracked a little today in a heartwarming scene on the South Lawn of the White House. While the two world leaders were inside the White House palavering, Mr. Gorbachev's bodyguards and drivers were outside enjoying the uncommonly balmy Washington weather. **********Undaunted by the presence of a dozen armed men - and probably encouraged by the fact that President Reagan frequently feeds squirrels here with walnuts imported from Camp David - an American squirrel scampered up. A burly, gray-haired man in a black raincoat bent down to feed it some crumbs. **********The animal lover, who laughed and turned his back when a reporter asked for his name, was none other than Gen. Mikhail Tolkachayev, hero of the Battle of Stalingrad and now the head of Mr. Gorbachev's K.G.B. protective detail.  The Official's Two Lines **********On Day 3, some astringent commentary livened up the scene. **********Natan Sharansky, one of the founders of the Helsinki Watch Committee in Moscow, a human rights group, took issue with the comments of Gennadi I. Gerasimov, the Soviet press spokesman, that most of the Jews who wanted to leave the Soviet Union left in the 1970's. **********Mr. Sharansky, who served time in a Soviet prison on an espionage charge before he was released to the West, told a story intended to prove that the charming Mr. Gerasimov often offers the official Soviet line -whether or not he believes it. **********He said that Mr. Gerasimov and his wife had come to dinner at his parents' home in Russia years ago, just after Mr. Gerasimov had finished an American stint as a reporter for a Soviet journal, Literaturnaya Gazeta. **********''Mr. Gerasimov was saying at dinner how wonderful and what a great country the U.S. is, and how unhappy he was to come back to Moscow,'' Mr. Sharansky said. ''At the same time, the articles by Mr. Gerasimov were about how awful life in America was. **********''In order to stay and enjoy life in America, he had to publish articles about how awful it was. Today, to enjoy life as a Soviet official, he is ready to say all kinds of ridiculous things.''  Raisa Gorbachev, in Brief **********Will wonders never cease? The first official biography of Raisa Gorbachev - all five sentences of it -was released by the Soviet Information Center today. **********The biography was characteristically cryptic but was snapped up by Kremlinologists who have been kept in the dark on even the simplest facts about the Soviet First Lady. **********Although Mrs. Gorbachev recently answered a question posed to her in Russia recently about where she was born by saying merely ''in Russia,'' this profile reports for the first time that she comes from Siberia. She was born in the city of Rubtsovsk, and her father was a Russian railway worker. **********The profile confirms widespread reports that Mrs. Gorbachev holds the equivalent of an American master's degree in sociology, that she graduated from Moscow State University, which her husband attended, and that she has taught at Soviet institutes of higher education. **********It mentions her only official position, a member of the Presidium of the Board of the Soviet Cultural Foundation, and concludes with the brief note that ''she has an adult daughter.'' This daughter is not mentioned on the biography released at the same time for Mr. Gorbachev - not because the daughter is not his, but because Russians regard family as properly a matter for a female fact sheet. **********Sovietologists are still left to argue about her age - 53 or 55 - and about when she met and married her husband.  Caviar Without Vodka **********Since the Russians believe in teetotaling these days, at least officially, vodka was not on the menu for the reciprocal dinner at the Soviet Embassy tonight. But a Soviet diplomat broke the veil of secrecy about the dinner to confide, ''It would be considered a travesty if we didn't serve caviar.'' **********For weeks the embassy staff has been busy repainting and refurbishing the 1909 Beaux-Arts-style mansion five blocks from the White House. Dinner took place in the glittering grand ballroom amid the gold leaf pilasters, ornately carved moldings, magnificent chandeliers and damask-draped windows. **********Pamela Harriman, who will be entertaining Mrs. Gorbachev at her Georgetown home on Thursday, was there, along with Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, Howard H. Baker Jr., chief of staff to the President, and Armand Hammer, the industrialist and philanthropist who has both business and cultural interests in the Soviet Union. Mr. Hammer hit the summit jackpot - he is one of the rare Americans without ''official'' status who received invitations to both the White House and Soviet dinners. **********The entire block has been closed to pedestrians and cars all week, but Secretary of Defense Frank C. Carlucci said that posed no problem for him. ''One of the things about this job,'' he said, ''is that you get to ride with people who take care of those kind of things for you.''  The Schedule Today  All times are Eastern Standard.  9 A.M.: Mikhail S. Gorbachev meets privately with Vice President Bush.  9:15 A.M.: Mr. Gorbachev and Vice President Bush have breakfast with academicans, scientists and industrialists.  10:30 A.M.: Talks continue with President Reagan in the Oval Office.  Noon: Working luncheon at the White House.  2 P.M.: Departure ceremony at the White House.  3 P.M.: Mr. Gorbachev meets with U.S. business leaders at the Soviet Embassy.  5 P.M.: Mr. Gorbachev says farewell to Soviet Embassy officials.  5:30 P.M.: Mr. Gorbachev holds a news conference at the Soviet Embassy.  8 P.M.: Mr. Gorbachev leaves the U.S.  9 P.M.: President Reagan addresses the nation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/25/busin.main_headline: Why Sprinklers Stay on the Sidelines
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/25/busin.print_headline: WHAT'S NEW IN HOTEL SAFETY; Why Sprinklers Stay on the Sidelines
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/25/busin.body_text: **********IN A 1983 survey of its 8,200 members, the American Hotel and Motel Association found that, while more than 70 percent of respondents had smoke, fire or heat detectors in guest rooms, less than 10 percent had installed automatic sprinklers. The absence of sprinklers in guest rooms, fire protection experts said, is a glaring deficiency in hotel safety measures and could result in future fires and needless deaths. **********Since that survey, fire codes in a few cities and states have been tightened to require sprinklers in newly constructed hotels. But still fewer of the new laws require existing hotel owners to go to the considerable expense of ''retrofitting'' existing hotels with sprinkler systems. **********In the absence of such requirements, fire experts do not foresee significant sprinkler coverage for several more years. Installation of sprinkler systems is a costly investment that many in the lodging industry continue to avoid. And that, fire protection specialists warn, could be a serious and costly mistake. **********''Had there been sprinklers in the area where the fire started at the Dupont Plaza Hotel, it would never have gotten out of that room,'' said John A. Viniello, president of the Patterson, N.Y.-based National Fire Sprinkler Assocation, which sent an investigating team to San Juan. ''The fire would either have been extinguished by the sprinklers or slowed enough so that people could have escaped.'' Like numerous states, Puerto Rico does not require hotels to install sprinkler systems. But a sprinkler system installed during construction can cost between $1.25 and $1.50 a square foot, and retrofitting existing hotels with a system can cost even more - from $2 to $2.50 a square foot, according to Mr. Viniello. That's a huge disincentive to an owner of a hotel with hundreds of thousands of square feet to worry about protecting. **********To help defray the expense, some states, including New Jersey and Alaska, provide tax incentives. Moreover, a number of large hotel chains have decided to bear the cost themselves, either in response to changes in local fire codes or to foster a reputation as a safe place to stay. **********''We think it is good business,'' said Robert T. Souers, a spokesman for the Marriott Corporation, which began installing sprinkler systems in its 164 hotels five years ago and has completed 90 percent of the hotels. Though the cost is ''substantial,'' he said, ''it makes for a safer environment'' that guests increasingly demand. **********Similarly, the Hilton Hotel chain has directed managers of its 300 hotels to install sprinklers by the end of the year, according to Henry Moore, fire protection manager for the chain. He said the effort would cost ''millions.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/16/busin.main_headline: NEW YORK HOSPITAL'S NEW CHIEF: Dr. David B. Skinner; A Chicago Surgeon Takes a Tough Case in New York
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/16/busin.print_headline: NEW YORK HOSPITAL'S NEW CHIEF: Dr. David B. Skinner; A Chicago Surgeon Takes a Tough Case in New York
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/16/busin.body_text: **********THE new medical economics is rewriting the book on hospital management - and managers. **********Two years ago, when the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center began a search for an administrator rather than a doctor to succeed its retiring director, ''the medical staff had its own case of cardiac arrest,'' said one New York physician. **********As a result, it was the doctors, not the administrators, who first approached Dr. David B. Skinner, a leading Chicago surgeon, to replace Dr. David D. Thompson, who will retire as head of New York Hospital this fall, at the age of 65. **********The doctors' sensitivty is not surprising: Tensions are rising generally between administrators and staff doctors as the nation's hospitals undergo painful cost-cutting to survive the stricter Medicare and private-insurance reimbursement plans in effect these days. **********Dr. Skinner, chief of surgery at the University of Chicago Hospitals and Clinics, may have the support of the medical staff at New York Hospital when he takes over on Oct. 1. But he will still have plenty of problems. **********Running a big, private, nonprofit hospital is very similar to running a corporation - though it can be even more complicated. Like corporations, hospitals must carefully manage cash flow and raise long-term funds for major projects. But the facilities cannot always seek to maximize their returns - if they fail to provide services to the community, such as health care for the indigent, they can lose their tax-exempt status. **********Hospitals are also labor-intensive, and dealing with personnel is perhaps the most difficult task for an administrator. There are the doctors, who channel patients to the hospital. There are the nurses, who work in a context of a severe nationwide shortage. Then come the technicians - also hard to hold on to - and other skilled and non-skilled workers who are often unionized. **********An administrator must also deal with regulatory authorities, a task considered especially difficult in New York because of unusually tough regulations and standards. In the wake of a state moratorium on hospital expansion in 1983 and subsequent legal difficulties, for example, New York Hospital has been waiting years for permission from state authorities to rebuild its main hospital. **********And in an era of rapidly changing health-care economics, a director has to develop a long-term strategy. Such strategies have increasingly involved affiliations with other hospitals, but while these can produce economies of scale, designing a network of hospitals and getting them to work together harmoniously can be a sensitive and difficult undertaking. **********Dr. Skinner - whose strengths may lie more in medicine and administration than in diplomacy - will face most of these challenges at New York Hospital. **********For one thing, the new reimbursement system does not account for the expense of providing the specialized services offered by teaching hospitals: New York Hospital runs the nation's biggest burn-treatment center, operates one of the most sophisticated neo-natal care units, and is a leader in cardiovascular medicine. **********Other problems come with the post, too. For the past three years, a series of medical mishaps has been eroding the prestige of the venerable, 216-year-old institution - New York's City's oldest hospital and the largest private, nonprofit health facility in New York State. In a 1984 case, a grand jury ruled that ''woefully'' inadequate care and repeated medical mistakes led to the hospital death of 18-year-old Libby Zion, admitted with a high fever. In 1985, the facility had to adopt written policies regarding lifesaving measures following the death of an 87-year-old woman who, the family claimed, was not terminally ill. Last February, the New York State Health Department charged that inadequate care was given to artist Andy Warhol, who died at the hospital after routine gall bladder surgery. Two months ago, a power failure that blacked out 20 percent of the huge Manhattan complex led to the death of a critically ill infant on a respirator. **********Dr. Skinner describes the headline-grabbing events as ''troubling.'' But he says such developments are not unique to New York Hospital and that the problems are being resolved. His main concerns, he says, are much bigger - nothing less than the evolution of the nation's health-care system. The lure of running New York Hospital was too much to resist, Dr. Skinner says, because what happens at this huge and prestigious hospital has a bearing on the rapidly changing health-care system. **********''I was successful in building a strong surgery department that is recognized nationally and internationally,'' he said. But at New York Hospital, ''I can do more for modern medicine.'' **********NOT exactly modest talk. But Dr. Skinner, an imposing figure with a strong and confident voice, is not one for false modesty. **********Asked for some biographical material during an interview in his office at the University of Chicago Hospitals, the 52-year-old native of Joliet, Ill., supplied a 42-page, single-spaced sheaf of facts. **********Among the credentials listed: a B.A. earned ''with high distinction'' from the University of Rochester, a ''cum laude'' medical degree from Yale, a series of surgical appointments at such top-notch institutions as Massachusetts General, Johns Hopkins and Bethesda Naval Medical Center, 13 honors and awards; memberships in 31 societies and on 12 boards; a dozen journal editorships; service on a dozen advisory panels. And that is just through page 6. **********As head of surgery at University of Chicago Hospitals since 1972, Dr. Skinner, a thoracic surgeon, has been deeply involved in administration, said Dr. Harry W. Schoenberg, a surgeon who is president of the hospital's medical staff. ''Because of the strength of his personality, he has the self-confidence that allows him to see all sides of a problem, not just his own perspective,'' he said. **********His reputation for building a great surgery department stems mainly from his ability to attract top talent. ''He brought in a lot of people who have made important contributions,'' said Dr. Schoenberg. **********Dr. Skinner's almost total absorption in medicine extends into his family life, too. When his oldest daughter, Linda, graduated from Johns Hopkins School of Medicine - two of his four daughters are becoming doctors - he wrote her a letter in which he outlined his views on the health-care system. Later he used the letter as the basis for a speech before the Chicago Surgical Society. Such a strong drive and personality may be what is needed at New York Hospital these days. But the assurance that Dr. Skinner projects has also resulted in a reputation for being autocratic and a bit arrogant. **********Some in Chicago say these traits were responsible for a breakdown in negotiations last year of a merger between the University of Chicago Hospitals and Michael Reese Hospital, another large and respected Chicago facility. **********Doctors say the talks were terminated after a memo written by Dr. Skinner leaked out to the medical community. The memo reportedly urged that the deal be closed so that the merged hospital could get rid of the ''butchers'' at Michael Reese. **********Dr. Skinner denies that he ever wrote that, but the rumors persist in Chicago's medical community. **********Always a tough bargainer, Dr. Skinner refused to accept the job at New York Hospital until the facility gave in to his demands for full administrative authority. As a result, he will hold the new post of president and chief executive officer. Dr. Thompson holds the title of director. **********The difference in titles is significant, says Robert Hatfield, chairman of the hospital's board of governors and retired chairman of Continental Can. Under Dr. Thompson, the board had considerable say in the hospital's affairs, he said. In creating the position of president and chief executive, the board has ''put all authority in Dr. Skinner's hands,'' he added. **********Dr. Skinner is already considering some new strategies at New York Hospital - including the acquisition of smaller, lower-cost hospitals in the region. These would handle the more routine - and less expensive - work, and channel the more difficult cases to New York Hospital, explains Dr. Skinner. Profits produced by the smaller units would then be used to subsidize New York Hospital. **********Despite its big endowments and its reputation for top-quality financial management, the hospital could use the financial boost in an era when it is cutting costs: The facility plans to cut the number of its beds by more than 6 percent, to 1,026 from 1,096. **********Another project Dr. Skinner is considering could also bring in revenues - setting up a hospital-affiliated H.M.O-like group practice in which patients pay set annual fees. **********Dr. Skinner does not favor all types of H.M.O.'s, especially those owned by doctors themselves. In such groups, he says, if profits are the result of efficiency, ''that's fine.'' But he fears that the quest for profits might mean that ''patients may not be satisfactorily cared for.'' **********Patient care is also his priority, he says, when it comes to running a teaching hospital. New York Hospital works intimiatley with Cornell Medical College, but Dr. Skinner says the two are distinct and that his responsibility is the hospital. ''A university puts research and teaching first,'' he said. ''The hospital has a clear mission to put the patient first.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/24/world.main_headline: Russians Say Estonian Could Seek a Pardon
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/24/world.print_headline: Russians Say Estonian Could Seek a Pardon
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/24/world.body_text: **********The Soviet Union said today that Karl Linnas, who was deported here from the United States on Monday, could appeal for pardon from the death sentence for war crimes that was passed by a Soviet court in his absence. **********Boris Pyadyshev, a Foreign Ministry spokesman, said at a briefing that such an appeal could be submitted to the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet, the equivalent of a collective national presidency, which is headed by Andrei A. Gromyko. **********The spokesman repeated an earlier declaration that no statute of limitations applied to the crimes of which the 67 year-old land surveyor from Greenlawn, L.I., was convicted in 1962. **********A Soviet court convicted Mr. Linnas of having directed mass killings of Jews and others while he was commander of a concentration camp at Tartu, in Estonia. **********Mr. Linnas was stripped of American citizenship during his eight-year legal struggle against deportation. **********The spokesman's remarks on whether Mr. Linnas faced retrial were ambiguous. He said a court would resolve the question of execution of sentence and examine ''additional circumstances of his criminal activities'' that may have come to light since his trial. **********Much of the opposition to Mr. Linnas's deportation in the United States was based on the charge that most of the evidence at his trial in absentia was supplied by Communist-ruled countries.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/09/world.main_headline: U.S. SAYS SOUTH AFRICA REBELS ARE OBLIGATED TO COMMUNISTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/09/world.print_headline: U.S. SAYS SOUTH AFRICA REBELS ARE OBLIGATED TO COMMUNISTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/09/world.body_text: **********The State Department said in a confidential report delivered to Congress today that the African National Congress was deeply obligated to Moscow and the South African Communist Party for military assistance in waging guerrilla warfare against the Pretoria Government. **********But the report is ambiguous on whether Communism or black nationalism is the predominant ideology in anti-apartheid politics and particularly in groups such as the African National Congress, the principal guerrilla organization seeking to topple South Africa's white-run Government. The group is marking its 75th birthday today. **********The 11-page study by the department, entitled ''Communist Influence in South Africa,'' was prepared in response to a request from Congressional conservatives angered over the enactment last year of economic sanctions against South Africa. **********Such requests often become part of legislation, and the department similarly was obliged to provide a report demanded by Congressional liberals as to the extent of malnutrition in the so-called black homelands within South Africa. Widespread Hunger Found **********That report found widespread hunger in the homelands and an infant mortality rate sharply above that for whites in South Africa as well as higher for blacks living in urban areas such as Soweto, which adjoins Johannesburg. **********The homelands are supposedly autonomous black entities created by the South African Government in rural areas within South Africa's boundaries, but they are not recognized as independent by any government other than Pretoria. The State Department study relied largely on previously published data because United States policy forbids contact with the homeland authorities. **********The question of how much influence Moscow has in the African National Congress and other such groups has become a leading issue in the debate as the Administration struggles to reshape its southern African policy, with a new emphasis on contacts with black opposition groups in South Africa. **********The State Department report comes a few weeks before Secretary of State George P. Shultz is scheduled to confer in Washington with Oliver Tambo, the head of the rebel group. Mr. Shultz is currently traveling in West Africa, where America's policies toward South Africa is a principal item in his discussions with African leaders. Speech in Washington **********Mr. Tambo is scheduled to deliver an address in Washington on Jan. 28 and meet with some Congressional leaders. He is expected to confer with Mr. Shultz at the same time. **********The report portrays the South African Communist Party as having aligned itself with the popular rebel movement principally for opportunistic reasons. **********''The South African Communist Party, banned since 1950, lacks a mass following but has exercised considerable influence through its alliance with the African National Congress,'' according to the study. ''The S.A.C.P. continues to view its historical alliance with the A.N.C. as its main hope for winning power in South Africa.'' **********The study says the South African Communist Party has persuaded Moscow that an alliance with the African National Congress is the best hope for achieving influence in South Africa. ''Moscow has long shared the S.A.C.P.'s assessment of the A.N.C. as the major potential catalyst for political change and it hopes to steer the A.N.C. in directions favorable to Soviet interest,'' it says. 'Deeply Beholden to Soviet' **********The department report said, ''The A.N.C. is deeply beholden to the S.A.C.P. and the Soviet Union for the arms and training that made possible the upsurge in guerrilla activity that has boosted its prestige in South Africa in recent years. **********''Dependence on Moscow for military assistance will continue to entrench Party influence in the A.N.C. and its strong representation in the A.N.C. hierarchy.'' **********The report also says there is considerable cross-membership between the rebel organization and the South African Communist Party. Noting that the African National Congress's governing council consists of 30 people, the report says, ''Roughly half the 30 members are known or suspected S.A.C.P. members.'' **********The department's report also says, however, that the Communist Party has almost no influence in the black labor movement in South Africa, one of the leading engines of reform in the black political equation. **********In a speech last month, Mr. Shultz said the Reagan Administration was deeply concerned about the rebel group's ''Communist connections and links to Moscow.'' **********He said the current series of American Government contacts with the African National Congress did not signal approbation of such groups, but recognition that they have an important role to play. Leaders of the rebel groups in recent months have met with high-level officials in the State Department. Before that, no American official higher than an embassy political officer had conferred officially with anyone from the rebel group.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/08/busin.main_headline: Heileman Chairman Likely to Fight Bid
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/08/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Heileman Chairman Likely to Fight Bid
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/08/busin.body_text: **********Russell G. Cleary, the chairman and chief executive of the G. Heileman Brewing Company, made his reputation in the beer industry as an acquirer of breweries. Now the expansion-minded Heileman is itself the target of a big Australian brewer. **********Mr. Cleary, 53 years old, has had no comment on last week's offer by Bond Corporation Holdings of Perth to purchase Heileman for $38 a share, or $1.2 billion. Heileman's stock jumped to well over that price, however, indicating Wall Street thinks Bond will have to raise its bid. **********And Mr. Cleary, who has a reputation as a tough maverick in the industry, would not be expected to yield his company without a protracted battle. **********''At $38, frankly, he would be crazy to accept the bid,'' said an industry analyst, George S. Dahlman of Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood Inc., in Minneapolis. A price of $45 a share would be more like it, he said. **********Mr. Cleary is a personable yet aggressive marketer, Mr. Dahlman said, adding that Heileman might be a bit thin in management because Mr. Cleary did most things himself. **********The letter to Mr. Cleary from Alan Bond, the chairman of the Australian bidder, assured him that management would stay in place and asked him to check with Pittsburgh Brewing, a recent Bond acquisition, to find how well things might go under Bond. **********Mr. Cleary built Heileman from the 15th-largest brewer to fourth place after Anheuser-Busch, Philip Morris's Miller and Stroh Brewery, largely by developing aggressive regional brands, such as Old Style, Black Label and Lone Star. The company would have been bigger yet had Mr. Cleary been successful in his attempts to acquire the Pabst Brewing Company and Schlitz, moves that were blocked by antitrust objections. **********Mr. Cleary entered the beer business after marrying the daughter of Heileman's chairman, Roy E. Kumm. That was back when Mr. Cleary was a law student at the University of Wisconsin. When he graduated, he practiced law and went into real estate in La Crosse, Wis., his hometown and the headquarters of Heileman. In 1960, Mr. Kumm asked him to join Heileman, and when Mr. Kumm died unexpectedly in 1971, Mr. Cleary took over the business leadership at the age of 36. **********Heileman became a potential takeover target, analysts say, when its acquisition strategy recently began to falter, with its market share falling and profits shrinking. Bond, its suitor, is one of Australia's leading brewers and has interests in broadcasting, energy and property. Mr. Bond, its chairman, sponsored an Australian yacht that won the America's Cup.
