https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/11/busin.body_text: **********The Bear Stearns Companies has filed suit in Federal District Court in Manhattan against the brokerage house of Jardine Strategic Holdings Inc. of Hong Kong for withdrawing from an agreement to acquire a stake in the company. **********Jardine pulled out of the deal to buy a 20 percent stake in Bear Stearns, the parent of the Bear, Stearns & Company brokerage, after the stock market plunged in October. **********The two companies had completed an agreement on Sept. 30 for the purchase at $23 a share. **********Jardine pulled out of the deal on Oct. 23, after the share price on the open market had dropped to $12.50. Shares of Bear Stearns closed yesterday at $9.875, down 25 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange. **********The suit will seek more than $200 million in damages, people with knowledge of the suit said. Several shareholders of Bear **********Stearns have also filed suits against Jardine. Jardine Strategic is a unit of **********Jardine Matheson Holdings Ltd., a British-run company founded in 1832.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/05/world.body_text: **********The Soviet Union opened its chemical warfare center here to foreign disarmament negotiators this weekend in an effort to convince the West it wants to destroy chemical weapons. **********Diplomats and experts from 45 countries, including the United States, were shown what Soviet military officers said was the entire range of chemical-weapon delivery systems and a process for destroying toxic agents in the field. **********''We decided to display this equipment to help create the right atmosphere at the Geneva disarmament talks for a convention banning chemical weaponry,'' said Gen. Vladimir Pikalov, commander of Soviet Chemical Forces. **********Talking to foreign reporters at the site, on the Volga about 550 miles southeast of Moscow, he said the Russians wanted to put an end to talk about a sinister secret base at Shikhany.  'Confidence-Building Measure' **********The American representative at the 40-nation Geneva Disarmament Conference, Max L. Friedersdorf, told reporters today that he believed the Soviet military had put on a complete display of its chemical weapons during the two-day visit. **********''This has been very important as an East-West confidence-building measure, but we still don't know what the Soviet stockpiles are,'' he said. **********Over the weekend, Western diplomats sought to convince General Pikalov and other senior Soviet officers that Moscow would have to reveal the extent of its stockpiles before an agreement could be completed in Geneva. **********Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, announced in April that the Soviet Union was halting production of chemical weapons, including toxic gases and other agents of the type used in World War I.  U.S. Binary Weapons Planned **********The United States says it stopped making chemical weapons in 1969. But in December it is to begin producing binary weapons, a new generation of devices in which toxic effects result only when two chemical agents in a warhead are mixed. **********The United States says it will produce binary weapons because the Soviet Union built up a huge stock of chemical arms in the 1970's and early 1980's. That stockpile has been estimated in the West at between 200,000 and 500,000 tons. **********Officials have declined to make public the level of American stockpiles of chemical weapons. However, diplomats from other Western countries say Washington has provided Moscow with a clear indication of the size of its stockpiles and where they are.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/02/world.main_headline: INDIANS TO SEND CONVOY TO SRI LANKA
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/02/world.print_headline: INDIANS TO SEND CONVOY TO SRI LANKA
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/02/world.body_text: **********India announced today that it would send a convoy of unarmed ships to northern Sri Lanka on Wednesday to provide ''humanitarian assistance'' to ethnic Tamils besieged by a weeklong offensive by Government forces. **********The unexpected announcement marked the first overt attempt by India to undercut Sri Lankan sovereignty and intervene directly in Colombo's four-year-old battle against Tamil guerrillas seeking an independent nation in the north and east. **********Not since 1971, when India invaded what was then East Pakistan and helped it become the nation of Bangladesh, has New Delhi intervened directly in a neighboring country's domestic affairs. **********It was unclear if Sri Lanka would try to stop the Indian flotilla, an action that might risk a confrontation in the Palk Strait, where there have been minor clashes involving fishing boats and coast guard ships of both countries in the past. The strait separates the island nation and India. Officials met here late tonight to discuss the handling of the situation. Certain to Cause Concern **********Indian officials emphasized that the current move was stricly nonmilitary and that it continued to support the territorial unity of Sri Lanka. But the action was certain to cause concern in Pakistan and other countries distrustful of Indian motives. **********Indian officials said Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi had decided to act because of anger that the President of Sri Lanka, J. R. Jayewardene, had ignored his appeals to stop the military offensive and allow India to resume its mediation of the war. **********In a statement, India cited Sri Lanka's claim that its ''all-out military assault'' was ''a fight to the finish'' and that it had subjected civilians to ''sustained strafing and bombing'' and tried ''to keep this tragic story from the world.'' The statement said India was inviting reporters to accompany its mission so they could verify reports of ''large-scale civilian deaths.'' **********An Indian official said tonight that a convoy of 20 ships would go to the northern Jaffna Peninsula on Wednesday, a distance of about 30 miles, and that the Indian Red Cross would distribute food and medicine. It said that the convoy would be unarmed and accompanied by no armed vessels, and that the mission would not be postponed or negotiated with Colombo. **********The Government here reacted with surprise and caution, saying the move was unnecessary and uncalled for. But officials said that if New Delhi wanted to send assistance, it should do so only after consulting with Sri Lanka. Parliament to Meet **********Meanwhile, an emergency meeting of Parliament was called here for Tuesday, where it was considered certain that India's move would be widely condemned as a violation of Sri Lankan sovereignty. **********New Delhi's announcement, conveyed to Sri Lanka at noon today, came as Colombo asserted that its 3,500 troops had finished the task of controlling a small, 20-square-mile section of the peninsula used as a supply center and staging area by the insurgents. **********The Government also said that all shelling and aerial bombardments by Sri Lankan forces had stopped and that a curfew imposed in the peninsula would be eased starting today. **********There were also reports that a fuel embargo imposed since January throughout the peninsula would be eased. **********Indian officials said this appeared to be a response to New Delhi's action. They pointed out that Sri Lankan officials have suggested that the current offensive was actually a prelude to a broader effort to eliminate guerrillas, believed to number from 1,200 to 2,000, from the whole peninsula. Divergent Claims in Fighting **********New Delhi says d that hundreds and perhaps thousands of civilians have died in the last week, essentially supporting the claims of Tamil spokesmen in the area and in southern India, which the Tamil groups use as a political base and sanctuary. **********But Sri Lanka asserted today that fewer than 50 civilians had died, and that most of the roughly 200 dead were soldiers and guerrillas. **********It has been impossible to verify the divergent claims, but some Western diplomats said here this week that they believed the Tamil and Indian claims were exaggerated.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/10/world.main_headline: BRITISH CITE 'OPEN DOORS' ON THE FERRY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/10/world.print_headline: BRITISH CITE 'OPEN DOORS' ON THE FERRY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/10/world.body_text: **********The British Government today cited an ''inrush of water through the open bow doors'' as the probable cause of the capsizing Friday night of the North Sea ferry in which 134 people were killed. **********A total of 409 people survived, clambering for their lives through the darkness and icy waters within the ferry, the Herald of Free Enterprise, after it rolled over soon after beginning a passage from Zeebrugge, Belgium, to Dover, England. **********As the Transportation Ministry reported to Parliament on its initial findings in the ferry disaster and began a formal inquiry to be led by an Admiralty Judge, Sir Barry Sheen, the Government advised ferry companies to install warning lights on the bridges of their boats so the captain can tell when the vehicle-loading doors are open. **********Reuters reported, however, that the technical director of Schichau Unterweser, which built the Herald and two sister ships in the Townsend Thoresen line, said today that the stricken vessel was equipped with the warning system specified by today's advisory. Townsend Thoresen officials said furthermore that crewmen responsible for closing the doors would report by telephone if they had problems. Regulations Re-Emphasized **********Survivors reported that crewmen were frantically working with sledgehammers to guide the hydraulic doors shut as the Herald headed into heavier seas beyond the inner harbor of Zeebrugge. She rolled onto her port side less than a mile offshore, tumbling passengers, autos and trucks as the ocean rushed in. **********Officials of the ferry company have said it was a common practice to leave open the bow doors, which normally are nine feet above the water line, long enough to ventilate exhaust fumes from the boat's cavernous vehicle decks. **********Mr. Moore, however, told the House of Commons that the Government was re-emphasizing current requirements that all openings in a ferry's superstructure and hull be closed by the crew ''before they proceed to sea.'' **********He said the initial inquiry found no structural flaws in the ferry, but he did not comment on theories that the boat capsized because of a combination of slipshod procedures involving the open doors and an improper distribution of ballast that lowered the bow and put the doorway dangerously close to the waterline. **********The Belgian Government has already begun an inquiry that includes the option to make recommendations on whether criminal charges should be brought in the accident. Captain Still in Shock **********The captain of the boat, identified as David Lewry, remained in shock with a collapsed lung and was unable to answer questions about the capsizing, company officials said. **********The opposition Labor Party rose in Commons to stress that the inquiry must focus on whether commercial pressures in the busy ferry industry between Britain and the Continent compromised safety by emphasizing rapid turnaround measures. Truck drivers who are veterans of the ferry run said it was not unusual to see a boat's doors still open as it headed across the inner harbor toward the open sea. **********The Herald is of the rapid-loading ''roll on, roll off'' design that minimizes interior bulkheads; her interior resembles a hangar. Some critics have said this design was a contributing factor in the disaster. Others have asserted that the large tractor-trailer rigs on the boat were not sufficiently tied down and thus aggravated the deadly imbalance, crashing to port as the boat began to list. **********''I share the grief and anguish of those who are bereaved,'' Mr. Moore said. Identifications Continue **********Family members journeyed to a gymnasium morgue in Zeebrugge to identify the 53 bodies recovered thus far. The bodies of another 81 victims are presumed trapped within the boat, which rests in 30 feet of water, her port half fully submerged. **********There has been growing criticism that it may take weeks to recover the bodies because of the nature of the salvage operation, a technique of attaching cables to the hull, hauling it upright and pumping out water to keep it afloat. **********Company officials stressed that their first priority was recovering the bodies and not keeping the boat in one piece for future service. Other methods, such as cutting open the hull, would be less efficient in terms of retrieving the bodies, they said. **********The British tabloids were busily buying up survivors' tales, hailing reputed heroes and heroines and focusing on small children orphaned by the disaster. An earlier tabloid report that one crewman had hysterically confessed to causing the disaster was denied.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/20/busin.main_headline: Move to Head Clinique Logical for Editor of Elle
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/20/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Move to Head Clinique Logical for Editor of Elle
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/20/busin.body_text: **********Karen Anderegg, the newly named president of Clinique Labs Inc., the cosmetics company, sees her current job as editor in chief of Elle magazine as a logical launching pad for her new post. **********Ms. Anderegg has followed the cosmetics industry for a variety of magazines since 1963, and she noted yesterday that one need not be a chemist to run a cosmetics company. The scientific intricacies can be learned, she said, and she intends to start studying. **********But it is the less technical skills, such as creating an image for a product line and communicating that image to the consumer, that she describes as her particular strength. **********Clinique ''relates to the Clinique customer the way I relate to the Elle reader, with tremendous respect, a strong credibility, a strong rapport, an emphasis on information,'' she said. **********This is not the first time that Leonard Lauder, the president of Estee Lauder, has turned to a fashion journalist to head Clinique. The company's only other president, Carol Phillips, was a 20-year veteran of Vogue when she was recruited by Mr. Lauder to found Clinique 19 years ago. **********Annual sales of that cosmetics line, which is sold only in department stores by clerks in white laboratory coats, are estimated to be about $500 million at retail in the United States, making Clinique the best-selling makeup and skin-care label on the department store floor. **********''Journalists are accustomed to turning out a new product on a regular basis, a new product that is fresh yet addresses their traditional audience,'' Mr. Lauder said. He pointed out that Jeanette Wagner, president of Estee Lauder International, had formerly been with Cosmopolitan. **********Ms. Phillips will remain with Clinique, with the title of chairman, though her exact responsibilities are not yet defined. John Evans, the president of Murdoch Magazines, Elle's parent company, said a successor to Ms. Anderegg would be named within a week. **********Ms. Anderegg, 46, grew up in Council Bluffs, Iowa, and graduated from Stanford University in 1963. She was a copywriter at Vogue for nearly a decade, where she worked with Ms. Phillips. She then joined Madamoiselle, where she became managing editor. In 1980, she returned to Vogue as associate editor, then joined Elle in 1985, just months after the magazine was founded.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/17/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: A NATIONWIDE program designed to stimulate inventiveness in American school-age children will start on Feb. 5 with a three-day conference here for 600 teachers. Sponsored by the United States Patent Model Foundation, the program, ''Invent America!,'' is expected to involve 85,000 elementary schools throughout the country. **********The foundation, which was organized in 1984, was chartered to recover 100,000 19th-century patent models for the Smithsonian Institution and to stimulate American inventiveness, largely through education. Support has been received from the White House and various Government agencies, including the Patent and Trademark Office. **********Financing is being provided by Mastercard International Inc. of New York for the teachers' conference and for more than $100,000 in awards to be given schools, teachers and students.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/27/world.print_headline: THE WHITE HOUSE CRISIS  Retracing the Steps Leading to Six Arms Sales: Charts From the Report; Transaction Six: October 1986 Sale of 500 U.S. TOW Missiles and Various Hawk Missle System Spare Parts
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/27/world.body_text: **********STEP 1: Iranian representatives (the Second Channel) deposit $7 million into Lake Resources account on September 26  [ 1 ]  to cover purchase of 500 TOW's and additional HAWK spares. STEP 2: Lake Resources transfers $2.037 to the C.I.A. Swiss account. Because of a communications failure between North and Secord, the deposit is made to a closed account. STEP 3: Because the funds are not immediately available for the Defense Department, North asks Israel to deliver 500 TOW's from its own inventory. STEP 4: 500 Israeli TOW's delivered to Iran on Oct. 30 and 31. STEP 5: 500 TOW's released to C.I.A. and transported to Kelly Air Force Base 3. STEP 6: TOW's shipped to Ramstein, West Germany, Nov. 6. STEP 7: C.I.A. proprietary airline delivers TOW's to Israel Nov. 7 as replacements.  Note: The difference between the amount provided by Iran and that paid to C.I.A. (Defense Department was still unpaid for this last shipment as of January 20, 1987) leaves almost $5 million unaccounted for. This brings the total amount available for diversion between February and October 1986 to approximately $19.8 million, less actual costs incurred in support of the operation.  [ 1 ] There is some discrepency surrounding these dates. The Sept. 26, 1986, date is contained in a note from North to Poindexter which also contains the $7 million figure. The C.I.A. report, relying on George Cave, states that the relative brought a check for $4 million with him to the late-October meetings in Frankfurt. Confronted with this inconsistency, the Board has chosen to rely on the contemporaneous account of Lieut. Col. North.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/19/world.main_headline: Fanfani Is Sworn In as Head of Italy's 46th Postwar Cabinet
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/19/world.print_headline: Fanfani Is Sworn In as Head of Italy's 46th Postwar Cabinet
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/19/world.body_text: **********Amintore Fanfani was sworn in today as Prime Minister of a minority Italian Government that is expected to lose a vote of confidence in Parliament in the coming week, paving the way for elections June 14. **********President Francesco Cossiga swore in the Christian Democrat, 79 years old, to lead Italy's 46th postwar Cabinet against the bitter protests of several political leaders, in order to break a deadlock that has hampered Government action for more than a month and that led to the resignation April 9 of Bettino Craxi, a Socialist, from the Prime Minister's job. **********The major task of the new Government, in addition to administering affairs before the elections, will be to play host to the Venice meeting of seven major industrialized nations in June. **********Preparations for the summit meeting are in the hands of the Foreign Minister, Giulio Andreotti, who retained his post in Mr. Fanfani's Cabinet. Visit by Reagan **********President Reagan is also scheduled to pay an official visit to Italy before the Venice meeting at the invitation of Mr. Cossiga. Although some Italian leaders have thought the visit should be postponed, to avoid the semblance of interference in the vote, the White House is understood to desire that the visit go ahead. Mr. Reagan is also scheduled to see Pope John Paul II. **********Mr. Cossiga had been widely expected to ask Mr. Fanfani to form for the first time what is described here as an ''institutional government,'' meaning that it consists of ministers from only one party, in addition to several senior civil servants, with the sole purpose of preparing the vote, which will take place about a year earlier than the next regularly scheduled parliamentary election. **********The choice fell to Mr. Fanfani, officials close to the President's office said, because he occupies, as incumbent President of the Senate, or upper house of Parliament, the second highest position by protocal within the republic and is broadly viewed as a neutral figure. **********It is the sixth time Mr. Fanfani, a law professor, has led an Italian Government. **********None of the other parties in the former five-party Cabinet headed by Mr. Craxi, which also included Socialists, Republicans, Liberals and Social Democrats, agreed to send ministers. **********The Government's crisis was largely a result of political infighting between Mr. Craxi's Socialists and the Christian Democrats, the largest party in the former Cabinet with roughly 60 percent of its parliamentary support. **********The Christian Democrats insisted that the other four parties abide by an accord reached last summer to hand the office of Prime Minister to someone of their party this year, but the Socialists pressed for early elections, hoping to parlay Mr. Craxi's achievements and popularity as Prime Minister into electoral gains.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/28/busin.main_headline: India Hints At Talks on Bhopal Suit
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/28/busin.print_headline: India Hints At Talks on Bhopal Suit
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/28/busin.body_text: **********The Government of India, apparently willing to resume negotiations, declared today that it was ready for a ''just and fair'' settlement with the Union Carbide Corporation over compensation for victims of the 1984 gas-leak tragedy at Bhopal. **********In a statement before a court at Bhopal, in central India, a senior lawyer for the Government said it wanted a settlement of their claims that would be ''just and fair and reasonable to all parties concerned.'' This is the first time in recent months that India has publicly shown willingness to settle the bitter dispute with the American company out of court. **********But the lawyer, Vepa Sarathy, did not state a figure that the Government would consider fair. **********India is suing for damages of $3.3 billion from Union Carbide for the gas leak from a subsidiary's pesticide plant at Bhopal. More than 2,500 people were killed on Dec. 3, 1984, and more than 200,000 were injured. Many are still receiving medical treatment. **********Mr. Sarathy was responding to an offer by the company earlier this month to pay about $5 million as immediate relief to victims of the disaster, without conceding any liability for it. He dismissed that offer as ''insignificant'' but mentioned an ''atmosphere of reconciliation'' between the two adversaries. **********Robert Berzok, director of corporate communications for Union Carbide, said at company headquarters in Danbury, Conn., that Union Carbide continued to support ''a spirit of reconciliation that would lead to a just, fair and reasonable settlement.'' When asked whether Union Carbide was considering reopening talks with Indian officials, he said he had nothing to add to his statement.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/10/busin.main_headline: TURNER DISCUSSING SALE OF POSSIBLY LARGE STAKE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/10/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; TURNER DISCUSSING SALE OF POSSIBLY LARGE STAKE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/10/busin.body_text: **********Ted Turner, head of the financially troubled Turner Broadcasting System, may be negotiating to sell a significant piece of his 80 percent stake in the television and cable company, Wall Street analysts and sources close to Turner Broadcasting said yesterday. **********The company refused to say how much stock might be sold. Some analysts thought that it was too early in the negotiations to assess the situation but felt that Mr. Turner would fight vigorously to maintain control - even if he sold a substantial stake. **********Speculation over the possible sale by the broadcaster developed after Turner Broadcasting released a 49-word statement saying only that it was discussing a possible ''infusion of equity capital into the company'' by what it called ''a group of cable operators.'' **********The company said that discussions were continuing on the possible infusion of capital but stressed that there was ''no assurance'' the talks would lead to any firm agreement. It described the capital infusion under discussion as ''material'' but would not elaborate. **********Storer Communications said that it was a member of the group. Reuters news service quoted Andy Holgate, a spokesman, as saying, ''We have been approached by Turner Broadcasting and expect to talk with them in the relatively near future concerning an opportunity for investment in their company.'' Cox Communications said it had also been approached and was examining the proposal, Reuters added. **********Drexel Burnham Lambert, which has advised Turner in the past, is thought to be helping the company round up possible investors. It did not return phone calls for comment. **********Mr. Turner's office in Atlanta said the executive was not available for comment, and other officers declined to elaborate except to say that the group it mentioned referred to ''a number of different operators'' that would be independent of one another. **********A company spokesman, Arthur Sando, said the statement was made after the stock began trading heavily on the American Stock Exchange in the last few days. It said the Amex had not asked for the statement. **********Turner common stock jumped $2.875, to $18, in heavy trading yesterday. Its preferred stock rose 50 cents, to $9.50, also in heavy trading. Last Wednesday, almost 3 million preferred shares changed hands as word spread that new money might be coming into the company. **********Turner lost nearly $120 million in the first nine months of 1986 on revenues of $401 million. It earned $15.6 million in the period a year earlier on revenues of $259.4 million. **********Analysts who follow Turner and other cable television executives felt strongly that the discussions under way might involve Telecommunications Inc. of Denver, the nation's biggest cable television operator, and its president, John C. Malone. Telecommunications owns about 3 percent of Turner Broadcasting. Mr. Malone did not return calls made to his Denver office. **********Kenneth T. Berents, who follows Turner for the Baltimore investment house of Legg Mason Wood Walker Inc., said he had heard from his sources that several of the big cable operators might be talking to Turner Broadcasting, including Telecommunications and the American Television and Communications Corporation, an 80 percent owned Time Inc. subsidiary. In Denver, James C. Duffy, a spokesman for A.T.C., said none of the executives were availbale for comment. **********Some analysts declined to speculate on how much money might be attracted. One analyst, asking not to be identified, said he thought $100 million to $150 million, ''or even less,'' might be the target figure for the present. **********The Turner spokesman, Mr. Sando, said the company owed $150 million in short-term debt and $1.2 billion in long-term debt stemming from its $1.6 billion purchase of the MGM/UA Entertainment Company with high-yield securities, or ''junk bonds.'' He said that no payments were overdue but that the interest rate climbed a half-point every quarter the debt remained unpaid. The next deadline is March 15, he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/08/world.main_headline: FEDERAL JURY ON ARMS CASE TO BE EMPANELED IN WEEKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/08/world.print_headline: FEDERAL JURY ON ARMS CASE TO BE EMPANELED IN WEEKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/08/world.body_text: **********A Federal grand jury will be empaneled before February to begin hearing testimony in the Iran-contra arms case, according to Government officials knowledgeable about the investigation. **********They said that the special prosecutor in the case, Lawrence E. Walsh, had also been in contact with Congress about the possibility that it might grant immunity to key witnesses. **********They said that Mr. Walsh talked last month with the chairman of a special Senate committee investigating the case, Senator Daniel K. Inouye, Democrat of Hawaii. The two men, they said, agreed that no Congressional immunity would be granted without prior notification of Mr. Walsh. **********The decision to open the grand jury's inquiry this month came as Mr. Walsh announced appointment of a 12-member staff that included several lawyers from prominent New York law firms. He said he would open offices in New York and Washington. #3 Investigations of Contra Aid According to Government officials, Mr. Walsh will study the Iran-contra arms case and is expected to take control of at least three Justice Department investigations into potentially illegal support for Nicaraguan rebels. **********At the same time, they said, Mr. Walsh has decided not to take over another major Iran-arms prosecution being handled by the Justice Department in New York. **********That prosecution, involving 18 defendants accused of conspiring to sell arms to Iran, had been on hold for the last two days while Mr. Walsh debated whether to take over for the case. **********On Capitol Hill meanwhile, the House of Representatives voted 416 to 2 today to create its own special committee to investigate the Iran-contra matter. The Senate set up its committee Tuesday. 'Fair and Objective' Inquiry **********Representative Lee H. Hamilton, an Indiana Democrat who was named chairman of the committee, promised an ''expeditious, thorough, fair and objective'' investigation. **********The top Republican on the panel, Representative Dick Cheney of Wyoming, called himself ''a very partisan Republican,'' but he said he had ''every reason to expect'' an impartial inquiry. **********The resolution establishing the panel provided for a conclusion of the investigation by Oct. 30. Hearings could begin as soon as next month. **********The only representatives voting against creating the committee were William S. Broomfield of Michigan and Philip M. Crane of Illinois, both Republicans. Argument of Opponent **********Mr. Broomfield complained that the resolution setting up the committee permitted the investigation to last too long and did not provide sufficient safeguards to protect national security secrets. **********The officials said that Mr. Walsh, a former Deputy Attorney General who once served as a Federal judge in Manhattan, appeared to be moving quickly to begin his investigation. **********In a written statement today, Mr. Walsh said that the 11 staff lawyers named today had received ''necessary background investigations and a full exploration of any possible conflicts with the subject matter of the investigation.'' **********He also named a chief administrator, Herbert E. Hoffman, who once served as director of the Washington office of the American Bar Association. **********Four of the lawyers are associated with the New York law firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell, where Mr. Walsh was a partner from 1961 to 1981. **********One of the lawyers, John G. Douglass of Richmond, Va., had been an Assistant United States Attorney in Baltimore, where he served last year as proseuctor in the trial of Ronald W. Pelton, a former National Security Agency employee who was convicted of spying for the Soviet Union. Prosecutor in Friedman Case **********Another of the lawyers, David M. Zornow, is an Assistant United States Attorney in Manhattan and was a member of the prosecution team at the trial of Stanley Friedman, the former Bronx Democratic leader who was recently convicted of racketeering and mail fraud charges. **********A partner at Davis Polk, Guy M. Struve, will head the New York office. According to the statement, Mr. Walsh will work in Washington. **********These are the other lawyers named to the investigation: Geoffrey S. Berman of Davis Polk. Michael R. Bromwich, chief of the Narcotics **********Unit of the United States Attorney's office in Manhattan. David D. Brown 4th of Davis Polk. Richard C. Ford of Crowe & Dunlevy Inc. of **********Oklahoma City, Mr. Walsh's law firm. Paul L. Friedman of White & Case in Washington, a former Assistant United States Attorney in Washington and a former Assistant to the Solicitor General. Christian J. Mixter of Davis Polk. Robert N. Shwartz of Debevoise & Plimpton in New York, a former Assistant United States Attorney in Manhattan. Audrey Strauss of Mudge Rose Guthrie **********Alexander & Ferdon in New York, a former Assistant United States Attorney in Manhattan who was chief of the United States Attorney's Securities and Commodities Fraud Unit.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/17/world.body_text: **********Six Americans were killed Wednesday night when their helicopter crashed on a mission to evacuate a wounded American military adviser, an American Embassy spokesman said today. **********Another American was wounded in the crash, which occurred during a violent storm sometime before midnight on the shore of Lake Ilopango, just northeast of San Salvador.  [ In Washington, a Defense Department spokeswoman said one of those killed was Lieut. Col. James M. Basile, 43 years old, of Cheshire, Conn., an Air Force officer who was deputy commander of the United States Military Group attached to the United States Embassy in El Salvador, The Associated Press reported.  [ The A.P. also reported that a Salvadoran justice of the peace, Nesbia Alvarenga, identified them as Lieut. **********Col. Joseph Librado Lujan, 43; Second Lieut. Gregory Paredes, 24; Sgt. Linn V. Keen, 27; and John Douglas **********Raibon, 39, and Douglas Lee Adams, identified only as soldiers. ]  The military adviser the team was to evacuate, Staff Sgt. Timothy C. Hodge, 29, who had been seriously wounded when a rifle accidentally discharged at a Salvadoran Army training base in the town of La Union, the spokesman said. **********The crash caused the largest single loss of American lives in El Salvador since American involvement here began growing in 1979. The casualties were three helicopter crew members, two medical specialists and two military advisers who were to coordinate the evacuation of Sergeant Hodge, the embassy spokesman said. **********The rescue team took off in an American Army helicopter at about 10:40 Wednesday night from San Salvador shortly after receiving news that the adviser had been wounded in the gun accident, the embassy spokesman said. **********American military officials wanted to bring him back to the capital for emergency treatment, the spokesman said. **********The sole survivor of the crash, Sgt. 1st Class Thomas G. Grace, 32, and Sergeant Hodge are both in serious condition in hospitals here, according to a Pentagon spokeswoman.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/25/busin.body_text: **********The Eastman Kodak Company said yesterday that it would introduce a new minilab system for photofinishing, the first such system designed and built in the United States. **********The Minilab System 20, which will sell for about $43,000, is intended for a low-volume photofinishing market. College bookstores, food and drug stores, video stores, amusement parks and hotels are potential buyers, Henry Kaska, a spokesman for Kodak, said. The minilab is expected to be available in October. **********The system can handle up to 20 orders an hour, Kodak said, adding that it provides photofinishing of the same quality as the high-speed 3510 color printer that Kodak introduced last October. **********All parts and components of the new minilab are made by American companies, the first instance of this in the competitive market dominated by Japanese companies. Kodak offers two other minilabs imported from Japan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/15/world.main_headline: Notes From North Describe Meeting on Contra Support
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/15/world.print_headline: IRAN-CONTRA HEARINGS; Notes From North Describe Meeting on Contra Support
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/15/world.body_text: **********Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North told a meeting of mid-level Government officials last August that he was giving money to contra leaders and running an air resupply operation that used C-123 aircraft, according to handwritten notes he took at the time. **********According to officials who have seen the notes, which have been turned over to the Congressional select committees investigating the Iran-contra affair, they suggest that Colonel North told State Department, Central Intelligence Agency and Pentagon officials of his contra operations months before a C-123 transport plane was shot down over Nicaragua Oct. 5. **********The disclosure is potentially significant because several Cabinet officers and other senior Reagan Administration officials, including Assistant Secretary of State Elliott Abrams, emphatically insisted at the time that they knew of no United States Government connection to the downed plane. **********Later, Mr. Abrams said the inaccurate statements had stemmed from an incomplete knowledge of Colonel North's activities. Testimony About Meeting **********Last week, Colonel North testified he had attended a Pentagon meeting in August in which he gave mid-level officials a detailed account of some of his activities in support of the contras. At the time, Congress had approved $100 million for the rebels but had not released the money. **********Colonel North testified that he probably mentioned the air operation he was directing. He said, however, that he was uncertain precisely what he said and urged the committee to review his handwritten notes. **********Government officials who have seen the notes say they show that Colonel North attended a meeting at the Pentagon Aug. 28 and described payments to contra leaders, the air operation and its use of C-123 planes. **********Attending, Colonel North testified, were Lieut. Gen. John Moellring, a special assistant to the Chairman of Joint Chiefs of Staff; Mr. Abrams and his senior aide, James Michel; Alan D. Fiers, head of the C.I.A.'s Central America task force, and Richard Armitage, the Assistant Secretary of Defense for International Security Affairs. Denial From Abrams **********Mr. Abrams said today that he had not attended the meeting, and there was no indication in Colonel North's notes that he did. ''On Aug. 28, 1986, I was on vacation with my family,'' he said. ''I do not recall ever being told that a meeting took place in my absence at which a detailed description of the private air operations was made or that salary payments to individual resistence leaders were discussed.'' **********Mr. Fiers has insisted to investigators that he knew nothing about Colonel North's role in the resupply effort, and a C.I.A. spokesman had no comment. General Moellring has retired and could not be reached. The Pentagon said it was not commenting on the hearings, and Mr. Armitage was out of town. **********A State Department spokesman said Mr. Michel attended the meeting, but that he had no comment on what took place. **********A State Department official said Mr. Michel had given Mr. Abrams an account of the August meeting after it took place. This official said Mr. Abrams was unaware of Colonel North's possibly questionable activities, including his role in the air operations, until they were publicly disclosed. A Sensitive Operation **********''We went down item by item on my check list,'' Colonel North testified last week, adding that he ''asked them point-blank whether this should continue.'' **********The support payments to the contra leaders that Colonel North mentioned to the other officials were among the Administration's more sensitive operations on behalf of the rebels. The rebel leaders initially received payments from the C.I.A., but those payments were cut off in early 1985 after the Congressional intelligence committees pointed out that some of those receiving support were giving speeches in the United States and lobbying Congress on behalf of the contras. Members said they objected to any C.I.A. operation that could influence American public opinion. The C.I.A. had no comment today.  A document released by the committee last week, a 1985 letter from Colonel North to the contra leader Adolfo Calero, shows that the colonel's payments to another contra leader, Arturo Cruz Jr., began after fears arose that members of Congress would publicly disclose that Mr. Cruz was on the payroll of what the document called ''the company.'' **********Government officials confirmed this was a reference to C.I.A. money previously funnelled to Mr. Cruz, payments that were being made even in 1984, when he was briefly a candidate for President in Nicaragua. **********The complete document was made public by the committee last week. In it, Colonel North wrote: ''We may have to very soon assume the cost of what the company is providing to Arturo. You and I both recognize his value and limitations. Some in our Congress are aware the company is paying him and have threatened to expose the connection. This could be devastating to our forthcoming campaign to restore the funding. I will find out soon how much he is getting and let you know, but it seems as though something should be set aside for this purpose.'' **********Mr. Cruz was one of three directors of the contra movement in mid-1985 and resigned this year. He has acknowledged that in December 1985, Colonel North offered him support payments and that he received about $7,000 per month from January to November. Earlier this year, he resigned from the contra directorate.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/26/busin.body_text: **********More than any other financial services company, Fidelity Investments has promoted the love affair between investors and mutual funds. During the last five years, Fidelity's selection of funds has more than tripled, to more than 100, and its assets under management jumped to $85 billion, from $19 billion. **********Fidelity customers can turn to one of nearly three dozen sector funds, which invest in stocks in industries including electronics, chemicals, housing or brokerages. For more variety, they can invest in international stock and bond funds. And if customers want to play it safe, more than 20 money market funds are available. Challenges Since October **********But Fidelity is facing tough challenges, largely stemming from the stock market collapse in October. The burden of grappling with these problems belongs to Edward C. Johnson 3d, the current chairman, whose family has controlled the firm since its founding in 1946. **********As Mr. Johnson put it, ''From the current trend of sales, the general public seems to be discouraged'' with investments in equity funds. **********No longer are individual investors so eager to thrust their money at Fidelity's high-performing stock funds. The assets of its equity funds have risen to $27 billion, from $4 billion in 1982, but the sales pace is now about half what it was before the stock market plunged on Oct. 19. **********During the market collapse, Fidelity stood out among institutional investors for the impact that its huge stock sales had on the market. Mr. Johnson admitted that Fidelity's stock transactions on Oct. 19 were triple their normal volume. Fidelity said it intends to increase its bank lines of credit to avoid the need to execute large sell orders when customer redemptions run high. **********Fidelity's once-envied customer service operation also faltered on Oct. 19. The firm, considered by competitors to be one of the premier service organizations, disappointed many of its customers who were delayed in getting through clogged telephone lines when they were most desperate to make a change in their holdings. **********What happened to Fidelity in October is significant because the mutual fund firm, because of its size and the variety of its products, serves as a window on the financial services industry. Since taking over as chairman from his father in 1972, Mr. Johnson, 56 years old, has built the firm into a financial powerhouse with estimated revenues of $800 million. Fidelity now has 54 investor centers in major metropolitan areas nationwide. Shrewd Marketing Tactics **********Its shrewd marketing approach, in fact, has made Fidelity the Procter & Gamble of the financial business. Besides offering the broadest array of funds, Fidelity inundates investors with information, with offerings that range from video cassettes on tax planning to a magazine that promotes the firm's products and provides financial planning advice. **********Although it is best known for its mutual funds, Fidelity also offers a discount brokerage, real estate investments, a cash management account and other financial services. At the end of November, 47 percent of the $75 billion in managed assets was invested in money market accounts, 38 percent was in stock funds and 15 percent was in bond funds. **********To deal with the effects of the stock market collapse, Mr. Johnson and his staff have adopted new marketing tactics to keep money coming in. **********With investors skittish about equities, Fidelity has cut back on its advertising of stock funds and has stepped up promotion of the high-income features of bond and money-market funds. In addition, Fidelity is offering commission-free trades to people who sell stocks and switch their assets into a Fidelity fund. Fixing the Phones **********Fidelity executives have also been working to correct operational problems, like the overburdened telephone system. **********Customers normally must wait no longer than 19 seconds for a representative to answer the phone, but on the three peak trading days starting Friday, Oct. 16, they had to wait up to four minutes, Mr. Johnson said. Some customers reported waits of much longer. **********''We were not pleased with our ability to handle the volume,'' he said. ''Too many people had to wait too long.'' **********Mr. Johnson has taken steps to insure that Fidelity could handle a volume of calls similar to the hundreds of thousands that poured into the firm's phone centers on Oct. 19 and 20. **********The firm said that the number of incoming lines has been increased by 50 percent and that 200 staff members have been trained for emergencies to help out the 1,500 men and women who handle telephone customers full-time. **********''We just did not envisage that kind of volume,'' Mr. Johnson said of the October experience. ''We were just wrong on that particular issue.'' Assets Down $10 Billion **********Although sales of shares in stock mutual funds have dropped, redemptions from the funds have apparently not posed a problem. The privately held firm does not reveal redemption figures, but Mr. Johnson said they were in line with overall industry withdrawals, which have been considered relatively small. Since October, Fidelity's total managed assets declined to $75 billion, from $85 billion, mostly because of the drop in the value of the stocks it holds. **********Even if the broad market crumbles, Mr. Johnson said he believed that his firm would be able to sell shares in the 32 sector funds that invest in specific industries. Since Fidelity, which pioneered these volatile funds, offers such a variety of them, Mr. Johnson reasons that some are bound to outperform the industry averages. ''I would think we would continue to market them somewhat aggressively,'' he said. **********However, Mr. Johnson indicated that Fidelity would remain attuned to the marketplace, adding that the firm would drop one campaign and create another if it found individual investors do not want sector funds - or for that matter, any type of fund. **********''If people don't want to buy them, we're certainly not going to spend a lot of money on advertising,'' he said. ''If people express considerable interest, we'll continue to market them.'' **********Should stock prices fall further, Fidelity will obviously suffer. But its range of products should position it to survive in any economic environment. Mr. Johnson recalls the difficulties that sprang from the bear market in stocks in 1973 and the following years. When individuals avoided stocks, Fidelity developed money market and tax-exempt bond funds to entice them. As a result, the firm became an industry leader in those areas, too. **********''We lived sparsely, but we lived well between 1974 and 1981 when no matter how hard we tried to sell equities, we could hardly sell a share,'' he said. ''If the same situation comes back again, we will adapt.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/12/busin.main_headline: Robins Has New Plan For Claims
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/12/busin.print_headline: Robins Has New Plan For Claims
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/12/busin.body_text: **********The A. H. Robins Company yesterday offered a revised proposal for compensating women who say they were injured by the company's Dalkon Shield contraceptive device. **********The new plan eliminated several provisions that drew the most criticism when the company filed its original proposal in the United States Bankruptcy Court in Richmond last month. **********Robins sought protection from its creditors when it filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy in 1985, under pressure from the Dalkon Shield suits. The company proposes to set up a $1.75 billion trust fund to pay more than 330,000 women who said that the Dalkon Shield intrauterine device had caused sterility, pelvic infection or other injuries. **********Under the original plan, Robins had proposed to pay some women as little as $100 for their injuries and to charge a $200 nonrefundable fee for women who had pressed their claims beyond the initial stages. Those provisions have now been dropped. **********''The new plan also provides that, if all the money in the trust is not used up in paying off the women's claims, the first $50 million of the leftover money will be distributed on a pro rata basis among all the claimants in lieu of punitive damages,'' said James C. Roberts, a lawyer for Robins. Earlier, the company had argued that there should be no punitive damages and that any leftover money belonged to it and not to the claimants. **********The schedule of proposed payments, running from $200 to $3,000 for the simpler claims, has also been dropped, with a new schedule to be designated by the trustees.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/01/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Guarded Optimism on Bonds
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/01/busin.body_text: **********Treasury bond yields have dropped sharply the last 11 days, though traders acknowledge that the new-found optimism may have fragile underpinnings. **********The decline in 30-year government bond yields to 8.64 percent on Friday from 9.05 percent on May 21 was the most significant since yields began rising from 7.55 percent on March 26. Investor demand for bonds has been modest, traders said, but demand has improved sharply from securities dealers and other speculators who were aggressively selling bonds during April and most of May. **********''The improvement in the dollar and the unwinding of some commodity prices have removed some of the inflation fear that was such a negative for the market,'' said William S. Coleman, director of government bond trading at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. At the same time, he said, ''there are definitely more buyers, including some nibbling from overseas'' and a cessation of the heavy selling by bond mutual funds that depressed the market during April and most of May. The Volcker Question **********The major risk in the market now, Mr. Coleman said, is the question of whether Paul A. Volcker will be reappointed chairman of the Federal Reserve. His term expires in August, and rumors about his reappointment or departure circulate almost daily in the bond market. Traders expect his retirement from the board would push both dollar and bond prices lower, while his reappointment would lift both markets. **********Expectations about the summit meeting of industrial powers in Venice next week vary widely. Some securities dealers said that the improvement in the dollar during the past month (from a low of about 137 yen to 144 yen Friday), plus the moves toward lower short-term rates in Japan and West Germany and higher rates in the United States, are good reasons for not expecting any major new initiatives. Friday's announcement by the Japanese Government of a new spending plan, larger than expected, was another needed change in policy, they said. **********But others said the improvement in the dollar has occurred precisely because new initiatives are expected. Without some tangible follow-through at Venice, they predicted the dollar would again weaken and there might be renewed upward pressure on American interest rates in order to attract foreign capital. **********''If the policies implemented are believable, then the decline in bond yields is sustainable, and there will be a reversal of the recent pressure on the Fed to tighten monetary policy,'' said William Sullivan, senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc.''But if the summit breaks up with a general statement agreeing that the appropriate policies are already in place, then the dollar could weaken and upward pressure on rates would re-emerge.'' Dollar Seen as Vulnerable **********Thomas Campbell, vice president and foreign exchange trader at the First National Bank of Chicago, predicted that even if the foreign exchange and bond markets are stable through the summit, the dollar would still be vulnerable. ''If the April trade data show too large a deficit,'' he said, ''then people might again say, 'It doesn't matter what comes out of the summit, the economics show the dollar has to come down.' '' **********The merchandise trade deficit of $13.6 billion in March was down from $15.1 billion in February. But even if the trade deficit continues to shrink in coming months, contributing to faster growth in gross national product (as it did in the first quarter), some analysts worry that the improvement will be too slow to stave off protectionist legislation that will raise inflation and too little to prevent another round of dollar devaluation in the foreign exchange markets. **********A recent study by economists at the Deutsche Bank, for example, concluded that even if the American trade deficit declines this year and next, the present level of the dollar suggests that the deficit might begin rising later, once the effects of the recent dollar devaluation are exhausted. **********''The persistent U.S. external deficit and the unprecedented overhang of dollars will remain major depressants on the dollar's exchange value for years to come,'' the study said. The remedy, the bank said, is economic policy coordination among nations that would enable them to quickly correct large trade surpluses and deficits. **********Besides the inflationary impact of a weaker dollar, the bond market pays close attention to foreign exchange developments because the Federal Reserve in April showed it was willing to raise short-term interest rates to make the dollar more attractive. Rate Rise Seen as Temporary Neal M. Soss, chief economist at the First Boston Corporation, noted last week that higher interest rates are not in the best interest of the world economy and not the true preference of the Federal Reserve. At a luncheon for institutional investors, he predicted that the Fed's use of higher interest rates to defend the dollar ''will not really persist for a long period of time.'' **********The First Boston analyst said that a financial crisis or the accumulation of signs of weak economic growth are two developments that would cause the Fed to shift its focus away from the dollar and back to domestic affairs. Alternatively, he said, agreements reached at the Venice summit meeting next week might foster enough stability in the foreign exchange markets that the Fed might no longer find it necessary to use higher interest rates as a tool to maintain the dollar's value. **********Developments that would promote stability in the dollar, Mr. Soss said, include the reappointment of Paul A. Volcker as chairman of the Fed, repeal of some recently imposed tariffs, arranging for Japan to increase its investments and lending to Latin America, stimulation of the Japanese and West German economies, and some reduction in the American budget deficit. https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/18/world.body_text: **********In an attempt to pressure Lieut. Gen. Henry Namphy to step down, four leading presidential candidates have announced agreement on a coalition government that would replace him if he yields. **********The four candidates also announced the formation of a working committee to organize the opposition, and once again demanded that the Namphy Government surrender power. **********The show of unity, which was announced late Wednesday after meetings with American diplomats, culminated days of negotiations between the four candidates, who until recently were attacking one another. A Setback for Namphy **********Western diplomats welcomed the announcement and called it a setback for the Namphy Government, which canceled the presidential election last Nov. 29 after soldiers and thugs in civilian clothes killed at least 34 voters. General Namphy has ordered a new election for Jan. 17 under tight controls. **********The diplomats noted that the four candidates had united despite a continuing campaign of intimidation that forced them out of their homes and made it difficult for them even to meet. **********''We're very pleased,'' a United States Embassy spokesman said in Port-au-Prince. ''It's a very good thing the opposition is finally getting its act together. But it's too bad that it took terror for them to get it together.'' **********Citing continuing violence, the four candidates - Marc Bazin, a 55-year-old economist; Gerard Gourgue, a 61-year-old lawyer and human-rights activist; Louis Dejoie 2d, a 59-year-old building contractor, and Sylvio C. Claude, a 55-year-old Baptist minister - declined to identify the members of the proposed coalition government. **********The agreement on the coalition increases the likelihood that the four candidates, who are estimated to command 80 percent of the vote, can organize an effective boycott of the Jan. 17 election, which the Government is organizing over widespread opposition. **********But in announcing the coalition, the opposition also showed its weakness. The failure to do more than repeat demands that the Government step down underscored how little pressure it could put on the Government. **********''There aren't many opportunities left for the opposition,'' a Western diplomat said. ''It's very important that the opposition is finally working together. But what can it do?'' **********Aides to the candidates acknowledged that the opposition was confused about what to do next.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/13/busin.body_text: **********The Ford Motor Company's president, Harold Poling, called on Japan today to curb car exports to the United States to less than 2 million annually, from the current 2.3 million. **********At a news conference before a speech to the Detroit Economic Club, Ford's second-ranking officer said the United States should consider imposing import tariffs on Japanese cars unless Tokyo moved voluntarily to roll back exports. **********Mr. Poling said Japanese companies should have their imports reduced to compensate for increases in their American production. Many domestic-built Japanese cars contain large amounts of imported material, including engines and transmissions. **********Mr. Poling's comments were the strongest recent call for a rollback in Japanese imports by any major Detroit auto maker and follow by one day a call by the United Automobile Workers for a curb on Japanese car imports as well as auto parts.
