https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/28/busin.body_text: **********Asher B. Edelman, the New York investor, said he had filed for permission from the Federal Trade Commission and the antitrust division of the Department of Justice to increase his stake in the Foster Wheeler Corporation from his current 11.2 percent level. **********Mr. Edelman and a group of his associates have previously threatened to begin a hostile takeover of the Livingston, N.J., construction and engineering concern. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Mr. Edelman said the senior management of Foster Wheeler has refused to meet with the Edelman group. Foster Wheeler did not comment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/29/busin.main_headline: ALLIED SELLS STAKE IN SPUN-OFF HENLEY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/29/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; ALLIED SELLS STAKE IN SPUN-OFF HENLEY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/29/busin.body_text: **********The Allied-Signal Corporation has sold its 15.6 percent stake in the Henley Group back to that company for $465 million, severing its most important ties with the concern that Allied spun off just last year. **********In addition to the $465 million, Allied-Signal will get $65 million for modifying contracts between the two companies. **********One of those changes will strengthen Henley's Wheelabrator Technologies subsidiary enough so that the unit can eventually be made a separate public company, Henley said. Wheelabrator Transaction **********Michael D. Dingman, chairman of Henley, said in a telephone interview that the Wheelabrator transaction could take several forms, and will probably be completed within six months. **********On Henley's side, the buyback will also free it to move on to other matters - particularly making a very large acquisition. **********''In the next few months, you'll see some action,'' Mr. Dingman said, when asked about the prospect of his company making an acquisition. ''We're coming up there,'' he said without elaborating. **********The $530 million payment to Allied-Signal will hardly dent Henley's wallet. Henley, which is based in La Jolla, Calif., has about $1 billion in cash available to it and recently set up credit lines worth another $3 billion. Owens-Illinois Rumors **********There have recently been rumors that Henley might be interested in acquiring Owens-Illinois Inc., a company that has received a buyout offer from Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company. But Wall Street sources, who asked not to be identified, said Henley had no interest in Owens-Illinois, feeling that Kohlberg, Kravis's bid has already made the company too expensive. **********Mr. Dingman, who was formerly the head of Wheelbrator-Frye before it merged with the Signal Companies, resigned from Allied-Signal's board of directors as part of the buyback agreement. **********He also said that some of Wheelabrator's stock would probably be sold to the public, and some might be distributed as a dividend to the current shareholders of Henley. A company spokesman said that Henley, a company whose philosophy is to create values by buying and selling businesses, would retain a sizable chunk of Wheelabrator Technology's shares. **********Mr. Dingman said that ''foreigners'' had expressed an interest in investing in Wheelabrator, a company that is in the forefront of the promising market for turning waste products into energy. He did not, identify the interested parties. **********Allied-Signal announced in late 1985 that it was divesting itself of some 30 subsidiaries into a new publicly held company. That transaction, which created Henley, was completed in mid-1986. Henley's separation from Allied-Signal has, so far, been very successful. As promised, Henley has been spinning off assets to its shareholders. In addition, the company recently had a very successful initial public offer. **********Allied-Signal retained 19.5 million shares of Henley convertible preferred stock, which represented 15.6 percent of the 129 million shares the company has on a fully diluted basis. Those are the shares that were sold yesterday. Allied-Signal and Henley had previously announced that they were conducting negotiations regarding the repurchase by Henley of the stock, and most analysts figured that the successful conclusion of the deal was a foregone conclusion. **********Sources familiar with the buyback, however, said the negotiations were complicated by the modification of the so-called support agreements, which committed Allied to helping some of the projects that Henley had under way. For instance, under the newly revised support agreement for the waste-to-energy projects, Allied-Signal will help Wheelabrator receive a single-A bond rating on a number of its current projects that are under development. **********The sale of the Henley stock gives Allied-Signal funds to retire debt and repurchase the last of the preferred shares it has outstanding. **********''These agreements will provide Allied-Signal with an additional $530 million in cash and is another step in sharpening its focus on high-technology businesses,'' said Edward L. Hennessy Jr., chairman and chief executive officer of Allied.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/22/world.main_headline: SOUTH AFRICA SAYS IT MAY SOON SIGN ATOMIC AGREEMENT
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/22/world.print_headline: SOUTH AFRICA SAYS IT MAY SOON SIGN ATOMIC AGREEMENT
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/22/world.body_text: **********South Africa indicated tonight that it might soon sign a treaty intended to curb the spread of nuclear weapons. **********President P. W. Botha said his Government was prepared to begin talks with the nuclear powers on the possibility of signing the 1970 Nonproliferation Treaty, which has been signed by 134 nations. **********''South Africa hopes that it will soon be able to sign the Nonproliferation Treaty and has decided to open discussions with others to this end,'' Mr. Botha said. The South African Government has until now consistently refused to sign the accord. Agency Officials Meet **********Mr. Botha's statement came as officials of the International Atomic Energy Agency were meeting in Vienna. **********Some Western diplomats said the move might be directed at staving off a Nigerian-led effort to suspend South Africa from the agency. But others said it was part of a larger plan of concessions to win Western support for a negotiated racial settlement in South Africa that would limit the influence of exiled nonwhite movements. **********South Africa's nuclear industry is shrouded in secrecy and the Government has refused to confirm or deny persistent rumors that it has collaborated with Israel in the development of nuclear weapons. Weapons Tests Charged **********South Africa has faced accusations in the United Nations and other international forums that it has tested nuclear weapons. The accumulated suspicion has been compounded by its refusal to open its uranium enrichment plant at Valindaba, west of Pretoria, for inspection. **********If South Africa joined the accord, analysts said, it would have to negotiate a ''safeguards'' agreement allowing agency inspectors to visit the country's nuclear plants to check that fuel was not being used for nuclear weapons. **********Western diplomats said such a move would mean a major scaling down of the country's nuclear energy program. Prepared to Negotiate **********Mr. Botha said in his statement that talks could depend on the results of the Vienna meeting, adding that his Government was prepared to negotiate on the inspection of its nuclear facilities. **********''Any safeguards agreements which might be negotiated with the I.A.E.A. will naturally be along the same lines as and conform with agreements with other nonproliferation signatories,'' Mr. Botha said. Although the charter of the International Atomic Energy Agency does not expressly provide for expulsion, members can be deprived of the ''rights and privileges of membership'' by a two-thirds vote of the General Conference. **********Agency officials say this would amount to expulsion since South Africa would no longer have access to agency meetings and seminars or to the information on nuclear safety and other technical topics that it collects, assesses and circulates to member countries. **********However, the I.A.E.A. would continue to inspect South African nuclear installations currently under safeguards since these inspections are made under separate agreements between Pretoria and the agency. Reactors Under Inspection **********South Africa already has two French nuclear power reactors operating at Koeberg near Cape Town, which France placed under I.A.E.A. inspection when it built them. South African scientists also operate a research reactor called Safari 1 that is under agency inspection. **********Under the Nonproliferation Treaty, Britain, China, the Soviet Union and the United States are allowed to retain their nuclear weapons but pledge to work for nuclear disarmament and a ban on nuclear testing. France, which also has nuclear weapons, refuses to sign but acts as if it were a signer allowed such weapons. **********South Africa effectively controls the output of uranium in South-West Africa, the South African-controlled territory also known as Namibia, although it is mined by a subsidiary of the British-based multinational Rio Tinto Zinc. **********The uranium mined at the Rossing Mine in South-West Africa is widely used in the West, and a suspension of Pretoria from the agency could have political implications that might lead to a disruption in the West's uranium supply, analysts said.  ISRAEL IS A TARGET, TOO **********UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 21 -The same coalition of countries that is trying to oust South Africa from the atomic agency is also trying to expel Israel, according to diplomats and agency officials. **********The campaign has been mounted by third world nations with some Soviet support. It is strongly opposed by the United States and other Western members, which argue that expelling South Africa and Israel would politicize a technical United Nations agency and weaken efforts to improve reactor safety and stop the spread of atomic weapons. **********In a telephone interview from Vienna, the United States Energy Secretary, John S. Herrington, warned that Congressional support for funds for the I.A.E.A. was likely to ''collapse'' if Israel and South Africa were expelled, perhaps forcing the United States to withdraw from the organization. **********He said the vote on South African and Israel membership, expected Thursday or Friday, was likely to be close. **********''How can we tell Congress that money for the I.A.E.A. is money well spent if that body acts in so political a way and expels two members for purely political reasons?'' Mr. Herrington asked. **********American officials said Mr. Herrington had told Soviet delegates today that Russian support for ousting the two countries breached the spirit of the emerging new superpower nuclear arms reduction treaty. He said it also appeared inconsistent with Moscow's decision to cooperate closely with the I.A.E.A. after the Chernobyl disaster, passing on lessons learned from the accident to nuclear power station operators everywhere.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/19/busin.body_text: **********Bankers, already nervous about encroaching competition from brokers, retailers, auto makers, and others, have a new worry: The outlook for the nation's economy. **********In interviews, top bankers attending the annual convention here of the American Bankers Association said their theme this year was winning greater powers to take on the nonbank rivals. Many of them wore buttons saying, ''Kill the Moratorium,'' a reference to a moratorium on new bank powers. The moratorium is set to expire March 1. **********But at the dinners and receptions that most of the 6,500 participants have attended, conversations have focused heavily on more immediate economic issues: The next move for the stock market, which plunged last week, and prospects for the economy over all. Forecasts Are Gloomy **********In general, the forecasts being made here are gloomy. **********Most bankers, for example, seem to believe that interest rates have not peaked. A majority of those contacted said short-term rates will rise by anywhere from one to two percentage points by spring. The prime rate has already been raised to 9.75 percent by three banks and others may follow. The prime is the rate to which most loans to small- and medium-size companies are tied. **********''If I had to make a guess now,'' said Alan S. Fellheimer, chairman and chief executive of Equimark, Pittsburgh's third-largest bank, ''I could see a prime rate of 11.75 percent to 12 percent by the end of the first quarter.'' **********Because the markets have been in such turmoil, the predictions are more tenuous than usual, and what such a rate increase in such a short time would mean is, of course, equally uncertain. But bankers said that in general, companies would find it more difficult to obtain loans as lenders become skittish about customers' ability to pay interest. **********Beyond that, bankers said, a slowdown in economic growth would be inevitable. So far, no one seems willing to declare that a recession is around the corner. But bankers, noting that the two percentage-point rate increase since mid-April has already depressed commercial and housing construction, said additional rate increases that will take place in coming weeks will spread to other sectors of the economy. 'Looking at 2 Percent Growth' **********A two percentage point increase ''would call into question the sustainability of the recovery,'' said William E. Gibson, chairman of the asset-liability committee at the Continental Illinois Bank and Trust Company. ''You'd be looking at 2 percent growth rather than 3 percent.'' **********''The possibility of a recession is higher today than it was six months ago precisely because of higher rates,'' said Anthony P. Terracciano, formerly of the Chase Manhattan Bank and now president and chief operating officer of the Mellon Bank Corporation. **********Bankers are also worried about the stock market. **********In recent years, the bull market in stocks has provided bankers with increasing fee income for their trust departments. Last week, however, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 235.48 points, or 9.49 percent. Friday's 108.36-point plunge in the Dow seemed to be on everyone's lips. Now, while few, if any, bankers here are predicting a catastrophic decline in the Dow, the prevailing opinion was that the index could fall hundreds of points before stabilizing. **********The problem, bankers said, is an even greater amount of uncertainty than usual. Whereas financial markets in the past focused almost entirely on inflation and interest rates, the stock market today seems gripped by a multitude of fears, bankers said. These include concerns that the United States trade deficit will not shrink, the Federal budget deficit will remain huge, and the value of the dollar, which affects inflation in this country, will fall further. Pressure on Equity Prices **********In the absence of clear resolutions to any of these uncertainties, many investors will choose to steer clear of the stock market, bankers said. And that could put further pressure on equity prices when the stock market reopens this morning. **********''All I hear inside the bank is about the unbelievable degree of anxiety in the marketplace,'' said Charles Pistor, chairman and chief executive of First Republicbank of Dallas and the incoming president of the bankers association. ''The uncertainties are producing anxiety beyond the fact base, beyond the fundamentals.'' **********Indeed, beneath the somber economic projections being made is a feeling of frustration - a belief that the higher interest rates and flagging stock market are simply not justified by real economic developments. **********Bankers noted, for example, that interest rates generally rise because of strong demand for credit or out of fears of inflation. For months, however, business demand for loans has been weak, and there have been no jolts to the economy, such as an oil shortage, that would produce inflation. **********If there is a real problem, it is that the trade deficit has not narrowed significantly. Financial markets, therefore, may be responding not to bad news but to a lack of good. **********''The problem is that the trade deficit is not getting any better, and the market is deeply concerned about it,'' said Mr. Gibson at Continental Illinois.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/04/world.body_text: **********Argentina's recent military crisis set off a conflict between the Government of President Raul Alfonsin and the privately owned press over coverage and the way the Government used television to rally support. **********The rebellions by army units also highlighted the near monopoly on television news by the Government and its ownership of most provincial radio stations. The state's dominant role in broadcast journalism developed during four decades of authoritarian Governments, but leaders of privately owned television, radio and newspapers contend that such a position contradicts the new political democracy. **********La Nacion, the country's most prestigious newspaper and one that usually supports President Alfonsin, said Government influence over television and radio was ''present in these days like a retardatory factor in our democratic maturity.'' It suggested that the continued existence of the state-owned networks had tempted the Government into using them for propaganda purposes during the rebellions. **********The rebellions, which broke out on April 16 and continued for six days, began after judicial efforts to prosecute officers who are accused of human rights violations committed during counterinsurgency warfare a decade ago. After the rebellions, the army high command was restructured, and the Government decided to seek legal ways to restrict prosecution to high-ranking officers. TV Used to Urge Support **********During the tensest days of the crisis, the main television channels regularly urged people to go to the Plaza de Mayo in the capital or to plazas in provincial towns to demonstrate support for the Government. The phrase ''Democracy or Dictatorship'' flashed frequently across the bottoms of television screens. Correspondents and newscasters praised the turnout and urged more people into the plazas. By contrast, there was very little television news coverage of the actions and demands of the rebellious officers. **********Most of the coverage of the officers was by several privately owned radio stations in the capital and by newspapers and two news agencies, which were criticized by the Government and prominent members of the Radical Civic Union, the President's party. **********The Mayor of Buenos Aires, Facundo Suarez Lastra, charged last week that private radio stations had covered the crisis badly because they had ''given access to the air to seditious elements.'' He mentioned specifically an interview broadcast with Lieut. Col. Aldo Rico, leader of the rebels at Campo de Mayo, the military base near Buenos Aires, where President Alfonsin personally intervened to obtain the surrender of the rebels. **********News associations said several radio stations and one news agency had obtained interviews with Colonel Rico by telephone by calling the numbers listed in the telephone book for the infantry school at the Campo de Mayo. Government Objects to Reports **********While the crisis was under way, Government representatives issued several appeals to the press not to report on the news conferences or proclamations of the rebel officers. **********Julio Lopez, deputy director of press relations for the Government, said in an interview today that the Government had also objected at the time to some press reports that the rebellion was spreading to units that, in fact, were not in rebellion. He said ''the only problem was that some people did not check their sources.'' **********Mr. Lopez defended the use of television to garner support for the Government, saying it had been part of a ''spontaneous'' outpouring of effort to support democracy. **********He also said that some of the conflict over news coverage had been inevitable in the heat of the crisis and that it reflected the fact that Argentina is still making a transition to democracy. **********The country's largest circulation newspaper, Clarin, said the disagreement over the coverage came about because of conflicting views over the place of the press in a democracy. Obligations of the Press **********In an unusually long editorial signed by its editor, Ernestina Herrera de Noble, the newspaper said there were some who thought that ''the press ought to reflect all the facts'' and others who thought that the press should be ''adversaries in the democratic system.'' She said Clarin saw its place as a presenter of facts and not as an element in the exercise of power. **********La Nacion, as well as several smaller newspapers, said the experience of the past two weeks demonstrated the need to privatize the dozens of radio and television stations that were inherited by the Government from previous Administrations. **********The state has played a prominent role in radio and television since their introduction in Argentina, but at various periods there have been trends toward privatization - all of them eventually supplanted by new trends toward state control. At one point, in the first Administration of Juan Domingo Peron, who took power in 1946, most newspapers also were state controlled. **********All television stations were nationalized by the last Peronist Government in 1974. Since then, only one, Channel 9 in the capital, has been sold to private owners. Channel 9 is primarily an entertainment station. Privatizing Radio **********Toward the end of the last military regime, which gave up power after Mr. Alfonsin's election in 1983, privatization of radio stations was begun. Most of the stations in the capital have been sold or returned to private owners, and it was those stations that were most aggressive in covering the recent crisis, sending mobile units to key locations. **********A law pending in Congress would continue that privatization, but it is not thought to be near passage. **********The daily business newspaper Ambito Financiero reported that more than 60 radio stations, most of them in the provinces, and 17 television stations were still in Government hands.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/27/busin.body_text: **********The Economy **********The trade problem has emerged as a major issue among contenders for the 1988 Presidential nominations. The reasons: Trade legislation has been approved in the House and the Senate, while trade-sensitive areas such as Iowa and the Southern states will provide the first tests for the candidates. Views range from the ''protectionist'' position of Representative Gephardt to a variety of free-trade policies.  [ Page A1. ] **********The lower dollar is beginning to produce healthier earnings for U.S. companies. The impact of the drop on corporate balance sheets has been fairly recent, despite the fact that the dollar has been falling against major foreign currencies for two years.  [ D1. ] **********U.S. Attorneys and the S.E.C. are investigating bond sales worth about $12 billion that were made in the hectic days of December 1985 and August 1986, when lawyers and dealers worked around the clock to complete financings that would soon be banned by changes in Federal tax laws.  [ D1. ] **********Major banking legislation is on the line in Congress, with only a few days left before the August recess. The bill that conferees approved would rescue the F.S.L.I.C. and slow deregulation. The request was made at a meeting Friday between Brazil's new Finance Minister, Luiz Carlos Bresser Pereira, and a group that included the chairmen of several major U.S. banks. https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/07/world.main_headline: COAST GUARD DUTY PLANNED FOR GULF
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/07/world.print_headline: COAST GUARD DUTY PLANNED FOR GULF
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/07/world.body_text: **********The Reagan Administration plans to send four small Coast Guard patrol vessels and several search-and-rescue aircraft to the Persian Gulf to join the Navy there, Pentagon officials said today. **********The units, normally used to detect and arrest drug smugglers and for safety patrols, will most likely operate near Bahrain. There, they would be in position to guard the lightly armed command ship of the Navy's escort fleet, as well as some small barges that the Navy is leasing for offshore supply and maintenance. **********The barges are considered potential targets for attacks by Iranian speedboats, which last week massed and feinted across the gulf before being driven off by Saudi forces. **********The Coast Guard aircraft, which are expected to include both fixed-wing planes and helicopters, could be used to patrol nearby waters to detect small vessels and aircraft used by Iran. **********The plans to dispatch the Coast Guard units was first reported Monday night by NBC News. Review of Abilities **********The Pentagon's spokesman, Fred Hoffman, said today that ''there has been a recent review of Coast Guard capabilities and their potential use in the current situation in the gulf,'' but that no final decisions had been made. **********At a regular Pentagon news briefing, he refused to confirm that the Coast Guard units would be sent to the gulf. **********An official said the Coast Guard planned to send about four patrol vessels and about five aircraft. He did not say when the units would arrive. **********The Coast Guard has several types of patrol boats available, including a 110-foot vessel with a crew of 16. It flies three types of helicopters for search and rescue, along with small fixed-wing aircraft for the same purpose, a Coast Guard official said. **********Officials said the military effect of the small units, which are lightly armed but could be equipped with additional guns and missiles, would be slight. But their presence would free the Navy's frigates for more important duties, including escorting Kuwaiti oil tankers sailing through the gulf under the American flag. **********One official said the Coast Guard was eager to expand its role in the gulf, previously limited to inspecting Kuwaiti vessels to make sure they met the legal requirements for registration under the American flag. The Coast Guard's operating budget has been sharply cut by Congress in recent years, and some officials believe that by adopting a higher profile the guard can reverse this trend, he said.  BAGHDAD THREATENS AIR RAIDS **********MANAMA, Bahrain, Oct. 6 (AP) -Iraq threatened today to retaliate for the latest Iranian missile attacks on Baghdad by blitzing Iranian cities with air raids, artillery and new long-range missiles that can reach Teheran. **********Later in the day, it said Iraqi jets raided a ''large naval target,'' usually meaning a ship. There was no immediate confirmation of the attack. **********Two missiles hit the Iraqi capital Monday night and early today, killing or wounding an unspecified number of people. Iran had fired two dozen Soviet-made Scud-B missiles into Baghdad beginning late last year, but these were the first attacks since Feb. 13. **********Government newspapers in Baghdad said the military would make the first use of a new type of Iraqi-manufactured missile to attack Iranian cities, indicating Teheran would be the main target.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/02/world.main_headline: Israel Cabinet Defers Issue of Security Agency
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/02/world.print_headline: Israel Cabinet Defers Issue of Security Agency
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/02/world.body_text: **********The Israeli Cabinet today postponed discussion of an official inquiry's report that concluded agents of the Shin Beth internal security service had routinely committed perjury to convict terrorist suspects. **********Although the report captured the front pages of Hebrew newspapers today, few Israelis appeared very much surprised by its revelations. **********''We didn't need this report to burst the myth called the Shin Beth, an acronym we didn't dare say aloud just two years ago,'' said a popular talk show host on the Israeli Army radio. ''The myth was already shattered.'' **********The speaker added that the report's authors had ''merely displayed the fragments before us.'' Use of Force Vague **********The report said limited use of physical force against terrorism suspects who may be withholding information was unavoidable and justified. It said agents who were singled out in two scandals that rocked Shin Beth recently had been acting according to established norms, and it recommended that they not be punished. **********The section of the report that was made public was deliberately vague about the extent to which interrogators used physical violence, and it recommended drawing clear guidelines to prevent excessive violence. **********''The Shin Beth has come out stronger from the report,'' said an editorial in the tabloid Hadashot. ''The commission has recognized the agency's claim that there is a significant difference between a criminal investigation and an investigation of hostile terrorist activity.'' **********An editorial in the mass-circulation Yedioth Aharonoth, said: ''This was a courageous report, because it doesn't blur and doesn't sweep anything under the carpet. More than anything else, the report reveals bravery when it obligates not only the use of psychological pressure in Shin Beth interrogations, but, in irregular cases, also the use of a moderate measure of physical force.'' Retrials May Be Sought **********The Cabinet is expected to schedule a special meeting for discussion of the inquiry, which will also be debated in Parliament, possibly later this week. **********Lawyers who represent Palestinians said they were examining the possibility of seeking retrials for clients who were still in jail. **********''The report says since 1972, the Shin Beth regularly lied to courts on the way evidence was obtained,'' said one lawyer, Avigdor Feldman. **********''In that time, at least 3,000 to 4,000 people were convicted on the basis of confessions.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/03/busin.body_text: **********After a first-quarter report that indicated sales were below projections, the Adolph Coors Company has imposed a hiring freeze. The freeze began May 15 in Coors's brewing division, which then had 5,931 employees, a company spokesman said. While falling behind projections, Coors's first-quarter shipments of 3.05 million barrels were 2.8 percent higher than during the corresponding period last year. In 1986, the company produced a record 15.24 million barrels of beer.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/04/world.main_headline: POSITION OF STARK FOCUS OF DISPUTE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/04/world.print_headline: POSITION OF STARK FOCUS OF DISPUTE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/04/world.body_text: **********Iraq is maintaining that the American frigate Stark was inside an exclusion zone near Iran when the ship was mistakenly attacked by an Iraqi jet, but the United States has strong evidence that the Stark was outside the zone, the Pentagon said today. **********''The essential difference in the U.S. and Iraqi versions of what occurred in the attack on U.S.S. Stark concerns the exact locations of both the Iraqi Mirage F-1 and U.S.S. Stark throughout the attack,'' said a detailed chronology released by the Defense Department. **********The chronology was based on the findings of Rear Adm. David Rogers, who recently returned from Baghdad where he led an American team in a joint inquiry by the two governments. **********Procedures have been devised to prevent another attack, according to the Pentagon. Procedures 'Very Sensitive' **********''We are convinced that, if approved by our two Governments, these measures will reduce to an absolute minimum the chances of another attack,'' said the four-page memorandum released today. ''However, the procedures themselves are very sensitive and we will not discuss them.'' **********One official said the United States will equip its naval vessels and merchant ships they escort with devices to broadcast identification signals, and that the Iraqis will be equipped to receive the signals. **********According to the Pentagon description of the attack on the Stark, the Iraqi pilot monitored emergency radio channels but never heard two signals by the Stark on those channels identifying herself. The pilot understood English, the language used in the signals, and an American surveillance plane confirmed that the calls were made. **********The American team that went to Baghdad did not interview the Iraqi pilot, but was told by Iraqi officials that he believed he was attacking an Iranian ship inside the exclusion zone, the Pentagon's memorandum said. **********The Iraqi version of the locations of the plane and the ship is based on data generated by the Mirage's navigating equipment, which Iraq says is ''highly reliable,'' the memorandum said. **********But the Pentagon said the United States ''remains certain'' that the ship was outside the exclusion zone, which runs down the Gulf parallel to Iran. The Awacs plane, the Stark herself, and two other American ships all placed the Stark 12 nautical miles west of the exclusion zone, the memorandum said. **********Iraq puts the ship's location more than 20 miles to the east, inside the exclusion zone, declared by Iran in an effort to protect its own shipping. **********The memorandum also revealed that the Iraqi pilot launched his first missile at the Stark from about 25 miles, farther than had been previously stated, and that the Stark's crew first became aware that she was being viewed by the aircraft's radar four minutes before the first missile hit. **********The Pentagon today identified three ships that are to depart for the gulf later this week to reinforce the naval squadron there. They are the destroyer Kidd, the frigate Klakring and the frigate Flatley.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/04/busin.body_text: **********The debt rescheduling accord struck last week between Poland and its Paris Club group of creditor governments covers more than $8 billion, a Polish Government spokesman, Jerzy Urban, said today. https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/12/world.main_headline: Reporter's Notebook: Foreigners in Tibet Protest
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/12/world.print_headline: Reporter's Notebook: Foreigners in Tibet Protest
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/12/world.body_text: **********Over the last three weeks, Lhasa has been shaken by three demonstrations against Chinese rule, protests led by shaven-headed monks from monasteries hammered into the mountains edging the north of the city. **********Because Buddhism exerts such a powerful and pervasive influence over the lives of most Tibetans, the moral authority of monks remains high. ''The monks show the way,'' was how one Tibetan here put it. **********But on the fringes of the protests and later working behind the scenes were some foreigners who believe in the cause of Tibetan independence. Many of them live in the white-block, three-story Banakshol Hotel, a haven for budget travelers and others who do not mind washing their clothes or brushing their teeth in the communal sinks in the hotel's courtyard. **********Three foreigners said in interviews that they had thrown stones at the Chinese police at the most violent demonstration on Oct. 1. **********During that protest, the Chinese police arrested monks who were leading pilgrims around the Jokhang Cathedral, Tibetan Buddhism's holiest shrine. Angered at the arrests, crowds of Tibetans formed in front of a police substation across an alleyway from the Jokhang and began throwing stones. Soon police vehicles were overturned and set afire, and the police station was set ablaze. **********Several foreigners asserted that they hung in the shadows of Jokhang doorways capturing on film the destruction of the police station and the reaction of the police, who fired small arms and automatic weapons into the crowd. At least nine Tibetans were killed by gunfire, and China now reports the death of six Chinese, most of whom are presumed to be policemen. **********The participation of the foreigners in the protests was well known in the monasteries around the city, monks said, and the monks there expressed admiration for their activities. **********''Tibetans protected the foreigners,'' one monk said. ''We helped them get away from the police.''  Shows of Strength **********As the demonstrations grew, the authorities in Beijing responded by sending 600 heavily armed policemen to Lhasa to maintain order. Last Sunday, three days after the burning of the police station, a Deputy Minister of Public Security flew to Lhasa. **********As the Deputy Minister arrived at Lhasa's airport, squads of policemen were there to welcome him, and the arrival was filmed for later broadcast on Lhasa television. **********Later in the week, he had his picture taken in front of the Jokhang Cathedral. Evidence that perhaps Lhasa had not returned to normal, as the Chinese said it had, was suggested when he appeared surrounded by dozens of policemen with assault rifles and machine pistols. **********Intimidation of the Tibetan populace increased on Wednesday, Oct. 7, the 37th anniversary of China's invasion of Tibet. A bit after midday, a convoy of open-bed trucks led by a station wagon, its rooftop red light spinning and its siren screaming, crawled down the main street of the city. On each of 13 trucks, 25 to 30 policemen stood rigidly at attention clutching AK-47 rifles. **********Tibetans lined the street, silently watching the procession of strength. There were no demonstrations that day.  Long Isolated, Then Open **********When the news of an anti-Chinese demonstration in Lhasa and the arrest of 21 monks reached Beijing on Sept. 29, foreign reporters were surprised that it was reported in some detail by the official Chinese press agency, which mostly devotes itself to glowing accounts of China's modernization efforts. **********Two days later, two reporters from The Associated Press and Agence France-Presse rushed to Chengdu, the first leg of the trip to Lhasa. There, they interviewed tourists returning from Lhasa and learned that a far more bloody demonstration had taken place on Oct. 1. Tourists provided vivid descriptions of battles between stone-throwing Tibetans and gun-firing policemen. There were reports of young monks being shot and two elderly monks escaping from the burning police station. **********With that report, nearly 20 foreign reporters based in Beijing all headed toward Lhasa, where more detailed descriptions of events were provided by tourists and by monks. **********From the 17th to the 19th centuries, Tibet was so isolated that only the fervent religiousity of Jesuit missionaries or the determined ambition of explorers drove Westerners toward this mysterious land. Surrounded by soaring snow-capped mountains, Lhasa became in the popular imagination a ''lost kingdom.'' **********The Chinese invasion of 1950 and the Chinese armed suppression of an independence movement in 1959 further sealed Tibet off from the world. **********Now, with daily flights in and out of Lhasa, Tibet has become a relatively easy destination. And though the Chinese authorities have now prevented foreign reporters from covering events in Tibet, there was a brief opening during which the story was brought to newspapers across the world. **********At first the authorities, whether through confusion or indecision, permitted journalists to file substantial reports on police brutality, the mood in monasteries and the overall situation in Lhasa. At the Lhasa Hotel, where foreign reporters were housed, Chinese officials ordered the two telexes shut down but permitted some telephone calls overseas. Meanwhile, officials at Lhasa's telecommunications office installed a second telex to handle the surge in business. **********Then on Tuesday, another protest took place at which 90 monks were arrested, many after being beaten by policemen wielding rifle butts, clubs and belts. Reports of this protest were transmitted by telex and telephone to the outside world. Then the Chinese authorities severed all links. **********Early Thursday morning, a senior Chinese official summoned all the reporters at the Lhasa Hotel to a meeting and told them they were expelled from Tibet for having failed to apply for permission to enter the province.  Fear of Chinese **********At the ancient monasteries just outside Lhasa, monks moved quietly through the dark corridors that lead between cavernous prayer halls and tiny sleeping chambers suffused with the fragrance of yak-butter lamps. **********Fear of the Chinese was palpable, with monks shepherding visitors into darkened corners. Here and there, the outlawed Tibetan flag peeked from behind a Buddha figure or adorned the wall of a chamber. **********Everywhere the talk was of the Dalai Lama, the exiled leader of Tibetan Buddhism, who was denounced by the Chinese for supposedly instigating the protests in Lhasa. **********At one monastery, a 63-year-old monk told two visitors: ''The Dalai Lama is the only one religious and political leader for us. The Chinese Government says the Tibetan people don't want independence. But everyone wants independence. Everyone loves the Dalai Lama.'' **********Sitting next to him on the sleeping pallet, another old monk, tears streaming, said: ''There are thorns all around us. If the Dalai Lama were here, it would all be flowers.''

A spokesman for Crazy **********Eddie, a New York electronics retail chain, said the company had no response. The company last held a shareholders meeting in July 1986. **********Entertainment Marketing's move was seen as another reaction to the falling stock price of Crazy Eddie. The company has been hurt by sliding sales and margins. **********The stock was selling at a record high of $21.625 a year ago. It closed today at $4.25 a share, up 12.5 cents. They were bought at an average price of $7.52. **********Under state law in Delaware, where Crazy Eddie is incorporated, if a company has not scheduled its stockholders meeting within 13 months of the prior one, shareholders can ask the court to order it to do so, said Cecil Schenker, the attorney for Entertainment Marketing.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/16/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Staff Cutbacks For Boeing Jet
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/16/busin.body_text: **********The Boeing Company said today that it was continuing to cut back the manpower being assigned to develop its futuristic 7J7 aircraft and said it was no longer predicting when the aircraft would be available. **********In August, Boeing had postponed the date of availability of the aircraft to 1993, from 1992. **********Today, however, Boeing declined to say when the aircraft would be available, indicating that further delays are likely. **********Boeing also said that employees working on the 7J7 would be consolidated with others into an Advanced Programs Organization, to work on that plane as well as others. The number of workers assigned to the 7J7 itself will be reduced to 300, from 600, after having already been reduced from 900, to 600, since August, said Jack Gamble, a Boeing spokesman. **********The 7J7 has been portrayed as Boeing's grand gamble to utilize advanced technology to keep itself at the forefront of the commercial aircraft industry. The key to the aircraft would be a new type of engine, known as a propfan. **********The 7J7 was supposed to be so advanced that customers would wait until the early 1990's for it, rather than buying Airbus Industrie's 150-seat A320, which will be available next year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/28/world.main_headline: Soviet Prices: Strawberries Are a Model
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/28/world.print_headline: Soviet Prices: Strawberries Are a Model
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/28/world.body_text: **********At the Central Market today, a vendor sat behind an assortment of choice strawberries, telling the few inquiring shoppers that the berries cost the equivalent of $5.50 a pound. There were few buyers, and no line. **********At the same time on a street out back, a Government truck pulled up and delivered 30 small crates of strawberries - some ripe, some overripe, some moldy - at $2.40 a pound. A scolding saleswoman shoveled them into the bags of customers who had formed a 15-minute line. **********The strawberry scene spoke eloquently of the bizarre anomalies of the Soviet pricing system and its byproducts: unreasonably high or low prices and long lines for products whose quality is uneven at best. Complex of Controls and Subsidies **********The rigid pricing system is a complex fabric of Government controls and subsidies with isolated patches of quasi-free market economies, including farm markets that sell produce from private plots. **********It is this system that Mikhail S. Gorbachev is proposing to alter with his program, newly endorsed by the Communist Party, to gradually introduce price flexibility in the Soviet economy. **********Inherent in the issue of prices, according to Western and Soviet analysts, are the key difficulties that face most of Mr. Gorbachev's initiatives in his broad drive to remake Soviet society: *********** Reining in a powerful bureaucracy, in this case the State Committee for Prices, known by the acronym Goskomtsen. It sets more than 200,000 wholesale and retail prices annually, on everything from raw materials like ore and grain to bread, shoes, chinaware and cars. *********** Potentially tampering with a basic tenet of Communist ideology and the Soviet social contract, in this case overall price stability and drmatically low prices on basic foods, housing, education and mass transit. *********** Taking a cumbersome, inefficient but predictable system and introducing an element of the unknown, in this case, a limited role for competitive forces and the possibility of politically explosive inflation. Food price increases in Eastern Europe have sometimes touched off protest and political instability. 'Jumping Out Into the Unknown' **********A Western diplomat predicted last week that conservatives would call the pricing innovations a threat to the basic order of Communism. The current system, he said, is a known quantity, but Mr. Gorbachev's proposals are ''jumping out into the unknown.'' **********The new pricing policies, like most of the sweeping changes, have not been worked out in enough detail to be made law during a session next week of the Supreme Soviet, the nominal Parliament. **********The one economic law the Supreme Soviet is expected to enact will allow the state's enterprises greater freedom to manage their own affairs, chose their managers and offer bonuses to their workers. **********How fast and how far Mr. Gorbachev will jump on the price issue is still under discussion, according to Abel G. Aganbegyan, the economist who was selected to explain Mr. Gorbachev's new proposals at a news conference. **********Mr. Aganbegyan explained that the alternatives under discussion were either a stage-by-stage shift in the present pricing mechanisms, with the first stage affecting only wholesale prices, or an overall re-examination of wholesale, retail and agricultural prices, with no changes before 1990. Instrument of Efficiency **********The guidelines for Mr. Gorbachev's economic changes, approved Friday by the Communist Party's Central Committee, said prices should be made ''an effective instrument for raising the efficiency of social production, for developing economic management methods and for deepening cost-accounting and self-financing.'' **********The role of the price-fixing committee would be reduced in part by increased freedom of factories and large enterprises to contract directly with each other for industrial goods. **********The Central Committee program said that wholesale prices should be amended to reflect production costs more accurately and that raw materials and fuel - such as heating oil -should be priced to reflect production cost and to discourage waste. Little Incentive on Costs **********Until now, according to American specialists, wholesale prices were supposed to be roughly equivalent to production cost. But there was little incentive to keep costs down because of widely available subsidies. **********In contrast, retail prices were supposed to be set at a level that would guarantee a balance between supply and demand. This was a goal that was largely unmet, judging by the periodic shortages of everything from fruit to furniture. **********Prices were also used to insure that some products were accessible to low-paid workers. Meat in state stores in Moscow and other cities sells at less than half the cost of production. Like other foods, particularly bread, it is heavily subsidized. But buyers often have to wait in line for meat that is of low quality, if available at all. In farmers' markets, it is likely available but higher priced. $115 Billion in Subsidies According to Mr. Gorbachev's speech Thursday, the Soviet economy spends 72 billion rubles a year (more than $115 billion) in subsidies. More than 50 billion rubles of this goes to agriculture. **********The farm subsidy has increased 150 percent in the last 10 years, and is now more than 12 times the 1966 level of four billion rubles, according to articles in the Soviet press. **********''What is happening?'' asked a professor of economics, R. Khasbulatov, writing in Komsomolskaya Pravda. ''Agricultural productivity is virtually at a standstill'' and the inefficiency is forcing up subsidies. **********He said such subsidies were paid for in part by inflated prices on goods like imported jeans (marked up sevenfold) and similar products. **********The average wage is slightly under 200 rubles a month, or $310. Even with subsidies, about 30 percent of the total is spent on food, according to a 1985 survey - compared with 19 percent by American families, economists said. Risks of Social Unrest **********To increase the prices of bread and meat, for example, which have changed little in decades, without increasing salaries is to ask for social unrest. In Poland in 1976, an increase in food prices was canceled after widespread protests, strikes and, in one city, riots. **********But to increase salaries means increased prices for the goods the workers produce - and the essential elements for inflation are then present. **********What about inflation? The word did not appear in the discussion of prices in the Central Committee blueprint. The most it would caution was: ''It is necessary . . . to overcome the tendency toward the growth of prices on the basis of the development of the competitive power of enterprises.'' **********This was a prescription for letting competition achieve price cuts.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/26/busin.main_headline:
WHAT'S NEW IN PRIVATE PRISONS;
WEEKEND WORK WITHOUT TRIPLE PAY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/26/busin.print_headline:
WHAT'S NEW IN PRIVATE PRISONS;
WEEKEND WORK WITHOUT TRIPLE PAY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/26/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: RUNNING prisons is not the only way to make money from the prison system. Nowadays, hotels, computer companies and manufacturers are also profiting from incarceration. They are hiring inmates, usually below minimum wage and with no extra pay for weekends or holidays, to provide goods and services at a fraction of normal costs. **********RUNNING prisons is not the only way to make money from the prison system. Nowadays, hotels, computer companies and manufacturers are also profiting from incarceration. They are hiring inmates, usually below minimum wage and with no extra pay for weekends or holidays, to provide goods and services at a fraction of normal costs. Moreover, since the work is typically done inside the correction facility, overhead costs are virtually nil. **********The idea of prison labor is not new, of course. Most state governments in the 19th century contracted out convicts to mines, sweatshops and farms. Later, prisoners were used in state-run industries to make license plates, road signs and other public goods. In fact, half the states still will not let prisoners make goods for sale to the general public. **********But in the other half, prisoners are busily making lamps, shoes and other items for retail consumption. Some are even staffing phones and computers. **********For example, Best Western International in Phoenix, which operates 1,900 hotels in North America, installed computer terminals in the Arizona Center for Women, a pre-release center, in 1981. It pays 30 inmates $4.50 an hour to serve as telephone reservation operators. ''Especially during the peak season in the summer, we need to call people into work at a moment's notice, '' said company spokeswoman Lois Kein. ''Temporary workers can't just drop what they're doing and come in.'' **********Best Western apparently is pleased with the way the prisoners handle the job. It has employed 16 former inmates to work full-time. **********States that buy the output of prison industries often find their own supply costs drastically slashed. Three years ago Florida shifted control of all prison industries to Prison Rehabilitative Industries and Diversified Enterprises (PRIDE). The nonprofit organization uses inmates to produce more than 46 types of goods, including shoes, metal furniture and car tags. The wares are sold to public agencies. **********Last year PRIDE sold 1.2 million pairs of shoes and work boots at prices ranging from $13.25 to $18.75, several dollars cheaper than American competition. It could charge that price because it paid inmates between 55 cents and $1.10 an hour. **********However, James McDonie , director of national sales for PRIDE, quickly points out that wage rates for regular workers in some countries are even lower. **********''It's wrong to believe that inmate labor is a whole lot cheaper,'' he said. ''We're competing against Hong Kong and South Korea.'' **********Indeed, even behind bars, prisoners are part of an international economy. The Control Data Corporation in Minnesota used inmates at the Stillwater prison to assemble computer components, but that program ended seven months ago when the manufacturing of those products was shifted to Portugal. **********Other prisoners have discovered the perils of corporate mergers. In 1984, Howard Johnson's Inc. established a telephone reservation operation at the Mabel Bassett Correctional Center in Oklahoma City. The program ended the next year, when the company was bought by the Marriott Corporation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/10/world.main_headline: A FALL GUY YES, A PATSY NO, A PRESIDENT'S SERVANT SAYS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/10/world.print_headline: IRAN-CONTRA HEARINGS; A FALL GUY YES, A PATSY NO, A PRESIDENT'S SERVANT SAYS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/10/world.body_text: **********He was willing to take the hit. He was ready to be dropped like a hot rock. He would play the ''fall guy,'' as he put it in tough-guy lingo, allowing his superiors to finger him on a scheme that was going down the tubes. **********But Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North would not play the patsy. **********''When I heard the words criminal investigation,'' he told the Iran committee today, ''my mindset changed considerably.'' **********''There was probably not another person on the planet Earth as surprised as I was to hear that someone thought it was criminal,'' he said. ''And that I was the only person on the planet Earth named on that appointment order.'' **********Colonel North, who has turned the Iran committee hearings into electrifying theater, did not disappoint today. Cast no longer as a flip and combative cowboy blithely bending the law, the colonel now presented himself as the earnest servant of the President -with an affecting crack in his voice -seeking to convince a thickheaded Congress that he was being railroaded. Subtle Combat **********He had a worthy opponent in Arthur L. Liman, who clearly felt he needed to wrest back some of the sympathy Colonel North has won this week. The colonel jutted his chin out and the counselor tucked his in. But their combat was subtle and soft-voiced, for the most part, as if Mr. Liman had decided he could not win with the aggressive, condescending manner that often characterized his questioning on previous occasions. **********John W. Nields Jr., the gentlemanly House counsel, had been expected on Tuesday and Wednesday to play the good cop, but he was often aggressive - possibly because he was genuinely angry at times. Now Mr. Liman, whom the heralds had cast as the hard guy, played Mr. Nields's expected role - a neat and surprising reversal. His questions were pointed but his manner mild. Liman Changes Tactics **********Mr. Liman, who had been a caustic and stabbing interrogator with other witnesses, like Maj. Gen. Richard V. Secord, changed tactics with the popular Marine officer. The public, he apparently realized from the flood of calls and letters coming into the committee office, felt the colonel was being unfairly picked on. In May, indeed, Mr. Liman also received a flood of letters complaining that he had badgered and mistreated General Secord, a retired Air Force major general who was the first witness before the committees. **********Today, Colonel North's lawyer, Brendan V. Sullivan Jr., tried once more to portray his client as the beleaguered victim of Congressional bullying. ''Why don't you get off his back?'' Mr. Sullivan snapped at his interrogators. **********So Mr. Liman cleverly acted the high school principal with the errant schoolboy - trying to make Colonel North see his errors despite the colonel's continuing protests that he had done nothing illegal or wrong in the diversion of funds to the Nicaragan rebels. 'Go Stand in the Corner' **********''And have you wondered why, if it was a good idea,'' Mr. Liman said, silkily, ''that the President of the United States dismissed you because of it?'' **********The colonel replied: ''If the Commander in Chief tells this lieutenant colonel to go stand in the corner and sit on his head, I will do so.'' **********Mr. Liman also asked - in that sympathetic voice with the edge of the disciplinarian - why the witness did not confront Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter upon learning that his boss had not received the approval of the President on memos as he had thought. Giving a Civics Lesson **********''I'm not in the habit of questioning my superiors,'' Colonel North replied at one point. ''If he deemed it not to be necessary to ask the President, I saluted smartly and charged up the hill.'' **********The lawyer spoke to the younger man as though he were giving him a civics lesson. **********''And you would agree with the proposition, wouldn't you, that in our desire to promote democracy abroad, including Nicaragua and elsewhere, we must never sacrifice our democratic values here?'' he asked, as the Colonel nodded. **********But while Mr. Liman may have achieved the impression that Colonel North's superiors were painting him as a ''loose cannon'' to save themselves, Colonel North remained protective of his former bosses. **********''That is the part of any subordinate,'' he said. ''Every centurion had a group of shields out in front of him - a hundred of them.'' **********He said he did not think that the former national security advisers Robert C. McFarlane and Admiral Poindexter ''would have ever placed me in jeopardy of a criminal prosecution.'' Painting North as Delinquent **********He said he was willing to ''take the rap'' in the political arena, but not in the criminal courts. **********Mr. Liman asked the colonel if he had not winced when he was read the section of the Tower Commission report that quoted the President as saying he knew nothing about the National Security Council staff's efforts on behalf of the contras. **********''I don't know what you read in my wince,'' Colonel North snapped. ''It may have been that my back hurt.'' **********Mr. Liman was at his sharpest, acting appalled and moving in to paint Colonel North as very delinquent, when the witness jauntily confessed that he had shredded documents from his files even while the Justice Department officials were in his office collecting files for evidence. Fairness Was 'Out the Window' **********''That's a pretty high-speed shredder,'' the colonel said, smiling. ''It eats 'em pretty quick.'' **********Colonel North's lawyer, Mr. Sullivan, testily objected to the committee on the slightest hint that the colonel was being bullied - telling Mr. Lyman he was ''in dreamland'' and that, with Congress, fairness was ''out the window.'' **********In his opening statement, Colonel North continued to present himself as a selfless patriot, the servant of ''a great President'' - better able than Congress to judge the needs of the United States - ''a nation at risk'' in a ''dangerous world.'' 'Son of Checkers' **********Colonel North's opening statement was dubbed ''Son of Checkers'' by skeptics in the chamber - because of its similarity in tone to Richard M. Nixon's famous speech of 35 years ago, in which the issue of whether he should have accepted money from wealthy contributors got lost in a melodramatic miasma about his wife's cloth coat and his cocker spaniel. The Colonel's Best Friend **********With his wife sitting behind him, making her first appearance at the hearings, the Colonel said, ''My best friend is my wife, Betsy, to whom I have been married for 19 years, and with whom I have had four wonderful children, aged 18, 16, 11 and 6.'' **********Colonel North has been drawing better ratings on television than the daytime soap operas, and he is drawing ever bigger crowds in person. Many Drive Long Distances **********Although the reaction to him on his first day was mixed, today it was leaning positive. Many had driven long distances just to see Colonel North, and commented sympathetically that he looked emotionally drained and must be worried about the terrorist threats on his life and the legal threats to his liberty. **********''He has revealed names from higher up,'' said 20-year-old Kathleen Moore from Miami. ''He's definitely not going to take the rap alone.'' **********Michael Wilson, a 12-year-old from Pasadena, Calif., agreed, saying, ''I think Reagan should be in there testifying.'' A Patriot Not a Profiteer **********Some of the committee members remained immune to the witness's legendary charm. **********''He thought he was a separate Secretary of State,'' sniffed Jack Brook, a Texas Democrat. **********But others melted under Colonel North's insistence that he was patriot, not profiteer. **********''He handled himself very well -he's articulate and intelligent and presents himself in a very smooth way in being able to turn questions that should go one way into a more positive vein,'' said Louis Stokes, Democrat of Ohio. **********Representative Henry J. Hyde, Republican of Illinois, called the Colonel ''one of those people like Douglas McArthur or F.D.R.,'' adding: You either love him or hate him. It's hard to be indifferent.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/17/world.print_headline: Gorbachev Says 1987 Could See Arms Pact
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/17/world.body_text: **********Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, said today that a treaty eliminating medium-range nuclear missiles could still be worked out this year by the superpowers, and that an accord to cut long-range weapons was possible early next year. **********Mr. Gorbachev made the statement in an article published in the Soviet press today in conjuction with the opening of the 42d session of the United Nations General Assembly. It was treated as a major pronouncement and was issued by the official press agency Tass. **********Mr. Gorbachev said a treaty eliminating American and Soviet medium- and shorter-range nuclear missiles was ''possible and realistic.'' **********''The Soviet Union is proceeding from the premise that a relevant treaty could be worked out before the end of the current year,'' he said. **********He described as ''conducive to a certain extent'' West Germany's announcement last month that it would not seek to modernize its 72 Pershing 1A missiles equipped with American nuclear warheads. Elimination of those weapons is one of the sticking points in completing an agreement. **********''The treaty on medium- and shorter-range missiles would be a fine prelude to a breakthrough at the talks on large-scale - 50 percent - reductions in strategic offensive arms in conditions of the strict observance of the ABM treaty,'' he said. **********''I believe that, given a mutual striving, an accord on that matter could become a reality as early as in the first half of the next year,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/11/world.main_headline: 'Leave Us in Peace,' Costa Rican Pleads
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/11/world.print_headline: 'Leave Us in Peace,' Costa Rican Pleads
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/11/world.body_text: **********President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica accepted the Nobel Peace Prize today with a plea of ''utmost urgency'' that the superpowers cease intruding in Central America and ''send our people plowshares instead of swords.'' **********''If they, for their own purposes, cannot refrain from amassing the weapons of war, then, in the name of God, at least they should leave us in peace,'' said the 46-year-old President, who was the architect of the peace accord signed in Guatemala Aug. 7 by five Central American nations. **********Mr. Arias used the acceptance ceremony in the ornate Aula chamber of the University of Oslo to address himself directly to the United States and the Soviet Union to ''leave the interpretation and implementation of our peace plan to us.'' **********He mentioned neither superpower by name, but he had made his concern explicitly clear in remarks here Wednesday, particularly in cautioning the Reagan Administration that its continued attempt to send arms to the rebels in Nicaragua was undermining the Guatemala accord, which aims at a regional cease-fire and negotiations. An Audience of 700 **********''I say to them with the utmost urgency: Let Central Americans decide the future of Central America,'' he declared of the superpowers in a brief, simple acceptance speech delivered to 700 guests led by King Olav V. ''Support the efforts for peace instead of the forces of war in our region,'' Mr. Arias pleaded, speaking in English in a slow, grave tone. ''Send our people plowshares instead of swords, pruning hooks instead of spears.'' **********The President was honored with this year's medal and $340,000 award after he successfully persuaded the leaders of Nicaragua, Guatemala, Honduras and El Salvador to join with him in signing the regional accord. **********The pact, to be carried out in full by January, aims at cease-fires in the civil wars of Nicaragua, El Salvador and Guatemala, amnesty for guerrilla fighters and the furtherance of such democratic ideas as a free press and the release of political prisoners. **********The key to it, he told the Nobel audience, is not peace to be followed ''someday'' by political progress. Rather, he said it promised ''peace and democracy, together, indivisible, an end to the shedding of human blood, which is inseparable from an end to the suppression of human rights.'' To Use Money for Needy **********For all the speculation and publicity that greets the Peace Prize each year, the award ceremony itself is unpretentious. Mr. Arias, who intends to use the money to start a foundation for the needy, reflected the day's simplicity in a speech of roughly 800 words, one of the shortest on record. **********The Nobel committee made no secret of the fact that it made the award in part to endorse the region's attempt to supersede East-West rivalry in the area by engineering its own peace plan. **********''The plan is a signpost in the work for peace the whole world over,'' Egil Aarvik, chairman of the Nobel committee, declared in presenting the award. He said few regions of the world have had worse experiences of civil war in recent years.
