https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/14/busin.body_text: **********The Economy **********The Administration indicated it wants the dollar to fall further. But Administration sources, who cited worry about the record trade deficit, would not say how much they wanted the currency to decline. Since Christmas, the dollar has been dropping relentlessly against the world's second most widely used currency, the West German mark.  [ Page A1. ]  The dollar sagged further on world markets despite intervention by the Bank of Japan. In New York, gold rose $2.05, to $410.55 an ounce.  [ D1. ]  Rates fell on Treasury bills and rose for long-term notes and bonds as the effect of the dollar's decline became more pronounced in the credit markets.  [ D19. ] **********U.S. efforts to curb high-technology exports are criticized in a report by the National Academy of Sciences. Pentagon officials, in turn, reacted adamantly to the criticism, contending that the loss of military technology to the Soviet bloc could be accelerated if the report's recommendations were put into effect.  [ D1. ] **********The Fed's two vacancies are likely to be filled by Leif H. Olsen, formerly the top economist at Citibank, and Edward W. Kelley, an investment adviser from Texas, according to Government and business sources. And prospects appear to have dimmed that Beryl W. Sprinkel, the President's chief economic adviser, will be chosen to succeed Paul A. Volcker as Fed chairman.  [ D1. ] **********The I.R.S. is stepping up the fight on tax evaders. Using its computers and other data, the agency plans to hunt down the one million Americans who fail to file income tax returns each year.  [ D2. ] **********The Supreme Court upheld a California law requiring employers to grant up to four months of unpaid leave to women who are disabled by pregnancy and childbirth.  [ A1. ]  The Court struck down New York State rules on liquor pricing that it said allowed wholesalers to dictate artificially high retail prices.  [ B1. ] Companies **********A.T.&T. has banned pregnant women from chip production, citing a University of Massachusetts study that found a sharply higher incidence of miscarriages among workers who produce computer chips. As a result of the study, in recent weeks numerous semiconductor makers have offered pregnant women the option of moving out of areas where silicon chips are made.  [ D1. ] **********The Owens-Illinois board will weigh a sweetened bid from Kohlberg, Kravis, but its meeting date was not disclosed. Owens-Illinois stock recovered, rising $3.125, to $54.25.  [ D1. ] **********The semiconductor industry's leading indicator rebounded strongly in December, indicating growing demand.  [ D5. ] **********Control of three LTV pension funds was seized by the Federal Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation.  [ D5. ] **********VF's Wrangler jeans unit will close eight plants in Arizona and North Carolina and dismiss up to 1,200 employees.  [ D5. ] Markets **********Stock prices closed mixed, although the Dow Jones industrial average rose an eighth straight time. Despite a 3 7/8-point decline by I.B.M. stock, the blue-chip Dow index gained 3.52, to close at a record 2,012.94. Volume was 170.9 million shares.  [ D8. ] **********Energy prices retreated as profit takers took advantage of the recent oil rally.  [ D16. ]  Technology **********Sony faces another lonely battle in video cassettes. The company, whose Beta format has been outsold 10 to 1 by VHS, may be falling behind in video cameras, too. Consumers have begun to choose the VHS Compact format over Sony's 8-millimeter version.  [ D6. ] **********Miniature, hand-held photocopiers have come to America. The gadgets, which were status symbols last year in Japan, are expected to appeal to students, traveling executives, engineers and contractors. Advances.  [ D6. ] Today's Columns **********The disparity between a roaring bull market and a sluggish economy is not perceived as a contradiction by analysts who see sustained growth ahead. But others say the market is bound to crash sooner or later. Leonard Silk. Economic Scene.  [ D2. ] **********The beneficiaries of the market's surge include the long-depressed oil-service stocks as well as stocks in such ''niche'' sectors as check printers and coffin makers. Market Place.  [ D8. ]

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/19/busin.body_text: **********In France, Jacques Stern is admired as a corporate savior for rescuing Groupe Bull, the country's largest computer company, from the brink of bankruptcy. While that was quite a feat, many in the computer industry say that he faces a far tougher task in trying to resurrect Honeywell Bull Inc. **********That is the name of the company that was formed in late March when Minneapolis-based Honeywell Inc. spun off its Information Systems division to a newly formed joint venture owned by Bull, the NEC Corporation of Japan and Honeywell. **********But the venture represents much more than a new name and ownership structure for Honeywell's computer business. Perhaps even more important, it represents a powerful alliance among these three large computer makers, which plan to pool much of their research-and-development, production and marketing activities. **********Although this alliance creates one of the world's biggest players in the computer business, many in the industry say its size hardly guarantees its success. Competing With Giants **********Indeed, the most immediate challenge facing Mr. Stern, who is chairman of both Bull and the Honeywell Bull joint venture, is avoiding being trampled by two other computer powers: giant International Business Machines and Digital Equipment, the Maynard, Mass., company that has been dazzling the market with its new array of products. **********Bull, which dominates the consortium, must still prove that it can compete on the merits of its technology rather than its political connections. While Bull is certainly a leader in Europe, the French Government played a major role in its revival - by steering most of its business Bull's way and twisting French businessmen's arms to buy from the company. **********In the United States, Mr. Stern faces an even more daunting challenge: reversing Honeywell's shrinking market share, which has plummeted to 2.5 percent, from 7 percent a decade ago. **********One reason for that decline is that Honeywell, with information-processing sales of $2 billion, has had trouble keeping apace of much larger I.B.M. and Digital in developing state-of-the-art products. Moreover, with Honeywell's survival in computers in question for so long, many key customers and employees abandoned what they thought was a sinking ship. 'Very Late in the Game' **********''It's not quite a long shot for the joint venture to turn things around, but it's very late in the game to be starting over,'' said George F. Colony, a consultant with Forrester Research Inc. in Cambridge, Mass. **********Mr. Stern readily acknowledges that Honeywell Bull has its problems, including a dispirited marketing staff. Still, he is unfazed by the doomsayers. Many people were similarly pessimistic about Bull when the French Government named him head of the state-controlled company in 1982, Mr. Stern recalled. **********Now, he is confident that he can revive Honeywell's computer business by using many of the strategies he used to resuscitate Bull. Indeed, the new joint venture has already stopped the market-share slide in the United States, he asserted. How? Just by persuading customers that its owners are committed to staying in the business, according to Mr. Stern. **********''When you invest in the computers, you want to make sure you choose the right vendor, someone who will be around for the long term,'' he said. ''Our joint venture has reassured customers because they see we are committed to the business.'' **********Not that such commitment is enough to insure Honeywell Bull'ssurvival in a world were I.B.M. is king, said the 55-year-old Mr. Stern, who ran his own successful software company before joining Bull. **********Still, Mr. Stern is hoping that Honeywell Bull - and the Bull-NEC-Honeywell alliance - can capitalize on computer users' fears of a world in which the only choice might be I.B.M. Many users also want ''open systems'' - or ones capable of tying together equipment from four or five companies. **********''One of our strategic choices is to be open to other suppliers,'' said Francis Lorentz, Bull's chief operating officer and Mr. Stern's right-hand man. ''We think customers want freedom. They don't want to be trapped by one supplier.'' **********Mr. Stern also hopes to capitalize on the increasing importance of distributed data processing and networking - or the movement by computer users to replace the big, central mainframe computer with an array of smaller computers that are tied together. Turnkey Systems Stressed **********Finally, Mr. Stern does not want Honeywell Bull simply to sell computers. Rather, he wants it to provide customers with so-called turnkey systems - or complete hardware-software packages tailored to solve customers' specific problems. **********Jerome J. Meyer, the longtime Honeywell manager who is Minneapolis-based Honeywell Bull's chief executive, sees eye to eye with his French colleagues on this strategy. ''A lot of customers do not want to talk about the need for more processors or more memory but about 'How do I link my three plants together? or How do I get rid of my inventory bulge?' '' the 49-year-old Mr. Meyer said. **********These strategies are hardly radical. Almost every major computer company in the world now asserts it is a maker of systems that offer total solutions, rather than just computers. **********Still, in Europe, Bull is one of the acknowledged leaders in marketing open systems, networking and turnkey solutions. Indeed, it has been in the forefront of pushing European computer makers to adopt international standards so computers made by different companies can be tied together. **********The big question, of course, is whether Honeywell Bull can do the same in the United States, where Digital, in particular, has been successfully taking the same approach? **********Indeed, many analysts say that Mr. Stern may find the going a lot tougher in the United States than in Europe. ''Stern has been a good, hard-hitting, no-nonsense chief executive who has understood the European markets well,'' said Ann Courtright, research director for the Yankee Group, the Boston-based market-research and consulting concern. ''But the American markets are different; they are much more competitive. In Europe, you compete against I.B.M. In America, you compete against I.B.M., Digital and a lot of smart, well-financed start-ups like Apollo.'' **********For that reason, Honeywell Bull needs to be a strong marketer - a talent it has lacked. ''They haven't shown the superaggressive marketing you need to take accounts from I.B.M. or Digital,'' Ms. Courtright said. **********Mr. Stern said he planned to devote a lot of his energies to revitalizing Honeywell Bull's marketing staff. But he also stressed that Honeywell Bull had its strengths, including its base of 10,000 Honeywell customers. **********Bull and Honeywell Bull's market strengths also complement each other, he said, noting that, while Bull is strong in serving the Government and banking and insurance industries, Honeywell is important in manufacturing. **********''Honeywell's installed base is large enough to support a satisfactory growth rate provided the new company can keep coming up with cost-effective, up-to-date products,'' said Ulrich Weil, a Washington-based analyst. Competitive Products Needed **********But many analysts wonder whether Honeywell Bull can come up with competitive products when Honeywell itself could not. In response, Mr. Meyer, Honeywell Bull's chief executive, said the joint venture, as part of the Bull-NEC-Honeywell alliance, had the size and critical mass that Honeywell alone lacked. **********The joint venture will start with $2 billion in revenues, while Bull, the dominant owner with a 42.5 percent share, has revenues of $3 billion. (Honeywell also has a 42.5 percent stake, but under the terms of the agreement, Bull will increase its share to 65.1 percent and Honeywell's will drop to 19.9 percent in two years. NEC owns the remaining 15 percent.) Mr. Meyer said the joint venture could cut costs by consolidating factories and product lines and teaming up with Bull and NEC in research and development. NEC will focus on developing top-of-the-line mainframes, and the joint venture will spend about $500 million a year developing the rest of the computer line. **********Some industry experts caution, however, that getting the three partners to cooperate might not be so easy. Martyn Roetter, a computer consultant with Arthur D. Little, said, ''Meyer has to balance the interests of three different owners, and he has to be able to extract from the three owners the money and resources to insure'' the joint venture ''can get the kind of marketing and products it needs.'' Difficulty Downplayed **********Mr. Meyer and Mr. Stern play down the difficulty of this task, noting that the three companies have a long history of cooperating and are eager for the joint venture to work. **********Indeed, Honeywell was a major Bull shareholder before Bull was nationalized. Bull's leaders also point out that Honeywell, Bull and NEC have long shared technologies and marketed many of one other's products. ''It will be easier for us to tie our product lines together than it would be for two competing companies that merge, like Sperry and Burroughs,'' Mr. Stern said.  Bull officials said they had long wanted to expand outside of France, and they seized the opportunity when Honeywell decided to reduce its role in computers. Bull officials saw expanding beyond France as crucial to Bull's achieving the critical mass and economies of scale they believed it needed to survive in computers. **********Honeywell, which did not sell the military part of its computer business, received $527 million in the deal, 28 percent below book value. Bull paid $131 million. NEC, which wanted to strengthen its marketing presence in the United States, paid $46 million. And Honeywell Bull gave Honeywell $350 million in the form of a negotiated loan. **********If the Honeywell deal had come along a few years ago, Bull could never have pursued it. At current exchange rates, Bull lost $198 million in 1982 and about $100 million a year in 1983 and 1984. But thanks to Mr. Stern's strategies, Bull earned $18 million in 1985 and $45 million last year. **********When it looked as if Bull would go under in 1982, the French Government - interested in saving 20,000 jobs and the French computer industry - acquired most of Bull's shares. Bull had almost $1 billion in debt, and no bank was willing to lend it more to tide it over. **********Since 1982, the Government has pumped $600 million into Bull and has left Mr. Stern alone to chart its strategy. Now the company, which is scheduled for to be sold to the public sometime after 1988, is estimated to be worth $1.2 billion. So the Government stands to make a respectable profit. **********Now Mr. Stern hopes he can make a respectable profit on his investment in Honeywell Bull.  The Partners in the Honeywell Bull Joint Venture  The Strengths of Each  Compagnie des Machines Bull  (42.5% Interest)* *********** Networking expertise *********** Turnkey solutions *********** Major positions in West Germany and France  Honeywell Information Systems  (42.5% Interest)* *********** $10 billion installed base *********** Day-to-day management team  N.E.C.  15% Interest *********** High-end mainframes *********** Research and Development clout  * Honeywell has the right, which its management has committed to exercise, to require Bull to buy an additional 22.6 percent of H.I.S. on Dec. 31, 1988, thus reducing Honeywell's share to 19.9 percent and raising Bull's to 65.1 percent.  Financial Standing of the Main Partners  Honeywell, the parent company of Honeywell Information Systems, reported a $398.1 million loss on sales of $5.38 billion in 1986 and cited a $407.7 million loss on the disposal of H.I.S. and a loss of $3 million on H.I.S. operations. Below, results of H.I.S. and Compagnie des Machines Bull.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/17/world.body_text: **********A former employee of Radio Marti, a branch of the Voice of America broadcasting exclusively to Cuba, charged today that the organization was using its staff to gather intelligence rather than convey information. **********The former employee, Hilda Inclan, who said she resigned as the station's Miami bureau chief this month, said she had been ''forced to instruct my reporters to do intelligence gathering rather than being simply reporters.'' Authorized by Congress in 1983 after a heated debate, Radio Marti began broadcasting to Cuba in May 1985. **********Ms. Inclan's charges were denied by Michael W. McGuire, spokesman for the Voice of America, which under the law is responsible for Radio Marti's programming. ''What Ms. Inclan says about Radio Marti's intelligence gathering is completely false,'' he said. Letter to Director **********Mr. McGuire indicated that what Ms. Inclan called ''intelligence gathering'' was really research about conditions inside Cuba. He said that two of the most successful programs beamed to Cuba, one on AIDS and the other on housing conditions on the island, were the result of both research and reporting. **********Speaking at a news conference, Ms. Inclan said that after April she noted that interviews by her reporters with Cuban refugees arriving by boats in Miami were not put on the air. When she complained in a letter to Radio Marti's director, Ernesto Betancourt, he replied that some refugees ''have been shown to be Castro infiltrators,'' she said. **********In May, Mr. Betancourt, in a letter to Perry Rivkind, district director of the Immigration and Naturalization Service in Miami, said that ''the only person authorized by Radio Marti to interview'' newly arrived Cuban refugees was Tony Rivera, chief of the station's research operations in Miami, because ''the arrival of raft people from Cuba is no longer newsworthy.'' **********Ms. Inclan said that Mr. Rivera was ''neither a reporter nor an editor'' and that according to Radio Marti's guidelines its Department of Research and Policy, which she said was larger than its news component, was not authorized to conduct interviews for broadcast purposes. Mr. McGuire called that statement ''irresponsible.'' Problems Called Endemic **********Ms. Inclan also said that problems between professional reporters and the top policy-making officials at Radio Marti were ''endemic.'' She said that ''most professional journalists have resigned from the station.'' **********''I don't think Radio Marti fulfills its function if the voices of newly arrived refugees and those of former political prisoners now in Miami are not allowed on the air,'' she said. ''I feel that the current Radio Marti practice of limiting refugee interviews to internal use has made it impossible for its Miami news bureau to do its job. The statutory language of the law creating Radio Marti makes it clear that Congress intended these interviews and the information they provide be broadcast to Cuba.'' **********Ms. Inclan, who has been a journalist for 20 years, received a performance award from Radio Marti last January. She became Miami bureau chief in January 1986.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/12/world.main_headline: MCFARLANE UNDER OATH: HE CHARTS A PLUNGE INTO PARALYSIS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/12/world.print_headline: MCFARLANE UNDER OATH: HE CHARTS A PLUNGE INTO PARALYSIS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/12/world.body_text: **********In his first appearance before the special committees on the Iran-contra affair, Robert C. McFarlane explained how the Administration's policy unfolded and gave his first extensive comments on the contra-supply operation. Here, as recorded by The New York Times, are excerpts from his testimony.  OPENING STATEMENT **********In the six months since the Iran-contra controversy erupted, many people have come to believe there is something wrong with the way that this country makes foreign policy. They probably don't know how wrong.  * * * **********Failures like those in the Iran-contra affair do not happen every day. But on any policy issue where party or ideological interest diverge substantially, the system is becoming increasingly subject to incoherence or paralysis.   $ ? * * * **********Individual mistakes, including my own, should of course be identified. But a solution to the fundamental problems that led to these investigations will require much more. It will require reform of institutions and processes. And most important, it will require change in the attitudes and behavior of the men and women who hold and exercise public power.   $ ? * * * **********A thorough and concerted analysis of our Nicaraguan problem would have produced a clear definition of U.S. interests in Nicaragua and identification of threats to those interests . . . But this type of fundamental Government-wide analysis was never made. Therefore, in December 1981, when the C.I.A. presented a proposal for initiating covert action in Nicaragua, there was no framework within which to analyze it. . . . **********There's little doubt in my mind that if we could not muster an effective counter to the Cuban-Sandinista strategy in our own backyard, it was far less likely that we could do so in the years ahead in more distant locations. There's a corollary to that proposition: For if we did prevail in Nicaragua, the President might go far toward inhibiting Soviet pursuit of this strategy in other areas. In short, there was a powerful and, to many, persuasive case that to lose in Nicaragua would invite the Soviets to step up their investment in aggression significantly in other developing nations of the world. We had to win this one. **********And this is where the Administration made its first mistake. For if we had such a large strategic stake, it was clearly unwise to rely on covert activity as the core of our policy. **********There are two basic reasons for this. The first is that you can never achieve a sufficient level of resources through a covert policy to cope with a determined effort backed by the Soviet Union. . . . The other reason . . . is that you cannot get public and Congressional support for such a policy. **********If you decide to engage in conflict with a Soviet client in whom the Russians are prepared to make a substantial investment, you must have the American people and the U.S. Congress solidly behind you. Yet it is virtually impossible, almost as a matter of definition, to rally public support behind a policy that you can't even talk about.  * * * **********The President repeatedly made it clear in public and in private that he did not intend to break faith with the contras. He directed that we continue, make continued efforts, to bring the movement into the good graces of Congress and the American people, and that we assure the contras of continuing Administration support, to help them hold body and soul together until the time when Congress would again agree to support them. **********Congressional restrictions made it impractical for either the Defense Department or the Central Intelligence Agency to function even as liaison with the contras. The State Department has always been disinclined to be associated with a covert action. But the President had made clear that he wanted a job done. The net result was that the job fell to the National Security Council staff. **********I think it's fair to say that this occurrence was not an example of an N.S.C. staff eagerly grabbing power from other departments and agencies. In the case of the contra operations, the N.S.C. was the agency of last resort. And it was not the right agency, as subsequent history clearly revealed. **********To carry out the President's wishes, I relied on two staff officers: Donald Fortier, now deceased, director of the political-military affairs division, and one of his deputies, Lieut. Col. Oliver North, whose existing responsibilities included Latin American military affairs. **********I told Mr. Fortier, who had a long, long experience in legislative relations, to oversee the effort to gain Congressional support. **********I told Colonel North to do two things. The first was to be a visible sign of the President's strong personal support, to show the contras that they would not be forgotten or abandoned, even though we could not provide them with financial support. **********The second, more specific, responsibility I gave Colonel North was to help the contras in their efforts to become a real political movement, genuinely respecting democratic principles and human rights. **********I did make a special point of stressing to my staff that we were to operate at all times within the law. And that, in particular, we were not to solicit, encourage, coerce or otherwise broker financial contributions to the contras.  $ ? * * * **********I regret, and I will continue to regret, the mistakes that I have made. But I must say this: The policy makers who create conditions like this must bear some of the moral responsibility for the failures that follow. **********We need a truce. We need a willingness once more to forge bipartisan coalitions that can govern responsibly. We need this incident, perhaps, to shock us into realizing that our short-sighted behavior could well take the country to the brink of disaster. **********Finally, we need to see that the present practices threaten to destroy our position of leadership among allies and put at risk even our ability to provide for own security.  QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS  A Country Called 2 **********ARTHUR L. LIMAN. Did you, in fact, succeed in obtaining money from another country, which we'll call Country 2? A. That's correct.  Q. And would you tell the committee how that happened? **********A. . . . The meetings that I held with the officials from Country 2 occurred about quarterly in my office, or in his, or at home. And in these meetings we would discuss . . . foremostly the region of the world where this country was resident - located; concerns that it had about its relationship with the United States, hopes that it had about assistance we could provide, in some arms sales and any of the dozen kinds of bilateral cooperation that was on his mind at the time... **********I would talk about some of our concerns about them and generally we would expand to talk about more distant countries and generally how the President was faring in his policies globally, politically at home and abroad... **********I did in fact make clear that it looked as though we were headed for a substantial setback - a defeat -regarding Congressional support for the contras . . . and because of that it would represent a substantial loss for the President. . . . **********He weighed that. He agreed. He said he would like to think about it and did so within a matter of days - two or three days, contacted me and made clear that he intended to provide a contribution of a million dollars per month, ostensibly from private funds, that would be devoted to - as a humanitarian gesture - to subsistence of the contras through the end of the year.   $ ? * * *  The Inner Circle **********Q. And when did you tell the President about this? And what did you tell him? **********A. I expect it was within a day - no more than a couple of days unless we were traveling - and in that meeting with the President I provided to him in writing a note card which made clear that Country 2 had chosen to volunteer some $1 million per month through the end of the year for contra subsistance. And after that meeting was over, I was called to come back and pick up the notecard which, as I recall it, expressed the President's satisfaction and pleasure that this had occurred. **********Q. Did you do it by slipping a notecard in there because you did not want to communicate it orally in the presence of others who were in the briefing meeting? **********A. That's correct.  $ ? * * * **********Q. Did you communicate to anyone else at that time besides Admiral Poindexter and the President that Country 2 had made this contribution? **********A. I believe within a day or so I also communicated it to the Vice President personally. **********Q. Did you communicate it to the Secretary of State at that time? **********A. I had a pattern of weekly breakfasts with the Secretaries of State and Defense with the three of us, our deputies and directors of political-military affairs usually, and at an early meeting on one of those Wednesdays following this episode, the question came up by one of those Cabinet officers and I drew them aside at the end of that breakfast and told them that it had been provided for through the end of the year. And neither gentleman pressed the matter further. **********Q. Did you tell them which country had provided for it through the end of the year? A. No, I did not.  Q. Did either Secretary ask you which country provided it? **********A. No, they did not.  * * *  Walking a Fine Line **********Q. Tell us exactly what kind of support you were to assure the contras of, during this period when you were prohibited from spending any money to support them. **********A. Well, basically it was smoke and mirrors. It was a matter of trying to demonstrate, simply by the presence of a White House person, someone close enough to the President to achieve, simply by dint of the proximity, credibility with the contra leaders . . . **********But I also made very clear that this has to be done within the law. and because I took the law to express what I had gotten personally from a number of members of Congress and the Senate, that we're cutting off money for the contras and we don't want any money raised for the contras, and bringing an end, really, to the contra movement and campaign was their purpose, through the purse string. **********Q. Now, you gave instructions to Colonel North on what he was supposed to do? **********A. Yes I did. * * * **********Q. Did you put any limitations on what Colonel North should do with respect to the contras? **********A. Only to stay within the law and to be particularly careful not to be associated with or take part in any fund-raising activities. **********Q. And did you tell him that he was not, as your statement indicates, to broker any contributions, or solicit contributions, or encourage contributions? **********A. It became a kind of litany of mine in staff meetings: solicit, encourage, coerce or broker. And it was applicable to everyone on the staff.   $ ? * * *  Doubling the Ante **********A. I was advised by a resident official of Country 2 that . . . they, Country 2, had elected to carry on with their contributions they had made but to be at about double the monthly level it had been in the previous year. **********Hearing of that, I advised the President, within a day or so . . . **********Q. Now, let's go over this again. The amount this time at $2 million a month was roughly $24 million, $25 million? Is that what you understood you were being offered? **********A. That is correct. I heard both figures mentioned later but soon after that news was reported to me by the foreign official, the Secretary of Defense here and the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs also told me they had heard the same thing, but their figure was 25. * * * **********Q. The Secretary of Defense told you he had heard about it directly? Am I correct? A. Yes sir. **********Q. . . . And the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff told you he knew of it? A. That's correct. Q. All right, did you tell the Secretary of State? **********A. No, I did not at that time. Later. * * * **********Q. The truth is that you didn't until sometime around June of 1986, is that correct? **********A. That's correct, yes sir. * * * **********Q. Why not tell the Secretary of State? A. Well, there's no reason not to.  Q. Well, what was in your mind, in terms of not telling him? **********A. Well, I think it was probably oversight, Mr. Liman, just error on my part. I had no personal inhibition about telling him. I think I should have. Q. Did you tell the D.C.I.? A. No I didn't. **********Q. Is it a fact that you regarded this source of funding as a matter to be held as a closely held secret? **********A. Yes I did.   $ ? * * * **********Q. And what about the Vice President? Did you feel obliged to tell him also? **********A. I'm not certain it was my habit to do that, but the Vice President was privy to whatever the President knew. . . .  Quid for a Quo **********Q. Were you uncomfortable about receiving the money from a third country? **********A. Well I believed strongly that we could not, and should not, expect to sustain the policy with this kind of support and that this had to be the last time. **********Q. Were you uncomfortable that you might be creating some implicit quid for a quo? **********A. Yes. You always have to consider what is it that you may invite by way of reciprocal gesture or concession. What obligation do you incur for having had some contribution of this kind, yes. **********Q. And as I understand the line that you were drawing, you couldn't come right out and say, ''I want a contribution?'' Am I correct? That would be a solicitation? A. That's correct. Q. But you could express the concerns about the fact that the contras were running out of funds? A. That's correct. Q. And if, in response to those concerns, the foreign leader offered the money, you could tell him where to deposit it? **********A. Well of course when it was legal the previous summer, he would have known that, so. **********Q. But you could tell him, ''thank you,'' when he offered it in February? **********A. Yes. * * *  A North Memo **********Q. After you received this memorandum from Oliver North in which he proposed going back to the Country 2 for $25 to $30 million, do you recall that you discussed the subject of third-country funding with the D.C.I., Mr. Casey? A. I don't believe I did, no.  Q. . . . Maybe this will refresh your recollection. Would you look at 36-A? Which is a memorandum of a meeting that you had with the director, prepared by his office. The meeting was March 21, and the North memorandum to you was dated March 16.  $ ? * * * **********Here you're being told by the director that if you rely on third countries for lethal support for the contras and it gets out, Congress could penalize those countries as well as the contras. Right?  A. Yes. **********Q. And you acknowledge that that was a serious issue. A. Uh huh.  Q. And that you would leave it to the President to decide. A. Yes.  Q. Did you bring it to the President? Do you have any recollection of that, sir? A. I know that I did not.  Q. Then why did you tell the D.C.I. that you were going to leave it to the President and not do it? **********A. Well, first, you assume that this is an accurate record there. It's the first time I've seen this document . . . **********I normally disagreed with the director on how a given matter ought to be taken on and promoted with the Congress. And I also found that it didn't do very much good to argue about it. And that the easy way to resolve a given conflict was just to acknowledge that the only way you're going to solve this is elevate it to the boss. Well, that would always at least get us on to the next agenda item.  * * *  On Playing God **********Q. Did there come a time when you received a call from an Israeli representative telling you that as a result an American hostage would be allowed to go free? * * * **********A. It was a report from Mr. Kimche in Israel that as a practical matter they had run into difficulties with the Iranian intermediaries - that nonetheless he believed that while his expectations that all hostages would be released had not been fulfilled or would not be fulfilled, that we ought to continue the dialogue with them anyway and that the United States could expect one hostage to be released within a couple of days. His call must have been on or about the 10th to 12th of September. **********Q. Were you asked to play God and choose one hostage? **********A. Yes. And I asked for Mr. Buckley. **********Q. And that was a subject of some anguish to be put in the position of having to choose? A. Yes. Q. And it brought home to you, I take it, what it really meant to be negotiating for hostages? **********A. Well it was very clear that this was not the kind of exchange that was proper. **********Q. And did you report to the President that as a result of the Israeli shipment, a hostage would be released? A. Yes, I did. Q. And you told him ultimately that it was Mr. Weir? **********A. Yes, I did.  * * *  Learning of Diversion **********Q. Did you have a discussion with Colonel North about the proceeds of the sale? **********A. Not truly a discussion, if you're referring to the tarmac exchange. That's a very short bit of news that I learned. **********Q. Where did it occur? And tell us in your own words what you recall of what Colonel North said. **********A. Well, we left Teheran in the morning, Teheran time . . . We got on the plane and went back to Israel. And upon arrival . . . the others in my party were unloading the baggage and personal effects from the aircraft. **********And I suppose I was obviously dispirited by the events in Teheran. And Colonel North, I think in an effort to be supportive, mentioned to me offhandedly that I shouldn't count it a total loss; that we are applying some of the funds from the Iranian connection to Central America, or words to that effect. **********And I was a little startled.  * * * **********A. Upon hearing Colonel North's statement that we don't have a problem, I said, you've got a problem with that channeling of money to the contras.   $ ? * * * **********Q. And when you said you have problem, what did you mean? What kind of problem? **********A. It just seemed to me that unless someone could stand up and say that this is on the basis of a finding, or is chartered by specific decision by the Admiral or the President, that I could not imagine this kind of thing being justified in law, or at least not that I had heard of. And - Q. Now, yet this was the same thing he told you originally in Teheran? A. Or on the tarmac, yes, in Israel.  Q. On the tarmac in Israel. And now some months later, you're telling him that he's got a problem and you can't imagine, unless there was some kind of finding or other authority that this would be lawful. Right? **********A. Yes.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/28/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY: PRINTOUTS; Computer Crime Is 'Big Business'
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/28/busin.body_text: **********In computers, at least, crime appears to pay. August Bequai, a Washington lawyer writing in ''Techno-Crimes'' (Lexington Books), estimates that the annual take of computer criminals could reach $5 billion a year. The greatest potential for high-technology thievery with minimal risk is in electronic fund transfering, Mr. Bequai says, where the average theft is measured in tens of thousands of dollars - dispelling the image of the computer criminal as a socially retarded teen-ager creating mischief from a suburban bedroom. **********The chances of being caught, on the other hand, are slim because local, state and even Federal law enforcement agencies lack the expertise, resources and jurisdiction to combat these sophisticated and shadowy criminals. The problem is fueled by an apparent lack of interest in computer security at many corporations, he concludes.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/09/busin.main_headline: Gould Inc. to Sell Division to Litton
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/09/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Gould Inc. to Sell Division to Litton
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/09/busin.body_text: **********Gould Inc., a computer maker based in Rolling Meadows, Ill., said it had agreed to sell its microwave products division to Litton Industries, based in Beverly Hills, Calif. The division, which employs about 300 people, makes gallium arsenide semiconductor products as well as microwave amplifiers and subsystems, primarily for military applications. **********Upon completion of the sale, terms of which were not disclosed, the Gould unit would become part of Litton's electron devices division, which is based in San Carlos, Calif. Litton would move its solid-state microwave group, which is a relatively small part of the division, to San Jose, Calif. Gould said the sale was part of the company's previously announced plan to divest itself of its military systems businesses.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/02/world.main_headline: Canada Tornado Death Toll 27; Search Goes On
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/02/world.print_headline: Canada Tornado Death Toll 27; Search Goes On
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/02/world.body_text: **********Hundreds of rescue workers dug through mounds of twisted rubble at a trailer park and an industrial area today that had been devastated by tornadoes that killed at least 27 people and injured more than 200. **********As many as five tornadoes swept in from the south with little warning Friday during a thunderstorm that pelted the city with fist-size hailstones, driven by winds up to 60 miles an hour, just as the evening rush-hour began. **********Mayor Laurence Decore said 20 people had been killed in Edmonton and 7 in the nearby industrial area to the southeast. **********More than 1,000 police officers, firefighters and other city workers helped hundreds of volunteers as rescue teams found 13 bodies at the trailer court, the worst-hit area, on the northeast edge of the city. At least seven others were killed in the city. Boxcars Tossed About **********The Royal Canadian Mounted Police also said there were seven dead south of the city, where a dozen homes were destroyed and farm buildings were leveled. **********Scores of cars, tractor-trailers, garbage trucks and boxcars from two stationary freight trains were tossed around like toys by the tornadoes, which touched down in at least seven places. Power, phone and water service were disrupted for hours. **********''Last night the city of Edmonton experienced its worst tragedy in memory,'' Mr. Decore said at a news conference. **********Edmonton is an oil and grain-farming city of 650,000 in central Alberta, on the western Canadian prairie. **********Reports of 34 confirmed deaths made by provincial and city emergency agencies early this morning were said to have resulted from confusion among rescue workers in reporting the number of bodies taken to hospitals and temporary morgues. #250 Trailers Wrecked ''Since reviewing the statistics and what happened, there was a duplication in reporting by ambulance and medical personnel,'' the Mayor said. **********He said at least 250 trailer homes had been destroyed at the Evergreen Mobile Home Park, where about 800 families lived. A tornado cut a 300-yard-wide swath through the grounds. **********Mountains of twisted metal, splintered wood, broken glass and household belongings were left behind by the tornadoes that moved for nearly an hour along the perimeter of Edmonton. **********Dogs were used in the search for victims, along with bulldozers and other heavy equipment. **********''We're fairly certain now that we've accounted for most if not all of the people'' at the two sites, Police Inspector Frank Topp said. **********He said the rescue effort was hampered by heavy traffic caused by torrential rains that flooded roads. A light rain was falling today.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/10/busin.body_text: **********A Soviet official said today that his country stood by its earlier estimate that 210 million metric tons of grain was produced in 1987. Valeriy Biryukov, head of the raw materials department of the Soviet trade delegation in London, said, ''Though we had bad weather, it was the same size as last year's crop.'' Next year's goal is 235 million tons, he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/03/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********The analysis of the hemorrhaging of America's high-tech skills (''Stopping the High-Tech Giveaway,'' March 22) fails to note the role of this nation's universities in the problem. Our colleges have actively recruited more than 340,000 foreign students. The largest fields of study are engineering, the physical sciences and computer science. **********Although most of these students remain here after graduation (and thus violate the terms of their student visas), a few countries insist that they return home. They then proceed to beat our brains out with the knowledge acquired from research work under a National Science Foundation grant. **********It seems wise to insist that all recipients of government grants be American citizens.  IRWIN FEERST   Massapequa Park, N.Y., March 23

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/06/world.main_headline: HOUSE DEMOCRATS PLAN VOTE ON A CONTRA-AID MORATORIUM
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/06/world.print_headline: HOUSE DEMOCRATS PLAN VOTE ON A CONTRA-AID MORATORIUM
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/06/world.body_text: **********The House Democratic leadership, settling on its strategy to fight continued aid to the Nicaraguan rebels, said today that the House would vote next week on a six-month moratorium on the release of $40 million in military aid that President Reagan formally requested today. **********But the Democratic leadership in the Senate is still undecided about its strategy, leaders acknowledged today that they might not have the votes to pass any proposal to block or delay the $40 million to the rebels, or contras. President Seeks Release of Funds **********The decision on strategy in the House came as President Reagan this afternoon formally requested release of the $40 million. **********Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, the House Republican leader, immediately criticized the Democrats' plan to vote on a moratorium. He said it ''was just a trick to let members think they can get off the hook'' by avoiding a straight vote on whether to approve or disapprove the $40 million. In a move to counter the moratorium vote, Mr. Michel filed his own resolution to force a vote on releasing the $40 million. **********The vote in the House next week and any voting on the issue that would follow in the Senate will be major tests of the power of the new leadership that took charge in Congress since the Democrats regained control of the Senate. **********For the White House, meanwhile, the votes will be the first trial for the new leadership Mr. Reagan has brought in to help him recover from the Iran-contra affair. **********Democratic leaders in the Senate said one factor that has made them less optimistic about blocking aid to the contras is the appointment of Howard H. Baker Jr., the former Senate majority leader, as President Reagan's chief of staff. Several Democrats said Mr. Baker will be able to pick up several votes the Democrats thought they had. **********Both the House and Senate leaderships agree that they cannot, in the end, block the distribution of the $40 million because the President is expected to veto any bill disapproving the money. The leaders say they cannot muster the two-thirds vote needed to override a veto. **********But opponents of aid to the contras in both houses want to make as strong a showing as possible, to set the stage for the battle that is expected later this year when President Reagan requests $105 million of new military aid for next year. The House leadership's decision to have a separate vote on a moratorium represents one effort to demonstrate resistance to aiding the contras.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/20/busin.body_text: **********The stock market charged ahead yesterday to its 12th consecutive day of a feverish rally. **********The Dow Jones industrial average topped the 2,100 mark, only seven trading days after crossing the historic 2,000 level. In the 12 trading days of this year, the average has climbed 206 points, or almost 11 percent. **********With yesterday's 25.87-point rise, to 2,102.50, the average matched a previous record of 12 consecutive advances, set in 1970 from Nov. 19 through Dec. 7. **********''Only a fool would try to predict when this market is going to top out.'' said Larry Wachtel, market strategist at Prudential-Bache Securities. 'Loads of Fresh Cash' **********He added that ''people can argue about the economic outlook all they want,'' but the fact is that ''loads of fresh cash'' - from mutual funds and pension funds and from overseas investors - ''flood the market every day.'' **********In addition, individual investors are cautiously beginning to buy stocks on their own for the first time in several years. **********Compared with last week's record turnovers, trading paled yesterday, on the holiday honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was heavy at 162.8 million shares, but far below last Friday's turnover of 218.4 million, and the record 253.1 million shares that changed hands the previous day. But market analysts said individual and institutional investors were no less enthusiastic than last week. Superbulls and Nervousness **********The tremendous leap of this year has stunned Wall Street. While it has converted some professionals into superbulls it has also created nervousness. William M. LeFevre, senior vice president and market strategist at Advest Inc., said that ''it took only seven trading days for this market to go from 2,000 to 2,100. Back in February-March of 1986, it took 21 days each for the Dow to go from 1,600 to 1,700 and from 1,700 to 1,800. If this doesn't signal some kind of blow-off, then I don't know what does.'' **********But Steven G. Einhorn, a partner in Goldman, Sachs & Company, disagreed with the view that the market had peaked out, saying: ''The whole economy is awash in liquidity, courtesy of the Federal Reserve. Also, the continues to flow into the equity market. Then we have the foreign investors, who were the largest single buyers of stocks in 1986, some $25 billion or five times what they invested here in 1985.'' **********Another market optimist is Anthony Ludovici, senior investment analyst at Tucker, Anthony & R. L. Day Inc. ''From a technical point of view we are extremely happy that the Dow's transport index reached its second record level in a row,'' he said. ''This confirms the validity of the Dow industrial average.'' **********But the best reasons for being bullish, Mr. Ludovici said, ''was that the market since mid-1982 has been in its first 'super cycle' since the 1920's. By comparison, the wild 'go-go' years of the late 1960's was nothing more than a good market.'' **********And even naysayers were hedging their bets. One usually outspoken analyst, who asked not to be identified, said: ''I don't like markets that shoot up on declining volume. Nor the fact that today's gainers were only twice as large as the losers, or that gold has been rising with the market. But I'm not shorting this market.'' Investors sell shares ''short'' in expectation of a price decline. Since the first of the year, those who have sold the market short have been among the biggest losers in the market, according to brokers. 'Uncertainty About Economy' **********The seeds of the stock rally may have been planted in the second half of last year when the market idled after a strong rise. At that time, ''many investors who were uncertain about the impact of the new tax rules as well as the economy stayed on the sidelines,'' said Monte Gordon, research chief at the Dreyfus Corporation. But today, he added, ''all that remains is the uncertainty about the economy.'' Predictions of sluggish growth satisfy Wall Street because that pace would restrain inflation. **********During the 1970 rise for 12 consecutive days, the Dow Jones average climbed 8.5 percent, to 818.66, on the strength of an economy that was bounding forward. **********On the Big Board yesterday, 1,057 stocks closed higher, while 576 declined. The Dow Jones transportation average jumped 10.30 points, to 882.51, also a record. Many analysts took that as a confirmation of the Dow's surge. A record was also set by the Dow utilities average, which rose 0.52 point, to 223.34. **********The Standard & Poor's index of 500 blue chips, which is the favorite of professional investors, jumped 3.06 points, to a record 269.34. Sharp Pullback at Start **********Stocks pulled back sharply at the start of trading yesterday, throwing an extension of the market's winning streak into doubt, with the Dow average off 19 points. Profit taking was one factor as well as initial uneasiness over the dollar, which continued to fall sharply. **********But the focus on the positive aspects of the weaker dollar again replaced concern that foreigners may begin to shun American securities if the currency weakens too dramatically. The falling dollar should help the profitability of American companies by helping them meet foreign competition. A cheap dollar makes imports more expensive and exports to other nations cheaper. **********A strong surge in technology shares also revived the market. **********Analysts noted that, during the 12-day rally, each time the market has backed off eager buyers flooded in to bargain-hunt and to make up for lost buying opportunities. There have been few such chances. **********''We began with a little bit of a correction this morning, but I still would not bet against this market,'' James Andrews of Janney Montgomery Scott said. I.B.M. Earnings Due Today **********The market advance was led by such movers of the Dow average as International Business Machines, which jumped 5 1/4, to 125 1/4, on a turnover of 2.7 million shares. I.B.M.'s results for the fourth quarter of 1986 are due today. Several analysts said the giant computer company's earnings might be better than expected. But they attributed I.B.M.'s strong gain to general market conditions as well as the higher earnings reported yesterday by two other computer makers. **********American Telephone and Telegraph was second on the active list, rising 3/4, to 26 3/4. Owens-Illinois, involved in a takeover situation, added 3 1/2 at 59. Digital Equipment, reflecting the strong computer group, climbed 6, to 143, while National Semiconductor rose 5/8, to 14 1/8, and Hewlett-Packard added 4 at 54. **********The only minuses on the active list were Pan Am, off 1/4, to 5 3/4, and Boeing, down 1/4, to 50 3/4. **********Gold shares were active as bullion prices increased. ASA Ltd. rose by 2 1/2, to 42 1/8; Dome 1/8, to 9 3/8; Newmont 2 1/4, to 68 1/2, and Campbell Red Lake 7/8, to 23 1/4. **********At the American Stock Exchange, its market value index soared 3.21 points, to a record 293.97, but volume fell to 14 million shares from 18.6 million last Friday. Home Shopping Network jumped by 12, to 65, and led the Amex's most active list on a turnover of 972,500 shares. The company said yesterday that it was making two acquisitions. **********In the over-the-counter market, the Nasdaq index rose 2.72 points, to 392.59, but did not set a record.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/15/busin.main_headline: Advertising; Norstar Consolidates At Duke & Brennan
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/15/busin.print_headline: Advertising; Norstar Consolidates At Duke & Brennan
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/15/busin.body_text: **********Two of Norstar Bancorp's agencies have merged and have been rewarded with all the company's consolidated New York State advertising business. Billings could be in the area of $5 million to $8 million. **********Duke & Brennan has resulted from the merger of Marc Duke & Associates in Kingston, N.Y., and MFB Productions of Williamsville, N.Y. Mr. Duke is chairman and Michael Brennan, president. Other important officers in the merged unit are John Bieber and Robert Davis, both of whom are out of the New York big-agency scene. **********In addition to the two towns where the two agencies were based, Duke & Brennan will have offices in Albany, the bank's headquarters city, and in New York City.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/15/busin.main_headline: RIDING OUT SLUMPS IN A VOLATILE MARKET
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/15/busin.print_headline: INVESTING; RIDING OUT SLUMPS IN A VOLATILE MARKET
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/15/busin.body_text: **********WALL Street's unprecedented surge has made a lot on investors very happy - and very nervous. Those not content merely to take their gains and run are often forced to ride out the storms of a highly volatile market, hoping that the latest trough is not the start of a prolonged slump. Some brokers argue that such investors can have their cake and eat it too, by hedging their portfolios with put options. Such options give investors the right to sell a stock at a particular price over a set time frame, and will normally increase in value as an underlying stock sags. **********But others say that a put strategy - because of the starting costs, the commissions and often crucial timing involved - can make a bad situation worse. These naysayers contend that for the average small investor - whose talent at calling market turns is notably imperfect - hedging with options is more a broker's dream than a customer's. **********Even for options that appear low-priced, the cost for an individual investor to buy this kind of ''insurance'' can run prohibitively high. **********Both the potential and costs of the game can be seen in a recent trade that one New York broker put through for a client. On Jan. 23, with shares of the Walt Disney Company at $56.38, the February 55 Disney put option was quoted at $1.25 (or $125 per 100 shares, as the puts are sold). The put - a right to sell the stock at $55 a share - protected an investor against any decline below $55. Three days later, Disney had sunk as low as $52.38 and the put had risen as high as $3.50 ($350). Thus a holder of 1,000 shares of Disney lost $4,000 as the stock fell, but recouped $2,250 in appreciation of the put, before commissions. For an investor with a heavy Disney position and a nimble sense of market timing, that could be a good trade. But it is a rare outcome, according to other professionals. Indeed, within days, Disney had recovered to $56.50, and the put had fallen back to 88 cents. **********A holder of just 100 shares, however, would have fared much less happily. The loss on the stock would be $400, partly offset by a $225 gain on the put option. But round-trip brokerage commissions of at least $70 would cut that benefit to $155. The small Disney investor who hedged at an almost perfect time still would have a net loss on the total position - the stock and the put - of $245, 61 percent of what would have been lost without ''insurance.'' **********The strategy, said the broker who recommended it - a vice president at a major wire house - is suitable for ''short-term time frames, when the output of dollars is at the lowest'' and the market appears most vulnerable. The price of the put, at $1.25, was ''reasonable,'' he added. Yet unless Disney drops below $55 by the expiration, Feb. 21 - the cost of the put plus the commission will be lost. Is that a ''reasonable'' price for a nervous investor to pay for a better night's sleep? Many would say no. **********The smaller trader's put on 100 Disney shares cost $160, including a one-way commission. That equals 2.9 percent of the amount protected, $5,500. But at the time of the purchase, the option had just 29 days left before expiration. Thus the annualized cost is 36.5 percent - expensive insurance. **********For larger players, with 1,000 Disney shares, the percentages are only slightly better. Commissions count for less; a discount broker might trade 10 put options for the same $35 minimum as one. Ten contracts would cost $1,285, including the broker's charge, which on an annualized basis equals 29.4 percent of the $55,000 protection. **********Carrying less insurance lowers the cost, of course. A February 50 put, with Disney at $56, cost 38 cents on Jan. 23. But for the 100-share trader, that represented an annualized cost of about 9.6 percent before commission, 18.4 percent with a one-way broker's fee. For the investor hedging 1,000 Disney shares, the cost equaled 10.4 percent annualized, including commission. This strategy would begin to soften losses only after Disney dropped below $50, a decline of 10.7 percent. Giving up even 9 percent (annualized) for this kind of protection makes little sense to many professional investors. Over a long period, equity markets appreciate at only about 9 percent annually, noted Thomas S. Mitchell, a general partner at Weiss, Peck & Greer. ''You've constructed a strategy where you can't make money over the long term,'' he said. **********Beating those odds requires an investor to buy insurance only occasionally, correctly picking market turns, the way a driver might buy auto insurance only if he expects an accident soon. A Boston broker likened them more to conventional short-swing scalping than to insurance. Said a Midwestern money manager, ''It's a hell of a good thing for brokers; it creates a lot of trading.'' **********Investors with large, diversified portfolios can employ the options on stock indexes, such as the S.&P. 500, the narrower S.&P. 100, or the broad Value Line Index. Sometimes the insurance can be cheaper. Al Frank, who edits the Prudent Speculator newsletter and manages about $60 million, decided in mid-January that the market was vulnerable and bought February S.&P. 100 puts at $75 per contract. He thus hedged a personal portfolio of $1.7 million at a cost of $5,250, plus commissions. **********On an annualized basis, the outlay worked out to about 4.1 percent before commission - paltry compared to the returns Mr. Frank has been generating. The puts looked so cheap, in fact, that Mr. Frank bought twice as many contracts as he needed for insurance. Two weeks later, the market had soared and the options had lost more than half their value. By last week they had lost more than 90 percent of their value. Said Mr. Frank of portfolio insurance: ''It's more difficult to manage than it sounds.''

The group is led by the **********Kingston Holding Company, which owns the Colonial Indemnity Insurance Company of Kingston, N.Y. **********In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the group said Kansas City Southern's stock was undervalued. It also said it was considering future action, which could include making a friendly bid to acquire Kansas City Southern, recommending a recapitalization or restructuring of the company, or seeking representation on its board. **********The group said it paid about $48 million for the 754,600 shares it had acquired. **********A spokesman for Kansas City Southern said the company had not seen the S.E.C. filing and was not familiar with the Kingston group.
