https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/07/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Beverly Hills Hotel Is Sold
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/07/busin.body_text: **********A company controlled by the Sultan of Brunei, reportedly one of the world's richest men, bought the Beverly Hills Hotel from Marvin Davis, the Denver oilman, for $200 million, spokesmen for Mr. Davis said today. **********The sale is the second in eight months for the 260-room hotel at Sunset Boulevard and Rodeo Drive, known for its Polo Lounge and pool-side cottages and as the scene for countless movie deals. **********Last December, a partnership led by Mr. Davis bought the hotel for $135 million from Ivan F. Boesky, his wife and her family. That sale came after Mr. Boesky's $100 million settlement of insider-trading charges and a family feud over accusations that Mr. Boesky had improperly used the hotel's funds for stock speculation. **********Mr. Davis, who lived in the hotel for four years while he was co-owner of the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation, was not interested in selling the hotel, said an individual close to Mr. Davis, who asked not to be identified. ''But this guy persisted and persisted,'' he said. **********Officials at Brunei's mission and embassy were unavailable to comment late today.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/15/world.body_text: **********Reagan Administration officials said today that they had learned that Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, planned to give a major address Thursday, as arms negotiators from the two sides meet in Geneva. **********Yuli M. Vorontsov, the new chief Soviet negotiator, and Max M. Kampelman, the American negotiator, are expected to meet privately on Thursday as a prelude to the next round of talks. **********Soviet officials have said that Soviet negotiators will be prepared to negotiate seriously on what research is allowed under the ABM treaty, a major issue in the talks. But Soviet officials also have said that they still oppose the Reagan Administration's position that extensive testing of space-based systems is permitted. **********''It is our position there should be no testing in space within the framework of S.D.I. because it is contrary to the antiballistic missile treaty,'' Yuri V. Dubinin, the Soviet Ambassador to Washington, said at a news conference today. S.D.I. is President Reagan's Strategic Defense Initiative, commonly known as ''Star Wars.'' Some Noteworthy Shifts **********Mr. Gorbachev's speech will come on the anniversary of his proposal to eliminate all nuclear weapons by the year 2000. That proposal was generally regarded as propagandistic in tone by American officials. **********But tucked in among the utopian proposals in Mr. Gorbachev's speech last year were some noteworty shifts in some Soviet negotiating positions. For example, the speech signaled the abandonment of the earlier Soviet demand that British and French forces be reduced along with American missiles as part of an ''interim'' ageement on medium-range arms. **********Some senior Administration have said that Mr. Gorbachev might offer some sweeping new proposals, but have questioned their potential significance. **********''We will probably hear several Soviet public declarations about 'new' intiatives but witness little, if any, real movement,'' Edward L. Rowny, an arms control adviser to President Reagan, said Tuesday. New Moves Expected Later **********Mr. Rowny speculated that the Russians would wait until later in the year to make important new moves. The Soviet Union would do so, he said, to provide time for assessing what action the new Congress takes on arms control issues and on the military budget. Mr. Rowny also speculated that the Russians would delay any new moves out of a belief that the Reagan Administration would be more eager to compromise as the Administration's time in office runs out. **********Soviet officials have previously suggested that the Soviet Union might alter its demand that the 1972 antiballistic missile treaty be interpreted in a very strict way that would confine research on space-based defensive systems to the laboratory. But the Russians have never introduced more flexible proposals on this issue in the formal negotiations. **********Administration officials have said that United States has not changed its basic negotiating position. The Administration has proposed a very loose interpretation of the treaty, which would allow extensive testing and development of space-based defensive systems. The Administration's interpretation of the treaty has been disputed by most of the original American negotiators of the agreement. Question Before White House **********One undecided question that is before the White House is whether to lift the Administration's proposed ban on long-range mobile missiles. **********Over the last year, the United States has yielded the tactical initiative to the Russians in the Geneva arms talks. **********The reactive American approach, in part, reflects the difficulties that the Administration has had in working out its internal disagreements on arms control issues, according to Administration officials. **********It also reflects the view of current officials that past Administrations have been too eager to suggest compromises on difficult issues. ''You don't want to operate on the assumption that every time you come back to the table, somehow we must be the ones who are going to be making the moves in order to resolve the differences,'' Mr. Kampelman told reporters before he left for Geneva. Other Issues in Other Forums **********The Geneva talks deal with measures on defensive systems and on ways to reduce long-range arms and medium-range weapons. **********But the two sides have discussed other arms issues in other forums. **********Administration officials told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on Tuesday that the United States had proposed that the two sides continue discussions on ways to improve the monitoring of two treaties that limit the size of underground tests. The Soviet Union has stressed the importance of stopping all tests. **********Today, the two sides also met in Geneva for private talks on the establishment of nuclear ''risk reduction centers'' in Washington and Moscow that would exchange information in order to reduce the risk of accidential nuclear war. **********Richard N. Perle, an assistant Defense Secretary, and Col. Robert B. Linhard of the National Security Council, represented the United States. The Soviet Union was represented by Aleksei A. Obukhov, who also is a member of Soviet arms control delegation. The issue is regarded as peripheral in a political sense but progress could improve the atmosphere.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/08/busin.print_headline: SENATE TRADE BILL GAINS; NOT AS HARSH AS HOUSE'S
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/08/busin.body_text: **********The Senate Finance Committee today approved its trade bill, a much less retaliatory measure than that passed by the House last week. **********The vote was 19 to 1, with only Senator Malcolm Wallop, Republican of Wyoming, opposing the bill. **********If the Finance Committee version is not changed significantly in the full Senate, it is expected that the House version will be toned down to reach a compromise. But the Reagan Administration has objected even to the comparatively mild Finance Committee bill, so it is not clear if such a compromise would be acceptable to the President. The Senate is expected to consider the bill in June. **********Comprehensive trade legislation has become one of the top priorities in the House and the Senate this year, and many Democrats hope it will be an important issue in the 1988 Presidential campaign. **********Many members of the House and the Senate who are worried about protectionism are pushing for a moderate bill that has a chance of being signed by the President. But others argue that the legislation needs to be tougher to send a meaningful signal to the nation's trading partners and have any chance of reducing the record $170 billion trade deficit. **********The Finance Committee bill does not include the amendment proposed by Representative Richard A. Gephardt, Democrat of Missouri. That amendment requires trading partners, like Japan, to reduce their trade surpluses with the United States according to a rigid formula if they persist in closing their markets to American goods. That amendment was narrowly approved in the House on a vote of 218 to 214. Not Offered in Committee **********Senate supporters of this proposal did not offer it in committee today, and they acknowledge that winning approval of it in the full Senate would be difficult. In addition, the Administration has indicated that the President would veto any trade bill with the Gephardt amendment in it. **********Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., Democrat of Michigan, said he did not offer the amendment to the committee because it would have been defeated. He said the amendment would be the ''ultimate test'' of the effectiveness of the trade bill and he wanted to work on a compromise to offer on the Senate floor. **********Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who is chairman of the Finance Committee, agreed that there is a consensus that something must be done about countries that have attained large trade surpluses primarily from shutting out American products. But, he added: ''I want a trade bill that can become law. I'm not looking for a political issue.'' **********He contended that the Finance Committee bill would have enough support to pass and enough to override a Presidential veto. **********Before final approval today, the committee passed a Bentsen amendment that requires the President to propose measures to reduce reliance on imported oil when imports exceed 50 percent of consumption. The proposal would allow imposition of an oil import fee, new tax breaks for the oil industry and conservation measures. **********Another amendment adopted would limit lamb imports to help American producers. Similarities to House Bill **********The Senate bill includes many provisions that are also in the House bill. Among them are an extension and broadening of trade adjustment assistance to workers and companies injured by imports. The bill also designates as an unfair trade practice the denial by other countries of workers' rights, such as the right to form unions. **********The major difference between the two bills is in retaliatory provisions. Both require some retaliation, but the House bill goes much further. **********Under the Senate proposal, the Administration is required each year to initiate actions against unfair trade practices that close markets to American products. **********If the practices violate trade agreements, the President must retaliate within 19 months if there is no agreement with the country or there is no settlement of the dispute by a panel set up under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The specific retaliation, which the President can choose, must equal the dollar value of American trade lost. Exceptions Granted **********There are four exceptions under which the President can avoid retaliation: a GATT ruling that the United States' position is wrong; a settlement agreeable to the industry involved; an agreement by the foreign country to allow in enough other products to offset the trade loss, and a Presidential ruling that retaliation would harm national security. **********For lesser unfair trade practices, the retaliation is not mandatory and there are broader exceptions. **********In the House-approved bill, there are similar provisions for product-by-product or industry-by-industry retaliation. But there is no automatic initiation of the cases, and the exceptions are broader. **********The House bill, however, has provisions that require retaliation against countries, like Japan, that have built up large trade surpluses with the United States partly by shutting out American products. Quotas or Fees **********Under the House bill, if negotiations to eliminate the trade barriers fail, the Administration is required to impose quotas or fees equal to the trade lost. Then the Gephardt amendment requires that if the country persists in the unfair trade practices, actions be taken to reduce the country's trade surplus with the United States by 10 percent a year. **********The Administration can do this by banning imports or canceling trade agreements. Or the country can reduce the surplus by importing more American products or exporting less. **********These provisions will be at the heart of the eventual negotiations between the House and the Senate on a final bill. Many members of the Senate think both provisions are protectionist and will result in retaliation against the United States. **********The Senate bill also requires that the Administration submit a comprehensive trade policy statement to Congress. When it does, the procedure for quick approval of trade agreements will be extended. That procedure expires in January 1988. Trade negotiatiors contend that the procedure is necessary for negotiations because without it other countries have no assurance that a trade agreement will be ratified.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/01/busin.body_text: **********FACED with declining worldwide liquor consumption, the international liquor industry is turning to consolidation as a way to prop up sagging sales. Indeed, analysts say that by the end of the decade the industry, traditionally the domain of small, independent operators, will consist of a handful of conglomerates. **********The decline in consumption, estimated to be at least 2 percent a year, has propelled the industry into a flurry of deals - both takeovers and mergers - intended to give liquor companies complete control of their products, from the distillery to the shelf. **********The deals can take many shapes. In some cases the distiller of one brand might buy another, or move closer to the consumer and acquire a distributor that has profitable market penetration. **********Britain's Guinness P.L.C., for example, entered into a joint marketing agreement in June with Moet-Hennessy, a French company that in 1980 had acquired its own distributor, Schiefflin & Company. Then last month Guinness purchased its United States importer, Schenley Industries. Guinness has also entered into a joint operating agreement with the Bacardi group in Spain. **********Guinness's chief executive, Anthony Tennant, had a similar strategy when he was head of Grand Metropolitan P.L.C.'s subsidiary, International Distillers and Vintners. In 1980 Grand Metropolitan acquired Liggett Group Inc., the American distributor of Grand Metropolitan's J & B Scotch. **********More recently Grand Metropolitan has continued its expansion. In January it acquired Heublein Inc., the American marketer of almost 100 brands of spirits, wines and beers in the United States, including Grand Met's Black Velvet whisky. And in July it forged an international drinks distribution network with Martell, the French cognac maker. **********The motives for these deals vary. In many cases the company being acquired not only can add to the balance sheet, but also can provide funds to promote slower sellers. Beyond that, however, there is the question of trying to grab a bigger piece of a smaller pie. **********''If you don't go out there, the best distributor will belong to a competitor,'' said Fiona Mathieson, an industry analyst with Wood Mackenzie. ''By controlling brand and product rights through the point of sale, your own management skills are at test. You are effectively wiping out the competition.'' In addition, said Frank Walters, the director of research at Impact, a spirits industry newsletter, building new brands can be costly. ''It's a lot more economical to buy a brand,'' he said. ''The one-brand company is going to find it very hard to compete.'' **********With its longstanding base of production in Britain and its centuries-old access to overseas markets, the British spirits industry has pioneered the consolidation. The more recent mergers focus on the United States and Southeast Asia, where the market for imports has expanded in recent years. For example, while sales of domestic vodkas have declined since 1980 in the United States, sales of imported vodkas have soared. **********Analysts say that with United States consumption of liquor estimated to have peaked in 1984, it is only a matter of time before the American liquor industry completes its consolidation. ''U.S. companies have had such a big market for so many years,'' said Michelle Proud, an analyst at Wood Mackenzie, ''That they haven't had to look abroad.'' **********The Bacardi group, a loosely bound conglomerate of 13 distillers and distributors, and the producer of the world's best-selling liquor, Bacardi rum, has been especially courted in recent years. The 125-year-old Cuban company anticipated current trends toward consolidation decades ago, so by the time Fidel Castro nationalized the Cuban liquor industry in 1959, Bacardi had already built a production and distribution network in the United States and Puerto Rico. The group, which is still largely owned by descendants of the Bacardi family, has always resisted joint ventures, but there are signs, such as the agreement with Guinness, that Bacardi is finally looking for a partner. **********''Bacardi, like everyone else, is under pressure to enter distribution agreements,'' Ms. Proud said. Nonetheless, the group recently rebuffed overtures by Allied-Lyons P.L.C., one of Britain's largest pub owners and brewers, and the owner of Hiram Walker Resources, the North American spirits giant. At the time of Hiram Walker's sale to Allied-Lyons last year Hiram Walker owned 13 percent of the Bacardi group. Bacardi bought back the stake last month. **********In the current environment, Ms. Mathieson said, Bacardi's multinational licensing, bottling and distribution network puts the company in an extremely favorable bargaining position. Analysts say that a major deal with the Bacardi group would effectively close the door on any significant entries into the international spirits industry.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/14/busin.main_headline: More Settlements Awaited in Power System's Default Case
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/14/busin.print_headline: More Settlements Awaited in Power System's Default Case
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/14/busin.body_text: **********The $92 million settlement announced last week against one set of defendants in the Washington Public Power Supply System's bond default case is seen as a pattern for settlements with other groups of defendants. **********''Over all, we're looking for a very significant recovery in the case,'' said Paul M. Bernstein, chief counsel for the bondholders. He helped negotiate the settlement with the bond underwriters. **********In the settlement, the lead underwriters of the bonds - Merrill Lynch, Salomon Brothers, Smith Barney and Prudential-Bache - agreed to pay $80 million plus $12 million interest for 18 months. **********The underwriters were among defendants named in a class-action lawsuit by holders of $2.25 billion of the power system's bonds. The bonds went into default in July 1983 after construction was halted on two nuclear plants - one near Richland, Wash., and one west of Olympia, Wash. - with each of the plants less than 25 percent complete. Pressure on Others Seen **********Trial of the suit in Federal District Court is a year away. Lawyers say settlement pressure is mounting on the remaining defendants, which include the architects and engineers of the abandoned plants, the attorneys and financial advisers to the supply system and bond-rating agencies. **********The lawsuit has been combined with one filed by the Chemical Bank, the bondholder trustee, which names the supply system, the Bonneville Power Administration and the 88 utilities in the Northwest that were involved in the nuclear project. **********William Berls, Chemical's vice president for trusts and investments, said in a telephone interview, ''We think it is encouraging to see a settlement in the morass of litigation.'' But he declined to speculate on whether similar deals might follow, citing an order from Federal District Judge William Browning that forbids discussing details of negotiations. **********But James Curtis, Bonneville's deputy financial manager, declared, ''As a practical matter, this is the first initiative and will make settlement seem a more realistic outcome to other defendants.'' Projections of Outcome **********Analysts have long considered that a sweeping settlement by all parties might net the bondholders between $225 million, or 10 cents on the dollar, and $1 billion. Already $106 million of settlement funds is held in escrow by Chemical. This is in addition to the undewrwriters' $92 million settlement last week. **********Analysts view the settlement as a important step toward clearing the way for the supply system to refinance $6.1 billion in outstanding bonds for its three remaining nuclear plants. **********Some $2.6 billion of these bonds still bear interest rates between 11 percent and 15 percent - well above today's market rates for similar bonds - and they represent the largest block of tax-exempt municipal bonds that have not been refinanced. But the supply system has been denied access to the bond market since the default. Analysts believe access could be regained within the next year or two, once the litigation is resolved. Tax Corrections Sought **********The Northwest is now paving the way for refinancing by pushing for Congressional corrections in the Tax Reform Act of 1986. Gary Petersen, a supply system lobbyist, said: ''There's tremendous support throughout the Northwest from utility associations for refunding because rate payers could save up to $130 million annually if interest rates dropped to 9 percent. This infers that the region wants settlements.'' **********Gary Lundgren, vice president of Marshall & Meyer Inc., a Seattle-based bond house, believes underwriters were major players in the lawsuit and ''settled too cheap, for nickels on the dollar, which is good for underwriters, not bondholders.'' He added, ''The 'deep pockets' now will be Bonneville, the 88 utilities and remaining defendants.'' **********But suggestions that the underwriters did not pay enough were termed ''crazy'' by Mr. Bernstein, the bondholders' lawyer. ''It was an excellent settlement,'' he said in a telephone interview. ''We believe they were less culpable than other defendants.'' Viewpoint of the Utilities **********But whether all groups of defendants will go along with the underwriters' action remains to be seen. **********Al Malanca, the lawyer for about half of the utilities, threatens to go to trial rather than have consumers finance a settlement through rate increases. The utilities insist they are not liable because the Supreme Court of Washington State ruled that utilities did not need to repay revenue bonds on nuclear plants that would never be completed. **********''Somebody is going to have to crawl over my dead body before my clients will have to raise their rates,'' said Mr. Malanca.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/09/busin.snippet: LEAD: The major stock market pullback that started two weeks ago continued yesterday, but a late rally turned a rout into a modest loss. The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 2,545.12, down 16.26 points.
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/09/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: The major stock market pullback that started two weeks ago continued yesterday, but a late rally turned a rout into a modest loss. The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 2,545.12, down 16.26 points. **********The major stock market pullback that started two weeks ago continued yesterday, but a late rally turned a rout into a modest loss. The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 2,545.12, down 16.26 points. **********Wall Street was battered in early trading, and at one point the Dow was down 62 points, to below 2,500. Then the turnaround began, driven by buying to cover short sales of futures contracts and some futures-related buy programs. **********Volume on the Big Board was the seventh largest ever, with 242.9 million shares traded, up from 129.1 million shares on Friday. More than 42 million shares were traded in a single stock, Pacific Gas and Electric, apparently because it was involved in dividend-capture strategies favored by institutions. **********The Dow has now fallen in five straight sessions, and since Aug. 25 it has gained on only two days out of 10. In that time the Dow has lost 177.3 points, or 6.5 percent, from its record high of 2,722.42.Broader Market Gauges **********Broader market gauges than the Dow also had a rough day, as 1,532 stocks declined on the New York Stock Exchange and just 252 rose. The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 1.99, to 175.59, and the S.& P. 500-stock index dipped 3.14, to 313.56. Both indexes rebounded after early, steep declines. **********And two indexes that track smaller issues sagged badly. The American Stock Exchange index fell 7.29, to 347.13, and the Nasdaq index of over-the-counter stocks dropped 8.88, to 437.60. **********The stock market took its early cue yesterday from the credit market, where long-term Government bonds collapsed. Prices on the 30-year bond fell by two points in early trading. It finally closed about a point and a half down, and its yield rose above 9.6 percent. [Page D19.] Such a high yield, on what basically is a ''riskless'' investment, is inimical to stocks, which compete with bonds for investors' funds. **********And there was little good news from the currency markets, where the dollar was hurt early by the expectation that the latest trade deficit figures, which will be disclosed Friday, will be bad. It later steadied after heavy intervention by foreign central banks. A volatile dollar discourages foreign investors, who are loath to risk money in the American stock market, knowing that any gains they make might be wiped out in currency translation. [Page D16.] Market experts said the Dow seemed to hold at the psychologically important 2,500 level, as bargain hunters and futures related buy programs cushioned the fall.Comeback Eases Some Nerves **********The late comeback eased some nerves, but many traders know they are not out of the woods yet. Amid a bull market that seemed so unstoppable - in 1987 alone, the Dow had surged more than 43 percent - talk of a forthcoming ''correction'' was commonplace. But its swiftness has created some fear where before there had only been wariness. **********A lot of people believe the stock market has not been reflecting economic realities. **********Henry M. Greenleaf Jr., president of HT Investors Inc., a money manager in Providence, R.I., said, ''All you have to do is look out of the window of your subway or your car to realize that all the wealth out there is certainly not distributed, and that means social problems down the line.'' This, he said, leads him to believe that the stock market will eventually have ''a hard landing.'' **********At Julius Baer Securities, the American trading arm of the big Zurich bank, Bernard Spilko, the managing director, said, ''With interest rates at a historic bull market high, corporate earnings and liquidity will not be sufficient to sustain the bull market for the next quarter.'' **********Other analysts, however, believe the current selloff has been overdone. **********''I think we're going to pop,'' said Peter G. Grennan, at Shearson Lehman Brothers. ''I expect a reflex knee-jerk type of rally. On a short-term basis, we're oversold.'' After that, he said, ''the bigger question is: Are we starting something more serious, or are we going into a trading range?'' **********And in its latest Market Letter to clients, Merrill Lynch, the nation's biggest brokerage, commented, ''We think the market's long uptrend is bent, not broken.''Few Sectors Are Spared **********Few stock sectors were spared yesterday. **********Among the big losers, I.B.M. fell 3, to 157 3/4; Digital Equipment 3 1/8, to 182 7/8; Merck 1 1/4, to 212; Mobil 1 5/8, to 48 3/8; Coca-Cola 1 3/8, to 49 1/4; Philip Morris 1 3/4, to 111 3/8; USX 1 1/4, to 33 3/4, and Morgan Stanley 3 5/8, to 76 1/2. Many of these and other large-capitalization issues had been down much more before bargain hunters bid up their shares in the last hour of trading. **********Two natural resource stocks, Alcoa, up 1 5/8, to 57 3/8, and Phelps-Dodge, up 2, to 45 3/4, bucked the trend, as did Kodak, up 3 3/8, to 98 7/8, and Dow Chemical, up 3, to 97 1/4. **********Newmont Mining rose 1 7/8, to 90 1/4, after an investor group led by T. Boone Pickens began a $95-a-share tender offer for 28 million Newmont common shares. The group, Ivanhoe Partners, outlined the financing for its takeover bid, indicating it would contribute $600 million of its own cash. **********GAF soared 12 1/4, to 66 3/4, after a management group led by its chairman and chief executive, Samuel J. Heyman, made a $2.2 billion buyout offer for the chemical and building material maker. **********In over-the-counter trading, Argonaut Group fell 6 3/4, to 44, after a takeover deal foundered.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/17/busin.main_headline: Gencorp Gets Offer For Its Tire Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/17/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Gencorp Gets Offer For Its Tire Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/17/busin.body_text: **********Gencorp Inc. said yesterday that it had received an offer from the management of its General Tire and Rubber Company unit to purchase the subsidiary in a leveraged buyout. The price was not disclosed. **********Charles R. Tilden, a Gencorp spokesman, said that the company expects additional offers for the tire unit within the next week. **********''We are expecting other offers, and we will not discuss the details of any of them until our management decides which one it will recommend to the board,'' Mr. Tilden said. **********Last week, Continental Gummi-Werke A.G., the large West German tire maker, said it would make an offer to acquire Gencorp's tire manufacturing operations. That bid is expected by early next week. **********Gencorp said the management group is being led by Gilbert H. Neal, president of General Tire. Gencorp would not provide any details on the group's bid or its financing, and Mr. Neal, who was said to be traveling, could not be reached for comment. **********Mr. Tilden also said that Pirelli Tire of Italy had expressed interest in acquiring General Tire and that a public offering of the unit remained possible. Gencorp's stock was up 37.5 cents yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, closing at $104.375. **********Analysts have contended that the General Tire operations would bring in about $600 million. In April, the company placed the tire unit up for sale after averting a $2.2 billion hostile takeover bid by a group consisting of Wagner & Brown, the Texas oil producers, and AFG Industries, a California glass company. Gencorp fought the takeover by announcing a repurchase of 54 percent of its stock at $130 a share. The repurchase was to be financed by the sale of Gencorp's tire business as well as its soft-drink bottling unit and the broadcast operations of its RKO General subsidiary. **********The sale of the units would leave Gencorp with Aerojet General, a maker of aerospace and defense products, and Diversitech General, a manufacturer of plastic and industrial products. The two divisions accounted for nearly 50 percent of Gencorp's sales and 57 percent of its profits in 1986.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/08/busin.main_headline: Advertising; Revolution In Britain: One View
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/08/busin.print_headline: Advertising; Revolution In Britain: One View
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/08/busin.body_text: **********IN the agency world there are the conglomerates, as typified by Saatchi & Saatchi and the Interpublic Group of Companies, and the colonial (or branch) networks, like those run by J. Walter Thompson, Young & Rubicam and Foote, Cone & Belding. A more recent phenomenon is what Peter Scott, chief executive of Britain's WCRS Group, describes as a creative federation. **********His own publicly held company, which has acquired America's Della Femina, Travisano & Partners and HBM/Creamer, is just such an organization. So are two other British agencies - Boase Massimi, which bought New York's Ammirati & Puris, and Lowe Howard Spink & Bell, which now owns Laurence Charles, Free & Lawson. **********They are medium-sized creative agencies all, he told American agency executives at a meeting of the Western Region of the American Association of Advertising Agencies in Laguna Niguel, Calif. He didn't have to tell his audience that the conglomerates are giants composed of differently named chains or that the networks are single agencies with many far-flung offices. This they already knew. **********He described conglomerates and colonial networks as ''yesterday's solutions,'' and said his shop and its peer agencies are geared to the concept that ''business but not advertising or creative solutions is becoming global.'' **********All the talk about global ad campaigns may be fine for Coca-Cola, he said, but there are darn few others that would benefit. His point was that the advertising of most global products requires local solutions. **********Mr. Scott got to that point in his speech after a first-rate job of explaining the progress of the British agency from a fiefdom subservient to American interests to a booming business that has shaken off its shackles and is buying United States companies left and right. **********As the American colonists rebelled against the absentee management of the British crown, so the British agency business has rebelled against the absentee management of American international agencies, Mr. Scott said. **********And with the help of a far healthier economy brought about by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, the British advertising community has almost flipped the percentage of billings at the top 20 agencies in Britain from 70 percent in the hands of American agencies to only 40 percent. **********At the same time, Mr. Scott maintained, there has been a return of creative advertising in the British tradition that was all but stamped out by the introduction of on-site American managers and their promulgation of research-dominated creativity. **********Came the revolution, and ''the British advertising industry once again came to believe that advertising could be effective without being insipid,'' he said, adding, ''It remembered that advertising could entice, charm, amuse and flatter the consumer and still be effective.'' **********The management of Mr. Scott's agency, begun in 1979 as Wight Collins Rutherford Scott, realized a few years later that because of British tax laws it had the choice of selling out and giving up ''the identity, independence and entrepreneurial drive that had been snuffed out like a flame in so many good and occasionally great British agencies, or fighting to retain the values and culture that had made the business a success,'' Mr. Scott said. To fight meant to go public. So his agency copied the Saatchis and offered shares to the public. **********Once public, the management realized that ''no agency - no matter how good, how energetic, how creative - can expect to survive, thrive and prosper as a single profit center business in the long term.'' **********That led to diversification, to other areas of marketing service in order to escape the threat of client conflict, and ultimately to buying United States agencies and becoming a colonial power. **********British imperialism once again.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/17/world.main_headline: Guatemalan Refugees in No Hurry to Return
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/17/world.print_headline: Guatemalan Refugees in No Hurry to Return
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/17/world.body_text: **********The return of more than 40,000 Guatemalan Indians who fled to Mexico to escape military repression is proceeding slowly, according to Government officials and human-rights advocates. **********After the inauguration of an elected civilian President in Guatemala 16 months ago, the refugees were encouraged to return to their homes. But less than 2,000 have done so, officials said this week. **********In at least one village, refugees who returned from Mexico have been treated harshly by local authorities. Some say they will try to go back to Mexico if conditions in Guatemala do not improve. **********Guatemalan Indians flooded into Mexico after a coup in March 1982 that installed Gen. Efrain Rios Montt as President. In that period, many thousands of Indians were killed as soldiers swept through the western highlands in search of guerrillas. At least 100 villages were destroyed, and many more were abandoned, according to diplomats and other foreigners. **********The new civilian president, Marco Vinicio Cerezo, has told local officials to help resettle refugees who return. His wife, Raquel Blandon de Cerezo, visited refugees in Mexico and urged them to come back. But senior military officers, quickly taking exception to her appeal, said refugees would be wise to remain in Mexico for the time being. **********''Mrs. Cerezo has all the good will in the world, and everyone wants to make the refugees welcome, just as she does,'' said Jorge Luis Archila Amezquita, who heads the human-rights commission of the Guatemalan Congress. ''But we cannot possibly absorb 40,000 of them at once. We are trying to create conditions for their return, and we would like them to return a few at a time.'' **********The refugee camps in Mexico are supported by the office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, which has allocated $8.9 million for their operation in 1987. In Guatemala, by contrast, returning refugees face unemployment and poverty as well as the hostility of some military officers who think some of them may have ties to Marxist guerrillas. Acceptance of Amnesty Required **********Many returning refugees have been required to sign a document accepting Government amnesty, a practice that was condemned last month by a United Nations official, Jorge Santiesteban. **********''This would signify admission that they participated in armed rebellion,'' Mr. Santiesteban said. ''The refugee camps are centers of peace and work, not guerrillas.'' **********Carmen Rosa de Leon, who heads a Government agency assigned to oversee the return of refugees from Mexico, said the Government recognized the rights of those who want to return, but is no longer actively encouraging them. **********''All Guatemalans have the right to live in their country, but there is the practical problem of how to care for them with the limited resources we have available,'' she said in an interview. She also confirmed reports that one group of villages in Huehuetenango, a western province, had been mistreated. She said the Government would help them go back to Mexico if no other solution was possible. **********According to foreigners who have recently visited Huehuetenango, 49 Indians who returned to the village of Nubila in January have been made to perform manual labor and to take part in nightly civil patrols, and they have not been able to reclaim their farmland. The foreigners said the military commissioner in Nubila, a civilian appointed by the army, was apparently trying to drive the Indians away. Resistance by an Officer **********''The problem in Nubila is that the village was completely abandoned, and outsiders came and began farming the land there,'' Miss de Leon said. ''It seems that the military commissioner was making a business of renting these lands to whoever wanted them. Now, five years later, when the rightful owners are starting to come back, he is resisting.'' **********Miss de Leon said she planned to visit Nubila next week and indicated that she might seek removal of the military commissioner there.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/18/busin.body_text: **********The Communications Satellite Corporation said today it would sell its manufacturing businesses and dispose of two planned direct-broadcast satellites as part of a major reorganization. **********The decisions resulted in a charge against profits of $90 million for the quarter ended June 30, resulting in a net loss for the period of $83.8 million. **********''These actions better position us for the future,'' said the company's chairman, Irving Goldstein. **********Comsat said it was abandoning a project to orbit two direct-broadcast satellites that were to provide entertainment programming to owners of satellite-dish receivers. **********Richard McGraw, a company spokesman, said the satellites, currently under construction, would be disposed of ''as junk.'' **********The company also said it planned to sell all of its manufacturing businesses, including Amplica Inc., a subsidiary that designs microwave components and systems for the military electronics industry. **********The company had previously announced an agreement to sell its Comsat International Communications Inc. subsidiary and its technology products small-terminal business. **********Mr. Goldstein said the company would improve programming offered by Comsat Video Enterprises, which provides movies and other entertainment services to hotels through satellite transmissions.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/16/world.main_headline: Rights Seminar Is Split on Coexisting With Soviet
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/16/world.print_headline: Rights Seminar Is Split on Coexisting With Soviet
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/16/world.body_text: **********An unusual independent human rights seminar ended today with some of its leaders, united by experience in Soviet prisons and labor camps, parting ways over how to coexist with the Government that imprisoned and freed them. **********In their review of the seminar at a press conference today, various organizers emphasized the subjects that had united the 400 participants, such as their intent to press for freedom for what they said were dozens of people imprisoned or in psychiatric confinement in the Soviet Union for political or religious activity. **********But against a background of official harassment, including the brief detention of several participants and threats of prosecution and harm, the group's two best-known figures, Lev. M. Timofeyev and Sergei I. Grigoryants, made public their longstanding disagreement about how to approach the Soviet Government. **********Mr. Timofeyev, leader of Press Club Glasnost and the chief organizer of the seminar, repeatedly made the point that the movement should seek a ''constructive dialogue'' with all elements of Soviet life, including the Communist Party. 'We're Prepared for Cooperation' **********''We want more than anything a constructive path for the expression of those ideas that came up in the course of the seminar,'' he said in an interview tonight. ''We're prepared for cooperation with any groups, official or unofficial, who support our ideas.'' **********But Mr. Grigoryants, editor of a nongovernmental magazine, called Glasnost, asserted that the Soviet Government ''has absolutely no use for us'' and that conciliation can only muddy the movement's ''purity and clarity.'' **********The growing gap between the two men was just one outcome of a freewheeling few days of discussion on everything from changes in the legal system to the rights of the disabled, from religious persecution to disarmament. **********The seminar was attended by an international contingent representing the United States, Sweden, the Netherlands and included a member of the Czechoslovak human rights group Charter 77. International Group Seeks Links **********Among the foreign participants was Gerald Nagler, head of the International Helsinki Federation, who said his human rights organization was seeking links with official Soviet organizations. He said his group has held discussions with Yuri B. Kashlev, the Foreign Ministry official responsible for human rights, about sending a delegation to the Soviet Union. **********''We have made it clear to them that when we are here we would continue to meet with our friends,'' he added, indicating Mr. Timofeyev, Mr. Grigoryants and the other organizers present. **********Among the most troubling subjects discussed was the continued imprisonment of at least 20 people on charges of anti-Soviet agitation and propaganda, the charge that Mr. Timofeyev and Mr. Grigoryants were imprisoned for until earlier this year. **********The Rev. Gleb Yakunin, a Russian Orthodox priest, said he believed that at least 260 other religious believers have been imprisoned under a variety of Soviet laws forbidding certain kinds of religious activity, including charity work and proselytizing. **********One of the seminar's 10 sections approved a resolution calling on the Government to abolish internal passports and requirements that Soviet citizens be registered with local authorities before they can live in a city or district. **********Another section disagreed, saying that the Soviet public should first be prepared to think in those terms before such a demand could be made, according to Sergei A. Kovalev, organizer of a section on legal rights. **********At a section on the rights of the disabled, a state bus unexpectedly drove up with three disabled party members who went to the apartment of the organizer, Yuri D. Kisilev, and argued with the seminar participants.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/10/world.main_headline: DRY CITIES OF WEST BUY UP FARM WATER RIGHTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/10/world.print_headline: DRY CITIES OF WEST BUY UP FARM WATER RIGHTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/10/world.body_text: **********For more than a century, farmers here have taken the cool brown water of the Arkansas River, channeled it into their fields in shallow ditches, and watched the land explode with color and crops. **********But in recent years, the Arkansas River Valley has turned increasingly barren as farmers, many under financial strain, have begun to sell their crucial asset, their water, to expanding urban areas many miles away. **********''I don't feel good about it,'' said Kenneth Carter, an Ordway farmer who recently got $400,000 from the Denver suburb of Aurora for his rights to water for 225 acres, plus some other rights he had. ''I've always thought we would be much better off if we had never heard of a water sale.'' **********When Aurora went water-shopping at the end of 1986, it bought the rights from 300 sources, primarily farmers, increasing its water supply by 30 percent. The total price of $50 million was financed through a bond issue. **********The sale of water rights, which allow the owners to take the specified amount of water for their use, was once regarded as unthinkable. But it is becoming increasingly common across the arid West. The demand for water in urban areas is outpacing supplies in mountain rivers and reservoirs while farming, which experts estimate has consumed more than 80 percent of the West's water, is in a crisis. **********Water marketing meets with political approval from both conservatives and liberals and thus may represent part of a permanent change in the West's way of life. **********In the last few years a heated debate has developed, with proponents of selling water contending that a free market will bring more efficient distribution of an often-subsidized, often-squandered resource. But others say water sales are draining the life from many small communities and may cause irreparable damage. **********''What this does to a community shouldn't be done to a dog,'' said Frank Milenski, a retired farmer from La Junta, Colo., where sales of water rights are causing steep declines in land values, reducing property-tax income and drying up sales in farm-related businesses. **********''This is my home and the home for a lot of people,'' said Mr. Milenski. ''If a man wants to sell his water rights, that's his business. But it shouldn't ruin the rest of the community.'' **********Similar concerns can be found across much of the West. In Arizona, farmers are upset because booming towns near Phoenix are buying entire ranches just for their water. ''For the farmers left, this is very much a threat to their own water supply,'' said Deborah Flowers, the director of information for the Arizona Farm Bureau. Restrictions Are Adopted **********California Farm Bureau members voted in December to support a number of restrictions on sales and transfers. ''There are some potential problems that need to be nipped in the bud,'' said Jim Eller, the group's legislative director in Sacramento. ''A grower just can't arbitrarily sell his water if it's going to affect others.'' **********The issue has emerged in response to two large regional forces: waning Federal interest in financing huge water projects, and the continued strong growth of metropolitan regions. **********''Almost universally, the cities are turning to agriculture,'' said John A. Folk-Williams, the president of Western Network, a New Mexico research group specializing in natural resource issues. ''That's because agriculture accounts for 80 to 90 percent of the water used in most Western states and a lot of it is used to produce low-value crops, such as alfalfa and pasture.'' **********''Something has to give,'' said Dick Gardner, an economist with the budget office of Gov. Cecil Andrus of Idaho. ''As long as there's water available for urban growth and new industry, that's fine. But today, the rivers of the West are generally fully appropriated.'' Anxiety About Big Dams **********The concept of water marketing enjoys considerable and broad political support across the West. Conservatives like it because it reduces the Federal role in water development. Liberals are drawn to it because more efficient exchanges of water could reduce the need for large, environmentally destructive dams. **********Traditionally, farmers and ranchers have been among those most opposed to the water sales. But even that has started to change as the farm economy has worsened. **********''Farmers are sitting there with something marketable,'' said Bill Milenski, Frank's son, who is a loan officer with the Rocky Ford National Bank in Rocky Ford, Colo. ''To keep the wolves away from their door, farmers are selling the best producing asset they have.'' **********For some farmers, the sale of water rights is a last desperate act to save the farm. But in the Arkansas Valley, home of some of the nation's richest melon fields, the sale of water rights is the equivalant of agricultural suicide. **********''Water is everything here,'' said Mr. Carter. ''The land is not hardly worth anything without water. You can't produce much of anything without irrigation.'' He Will Live on the Interest **********A rugged, wind-bronzed Colorado farmer, Mr. Carter said he sold his water rights not out of financial hardship, but because it made good business sense. **********Of the roughly $400,000 he got from the town of Aurora in December, he said: ''I can take that money, put it in the bank and draw interest and make a lot more money that I could farming. Besides, I'm 68 years old and I could stand a little fishing, too.'' His fertile land, which once sprouted melons, beets, alfalfa, corn and other crops, will now be left to bake and crack in the summer heat. **********The price Mr. Carter received, $1,500 for each acre-foot of water a year, was a good one, although not spectacular. Prices for water rights in the West typically range from less than $100 to $2,000 for an acre-foot, the amount of water that would cover a level acre to the depth of one foot. But in some cases, rights have sold for up to $10,000 an acre-foot. **********The price ''really varies depending on how water-tight a region is,'' said Jo Clark, the director of programs for the Western Governors Association. An acre-foot, roughly, will supply the needs of a family of four for a year. A Big Portion Has Been Sold **********Today, the water rights to 60,000 acres of the 320,000 acres of irrigated land in the Arkansas River Valley have been sold, said Frank Milenski. Without water, the land's value drops from $700 or $1,000 an acre to less than $100, he said. **********The environmental impact could also be severe, he said. ''If the ground isn't protected properly and the wind starts blowing, you could see giant duststorms like we had in the 30's, and that would be totally devastating,'' Mr. Milenski said. **********The Western Governors Association said in a report last summer that the detrimental effects of water sales could be reduced if farmers leased their water rights, instead of selling them permanently as around Ordway, or if they sold only a part of them. ''Agriculture currently has the rights to about 85 percent of the water in the West,'' the report said. ''If farmers yielded only 10 percent of this, it would provide enough water to meet urban demands in most areas into the 20th century.'' **********But in the Arkansas River Valley, cities are frequently purchasing 100 percent of a farmer's rights, which could someday bring back the desert. **********''There is no way to compensate these people for the long-term effects on their community,'' said Mr. Folk-Williams. ''And when the water is taken away, what's left to attract new industry? Nobody has answered that question yet.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/20/busin.main_headline: I. Magnin Chief Leaving To Join a New Company
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/20/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; I. Magnin Chief Leaving To Join a New Company
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/20/busin.body_text: **********Steven M. Somers is leaving as chairman and chief executive of I. Magnin to take an entrepreneurial fling with a start-up company. **********Mr. Somers, 47, has been chief executive at Magnin's, the San Francisco-based unit of Federated Department Stores, for the last eight years. He is joining a company called Initials Plus Inc. as president and chief operating officer. Federated has not named a successor to Mr. Somers. **********Mr. Somers said yesterday that he was taking a substantial cut in salary, security and benefits to join Initials Plus, although he declined to give any numbers. He is a major shareholder in the new company, which went public in November and trades over the counter. **********Initials Plus licenses independent retailers - so far mostly women -who sell ''upscale'' products designed for gift giving. The stress is on personalized service. The customer gives the retailer a list of birthdays and other events. They are fed into a computer and the retailer gets in touch with the customer with the reminder and a sales pitch for a gift from the Initial Plus catalogue. **********The business, which got under way in the fall, offers about 100 products so far, and they can be engraved with initials or monogrammed at no extra charge. About 70 licensees have been signed up. **********Mr. Somers said the concept combined aspects of retailing, catalogue selling and direct marketing. Initials Plus was developed by Michael D. London, 45, who earlier started a company called Headquarters Inc., a nationwide network of executive busness centers that he sold to United Technologies. **********Mr. Somers was born in Brooklyn and raised in Freeport, L.I. He graduated from Syracuse University and went to work for Federated at Abraham & Straus. He left Federated for six years, working for Gimbels. ''I opened up their 86th Street Store -I'm glad I wasn't there to close it,'' he said. Gimbels ceased operations in Manhattan last year. **********Mr. Somers worked for Federated a total of 17 years, including a stint at Burdines in Miami. He is married and has three children. **********He acknowledged the risk in joining with Initials Plus but added that the company would be going ''from zero to one hundred miles an hour very quickly.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/14/busin.main_headline: GLOBAL CUT URGED FOR FARM AID
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/14/busin.print_headline: GLOBAL CUT URGED FOR FARM AID
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/14/busin.body_text: **********Ministers of 24 industrial nations called on their governments today to reduce expensive farm support programs, and they also disclosed a new willingness by West Germany to stimulate its economy in response to sagging growth. **********The ministers' communique, at the end of a two-day meeting of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, was the first time that there had been a consensus among the United States, Europe and Japan that farm support programs need to be cut. **********The subsidies cost O.E.C.D. nations more than $100 billion a year and have produced enormous surpluses of farm products. While officials concede that slashing the farm aid is a formidable task, they maintained that they had taken a critical, and difficult, first step. 'The Urgency of the Problem' **********''A few years ago it would have been impossible to have agreed on an issue as controversial as farm policy,'' said Frans Andriessen, agricultural commissioner for the European Community. ''Our agreement says something about the urgency of the problem worldwide.'' **********While agricultural trade barriers are already a subject of trade talks, this accord increases the scope of negotiations by asserting that farm subsidies are a form of protectionism that should be limited. Reducing agricultural subsidies would almost certainly produce sweeping changes for farmers around the world. **********In another section, the communique, which also focused on efforts to stabilize the dollar and end trade imbalances, stated that West Germany would adjust its growth strategy if a ''serious risk'' to sustained expansion of domestic demand developed. A Commitment by Bonn **********American and European officials who have long called on Bonn to stimulate domestic demand praised the commitment. West Germany, which reported weak economic growth in the first quarter, said it would examine its growth statistics in June to determine whether its economy is in need of stimulation, a condition that German officials said would be reached if the growth rate were below 2 percent. **********Several ministers said the stimulation could take the form of an interest rate cut or an accelerated tax cut. On Tuesday, West Germany ordered a reduction in a key rate that its central bank charges some domestic borrowers. **********''We were quite pleased that they acknowledged that they would take another look if growth doesn't materialize in the way they hope,'' Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d of the United States said. At a news conference earlier in the day, Mr. Baker noted, ''We'd like to see them do as much as they can as soon as they can.'' **********Mr. Baker and many other economic ministers expressed confidence that progress was being made in coordinated international efforts to reduce trade imbalances, preserve growth and calm currency markets. **********''What is needed is some patience,'' said Jean-Claude Paye, the O.E.C.D.'s Secretary General. ''Economic actions need time to bear fruit.'' A Shift in Stances **********For years, the Americans have struggled to put the issue of rapidly rising farm subsidies on the international agenda. American officials said they were delighted that the stalemate had been broken at this O.E.C.D. meeting as two strong advocates of subsidy programs, West Germany and Japan, shifted their stances and decided to support a broadly worded communique that calls for market forces to play a larger role in determining farm production and prices. **********''This is not just a financial and economic question, it's a social and political question in every country,'' Mr. Baker said. ''It's only when we move on a multilateral basis that any country, including the United States, will find the political will to deal with this problem.'' **********Ministers said the breakthrough agreement lays the groundwork for discussions of agricultural policy at the economic summit meeting in Venice June 8-10. **********''This is all about building political support around a bunch of principles,'' one senior United States trade official said. **********Agricultural experts said the hardest work would be to negotiate a detailed trade agreement - as part of the Uruguay Round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade -that would limit both agricultural subsidies and protectionist measures against farm imports. A Comparison by Baker **********''It will be a difficult process, just like dealing with third world debt,'' Mr. Baker said. ''Just because these are difficult problems, though, doesn't mean we shouldn't address them.'' **********Many ministers said changes could face stiff opposition from farm groups in their countries. Indeed, a German official vowed that his country would never agree to a cut in farm prices. To win German backing, the communique was worded to say that governments would have flexibility in the ways they reduce support to their farmers, with each tailoring its approach to meet its needs. **********One provision in the communique aims to limit overproduction by stating that ''farm income support should, as appropriate, be sought through direct income support'' rather than by providing price guarantees or other supports that encourage farmers to grow more. **********''The key issue was how to reduce surplus production,'' said Martin Bangemann, West Germany's Minister of Economics and president of the O.E.C.D. meeting. ''We see we should concentrate our efforts on helping farmers, not the farms.''
